description: AS the public tries to imagine unconventional warfare in these troubled times, picture this:

title: The Solitary Life and Interesting Diet of an Argentine Woodcutter
description: What is to be learned from the days-in-the-life-of saga ''La Libertad''? Well, that an armadillo apparently doesn't have much fat.

title: U.S. SET TO WIDEN FINANCIAL ASSAULT
description: Widening the financial assault on Osama bin Laden, administration officials are preparing to freeze the assets of about two dozen more charities and other organizations that are suspected of providing money and support to his terrorist operations, government officials said yesterday.

title: Ashcroft, Seeking Broad Powers, Says Congress Must Act Quickly
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft implored lawmakers today to approve the Bush administration's antiterrorism package by next week, warning: ''Talk will not prevent terrorism. We need to have action by the Congress.''

title: City, Noting Traffic Decrease, Continues Lone Driver Rules
description: The city's rules preventing most cars with just one occupant from crossing into Midtown and Lower Manhattan on weekday mornings did cut traffic congestion last week and will continue indefinitely, officials said yesterday.

title: Essay; For a Muslim Legion
description: How do we get the best intelligence within Afghanistan about the whereabouts of the bin Laden terrorists? From local villagers, of course, some of whom know where caves and camps are.

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?; Stopping Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Rust and Inexperience Foil Saints
description: The New Orleans Saints flew into Newark International Airport on Saturday night and stayed at a hotel nearby. On their bus ride from the hotel to Giants Stadium on Sunday morning, several of the players strained their necks and pressed toward the windows, hoping to gain a glimpse of Manhattan and the open space where the World Trade Center's twin towers once stood.

title: Penn Remains Unbeaten Using Balanced Attack
description: After Gavin Hoffman threw for 3,214 yards last season to lead Penn to the Ivy League championship, one would expect the Quakers to rely on their quarterback to guide them again. But a healthy running back Kris Ryan has Penn (2-0, 1-0 Ivy) revamping its approach. Ryan, a senior, has taken the pressure off Hoffman with 285 yards rushing and 4 touchdowns.

title: Dutch Frankness on Immigrants Treads Where Many Nations Fear to Go : Europe's Muslims:A Difficult Debate
description: THE HAGUE  With a six-column banner headline on page one, a leading Dutch newspaper reported last week that as a result of the terrorist attacks on the United States more than 60 percent of the Dutch agreed with the idea that Muslim immigrants who supported the attack should be expelled from the Netherlands.

title: Support for U.S. Security Plans Is Quietly Voiced Across Canada
description: In small towns and cities, from Atlantic Canada through the prairies to the Pacific coast, many Canadians are saying what Washington would like to hear, if it could hear them.

title: 49ers a True Test for Edwards's Work-in-Progress Jets
description: The Jets' defense toiled in blissful silence last week, the cacophony of questions directed instead toward an offense with growing pains. The defense, after all, made numerous game-saving plays, holding the Patriots to so little offense that the Jets' woes could be discussed through the prism of a victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HATTON, TERENCE S.
description: HATTON-Terence S. Age 41, Captain, Rescue Co. 1, FDNY, died bravely in the line of duty with his men at the World Trade Center terrorist attack on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Beth Petrone Hatton, devoted son of Grace and Kenneth, Deputy Chief ret. FDNY, loving brother of Grace Hatton Antoniou and brother-in-law of Ted Antoniou, cherished uncle of Conor Antoniou, nephew of Donald Hatton, beautiful grandson of Grace O'Donnell and best friend to deceased brother Kenny. Dear son-in-law of Dominick and Antoinette Petrone, brother-in-law to Karen and Chris Malin, James Petrone, Bennett Petrone and uncle to Nicholas and Thomas Malin. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Thursday, 10 AM, at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Ave at 51st St. Interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions in his memory be made to The Rescue Company 1 Memorial Fund, 530 W. 43rd St. New York, NY 10036.

title: Gross! The Inside Story Of China's Festive Cake
description: Although last-minute customers continued to sift through piles of elaborate red and gold gift boxes, the mood was subdued among the women selling moon cakes in the basement of the state-run Blue Island department store.

title: Takahashi Sets Women's Mark For Marathon
description: A year after winning the Sydney Olympics and unveiling her eccentric dietary habits, Naoko Takahashi of Japan became the first woman to run 26.2 miles in under 2 hours 20 minutes yesterday, setting a world record at the Berlin Marathon.

title: Treasury Offerings Set for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill on Tuesday.

title: Live From New York, Permission to Laugh
description: On the season opener of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' this weekend, the funniest routine was also the riskiest. During the ''Weekend Update'' segment, Darell Hammond impersonated the Rev. Jesse Jackson explaining how he was invited to negotiate with leaders of the Taliban. ''I had a hang-up call on my machine, so I star-sixty-nined,'' he said.

title: Isolated Family Finds Support and Reasons To Worry in Illinois
description: The wispy girl with the chocolate-drop eyes piled the plastic blocks one atop another -- red and blue and yellow and green -- until the tower on the coffee table rose above her head, beyond the reach of her little arms. Then she picked up a toy plane and crashed it into a high story, toppling the tower onto the rug.

description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The smell breaks my heart. The smell makes it all worse. It makes it more real, and I wish it weren't real.''

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?; America's Gate
description: To the Editor:

title: The industry sees changes in big accounts, but also layoffs and profit warnings.
description: AS Madison Avenue slowly seeks a return to business as usual -- whatever that may now mean -- agencies are being affected by changes in accounts for large advertisers like the Coca-Cola Company and the Burger King Corporation, with billings estimated at $575 million.

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?; Political Paradoxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: TO THOSE WHO PERISHED

title: Johnson Joins Growing Roster Of Ailing Yanks
description: The Yankees lost another player to injury yesterday, the fourth in four games. Nick Johnson, a rookie contending for a spot on the postseason roster as a pinch-hitter, was hit on the right instep by a pitch. X-rays did not reveal any broken bones.

title: U.S. and Pakistan Discuss Nuclear Security
description: American military and intelligence officials have talked with the Pakistani government about concerns over the security of its nuclear weapons stockpile and the country's two nuclear plants, two Pakistani officials say.

title: Defense's Looks Can Be Deceiving
description: How good is the Giants' defense?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Officer Charged With D.W.I.
description: A car driven by an off-duty correction officer struck another vehicle as a man was working under its hood, killing him, the police said. The officer, Sean E. Duffy, 38, of Staten Island, was arrested shortly after the accident and charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said. The victim, Ricardo Herrera, 29, also lived in Staten Island. Mr. Herrera was working under the hood of his disabled car along the West Shore Expressway about 1:30 a.m. when it was struck from behind. Other charges against Mr. Duffy were pending yesterday. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Just How Loud Was 'The Shot'?
description: The home run Bobby Thomson hit 50 years ago has long held the label The shot heard 'round the world. But now that half a century has passed, it is time to put the home run in better perspective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKENFELD, KAREN F.
description: BERKENFELD-Karen F. Loving and caring wife of Steve. Beloved daughter of June and Phil. Cherished sister to Bob, Kathy and the late Sylvia. Dear sister-in-law to Shari and Mike. Loved cousin to many including Korki and Jon. Devoted Godmother to Phil and Andrew. Our sadness is great, the void will be constant. She touched so many, this gracious person. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Tuesday, October 2, at 1:30 PM. Burial in Ludlow, PA.

title: Sports of The Times; Some Empty Seats at Giants Stadium
description: THERE are always some empty seats at a Giants game, but yesterday there seemed to be more than usual.

title: Blair Says He's Seen Proof of bin Laden Role
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, apparently seeking to bolster the United States-led coalition against terrorism, said today that he had seen ''incontrovertible evidence'' linking Osama bin Laden to the attacks on the United States on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, ALAN M.
description: SIMON-Alan M. Age 69, died at his home in Manhattan, on September 29, 2001. Beloved husband of Toni Lautman Simon. Loving father of Andrew and Leslie Simon and father-in-law of Nancy Simon and Marc Bender. Devoted grandfather of Allison and Samantha Simon, and Arlo and Philip Bender Simon. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Monday, 6-8 PM, with service Tuesday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, The Horace Mann School or Yale University.

title: Moviegoers Are Returning, Even to Action Thrillers
description: Coming into this weekend, the first since the Sept. 11 attacks in which Hollywood tried to restore a level of normalcy to the movie distribution cycle, studio executives fretted about what kinds of stories the audience might be willing to watch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIGGS, GEORGENE W.
description: BIGGS-Georgene W. Died September 29, 2001, at the age of 94. Devoted wife of the late William R. Biggs. Beloved mother of Barton, Jeremy and Christopher. She was the adored grandmother of Wende, Gretchen, Barton, Fiona, Allegra, Melissa, Robin, Courtney, Jennifer and Christopher. She is also survived by 17 great-grandchildren. There will be no memorial service. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALGER, DAVID DEWEY
description: ALGER-David Dewey. Was tragically lost on 11 September 2001, at the World Trade Center. A Memorial Service to celebrate his remarkable life will be held at Saint Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and 53rd Street in Manhattan, on Friday, 5 October 2001, at 11 a.m. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to a worthy WTC relief fund. Gifts may also be made to the Foundation for Alger Families, a charitable foundation established to assist the families of Fred Alger Management employees lost in the attack on the WTC.

title: After Devastating Loss, Mets Build on Slender Hope
description: The Mets had come to believe they were destined to win the National League East, and their shocking loss Saturday had dealt destiny a body blow.

title: 'Banner' Rings in Many American Ears
description: All across the country, people are answering their cellphones to the strains of ''The Star Spangled Banner.''

title: British Secretly Used Babies' Bones in Tests
description: In a remarkable evocation of the secretive ways and hidden priorities of the cold war, Britain's Atomic Energy Agency acknowledged today that thousands of bones were taken from dead babies without parental consent to help ascertain the impact of atmospheric nuclear testing.

title: Phillips Gives Benitez Vote of Confidence
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips emphatically defended closer Armando Benitez yesterday, saying he had no intention of trading him despite Benitez's repeated failures in big situations.

title: Seriously. People Seem Ready for a Good Laugh.
description: ''Comedy equals tragedy plus time,'' said a character in one of Woody Allen's movies, ''Crimes and Misdemeanors.'' For the creators of The Onion, a satirical weekly newspaper based in New York City, that formula posed a daunting test in the days after Sept. 11. When is it safe to try comedy again, especially after such a profoundly tragic event?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERT, DR. MAX
description: HALPERT-Dr. Max. Beloved father of Daniel and Jonathan (Aviva). Will be missed by grandchildren Tzippora (David) Baratz, Ariella (Jonah) Kaszovitz, Tzofit (Avigdor) Butler, Yehuda (Shoshana) and Rafi, and 11 great-grandchildren.

title: Pope Opens Bishop Synod; Role of Each Is the Focus
description: At a Mass in St. Peter's today, Pope John Paul II opened a meeting of bishops from around the world who will spend the next month discussing their role in the church and that of the pope.

title: Subway Cars for Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 30 (AP)  South Carolina's Department of Natural Resources has signed an agreement to take 300 old New York City subway cars to build artificial reefs and is awaiting a decision from New York.

title: Exiled King and Opponents of Taliban to Push Election
description: ROME, Oct. 1  The exiled king of Afghanistan and leaders of the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance agreed today to convene an emergency "Supreme Council" by the end of this month and organize an election to replace their country's militant Islamic rulers.

title: Conference Pictures Are Clearer
description: The first month had a blurry focus, but the college football season snapped into clarity on Saturday. After early classics that felt like exhibitions, nonconference mismatches that seemed like scrimmages and a week of postponements in the wake of terrorism, the sport found sharper definition. Oklahoma, Clemson, South Carolina, Northwestern and Purdue earned thrilling victories, some of them historic, some of them with the help of trick plays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERVIN, ANITA
description: PERVIN-Anita. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with profound sorrow the death of our longtime member. Our condolences to her family and friends. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Ellen R. Saxl, Co-President Michael H. Laufer, Co-President

title: Valentine Takes Heat, But He's Not at Fault
description: The damage control for Armando Benitez started two minutes after Mets Manager Bobby Valentine peered into the sunlight above Turner Field for the first time yesterday. Valentine was asked how he felt 18 hours after the ninth-inning fiasco Saturday that never should have happened and that choked the Mets' season, and he performed a verbal dance that would have made a public relations specialist beam.

title: Slew of Supreme Court Cases to Focus on '96 Telecom Law
description: The Supreme Court begins its term on Monday with a full plate of telecommunications cases that lawyers say demonstrate the shortcomings of the landmark 1996 law that was supposed to deregulate the industry and introduce competition to telephone markets long dominated by monopolies.

title: Summertime, and the Living Is Approaching Unbearable
description: Character is destiny, it has been said. As true as that may be, Lucrecia Martel's remarkable debut film, ''La Cinaga,'' shows how geography and climate also determine human fate. For whether or not we recognize it, we all live in nature. And in ''La Cinaga'' nature looms over the characters like a malevolent giant exhaling fetid vapors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, SHEILA BROWNE
description: McCARTHY-Sheila Browne. Of Lawrence, LI, on September 29, 2001. Wife of John C. McCarthy. Mother of Robert McCarthy, Winifred Post, Curtis Dwyer and the late Thomas Dwyer. Grandmother of nine-Will, Sheila and Thomas Post, Erik and Spencer McCarthy, Ned and Max Dwyer and Madeline and Casey Dwyer. Sister of Peter C. Browne. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, 11 AM, at Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to ''The Memorial Fund of Trinity-St. John's Church.''

title: Making a Cautious Start but Getting Carried Away
description: 30 DAYS IN SYDNEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCHUGH, DENIS J. III
description: McHUGH-Denis J. III, age 36. Died tragically on September 11, 2001; resident of Manhattan, native of Brooklyn, N.Y.; loving son of Bernadette and the late Denis J. McHugh, Jr.; dear brother of Bernadette McHugh Torres and Timothy McHugh; cherished brother-in-law of Reinaldo Torres and devoted uncle of Ryan and Daniel; loving and cherished nephew, cousin and friend to many. Celebration of Life and Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday, October 2, at 10AM at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Avenue at 50th Street, NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Christopher's Inn, P.O. B. 150, Graymoor, Garrison, N.Y. 10524 in memory of Denis J. McHugh III.

title: Taliban Say They Hold Bin Laden, for His Safety, But Who Knows Where?
description: Osama bin Laden is still in Afghanistan ''under the control'' of the Taliban government at a hideout known only to ''the people responsible for his safety,'' the Taliban ambassador to Pakistan said today.

title: Giants Hold On As Refs Control, Start to Finish
description: It was the last play of the day and New Orleans quarterback Aaron Brooks was in a full sprint to his right as his wide receivers scattered frantically to his left.

title: U.S. Expects Reyna to Play Against Jamaica
description: Claudio Reyna's knee injury, sustained Sunday while he was playing for Glasgow Rangers against its archrival, Celtic, is not as severe as it was originally thought, according to officials at the United States Soccer Federation.

title: Accounts
description: Red Roof Inns, Dallas, owned by the Accor Economy Lodging division of Accor, to the San Francisco office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its account, which had been at the Richards Group, Dallas. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. Richards continues handling a Red Roof sibling, Motel 6.

title: Were Those Really the Days? A Homer Among Bad News
description: At the induction center on Whitehall Street in Lower Manhattan, draftees watched baseball history unfold on the television sets installed by the Army, a dramatic sendoff from civilian life toward a journey to the hills of Korea.

title: A Concert Offers City Some Time For Healing
description: Many great performing artists give generously of their time when called upon to participate in memorial concerts. But time was an especially tight commodity for two of the artists who appeared last night in Carnegie Hall's free concert of remembrance to honor the victims of the tragedy of Sept. 11.

title: Avoiding the Risks Of Seeming Exploitive
description: At 1:30 a.m. on Sept. 11, Judith Regan, a publisher at the HarperCollins division of the News Corporation, hung up the phone with New York City's police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, after going over the final editing of the manuscript of his memoir, Ms. Regan said last week.

title: Vikings Summon Extra Effort to Overcome Turmoil
description: The two most scrutinized players in football this past week had to be Minnesota wide receivers Cris Carter and Randy Moss, for unflattering reasons.

title: The Shot Heard 'Round the World
description: On Oct. 3, 1951, Bobby Thomson hit the home run for the New York Giants that snatched a pennant from the Brooklyn Dodgers. Fifty years later, The Times takes a look back.

title: Money Will Go Out, He Says, but First It Must Come In
description: Who says the age of irony is over?

title: For the Devils' Defense, Age Means Experience
description: The Devils' decision to start this season with three defensemen born in the spring of 1964 could haunt them next spring in the playoffs -- unless Coach Larry Robinson gives Scott Stevens, Ken Daneyko and Tommy Albelin plenty of rest this winter.

title: G.E. Is Accused of Trying to Undercut Order to Dredge Hudson River
description: New York State officials and environmental groups say they are worried that General Electric is trying to sabotage the landmark federal order that the company dredge the Hudson River to remove poisonous chemicals.

title: In a New Climate of Unity, Justices Face Divisive Issues
description: Contentious domestic issues that have almost vanished from the national conversation during the past three weeks dominate the docket for the new Supreme Court term that begins on Monday.

title: A Cool Letterman Earns a Place on New York's Top 10 List
description: Late in the show on his first night back after the attacks on New York, following an emotional monologue about the anguish and rage of the country and of New York City, David Letterman broke for a commercial.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Military Finds Short Supplies Of Spying Craft As Need Rises
description: The military is concerned about a shortage of surveillance equipment as the pursuit of Osama bin Laden is heating up, senior Pentagon officials and congressional aides said in interviews in the last few days.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POOL, JEAN MACKENZIE
description: POOL-Jean MacKenzie. Memorial Service, Sunday October 7, 2001, 2:00PM. AAAS 136 Irving Street, Cambridge, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, MATILDA E.
description: MURRAY-Matilda E. On September 30, 2001. Born in Rochelle Park, NJ. Loving sister of the late Rev. John, T.S.J. and James E. Survived by sister-in-law Caroline Murray and cousin Claire Nelson. Dear aunt of Mary DeBock, Eileen Cavanaugh and Janet Lynch. Also survived by many grandnieces and nephews, and great-grandnieces and nephews. Visiting Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, at St. Anselm's R.C. Church. Interment at Calvary Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: A Call Is Born, And Saved By a Mom
description: On Oct. 3, 1951, Lawrence Goldberg made one change in his routine before he left his home in Flatbush for his job in Manhattan as a trip planner for the Automobile Club of New York. He tuned his radio to WMCA 570 and told his mother to hit the record button of his Webcor reel-to-reel tape recorder when Game 3 of the Dodgers-Giants playoff reached the bottom of the ninth inning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACK, BRYAN CREED
description: JACK-Bryan Creed. The Henry Luce Foundation is saddened by the loss of former Luce Scholar Bryan Jack who died on September 11, 2001, aboard hijacked American Airlines Flight #

title: The Psychiatrist in the House Feels the Nation's Trauma
description: IN the days after the terrorist attacks, Representative Jim McDermott of Washington, the only psychiatrist in Congress, could not get his mind off the image of a plane crashing into the World Trade Center.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl Shot and Killed
description: A 15-year-old girl was fatally shot last night as she was standing outside a building in the Remsen Village neighborhood of Brooklyn, the police said. The girl, who was not identified, was struck once in the chest by a bullet at about 9 p.m. in front of 1370 Ralph Avenue. She was taken to Kings County Hospital Center and died 20 minutes later. Details were still sketchy early today, but it appeared that the girl may have been a bystander, the police said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Ex-King Meets Taliban Foes And 11 From U.S. Congress
description: The 86-year-old exiled king of Afghanistan, who has spent decades in near-total isolation here, met with anti-Taliban military commanders of the Northern Alliance and an American congressional delegation at his home today, where the Americans promised to help him unite his countrymen against the militant Islamic Taliban government.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: In Shelley or Auden, in the Sonnet or Free Verse, The Eerily Intimate Power of Poetry to Console
description: Bits of famous poems, original poems, snatches of verse pinned alongside photos of the victims. In the weeks since the terrorist attacks, people have been consoling themselves -- and one another -- with poetry in an almost unprecedented way. Almost immediately after the event, improvised memorials often conceived around poems sprang up all over the city, in store windows, at bus stops, in Washington Square Park, Brooklyn Heights and elsewhere. And poems flew through cyberspace across the country in e-mails from friend to friend.

title: Pop Anthem or Classic Couplet To Sustain a Weary Soul
description: Until terrorists destroyed the World Trade Center and damaged the Pentagon, most radio stations only played ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' if they were signing off the air. But over the past three weeks, many listeners have wanted to hear it time and again along with ''God Bless America,'' ''America the Beautiful'' and more recent patriotic songs like Lee Greenwood's ''God Bless the U.S.A.'' Blaring, defiant rock songs, like Metallica's ''Don't Tread on Me,'' also found themselves taking on new meanings.

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESLER, MAX M.
description: CHESLER-Max M. On September 30, 2001, age 91. Husband of the late Shirley Chesler. Father of Nancy Carroll, Kathy Dodd, Michael Appelbaum, Robert Appelbaum and Carol Charnoff. Services Monday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: For Many With Trade Center Ties, Music Provides a Respite
description: Tim Wilkin took his place in the line outside Carnegie Hall at 7:10 a.m. yesterday, 4 hours and 50 minutes before the box office was to start handing out more than 2,000 tickets to a concert honoring those killed in the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Dr. Wilkin, an infectious-disease specialist at Columbia-Presbyterian Center, had brought along things to read -- medical journals, for a paper he had to write.

title: A Fusion of Hip Swivels From Africa and Classical Hindu Gestures
description: Last June when Dance Theater of Harlem performed at the Apollo Theater in Harlem for the first time, it presented three familiar works. On Wednesday night the company's program at City Center packaged the same ballets as ''The Apollo Show.'' And a terrific show it is.

title: Bush Chooses Retired General as His National Counterterrorism Coordinator
description: President Bush has selected a retired Army general to become his chief aide for counterterrorism, completing the selection of his new top homeland security team.

title: Nguyen Van Thieu Is Dead at 76; Last President of South Vietnam
description: Nguyen Van Thieu, the former president of South Vietnam who led his nation through most of its war against North Vietnam until it was finally overrun by a Communist offensive in 1975, died late Saturday at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center here, a hospital spokesman said. He was 76.

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?; Let Us Bow Our Heads
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Stocks End the Day Lower
description: Stocks fell moderately today as investors, still nervous about the scope of American military reaction to the terrorist attacks, were discouraged by more weak economic data and a fresh wave of corporate earnings warnings.

title: Fresh Kills Journal; Mountains of Twisted Steel, Evoking the Dead
description: If somewhere on earth there has ever truly existed a rag-and-bone shop of the heart, as in Yeats's dreamy phrase, that shop is open for business here, now, on a colossal and grotesque scale.

title: Agents Wanted. Should Speak Pashto.
description: As the Bush administration promotes legislation that would expand its power to place wiretaps on suspected terrorists, it faces a troubling obstacle: few of its intelligence agents are fluent in Arabic, the native language of Osama bin Laden. Even fewer understand Farsi or Pashto, the most common languages in Afghanistan.

title: Fund for Victims' Families Already Proves Sore Point
description: The compensation fund created by Congress 10 days ago, which could pay the families of victims in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks more than $1 million each, has begun to generate both resentment and confusion about its ultimate fairness and effectiveness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHAN, MICHAEL
description: KAHAN-Michael. Brooklyn College mourns the passing of Professor Micheal Kahan, Department of Political Science. Professor Kahan was a devoted teacher and mentor for nearly 30 years. Frequently sought after as an expert and commentator on the local and national political scene, he recently authored ''Media as Politics: Theory, Behavior and Change in America.'' His generous spirit and strong presence will be greatly missed by his department, the campus community and beyond. Christoph M. Kimmich, President Brooklyn College

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?; Economic Factors

title: Tehran Aide Assails Terror But Opposes U.S. Attack
description: Iran believes that the terrorists behind the Sept. 11 attacks must be brought to justice and the Taliban government in Afghanistan replaced, according to a senior Iranian diplomat.

title: Defense Secretary Warns Of Unconventional Attacks
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld warned today that he expected the enemies of the United States would eventually help terrorist groups obtain chemical, biological and possibly even nuclear weapons technology.

title: Software to Track Customers' Needs Helped Firms React
description: Early on Sept. 11, a Northwest Airlines flight bound for Minneapolis aborted its takeoff from San Jose, Calif., just as it was to leave the ground. The captain announced that the World Trade Center and Pentagon had just been attacked, and he turned the plane around.

title: Counting Losses, Department Rethinks Fighting Every Fire
description: The New York Fire Department, reeling from its losses in the World Trade Center attack, is pushing 300 more recruits than normal through its training program. It has turned to retirees to augment its depleted ranks. It has snapped up fire equipment destined for other cities.

title: Travelers Take to the Skies Again With a Mix of Wariness and Resolve
description: ''Security! Woman approaching the stage here!'' shouted the folk singer performing at Kitty O'Shea's pub inside the Logan Airport Hilton.

title: First Monday
description: The Supreme Court begins a new term today, with a still-expanding docket that embraces disputes over school vouchers, affirmative action, property rights and the death penalty. But this first Monday also brings a heightened appreciation for the strength and continuity of the constitutional system in which the high court acts as peaceful arbiter of some of society's most vexing social and political issues. The expected presence of Solicitor General Theodore Olson, whose wife died aboard the hijacked jet that smashed into the Pentagon, only increases the occasion's poignancy.

title: For Brooklyn Democrat, A Bad (Election) Day
description: The boxes in the Thurgood Marshall Democratic Club in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, sat ready to be discarded this past weekend. One was filled with the campaign literature of Alan G. Hevesi. The other contained fliers for Jeannette Gadson, who lost the party's nomination for Brooklyn borough president.

Reposing in the Jesuit Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Rd. on Monday 2-5pm and 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-5pm. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday at the Fordham University Church at 7:30. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc. Directors 718-654-0500

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, NATHAN, M.D.
description: MINTZ-Nathan, M.D. On September 29, 2001. Loving husband of Edith. Devoted father of Sandra, Alan and Rachel. Dedicated doctor. Memorial service December 5, 2001; details to be announced. Contributions may be sent to the New York Times September 11th Neediest Fund.

title: Gdansk Journal; Mapping a Glossy Future for a Has-Been Shipyard
description: When Janusz Lipinski looks out over the giant shipyard here where the Solidarity movement helped bring down Communism, he does not see acres of dreary and mostly deserted buildings.

title: A Place to Run From
description: Even in this restless time, America's politicians need the appearance of a healthy root system. Successful Presidential candidates in particular seem to require an elaborate connection to some modest place, a down-home setting for the campaign's background myth. Thus, Vice President Al Gore, mostly of Washington, D.C., has returned to Tennessee and not merely to dust off his old family homestead. Mr. Gore needs to establish a headquarters that will operate more efficiently than the one that turned him from front-runner into self-described underdog. But the real goal is to minimize his deep connection to Washington, to identify him with that supposedly more authentic America out there, to be, as he said, closer to Kmart than K Street.

title: Equity Offerings Planned This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: The Home Run That Broke a Girl's Heart
description: In 1951, when I was a 10-year-old in Brooklyn, baseball was my family's religion; the Dodgers were our denomination, Ebbets Field was the church. We lived in Crown Heights on Carroll Street near Franklin Avenue, a few blocks from the ballpark. When the Dodgers played one of their relatively infrequent night games at home, and I was sent to bed before the game ended, I could hear the roar of the crowd through my bedroom window. I knew so much about the game I was a quiz kid, appearing on a silly daytime TV show called ''There's One in Every Family.''

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?
description: To the Editor:

title: The News Media Make Ready For War
description: For journalists, the news story of a lifetime is breaking. But it won't come easily, cheaply or quickly.

title: A Fastball, a Swing And Forever
description: When Ralph Branca was reminded that the 50th anniversary was approaching, he laughed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIMAN, MILDRED ''GONG GONG.''
description: KLEIMAN-Mildred ''Gong Gong.'' Died on Septebmer 29, 2001, at the age of 94. Adored mother of Lynne Spanbock. Beloved grandmother of Richard, Jane, Janese and the late Paul Spanbock. Loving great-grandmother of Alex, Emily and Bari. Devoted wife of the late H. Paul Shanik and the late Morris Kleiman. A woman of great strength and dignity, filled with love for her family and friends. She will be forever in our hearts. Graveside service Monday, October 1, at 10 AM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWE, JACQUES
description: LOWE-Jacques. A memorial service to honor Jacques, celebrated photo-journalist, will take place at 7PM, on Tuesday, October 9th, at St. Peter's Church, 54th St. (at Lexington Avenue). Contact Thomasina Lowe, 212-227-3298.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWLAN, TRUDI (NEE MANDLER)
description: COWLAN-Trudi (nee Mandler). On September 29, 2001. Born in Vienna, Austria, on July 9, 1927. Much loved by daughter Maggi, son-in-law Sam Lawson and grandson Josh, and daughter Janet Cowlan Miller, partner John Murphy and son Sean. A longtime companion of Lee Salisbury. In lieu of flowers, donations to Palliative Care, Jewish Home & Hospital, 120 W. 106 St, NYC 10025. Services Wed, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Shocked Germany Weakens Cherished Protections
description: Last week, Berlin's prestigious Humboldt University reluctantly confirmed that it had given information on 23 Arab students to the German government. While the university hastened to say that it had told the students of the questions asked about them, the disclosure of what would have been private information only a few weeks ago represents an important change here.

title: What's Doing Around Town
description: From Broadway and Off Broadway to concert halls and jazz clubs, New York City's stages are returning to normal schedules. Here is a sampling of performances.

title: Auto Sales Resume, but Industry Outlook Seems Worrisome
description: David Jaroszewicz is doing his part to revive the economy. Under a nearly cloudless Saturday sky here, between Detroit and Ann Arbor, he is selling cars again. Mr. Jaroszewicz surveys the few clusters of couples, some drawn by General Motors' new zero percent financing, twisting through a field of Grand Prixs and Grand Ams under a towering American flag.

title: Kay Teer Crawford, 88; Guided Drill Teams' Growth
description: Kay Teer Crawford, whose sympathy for high school girls who did not make the cheerleading squad in her Texas hometown led her to start one of the first of the drill teams, died on Aug. 29 at her home in Redondo Beach, Calif. She was 88.

title: New York Expands Immigrants' Eligibility for Health Program
description: The Pataki administration, steering clear of a potential lawsuit, has decided to extend a new state-subsidized health insurance program for the working poor to all legal immigrants.

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?; Stopping Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: For Ferrer And Green, A Refrain: He Started It
description: Fernando Ferrer and Mark Green continued to trade barbs yesterday over plans to rebuild Lower Manhattan and whether Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani should be allowed to stay on after his term ends, as each candidate tried to suggest -- in the time-honored political tradition -- that the other one started it.

title: These Fallen Fathers Were at-Home Heroes; Shopping, Washing and Diapering In Defiance of Traditional Sex Roles
description: Jeannine McIntyre's husband, Donald, a Port Authority police officer, planned to join the Parent-Teacher Association in New City, N.Y., even if he was the only man. He often surprised his 5-year-old daughter with ''hair pretties,'' as she called barrettes. He had saved enough overtime for a monthlong paternity leave when his third child was born in December.

title: Name of Pilot Who Roused Passengers Still a Mystery
description: Federal agents are now reasonably certain who piloted the four jets hijacked on Sept. 11. But despite a much happier outcome, United Airlines is still not sure who was in the cockpit of Flight 564, which took off safely four days later from Denver and landed without incident at Dulles Airport near Washington.

title: Why Game 2 Was Relatively Significant
description: There must be at least five million people who claim they were present on Oct. 3, 1951, when that home run was hit. I make no such claim. But I can swear out an affidavit that I was at the Polo Grounds the day before, along with about 38,000 others, at a game made unforgettable because of the febrile behavior of my father-in-law, Fred.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B.

title: Letting Empire Go For-Profit
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has been trying since 1996 to guarantee its future by shedding its not-for-profit status. Now facing up to $50 million in losses from the destruction of its offices at the World Trade Center, the company needs to sell stock to make the investments needed to compete with other insurers. Yet its chances of converting to a for-profit corporation are caught up in political disputes. Without quick action by the state, Empire may be forced to accept a disadvantageous buyout from another not-for-profit insurer just to remain financially viable.

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?; Stopping Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Vows Aid Workers' Trial Will Be Fair
description: The trial of eight Western aid workers charged with trying to convert people to Christianity resumed in Kabul, Afghanistan, today, and the chief justice of Afghanistan's Supreme Court assured them that they would be treated fairly despite the possibility of American air strikes.

title: Leg Injury Stops Barber
description: Running back Tiki Barber hobbled off the Giants Stadium field today holding the back of his left leg after he scored the Giants' second touchdown, a 14-yard dash around right end in the second quarter.

title: Giuliani Tells U.N. It's Time to Act Against Terrorism
description: In an impassioned call for action, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani told the United Nations today that it was time "to draw the line" against terrorism and to hold accountable any nation that supports or condones it, or "you will fail in your primary mission as peacekeepers."

title: Can an Aging Michael Jordan Still Lift Brands He Endorses?
description: He is a brand, an icon, a legend, the name behind his own musky cologne and brand of sneakers. He retired to play minor league baseball in 1993, returned to win the last three of his six National Basketball Association championships with the Chicago Bulls, then retired again in 1999. A year later, he took over as the president of basketball operations for the Washington Wizards, perennial doormats who won only 19 games last season.

title: An Outpouring of Dollars
description: An avalanche of donations has descended upon New York City since Sept. 11, creating a cash mountain that now exceeds $600 million. Experts say that never has so much charitable money been raised so quickly. The sources ranged from children's lemonade stands to corporate giants like General Electric, whose $10 million donation jump-started Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's Twin Towers Fund. And the fund-raisers are still going on.

title: Bush Announces Second Visit to New York
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 - President Bush will visit New York City again on Wednesday to talk to schoolchildren, the White House said today. His visit is intended to ease anxieties lingering from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: People
description: Dana Anderson, executive vice president and managing director at the Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was promoted to president and chief executive. She succeeds Brian Williams, who resigned, the agency said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOCCI, DONATO (DAN)
description: SOCCI-Donato (Dan). On September 29, 2001. Born in Camden, NJ, of the late Sylvia (Marini) and Donato Socci. Resident of North Flushing for over 50 years. Attended Cornell University and gradaute of St. John's University School of Law. Served in the armed forces during WWII. Practiced as a successful trial attorney with USF&G Insurance Co, and subseuqently with General RE Insurance Group. A beloved patriarch, whose intellect, poise, love of family, strong morals and commanding character will not be forgotten. Attorney at law. Beloved husband of Susanna for 52 years, loving father of Christopher, Silvia Composto, Donna, Lauretta, Anthony and Linda Von Ancken. Devoted grandfather of Nicole, Daniela and Gabriella Composto, Brian and Victoria Von Ancken and Andrea, Michael and Daniel Socci. Reposing tomorrow at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 14920 Northern Blvd, Flushing. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:15 AM, at St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting Monday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Safer Borders
description: Add a week, at least, of American commerce to the list of casualties from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. In the hours following the collapse of the twin towers, the United States applied a tourniquet to the transportation arteries that feed our national economy. The first campaign in the war to protect the American homeland was to impose an embargo -- on our own economy.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Taking On the Taliban

title: Giants Stadium Super Bowl?
description: Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said today that the N.F.L. was considering Giants Stadium, along with at least three other sites, as a potential location for this season's Super Bowl. He said the league still hoped to keep the Super Bowl in New Orleans and play a full regular season and postseason.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANOVER, MAE
description: HANOVER-Mae. Of Tamarac, FL, 88 passed away on September 30, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Ernest J. Mother of Steven J. (wife Abby). Nana Mae to Evan, Andrea and David. Dear sister of Rose Silverberg, Bernice Kearney and the late Alice Wechsler and Minnie Schecter. Dear Aunt Mae to many. ''She did it her way.'' Graveside service 10:30 AM, Wednesday, New Mt. Carmel, Queens.

title: Intel to Offer New Chips Today In Hope of Buoying Laptop Sales
description: The Intel Corporation plans today to introduce a dozen new microprocessors into the slowing market for laptop computers, including chips that the company says will run small laptops at faster speeds while draining less battery power.

title: German Bank Is Said to Prepare Bigger Bid for British Phone Lines
description: A German bank is preparing to raise an earlier offer for the fixed-line business of British Telecommunications, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Metro Matters; Outflanking The Mayor Of America
description: NOBODY in America stands taller than Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani does today. From Yankee Stadium to ''Saturday Night Live,'' from the United Nations to the halls of Congress, he is all but floating on waves of adulation.

title: Microsoft Customers Balk At Automatic Upgrades
description: A new software licensing program from Microsoft that goes into effect this week has some corporate customers complaining that they will end paying more and buying upgrades they do not need.

title: NTT DoCoMo Introduces New Generation Cellphone Service
description: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone operator, will introduce the world's first third-generation cellular phone network Monday, hoping to thwart skeptics and solidify its shaky grip on the country's $70 billion wireless market.

title: Clinton Disbarred From Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 - The Supreme Court said today that a lawyer who was disciplined in his home state of Arkansas cannot practice law before the High Court. The action was totally unremarkable, except that the lawyer in question is former President Bill Clinton.

title: Patriotism Calls Out the Censor
description: In the first Gallup poll published after the disastrous invasion of Cuba at the Bay of Pigs in April 1961, President John F. Kennedy's approval rating jumped 10 points to 83 percent. The commander in chief looked at the numbers -- the disapproval was only 5 percent -- and said, ''The worse I do, the more popular I get.''

title: The Internet's Best Players Are Competing Face to Face
description: The third annual OKbridge Internet World Championship, which lets players compete internationally from home, has reached the quarterfinal stage. The Romanian team that upset its American opponents in the final a year ago is due to play Hong Kong. France plays Iceland in the other match in the Eastern hemisphere half of the bracket. The surviving team will visit Las Vegas in November to contest the world final.

title: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Approves Covert Aid for Taliban Foes
description: President Bush has approved a secret effort to strengthen a diverse array of groups opposing the Taliban rulers of Afghanistan, administration officials said today.

title: In Rapid Shift, a Budget Surplus Is Expected to Turn Into a Deficit
description: Analysts inside and outside the government say the large federal budget surpluses of recent years are likely to give way to a deficit in the fiscal year that starts on Monday, a stunningly swift turnabout brought on by the weakening economy and the costs of the campaign against terrorism.

title: Cybersnooping for Sounds and Images, Not Suspects
description: Benjamin Franklin, the first electric performance artist, wrote that those who ''give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary safety deserve neither liberty nor safety.'' As the debate over the balancing of personal freedom and public safety heats up, Alex Galloway has begun a computer-art project that provides food for thought.

title: New Military Systems May Be Tested in Field in 'War Against Terrorism'
description: The military action being contemplated by the Bush administration could quickly become a proving ground for weapons and support systems developed since the Persian Gulf war a decade ago. How they fare could affect billions of dollars in military spending in the coming years.

title: In a Landscape of Sadness, Offering Just Her Presence
description: At 8:30 one recent morning, Carol O'Neill sat in her Jeep Cherokee, wrapping the ends of her blond hair around fat blue curlers. She wore the same black knit suit with brass buttons that she had worn almost every day for two weeks. Beside her was a manila folder, containing a Post-it Note with neat cursive script reading ''Stacey McGowan, Grace Memorial Church, 10:30 a.m.,'' and directions from Huntington Bay, on Long Island, where Mrs. O'Neill lives, to Nyack, N.Y., where the church is.

description: Aweek ago, when the Yankees clinched the American League East, they viewed the final week of the season as a much-needed opportunity to prepare themselves for the playoffs and resolve any lingering injury issues. Now, this week could have much bigger implications.

description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 314 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 255. In all, 5,657 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

description: BLANCK-Gertrude. Died September 29, 2001, of pancreatic cancer. Her family will love and miss her always. Susan, Robert Peter and Thomas Franzen

title: Provocative At a Time of Provocation
description: In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, George Steel, the executive director of the Miller Theater at Columbia University, wondered if he should open his season as planned: the Absolute Ensemble in the New York premiere of ''Blood on the Floor,'' a raw, jazz-infused 1996 work by the British composer Mark-Anthony Turnage, which takes its name from a grim painting by Francis Bacon. Perhaps what had been a provocative choice had become ''unbearably provocative?''

title: A Technology Delivers the Dailies to Some New Doorsteps
description: If there was one thing stranded travelers at the Vancouver, British Columbia, airport hotel wanted more than their breakfast the morning of Sept. 12 it was their newspapers. With no planes flying, none had been delivered, but the news arrived all the same.

description: WASHINGTON (AP) -- The Supreme Court ordered former President Clinton disbarred from practicing law before the high court on Monday and gave him 40 days to contest the order.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Supreme Court Prepares To Hear Telecom Cases

title: The Investigation So Far
description: The worldwide investigation has identified 19 hijackers who crashed the four jets on Sept. 11 and uncovered much about their preparations and backgrounds. But while 350 people have been detained and 400 more are sought for questioning, the United States has not identified accomplices or networks linking the attack to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi hiding in Afghanistan whom President Bush has called the prime suspect.

title: New Accounts
description: Red Roof Inns, Dallas, owned by the Accor Economy Lodging division of Accor, to the San Francisco office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies ( news/quote ), to handle its account, which had been at the Richards Group, Dallas. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. Richards continues handling a Red Roof sibling, Motel 6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHBERG, PEGGY R.
description: HIRSCHBERG-Peggy R. On September 30, 2001. Beloved wife of Gary. Devoted mother of Stacy and Amanda. Loving sister of Andie Gordon. Cherished aunt to Sanford and Jeffrey Mittleman, and Lindsey and John Gordon, and dear friend to many. Funeral service will be held Monday, October 1, 2001, at the Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY, at 1 PM. Interment will follow the services at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastingson-Hudson, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Developmental Chemotherapy Service Fund of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, in gratitude to Dr. David Spriggs.

description: A memorial service for Jane Dudley, the modern dancer, choreographer and teacher who died on Sept. 19, will be held today at 10:30 a.m. in St. Ansgar's Chapel at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

description: Arif Ali Khan Abbasi, educated at Oxford, retired head of Pakistan International Airlines, recently went to a mosque in Karachi to kneel for noon prayer.

title: Five Girls In Search of The Best in Themselves
description: At a time when the country is hungry for hope, there's a welcome helping in ''Five Girls.'' This ambitious documentary, being broadcast tomorrow night as part of the ''P.O.V.'' series on PBS, offers moving, detailed portraits of five young women in the Chicago area. They have widely varied backgrounds and prospects, but each is sustained through the minefield of adolescence by a determination to find the best in herself.

title: Marchers Oppose Waging War Against Terrorists
description: Several thousand protesters demonstrated here today against any military offensive in response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and near Washington.

title: Campus Culture Wars Flare Anew
description: The terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and the nation's prospective response have begun to reignite the culture wars that divided university campuses more than a decade ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGELBAUM, FRANCES
description: SIEGELBAUM-Frances. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Stanley and Dianne Siegelbaum and Sandra and George Gottlieb. Adored grandmother of Elizabeth and David Spivak, Stacey Gottlieb, Howard Siegelbaum and Steven Siegelbaum. Loving sister of Molly Salov. Services today, 10:30 AM, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY.

title: A Long Goodbye for Ripken Leaves Things a Bit Unresolved
description: Many extra innings and cold and rain emptied the stands of most fans who came to see Cal Ripken play his last game at Yankee Stadium yesterday, but Ripken was still out there, tucking his right hand in his back pocket to keep warm.

title: Help to Make Ends Meet on Only One Salary
description: As Donnie Taylor walked to the door of his apartment on the morning of Sept. 11, he was accompanied by Janice Dukes, who bade him goodbye as she did every morning, with a kiss. ''O.K., Dukes,'' Mr. Taylor said, ''have a good day and I'll talk to you later.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTON, ALBIN
description: SALTON-Albin. Died on September 28, 2001, at the age of 85. He was born in Budapest, Hungary, on August 27, 1916, and came to the United States in 1937. Educated at Queens College, Cambridge, England and at Harvard Business School, Mr. Salton was Managing Director of Lehman Brothers, Inc., prior to his retirement. He was a world traveler and connoisseur of arts and antiques. Mr. Salton's parents, Joseph Tivadar and Emmy of New York, and his sister, Thea Elek of Philadelphia, predeceased him. His wife, the former Anny de Rivera, whom he married in 1968, died in 1997. He leaves his niece, Maria Elek Roberts, her husband Larry, grandniece Teresa, grandnephews Gregory, Bruce and Eric Roberts, together with their families, including two great-grandnephews. He will be missed by his family and a host of friends in New York and throughout the world. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, 11:30 AM, on October 6, 2001. In accordance with Mr. Salton's request, friends are encouraged to make donations to their favorite charity in lieu of flowers.

description: Archaeologists have found evidence that appears to support the theory that a catastrophic flood struck the Black Sea region more than 7,000 years ago, turning the sea saline, submerging surrounding plains and possibly inspiring the flood legends of Mesopotamia and the Bible.

title: Madhavrao Scindia, Princely Indian Politician, Dies at 56
description: Madhavrao Scindia, scion of one of India's legendary royal families and a senior leader of the opposition Congress Party, died yesterday when a small plane carrying him to a political rally crashed into a paddy field during a lashing rainstorm. He was 56.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEDINA, STANDISH

Lawyer, fireman, sailor, local historian, pole vault champion. Graduate of The Hill 1933, Princeton 1937, Columbia Law 1940. Survived by children Jeremy Medina and Meredith Murray, seven grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Private cremation. Future memorial service to be announced. Donations in his memory may be made to the Green Village Fire Department, Green Village, NJ.

title: New Economy; Solidifying trademark protection in a global market, where logos can transcend language.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, LESTER, D.D.S.
description: BECK-Lester, D.D.S. Of New York City and Delray Beach. Oral and maxillofacial surgeon. Died at the age of 69, on September 29, 2001. Former Chief of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery at Good Samaritan Hospital. Former Head of Liability Committee for Suffolk County Dental Society. Former Board member of Cold Spring Country Club. Loving husband and best friend to Phyllis; adored and beloved father, grandfather, and best friend to Richard, Carol, Dina, Jason and Callie. An honest and pure man with great strength of character who was loved and touched so many people deeply; friends and strangers alike. Highly respected in his profession. We love you very, very much and will miss you forever. Services on Monday, October 1, at 2 PM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 516921-5757.

title: Three New York Teams, Nine Days of Classic Baseball
description: Bobby Thomson's famous home run of Oct. 3, 1951, is baseball's most legendary single dramatic moment, but his shot to left field was only the capstone of the most remarkable nine-day stretch New York baseball ever experienced. It started on Friday afternoon, Sept. 28, at Yankee Stadium with Allie Reynolds pitching a no-hitter and continued until a rainout on Sunday, Oct. 7, that proved inopportune for the Giants and fortuitous for the Yankees.

description: Following is the text of an address by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani to the United Nations Monday morning, as recorded by The New York Times :

title: Suburbs Beckon to Some Who Might Be Rethinking Life in the City
description: The air tastes sour. Dust clings to everything. And the neighborhood feels as homey as a battlefield.

title: Hawaiians Lose Sleep Over Tiny Frog With Big Voice
description: The high-pitched shriek co-KEE! co-KEE! co-KEE! -- was piercing enough to awaken Gail Souza in the middle of the night.

title: Milan Reviews
The Renewed Glory of Old Glory
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about the terrorist attacks' impact on New York's classical music institutions misstated the Carnegie Hall connection of Herman Sandler, a donor to several arts organizations, who is listed as missing at the World Trade Center. He was not a member of the Carnegie Hall board; his wife, Suki Sandler, is.

title: Magazine Publishers To Gather in New York
description: The Magazine Publishers of America and the American Society of Magazine Editors are moving the 2001 American Magazine Conference to New York from Phoenix and shortening the event by one day.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: No Bonuses For Cisco Executives
description: Top executives at Cisco Systems Inc. will not receive bonuses for the 2001 fiscal year because the company fell short of its financial goals, company officials said yesterday. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., is the nation's leading maker of computer-networking equipment. The company said in its annual proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it ''failed to achieve its corporate financial performance targets.'' In August, the company posted an annual loss for the first time in 11 years and said its first-quarter sales could be down by as much as 5 percent.

title: Searchers Find Remains of 50 People, Officials Say
description: In a grim mark of progress, searchers have moved closer to the center of what had been the north tower of the World Trade Center, and opened pockets of debris that contained the remains of 50 people, officials said yesterday.

title: Fed Makes 9th Rate Cut This Year in Effort to Revive Economy
description: Faced with an economic deterioration that has accelerated since the terrorist attacks last month, the Federal Reserve once again cut interest rates today by an expected half a percentage point, to their lowest level since 1962.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBERSON, JAMES
description: GIBERSON-James. (F.D.N.Y.) Of Huguenot, Staten Island, on September 11, 2001. Loving husband of Susan (nee Nordgaard). Devoted father of Erika, Cari and Sara. Beloved son of Harold and the late Geraldine. Dear brother of Nancy DiCostanzo, Robert and Richard Giberson. Also survived by 10 nieces and nephews. Friends and family are invited to gather at Casey McCallum Rice Funeral Home, 30 Nelson Avenue, Staten Island, on Thursday, October 4th, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Memorial service Friday, October 5, at 1 PM at Christ Lutheran Church, 125 Cleveland Ave., Great Kills, SI. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the Memorial Fund of Christ Lutheran Church or UFA Widows and Children's Fund, 204 East 23 St., New York, New York 10010.

title: No Special Accounting Breaks for Recent Corporate Setbacks
description: In an abrupt reversal, accounting rule makers have decided that no expenses stemming from the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon will be classified as extraordinary.

title: Judge Orders the Reinstatement Of a Superintendent Fired in '99
description: A state judge has ordered the Board of Education to reinstate a school superintendent fired two years ago by Rudy Crew, then the schools chancellor, in a case that has been closely watched by educators concerned about the movement to evaluate supervisors largely on test scores.

title: The Fight Ahead: Can We Learn From the Past?; The Lost Files
description: To the Editor:

title: Victims' Families Promised Some Health Coverage
description: Thousands of people are in danger of losing their health insurance in the aftermath of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, according to consumer advocates and health care agencies.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about expectations of a federal budget deficit misspelled the name of a public relations firm in which Stanley Collender is managing director for the federal budget consulting group. Mr. Collender, who said he considered a deficit likely, works for Fleishman-Hillard, not Fleischman-Hillard.

title: Air-Security Panel Makes Recommendations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  The team appointed by the transportation secretary to recommend improvements in aircraft security has expressed doubts about the qualifications of the people now searching planes, and about the idea of pilots carrying guns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALGER, DAVID DEWEY
description: ALGER-David Dewey. Was tragically lost on 11 September 2001, at the World Trade Center. A Memorial Service to celebrate his remarkable life will be held at Saint Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and 53rd Street in Manhattan, on Friday, 5 October 2001, at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to a worthy WTC relief fund. Gifts may also be made to the Foundation for Alger Families, a charitable foundation established to assist the families of Fred Alger Management employees lost in the attack on the WTC.

title: Families Recall Vacations, a Singing Voice, the Love for a Profession
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 344 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 289. In all, 5,219 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: Senator Byrd Scolds Colleagues For Lack of Debate After Attack
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who stands constant guard over Congressional prerogatives, chided his colleagues today for avoiding debate on serious issues in what he called an excessive effort to seem united after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Experts Call for Better Assessment of Threats
description: Federal agencies and Congress are racing to check the security of everything from soybeans to municipal water supplies to nuclear reactors to whole cities. Last week, concern rose with the disclosure that the suspected jet hijackers had investigated crop-dusters -- and thus, conceivably, the possibility of spreading deadly germs or chemicals.

title: New Library of Alexandria Opens (Few) Doors
description: The modern incarnation of the Library of Alexandria staged a temporary opening today, welcoming residents of the once glamorous but now dilapidated port city to use the building for six weeks while administrators wrestle with a long-delayed formal inauguration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, MONSIGNOR JOHN F.
description: WILSON-Monsignor John F. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of Holy Name Church, 245 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, on September 29, 2001. Reposing in M.J. Smith Funeral Home, 248 Prospect Park West, Tuesday October 2nd, from 2-5 P.M. Mass of Transferral at Holy Name Church at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass at Holy Name Church, Wednesday, October 3rd at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Reverend Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Long Branch: Train Hits Truck
description: A passenger train struck a pickup truck at a railroad crossing, disrupting service for three hours, New Jersey Transit officials said. No major injuries were reported. The train, westbound from Penn Station to Bay Head, hit the truck around 8:10 p.m. Sunday, Anna Farneski, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit, said yesterday. Service between Red Bank and Bay Head was suspended until 11:30 p.m. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Abrupt End To Royal Tempest
description: A television production company owned by Prince Edward gave up the film shot by one of its crews in violation of a privacy agreement for coverage of Prince William -- the son of Charles and Diana -- as he started college in Scotland. Prince Edward is Prince William's uncle. Prince Edward's production company, Ardent Productions, turned the footage over to Buckingham Palace, which said it did not contain pictures of William. The Ardent crew stayed on at the St. Andrews University campus for several days last week after other crews agreed to leave.

title: Goodbye to Mademoiselle: Cond Nast Closes Magazine
description: After struggling to revamp its identity in a depressed advertising environment, Mademoiselle, the 66-year-old magazine for young women, long considered a mainstay of the Cond Nast stable, is closing.

title: Arab-Israeli Cease-Fire? The Deaths Are Mounting, Along With the Finger-Pointing
description: Here is what a quiet day looks like during the nominal ceasefire in Israel: today, just one car, packed with explosives, nails, and ammunition, blew up along a busy street here, and it did not hurt anybody.

title: Americans Expect Reyna to Face Jamaica
description: Claudio Reyna's knee injury, sustained Sunday while he was playing for Glasgow Rangers against its archrival, Celtic, is not as severe as it was originally thought, according to officials at the United States Soccer Federation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Cardinal Egan Comments On Terror
description: Cardinal Edward Egan, in Vatican City for a monthlong meeting of Roman Catholic bishops from around the world, said yesterday that ''words like vengeance, retaliation and so forth are not the words of civilized people.'' The cardinal witnessed the collapse of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 and administered last rites to victims. With Pope John Paul II listening, Cardinal Egan said that the United States must not ''get involved in a lot of injustice to settle our accounts.'' Marina Harss (NYT)

description: Having battled through three recessions in the last decade, Japanese executives are preparing for a fourth, and business confidence is dropping, according to the latest quarterly Tankan survey released today by the Bank of Japan.

description: DESREAU-Edwin R. Son of Max and Beatrice, brother of Diane Zelanko. Died September 6, 2001. His family and friends will love and miss him always. Graveside services will be at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY on October 7, 2001 at 1 P.M.

description: A television commercial featuring images of police officers and firefighters working at the World Trade Center disaster scene is being used as a club by both sides in the New Jersey governor's race.

title: A Sense of American Unfairness Erodes Support in Gulf States
description: The prosperous, pro-Western Arab states in the Persian Gulf are not countries where people take their protests into the street. So the general dismay about perceived American tolerance of violence against Palestinians, and the resulting lack of faith in American leadership, are scarcely visible.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: 'Hard Knocks' and Some Easy Money
description: If you knew that some Baltimore Ravens players had been paid to cooperate with NFL Films and HBO Sports in the making of ''Hard Knocks,'' would you have viewed the documentary series differently?

title: Emmy Show Returning To Two-Coast Format
description: For the first time in more than 30 years the Emmy Awards show, to be held on Sunday night at 8, will be bicoastal, with the bulk of the ceremony here and a simultaneous broadcast from a studio in New York. Executives at the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences said many nominees from New York preferred not to travel to Los Angeles for the event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINSLY, BETTY
description: PINSLY-Betty. Age 94, on September 30, 2001. Of Hallandale, FL, formerly of Queens, NY. Survived by her son Stephan, daughter Shelley Stein, sister Sylvia Lattman, five loving grandchildren.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Columbia U. Search Narrows
description: The search committee for a new president of Columbia University has narrowed its choices, and although the short list includes Lee C. Bollinger, left, president of the University of Michigan, the committee's chairman, Henry King, cautioned yesterday that there were other candidates. Mr. King said the trustees would make the final choice next July. The Columbia Spectator, the campus newspaper, quoted unnamed sources yesterday as saying the committee ''may be on the verge of recommending'' Mr. Bollinger. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRNE, MARGARET M.
description: BYRNE-Margaret M. Of the Villa Maria Home for the Aged, North Plainfield, formerly of NYC, on September 29, 2001. Daughter of the late John and Jennie (nee Mc Phillips) Byrne, sister of the late Alice, Claire Garvey, Frances, John, William, Elizabeth Keegan, Jane deGrandpre, Mary; also survived by a brother-in-law, Dr. Arthur B. deGrandpre and many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and nephews, and great grandnieces and nephews. Please omit flowers but memorial contributions may be made to St Ignatius Loyola Church or Villa Maria Home for the Aged.
