title: A Study Links Prayer and Pregnancy
description: Researchers at Columbia University, expressing surprise at their own findings, are reporting that women at an in vitro fertilization clinic in Korea had a higher pregnancy rate when, unknown to the patients, total strangers were asked to pray for their success.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Globespan Agrees To Buy Virata
description: Globespan Inc., whose circuits enable high-speed data transmission over copper phone wires, agreed to buy the Virata Corporation in a stock transaction with an indicated value of $587.8 million. Virata shares fell as much as 18 percent. Globespan will swap 1.02 of its shares for each share of Virata, a maker of chips for fast Internet access. Based on Friday's stock prices, the deal values Virata at $9.22 a share, less than its closing price Friday. The companies, which portrayed the deal as a merger of equals, said they would save $30 million to $35 million in the first full year after the deal closes, which is expected in three to six months. Shareholders of Globespan will own almost 53 percent of the company, while Virata's will hold about 48 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERLAIN, RICHARD T.
description: CHAMBERLAIN-Richard T., 60, son of Herbert J. & Vivian E. Crimmins, passed Sept. 27, 2001, Brevard, NC. Formerly of Yonkers & Mamaroneck, NY. NYPD Detective, 1969-1990. Survivors include wife, Frances Amodeo Chamberlain, sons Brian G., Keith R., Brendan T., grandson, Ian H., & siblings Herbert J., Regina Orchanian, Thomas M., Bryan F. & Loretta Mulford. Service held at Sacred Heart Church, Brevard, NC. For info call Moody-Conolly 828883-8161. Gifts to Lymphoma Res. Found. of America, 310-204-7040.

title: Democrats Go to Long Island To Aid Suozzi's Uphill Trail
description: Two dozen Democratic officials appeared with Thomas R. Suozzi today to rally behind his candidacy for Nassau County executive, but he seemed more focused on Republicans.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Gunmaker Lawsuit Rejected
description: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the City of Bridgeport could not sue gun manufacturers and retailers for millions of dollars in medical and other costs resulting from gun violence. The court ruled that Bridgeport lacked legal standing to pursue a suit, in part because Bridgeport's injury -- the medical and other costs -- did not result directly from the manufacture and sale of weapons. Bridgeport had estimated the costs at $100 million. The court upheld a lower-court decision dismissing a lawsuit against Smith & Wesson and others by Mayor Joseph P. Ganim, left. He may appeal. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Red Tape Cut and Rivers Dredged to Carry Debris by Water
description: The city has nearly completed a super-accelerated dredging of the East and Hudson Rivers to create barge ports to carry away a large share of the 1.2 million tons of debris from the World Trade Center site.

title: Officials Pleased by Morning Traffic With Car-Pooling Rule
description: New York City's morning ban on driving alone into Manhattan via four bridges and two tunnels cut deeply into traffic on those crossings yesterday, and transportation officials' fears about a nightmarish commute were largely unfounded.

title: College Plans Little Altered By the Attack; U.S., Not City, Is Seen As Terrorists' Target
description: When Columbia University's associate admissions director, Shawn L. Abbott, headed to Portland, Me., last week to talk to high school students, he was uncertain what to expect. Images of the smoldering ruins of the World Trade Center were everywhere. He and his colleagues feared that students and their families might no longer see New York as the ideal college town.

title: Debating Patients' Capacity to Decide
description: The patient, a 38-year-old man at a small hospital in Providence, R.I., was suffering intense pain from a bowel obstruction. But when his doctor recommended an operation, the man refused, saying he was afraid of surgery.

title: A Spirited Argument From a Composer Nearing 93
description: Extreme old age can befuddle the mind or, as in the case of Elliott Carter, it can clarify it to a new degree. Mr. Carter, who will be 93 in December, confirms the theory that learning is not a process of accumulation but of paring away the unneeded. His new Cello Concerto had its premiere performance by the Chicago Symphony here on Thursday night. The orchestra commissioned the piece, Daniel Barenboim conducted, and Yo-Yo Ma played the solo parts.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Indonesia: Irian Jaya Rebels On The Move
description: Separatist rebels in a remote province, Irian Jaya, have reportedly occupied a district capital for the first time. Officials said 200 rebels from the Free Papua Movement seized the mountain town of Ilaga, burned down the police station and raised their own flag. The army was preparing to fly in reinforcements to the jungle-covered mountain area. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: For the Families, a Chance to Share Tears and Love
description: Since Sept. 11, the name of the bond trading firm Cantor Fitzgerald has become synonymous with loss. By now, the numbers are only too familiar: more than 600 of 1,000 employees gone, leaving behind 1,500 children. And so yesterday, at a memorial service held in a sunless Central Park, statistics went unmentioned while individuals were remembered.

title: MEDICIS PHARMACEUTICAL TO ACQUIRE ASCENT PEDIATRICS
description: The Medicis Pharmaceutical Corporation said yesterday that it planned to acquire Ascent Pediatrics Inc. for $60 million and up to five years of incentive payments to enter the market for children's drugs. In addition to Medicis's initial payment of about 41 cents for each share of Ascent, the company has agreed to pay up to $10 million a year for five years in incentive payments if certain goals are met. Medicis, which is based in Scottsdale, Ariz., sells skin-care medications. It would enter the pediatrics business with Ascent's 70-member sales force and products that include Orapred, an asthma treatment, and Primsol, an antibiotic. The announcement was made after United States markets had closed.

title: What's Doing Around Town
description: From Broadway and Off Broadway to concert halls and jazz clubs, New York City's stages are returning to normal schedules. Here is a sampling of performances.

title: Tunnel Vision; Rough Rider on the Redbird Express
description: Like many others, Edward R. Levitt cannot live his life the way he used to anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLEN, THOMAS P. III
description: CULLEN-Thomas P. III, (F.D.N.Y). Of Staten Island on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Susan (Quinn), loving father of Thomas P. Cullen IV, cherished son of Rita and Thomas P. Cullen Jr, dear brother of Rita and Sean Quinn. Funeral from the Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Ave, Staten Island. A memorial Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola, R.C. Church in Manhattan on Friday at 10AM. Visitation at Casey Funeral Home will be Thursday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the Uniformed Firefighters Association, 204 East 23rd St, NY, NY 10010, would be appreciated.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is not a time for further study or vague directives. The evidence of terrorism's brutality and inhumanity, of its contempt for life and the concept of peace, is lying beneath the rubble of the World Trade Center less than two miles from where we meet today.''

title: Ex-King and Rebels to Hold Special Council
description: The exiled king of Afghanistan and leaders of the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance agreed today to convene an emergency ''Supreme Council'' here by the end of this month, as a first step toward replacing their country's militant Islamic rulers.

title: The Big City; Twisted Logic On Improving Air Security
description: AIRLINE officials and politicians on Capitol Hill have a favorite remedy to the security lapses at airports: a new federal work force to run security operations. But would it do any good?

title: Ad-Libbing His Way Into Trouble
description: Shortly after the terrorist attacks, the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, summoned reporters to the Treasury Department's diplomatic reception room to describe how the strikes had hurt the economy and what the administration would do to limit the damage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JERKOWSKY, ROSALYN
description: JERKOWSKY - Rosalyn. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Jewish Outreach Institute in New York, mourn the passing of Rosalyn Jerkowsky, loving mother of Ruth Elkes, wife of Terry Elkes, our esteemed President of the Board. Through her life, she taught the values that live on in her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren, to whom we express our deepest sympathy: to Ruth and her husband Terry and all the members of the family. Private services to be held at the request of the family. Dr. Kerry M. Olitzky, Exec. Dir. Dr. Egon Mayer, Founding Dir.

title: They're Off to See Wizards and Jordan
description: The practice court of the Washington Wizards swelled with reporters, camera lenses and television lights. The N.B.A. does not open for business until Oct. 30, but Michael Jordan's first official day of work as a Wizards ballplayer stoked the usual Michaelmania embers today. A crush of news media, fans snaking around the MCI Center for tickets -- grand attention paid to an unretired American sports icon.

title: Making the Most of Giuliani
description: New York is on the edge of an economic abyss. That reality -- not the mayor's personality or city politics -- is what New Yorkers have to focus on as they consider Rudolph Giuliani's request to stay on for three months after his term ends. Regardless of who in New York likes Mr. Giuliani and who doesn't, and regardless of the unwillingness of many local politicians to see him remain in office even a day after Jan. 1, he has come to symbolize the best of New York to the rest of the country. And we badly need the rest of the country to help pay for our reconstruction.

title: Husavik Journal; Gad, Alligators! Is Iceland Balmy, or Plain Barmy?
description: Here on Iceland's northern shore, the arctic grouse are already wearing their white winter coats as the snows fringing the peaks prepare to creep into the lanes of this tiny fishing town.

title: Compaq Says It Will Show Operating Loss in Quarter
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that it had missed its third-quarter sales goals by as much as 12 percent and would post an operating loss, largely because of a virtual halt to its business after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

It is the Special Air Service, not the Strategic Air Service.

title: Stocks Somewhat Higher Ahead of Today's Fed Meeting
description: Stocks rose modestly today as investors made few moves ahead of a possible interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve.

title: Maker of Hush Puppies Reports a Profit
description: ROCKFORD, Mich., Oct. 1 (Bloomberg)  Wolverine World Wide Inc. ( news/quote ) said today that it earned $14.4 million in its most recent quarter, reversing a year-earlier loss as sales of its Merrell and Wolverine shoes for outdoor and industrial use increased.

title: Mayor Asserts He, Not State, Will Oversee Charity Efforts
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he would coordinate the charitable groups responding to the attacks on the World Trade Center, a move that comes only days after New York State's attorney general had taken steps to perform that function.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOR, JAMES LEE
description: CONNOR-James Lee, 38. Of Summit, N.J. Formerly of Manhasset, New York. Taken from us in the September 11th attack on the World Trade Center. Jim was a 1985 graduate of the College of William and Mary. He started his career at Bear Stearns and left in 1989 to join the startup investment banking firm of Sandler O'Neil. He was made a partner in 2000. He leaves his wife Jamie (DiBona) formerly of Virginia Beach, VA, his 2 sons Jimmy (7) and Jack (4); his parents Ruth Ann and Jim Connor of Cutchogue, New York, formerly of Manhasset, NY; his sister Cathy Connor Dodge, his brother-in-law Tod Dodge and their children Tommy, Laura and Tara of Manhasset, New York; his uncle Reverend Robert Connor of Manhattan and Tom Murphy of Brooklyn Heights, his in-laws Dr. Doug and Gail DiBona of Virginia Beach, VA, his brother-in-law Kevin DiBona and his wife Missy & their children Tommy, Caroline and Katie of Virginia Beach, VA. Jim was an avid golfer and sports enthusiast. He will forever be remembered for his quick wit and engaging sense of humor. A memorial service will be held at St. Teresa's in Summit, New Jersey on October 13 at Noon. In lieu of flowers, an endowment in Jim's name has been established at the Golf Department at the College of William and Mary. Contributions may be made: W.M.A.E.F.-GOLF, C/O Tom Jensen, 11434 Greenmoor Lane, Oakton, VA. 22124.

title: Lion Nathan in Wine Deal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Oct. 2 (Bloomberg News)  Lion Nathan Ltd. has agreed to buy Petaluma Ltd. for 222 million Australian dollars ($110 million), its second wine acquisition in less than a week.

title: NEGOTIATORS BACK SCALED-DOWN BILL TO BATTLE TERROR
description: Democratic and Republican negotiators in the House reached agreement today on a bill that would give law enforcement officials expanded authority to wiretap suspected terrorists, share intelligence information about them and monitor their Internet communications.

title: Hot Spots Linger at Ground Zero
description: With the city's permission, a twin-engine plane from EarthData International flies almost daily over the World Trade Center site. The plane is equipped with an instrument that can detect small changes in the amount of heat coming to the surface. After flying over other parts of Lower Manhattan to measure normal temperatures, the plane heads for the site, where the instrument registers any temperature difference higher than 1.8 degrees. The hot spots shown are hotter than normal by about 60 degrees or more. STEVE DUENES

title: Salon Will Start Charging its Web Readers
description: The Web magazine Salon, facing sharply lower advertising revenues and increased costs for gathering news, has decided to make its news and political coverage available only to paying subscribers.

title: Waiting for Economic Answers
description: President Bush and his national security team have done a good job of assuring the American people that they understand the political and military challenges of the fight against terrorism. The administration has seemed less sure-footed when it comes to handling the threat to the nation's economy. With Congress beginning to debate a possible stimulus package this week, the White House has been surprisingly silent on how seriously it regards the current economic situation, or what it wants to do to improve it. Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill and the rest of the Bush team have yet to show full command of the issues they face.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIGGS, GEORGENE W.
description: BIGGS-Georgene W. Died September 29, 2001, at the age of 94. Devoted wife of the late William R. Biggs. Beloved mother of Barton, Jeremy and Christopher. She was the adored grandmother of Wende, Gretchen, Barton, Fiona, Allegra, Melissa, Robin, Courtney, Jennifer and Christopher. She is also survived by seventeen greatgrandchildren. There will be no memorial service. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARNER, MARTIN
description: GARNER-Martin. Of the Actors' Home in Englewood, NJ. Beloved husband of Virginia (nee Micallef). Services Wednesday, 2 PM, ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park St, Hackensack.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINSTEIN, AARON
description: WEINSTEIN-Aaron. Gone four years. Remembered with love. Ruth, Bob, Michael, Lois, Cheryl, Leslie, Eri

title: The Fight Ahead: Can We Learn From the Past?
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Crowning Good With Sisterhood

title: OBSERVATORY
description: This Old, Old House

title: Recapturing the Madness Of the Nixon White House
description: PRESIDENT NIXON

title: Sears Tower Workers Are Plagued By Rumors
description: Another day, another false alarm.

title: People
description: Jonathan Harries, executive vice president and worldwide creative director for global brands at Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named chairman at the Chicago office and worldwide creative director at the agency. The chairman's post is new; in the creative post, Mr. Harries succeeds Geoff Thompson, who is retiring, the agency said.

title: IKON, DISTRIBUTOR OF PHOTOCOPIERS, TO CUT 2,600 JOBS
description: Ikon Office Solutions Inc., the largest American distributor of copiers from Canon Inc. and the Ricoh Company, will eliminate about 2,600 jobs and said profit for the quarter that ended yesterday would be lower than forecast. Ikon said profit from operations was 9 cents to 12 cents a share in the quarter, less than its estimate of 14 cents. Ikon will have a loss after taking a pretax charge of about $65 million for the job cuts and exiting some businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ISAAC
description: STERN-Isaac. Yale University and the School of Music mourn the loss of Isaac Stern, one of the most beloved violinists of his generation, a champion of music as a profoundly unifying force, and a mentor of enormous influence. He was a cherished friend who unselfishly shared his unique gifts with our community. We were honored to bestow the degree of Doctor of Music upon him. To his children and to his entire family we extend our heartfelt sympathy and our eternal gratitude for sharing his energy and talents with us. Richard C. Levin, President of Yale University Robert L. Blocker, The Lucy and Henry Moses Dean of Music

title: Lancelot and Guinevere, Trysting in Central Park
description: Will somebody please buy the Gorilla Repertory Theater Company a calendar? The intrepid troupe is performing outdoors at night again, apparently unaware that this is the time of year when meteorologists begin replacing phrases like ''balmy evening'' with those like ''overnight lows near freezing.''

title: Afghanistan's Ethnic Groups, and Pinpointing the Taliban's Strongpoints
description: AFGHANISTAN is a vast and forbidding country, swept by deserts, mountains and a terrain so harsh that arable land often stretches no more than a few feet on each side of a riverbed. Its history is equally unforgiving. At the crossroads of Central Asia, Afghanistan has been crisscrossed by traders and would-be conquerors for centuries. The last invader, the former Soviet Union, departed in 1989, and the husks of its tanks still litter the landscape.

title: How to Kill Castro? 60's Fantasies Resonate Today
description: Assume for a moment that the United States must deal with a charismatic foreign leader opposed to its way of life, a man who is part of an international conspiracy with a history of assassinations and with blindly loyal adherents said to have spent years infiltrating the government and other vital institutions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIAMMONA, VINCENT F.
description: GIAMMONA-Vincent F. Lieutenant, FDNY, with Ladder 5, died in the line of duty on September 11, 2001, at the World Trade Center disaster. Beloved husband of Theresa (nee Varvaro). Loving father of Francesca, Toni-Ann, Nicolette and Daniella. Dear son of Capt. Vincent (retired FDNY) and Dorothy Giammona. Loving brother of Louise Caudullo, Linda Giammona-Julian and Steven. Dear son-in-law of Vincent and Frances Varvaro. Memorial service Wednesday, October 3, 2001, at Holy Name of Mary Church, Valley Stream, New York, at 1 PM. A trust has been established for the benefit of his dependents. In lieu of flowers donations to the Lt. Vincent F. Giammona Memorial Trust, 2 Haven Avenue, Suite 221, Port Washington, New York 11050, are appreciated.

title: Much of Swissair Seeks Bankruptcy
description: Deep in debt and desperate for cash, the Swissair Group announced drastic action to revamp itself today, including a filing for bankruptcy protection for many of its operations and a sale of control of Crossair, its regional subsidiary, to Switzerland's two largest banks.

title: NATO Says Evidence Proves bin Laden Link
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 2 -- NATO said today that the United States had provided "clear and compelling proof" that Osama bin Laden was behind the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. In response, the alliance said it was ready to fight at America's side should the United States ask for such help from its 18 NATO allies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLETT, ALBERT P., S.J.
description: BARTLETT-Albert P., S.J. Beloved uncle of Mrs. Eileen Nihan, Mrs. Noreen Noel, Mrs. Kathleen Betsch. Reposing at St. Helena Church, Bronx, NY Tuesday 27PM. Mass at St. Helena Church, Tuesday, 7:30PM. Visitation Wednesday at the Loyola Hall Chapel, Fordham University 3-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian burial at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Loyola Hall, Fordham University, Thursday 11AM. For further information contact Farenga Brothers Inc., Directors, 718-654-0500.

title: Girl Killed in Brooklyn Was Apparently Bystander
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn girl who was fatally shot Sunday night as she left a talent show for teenagers was most likely an innocent bystander, the police said yesterday.

title: Like Nostradamus, but Carrying Anthrax Pills
description: THE little black beeper box attached to Dr. Harvey Kushner's black leather belt emits another shriek as he, briefly, plays hard to get. It sounds urgent, but he doesn't startle easily. And he feels relatively safe behind the locked doors and locked windows that lend his cinder block office on the leafy C.W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville, N.Y., its bunkerish tone.

title: Breaking the Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REALE, VIRGINIA (FIOCCO)
description: REALE-Virginia (Fiocco), November 18, 1897-September 29, 2001. Daughter of the late Rose (Collica) & Enrico Fiocco, stepmother Antoinette. Beloved wife of the late Salvatore Reale, loving mother of daughter Eleanor & son-in-law John Lavarello, son S. Robert & daughter-in-law Mary Reale. Daughter Vera (Elvira) Reale, grandmother of Elaine (Lavarello) & Vincent Cipriani, Virginia (Reale) and Anthony Russo, loving sister of Medora Bandonee, Edith Keefe, Viola Gulinello, Gloria Morris, Veronica Gambino, Enrico, John & Cosmo Fiocco and the late Antoinette Fiocco, Nancy Giardina, Irene Stella, Louise Pine. A great loss to all, including many cousins, nieces & nephews. Her love & compassion lives on in all of us. A shining star who will be in our hearts forever. Reposing Wed. & Thurs. 2-5 & 7-10 at Cusimano & Russo, Inc., 2005 West 6th Street, Brooklyn, New York. Funeral mass Friday 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompeii Church, NYC. Interment St. Raymond Cemetery.

title: A Breakthrough for Kazakhstan's Oil
description: Nine long years after a consortium was formed to build it, a $2.6 billion pipeline from the Tengiz oil field in western Kazakhstan to Novorossiysk, a Russian port on the Black Sea, is finally ready to begin operating. Oil will start flowing in the next few days, bound for customers in the Mediterranean and Western Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JELINEK, HUGO
description: JELINEK-Hugo. Born 1901, in Austro-Hungary. Immigrated to the United States on October 12, 1939. He was the founder of H. Jelinek Dental Alloys, Inc. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Devoted father of Ruth Schapira and Judith Gerstl. Adored grandfather of Ralph and Paul Schapira, and Jonathan and Janis Gerstl. Loving great-grandfather. Graveside service was held.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Sign Of U.S. Rower
description: The coast guard said it had called off a search for a lone American rower in the Atlantic after his emergency search beacon was found floating alone in the sea. Nenad Bilic, 62, a retired cardiologist from Chicago, set off in a 21-foot red cedar boat, The Lun, from Cape Cod, Mass., on May 11, heading for southwestern Ireland. The coast guard said Mr. Bilic's beacon was activated on Sunday 230 miles west of Ireland. The crew of a Royal Air Force helicopter found the beacon overnight but there was no sign of Dr. Bilic or the boat, the coast guard said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: CARDINAL EGAN COMMENTS ON TERROR Cardinal Edward Egan, in Vatican City for a monthlong meeting of Roman Catholic bishops from around the world, said yesterday that "words like vengeance, retaliation and so forth are not the words of civilized people." The cardinal witnessed the collapse of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 and administered last rites to victims. With Pope John Paul II listening, Cardinal Egan said that the United States must not "get involved in a lot of injustice to settle our accounts."

title: Why Would a Playwright Weave a Mystery Around a Wool Jacket?
description: The jacket, a gray lamb's wool sport coat, is already lying on the stage floor as the audience enters, and it is lying there again as the play ends. In between it is worn by both the play's actors, who each take on several roles and trade the jacket back and forth as they change identities or exchange places in the spotlight. At one point the jacket serves as a bone of contention between two characters, gay lovers who are the focus of two of the play's three concentric tales.

title: Mets Come Home and Go Absolutely Nowhere
description: One of the believers, seated down the left-field line, held up a homemade sign in the late innings that read, ''Let's See a Dream Come True.'' The Mets have tried. For five weeks of scintillating baseball, they hit in the clutch, made the plays, got the big outs.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; In a New Term's Somber First Day, Justices Hear Arguments on Inmate Rights
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether inmates in a federal prison or detention center run by a private contractor can sue the company for violating their constitutional rights.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Seeks To Make Amends
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's semiapology for his disparaging remarks about Islamic civilization has apparently not satisfied his critics, especially in Arab countries. Today he will meet with the Saudi ambassador, the head of the Islamic Cultural Center in Rome and other Arab officials. The Arab League secretary general, Amr Mussa, said he had met with the Iranian foreign minister, Kamal Kharazi, on how to respond to what he called unacceptable accusations against Islamic culture. In a speech before the Italian Senate on Friday, Mr. Berlusconi expressed regret if his words last week had hurt Arab sensitivities. Gavino Angius, the senate leader of the opposition Democrats of the Left party, said Mr. Berlusconi's words had been stupid, had isolated Italy and were a gift to Osama bin Laden. Marina Harss (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: A Push For Generic Drugs
description: The state's Medicaid agency will begin encouraging doctors to prescribe generic drugs in an effort to trim its budget as state revenue projections fall. The agency, the Medical Assistance Administration, serves about 850,000 people with a $6 billion budget, about 40 percent of the Department of Social and Health Services' total. Under the program, which will begin on Dec. 1, Medicaid recipients will be limited to four nongeneric drugs per month; doctors must consult with a state-hired pharmacist to prescribe further brand name drugs.

title: The N.F.L. Drops the Ball
description: The National Football League appears close to a deal that will keep this season's Super Bowl in New Orleans. This will come as a disappointment to Senator Charles Schumer, who had been lobbying the N.F.L. to move the game to New York -- or rather to New Jersey's Meadowlands stadium, which is as close as you can currently come. Mr. Schumer had argued that the move would show support for the metropolitan area in the wake of the terrorist attack, and pump needed tourist dollars into its economy. Super Bowl XXXVI was actually not on many New Yorkers' minds when they thought about economic recovery. But on reflection, we began to think the senator was onto something, and we are sorry to see the idea fizzle so quickly.

title: Stocks Close Higher After Fed Cuts Rates
description: The stock market rose today after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by an anticipated half a percentage point in an effort to revive the declining economy.

title: Blood Donors With a Need to Give
description: With growing concerns about the adequacy of the nation's blood supply, blood bank officials may welcome a new study suggesting that people with an uncommon blood disease can make suitable donors.

title: Footlights
description: Of Life and Loss

title: Hitchcock Makes His Case to Join Postseason Rotation
description: When the Yankees clinched the American League East a week ago, they presumably had ample time to prepare for the postseason and resolve any lingering injuries. Now, their final week could have bigger implications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANADE, EUGENE
description: CANADE-Eugene. A former UN official and an artist, son of artist Vincent Francis Canade, died in Paris on September 16, 2001. Born in New York, on November 22 1914, Eugene Canade received a BA from Brooklyn College in 1939, served as captain in the Medical Administrative Corps of the US Army from 1940 to 1946, and after the war, started working with UNICEF in New York, and soon after, in the Paris office until retirement in 1979. He was a painter, sculptor, and print-maker whose work was exhibited as a one-man show in Paris at the Lucie Krogh gallery in 1963. It was also part of the October 2000 exhibit in Queensbury, New York, ''It Becomes our Life: The William Bronk Collection,'' commemorating his close friend William Bronk. He illustrated a number of books of poetry by William Bronk and by James Weil. Deeply loved by his entire family, he was predeceased by his wife, Ethel S. Canade (May 12, 1912-January 19, 1987). He is survived by his brother Vincent Canade, sisters Celia Raupp and Florence Lambert; his children, Anne and Arsene Bonafous-Murat, Laura and Erwin Solomon, Francesca Canade Sautman, and Bianca and Marvin Bakalar; and by his eight grandchildren and one greatgrandson.

title: A Hopeless And Helpless Self-Help Specialist
description: Anyone who saw ABC's wry, clever promos for ''Bob Patterson'' this summer -- Charlie Sheen and Regis Philbin saying that Bob Patterson, the country's No. 3 self-help guru, made them who they are -- be prepared for a letdown. The show's fresh premise has been turned into an irredeemable, trite sitcom. With Jason Alexander as the whining, insecure Bob (he's still George from ''Seinfeld,'' only successful) the series may be the season's biggest disappointment, with its potentially hilarious hero wrapped in already exhausted jokes.

title: 28,000 State Workers Strike in Minnesota, Drawing Fire
description: Nearly 28,000 Minnesota state employees walked off the job today in a demand for higher pay, drawing criticism from many Minnesotans, who said the strikers were acting selfishly at a time of national crisis.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Survivors from the 60th floor of 2 World Trade who work in Morgan Stanley's municipal bonds department at their temporary office, Varick St., New York, Sept. 18, 2001

title: Foreign Affairs; Eastern Middle School
description: I recently attended meet-the-teacher night at Eastern Middle School, my daughter Natalie's school in Silver Spring, Md. The evening began with the principal noting that Eastern, a public school in suburban Washington, had 40 different nationalities among its students. Before the teachers were introduced, the school's choir and orchestra, a Noah's ark of black, Hispanic, Asian and white kids, led everyone in ''God Bless America.'' There was something about the way those kids sang together, and the earnest, if not always melodious, way the school orchestra pounded out the National Anthem, that was both moving and soothing. As I took in the scene, it occurred to me how much the Islamic terrorists who just hit America do not understand about America.

title: N.F.L. Nears Deal on Super Bowl
description: The N.F.L. has a tentative agreement to keep its championship game in New Orleans. The date will be moved back one week to Feb. 3, ensuring that the postseason will be played in its entirety.

title: Official in Election Battle Turns Eyes to Florida Race
description: Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state who became a household name for her role in the presidential recount last year, is expected to announce on Tuesday that she will run for Congress next year.

title: CARMIKE CINEMAS FILES PLAN FOR REWORKING DEBT
description: Carmike Cinemas Inc., a movie-theater chain trying to emerge from bankruptcy, filed a recovery plan that restructures about $650 million in debt. Carmike, with 328 theaters in 35 states, sought Chapter 11 protection in United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware in August 2000 after failing to make $9 million in interest payments to bondholders. Around $263 million of Carmike's bank loans and $200 million in senior subordinated notes are restructured under the proposal. Bank lenders and noteholders would be fully paid from a combination of new debt and cash under the plan.

title: New Blueprint for Military Shifts Priority to U.S. Soil, Revising 2-War Strategy
description: The Defense Department sent Congress a sweeping review of strategy today that was strikingly prescient in warning of new terrorist threats on American soil, even as many of its specific findings have been overtaken by the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Drinking's Long-Term Toll on the Brain
description: Elderly people who drink alcohol heavily appear to have more brain shrinkage, or atrophy, than those who drink lightly or not at all. Moderate drinkers seem to have overall healthier brains than nondrinkers, according to a report in the journal Stroke.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Bangladesh: The Voting Begins
description: Bangladeshis voted in national parliamentary elections that pitted the Awami League -- whose leader, Sheik Hasina, recently completed a five-year term as prime minister -- against the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, led by Khaleda Zia. The results of the election, which was marred by violence, are expected on Wednesday. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Blair Tells Taliban It Faces War Over bin Laden
description: BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 2  Prime Minister Tony Blair declared that that Osama bin Laden was clearly responsible for the terrorist attacks on the United States and challenged the Taliban regime in Afghanistan to give him up or "face the consequences."

title: Barber's Injury Is Setback for Giants
description: Running back Ron Dayne helped carry the Giants to victory over New Orleans on Sunday. Dayne had better be ready to do it again. And again.

title: The Investigation So Far
description: President Bush said that a global web of shared intelligence was gradually yielding information about the identities and hiding places of people connected with Osama bin Ladens network, Al Qaeda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, MILTON
description: SILVER-Milton. The Aspatuck Club of Westhampton Beach mourn the passing of a former member and friend. Mark S. Weiss, President Robert Bailin, Vice President

title: The Fight Ahead: Can We Learn From the Past?; Helping the Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAZIOSO, TIMOTHY G. AND JOHN M.
description: GRAZIOSO-Timothy G. and John M. Of Gulf Stream, FL and Middletown, NJ, both formerly of Clifton, both missing since the September 11, 2001 attack on the World Trade Center. Timothy, beloved husband of Deborah (Pankanin) and loving father of Lauren and Briana. John, beloved husband of Tina (Lytle), and loving father of Kathryn, Kristen, and Michael. Both devoted sons of Sandra (Fornelius) Grazioso and Henry Grazioso. Dear brothers of Carolee Azzarello, and her husband John. Cherished halfbrothers of Karen Ventre and Kristy Grazioso. Memorial Mass Thursday, October 4, 12 Noon, St. John Kanty RC Church, 49 Speer Ave., Clifton. In lieu of flowers, donations to Timothy and John Grazioso's Children Trust Fund, PO Box 1193, Newark NJ 07101-1193, would be appreciated. Information: Shook Funeral Home, 639 Van Houten Avenue, Clifton.

title: William Laporte, 88, Ex-Chief Of Pharmaceutical Company
description: William F. Laporte, a former president and chairman of the American Home Products Corporation, died on Sept. 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 and also lived in Buck Hill Falls, Pa.

title: World Bank Says Poor Nations Will Suffer Worst Economic Toll
description: Though the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks will very likely take a heavy toll on the economies of the United States and other wealthy nations, they may have an even greater impact on poor nations that do not have safety nets in place to absorb a sharp economic downturn, the World Bank predicted in a report issued today.

title: Giuliani's Quest for a Term Extension Hits a Wall in Albany
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's chances of staying in office past Dec. 31 dimmed markedly today. State lawmakers declared the idea of extending his term by 90 days all but dead, and some in the mayor's camp said he would not try to run for a third term.

title: Green's First Shot for the Runoff
description: Mark Green, the public advocate, released a 30-second ad called ''Faces'' yesterday, his first television commercial of the runoff campaign for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

title: JACK IN THE BOX LOWERS EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Jack in the Box Inc., the drive-through hamburger chain, lowered its earnings outlook for the fiscal fourth quarter and 2002, citing a sales decline since the terrorist attacks Sept. 11. Shares of Jack in the Box, which is based in San Diego, fell $5, or 18 percent, to $23. The company expects earnings in the quarter ended Sept. 30 to be about 49 cents a share. The company was expected to earn 55 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Jack in the Box said it expected 2001 earnings of $2.10 a share, less than its previous forecast of $2.16. The company lowered its 2002 earnings forecast to $2.18, less than the $2.46 average estimate of seven analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: An agency giant is expected to warn of lower profits, and analysts darken their outlook.
description: FURTHER underlining the deteriorating condition of the advertising economy, one of the world's largest agency companies is expected to warn investors today that profits will not meet expectations, while several analysts further reduced their estimates for ad spending this year and next.

title: Senator Strom Thurmond Collapses
description: WASHINGTON -- Sen. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the nation's longest-serving senator, collapsed Tuesday in the Senate after complaining of feeling weak. But a few minutes later the 98-year-old Republican was standing and talking.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Testimony On Farm Bill
description: A coalition of cities, mayors and municipal water agencies testified on the farm bill before the House, asking lawmakers to finance conservation measures that would require farmers to change some of their methods to reduce upstream water pollution. The House takes up the $171 billion bill on Wednesday and will consider an amendment by Democrats and moderate Republicans that would shift $19 billion of that money to conservation. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: When Afghanistan Collapsed
description: Picture this: A river in Afghanistan, late fall 1987. A group of young men are fishing. They prepare their bait -- something that looks like a marshmallow on a stick -- and toss it into the river. Boom! Fish float to the surface, some dead, some alive. The men laugh and splash around in the water harvesting their catch. The cameraman shouts at them not to get his camera wet.

title: Review/Fashion; Business as Usual, but Not Quite, on the Runway in Milan
description: In almost any circumstance, fashion has trouble dealing with reality. How often do you see clothes in a magazine that would look ridiculous in real life? How many times have you read that a $600 handbag is ''well priced''? Fashion editors have a genius for accommodating extremes, and most of the time the public is happy to play along in the deception.

title: A Soprano With Scissors, Cutting a Man Down to Size
description: Ariane Malia Reinhart performed four premieres by leading choreographers in a well-balanced solo program on Friday night at the Joyce SoHo. She was especially satisfying in two works that proved her to be a well-trained soprano as well as a skilled dancer.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Ex-Clinton Aide Might Run After All
description: Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff in the Clinton administration, is reconsidering a decision not to run next year for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Senator Jesse Helms, a leading Democratic official said. Scott R. Falmlen, the director of the state Democratic Party, said Mr. Bowles, an investment banker in Charlotte, had been making calls recently to consultants and elected officials. The two leading Democratic candidates are Secretary of State Elaine F. Marshall and State Representative Daniel T. Blue Jr., while Elizabeth Dole, the former presidential candidate, and former Mayor Richard Vinroot of Charlotte are pursuing the Republican nomination. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: ASSISTED LIVING CONCEPTS FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Assisted Living Concepts Inc., a leading chain of retirement homes, filed for bankruptcy protection after bondholders owning about 47 percent of the debt agreed to a reorganization plan. The company listed $331.4 million in assets and $252 million in debts in Chapter 11 papers filed yesterday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. Assisted Living, which is based in Portland, Ore., said creditors holding $75.8 million of the company's outstanding $161.2 million in convertible bonds had agreed to a bankruptcy recovery plan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Acquisition Dropped
description: Finland's largest insurer, Sampo Oyj, said it abandoned a $2.3 billion bid for Storebrand, a Norwegian rival, after a collapse in Storebrand's share price and opposition from government regulators. Storebrand's shares have lost 39 percent of their value since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. Insurance stocks have been among the hardest hit as investors worry about claims related to the collapse of the World Trade Center and damage to the Pentagon. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Revamped and Renewed, Nets Look for a Fresh Start
description: Only four players from the Nets' roster of last season returned to the team's practice facility this afternoon for media day, highlighting the swift changes sweeping the organization since the summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURACK, ZAHAVA
description: BURACK-Zahava. It is with deep sorrow that we record the death of Zahava Burack, a Vice President and past Guest of Honor. Zahava was a dedicated worker for education in the State of Israel. A deep void will be left in our ranks with her passing. To her son Jeff and her sisters, we offer our sincerest condolences. Elias Strum, President The American Friends of David Yellin College of Education

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARLING, ELIZABETH ANN
description: DARLING-Elizabeth Ann, 28. A native of Peekskill, N.Y. is missing in the September 11th World Trade Center tragedy. She was a financial analyst at Marsh & McLennan. She was the daughter of Earl and the late Margaret (nee Holloway) Darling, of Peekskill. She is survived by a son, Michael Praileau Jr., 2, and his father, Michael Praileau Sr.; a brother, Richard; her paternal and maternal grandmothers, many uncles, aunts and cousins. Memorial service at 11 A.M. Saturday, October 6th at Light of the World Christian Church, 2084 Crompond Road (Route 202), Yorktown Heights, N.Y. Memorial donations may be made to The Trust for Michael Praileau Jr., 637 Ashford Avenue, Ardsley, New York 10502.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERT, MAB
description: LAMBERT-Mab, 84. Died NYC Sept 29. Widow of Dr. Adrian Lambert. Survived by her children Robin Baskett (Mrs. Charles), Adrian Lambert, Cassie Nissen and granddaughter Alexandra von Raab. Private service. Contributions to Grosvenor Neighborhood House, 176 West 105 Street, NYC 10025, or Shipley School, 814 Yarrow Street, Bryn Mawr, PA. 19010.

title: Bush Says Reagan Airport Will Reopen on Thursday
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 - President Bush announced today that Reagan National Airport, a vital transportation link to the nation's capital and a symbol of its vitality, will reopen on Thursday.

title: Sister of Terrorist Victim Decides to Perform Tribute
description: The American figure-skating community had already planned to convene at Madison Square Garden on Friday, marking the 40th anniversary of a plane crash that killed the 1961 national team, its coaches and officials, and devastated a generation of American skating. It was not supposed to be a tearful night; the event would include Michelle Kwan, Scott Hamilton and Kristi Yamaguchi in a celebration of how far the sport has come in those 40 years.

title: U.S. Watchful As Iran Envoy Seeks Weapons From Russians
description: Iran's defense minister arrived in Moscow today to conclude long-delayed talks on a large purchase of Russian arms, an agenda now likely to be joined by discussions of Tehran's role in a global campaign against terror.

title: DYNEGY SAYS EARNINGS WILL MEET OR EXCEED ESTIMATES
description: Dynegy Inc., a power producer and energy trader, said earnings this year and next would meet or beat analysts' estimates. Profit will be at least $2.07 a share this year and $2.50 to $2.60 a share in 2002, a Dynegy spokesman, Steve Stengel, said. The average estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call are $2.06 a share for this year and $2.56 a share for next.

title: Smallpox Vaccine Production Accelerated
description: Responding to increasing concerns about bioterrorism, the company making a smallpox vaccine is sharply accelerating production and now plans to deliver 40 million doses to the federal government next year, a spokesman for the health and human services secretary, Tommy Thompson, said yesterday.

title: Finding the Right Spark for a Guy With a Problem
description: Lone Sherfig's warm and fuzzy romantic comedy ''Italian for Beginners'' is the first movie directed by a woman to follow the rigorous aesthetic principles of the Dogma 95 film makers who insist on natural lighting, hand-held cameras and other supposedly purifying cinematic techniques. It is also the first time that the style has been applied to a light romantic comedy, in this case the story of six lonely singles in their 30's who pair off and travel together to Venice. The result is a movie that looks like a John Cassavetes film but ends up emitting the benign feel-good vibrations of a movie like ''Enchanted April.''

title: National Briefing | West: California: Challenge To Redistricting
description: A group of Latino organizations filed a federal lawsuit seeking to overturn parts of California's Congressional redistricting plan, which was recently approved by the Legislature and the governor after months of negotiations. The groups, led by the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, contend that a number of districts in Southern California were recast in ways that split up concentrations of Latino voters, diluting their influence. In particular, they said, the percentage of Latino voters would be reduced sharply in the district held by Representative Howard L. Berman in the San Fernando Valley in Los Angeles. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Fewer Dot-Com Jobs Cut In September
description: Layoffs at dot-com companies continued to decrease in September, with just 2,986 jobs cut, compared with 4,899 eliminated in August, according to the outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., which tracks employment data. Although the September layoffs brought the total number of dot-com jobs cut in the last 15 months to more than 125,000, last month's layoffs were the industry's lowest since July 2000, when the sector began a long cycle of shedding jobs. In a statement announcing the new data, John A. Challenger, chief executive of the firm, said, ''The dot-com sector may be stabilizing, which would account for the decline in job-cut announcements.'' (Susan Stellin)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDRUCKI, JEAN
description: ANDRUCKI-Jean. Born in New York Hospital on October 1, 1957. She grew up and attended school in Smithtown, New York. She was in the first class to attend Smithtown High School West, where she played three sports. She was in the first graduating class and was awarded the scholar athlete award and most valuable female athlete. While a student at Smithtown High School she and her dear friend, Kathy Hanlon, chaperoned dances for the Junior League for developmentally disabled citizens for three years. She also volunteered as a camp counselor at Camp Wilton in New York State. As a young woman, Jean led a group of adults and children who, for several years, sang in the local nursing home during the holidays. She also brought out children from the city to spend ''weekends in the country'' at Smithtown. Jean travelled extensively visiting Africa twice to view the natural beauty and the wildlife. She was greatly concerned about the environment and found her joy in the outdoors camping, kayaking, and bicycling. As an adult, Jean completed four triathalons and although girls could not play soccer when she attended high school, she did manage, as a woman, to join the Bergen Kickers and later to play with Leitrim's team in the upper Bronx. Jean attended Stony Brook University graduating in 1980 from an accelerated program and earning a B.A. in political science and an M.S. in Urban Policy Sciences. In 1981 she completed an M.S. in Mechanical Engineering. Jean was initiated into Pi Sigma Alpha, the national Political Science honor society. Jean joined the Port Authority in April 1982. In December '83 she was assigned to the Fire Safety Section. In '85 she was elected into the Society of Fire Protection Engineers. She advanced through the P.A. and was presently the Operations Manager for Risk Management in the Treasury Dept. Jean was the kind of aunt every kid wished for. She loved her nephews dearly and certainly did dote on them. They are George and Michael Andrucki and Michael Devlin Izzo. We truly looked forward to her weekends at home in her beloved Smithtown; she never really became a full fledged ''city girl.'' We, her family, will grieve endlessly for her. Our lives and the lives of all her many friends will never be the same with the loss of her beautiful spirit and her compassionate, loving heart. The world will be a poorer place having lost this gentle and kind woman. Services for Jean will be held in Hoboken at Frank Sinatra park on Friday, October 5 at 6 P.M. and in Smithtown, St. Patricks Church, Main Street, 10:30 mass on October 11. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to The Nature Conservancy, 4245 North Fairfax Drive, Arlington, VA. 22203-1606.

The slump in semiconductor prices accounted for most of the decline, with exports totaling $970 million, down 63 percent from a year ago. Joe Begley graduated from Cathedral Grade School, St. Agnes HS, Fordham College Class of '36, and Columbia University Class of '38. Married in 1948 to the former Patricia Charles in St. Patrick's Cathedral, a church with which he maintained a lifelong relationship. He served in The Army Air Force from 1943 to 1946. Subsequently Joe Begley pursued a career in human engineering and worked with The Air Force, Raytheon, Avco, and GTE. Joe is survived by the people he loved, all of whom will miss his Irish smile and blue eyes, his wife of 53 years, Pat, his children, and 12 grandchildren. His children living in NYC are, Patricia Begley Beane, Joseph T. Begley Jr., Mary Mayland, and Rita Finkel. Only one son, Christopher Begley remains in the Lowell area. His sons and daughter-in-law are George H. Beane, Robin Berko Beane, Ed Mayland, Glen Finkel, and Bruce Fidorek. Interment was at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. He will rest in peace in the same cemetery as ''The Babe.'' Gifts in his memory may be made to Fordham University, Office of Development, 113 West 60th Street, Room 315, New York, NY 10133-0003 (Attn: Joseph T. Begley Scholarship, FCO 36). He was a true Catholic gentleman and there is no better way to remember his life of generosity and kindness to everyone he met.

title: ANC RENTAL AND LENDERS AGREE TO DELAY LOAN REPAYMENT
description: The ANC Rental Corporation, parent of the Alamo and National car rental services, agreed with lenders to delay a $70 million payment and hired a turnaround leader as demand slowed after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The principal payment, which was due yesterday, was deferred until Nov. 30, the company said. ANC Rental also said some financial terms on its loans will be suspended until Nov. 15, without providing details. ANC Rental named William N. Plamondon III, former chairman of its board's audit committee and the former president of the Budget Rent a Car Corporation, as chief restructuring officer. ANC is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: National Briefing
description: WESTCALIFORNIA: CHALLENGE TO REDISTRICTING A group of Latino organizations filed a federal lawsuit seeking to overturn parts of California's Congressional redistricting plan, which was recently approved by the Legislature and the governor after months of negotiations. The groups, led by the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, contend that a number of districts in Southern California were recast in ways that split up concentrations of Latino voters, diluting their influence. In particular, they said, the percentage of Latino voters would be reduced sharply in the district held by Representative Howard L. Berman in the San Fernando Valley in Los Angeles.    James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEMIROFF, LEO, (NORTHRUP, ERIC)
description: NEMIROFF-Leo, (Northrup, Eric), 87. Of Croton-on-Hudson, New York, died Friday, September 28, 2001. Retired science and medical writer/editor, he leaves Mili, his wife of 67 years; his children, Sandra, David, Judith and Margaret; seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Deeply committed to peace and social justice, Leo's generosity, compassion, lively intelligence, humor, and imagination touched all who knew him. Leo's passing leaves a great void in our hearts, but the memory of his remarkable presence will remain with us always.

title: The Deadly Whisper of Ovarian Cancer
description: In 1958, as I was turning 17 and my brother 13, our mother died of ovarian cancer. She was only 49 and, until the miserable year that followed the diagnosis, she had never had anything more serious than a cold. She missed many good years as a wife, mother, friend and beloved elementary schoolteacher.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Loudonville: A Drop In Consumer Confidence
description: New Yorkers' confidence in their economic well-being, and thus their willingness to spend money in stores, plunged after the World Trade Center attack, according to the latest survey by the Siena College Research Institute. Confidence, as measured by a running index of attitudes, fell to 72.0 in late September from 80.7 in late August. The decline for metropolitan New York City was larger than in upstate New York, where the index fell from 82.2 to 77.6. Nationally, the index fell from 91.5 to 81.8 in the same period. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

The museum said last week that a 500-year-old painting in its collection was stolen during World War II from Poland's National Museum in Warsaw. The artwork, ''The Holy Trinity, Seat of Mercy,'' is a small oil on wood painting by the Nuremberg-born Georg Pencz.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Acquisition Expected
description: The German pharmaceuticals and chemicals conglomerate, Bayer, is expected to announce today that it has reached an agreement to acquire the farm chemicals business of Aventis for 7.25 billion euros, or $6.6 billion, people close to the discussions said. The company is expected to provide details of the deal, which would still require regulatory approval as well as the blessing of labor unions, during a news conference this morning at its headquarters in Leverkusen. For Bayer, which has struggled after the withdrawal of its cholesterol-lowering drug known as Lipobay or Baycol, the purchase of CropScience, the Aventis unit, would be a big step forward in expanding its agrochemicals operations. In swallowing CropScience, the third-largest player in the $33 billion agrochemicals industry, Bayer would jump from sixth to second, behind the industry leader Syngenta, analysts said. Aventis, the French-German conglomerate, has been eager to sell CropScience, which is 24 percent owned by Schering, a German rival, to concentrate on its pharmaceuticals business. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

description: SILVER-Ida Ostreich, 90. Of New York City and Kingston, RI, died September 29. Loving wife of the late Bernard Silver. Devoted mother of Stephen Silver & Naomi Neft. Caring mother-in-law of Margot Silver and David Neft. Cherished grandmother of Amy and Kate Silver and Michael and Debbie Neft. She is also survived by her loving siblings Leonard Ostreich and Beatrice Kunin, and will be affectionately remembered by numerous cousins, nieces, nephews, and countless friends and neighbors. Ida had a distinguished 40-year career with the NYC Board of Education as a teacher, guidance counselor, program coordinator and administrator. After retirement, she continued her service as a volunteer with SKOLE, Foster Grandparents (RI), and The Door (NYC). An inspiration to all, she lived each day to the fullest with boundless energy. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHALEN, JAMES J.
description: WHALEN-James J. A memorial service will be held Friday, October 12, for James J. Whalen, president emeritus of Ithaca College. Whalen, who led the College during a period of unprecedented growth, passed away Thursday, September 6, in Boston after a brief illness. The memorial mass will be held at 3:00 P.M. at Immaculate Conception Catholic Church in Ithaca, with Father John DeSocio officiating. A campus reception will follow at the James J. Whalen Center for Music. He is survived by his wife, Gillian Hamer Whalen; brothers Robert, Frank, & Jerome; sister Mary Noel; & their families. During Whalen's presidency, from 1975 to 1997, the College experienced increases in academic and cocurricular programs, in the size and caliber of the faculty, in the number and quality of the students, and in physical and fiscal resources. Upon his retirement he was named president emeritus & was awarded the honorary degree of doctor of humane letters. Born March 6, 1927, in Pottsville, Pennsylvania, he was a graduate of Franklin and Marshall College. He held Master's and Doctoral degrees in clinical psychology from Pennsylvania State University and was a licensed clinical psychologist. Before coming to Ithaca College, he served as president of Newton College of the Sacred Heart and held a variety of administrative positions at Ohio University and the University of Maryland. In a 1986 Exxon Foundation study, he was named one of the nation's top 100 higher education chief executive officers. In 1997 the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities (NAICU) gave him the Henry Paley Memorial Award for outstanding service. He was also awarded honorary doctor of law degrees from both Newton College and Ohio University. In 1999 the Ithaca College Alumni Association named in his honor the James J. Whalen Meritorious Service Award, which recognizes distinguished achievements and contributions to the College by nongraduates. The new home of the College's founding school, the School of Music, was dedicated as the James J. Whalen Center for Music in October 1999. He had served as chairman of the boards of directors of the American Council on Education (ACE), the NAICU, and New York's Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities. A champion of integrity in intercollegiate athletics, he was a charter member of the Presidents Commission of the NCAA and chair of its Division III subcommittee, co-chair of the NCAA Task Force on Gender Equity, and a member of the Knight Foundation Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics. For his contributions to higher education in the military, he received the Exceptional Service Award, the highest civilian honor given by the U.S. Air Force, and was named an honorary member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He had served as chairman of the boards of visitors of both Air University and the Army War College, and he was a member of the board of visitors of the Marine Corps University. He was technical adviser to the Process for Accreditation of Joint Education of the Joint Chiefs of Staff as well as educational consultant for the chairman of that endeavor. He had most recently served on the board of advisers for the National Student Records Clearinghouse and as a mentor for the ACE fellows program. Contributions in his name can be made to support the Turtle Bridge Scholarship, which was established by James and Gillian Whalen to honor academically outstanding seniors who are actively involved in the campus and/or local communities. Donations should be sent C/O Shelley Semmler, vice president for institutional advancement, Ithaca College, 237 Alumni Hall, Ithaca, New York 14850.
