Linda Ellerbee was host for the program, ''Kids, Terrorism and the American Spirit,'' which featured a round table of 12 youngsters who expressed their fears and hopes for the future.

title: Marketing Campaign for Gold Miners
description: AngloGold, Barrick Gold and other mining companies have proposed spending as much as $200 million a year on the industry's biggest marketing campaign ever, aimed at increasing bullion prices and demand for gold jewelry.

title: Cakes That Started in Tokyo Arrive on New York's Doorsteps
description: Looking for something to do while her husband was at work, Kazuko Emy Wada of Tokyo started baking the fancy cakes she had learned to make as a child. Caterers and restaurants bought them and she opened a cafe there. That was 15 years ago. Now, her Lady M (for Emy) cakes are being baked in New York and can be ordered for delivery in Manhattan. By early next year, Mrs. Wada, above left, with Sasaki Seiichi, her executive pastry chef, plans to open a bakery and cafe on the Upper East Side.

title: The Next Moves in a Shadow War
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Giant To Introduce Discount Plan For the Elderly
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the second-largest drug maker, plans to announce today that it is creating a national discount program for low-income elderly people who lack prescription drug coverage, reducing the price of its drugs by 25 percent or more.

title: Fed Cuts Its Benchmark Rate To 2.5%, Hitting 39-Year Low
description: The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point today to the lowest level in 39 years, continuing its effort to pump some vigor back into an economy that shows all the signs of having lapsed into recession.

title: Pentagon Tries To Avoid Using Pakistan Bases
description: The Pentagon is shaping its war plan to minimize the use of Pakistani bases in a military strike against the Taliban, fearing that an extensive deployment there could destabilize a critical but volatile ally that has tested nuclear weapons, senior Bush administration officials said today.

title: Recipe: Slow-Cooked Leg of Lamb With Fresh Mint Sauce
description: Time: about 6 hours 4 large garlic cloves, peeled

title: Clemmensen Makes Devils' Roster
description: The rookie goaltender Scott Clemmensen, who led Boston College to the N.C.A.A. Division I hockey title last spring, will be the backup goaltender Saturday night when the Devils open the regular season in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNFIELD, ALAN
description: CORNFIELD-Alan. Of Dix Hills. Loving husband of Donna. Devoted father of Danny and Paige. Devoted son of Jules and Meme. Loving brother of Cara and Ann. Adored son-in-law of Harold and Marci Klein. Loving brother-in-law and friend of Robert Goldstein and Stephanie Klein, Cheryl Klein and David Norman, Perry Silver and Paul Golden. Adored uncle of Justin, Molly, Jacob, Emma, Elan, Dina and Lindsay. Visitation Wednesday 7-9 PM. Fire Department services 8 PM. Funeral Thursday 1PM at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc., New York.

title: Bush Calls for Billions More to Give the Economy a Boost
description: In his second visit to Manhattan since the terrorist attacks, President Bush said today that his administration would ask Congress to authorize $60 billion to $75 billion more to encourage consumer confidence and bolster business investment.

title: Lacking Cash, Swissair Grounds All Its Flights
description: Swissair abruptly stopped flying today because it lacked cash to pay for jet fuel and landing fees and feared that its planes would be seized by creditors at foreign airports. At least two planes were seized, at Heathrow Airport near London, though one was later released.

title: Frank Gasparro, 92, of Mint; Art Is on 100 Billion Pennies
description: Frank Gasparro, who as an engraver at the United States Mint designed the tails side of the current Lincoln penny, showing the Lincoln Memorial, died on Saturday in Havertown, Pa. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, IDA OSTREICH
description: SILVER-Ida Ostreich, 90. Of New York City and Kingston, RI, died September 29. Loving wife of the late Bernard Silver. Devoted mother of Stephen Silver & Naomi Neft. Caring mother-in-law of Margot Silver and David Neft. Cherished grandmother of Amy and Kate Silver and Michael and Debbie Neft. She is also survived by her loving siblings Leonard Ostreich and Beatrice Kunin, and will be affectionately remembered by numerous cousins, nieces, nephews, and countless friends and neighbors. Ida had a distinguished 40-year career with the NYC Board of Education as a teacher, guidance counselor, program coordinator and administrator. After retirement, she continued her service as a volunteer with SKOLE, Foster Grandparents (RI), and The Door (NYC). An inspiration to all, she lived each day to the fullest with boundless energy. Services Thursday, Plaza Funeral Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Ave., 12:30 PM. Donations may be sent to The Caring Community Senior Center, 20 Washington Square North, New York, New York 10011.

title: Decrees on Fixing Schools May Fail the Reality Test
description: WHEN airliners crashed into the twin towers, President Bush was giving a speech in Florida urging Congress to hurry and get an education bill to his desk. Versions passed by the House and Senate have been stalled in a conference committee since June -- for good reason. They try to enact changes that are more slogans than practical solutions.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Death Is Called Hate Crime
description: The killing of an Arab-American shopkeeper in a tiny convenience store in East Reedley is being investigated as a hate crime related to the Sept. 11 attacks. The victim, Abdo Ali Ahmed, an American citizen born in Yemen, had received a death threat before he was killed on Saturday in his store by a gunshot blast to his abdomen. Witnesses told investigators that a car full of teenagers sped away at the time of the shooting, which took place just yards from where the victim lived with his wife and six children. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: City's Budget Is Battered In the Aftermath of Attack
description: The attack on the World Trade Center has doubled the city's projected budget gap to roughly $4 billion, forcing the Giuliani administration to order all agencies to curtail spending.

title: Dayne Is Boring, but Beautiful
description: It was a thrilling end to the Giants' victory over the Saints Sunday, with a stirring goal-line stand that revitalized and nourished the defense's veterans as it seasoned the unit's promising rookies.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Running Against The Boss
description: Lt. Gov. Steve Windom, a Republican, says he will run for governor in 2002. Mr. Windom's campaign mailed postcards to supporters on Saturday saying he planned to run but would postpone an official kickoff tour because of the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. Windom is the fifth Republican to announce his candidacy. Gov. Donald Siegelman, a Democrat, plans to seek re-election. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Bottomless Cups Of Redemption, Sunnyside Up
description: Musicals don't come any more clean-cut than ''The Spitfire Grill,'' a story of small-town America that makes ''The Music Man'' look dark and twisted. Sure, there's the occasional mild obscenity, spoken or sung, and there are plot references to rape, incest and manslaughter.

title: The Next Moves in a Shadow War
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, MICHAEL J.
description: ARMSTRONG-Michael J.; McCABE, Michael J.; TUCKER, Michael. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the tragic deaths of its members, Michael J. Armstrong, Michael J. McCabe, and Michael Tucker, in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, and extends sincere sympathy to their families. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Jordan Is Still Lacing Them Up One Shoe at a Time
description: He found his teammates through narrow crevices, playmaking out of the post. He got back on defense, even when it was three-on-one. He may have acted like Kwame Brown's stern older brother, but even Brown, the No. 1 draft pick, understood the method to Michael Jordan's madness.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about delays for commuters into Manhattan on Monday morning misidentified the employer of John Egger, a police officer at the train terminal in Hoboken, N.J. It is New Jersey Transit, not the Port Authority.

title: The Investigation So Far
description: NATO said the Bush administration had provided "clear and compelling proof" that Osama bin Laden was behind the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. In Paris, the authorities said they had uncovered a bin Laden plot to bomb the American Embassy.

title: Bad Guys for Bad Times; Hollywood Struggles to Create Villains for a New Climate
description: After more than a decade of fumbling about in search of a workable bad guy upon which to hang its crowd-pleasing action blockbusters, Hollywood has been handed the gift of actual national villains in the form of Islamic terrorists. But unlike the months after Pearl Harbor, when moviemakers enthusiastically embraced stereotypes of Japanese evil, this time the entertainment industry has opted for restraint to avoid accusations of bias and the danger of offending audience sensibilities in an increasingly multiracial America.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPINA, MARY A.
description: SPINA-Mary A. October 3, 1991. Remembering a special mother for years of love. J.S.S

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Business Travel; As travel begins to pick up again, the airlines are using new strategies, and prices, to sell tickets.
description: AS air travel slowly picks up again, the major airlines are busy promoting lower business-travel fares, tweaking advance-purchase and minimum-stay restrictions, and devising new ways to sell tickets on the Internet and through targeted e-mail promotions to regular customers.

title: From Taiwan, a Fear of China Technology
description: HSINCHU, Taiwan  Morris Chang was born in China, but unlike some Chinese emigres, he feels little desire to return.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHATARY, MAGDA (NEE SZENTGYORGYI, HORVATH)
description: CHATARY-Magda (nee Szentgyorgyi-Horvath), born in Budapest, Hungary. Artist, principal engineer, and devoted mother. Passed on September 27th, 2001, age 74. Survived by her loving daughter Christina, dear brother George, and many caring family members and true friends, as well as her beloved little Milou. We will forever miss her noble soul, angelic spirit, wit, and essential love of life. Funeral to be held in Budapest. New York City memorial services to be announced. ''...murmur, a little sadly, how love fled and passed upon the mountains overhead, and hid her face amid a crown of stars.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: No Death Penalty In Killing
description: Nassau County prosecutors will seek life imprisonment without the possibility of parole, and not the death penalty, for Shaun T. Alexander, left, the Hofstra University student charged with killing a classmate on April 25, District Attorney Denis E. Dillon said yesterday. Mr. Dillon has never sought the death penalty but said he would, if there were no other way to protect the public. Mr. Alexander, 23, is charged with first-degree murder in the mutilation death of Max B. Kolb, 20. Mr. Alexander's lawyer said his client was likely to plead not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Arabs and Israelis: A Renewed Focus
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHAN, MICHAEL
description: KAHAN-Michael. Died on Sunday, September 29, 2001. Our wonderful wise brave husband, brother, friend, teacher, adviser, storyteller. With our love. Emily. Sophie. Floria. Dara. Michael. Asher. Davi. Roz. Richard. Lionel. Samantha. Marc. Theresa. Services will be at the Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, Thursday, October 4th at 11:45 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The Michael Kahan Scholarship, care of Executive Vice Chancellor Louise Mirrer, City University of New York, 535 East 80th Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: Recalling Laughter, Pets, Sacrifice, Friendship, Good Cheer, a Dream
description: CHARLES HENRY KARCZEWSKI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDGRABEN, HAROLD
description: GOLDGRABEN-Harold. On September 30, 2001. Loving brother of Norman and the late Seymour and the late Jerome. Dear uncle and great uncle. He will be missed.

title: Bonds's Record Chase Becomes a Slow Walk
description: Barry Bonds has never dreamed about hitting 71 home runs. He said today that he has kept his dreams more realistic.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: One Angry Governor

title: Arabs and Israelis: A Renewed Focus
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Britain: Ruling In Teacher Case
description: A judge has ruled that a middle-aged black schoolteacher is entitled to back pay and other compensation because he was denied a promotion based on race and age, court documents show. On Friday, a judge dismissed an appeal filed by the Norwalk Board of Education seeking to have an earlier state decision overturned. The decision found that the teacher, John J. Sanders, who was 49 in 1997 when he applied for a job as assistant principal of Nathan Hale Middle School, was unfairly passed over for the promotion. A white teacher, Michael McGrath, then 28, got the job and is now principal of the school, where Mr. Sanders still teaches.

title: Despite Afghan Refugee Crisis, U.S. Bureau Still Has No Chief
description: At a moment when the State Department is urging the administration to make taking care of Afghan refugees a top priority, its refugee bureau -- which handles a nearly $1 billion budget -- is without a permanent leader.

title: Muslim Leader Presses Agenda of Understanding
description: No fewer than five F.B.I. agents gathered around Agha Saeed after he drove from Washington and checked in for one of the first flights allowed to leave Baltimore following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Can New York Recover Without Giuliani?
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Good for Black-and-White TV
description: Laptop dinners that bear almost no resemblance to the TV dinners of yore -- with enticing selections like chicken fricassee with shiitake mushrooms (left), or luscious pot roast with gravy, mashed potatoes and creamed spinach -- are sold to go at R.S.V.P., a prepared-food shop at 1012 Lexington Avenue (73rd Street). The dinners, a different one each day, are $22 to $25 and come in oven- and microwave-safe trays. Salad and dessert are included.

title: Lawyers on Each Side Debate Intent in Wedding-Day Killing
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers agreed today that a prominent businessman fired the shots that killed his former girlfriend two years ago on the day she was to marry another man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, ROBERT
description: MANDEL-Robert. Our deepest sympathy to the Mandel family. He was the best. Millie Monti and Rose Zappulla

title: Adventures On the Way Back Home From Troy
description: Has Plcido Domingo made some Faustian pact to keep himself vocally fresh at 60? It's beginning to seem like the only explanation.

title: Claim of Plot Against Embassy in Paris
description: A Frenchman of Algerian background has told French investigators that he was part of a plot by Osama bin Laden to blow up the American Embassy in Paris, according to a French official familiar with the testimony.

title: F.A.A. to Let Stranded Aircraft Take to Air
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced plans yesterday to let general aviation aircraft, like business jets and helicopters, escape from 204 airports, heliports and other sites near New York and Washington where they have largely been grounded since Sept. 11.

title: Results at News Corporation To Miss Its Financial Goals
description: Joining the parade of financial woes stemming from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the News Corporation of Australia said yesterday that it would badly miss its main financial goals for its fiscal year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REALE, VIRGINIA (FIOCCO)
description: REALE-Virginia (Fiocco), November 18, 1897-September 29, 2001. Daughter of the late Rose (Collica) and Enrico Fiocco, stepmother Eugenia, stepmother Antoinette. Beloved wife of the late Salvatore Reale, loving mother of daughter Eleanor & son-in-law John Lavarello, son S. Robert & daughter-in-law Mary Reale. Daughter Vera (Elvira) Reale, grandmother of Elaine (Lavarello) & Vincent Cipriani, Virginia (Reale) and Anthony Russo, Robert Reale. Great-grandmother of Christine Cipriani and Robert Anthony Russo. Loving sister of Medora Bandonee, Edith Keefe, Viola Gulinello, Gloria Morris, Veronica Gambino, Enrico, John & Cosmo Fiocco and the late Antoinette Fiocco, Nancy Giardina, Irene Stella, Louise Pine. A great loss to all, including many cousins, nieces & nephews. Her love and compassion lives on in all of us. A shining star who will be in our hearts forever. Reposing on Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-10 at Cusimano & Russo, Inc., 2005 West 6th Street, Brooklyn, New York. Funeral mass Friday 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompeii Church, New York City. Interment St. Raymond Cemetery.

title: Taliban Say They Want to Negotiate With the U.S. Over bin Laden
description: QUETTA, Pakistan, Oct. 2  Afghanistan's ruling Taliban said tonight that they were ready to negotiate with Washington about turning over Osama bin Laden to a third country, apparently in an effort to avert a military attack by the United States and its allies.

title: Uncertainty About Fate Of Leases
description: Can they break their leases? That is the urgent question for many tenants of apartments near the World Trade Center site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURRER, GUSTAV T.
description: DURRER-Gustav T. Retired dentist of Manhattan, at the age of 90. Beloved husband of Margot Ammann Durrer. He died peacefully at home after a short illness. He practiced prosthodontic dentistry in Rockefeller Plaza from 1946 to 1995 and served on the teaching staff of New York University College of Dentistry, Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery and Stonybrook University College of Dentistry. He lectured in USA and abroad. Born and educated in Switzerland, he immigrated to America in 1939, serving in the Medical Corp. of the US Army from 1942-1946. He shall be sorely missed by his wife, his sister and brother-in-law and nieces and nephews in Switzerland as well as friends and colleagues here and abroad. He will be remembered for his honesty, compassion, dry sense of humor and gentle, courtly manner. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday, October 4th, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Funeral mass will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th, Friday, October 5th, 10:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Rogosin Institute at 505 East 70th Street, NYC 10021.

title: The Next Moves in a Shadow War
description: To the Editor:

title: Official Removed After New Security Lapses at Boston Airport
description: Exasperated by a series of security lapses at Logan International Airport since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift today stripped responsibilities there from the director of public safety for Massport, the agency that runs the airport.

title: Driving Curbs Bring Big Drop In Traffic Crossing East River
description: Traffic on all East River bridges has begun to show a slight increase but significant decreases continue overall since car-pooling rules were introduced, Deputy Mayor Joseph L. Lhota said today.

title: Companies Responding to Potential Threat
description: Chemical, fuel and manufacturing industries, power and water suppliers, and agencies dealing with transportation and the environment are scrambling to safeguard a vast array of dangerous materials, to keep them out of the wrong hands.

title: U.S. Citizens In Italy Urged To Use Caution
description: The State Department said today that it had received information about possible attacks on ''symbols of American capitalism'' in Italy in the next month, and that Americans in that country should be cautious.

title: Florida's Secretary of State Seeks House Seat
description: Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state who became a national figure during the presidential election last November, said today that she would run for Congress next year and that her role in the presidential contest would not be a major factor in her own race.

title: From Taiwan, a Fear of China Technology
description: Morris Chang was born in China, but unlike some Chinese migrs, he feels little desire to return.

title: Merrill Said to Be Set to Replace Heads of 2 Units
description: Amid the turmoil caused by the attack on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, Merrill Lynch & Company may be losing more senior executives.

title: The New York Times College Program
description: Educators face a growing challenge to connect classroom text to current experience. The New York Times College Program can ignite student interest by linking learning to living - to deepen student interest and stimulate discussion.

title: Can New York Recover Without Giuliani?
description: To the Editor:

title: Powell Says U.S. Had Signs, But Not Clear Ones, of a Plot
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the Bush administration had received a ''lot of signs'' that terrorists were planning attacks against the United States but extensive efforts by intelligence agencies failed to pick up enough information to stop the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington.

title: How Attitude Reached America With Columbus, No Less
description: Christopher Columbus may have been out to explore the New World, but his crew members had their own agendas. In Dario Fo's mind, one of them, Johan Padan, was simply trying to get as far away from the Inquisition as possible. (''Just the idea of being tied to the wheel with all those spikes,'' he says. ''It's very uncomfortable.'') The only reason the inquisitors are interested in him is that he has been seeing a young woman now suspected of being a witch. (One night, while they're making love outdoors, she teaches him how to predict a hurricane by looking at the moon and the clouds, and this trick comes in very handy later on.) So even though Johan is terrified of water, he volunteers his services as a caulker, who patches sails, and signs on with Columbus to cross the Atlantic.

title: Now They'll Even Cook It for You
description: THE brick town house that sits on the corner of 49th Street and Avenue of the Americas is an anomaly. Back when Rockefeller Center was being developed, the owners refused to sell, and in the decades since, as corporate towers lined up along the avenue like a row of glassy dominoes, the building clung to its corner like the last stubborn tenant in a rent-controlled apartment.

title: MY JOB; I'm on the Hunt for Lost Data
description: Years ago, when I worked in data recovery for a large television network, an electrician dropped a screwdriver down an electrical panel. A bolt of electricity blew him off the ladder and started a fire in seven of the panels. He brought down the company's computer system. We worked all weekend to restore the data.

title: Giuliani Won't Run for Third Term
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said this afternoon that he will not seek a third term in office by running on the Conservative Party ticket in the November election. However, his offer to extend his term by three months to help with the transitition remains open, he said.

title: Hopkins Sees Bar by Garden; Senior Official There Denies It
description: Bernard Hopkins ended the dispute over the middleweight championship Saturday, but he has a continuing dispute with Madison Square Garden.

title: Another Thomson Record
description: Fifty years ago, Ronny Buchman was a messenger for a company that, among other things, made recordings for Voice of America. His friend Allen Schwartz was in his freshman year at City College. They were Giants fans living a block apart deep in Dodgers territory, in Bensonhurst.

title: Market Place; Cheap Credit, Except for Those Who Need It Most
description: The Federal Reserve made it cheaper yesterday for some people and companies to borrow. But its efforts to stimulate the economy are being hampered by a plunge in consumer confidence and by financial markets that are hesitant to provide money to the companies that need it the most.

title: Britain Seeking to Increase Number of Foreign Workers
description: LONDON, Oct. 3  Saying he wanted to tackle the dual problems of illegal immigration and a clandestine economy that exploits unskilled workers, the British Home Secretary said today that he would introduce legislation expanding the country's limited work-permit program to allow greater numbers of foreigners to seek jobs in Britain.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rival Sues Tivo Over Patent
description: Pause Technology said it had filed a patent infringement lawsuit against Tivo, the market leader in sales of personal video recorders to consumers. The patent at issue, issued in 1995 and reaffirmed in 2000, covers technology that enables viewers to pause live TV, fast forward programs and replay parts of programs while they are being recorded. So far, only Motorola has announced it will license the Pause patent for its future line of personal video recorders. ''We are surprised and disappointed,'' said Rebecca Baer, a spokeswoman for Tivo, which also holds patents on personal video recording technology. ''We stand by our prior claim to this company that we don't infringe.'' Tivo's shares slid 34 cents, or 10.2 percent, to $3.01. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: The Next Moves in a Shadow War
description: To the Editor:

title: In an uneasy climate, the group approach is so popular, even rivals unite in campaigns.
description: ''UNITED we stand'' can now be considered more than a patriotic exhortation. Increasingly, it is serving as a strategy for advertisers to attract the attention of consumers in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Repairing The Damage
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi met with diplomats from Egypt, Morocco, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia and other Arab nations in an effort to calm the fury opened by his derogatory remarks about Islamic culture on Sept. 26 when he spoke of ''the superiority of our civilization.'' He gave his visitors his full text, saying his words had been taken out of context. His office said later that Mr. Berlusconi had voiced ''deep respect for Islam, a great religion.'' Marina Harss (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: A Vote On Tougher Abortion Laws
description: The Irish government announced plans to hold a national referendum before next spring on measures that will make it more difficult for women to have abortions. According to the outcome of a 1992 Supreme Court case, abortion is illegal in Ireland unless carrying the pregnancy to term threatens the mother's life, or if she threatens to commit suicide. The new proposal will create legislation to uphold that ban and will remove the suicide provision. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: An Accord On Charities
description: Taking steps to avert a political turf war, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the New York State attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, pledged yesterday to work together in coordinating the charitable response to the World Trade Center attack, their aides said.

title: Sharing the Evidence on Terror
description: It is important to demonstrate to the world that America stands for justice in its response to the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. By sharing some of its evidence linking Osama bin Laden and his terrorist network Al Qaeda to those attacks with foreign leaders this week, the Bush administration has honored fundamental American values. A portion of this material should be made public as well. Secretary of State Colin Powell was right to promise such a presentation of evidence last month. It would help build stronger international support for the campaign against terrorism.

title: Russia and Iran Sign Arms Deal; Nuclear Reactors on the Way
description: Six years after it stopped major arms sales to Iran under pressure from the United States, Russia signed a new military accord with Iran today that the Kremlin said could lead to $300 million in annual sales of jets, missiles and other weapons.

title: THE BOSS; How I Came to Love Stocks
description: When I was a junior in high school, I worked as an assistant to a broker's assistant at a Merrill Lynch retail branch in Princeton, N.J., getting coffee and answering phones. From the moment I started that job, I fell in love with the stock market. I also bought my first stock -- 10 shares of Johnson & Johnson.

title: Morality of Sex Selection
description: To the Editor:

title: Philippines Offers U.S. Its Troops And Bases
description: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo said today that as the leader of a country that has fought back against Islamic militants, she is prepared to ''go every step of the way'' with the United States.

title: Nortel Will Cut Work Force by 20,000
description: Nortel Networks of Canada said yesterday that it was cutting 10,000 jobs and reducing its work force by an additional 10,000 jobs through the sale of businesses, leaving the company with fewer than half the employees it had at the beginning of the year.

title: One Philosopher's Alchemy: Teaching as Romance
description: Maxine Greene's idea of professional development for teachers is to have math instructors watch a dance performance of a poem set to music. She laments that many schools have been turned into what she terms boot camps run by drill sergeants. Her grading policy is so liberal that she has failed few students in more than 30 years of teaching.

title: Defining Terms
description: The terrorist attacks have put the news media in an odd position. Showing skepticism of government -- part of their job description -- or straying from national sentiment can lead to fierce accusations of treason.

title: Welch, of G.E., Signs On at Clayton, Dubilier
description: John F. Welch Jr., the former chairman of General Electric, decided on at least one second career path yesterday, joining the leveraged buyout firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice as a special partner.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a theater review yesterday about a revival of ''Some Voices,'' a 1994 play written in response to Britain's release of many institutionalized mentally ill people, misstated the show's closing day at the Greenwich Street Theater. It runs through Sunday, not Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, CYNTHIA LOIS
description: RUBIN-Cynthia Lois. Beloved wife, mother, sister, grandma, mother-in-law of Stanley, Marty, Lisa, Alan, Gail, Danny, Abby, Debra and Michael. In our hearts forever. Service on Thursday 11:30AM ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd and 66 Ave, Forest Hills.

title: Kidd Is Named Captain Before Nets Open Camp
description: Jason Kidd said goodbye to his 5-day-old twin daughters, Miah and Jazelle, in Phoenix on Monday morning, and as he checked into his Rutherford hotel room that evening, the phone rang. So much for the shower.

title: Homeland Security In a Pentagon Post
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld named Army Secretary Thomas E. White today to be the Pentagon's first homeland security coordinator.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: The Next Moves in a Shadow War
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Rejects Electricity Plan Favored by California Leader
description: The California Public Utilities Commission rejected a proposed rate increase for electricity consumers today , throwing into turmoil the state's plan for covering the billions of dollars it has been forced to spend to buy power in the energy crisis.

title: Sallie Mae Offers Aid to Terror Victims
description: Sallie Mae, the largest private provider of education loans in the United States, has announced that it will forgive the federal and private Sallie Mae student loans of the spouses of those who died or who have been permanently disabled in the attacks on the World Trade Center. With a $1.5 million endowment, a new fund is providing this assistance and will also give scholarships for post-secondary education of up to $25,000 a year to the children of those who died or were permanently disabled, including the children of police, fire and medical personnel. Applications for loan relief and scholarships will be accepted beginning Oct. 18. More information is available at www.salliemae.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, MARY FERGUSON
description: RUSSELL-Mary Ferguson. Died peacefully in Essex, CT, on September 29, 2001. Beloved wife of Tuck for 55 years. Mother of Tom, Jennifer and Sarah. Born in Schenectady in 1914, was brought up in Hartford and graduated from Miss Porter's School in Farmington. She worked for the Office of War Information in the Middle East during WWII and later for the United Nations Association. Then she became a partner in Frederics Helton Travel. She lived in New York City for many years and served on the Board of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center and the Isaacs Center. She was also a resident of Fishers Island where she was an active participant in the creation of the H.L. Ferguson Museum. Funeral service was held on Fishers Island, October 1. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to the H.L. Ferguson Museum, Fishers Island, NY 06390.

title: Yanks Will Not Raise Ticket Prices
description: The Yankees announced yesterday that they would not raise ticket prices for the 2002 season, the first time since 1990 that ticket prices will go unchanged.

title: City Will Give Urns To Victims' Families
description: The family of each victim in the World Trade Center attack will be given wooden urns containing soil from the site, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Night Flight Rules
description: Shares in BAA, Britain's biggest airport operator, fell more than 3 percent after a European court ruled that night flights at Heathrow Airport near London violated the rights of people living nearby. The European Court of Human Rights ruled that a 1993 British government decision to permit increased night flights failed to ensure residents' ''right to respect for their homes and their private and family lives.'' Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: W. B. McCarthy, 79, Ex-Times Executive
description: W. Barry McCarthy, an executive at The New York Times Company for two decades, died last Wednesday in Stamford, Conn. He was 79 and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

description: The United States recognizes the importance of dealing with Afghanistan's refugee crisis as part of the political and military strategy for an antiterrorism coalition. But what concrete steps should decision makers take to address the looming catastrophe?

title: Some Americans Rush to Fill Jobs to Root Out Terrorists
description: Many Americans looking for work put off their plans temporarily after the terrorist bombings on Sept. 11. But others took the attacks as a call to arms.

title: Sports of The Times; Mike Piazza Goes Back To the Site
description: IT was only a month or two ago that Mike Piazza went shopping in the shadow of the World Trade Center. He has a friend who lives in Battery Park City, and they walked and shopped and gawked at the twin towers.

title: Mother Is Given Help To Allay Many Fears
description: Kwami Dabreo and the rest of his fourth-grade classmates looked up from their art projects.

They receive radio signals from three or four satellites, then calculate the user's position; the devices do not send signals.

description: INTERNET

title: NATO Says U.S. Has Proof Against bin Laden Group
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 2  NATO said today that the United States had provided "clear and compelling proof" that Osama bin Laden's terrorist organization was behind the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. In response, the alliance said it was ready to fight at the side of the United States should it ask for such help from its 18 NATO allies.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lower Township: Military Closes Beach
description: A popular Cape May County beach will remain closed indefinitely because it is close to a Coast Guard base, a Coast Guard official said yesterday. United States Fish and Wildlife officials agreed to keep the beach, Two Mile Beach, in Wildwood closed to the public as a security buffer to the base, the Long Range Aid to Navigation Support Unit. Along with other military installations, it was closed to the public after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Hudkins, a spokesman, said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLETT, ALBERT P., S.J.
description: BARTLETT-Albert P., S.J. Beloved uncle of Mrs. Eileen Nihan, Mrs. Noreen Noel, Mrs. Kathleen Betsch. Reposing at St. Helena Church, Bronx, NY Tuesday 27PM. Mass at St. Helena Church, Tuesday, 7:30PM. Visitation Wednesday at the Loyola Hall Chapel, Fordham University 3-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian burial at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Loyola Hall, Fordham University, Thursday 11AM. For further information contact Farenga Brothers Inc., Directors, 718-654-0500.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: A Search For Weapons In Prison
description: A team of 75 officers has begun a cell-to-cell search of the maximum-security prison in Walpole after an increase in the number of weapons found at the prison and a rise in assaults there. Justin Latini, a spokesman for the State Department of Corrections, said the 680 inmates would be locked down during the search, which is expected to last a few days. Fox Butterfield (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALGER, DAVID DEWEY
description: ALGER-David Dewey. Was tragically lost on 11 September 2001, at the World Trade Center. A Memorial Service to celebrate his remarkable life will be held at Saint Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and 53rd Street in Manhattan, on Friday, 5 October 2001, at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to a worthy WTC relief fund. Gifts may also be made to the Foundation for Alger Families, care of Fred Alger & Company, 30 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, New Jersey 07302, a charitable foundation established to assist the families of Fred Alger Management employees lost in the attack on the WTC.

description: President Bush announced yesterday that Ronald Reagan National Airport would open tomorrow, with service to both New York and Boston on the US Airways and Delta shuttles and to eight other cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, ARTHUR
description: KAUFMAN-Arthur. We mourn the passing of our good friend and client, and extend our sympathy to the Kaufman family. We are honored to have known & worked with him. Silverberg Stonehill & Goldsmith

title: For Torre and Yankees, Thoughts of the Athletics Can Wait
description: Joe Torre is not quite at the stage where he is thinking about Jason Giambi and Barry Zito. He is still worried about Orlando Hernndez and Paul O'Neill, still learning who, among his own players, will be healthy enough to play in the first round of the playoffs. In the next 72 hours, Torre will probably begin to think more specifically about the Oakland Athletics, the team the Yankees will most likely face in the first round.

title: Eighth Graders' Exam Results Delayed by a Scoring Problem
description: State education officials said yesterday that a problem in scoring reading and writing tests taken by about 200,000 eighth-grade students statewide had prompted them to delay releasing the results by up to three weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANCK, GERTRUDE
description: BLANCK-Gertrude. The New York School for Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis and its membership Society honor the memory of our colleague and mentor, Dr. Gertrude Blanck. She was an innovator in training psychoanalytic psychotherapists, including the founders and faculty of our institute.

title: Emotion Through Motion From Pearl Lang
description: There is no movement without emotional resonance in Pearl Lang's choreography. The three plotless dances and a new dance-drama that the Pearl Lang Dance Theater presented at the Kaye Playhouse were exhilarating, all models of feeling expressively recreated on stage.

title: Revised Travel Plans Reflect Goals of Administration Under War Clouds
description: In the old presidency, the one that ended shortly before 9 a.m. on Sept. 11, George W. Bush had plans to build up his image as a world leader with a 10-day trip this month to Beijing, Shanghai, Tokyo and Seoul. There were also early preparations for a trip to India after the first of the year. Closer to home, Mr. Bush had a mid-September weekend planned at his Texas ranch.

title: Williams and Croce Head to NBC Studio
description: Jayson Williams, who never met a microphone he did not love, and Pat Croce, who rarely stops talking, were added yesterday to NBC Sports' revamped NBA Showtime studio program. They will join Mike Fratello, who is returning to NBC, where he was once its top N.B.A. game analyst.

title: Kuwaitis Still Missing 11 Years After Invasion
description: The posters and banners and yellow ribbon decals that went up all over Kuwait all those years ago read, ''We would never forget you,'' but forgotten is what the relatives and campaigners for Kuwait's missing in the gulf war fear their loved ones have become.

title: The Next Moves in a Shadow War
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Maoists Free Policemen
description: Maoist rebels who have demanded that Nepal abolish a monarchy recently blighted by mass murder released 22 policemen as a gesture to improve the atmosphere for peace talks with the government. Those freed were among the 71 policemen captured by rebels two months ago in western Nepal. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: A Primer That Even Tempts The Pros
description: I WAS initially drawn to ''In the Sweet Kitchen'' by Regan Daley earlier this year, when the book, which was not yet even sold in the United States, won the International Association of Culinary Professionals' top cookbook award. Why had I never heard of its author?

title: Banks' Rates Giving Savers Little to Cheer
description: As miserable as returns have been on stocks, investors who seek out the most conservative investments -- money market accounts and certificates of deposit -- have also suffered this year as the rates paid on these savings have dwindled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILSTEIN, SEYMOUR
description: MILSTEIN-Seymour. Peacefully on October 2nd. Beloved husband of Vivian for 56 years. Most cherished father of Connie and her companion, Jehan - Christophe, Philip and Cheryl. Adored grandfather of Abby and Rick, Joanna, Merrie, Josh, Toby and Larry. Devoted brother of Paul and Gloria. A great man, a man of honor, he was loved and respected by all who knew him. Services private. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Land Confiscation May Proceed
description: The Supreme Court ruled that the government could continue acquiring white-owned farms through forced sale. The judges said they would determine at a later date whether the police have restored law and order on farms that have been invaded by black squatters. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Coming In From the Cold of Diplomatic Obscurity
description: FOR the last five years, Ravan Farhadi has been the ambassador of a shrinking state.

title: Okinawa Justice Is Tilted Against Them, Americans Say
description: This is the story of a rape and of a death and the different attention each has provoked on this small island where more than 20,000 American troops are based.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Consumers Lose Confidence
description: Consumer confidence in France fell in September to its lowest level since May 1998, the French statistics institute said. The index dropped to minus 15 in September from minus 10 in July, the last month it was published. The institute said that about 44 percent of the confidence survey was conducted before the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States. The report follows the institute's French business confidence index, which fell to its lowest point in five years last Thursday. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Protesting A Neo-Nazi March
description: Shopkeepers on the Kurfrstendamm in Berlin plan to black out their windows today to protest an expected neo-Nazi march on the national holiday marking the reunification of Germany. Authorities expect counterdemonstrators to greatly outnumber the estimated 1,000 rightists. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Leaves That Impress With Aroma, Not Autumnal Color
description: Kaffir lime leaves, with their heady citrus fragrance, are essential in Thai dishes. Avocado leaves, which have a nutty aroma and taste slightly of anise, are used in Mexican cooking. And many Indian recipes call for pungent curry leaves and earthy, slightly bitter fenugreek leaves. Now, these aromatic leaves are being sold dried in small packages at Adriana's Caravan in Grand Central Terminal and by mail from (800) 316-0820 or www.adrianascaravan.com. Dried artichoke leaves from France, which lend a delightfully lemony sweetness to soups, the latest addition, are $4.50 an ounce. The avocado leaves are $1.50 an ounce, curry leaves are $4.95 a quarter- ounce, fenugreek leaves are $2.50 an ounce and kaffir lime leaves $8 for half an ounce. The curry leaves are occasionally available fresh, and the lime leaves are also sold frozen.

title: Health Secretary Promotes F.D.A. Choice
description: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, is promoting a food safety expert to be the next chief of the Food and Drug Administration, but the White House has yet to approve him.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Safety Fears Shut Fertilizer Plant
description: Authorities closed a fertilizer plant near Bordeaux in the wake of the explosion at a similar factory in Toulouse on Sept. 21. The police are still searching for the cause of the blast, which killed 29 people, injured several thousand and caused millions of dollars in damage to the factory and to homes, offices, schools and hospitals. The Bordeaux plant, also owned by the group TotalFinaElf, is to remain closed pending a review of its overall safety. Marlise Simons (NYT)

description: ''This is a battle with only one outcome: our victory, not theirs.''

title: New Chairman Is Elected at Pratt Institute
description: ROBERT SIEGEL, left, a co-founder of Gwathmey Siegel & Associates Architects, was elected chairman of the board of trustees of Pratt Institute, replacing JAMES F. FULTON. Mr. Siegel graduated from Pratt in 1962 and received a master of architecture degree from Harvard University in 1963. A fellow of the American Institute of Architects, he organized an intern program for Pratt students at Gwathmey Siegel and has been a member of the executive committee of Pratt's board. Karen W. Arenson

description: The crowd on Baxter Street had expected to catch a glimpse of President Bush as he arrived for a visit to an elementary school today.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Hospital Construction Starts
description: Two decades after planning began, construction of a new Jersey City Medical Center began over the weekend. Bulldozers are clearing a site a few blocks from the waterfront, which is near the current center, an Art Deco complex that opened in 1931. The center is expected to be completed in 2004, at a cost of $168,000. Work began after Liberty HealthCare System, the hospital's parent, completed a deal for mortgage insurance, said Lynn McFarlane, a hospital spokeswoman. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Ancient Secret System Moves Money Globally
description: With nothing more than a telephone and a fax machine, Tarir Khan transfers money almost anywhere in the world -- no questions asked, no names used and no trail for law enforcement to follow.

description: It was supposed to be the biggest wine auction in history.

title: 'I Guess I'm Still In One Piece'
description: Jerry Seinfeld, whose hit NBC comedy series was largely a celebration of the idiosyncrasies of New York, had the same helpless feeling as many other New Yorkers in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center.

title: CONSECO WRITES OFF $475 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: Conseco Inc., the struggling insurance and finance company, lost money for the second consecutive quarter as it wrote off $475 million in junk bonds, mortgage securities and other assets. The write-offs bring to $2.1 billion the amount erased from the company's earnings since 1999 from a series of one-time charges. The charges included $225 million to write down the value of mortgage bonds held by Conseco's mobile-home lending unit; $125 million related to holdings of high-yield bonds; $45 million to write down the value of a stake in Telecorp PCS, a wireless telephone maker; $40 million stemming from its money-losing major medical business; and $40 million in guarantees for executives who took out loans to buy Conseco stock.

title: Berlin Freezes Assets
description: The German government has frozen 214 bank accounts it believes are linked to terrorists as part of an effort by allies of the United States to comply with a request by the Bush administration, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: Students Will Skip Dinner to Raise Money
description: Cornell University students have come up with another way to help families affected by the World Trade Center disaster. By giving up a dinner through their university meal plan, the students hope to raise $20,000 for the United Way Sept. 11 Fund. The goal is for 3,000 students to donate the money that would ordinarily go toward their dinner on Oct. 12. The donations will close down three campus dining halls that Friday evening because the money raised would usually go toward running the halls. Allison Fass

title: Unknown Russian Beats Kournikova
description: Anna Kournikova lost again in her comeback from a foot injury, beaten yesterday by a wild-card entry ranked 248th in the world in the first round of the Kremlin Cup in Moscow.

title: The Joyce Thanks Its Local Police and Firefighters
description: Life lived, with an emphasis on loss, was the dominant theme among the dance companies that performed in two benefit evenings organized by the Joyce Theater in connection with the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: 2 Diagnoses Of Nile Fever
description: Two elderly Nassau County residents are the 9th and 10th New Yorkers to receive diagnoses of West Nile virus this year, health officials said yesterday. The State Department of Health diagnosed the virus in a 70-year-old woman from East Meadow and a 73-year-old man from Seaford, both of whom were hospitalized late last month, said Cynthia D. Brown, a spokeswoman for the Nassau County Department of Health. The patients' names were not released. Of the remaining eight New Yorkers stricken by West Nile, five live in New York City, one in Suffolk County and two others in Nassau -- one of whom, a 75-year-old woman from Valley Stream, has since recovered, Ms. Brown said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Brunswick: E-ZPass Customer Service
description: Responding to customer complaints, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced yesterday that E-ZPass has expanded customer service hours on weekdays to 7 a.m. to 9 p.m., from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. It has also added new Saturday hours from 9 a.m. until noon. Thirty-nine customer service representatives have been hired to handle customer phone calls with questions or complaints. There is also a new 24-hour toll-free number, (866) 591-8966, to handle automated services.

title: Ad Agency Is Said to Consider Backing Out of Bid It Made
description: The WPP Group is seriously considering walking away from its proposed acquisition of the Tempus Group, by arguing that the Sept. 11 terror attacks have had a material adverse effect on the company's business, people close to the negotiations said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, NATHAN, M.D.
description: MINTZ-Nathan, M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague, teacher and friend. Dr. Mintz began his association with Mount Sinai in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology in 1934. After receiving additional training in Pathology, he devoted the next 60 years to clinical teaching and to the superb practice of medicine in OB/GYN. He will be fondly remembered for his warmth and compassion, and for his traditional bedside manner. He was loved by his patients and respected by his colleagues. The AAS salutes Dr. Mintz's outstanding commitment to Mount Sinai and his many years of service. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Anthony Squire, M.D., President Vicki Lopachin, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

description: Business was in overdrive at the Apache Corporation earlier this year. Apache, one of the largest independent natural gas and oil companies in the United States, committed to spend close to $900 million this year to find and develop energy resources in North America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLIN, JEAN M.
description: COLLIN-Jean M. Age 42, of NYC, missing and presumed dead in the World Trade Center attack of September 11. Jean was a Risk Manager for Pfizer, Inc. and was attending a meeting at the WTC. She was a graduate St. Vincent Ferrer HS, Grace Institute, and Pace University, and spent her entire professional career with Pfizer. A Stuyvesant Town native, Jean had many lifelong neighborhood friends. Jean weekended in the Northern Catskills where she also had many friends. Among her many accomplishments, Jean prized 3 NY Marathon completions. Her pleasant personality, engaging smile and trusted friendship will be missed by all. Jean is survived by her mother, Charlotte, sister Kathleen, brother Kevin, nephew Matthew, niece Jennifer, and close friend Don. A memorial service will be held at 1PM on October 6 at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the Jean Marie Collin Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Ms. K. Dwyer, AYCO Charitable Foundation, PO Box 8009, Clifton Park, NY 12605.

title: A Looming New York Fiscal Crisis
description: The New York economy, already shaky before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, is headed for an aftershock that could produce the biggest budget crisis since the 1970's. Estimates of lost city and state tax revenues over the next 18 months approach $10 billion. The shortfalls would come on top of multibillion-dollar deficits already projected for the next fiscal year. In preparing his first budget, the next mayor of New York City may have to close a gap of $4 billion or more, a nearly impossible task without major sacrifice by New Yorkers and help from Albany and Washington.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Loss Forecast
description: UFJ Holdings became the third major Japanese bank in the last two weeks to lower its half-year earnings as new accounting rules forced the company to write off 295 billion yen ($2.5 billion) in losses on its stock portfolio. Over all, UFJ said its loss would be 65 billion yen ($541 million) in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30, a period when the benchmark Nikkei 225 index slid 25 percent. Under the new rules, Japanese banks must value their stockholdings at current prices, not their purchase price. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: VENEZUELAN PHONE COMPANY REJECTS ADVANCES BY AES
description: The leading telephone company in Venezuela, Compaa Nacional de Telfonos de Venezuela, known as CANTV, rejected a $1.4 billion takeover bid from the AES Corporation of the United States, saying the bid was insufficient. CANTV said an AES takeover would be detrimental to workers, minority shareholders and the company. The telephone company said its board had agreed to study other options that would benefit shareholders. AES, which is based in Arlington, Va., bought control of Electricidad de Caracas in a $1.66 billion takeover, the largest unsolicited bid in the country's history, last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLEN, THOMAS P. III
description: CULLEN-Thomas P. III, (F.D.N.Y). Of Staten Island on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Susan (Quinn), loving father of Thomas P. Cullen IV, cherished son of Rita and Thomas P. Cullen Jr, dear brother of Rita and Sean Cullen. Funeral from the Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Ave, Staten Island. A memorial Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola, R.C. Church in Manhattan on Friday at 10AM. Visitation at Casey Funeral Home will be Thursday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the Uniformed Firefighters Association, 204 East 23rd St, NY, NY 10010, would be appreciated.
