title: Leader's Bitter Rival Appears Set to Win Bangladesh Election
description: In national parliamentary elections in Bangladesh, Khaleda Zia, who has sought for years to destabilize the government of her hated rival for power, Sheik Hasina, through a campaign of often violent general strikes, appeared headed tonight for a huge upset victory.

title: Eisley in Three-Way Fight for Job in the Game He Loves
description: A few weeks ago, Howard Eisley, the Knicks' recently acquired point guard, was feverishly flicking channels with his remote control. He needed a game to watch.

title: Democracy in Wartime
description: When I was young, politicians knew their history. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Harry Truman, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson -- all were steeped in the lore of victories and defeats past. I am therefore astonished by reports that Democrats are having trouble finding candidates for the midterm Congressional elections in 2002. Prospective candidates apparently believe that the national unity produced by the terrorist attack is bound to favor the party in power and reject the party in opposition.

title: Reckonings; An Injured City
description: Will the terror attack permanently damage New York's position as America's economic capital? No sentimentality, please, despite the mock headline in The Onion, ''Rest of Country Temporarily Feels Deep Affection for New York.'' This is a real question and deserves a serious answer.

title: From Taiwan, a Fear of China Technology
description: HSINCHU, Taiwan  Morris Chang was born in China, but unlike some Chinese emigres, he feels little desire to return.

title: Parties Struggle in Senate Over Labor Dept. Nominee
description: The Senate warmed up today for its first party-line fight since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks when the senators quarreled over the nomination of Eugene Scalia to be the No. 3 official at the Department of Labor.

title: Sky Is Not the Limit For the Islanders
description: Peter Laviolette is still new around here. He has apparently not heard that most Islanders fans would be happy this season -- make that delighted -- if the team finished with a playoff berth, or even a winning record, or at least higher in the standing than the despised Rangers.

title: Anyone Have a Hit?
description: One week into the new television season new hits are not too easy to pick out amid the generally disappointing results for new series on the four broadcast networks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, EDWARD
description: RYAN-Edward. Age 42. Missing at the site of the World Trade Center tragedy, September 11, 2001. A memorial Mass will be celebrated at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church White Plains Post Road, Scarsdale, NY on Saturday, October 6, 2001 at 10:45AM. He is survived by his wife Diane, children Edward, Megan, Joseph and Kelly along with the Ryan and Kettenacker families. He was First Vice President of Carr Futures. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made C/O Diane Ryan for the benefit of Edward, Megan, Joseph and Kelly Ryan or the Edward Ryan Memorial Fund C/O Wendy Phelps, both at 1199 Ulster Ave, Kingston, New York 12401.

title: The Dwindling Power of Rate Cuts
description: Yesterday the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates for the ninth time this year. The federal funds rate, the key tool of monetary policy, is now 2.5 percent -- below the level of inflation. The Fed was hoping it would buoy investor and consumer confidence, and given the markets' current psychology, it probably had little choice. The stock market did respond well to the move.

title: Circle Line Somberly Views Altered Skyline
description: With its foghorn sounding farewell to Midtown, the ship edged away from the pier and pushed south along the Hudson River. The waters that surround Manhattan Island are uncertain these days, but life must go on, and so must the Circle Line. There are things to point out, things to see.

title: Endowments From bin Ladens Prove Awkward
description: Months ago, Dale F. Eickelman, a professor at Dartmouth College, accepted a grant from a program at Oxford University to study the splintering religious and political leadership within the Islamic world, including the role of Osama bin Laden.

title: An Epicure's Way With the Bean
description: AMERICANS have never really appreciated beans the way people in certain other cultures do, but Cesare Casella, the chef at Beppe, is on a mission to change that. He is cooking traditional Italian dishes that focus on beans, not so much because of their inestimable nutritional value but because of their versatility and taste.

title: N.Y.U. Is Sued Over Denial of Tenure
description: Supporters of JOEL WESTHEIMER, an assistant professor who was recently denied tenure at New York University's Steinhardt School of Education, announced this week that they were filing charges against N.Y.U. with the National Labor Relations Board. His supporters, who include students and other professors, contend that the university is retaliating against Dr. Westheimer for testifying against it in the board's hearings on the right of N.Y.U.'s graduate student teaching and research assistants to unionize. They say that Dr. Westheimer's work had been rated highly until the hearings. University officials called the charges false and said that Dr. Westheimer's testimony was not a consideration in the tenure decision. Karen W. Arenson

title: The Mets' Unexpected Run Turns Lousy
description: It was inspiring, unexpected and memorable. The Mets emerged from a four-and-a-half-month malaise in the middle of August to incredibly rumble into the division race. It was a shock, but it gave their fans something to dream about. Up until last weekend, the Mets still had a chance to miraculously finish in first place in the National League East. Who could have imagined that

title: Rendezvous Of Suspects In Hickackings Is Investigated
description: Spanish authorities say they are investigating whether Mohamed Atta, who is suspected of leading the Sept. 11 suicide attacks, met with others involved in the attacks on trips to Spain last January and July.

title: Footlights
description: Shedding Light

title: XEROX SAYS FLEXTRONICS WILL BUY A MANUFACTURING UNIT
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that Flextronics International Ltd. had agreed to pay about $220 million to buy and to operate all of its office-equipment manufacturing, about half of Xerox's total production. About 5,000 jobs will be transferred to Flextronics, and 1,000 more will be cut, including positions in California, New York and Britain, said Ursula Burns, president of the Worldwide Business Services unit. Xerox has 85,000 employees. Xerox is focusing on high-speed printing and production machines. Flextronics will make most of the Document Center line of copiers, as well as small printers and multifunction office machines, as part of a five-year agreement.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: More Security For Producer Of Vaccine
description: The National Guard is providing extra security at the company that is the nation's sole producer of the anthrax vaccine. Pentagon officials called on the Guard after examining company security measures at the BioPort Corporation, in Lansing. The company supplies the military with a vaccine for anthrax, which can be used as a biological weapon. The vaccine is not available to the public. A company spokesman said BioPort had not been threatened. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Archive Honor for Scorsese
description: For many years Martin Scorsese has been as devoted to preserving old films as he is to making new ones. In recognition of that, the International Federation of Film Archives has named him the first recipient of its award for preservation. The presentation will be made tonight at the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall, before the screening of the restored version of Charles Laughton's film ''The Night of the Hunter.'' The award is a film can made of silver from Taxco, Mexico.

title: Debate on Air Security Fixes on Federal Role
description: The White House and both houses of Congress struggled today to agree on legislation that would tighten aviation security, as divisions remained over whether the federal government would run the whole security effort or just supervise it.

title: An Old-Fashioned, Versatile Treat
description: LONG before popcorn forged its reputation as a snack food, it had another life in the American kitchen. It may have been a novelty, but as cooks ground it into flour and folded it into puddings, cakes and soups, there was a reverence for its value as a gift of the harvest season, one that could be savored through the cold months.

title: I'm on the Hunt for Lost Data
description: Years ago, when I worked in data recovery for a large television network, an electrician dropped a screwdriver down an electrical panel. A bolt of electricity blew him off the ladder and started a fire in seven of the panels. He brought down the company's computer system. We worked all weekend to restore the data.

title: Schools Struggle, Delicately, to Balance the Normal With the Surreal
description: In Brooklyn, several young schoolchildren falsely claimed that their fathers had died in the World Trade Center attack in a muddled attempt to identify with classmates who actually had lost parents.

title: The Battery Is Down, All Right; Once Happily Isolated, an Area Is Now Badly Crippled
description: Living in Battery Park City today means having the National Guard's steely gaze upon you. It means not being able to have visitors drop in or have food or medications delivered without special permission. It means being cut off from the subway and having to walk two dozen blocks to Canal Street to hail a cab.

title: What's Doing Around Town
description: From Broadway and Off Broadway to concert halls and jazz clubs, New York City's stages are returning to normal schedules. Here is a sampling of performances.

title: The Call of the City Above the City
description: The horror of the attacks on the World Trade Center has left millions of Americans with a kind of collective acrophobia. For many, airplanes, skyscrapers and even elevators provoke feelings of fear.

title: House Panel Calls for 'Cultural Revolution' in F.B.I. and C.I.A.
description: The House committee that oversees the nation's intelligence agencies has called for far-reaching changes in intelligence operations and for an independent investigation into why government did not foresee or prevent the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.

title: Earlier Hijackings Offered Signals That Were Missed
description: Over and over since Sept. 11, aviation and security officials have said they were shocked that terrorists had hijacked airliners and crashed them into landmark buildings.

title: Mets' Elimination Isn't Inevitable; It's a Fact
description: The Mets players shuffled past each other in their dugout at Shea Stadium last night, silently collecting their equipment and retreating to the clubhouse. Some knew a loss eliminated them from playoff contention. Others felt it. Still others thought the slightest chances still existed.

title: Routines in Chaos, Employees Cope With Makeshift Offices
description: On the day that two planes struck the World Trade Center towers, Greg van Inwegen, the director of the research center for Deutsche Bank, which was at 130 Liberty Street next to the towers, grabbed only his briefcase and began a harrowing escape for his life.

title: Plan to Expand U.S. Powers Alarming Some in Colorado
description: The people who live under the formidable jaw of Pikes Peak like their churches, houses and cars big, and their government small. They send a steady flow of Republicans east, and do not expect much to come west, unless it is tax cuts or farm subsidies.

title: Can New York Recover Without Giuliani?
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: EMI Licenses Catalog
description: The EMI Group, the third-largest record label in the world, said yesterday that it would license its catalog of songs to the Pressplay online music service, making it the first music company to join both major Internet music plans. Pressplay is an equally held joint venture between Sony and Universal, a unit of Vivendi Universal. EMI, whose catalog includes recordings by Janet Jackson, above, and the Beatles, is also one of three major labels -- AOL Time Warner and Bertelsmann are the others -- backing Pressplay's rival, MusicNet. Both Pressplay and MusicNet are trying to offer music from the five major record labels, but both face the challenge of convincing fans, many of whom are accustomed to free services to pay subscriber fees. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about a change of chefs at Atlas in Manhattan misstated the length of time the new chef, David Coleman, had worked at the restaurant before his promotion. It was 10 months, not 3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIRACUSE, PETER A.
description: SIRACUSE-Peter A. On Tuesday, September 11, 2001, of Manhattan formerly of Bethpage, NY. Beloved husband of Alana Edelberg Siracuse. Devoted father of Ryan Joseph Siracuse. Loving son of Marilyn McCloskey Siracuse and the late George Siracuse. Dear brother of Laura Siracuse; Diane Beninati; George; Matthew and Joseph Siracuse. A memorial mass will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Ave. Manhattan on Friday, October 5th at 1:15 PM. For information The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave., Maplewood, New Jersey 07040.

title: In Stepping Down, Governor Is Stepping Up to New Plate
description: In his first public comments since President Bush chose him to coordinate the defense of the United States against terrorism, Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania warned today against giving up basic freedoms in the name of safety.

title: Danes Bearing Goodies Arrive on West 14th
description: Bodum, the Danish housewares and home accessories company, has just opened its largest store -- its first in New York -- at 413 West 14th Street.

title: Ford to Settle E.E.O.C. Suit
description: Ford Motor failed to punish a white worker who discussed ''lynching'' in front of black workers, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission says in a discrimination lawsuit against the company.

title: Ferrer Is Endorsed by Koch, Who Also Criticizes Green
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch threw his formidable political personality behind Fernando Ferrer in the mayoral race, yesterday, saluting Mr. Ferrer for standing up to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and sharply criticizing Mark Green for failing to do the same.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHTON, THOMAS J.
description: ASHTON-Thomas J., 21. Of Woodside, NY, died tragically and innocently on September 11, 2001, while working on the 95th floor of One World Trade Center. Precious and cherished son of John and Kathleen Ashton. Beloved brother of Colleen & Mary Ashton. Loving boyfriend of Jacqueline Crilley. Dedicated and loving grandson of Lewis & Kathleen Worth, Virginia and the late John Ashton and great-grandmother Agnes Carroll. Tommy's life and memory will also be cherished by a large, loving extended family and dear friends. Tommy lived his entire short life in St. Sebastian's parish in Woodside, Queens, where he attended St. Sebastian's School. A 1997 graduate of Archbishop Molloy High School, Briarwood, Tommy excelled as a competitive swimmer and was captain of both Molloy's swim team and the Flushing Flyer's swim team. Tommy attended St. Francis College in Brooklyn as a political science major. He was an IBEW Local 3 apprentice electrician who admired the beauty, majesty and purpose of the World Trade Center towers. A gift to family and friends, Tommy was a loving, kind, deeply introspective and spiritual person who enjoyed relaxing weekends in the mountains, fun evenings with family and friends and Mets games. Family and friends will honor Tommy's memory at a Memorial Wake on Thursday, October 4, and Friday, Oct. 5, at Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home 41-45 58th Street, Woodside, Queens (from 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM). A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, October 6, at 10:30AM at St. Sebastian's Church, 58th St and Roosevelt Avenue, Woodside. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made payable to: Archbishop Molloy High School, 83-53 Manton Street, Briarwood, NY 11435 (please indicate on check: for The Thomas Ashton Memorial Fund).

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Taking Gray Wolf Off Endangered List
description: Gov. Dirk Kempthorne ordered the state's wildlife agency to work with the federal Fish and Wildlife Service and other state governments to remove the gray wolf from the endangered species list. An initiative announced by the federal agency in July would reclassify gray wolves, which have been on the list since 1974, from endangered to threatened in three regions of the country. Gray wolves once roamed much of the country, and recovery efforts have been largely successful in the West. Environmental groups say reclassification would abolish many protections that made the efforts successful. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Student-Teacher Protest
description: Scores of Argentine teachers and students blocked the border bridge between La Quiaca, Argentina and Villazn, Bolivia, and interrupted trade in protest against the arrest of seven members of local teachers union over the weekend. Teachers have been striking in northwestern Jujuy Province for two months demanding back wages. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Mobile Phone Fee
description: In an about-face, SFR, the French mobile phone company controlled by the media company Vivendi Universal, paid the government 619 million euros ($568 million) as the first installment for a third-generation wireless license after withholding the money for about 24 hours in the hopes of renegotiating the terms. Jean-Marie Messier, Vivendi's chief executive, said, ''This price is now disproportionate to the benefit we can extract from the license,'' and that if the government refused to lower the fee, the company would take legal action. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: For Inept Jets, It Has Been 3 Games and a Cloud of Disgust
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards had a chance encounter with Curtis Martin in a hallway today. Martin asked how Edwards was doing, Edwards asked how Martin was doing, and soon two couches were needed to help figure out how lousy both of them were feeling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICLEMENTE, FRANK F. (''DEKE'')
description: DiCLEMENTE - Frank F. (''Deke''). On Friday, September 28. For four decades Deke was a beloved mentor and counselor-on the playing fields and in the Physical Education Department-to thousands of young men at Phillips Academy Andover. After graduating from Springfield College (MA) in 1935, he joined Andover the same year as an instructor in chemistry and assistant in the Physical Education Department. He coached varsity basketball starting the same year. Along the way he developed an intramural competitive system for Juniors in various team sports. Beginning in 1947 Deke coached soccer until his retirement in 1975. Under his guidance the team achieved its first-ever victory over arch-rival Phillips Academy Exeter in 1952. During the next 11 years his soccer teams defeated Exeter seven times. Survivors include his wife Bernadine of Andover, MA; his daughter Ann Ross of New York City and son Jim DiClemente. Deke will be greatly missed by all those alumni whose lives he touched during their young and formative years. Reg and Lois Collier PA, 1945

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATES, STEVEN J.
description: BATES-Steven J. At age 42 of Glendale, New York. Lieutenant, Engine Company 235, Brooklyn. In the line of duty at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. A memorial service celebrating his life, will be offered at the Redeemer Lutheran Church, 69-07 Cooper Avenue, Glendale on Saturday, October 6, 2001 at 1:00PM. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested to either the New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, NY 10475, or the Widows and Orphans Fund of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, 204 East 23rd Street, New York City, NY 10010.

title: Jets Need to Get a Grip, On Opposing Rushers
description: No doubt when the Jets gathered yesterday and watched the video of their Monday night pratfall against the San Francisco 49ers, it was a horror show.

title: F.T.C. Plans To Abandon New Bills On Privacy
description: The Federal Trade Commission will abandon efforts, begun during the Clinton administration, to get new laws to enhance online consumer privacy and will concentrate its efforts instead on enforcing existing laws, according to sources close to the commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EICHENBAUM, ANNETTE
description: EICHENBAUM-Annette. Devoted wife of Joseph A. Loving mother of Gary and Kenneth. Dear sister of Mark Tykocinski. Services Thursday, 10 AM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column yesterday about the farm bill in the House misstated the action of a coalition of cities, mayors and municipal water agencies. They sent a letter to members of Congress promoting conservation measures; they did not testify on the bill.

title: A Latin Border Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: Electrical Problems Cause Delays on the L.I.R.R.
description: As drivers adjust to the city's new car-pooling rules and continue to battle heavy traffic, a major electrical problem on the Long Island Rail Road threw another wrench into the morning commute yesterday, delaying some Manhattan-bound trains for more than half an hour throughout the morning rush.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a letter left behind by terrorists who attacked New York and Washington misstated the year of the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat in Egypt, an event cited by one authority on Islam as an example of violence committed by radicals with middle-class roots. It was Oct. 6, 1981, not 1979.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about ''Alfred Jensen: Concordance'' at the Dia Center for the Arts, in Manhattan, misidentified the enthusiast who bought the painting ''Forsaken'' and commissioned a mural for the Time & Life Building in Paris. He was Henry Luce III, chairman and chief executive of the Luce Foundation; Henry R. Luce was his father.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMARTINI, FRANK A.
description: DeMARTINI-Frank A. Of Brooklyn, NY. Missing since September 11 in the World Trade Center attack. Beloved husband of Nicole (Fasnacht). Devoted father of Sabrina and Dominic. Beloved son of Alfred and Alberta De Martini of Haddon Heights, NJ and Philadelphia, PA. Engaging brother to Alfred, Nina, Rosemary, Paul and their spouses. Terrific uncle to their children. For the Port Authority, Frank was Construction Manager of the World Trade Center, a building that he passionately admired. Raised in Haddon Heights, NJ, he earned a degree in architecture at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn where he practiced his profession and developed real estate after graduating in 1974. He was hired by the structural engineering firm Leslie E. Robertson Associates to help with the repairs of the 1993 terrorist bombing at the World Trade Center. He will be remembered for his courage, his passion, his love for his family, and his joy in being a parent. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on Friday, October 5 at 3PM at the Lafayette Presbyterian Church, 85 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn NY with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowerrs, donations can be made to the Daughters of Wisdom, Bethany House, 1342 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, New York 11213.

title: Recipe: Green Beans and Tomatoes
description: Time: at least 1 hour 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Woodstown: 2 Accused Of Waste Violations
description: Two men have been indicted on charges that they recklessly disposed of agricultural waste, including pig waste, from their farm, possibly polluting streams in the area. The men -- Joseph R. Johanson, 54, and his son Robert, 30 -- were accused on Monday of allowing rainwater runoff on their Woodstown farm. The elder Johanson's lawyer said the two were not guilty. He said the Johansons had been forced to sell their pigs and take jobs as corrections officers because of an unrelated state lawsuit. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Palestinians Attack Israeli Settlement
description: Two Palestinian gunmen attacked this Israeli settlement at the northern edge of the Gaza Strip on Tuesday night, killing a young couple and wounding 15 others in the boldest and deadliest assault on such a community in more than a decade.

title: 'I Guess I'm Still in One Piece'
description: Jerry Seinfeld, whose hit NBC comedy series was largely a celebration of the idiosyncrasies of New York, had the same helpless feeling as many other New Yorkers in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center.

title: Election Board Nears Result For Advocate
description: Preliminary results released yesterday showed that Norman Siegel was in second place behind Betsy F. Gotbaum in the Democratic primary for public advocate. The city's Board of Elections began mailing out absentee ballots last night with their names for the Oct. 11 runoff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLISKIN, DAVID
description: PLISKIN-David. Age 94. Attorney & Artist. On Oct. 2, 2001 in Daytona Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Bertha for 69 years. Father of Thomas Pliskin, Shrewsbury, N.J., and Susan and husband Jonathan Kopald, Fort Montgomery, New York. Cherished grandfather of Deborah. Inquiries to Haigh-Black Funeral Home, 386-252-4771.

title: CALENDAR
description: Portuguese Combinations

title: Terror Strikes America / Military Preparations : America's 'We'll Call If We Need You' War
description: PARIS  In the week immediately following the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, European voices rose to suggest the coming of a new world equation in which a chastened, even humiliated America would be forced to abandon what were called its me-first, unilateralist instincts.

title: Democrats In Senate Are Pressured On Terror Bill
description: The Bush administration and its Republican allies in the Senate sharply increased pressure today on Senate Democrats to act more quickly on antiterrorism legislation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTSON, MARY ANN WINDELS
description: ROBERTSON-Mary Ann Windels. Of Darien, CT. on September 26, 2001. Mother of Mary (Polly) Windels & Richard Windels. Sister of Raymond Pratt Norton Jr. Grandmother of two. A memorial service will be held at the United Church of Rowayton, Rowayton, CT., on Friday, October 5, 2001 at 11 A.M. Friends may call at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, CT. on Thursday, October 4th, 2001 from 6-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Darien Library, 35 Leroy Ave, Darien, CT. 06820, the Darien YMCA, 2420 Post Road, Darien, CT. 06820, or the Richard Rosenthal Hospice Residence, 1029 East Main Street, Stamford, CT. 06902.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Warnings Went Unheeded

title: Shares Close Up After the Fed's Move to Reduce Rates
description: Stocks rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by half a percentage point in an effort to revive a declining economy.

title: In the Bay Area, Pacifist Orthodoxy Faces Dissent
description: Kevin Danaher cannot believe much of the news he hears these days. He says he cannot believe the polls that say 90 percent of Americans approve of a military response to the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Another Original Moves In on Clinton Street
description: IN a world of eccentric fusion menus, where chefs are always looking for something new and different, it's not too often that I stumble across a restaurant that offers a lamb tongue sandwich, much less lamb tongue with almond butter and red currant jelly. But that sandwich is the signature item at aKa Cafe, a storefront offshoot of 71 Clinton Fresh Food on the Lower East Side that takes the familiar downtown sandwich-and-wine bar into a stratosphere of unexpected flavor combinations.

title: Age May Be Catching Up to Franco's Left Arm
description: There was the line drive off Robin Ventura's bat in pregame workouts that struck John Franco's ankle in August. That, Franco said, was unavoidable. But there is also the tendinitis that has plagued Franco for most of the second half of this season, yet another nagging injury that sidelined him.

title: U.S. Charts A High-Tech Strategy for Afghan War
description: PARIS  U.S. forces in Afghanistan will rely heavily on new high-tech weapons to produce a fast-moving, hard-hitting force designed to break the ruling Taliban militia and eventually root out the bin Laden terrorist network, experts said Tuesday.

title: Environmentalists Oppose Shift on Hudson Dredging
description: A half-dozen environmentalists told officials at the Environmental Protection Agency here today that they opposed altering the government's half-billion-dollar directive on how the General Electric Company should dredge the Hudson River of poisonous chemicals.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Jon Alper was named to the new post of senior account supervisor at the public relations group at the Brownstein Group, Philadelphia. He had been an account supervisor at Miller/Shandwick Technologies, Boston. Also, two other public relations executives at Brownstein were promoted: Caralyn Gilotti, account manager, becomes senior account manager, and Owen Murphy, account coordinator, becomes associate account manager. Miller/Shandwick is part of Weber Shandwick Worldwide, a unit of the Advanced Marketing Services division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNDALL, MAGDALENA F.
description: TYNDALL-Magdalena F. Of Lawrence, L.I. On October 1, 2001. Loving mother of Dean MacGuire and Robert Tyndall. Devoted grandmother of Timothy, Christopher, Alexandra and David. A memorial service will be held on Saturday 11 AM at Trinity-St. John's Church, Hewlett, L.I.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Body Shop Talks
description: The British pioneer of natural beauty products, Body Shop International, which has been overtaken by cheaper rivals, said it was in takeover talks with unspecified potential buyers as first-half profit fell by about 60 percent, to $2.8 million. The news pushed the share price up almost 5 percent, less than one- quarter of the 1992 high. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Sallie Mae Offers Aid to Terror Victims
description: Sallie Mae, the largest private provider of education loans in the United States, has announced that it will forgive the federal and private Sallie Mae student loans of the spouses of those who died or who have been permanently disabled in the attacks on the World Trade Center. With a $1.5 million endowment, a new fund is providing this assistance and will also give scholarships for post-secondary education of up to $25,000 a year to the children of those who died or were permanently disabled, including the children of police, fire and medical personnel. Applications for loan relief and scholarships will be accepted beginning Oct. 18. More information is available at www.salliemae.com. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about fear of potential hazards misspelled the surname of a psychologist who said that even if a fear was irrational it made sense to do what made one comfortable. He is Dr. George Loewenstein, not Lowenstein.

title: Recipe: Popcorn Soup
description: Adapted from Le Relais, Louisville, Ky.

title: World Tourism Officials Look Hard for Optimism
description: Along with a tropical rain, gales of bad news battered a world tourism conference here this week: dozens of trans-Pacific flights canceled, hundreds of Japanese tour groups dropping trips to the United States and tourism bookings vanishing in Asia's poorest nations, including Cambodia, Nepal and Thailand.

title: Seymour Milstein, City Real Estate Magnate, Dies at 81
description: Seymour Milstein, who, with his brother, Paul, presided over a multibillion-dollar real estate and banking empire with three million square feet of office space, 8,000 apartments and one of New York's oldest financial institutions, the Emigrant Savings Bank, died yesterday at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

title: NATO Says U.S. Has Proof Against bin Laden Group
description: NATO said today that the United States had provided ''clear and compelling proof'' that Osama bin Laden's terrorist organization was behind the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. In response, the alliance said it was ready to fight at the side of the United States should it ask for such help from its 18 NATO allies.

title: Uprooted Greenmarkets Seek Spaces
description: THE 16 farmers who had set up their stalls at the Greenmarket at Liberty and Church Streets on Sept. 11 escaped with their lives when the twin towers were destroyed, though several suffered smoke inhalation and burns, and 10 lost their trucks. Traffic restrictions below Canal Street since then have forced the closing of three other markets, and security concerns have closed the one at the United Nations. That means there are more than 40 farmers with lots of produce and nowhere to sell it.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Higher Tax On Cigarettes
description: The state tax on a pack of cigarettes was raised by 18 cents on Monday, to 77 cents. Before the increase, a pack cost $3 to $4. The state budget, passed in July, called for the increase, which legislators estimate could generate an additional $130 million over the next two years. The state will use most of the money to pay for a prescription drug program for the elderly. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Tough Talk From Blair On Taliban
description: Sealing his standing as America's most passionate and steadfast ally in the fight against terrorism, Prime Minister Tony Blair declared today that Osama bin Laden was responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks and challenged the Taliban leaders in Afghanistan to give him up or ''face the consequences.''

title: Driving Curbs Bring Big Drop In Traffic Crossing East River
description: Traffic on all East River bridges has begun to show a slight increase but significant decreases continue overall since car-pooling rules were introduced, Deputy Mayor Joseph L. Lhota said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORINS, KENNETH, M.D.
description: KORINS-Kenneth, M.D. Suddenly on September 29, 2001 at age 35. Loving husband of Maria and devoted father of Jessica. Dedicated doctor and humanitarian. Services today, 10:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Messier Is Not Looking Ahead
description: Don't ask Mark Messier, the Rangers' captain, if he will play next season, his 24th. Messier, whose contract ends at the end of the season, has a simple answer.

title: Private Ruminations on Decay, Sung Loud for All to Hear
description: When Sparklehorse played at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night, flowers were attached to every microphone stand, and anyone who sang seemed to be leaning over to smell the roses. It was an ambiguous touch of nature -- fresh flowers but dead ones, decorating impassive electronic gear -- from a band that forges an eerie composite of the rustic and the synthetic.

title: EUROPEANS FINE ARCHER AND OTHERS FOR PRICE FIXING
description: The European Commission fined the Archer Daniels Midland Company and five other companies a total of 57.5 million euros ($52.7 million) for price fixing and antitrust violations in the market for sodium gluconate, a chemical used mainly for cleaning glass and metal. The other companies were Akzo Nobel N.V, Avebe B.A., the Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Company Ltd., Jungbunzlauer A.G. and Roquette Frres S.A. Fujisawa of Japan, was granted a reduction of 80 percent of its fine, to 3.6 million euros ($3.3 million), for being the first to supply decisive evidence of the cartel. Jungbunzlauer of Switzerland, received the biggest fine, 20.4 million euros ($18.7 million), while Archer Daniels of Decatur, Ill., was fined 10.13 million euros ($9.29 million). The commission said the companies ran the cartel from 1987 to 1995. They said the market was worth 18 million euros ($16.5 million) a year. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: The Serbs Act To Apprehend 2 Top Leaders Of Bosnia War
description: The Bosnian Serb parliament adopted a law today that should open the way for the arrest of the two most notorious war crimes suspects to remain at large in the region: Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the movie character actor Victor Keung Wong by The Associated Press on Saturday omitted two survivors. They include two sons, Anton and Duncan Wong of New York City.

title: Travel Push Includes 10,000 Free Air Tickets
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented short-term plans yesterday to boost New York City's reeling tourism industry. The program includes a plane ticket giveaway to 10,000 out-of-towners.

title: East River E-ZPass
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Farmers Protest W.T.O.
description: Thousands of farmers rallied in Bangalore to protest the World Trade Organization, saying it was allied with multinational corporations against farmers. M. D. Nanjundaswamy, who fought the entry of Kentucky Fried Chicken into India, said W.T.O. rules allow in cheap imports and forced a reduction of subsidies. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Auto Sales Off in September, But Less Than Expected
description: United States auto sales slumped last month, but were better than analysts expected.

title: Fed's Statement on Interest Rates
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates:

title: Our Towns; Helping Hands Try to Heal Aching Heart
description: THERE was a knock and Joan York said, ''That's my neighbor Helen checking on me.'' Helen Daly, from two doors down, comes every day. There was a buzzing, Joan peeked out and there was Helen's husband, Jason, mowing her lawn.

title: Aid Is Less Than Canada's Airlines Sought

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Indians Awarded $248 Million
description: A federal judge has raised the amount the state owes the Cayuga Indian Nation to nearly $248 million from $36.9 million, court documents show. The judge said Tuesday that the lower figure granted by a jury last year was inadequate interest on the value of more than 64,000 acres in Cayuga and Seneca Counties that were illegally seized more than 200 years ago. The tribe plans to use whatever money is awarded to buy back land there. The state plans to appeal the decision, saying the amount is too high. The tribe also plans to appeal, saying it is too low. An economist who testified for the tribe estimated lost interest at $1.7 billion. Hope Reeves (NYT)

But years later, when the Taliban government began to crack down on secular culture, arresting musicians and forbidding public performances of music, Quraishi found what he was meant to do in life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAY, EDWARD
description: DAY-Edward. 45. Firefighter. Friend to all. As a firefighter for 13 years, Edward (Eddy) Day, 45, loved his job as a member of Engine Company 28 and Ladder 11 on Manhattan's Lower East Side. He transferred there in 1989 after having been posted briefly at Engine Company 4, also in Lower Manhattan. The members of both firehouses knew him as a fun loving friend to all. Including Eddy, six members of Ladder 11 are missing as a result of the collapse of the World Trade Center. Eddy was a life-long resident of Staten Island who enjoyed participating in many sporting activities. He was a thirddegree black belt in karate and enjoyed teaching children the discipline and respect associated with karate. He was an accomplished runner who ran in the NYC marathon several times. He was an avid golfer who enjoyed taking trips to Myrtle Beach, SC, with his golfing buddies. Eddy was very proud to have learned to swim at the age of 40. He attended St. John the Baptist de la Salle grammar school, Curtis High School, and Staten Island Community College. His love of the outdoors and nature held a large place in his heart. This love extended towards various animals that he and his wife cared for in their home: a dog, several cats, three snakes and a rabbit. He and Bridgitte (Gitta), his wife of 20 years, and the same group of friends always vacationed at least one week per year in the Adirondacks Mountains of upstate New York. ''His eyes would light up when he talked about vacationing at Pecks Lake,'' said his long time friend Margaret Duffy-Shanley. He had an appetite for learning new things. If a topic interested him, he would simply read a book on the subject and then do it. He enjoyed troubleshooting computers, he re-built his garage and added a deck and a new roof onto his house. He was a self-taught auto and motorcycle mechanic as well. He learned German so that he would be able to communicate with his wife's family. He very much enjoyed visiting Germany and spending time with his family and friends there who miss him dearly. ''He was my life,'' said his wife. Known for his love of fun and friends, Eddy enjoyed relaxing with the occasional beer and schnapps. ''He was always the life of the party, usually laughing the hardest at his own jokes,'' said his mother, Grace Day. The memorial service for Edward Day will be held on Saturday, October 6, 2001, at 2:00 PM on Staten Island at the Music Hall at Snug Harbor Cultural Center. He is survived by his wife Gitta, brothers Bill and Tim, sister Liz, and parents Edward & Grace.

Mr. Aarnio is best known for his Ball chair (1962), with speakers or telephones; the transparent Bubble chair (1968), suspended from a chain; and the round, rocking Pastil chair (1967). This month, M2L, Mr. Aarnio's East Coast distributor, is offering eight designs, including the newly reintroduced 1973 Pony seat, right. ''It's for the privileged child,'' said Michael Manes, the owner of M2L. Or the adult with a sense of humor. The Pony is $1,700. Other pieces start at $350. M2L is at 215 East 58th Street. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Names A President
description: Edward D. Breen will succeed Robert L. Growney as president and chief operating officer of Motorola on Jan. 1, the company maker said. Mr. Breen, left, previously was head of Motorola's networks sector. He was chairman and chief executive of the General Instrument Corporation, which merged with Motorola in January 2000. The move was not unexpected on Wall Street. Mr. Growney, who underwent heart bypass surgery in May 2000, had announced his intention to retire in 2002, after more than 36 years with the company. He will become vice chairman until he retires on March 31, 2002. Mr. Breen has generally received praise for his energetic and no-nonsense management of the company's broadband-cable and network units. Shares in Motorola rose 12 cents, to $15.35. The F.A.O. expects about 4,000 delegates from 192 countries to attend the meeting. Marina Harss (NYT)
