Grandfather of eight grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, Washington DC on Monday, October 8, from 7 to 9 PM, and Tuesday, October 9, from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9. Services will be held at the Old Post Chapel at Fort Myer, Virginia on Wednesday, October 10, 9:45 AM. Interment to follow at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to www.libertyunites.org.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Credit Ratings Are Cut
description: Two credit agencies cut their ratings on debt securities issued by Nortel Networks yesterday after the company said it expected a sharp decline in sales this quarter. Standard & Poor's lowered its rating on Nortel to BBB- from BBB and Moody's Investors Service cut its rating to Baa2 from Baa1. The changes will result in a slight increase in Nortel's borrowing costs. But the company's bonds will still be considered ''investment grade,'' meaning that most financial institutions will still be able to hold the bonds in their portfolios. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Kashmir Mourns 38 Attack Victims
description: With tears rolling down his cheeks, Farooq Abdullah, chief minister of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, eulogized the 38 victims of Monday's terrorist attack on the state assembly and called for reprisal attacks on Pakistan, where the group blamed for the attack is based. ''The time has come to wage a war against Pakistan and to bomb the militant training camps there,'' he said. ''We are running out of patience.'' Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Wallcoverings From an Artist
description: Louis Comfort Tiffany, Lockwood de Forest and now, how about Candace Wheeler (1827-1923), a Tiffany collaborator and America's first prominent woman interior and textile designer? Starting Wednesday, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will show 105 textiles, wallpapers, paintings and photographs relating to her career. Her designs include the Honeybee Frieze (right), which, with its accompanying wallpaper, won the top prize of $1,000 in an 1881 competition. J. R. Burrows & Company holds the license for reproductions of her fabrics and wallpapers, including the Honeybee Frieze ($20 a yard) and wallpaper ($120 a roll). At the Waltham Wallpaper & Paint Corporation, 591 Main Street, Waltham, Mass., 02452; (781) 893-3732, or Burrows at (800) 347-1795 or www.burrows.com. N. C. MAISAK

title: Sabena of Belgium Gets Loan and Asks For Court Protection
description: Sabena, Belgium's ailing airline, sought protection from creditors today, and the Belgian government provided a $115 million bridge loan for one month to try to salvage at least part of the airline.

title: Report Finds Substantial Lapses in Security for Shipments of Missiles Within the U.S.
description: Security for domestic shipments of surface-to-air missiles, cruise missiles and other explosives has been so poor that terrorists could easily obtain them for use in an attack in this country, according to a classified government report and other confidential records.

title: Islamic Jihad, Forged in Egypt, Is Seen as bin Laden's Backbone
description: CAIRO, Oct. 3  It was the marksman's equivalent of threading a needle on the run.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NESHER, ARYEH
description: NESHER-Aryeh. Died peacefully on October 3, 2001. A legendary fundraiser for Israel and Jewish causes. A loving husband to his wife Lili. A devoted father to son Avi (and Iris), daughter Tali (and David) and adoring grandfather to grandchildren Maya, Jake, Tom and Ari. Services Friday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: For Many Since the Attack, No Cable Means No TV
description: Seconds after the first plane slammed into the north tower of the World Trade Center, the broadcast signals of almost every major television station in the New York region went dark. Since then, most viewers without cable television have seen just blue screens or fuzz-filled programs.

title: Planned Parenthood to Take Sides With Its Endorsement of McGreevey
description: The political arm of Planned Parenthood will endorse James E. McGreevey for governor of New Jersey on Thursday, an unsurprising move on its face but one that the group's national president linked to the Rev. Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson's blaming abortion providers and feminists for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Experts Call for Better Assessment of Threats
description: Federal agencies and Congress are racing to check the security of everything from soybeans to municipal water supplies to nuclear reactors to whole cities. Last week, concern rose with the disclosure that the suspected jet hijackers had investigated crop-dusters  and thus, conceivably, the possibility of spreading deadly germs or chemicals.

title: Green Finds a Transformed Landscape for the Race
description: Just six weeks ago, as he waited for another mayoral debate to begin in the same television studio where last night's was held, Mark Green, exuding confidence, tested his microphone with a little joke. ''I'll try for a contentious debate,'' he said in a mock-earnest voice. ''I'll try for a contentious debate. Don't blame me if I utterly fail.''

title: White House Criticizes Republican Farm Bill
description: The Bush administration came out against the $171 billion House version of a farm bill today, saying it would give too much money to commodity subsidies and not enough to conservation efforts. The White House stance set up a battle within the Republican Party over who would determine farm policy for the next decade covered by the bill.

title: Ownership of Funds Is Up
description: The number of households that own mutual funds rose 5.9 percent last year to 54.8 million, 52 percent of all households in the nation, according to a survey by the Investment Company Institute, a a fund industry association in Washington. In 1999, 51.7 million households, 49 percent of the total, owned mutual funds, the survey said. More people invested in define contribution retirement plans, the group said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JEROME G.
description: SHAPIRO-Jerome G., 77. Died Tuesday, October 2, 2001 after complications from a stroke and Alzheimer's disease. He practiced law in New York City for over 45 years with the firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, becoming its Chairman from 1975-1989. Survived by his wife of 42 years, Marjorie Mackay Shapiro, three children, Jeffrey Kemble, Jill Dara and Eric Noach, and six grandchildren. He is also mourned by his beloved sister, Norma Kleiner and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue and West 91st Street on Sunday, October 7th at 3 PM. Burial service will be at Abel's Hill Cemetery in Chilmark, MA at 4 PM on Thursday, October 4, 2001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his honor to the Alzheimer's Association of New York, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

title: A festival of 'Britishness,' slightly adapted since Sept. 11, will celebrate New York.
description: THE British, long among the United States' staunchest allies, are reaffirming their support of the country and New York specifically with a two-week citywide festival of cultural and commercial activities backed by a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign.

title: A Man of Endearing Habits, and a Father Loved Even by Strangers
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 369 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 310. In all, 4,986 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: Pay Claims Now, Quibble Later; Insurers Tend to the Disrupted Businesses in New York
description: Geoffrey R. Montreuil walked into a medical diagnostic office on the ground floor of an abandoned building a block from the ruins of the World Trade Center on Tuesday morning. He ran his hand over a hulking magnetic resonance imaging machine worth nearly $2 million.

title: Nissan Workers Reject Bid To Join Union in Tennessee
description: The latest effort by the United Automobile Workers to organize a plant operated by a foreign automaker failed late last night in Smyrna, Tenn., as Nissan workers voted more than 2 to 1 to reject the union.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Agha Saeed, national chairman of the American Muslim Alliance, referred incorrectly in some copies to one of the universities where he is a professor. It is California State University at Hayward, not Caltech.

title: Reports Swirl Out of Afghanistan Of Panic and Taliban Defections
description: The Taliban's top Islamic clerics have left their headquarters in the southern Afghan city of Kandahar to escape the risk of American bombing, and other senior Taliban officials have fled to Pakistan or sent their families across the border as refugees, according to reliable accounts reaching Pakistan.

title: Making a Case Against bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Loss of Net Halts An Online Ritual
description: FOR Neil Tow, a 23-year-old student at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Morningside Heights, the Internet serves a religious function. Asking acquaintances and friends for forgiveness before Yom Kippur as a way to atone for sins committed against people is an age-old Jewish practice. Mr. Tow and many of his fellow students gave the practice a modern twist by asking for forgiveness through group e-mail messages.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Keeping Caladiums

title: TIFFANY SAYS THIRD-QUARTER SALES WILL DECLINE
description: Tiffany & Company's fiscal third-quarter sales will decline about 10 percent and profit will fall more than forecast as shoppers, worried about the slowing economy and shaken by the terrorist attacks, spend less on jewelry. Earnings in the quarter, which ends Oct. 31, will fall to 12 cents to 15 cents a share, from 24 cents a year earlier, Tiffany said. Tiffany, which is based in New York, had sales of $369.7 million a year earlier. Fourth-quarter profit will be 49 cents to 56 cents a share, compared with 56 cents the previous year, the company said.

title: Ninth Man Held in Suspected Plot Against Paris Embassy
description: PARIS, Oct. 3  A young Frenchman of Algerian background, extradited here from Britain over the weekend, today was ordered held and placed under formal investigation, becoming the ninth suspect in a case that may link Osama bin Laden with a plot to blow up the United States Embassy in Paris, French officials and newspapers reported.

title: Hezbollah and Hamas Put on Back Burner
description: Even as the Bush administration mobilizes for war in Afghanistan, it has been unable to resolve where two anti-Israeli organizations -- Hezbollah and Hamas -- fit into its global campaign against terrorism, senior administration officials said today.

title: Getting In on Some Decorator Deals
description: On Oct. 10, 11 and 12, there will be the annual public warehouse sale of Donghia furniture and textiles, ordinarily sold only to decorators, designers and architects. Upholstered furniture, fabric, dining tables and chairs, lighting and beds will be offered at deep discounts. The Eaton Club Chair, above left, will be $1,220; retail is $4,070. Increspato, above right, Venetian glass table lamps, will be $725; retail is $2,420. Discontinued fabrics -- including striped chenilles, damasks and linens -- will be available at $10 to $40 a yard; at retail they cost $50 to $245 a yard. Shipping is extra. At the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street (Houston Street); doors open at 9 a.m. Information, (212) 925-2777 MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A Panton Renaissance, Walls, Chairs and All
description: The early work of Verner Panton (1926-1998), the Danish design radical, was rooted in organic modernism. Later he turned to Pop. Zesty Myers and Evan Snyderman, who own R 20th Century in TriBeCa, have re-created Panton's designs for trade shows in Europe. ''We're presenting two living environments, from floor to ceiling, Mr. Myers said.'' One, below, is based on Panton's 1970 Visiona 2-Living Tomorrow installation in Cologne, Germany, and includes 46 molded red plastic panels from 1969 ($1,000 each).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Guilty Plea In Video Case
description: A former teacher has pleaded guilty to taking lewd pictures of high school cheerleaders on Long Island and selling the images on the Internet, according to District Attorney James Catterson Jr. of Suffolk County, left. The teacher, Kevin Matthew Dern, 29, a former Greenwich, Conn., resident now living in Bensalem, Pa., was charged with 53 counts of violating the civil rights of the cheerleaders whose images he sold, and 3 counts of endangering the welfare of a child. The police searched Mr. Dern's Greenwich home and computer on Feb. 6, seizing information about the pay-for-view Web site, which has since shut down. Phillip Russell, Mr. Dern's lawyer, said his client had pleaded guilty to close the Suffolk case while he fights related charges elsewhere.

title: Democratic Gains Falter With Tighter Security in Central Europe
description: Since the terror attacks in the United States on Sept. 11, several governments in Central Europe have called for tighter security precautions, possibly reversing the direction of democratic gains the nations have made since the fall of Communism.

title: Interpublic Units Trimming Staffs
description: Two agencies that are part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies are cutting jobs or considering layoffs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nissan Workers Reject Union at Tennessee Plant

title: Soul-Searching, Pyrotechnics and an Exotic Aviary
description: After a generation of genteel respectability and a number of financial crises, the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra is aiming to right itself with new musical leadership. Robert Spano -- young, energetic and no friend of the status quo -- has just begun the first of the 14 weeks he will spend here each season. There is wary optimism on the money front and even talk of a new $200 million hall to replace the simple 1,700-seat space here in the Woodruff Arts Center.

title: A New Crop Of Palmtops With Roots In the PC
description: TODAY is a big day for hand-held computing nuts. It marks the release of Pocket PC 2002, Microsoft's next-generation operating system for pocket computers, as well as the debut of several palmtops that run it. Their makers -- Compaq, Toshiba and Hewlett-Packard -- have much to celebrate: they have succeeded in thinking small. But Microsoft continues to think big, which is not always a good thing in machines with three-inch screens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HARDY WILLIAM
description: SMITH-Hardy William. On October 3, 2001. Beloved friend of the late Peter Glenville. Theirs was a partnership radiant with the warmth of their associations, the creativity of their love for life and the distinction of their achievements together in theatre and film. Adored uncle of Holly Book and Meridel Jellifer. Loving great uncle of and inspiration to Asher Book and his other nieces and nephew. There were none more loyal and generous, kind and true than Hardy. He will be ardently missed. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday, 2-4PM and Friday 2-4 and 68PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10:30AM at Saint Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Ave at 66th St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLEN, THOMAS P. III
description: CULLEN-Thomas P. III, (F.D.N.Y). Of Staten Island on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Susan (Quinn), loving father of Thomas P. Cullen IV, cherished son of Rita and Thomas P. Cullen Jr, dear brother of Rita and Sean Cullen. Funeral from the Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Ave, Staten Island. A memorial Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola, R.C. Church in Manhattan on Friday at 10AM. Visitation at Casey Funeral Home will be Thursday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the Uniformed Firefighters Association, 204 East 23rd St, NY, NY 10010, would be appreciated.

title: Artificial Butter Suspected in Lung Disease
description: Workers in two states have come down with a severe lung disease that is apparently linked to their work with vats of artificial butter flavoring, doctors have reported.

title: Politically Incorrect And Proud to Show It
description: Mr. Charles, a minor cable television host with a major sense of himself, has his own little recipe for escaping the grimness of the everyday world. ''I take what I call a nelly break,'' he explains happily to the audience at the Greenwich House Theater, where ''Rude Entertainment,'' a wispy and waspish trio of short plays by Paul Rudnick, opened last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, HYMAN I., M.D.
description: GARDNER-Hyman I., M.D. Age 95, died October 2, 2001, in New City, NY. Born on the Lower East Side in 1905, he was a general practitioner in Brooklyn from 1934 to 1991. Married in 1934 to the late Nettie Geringer, he is survived by his children Michael, David and Debra, and Marjorie and the late Joel Wineburgh; grandchildren Eowyn, Chanah and Yehudah, Steven and Diana, Susan, Amy, Lisa and Rebekah; great grandchildren Menachem Mendel and Henry. The eldest of eight children, he is also survived by brother Ben Gartner and sister Yetta Schultz. He was beloved by his family, friends, and many grateful patients. Services on Thursday, 10:30AM, at Weinstein, Garlick & Kirschenbaum, Coney Island Avenue and Avenue H, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Hadassah.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Muggers Attack Blair's Son
description: The police reported that Euan Blair, the 17-year-old son of Prime Minister Tony Blair, was attacked in North London early Friday by muggers who tried to steal property from him and a teenage friend and rifled their pockets. They said the would-be robbers made off empty-handed after ''some pushing and shoving.'' There were no reports of injuries or arrests. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Train Company Pays For City's Overtime
description: CSX Transportation paid the City of Baltimore about $373,500 to cover overtime costs for emergency workers who responded to a July freight train derailment and fire in a downtown tunnel. CSX Transportation, a unit of the CSX Corporation of Richmond, Va., said the payment was not an acknowledgment of responsibility. The July 18 crash, which is under federal investigation, shut down much of downtown and delayed East Coast freight traffic. CSX has also paid $50,000 to merchants who lost business and $20,000 to a merchants' marketing group. The city has estimated damage at more than $1.3 million. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: At Home

title: Officer Picking Up Where Point Given Left Off
description: Prince Ahmed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia and Bob Baffert have been to Belmont Park before for America's oldest 2-year-old stakes race. In fact, the owner and trainer ran a pretty good horse last year in the Champagne Stakes: Point Given.

title: Digital Printers Cut The PC From the Equation
description: Those intrigued by digital photography but dismayed by all the photo-editing software and expertise required to get a finished print may have cause for celebration. This week Hewlett-Packard introduced printers that eliminate the pesky computer from the process.

title: Researchers Say Gene Is Linked to Language
description: A team of geneticists and linguists say they have found a gene that underlies speech and language, the first to be linked to this uniquely human faculty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASSER, THOMAS
description: GLASSER-Thomas. Age 40 of Summit, New Jersey lost tragically in the terrorist attack at the World Trade Center, September 11, 2001. Loving husband of Meg, devoted father of Dylan and Lukas. Adored son of Dr. Gerald J. Glasser and Anne Glasser, both of Westfield, New Jersey. Brother of Margie and Laura. Beloved son-inlaw to Dr. Herbert and Barbara Bloom. Loved as a brother by Joel, Sam, Billy, Heidi, Patricia and Lisa and friend to many. Tom was a graduate of Haverford College, received his MBA from NYU and was a partner at Sandler O'Neill. Tom's generosity, kindness and friendship was an inspiration to all who where privileged to know him. A celebration of Tom's life will be held Saturday, Oct. 6, 2001 at 3:15 P.M. at the Reevs-Reed Arboretum, 165 Hobart Ave., Summit, New Jersey. Directions and contribution information may be found at: www.sandleroneill.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUFRO, SALWYN
description: SHUFRO-Salwyn. Beloved husband of 71 years of Edna; devoted father of Edward Shufro and Joan Shufro Silverman; grandfather of Joyce Espinosa, Nicholas and Jennifer Shufro, Gregory and Jennifer Shufro, Susanna Silverman, Valerie Silverman and great-grandfather of Zachary and Julia Shufro. Son of Jacob J. and Rebecca P. Shufro. Born in 1905 in New York City. Co-founded Shufro, Rose & Co. in 1938 as a member of the New York Stock Exchange, an investment advisory. Esteemed by partners, friends and employees, he was a man of vision in the investment business. Among his clients were many prominent figures. Services are private. The family will be receiving visitors at Frank E. Campbell, on Thursday, October 4th, 6 PM to 9 PM and at the home of Joan and Ronald Siverman, on Monday, October 8th after 7PM.

title: Governments Intervene to Prop Up Ailing Airlines
description: Deeply embarrassed by the sudden grounding of Swissair on Tuesday, stranding thousands of passengers around the world, the Swiss government stepped in today with a bailout to get the airline flying again.

title: Off Broadway Finds Ways To Keep Shows Open
description: On a good week, many of New York City's hundreds of Off Broadway theaters struggle to make the rent, pay salaries and entice customers to travel to often out-of-the-way venues with less than comfortable seats.

title: Piece-by-Piece Coalition
description: Carefully limited military action against Afghanistan may well begin some time this month, ranking officials here and in London say, but much about it remains uncertain.

title: Stocks Rally on Tax Break Plan And Words From Cisco Chief
description: Stocks rose yesterday after President Bush proposed a hefty package of government spending and tax breaks to revive the national economy, which appears headed toward recession after the terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOUNITZ, JEROME
description: KOUNITZ-Jerome, 84. Of Trenton, NJ on October 1, 2001. Decorated World War II Army Veteran. Beloved husband of Carolyn, devoted father of Jan (Debbie), Martin (Lisa), Lance and Josh Kounitz, Michael (Barbara) Goodman. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Services Friday 10AM at Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 1534 Pennington Road, Trenton, NJ. Burial Union Field Cemetery, Ridgewood, New York.

title: Now That's a Riddle: A Dancing Sphinx
description: Dance Theater of Harlem's first production of ''Sphinx,'' a ballet that Glen Tetley created in 1977 for American Ballet Theater, is downright splendid. With a fantastic set (huge wings flanking a platform), a turbulent score and its distilled drama, the work has grown in theatrical impact.

title: Images to Aid Disaster Relief
description: The run on postcards showing the World Trade Center gave James Danziger, chief executive of Artland.com, the idea of offering 11 high-quality prints by photographers in his stable -- Joel Meyerowitz, Sheila Metzner, Tom Baril and Richard Berenholtz. At right, ''The Twin Towers II'' by Ms. Metzner, $295 unframed. Proceeds go to the New York State World Trade Center Relief Fund. The color and black-and-white photographs are $195 to $295; www.Artland .com.

title: With Cellphones, Who Knows Where the Time Goes?
description: A PROFESSOR I had in college once remarked that Americans are not adequately schooled in making estimates. And if my experience in trying to gauge how many cellphone minutes I've used up is representative of the rest of the population's, we may be in worse trouble than my professor thought.

title: Giants Stress Foe's Talent, Not Record
description: It is called a trap game and Giants Coach Jim Fassel recognizes one when it comes up on the schedule. Fassel used that term today to refer to Sunday's game against the Washington Redskins. With the Giants coming off consecutive victories and the Redskins without a victory and in apparent disarray, Fassel knows some of his players may be looking past Washington to next week's game with the St. Louis Rams.

title: The Investigation So Far
description: The investigation's public focus remained on Europe, with new leads reported in France and Britain. A German magazine reported that a will had been found in the luggage of the hijackers' suspected ringleader.

title: Toward a Balanced Terrorism Bill
description: Resisting heavy pressure to rubber-stamp Attorney General John Ashcroft's carelessly written antiterrorism package, Congress is working diligently to create a bipartisan compromise that respects both civil liberties and national security needs. The White House could aid this process greatly by telling Mr. Ashcroft to desist from making scurrilous remarks suggesting, without any legitimate basis, that lawmakers engaged in this thoughtful balancing process are somehow making the nation vulnerable to another attack.

title: New Stars and Two Debuts In Met's Venerable 'Bohme'
description: The ripple effect from the Sept. 11 attacks continues to be felt in places one might not expect. At the season opening on Monday night of the Metropolitan Opera's ''Bohme,'' it was evident in the absence of the two stars who had been scheduled to appear in the lead roles, Roberto Alagna and Angela Gheorghiu, who canceled in the wake of the events.

title: On the Front Line, Pursuing the God of Peace
description: LIFE as a Christian, a follower of what he unstintingly calls the ''God of Peace,'' has taken the Rev. John Dear, to a North Carolina jail for whacking an F-15E fighter jet with a hammer. (''I didn't even dent it,'' he recalled sheepishly.) It has taken him to Belfast, to Iraq and to a stint in a Salvadoran refugee camp whose misery and poverty, like that in much of the world, he blames on America, the land that he loves.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Community: Confidence Down
description: Last month, business confidence in the euro zone dropped to its lowest level since January 1997, the European Commission said today. The latest survey was conducted before Sept. 11, and attributed the weakening mood to shrinking industrial production in the euro area. Consumer confidence across the European Union, meanwhile, remained flat at a five-year low, the commission said on Tuesday. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: For Refugees, It's Boutique Relief
description: LAST Thursday night, Katie Brophy, 26, invited colleagues over to her place for drinks. Ever since Sept. 11, such escapist rituals -- a glass of wine, watching television on the sofa with good company -- have become precious affirmations of normalcy. But Ms. Brophy's home, once Battery Park City, is now the Royalton hotel, where it's easy to feel outwitted by a bathroom fixture, and where the Kit Kat in the minifridge costs $6.

title: Powell Tries to Allay Worry Of Senators on Muslim Rage
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell took the unusual step of inviting the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to lunch today. His guests emerged satisfied, they said, that the Bush administration would try to alleviate a major concern: that military action against Osama bin Laden would inflame the Muslim world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTON, ALBIN
description: SALTON-Albin. Died September 28, 2001, at the age of 85. He was born in Budapest, Hungary, on August 27, 1916, and came to the United States in 1937. Educated at Queens College, Cambridge, England and at Harvard Business School, Mr. Salton was Managing Director of Lehman Brothers, Inc., prior to his retirement. He was a world traveler and connoisseur of arts and antiques. Mr. Salton's parents, Joseph Tivadar & Emmy of New York, & his sister, Thea Elek of Philadelphia, predeceased him. His wife, the former Anny de Rivera, whom he married in 1968, died in 1997. He leaves his niece, Maria Elek Roberts, her husband Larry, grandniece Teresa, grandnephews Gregory, Bruce and Eric Roberts, together with their families, including two greatgrandnephews. He will be missed by his family and a host of friends in New York and throughout the world. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, 11:30 AM, on October 6, 2001. In accordance with Mr. Salton's request, friends are encouraged to make donations to their favorite charity in lieu of flowers.

title: 2 Drug Makers to Pay $875 Million to Settle Fraud Case
description: A joint venture of Abbott Laboratories and Takeda Chemical Industries agreed yesterday to pay $875 million to settle criminal and civil charges that it had illegally manipulated the Medicare and Medicaid programs.

title: Suspect's Will Suggests a Longtime Plan to Die
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  Mohamed Atta, described by law enforcement officials as the ringleader of the Sept. 11 hijackers, left a will in which he said he wanted to be buried "next to good Muslims," with his corpse pointed east toward Mecca, the officials said.

title: Gain for Trade Bill That Some See as Aid in Terrorism Fight
description: House lawmakers announced a compromise agreement today that would give President Bush the authority to negotiate trade accords with limited Congressional involvement, a tool the Bush administration says will help it recruit allies in the fight against terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNDELL, MONSIGNOR JOSEPH J.
description: MUNDELL-Monsignor Joseph J. Monday, Oct. 1, 2001, Washington D.C. Beloved brother of Mary Catherine Coffey, Anne Mundell Creed, and the late Reverend James Mundell, M.M. Also surviving are four nieces and nephews. Visitation Thursday, October 4th 3PM with Vigil Mass at 7:30PM at the Immaculate Conception Church, 8th & N Sts NW. Mass of Christian burial Friday October 5th 11 A.M. at the Immaculate Conception Church. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Immaculate Conception School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHAN, MICHAEL
description: KAHAN-Michael. The City University of New York mourns the untimely passing of Michael Kahan, esteemed Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College since 1973, and University Fellow for Special Projects this year. A popular teacher and dedicated mentor, his classes on the American Presidency and Middle East Affairs were always oversubscribed. He was a passionate advocate for CUNY's educational mission. Professor Kahan was a member of the University Faculty Senate Executive Committee, scholar, expert and commentator on local and national politics, and activist in national debates over issues such as gun control, school vouchers, and affirmative action. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved family. He will be sorely missed. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr. Vice Chairman Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about people who have been declared missing at the World Trade Center misstated the relationship between Robert Chin, a 33-year-old Xerox employee who worked at Fiduciary Trust, and Suk Tan Chin, who posted an inquiry on that company's Web site. He was her younger brother and only sibling, not her youngest brother.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Peace Force Gets French Commander
description: A French general, Marcel Valentin, has taken command of the multinational peacekeeping force in Kosovo, the first Frenchman to command the force since it was formed two years ago. He said Kosovo is approaching a ''historic junction'' next month when it will elect an assembly and a president, and he promised to continue the work of his predecessor to improve security.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Grown Man Meditates On a Young Man's Game
description: HOOP ROOTS

title: Yielding (or Not) to the Magic of Exotica
description: ARCANUM: OF STEAMWORKS

title: San Antonio Journal; A Forum Recalls Unheeded Warnings
description: A certain I-told-you-so atmosphere wafts through the speeches and conversations of former intelligence officials, army special forces commanders and police chiefs attending a security industry convention here.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rulings In Embassy Bombing Case
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has refused to dismiss charges against or grant a new trial for two men convicted in connection with the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa, which the authorities say were masterminded by Osama bin Laden. The judge, Leonard B. Sand, said Tuesday that there was no merit to arguments by the two defendants, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, a Saudi man who helped to deliver the bomb in Nairobi; and Wadih El-Hage, who was convicted of terrorism conspiracy. Two other convicted defendants did not file motions; all four men are to be sentenced this month. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Doctor Set For Trial
description: A family-practice doctor who has been charged with illegally selling prescriptions for OxyContin, a heroinlike pain reliever, is scheduled to go on trial on Dec. 10. The doctor, Kevin J. Lickfield of Marlton, has pleaded not guilty to charges that he earned $4,000 to $6,000 a week selling signed prescriptions for OxyContin, a drug used by cancer patients that has been linked to more than 100 overdose deaths in southern New Jersey and Philadelphia in the last two years. Dr. Lickfield was released Tuesday on $150,000 bail.

title: Quick Fixes to Aid An Ailing Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Disabled Take Part In Water Marathon
description: A club for disabled athletes and the New York City Sports Commission will be holding the city's first kayak marathon on Saturday, with 24 kayakers paddling 26.2 miles around Manhattan.

title: U.S. TAKES BIG ROLE IN AIRLINES' CRISIS
description: Using power granted by emergency legislation, the federal government is taking on its biggest role in shaping the nation's airlines since the industry was deregulated a generation ago, government officials and airline executives say.

title: Corrections
description: Two pictures in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about risks and benefits of transplanting animal organs into people were reversed. Dr. David K. Cooper, an immunologist at the Massachusetts General Hospital, was at the left, and Jonathan S. Allan, D.V.M., a scientist at the Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research, at the right.

title: Making a Case Against bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WURTZEL, MORRIS
description: WURTZEL-Morris. September 29, 2001, age 92. Dedicated and caring husband of Claire. Beloved father of Sheila, Beverly and Phyllis. Loving grandfather of David, Lesley, Ilene, Deborah, Richard and Robert. Proud great grandfather of Sara, Jessica, Rachel, Jacob, Cameron, Carter, Brandon and Bailey. Adored uncle of Myra, Brian, Laurie and Jeremy. He was a ''man for all seasons'' and will be soely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALEXANDER, SHEPARD L.
description: ALEXANDER-Shepard L. Who passed away on September 12 at the age of 100 will be remembered at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University on October 9. The memorial service will begin at 1PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Shepard L. Alexander Scholarship Fund of Columbia College will be most appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, EDWARD
description: RYAN-Edward. Age 42. Missing at the site of the World Trade Center tragedy, September 11, 2001. A memorial Mass will be celebrated at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church White Plains Post Road, Scarsdale, NY on Saturday, October 6, 2001 at 10:45AM. He is survived by his wife Diane, children Edward, Megan, Joseph and Kelly along with the Ryan and Kettenacker families. He was First Vice President of Carr Futures. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made C/O Diane Ryan for the benefit of Edward, Megan, Joseph and Kelly Ryan or the Edward Ryan Memorial Fund C/O Wendy Phelps, both at 1199 Ulster Ave, Kingston, New York 12401.

title: Ninth Man Held in Suspected Plot Against Paris Embassy
description: PARIS, Oct. 3  A young Frenchman of Algerian background, extradited here from Britain over the weekend, today was ordered held and placed under formal investigation, becoming the ninth suspect in a case that may link Osama bin Laden with a plot to blow up the United States Embassy in Paris, French officials and newspapers reported.

title: A Roman God Watches Over Straphangers
description: The ancient Romans assigned the job of protecting travelers to the god Mercury, and his image is now at work at the Clinton-Washington Avenues station in Brooklyn (the G train). Near the token booth, on space normally reserved for ads, neighborhood artists have hung eight paintings. Mercury, right, by John Woodrow Kelley, floats on clouds near a dreamlike rolling landscape by Josh Dorman and a depiction of a scrupulously neat 1940's subway car by Gwynne Duncan (not shown). Mr. Kelley said that clouds in his artwork ''represent infinity, the unknown the human soul proceeds toward.'' On Lafayette Avenue. No token necessary. EVE M. KAHN

title: Suspect's Will Suggests a Longtime Plan to Die
description: Mohamed Atta, described by law enforcement officials as the ringleader of the Sept. 11 hijackers, left a will in which he said he wanted to be buried ''next to good Muslims,'' with his corpse pointed east toward Mecca, the officials said.

title: Energetic, Young Coach Is Popular With Players
description: Peter Laviolette, the Islanders' young and energetic new coach, actually finds time in his daily schedule to do things other than worry about hockey. For example, he usually sleeps once a day. He joked earlier this week that he does not wake up his wife, Kristen, and engage in chalk talks with her in the middle of the night.

title: Chinatown, Its Streets Empty, Quietly Begins to Take Action
description: Though it was spared physically on Sept. 11, the Chinatown that President George W. Bush visited yesterday showed signs of trauma most everywhere, from jobless workers to streets with barricades to shops teetering on bankruptcy.

title: When the Palmtop Is Almost a PC
description: In today's Circuits section, I reviewed the latest batch of Pocket PC's -- palmtop computers that run the latest version of Microsoft's Windows CE operating system.

title: Subdivided and Licensed, There's No Place Like Art
description: CALIFORNIA landscapes have long served as laboratories for social experiments, from the visionary to the flaky. On Sept. 8, several hundred people gathered on former ranchland 35 miles northeast of San Francisco to see the latest chapter, writ in cute cottages and mock-cobblestone driveways. The housing development, still under construction, is called the Village, a Thomas Kinkade Community. With narrow streets, stone pillars and picket fences, it evokes a nostalgic homeyness, imposed on Vallejo's bare, sunburned hills.

title: Sentiment Is Rising in Japan for a More Muscular Military
description: In Japan, the American declaration of war on international terrorism has already had one dramatic, if largely unintended, effect: pushing this country's debate over the role of its armed forces further in the last three weeks than in the previous three decades.

title: The Harvest Moon
description: Tuesdays full moon is also the harvest moon. In two out of three years this title is usually bestowed upon the September full moon, but Tuesdays full moon comes the closest to the autumnal equinox so this year it falls in October.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Fox To Visit Bush And Giuliani
description: President Vicente Fox visits President Bush today to discuss border security issues and to promote broad immigration reforms. Mr. Fox's hastily arranged visit to the United States is also a response to criticism that the Mexican government has not forcefully expressed its support for the United States during the terrorism crisis. Later today Mr. Fox is scheduled to travel to New York to tour the wreckage of the World Trade Center with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Aide to Clinton Joins the Race For Helms Seat
description: Erskine B. Bowles, a former chief of staff in the Clinton White House, announced yesterday that he would run as a Democrat for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANAVAN, SEAN T.
description: CANAVAN-Sean T. age 39, of Valley Stream, L.I. and Bayridge, Brooklyn. Died tragically on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Member of the Bayridge AOH and the NYC District Council of Carpenters, Local 608. Beloved son of Kieran and Rose. Loving brother of Ciaran, Kathleen McKeon, Teresa McCaffery, Celine Traynor and the late Dermot. Also grieving are many nieces, nephews and extended family in both New York and Ireland. Memorial Mass Saturday October 6, 2001 at 1:30pm at St. Boniface RC Church, 631 Elmont Rd., Elmont, NY. For further information contact the O'Brien-Sheipe Funeral Home, Elmont, NY.

title: More Love the Police but Fewer Want to Join
description: The public affection for police officers demonstrated so visibly in roadside signs and standing ovations at ball games since the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center has had little impact on the Police Department's efforts to recruit new members or stave off retirements, according to city and union officials.

title: Hmmph. Fuzzy Indeed.
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Storrs: College Student Found Dead
description: A University of Connecticut student was found dead on the floor of his dormitory room, the campus police said. An autopsy has been scheduled but the police said there was no evidence of a crime. The student, Peter Gwiazdowski, 20, a junior from West Haven, was found in Eddy Hall on Tuesday night.

title: For the Weary, Pillows to Fall Back On
description: BUYING a bed pillow used to mean choosing a standard rectangle filled with down or the same size rectangle filled with synthetic fiber or foam rubber. One size, three fillings. Now, you can lose a night's sleep over the choices. There are pillows for backaches, neck aches and leg aches. Then there are the fills, from feathers, down and Dacron to space-age gels and foams that respond to body size, shape and temperature.

title: Times E-Mail Report
description: NYTimes.com, the Web site of The New York Times, said yesterday that it would introduce a free, daily e-mail newsletter starting on Monday and focusing on financial news.

title: Nissan Workers Reject Bid to Join Union in Tennessee
description: The latest effort by the United Automobile Workers to organize a plant operated by a foreign automaker failed late last night in Smyrna, Tenn., as Nissan workers voted more than 2 to 1 to reject the union.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: New York's Economy: Grim

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODELL, ALBERT
description: MODELL-Albert. A gentle man adored by all who knew him. We will always cherish the love and laughter we shared. Cousins Selma Modell Rosen Doris and Norman Tipograph Shelby and Bill Modell

title: Super Bowl Stays Put
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: A Rights Court For East Timor
description: The government announced that it would set up a special court to prosecute soldiers and officials accused of rights abuses in East Timor in 1999. Two dozen people have been named as possible defendants, but several key figures, including the former armed forces chief, General Wiranto, are not among them. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Fighting Frogs With Caffeine
description: State agriculture officials said they had obtained preliminary federal approval to begin spraying an unlikely pesticide, concentrated caffeine, in wooded areas to kill hundreds of noisy tree frogs rarely found outside the Caribbean. The tiny frog, the coqu, is ubiquitous in Puerto Rico, and is believed to have arrived in Hawaii in recent years as a stowaway on imported houseplants. While residents have complained that the frogs' screeching mating calls are keeping them awake, environmental officials worry that the frogs pose a threat to native spiders and crickets. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: Mapping the Hazards To Keep Rescuers Safe
description: WHEN Glenn Sekins arrived on Sept. 12 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, a staging area for rescue operations after the attacks on the World Trade Center, he took a black felt-tip marker and drew a crude map of the streets and buildings at the disaster site on a piece of cardboard left over from a trade show.

title: An Effective, Responsible Stimulus
description: President Bush got more specific yesterday about what he wants to do to help the economy. During a trip to meet with business leaders in New York, Mr. Bush revealed he was aiming for $60 billion to $75 billion in tax cuts and new spending, over and above the $40 billion already pledged for recovery from the terrorist attacks. It was a promising start, and the administration should now start working with Congress to deliver a stimulus package as quickly as possible.

title: Birdies Earn Mielke Met P.G.A. Title
description: Mark Mielke birdied the final two holes and shot a four-under-par 70 for a 54-hole total of 204 to overtake Carl Alexander and win the Izod/Lincoln Met P.G.A. championship at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Information on Classes
description: FOR information on community emergency response classes, call the county or state emergency management offices. They are listed in the government section of the phone book.

title: Travel Fears End Plans for China Bout
description: The promoter Don King has agreed not to hold the Nov. 25 heavyweight title fight between John Ruiz and Evander Holyfield in China because of security concerns raised by Home Box Office, which will broadcast the fight, an official at Don King Productions said.

title: This Exception to a Rule Is More Valid Than the Rule
description: For a century and more, social players have insisted on ''covering an honor with an honor.'' Unfortunately, there are so many exceptions to this guideline that it has little validity.

title: Making More Calendars In Microsoft Outlook
description: Q. Can I have more than one calendar in Microsoft Outlook, perhaps one for a special project and one for regular appointments?

title: 'Super' Heroin Was Planned By bin Laden, Reports Say
description: The terror network headed by Osama bin Laden has tried to develop a high-strength form of heroin that it planned to export to the United States and Western Europe, according to intelligence reports received by United States officials.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNISOURCE ENERGY CORP., Tucson, operator of Tucson Electric Power Co., said it had sold its 26 percent stake in an electricity generating facility in Curaao to an undisclosed buyer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Evacuated
description: Two people were evacuated from a three-story building at 783 Eighth Avenue last night after the facade bowed on one side. After responding to reports from onlookers just after 8 p.m. of a gaping crack next to a second-story window of the building, which is between 47th and 48th Street, police and firefighters closed off several blocks along Eighth Avenue to traffic. Traffic resumed at 9 p.m., when an inspection found no imminent threat that the building would collapse, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOLINS, CLAIRE (NEE ROTHSTEIN)
description: TOLINS-Claire (nee Rothstein). Loving wife of the late Albert Tolins. Devoted mother of Roger Tolins and mother-in-law of Doris Tolins. Cherished grandmother of Fran and Joshua Weingast and Jonathan Tolins. Beloved great grandmother of Arielle & Joanna Weingast. Dear sister of Anne Gerber and Rose Kester & sisterin-law of Harold Kester. She will be affectionately remembered by numerous nieces and nephews & countless friends and neighbors. Claire had a distinguished career of more than thirty years with the NYC Board of Education as a teacher and administrator. She was the recipient of the Grand Street Boys Award as one of the ''Ten Best Teachers in New York City.'' After retirement from her teaching career, Claire devoted her life to community service. She was elected and served as the first woman Commissioner of the City of Hallandale, Florida. She also served as a member of Hallandale's Development Review Board. For many years, Claire was the President of Fairways Hadassah in Hallandale. An inspiration to all, she lived each day with boundless energy. Services Friday, Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1921 Pembroke Road, Hollywood, Florida, at 9:00 A.M. Donations in Claire's memory may be sent to Hadassah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACK, MARTHA
description: HACK-Martha. Died Oct. 2. Golden Rule W&L for 67 years. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street & Amsterdam Ave Thursday, Oct 4, 1:30PM. Survived by Norma, Nina and Mary Ginsberg. No flowers, please.

title: Islamic Jihad, Forged in Egypt, Is Seen as bin Laden's Backbone
description: It was the marksman's equivalent of threading a needle on the run.

title: Amex Seat, at a Discount
description: An American Stock Exchange seat sold this week for $410,000, down $95,000, or 19 percent, from the previous sale in August and the first since the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center. The sale, on Tuesday, was the lowest price for an Amex seat in two years, said Bart Liang, a partner in PBL Partners in Chicago, which owns 162 seats on the four largest options markets. He cited a sale as high as $675,000 a year ago. Statistics were not immediately available from the exchange. Each seat conveys the right to trade on the exchange. The exchange's floor was closed for three weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks. For two weeks, Amex stock and exchange-traded fund trading took place at the rival New York Stock Exchange while the Philadelphia Stock Exchange was host to Amex options trading.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Far East Hit By Forest Fires
description: Some 35 forest fires have ravaged almost 200 square miles in Russia's far east near the China border this week, officials said. The Emergencies Ministry said its firefighting efforts were hamstrung by a lack of equipment; only one airplane and two helicopters are in use, said a spokeswoman in Khabarovsk, only miles from the fire zone. Carbon dioxide levels in Khabarovsk were said to be five times higher than what is considered safe.

title: Travel Fears End Plans for China Bout
description: The promoter Don King has agreed not to hold the Nov. 25 heavyweight title fight between John Ruiz and Evander Holyfield in China because of security concerns raised by Home Box Office, which will broadcast the fight, an official at Don King Productions said.

title: Before Opening Up, a Laptop Looks for Matching Prints
description: The release of a new Acer laptop this week seemed perfectly timed for a suddenly suspicious era. The TravelMate 740 notebook has a fingerprint-recognition sensor built into its palm rest that can help wary users restrict access to sensitive data. If the correct fingerprint is not offered during start-up, the machine refuses to boot.

title: Online Karaoke Preserves Your Version of 'Lean on Me'
description: Karaoke may be brutal on sober ears, but until recently it has had one fortunate characteristic: performances were ephemeral. A singer might stand up to belt out a Bette Midler tune, but after the last awkward note, it was possible to forget that the mangling ever happened.

title: Sports of The Times; Different Strokes For Rivals
description: BRUCE SMITH'S voice was muffled on a speaker phone yesterday, but his underlying message was crystal clear. Just three games into the season, the high-priced, built-to-win-now Washington Redskins were near meltdown.

title: Ferrer and Green Battle in Debate Over Claim of Divisiveness
description: Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer battled last night over Mr. Ferrer's promise to be the mayor for ''the other New York.'' Mr. Green denounced his opponent's central campaign theme as ''divisive,'' while Mr. Ferrer responded that his opponent for the Democratic mayoral nomination was ''denigrating the issues that I've raised.''

title: Bonds Sets Record, but Not the One He Wants
description: When Barry Bonds walked yet again in the sixth inning tonight, they did not stop the game and give him the ball. The Houston Astros had already given him enough balls.

title: Dell Stands by Profit Outlook, Surprising Many on Wall St.
description: The Dell Computer Corporation ( news/quote ), which has been aggressively cutting prices to win market share, surprised Wall Street today by announcing that it would meet its profit and sales forecasts for the quarter.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Mayor With a Camera

title: The Next Mayor's Job
description: New York's next mayor faces one of the most daunting challenges in the city's history -- rebuilding after the World Trade Center attack last month. The two remaining Democratic candidates are now telling voters how they would tackle the job. It is important to listen. All campaign promises made before Sept. 11 that involve new spending have become virtually irrelevant. The most important question in this disrupted but crucial mayoral election is who has the skills, depth and fortitude to handle the rebuilding and the enormous budget gap that the attack helped create.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Storage Equipment Battle Escalates
description: The Quantum Corporation went to court yesterday in an unsuccessful effort to stop the Imation Corporation from selling data storage tape drives made under a license granted by Quantum in 1999. The suit, filed in California state court in Santa Clara County, came two days after Imation filed its own lawsuit accusing Quantum of, among other things, seeking to fix storage equipment prices and to restrict market access by refusing to approve Imation's products. Imation began selling its products earlier this week without obtaining Quantum's approval, as required under the original license. Michael A. Brown, the Quantum chief executive, said Imation's drives had failed to meet Quantum's reliability and compatibility standards. A hearing on Quantum's request for a restraining order was scheduled for Oct. 26. Imation's antitrust case, proceeding in a federal court in Minnesota, seeks $450 million in damages and an injunction against anticompetitive behavior. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Brodeur's Extension Lucrative
description: The Devils responded yesterday to the wishes of Martin Brodeur, the cornerstone of the franchise, by signing him to a five-year extension worth about $40 million. Under the deal, first revealed by Brodeur's lawyers yesterday and confirmed by the goalie last night, the last year of the contract is an option year with many incentives.

title: Lawmakers Backing Plans On Terrorism And Licenses
description: With patriotic pomp, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco today offered a legislative response to the Sept. 11 terror attacks, including $9 million for antiterrorism intelligence gathering and a new state driver's license that would be harder to forge.

title: Imagining John Lennon, In a Time Of Anguish
description: When the TNT cable channel planned ''Come Together,'' its tribute to John Lennon, the show was going to be a benefit for gun-control groups, a concert ''in support of a nonviolent world.'' After the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, it inevitably changed. The rescheduled concert, which was broadcast live on Tuesday night from Radio City Music Hall on the WB network and on TNT, became a benefit for relief efforts through the Web site www.helping.org.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAY, ROBERT J. JR.
description: SHAY-Robert J. Jr. Of Great Kills, SI, on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Dawn (nee Turkus). Loving father of Robert J. III and Ryan. Dear son of Robert and Maureen Shay. Loving brother of Jimmy, Michael, Maureen, Eileen, Kathleen, Leanne and Carolyn Shay. Funeral Mass on Friday, October 5th, 1 PM, at St. Clare's RC Church, 110 Nelson Avenue, Staten Island. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Shay Childrens Education would be appreciated.

title: In America; First Person Singular
description: This year's mayoral race was Mark Green's to lose.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Groups Urge Delay On 'Charitable Choice'
description: Forty-four religious, civil liberties, labor and education groups have sent a letter to President Bush urging him to postpone action on his ''charitable choice'' proposal to give government money to religious charities. The letter is a response to statements from White House advisers that the proposal has a better chance in the wake of the terrorist attacks. The groups, most of which already opposed the proposal, said, ''This is no time to divide us along religious lines.'' Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Easing the Signal Squeeze for Satellite TV
description: ONE of satellite television's oft-heard selling points has been the quality of its digital pictures and sound. But some direct-broadcast satellite subscribers have found that ''digital'' cannot necessarily be equated with ''good.''

title: Britain Hears Proposals To Relax Immigration
description: Addressing the dual problems of illegal immigration and a clandestine economy that exploits unskilled workers, the home secretary proposed today to introduce American-style work permits to let greater numbers of foreigners seek jobs here.

description: Here, in a bustling college town where Greyhound is often the next best thing to having your own set of wheels for getting home, news of the bus attack in Tennessee early this morning left students wondering, Is anything safe anymore?

title: Americans Are Target Of Radicals In Indonesia
description: Sweeping: It is an English word that has taken on an unsettling meaning in Indonesia.

description: Jennifer Schaefer-McCoy canceled her vacation plans last summer so she could pay a scalper $1,425 for three tickets to Cal Ripken's final home game at Camden Yards on Sept. 23.

title: Attack Investigation Runs Through Utah and Its Brigade of Language Experts
description: Here along the busiest freeway in the state, about 25 miles south of downtown Salt Lake City and nearly 2,000 miles from the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, is another kind of ground zero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVAS, ANTHONY
description: SAVAS-Anthony. Of Astoria, NY, tragically on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Tony was a construction inspector for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey working on the 88th floor of the North Tower. Tony saw front line action during the Korean War and helped save lives there and during the 1993 bombing of the Twin Towers. He loved $2 cigars, dancing, his country and his family. Family and friends will remember Tony for his tremendous wit, boundless sense of humor and joy of life. His children will always admire him for his devotion, example of fairness and unparalleled perseverance. Tony was a committed husband, devoted father and proud grandfather. He is survived by his wife Phaedra, his children Sandra Savas, Christina Christman, and John Savas; daughter-in-law Bernadine Savas and son-in-law Robert Christman; and grandchildren Jessica and John. Reposing: Basis Funeral Home, 27-12 23rd Ave., Astoria, NY, Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral liturgy, St. Demetrios G.O. Cathedral, 30-11 30th Drive, Astoria, Saturday 10:15 AM. in lieu of flowers donations to the American Red Cross and Salvation Army would be greatly appreciated.

title: Bush Differs With Bill on the U.S. Role at Airports
description: The Bush administration today sought to scale back a Senate bill that would have federal workers assume the role of screening passengers and baggage at airports. The administration proposed instead that such federalization become an option, but not a requirement, for the Transportation Department.

title: Only Certainty To Economists Is Dire Outlook
description: As President Bush met with corporate executives yesterday to discuss the national economy, New York politicians, economists and business leaders began to grapple with an economic outlook that ranges from awful to appalling.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Former Mayor Wins A New Term
description: Albuquerque has a new, but familiar, mayor. Martin Chvez, 49, a Democrat who was mayor from 1993 to 1997, led the nonpartisan mayoral race on Tuesday with 31 percent of the vote in a field of seven candidates. The incumbent mayor, Jim Baca, also a Democrat, tied for third with about 11 percent of the vote. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about people who are in danger of losing health insurance because of the terrorist attacks misstated the percentage of those eligible under federal law who pay to continue their coverage after losing jobs. It is 20 percent, not 80.

title: Mets Feel a Bit Out of It, But Secure a .500 Finish
description: For the first time since the final day of the 1997 season, the Mets played a game in which they were not alive for a playoff spot. It felt odd, and Manager Bobby Valentine's lineup reflected that. Six regular players had the night off.

title: EL PASO ENERGY TO BUY GAS ASSETS FOR $283 MILLION
description: El Paso Energy Partners L.P., owner of natural gas and oil pipelines in the Gulf of Mexico, agreed to buy a gas-processing plant and a stake in offshore pipelines in two separate transactions valued at $283.5 million. The publicly traded partnership, which was set up by the El Paso Corporation, said it acquired the Chaco gas processing plant in New Mexico from a consortium of banks for $198.5 million. El Paso Energy Partners also acquired the 50 percent of Deepwater Holdings L.L.C. it did not already own from the El Paso Corporation for $85 million. The Deepwater joint venture owns the High Island Offshore System, a 204-mile pipeline system that brings gas from the Gulf of Mexico to interstate pipelines onshore. The El Paso Corporation and the El Paso Energy partnership created the Deepwater venture.

title: Famous Faces With Pull Get Into Disaster Zone
description: Don King did not take no for an answer, but Elton John did. Barbara Walters took matters into her own hands. Reggie Jackson? The governor of New York plans to take care of him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Faster Cellphones
description: A leading operator of mobile phones, NTT DoCoMo Inc., expects to begin faster cellphone service in Europe in the second half of 2002, said its president, Keiji Tachikawa. DoCoMo expects Hutchison 3G UK Holdings Ltd., the British-based telecommunications unit of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., led by the the Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing, to start the services. DoCoMo owns 20 percent of Hutchison 3G. DoCoMo, based in Tokyo, has spent about 600 billion yen ($5 billion) for stakes in European cellphone companies.

title: Karachi Journal; In a City of Everyday Mayhem, Things Get Worse
description: Sometimes he brings in the living, sometimes he brings in the dead and sometimes he merely gathers the pieces. Driving an ambulance in Karachi is bloody work for Sardar Ahmeel, but it is regular.

title: Fidelity Investments Agrees To Help Rescue Colt Telecom
description: Fidelity Investments agreed today to bail out the Colt Telecom Group, a struggling British provider of voice and data services to companies, by helping it to raise roughly 400 million ($590 million) of fresh equity.

title: 'Hijacking' in India Turns Out to Be False Alarm
description: The widely reported midair hijacking of a Boeing 737 jet on its way from Bombay to New Delhi this morning turned out to be a false alarm, authorities said.

title: Vastness of Request Is Greeted by Doubts
description: It is a breathtaking laundry list of need: $18 billion to clean up and rebuild Lower Manhattan, $12.5 billion in expected losses in state and city tax revenues, $3 billion in overtime and other staffing demands and $2 billion to replace fire trucks and other equipment.

title: Tanglewood-Style Season Planned for the Poconos
description: Plans for the inaugural season of the Mountain Laurel Center for the Performing Arts, a 675-acre Tanglewood-in-the-Poconos, were announced yesterday, along with more than $30 million in government grants and loans to support the project.

title: 6 Killed in Greyhound Crash in Tennessee After Passenger Slits Driver's Throat
description: A passenger on a Greyhound bus slashed the neck of the driver early this morning, and as the two men struggled for control of the steering wheel, the bus careered across two lanes of oncoming traffic on an Interstate highway and flipped over, killing the assailant and five other passengers, law enforcement officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Agha Saeed, national chairman of the American Muslim Alliance, referred incorrectly in some copies to one of the universities where he is a professor. It is California State University at Hayward, not Caltech.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Homestore Profit To Miss Estimates
description: Homestore.com, the largest home-sales site on the Web, said its third-quarter earnings would be lower than it had projected, mainly as a result of the deteriorating online advertising market. The company, based in Westlake Village, Calif., also said its business had been hurt by the attacks on Sept. 11 because its sales staff had been forced to cancel customer visits. Homestore.com now projects third-quarter revenue of $114 million to $118 million and a third-quarter pro forma loss of 1 cent to 6 cents a share. The company had been expected to earn 16 cents a share on sales of $131.5 million. Realtor.com, Homestore's largest site, is the official Web site of the National Association of Realtors, with roughly 1.3 million home listings, or 90 percent of all online home listings. Homestore shares slid 85 cents, or 12.1 percent, to $6.20. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Police To Re-Enter Rebel Areas
description: Interior Minister Ljube Boskovski said police patrols were preparing to re-enter rebel-held areas. Two shooting incidents overnight showed that rebels who should have disarmed still seem to be present, he said. The announcement took NATO-led peacekeepers by surprise; the government has yet to pass an amnesty for rebel fighters, and has not approved the package of political reforms as part of the peace process.

title: In Little Time, Pop Culture Is Almost Back to Normal
description: As the country moves past its initial period of shock over last month's terrorist attacks, and movie releases and the opening of the television seasons return to their normal rhythm, what's most striking is how unchanged the appetite for popular culture seems to be.

title: Turning the Page To a Fresh Worldview
description: AS the shock of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 gives way to anticipation of an American response, anyone with an Internet connection has access to sources of international news and opinion that were once the preserve of intelligence analysts and diplomats: local newspapers all over the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAZIOSO, TIMOTHY
description: GRAZIOSO-Timothy. The New York Chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International records with deep sorrow the passing of our dear friend and member of the Board of Directors, Tim Grazioso, who has been missing following the World Trade Center tragedy on September 11, 2001. Tim joined the Chapter Board of Directors in 1996 and served the Chapter in the past as Vice President of Finance. He had just begun a term as Vice President of Fundraising. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Debbie, loving children Briana and Lauren, and his entire family. Lawrence B. Sorrel, President JDRF/New York Chapter Alexandra Ziogas Executive Director JDRF/New York Chapter

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Strike At Aluminum Smelter
description: More than a third of the 750 unionized workers at the country's huge aluminum smelter went on strike and were being immediately laid off, the smelter's biggest shareholder, B. H. P. Billiton, said. Labor-management tension over pay, working conditions and the employment of expatriates has been brewing since early this year when there was a brief work stoppage at the smelter, and the company said the latest labor action was illegal because the workers' union had not exhausted other settlement options. The smelter has been a key part of the impoverished country's strong economic growth.

''Deke'' DiClemente, legendary Phillips Academy basketball, soccor coach, who died Sept. 28, 2001, will be held at 3PM Saturday, Oct. 27, in Cochran Chapel, Phillips Academy, Andover, MA. Donations in his memory may be made to Trustees of Phillips Academy 180 Main St, Andover, MA. 01810.

Pei, Ian Bader has helped create many large buildings, including courthouses, colleges and the renovated Louvre. But there's one building, he says, that ''I get to do all by myself'' -- a 14-by-18-foot pavilion in his family's backyard in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

description: GRUNWALD-Lotte (Moses). November 15, 1915-October 2, 2001. Daughter of the late Jennie (Posen) and Hugo Moses. Beloved wife of the late Kurt Grunwald. Loving mother of daughter Cecille and son-in-law Morgan Alexander Gunst and son Roger Hugh Grunwald. Grandmother of Marissa and Martin Gunst. Loving sister of Anne Bodenheimer and the late Ilse Moses and aunt of Howard Bodenheimer. A great loss to all including her cousins, nieces, nephews and friends. Her love of lifeof the arts, travel and her family gave her joy. Her humility and decency will always be remembered. Memorial gifts may be sent to Shaare Zedek Medical Center, Jerusalem 12, Bayit St., Jerusalem 91031, Israel and The All Stars Project, Inc., 500 Greenwich St, 2nd Flr, New York, N.Y. 10013. title: Britain Tracing Trail Of One More Jihad Group
description: Since the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States, the British police have been hunting down suspected Islamic militants and investigating the activities of a shadowy organization called Sakina Security Services. On its Web site, the group offers young Muslim men the ''ultimate jihad experience'' of training in military techniques using live ammunition.

title: Players in Motion All Over N.H.L.
description: When the N.H.L. shuffled its deck this summer, many aces and face cards were dealt to different hands. It will happen again in February, when world-class stars reassemble on various national teams for the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City. In both configurations, the talents and personalities of these rosters will take some getting used to.

title: In Crisis Zone, a Wireless Patch
description: MOST people looking up at Lower Manhattan's skyline the week after the World Trade Center attacks were contemplating what was no longer there. Nathanial Freitas was looking for help. Hoping to find a way to restore his company's downed Internet connection, he stared up at the windows across the street from his firm's SoHo office and wondered who might be browsing the Web over there. What he hoped to find was a company that was still online and would be willing to share its high-speed link to the Internet.

title: House Panel Approves Bill Expanding Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  By a vote of 36 to 0, the House Judiciary Committee approved a bill tonight that would give law enforcement officials broad new authority to investigate terrorist suspects.

title: Totaling Up the Damage, and Not Forgetting the Tips
description: After she graduated from Long Island University's C. W. Post campus with a B.A. in philosophy in May, Kristina Leath felt confident getting a nicer apartment. She had a job as a waitress at Windows on the World, and the money was good.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: State Sues Over Shipwreck
description: More than two years after a freighter, the New Carissa, ran aground on the southern coast of Oregon, the state is suing the ship's owners to force them to remove the remaining part of the 639-foot hull and pay for restoration of the state beach where it rests. The lawsuit, filed on Tuesday in Coos County Circuit Court, says the ship's owner, Green Atlas Shipping; its operator, the TMM Company Ltd; and their parent company, the Taiheiyo Kaiun Company, are trespassing. It asks for nearly $1.5 million in ''storage charges.'' Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: In a Spot: The Bad Guys
description: Publishing is in a muddle after the terrorist attacks and in no way more so than in worrying about the thriller genres. Book people are debating what book people never should: What is acceptable? What kinds of villains wouldn't offend? Do terrorist novels cut too close to the psyche? There's even the apprehension that real life is more dramatic and eventful than plot-twisting thrillers and adventure tales, the fear that life is outstripping and outpacing the fertile imaginations of authors. Why spend $30 or so for a book when your newspaper and television bring you the real thing?

title: Economic Scene; Videoconferencing may at last get the critical mass it needs.
description: WILL the current reluctance to travel stimulate widespread use of videoconferencing? The stock market seems to think so. Shares of companies that specialize in videoconferencing have shot up 30 percent or more in the last two weeks.

title: Martin Has Something to Prove To the Nets, the Fans and Himself
description: In his rookie training camp last year, Kenyon Martin was sweating, scowling and gasping. This was the Nets' top draft pick?

description: To the Editor:

title: Focus of Candidates' Claims Is on Ability to Unite the City
description: Following are excerpts from the debate last night between the two Democratic candidates for mayor, Fernando Ferrer and Mark Green, as recorded by The New York Times. The debate, broadcast on NY1 News, was the first of two required by the Campaign Finance Board in the Democratic runoff.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Petroleum Purchase
description: The BG Group of Britain agreed to buy the oil and natural gas fields of Enron in India for $388 million. The operations include a 30 percent stake in the Tapti gas field and the Panna/Mukhta oil and gas fields, plus 63 percent of an untapped deposit on the country's west coast. BG said the assets held more than 170 million barrels of oil and gas. They do not include Enron's Dabhol Power project, which has been entangled in a nine-month payment dispute with the Maharashtra State Electricity Board. Enron is looking to sell its 64 percent stake in the project for $1.2 billion to cover the cost of its investment. Tata Power and BSES, both of India, have indicated an interest, people close to the talks said. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: OPEC Considers Reducing Oil Production
description: Less than a week after deciding to maintain production levels despite sharply declining oil prices, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is considering a decrease in output by 500,000 barrels a day, said the group's secretary general, Al Rodrguez Araque.

title: The War on Terror Finds Wary Support in France
description: Alain Leforestier grew up in the Normandy region where the military cemeteries offer irrefutable evidence that American soldiers have laid down their lives when France was in need.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILSTEIN, SEYMOUR
description: MILSTEIN-Seymour. Peacefully on October 2nd. Beloved husband of Vivian for 56 years. Most cherished father of Connie and her companion, Jehan - Christophe, Philip and Cheryl. Adored grandfather of Abby and Rick, Joanna, Merrie, Josh, Toby and Larry. Devoted brother of Paul and Gloria. A great man, a man of honor, he was loved and respected by all who knew him. Services private. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, CELIA
description: GOLDSTEIN-Celia. The loving wife of the late Al. Beloved mother of Irving of Las Vegas, Stephen of Washington, DC and Burt of Westfield, NJ. Adored mother-inlaw. Also survived by 6 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Services will be Sunday, 10:00 AM at ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 66th Ave, Rego Park. Contributions may be made to, Make a Wish Foundation-Mid Atlantic, 10920 Connecticut Ave., Kensington, MD. 20894.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLETT, JOSEPH P.
description: KELLETT-Joseph P. Lost in the September 11, 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Kane) Kellett. Adoring father of Julie Anne and Cameron Marie. Loving son of Anne (nee Butler) Kellett and David Kellet. Special nephew of John and James Butler. Devoted brother-in-law of Edward Kane. Also survived by many cousins. Visiting hours Saturday 9 AM-12:30 PM at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Memorial Mass Saturday 1 PM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church.
