In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Julie Anne and Cameron Education Trust Fund, C/O Barry Mahler Esq., 274 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10016, would be greatly appreciated.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro dropped on an unexpected sign that business outside of manufacturing improved in the United States last month. In New York, the euro settled at 91.31 cents, down from 91.86 cents on Tuesday.

title: University of Michigan President Is Nominated to Lead Columbia
description: Lee C. Bollinger, the University of Michigan president who has drawn national attention for his forceful defense of Michigan's affirmative action policies, has been nominated as the next president of Columbia University by its search committee.

title: Health Secretary Testifies About Germ Warfare Defenses
description: Federal health officials said today that they were accelerating production of a new smallpox vaccine, and taking other steps to strengthen the nation's biodefenses.

title: BENEFIT BOUTS
description: Seventeen New York boxing figures, most emerging from retirement, will participate in a series of exhibition bouts Nov. 7 at Gleason's Gym in Brooklyn to benefit the Twin Towers Fund.

title: Blair Lays Out Evidence Pointing to bin Laden
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain today laid out the clearest case yet of Osama bin Laden's involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Bush Offers Extra Aid for Workers Left Jobless by Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  With new data showing unemployment rising sharply, President Bush proposed measures today to help people who lost jobs following the terrorist attacks, and the administration began negotiating in earnest with Congress on broader efforts to revive the flagging economy.

title: Van Gundy Lets Knicks Run, At Least in Training Sessions
description: Jeff Van Gundy is known as the man who bridles thoroughbreds, the coach who disdains the fast break, the suppressor of all that is spontaneous and exciting about basketball.

title: Putin Softens His Stance Against NATO Expansion
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, moving swiftly to capitalize on the newfound solidarity with the West over fighting terrorism, indicated today that he might show flexibility over NATO expansion and agreed with European Union officials to consult monthly on security affairs.

title: WILLIAMS-SONOMA EXPECTS TO MEET PROFIT ESTIMATES
description: Williams-Sonoma Inc., owner of the Pottery Barn and Williams-Sonoma chains, expects to meet third-quarter and annual profit forecasts even as sales fall below previous estimates. Third-quarter earnings will be 5 cents to 7 cents a share and profit this year will be $1.17 to $1.24, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected the company to earn 5 cents in the third quarter, which ends Oct. 28, and $1.15 for the fiscal year, which ends Jan. 3. Sales are lower than forecast as consumers concerned about the economy buy fewer home accessories and kitchen goods after the terrorist attacks.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Passaic: Man Accused Of Bomb Threat
description: A man was charged with making a false bomb threat that prompted the evacuation of 13,000 students in 19 schools. The man, Omar Tecat, 31, of Garfield, was arrested Tuesday, and accused of making calls to three unspecified schools in Passaic and Clifton warning that they would be bombed that morning, the authorities said. It was the sixth bomb threat against Passaic schools since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, said Robert Holster, the district superintendent. The bomb squad has responded to 31 threats statewide, only a fraction of the total reported. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: City Lifts a Ban Against Vehicles, at Least Partly
description: The mayor's Office of Emergency Management announced last night that delivery trucks, taxis, school buses and city shuttles, along with resident vehicles, would be allowed in the southern part of Battery Park City, ending a total traffic ban that left residents angered and isolated for the last three weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, SALLY WEN
description: YOUNG-Sally Wen. 84, American Chinese Socialite and Chairman American Hawaii Cruise Line, San Francisco, Sally died peacefully the evening of October 1, 2001. Sally was born in Shanghai, China, she received her undergraduate degree from Soochow University in China and a graduate degree from Radcliff College. She completed her doctor of jurisprudence from the University of Indiana, although she never practiced law she became a research librarian for Speas Associates of Manhasset, L.I. She was Chairman of San Francisco based American Hawaii Cruise Lines and worked for the Hong Kong shipping magnet, C.Y. Tung. She was married to Dr. Henry L. Wen, a professional engineer and expert in miniature parts manufacturing technology at Singer General Precision. Henry passed away in 1979. Sally lived in San Francisco for the past 23 years. There she met Paul Young, an investor from Taiwan, and they married in 1989. Surviving are her husband Paul, a daughter Harriet Tung of Hong Kong, a son Henry L. Wen Jr. of Danville, CA, shared children Frank, Gary and Elaine Young of Taiwan, grandchildren Leigh Chou of Hong Kong, Pam Tung of New York, Sascha Wen of South Carolina, Bridget Sally and Ryan Wen of California. Services 9 A.M. Sunday, October 7, at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st St, NYC. Interment at Ferncliff Cemetery, Ardsley, NY. In lieu of flowers please send donations in Sally's memory to the Zen Hospice Project, 273 Page Street, San Francisco, CA. 04102-5616.

description: Even James Darling's grandmother called from the state of Washington to find out what was wrong with the Jets' defense.

title: A Garden Gathers Stones and Moss On a Cliff Over the St. Lawrence
description: THE way to Morse and Mary Dial's home is marked by a little black mailbox near this town on the rocky St. Lawrence River. A meadow of goldenrod, Queen Anne's lace and chicory, jagged sumac and arborvitae flanks the narrow gravel drive that winds toward a wash of light that can only mean water.

title: Transcript of the Hempcar Crew's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, October 2, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Scott Furr and Grayson Sigler, also known as the Hempcar Crew, who drove more than 10,000 miles in a car powered by hemp. This discussion was one in a continuing series organized by forum participants.

title: Show the Evidence
description: Although American and British officials say they have ''no doubt'' that Osama bin Laden and the Al Qaeda terrorist organization were behind the crimes of Sept. 11, so far no actual evidence has been made public. The Bush administration has given secret briefings to leaders of NATO and American allies, but the strongest information the public has of a link between Mr. bin Laden and the terrorists' acts is that Mohammad Atta, one of the hijackers, received $100,000 from a source in Pakistan that apparently cannot be definitely identified.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Toxic Leak From Ship
description: The coast guard said a stricken German-owned cargo ship was likely to head for port for repairs after an explosion tore through a hold carrying chemicals and set off a leak of toxic gases, forcing the vessel to anchor near the southeastern English resort of Margate. The vessel, the Bilbao, registered in Antigua, was carrying 3,300 tones of ferrosilicone, which may have exploded when water entered the hold, the coast guard said. Its seven-member crew was reported safe. Alan Cowell (NYT)

She had clients to attend to, she needed the money and, most of all, she longed for something familiar. Her office was one place that did not remind her of Tony.

title: O'Neill Makes His Presence Felt Immediately

O'Neill did a deep knee bend after he finished putting on his uniform, joints cracking like popcorn kernels, then stared at his still-mending foot again. He was a little anxious, a little excited.

title: Securing the Lines Of a Wired Nation

E-mail messages, however, seemed to sail through the crisis to their destinations. The smooth traffic was hailed by many experts as testament to the underlying strength of the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, CHARLES J.

title: Russian Plane From Tel Aviv Crashes Into Black Sea
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4 — A Russian airliner carrying 76 people, including scores of Jewish holiday celebrants, from Tel Aviv to Novosibirsk in central Siberia exploded in flight and plunged into the Black Sea off Russia's coast today.

title: Attacks' Impact on Economy of City Estimated at $90 Billion
description: The attacks that destroyed the World Trade Center could have a $90 billion to $105 billion impact on the economy of New York City, the city's comptroller said today in the first official report estimating the damage.

description: Thomas H. Bailey, the chairman of Janus Capital, the Denver mutual fund company, proved yesterday that he still knows how to sell high.

description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts is undertaking a review for the account of its Sheraton and Westin lodging chains, with billings estimated at $20 million to $30 million. The incumbent, the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, is not taking part.

title: Online Images That Stay True to Form on Any Screen
description: EXPLORING the Web on a cellphone may seem like a good idea when you're constantly on the run, but with sites bursting with graphic images, it's certainly not very easy. You're likely to find yourself staring, say, at a part of a giant logo unless you can find special scaled-down versions of Web sites that many developers have created for wireless users.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Alpine: Lost Hikers Rescued
description: Some 30 hikers in the Palisades Interstate Park lost their way as darkness fell yesterday, but summoned help with cellphones. Five hours later, rescuers led them down to the shore and brought them by boat to safety, the police said. The hikers were walking along the Hudson River shore below the Palisades, said Sgt. Eric Schmidt of the Palisades Interstate Parkway Police. Because so many official boats are on guard duty after the World Trade Center attack, several Closter and Alpine firefighters used their own pleasure boats, Sergeant Schmidt said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: For Fire Dispatchers, Guilt-Tinged Grief
description: Some said they fell back on their training to guide them through the chaos of Sept. 11. Others, with no shame, said they felt like running for the door. But for every fire alarm dispatcher who worked that day, who sent the first rescue workers into the twin towers, who fielded the final calls from people on doomed floors, it is a day that swirls with memories, with tempered pride, with grief and with guilt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIGHE, ROBERT J., JR.
description: TIGHE-Robert J., Jr. On September 3, 2001, in Florida, age 51. Beloved husband of Constance, son of Margaret and the late Robert, Sr., brother of Michael, son-in-law of Eleanor Nagle. A native of NYC, he graduated from Fordham Prep, Boston College and received his MBA from NYU. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on Saturday, October 13, 2001, at 11AM at St. Ignatius Loyola Church at 84th and Park Ave., NYC. "The Siege" is most talked about, with its terrorist attack on New York, but Video Hound's Golden Movie Retriever lists more than 300 titles under the terrorism heading.

title: The Missing and the Dead
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 380 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 321. In all, 4,986 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: The Challenges of Alliance With Russia
description: Throughout the 1990's, any use of force by the United States sent President Boris Yeltsin of Russia into a red-faced fury. No matter the target, he would fulminate about Washington's arrogance, invoke Russia's nuclear might, even warn of World War III. Mr. Yeltsin's outbursts were brief but ferocious, and they reflected a widespread conviction among Russians that deep down, America's interests were different from theirs.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Wednesday and on Sept. 20 about an underground system of transferring money internationally mistranslated the term ''hawala,'' by which it is known. (The error also appeared on Wednesday in the daily capsule summary of the terrorism investigations.) The word, originally Arabic and now used in several languages in Southwest Asia, means a bill of exchange or promissory note, not trust or in trust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DONALD J..
description: COHEN-Donald J.. Dr. was a true giant...world renowned in the field of child and adolescent psychiatry. Uner his leadership, the Yale Child Center became the gold standard for excellence in research, teaching and service. He made the connections between biology, psychoanalysis, and child development understandable and useful. In addition to his pioneering efforts in biological research of Autism and Tourette's syndrome, he was a training analyst and an expert in the development of social interaction in children. He was a founding father in the field of Developmental Psychopathology, which has become a widely used paradigm for conceptualizing psychological well-being and impairment in children. He was at once a true visionary and practical efficient clinician. Using his talents and interest, he impacted the field of child development in everlasting ways worldwide. His singular influence will continue to be transmitted by his pupils in Korea, Turkey, many parts of the former Soviet Union, China and Brazil. He was a forceful, passionate social advocate for children's rights. Undoubtedly, his manifold achievements will be recounted again and again in the tributes paid to him. We, however, will be eternally grateful for two of his great loves: his Jewish heritage and Israel and mentoring the careers of promising young students. A major crystallization of these two passions stands now as the Feinberg Child Study Center at Schneider Children's Medical Center of Israel,...the culmination of over two decades of support and inspiration of young clinicians and his multifaceted approach to understanding children. Together with Dr. Alan Apter, Dr. Itamar Shalit, of Israel, and with the encouragement of Mr. Irving Schneider and the Feinberg family, he conceived the development of a center of excellence in Israel. Its mission is to enhance and serve the welfare of children in Israel as well as the entire troubled region. Our work has just begun. It will be an uphill task without Donald's leadership, but his everlasting inspiration will make the Feinberg Child Study Center a true legacy to this great physician. Dr. Itamar Shalit, Dir., SCMCI Dr. Alan Apter, Director, Feinberg Child Study Center The Staff of the Feinberg Child Study Center

title: Vegetable Pasta With Pesto
description: The sauce for this dish is really a kind of grilled salad in pesto. That blanching also has another function -- it allows for much of the moisture to be forced out of the leaves. The belief among those who use this relatively unfamiliar method (including Tom Colicchio , the chef from Craft and Gramercy Tavern in Manhattan) is that blanching the leaves will preserve the pesto longer (refrigerated) than if raw leaves are used. It also brightens the color of the leaves, which makes the resulting sauce that much more colorful.

description: Pasta is so familiar it's tempting not to think much about it while you throw together some routine dish. But, really, it deserves a little more thought than it usually gets in the kitchen, even among reasonably accomplished cooks.

title: Some Rental Car Companies Lobby for U.S. to Back Loans
description: A coalition of rental car companies has begun lobbying Congress and the White House for a five-year, $1.5 billion package of loan guarantees, saying that they, like the nation's airlines, have been devastated by a plunge in business after the terrorist attacks, officials said yesterday.

title: G.E. and the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Plans to Send $320 Million In Food and Medicine to Afghans
description: President Bush announced today that the United States would try to deliver $320 million in food and medical supplies to help Afghanistan's population survive the approaching winter. The announcement appeared aimed at winning over the Afghan people even as Mr. Bush tries to undermine the Taliban government and perhaps deal it a military blow for harboring Osama bin Laden.

title: BONDS IS UNLEASHED, SMASHING HIS WAY ALONGSIDE McGWIRE
description: Shaking the dust off a bat that had been generally idle in a three-game series while he walked eight times and was hit once, Barry Bonds launched himself into the record book tonight by lashing his 70th home run of the season against a rookie pitcher making only his second major league appearance.

title: Political Memo; McGreevey Faces Test in Renewed Campaign
description: So far, James E. McGreevey has seemed to be waltzing to victory in the New Jersey governor's race. Untested in the Democratic primary and ahead in the polls, he has said little and done less to grab anyone's attention, even as his Republican rival, Bret D. Schundler, has monopolized the spotlight with generally unfavorable results.

title: Michael Berkeley: Everything Was in Place
description: When hot-air tension ballooned, Michael J. Berkeley knew just how to prick it. Once, as he and his wife, Lourdes Perez-Berkeley, were driving in a fancy neighborhood, their car sputtered to a halt. Yet again, Mr. Berkeley, a risk taker, hadn't filled up the tank. Her temper ignited. Mr. Berkeley knew she was itching to shout, ``I told you so!'' But the born charmer grinned and burst out laughing: at himself, their problem, at the lecture he knew she so badly wanted to deliver. His wife couldn't help laughing, too.

title: Bank of England Makes Cut Of Quarter-Point in Key Rate
description: The Bank of England cut its benchmark lending rate by a quarter of a point today, to 4.5 percent, saying that it was worried that the terrorist attacks in the United States would send ripples through the British economy in the form of reduced spending and consumer confidence.

title: Blair Leaves British Awed Or Seething Over His Role
description: Ever eager to cement the putative international coalition against terrorism, Prime Minister Tony Blair flew posthaste to Moscow today to meet President Vladimir V. Putin. In his slipstream he left a nation part awed by statesmanship compared to Gladstone or Churchill -- pillars of Britain's national memory -- and part seething to deny him a place on that pedestal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUFRO, SALWYN
description: SHUFRO-Salwyn. Beloved husband of 71 years of Edna; devoted father of Edward and Marlene Shufro and Joan and Ronald Silverman; grandfather of Joyce Shufro Espinosa, Nicholas and Jennifer Shufro, Gregory and Jennifer Shufro, Susanna Silverman, Valerie Silverman and greatgrandfather of Zachary and Julia Shufro. Son of Jacob J. and Rebecca P. Shufro. Born in 1905 in New York City. Graduate of City College and Harvard Business School. Co-founded Shufro, Rose & Co. in 1938 as a member of the New York Stock Exchange, an investment advisory firm. He was a man of vision and integrity, loved and esteemed by all who knew him. Services are private. The family will be receiving visitors at the home of Joan and Ronald Silverman, on Monday, October 8th after 7PM.

title: Reviews of Current Releases
description: For all New York Times film reviews since 1996, go to the Film Archive .

title: Good Cop, Bad Cop
description: In Antoine Fuqua's ''Training Day,'' Denzel Washington, left, stars as a scheming undercover detective with a new, young partner (Ethan Hawke, right). The film follows them through street incidents that paint a bleak portrait of a dirty cop.

title: Technology Shares Gain as the Broader Market Retreats
description: Technology stocks rose for the third consecutive session yesterday after Dell Computer issued a reassuring earnings outlook, but they closed well off their highs.

title: U.S. Acts On Shortage Of Treasuries
description: The government, which normally announces the sale of Treasury securities well in advance, conducted an immediate auction for the first time yesterday in an effort to ease problems in the Treasury market.

title: Trade-Off by Environmentalists on Rebuilding; Looser Rules for Manhattan Are Backed to Avoid a Bigger Threat: Sprawl
description: Corporate leaders and politicians who argue that New York City must rebuild Lower Manhattan as quickly as possible -- even if it means sidestepping or streamlining some environmental protection rules -- are getting support for their position from what might seem an unlikely quarter: environmentalists.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ex-AremisSoft Executives Accused of Fraud by S.E.C.

title: GENENTECH AND XOMA TO DELAY FILING FOR PSORIASIS DRUG
description: The drug makers Genentech Inc. and Xoma Ltd. said yesterday that they would delay filing for approval of their Xanelim psoriasis drug after the Food and Drug Administration asked for a new study. The companies said they would not file their Xanelim application until next summer because the agency requested an additional study to confirm that the drug used in clinical trials was equivalent to the drug made for commercial purposes. The companies had expected to file by the first quarter of 2002. The agency sought the study after the companies changed manufacturing processes to allow for production of large-scale quantities of Xanelim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIFTER, ELI, PH.D.
description: SEIFTER-Eli, Ph.D. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University notes with profound sorrow the death of Eli Seifter, Professor Emeritus of Surgery and of Biochemistry, and a distinguished member of Einstein's faculty for nearly four decades. Dr. Seifter was a creative and prolific scientist and a widely admired and generous teacher who brought to his teaching an unusual breadth of scholarship and experience, ranging from plant and insect physiology to clinical and pharmacological aspects of biochemistry. We extend our deepest condolences to his brother, our beloved faculty member Sam Seifter, Ph.D., Distinguished University Professor Emeritus of Biochemistry, and to the entire Seifter family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva Unversity

title: Trade Center Leaseholder Pledges to Rebuild
description: The schedule for a Nov. 11 lecture at the Real Estate Institute of New York University called for its moderator, Larry A. Silverstein, to relive his triumph in acquiring a 99-year lease on the World Trade Center, a feat he accomplished in July. Last week, Mr. Silverstein, a real estate developer, decided not to cancel the lecture. Instead, he altered the pamphlet to read, ''The World Trade Center: What Is to Come,'' and did not include a question mark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JAMES F. IV
description: MURPHY-James F. IV. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the tragic death of active member James F. Murphy IV in the terror ist attack on the World Trade Cen ter, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: STRIDE RITE CUTS 120 JOBS AND FORECASTS QUARTERLY LOSS
description: The Stride Rite Corporation, which makes Keds and its namesake brand of children's shoes, said yesterday that it had laid off 20 percent of its administrative employees, cutting 120 jobs, and would report a loss in the fourth quarter of its fiscal year. The loss for the quarter, which ends in November, will be 6 cents to 8 cents a share, and sales will be slightly lower than a year earlier, the company said. Stride Rite, which is based in Lexington, Mass., also said net income in the third quarter, which ended Aug. 31, fell 8 percent to $7.15 million, or 17 cents a share. Sales declined 6.5 percent.

title: Some Workers Are Finding It a Difficult Time to Strike
description: There is never a good time to go on strike, union leaders often say, but the walkout on Monday by nearly 28,000 Minnesota state employees seems to have come at an especially inopportune time.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Governor Fires Economic Official
description: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove fired the director of the state's economic development agency, James C. Burns, who helped lure a $900 million Nissan assembly plant last year. Mr. Musgrove's decision came after Mr. Burns announced that he had filed for bankruptcy in the wake of divorce proceedings and accusations of racial bias in the handling of land purchases for the Nissan site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISLER, SAM
description: ISLER-Sam. Lincoln Square Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of our member, Sam Isler, beloved husband of Marilyn Isler. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Ken Cappell, President

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: The Koreas: A North-South Road
description: Negotiators from North and South met at the base of Mount Kumkang in North Korea to discuss reopening an east coast road link. The South had called for rebuilding the road to replace the expensive ferry service that has carried visitors to Mount Kumkang since it was opened to tourism in late 1998. The road was used for normal traffic before the Japanese surrender in 1945 that ended colonial rule but brought about the division of the peninsula. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Libya Cited In '86 Bombing
description: Prosecutors told a court that Libya ordered the fatal 1986 bombing of the La Belle disco in Berlin, a favorite of American soldiers. ''In the La Belle case, the state of Libya is guilty,'' the chief prosecutor, Detlev Mehlis, said in closing arguments in the case, and said the attack had been ordered at a ''very, very high'' level in Libya. Prosecutors requested life sentences for four people accused in the attack. The bombing killed two American servicemen and a Turkish woman. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: After a Killing, Colombian Leader Has to Decide on Peace Talks
description: With Colombians outraged over the rebel killing of a beloved musical figure, President Andrs Pastrana is facing what may be his most difficult decision since he embarked on a peace effort, whether to continue negotiations with a guerrilla group reviled by most Colombians.

title: NATO Quickly Gives the U.S. All the Help That It Asked
description: NATO moved swiftly today to back up earlier promises of support for the United States campaign against terrorism with hardware and intelligence, giving the Americans every bit of the help that they asked for in an eight-point shopping list submitted on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ELIZABETH
description: LEVINE-Elizabeth. On October 1, 2001. Beloved daughter of Arnold Levine & the late Barbara Levine. Loving sister of Steven, Audrey and Lisa, and aunt of Zachary, Sarah and Justin. Services Friday 10AM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to the M.S. Research and Treatment Center at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital or the National M.S. Society.

title: A Growing List of Foes Now Suddenly Friends
description: The terror attacks of Sept. 11 forced an immediate and radical shift in American relations with the rest of the world. What had been a drifting search for a foreign policy by a new Republican administration suddenly acquired a hard, overarching purpose, in which friends and foes were coldly redefined according to whether they were with the United States or against it.

title: Brought Up to Be Prodigies, Three Siblings Share a Melancholy Oddness
description: Wes Anderson's ''Rushmore,'' shown at the New York Film Festival three years ago, was the story of a brilliant, annoying schoolboy blundering into the world of adult emotions. Max J. Fisher, the hero of that film, was not only precocious; he was enchanted by the idea of his own precocity.

title: Terror Laws Near Votes In House And Senate
description: House and Senate leaders said today that they expected to pass separate bills next week in an effort to enhance the fight against terrorism, with the Senate's version giving substantially more authority to law enforcement officials than the one in the House.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Credit Card Stake
description: Citigroup has told the Korea Exchange Bank that it will not buy the bank's controlling ownership of a credit card company. The Korea Exchange Bank said Citigroup had cited a slump in the United States economy since the terrorist attacks as the reason it cannot take over the bank's 51 percent stake in the company. Korea Exchange Bank, in which Commerzbank of Germany holds one-third of the shares and the government owns most of the rest, is under orders from the government to improve its finances. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, MICHAEL J.
description: ARMSTRONG-Michael J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the tragic death of active member Michael J. Armstrong in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a $22,000 state fine imposed on the Westchester Medical Center in the death of a 6-year-old boy during a magnetic resonance imaging test misstated the hospital's location. It is in Valhalla, N.Y., not White Plains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NYGAARD, JENS
description: NYGAARD-Jens. Beloved great conductor of the Jupiter Symphony, humanitarian and teacher. Memorial services Oct. 8, 2PM and 7PM, Good Shepherd Church, 152 W. 66 St. No flowers or donations.

title: A Love Made in Heaven (Actually, a Sweet Shop)
description: The new romantic comedy ''Serendipity'' takes its title from two sources. One is the quality that word embodies: ''It's a nice sound for what it means, a fortunate accident,'' says Sara Thomas, played by a luminous but determined Kate Beckinsale. The other is a real-life Manhattan dessert shop, which puts this movie in the same class as other New York films based on actual locations, like ''Coyote Ugly.''

title: Rumsfeld Secures Aid of Quiet Desert Ally
description: To shore up the new coalition in the war against terrorism, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld today clambered into an Omani Puma helicopter and flew to a remote desert camp to meet the Sultan of Oman, Qaboos bin Said.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Governor Seeks Tornado Relief
description: Gov. Parris N. Glendening has asked President Bush for disaster relief to help pay for a deadly tornado that tore through the state last week. In a letter to Mr. Bush, the governor estimated cleanup costs at $711,000. The damage estimate covers uninsured property only, and it represents a tiny fraction of total tornado damage, estimated at $70 million. The Sept. 24 tornado killed two people. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Holyfield-Ruiz Bout Won't Be in China
description: The promoter Don King has agreed not to hold a Nov. 25 heavyweight title fight between John Ruiz and Evander Holyfield in China because of security concerns raised by Home Box Office, which will televise the fight, an official at Don King Productions said.

title: McGuire Awards Go to 7 Coaches
description: Seven outstanding high school coaches, including Moe Finkelstein of Thomas Jefferson in Brooklyn, were named yesterday as the 2001 recipients of the third annual Frank McGuire Foundation Awards.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Cutbacks At Airlines
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said it would cut as many as 2,500 jobs and reduce passenger capacity an additional 10 percent because of the terrorist attacks in the United States. The airline reduced capacity by 5 percent soon after commercial jets crashed into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. The additional reductions will take effect Oct. 28. KLM did not rule out taking further action as the full impact of the terror campaign on the airline industry becomes clear. It estimates that the attacks resulted in a loss of $46 million during September. KLM said it would use smaller aircraft and reduce the frequency of flights to many destinations. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINS, BRIAN T.
description: CUMMINS-Brian T. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the tragic death of active member Brian T. Cummins in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, and ex tends sincere sympathy to his fa mily. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: City Says the Attack Could Cost $105 Billion
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi issued the first official estimate yesterday of how much the World Trade Center disaster will cost New Yorkers, and the number is a shocker: as much as $105 billion over the next two years.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 8 p.m. Thursday.

title: House Rejects an Effort To Redirect Farm Policy
description: The House narrowly defeated an effort to shift billions of dollars to environmental programs today, derailing a measure endorsed by the Bush administration to redirect farm policy away from crop subsidies for big farmers in favor of trade and environmental measures.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Emergency Business Grants
description: The Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, said yesterday that she had created emergency grants for shops, restaurants and other small businesses below Canal Street in danger of closing. The $30,000 fund will be administered by the Manhattan Borough Development Corporation. To be eligible for a $1,500 grant, a business must have been open for three years. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Cantor's eSpeed Will Take Over Trading
description: Cantor Fitzgerald's chief executive, Howard W. Lutnick, whose bond-trading firm was devastated in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, said yesterday that his two-and-a-half-year-old eSpeed Inc. electronic trading unit would account for most of his partnership's business.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Arrests In Slaying Of Girl
description: Two members of a gang have been charged with second-degree murder in the late August drive-by shooting of a 14-year-old New Cassel girl, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The authorities said the men, identified as Olvin Reyes, 21, a Roosevelt landscaper, and Marvin Osorio, 18, a Westbury high school student, were members of the MS-13 gang. They were aiming for a man they believed to be a member of a rival gang. Instead, two bullets struck the man's friend, Jennifer Grimes, an honors student and violin player. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, MICHAEL J.
description: McCABE-Michael J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the tragic death of active member Michael J. McCabe in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILSTEIN, SEYMOUR
description: MILSTEIN - Seymour. The Trustees, Physicians, and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital deeply mourn the passing of one of our greatest leaders and benefactors, Seymour Milstein. He was a giant in this city-an extraordinarily successful businessman, a model philanthropist, a statesman concerned about the well-being of the city, and a caring humanist who dedicated himself to helping to provide the highest quality of health care for all the citizens of New York. Truly one of a kind, he was a member of the Board of Trustees of The Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York beginning in 1988, and served as Chairman from 1989 to 1996. In 1989, he and his family gave the Hospital the single largest donation in its history. The Milstein Hospital Building was named in their honor. During his Chairmanship, The Presbyterian Hospital achieved financial stability, modernized its infrastructure, improved its community outreach, maintained its leadership in research and clinical care, and recruited distinguished clinicians and administrators. A wise counselor, a strong leader, a dedicated supporter, a generous donor, and a devoted friend-all of these qualities characterized Seymour Milstein and his connections to us. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Vivian; his brother, Paul; his sister, Gloria; his son, Philip; his daughter and our esteemed Trustee, Constance; and to the entire Milstein family. John J. Mack Chairman, Board of Trustees Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We used to take three days to plan a single funeral. The lines were straight. You could hear a pin drop. But now you lose things. The lines may not be as straight. The response to commands may not be as crisp.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRAY, DAVID
description: WRAY-David. Died October 4, at the age of 75. Beloved husband of Ann, father of Vicki, Larry and Susan. Devoted grandfather of Sarah and Jesse, father-in-law of Monica and Ron. David was an educator, passionate skier and a consummate artisan. We will miss his guidance, his generosity of spirit and the overall joy he brought to our lives.

title: Florida Man Is Hospitalized With Pulmonary Anthrax
description: A 63-year-old Florida man has contracted pulmonary anthrax and has been hospitalized with the infection, health officials said yesterday.

title: On 'West Wing,' a Twilight World Where Fact Meets Fiction
description: One minute we were in a fictional version of the White House, which the Secret Service had sealed off because of a security breach; seconds later the screen flashed information about how to contribute to the Twin Towers Fund, and then we were in the land of stylized commercials, lured by the neon-bright dazzle of Times Square to buy a car. That brief sequence on NBC near the start of ''The West Wing'' on Wednesday was more revealing than anything on the show itself, which Aaron Sorkin wrote as an oblique response to the terrorist attacks last month.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Some in G.O.P. Balk at Growing Federal Role
description: Little more than three weeks after the terrorist attacks, some conservative Republicans are pointedly challenging the Bush administration on the scope of the stated campaign against terrorism and its new receptiveness to an expanded federal government.

title: Finding the Elysian Fields in Dutch Pastures
description: We each have our own private golden age, a time when life seems secure and the future bright, when everything says hello and there are no goodbyes.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: At the Movies, Losing Our Fears
description: Last weekend, a tough, somewhat violent suspense film called ''Don't Say a Word'' was No. 1 at the box office. I was personally pleased at this news because I wrote the novel on which the film is based and Hollywood was watching audience reaction to the movie as an indicator of how action films would be received in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. As a citizen, I had something else at stake, too.

title: Uzbekistan Offers U.S. an Airbase, but Not for Attacks
description: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan, Oct. 5 — The president of the Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan said today that he would allow American forces to use its territory to carry out search-and-rescue missions and bring in supplies for a military campaign against Osama bin Laden and the Taliban regime in neighboring Afghanistan.

title: British Detail bin Laden's Link to U.S. Attacks
description: In the days before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, Osama bin Laden indicated that he was ''about to launch a major attack on America,'' according to a British government document released today.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Probation In Suffocation Death
description: A married couple was sentenced to 10 years of probation and 1,000 hours of community service for their role in the suffocation death of a 10-year-old girl last year in an alternative therapy session. The couple, Brita St. Clair and Jack McDaniel, assisted therapists who wrapped the girl in sheets and told to fight her way out to simulate being ''reborn.'' The couple pleaded guilty to criminally negligent child abuse. The two primary therapists in the case were sentenced to 16 years in prison earlier this year. The therapy, called rebirthing, has been outlawed in the state. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAWI, SAIDA
description: NAWI-Saida. On October 4, 2001. Loving mother of Constance, Donald and David. Dear grandmother of David, Ellen, Nancy, Gabriella, Daniela, Thalia, Rachel and Diana. Great grandmother of Jonathan, Daniel, Jamie, Sam, Justin and Noah. Service Friday 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sadness and Fear as a Group Feels Doubly at Risk
description: Beneath the silk white scarf and coffee-brown skin, it is American blood that flows through Hannah El-Amin's veins.

title: Jakarta Journal; If Tommy's So Hard to Find, Justice Is Indeed Blind
description: Where's Tommy? (As if they didn't know.)

title: West Coast Offense: Jets Aren't Quite There
description: Vinny Testaverde says it is a matter of a missed block here, a poor throw there, a dropped pass, the little things that are impeding the development of the Jets' offense.

title: Evidence on bin Laden, Pressure From Bush and the Grim Task
description: On several fronts, the United States and its allies moved closer toward military action in Afghanistan, most clearly by strengthening the case that they have built against Osama bin Laden.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: India: Funeral For A Political Prince
description: Hundreds of thousands of people gathered in the central Indian city of Gwalior for the funeral of Madhavrao Scindia, 56, deputy leader of the opposition Congress Party and the scion of one of India's fabled royal families, who died on Sunday in a plane crash. His son, Jyotiraditya, a 31-year-old businessman, lit the pyre. Senior Congress leaders hope he will run for his father's seat in Parliament. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Op-Art
Watch Out for a Trucker Who Can't Take a Joke
description: Midway through ''Joy Ride,'' Venna (Leelee Sobieski), a college student on summer vacation, meets up with her high school friend Lewis (Paul Walker) and his brother, Fuller (Steve Zahn), for a cross-country drive. Unbeknownst to her, the brothers have been through a hair-raising ordeal on their way to pick her up. They think that it's all behind them until the psychotic truck driver who has been stalking and tormenting them as vengeance for a CB radio prank calls their motel in the wilds of Nebraska to announce that he's not finished with them.

title: Scott Near Decision On Shooting Guard
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott said yesterday that he would decide his preseason starter at shooting guard on Monday. The competition is between Kerry Kittles, returning from a year layoff due to knee rehabilitation, and Lucious Harris, who started 50 games last season.

title: Bonds Hits 70th to Tie Record
description: Frustrated by pitchers who would not challenge him and batting in the ninth inning against Houston, Barry Bonds blasted home run No. 70 last night and tied the glamorous major league record set just three years ago by Mark McGwire.

title: 'Chop Suey'
description: Directed by Bruce Weber

title: Print the Recipes
description: Vegetable Pasta With Pesto

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBAM, MANNY
description: ALBAM-Manny. The Manhattan School of Music is saddened by the death of renowned composer, arranger, conducter and jazz faculty member Manny Albam. Since 1993 Manhattan School musicians have been privileged to share the insight, humor, passion and humanity that made Mr. Albam's presence in the jazz world so remarkable. As a colleague and friend he will be missed by all. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Marta Istomin, President

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Vehicle Exports Are Up
description: Depreciation of the Korean won raised Korean motor vehicle exports last month to their highest level this year. With prices of Korean cars declining on world markets, manufacturers exported 165,516 vehicles in September, an increase of 14.1 percent over August, while selling 134,226 vehicles inside Korea, up 9 percent from August and 9.8 percent from September 2000. Share prices for Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors, owned by Hyundai, Korea's dominant carmaker, rose 15 percent, the maximum permissible daily gain on the Korea Stock Exchange.

title: Introduction
description: Pasta is so familiar it's tempting not to think much about it while you throw together some routine dish. But, really, it deserves a little more thought than it usually gets in the kitchen, even among reasonably accomplished cooks.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Philippines: 13 In Muslim Group Captured
description: The government said it had captured 13 members of the Muslim militant group Abu Sayyaf, which has kidnapped scores of people and still holds at least two Americans. An official said a total of 178 members of the group had been captured in a long-running military offensive. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Britain's Bill of Particulars: 'Planned and Carried Out the Atrocities'
description: Following is the text of the report issued from Britain on the terror attacks on Sept. 11, ''Responsibility for the Terrorist Atrocities in the United States, 11 September 2001'':

title: Ground Zero, Brutal and Noble
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Former AremisSoft Officials Accused of Fraud by S.E.C.
description: The two former top executives at AremisSoft, a publicly traded software company, were accused yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission of defrauding investors of at least $200 million and possibly much more.

title: Florida Community Can't Shut Down 'Voyeur Dorm'
description: For years cities and towns have been able to rely on zoning laws to keep adult entertainment businesses -- and their patrons -- far away from tony residential areas. But what happens when an R-rated business's clients never set foot on its premises and instead pay for and view sexual fare on home computers via the Internet?

title: Hard Questions Over Honoring the Dead
description: As families and funeral directors try to make their way through the unfamiliar territory of catastrophic death, they are being confronted with delicate questions, forcing what can be an uncomfortable examination of beliefs about the appropriate treatment of what death leaves behind.

title: For Public Art, A New Scrutiny
description: In the wake of the World Trade Center attacks, questions of taste and suitability are being addressed in the art world as never before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DR. HARRY
description: KAPLAN-Dr. Harry, 88. Of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Westfield and Monmouth Beach, NJ. Survived and cherished by wife Barbara, children Arthur, Louis, Leslie and Chaia (Judy), 11 grand children and brother Nathan. Chemist, life long member of Temple Emanu-El, and civic activist. Service 11:30 AM, on October 8th, Temple Emanu-El, Westfield, NJ

title: Most Afghan Opium Grown In Rebel-Controlled Areas
description: New data collected by the United Nations indicates that most opium grown in Afghanistan this year was in areas controlled by the Northern Alliance, a rebel group now being courted by the United States and its Western allies as a means to destabilizing and even toppling the ruling Taliban.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Girl Struck By Car
description: A 12-year-old girl was admitted in critical condition to St. John's Queens Hospital after being struck yesterday by a car driven by a man with a learner's permit, the police said. The girl, whose name was not released, was hit near Beach Channel Drive and Mott Avenue just before 8 a.m. The authorities said the car's driver, Gabriel S. Parrott, 22, of Arverne, Queens, was charged with violating the terms of his learner's permit and driving with an obstructed view. The girl was later transferred to Long Island Jewish Hospital. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVAS, ANTHONY
description: SAVAS-Anthony. Of Astoria, NY, tragically on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Tony was a construction inspector for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey working on the 88th floor of the North Tower. Tony saw front line action during the Korean War and helped save lives there and during the 1993 bombing of the Twin Towers. He loved $2 cigars, dancing, his country and his family. Family and friends will remember Tony for his tremendous wit, boundless sense of humor and joy of life. His children will always admire him for his devotion, example of fairness and unparalleled perseverance. Tony was a committed husband, devoted father and proud grandfather. He is survived by his wife Phaedra, his children Sandra Savas, Christina Christman, and John Savas; daughter-in-law Bernadine Savas and son-in-law Robert Christman; and grandchildren Jessica and John. Reposing: Basis Funeral Home, 27-12 23rd Ave., Astoria, NY, Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral liturgy, St. Demetrios G.O. Cathedral, 30-11 30th Drive, Astoria, Saturday 10:15 AM. in lieu of flowers donations to the American Red Cross and Salvation Army would be greatly appreciated.

description: A special newspaper advertisement that ran yesterday for United Airlines urging Americans to fly again presented brief descriptions of recent business trips taken by six people, promoting new lower fares to stimulate business travel after the terrorist attacks. If the names seemed familiar to readers on Madison Avenue, there was a reason: five of the six are employees of the United agency, Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis.

title: U.S. Jews Split on Washington's Shift on Palestinian State
description: A significant split has emerged among American Jewish organizations over the Bush administration's consideration of a diplomatic initiative that would include United States support for the creation of a Palestinian state, according to prominent members of Jewish groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPORTE, WILLIAM
description: LAPORTE-William. The faculty, staff, students and alumni of Columbia University's Health Sciences Division mourn the passing of our good friend William Laporte, an esteemed trustee of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Over many years of service to both the hospital and the University, Mr. Laporte was generous with his time, expertise and spirit-resulting in important advances and new directions in research, clinical care, education, and community service. We offer our deepest condolences to his children, Suzanne, Lynn and William, and to his nine grandchildren. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences, Columbia University Health Sciences

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTZ, JOHN C.
description: HARTZ-John C. The Board of Govenors, members and staff of the Somerset Hills Country Club, Bernardsville, NJ extend our heartfelt sympathies to the family of our President John C. Hartz on the loss of their beloved husband, father and brother at the World Trade Center on Tuesday, September 11th, 2001. Our thoughts and prayers are with you now and always. May your faith in God, friends and family see you through this terrible time.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Mussels in Tomato Sauce
description: Spaghetti is the pasta of choice here, paired with what is essentially a basic tomato sauce. We've added mussels, saffron and various garnishes (including olives and capers) to achieve a bit of rustic personality. The cooking is finished by joining the pasta just before it's finished with the nearly finished sauce so that the spaghetti can be enriched by absorbing some of the sauce. The ingredient called "tomato sauce" is the familiar stuff in cans and jars on grocery shelves; buy one that's as close to pure tomatoes as you can. Of course when tomatoes are in season, it's simple enough to make a batch of your own by slowly cooking tomatoes with a little chopped onion for two or three hours.

title: TALKING POLITICS -- Lower Manhattan; On the Trade Center's Periphery, Mercurial Opinions on the Candidates
description: This is how Richard Fitzgerald, a private chauffeur who lives in Greenwich Village, described his feelings about some of the mayoral candidates in late August, three weeks before the scheduled primary: ''I like Mark Green the best. He is sort of a voice for the people.'' And on Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican candidate: ''I think he's paying his place on the ticket. I don't think he's earned a place in politics.''

title: A Knock at the Door, With the Message of Death
description: The knock on the door comes without warning. On the other side stand police detectives, or a fire battalion chief, maybe a member of the clergy, bearing what now passes for good news. Your loved one has been identified.

description: Directed by Tom Sawyer

title: Groups Plan Vigils and Rallies to Urge Alternatives to War
description: Peace groups around the nation are preparing vigils and rallies on Sunday to demand legal and diplomatic alternatives to war.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Justice Dept. Approves Redistricting
description: The federal Department of Justice approved the state's 2001 redistricting plan, allowing new political boundaries to go into effect despite numerous challenges in the State Supreme Court. Alaska is one of nine states with a history of minority disenfranchisement that requires Justice Department approval for any changes in the electoral process; the department found that the plan complied with the Voting Rights Act of 1965, despite complaints from Alaska Natives that it would reduce their voting power. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Global Crossing Warns on Revenue and Appoints a Chief
description: Global Crossing, the company that initially stoked Wall Street's enthusiasm for globe-spanning fiber optic systems, said yesterday that it would report disappointing revenue for the third quarter, and it announced a reorganization intended to calm fears over its finances.

title: A Revolution Witnessed, Not Just Reconstructed
description: On two previous occasions, with ''The Marquise of O'' in 1975 and with ''Perceval'' three years later, Eric Rohmer shifted his attention from the intricacies of modern love and ventured into the terrain of period drama. His new film, ''The Lady and the Duke,'' which will be shown tonight and Sunday at the New York Film Festival, takes place during the French Revolution.

description: To the Editor:

title: Administrator Quits Post Overseeing Public Theater Finances
description: Former Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter is stepping down as executive director of the Joseph Papp Public Theater, less than a year after she was hired to help bring financial order to an organization long identified with its charismatic creative leader, George C. Wolfe.

title: Gerhard Richter
description: Marian Goodman Gallery

title: Bucking Government Bailouts
description: As governments across Europe rush to deliver emergency aid to an aviation industry on its knees, one airline's chief executive is shouting ''Not so fast!'' as loudly as he can.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The tersely named, semisubterranean Bid provides customers at Sotheby's two things they need desperately, real food and prices that cannot be changed with the wave of a paddle. Bid's location, off the main entrance of the auction house and a few steps down, imparts a hybrid atmosphere. The restaurant feels a little like an executive canteen, a little like the best restaurant in a major museum. The dcor is soothing beige on beige, with steel light fixtures straight out of Flash Gordon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELCHER, BENJAMIN MOORE JR.
description: BELCHER-Benjamin Moore Jr., 66. Died October 3, 2001 at a Bangor hospital. He was born March 4, 1935 in New York City, the son of Ben Moore and Nancy (Knapp) Belcher Sr. Benjamin attended the Taft School, Princeton University, class of 1957 and received a law degree from the University of Virginia. He retired as Senior Vice President and Board of Directors of the Benjamin Moore Paint Company. In 1999, Benjamin was ''Man Of The Year'' of the AntiDefamation League Award, for the Paint Industry and he was an advisor to the Benjamin Moore Scholarship Fund in Ireland. Benjamin was active in both, the Bar Harbor Congregation Church, Bar Harbor, ME and the Congregational Church of Naples, FL., as a member of their choirs. He was a member of the Mt. Desert Summer Choral, on the board of the Wendell Gilley Museum, co-chair of fundraising Capital Campaign of Harbor House, a member of the Southwest Harbor fleet, the Causeway Club in Southwest Harbor and the Collier Reserve and Athletic Country Club of Naples, FL. Benjamin is survived by his wife Diana (Lupien) Belcher of Southwest Harbor and Naples, FL. One son, Benjamin M. Belcher III and wife Tracy of St. Charles, IL. One daughter, Allyson K. Sarkis and husband Paul and granddaughter Shivaun of Sidney, Australia. Stepchildren; Chandler Woodall of Stamford, CT, Marshall and Cecilia Woodall, Elmsford, NY. Debi and Les Draper and their children Andie and Noah of Huntington Beach, CA. One brother, Ward C. Belcher and wife Susan of Ridgewood, NJ. Two sisters; Jane Phinney and husband George of Ripton, VT and Sara Wardell and husband Richard of Salisbury, CT, and several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by a brother, Dr. Jonathan Belcher and one sister, Nancy Ann Belcher. A service of remembrance will be held 10:30 AM, Monday, October 8, 2001 at the Bar Harbor Congregational Church, Bar Harbor, ME, with Reverend Dr. Sandra Reed officiating. In lieu of flowers, family has requested contributions go to the Capital Campaign for Harbor House in Southwest Harbor, ME 04679. For information contact, Fernald Funeral Chapel, Mt. Desert, ME.

title: A Change in Jury Duty: Now, a Call May Be Enough
description: The time when answering a summons for jury duty meant waiting two or three days in a crowded room without ever being called for a trial will soon end throughout New York City. Court officials are shifting permanently to a system in which prospective jurors call the night before to find out if they are needed.

title: Lobbying Down to the Wire As Industry and Politicians Battle Over Aid to Carriers
description: New rules expected to be released by the Bush administration today will give a four-member panel headed by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, broad powers to dole out $10 billion in federally backed loans to the airline industry.

title: Filipinos Recall Hijack Suspects Leading a High Life
description: MABALACAT, Philippines  They stayed at a popular resort hotel here, drank whiskey with Philippine bargirls, dined at a restaurant that specializes in Middle Eastern cuisine and visited at least one of the local flight schools.

title: Spending Is the Hard Part
description: After a week of jousting, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and New York State's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, have agreed to share responsibility for coordinating the distribution of nearly $700 million in private charity raised since the World Trade Center disaster on Sept. 11. It is not clear how this will play out in practice, but an inappropriate turf war seems to have been avoided.

description: Articles on Wednesday and on Sept. 20 about an underground system of transferring money internationally mistranslated the term ''hawala,'' by which it is known. (The error also appeared on Wednesday in the daily capsule summary of the terrorism investigations.) The word, originally Arabic and now used in several languages in Southwest Asia, means a bill of exchange or promissory note, not trust or in trust.

title: For Rebuilders, Inspiration All Around
description: WE may be ready for comedy, but are we ready for seriousness? This should be the pressing question for those now contemplating the future of the financial district in Lower Manhattan. We are prepared for real estate, but can we handle architecture? Can our builders bring themselves to acknowledge that there is a difference between them?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Not On Our Doorstep!
description: Prime Minister Bertie Ahern denounced a British decision to open a new nuclear waste plant as ''entirely inappropriate'' in light of concern about terrorist attacks on the proposed site, the nuclear complex at Sellafield, 120 miles across the Irish Sea from Dublin, the capital. Mr. Ahern said he would raise the matter soon with the British prime minister, Tony Blair. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Teachers' Backing Gives Ferrer Labor's Triple Crown
description: The New York City teachers' union voted last night to endorse Fernando Ferrer for mayor, giving him a clean sweep of the three most sought-after unions in local politics: health and hospital workers, city employees and now teachers.

title: Vegetable Pasta With Pesto
description: The sauce for this dish is really a kind of grilled salad in pesto. The grilling intensifies the flavor of the vegetables, and the basil in the pesto will be intensified, too, by briefly blanching it. That blanching also has another function -- it allows for much of the moisture to be forced out of the leaves. The belief among those who use this relatively unfamiliar method (including Tom Colicchio , the chef from Craft and Gramercy Tavern in Manhattan) is that blanching the leaves will preserve the pesto longer (refrigerated) than if raw leaves are used. It also brightens the color of the leaves, which makes the resulting sauce that much more colorful.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Tokyo: Premier To Visit China, Korea
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi will visit China and South Korea over the next 10 days in an attempt to repair relations strained by his government's approval of a contentious textbook, and his August visit to a shrine honoring Japanese war veterans. Officials said Mr. Koizumi would express remorse for Japan's wartime atrocities and seek to allay concerns in Beijing and Seoul about the deployment of Japan's Navy to the Indian Ocean. Japan has offered to provide rear-area support for American military operations in Central Asia. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Poorly Prepared Asian Countries Warned of AIDS Epidemic
description: After years of assuming that they were safely on the sidelines of the global AIDS epidemic, many Asian countries now find themselves facing serious health crises and are often poorly prepared to respond, a new report finds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HARDY WILLIAM
description: SMITH-Hardy William. On October 3, 2001. Beloved friend of the late Peter Glenville. Theirs was a partnership radiant with the warmth of their associations, the creativity of their love for life and the distinction of their achievements together in theatre and film. Adored uncle of Holly Book and Meridel Jellifer. Loving great uncle of and inspiration to Asher Book and his other nieces and nephew. There were none more loyal and generous, kind and true than Hardy. He will be ardently missed. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday, 2-4PM and Friday 2-4 and 68PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10:30AM at Saint Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Ave at 66th St.

title: An Agency of Builders Honors Its Dead
description: The gathering of more than 5,000 people in the Theater at Madison Square Garden yesterday was as much a reunion for a proud agency as it was a memorial service for its dead. After all, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has had to continue operating even after losing 74 employees and a home that many saw rise from the ground three decades ago.

description: AS pastimes go, buying, restoring and driving old cars is a harmless -- though often expensive -- indulgence, far removed from the worlds of global politics and terrorist plots.

title: Mike Mansfield, Longest-Serving Senate Majority Leader, Dies at 98
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5  Mike Mansfield, who served as Senate majority leader and United States Ambassador to Japan longer than anyone else, died this morning at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, where he had been a patient since Sept. 27. He was 98.

title: Hernndez Not in Pain But Not In Lineup
description: Orlando Hernndez's October feats are part of Yankees lore, pinned to him like medals since his first playoff start, when he beat the Indians on a cold night in Cleveland and saved the 1998 season. His standing as one of the greatest postseason pitchers is entirely incongruous with the confusion surrounding him these days.

title: 4 Companies Are Hired To Oversee Contractors
description: In the wake of reports that World Trade Center debris has been plundered, the Giuliani administration has hired four private companies that will start today to monitor contractors and subcontractors working at the site.

title: ARAMARK BUYING SERVICES BUSINESS FROM SERVICEMASTER
description: The Aramark Corporation, one of the biggest food vendors to arenas, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the ServiceMaster Company's facility-services business for $800 million, expanding its customer base of hospitals and schools. The services unit provides custodial work, plant management, groundskeeping and food services to clients including Princeton University and the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, Aramark said. The unit, with annual sales of almost $1 billion, employs 18,000 people and manages 69,000 others for its customers. An Aramark spokeswoman would not comment on whether jobs would be cut. ServiceMaster is divesting itself of its commercial-services operations to focus on residential customers, a spokesman, Steve Bono, said. The company provides a pest-control service through its Terminix unit and provides lawn-care and cleaning services through its TruGreen ChemLawn and Merry Maids businesses.

title: Security Chief Leaving Post
description: The chief of security at the Federal Aviation Administration will leave his job next month to ''pursue other opportunities,'' a spokesman for the Transportation Department said this evening.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Compaq Recalls Cords And Adapters
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said it would recall about 1.4 million power adapters used with some of its Armada and Prosignia notebook computer models sold between September 1998 and July 2001. The recall comes after reports from the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission that five of the alternating current adapters had overheated and four of those had caught fire. No personal injuries or property damage were reported. A Compaq spokesman said replacing the recalled adapters, which were supplied by an outside vendor, would have no material impact.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 5  In a visit here that would have been unimaginable a month ago, Prime Minister Tony Blair today looked ahead to an Afghanistan without the Taliban government.

description: WINCH-Rita M. (nee Kelhetter). On October 1, 2001. Survived by children, Richard and Linda Winch, Mary Ann Sayers, Alyson and Patrick Milbourn and grandchildren, Larry, Irene, Alex, Kristin and Kimberly. She will be missed.

description: While the terrorists who plotted and carried out the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States lived and worked in many European countries, including Britain and France, Germany appears to have been their haven of choice.

description: The Rangers team that will begin the 2001-2 season tonight is one in transition, one that has missed the playoffs for four consecutive seasons and desperately wants to avoid doing so for a fifth time. As such, it is an extremely difficult team to gauge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURHAM, ANN KOREN
description: DURHAM-Ann Koren, 87 years old, died on October 1, 2001. Born in Gloversville, NY, and a graduate of New York State Teachers College in Albany. A treasured volunteer of National Council of Jewish Women and a founder of CLASP and Open Door. Honored as Lakeville's Woman of the Year in 1974 and recipient of the Hannah G. Solomon Award in 1990. Widow of Bernard. Survived by son, Ralph, and daughter-in-law, Ann, of Woodstock, NY, and Jonathan of Manhattan. Donations may be made to NCJW-Lakeville Section, CLASP and Open Door.

description: Kwame Brown absorbed a hard slap across his forearms as he rose for a shot during practice. Brown, the No. 1 overall pick in the draft this year, shot an incredulous glance at the referee, waiting for a call.

title: Recession Is Scary, but Is There an Alternative to Stocks?
description: WITH the economy in recession, the rate on three-month Treasuries is below 2.25 percent. The last recession with rates that low ended in 1958.

description: For their last night on earth, the pair of terrorists stayed at a Comfort Inn on a sterile strip of gas stations and fast-food joints here.

description: Glenn Parker has played 162 National Football League regular-season games and has started 129. Jason Whittle has played 36 and has started 3. But when the Giants (2-1) face the Washington Redskins (0-3) on Sunday at Giants Stadium, Whittle will be the starting left guard and Parker will almost surely sit out the game nursing a concussion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELLITTO, MATTHEW
description: SELLITTO-Matthew. The Board of Governors, members & staff of the Somerset Hills Country Club in Bernardsville, NJ, extend our heartfelt sympathies to our members, the Sellitto family, on the loss of their beloved son Matthew at The World Trade Center on Tuesday, September 11, 2001. Our thoughts and prayers are with you now and always. May your faith in God, friends and family see you through this terrible time.

title: Local Officials Scramble to Develop Antiterrorism Plans of Their Own
description: Governors, legislators and local officials in virtually every state are considering proposals to fight terrorism and protect the public as varied as enacting death penalty laws, placing armed marshals on cruise ships and increasing scrutiny of meat inspection to prevent tampering.

title: Man in Bus Attack Fought in Croatian War
description: The 29-year-old Croatian man who slit the neck of a Greyhound bus driver on the Interstate near here Wednesday morning fought in the Croatian Army in a region with some of the most brutal fighting in the civil war in Croatia in 1991, the Croatian news agency reported today.

description: They are among the legions of Lower Manhattan jobless -- the three Peruvians who used to clean apartments at Battery Park City, the Mexican cook from the concourse under the trade center, the pizza delivery man who whisked large pizzas up and down the towers.

title: Zito Seeks Top-Grade Efforts In Gold Cup
description: Nick Zito has had many good afternoons at the racetrack. He has won a pair of Kentucky Derbies and a Preakness, and he experienced a magical 30 minutes at Belmont Park 356 days ago when A P Valentine captured the Champagne Stakes and Albert the Great stormed off with the Jockey Club Gold Cup a race later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JEROME G.
description: SHAPIRO-Jerome G., 77. Died Tuesday, October 2, 2001 after complications from a stroke and Alzheimer's disease. He practiced law in New York City for over 45 years with the firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, becoming its Chairman from 1975-1989. Survived by his wife of 42 years, Marjorie Mackay Shapiro, three children, Jeffrey Kemble, Jill Dara and Eric Noach, and six grandchildren. He is also mourned by his beloved sister, Norma Kleiner and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue and West 91st Street on Sunday, October 7th at 3 PM. Burial service will be at Abel's Hill Cemetery in Chilmark, MA at 4 PM on Thursday, October 4, 2001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his honor to the Alzheimer's Association of New York, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

description: Many a hapless romantic has fallen in love only to discover that that special someone is, well, a snake. So it is in Chinese Theater Works' latest production, with one difference: that characterization is literally true.
