description: TRANSACTIONS

title: Pakistan Finds U.S. Charges Good Enough for Court
description: In a statement likely to reverberate through the Muslim world, Pakistan said today that evidence compiled by the United States of Osama bin Laden's involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon was enough to justify charges in a court of law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEGA, PETER A.
description: VEGA-Peter A. Firefighter, died in the line of Duty on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Regan and father of Ruby Mae. Cherished son of Maureen Rosenberg, Ira Rosenberg and Pedro Vega. Dear brother of David Rosenberg, Leo Vega, Patricia Vega and Gloriana Vega. Beloved grandson of Helen & James Murphy, Ana and Pedro Vega and Ruth & Sam Rosenberg. Dear nephew of Brian, Michael, and Shelley. Also survived by many loving family members and friends. Memorial service to be held at 12 PM October 6, 2001 at Our Lady of Peace Church, 522 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, NY.

title: A Terror Alert On New Stickers
description: Aside from a few bright spots, video proceeded uninspiringly last week. Dealers report increased interest in movies with violent and terrorist leanings, not that those were ever weak categories. ''The Siege'' is most talked about, with its terrorist attack on New York, but Video Hound's Golden Movie Retriever lists more than 300 titles under the terrorism heading.

title: Sweet 'Cannelloni'
description: This dessert is a bit of a trompe l'oeil: resembling a cannelloni, it is actually tubes of pasta stuffed with sweet cheese. It's served with raspberries coulis just to keep the amusement going, since the puree looks a bit like tomato sauce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUFF, EDITH BRENER (NEE JORDAN)
description: RUFF-Edith Brener (nee Jordan). Died peacefully, Wednesday, October 4, 2001. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club and an active member of Planned Parenthood, and the Citizens' Committee for Children. She lived fearlessly, loving life, her friends, and the arts passionately. Edith is survived by her children, Jordan and Thomas Brener, her devoted friend, Rossario Quintero, and her loving companion, Peter Munves. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in her name to Planned Parenthood.

title: The Microsoft Conundrum
description: Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly invoked both national purpose and practical reason last Friday as she ordered the two sides in the Microsoft antitrust case to return to the negotiating table one last time. The ''recent tragic events,'' she said, lent an added urgency to resolving the issue, given its importance to the national economy. A settlement can surely be reached ''if everybody is reasonable'' and ''acts in good faith,'' the judge declared.

title: Gloria Foster, Stage Actress, Is Dead at 64
description: Gloria Foster, the distinguished stage actress who portrayed generations of African-American characters in plays like ''In White America'' and ''Having Our Say,'' died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 64.

title: Many Lenses, All Viewing Movement
description: Everything Ginette Laurin choreographs for O Vertigo, her dance company from Montreal, is worth a look, and her new work, ''Luna,'' which runs through Sunday at the Joyce Theater, is no exception.

title: Reverence in Japan for Nature's Beauty, Humility and Accidents
description: When it comes to exploring the visual possibilities that lie between plain and fancy, few cultures have been as thorough as Japan's. In Japanese culture all objects, from the lowliest tool to the most elaborately embroidered kimono or ostentatious lacquer writing box, have an equal right to be beautiful, in their own way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADDOCK, MARY V. (NEE DONOVAN)
description: PADDOCK-Mary V. (nee Donovan) of New York City formerly of Stony Brook, L.I. A past president of the St. James RC Church Rosary Altar Society. Beloved wife of the late Robert S. Paddock. Loving mother of Patricia Riviere, Barbara Paddock, Valerie O'Neill, Kenneth Paddock and Donald Paddock. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Scott and John Riviere, Kate and Jimmy O'Neill, Sean, Robert and Brigid Paddock and Ian Paddock. Reposing at O.B. Davis Funeral Home, Port Jefferson Station, New York. Visiting Friday 2-4 & 7-10. Mass Saturday 9:45 AM at St. James RC Church in Setauket. Interment Oak Hill Cemetery in Stony Brook.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Outlook
description: Fiat S.p.A. said it would not meet its 2001 targets for operating profit and debt reduction, adding that it planned to cut car production in Italy by 100,000 units by the end of the year. Fiat said demand for nearly all its products, including cars, car parts, industrial vehicles and construction equipment, was expected to fall because of the tumultuous state of the world economy after the terrorist attacks. Previously, Fiat had expected operating profit to rise to about 1.1 billion euros from 854 million euros the year before.

title: Rafalski, Nemchinov May Miss Opener
description: The day after they secured goaltender Martin Brodeur for five more years, the Devils prepared for tomorrow's season opener against the Capitals in Washington uncertain about the status of two players. Defenseman Brian Rafalski is nursing a groin strain and forward Sergei Nemchinov is nursing a leg injury.

title: Earnings Decline 7.9% at Alcoa
description: Alcoa Inc. said today that its third-quarter profit fell 7.9 percent because of falling demand and predicted a weak fourth quarter.

title: STARBUCKS IN JOINT VENTURE WITH GERMAN RETAILER
description: The Starbucks Corporation, the specialty coffee chain, said yesterday that it had formed a joint venture with KarstadtQuelle, Germany's biggest department store company, to expand into Germany. The first Starbucks store in Germany, which has Europe's biggest economy, is expected to open in Berlin in early spring, Starbucks said. Starbucks, which has more than 4,600 outlets worldwide, has said it sees potential for as many as 1,400 stores in Germany. Starbucks, which is based in Seattle, has six shops in Switzerland and plans to open in Vienna in December, as part of a plan to open at least 650 outlets in Continental Europe by the end of 2003.

title: The N.B.A. Negotiates In a Changed World
description: The N.B.A. season does not begin until Oct. 30, but talks have already begun to sell the TV rights that start with the 2002-3 season.

title: Art in Review
description: Gerhard Richter

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Beatty Viewpoint

title: This Is Not a Mentoring Program to Emulate
description: In a black leather jacket, with flamboyant jewelry that includes a big platinum-and-diamond crucifix, Detective Alonzo Harris (Denzel Washington) looks like a modern version of a Medici prince, or Suge Knight. He's the Machiavellian figure in the intermittently successful police drama ''Training Day.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel To Stick With Motorola
description: Nextel Communications Inc., the fifth-largest United States wireless company, said it would use Motorola Inc. equipment to upgrade its existing network rather than install new equipment that relies on technology from Qualcomm Inc. Terms were not disclosed. The upgrade will double Nextel's call-carrying capacity, the company said in a statement. Other changes will increase the speed at which Nextel users can search the Internet and corporate databases. Shares of Nextel, which is controlled by Craig O. McCaw, had fallen amid concern about the high cost of network upgrades using the Qualcomm standard. Yesterday, the shares climbed $1.80, or 24.5 percent, to $9.16.

title: Sailing Into a Sea of Troubles; No Grace Period for New Chief of American Express
description: Everything is so topsy-turvy at the American Express Company these days that some midlevel managers have spacious offices with soothing water views but Kenneth I. Chenault does not.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the arts pages on Wednesday for a movie image of a Japanese soldier with his finger on the trigger of a pistol, with an article about how Hollywood has avoided racial stereotypes of villains in recent years, misidentified the film. It was ''Wake Island,'' not ''Bataan.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Three Bacterial Meningitis Cases
description: Bacterial meningitis was detected this week in three young people in the Detroit area. They remain in critical condition in different hospitals while the Wayne County health department conducts tests to determine if the cases are connected. Bacterial meningitis is an infection of membranes around the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms may include headaches, fever and neck stiffness. The infection is fatal in about 10 percent of the cases and can cause serious harm, including brain damage. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Former Chief Justice Enters Race
description: One day after tendering his resignation as chief justice of the State Supreme Court, Daniel Whaten surprised many by applying for a new job, as governor. Mr. Whaten, 61, announced that he would run as a Republican to succeed Angus King, an independent finishing his second and last term. Mr. Whaten, who served 10 years as chief justice, said he won his last election bid, to be class president of his high school, in 1957. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Album of the Week
description: SYSTEM OF A DOWN: -- ''Toxicity'' (Def American/Sony). Whew! A metal band that obsesses on something outside the psyche. Right near the beginning of ''Toxicity,'' the point at which most metal bands would be swaggering and establishing bad-man credibility as they sing about some private disorder or another, this band's singer, Serj Tankian, howls in his scrappy street-protester's voice: ''Minor drug offenders fill your prisons/You don't even flinch/All our taxes paying for your wars/ Against the new nonrich.''

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: A Challenge To Redistricting
description: Lawyers for 13 petitioners argued before the Oregon Supreme Court on Wednesday that Secretary of State Bill Bradbury, a Democrat, favored his party and ignored existing county lines in redrawing the state's legislative districts. Michael Reynolds, an assistant attorney general, defended the plan, saying it lawfully satisfied the need for new State House and Senate districts required by population changes. Mr. Bradbury was handed the redistricting job in July after legislators failed to reach an agreement. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: In Dallas, Using Target Practice for Anger Management
description: Pop! Pop! Pop! Revenge is sweet and acrid along the shooting range, but only virtual.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Arrested In Killing
description: A 20-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with the shooting death of a 15-year-old bystander who was hit by one of several shots fired into a crowd outside a dance club last weekend, the police said. The bystander was caught in the middle of two feuding gang factions, the police said. The man, Kevin Morrison, was charged with murdering the bystander, Victaya Anderson, left, also of Brooklyn, outside Club Warehouse at 1370 Ralph Avenue shortly before 9 p.m. Sunday night, the police said. Victaya had left a talent show for teenagers and was standing among 300 people when shots were fired, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: On the Street: Market Days
Musical Cares
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Green Assails Ferrer's Call For Decentralizing Business
description: Mark Green charged yesterday that Fernando Ferrer was not prepared to rebuild the city's economy in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center, saying his plans did ''not measure up to the crisis'' and warning that his call to decentralize office space could break up the financial district.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Ban On Same-Sex Marriage
description: A provincial Supreme Court ruled for the first time that prohibitions on same-sex marriages violate basic rights, but then decided that since marriage was intended solely for raising and sheltering children, the ban would stand. The British Columbia High Court was hearing a case brought by a group of same-sex couples. Other cases will be heard this fall in Ontario and Quebec.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Wireless Venture
description: Virgin Mobile has reached an agreement that will allow it to sell wireless services over Sprint PCS Group's network, the companies said. The joint venture, beginning in the first half of 2002, is the British company's first foray into the American market. The companies had been negotiating for several months and an agreement had been expected. Sprint PCS will contribute $50 million in services and will own half of Virgin Mobile U.S.A. The Virgin Group, the privately held conglomerate run by the British entrepreneur Richard Branson, above, and the parent of Virgin Mobile, will inject $50 million in cash and own the rest. Customers will pay for minutes of long- distance calls or other services, including music and entertainment, as they use them, rather than receiving monthly bills. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A New Night Club Act For a Soap Opera Star
description: Susan Lucci

title: Sun Microsystems Says Loss To Be Bigger Than Expected
description: Sun Microsystems said today that it would post a wider-than-expected loss for its first fiscal quarter and lay off about 3,900 employees, or 9 percent of its work force, in an attempt to become profitable again by June.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: U.S. and Afghans: Decision Time
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fewer Tire Replacements Expected
description: The Bridgestone Corporation said its Firestone subsidiary in the United States would probably replace fewer than 400,000 tires, about half of those covered under its latest recall, because most of the affected tires are already off the roads. Japan's largest tire maker said it would spend about $30 million to replace the tires. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; FAIR PLAY WAS SERVED, AND A RECORD WAS SET
description: There is a new home run champion this morning. Barry Bonds stepped to the plate last night in the first inning, and with one mighty swing ended his relentless assault on Mark McGwire's single-season home run record that began in April. Bonds blasted No. 71 off the Dodgers right-hander Chan Ho Park. In the third inning, he stepped to the plate again. He couldn't possibly hit No. 72, could he? In this summer of milestones, was there any doubt?

title: Dr. Rhys Jones, 60, Researcher Of Human Origins in Australia
description: Dr. Rhys Maengwyn Jones, a pioneer investigator of human origins in Australia, whose research pushed back the beginning of human settlement there to a far earlier date than previously thought, died on Sept. 19 in Canberra, Australia. He was 60.

title: Historians Weigh Attack's Impact On New York City
description: For weeks historians have been e-mailing one another the text of a poignant and prescient essay, ''Here Is New York'' by E. B. White. In 1949, bringing home the new nuclear reality of the postwar age, he wrote: ''The city, for the first time in its long history, is destructible,'' adding: ''Of all targets, New York has a certain clear priority. In the mind of whatever perverted dreamer might loose the lightning, New York must hold a steady, irresistible charm.''

title: Religion Journal; Shrines Serve the Need for Healing in Public Spaces
description: Since shortly after the terrorist attacks that destroyed the World Trade Center, New Yorkers have been creating impromptu shrines, memorializing the victims. People have placed photographs of the dead and missing, together with flowers and American flags, in many places, including the walls in Grand Central Terminal, Pennsylvania Station and the 42nd Street subway stop, some of the city's most heavily traveled junctions.

title: In Aftermath of Attacks, Hughes Refocuses Her Life
description: Sarah Hughes had seen most of these skaters before. She had met Nancy Kerrigan. She has competed against Michelle Kwan. And she has even chatted with Peggy Fleming, whom Hughes idolized as a youngster.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: U.S. and Afghans: Decision Time
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Space Tourist Is Rejected
description: The beleaguered space agency turned down a potential tourist for being too demanding, news agencies reported. The space chief, Yuri Koptev, said Mark Shuttleworth, 27, a South African tycoon who spent the summer at the astronaut training center in Russia, wanted a miniumum two-week trip and a second free trip if the first attempt to dock with the International Space Station failed. Dennis Tito, a California millionaire, reportedly paid the agency $20 million to become the first space tourist last spring.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: The Koreas: Talks On A Road Link Stall
description: The two Koreas failed to agree on a land route linking South Korea to Mount Kumkang, just above the demilitarized zone that divides the Korean Peninsula. They did decide to meet again on Oct. 19 but disagreed on where. The North prefers the same location, the base of Mount Kumkang. The South suggests the slope of Mount Sorak on its side of the demilitarized zone. South Korea has proposed rebuilding a road over which tourists could go to Mount Kumkang instead of by boat.

title: Attacks Add New Twists To City's Talks With Labor
description: In creating huge problems for New York City's budget, the attacks on the World Trade Center have created new tensions and twists in the city's long-stalled labor negotiations.

title: TALIBAN'S RIVALS SHOW OFF FORCES
description: As forces of the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance showed off 40 Russian-built battle tanks in a military parade in northern Afghanistan, its leaders suggested that an offensive against the Taliban could come in the form of a powerful strike toward Kabul coordinated with American air strikes.

title: In Nebraska, an Oasis of Insight Into Afghanistan's Heart
description: WHEN Thomas E. Gouttierre, a baker's son from Maumee, Ohio, applied for the Peace Corps in 1964, he had never even flown on an airplane, never mind traveled beyond the United States. He wanted to go somewhere that ''wasn't hot'' and ''wasn't in the Western Hemisphere,'' so he listed Iran, Turkey and ''anyplace but Latin America'' as his three choices.

title: As Loss Widens, Chip Maker Blames Price War With Intel
description: Advanced Micro Devices said today that a price war with its chief rival, the Intel Corporation, had driven down third-quarter revenue by 22 percent from the second quarter and widened its net loss to as much as $220 million.

title: Taking Account of the Dead, Feeling Weight of History
description: In the hours after the World Trade Center's twin towers fell, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani predicted that the number of people dead in the ruins would be ''more than any of us can bear ultimately.'' The weeks since then have proven the mayor grimly correct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARUS, HARRY
description: LAZARUS-Harry. Died on October 5th. A gentle 100 year old. Predeceased by his wife Esther. Survived by loving children Ann, Burt and Stuart; grandchildren Bruce, David, Karen and Barton; great-grandchildren Max and Samuel. Graveside services Glenville Cemetery, Sunday at noon. Contributions can be made to the Andrew Stern Memorial Fund.

title: With the A's Looming, Clemens Falters Again
description: Roger Clemens did not lose over a span of 127 days this season. The team with baseball's worst record has beaten him twice in the last 11 days.

title: A Bank Analyst Who Loved to Fish, and an Aunt Who Loved Salsa
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 380 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 321. In all, 4,986 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, GEORGE G.
description: COHEN-George G. Of Roslyn, N.Y. On October 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Lilly. Father of Susan and Alan. Grandfather of Julian, Wendy and Madeline. Father-inlaw of Barry & Judy. Cherished uncle, cousin, brother and brotherin-law. Funeral Sunday, October 7th, 1:15 P.M., Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, Plandome. Donations to FRAXA Research Foundation or the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Improving Our Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Soon After Rebuking U.S., Israel Moves Into 2 Arab Neighborhoods
description: Hours after rebuking the United States for its role in the Middle East and declaring that Israelis would ''depend only on ourselves,'' Prime Minister Ariel Sharon began one of the biggest military assaults of the yearlong conflict today, sending troops, tanks and Apache helicopters against Palestinian gunmen here.

title: STAPLES SAYS ITS SALES FELL AFTER TRADE CENTER ATTACKS
description: Staples Inc., the office-supplies retailer, said yesterday that its same-store sales had fallen 4 percent to 6 percent in the fiscal third quarter. The company lost $30 million to $40 million in sales during the week and a half after the terrorist attacks against the United States, said John Mahoney, executive vice president, on a conference call with analysts and investors. The company still expects to meet earnings estimates for this year, Mr. Mahoney said.

title: U.S. Troops Are Deployed To Former U.S.S.R.
description: The United States today deployed soldiers to the former Soviet Union for the first time, dispatching about 1,000 troops to Uzbekistan, Pentagon officials said, to aid in the expected war against terrorists and their protectors in Afghanistan.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Seymour Milstein, the New York real estate and banking executive, omitted an account of his wide-ranging philanthropy. Additional information appears today, on Page C15.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Lawmaker Resigns Post
description: The chief parliamentary whip for the president's African National Congress Party has quit his leadership post after being charged with fraud and corruption. By stepping down, the lawmaker, Tony Yengeni, spares his party the burden of deciding whether to suspend him as the police press ahead with their investigation of a multibillion-dollar arms deal. Mr. Yengeni, who was chairman of a key parliamentary defense committee, is accused of promising to help a defense contractor in exchange for a low price on a Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle.

title: A Series to Foster the Young Finds One Well Under Way
description: Troy Cook, baritone

title: MIDWEST BANK RAISES PROVISION FOR POSSIBLE LOAN LOSSES
description: U.S. Bancorp, a regional banking company based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit would be cut by $655 million because it increased the amount of money it had set aside to account for possible loan losses after the terrorist attacks last month. The company said it raised its provisions to 2.12 percent of its outstanding loans as of Sunday from 1.45 percent as of June 30. U.S. Bancorp said loans at risk were primarily those made to the transportation industry, particularly aviation, and the manufacturing industry. The report set off a 16 percent decline in U.S. Bancorp's stock price.

title: Puzzling Piece of Wreckage
description: Rummaging through hills of steel wreckage from the World Trade Center at a Jersey City scrapyard, a structural engineer has found what appears to be a few pieces of the south tower that were directly hit by the Boeing 767 jetliner.

title: Ferrer Adds Koch to Endorsers in Bid to Broaden His Base
description: Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and mayoral candidate who faces Mark Green, the public advocate, in a runoff on Oct. 11, has revised one of his commercials, to include, for the first time, Ed Koch, who endorsed him on Tuesday.

title: A Texas Family Rounds Up 3,000 Teddy Bears
description: This is so corny that no self-respecting New Yorker would believe it. But it is true.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Ex-Governor Has Alzheimer's
description: Former Gov. Carroll Campbell, 61, disclosed that he was in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease. Mr. Campbell, who in 1987 became only the second Republican governor of South Carolina since Reconstruction, played an important role in George W. Bush's primary election victory in the state over John McCain, an outcome that propelled Mr. Bush to the 2000 Republican presidential nomination. The eight-year-long Campbell administration also set the stage for Republicans to take control of the Legislature for the first time in a century. Mr. Campbell is now president of the American Council of Life Insurers, in Washington.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Regional Carriers To Merge
description: British Airways said it would merge its two regional carriers to try to cut costs and better compete with European budget airlines like Easyjet and Ryanair. British Airways said it would merge its British Airways Regional operations with CitiExpress, which was formed earlier this year in a merger of two of the company's other regional airlines. The slimmed-down regional business would operate with about 200 fewer workers, would reduce service on some routes and would cancel others, like Manchester to Bristol, England. British Airways has already cut 7,000 jobs after passenger traffic fell 22 percent last month following the terrorist attacks in the United States. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: U.S. and Afghans: Decision Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking for Heroes -- and Finding Them
description: In the benumbed first days after Sept. 11, America went on a hero hunt. We needed to balance out the grief. The rescue workers who ran into burning buildings, the World Trade Center employees who stayed behind with colleagues who couldn't escape, the airplane passengers who died thwarting the hijackers: we shored ourselves up with their stories. Heroes act as we like to think we would have, given the opportunity and the courage.

title: U.S. and Afghans: Decision Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Meeting Lean Times, Salesman Casts Net Wider and Deeper
description: Rolling down County Road 38 in his dark green Plymouth Neon with an American flag taped to the antenna, Tom Giorgio looks out at the suburban landscape and talks about how much better the economy was not just before Sept. 11, but a year or two ago.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Ruling Out Peso Devaluation
description: With tax receipts and stock prices falling and interest rates soaring, President Fernando de la Ra and other senior officials publicly insisted that they would not consider a devaluation under any circumstances. Mr. de la Ra said he would continue to stand by the decade-old policy of pegging the value of the peso to the dollar.

title: A Flawed Stimulus Plan
description: Responding to the demands of Republicans in Congress, President Bush has laid out a stimulus package that relies in large part on ineffective, irresponsible and regressive tax cuts. He gave short shrift to Democratic demands that the stimulus contain government spending designed to boost the economy as well.

title: Hall Welcomes Chaney, Malone and Krzyzewski
description: John Chaney and Mike Krzyzewski are college coaching legends, while Moses Malone bypassed college to become a legend in the National Basketball Association.

title: Pipeline Crews Tackle Huge Oil Spill Caused by Shooting
description: Workers struggled today to contain one of the largest spills in the 24-year history of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline, caused on Thursday by a man who fired a bullet into the 4-foot-wide structure after a heavy bout of drinking, law enforcement officials said.

title: A Prayer Before Flying; Places to Worship Help Soothe Souls at an Airport
description: Josephine Rogers arrived at Kennedy International Airport last Saturday at 3 p.m., her heart heavy and her luggage loaded with the gifts she had collected for her 70th birthday, during what was supposed to be a celebratory three-week visit with her relatives in New Jersey.

title: Correction: S. Milstein's Philanthropy
description: Seymour Milstein, long a partner with his brother, Paul, in the family real estate and banking businesses, left a wide-ranging record of philanthropy in New York when he died Tuesday at age 81. An obituary on this page on Wednesday omitted that aspect of his life.

title: U.S. and Afghans: Decision Time
description: To the Editor:

title: In Pakistan, Blair Repeats Allies' Goals
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain made a five-hour visit to this nation of 140 million Muslims today bearing a promise central to preparations for an allied military thrust into Afghanistan -- that the target will be Osama bin Laden and, perhaps, the Taliban government, but not ordinary Afghans or their Islamic faith.

title: Musical Comedy Soap Opera? Sure. From Egypt.
description: This year's New York Film Festival has offered inspiring evidence that some of the masters of world cinema remain spry and inventive well into old age. The french directors Jacques Rivette and Eric Rohmer, at 73 and 81, have struck out in surprising new directions, while Manoel de Oliveira, in his 10th decade (and his eighth behind the camera) continues to show his calm mastery of the medium. And let's not forget Youssef Chahine of Egypt, who turned 75 this year, and whose new film, ''Silence . . . We're Rolling'' is a reckless, buoyant hodgepodge, a musical screwball soap opera that will leave you dumbfounded and, if you're in the right mood, delighted.

title: Rangers' New Model Quickly Loses Its Shine
description: Another Rangers season starring Eric Lindros -- began tonight, but it looked like a rerun of the last four seasons.

title: Florida Man Dies of Rare Form of Anthrax
description: A 63-year-old Florida man who had been hospitalized with pulmonary anthrax on Tuesday died today, state health officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Publisher Revises Outlook
description: VNU, the Dutch publisher of The Hollywood Reporter and Billboard magazine, said profits for the full year would be less than expected after the terrorist attacks in the United States damped advertising sales. The company said per-share earnings before good will might fall as much as 5 percent. The announcement is the second time this year that VNU has lowered its profit forecasts. It said it would cut as many as 400 jobs, or 11 percent of its staff, in the business information subsidiary. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Accident Suspected in Black Sea Crash
description: As Black Sea salvage ships ferried the shattered wreckage of a Siberian Airlines jet to Russia's shore, Pentagon officials said they strongly believed that a long-range antiaircraft missile fired during a major Ukrainian training exercise had struck the jet before it exploded and crashed Thursday.

title: I.N.S. Urges Immigrants to Report the Missing
description: The chief of the nation's immigration agency yesterday urged immigrants who are in the country illegally to report friends and family missing in the trade center attack and to seek disaster relief without fear of retribution.

title: Abroad at Home; For Israel's Sake
description: The Middle East peace initiative that President Bush was planning before Sept. 11 is desperately needed now. It would help the international struggle against terrorism. But more important, it is the only hope of ending the ratcheting cycle of violence that afflicts Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Group of 7 Set to Explore Ways to Recharge World Economy
description: Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said he and his counterparts from the world's leading industrial nations would explore fresh ways of stimulating their economies when they gathered here this weekend. But European and Japanese leaders played down expectations that wealthy countries would act in concert to address the worsening global slump.

title: Guardsmen Take Positions at Terminals
description: Wearing fatigues and carrying M-16 rifles, more than a thousand National Guard troops took up security positions yesterday at airports across the country, where they watched gates, checked luggage and tried to reassure passengers at half-deserted terminals that air travel was safe again.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Bombs Tied To Survivalists
description: The authorities found numerous bombs, bomb-making material and more than 12,000 rounds of ammunition inside five campers parked in rural southern Illinois that they believe belonged to a survivalist group. Investigators said that the group, the United Survivalists of America, was small and that they did not suspect it of plans to use the arsenal for an attack. The Pike County sheriff, Paul Petty, said one man had been charged with unlawful use of a weapon and held on $50,000 bond and that another was being sought. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Deal Salvages Idea of Online Private Equity
description: The assets of Offroad Capital, a failed online investment bank, have been bought by the owners of the New York Private Placement Exchange, a privately run electronic trading network for shares of companies that are not public. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Philippines: Defending The First Husband
description: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo asked prosecutors to investigate allegations of corruption against her husband, Jose Miguel Arroyo. Calling her country ''a large gossip factory,'' she said she was acting to clear her husband's name and to set a standard of openness in government.

title: Slain Arab-American May Have Been Hate-Crime Victim
description: Last Saturday, on his last day, Abdo Ali Ahmed opened his convenience store at 7 a.m., the same as always. His customers had come to rely on Ahmed's East Reedley Store for coffee and cigarettes on their way to work in the grape fields and packing houses.

title: U.S. Strongly Rebukes Sharon for Criticism of Bush, Calling It 'Unacceptable'
description: The White House reprimanded the Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon today for what it called his ''unacceptable'' remarks about President Bush, as the administration frantically tried to discourage Mr. Sharon from carrying out threats to take further military action against the Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JEROME G.
description: SHAPIRO-Jerome G., 77. Died Tuesday, October 2, 2001 after complications from a stroke and Alzheimer's disease. He practiced law in New York City for over 45 years with the firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, becoming its Chairman from 1975-1989. Survived by his wife of 42 years, Marjorie Mackay Shapiro, three children, Jeffrey Kemble, Jill Dara and Eric Noach, and six grandchildren. He is also mourned by his beloved sister, Norma Kleiner and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue and West 91st Street on Sunday, October 7th at 3 PM. Burial service will be at Abel's Hill Cemetery in Chilmark, MA at 4 PM on Thursday, October 4, 2001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his honor to the Alzheimer's Association of New York, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

title: Flailing Wildly to Escape the Darkness
description: Wrath and pain, desire and self-loathing, ferocity and meditation all find a complicated balance in Tool, which played a two-night stand at Madison Square Garden this week.

title: Pleasure Domes Built of Giggles and Moonlight
description: Once upon a time a great pleasure palace was built on the edge of the sea. Streets curled past onion domes and minarets; statues moved as if they were alive; great elephants shed their lumbering bulk as they plunged down enormous slides. At night the edges of the cupolas and balustrades were draped with what was said to have been ''a huge mantle of light,'' a luminous -- almost lunar -- demonstration of magical powers.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Ruling Upheld
description: A Belfast court upheld a ruling that David Trimble, former first minister of Northern Ireland's power-sharing government, could not ban two Sinn Fein ministers from attending meetings with their counterparts in the Irish Republic. Mr. Trimble, who is also leader of the Protestant Ulster Unionist Party, banned Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun from the meetings because the Irish Republican Army, which is linked to Sinn Fein, failed to meet deadlines for disarmament. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Islam and Its Adherents Ride the Publicity Wave
description: ''Modern Muslim women!'' Oprah Winfrey cheered at the end of her show yesterday, with the sense of triumph that her audience now saw that the phrase was not a contradiction. She also displayed a trace of relief that she had gotten through something tough.

title: A Lieutenant Governor Faces Ethical Questions
description: Most days, Connecticut's lieutenant governor, Jodi Rell, is in the spotlight in a positive way, presenting a plaque to a volunteer or cutting a ribbon on a new school. But lately she has come under a harsher glare, fielding questions about her ethical conduct.

title: Wild Drama Based on 'Equus' And a Work Set to Gershwin
description: Dance Theater of Harlem

title: Mike Mansfield, Longtime Leader Of Senate Democrats, Dies at 98
description: Mike Mansfield, who served as Senate majority leader longer than anyone else and was instrumental in the 1960's and 1970's in the enactment of legislation on civil rights, social policy and foreign affairs that changed the course of the country, died today at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 98.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN MAKE LATE PUSH TO FORGE COALITION FOR COMBAT
description: The Pentagon today sent nearly 1,000 troops trained for mountain warfare to the Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan as senior American and British officials completed trips to shore up a loose coalition of nations that would be needed to support any military action.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bush Requests Tax Cuts From Rest of Stimulus Plan

title: Correspondent; The 40-Year War
description: A dozen years ago in Termez, a dusty Uzbekistan border town that may again become a dateline, I watched the Russian Army begin its retreat from Afghanistan. As paratroopers crossed a railroad bridge into the waiting arms of parents and girlfriends, an all-girl, all-drum band from a local school tapped out a cheerless homecoming rhythm. When I asked the soldiers what they had accomplished down there, expecting at least a rehearsed sample of national pride, they would stare blankly. ''We survived,'' one weary private shrugged. The war that had sent home 15,000 zinc coffins had also killed off a lot of illusions.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: U.S. and Afghans: Decision Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Even at 6, Beautiful Pleasure Refuses to Act Her Age
description: There are mornings in Lexington, Ky., when Donna Ward leaves her flak jacket in the barn, hops on the 6-year-old mare Beautiful Pleasure and walks her in the fields of the Ward family's Fort Springs Farm.

title: Counterpoint to Unity: Dissent
description: The novelist Alice Walker argued that the best way to punish Osama bin Laden for the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 would be not to strike militarily: ''The only punishment that works is love.'' Noam Chomsky, the perennial dissenter from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, argued that American actions around the world had caused more death and destruction than took place in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania. Chalmers Johnson, a political science professor, in an article in The Los Angeles Times, wrote that a military ''overreaction'' by the United States would turn the country into a ''rogue state'' that would be subject to more terrorist attacks.

title: White House Approved Data Blair Released
description: The White House acknowledged today that it had coordinated and approved Britain's release on Thursday of details of the case against Osama bin Laden, even though it had declined, on national security grounds, to publish a similar accounting of the evidence against the suspected mastermind of the attacks on the Pentagon and the World Trade Center.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 8 p.m. Friday.

title: Principles, Postures And a Mayoral Race
description: To the Editor:

title: The Case Against bin Laden
description: The American case against Osama bin Laden has now been put before the world, thanks to Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair. Mr. Blair said Thursday that his review of the evidence left ''absolutely no doubt'' that Mr. bin Laden and his terrorist network were responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks. Some Americans may be wondering whether the world will find those assurances from our closest European ally particularly convincing. But the report released by Britain, in a move coordinated with the White House, demonstrates that the Bush administration has enough information about the links between Mr. bin Laden, the Taliban leadership of Afghanistan and the terrorist assaults to make a strong case.

title: Deadline Set on Cellphone Emergency Calls
description: The Federal Communications Commission gave Verizon Wireless Inc. and four other mobile phone companies more time today to start installing gear that pinpoints the location of customers dialing 911, and expressed disappointment at the delays that caused the decision.

title: Tennessee Williams, the Early Years
description: Anatole Fourmantchouk and the New York Art Theater try to give dramatic life to ''Something Cloudy, Something Clear,'' a script Tennessee Williams evidently struggled with for 40 years in various forms before it was finally presented once, 20 years ago, less than two years before he died. The result, for all the music, dancing and melodramatic posturing Mr. Fourmantchouk has supplied, is an unceremonious burial of the bones of this plotless, prosey, maudlin recollection of Williams's life on the beach in Provincetown, Mass., in 1940, four years before his first great success, ''The Glass Menagerie.''

title: Federal Study Endorses Plan For Pipeline
description: Despite fierce opposition from many local officials and residents here, a federal environmental study has recommended approval of the Millennium Pipeline, a high-pressure natural gas line that would run through Westchester County and parts of upstate New York.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Two Struggling Companies Win Reprieve From Korean Creditors
description: Hynix Semiconductor, the most closely watched corporate patient in South Korea's financial critical-care ward, got a reprieve from its creditors today, keeping it out of bankruptcy for the time being.

title: On Bleak Night, Harris Provides Bright Moment
description: The Mets arrived at Shea Stadium yesterday knowing this would be their final weekend of the season. Instead of pursuing a postseason berth or solidifying their playoff rotation, the Mets are tending to unfinished business. "Thunder Road" quietly played in the clubhouse before the game, but Al Leiter was sifting through mail, not bouncing to Bruce Springsteen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNELLY, REV. ALFRED THOMAS, S.J.
description: HENNELLY-Rev. Alfred Thomas, S.J. Beloved brother of Robert J. Loving uncle of Maureen Diaz. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road, Bronx, N.Y. Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Murray-Weigel Chapel Monday, 11:30 AM. For information, contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors, 718-654-0500.

title: Shares Advance on Prospect Of $60 Billion in Tax Cuts
description: The stock market rose modestly yesterday after President Bush urged Congress to approve $60 billion in tax cuts to help shore up the economy after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Expert Sees a Good Play, Then Looks for a Better One
description: A quarter of a century ago, the Italian Blue Team, which had dominated world play for two decades, was ending its long run of success. Its players seemed to have difficulty in adjusting to the newfangled bidding screens, which run diagonally across the table so that nobody can see his partner.

title: Fans at L.S.U. Are Living in Purple-and-Gold World
description: They are streaming in from the bayous, convoying from the red-dirt cities up north and zipping over from New Orleans, more than 90,000 of them. The most feverishly stricken are leaving purple-and-gold houses, driving purple-and-gold cars and tailgating in purple-and-gold recreational vehicles with their hydraulic barbecue pits and ceiling fans strung in the oak trees to blow around the heat from the afternoon and the jambalaya.

title: Knicks Have Learned 3 Won't Go Into 2
description: It was the problem that would not go away, the one that kept Latrell Sprewell, Allan Houston and Glen Rice on edge for most of last season. With three All-Stars playing two positions, there was no way to satisfy everyone. So in August the most dissatisfied member of the group, Rice, was shipped out.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I just never thought I would ever see armed military in the airports.''

title: F.B.I. Curbed Scrutiny of Man Now a Suspect in the Attacks
description: The F.B.I. held back its own agents last August from opening a criminal investigation of a man who investigators now suspect was meant to be the 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 attacks, a senior Justice Department official said today.

title: Glenn Ready to Show Jets He Is Handy on Returns
description: Standing alone, which is what punt returners do, Aaron Glenn rubbed his hands together and then braced for Tom Tupa's arcing kick. Glenn inched back, made a safe basket catch, then skittered past would-be tacklers, finding daylight. In moments, he was all alone again.

title: At Security Companies for the Rich, Flush Times
description: In fretful times, the rich are different. They can salve fear with money. Since Sept. 11, they have been rubbing it on quite heavily, security experts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFNER, SAUL
description: GEFFNER-Saul. October 3, 2001, resident of Providence, R.I. Beloved husband of Frances (nee Katz) Geffner. Devoted father of Dr. Mitchell E. Geffner & Marsha G. Rice. Loving brother of Lillian Reisman and the late Sally Leitner and Molly Milowe. Adored grandfather of six. Graveside services on Sunday, 2:30 at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Temple Shalom, 223 Valley Road, Middletown, RI 02842.

title: U.S. and Afghans: Decision Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Jimi Hendrix Again, Going Out With a Bang
description: It's as much fun to watch Jimi Hendrix in the choice offstage moments of the documentary ''Blue Wild Angel: Jimi Hendrix Live at the Isle of Wight'' as it is to watch him alternately gun and strum at this now legendary 1970 concert.

title: Military's Sole Supplier of Anthrax Vaccine Still Can't Make It
description: With concern growing over the possibility of biological weapons being used against Americans, anthrax vaccine should be pouring out the door of the only laboratory in the United States licensed to make it.

title: Backing Ferrer, Union Focuses On Teacher Pay
description: As the union representing New York City teachers formally endorsed Fernando Ferrer for mayor, its leader sought to portray him yesterday as the candidate who would rebuild Lower Manhattan and make New Yorkers feel safe without abandoning the goal of making teachers' salaries competitive with those in the suburbs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBENSTEIN, HENRY
description: RUBENSTEIN-Henry. My Beloved. Nine years later and still I miss your gentle touch and understanding. Always, Your Beatrice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADDOCK, MARY V. (NEE DONOVAN)
description: PADDOCK-Mary V. (nee Donovan) of New York City formerly of Stony Brook, L.I. A past president of the St. James RC Church Rosary Altar Society. Beloved wife of the late Robert S. Paddock. Loving mother of Patricia Riviere, Barbara Paddock, Valerie O'Neill, Kenneth Paddock and Donald Paddock. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Scott and John Riviere, Kate and Jimmy O'Neill, Sean, Robert and Brigid Paddock and Ian Paddock. Reposing at O.B. Davis Funeral Home, Port Jefferson Station, New York. Visiting Friday 2-4 & 7-10. Mass Saturday 9:45 AM at St. James RC Church in Setauket. Interment Oak Hill Cemetery in Stony Brook.

title: XEROX HIRES PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS AS NEW AUDITOR
description: The Xerox Corporation, the subject of an accounting investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that it had named PricewaterhouseCoopers to replace KPMG, the company's independent auditor for more than 30 years. Xerox restated earnings for the last three years in May because some accounting practices were misapplied. The company delayed filing its annual report in April after KPMG requested more time to review the books after the S.E.C. investigation was disclosed.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GREENLIGHT CAPITAL LLC., New York, a private money manager, said it had acquired an 8 percent stake in Patina Oil and Gas Corp., Denver, a fuel exploration company. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Ties Between a Mosque and Fort Bragg Stay Strong and Neighborly
description: In the shadow of one of the nation's most important military bases, Imam Mustafa T. Shakir paused during afternoon prayers to note the curiosity that has suddenly sprung up about Islam, a faith with about a billion adherents worldwide.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Anthrax Vaccine Problems

title: Frederick Lussen, Detective In Famed Cases, Dies at 91
description: Frederick M. Lussen, a police detective who investigated many of the city's most famous cases in the 1960's and 70's, from gangland shootings to the Mad Bomber, died on Oct. 4, at his home in Nanuet, N.Y. He was 91.

title: Job Cuts Increased Even Before Sept. 11
description: In the weeks before Sept. 11, the American economy lost more jobs than in any similar period in the last decade, the government reported yesterday, making clear that the country was sliding into recession even before the terrorist attacks.

title: Sacrificing His Ambition For Giuliani
description: NOT to worry, Terrance M. Gray said on the phone to a fellow who was wondering how to recognize him when they met the next day. Look for the only person in the law library of the Bronx County Courthouse who resembles Theodore Roosevelt.

title: U.S. TRACES PATH OF HIJACKER TIED TO OTHER ATTACKS
description: Investigators have discovered that one of the suspected hijackers of the jet that crashed into the Pentagon on Sept. 11 was tied to two previous attacks against American targets by Osama bin Laden's terror network, American and foreign officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Vital Signs column of Science Times on Tuesday about prayer and the success of in vitro fertilization misstated the title of the journal that published a study on the subject. It is The Journal of Reproductive Medicine, not Reproductive Health.

title: The Fading Appeal of Farm Subsidies
description: An enlightened effort to reform the country's costly, discriminatory farm program went down to defeat on Thursday. But there were enough good omens to inspire hope that the days of old-fashioned, New Deal-era subsidies may be numbered, and that the reformers can actually win this battle when the Senate takes up the issue.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO CLIMBS. The euro rose to a five-month high against the yen and its strongest level this week against the dollar. The euro climbed to 111.41 yen from 111.00. Against the dollar, the euro rose to 91.77 cents from 91.59.

title: Collins Showing Vast Improvement
description: For the rookie center Jason Collins, class is in session even before the Nets' morning practice. Arriving early, he sits with the assistant coach Mike O'Koren, discussing the Nasdaq and even correcting his word usage.

title: Ordez Gets Sharper With Bat and Glove
description: Like the Mets, Rey Ordóñez has had a strong finish, salvaging something from what was a dismal year, although both Ordóñez and the team fell short of their goals. Has Ordóñez played well enough, though, to approach the form he demonstrated at the end of the 1999 season?

title: Serenity Becomes Poignancy In the Face of Adversity
description: Jos Navas and Walter Haman

title: Hollywood, A Funhouse Of Fantasy
description: While watching ''Mulholland Drive,'' you might well wonder if any film maker has taken the clich of Hollywood as ''the dream factory'' more profoundly to heart than David Lynch. The newest film from the creator of ''Blue Velvet'' and ''Twin Peaks'' is a nervy full-scale nightmare of Tinseltown that seizes that concept by the throat and hurls it through the looking glass.

title: Airlines Match Delta's Cut-Rate Fares
description: Most major airlines today matched Delta Air Lines, the nation's third-largest carrier, in cutting fares as much as 50 percent on routes worldwide to draw travelers back to airplanes.

title: Upbeat Report on City Services Seems Part of a Sunnier Time
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani released the latest report card on city services yesterday, presenting a case that his administration has made progress on many initiatives.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Indonesia: General Held Liable In Atrocities
description: An Indonesian general, Johnny Lumintang, denied any guilt in the human rights violations in East Timor in 1999. On Thursday, in a suit filed by six East Timorese plaintiffs, a federal court in the United States found him liable for $66 million in damages for his role in atrocities there.

title: NEWPORT NEWS AGREES TO TALKS WITH GRUMMAN
description: Newport News Shipbuilding Inc., the target of a takeover battle between the General Dynamics Corporation and the Northrop Grumman Corporation, said yesterday that it would begin talks with Northrop Grumman. Newport News said it remained committed to its existing agreement to be acquired by General Dynamics but said the bid from Northrop Grumman might now be superior because of a recent rally in Northrop's stock price. Both companies bid $2.1 billion, or $67.50 a share, for Newport News, which designs and builds nuclear-powered aircraft carriers and submarines. General Dynamics' bid was all cash and Northrop's bid included a combination of cash and stock. Newport News said yesterday that Northrop's bid now appeared to be worth $72.67 a share, prompting it to agree to the talks. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILSTEIN, SEYMOUR
description: MILSTEIN-Seymour. Temple Israel Center of White Plains mourns the passing of Seymour Milstein, a long standing member of our community. A wise, courtly, and generous man, he was a prime mover in conceiving of, and making possible, the physical renewal of our synagogue, and particularly the sanctuary that bears his family name. Known as a builder of structures, his manifold philanthropic endeavors throughout the metropolitan area will ensure that he is remembered as a builder of medical knowledge, of understanding and tolerance, and of religious communities. Our deepest condolences go to his wife Vivian, to his children Philip and Cheryl, and Connie and her companion Jehan-Christophe, to his grandchildren Abby and Rick, Joanna, Merrie, Josh, Toby, and Larry, to his brother Paul and Irma, to his sister Gloria and Louis Flanzer, and to his greater family. May his memory endure as a blessing. Gordon Tucker, Rabbi Mark Bieler, President

title: A Pro-Taliban Rally Draws Angry Thousands in Pakistan, Then Melts Away
description: A small boy of 4 or 5, his face as blank as a doll's, rode the shoulders of an angry crowd through the Raja Bazaar, his head wrapped in a black turban, one small hand holding a plastic toy pistol in the air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NYGAARD, JENS
description: NYGAARD-Jens. Beloved great conductor of the Jupiter Symphony, humanitarian and teacher. Memorial services Oct. 8, 2PM and 7PM, Good Shepherd Church, 152 W. 66 St. No flowers or donations.

title: Immigrant Who Didn't Understand Robber Is Killed
description: An immigrant from Guinea who knew little English was killed during a robbery at a Brooklyn restaurant early yesterday apparently because he did not understand an assailant's command to hand over his wallet, the police said.

title: New York in 1975
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Sri Lanka: 25 Rebels Killed In Sea Battle
description: A navy patrol engaged a flotilla of rebel boats off the northeastern coast, a territory now held by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the separatist group fighting for a Tamil homeland since 1983. Military officials said 25 rebels were killed and two rebel boats destroyed. The sea battle, the second this month, was another sign that peace efforts are going nowhere for now. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Bankruptcy Protection Granted
description: The air carrier Sabena was granted bankruptcy protection until Nov. 30 by a Brussels court yesterday, while the European Commission said it had received notification of the Belgian government's plans to grant Sabena a bridge loan of $115 million. However, a wider rescue bid agreed to in July involving $395 million from the government and from Sabena's other parent, Swissair, will not be submitted for commission scrutiny now. That plan ''will have to be revisited and new large-scale measures will have to be developed,'' Sabena said in a statement. Separately, only four other countries have notified the commission of their intentions to grant aid to their airlines: Britain, Greece, Portugal and Denmark. The commission said the only official complaint it had received so far about the Sabena rescue attempt was from Ryanair. ''Ryanair's complaint will be examined,'' said Gilles Gantelet, a commission spokesman on transportation issues. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Raising Munich, Sharon Reveals Israeli Qualms
description: Israeli officials have been quick to try to contain the damage done by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's outburst on Thursday against the United States, in which he invoked the appeasement of Hitler in 1938 to warn Washington against making deals with Arab states at Israel's expense. But exaggerated or not, the statement exposed a frustration many Israelis feel with the Bush administration's antiterror campaign, and a serious political problem that this campaign poses for Mr. Sharon.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about the Islanders and the start of the National Hockey League season misstated the means through which the Detroit Red Wings obtained the goaltender Dominik Hasek. It was a trade, not free agency.

title: Supreme Court of Georgia Voids Use of Electrocution
description: Georgia's Supreme Court became the first appellate court in the country today to rule that electrocution is an unconstitutionally cruel and unusual punishment, leaving Alabama and Nebraska as the only states using the electric chair as their sole method of execution.

title: Wall St. Lifeline Shakes Off Dust, and Critics; Disruptions Put Bank of New York to the Test
description: From the roof of the Bank of New York's Art Deco headquarters, just down the block from the New York Stock Exchange, one can easily see why the bank has been at the uncomfortable center of Wall Street's recovery.

title: Afghan Rebels Are Nervous As Food Supplies Run Low
description: As a Taliban jet roared overhead here today, a group of mothers in a house in rebel-held territory here grabbed their children and enveloped them in their arms. They huddled in the corner, shielding the children with their bodies. The jet roared above. The children screamed. A distant explosion sounded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHERRY, MARY ELIZABETH
description: McSHERRY-Mary Elizabeth. We mourn the passing of our mother, but will always cherish the many wonderful times she shared with us. Mom was the greatest. She always made us feel that we were the greatest and we'll love her forever. Her Children and Grandchildren

title: The Debate on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: House Votes for More Spy Aid And to Pull in Reins on Inquiry
description: The House today approved a significant infusion of new spending for the nation's intelligence agencies, while backing away from a wide-ranging independent inquiry into the performance of the government leading up to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Principles, Postures And a Mayoral Race
description: To the Editor:

title: With Injury to Barber, Giants Look to Backup
description: Coach Jim Fassel will not say it directly, but it seems almost certain that Tiki Barber, the Giants' best runner, will sit out Sunday's game here against the Washington Redskins.

title: As Rhodes Misses Record, Japan's Fans Lose Out, Too
description: For many, his quest had come to say as much about Japanese provincialism and insularity as as it did about baseball. But in the end, Tuffy Rhodes, a veteran American player with the Kintetsu Buffaloes, came up short in his bid to set a single-season home run record in Japan.

title: Despite Money Issues, Devils Look Forward
description: The Devils have been the team to emulate in the Eastern Conference in recent seasons. With more than 100 points in each of the last five seasons, and with Stanley Cup championships in 1995 and 2000, they have set a standard for chemistry, skill, speed, strength and goaltending.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Frank Gasparro, designer of the reverse side of the Lincoln commemorative penny issued in 1959, included an outdated reference to the uniqueness of the design. While the coin was the first circulated by the United States with a likeness of the same person on both sides, it is no longer the only one; the 1999 New Jersey quarter has George Washington on both front and back.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Australia: Premier Calls Elections For Nov. 10
description: Prime Minister John Howard announced that a parliamentary election would be held on Nov. 10. Though he was in political trouble not long ago, his popularity has soared because of his refusal to allow boat people from the Middle East to land in Australia. Opinion polls also show that most Australians support his strong backing for United States counterterrorism initiatives. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: U.S. Military Exercise in Egypt Could Serve as Staging Ground
description: In the shadow of its military buildup near Afghanistan, the United States has been amassing an air, land and sea force of 23,000 in Egypt in preparation for a monthlong military training exercise that begins on Monday.

title: Bonds Breaks Homer Record, And Then Some
description: The instant Barry Bonds unleashed his spring-loaded swing tonight, the moment his black maple bat made sweet contact on a pitch, the 1-0 fastball delivered by Dodgers starter Chan Ho Park shot into the night sky.

title: Manny Albam, 79, Jazz Composer and Player
description: Manny Albam, a musician, composer and arranger in the jazz world of the 1950's and 60's who also played a major role in the growth of jazz education, died on Tuesday at his home in Croton, N.Y. He was 79.

title: Another Series Of Last Rites Is Under Way
description: Nearly every day since the World Trade Center attack, grieving wives and city officials have attended memorial services, sometimes funerals, for New York City firefighters lost in the disaster.

title: E.P.A. Says Air Is Safe, But Public Is Doubtful
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has tested the air in Lower Manhattan more than 1,000 times and has concluded that it does not show dangerous levels of contamination.

title: In Performance
description: CLASSICAL

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Oil prices, in a three-week slump, fell on growing disbelief by traders that OPEC would cut output to defend its target price range. In New York, the price for December delivery fell 24 cents, to $22.39 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESCOTT, JOSEPH
description: PRESCOTT-Joseph. 88 years old. Died on October 4, 2001. Born July 3, 1913, in Fall River, MA. Retired professor of English, Wayne State University. Graduate of Harvard College and Ph.D. Harvard University. Dr. Prescott's doctoral thesis was the first written in the US on James Joyce's ''Ulysses.'' Beloved husband of the late Myrtle Saperstein Prescott and beloved father of the late Eleanor Prescott. Dr. Prescott is survived by his loving grandsons James and Matthew, and devoted son-in-law Nicholas G. Garaufis. In lieu of flowers please make contributions in his memory to the Columbia University School of Journalism, New York City 10027. Please specify that the contributions are to honor the memory of Eleanor Prescott.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, MARY BRAMAN
description: MURRAY-Mary Braman. Of Lawrence, NY. October 5. Beloved wife of Arthur F. Devoted mother of James, Anne, Michael and the late Arthur F., Jr. Step-grandmother of Fred Leuzinger. Cherished sister of Eleanor Grasso, Lawrence Braman and the late Chester A. Braman, Jr. Visiting at Meserole Funeral Home, 143 Lord Avenue, Inwood, NY, Monday, October 8, 7-9 PM. Directions 516239-1398. Memorial service at 11:30 AM, October 9, at Trinity-St. John's Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557. Donations to Trinity-St. John's Memorial Fund are appreciated.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: TDK Will Cut 8,800 Jobs
description: The TDK Corporation, Japan's largest maker of disk-drive components, said it would cut 8,800 jobs, or 20 percent of its work force, as demand for electronics parts fell. The company, based in Tokyo, will cut 3,400 employees by the end of March 2002 and the rest by March 2004, said a spokesman, Nobuyuki Koike. TDK is the latest Japanese company to blame a slowdown in the global economy for a work force reduction. Komatsu Ltd., the second-largest maker of construction machinery, said on Tuesday that it would cut 12 percent of its work force.

title: Panel of Iran Parliament to Review Foreign Policy
description: The Iranian Parliament has selected a special panel to study the nation's international relations in the face of a possible military strike by the United States against Afghanistan.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Deployments and Tensions

title: Jury Acquits Teenage Boy In Stable Fire
description: A teenager accused last year of igniting a fire in a Brooklyn stable that killed 21 horses and sent 30-foot flames soaring into the night sky was acquitted yesterday by a state jury.

title: Cayn Journal; Persistence Reclaims Indians' Ceremonial Grounds
description: At 83, Filomena Cayn is missing several front teeth and needs the help of a long stick to hike the wooded Andean trails of Lann National Park. But her memory is acute and the memories of the Mapuche Indians are full of struggle and pain.

title: As F.A.A. Eases Flight Bans, Airports Seek Return to Normal
description: A ban on flights of small private aircraft near Kennedy International Airport that had all but shut down Teterboro Airport in Bergen County, N.J., and Republic Airport in Farmingdale, N.Y., is to be scaled back today, and the airports said they would try to return to normal service.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a business jet venture planned by the UAL Corporation misstated the cost of a time share offered by Executive Jets Inc., the market leader. Its smallest share is a one-time investment of $375,000 plus $130,000 a year in fees for 50 hours of flying, not a total fee of $500,000 a year.

title: A Year Later, Free Serbia Struggles to Overcome Its Past
description: In a spirited re-enactment of the popular uprising that swept Slobodan Milosevic from power a year ago, fleets of trucks and buses, led by two yellow bulldozers, swept into the square in front of the federal Parliament today. One of the leaders of the revolt who spearheaded the punch into Parliament a year ago, when protesters set it ablaze, was swept up the steps in a cacophony of horns, whistles, a factory siren and a traditional Serbian brass band.

title: A Delicate and Humorous Glue For Schnittke's Varied Styles
description: New York Philharmonic

title: Oil Experts See Little Chance Of Cut in Russian Production
description: Russia, the world's second-largest oil exporter, is unlikely to reduce output or even slow its growth, despite pressure from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to fall in line with its attempts to shore up prices by restricting supply, analysts say.

title: Two College Powerhouses Think Really, Really Big
description: John-Michael Liles confided in his diary on Tuesday that he was trying to focus on his kinesiology class but that he had something else on his mind.

title: CABLEVISION SAYS IT MIGHT SELL SOME OF ITS SYSTEMS
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation of Bethpage, N.Y., said yesterday that it might sell some systems in the region after canceling a $1 billion stock offering and cutting 2001 financial forecasts. The company, which serves three million homes, said it was considering options that included selling assets, borrowing under its credit facilities or cutting capital spending. Investors have said AOL Time Warner Inc. is a likely bidder for Cablevision's cable properties because AOL Time Warner owns adjacent systems. Cablevision cited general market conditions for canceling the sale of stock.

title: Algerian Pilot Held in London Was Hijacking Suspects' Lead Trainer, Prosecutor Says
description: At flight schools here, people remember Lotfi Raissi working the controls of flight simulators with several Middle Eastern men. Mr. Raissi, an Algerian, had received his pilot's license in Arizona, and he told neighbors he was helping other Arab students learn to fly.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Weekend yesterday with a Critic's Notebook article about the progressive tradition in New York City architecture was published in error. It showed the Deutsche Bank building on the south side of West 53rd Street in Manhattan; the new building of the American Museum of Folk Art is across the street.

title: New Airline Board Is Given Wide Authority to Support the Industry
description: The Bush administration issued rules today giving a special emergency board wide discretion to support the troubled airline industry, even allowing it to use government-backed loans to underwrite mergers if it sees fit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DR. NATHALIE
description: FRIEDMAN-Dr. Nathalie. Passed away peacefully and with dignity in her home on Friday, October 5, 2001 at the age of 74, concluding a six year battle with cancer. Survived by adoring husband Israel Friedman; devoted children Steven (and Sheira) Schacter, Jessica (and Allen) Gribetz, Judith (and Mark) Tykocinski, and Naomi (and Jonathan) Price; loving brother Rabbi Haskel (and Audrey) Lookstein. Daughter of the late Rabbi Joseph and Gertrude Lookstein, and proud grandmother of eighteen grandchildren. Funeral services at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, 125 E. 85th St., Sunday, October 7th at 9:45 AM.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Frank Gasparro, designer of the reverse side of the Lincoln commemorative penny issued in 1959, included an outdated reference to the uniqueness of the design. While the coin was the first circulated by the United States with a likeness of the same person on both sides, it is no longer the only one; the 1999 New Jersey quarter has George Washington on both front and back.

title: Life, Ephemeral
description: To the Editor:

title: New Software Patent Law For Europe Looking Limited
description: The European Union appears to be moving toward unified regulations for software patents that would be less encompassing than regulations in the United States and Japan.

title: On Streets Of Jordan, Doubts Lurk About War
description: ''America is excellent,'' said Bassam Koranie, a businessman here, and he meant it. His brother is an American citizen, an immigrant from Jordan who now sells cars contentedly in Los Angeles. ''No, we don't hate Americans.''

title: U.S. and Afghans: Decision Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Principles, Postures And a Mayoral Race
description: To the Editor:

title: From Montreal, Melancholy And a Bad Case of Jitters
description: Coleman and Lemieux

title: Peca, Parrish and Osgood Make Difference for Isles
description: Michael Peca played his first National Hockey League game in almost 18 months tonight. Every hockey player should take such a breather.

title: A Sentimental Education (With Sex Lessons, Too)
description: ''Y Tu Mama Tambien'' -- the phrase translates from Spanish as ''And your mama, too'' -- is one of those Bildungsroman films that could begin or end with the phrase, ''And my life was never the same again.'' (The movie uses a voice-over narration, which it mercifully relies on less and less to explicate the inner lives of the characters.) But the director, Alfonso Cuar n, works with a quicksilver fluidity, and the movie, which plays today and tomorrow at the New York Film Festival, is fast, funny, unafraid of sexuality and finally devastating.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Challenge To Governor Siegelman

title: From Warsaw to Hollywood, a Film Mogul's Odyssey

The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Seymour Milstein, a distinguished leader in the Jewish community. As one of New York's most prominent real estate developers, he was deeply admired for his extraordinary leadership in business and philanthropy. His professional success was matched only by his compassionate concern for others. Through his exceptional devotion to UJA-Federation and its beneficiary agencies, he improved medical, educational, and cultural services for thousands of people in our community. His significant contributions to the Jewish community, and to humanitarian causes throughout New York City, will be felt for generations to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to Philip; to Mr. Milstein's beloved wife, Vivian; to his daughter, Constance; and to the entire Milstein family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. title: Enuf Pafology
description: Any book that's described on its dust jacket as ''a novel of family, race and publishing in America'' is bound to generate some skepticism. But Percival Everett's new novel, ERASURE (University Press of New England, $24.95), cunningly pokes fun at such lofty sentiment. With equal measures of sympathy and satire, it craftily addresses the highly charged issue of being ''black enough'' in America. Meet Thelonious Ellison, a k a Monk, an extremely intellectual yet not very successful avant-garde writer who has recently returned to Washington to care for his ailing mother. While there, sifting through the detritus of his family drama, Monk finds himself obsessed with the overwhelming success of another African-American writer's best seller, ''We's Lives in da Ghetto.'' He is appalled that the novel's young, middle-class, Oberlin-educated author based her book's so-called authentic urban experience on a couple of days spent visiting relatives in Harlem. In a fit of pique, Monk fires off a parody entitled ''My Pafology.'' (That book is printed in its entirety here.) Raw and scathing, a suburban teenager's gangsta fantasy brought to life, it tells the story of Van Go Jenkins, a hard-as-nails narrator steeped in the anger and futility of his inner-city life. The rub, of course, is that the novel, written under the pseudonym Stagg R. Leigh, also becomes a critical and commercial success. What, then, is a self-respecting writer to do? Accept the six-figure advance and multimillion-dollar movie deal? It is only thanks to Everett's well-calibrated and witty handling of this material that Monk manages to think his way through such a sticky situation. Jenifer Berman

title: Seeing a Garden's Bones, Imagining Its Body

I keep looking at the tall, red cedar that marks the brow of a field on our land, and pondering where I might plant a few cedars of my own; a little group of them perhaps, by an old foundation that for a few years has cradled my compost pile.

''His father was a fireman, and I knew that's what he always wanted to do,'' said Ms. Light, now the marketing director for Playboy Enterprises in New York. ''He loves it, and I supported him.''
