description: RAY OPTHOF scanned the faces. It was 7:40 a.m. Friday. The commuters, many of them New Yorkers suddenly working in New Jersey, stood three deep, waiting for the next trolley at the Newport station. ''There,'' said Mr. Opthof, a New Jersey Transit operations engineer. ''See? Over there. Definite first-timer.''

title: Connecticut Calls It a Night; One Family, Two Bosses, Three Hours of Sleep
description: THERE aren't enough hours in the day for Joseph Gibson.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a restaurant review of Marybeth's in Irvington last Sunday misstated the decade of Stanford White's design for the restaurant's building, the Cosmopolitan. It was the 1890's, not the 1980's.

title: In 80's, Afghan Militias Used U.S. Rifles
description: In the late 1980's, an American-based agent for Al Qaeda, the terrorist network led by Osama bin Laden, shipped to Afghanistan 25 military-style rifles capable of shooting down helicopters, piercing armor or destroying fuel tanks from long distances, according to a report by a gun control organization.

title: Art/Architecture; Beauty in the Shadow of Violence
description: I DON'T go to museums to relax or to be soothed. I don't go to be reassured that civilization still stands. I go with other needs and expectations. I go to be stimulated, to get the latest news from the distant past, to be made to think, though not necessarily to think easy thoughts.

title: In U.S. Plan, Taxpayers Would Cover Terror Claims
description: The Bush administration and Congress are preparing legislation to have taxpayers pay major insurance claims arising out of terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UPBIN, RUTH
description: UPBIN-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Elias. Devoted mother of Stanley, Sandra (Cookie) Hoffner and the late Jeanne Thompson. Loving sister of Barney Rosenstein. Cherished grandmother of Amy, Andrew, David, Steven, Richard, Sean, Ann Starr and Maccabee. Great grandmother of 10. Services today 1:30 PM at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Setting the Traps to Snare Online Predators
description: AFTER countless hours in the dim glow of computer screens, the police have learned to expect hurdles as they investigate suspected predators who troll the World Wide Web for children. Internet service providers unknowingly discard evidence. Language barriers can delay contact with the police in faraway jurisdictions. And young victims, blurry-eyed with romantic visions, have a hard time believing they were victims at all.

title: Lingering Echoes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Film, White Lies and Male Models
description: LAST weekend, while the national mood was still so somber and dispirited, two million people went to see ''Zoolander,'' a movie about male modeling. Three days into its release, ''Zoolander'' became a hit.

title: John C. Lilly Dies at 86; Led Study of Communication With Dolphins
description: Dr. John C. Lilly, a neuroscientist and writer who explored human consciousness, dolphin communication and the borders of reality with the showmanship of P. T. Barnum and the infectious zeal of Jacques Yves-Cousteau, died on Sept. 30 in Los Angeles. He was 86 and lived in Maui, Hawaii.

title: Thunderous Attack Heard in Kabul
description: TOPDARA, Afghanistan, Oct. 7  Sending bright flashes of light and loud concussions rolling across this farming plain just 35 miles north of Kabul, American military forces began what looked like a steady bombardment of targets in the Afghan capital tonight.

title: Unblinking Eye For the Unique
description: IT started in 1976 with an internship at WBZ in Boston during my senior year at Tufts University. I wanted some work experience, so I became a gofer for a public affairs program. I carried the camera equipment and answered the phone.

title: Syria Is Likely to Join U.N. Security Council
description: Syria, a country on the State Department's list of those that sponsor terrorism, is expected to win one of the 10 rotating seats on the Security Council next week with no resistance from the United States.

title: Cross-Checking, Slashing, and Moving Day
description: IN a scene repeated daily in communities all over Long Island, the big black-and-yellow rental truck sat in the driveway as the neighborhood's newest family sat on the floor of an empty living room and talked about their move.

title: Theater Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: A Chardonnay From Nassau
description: Banfi Vintners, with chardonnay planted next to its Old Brookville headquarters, is Nassau County's sole producer. Famously, it represents America's No. 1 and 2 imports: Concha y Toro (Chile) and Riunite (Italy).

title: BEACH CLOSED
description: Two-Mile Beach, a part of a national wildlife refuge in Lower Township, Cape May County, which normally opens to hiking and surf fishing on Oct. 1, will remain closed indefinitely because of security concerns for the Coast Guard station situated next to it, said Bruce Luebke, assistant manager for the Cape May National Wildlife Refuge. The beach is closed from spring until fall because it is a nesting ground for the endangered piping plover, but it is usual opens after the nesting season ends. The Coast Guard base by the beach houses the Loran Support Unit, an electronic navigational facility that guides planes and boats. Karen DeMasters

title: Is Gold Relevant? Quiet, Please!
description: THE debate over the role of gold in investment portfolios may boil down to just a few percentage points. But you would never know that by listening to the fervor with which the two sides disagree.

title: Exploring India's Southern Variations
description: ''I LOVE to go to places like this, but none of my friends do. What fun,'' said a diner at House of Dosas, a South Indian vegetarian restaurant in Hicksville that attracts adventurous eaters seeking authenticity and variety. Conservative meat-and-potato types are not among the sprinkling of Anglos who join the many natives of the subcontinent at this new 64-seat spot at 416 South Broadway (516-938-7517).

title: Green Presses Attack Tactics, Accusing Rival of Inconstancy
description: The Democratic campaign for Thursday's mayoral runoff took on a more personal tone yesterday, as Mark Green sought to portray himself as someone who would not change his opinions on issues like abortion and the death penalty for political gain -- implying, none too subtly, that Fernando Ferrer is someone who would.

title: What's Doing In Puerto Vallarta
description: Puerto Vallarta first appeared as a dot on the map of Mexico in 1918, and for two generations thereafter remained a little village. Then Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton showed up.

title: Patriotism Will Define Columbus Day Parade
description: The route, up Fifth Avenue, will be the same. There will be a grand marshal, too: Bobby Valentine, the manager of the Mets.

title: A City Changed Forever? Maybe Not
description: It has become a widely repeated clich in New York City in the last few weeks that the future can no longer be predicted because everything has changed. Amid all the losses after last month's terrorist attacks, there is a feeling that the city has lost its compass and its map to the future, too.

title: Remains of the Day
description: Let's make the light sculpture conceived in ''Phantom Towers'' a reality. Towers of light would ''restore'' the skyline of our city and would be a fitting memorial to those whose lives ended there on Sept. 11.

title: Off to Bed in a T-Shirt, Long Johns or PJs
description: NOT everyone wears pajamas; some even admit it. When Marilyn Monroe was asked what she wore to bed, she supposedly replied, ''Chanel No. 5.''

title: 'Requiem for a Lost Empire'
description: It has always been my conviction that the house that sheltered their love, and later my own birth, was much closer to the night and its constellations than to the life of that vast country they had managed to escape without leaving its territory. The country surrounded them, encircled them, but they were elsewhere. And if, in the end, it discovered them, hidden deep in the woods in the Caucasus, this was the chance outcome of a game of symbols.

title: Sept. 30-Oct.6; Lethal Car Bomb in Kashmir
description: A suicidal attack on the legislative assembly in the Indian state of Kashmir killed 40 people, and has brought India's unease with the American-Pakistan alliance to combat terrorism into the open. India is demanding that the United States outlaw the group implicated in the attack, Jaish-e-Muhammad, which is based in Pakistan. Taking a page from the American playbook, Indian officials are talking about military strikes against training camps in Pakistan-held Kashmir. Celia W. Dugger

title: For Millie Readers, Some Final Advice
description: THE year was 1935: Franklin D. Roosevelt was starting Phase 2 of the New Deal, the Gallup Poll was just being created and Cond Nast published the first number of a magazine called Mademoiselle. It celebrated jaunty coeds and Butterick sewing patterns; it was a forerunner of generations of That Girls to come -- smart young women living on their own.

title: Cavett's Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Investment, Reborn
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRUSA, ROSE B.
description: PETRUSA-Rose B. On October 5, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Anthony, loving mother of Annette and Charles and grandmother of Jeffrey and Douglas. Dear sister of Jeanne, Frances and Paul. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Monday 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass at Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church, 307 East 33rd St. Tuesday 11 am. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Mary Manning Walsh Home or Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church.

title: Office-Building Plans Come Off the Shelf
description: THE need for prime office space as a result of the destruction of 13 million square feet of office space and damage to 16.5 million more square feet in the attack on the World Trade Center has caused developers and brokers to focus attention on long-dormant development projects in Midtown and elsewhere.

title: Legal Residency Hopes of Millions Dashed
description: In the summer, a bolt of hope shot through this city as the Bush administration edged toward granting legal residency to millions of illegal immigrants from Mexico and perhaps other countries.

title: Relief Extends to Student Loans
description: Financial relief for the victims of the attacks continues to grow. One of the latest forms comes from Sallie Mae, the nation's largest lender to students.

title: How the Growl Became a Roar
description: FOR most mutual fund investors, about the only nice thing that can be said about the summer of 2001 is that it ended.

title: Private Skies Of the Very Rich
description: AT a small dinner party in New York last weekend, the conversation among the well-to-do guests turned to vacation plans. The diners -- husbands in custom-made shirts, wives with dewy, laser-blasted faces -- spoke of the potential strain of commercial air travel and the special frustrations this holiday season will surely hold.

title: The Nation; Trying to Fight Two Wars at Once
description: PRESIDENT BUSH has discovered how hard it is to fight two wars at once.

title: Television/Radio; How to Tell New York Stories Now
description: LIFE in New York may have gotten infinitely sadder and more confusing after the events of Sept. 11, but on the small screen, art is not imitating life. At least not yet.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about schools' use of art and writing to help children cope with the attack on the World Trade Center misstated the grade of Adolfo Ruiz at Thomas A. Edison School in Union City. He is in the seventh grade, not the second.

title: Christopher Plummer Drops By Westport
description: CHRISTOPHER PLUMMER thinks of calling it his charity act, but that lacks panache -- a word and a style indelibly associated with the actor since his 1974 Tony Award-winning performance in ''Cyrano,'' the musical.

title: BackTalk; When Image and Reality Collide
description: The way a player is remembered seems a matter of large import in sports. A Hall of Fame enshrines each sport's ideals as manifested in certain men. Football is about assault and survival, as much as it is about anything. Collisions are where each play starts and ends. Grace exists on the field to elude savagery. Men are meant to smash into each other, the harder the better. But they are supposed to get back up. If not instantly, then in seconds, or minutes. After injury they come back. It may be months later, or even a year later. But they come back.

title: When Patriotism and Journalism Clash
description: Mark Preiser, a partner in Walter F. Cameron Advertising in Melville, on Long Island, said he learned about the dispute when a client telephoned to say that he was considering whether to pull his advertisements from News 12, Cablevision's all-news channel on Long Island.

title: Violent Sounds of an Escape From the 71st Floor
description: While much of the world will never forget the images of destruction, Omar E. Rivera will never forget the violent, terrifying sounds. Even in quiet moments, Mr. Rivera, who is blind, still hears the explosive boom of a hijacked plane smashing into 1 World Trade Center.

title: Addendum to the Syllabus: Terrorism in America 101
description: Brigitte Nacos, an adjunct professor of political science at Columbia University, had been slated to teach Political Science W3922, Section 3: ''Political Violence and Terror in the American Context'' long before Sept. 11.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Orangeburg; From Big Army Base to Residential Hub
description: WHEN Christine and John Cusack found out that they were expecting their first child, they made plans to buy their first house.

title: In a Valley of Desolation, Home Is Still Home
description: BEFORE Sept. 11, Battery Park City was a neighborhood that didn't have real problems. The biggest local controversy concerned a series of proposals that would have banned bicycles and dogs from the lovely esplanade that borders the Hudson.

title: 'Legal Lynching'
description: It is August 6, 1890. Ninteenth-century America is waking up to the power of twentieth-century technology, to the first lightbulbs, phonographs, telephones, automobiles.

title: Too Cool For School
description: Abercrombie & Fitch has offended more moralists than Eminem with its quarterly magalog, whose photos of seminaked college jocks put the ''camp'' into ''campus.''

title: The Nation: Hide and Seek; To Fight in the Shadows, Get Better Eyes
description: AS Sept. 11 dawned, thousands of people at America's intelligence agencies were already at their desks. Many had been assigned to think about the wrong things: what had happened the day before in Kosovo or the Kremlin, Indonesia or Iraq.

title: Travel Advisory; Bicycle Route Links North Sea Countries
description: A long-distance bicycle route linking seven European countries has recently been completed. The 3,750-mile North Sea Cycle Route passes through Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, England and Scotland using ferry crossings.

title: Text of Prime Minister Tony Blair's Remarks
description: The following is text of a speech by Prime Minister Tony Blair regarding Britain's role in the attacks on Afghanistan, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Plenty of Pain to Share in Zimbabwe Land Reform
description: Every morning the sun rises over the glimmering tobacco fields and the black revolutionary carefully sharpens his machete, determined to reclaim the land stolen from his grandfathers. The white farmer sips her tea and prepares for her daily walk, determined to keep the soil she bought and paid for 10 years ago.

title: Devils Routed as Jagr Joins In
description: Before the puck was dropped for his debut with the Washington Capitals tonight, Jaromir Jagr emerged through a tunnel enveloped by green laser lights and joined his new teammates on the blue line. When the thunderous ovation at the MCI Center subsided, the Capitals raised their Southeast Division championship banner. As video screens revisited the franchise's accomplishments of a season ago, Jagr took a step back from the blue line and let the rest of the team accept the applause.

title: Leaders of Both Parties Issue Joint Statement Backing Strikes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  In an unusual display of political unity, the top leaders of both parties in Congress issued a joint statement today endorsing President Bush's decision to begin military strikes in Afghanistan.

title: 'The World Below'
description: Imagine it: a dry, cool day, the high-piled cumulus clouds moving slowly from northwest to southeast in the sky, their shadows following them across the hay fields yet to be cut for the last time this year. Down a narrow dirt road between the fields, a horse-drawn carriage, two old people wearing their worn Sunday clothes seated side by side in it, driving to town for their grown daughter's funeral. Neither of them spoke, though you could see, if you cared to look, that the old woman's lips were moving ceaselessly, silently repeating the same few phrases over and over. It was her intention, formed over the long weeks her daughter lay dying, to rescue her grandchildren from their situation, from their motherless house. To take all three of them back to the farm with her. She was rehearsing what she'd say, though she wasn't aware of her mouth forming the words, and her husband didn't notice.

title: Military Clerics Balance Arms and Allah
description: The pipe organ in the small military chapel here at Walter Reed Army Medical Center is silent. Instead, the sound of worship is a human voice calling, deep and clear, ''Allahu Akbar'' -- ''God is great.''

title: Westchester Calls It a Night; The Treadmill, Dinner and Then The Second Job of Grading Papers
description: FOR the most part, Peter Gouveia's evenings are as orderly as his lesson plans. The affable 30-year-old teaches seventh-grade English at Rye Middle School, and lives in a condominium at Landmark Square, more familiarly known as the old Life Saver Building, in Port Chester.

title: Survey Says Most Employers Have Policies for Reservists
description: As the United States activates thousands of military reservists in response to the terrorist attacks, businesses are deciding how to handle compensation and medical benefits for the affected employees and their families.

title: Investing; Cherry-Picking REIT's in Flux
description: ON Sept. 10, a Jersey City office tower being built across the Hudson River from the World Trade Center had lease commitments for roughly one-third of its one million square feet of space. Three weeks later, the building was ''close to being full,'' said Mitchell Hersh, chief executive of the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, which owns it.

title: Pettitte Seems To Be Ready For Playoffs
description: Andy Pettitte pitched five scoreless innings in his first outing since being hit on the left elbow by a line drive Sept. 26, and appeared ready for his playoff start against Oakland Thursday.

title: Full Disclosure
description: UTILITY CLOSET, TRIBECA.

title: Turning Off the Television, Raising the Children Alone
description: After the first plane hit the World Trade Center, the phone lines out of the center lit up as people frantically tried to reach loved ones. If someone had tapped into those lines, they would have heard a cacophony of voices in different languages, some consoling, others frightened.

title: Sept. 30-Oct.6; Rush of Violence in Mideast
description: The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, infuriated the White House by saying it might ''appease Arabs'' in the haste to build an international coalition to fight terrorism, while Israelis and Palestinians swapped some of the bloodiest assaults of their yearlong conflict. Two Palestinian gunmen raided an Israeli settlement in Gaza, killing two, and a Palestinian dressed as an Israeli soldier shot up a bus station in Afula, killing three. Then Israeli forces occupied two neighborhoods in the West Bank city of Hebron, where five Palestinians died in fierce fighting. James Bennet

title: Cinderblock Kills Girl, 15
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn girl has died after being struck in the head by a cinderblock that fell from a building's facade, the authorities said.

title: Megan Hoey, James Galvin
description: Megan Gaele Hoey, a sales assistant, and James Francis Galvin, a police officer, were married yesterday by Msgr. Joseph P. Nagle at St. Saviour Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: You've Canceled the Trip, But Maybe Not the Bill
description: Many travel companies, like cruise lines and tour operators, have been quick to accommodate customers who changed their plans after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. But that has not been true across the board.

title: Flying Again
description: To the Editor: In ''Boarding a Plane, Staying the Course,'' (Sept. 23) Francine Prose refers to a range of motivators as reasons why people triumph over flight-related anxiety, including desire, professional obligation and private indulgence and now, since Sept. 11, moral obligation.

title: Oklahoma Defense Hooks Texas' Simms
description: Don't jump, Oklahoma Coach Bob Stoops told his strong safety, Roy Williams. Don't put yourself out of position the way you did before. Don't let Texas quarterback Chris Simms get around you and start a 97-yard drive to take the lead in the final two minutes of this fierce defensive drama.

title: Unemployed Struggle to Make Do in Difficult Economic Times; Computer Expert Turns to Odd Jobs To Help Pay Bills
description: If the United States was teetering on the edge of recession before Sept. 11, the terrorist attacks were a decisive shove over the edge. The number of workers filing for first-time state unemployment benefits has soared to a nine-year high. ''This is just the initial wave of layoffs due to the attacks,'' Steven Wood, an economist, said. ''There's another wave behind it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAVIK, VLADISLAV (WALTER)
description: SLAVIK-Vladislav (Walter), 77. Died September 10, 2001 of lung cancer. Born in Czechoslovakia, left the country in protest of the Communist regime. In 1950 came to the United States, was active in American Sokol Org. He served as a gymnastic coach, educator and translator. His leadership was always guided by Democratic principles in which he fiercely believed. Worked for the NY Times 1962-1991, in the composing room and chairman of the Typo. Union, local 6. Was President of the World Sokol Org. promoting international student exchange for gymnastic & cultural enrichment. In 2000, the Czech goverment presented him with the Jan Masaryk ''Gratias Agit'' award expressing appreciation for his contribution to the deepening Czech-American relationship and the restoration of democracy in the Czech Republic. He is deeply loved. And is greatly missed. Memorial services November 3, 2001, 2 PM in Sokol Hall, 420 East 71 Street.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: ON THE NIGHT PLAIN

title: Progress Is Apparently Made In Torre-Steinbrenner Meeting
description: With less than a month remaining on Manager Joe Torre's contract, he and George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, seemed to make progress today in negotiations for an extension.

title: Home Design; Domesticities
description: Everyone's home is, to some extent, a self-portrait. But few people actually wander around their house or apartment actively seeking affirmation. Instead, home becomes a haven from the rest of the world. It changes at your own pace, or not at all. You know where everything is (most of the time), and unless a pipe bursts or the chimney backs up, there are no unpleasant surprises. Here's the place where you like to have coffee every morning; over there's the chair where the light is just right for reading. This refuge may be modern and minimalist, or swagged and flowered, but it's just the way you like it, and when you walk in the door at the end of the day, you're exactly where you want to be.

title: At Small Airports, a Struggle
description: DAVID PRUTZMAN spent the last year trying to get his pilot's license. He spent more than $5,000 on instructor's fees, fuel expenses, plane rentals and licensing costs.

title: Paperback Fiction
description: This

title: After 5 for the 25-to-Life Set
description: AT the end of Institution Road, right before the mountains, sits what looks like a castle. Surrounded by walls, bladed-barbed wire and guard towers, the structure is in fact the Eastern New York Correctional Facility, a maximum-security prison that incarcerates 1,000 men, most serving long sentences, if not life.

title: Sharing the Small Stuff
description: ''Caillou'' looks at the world through the eyes of its 4-year-old namesake in six new episodes to have their premieres throughout the week, beginning tomorrow at 10 a.m. on Channel 13. From ''Celebrations,'' in which Caillou learns about differences while attending a hispanic friend's birthday party and a Chinese new year party, to ''Try, Try Again'' (as in practice makes perfect), the series takes life's not-always-so-simple lessons and presents them in a way preschoolers can understand.

title: New York Heightens Security as Mayor Tries to Calm City
description: New York City heightened security procedures today as the United States and its allies began a long-awaited military strike on Afghanistan in retaliation for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Lingering Echoes; The New York Pickle As Star of the Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Offer Tickets To Students for $10
description: The Knicks will hold an exclusive ticket sale today at noon at the Madison Square Garden box office. Tickets for home games during the 2001-02 regular season will be available for $10 each to students, grades K-12 only.

title: Fast Trains
description: To the Editor: While John Tagliabue's article ''Airlines Feel Pressure of Europe's Fast Trains'' (Aug. 12) highlighted the advantages of European rail travel, on two occasions, my husband and I have been thwarted in our holiday plans by train cancelations.

title: Cynthia Gooen, Jacob Lesser
description: Cynthia Rachel Gooen, the daughter of Susan and Kenneth Gooen of Somerset, N.J., was married in Washington last evening to Jacob Lesser, a son of Mary and David M. Lesser of New Haven. Rabbi Arthur Blecher officiated at the Washington Club.

description: SWIFT AS DESIRE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTLIN, WEISS, RANDI
description: WITTLIN-WEISS-Randi. 40, on October 6, after a courageous, prolonged bout with breast cancer. A love of life, a positive attitude and an unwavering determination to forge on and lead a ''normal'' life as a devoted wife and a nurturing mother... these were some of the qualities that defined Randi, that made her who she was, her modus operandi. That she was able to continually exhibit such fortitude and verve, notwithstanding the many challenges her fateful predicament brought, had those around her, family, friends, and neighbors alike, always marveling. As one special friend recalled, ''To accept fate without bitterness is rare, to accept it as Randi did, with such strength and resolve, is remarkable.'' After graduating with a marketing degree in 1983 from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, Randi pursued a career in marketing with Forbes, and subsequently with Times-Mirror Magazines. Randi is survived by her husband Ken, sons Roy and Gil, father Mike, brothers Ellis and Richard, in-laws Neil and Virginia, Ruth, Debbie, Sari, Douglas, David and Liz Darby, and nephews Donald, jared, Todd, Darren and Stefan. An inspiraton to us all, Randi will forever be in our hearts. We suggest contributions be made to the American Cancer Society, Breast Cancer Research, 19 W. 56th St, NYC 10019-3984. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Monday, October 8, 10:30 AM. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI. The family will receive for one day only directly after interment, at 9 Hamptworth Dr, Kings Point, NY 11024.

title: The Tested Value Of Toughing It Out
description: KENNETH E. LITTLE'S topical paperback defies the seductive truth that it's better to sell a stock at 80 and buy it back at 40 than ride it all the way down. He warns instead that unwary investors typically manage to achieve the reverse. They jump in just as the market peaks; they bail out at or near the bottom.

title: Film; When Crime No Longer Pays
description: SHOEHORNED rather awkwardly into the forthcoming film ''Bandits'' is an exchange between Cate Blanchett, as an unhappily married woman taken in tow by two bank robbers played by Bruce Willis and Billy Bob Thornton, and Mr. Willis, on the touchy subject of what his character does for a living. Indignantly disputing her suggestion that his actions harm innocent depositors, he reminds her that their funds are insured by the federal government. As if someone on the set had noticed that as rationales go, this bit of helpful information is on the flat side, Mr. Willis briefly turns into an anti-Washington zealot: ''The government steals money,'' he instructs Ms. Blanchett. ''We just take it back from them.''

title: Courtney Murray, Joseph Goldsmith
description: Courtney Murray, the daughter of Lois and William B. Murray of Key Biscayne, Fla., was married yesterday to Joseph Beatman Goldsmith, a son of Dorothy and Walter B. Goldsmith of Palm Desert, Calif. Judge John C. Cratsley of the Massachusetts Superior Court officiated at Gedney Farm, an inn in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Art/Architecture; For Now, Restricted Access. But What of the Future?
description: ONE day I'll take it for granted again: the sight of people walking south through Foley Square. But today it is the most beautiful vision in the world. Minutes after the World Trade Center attack, I saw people running north along Centre Street, past the United States Court House and the billowing clouds of black, sky-high smoke from which they were apparently trying to flee. When I returned home, the view of New Yorkers going about their business was as rousing as the American flag.

title: American Treasures
description: THE new frontier and the undiscovered vista -- in recent years, they have become the great quests for American travelers who look at familiar landmarks closer to home and sometimes see clichs. But in times when our souls are in need of balm, there is much to be said for the homey destination next door.

title: An Award for Perth Amboy
description: Perth Amboy has won a $50,000 award from the National Endowment for the Arts to pay for the design of a new high school that emphasize landscape considerations as well as the needs of an urban community.

title: A Hunting Tradition Is Upheld, Along With a Bond Between Cousins
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 393 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 335. In all, 4,979 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: Jessica Ross, John O'Neill
description: Jessica Ross, the daughter of Jane Ross Scott and the stepdaughter of Derek A. Scott of Yamhill, Ore., is to be married today to John Corry O'Neill, the son of Joanne and Hugh O'Neill of New York. Evelyn Langlieb Greer, the mayor of Pinecrest, Fla., is to officiate at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUFRO, SALWYN
description: SHUFRO-Salwyn. Beloved husband of 71 years of Edna; devoted father of Edward and Marlene Shufro and Joan and Ronald Silverman; grandfather of Joyce Shufro Espinosa, Nicholas and Jennifer Shufro, Gregory and Jennifer Shufro, Susanna Silverman, Valerie Silverman and greatgrandfather of Zachary and Julia Shufro. Son of Jacob J. and Rebecca P. Shufro. Born in 1905 in New York City. Graduate of City College and Harvard Business School. Co-founded Shufro, Rose & Co. in 1938 as a member of the New York Stock Exchange, an investment advisory firm. He was a man of vision and integrity, loved and esteemed by all who knew him. Services are private. The family will be receiving visitors at the home of Joan and Ronald Silverman, on Monday, October 8th after 7PM.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for RAINER HERTRICH and PHILIPPE CAMUS; Airbus, Unshaken, Is Not Cutting Back
description: THE airline industry crisis created by the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 quickly infected the American commercial aerospace industry. A week after the attacks, the Boeing Company said it would lay off up to 15 percent of its work force and trim 2002 production by 20 percent as financially struggling airlines scrapped plans to buy new planes.

title: Few Commando Units in Striking Distance
description: For all the emphasis that Pentagon planners have put on Special Operations forces in a war against the network of Osama bin Laden and the Taliban government, at the moment relatively few of these secretive soldiers are within striking distance of the heart of Afghanistan, officials at the Pentagon say.

title: Private Sector; Giving New Meaning to a Book Rush
description: It can often take months for the business book industry to adjust to changing economic conditions. But in the case of the trauma caused by the Sept. 11 attacks, the business publishing world has already responded. The first of what could be a business book trend, ''Financial Security in Troubled Times: What You Need to Do Now,'' by Ric Edelman, goes on sale Oct. 30. Mr. Edelman, a financial adviser in Fairfax, Va., who has written three personal-finance books including a best seller, ''Ordinary People, Extraordinary Wealth,'' said he wrote the book because the attack had ''left many people uncertain about the future and troubled about their personal financial security.'' He said his proceeds from the book, which costs $14.95 and is to be published by HarperBusiness, will be donated to Sept. 11 relief charities.

title: Lingering Echoes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-07-01: Close Reading: Elements of Impending Battles; The Volunteer
description: A commander in the Hezbul Mujahadeen, a band of Islamic militants, Kiramat Ullah loves to fight, loves to watch videos of fighting, loves to listen to songs about fighting and would be honored to die in battle against American soldiers. When I visited his militia's provincial headquarters outside Peshawar, a battered stereo was playing a tune that included these lines: ''The way of jihad/Is the way of success/The way of jihad/Is the way of the Koran.''

title: Sharon Apologizes Over Dispute With U.S.
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel apologized tonight for what he called a misunderstanding caused by his warning that the United States risked appeasing Arab nations the way Europe appeased Adolf Hitler before World War II.

title: Cause of Blast Fatal to 29 Still Eludes France
description: More than 100 investigators are working to figure out what caused the devastating explosion at a petrochemical plant in Toulouse last month, but have not yet answered the basic question, whether it was an industrial accident or a deliberate act.

title: Next Generation Turns to Table Games
description: GONE are the days when college students clustered around tables to play bridge. Now, they're updating their Palm handhelds and checking their e-mail, playing a quick game of solitaire before heading off to their next class.

title: Alyson Dritz, Jeffrey Schlosser
description: Alyson Blair Dritz, a daughter of Rollyn and James L. Dritz of Armonk, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Adam Schlosser, a son of Steven Schlosser of Saratoga, Calif., and the late Nina Schlosser. Rabbi Nadia Gold officiated at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Cyber Scout; A Test of Online Agencies
description: When the first plane hit the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, Sherry Stewart, a Cleveland-based systems engineer, was on Vancouver Island, more than 2,000 miles from home, helping a friend celebrate her 50th birthday. Ms. Stewart had booked the flight -- her first ever -- using the Travelocity Web site, and she was scheduled to fly home on Sept. 13.

title: A Key And Sympathy
description: Years ago, more than I care to remember, I learned about domesticity some would say the hard way. My mother died. She was 60, and I was a teenager.

title: Greetings From the New World: A Postcard From Columbus
description: During his voyage in 1492, Columbus wrote a letter to Raphael Sanchez, King Ferdinand's treasurer, announcing he had found new lands in the western ocean. The letter was published as a book in 1493 and other editions followed. The title of the document known as The Columbus Letter was: ''A Letter of Christopher Columbus to Whom Our Age is Much Indebted About the Recently Discovered Islands of India Beyond the Ganges in Search of Which He Had Spent Eight Months Before Under the Auspices and the Expense of the Most Invincible Ferdinand, King of the Spains.'' The Firestone Library at Princeton University has three copies. Stephen Ferguson, curator of rare books at Firestone Library, talked about them.

title: Sept. 30-Oct.6; No Autographs, Please
description: War has a way of making television stars. (Remember the Scud Stud, Arthur Kent of NBC News, during the Persian Gulf war?).

title: The 2 Worlds of Muslim American Teenagers
description: They are Americans who feel duty-bound by Islam to obey American laws. But some of them say that if their country called them to war against a Muslim army, they might refuse to fight. They cannot be shaken from the conviction that America is intrinsically anti-Muslim. Yet they see it as the one place where Muslims are free to be themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODES, DR. M.E.
description: HODES-Dr. M.E. The Board of Trustees, Scientific Advisory Board, and professional staff of the Israel Cancer Research Fund mourn the loss of a dear colleague and friend, Dr. M.E. (''Ed'') Hodes. Chairman Emeritus of ICRF's International Scientific Council, he was a dedicated humanitarian, deeply respected by all who knew him. His warmth, wit, wisdom, and devotion to ICRF will be sorely missed. Yashar Hirshaut, M.D. President Daniel G. Miller, MD President Emeritus Leah Susskind Chairman S. Donald Friedman Chairman Emeritus Donald Adelman Executive Vice President

title: Ireland Plans Referendum To Tighten Abortion Ban
description: The Irish government announced plans this week for a national referendum on a constitutional amendment that would ban on abortion except in cases when woman would die by carrying her pregnancy to term.

title: Justice Department Files Computer Associates Suit
description: The Justice Department has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Washington against Computer Associates International (NYSE: CA) of Islandia, saying that the company imposed improper restrictions on an Illinois software company it bought in early 1999.

title: Art/Architecture; Lowly Everyday Objects as High Art
description: ALLAH is the light of the heavens and the earth. His light may be compared to a niche that enshrines a lamp, the lamp within a crystal of starlight brilliance. Light upon light.'' These words from the Koran appear in elegant script on the exterior of a gilded glass mosque lamp from 14th-century Egypt, one of the treasures of the Metropolitan Museum Islamic collection.

title: Tweezer, an Airplane Risk
description: Before checking their luggage and heading toward the metal detectors, women should search one more place for possible contraband: makeup bags. In addition to confiscating disposable razors, scissors and Swiss Army knives, security officials at airports have been taking eyebrow tweezers, cuticle clippers and metal nail files. ''We haven't been gathering data, but we've seen it anecdotally,'' said Pasquale DiFulco, a Port Authority spokesman. ''We've collected things like manicure kits and metal tweezers with a sharp point on them.''

title: Broad Canvas on Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: The City Beautiful
Laurie Walters, Hans Bald
description: Laurie Jeanne Walters and Hans Walter Bald are to be married today by the Rev. Darwin Price at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Fort Greene Journal; A Godsend in the Guise of a Ball Field
description: At Brooklyn Technical High School, they called it a football practice ground. But there were more weeds than grass and the players were challenged more by broken glass and concrete rubble than by scrimmage opponents.

title: Corrections
description: The Habitats column last Sunday, about the owner of a penthouse whose home reflects her interest in China, misstated the age of an antique watering trough on the terrace. It is from the Ming Dynasty, A.D. 1368-1644; it is not 2,000 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RONALD
description: SCHWARTZ-Ronald. October 4, 2001. Boca Raton, FL. formerly of Bellmore, NY. Beloved husband of Adrienne. Cherished father of Meryl, Debbie and her husband Richard. Proud and loving Poppie to Rob, Josh and Erica. Son of the late Max and Rose Schwartz. Cousin and friend to many. Service at 10 A,M, Sunday, October 7th at Gutterman's, Woodbury, NY.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 7, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Forever Rad
description: I have not forgotten walking about New York in the 1970's and looking over my shoulder when the Weathermen were doing their bombing and killing. I have not forgotten the extraordinary security in the lobbies of buildings housing large banks and other potential targets.

title: Sept. 30-Oct.6; Britain to Revamp Asylum
description: The British government announced plans to overhaul its asylum system, saying it wanted to address the dual problems of illegal immigration and an underground economy that exploited unskilled labor. Under the current system, many would-be migrants turn to people traffickers to get into Britain, and work at menial jobs for little pay once they get there. Among the new proposals are to set up an American-style work permit system to allow highly skilled foreigners to live in Britain without specific jobs lined up, provided they support themselves while looking for work, and to expand the seasonal permit program in agriculture to other sectors. Sarah Lyall

title: Remains of the Day
description: 'Phantom Towers,'' the image on your cover is a fine proposal for a memorial for the World Trade Center (Sept. 23). What could better represent the lost lives, the courageous rescue effort, the inspired leadership and a city reborn than two towers of light reaching into the heavens? It would be a solemn reminder that New York and America are beacons of hope and freedom for the world.

title: A Greenmarket Program Is Raising A Crucial Crop: New Farmers
description: As New York City eased its way into dawn one summer Saturday, Augustin Juarez kneeled in the dirt and plucked fat fruit from one of 600 tomato vines.

title: After the Shock: Is This the Bottom?
description: THE hijackers brought down the World Trade Center and traumatized a nation. But it is not as clear that the economic damage they wrought will be long lasting.

title: Private Sector; The Healing Power of Art, From an Aerospace Veteran
description: Aeronautical engineering was Daniel M. Tellep's professional love for more than 40 years. He started as a scientist of experimental missile re-entry at Lockheed in the 1950's and rose to become chief executive of Lockheed and later, Lockheed Martin, one of the nation's biggest military contractors. But after he retired in 1996, Mr. Tellep decided to pursue a love he had long suppressed -- painting.

title: A Fund Finds Refuge In a Range of Bonds
description: BOND mutual funds have not always been investor favorites, perhaps because they are complex and tend to generate modest if steady returns. But bonds can be a refuge in quarters like the last one, when the stock market was unwelcoming.

title: Venice's Lido
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Venice'' (Aug. 12) did not mention one of the most beautiful areas of Venice -- the Lido, a narrow bar of land between the lagoon and the sea, just a short boat ride from St. Mark's Square.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-07-01; Out of Egypt
description: I almost know Mohamed Atta, the Egyptian who may have been at the controls of the jet that crashed into the north tower of the World Trade Center. I can almost make him out. I have known Egypt for nearly three decades, and so much of Atta's life falls neatly in place for me. I can make out the life of the 33-year-old man, one of a vast generation of younger Egyptians making their claims on a crowded land, picking their way through the cultural confusion that has settled upon the country in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLYWOOD, VERONICA C. (NEE GRAY)
description: HOLLYWOOD-Veronica C. (nee Gray). On October 5, 2001. Beloved wife of Francis X. Loving mother of Anne-Marie Govoni and Daniel. Dear grandmother of Katherine Hollywood, Matthew and Carolyn Govoni. Sister of Doris Hiller. Family will receive friends Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Conception Church, Tuesday, 10 AM.

title: Private Sector; Last Stop on This Caravan
description: Edward P. Bass may be best known for financing the Biosphere 2 experimental ecosystem in the Arizona desert, but his most offbeat, imaginative project may have been the Caravan of Dreams, an experiment in Fort Worth that lasted much longer but ended a week ago. Mr. Bass, a member of the wealthy Bass brothers clan, opened Caravan of Dreams in 1983 with a concert by Ornette Coleman, whose avant-jazz left Fort Worth socialites, in black tie, politely puzzled. At Caravan, Mr. Bass combined a jazz club, theater and, on the rooftop, grotto bar and global cactus garden under a geodesic dome. It began transforming the downtown into one of the nation's liveliest.

title: Film Festivals and Series
description: The 39th New York

title: Letting the Dogs Out For Puppy Kindergarten
description: DENY it if you will, but a pet's behavior almost always reflects on that of its owner, one of the factors that has led to a plethora of dog training schools in Westchester and the surrounding area, where people congregate after work to bask in the reflected glow of their animals' charms. They can also find others who won't mind talking about toilet training, nipping and neutering.

title: A Time for Warm and Cuddly
description: Asked what qualities they would look for in a companion, most New Yorkers until recently would have chosen smarts and successfulness over warmth and fuzziness. But the city has a serious case of puppy love. ''Everyone is depressed and wants something to hug,'' said Jeffrey Owens, manager of Pets on Lex on Lexington Avenue (85th Street), who reports a ''huge increase in puppy sales'' since Sept. 11. Grown-up puppies are in demand at the International Kennel Club on Second Avenue. At Urban Pets Inc. on Christopher Street, sales have increased 30 percent in recent weeks, said the manager, Fernanda Moritz. ''The people buying them are sad and upset,'' she said. Phyllis S. Zilkha, a Manhattan psychologist, says the puppy boom is a healthy sign. ''Taking care of a new life that is totally innocent, and loves you without judgment, gives you hope for the future,'' she said. And, perhaps, a new best friend. JENNIFER TUNG

title: Taking the Consumers' Pulse
description: If the economy were not already in recession, the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 probably sent it over the edge -- stopping most consumer activity in its tracks. How soon the economy recovers may have a lot to do with how quickly consumers return to their spending habits of earlier this year. The following statistics measure how consumers are doing.

title: Sept. 30-Oct.6; Economic Rescue Efforts
description: President Bush said he would work with Congress to create a package of new tax cuts and spending worth as much as $75 billion to help the flagging economy. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told lawmakers it was now clear that the economy could use help of that scale. But on Capitol Hill, Democrats emphasized helping laid-off workers, while Republicans said they wanted most of the money for tax cuts. Mounting job losses added to pressures to compromise. Richard W. Stevenson

title: In Hindsight, C.I.A. Sees Flaws That Hindered Efforts on Terror
description: George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, issued a secret directive shortly after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks declaring an abrupt end to business as usual in America's intelligence community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JEROME G.
description: SHAPIRO-Jerome G., 77. Died Tuesday, October 2, 2001 after complications from a stroke and Alzheimer's disease. He practiced law in New York City for over 45 years with the firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, becoming its Chairman from 1975-1989. Survived by his wife of 42 years, Marjorie Mackay Shapiro, three children, Jeffrey Kemble, Jill Dara and Eric Noach, and six grandchildren. He is also mourned by his beloved sister, Norma Kleiner and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue and West 91st Street on Sunday, October 7th at 3 PM. Burial service will be at Abel's Hill Cemetery in Chilmark, MA at 4 PM on Thursday, October 4, 2001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his honor to the Alzheimer's Association of New York, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

title: Phillips Faces a Busy, and Early, Winter
description: When Robin Ventura works out this winter, he will not reflect on the slumps or the hot streaks that marked his and his team's season. ''The baseball part is baseball,'' said Ventura, the Mets' third baseman. ''Most of it is just going to be the stuff that happened the last three weeks. That sticks in your mind more than baseball.''

title: The World: Alliance Building; When the Enemy of Your Enemy Is Your Friend's Enemy
description: GREAT promises -- and terrible possibilities -- attend the formation of an American-led coalition against terrorism. Even a loose alliance has to be built (and for the long haul) among nations with differing -- often conflicting -- national interests. In some regions, huge hopes have arisen that the coming confrontation will somehow also unloose solutions to a few of the most deadly and dangerous longstanding crises.

title: Liberties; Touch Of Evil
description: I've always loved film noir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOL, HYMAN
description: SOKOL-Hyman, 95. Of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Queens, NY, passed away September 29, 2001. Beloved husband of Elsie, loving father of Malcom (Sheila) Sokol and Barry (Ricki) Sokol. Cherished grandfather of four. He was much loved by everyone. Funeral services on Monday in Florida, at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 800-947-4256.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Putting the Pieces in Place

title: Reckonings; Fuzzy Math Returns
description: Post-terror nerves aside, what mainly ails the U.S. economy is too much of a good thing. During the bubble years businesses overspent on capital equipment; the resulting overhang of excess capacity is a drag on investment, and hence a drag on the economy as a whole.

title: Personal Business; Before Donating, Don't Be Afraid to Ask Questions
description: AMERICANS have opened their hearts and their wallets in the weeks after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, eager to help the victims and their families, as well as the thousands of volunteers at the disaster sites. Now specialists in charitable giving are advising people to take a few minutes to learn how to do the most good with their gifts.

title: Melissa Meyers, James Donahue Jr.
description: Melissa Ann Meyers, the daughter of Karen A. Meyers of Boston and Allen M. Meyers of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married yesterday to James Patrick Donahue Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donahue of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Mario Marzocchi performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: From Russia, With Realism
description: Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, has been quick to align himself with American diplomatic and even military initiatives in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. For this, he deserves Washington's gratitude and respect. But any substantive changes in American policies involving Russia must still be evaluated on an issue-by-issue basis. In some areas, like arms control and combatting terrorism, Washington's interests and Moscow's generally coincide. In others, like the defense of human rights in Chechnya and nuclear assistance to Iran, they do not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTA, LORETTA
description: COSTA-Loretta. On October 5, 2001, died peacefully at Calvary Hospital. Beloved wife of Dr. I. Joseph Costa. Devoted mother of Kathleen Clemens, Larchmont, NY, Joseph Costa II, Atlanta, GA, Laurie C. Archibald, East Granby, CT, and Thomas Costa, Los Angeles, CA. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Frances, Kate, Kyle and Jay and great-grandmother of Bailey. Memorial service at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Pelham Manor, 10 AM, on Tuesday, October 9. Donations to Calvary are appreciated.

title: To Rebuild or Not: Architects Respond
description: I agree with Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio, who say, ''We believe it would be tragic to erase the erasure.'' How can we, at this site, simply build ''bigger and better,'' as most of the other responding architects suggest? Like it or not, the World Trade Center is now a site of historic significance, a place of unspeakable atrocity, where in the span of a few hours America and democracy were changed.

title: Sept. 30-Oct.6; For Eyes That Can See
description: Usually, they stand silently. Sometimes they shake their heads, or mumble a few words of disbelief. Presidents, emirs, senators -- all have taken Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's personal tour of what remains of the World Trade Center after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CZAP, CAROLYNE
description: CZAP-Carolyne. Carolyne was my love, companion and gentle critic. She desrves a place in heaven for her unfaltering love, patience and tolerance. I will grieve for her as long as I last. Eugene

title: Army of Addicts, At Kabul's Door
description: Each addict's story here in the Pakistan city of Quetta is sadder than the next. Mooruddin Aki's arms were chopped off by the Taliban after authorities caught him smoking opium in an Afghan school. At 18, he begs on the streets and people who take pity on him place bills in his mouth.

title: Update
description: The Sept. 23rd cover was based on an idea by the artists Julian LaVerdiere and Paul Myoda, who had been working on an art project about the World Trade Center before the attack. We asked them to conceive a memorial for the towers, and when they came back with their proposal, ''Phantom Towers,'' we were struck by its haunting beauty and knew immediately that it should be our cover image. It has now also helped inspire a movement to make the memorial a reality. LaVerdiere and Myoda have joined forces with the architects John Bennett and Gustavo Bonevardi, who had independently arrived at a similar notion, and together they have produced another image, called ''Towers of Light'' (shown below). Under the auspices of the arts group Creative Time, the idea has gained official support. The mayor's office has become involved, and research into lighting techniques is proceeding apace. The final form may not be known for sure until the moment it lights up the skyline. ''It's an impulse many people shared, and there's no one right way to do it,'' says LaVerdiere. ''It's a collective vision.''

title: New York City May Issue More Notes, Mayor Says
description: The $1 billion in one-year notes that New York City sold last week to help finance recovery from the attack on the World Trade Center may be just the beginning.

title: The Right Stimulus For the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Computer 101: Parents Set Up Rules
description: FOR years, James and Barbara Debner had one computer, until their son turned 10 and their daughter became 8. Faced with a mounting demand to use the home computer, Mr. Debner gave the children the old one and bought a new one for the adults.

title: This Is a Religious War
description: Perhaps the most admirable part of the response to the conflict that began on Sept. 11 has been a general reluctance to call it a religious war. Officials and commentators have rightly stressed that this is not a battle between the Muslim world and the West, that the murderers are not representative of Islam. President Bush went to the Islamic Center in Washington to reinforce the point. At prayer meetings across the United States and throughout the world, Muslim leaders have been included alongside Christians, Jews and Buddhists.

title: Corrections
description: Two highlight entries in the Television section today have become outdated. ''Stalking Leopards'' (Page 16), scheduled for today at 8 on MSNBC, has been replaced by ''Afghanistan Revisited,'' about a trip by the author Sebastian Junger. ''Target America'' (Page 44), a ''Frontline'' documentary scheduled for Thursday at 9 on Channel 13, has been replaced by ''Looking for Answers,'' about the terrorist attacks and the intelligence failure.

title: Dance; Making the Most Of the Awkward And Threatening
description: GIVING his dance company the less than lyrical name Chunky Move and offering performances in such offbeat places as an abandoned shopping mall and a nightclub called Revolver are just some of the reasons Gideon Obarzanek has become a leading figure in Australian contemporary dance.

title: Saving Saturdays: Repairs After 5
description: IT'S the weekend and the choices are familiar: do maintenance and home-improvement chores, or take time off to relax. People being people, many chores, particularly preventive-maintenance tasks, are neglected in favor of leisure.

title: Music Listings
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA - Mon., 7:30; Fri., 8: Tchaikovsky's ``Yevgeny Onegin.'' Kringelborn, Karneus; Giordani, Hampson, Lloyd; conductor, Jurowski. Tue., 8; Sat., 1:30: Puccini's ``BohAeme.'' Hong, Mula; Lopardo, Caproni, Patriarco, Relyea; conductor, Rizzi. Wed., 7:30; Sat., 8: Mozart's ``Idomeneo.'' Upshaw, Vaness, Graham; Domingo; conductor, Levine. Thur., 8: Bellini's ``Norma.'' Eaglen, Zajick, Check; Margison, Colombara, Valdes; conductor, Rizzi. Metropolitan Opera House. (212-362-6000)

title: Stefanie Isser, Jonathan Goldblatt
description: Stefanie Brett Isser, the daughter of Eileen and Michael Isser of Bellmore, N.Y., was married last evening to Jonathan Ross Goldblatt, a son of Shawne and Arthur H. Goldblatt of Nesconset, N.Y. Rabbi Paul Kushner performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, N.Y.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-07-01: The Ethicist; Unlucky Profits
description: I read that footage of the first plane hitting the World Trade Center, captured by two filmmakers working on a documentary about the city's firefighters, was sold to a TV network. I don't know if they demanded a lot of money, but I wonder: Is it ethical for someone who just happened to be in the right place with a camera to profit from such a tragedy? Chris Knight, Toronto

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/David Rabin; Not Quite Lotus Land
description: PEOPLE have to eat, so restaurants are recovering. And no one blames people for having a drink or two, so bars are busy. But is New York ready to go back to the party-hardy mentality that has young men flocking to clubs looking for models, or for those hoping to be mistaken for them?

title: Helter Shelter
description: This Harlem town house is decorated to within an inch of its life, yet its rooms are obviously not the work of a professional decorator. Indeed, it's hard to think of a decorator with either the nerve or a sufficiently adventurous client to produce a place like this. These are spaces where Op Art-influenced wallpaper provides the backdrop for Warhol silk-screens and flea-market oil paintings. Where reproduction French furniture in the living room is covered in a fabric printed with black-power salutes. Where 19th-century photographic portraits mix with contemporary painting, and sofa cushions bear the image of Nelson Mandela. And where high-design objects like chairs designed by Robert Venturi and Wendell Castle mingle with junk-store kitsch like giant display bottles of liquor, presided over by portraits of George and Martha Washington. No, this is not the work of some pedigreed interior designer. This is Cary Leibowitz's world, and welcome to it.

title: Late Meetings but Not Too Late
description: MOST people who have had experience with community meetings probably wish they could do what Jean Stone did when meetings threatened to get out of hand.

title: Sarah Swersey, Jeff Wagenheim
description: Sarah Deborah Swersey, a daughter of Alice and Burt Swersey of Stephentown, N.Y., is to be married today at her parents' house to Jeff Wagenheim, the son of Carolyn Wagenheim of Cranford, N.J., and Kal Wagenheim of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. Susan Schultz, a Baptist minister, will perform a nondenominational ceremony.

title: $15 Million Loss for Fonar
description: The Fonar Corporation (Nasdaq: FONR) of Melville has reported a net loss of $15.2 million for fiscal 2000 on revenues of $46.5 million.

title: Officers Kill Man Holding Hostages
description: Aman with a history of mental illness was shot and killed by the police yesterday after a half-hour standoff in which he held two hostages at gunpoint inside his Bronx apartment, officials said.

title: Lia Caiazzo, Daniel Wiedemann
description: Lia Christina Caiazzo and Daniel Wiedemann were married yesterday in Wurtsboro, N.Y., by the Rev. Catherine Alder, a Congregational minister.

title: Paper and Pen
description: To the Editor:

title: Paradise Loft
description: The first thing I notice in William Kriegel's Manhattan duplex are the footprints my guide, David Mann, leaves on the first floor.

title: Popping the Question Seems More Important Than Ever
description: ''It scared me,'' said Alex Lopez when he heard what had happened at the World Trade Center. ''I thought I lost her.''

title: Music; Minimalist Classic In a New Reading
description: IN the early 1960's, Terry Riley, a young San Francisco-based composer who supported himself by playing ragtime piano at a saloon, had an epiphany. (Like many epiphanies of the era, it occurred, he has said, under the influence of psychedelic drugs.) Mr. Riley realized that ''things didn't sound the same when you heard them more than once, and the more you heard them, the more different they did sound.'' Mr. Riley's revelation led him to write his 1964 masterpiece of repetition, ''In C,'' which gave birth to the revolution known as Minimalism. Whether or not they acknowledge his parentage, Steve Reich, Philip Glass and John Adams are all Mr. Riley's heirs.

title: War Game
description: 'I am the most tired person on earth,'' 8-year-old Robert exclaimed as he trudged into my office and lay down on the couch. He explained that he had been ''running and running in a game of running bases.'' He detailed the rules of the game, including the proviso that there is no winner. Frankly, I could barely follow what he said. I was distracted by my relief at seeing him, as I had been at the beginning of each hour these last few weeks when I greeted my patients in the waiting room.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the filmmaker Fritz Lang misstated the surname of the author of ''The Films of Fritz Lang: Allegories of Visions and Modernity.'' He was Tom Gunning, not Browning.

title: BUSH SAYS 'TIME IS RUNNING OUT'; U.S. PLANS TO ACT LARGELY ALONE
description: Working with fluid coalitions of friendly countries whose tasks are still undefined, President Bush warned the Taliban government of Afghanistan today that ''full warning has been given, and time is running out.''

title: New York Heightens Security as Mayor Tries to Calm City
description: New York City heightened its security procedures today, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani spoke on television and walked the streets in an effort to calm the city.

title: Homework: How-To's and How Muches
description: NOBODY could accuse Joan and Patricia Connell of giving too little homework.

title: Mary Morrison, Justin Prisendorf
description: Mary Susan Morrison, a daughter of Susan and John Morrison of Wayzata, Minn., was married yesterday to Justin Blaisdell Prisendorf, a son of Donna and Anthony Prisendorf of Mill River, Mass., and Coral Gables, Fla. The Rev. Anne S. Alvord, a Congregational minister, officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents in Mill River.

title: A Final Salute as Ripken Bows Out
description: In the Baltimore Orioles' clubhouse in Camden Yards the other day, Cal Ripken was asked if he would have preferred being a basketball player. Silly question, meant to be a little joke.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-07-01: On Language; Nameless Event
description: The surprise attack on the U.S. fleet in 1941 is remembered by the name of the place where it happened: Pearl Harbor. The bloodiest day in all our wars is also identified by its locale: Antietam creek (though Southerners often identify that battle by the nearby town, Sharpsburg, Md). The shocking murder of a president is known by its victim: the Kennedy assassination.

title: A North Fork Artist at the Venice Biennale
description: TWO very different places defined by watery boundaries, Long Island and Venice, have a cultural connection through the art of Robert Gober, a North Fork resident who is representing the United States in the 49th Venice Biennale.

title: Going to the Country
description: FOUR nights a week, Carol McGinn of Cortlandt puts on a broad-brimmed hat, a western shirt, a denim skirt and black cowgirl boots. She's not headed anywhere south of the Mason-Dixon line. In fact, some nights she doesn't even leave Westchester. Her answering machine sums it up: ''We're probably out country dancing right now.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTELL, MILDRED

title: Extremism's Theological Roots
description: If there is any consensus among spokesmen and students of religion commenting on the events of Sept. 11, it is that those behind them do not in any way represent the Islamic faith. As the distinguished scholar of fundamentalisms, Martin E. Marty, put it in last week's New York Times Magazine, ''this is not Islam.'' The desire to exculpate Islam is understandable, not only on grounds of toleration and good sense, but also given the very real dangers some of our Muslim citizens have faced in recent weeks. Yet a larger question looms: to what degree does any religion bear responsibility for those who speak in its name?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, MURRAY
description: SCHWARTZ - Murray. Senator Schwartz, since 1978, the chairman of the board of the Honest Valid Association, a non for profit corporation founded by President Roosevelt in 1909, a former New York State Senator, former New York City Commissioner of Commerce, entrepreneur and community leader died at his summer home in Roslyn, New York, on Friday October 5. He was 82. Cause of death was coronary failure. Senator Schwartz served in the Senate from 1965 to 1973. He introduced legislation which improved New York State's traffic laws and ended the monopolistic Fair Trade Act. He was a founder and Vice President of administration of the Whale Oil Co., which became the second largest independent distributor of heating oil in the New York metropolitan area. Senator Schwartz was Commissioner of Commerce from 1974 to 1977. He was a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission from 1960 to 1964. He was a delegate to five Democratic Presidential Nominating Conventions and a democratic district leader in Queens. Senator Schwartz also founded the American Institute of Traffic Safety in Palm Beach County, Florida to promote safe driving and he owned and operated a number of travel agencies. Senator Schwartz is survived by his wife Janette (Jay); his brother Jack Lawrence, the composer of ''If I Didn't Care'' and other classics; his son and daughter-in-law, Fred and Liz Schwartz; his daughter and son-inlaw, Joanne and Fred LeBow; his grandchildren, Jenifer Cook and Jenifer's husband Chris Cook, David, Michael, Nicole and Alison Schwartz and David's wife Amy Schwartz; and his great-grandchildren Alexi and Stone Cook. The funeral is today at RiversideNassau North in Great Neck, New York, at 11:30 AM.

Pall said the court ruling protected its unique filter designs that extend filters' life while producing less waste.

description: FRIEDMAN-Dr. Nathalie. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Nathalie Friedman, a cherished friend of the Jewish community and beloved sister of our former board member and longtime advocate, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein. A member of one of New York's leading Jewish families, Dr. Friedman was a brilliant scholar and remarkable person. During her career as a professor of sociology at Barnard College, she conducted meticulous research and produced prominent studies on the role of education on Jewish women, the family, and the community. We send our deepest sympathies to Dr. Friedman's husband, Israel; to her children, Steven and Sheira Schacter, Jessica and Allen Gribetz, Judy and Mark Tykocinski, and Naomi Schacter-Price and Jonathan Price; to her 18 grandchildren; to Rabbi Lookstein and his wife, Audrey; and to the entire family. The effect was not unlike one's first reading of a Harry Potter novel and the re-experiencing of the unfettered flight of childhood dreams -- of endless possibilities -- that the books unleashed.

title: Getting E-Mail
description: To the Editor: There's a much easier solution to e-mail on the road abroad than searching for cybercafes or Internet kiosks (''Spinning a Web Link on the Road'' by Bob Tedeschi, Aug. 26). It's called PocketMail: a nine-ounce device about the size of a checkbook that contains an acoustic modem. (Although lots of phones don't have detachable cords, they all have handsets.) You type your message -- there's a keyboard and screen -- then dial a number from any telephone (free in the United States, England and Australia, a toll call elsewhere). You then hold the device up to the handset and it makes that analog beeping sound as it sends and receives all your e-mails in a matter of seconds. The service costs $15 a month.
