title: Letting Nature Ease the Pain
description: In early fall, I am always moved to leave my home on tourist-glutted Martha's Vineyard and visit the Second College Grant in northeastern New Hampshire. For a few days, I can revel in the sweet silence of the North Country and see no lights at night save those of the stars or the gas lamps shining through the windows of our log cabin when I return from fetching water with which to wash the supper dishes.

title: Practical Traveler; Trip Insurance: Refunds Vary
description: MOST insurance policies are designed to provide coverage if certain well-defined circumstances come to pass. Yet consumers who buy insurance are often surprised to discover -- sometimes too late -- the myriad exceptions lurking in the fine print.

title: Not Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: A Group of Exiled Elderly Find Refuge, Farther North
description: They were just digging into their silver dollar pancakes when the first plane crashed into the World Trade Center -- 68 elderly people who had recently uprooted themselves from familiar surroundings in Florida, Oregon or New York to move into a new luxury retirement and assisted-living home in Lower Manhattan.

title: To Rebuild or Not: Architects Respond
description: I understand why most of the architects want the towers to be rebuilt ''bigger and better.'' But do we really want a symbol of big money to stand out? Maybe something more modest. A place where any person could work comfortably. A symbol of America taking care of its people.

title: New Peepholes Will Be a First Line of Defense for the Aged
description: In the war against crime around Pelham Parkway, the latest front is the front door.

title: Back in the U.S.S.R.
description: REQUIEM FOR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENBAUM, ALBERT H.
description: TANNENBAUM-Albert H. Of NYC and Orient, NY, on October 2, 2001, at home in NYC. Over 80 years, he gave love, knowledge, and humor to family and friends. Shared 47 years with the late Lona. Loving father of Loren Hilf and Abby Tannenbaum; five grandchildren; one great-grandson. Al was an exuberant friend and colleague, an insatiable reader, thinker and talker, and an enthusiastic jazz, baseball and tennis fan. A lifelong New Yorker, he spent five decades covering NYC and the world at large as a newspaperman with the NY Herald Tribune, Daily News, etc. Memorial date to be announced. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: DataBank; A Rally Spurred by Technology Buying
description: As the horrific memories of Sept. 11 dimmed slightly, technology stocks dominated the market last week, snapped up by investors who decided to take a chance on the sector, which had long been battered. Their buying on Wednesday strengthened the Nasdaq market by nearly 6 percent, its biggest one-day gain in more than five months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, LEONARD
description: PARKER-Leonard. Age 80, died peacefully on Thursday, October 4, in Scranton, PA. He was the beloved father of Ileen Parker Truglia, Janet Parker Deitsch, Jill Landsman, and Fern Parker. He was separated from Eleanor Parker. Surviving sister Molly Green. Predeceased by Lillian Chottiner and Sylvia Brown. He was the beloved uncle of many nieces and nephews. He was the father-in-law to Dunewood Truglia, Robert Deitsch and Clifford Landsman. Grandfather to David and Jaime, David and Sarah, Shawn and Kaitlin, and Emily. He was in the steel industry on the east coast, one time owning Parker Steel Products. Born in McKeesport, PA, he lived in Clark Summit, PA, with Annette Fitch. Donations can be sent to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARA, LOUIS
description: ZARA-Louis. On October 5, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen Dillman Zara. Loving father of Philip, Daniel and the late Paul. Mr Zara was a renowned author, connoisseur of art; wrote and produced numerous televison and movie scripts for 20th Century Fox. Esteemed member of the Authors Guild, Melville Society, Overseas Press Club, Mineral Society of America, Macdowell Colony Fellows, The Appraisers Association of America, Charter Member of The American Numismatic Society and an honorary Life Member of the Anti-Defamation League. Service Friday, 2:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Unemployed Struggle to Make Do in Difficult Economic Times; Grounded on High-Flying Dream Job
description: If the United States was teetering on the edge of recession before Sept. 11, the terrorist attacks were a decisive shove over the edge. The number of workers filing for first-time state unemployment benefits has soared to a nine-year high. ''This is just the initial wave of layoffs due to the attacks,'' Steven Wood, an economist, said. ''There's another wave behind it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAINE, BARBARA HOGE
description: DAINE-Barbara Hoge. On October 4, 2001, at age 67. Beloved wife of the late Robert A. Daine. Loving mother of Virginia F. and James H. Daine and mother-inlaw of Kimberly A. Daine. Adoring grandmother of Dillon James and Shannon Marie Daine. Devoted daughter of Virginia McClamroch and the late James Fulton Hoge. Dear sister of James Fulton Hoge Jr., Warren McClamroch Hoge and Virginia Hoge Verwaal. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday, October 9, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Wednesday, 11 AM, at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91 St. Interment Thursday, 10 AM, at the First Congregational Church Cemetery, Old Greenwich, CT. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Point O'Woods Church, Point O'Woods, NY, 11706 or The American Cancer Society, 19 W. 56th St., NY, NY 10019-3984.

title: A Co-op's Right to Charge Fees for Its Documents
description: Q I reside in a Brooklyn co-op. I am writing to find out if I am supposed to receive the co-op's annual financial statements free when I need them. I would also like to know if our managing agent is supposed to fill out a bank questionnaire free when a shareholder is refinancing. Our managing company is insisting that we pay $50 for each of these services. . . . Madeline Padovano, Brooklyn.

title: The Investigation So Far
description: After the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the Bush administration quickly named Osama bin Laden as the leading suspect. Since then, a worldwide investigation has established links between his organization, Al Qaeda (the Base), and previous attacks on American targets -- a largely circumstantial case that NATO is using to press for military action. James Barron and David Corcoran

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AISENSTADT, DR. ANDRE
description: AISENSTADT-Dr. Andre. The Musicians, Trustees and Staff of the Marlboro Music School and Festival mourn the loss of one of their most enthusiastic and generous friends for over four decades and extend sincere sympathy to his family and friends. A member of the Board of Trustees since 1967, his devotion to Rudolf Serkin and Marlboro's musicians was manifested in many ways including the establishment, with his late wife Nuissia, of a recording studio and the Marlboro Recording Society. He often said that for him Marlboro was not just an institution, but an important humanistic philosophy-an embracing family. He will be remembered as a vital part of that family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EARLE, WILLIAM P.S. JR.
description: EARLE-William P.S. Jr. Of Palm City, Florida, and NYC. Died on October 1, 2001. He is survived by his children William, Julia, Valerie Miller and Doreen Mogavero, six grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. His life was devoted to his family, his work and his country. He was a retired Army Captain who lead the first wave onto the Phillipines during WWII. He returned home and became a member and Governor of the American Stock Exchange. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the New York Stock Exchange Fallen Heroes Fund at Mogavero Lee and Co, Inc, 25 Broad St, Apt PHE, NYC 10004, attn: Doreen Mogavero. A memorial service will be held at St. Albans Church on Staten Island, 10 AM, October 25, 2001. He will be greatly missed and lovingly remembered.

title: Resources
description: A selective list of where to find the architects, designers and products in this issue.

title: Sept. 30-Oct.6; A New Candidate in Florida
description: Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state who made controversial rulings on absentee ballots and late returns during the drawn-out presidential election last year, will now focus on her own campaign. Ms. Harris, a 44-year-old Republican and granddaughter of a citrus baron, announced that she would run for Congress. She wants the seat from the 13th District, a Republican stronghold around her hometown, Sarasota, which she represented in the State Senate from 1994 to 1998. Dana Canedy

title: As Ferrer's Gray Eminence, Roberto Ramirez Is a Force, and a Potential Power Broker
description: As Fernando Ferrer sprints toward the run-off for the Democratic mayoral nomination, he is being guided by one of the city's last reigning party bosses, Roberto Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic leader and master of borough-style realpolitik. The Rev. Al Sharpton may have overshadowed others on the Ferrer team, but no one seems to wield more influence behind the scenes than Mr. Ramirez.

title: The Endless Birthday
description: IF you are craving paella and you are somewhere to the southwest of Newark, you are not stuck with Red Lobster. A visit to Mlaga restaurant near Trenton will satisfy the seafood lover in you. At Mlaga, the talk is loud, the paella is first-rate, and the portions are suited to Fred Flintstone.

title: 6,000 Hot Dogs a Week
description: WHEN they moved to Larchmont seven years ago, Michael and Joy Millette were wary of the curious Chinese pagoda on Palmer Avenue in Mamaroneck that sold hot dogs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review in the Book Review on Sept. 23, about ''Canaries in the Mineshaft: Essays on Politics and the Media,'' by Renata Adler, misstated the timing of her employment at The Times. She worked for the paper in 1968 and 1969, not 1963.

title: Mother Interior
description: Legend has it that the first woman to have a career in interior decorating was the witty tastemaker Elsie de Wolfe, in 1904. In fact, with all due respect to the redoubtable Elsie, that credit belongs to Candace Wheeler, an innovator who hit the scene in the 1870's, back when man ruled not only the home but also the profession that decorated it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEBER, ROBERTA BERNSTEIN
description: HEBER-Roberta Bernstein. Died September 11, 2001 at 1 World Trade Center where she was an Assistant Vice President and Systems Analyst for Marsh & McLennan. Formerly of Paramus, NJ, she lived in Manhattan for the past six years. She is survived by her husband Jack Heber; her mother Belle Kagan Lanes; children Robyn Bernstein, Stuart and Amy Bernstein and Melissa Bernstein; stepchildren Sheldon and Sherrie Heber, Ron Heber and Lorraine and Ken Brause; and grandchildren Aurora, Alex, Jason, Jenna and Rachel. Her loving and caring ways will be missed by all her family and friends. A memorial service will be held Sunday, October 14th at 2:00 P.M. at the Jewish Community Center of Paramus in Paramus, NJ. Donations in her memory may be made to the SHARE cancer support group in New York.

title: Decades Later, Doing the Cross Bronx Expressway Right
description: John McNamara watched as his friends' buildings were demolished, and he feared his Throgs Neck home would be next.

title: Jenenne Whitfield, Tyree Guyton
description: Jenenne Whitfield and Tyree Guyton were married on Friday in Howe Park in Mount Vernon, N.Y., where in July the couple led a group of more than 100 volunteers in creating an art installation. Ernest D. Davis, the mayor of Mount Vernon, performed the ceremony.

title: Women Running Off With a Good Book
description: LIKE a sultry blonde in a Raymond Chandler thriller, Nancy Pelegano posed outside a convenience store in Vermont, a cigarette dangling from her fingertips, the smoke curling into a cloud rising about her. A car pulled up and she stepped into it. Driver and passenger sped off to a roadside motel.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 23 with an article about NBC's late-night programming gave an incorrect identification from the network for the show on which Jay Leno appeared as a guest of David Letterman. It was ''The Tonight Show,'' not ''Late Night With David Letterman.''

title: Sept. 30-Oct.6; Bus Attack in Tennessee
description: In another attack that initially raised fears of terrorism, a passenger slashed the neck of the driver of a Greyhound bus, which crashed beside an Interstate in Tennessee. The assailant and five others were killed. The vast bus line halted all service for six hours. The assailant was eventually identified as Damir Igric, 29, a Croatian who served in that country's army in 1991, during a brutal civil war. Sara Rimer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASSA, NICHOLAS G.
description: MASSA-Nicholas G. Of Manhattan, NY, died tragically on Tuesday, Setember 11, as a victim of the World Trade Center disaster in New York City. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, where he spent most of his childhood. He later lived in Long Island where he raised his family, before moving to New York City 14 years ago. He was employed in the insurance industry for over 40 years working for various companies. He was currently employed with Aon Corporation in New York City. He was predeceased by his mother Anna Massa. Surviving are his father Emilio F. Massa of Margate, FL, the mother of his children Edna Massa of Marlboro, NJ, a son Nicholas T. Massa of Lauderhill, FL, a daughter and son-in-law Donna & Marco Mercurio of Marlboro, NJ, a sister and brother-in-law Eleanor & Jim Moran of Levittown, NY, two grandchildren Ryan & Brendan Powers, his companion Patrice Regan, cherished by many aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces, nephews, friends and associates. The family will be receiving guests on Tuesday, October 9th, from 4-6 PM, at the Garden City Country Club, 206 Stewart Ave, Garden City, NY 11530; 516-746-8070. A brief memorial service will take place shortly after 5 PM, followed by a repast from 6-8 PM.

title: Streetscapes/The MetLife Building, Originally the Pan Am Building; Critics Once Called It Ugly; Now They're Not Sure
description: IN 1963 the Pan Am Building, just north of Grand Central Terminal, was to many critics one of the biggest and ugliest things on the Manhattan skyline. Today, as workers are cleaning and restoring the white facade of what is now the MetLife Building, there are signs that a new generation is re-examining that decades-old verdict.

title: Crisis Reshapes Mayoral Runoff, But More for Green Than Ferrer
description: The terrorist attack on the World Trade Center has created sharp stylistic and policy differences between the two Democratic candidates for mayor, with Mark Green seizing on it as the central focus of his campaign, and Fernando Ferrer arguing that it should not overshadow existing problems confronting the city.

title: Keeping the Trains Running As the Tracks Vanished
description: After the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, Larry Gould, a 21-year veteran planner for New York City Transit and the senior director of its operations analysis division, rushed to the agencys command center in downtown Brooklyn, where he remained, with a team of fellow planners, into the wee hours of the next morning.

title: Sacrificing His Ambition For Giuliani
description: NOT to worry, Terrance M. Gray said on the phone to a fellow who was wondering how to recognize him when they met the next day. Look for the only person in the law library of the Bronx County Courthouse who resembles Theodore Roosevelt.

title: Autumn's Zip
description: Anthropologie's suede-paneled zip-front sweater eases those transition days of fall, when something light is all you need. The first shipment of the sweater ($178) was sold out in a week, but now the second shipment has arrived. Available in black or brown (although brown is the hotter ticket), it is half-cardigan, half-jacket, a little bit 60's, a little bit 70's -- and, blessedly, not at all 80's.

title: Harris Sets Record in the Mets' Victory
description: Every now and then, Mike Piazza will spot Lenny Harris before a game and ask if he's going to get a hit that day.

title: Art/Architecture; Thinking of Sculpture As Shaped by Space
description: IN college I heard a story about Giacometti and Picasso walking down a decrepit street in Paris. Picasso, looking up at the ramshackle buildings, asked, ''How can these buildings possibly continue to stand?''

title: Amy Phillips, Alexander Rotter
description: Amy Elizabeth Phillips, the daughter of Alexander and Helen Phillips of New York, was married there yesterday to Alexander Rotter, the son of Elisabeth Sturm Bednarczyk of Vienna and Wolfgang Eyberger-Rotter of Loretto, Austria. The Rev. Dr. William Phillippe performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: 'The Tapir's Morning Bath'
description: Gatun lake, the enormous midsection of the Panama Canal, sprawls for thirty-seven kilometers around peninsulas of land, between fragments of drowned mountains, and over the Continental Divide. Oceangoing vessels slice through the canal and shudder into steel locks that close and open almost silently. The lake's shoreline is wildly irregular, and its waters are as green as the sea.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B.

title: Meals With New Meaning
description: On Thursday, the one-month anniversary of the attack on the World Trade center, many restaurants in New York and around the world will donate at least 10 percent of their sales to a scholarship and emergency relief fund for the children of food service workers who were among the victims. The chefs of the following six restaurants are among those leading the drive. A complete list of participating restaurants and other information can be found at www.windowsofhope.org.

title: Why So Many Creatures?
description: THE TAPIR'S MORNING BATH

title: Countless Questions, a Few Answers
description: Nearly a month after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, investigators are only beginning to understand the conspiracy that led to the largest act of terrorism in history. For investigators and the public, the inquiry has produced more questions than answers. Here are some of those questions and the answers, by Stephen Engelberg and Matthew Purdy of The New York Times.

title: Trying to Make Sense of the Senseless
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Succeed by Excess
description: THE time-warp factor can be cruel to designers. One minute you're riding the crest of a big wave, and the next you're splashing in your own wading pool, wondering where the buzz went. It hasn't died for Roberto Cavalli, but it's about to. He still has his cutie-pie fanatics, who on Wednesday came dressed in leather and fur, even though it was 75 degrees out. And for sheer bonehead fabulosity, there was a television man at the show toting a rolled-up red carpet, which he unfurled at the feet of the Italian celebrities.

title: Salt Air And Sails: Just a Day At Work
description: One after the next, a steady procession of buffed behemoths ambled onto the back porch of the Eastern Yacht Club in Marblehead, Mass., the morning of Sept. 29, and it was a little difficult to say what was scheduled to happen. Was it a sailing regatta, or a convention of outside linebackers?

title: 'Out of Its Mind'
description: Clearly, psychiatry is in crisis. Nobody denies that. Psychiatrists bemoan their field's fragmented, underfinanced services. Patients and coworkers worry about numerous foreign psychiatric residents who can barely speak English. And we can all see hordes of severely disordered people being consigned to homeless shelters and to prisons, while private hospitals commonly turn away such people and mental hospitals continue to shut down.

title: American Treasures: Florida; Where shuttles are launched, and astronauts remembered
description: The Kennedy Space Center is the site of some of America's greatest technological achievements, as well as a symbol of how the nation can rise above adversity. Each year, more than two million visitors make the pilgrimage to Cape Canaveral, Fla., just 45 minutes east of Orlando. The center is the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's main base for sending humans and their robotic surrogates beyond the Earth to explore the next great unknown.

title: Trying to Make Sense of the Senseless
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Sector; Ready to Ruffle Media Feathers
description: BILL CELLA has impressed many advertising colleagues with his self-effacing humor and wit. But they caution not to underestimate Mr. Cella, who just became one of the most powerful buyers of television ad time.

title: Sept. 30-Oct.6; Swissair Flying Again
description: Switzerland's flagship carrier, Swissair, whose finances had been suffering from ill-fated acquisitions of other European airlines, went into a nosedive after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The country's two largest banks, UBS and Credit Suisse Group, came up with a last-minute rescue package, but the airline quit flying for 48 hours for lack of cash, leaving thousands of passengers stranded. Elizabeth Olson

title: To Rebuild or Not: Architects Respond
description: In light of discussions about whether to rebuild the World Trade Center, the image on your cover expresses rather beautifully what might be considered instead: two adjacent parks connected by a footbridge, under which a stream meanders. In the center of each park would be a reflecting pool, and in the center of each pool a beacon that would, as evening falls, shoot heavenward in remembrance of those who lost their lives there.

title: Travel Advisory: Hotel; And Baby Makes Three
description: Some hotel guests act like babies, but they have an excuse. For them, the Metropolitan Hotel, on Lexington Avenue at 51st Street in Manhattan, serves a baby-food menu in its Lexington Avenue Grill. It features Enfamil products ($8 for 14 ounces) and Earth's Best Baby Food ($2.50). The grill is open 7 a.m. to midnight daily; (866) 638-7669, or www.metropolitanhotelnyc.com.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-07-01: Close Reading: Elements of Impending Battles; The Candidate
description: It has become customary in the weeks since Sept. 11 to begin every conversation by asking whether any close friends or loved ones died in the World Trade Center disaster. And so when I went to speak to the remaining Democratic contenders for mayor the week before last, I learned that Fernando Ferrer had lost many friends. On the other hand, Mark Green, the city's public advocate and currently the slight favorite to succeed Rudolph W. Giuliani as New York's next mayor, said that no one close to him perished. I couldn't help feeling badly for Green, for in recent weeks proximity to grief has become a strange sort of currency. Green must have felt this as well, for he quickly added that he had been attending a steady stream of funerals.

title: Habitats/Belle Harbor, Rockaways, Queens; Trading Manhattan Buzz For Beach and Boardwalk
description: THE house, a three-bedroom bungalow built in the 1930's, is just a little more than a block from the Atlantic Ocean. Even on a cool evening, it is gratifying to walk out onto the sand and feel the wind. On nearly every street, children are taking a last bike ride before it gets dark. It looks like any small town in the United States.

title: Taiwan Artists Mix Metaphors and Media
description: THE concept of the icon within the context of Taiwan's post-martial-law period is the subject of an exhibition at Brownson Gallery at Manhattanville College called ''Icon, Iconoclasm, Neo-Iconolatary: An Interpretation by Seven Contemporary Taiwanese Artists.''

title: The House That America Built
description: To the Editor:

title: American Treasures: California; The stars are on Hollywood Boulevard, if only in spirit
description: Hollywood Boulevard has not been the center of the movie world for a long time. But there is still something deeply compelling about the place, which draws thousands of visitors every day of the week. Surely they have no expectation of actually seeing a movie star. You're as likely to find Mel Gibson stepping out of your shower as to spot him, or other top stars, strolling in seedy downtown Hollywood.

title: Buying Online, Despite Worries
description: Even though many dot-com retailers have closed, interest in buying over the Internet remains strong: Consumers spent nearly $26 billion online last year, and the amount is expected to grow. Yet many online shoppers still have nagging concerns about safety, according to a survey released last week.

title: Tuxedos, Deconstructed
description: The fashion mood of late has not only been sober but also casual. Across the country, formal events are toning and dressing down. At the Emmy Awards ceremony tonight, for instance, expect guests in semiformal attire, and a black carpet replacing the red. For those who still seek a few ruffles and flourishes, though, the season's sportswear is rife with tuxedo-inspired details, suitable for day or night -- no jacket required.

title: Feeding Frenzy: Tough Talk To Go
description: REMEMBER when ''take out'' was a fun phrase, having more to do with egg foo yung, pepperoni pizza or your crush in homeroom than with anything violent or threatening? Lately, of course, its dominant meaning is martial if not murderous, to judge from the reporting, commentary and -- let's face it -- sheer hyperventilating in the media since Sept. 11.

title: Bonds's Moment Mixes Joy and Disappointment
description: An exhausting game of catch for Barry Bonds and the San Francisco Giants expired with ambivalence on the field just after midnight Friday.

title: Syrian in Hamburg is Linked To a Second bin Laden Aide
description: A Syrian businessman in Germany who is under investigation for possible links to some of the Sept. 11 hijackers had closer ties to top aides of Osama bin Laden than was previously known, court records show.

title: For O'Neill, Best Years Are to Come
description: Paul O'Neill is father to three children, and through them he learns more about his own father, who died two years ago. O'Neill is unsure, however, whether Charles O'Neill truly believed what he said after Paul was traded to the Yankees or if he was just trying to console his devastated son.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 23 about a rail tour of the Canadian Rockies misspelled the name of the train's vintage sleeping car and misstated the name of Queen Elizabeth's mother, who once used another car, the Royal Wentworth. The sleeping car is the N. R. Crump, as the picture caption said, not Krump. The Queen Mother is also named Elizabeth, not Mary.

title: Anti-Business Chickens Are Coming Home to Roost
description: Long Island lost hundreds of people when the World Trade Center collapsed. It also seems to have lost its way.

title: Experts' Top Choices, Gone Awry
description: IT is one of the most seductive pitches in the world of mutual funds: analysts at a big investment firm pool their collective wisdom and come up with a short list of their favorite stocks.

title: Eudora Welty, With Songs And Edginess
description: HOW does a theater company make a name for itself? The 12 Miles West Theater Company here has been in business for nine years and is still trying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESHNICK, MARTHA
description: MESHNICK-Martha. 81, on October 5. Loving mother to Ellen and Steve, and mother-in-law to Paul Immerman and Mary McKinney. Cherished grandmother to Maggie, Leah, Ellie and Laura, and sister to Jerry Farber. She was an independent woman with a warm sense of humor who will be missed by many relatives and friends. Donations may be made to the Don Monti Cancer Center, North Shore University Hospital, 300 Community Dr., Manhasset, NY 11030. Services Sunday, 10 AM, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Package Bomb Kills American In Saudi Arabia
description: Two foreigners, including an American, were killed tonight and four others were wounded when a package bomb exploded in the eastern town of Khobar, on the Persian Gulf coast, Saudi officials said.

title: Caboose in Yard Is a Direct Line to Court
description: THE red caboose by the railroad crossing sign in Franklin Davison's Baldwin driveway is an 1890 Canadian Pacific railroad car. Its cozy, antique-stocked 30-foot cabin has peeling green walls, a piano, a daybed, a 1920's wood stove and a bench that doubles as a coal bin. There are curtains over the chicken-wire windows and a wreath on the front door. It is also a licensed trailer.

title: Michigan Sends Penn St. to First 0-4 Start
description: Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State is in uncharted territory.

title: Elizabeth Liebeskind, Sean Livingston
description: Elizabeth Alice Liebeskind, the daughter of Mimi Liebeskind of New York and the late Richard L. Liebeskind, was married last evening to Sean Livingston, a son of Maura Elise Livingston of St. Augustine, Fla., and the late Samuel Livingston. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson officiated at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Beth Levison, Henry Sidel
description: Beth Levison and Henry C. Sidel were married last night at the Michelson Studio, an artist's loft in Manhattan. Rabbi Ari Fridkis performed the ceremony.

title: Around the Prescription-Drug Hurdle
description: THE attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon have delayed much domestic legislation, including measures to provide prescription drug coverage for the elderly -- perhaps for a long time. Before Sept. 11, President Bush and many members of Congress promised to make prescription drug benefits part of Medicare by year-end.

title: Tuxedos, Deconstructed
description: The fashion mood of late has not only been sober but also casual. Across the country, formal events are toning and dressing down. At the Emmy Awards ceremony tonight, for instance, expect guests in semiformal attire, and a black carpet replacing the red. For those who still seek a few ruffles and flourishes, though, the season's sportswear is rife with tuxedo-inspired details, suitable for day or night -- no jacket required.

title: Getting Back to Normal, Whatever That Is
description: BY the fourth week, there were fewer red, white and blue ribbons pinned to lapels. A businessman pushed a woman off a crowded No. 1 train during the morning rush hour. Meadows of candle-and-flower memorials that once lapped over sidewalks receded into buckets and vases. A well-dressed man with too much drink in him picked a fight with firefighters who were mourning their colleagues in front of a Greenwich Village firehouse.

title: Holden Helps Army Come Back to Post Its First Victory
description: Josh Holden rushed for 151 yards and 2 touchdowns today to help Army rally past Houston, 28-14, for its first victory of the season.

title: Taking the Pulse of Landmark Buildings Caught in the Collapse of the Towers
description: While they stood, the long shadows of the World Trade Center fell on some of New York's most historic buildings. And when they fell, several landmarks suffered damage from the shock to their foundations and the barrage of debris.

title: Behind the Scenes While Baby Takes a Bow
description: What are babies made of? With Mr. Salt and Mrs. Pepper as the proud parents, you can bet it's sugar or spice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, ELLEN (NEE MCWADE)
description: JACKSON-Ellen (nee McWade). Peacefully, September 15, 2001, in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. Predeceased by husband Stuart. Survived by her loving daughters Susan (Robert), Janet (Andre), Margaret (Harold) and her grandchildern Erica, Katherine, John, Suzanne, Stuart and William.

title: Courtney Gardner, Jon Chase
description: Courtney Anne Gardner, a daughter of Theresa L. Gardner and Michael R. Gardner of Washington, was married yesterday to Jon Robert Chase, the son of Mary Lee Chase and Robert O. Chase of Millinocket, Me. The Rev. Robert J. Lawton, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at a private house in Tuckerstown, Bermuda.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-07-01: Questions for Tony Kushner; Foreign Affairs
description: Q: You have a play coming out about Afghanistan later this season. Is that an example of an artist with his finger on the pulse or just serendipity?

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Weighing the Disaster's Impact Across the Hudson
description: ONE of the prime attractions of New Jersey's Gold Coast as an up-and-coming luxury rental and condominium market has been the view of Manhattan across the Hudson River. In the wake of the World Trade Center's destruction, as some residents find themselves turning away from their views of Manhattan, some are raising questions about the effect on demand for the area's upscale residences, while others are predicting that the attacks will have no long-term effect on the waterfront market.

title: Postings: On West Third Street Between Sullivan and Thompson Streets; New Academic Building for N.Y.U. Law School

title: American Treasures: Massachusetts; Where 2 lanterns warned of war, a candle glows for peace
description: On a late September Sunday, I decided to attend services at the Old North Church in Boston. It was a bright, friendly morning as I walked up Salem Street, past Polcari's Coffee, Monica's Salumeria and Theo's Cozy Corner, with its comforting smell of roast chicken. Above the narrow brick buildings and iron grillwork of the North End rose the church's famous steeple, brilliantly white and sturdy against a blue sky. From here, as all American schoolchildren used to know, on the night of April 18, 1775, the sexton, Robert Newman, hung two lanterns, signaling to waiting patriots in Charlestown that the British would be invading by water. And so began the War for Independence.

title: Beyond the Footlights: The Appeal of Being a Volunteer Usher

Rather, a theatergoer tripped over an umbrella and dropped the cake she was carrying onto the person seated in front of her.

title: Film; Wheeling Through the Wide Open Spaces, Oblivious
description: IN his travel memoir ''Roads: Driving America's Great Highways,'' Larry McMurtry confesses right at the start that ''there's no particular reason for these travels -- just the old desire to be on the move,'' and that's about as inarguable a justification for otherwise motiveless behavior as an American can muster. We're famously a restless people, attracted to wide-open spaces, movement for its own sake and the idea of something better just over the horizon. When we're not feeling free enough, we take to the road.

title: The Healing Power of Art, From an Aerospace Veteran
description: Aeronautical engineering was Daniel M. Tellep's professional love for more than 40 years. He started as a scientist of experimental missile re-entry at Lockheed in the 1950's and rose to become chief executive of Lockheed and later, Lockheed Martin, one of the nation's biggest military contractors. But after he retired in 1996, Mr. Tellep decided to pursue a love he had long suppressed  painting.

title: Countries Lag In Treating Mental Illness, W.H.O. Says

title: The Unexpected Kindness of Strangers; Fearful and confused, a sudden refugee in Shanghai is offered a memory of home by Japanese travelers
description: I WASN'T sure I wanted to go home. ''America's New War,'' they were calling it. Scary. Here in Shanghai, life continued, though I'd dropped halfway out of it. Still jet-lagged, I'd wake up at 4 a.m. and glue myself to CNN until the sun arrived. I felt no distance between me and home, only Shanghai felt safer.

title: Afghanistan After the Taliban
description: Twenty years of war have left Afghanistan so devastated that the only remaining basis for politics lies in ethnic and regional factions. Efforts to unite Afghans with a class-based ideology failed years ago with the end of Afghan leftist parties and of Soviet support. The Taliban's own Islamist appeal promised, for a time, to transcend factionalism and unite Afghans on a religious basis. That promise has gone unfulfilled.

''This is just the initial wave of layoffs due to the attacks,'' Steven Wood, an economist, said. ''There's another wave behind it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, DR. AUDREY K.
description: BROWN-Dr. Audrey K. The Department of Pediatrics and the College of Medicine at SUNY Downstate Medical Center at Brooklyn note with sadness the death of Dr. Audrey K. Brown, Professor and Director of Pediatric Hematology/Oncology from 1974-91. She was a world-renowned researcher in the field of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia and will posthumously receive the first Landmark Award from the American Academy of Pediatrics, Section on Perinatal Pediatrics in October, 2001. Her efforts to prevent brain damage due to bilirubin will benefit those yet to be born; that is her legacy. Dr. Stanley E. Fisher, Chairman; Dr. S.P. Rao and Dr. Scott Miller, Division of Pediatric Hematology/Oncology

title: Market Days
description: On these crisp fall weekends, the outdoor Greenmarkets are filled with the aroma of fresh apples and the color of autumnal flowers. Their simple pleasures are proving a welcome relief for many trying to return to normal lives amid the daily procession of funerals and memorial services in suburbs and city, where the tolling of bells and the wailing of bagpipes drown out impatient cab horns. The dress code at the markets accommodates a wide spectrum of looks, from country casual to a fashion student's elaborate dress (center, far right). There are shoppers on scooters, Rollerblades and bikes, often with dogs on a leash or in sling carriers. The sight of people with their pets, shoppers buying luscious dahlias and friends happy to see each other safe (Cicely Tyson and John Barry Ryan, top right) helps with healing.

title: 'Mary Shelley'
description: ONLY SEVEN PRISONERS WERE AVAILABLE FOR RELEASE WHEN THE citizens of Paris marched on the Bastille, but numbers were irrelevant. A symbol of power had been demolished. Thomas Paine, an Englishman, arranged for the key of the old fortress to be delivered to President Washington in the United States as a token of the inspiration which American independence had offered to Europe. `My country is the world, and my religion is to do good,' Paine declared two years later in The Rights of Man : this was the spirit in which liberal-minded Englishmen and women prepared to greet the new and honourable age of the republic in 1789. Among them, although they had not yet met, were Mary Shelley's parents, the philosopher William Godwin and Mary Wollstonecraft, the architect of modern feminism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANDLER, AMY
description: CHANDLER-Amy. New York, NY, age 97. On Wednesday, September 26, 2001. Member of the Civic Repertory Theater in the 1930s and the American Repertory Theater in the 1940s. Born in Philadelphia, PA, and came to New York in the 1920s with her friend Thelma Chandler to become a ballerina. Toured with Margaret Webster's company's Bus and Truck tours, which took the theater to towns and cities across the U.S., and the bus and truck tours of Golden Apple, Funny Girl, No Time for Sergeants and Teahouse of the August Moon. Companion to Jane Cowl. Lifelong Democrat. She was a lover and supporter of dogs and the arts, including the New York Metropolitan Opera, the New York City Ballet, as well as the theater and classical music. She was preceded in death by both her parents, her sister Joyce Neely, and her brother Jack Knorr. She is survived by her sister, Violet Brown of Bossier City, LA, and three nieces, Joyce Brown of Nottingham, England, Lois Ennis of Shreveport, LA, and Jill Knorr Smith of New Cumberland, PA. The family requests that donations in memory of Amy be made to the Actors Fund, 729 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10019.

There was no other place to have lunch, meet a friend for a drink after work, or give our children's showers and receptions and celebratory brunches. Although I loved walking the three blocks to Millie's, as before we will still patronize her and just get in the car and drive the three miles to her Manhasset restaurant. But for the landlord who failed to negotiate for a settlement that would have kept Millie Gubbins on Middle Neck Road, I hope the space goes vacant for years and he loses a lot of income.

title: Missing

And whatever the face, we knew it intimately: we looked twice at people who resembled it, irrationally searched for it in crowds. We knew these faces because the photographs of the missing were everywhere, obscuring the windows of pizzerias, clinging to street lamps, overlapping one another on bus shelters. The victims we knew were the ones who had caught our eyes, the ones we had first stared at.

title: An Emotion Too Big to Have
description: EVEN now, the finer literary arts seem somewhat beside the point. More information still feels needed -- more videos and photographs, more analyses by military strategists and airport security specialists and market watchers, more background and opinion from Middle East experts, more eyewitness testimony, more F.B.I. reports. History has become urgent too: chronologies of terrorism and pertinent points of comparison like the Battle of Britain, which Mayor Rudolph Giuliani kept citing the week of the attack. We can never seem to get enough data. No work of the imagination would appear capable of assuaging the blow of a reality sadistically choreographed for our eyes by murderous dramaturges. Dazed, hurt, struggling like the people who flocked to the rubble to assimilate the unassimilable, Americans revisit and review the atrocity they witnessed firsthand. We have become a nation, as Dwight Macdonald once put it, ''hagridden by facts.''

title: A Watchful State
description: A week after the attacks of Sept. 11, as the value of most American stocks plummeted, a few companies, with products particularly well suited for a new and anxious age, soared in value. One of the fastest growing stocks was Visionics, whose price more than tripled. The New Jersey company is an industry leader in the fledgling science of biometrics, a method of identifying people by scanning and quantifying their unique physical characteristics -- their facial structures, for example, or their retinal patterns. Visionics manufactures a face-recognition technology called FaceIt, which creates identification codes for individuals based on 80 unique aspects of their facial structures, like the width of the nose and the location of the temples. FaceIt can instantly compare an image of any individual's face with a database of the faces of suspected terrorists, or anyone else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DONALD J., M.D.
description: COHEN-Donald J., M.D. Director of the Yale Child Study Center. The National Tourette Syndrome Association, its Board of Directors, chapters, staff and membership are profoundly saddened by the death of Dr. Donald J. Cohen, Director of the Yale Child Studies Center. A true visionary, for over three decades Dr. Cohen steadfastly initiated and supported countless creative programs and activities designed to improve treatments and spur research into Tourette Syndrome throughout the world. His contributions to an improved understanding of TS treatment and the remarkable progress seen in scientific research have been seminal. For more than a quarter century, Donald mentored hundreds of physicians and researchers in the United States and in many foreign countries. His ability to create interest in the TS field through a myriad of published articles and professional speaking engagements, extensive teaching seminars at the Yale Child Study Center and by securing significant government funding for TS research has made an enormous impact on the field worldwide. All children touched by developmental disorders, as well as the field of child psychiatry have lost a towering intellect, a valuable professional and an outstanding human being. Paul S. Devore, President Judit Ungar, Executive Director Sue Levi-Pearl, Director Medical and Scientic Programs Neal R. Swerdlow, M.D., Ph.D., Chair Scientific Advisory Board Gerald Erenberg, M.D., Chair Medical Advisory Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBOTT, LOUISE S.
description: ABBOTT-Louise S. Passed away peacefully at the age of 93, September 29th at her home in Pomfret Center, Connecticut. She was born Louise Slocum in Jamaica Plain, MA. She graduated with honors from The Winsor School in 1926. She attended Vassar College and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Radcliffe College with a degree in political science in 1931. Throughout her life she was an avid tennis player. She won the National Doubles Championship at the age of 19 and was invited to compete at The Wimbledon Lawn Tennis Championships. In 1932 she married Charles C. Abbott, an instructor at The Harvard Business School. While she and the family lived in Cambridge, she devoted her energies to various secondary schools and civic endeavors. In 1954 she moved with her family to Charlottesville, VA., where her husband became the founding Dean of The Darden School of Business at The University of Virginia. While in Charlottesville, Louise Abbott was instrumental in establishing and nurturing The Wives Club, an organization devoted to supporting the wives of spouses studying at the business school. In 1972 she & her husband retired to their farm in Pomfret where she pursued her interests in bridge, mahjong, gardening & bird watching. Louise S. Abbott was predeceased by her husband Charles C. Abbott and her grandsons, W. Frederick Williams IV, John William Abbott and Hunter Austin Abbott. She is survived by five children, daughters Margaret, Ellen Eubank of Pomfret and Louise Williams of Maynard, MA; sons Charles C. Abbott of Charlottesville, VA, William S. Abbott of Pomfret and Preston H. Abbott of Guilford, CT; eight grandchildren; two great grandchildren and long time family member and friend Emma Feige. A memorial service will be held October 27th at The Pomfret School Chapel, Pomfret, CT, at 2 PM. The family suggests that in lieu of flowers contributions might be made to The Darden Partners, Darden School Alumni Foundation, PO Box 6550, Charlottesville, VA. 22906, or The Winsor School, 103 Pilgrim Road, Boston, MA. 02215, or New England Wildflower Society, 180 Hemenway Road, Framingham, MA. 01701.

title: The Making of the Speech
description: The president could not find the right words. Soon after the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were attacked on Sept. 11, he tried to articulate his response. In one week he gave more than a dozen speeches and remarks to comfort, rally and then -- when he'd rallied too much -- calm the country. To some, his language seemed undisciplined. He called the terrorists ''folks'' and referred to the coming battle as a ''crusade.'' He called for ''revenge,'' called Osama bin Laden the ''prime suspect'' and asked for him ''dead or alive.'' He said ''make no mistake'' at least eight times in public remarks. When Bush didn't seem lost, he often seemed scared. When he didn't seem scared, he often seemed angry. None of this soothed the public. ''It was beginning to look like 'Bring Me the Head of Osama bin Laden,' starring Ronald Colman,'' one White House official remembered.

description: ROSENBERG - Lenore Nathan Block. Of Buffalo NY, died peacefully September 27, 2001, in her ninetieth year. She is deeply mourned by her son, the writer Lawrence Block of New York City; her stepsons, Richard Rosenberg of Laguna Beach and Arthur Rosenberg of Albuquerque; her daughters-in-law, Lynne Block, Karen Rosenberg, and Loretta Mackay; her grandchildren, Amy Reichel, Jill Block, Alison Pouliot, Gretchen Faber, Diane Sweeney, Kenneth Rosenberg, David Poohina, and Jennifer Reyes; her greatgrandchildren, Sara and Marisa Reichel, Joseph Harrison, and Laura Rosenberg; and her brother and sister-in-law, Hi and Mim Nathan. She was predeceased by her two husbands, Arthur Jerome Block and Joseph Rosenberg; her daughter, Betsy Molina; and her brother, Jerry Nathan. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Cornell University, an accomplished painter, a woman of infinite warmth and wit, she's gone where the Saturday Review still publishes a Literary Cryptogram every week, and where there's an endless supply of unworked Double-Crostics; where Rubinstein and Horowitz and Art Tatum take turns at the piano, and where her favorite cities of New York and Paris and London are just around the corner. She was a great and gallant lady, and her absence leaves an enormous permanent gap in the skyline.

The consequences of such an attack could be so awful -- deaths conceivably reaching into the tens or hundreds of thousands -- that the government obviously has an obligation to prepare for the worst. title: QUICK BITE/Mahwah; Barbecue, and the Check, in a Jar
description: There is no Wawa in Mahwah. If you're looking for one of those convenience stores, head elsewhere. If you want barbecue, though, the Mason Jar is worth the trip to Mahwah. The Mason Jar is well north of the Mason-Dixon Line, but specializes in Southern-style hickory pit barbecue. The distinctive aroma of slow-cooked meat hits you in the parking lot. Or, if you've got a stuffed nose, you'll probably notice the giant pile of firewood out back. This is no ramshackle roadhouse, however. The Mason Jar is a large, pleasant family restaurant. You know the drill: wood paneling, hanging plants, ceiling fans. The wait staff is friendly and knowledgeable. Employees must pass a 30-question quiz on menu item, sort of a BBQSAT. That's no easy task, for in addition to the Jar-B-Que items, the Mason Jar also offers brick-oven pizza, sushi and a Sunday brunch buffet ($18.95 for adults). I came for the meat. The combination platter ($11.95, including two sides and corn bread) allowed me to sample Texas beef brisket, Carolina pulled pork, and boneless pork loin, all tender and tasty. I slathered the meat in the Mason Jar's two homemade sauces: a thicker, tangy tomato-based variety, and a ''wet'' spicy style. Sandwiches, chicken and half-racks of Memphis spareribs ($9.95) and Kansas City baby backs ($11.95) complete the barbecue selections. Ah, yes, the name. My Coke came in a Mason jar. That made sense. The bill also arrived in a Mason Jar. That made less sense. At that point, though, I was too full to worry about it. Jack Silbert

Included was a checklist of mistakes that would cut playing time.

title: Financing the Fight Against Terrorism
description: Now that the United States has begun its military campaign against the Taliban in Afghanistan, we have to face the question of how to pay for what promises to be a prolonged war on terrorism. Just days before Sept. 11, President Bush said that only a recession or a war could make him willing to spend the Social Security surplus. Now the nation confronts both difficulties.

But the present Year of the Snake demands the millennium-old tale ''The Legend of the White Snake,'' which, in more modern operatic manifestations, is suddenly sprouting around town.

title: Intel Develops A New Way To Produce Silicon Chips
description: Intel plans to announce today that its researchers have come up with a novel method for housing microprocessors that it hopes will speed development of high-performance microchips with more than a billion transistors. The company says such chips could be available in five or six years.

title: Adolescent Fantasies, Rough Real Life
description: Anas (Anas Reboux), the title character of Catherine Breillat's incisive sexual essay ''Fat Girl,'' is a fiercely intelligent, overweight 12-year-old loner who hides out from the world, absorbing its bitter truths from inside the self-protective envelope of her own billowing flesh. Ms. Reboux's extraordinary performance conveys Anas's mixture of precocious insight, animal canniness and vulnerability so powerfully that it ranks among the richest screen portrayals of a child ever filmed. And it provides a disturbing reminder that children's inner lives are as complicated (and their fantasies often as raw) as those of adults.

title: Shylock and Portia Speak to All Eras
description: Revenge, justice, mercy. Words that seem socially and politically charged today were already resonating through ''The Merchant of Venice,'' a play so deeply rooted in an enduring question -- how should justice, mercy and vengeance be balanced? -- that it speaks to any number of historical crises, including our own. Trevor Nunn's inspired idea was to transplant the play to the 1930's, when World War II was looming and anti-Semitism was bluntly expressed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALEXANDER, SHEPARD L.

description: With New York City under threat enough already, the Berlin Philharmonic gave it a little nonthreatening music in order to lighten the load. In its second and third concerts at Carnegie Hall on Friday and Saturday, three of Beethoven's five most beloved and often-played symphonies were paraded across the stage, accompanied by Brahms's dour D minor Piano Concerto with Maurizio Pollini as pianist.

title: Detached Giants Struggle in Sloppy Victory
description: With halting, unsure steps, most of them more awkward than able, the Giants defeated the Washington Redskins, 23-9, today with a detached performance that seemed to suit the mood at Giants Stadium.

description: From the Arab world's local Main Street, in Brooklyn, to Afghan mosques in Queens, to the halls of academe, many Muslims yesterday expressed sometimes tentative, sometimes anguished support for the attacks on Afghanistan. Many also feared for the innocent.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Airport Credit Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service has lowered the underlying rating on nearly $1 billion in bonds for the new International Arrivals Terminal at Kennedy International Airport. In lowering the rating to Baa3 from Baa2, Moody's cited a one-third reduction in passenger traffic for the terminal after the terrorist attacks. Bonds are i.o.u.'s backed by specific assets, in this case revenue from terminal businesses like food vendors and other fees. One of 10 terminals, it opened in June and was built with $934 million in Port Authority bonds, which are still rated AAA.

title: The Week in Business

title: Seeking Escape At the Cinema
description: The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks did not prompt Americans to stay home from the movies. In fact, from Sept. 10 to Sept. 30 box-office receipts for the 10 most popular films during that period -- $156.7 million -- was up 7 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.

title: 9 Feared Dead as Helicopter Is Downed by Abkhazia Rebels
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8  Five United Nations observers and four other people apparently died today after rebels shot down their Russian-made helicopter in Abkhazia, a separatist region of western Georgia along the Black Sea, a rebel official said today.

title: Wise French Whimsy Cocks Its Head and Winks
description: The Colleagues Theater Company was founded six years ago by the actress Catherine Wolf with the admirable -- and valuable -- aim of producing work that focuses in subject matter on older people and in casting on well-seasoned performers. It is a theater of the venerable, and its current production at the Neighborhood Playhouse, ''The Madwoman of Chaillot,'' rickety though it is, is full of reminders of things too easily forgotten.

Giuliani's attempt to extend his term.

title: A Welcome Distraction
description: The terrorist attacks have made it difficult for even ardent fans to reconnect with professional sports, but Barry Bonds's dramatic pursuit of the major league home run record indisputably rekindled interest in the end of an otherwise placid and largely predictable baseball season. On Friday night, with only three games left in the regular season, Bonds finally did it. He pounced on a 1-0 fastball from Los Angeles right-hander Chan Ho Park and rifled his 71st home run into the right-center-field stands at San Francisco's Pacific Bell Park, breaking Mark McGwire's three-year-old single-season record of 70 home runs. For good measure, he swatted No. 72 two innings later, and No. 73 on Sunday to end the season with a flourish.

title: Thunderous Blasts And Bright Flashes Mark Kabul Strikes
description: Under a clear sky lit by a three-quarters moon, a steady bombardment of Kabul began Sunday night, sending bright flashes of light and loud concussions rolling across this farming plain just 35 miles north of the Afghan capital.

Some goals are achievable right now, and automatic landing technology has been around since before World War II, although it is not used in commercial flights.

Instead of sitting surrounded by crumpled paper, the computerized writer has his mistakes neatly stored in digital memory.

title: Phone Providers Near Ground Zero Are Still Frantically Scrambling to Catch Up

Cellular antennas and data lines had already been out; now, all of a sudden, land lines went, too, and everyone from court officials to F.B.I. agents were scrambling to get phone service.

His portfolio is enormous, but his authority is vague. He will immediately plunge into a debate over how much power should be given to his office, which has been talked about for years by policy makers and bureaucrats but never, until last month, with much urgency.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Special Education Questioned
description: A new state study reports that Hispanic, black and American Indian students are far more likely than whites to be identified as having intellectual disabilities and emotional disturbances. They are then placed in special-education classes at a higher rate than that of whites, the report said. Officials are investigating to see if any ''misidentifying'' has occurred, a State Education Department spokesman said last week. Asian students are about one-fifth as likely as whites and the other groups to be identified with a disability, the report said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Celestial Excursions, Complete With Harp
description: The music in heaven, by some accounts, comes from choirs, harps and angels dressed in white. For the first half of her concert at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night, Bjork arrived in a white dress (with pearls, sequins, a tulle ruffle and a swan's head over her shoulder). She brought along a harpist, Zeena Parkins, and a choir of 11 women from Greenland. She also had a 54-piece orchestra in the pit and an electronica duo, Matmos, creating rhythms out of crackling static and homely sounds like cards being shuffled. Panoramic glacial landscapes filled a screen behind her.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bedford: Court Won't Hear School Case
description: The United States Supreme Court has declined to hear an appeal of a lawsuit by Bedford parents who claimed certain school programs, such as Earth Day celebrations, unconstitutionally promoted religion. The court, without comment, issued the order on Oct. 1. One of the plaintiffs, Mary Ann DiBari, had appealed the case to the high court after lower courts cleared the Bedford Central School District in Westchester County of the allegations. The suit said the district had promoted paganism, the occult, New Age thinking, and religion, such as requiring students to make likenesses of a Hindu god as part of a lesson on India.

title: After the Military Strikes, Solid Information and Details Were Slow in Arriving
description: It has become an American television ritual: As United States military forces take action, sporting events, comedy shows and dramatic series give way to the grim faces of news anchors and the hazy green, night-vision images of explosions and antiaircraft fire.

title: Metro Matters; Still Puzzling What Ferrer Stands For
description: IT isn't easy to focus on New York City's mayoral race now that the country is attacking the Taliban in Afghanistan. But in just three days, voters will still be selecting the man who may lead New York through its most trying years in a quarter-century. And still, one of the candidates remains something of a question mark.

title: America Strikes Back / Washington and London Make Their Case : Bush Vows 'Sustained, Comprehensive and Relentless Operations'
description: Following is the text of President George W. Bush's statement Sunday announcing the start of military strikes in Afghanistan. It was provided by the Federal News Service.

title: The American Offensive Begins
description: A new and more dangerous phase of America's counterattack against terror began yesterday with United States and British airstrikes against Al Qaeda training camps and Taliban military targets in Afghanistan. It was a moment we have expected ever since Sept. 11. The American people, despite their grief and anger, have been patient as they waited for action. Now that it has begun, they will support whatever efforts it takes to carry out this mission properly. For their part, the Bush administration and its allies must continue to proceed carefully and wisely.

title: Experts Say Bin Laden Is Distorting Sacred Text
description: Leading American scholars and practitioners of Islam said yesterday that Osama bin Laden had twisted and debased Muslim theology in a videotaped statement in which he called on ''every Muslim'' to ''rush to make his religion victorious'' by emulating those who attacked the United States on Sept. 11.

title: Rebounding Jets Turn Their Defense Into Points
description: It can be a sign of a maturing team when it can kick a bad team when it is down. And, more importantly, a sign that a struggling team might have found its footing is when it does not sink to the level of an even worse team. If that is the case, the Jets made progress today with a 42-36 victory over the inept Buffalo Bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRONBAUM, SADIE ''ZADA''
description: CITRONBAUM-Sadie ''Zada''. Of Lauderhill, FL, passed away on Wednesday, October 3, 2001. She is survived by her beloved husband, Jacob, her loving daughter, Beth Breus and devoted grandchildren, Lauren and Michael Breus.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of Saturday.

title: What Now for Wireless? Facing Harsh Realities; An Industry Adopts a New Pragmatism
description: In Manhattan last June, Discover magazine convened a panel of technology experts from companies that included I.B.M., Walt Disney and Nokia to hold forth on the future of wireless technology.

title: 5 Young Israelis, Caught in Net of Suspicion
description: As their lawyer tells it, when the five young men were picked up by F.B.I. agents in midday on Sept. 11, they had a box cutter with them. One man carried $4,000 in cash, another had two passports.

description: The strikes on the Taliban government opened what senior Pentagon and military officials said would be a weeklong, nearly day-and-night bombing campaign carried out by supersonic jets from aircraft carriers and heavy bombers flying from air bases as far away as Missouri.

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sought to reassure New Yorkers and tourists of their safety yesterday in the hours after American and British bombs began dropping on Afghanistan, and in the same breath warned that residents would have to get used to much tighter security throughout the city.

description: In an attempt to save Britain's railway system from collapse, Railtrack, the company that owns the tracks, will undergo a revamping that stops short of reverting to government control, a British court ruled today.

title: Madison Avenue Rides Wave of Patriotic Fervor
description: A month after the terrorist attacks on the United States, Madison Avenue is wrapping itself in red, white and blue in an outpouring of patriotism not seen in mainstream advertising since World War II.

title: Bush Warns 'Taliban Will Pay a Price'
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Striking at night from aircraft carriers and distant bases, the United States and Britain launched a powerful barrage of cruise missiles and long-range bombers against Afghanistan today to try to destroy the terrorist training camps of Osama bin Laden's Qaeda network and the Taliban government that has protected it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, AGNES M.
description: MURRAY-Agnes M. Age 93, died October 2, at her home. Widow of the late Roger F. Murray 2nd, former member of the Board of James Lennox House, and was active in West End Collegiate, First Congregational Church and in the Manhattan Church Women United. Loving mother of Roger F. Murray III, and his wife Linda, Wolfeboro, NH. Grandmother of Jennifer doCarmo, Beford, NH, Deborah and John Murray, Wolfeboro, NH. Great-grandmother of Robert F. doCarmo. There will be no calling hours. Memorial services Saturday, October 13, 11 AM, First Congregational Church, Wolfeboro, NH. Donations in her memory may be made to the Wolfeboro Area Children's Center, S. Main St, Wolfeboro, NH, or the Lake Wentworth Foundation, PO Box 2235, Wolfeboro, NH. Lord Funeral Home, Wolfeboro, NH.

title: Mexican Labor Protest Gets Results
description: At the time, it seemed an insignificant act of disobedience. About 900 workers at Mexmode, which produces sweatshirts for colleges in the United States, boycotted the company cafeteria because they were fed up with finding worms in their salads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOVEICHIK, AARON
description: SOLOVEICHIK-Aaron. The management and employees of Aron Streit, Inc. extend its deepest condolences to the family of Rabbi Aaron Soloveichik. For many years, he was our head rabbinical authority, a trusted advisor and a cherished family friend. The Aron Streit, Inc. Melgross and Aron Yagoda

title: Lewis's Elbow Fells Johnson
description: Buffalo quarterback Rob Johnson was knocked out for a few moments today after taking an elbow to the back of the head from Jets linebacker Mo Lewis.

title: Precautions Increase, and Officials Advise: Get Used to It
description: Security at bridges, tunnels, airports, commuter hubs, government buildings and other critical sites -- already high for nearly four weeks -- was ratcheted up across the New York metropolitan region again yesterday as the nation launched strikes in Afghanistan and Americans braced for possible new terrorist attacks.

title: Muted Response From Arab Governments
description: With the American air raids striking Afghanistan after dark, long after government offices in the Middle East were closed, initial official Arab reactions were somewhat muted.

title: Essay; Our 'Relentless' Liberation
description: ''America is full of fear,'' crowed a jubilant Osama bin Laden, in his taped message anticipating our response to his massacre of the six thousand. ''They cry for their children.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTELL, MILDRED
description: BERTELL-Mildred. Age 97. In Hallandale, FL. on October 4, 2001. We wish all people could celebrate Milly's life of love. All who had the privilege of sharing a few moments of her gracious being know what true generosity of spirit is. Her joy of life, her gift of humor, dignity and elegance were elements of the sweetness of her life. We have lost a most precious mother, grandmother, great grandmother and dear friend. Joyce, Leslie, Alan, David, Charlie and Briana, Michael and Diane, Lori and Richard, Steven and Gail, Sylvie and Norman, Morgan, Lindsey, Jessie, Jordan, Michaela, Jake and Kevin. Thank you dear Nana for coming into our lives. You were extraordinary.

title: U.S. and U.K. Bomb Targets in Afghanistan : Bush:'Battle Joined'
description: WASHINGTON  U.S. and British forces launched a thunderous air assault Sunday on military targets and suspected terrorist camps across Afghanistan, using scores of planes and ships massed over the past month to retaliate for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon.

title: Home Front: Edgy Sunday
description: When the word came that the waiting had ended, first from Kabul, then from officials at the Pentagon and finally from President Bush, it came on a pristine fall Sunday, ''a perfect day for football,'' as the announcers like to say, just as many people were sitting down in front of their television sets for their weekly dose of gridiron glory.

title: Pakistan's Leader Takes Steps to Solidify Control Ahead of U.S. Air Raids
description: Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, moved swiftly today to tighten his grip on the country's military by promoting two generals and restricting political opposition by placing a militant cleric under house arrest.

title: Congressional Leaders Offer Strong Endorsement of Attack
description: In an unusual display of political unity, the top leaders of both parties in Congress issued a joint statement today endorsing President Bush's decision to begin military strikes in Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILSTEIN, SEYMOUR
description: MILSTEIN-Seymour. Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center mourns the loss of our former chairman and is grateful for his and Paul's many years of guidance and support. Myron Strober, past Chairman Board of Trustees

title: No Significant Increase in Oil Price Is Seen
description: Oil prices, which have plunged in the last three weeks, are not expected to rise significantly in the wake of the initial United States strike against Afghanistan, analysts said yesterday.

title: Alienation Has Gripped the Redskins
description: Washington Redskins defensive lineman Bruce Smith knew this season would be different when, for the first time in his 17-year career, he got a roommate for road games. Marty Schottenheimer has changed many things in his short time as Redskins head coach, but assigning roommates, of all things, truly irritated some veterans, including Smith.

title: A Time of Reckoning
description: For Muslims of the Middle East and south and central Asia, the moment of reckoning arrived yesterday. The Bush administration has made what are, for an American government, extraordinary efforts to show that the war that began Sept. 11 will not be the war Osama bin Laden wants: a battle between Islam and the rest of the world, particularly the United States. Whether Muslims in the region accept, encourage and further this American effort will determine much of their fate in coming years. It will also determine how effective the war against terrorism will be.

title: Leading the Military in a New Mission: A War at Home
description: AS a West Point cadet and then Army officer, Thomas E. White was proud to wear his uniform home for the holidays, despite the protests against the Vietnam War that were raging all around him -- including in his own family.

title: A Hell's Kitchen Wonder

Public I Or Private I

title: Disputing the Focus on bin Laden
description: As much as Hitler during World War II or Nikita S. Khrushchev in the cold war, Osama bin Laden has emerged as the enemy incarnate for an America fighting Islamic terrorism. Soon after President Bush declared he wanted Mr. bin Laden ''dead or alive,'' in cowboy parlance, shooting ranges in the United States began selling targets of this bearded, turban-clad villain. Mr. bin Laden appeared to relish the role, judging by the tape of himself declaring holy war that was broadcast by the Pan-Arab Al Jazeera cable network after American and British forces launched air strikes on Afghanistan.

title: Starting From Strength
description: The combination of Curt Schilling and Randy Johnson evokes comparisons to other great pitching combinations. Here is how some of those combinationas have done in postseason play after regular seasons that were particularly impressive.

title: Agents of Recovery Under Stress
description: Xerox was lucky. It had enough parts to keep going, even when the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks caused a three-day hiatus on shipments. Still, Xerox factories that had previously stocked a day's supply of semiconductor chips -- items readily available from Japan -- will now hold four days' worth.

title: Morgan Stanley Executive Decides to Stay
description: Paulo Pereira, who was paid $8 million to $10 million last year as head of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company's European telecommunications banking group, is staying at the firm after agreeing to join the Goldman Sachs Group less than two weeks ago.

title: Sales Continue to Pick Up, Despite Start of Bombing
description: Perhaps it was the lure of the 50 percent off overcoat sales as the weather turned brisk or the new Denzel Washington thriller, but Americans continued their tentative return to malls, movie complexes and airports over this three-day weekend.

title: Copter Downed In Caucasus; 5 From U.N. Among 9 Dead
description: Five United Nations observers and four other people apparently died this morning when rebels shot down their helicopter in Abkhazia, a separatist region of western Georgia on the Black Sea, United Nations officials said today.

title: A Wary Warship Launches New Salvos
description: As warplanes from this ship joined in a second round of strikes in Afghanistan, commanders here said tonight that their greatest worry was the potential for retaliatory action.

title: A Greek Revival:A New Take on Classicism
description: ATHENS  With cascading drapes one of this summer's top fashion stories, Greek chic has never looked so cool. So how does an eternal ideal become a hot trend?

title: A Firefighter's Dream, an Ice Cream Truck, a Date at F.A.O. Schwarz
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Power To The Provinces
description: In a referendum on Sunday, voters endorsed changes in the Constitution to increase the autonomy of Italy's regions at the expense of the power of the central government. The central government will now be responsible for foreign relations, justice, electoral law, the environment, defense and public order, and the regions will manage all other matters and will have greater freedom to decide how federal money will be spent. Only a third of those eligible voted, but about 65 percent of those voting favored the changes. Marina Harss (NYT)

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Colombia: Lawmaker Slain
description: A Colombian congressman from the war-torn province of Arauca was assassinated on a Bogot street, the second congressman from that province to be assassinated in a week. Authorities did not know who was responsible for the brazen attack on Representative Luis Alfredo Colmenares, 48, a member of the opposition Liberal Party. But right-wing paramilitary gunmen are believed responsible for the Oct. 2 shooting of another representative, Octavio Sarmiento, a left-leaning congressman who had also belonged to the Liberal Party. The latest killing came a day after President Andrs Pastrana renewed the right of leftist rebels to occupy a swath of land in southern Colombia ceded to them for peace talks. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: America at War: Voices in a Nation on Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stores To Close
description: The last seven Castro Convertible stores in the New York region, including one on 23rd Street in Manhattan, will close within six weeks, officials of a liquidation company said yesterday. About 40 employees will lose their jobs, said the liquidation company, Buxbaum Group. Castro Convertible became a household name in 1948, when 4-year-old Bernadette Castro, the daughter of the company founder, appeared in the stores' advertising. In 1993, however, Ms. Castro, above, now the state parks commissioner, sold the company to Krause's Furniture, which filed for bankruptcy protection in July.

title: Mariners Need Only a Championship to Go With Their Records
description: When the Seattle Mariners played their first outdoor home game on July 15, 1999, the fans looked up and thought the sky was falling.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS RISE. Soybeans gained on concern that heavy rain in the next few days will delay the harvest in the Midwest. In Chicago, soybeans for November delivery rose 1.75 cents, or 0.4 percent, to $4.54 a bushel.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The task before us is difficult, but not impossible.''

title: JETS POUND TALIBAN SITES A 2ND NIGHT; F.B.I. AGENTS SHIFT ANTITERROR TACTICS
description: For a second day, B-2 stealth bombers flying from the United States joined carrier-based aircraft today to strike targets in Afghanistan as anti-American demonstrations began to roil Muslim capitals and Bush administration officials stepped up planning to oust the Afghan regime.

title: Iran Cleric Condemns Airstrikes
description: Iran's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, condemned the strikes on Afghanistan today as cruelty and said they would prove a major mistake for the United States and Britain.

title: Anxious Days in Pakistan
description: Though Afghanistan has become the first battleground in America's war against terrorism, Pakistan could well be the political epicenter of this unfolding conflict. The United States can win the military confrontation in Afghanistan but lose the war if Pakistan, with its 142 million people and nuclear weapons, falls under the control of Islamic fundamentalists. That is why the latest actions of Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, require the closest attention of the Bush administration, which is dispatching Secretary of State Colin Powell to Islamabad later this week.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Thunderous Night Attacks

title: Fiscal Disaster the City Can't Face Alone
description: ''Anything it takes to help New York.'' That sentiment from George W. Bush, expressed on Sept. 13, is in obvious contrast to the feelings of an otherwise not-so-different president, Gerald Ford, as summarized in the famous 1975 Daily News headline: ''Ford to City: Drop Dead.'' President Ford eventually did come to understand that the country couldn't afford to let its largest city, then in fiscal crisis, go bankrupt. Now, in a disaster for the city economy that has very different causes, President Bush's continuing support will be crucial. New York does not have the resources to recover on its own.

title: What Came First, the Asthma or the Egg?
description: Some art provokes strong reactions across the centuries -- especially if it was made with eggs.

title: Denying Fear, But Embracing Nagging Doubts
description: John Cimaglia almost did not attend yesterday's Columbus Day parade up Fifth Avenue. So, yes, the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center and the four difficult weeks that followed, punctuated by Sunday's televised images of Osama bin Laden promising more havoc for the United States, have unnerved him a little, making him wary, invading his dreams.

title: New York to Ask Government for $20 Billion More in Aid
description: New York will ask the federal government for an additional $20 billion in assistance to recover from the terrorist attacks that destroyed the World Trade Center and disrupted the city's and the state's economy, Governor George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said today.
