description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Travelocity Lays Off Workers
description: Travelocity.com Inc., the largest Internet travel seller, plans to eliminate 19 percent of its work force, or about 320 jobs, and close its call center in Sacramento, Calif., to reduce costs. Travelocity on Friday cut about 35 positions, or 10 percent of its workers not involved in customer service, and plans to cut 285 customer-service jobs when the call center closes in 60 days.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Case Fades Against Ex-Aide
description: A former finance minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, who resigned his office to fight charges against him, appeared headed for an acquittal in his forgery trial after the prosecution did not recommend any sentence against him. Prosecutors cited a lack of evidence, saying there was no other version to contradict the one given by Mr. Strauss-Kahn. Until November 1999, Mr. Strauss-Kahn was a rising star in the Socialist Party, a member of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's inner circle. He has been on trial for forgery after backdating bills for some $90,000 he was paid by a student insurance fund. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Spying for a Long, Hot War
description: The total surprise achieved by the perpetrators of the acts of war on Sept. 11 has forced a reappraisal of the entire American approach to combating terrorism. The top priority remains domestic. Legislation is now being considered to enhance the law-enforcement tools for detecting, pursuing and blocking terrorists here. The much harder and longer-term challenge will be building our intelligence capabilities. Now that war has begun, meeting this challenge has become still more urgent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, NATHALIE
description: FRIEDMAN-Nathalie. We mourn the passing of our beloved board member, Nathalie Friedman. Beneath her modest demeanor was a woman of great strength and dignity, a person of powerful intellect. She accomplished much in her lifetime and garnered only friends and admirers along the way. We shall miss her fine presence; her hard work, balanced judgment and wise counsel; her thoughtfulness and kindness. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. Blu Greenberg, President The Executive Committee The Board of Directors Jewish Orthodox Feminist Alliance

title: Stella McCartney:Rock Chick to Ringmaster of Raunch
description: PARIS  Let us fervently hope that the raucous, raunchy, rambunctious show that Stella McCartney sent out Monday blows the final whistle on fashion as circus.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Kurile Islands Fishing Dispute
description: Korean officials expressed concern that Japan was attempting to persuade Russia to keep Korean fishing boats away from the southern Kurile Islands. With a week to go before the Japanese prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, is to come here to try to smooth the frayed Korean-Japanese relations, the Foreign Ministry asked the Japanese ambassador, Terusuke Terada, to explain a Japanese news report that Japan and Russia were near a deal banning boats from other countries from entering the waters around the islands. Japan has claimed sovereignty over the southern Kuriles ever since Soviet forces captured them in the final days of World War II. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: 3 Share Nobel for Their Molecular Studies
description: An American and two Britons won the 2001 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday for discovering key molecules that regulate how cells multiply in living things, from yeasts to plants to humans.

title: P. J. Fitzgerald, 64, Lawyer in Manson Case
description: Paul J. Fitzgerald, the lead defense lawyer in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three young women who were his followers, died on Oct. 1 at his Beverly Hills, Calif., home. He was 64.

title: Reports of Bombing by U.S. Intrude on Private Grief
description: It was the kind of news that Bill Randolph would normally have watched at home with his partner, Wesley Mercer. They would have sat close together on the couch, surfed the news channels, and reassured each other that their world had not changed.

title: Fighting for Life 50 Floors Up, With One Tool and Ingenuity
description: Now memories orbit around small things. None of the other window washers liked his old green bucket, but Jan Demczur, who worked inside 1 World Trade Center, found its rectangular mouth perfect for dipping and wetting his squeegee in one motion. So on the morning of the 11th, as he waited at the 44th-floor Sky Lobby to connect with elevators for higher floors, bucket and squeegee dangled from the end of his arm.

title: Jobs Are Scarce in the Newest Economy
description: Judy Maness, the manager of the 24-hour Waffle House restaurant just off Interstate 85 here, has tucked away the ''Now Hiring'' sign.

description: Mexico won a seat on the United Nations Security Council today, strengthening President Vicente Fox's efforts to move his country away from its traditional isolation toward an active role in world affairs.

description: Over the last four weeks, the storeowners and shoppers in Little Kabul, the largest Afghan community in the United States, have grown used to the reporters and camera crews traipsing through.

title: A Different Kind of Wartime Economy
description: Given the nature of this new conflict with terrorism, the economy is not likely to be revived by the developments that fueled previous wartime booms, like surging orders for tanks and airplanes or demand for workers to replace those who go off to fight.

title: Japanese Leader, Visiting China, Is Mildly Rebuked on Army Role
description: China's leaders warned Japan today to ''remember the wariness of other Asian countries'' as it considers sending military forces to play a supporting role in the war on terrorism, but the friendly tone with which the message was delivered reflected a thawing of ties that have been badly strained in recent months.

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks Start Meaningful Games Now
description: AS diversions go, the Yankees will finally get to participate in one tomorrow night that we can at least attach relative meaning to. After 6 months, 1 week and 95 victories worth of manufactured gravity and hyperbolic story lines, the baseball playoffs begin under heightened security, a sense of urgency regarding a scary opponent and a red George Steinbrenner alert.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Retailer's Profit Falls
description: Australia's largest retailer, Coles Myer, said its income fell 49.9 percent in its most recent fiscal year. The results were worse than the company had forecast, even after downgrading its outlook several times in the year, which ended July 29. But restructuring costs, inventory write-offs and other provisions totaling 182.2 million Australian dollars ($93 million) surpassed the projections. Including those costs, the company's net profit fell to 150.8 million Australian dollars from 300.7 million Australian dollars in the previous year. John Fletcher, who took the helm as chief executive last month and began a program to cut costs and expand the profitable food and liquor units, called the performance unsatisfactory. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DECLINES. The dollar fell as military strikes on Afghanistan fueled concern that economic recovery will be delayed. In New York, the dollar settled at 119.83 yen, down from 120.34 yen on Friday.

description: Lebenthal to Be Sold To MONY for $25 Million

title: Interwave May Supply Telstra Equipment
description: Interwave Communications is expected to announce today that it has signed a five-year contract to supply wireless network equipment to the Telstra Corporation, Australia's largest mobile communications company, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: CENDANT COMPLETES TENDER OFFER FOR CHEAP TICKETS
description: The Cendant Corporation said yesterday that it had completed its $280 million tender offer for the shares of Cheap Tickets and had also obtained a $1.15 billion line of credit from a group of banks led by J. P. Morgan Chase. Cendant, which franchises businesses including Ramada hotels and Avis rental cars, paid $16.50 a share for Cheap Tickets, a seller of discounted airline tickets and hotel rooms. More than 90 percent of Cheap Tickets' shares were tendered in the offer ended Friday, Cendant said, and the purchase should be completed tomorrow. Cendant, based in New York, now has $2.9 billion in credit lines available.

title: Yankees' Road to Victory Is a Long, Slow Trip
description: Chuck Knoblauch changed positions in March and was almost traded in June before being benched occasionally in July, August and September. But when the Yankees open the American League playoffs against Oakland at Yankee Stadium tomorrow, Knoblauch will probably stroll to the plate in the first inning and loiter outside the batter's box to adjust his gloves. Then he will commence hitting in his unique style.

title: Hotel Discount at Disney
description: In honor of the 100th anniversary of Walt Disney's birth, the Courtyard by Marriott in the Walt Disney World Resort is offering rooms for $29 a night Sunday through Thursday until Dec. 25. The hotel is in the Downtown Disney area of Lake Buena Vista, Fla., and guests are able to enter the Disney theme parks an hour early on selected dates. To reserve the $29 rooms, guests must ask for the 100 Years of Magic celebration rate when reserving. The rate is subject to availability, must be prepaid and is nonrefundable. Information: (800) 223-9930 or >a href="http://www.courtyardorlando.com">www.courtyardorlando.com .

title: Truth and Justice, by the Blip of a Brain Wave
description: Since the World Trade Center bombing in 1993, Dr. Lawrence A. Farwell has been arguing that terrorist operations can be investigated through careful monitoring of the brain waves emitted by suspects during interrogation. The claim did not get very far with the Federal Bureau of Investigation or any other major law enforcement agency then.

title: Tunnel Vision; Mapping the Movements Of a Changing Subway
description: Maps tend to be pretty static things -- at least those of known lands like New York City that were long ago explored and charted and colonized with delicatessens and dry cleaners.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Plane Is Diverted
description: Passengers aboard American Airlines Flight 1272 travelling from Port-au-Prince, Haiti, to New York City said they smelled smoke, and the pilot immediately diverted the plane to Providenciales International Airport in the Turks and Caicos Islands. After nearly five hours on the ground and a thorough check that found nothing wrong, the 222 passengers reboarded and the plane took off for Kennedy International Airport, said Todd Burke, an American Airlines spokesman in Dallas. The problem may have been the heavy smell of cigarette smoke on a passenger's bag or clothing, Mr. Burke said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: A Look Behind the Scenes, From White House Aides
description: On Friday morning in the White House situation room President Bush turned to Gen. Richard B. Myers, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and asked, ''Dick, is Tommy Franks ready to go?'' He was referring to the crusty Army general who commands the American military in the Middle East and South Asia, and who was rapidly assembling forces for the coming war in Afghanistan.

title: Ripples From New York Start to Subside at Baltimore Waterfront
description: First came the unexpected shipment of a couple of hundred Jaguars, originally destined for New York. Soon cruise ships whose Hudson River dock was serving as a morgue began to arrive. And just the other day, the sailing of the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy from Newport News, Va., delayed for four hours a container ship headed here, raising the cost of unloading.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The American Advertising Federation, Washington, named seven young executives to its Advertising Hall of Achievement, honoring those ages 40 and under. They are: Linda Thomas Brooks, executive vice president and managing director at G.M. Mediaworks and G.M. Cyberworks, which report to the Interpublic Group of Companies through Campbell-Ewald, part of the FCB Group unit; Karen Edwards, vice president for worldwide marketing at Yahoo; Jack Griffin, president at Parade Publications, part of Advance Publications; Chan Suh, chief executive at Agency.com; Deborah Wahl, marketing communications manager at the Lincoln Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company; Tony Wright, chief strategy and planning officer for North America at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group; and Anne Kallin Zehren, publisher at Teen People, part of the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner. They will be inducted at a luncheon in New York on Nov. 14.

title: When the Pop Star Is the Brand
description: LONDON  "You do a commercial, you're off the artistic roll-call forever," the comedian Bill Hicks declared in 1994. But links between the commercial and creative worlds have only strengthened in the intervening years, with pop stars themselves becoming brands in their own right  and launching marketing-driven products off the back of their celebrity.

title: Footlights
description: Shedding Light

title: Homegrown Guards
description: The world's biggest security companies could be forced out of the lucrative South African market under legislation that would ban foreign ownership of such businesses.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Rethinking Driver's Licenses
description: Secretary of State Candice Miller said she would ask the Legislature to prohibit applicants who are in the country illegally from obtaining Michigan driver's licenses. The secretary of state currently issues licenses to all applicants who qualify, regardless of their legal status, under an opinion issued by the the state attorney general in 1995. Concern over the licensing process was prompted after several people who had been issued Michigan driver's licenses were questioned by the authorities after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELOITTE & TOUCHE, New York, the large accounting firm, said it had acquired assets from Klayman & Korman, Chicago, an accounting firm.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina, Brazil: Talks On Region's Economy
description: In an effort to resolve growing differences over economic policy at a time when a worldwide slump is looming, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil and Fernando de la Ra of Argentina have met in Braslia, along with the two finance ministers. Both countries are founding members of Mercosur, the world's third largest trade group, but have been openly critical recently of each other's tariff and currency policies, raising questions about the future of the bloc. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Bush Puts Limit On Inner Circle
description: President Bush will limit access to briefings on classified and sensitive law enforcement information, an administration official said today.

title: Can Israelis and Arabs Break the Logjam?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, THOMAS GEORGE
description: KENNY-Thomas George. Died October 6, 2001. For 75 years gave love and laughter to family and friends. The embodiment of the golden rule, he had open arms for everyone he met. Predeceased by sister Louise. Survived by the Kenny, Bellittieri, Van Doninck and Eyre families, and countless friends. Wake at Grant Funeral Home in Brentwood, LI, on October 8, where there will be an opportunity for everyone who wants to speak and share. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's Church, Babylon, on October 9. Please call funeral home, 631-273-4443, for details. We are profoundly grateful to Dr. Peterson and the staffs of St. Vincent's Hospital and Cabrini Hospice in NYC.

title: Soldiers Are Relaxed, but Ready to Go, at Compounds for Elite Units
description: Just down from armored-car road barriers bristling with sharpshooters, Sgt. Maj. Dennis Kolenc, combat paratrooper, stepped up to the first tee at Stryker Golf Course today, radiating a sense of relaxation that the rest of the nation might envy amid the unnerving war reports from Afghanistan.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Talks To Resume
description: The state and two striking employee unions have agreed to resume mediation talks this week, a move prompted by attacks on Afghanistan, union officials said. The negotiations, scheduled for Thursday, would be the first since talks broke off more than a week ago, leading to the walkout of 23,000 state workers, or roughly half the state's work force. The walkout has slowed government services, including health inspections and vehicle licensing. The state has called on nearly 1,000 National Guard members to take over essential services like nursing care. The two sides remain at odds on pay and health insurance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENDRICK, BRIAN
description: KENDRICK-Brian. The officers, members and staff of the Pawling Mountain Club mourn the passing of our fellow sportsman and dear friend. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Philip Bonanno, Chairman Peter Cholnoky, President

title: Scouting Report
description: DIAMONDBACKS (92-70) N.L. West champion

title: NBC, TBS AND TNT ADD WIZARDS GAMES
description: The Michael Jordan comeback television tour has begun. NBC has added two Washington Wizards games, on Nov. 3 and Dec. 1. TBS added two games, the season opener Oct. 30 against the Knicks and a game on Nov. 20. TNT added three games, on Nov. 1, Nov. 7 and Nov. 20. Richard Sandomir

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bodies Of 26 Stowaways Dumped In Sea
description: A report that 26 people -- part of a group of mostly ethnic Koreans living in China -- suffocated in the hold of a Korean fishing boat and then were thrown overboard led to the arrest of the fishing boat captain and seven crew members. The police were searching the waters around an island off the southwest coast of the Korean Peninsula for the bodies. The 26 were among 60 passengers who had left China on a Chinese vessel and then were transferred to the Korean boat near Korea. The police learned about the deaths after arresting 33 of the 34 survivors in a hideout on land. One of the stowaways escaped. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Bush Scolds U.S. Lawmakers on Classified Information Leaks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  President Bush scolded some members of Congress today, saying they had fallen short of their responsibilities by publicly discussing classified information about possible future terrorist attacks.

title: Glad to Be in the Pits, Wherever They Are; Commodity Traders Had Backup Plan
description: It was 1 p.m. and sugar was done, precisely 90 minutes after the commodities traders had packed themselves into two pits on the floor for a frenzied and roaring rush of buying and selling that made their old way of doing business seem somewhat leisurely.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Journey to the West Side

title: Market Place; Dissident holders vow to thwart any move to take Metromedia International private.
description: JOHN KLUGE, the 87-year-old media entrepreneur, may be the 13th-richest man in America, with what Forbes says is a $10.6 billion fortune. But his investment in the Metromedia International Group has not helped increase either his net worth or that of the company's shareholders.

title: U.S. Advises U.N. Council More Strikes Could Come
description: The United States told the Security Council today that it needed to leave its options open in investigating the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States and could not rule out taking further action against other groups and countries beyond Afghanistan.

title: Critic's Notebook: The Age of Irony Isn't Over After All; Assertions of Cynicism's Demise Belie History
description: In the anguished days following Sept. 11 cultural prognosticators were quick to declare the death of irony, cynicism and black humor. ''I think somebody should do a marker that says irony died on 9-11-01,'' Gerry Howard, editorial director of Broadway Books, told Entertainment Weekly. In an interview with The Los Angeles Times, the historian Taylor Branch talked about ''a turning point against a generation of cynicism for all of us.'' And in an essay in Time magazine Roger Rosenblatt argued that ''one good thing could come from this horror: it could spell the end of the age of irony.''

title: Morgan Stanley Selling Nearly Completed Office Tower to Lehman for $700 Million
description: Morgan Stanley, the giant financial company, is selling its 33-story tower nearing completion on Seventh Avenue in Midtown to a rival, Lehman Brothers, for about $700 million and moving several thousand employees outside New York City.

It showed Kevin Conroy, another victim. The picture appeared correctly on Sunday with a profile of Mr. Conroy.

Devoted father and father-in-law of Joyce and Michael Quinn, Matthew Ryan & Meaghan Ryan. Cherished son of Teresa and the late Martin Ryan. Fond brother of Brendan and Frank Ryan. For further information please contact the McCourt & Trudden Funeral Home Inc, 385 Main Street, Farmingdale.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Music Producer
description: Boosey & Hawkes, one of the world's oldest classical music publishers, said it had received a preliminary takeover approach from a consortium it did not identify. In addition to publishing, Boosey & Hawkes manufactures musical instruments in Europe and the United States. Boosey & Company was founded in the 1760's; Hawkes & Son in 1865. The two merged in 1930. Shares in Boosey & Hawkes rose 48 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: America at War: Voices in a Nation on Edge; Roles of Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: One Part Columbus Day, and One Part 4th of July
description: Under seas of American and Italian flags, thousands of marchers surged up a sun drenched, crowd-lined Fifth Avenue yesterday in a decidedly untraditional Columbus Day Parade that combined the patriotic themes of a nation newly at war with the tensions of a city under the threat of terrorism.

title: The Puzzle of Anthrax in Florida
description: The discovery that a second Florida man was exposed to anthrax and that anthrax spores have been found in the building where he and another victim worked has raised anew the question of whether biological terrorists might have been at work. When a 63-year-old Floridian was diagnosed with anthrax last week -- and died shortly thereafter -- his illness was described by health authorities as an isolated case with no clear link to terrorism. Now comes evidence that the case was by no means isolated, and that the workplace itself, a Boca Raton building housing supermarket tabloids, was contaminated, although perhaps only very slightly. The great unanswered question is whether the contamination was the work of terrorists, or a crime of some sort, or has a more benign natural explanation.

title: Snapshots Of Sept. 11: A Gathering Of Witnesses
description: ''We're making this up as we go along,'' said Charles Traub as he stood in a storefront at 116 Prince Street in SoHo, surrounded by a quiet swarm of people.

title: Weighing the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: American Imam Refutes Attacks and Defends Islam
description: GROWING up in Brooklyn, Siraj Wahhaj recalls, he felt a certain shame whenever he read that a black person had committed a crime. He feels something similar these days as a Muslim. Members of his faith stand accused not only of committing crimes on a heinous scale, but of doing it in Islam's name.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer's Loss Estimate
description: Zurich Financial Services has doubled its estimate, to $900 million, of the claims it expects to pay from the September terrorist attacks in the United States. The company has already twice reduced its earnings forecast this year, causing a sharp drop in the stock price. The Swiss company said it also expected lower investment income in the current economic downturn to cut back its profits. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIND, ALAN HERBERT
description: ELKIND-Alan Herbert. 76 years old. BS MSEE Columbia University, graduated from Annapolis Lt. JG U.S. Navy. Died from cancer. Beloved husband of 48 years to Emilie Schwartz Elkind. Devoted father to Jaine Elkind Eney, David Lloyd Elkind, Susan Elkind Orchant. Dear brother of Elaine Elkind. Proud grandfather to Julia, Elizabeth, Alexander, Elizabeth, Allison, Samuel and Emily. Funeral services Wednesday, October 10, 1:30PM at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, White Plains, N.Y. Donations in his memory to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Foreign Affairs; It's Freedom, Stupid
description: I happened to be reading Richard Reeves's compelling new biography of Richard Nixon last week, when a paragraph about Israel caught my eye. It was a memo that Nixon wrote to Henry Kissinger in 1969, describing his, and America's, feelings about Israel: ''[The Israelis] must recognize that our interests are basically pro-freedom and not just pro-Israel because of the Jewish vote. . . . [Golda] Meir . . . must trust [Nixon] completely. He will see to it that Israel always has 'an edge.' This is going to be the policy of this country. Unless [Israelis] understand it, and act as if they understood it right now, they are down the tubes.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALD, VICTOR
description: WALD-Victor. On September 11, 2001 Victor was tragically lost in WTC 1. People were drawn to his wisdom, irreverent wit, integrity and humanity. Victor was a scholar of history and religion and a keen observer of world politics. An institutional broker with Avalon Partners, Victor was held in high esteem by his colleagues. His proudest accomplishments were his wife Becky and beautiful daughters Alex and Dani. He was the beloved son of Fani and Dolphy and adored brother of Clarissa. Victor was also a cherished nephew, cousin, uncle and friend. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: Once again, broadcasters scramble their ad schedules to accommodate breaking news.
description: FOR the second time in less than a month, the major television networks scrambled their advertising schedules -- moving, postponing and canceling commercials -- to cover breaking news. The maneuvering included lengthening programs, shifting a show from one network to another and calling agency executives at home to buy commercial time on short notice.

description: To the Editor:

title: Natural Cause Appears Unlikely in 2 Anthrax Cases
description: With the discovery that a second person in Florida has breathed anthrax spores, experts on the disease are finding it hard to come up with a plausible natural explanation. Though they think such an explanation may still emerge, they are leaning toward the possibility that the spores were deliberately spread.

title: The Doctor's Most Neglected Patient
description: Doctors often do a poor job of taking care of their own health. In a new article in The British Medical Journal, doctors attributed this to the difficulties of living up to their own expectations, as well as those of their patients and colleagues.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Missile Overshot Target
description: New information on a Ukrainian military training exercise shows that one missile overshot its target by a much greater distance than was originally stated. American officials say a stray missile from the Ukrainian exercise caused the crash last week of a Siberia-bound Russian passenger jet, a charge Ukraine denies. All 78 aboard died. The commander of Ukraine's air defense forces, Volodymyr Tkachyov, said one of the missiles fired during the training on Thursday had flown 50 miles before falling into the sea. Previously the Defense Ministry said the stray missile had flown no farther than 25 miles. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Santarm Journal; Chicago Boy Makes Good (as Amazon's Bishop)
description: During the 27 years he served as the Roman Catholic bishop here, James M. Ryan had to visit Rome periodically on church business. Reporting to Pope Paul VI one day in the early 1970's, he spread out a map of the 125,000 square miles of Amazon jungle under his jurisdiction and said, ''Holy Father, this is my diocese, the largest in the world.''

title: Looking for Sports?

Readers who flip this section over, bottom-side up, will find the pages of SportsTuesday in their accustomed sequence, starting with S1.

title: Treatment of Early-Stage Hepatitis C Advances
description: German researchers announced last week that they had cured hepatitis C in 42 of 44 patients who were treated in the earliest stages of the disease.

title: Refugees at the Ritz
description: A quiet panic seems to hang in the air at the spring 2002 ready-to-wear collections in Paris, affecting even the most heedless observers of fashion's ongoing parade. It is not that the city itself has reacted with conspicuous alarm to the terrorist attacks in the United States and the allied bombing of Afghanistan. As beautiful as ever under chalky autumn skies, the city is steadfast in conforming to its pictorial clichs, and its residents to their temperamental ones. The overarching anxiety takes a subtler form.

title: Trade, Already Off, Faces New Hurdle
description: Trade, which contributed so powerfully to the world's growth for much of the 1990's, had been falling everywhere even before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, pulling national economies down with it. Now, with the prospect of further economic fallout from the war against terrorism, the damage is expected to increase, sidelining global trade as a force for economic recovery.

description: SCHLANGER-Joan. Age 64. Died at home late on October 8, 2001, of colon cancer. Survived by her husband Michael; her mother Shirley; her children Steven, Margo, Karen & Daniel; her grandchildren Harry and Leila; and her brother and sister Robert and Arlene. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASKINS, DR. CARYL PARKER
description: HASKINS-Dr. Caryl Parker. Dr. Caryl Parker Haskins, scientist, author, governmental advisor and pioneer entomologist in the study of ant biology died Monday, October 8, 2001 at the age of 93. He was the husband of the late Edna Ferrell Haskins. Dr. Haskins was a longtime resident of both Washington DC and Westport, Connecticut. He was the founder of Haskins Laboratories, a private, non-profit research laboratory established in 1935 and operating for the last 31 years in New Haven, CT. During his career he served as President & Research Director & Chairman of the Board of Haskins Laboratories, 1935-'87; Director, E.I. du Pont de Nemours, 1971-'81 and Research Professor, Union College, 1937-'55. In 1956, Dr. Haskins was appointed to the Presidency of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, a position he held until 1971. He remained a Trustee of Carnegie and Haskins Laboratories, as well as Trustee Emeritus of the National Geographic Society until his death. Caryl Haskins was born August 12, 1908 in Schenectady, New York to Caryl Parker Haskins and Frances Parker Haskins. He attended Schenectady High School, Albany Academy and entered Yale University in 1926. Caryl Haskins earned the D.Sc. from Tufts College, 1951; Union College, 1955; Northeastern University, 1955; Yale University, 1958; Hamilton College, 1950; and George Washington University, 1963. He earned the LL.D. from Carnegie Institute of Technology in 1930; University of Cincinnati, 1960; Boston College, 1960; Washington and Jefferson College, 1961; University of Delaware, 1965; and Pace University, 1974. In 1939, Caryl Haskins published his first book, the highly acclaimed ''Of Ants and Men,'' an analogous study of the societal structure of the two species. This book has been reprinted in 13 languages. In 1943, Haskins published ''The Amazon, The Life History of a Mighty River.'' That was followed in 1951 by ''Of Societies and Men.'' In all, Caryl Haskins published five books and some 230 articles and papers. He was also the holder of a 1934 U.S. patent on synthetic resin and method of preparation. Caryl Haskins once said, ''The man who is too old to learn was probably always too old to learn.'' Contributions to Carnegie Institution of Washington, 1530 P Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20005. For information call Guilford Funeral Home, in Guilford, CT., phone 203-453-3558.

title: A New Federal Office Opens Amid Concern That Its Head Won't Have Enough Power
description: Tom Ridge was sworn in today as the first director of homeland security, a position the country's leaders never felt was needed before Sept. 11 and a job experts fear will be nearly impossible.

title: Second Case of Anthrax Leads F.B.I. Into Inquiry
description: The F.B.I. took over the investigation of anthrax contamination in South Florida today after a co-worker of a man who died from the illness last week was also found to have spores of the disease.

title: As Anger Smolders in the Streets, Arab Governments Temper Remarks, or Say Nothing
description: The queasy feeling among Arab governments that American military strikes against Afghanistan could have negative reverberations at home was clearly evident in official reactions today.

title: Advanced Micro to Introduce Latest Chip
description: Advanced Micro Devices will introduce its newest microprocessor for desktop computers on Tuesday, in an effort to regain both lost ground on its rival, the Intel Corporation, and momentum in a troubled industry.

title: Pakistan Asks India to Revive Talks Aimed at Bringing Peace to Kashmir
description: After a week of rising tensions between India and Pakistan over Kashmir, Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, telephoned India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, tonight to ask him to resume negotiations they started in July in the Indian city of Agra, Pakistan's state-run news agency reported.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Talks On Air Routes
description: The budget airline controlled by Sir Richard Branson, Virgin Express, is continuing to hold talks with the Belgian government concerning the restructuring of Sabena, the national airline that filed for protection from creditors last week. Mr. Branson met with government officials last week and another meeting is scheduled for this week, people close to the discussions said. Virgin Express, which itself underwent a restructuring earlier this year to stem losses, is unlikely to inject money into a rescue package for Sabena, these people said. Virgin Express would be more likely to acquire some regional routes in the event the carrier is dissolved. Virgin Express currently receives 30 percent of its revenue from an agreement with Sabena that allows the Belgian carrier to book some of its passengers on Virgin Express flights from Brussels to London, Rome and Barcelona. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Europe: New Company Statute
description: The European Union passed a statute giving companies in Europe the right to establish as European companies and follow European Union rules rather than those of each country in which they do business. The statute, proposed 30 years ago, would enable companies to expand and restructure their cross-border operations without the red tape of having to set up a network of subsidiaries, the internal market commissioner, Frederick Bolkestein, said. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Bauhaus Rigor Meets Folkloric Flair in Expatriates' Collections : German Cool:Strictly Eccentric
description: PARIS  On a skinny counter at Galeries Lafayette sits a tiny black purse, with rings to attach it to the fingers and a furry side turned to the palm. How cool is that! The fashion crowd circles in awe the "Shopping Support" installation of Bless  the German design duo Ines Kaag and Desiree Heiss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPARI, DIANE T.
description: LIPARI-Diane T. Age 42, Missing at the site of the World Trade Center tragedy. Formerly of Fairview, NJ. Diane was Senior Vice President of Carr Futures. Beloved wife of Edward Tighe. Devoted daughter of Lorraine Gardella and Vincent Lipari. Dear sister of Joseph and Michael Lipari, Susan Kraljic and Lorraine Gardella. Diane is treasured for her kind heart, generous spirit and loving nature. A Memorial Mass will be held at 10:30 AM on Thursday, October 11th at St. Paul The Apostle Church, Columbus Avenue & West 59th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made in Diane's name to St. Joseph's School, 131 E. Fort Lee Road, Bogota, New Jersey 07603.

title: A Love Story Set Among Afghanistan's migrs
description: According to a note that appears on-screen at the beginning of ''Baran,'' 1.4 million refugees from Afghanistan are living in Iran. In the months since the film was completed, that number has most likely increased greatly, and the fate of the Afghans who have fled 20 years of war and deprivation has become suddenly and unexpectedly relevant to American movie audiences. Our lives and theirs, separated by geographical distance, cultural differences and almost unimaginable material disparities, seem much closer now than they might have a month ago.

title: Guggenheims Offer Novelty In Las Vegas
description: This city already has an Eiffel Tower, an Empire State Building and even an indoor version of the Grand Canal of Venice. So why not its own Guggenheim Museum? After all, New York, Venice and Bilbao each have one, as does Berlin, in a way.

title: Tying Russia to West, Putin Unveils Strategy, But Risks a Backlash
description: Until this month, critics here dismissed President Vladimir V. Putin's foreign policy as little more than tactics -- a trip to Cuba to appease nationalists, one to Germany to mollify liberals -- trying to placate everyone, but offering no strategy for Russia's future.

title: In 15 Hours, Submarine Kursk Is Raised From Sea Floor
description: The nuclear-powered Kursk submarine that sank in the Barents Sea in August 2000 with 118 crewmen on board was pulled to the surface today in a triumphant 15-hour operation tinged with bittersweet emotion.

title: Imagining Steinbrenner's October Surprise
description: Flakes fall to the infield dirt, the wind whipping them into adjacent eddies as they land. Either they are ash that has been carried through the night sky from neighboring chimneys warming Bronx apartments, or they are part of an honest-to-goodness early-season snow. Either way, they send a message: this is no time to be playing baseball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, BELLE ''BUDDY'' (NEE GUTTESMAN)
description: FEINBERG-Belle ''Buddy'' (nee Guttesman), age ninety-two, on October 8, 2001. Devoted, cherishing and cherished wife of the late Lawrence Feinberg. Devoted mother of Paul Feinberg & Linda Alwitt. Beloved grandmother of Karyn and Daniel Feinberg, Josh and Philip Alwitt, and great-grandmother of Kenzo Lawrence, Jacob Morris, Estelle and Olivia. Caring mother-in-law of Cyndy Feinberg and Robert Alwitt. Buddy brought her zest for life and her love to her family, her friends, and the pupils she taught in New York City schools. We will miss her.

title: Stocks Fall, With Notable Losses in Some Muslim Lands
description: Financial markets across Asia shivered today after American and British military strikes against Afghanistan. But the greatest tremors were felt in parts of Southeast Asia, where investors fled from countries with large, potentially restive Muslim populations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about an online community of opera lovers misstated the relationship between Stephen Poulos, a member lost in the World Trade Center attack, and a New York City Opera violist who played at his memorial service. The violist, Donald Dal Maso, had indeed met Mr. Poulos face to face, on one occasion.

title: Bin Laden's Media Savvy: Expert Timing of Threats
description: With his turban and camouflage jacket, his ornate Arabic and harsh vows of continued terror against America, Osama bin Laden revealed in his speech the instinctive cunning that has made him such a formidable foe.

title: Europeans Pledge Troops, if Necessary
description: European expressions of support for the military campaign begun by the United States and Britain in Afghanistan continued to roll in today. There were also scattered demonstrations in several countries that deplored the use of powerful air strikes against such a poor country.

title: Can Israelis and Arabs Break the Logjam?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Newly Urgent Election
description: If anything happens to the mayor of New York City, he or she is succeeded by the public advocate. That's how the City Charter reads. But in last month's Democratic primary, it was clear that many voters aren't aware of that detail. Four candidates virtually tied for second place and a spot in the runoff. One of them was a salsa performer, and another an attorney whose only experience with government was in taking the city to court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMOS, HARRY
description: RAMOS-Harry. With our deepest gratitude and most profound sadness we mourn for Harry, who is tragically missing since September 11, 2001, last seen in 1 WTC while trying to help our beloved Victor from the building. We are heartbroken at this terrible loss and send our deepest condolences to Harry's wife, Migdalia, his two sons, and all his family and friends. Harry is a true hero, selfless, kind and loving, and we will forever celebrate his life, mourn for him, pray for him, and hold him in our hearts.

title: Herblock, Washington Post Cartoonist With Wit and Bite, Is Dead at 91
description: Herblock, the Washington Post editorial cartoonist, whose critical eye and rapier pen made him one of the leading journalists of his time, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 91.

title: Lessons From Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghanistan Is Pushing TV To the Sounds Radio Used
description: For all of television's technological advances, its video phones and high-speed satellite hookups, its coverage of the first two days of strikes against Afghanistan has provided so few pictures that television news executives compared their reports to radio dispatches.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Sept. 25 about plans by the Federal Communications Commission to expand access to airwaves in the range of 2500 megahertz to 2690 megahertz for services like high-speed Internet access referred incorrectly to the services that already use those frequencies. They are fixed wireless services like Internet access, which are delivered by land-based towers -- not satellite Internet service.

title: Yanks and Torre Continue Talking About Contract
description: Joe Torre says he wants to stay on as Yankees manager after his contract expires Oct. 31. George Steinbrenner has said he wants to keep Torre as his manager. They have talked repeatedly about a new contract, meeting to negotiate as recently as last Saturday. But Torre continued to sound unsure about his future yesterday.

title: Rumsfeld Sees Long Battle; Says Bombs Aren't Enough
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld cautioned today that missiles alone could not wipe out terrorists, and he warned the nation to prepare for not months, but years, of battle, as United States bombers, fighters and warships began a more limited second day of strikes.

title: An Arab Station Offers Ground-Breaking Coverage
description: In an unconventional war in which propaganda is an essential weapon, an Arab-language satellite television channel is striking with relentless power.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Jets' Defense Struggling On the Routine Plays
description: When Jets Coach Herman Edwards walked into his team's locker room Sunday night, he found players who were not acting as if they had just won an important game.

title: Stock Market Shrugs Off Air Strikes
description: The United States stock market yesterday shrugged off news of the first military strikes against Afghanistan, indicating that investors prefer actually waging war to waiting around for it.

title: City Battens Down Further as U.S. Renews Bombardment
description: National Guardsmen will be posted at Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station, just as they have been at the city's bridges, tunnels and airports. State authorities sent dozens of armed correction officers to serve in posts around the aqueducts that handle the city's water supply. And the undercover police officers working in the city's subway system were ordered into uniform as a deterrent to possible new terrorist assaults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMANSKI, WEISBLOOM, INGRID
description: SYMANSKI - WEISBLOOM - Ingrid, 39. Born in Chicago. Tragically on September 11. Survived by her children Linee, Molly and Hannah. Parents Geoffry and Lynn Davis.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELACK, ELEANOR
description: BELACK-Eleanor. Beloved sister of Doris. Donations to American Lung Association of New York, 32 Park Ave South, NY. 212-889-3370

title: Very Real Questions for Fictional President
description: The television show ''West Wing'' picks up its story line tomorrow, extending a fictional plot based on a genuine problem -- the long history of hidden illness in the White House.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AUSTRALIA

title: A Soaring Dunk by Kittles Lifts the Nets Up With Him
description: Kerry Kittles burst behind the defense, catapulted into the air and slammed down a seamless alley-oop pass from Jason Kidd -- announcing, in one stunning instant, the hope of a new Nets season.

title: George P. Brockway, 85, Publishing House President
description: George P. Brockway, former president and chairman of the publishing house W. W. Norton & Company, died on Friday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 85.

title: From One Quantum State to Another, It's Shades of 'Star Trek'
description: It's not ''Star Trek,'' but physicists in Denmark have demonstrated a step that could lead to a primitive form of instantaneous teleportation.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Compaq and GE Aircraft In Venture
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it signed a five-year agreement to deliver services and technology infrastructure to GE Aircraft Engines in North and South America. The deal, valued at $95 million, expands on an existing arrangement dating from 1993. Under the agreement, Compaq will provide desktop support and help-desk services, inventory and equipment management and database administration, said Jeff Lynn, general manager of Compaq Global Services. All of these services will be centrally managed through a dedicated Compaq program office, which continually monitor GE Aircraft operations. Compaq shares rose 23 cents, to $9.05. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the funeral of Vincent G. Danz, a New York police officer who died in the World Trade Center attack, misidentified the daughter who was carrying his police hat. She was Winifred Danz, 8, not Emily, 5.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the editorial cartoonist Herblock in some late editions yesterday misspelled the name of the cartoon created by Garry Trudeau, who said Herblock wrote out of ''a truly deep conviction.'' It is ''Doonesbury,'' not ''Dunesbury.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNN, MARGARET FREYN ''MAGGIE''
description: DUNN-Margaret Freyn ''Maggie''. Cruciverbalist, musician, generous volunteer died September 25, 2001 in Shelburne, VT at age 85. Formerly of New Rochelle, NY. Predeceased by husband Thomas Mansfield Dunn. Survived by her children Thomas Freyn Dunn of Boston, MA and Sarah Mansfield Hoag (Sally) and her husband John W. Hoag of Toronto, Canada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, JULES
description: ROTH-Jules. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice. Devoted father of the late Dr. Sheldon Roth (Vickie) and Michael (Ellen). Loving brother of Fred (Virginia). Adored grandfather of Alexandra, Michelle (Andy), Joshua, Emily and Mikey. Graveside services were held at Mt. Ararat Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITKOWSKY, EARL
description: WITKOWSKY-Earl. 91. Died October 7. Survived by his son Paul, daughter-in-law Maria, grandchildren David and Anna, all of Radford, VA.

title: Bin Laden Images Mesmerize Muslims
description: Osama bin Laden's internationally televised speech on Sunday mesmerized many Muslims with its religious and historical imagery, a powerful combination that only magnified his standing with people who wanted to see him as a heroic spokesman for the weak against the strong.

title: Under the Towers, Ruin and Resilience
description: Underneath the remains of the World Trade Center, waiting silently in the gloom and dust as if for a boarding call that will never come, sits an empty PATH train nearly and neatly cut in half. Four of its cars are intact, but three more are squashed under debris from the collapse of the trade center's south tower.

title: Arafat's Policemen Kill 2 Palestinians At Anti-U.S. Rally
description: Protests against the airstrikes in Afghanistan erupted into extraordinary confrontations today in the Gaza Strip, when Palestinian security forces opened fire on Palestinian student demonstrators and killed at least two people, including a 13-year-old boy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROCKEFELLER, LAURA
description: ROCKEFELLER-Laura. Please join family and friends to commemorate Laura's life. There will be an opportunity for everyone who wants to speak and share. 9:00 AM to 12 noon Saturday, October 13, 2001, 92nd Street Y, 1375 Lexington Avenue at 92nd St. and Lexington, Kaufmann Concert Hall

title: Green Broadcasts Runoff Campaign's First Negative Ad
description: The campaign of the Democratic mayoral candidate Mark Green unleashed the first negative ad of the runoff election last night, labeling his opponent, Fernando Ferrer, ''borderline irresponsible'' and a proponent of ''higher taxes'' and a ''divided city.''

title: Home Run Calls Have a Hollow Ring
description: Two measures of a great home run call -- especially one that describes history being made -- are vocal excitement and choice of words. Two of the best recent calls occurred on the same pitch: the gimpy-legged Dodger Kirk Gibson hitting a game-winning home run against Oakland in Game 1 of the 1988 World Series.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The American Advertising Federation, Washington, named seven young executives to its Advertising Hall of Achievement, honoring those ages 40 and under. They are: Linda Thomas Brooks, executive vice president and managing director at G.M. Mediaworks and G.M. Cyberworks, which report to the Interpublic Group of Companies through Campbell-Ewald, part of the FCB Group unit; Karen Edwards, vice president for worldwide marketing at Yahoo; Jack Griffin, president at Parade Publications, part of Advance Publications; Chan Suh, chief executive at Agency.com; Deborah Wahl, marketing communications manager at the Lincoln Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company; Tony Wright, chief strategy and planning officer for North America at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group; and Anne Kallin Zehren, publisher at Teen People, part of the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner. They will be inducted at a luncheon in New York on Nov. 14.

title: Amid Financial Wrangling, Swissair Gets Half Its Flights Into the Air
description: Swissair was operating only half its flight schedule today and said it would cut 9,000 jobs as banks, creditors and shareholders wrangled over who was at fault for last week's grounding of the country's flagship carrier.

title: Inspiration From Hitchcock, Serling and Cellophane
description: The title of Doug Wright's mischievous and theatrically savvy evening of vignettes, ''Unwrap Your Candy,'' comes from the pre-curtain announcement, ubiquitous now at productions from the Fringe Festival to Broadway. You know: the one that wags a pre-emptive finger at those who would neglect to silence a cellphone or dare to liberate a peppermint.

title: What's Doing Around Town
description: From Broadway and Off Broadway to concert halls and jazz clubs, New York City's stages are returning to normal schedules. Here is a sampling of performances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTH, EDITH VOLIN
description: RUTH-Edith Volin, 86. New York City has lost one of its most exuberant supporters. Youthful and seemingly ageless, Grandma earned her Bachelor's Degree in Art History from Hunter College at age 81, climbed the Grand Canyon at 75, and worked on Wall Street until age 84. She is a role model for many in her will to ''do it all'' in life. We have lost a most precious and inspiring mother, sister, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt, cousin, and friend. Leslie (deceased), David, Saul and Ethel, Libby and Ben, Samuel (deceased), Irma, Martin & Barbara, Sam, Linda, Amber, Jonsara and Marcus, Josephine, Sebastian, Gabriella, Debby, Ken and Helene, Alicia and Alex, Howard & Karen, Jeffrey, Beth, Sari and Alan, Susan and Andrew, Jacqueline, Andrew, Emily, Madalyn, Matthew, Dana, BJ, Kelsey, Adam. Services will be held at 11 AM, Wednesday, October 10th, Plaza Memorial, 630 Amsterdam Avenue and West 91st Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Hunter College Scholarship Fund, 695 Park Ave., NYC 10021.

title: Jitters on Main Street
description: State and local officials are putting in place new security measures, fearing retaliation for American airstrikes in Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, MURRAY
description: SCHWARTZ - Murray. Loving brother of Jack Lawrence, passed away on October 5, 2001. You were loved and will be forever missed. Your dreams will go on, sleep well. Jack Lawrence

title: On Home Front, Bush Seeks to Avoid His Father's Fate
description: One of President Bush's most vital assets as he leads the military operation in Afghanistan is that Americans, overwhelmingly, have rallied behind him. His advisers say that if he is to succeed in getting his way on both the military and domestic fronts, he must maintain that steadfast public support for as long as he can.

title: U.S. Plane Crews Fight Hunger From the Sky
description: Two American transport planes touched down safely here this afternoon after having dropped more than 37,000 meals over eastern Afghanistan. The overnight flight was the first run of a campaign to help needy civilians in that country ravaged by war and drought, and to demonstrate that the airstrikes that began about the same time were not directed against ordinary Afghans.

description: A Different War Economy

title: In Streets of Pakistani Cities, Cries of 'Death to America!'
description: Chaudary Umadali stood in the blackened ruins of his movie theater this afternoon, a dignified man trying to make sense of the rage that led to its destruction.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Belize: Hurricane Imperils Coastal Areas
description: Facing a national state of emergency, thousands of residents of Belize City were being evacuated in anticipation of a hurricane with 140 m.p.h. winds and potential 18-foot-high storm surges. The storm, the strongest of the season, was threatening coastal areas of Belize, Guatemala and Honduras. It gained strength after passing through the Caribbean over the weekend where it claimed three lives in Santo Domingo. ''This is an extremely dangerous Category 4 hurricane,'' Richard Knabb, a meteorologist at the U.S. National Hurricane Center in Miami, told The Associated Press. ''This is going to cause extensive damage wherever it makes landfall.'' In 1998 a Category 5 hurricane killed thousands of people in Honduras. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMADESSA, JOHN J.
description: PALMADESSA-John J. On October 8, 2001 at age 73. Loving husband of Mary, and devoted father to Danielle and Douglas. Grandfather to Douglas Jr. Brother-inlaw to Anthony Aglione who was his ''brother at heart'' and many devoted nieces and nephews. Korean War Veteran, self-made entrepreneur and inventor. Founder and owner of Red Ball Interior Demolition. Resident of New York City and Palm Beach, FL. Former resident of Ho-Ho-Kus and Spring Lake, NJ. He was a giant of a man in his achievements. His generosity, caring, and compassion will be in our hearts always. John has inspired many pople and was greatly admired. He will be missed by all who have crossed his path. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. For further information regarding Funeral Mass, call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: An Opportunity to Show Off the Strings
description: Andre Previn is conducting the New York Philharmonic through this week, leading programs that lean toward the popular but that are by no means unchallenging. The centerpiece of the first program, for example, was the Britten Serenade (Op. 31), a work that makes extraordinary demands on the solo hornist, to say nothing of the tenor. And the heart of the second program is the Rachmaninoff Second Symphony, a big work that can be difficult to keep cohesive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, HOLLY
description: FEINBERG-Holly. Passed after a long illness on Oct. 7, 2001. Beloved wife of Franklin. Devoted mother of Jared & Jessica. Loving sister of Keith and dear friend to many. Funeral service is on Wednesday, at 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Sinn Fein Is Stumbling Block For Belfast Protestant Leaders
description: Protestant politicians threatened today to resign from Northern Ireland's power-sharing government after failing twice to exclude Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, from the government's executive branch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOWAN, EDWARD J.
description: McGOWAN-Edward J. The Board of Trustees of the Village of Saltaire is deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and former village attorney, Ed McGowan. Ed's skills as an attorney were equaled only by his steadfast loyalty, his warmth and generosity. His devotion to his work & family earned him the respect and love of all who knew him. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Jane and their children. Martin M. Berger, Mayor

title: High Court Sets Aside Ruling on Charges for Religious Events
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The United States Supreme Court today set aside an appeals court's ruling that enabled the city of Tucson, Ariz., to charge a religious gathering for the municipal services that it provides free to other nonprofit groups that hold events in the city's parks.

title: Limbaugh Tells Listeners He's Nearly Deaf
description: Rush Limbaugh, the country's most popular talk radio host, with an audience that reaches 20 million a week, announced to his listeners yesterday that he had suffered severe hearing loss over the last four months and was almost totally deaf.

title: More Limits Are Imposed on Carry-on Bags
description: Federal aviation officials announced today that they were limiting the amount of baggage that passengers would be allowed to carry onto commercial aircraft to one carry-on bag and one personal item, like a briefcase or a purse.

title: Lovers Dream of Escape, From Different Worlds
description: THE PICKUP

title: Dusty City May Be Pivotal to U.S. Effort
description: A dusty city in northern Afghanistan called Mazar-i-Sharif has become a vivid illustration of the strategy the Bush administration is using to undermine the Taliban.

title: Lebenthal to Be Acquired by the MONY Group
description: Lebenthal & Company, a New York institution made famous by its quirky ads extolling the virtues of tax-free municipal bonds, will announce today that it is being acquired by the MONY Group.

title: Berlin's Support of the U.S. Puts Greens in Uneasy Spot
description: The Greens, junior partners in Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's coalition, neatly caught their own predicament in a statement today that on one hand supported the American fight against terrorists but on the other stressed that ''the use of the military is never a solution to problems.''

title: Woman With Bloody Hands in Modern Dress
description: Opinions were divided over Leon Major's bleakly modern production of Verdi's ''Macbeth'' when it opened the New York City Opera season in 1997. But the blazing performance of the soprano Lauren Flanigan as Lady Macbeth and the compelling performance of the baritone Mark Delavan in the title role generated so much enthusiasm that the City Opera's ''Macbeth'' was deemed an important achievement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMIREZ, GASTON, M.D.
description: RAMIREZ-Gaston, M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and long time friend. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extented to his entire family. Jeffrey Freed, M.D., President William G. Stein, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria L. Padilla, M.D., Secretary George Raptis, M.D., Treasurer

title: Devising 21st-Century Escape Routes for Creative Exits
description: In office buildings around the country, a seemingly ubiquitous sign is drawing more attention these days. It reads, simply, ''Exit.''

title: Editors' Note; Flip-Over Sports
description: The Times introduces a novel temporary format today for its weekday metropolitan and sports reports -- back to back in a shared section. The arrangement allows separate front pages and complete contents for those important coverage areas as they both enter a busy news season, with the mayoral election and the baseball playoffs. The Times's facilities can print only four late-news sections at a time, but the sharing arrangement will accommodate the special section on ''A Nation Challenged'' for as long as necessary.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Seymour: 3 Killed In Auto Crash
description: Three men were killed and a fourth was seriously injured after their car struck a tree, shearing the vehicle in half, the Connecticut State Police said. The driver apparently lost control of the vehicle as it was heading south on Route 8, north of Bridgeport, around 7:35 p.m. Sunday, Sgt. J. Paul Vance, a spokesman for the state police, said yesterday. The police did not identify the driver. Three men, all from Ansonia -- Kenneth Carey, 26; Matthew Blackwell, 22; and John Kevalis, 21 -- were pronounced dead at the scene. Martin Kevalis, 22, was listed in serious condition at St. Raphael Hospital in New Haven. The two Kevalis men share the same address, but their relationship was not described by the police.

title: Race for New Jersey Governor Turns to Car-Insurance Reform
description: James E. McGreevey used a day when the attention of many voters was directed far from New Jersey to outline his plan for reducing the state's exorbitant auto insurance rates. But he provided few details, and there was little in his proposal that he had not called for four years ago in his last run for governor.

title: Bin Laden Spokesman Threatens More Strikes
description: Al Qaeda, the embattled terrorist network of Osama bin Laden, appealed passionately today to Muslims everywhere to mobilize for a "jihad," or holy war, against the United States and its interests around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPERMAN, JACOB H.
description: KUPERMAN-Jacob H. Age 94, peacefully on October 7, 2001. Devoted father of Elaine Lewis and Howard Kuperman, loving husband of the late Rose, grandfather of three, and brother of Adele. A great and honorable man, he was adored and respected by all who knew him. Services are private.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Dover: 2 Officers Hurt In Soccer Melee
description: Two Dover police officers were injured in a melee during a broadcast of a soccer match between Uruguay and Colombia, the police said. Patrolman Harry Ruiz suffered a concussion and Sgt. Bruce Cole aggravated a shoulder injury, after the two intervened in a brawl on Sunday involving about 50 people. Angel Mero, 36, the owner of the Baker Ballroom, where the World Cup qualifying match was shown, was arrested on charges of operating a public nuisance, the police said. Mr. Mero's wife, Silvanna, said her husband was innocent. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, SAMUEL
description: PAUL-Samuel. Beloved husband of the late Gladys. Devoted father of Fredarica and David. Adored grandfather of Robert, Joshua, Anne Sharon, Elizabeth, Michael, Eric and Victoria, and great grandfather of nine. Dear brother of Mildred and Sylvia. Services Wednesday 11:30 AM Temple Sinai, 131 Washington Ave., Lawrence, LI.

title: In Cleanup Effort, Specialists Are in High Demand
description: Standing 20 feet above the sidewalk on a mechanical lift, an employee of a disaster restoration company last week sent a high-pressure stream of hot water and cleaning solution up and down the louvers and grillwork of the huge air vents at the rear of 14 Wall Street.

title: Americans Feel Jittery, And Proceed With Caution
description: Last weekend, visitors to the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia could walk straight through its pavilion to the enduring national symbol. Yesterday, they had to pass through metal detectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISELS, DR. MORTON
description: MEISELS-Dr. Morton, 86. Died with dignity on October 7, 2001. Beloved husband of Emmy. Loving father of Penina, Peter, David, Michael, Steven and Susan. Devoted grandfather of 7 grandchildren. Graduate of Cornell University School of Veterinary Medicine, Class of 1941. Served as a Captain in the U.S. Army during W.W. II. Founder of Meisels Animal Hospital. All will his insight, advice and guidance. A memorial service will be announced. In lieu of flowers make donations to Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Avenue, Montgomery, AL. 36104.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISCO NELSON, GINGER
description: RISCO NELSON-Ginger. Died September 11, 2001 in the tragic event at the World Trade Center. Ginger, beloved wife and companion to William Nelson, was a Senior Vice President at Fred F. Alger Management, Inc. Ginger leaves her devoted mother Mary Caggiano-Malfi and three brothers, John, Joseph and Rick Caggiano, many family members and friends. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel on the campus of Columbia University on October 12 at 3:30PM to celebrate her remarkable life. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be given to the: Ginger Risco Memorial Scholarship Fund, The School of General Studies, 408 Lewisohn Hall, Columbia University, New York, N.Y. 10027.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPOFFORD, MARGARET W. ''ZEE''
description: SPOFFORD-Margaret W. ''Zee''. Died peacefully at home in her 97th year. Lifelong resident of New York and Fishers Island. She is survived by her four children, Nancy Yerkes, Nick Spofford, Peggy Benkard and John Spofford, her brother Shaw Walker, 13 grandchildren and 21 great-grandchildren. Memorial service at The Brick Church, Thursday October 11 at 11AM ; memorial service and commital St. John's Church, Fishsers Island, Friday, October 12, 3PM. In lieu of flowers, contrubutions in her memory to Guiding Eyes for the Blind or Planned Parenthood of NY would be appreciated.

title: A Scaling Back, Anger in the Streets and American Determination
description: Day 2 of the bombing campaign in Afghanistan looked a lot like Day 1, but on a smaller scale.

title: A Station Pursues Both the News and the Audience
description: When WCNC, a television station in Charlotte, N.C., broadcast an intelligent report on Charlotte's school desegregation battle, the newscast's share was 1. How bad is that? ''Just brutal,'' explains the station's news director. ''It's almost like not even being on the air.''

title: Arafat Decides to Take A Gamble on the West
description: Today, Yasir Arafat took a gamble, confronting a radical Palestinian crowd in a bid to shore up his own position and assert his international credibility as the possible leader of a Palestinian state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENAT, BETTY (KAUFMAN)
description: DeNAT-Betty (Kaufman), on Sunday, October 7, of Brookline, MA, formerly of New York. Wife of Ralph. Mother of Elyse and Neil Mansfield of Hyde Park, NY, Mark and Carin DeNat of Armonk, NY and Geri and Ron Mistretta of Brookline, MA. Grandmother of Sara, Aaron, Lauren, Jay and Peter. Graveside services were held in New Jersey on October 8. Remembrances may be made to The New York Uniformed Firefighters Association, 204 E 23rd St., NY, NY 10010. For information, contact the Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA.

title: For Pain Reliever, Questions of Risk Remain Unresolved
description: The prescription pain relievers Vioxx and Celebrex surged onto the scene two years ago with an unprecedented marketing effort by their makers and an avalanche of sales. Patients demanded the drugs. And doctors took out their prescription pads, often not even trying to dissuade people who would have done just as well with a cheap alternative, like acetaminophen or aspirin.

title: New Ideas In the War On Bioterror
description: An oily mixture resembling salad dressing that can blow up anthrax bacteria. A toxin detector made of a slice of living rat brain on an electronic chip. A drug that would kill all bacteria and another that would boost a person's immune system to withstand any pathogen.

title: Schumer Role Transformed by Alliance With Bush
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer traveled across his home state today, from Buffalo to Rochester to Syracuse, announcing the resumption of some commercial flights upstate but also taking time to try to reassure New Yorkers of their safety.

title: Review/Fashion; Chalayan Peels Away Time, Layer by Layer
description: ''I'm very drawn to things that have an element of life and death,'' Hussein Chalayan said after an apocalyptic spring collection that took references from as far back as the Greeks, added styles from later periods and then, in one of the most profound statements about fashion and the passage of time, cut away those layers. They were clothes with memory smoothed by time, like a stone from deep inside the earth. ''That was my journey,'' he said.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agilent Reaffirms Forecast
description: Agilent Technologies Inc. confirmed its fourth-quarter sales and earnings forecasts even after the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington forced rivals of the company, a test and measurement equipment maker, to lower their estimates. Agilent said in August that fourth- quarter sales would be $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion. The loss for the quarter, ending Oct. 31, was forecast to be 50 cents to 70 cents a share before some expenses. Agilent, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., has said it will cut 4,000 jobs, or 9 percent of its work force. Shares of Agilent rose 32 cents, to $21.42.

title: PREVENTIVE STEPS
description: The Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation have ordered agents across the country to curtail their investigation of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks so they can pursue leads that might prevent a second, possibly imminent, round of attacks, senior law enforcement officials said.

title: Lending Slows, Forcing Delays Of Some Deals
description: Young companies or those with a lot of debt have found it nearly impossible to borrow money since Sept. 11 because lenders have been unwilling to commit more money and investors have backed away from high-yield bonds.

title: The Giants' Running Game Is Limping to St. Louis
description: With his struggling offense already a concern, Giants Coach Jim Fassel conceded today that he did not know who would be available at running back next Sunday against the St. Louis Rams.

title: Health Care Workers Extend Contract in Wake of Attacks
description: With its contract expiring on Oct. 31, New York City's largest union of health care workers has agreed with an association of 67 hospitals and nursing homes to a five-month contract extension to delay a possible strike.

title: Stocks Drop In Europe But Recover
description: European stocks recovered from early declines today, after investors were heartened by a steadier opening on Wall Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREAKSTONE, ARNOLD
description: BREAKSTONE-Arnold. This very much loved husband, father, brother, uncle and friend succumbed to pancreatic cancer on October 7, 2001. The dignity with which he courageously battled this painful disease should be the criterion by which we all live our lives. He was the consummate gentleman. His kindness, good nature, and sense of humor will forever stay in our memories. We love you Arnie. Your premature parting from us will leave a hole in our lives. A eulogy will be held at the Lincoln Park Funeral Home, 625 McLean Ave, Yonkers, NY on Wednesday, October 10th at 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers and baskets, please make donations in Arnie's name to The Lustgarten Foundation, which is striving to find a cure for pancreatic cancer, 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, NY 11714 or lustgartenfoundation.org

title: Carriers Say Military Strikes Didn't Cause Drop in Traffic
description: The start of military action in Afghanistan on Sunday did not cause a noticeable falloff in air travel yesterday, according to airlines and travel agents, though several warned that it might be too early to draw conclusions and that international traffic would weaken.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Embraces New Airport Plan
description: Mayor James K. Hahn today formally abandoned a highly divisive plan for expanding Los Angeles International Airport, proposing a more modest strategy that emphasizes security over increased capacity.

title: United in Cause, Syria Allows Foes of Israel in Its Midst
description: If policy were as simple as rhetoric, the United States and Syria might be at war. The United States has declared war on terrorism, and Syria, for 15 years, has been on the State Department list of terrorism's sponsors.

title: For Yanks, a Battle of Attrition
description: It's elementary: the more pitches the Yankees force the Oakland starters to throw, the faster they will get into the soft spot of the Athletics' team - the bullpen. So the key for the Yankees' offense will be its ability to battle the Oakland starters through extended at-bats that will increase their pitches per inning from 15 or 16 to 19 or 20 and hasten their departure.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: New York to Ask Government for $20 Billion More in Aid
description: New York will ask the federal government for an additional $20 billion in assistance to recover from the terrorist attacks that destroyed the World Trade Center and disrupted the city's and the state's economy, Governor George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said today.
