title: Passengers Stop Man Who Tried To Force His Way Into Cockpit
description: A man tried to force his way into the cockpit aboard an American Airlines flight to Chicago from Los Angeles today, the authorities said, and the pilot was forced to make an emergency landing at O'Hare International Airport after being intercepted by two fighter jets.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: An Experimental Work, Overwhelmed by Topicality
description: This may not have been the right moment in history for the Kaitaisha Theater Company to have staged Shinjin Shimizu's ''Bye-Bye: The New Primitive'' in New York. Yet the production, presented Saturday night at the Japan Society, was eerily topical.

title: Best Buy Starts Site For Music on Web
description: The Best Buy Company, the largest electronics retailer, said today that its BestBuy.com Internet division has started a Web site that allows users to purchase music online by downloading digital files.

title: Differing Audiences In the U.S. and China
description: Only the crowd of 40,483 at Foxboro Stadium outside Boston saw live the American qualification to the World Cup finals on Sunday because ABC dropped the telecast to report the military action in Afghanistan.

title: Taboos Are Put to Test in West's View of Islam
description: PARIS  As the United States and Europe seek to hold together an anti-terrorist coalition including key Muslim countries, they clearly want no part of arguments that there are basic elements of opposition between Islamic and Western civilizations.

title: Rangers Ride Emotion to Victory
description: The Rangers rested yesterday, the day after their tearful and joyous 5-4 overtime victory over the Buffalo Sabres in the team's opener at Madison Square Garden.

title: Blair, Using Arabic TV, Says War Is Not on Islam
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair made an unusual, electronic bid for a hearing in the Arab world today, using the same Arabic-language satellite television station Osama bin Laden uses, and insisted on the air that the current conflict was ''not about the West versus Islam.''

title: Hospital's Breast-Feeding Success Story
description: The percentage of mothers who breast-fed their newborns jumped at a Boston hospital when it introduced a 10-step plan that had been widely used overseas to encourage breast-feeding and cut down on formula use, according to a new study in the journal Pediatrics.

title: Witnessing a Scene That's Not on Film
description: The cast and crew of Untitled Productions, while shooting a movie in the East Village, found themselves on a rooftop as a grim scene unfolded.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rail Agency Chief Resigns
description: The chief executive of Railtrack resigned after days of turmoil in which the government refused to give the ailing company a cash infusion and the High Court ordered that it be reorganized into a new, not-for-profit trust. In a furious statement criticizing the government's ''shoddy and unacceptable'' treatment of Railtrack -- which controls Britain's train tracks and is responsible for safety and maintenance, the chief executive, Steven Marshall, said that ''commitments, whether financial or otherwise, are made to be kept.'' Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Nassau Lawmakers To Meet
description: The Nassau County Legislature is scheduled to meet at the fifth floor legislative chamber, Ralph G. Caso Executive and Legislative Building, 1 West Street, Mineola, 2:30 p.m.

title: Pakistani Is Already Calling on U.S. to End Airstrikes Quickly
description: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan made clear today that he wanted the allied military campaign in neighboring Afghanistan to be brief and warned the United States not to press political change so fast that the Islamic clerics of the Taliban give way to a new goverment in Kabul that is unfriendly to Pakistan.

title: AMERICAN SOYBEAN EXPORTER BUYS UNIT IN ARGENTINA
description: Bunge, an exporter of soybeans, has agreed to buy the La Plata Cereal unit of Andre & Cie for about $70 million in cash and debt. The acquisition will make Bunge the largest soybean crusher and second-largest exporter in Argentina, the company said. Bunge, based in White Plains, expects the purchase to close in the first quarter and add to earnings the following quarter. La Plata exports soybeans, corn and wheat and operates a fertilizer business in Argentina. Andre, based in Lausanne, Switzerland, has been shedding assets since it filed for protection from creditors in March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTSON, ROBERT D.
description: MATTSON-Robert D. On September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Elizabeth (nee Higgins), loving father of Jean and James, son of Marguerite Mattson and brother of one. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Mt. Lakes, NJ on Saturday, October 13, at 10:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASS, ELEANOR
description: KASS-Eleanor. Of Bal Harbour, FL, passed away Sunday, October 7, 2001. She was the devoted and loving wife of the late Julius Kass, mother of Emme Pedinielli and Stephen Kass, mother-in-law of Joan and Etienne, grandmother of Andy, Jeff, Jimmy, Laura, Dominique, Daniele, and Jean-Pierre, and great-grandmother of Xander, Sam, Isabelle, Gabrielle and Sam Jessica. She is also survived by her lifelong soulmate and sister, Grace Copleman, & many loving nieces and nephews. Private funeral services were held in Miami on Monday. There will be a memorial celebration for family and friends on Saturday, October 13th, at her son Stephen's house in White Plains, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERT, MAB
description: LAMBERT-Mab. The Board of Directors and the Staff of Grosvenor Neighborhood House Inc. mourn the loss of their Associate Member Mab Lambert. Mab was an active member of the Board for over 30 years. She totally believed in the difference Grosvenor's programs made to families on the Upper Westside. Edna Cowen, President

description: As of 8 p.m. Monday.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B. And The Times introduces a novel temporary format for its weekday metropolitan and sports reports -- back to back in a shared section.

title: Don't Lose Sight of Real, Everyday Risks
description: The nation is quickly buying up stocks of gas masks, shelves are being stripped of antibiotics, and bottled water may not be far behind. Many travelers have canceled trips by air and taken trains or cars instead, even across the country. New Yorkers fearful of an attack on the subways insist on riding in cars on traffic-choked streets. Doctors in Boston report that patients with minor ailments like colds and sore throats have been calling out of fear that they may have been sickened by a toxic chemical or lethal germ introduced by terrorists.

title: When 'Nonlethal' Weapons Turn Lethal
description: Bean-bag weapons used by the Los Angeles police to subdue violent or disturbed people have caused a broad range of serious injuries, researchers are reporting.

title: Giuliani to Ask City Agencies For Broad Cuts
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani planned today to ask city agencies for broad spending cuts in response to the heavy losses New York has endured since the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center last month. State and city officials also were close to reaching an agreement on a new federal aid request seeking billions more dollars to stem those losses and keep businesses in Lower Manhattan.

title: Review/Fashion; Taking a Back Seat To Unfolding Events
description: Seven months ago the last time the affluent society's tastemakers convened here to think about clothes -- the Champagne that had fueled fashion's party for so long was already showing signs of running low. It was in mid-March, at the showing of the fall 2001 collections, that stock prices fell drastically enough to bring an end to the bull market and the euphoric new-economy spending that attended it. If French fashion seemed of questionable significance before that moment, it became even less justifiable as skirts resembling swatches of AstroTurf appeared on the runway while financial advisers on CNN were warning investors to put their money in recession-proof companies like those that make toothpaste. The mood was shifting, and presumably fashion would be shifting right along with it.

title: Ailing Camby Misses a Scrimmage, And the Worry Lines Begin to Form
description: More than 10,000 fans at Madison Square Garden yesterday witnessed one of the most distressing sights a Knicks fan can see: an inactive Marcus Camby.

description: CHAISSON-Charles G. On October 7, 2001. Beloved brother and uncle will be deeply missed. Charles' profound love of God's creatures, colorful sense of humor and conversation endeared him to so many. A man of deep integrity and work ethic. For those who wish, a donation to the Humane Society in his name would be greatly appreciated by his family. Till we meet again, Dear Brother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHON, HELEN RAISS
description: HIRSHON-Helen Raiss. Died on October 7, 2001 at home after a long illness. She was the widow of the late John Raiss and of the late Walter Hirshon. She was born in Seattle, WA, resided in NYC for many years, and was a longtime resident of Sands Point, New York. Beloved mother of Linda de Spirlet, John Carl Raiss, and James Frederick Raiss. Beloved grandmother of Andrea Dodd Warble, Kevin K. Dodd, Elizabeth, Monica and Jennifer Raiss and Jonathan Raiss, and beloved great grandmother of Keenan Thomas and Reilly Murphy Warble. Funeral service private. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate donations sent to the Long Island Alzheimer's Association.

description: In recent months, Osama bin Laden and his allies have planned attacks against targets in Saudi Arabia as part of their continuing effort to oust the Saudi royal family, American officials said today.

title: From Torn Steel, Cold Data of Salvage
description: When the twin towers fell, the two buildings that had once been admired for their endless structural and architectural complexity suddenly became a heartbreaking mass grave, a symbol of terrorism's reach, and -- at a coldly physical level -- 1.2 million tons of tangled debris.

title: William G. Cahan, 87, Surgeon and Tobacco Foe, Dies
description: William G. Cahan, a Manhattan surgeon, author and tireless advocate of laws and educational programs to reduce smoking, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: The Big City; Best Defense? Don't Get Defensive
description: IF we assume the worst about Osama bin Laden (and why shouldn't we?), it is rational to fear that his video harangue broadcast on Sunday was a signal for another terrorist attack. In that case, which of the following would have been the most rational course of action yesterday for a person with a desire not to die?

description: People submerged in cold water in accidents can sometimes be revived and recover even after periods of unconsciousness that would have caused death or brain damage if they had not been chilled.

title: Students Set to Return To Stuyvesant Near Ruins
description: When 3,000 students return to Stuyvesant High School in Lower Manhattan today for the first time since Sept. 11, any hope of avoiding tangible reminders of the World Trade Center disaster is likely to fade as they cross the Tribeca Bridge, which spans the West Side Highway and empties into the school's second floor.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix May Sell Plant
description: Hynix Semiconductor may sell some of its manufacturing operations to a Chinese consortium by early next year or form a strategic alliance with a semiconductor concern in Taiwan, a company spokesman said. Hynix officials say that the sale of at least one of its 12 chip-making plants will help persuade creditors to approve a $5.3 billion rescue package. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: At least 118 people were killed at Linate Airport here this morning when the pilot of a small Cessna plane took a wrong turn on a runway and collided with an SAS jet that was just reaching takeoff speed.

title: Wall St. Network Aids Survivors; Families That Grew Up Together Now Grieve Together
description: The friendships were forged in the intimate maelstrom of the desks at firms like Cantor Fitzgerald, where traders sat, lunch-counter style, every day for 10 hours straight, amid the flashing terminals and ringing phones, the shouting, the betting pools, the practical jokes -- men hurtling together through the years toward a prosperous middle age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISCO NELSON, GINGER
description: RISCO NELSON-Ginger. Died September 11, 2001 in the tragic event at the World Trade Center. Ginger, beloved wife and companion to William Nelson, was a Senior Vice President at Fred F. Alger Management, Inc. Ginger leaves her devoted mother Mary Caggiano-Malfi and three brothers, John, Joseph and Rick Caggiano, many family members and friends. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel on the campus of Columbia University on October 12 at 3:30PM to celebrate her remarkable life. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be given to the: Ginger Risco Memorial Scholarship Fund, The School of General Studies, 408 Lewisohn Hall, Columbia University, New York, N.Y. 10027.

title: Athletics' Front Office Has a Sharp Eye for Talent
description: Now just where would the Oakland Athletics have fit Todd Helton into their lineup? That would be the Todd Helton who this season slugged 49 home runs and drove in 146 runs and became the first player ever to have 100 extra-base hits in successive seasons.

title: Pakistani Police Kill 3 Protesters and a 13-Year-Old
description: Three anti-American protesters and a 13-year-old boy were shot dead today by Pakistani police officers as demonstrators tried to storm a police station in Kuchlak, a town near the Afghan border.

title: Pushing for Realism, Seat Belts and Good Manners on the Road
description: There's nothing in the law that says that the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration needs to be an emergency room doctor who has been active in boosting the use of seat belts. But that's the background of its new administrator, Dr. Jeffrey W. Runge, as it was of his predecessor. Since leaving the Carolinas Center for Injury Prevention and Control in Charlotte, N.C., where he was the director, Dr. Runge, 45, has spoken passionately about taking aggressive measures to reduce the ''body count'' on the nation's roads. If stronger enforcement of seat-belt laws forced 90 percent of people to use them, that could translate into 8,000 fewer deaths a year, he said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Suharto Kin's Trial Opens
description: A trial on weapons charges opened for a grandson of former President Suharto, Ari Sigit, who is accused of illegally possessing 70 cartridges. On Monday, prosecutors questioned Mr. Suharto's two daughters and one son-in-law over allegations of graft surrounding the construction of two toll roads. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: The Major Sauce Groups
description: SAUCE is like success: it has many mothers. I've always kept things straight through the five basic sauces I learned at the New York Restaurant School.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Gas Producer Acquisition
description: Continuing a spate of acquisitions in Canada by United States oil and natural gas producers, Burlington Resources said it planned to buy Canadian Hunter Exploration of Calgary, Alberta, for $2.1 billion. The deal will increase Burlington's gas reserves 12 percent, to 11.5 trillion feet. Natural gas makes up more than 95 percent of Canadian Hunter's production and reserves. Burlington has expanded aggressively in Canada recently, including its $1.6 billion purchase of Poco Petroleums in 1999. Gas producers' interest in Canada has increased because of dwindling domestic reserves and predictions of rising long-term demand for natural gas. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVIO, FRANK H., CMDR. USN RET.
description: SAVIO-Frank H., Cmdr. USN Ret. Age 84. On Oct. 7, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Margaret A. (nee Armao). Devoted father of Robin L. Savio of Virginia & Lorna G. Golder of Texas. Also survived by his sister, Genevieve Savio of New York City, five grandchildren, four great grandchildren and his loving friend, Helen Jacobs. Funeral Service Wednesday at 11:00 AM in Messiah Lutheran Church, 100 Media Line Road, Newtown Square, PA. where friends may call after 10:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the charity of the donor's choice. Interment is in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Metals Cuts
description: Japan's biggest nonferrous metals company, the Mitsubishi Materials Corporation, will cut 2,500 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, within three years because of a slump in demand from technology companies. The company, based in Tokyo, said it would also reduce salaries and take other measures and hoped to save 70 billion yen ($583.8 million) a year by the end of March 2004.

title: For Some, a Rolling Office; For Others, a Mobile Chapel
description: THEY'RE facing forward, hands on the steering wheel, eyes on the road. They're alone in their cars, driving, of course, just like you, checking out the passing lane or watching for their turnoff. But wait, this one's moving his lips as if he's talking to himself, and that one's sipping a drink. There's one over there who seems to be dancing in her seat, and the one in the car next to her -- is he shaving?

title: 'Survivor,' The Bellwether
description: Even though it's only on one network, ''Survivor'' will surely be the most closely watched program of the new television season by all television executives when its third edition kicks off tomorrow night on CBS.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., the appliance maker, said its GE Financial Assurance unit had acquired Centurion Capital Group Inc., Sherman Oaks, Calif., an asset manager, to increase sales of financial services to affluent investors. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, MURRAY
description: SCHWARTZ - Murray. Loving brother of Jack Lawrence, passed away on October 5, 2001. You were loved and will be forever missed. Your dreams will go on, sleep well. Jack Lawrence

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: A Film on a Nazi Death Camp's Little-Known Revolt
description: In the history of the Holocaust, the Sobibor death camp in eastern Poland has remained something of a footnote, a place where 260,000 Jews were murdered, as opposed to at least 1.1 million in Auschwitz-Birkenau. Having operated for just 18 months and closed long before the Allied victory in May 1945, Sobibor, like its victims, disappeared almost without a trace.

title: After Disturbance, Delta Flight Lands Safely With F-16 Escort
description: ADelta Airlines passenger jet on a non-stop trip from Atlanta to Los Angeles, landed under military escort this afternoon at Shreveport Regional Airport in Louisiana after the pilot reported a disturbance inside the cabin.

title: LIMITED AND INTIMATE BRANDS LOWER EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Limited Inc., the second-largest United States clothing retailer, and its Intimate Brands unit reduced their fiscal third-quarter earnings forecasts because of declines in sales. Limited, owner of Express and Limited chains, said lower sales would cut profit by about 3 cents a share. Intimate Brands, which runs the Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works stores, said earnings would fall by 2 cents. Limited has about an 84 percent stake in Intimate Brands. September same-store sales fell 10 percent at Limited and 13 percent at Intimate Brands, the companies said. The companies are based in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Oil Companies Are Increasing Their Already Tight Security
description: Immediately after the attacks on the United States, the major petroleum exporting countries, led by Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, vowed that oil would flow uninterrupted. Oil markets expressed their confidence, and prices have fallen over the last month, although barely budging with this week's American-led strikes on Afghanistan.

title: Ready for Their Comeback?
description: We all know why carburetors and drum brakes were relegated to the junkyard of automotive engineering - better technology came along. bu what about the styling cues of previous eras - white sidewalls and fender skirts, for example - and some features that seemed really useful, like bench seats and vent windows? With the Mazda Miata, Volkswagen New Beetle, Chrysler PT Cruiser and Ford Thunderbird signaling an era of retro-styling, could any of these be ready for a comeback? And would they appeal to the new generation of car buyers (or ''millennials,'' as some call the Y generation)? Edward R. Golden, the executive director of design for the Ford brand in North America, and Peter Davis, the director of advanced interior design at General Motors, were each asked these questions. JOESPH SIANO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARLIN, EVE
description: ZARLIN-Eve. December 7, 1906October 9, 2001. Much beloved sister, mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Donations to Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Monday about Catherine Breillat's ''Fat Girl,'' shown as part of the New York Film Festival, misstated the date of the commercial opening. It is today, not Friday.

title: An Authentic Sprinkle of Mexico
description: IF you have eaten in an authentic Mexican restaurant, you have probably eaten Cotija cheese without knowing it. It was sprinkled on the gorditas, the bowl of tortilla soup or the plateful of enchiladas, with hardly a mention on the menu. Cotija, which looks something like a crumbly, dried feta and tastes salty, pungent and sharp, is the unsung cheese of Mexico. Nevertheless, it is, like mustard on a hot dog or garlic in a tomato sauce, a nonglamorous but integral part of many dishes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEBLE, NANCY
description: KRIEBLE-Nancy. The trustees and staff of the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, Connecticut wish to express our deep sorrow at the passing of our friend Nancy Krieble, whose service as a trustee of this institution since 1974 has been without compare. Her personal qualities-selfless generosity, unwavering dedication, and an enormous love for art-have shaped the Florence Griswold Museum in every way. Nancy has inspired her fellow trustees to dream and plan for a bright future-and her vision and love for the Museum has led us each step along the way. We are deeply affected by her passing, but mindful that she would want us to steadfastly continue the work that meant so much to her. Together, we pledge our intentions to do so as a way of honoring our friend whom we shall miss greatly. We extend our condolences to her daughter Helen, her son Fred, and the entire Krieble family

title: Islanders Hope to Ride The Lucky Seven Line
description: Mark Parrish, only half-joking, would say later that the puck was on his stick before he even had a chance to yell for it. Parrish and Shawn Bates had been linemates for less than two full Islanders games, and they were already communicating like psychics and were scoring pretty goals as a result.

title: Downtown TKTS Booth Is Reopening
description: The Theater Development Fund announced yesterday that it would reopen its downtown TKTS booth, which offers same-day discount tickets for Broadway shows and other performances, at a new location in Bowling Green Park Plaza at the southern tip of Manhattan. The fund's former ticket booth, in the World Trade Center, was destroyed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Bin Laden Aide Threatens More Strikes
description: A top aide to Osama bin Laden appeared in a videotaped message tonight and implied that airplane hijackings like those that killed thousands of Americans at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon could be repeated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENEY, GEORGE FENTON
description: SWEENEY-George Fenton, 70. Of Rye Brook and Cutchogue, NY, on October 8, 2001. Beloved husband of Jane Paris. Devoted father to Patrick Sweeney, Heather Tetrault and Michele Cusack. Doting grandfather of Michael, Max, Desmond, Patrick, Brooke & Caroline. Loved for his joie de vivre, humor, loyalty, generosity, grace and style. For wake and service information call Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY, 914-967-0129.

description: Horse Show

title: Corrections
description: Anews analysis article on Tuesday about assessments of the taped speech by Osama bin Laden misstated the government background of one authority, Daniel Benjamin, a former United States official who is writing a book on religious terror. He served in the Clinton administration, not the Bush administration.

title: Counselors Waylaid by Outsized Task
description: Catherine Masterson arrived at the armory on Lexington Avenue and 26th Street in New York at 6 a.m. that first Saturday after the terrorist attacks and spent the next 14 1/2 hours counseling grief-stricken families of the victims. She especially remembers how she coaxed a 9-year-old girl who had lost her father into talking about her feelings by giving her two stuffed kittens, one wrapped in bandages and the other wearing a Red Cross uniform.

title: Anti-American Protests Increase, and Sponsors Plan More
description: Anti-American demonstrations widened in Indonesia today, with riot police firing tear gas to disperse angry protesters outside the United States Embassy in Jakarta.

title: Runoff Campaign Turns Confrontational and Strange as Candidates Trade Charges
description: The Democratic mayoral runoff election grew nastier yesterday on its next-to-last day, with an exchange of attack ads on the airwaves, sharp words between the candidates and even a circuslike confrontation, complete with an acrobat, between supporters of Fernando Ferrer and Mark Green on a Midtown street.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Verisign Climbs On Keyword Bandwagon
description: The operator of the database for .com, .org. and .net addresses VeriSign Inc. plans to announce today a deal that will allow companies that register Internet domains to also make available to the domain holders Internet locators called Keywords. Developed by the RealNames Corporation, based in Redwood City, Calif., the Keywords offer an alternative method of locating information online. Rather than typing in an address like www.barnesandnoble.com, for example, users can type ''Barnes & Noble'' into Microsoft's Internet Explorer to find the bookseller's Web page. Fees for the Keywords range from $50 to $199 a year. A RealNames spokeswoman said about 1.5 million Keywords had been registered since 1996. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Recipe: Red Wine Sauce
description: Adapted from Jonathan Crean

title: Building Repeat Business by Putting Drivers in a Ditch
description: DAVE WACHOB of New Hope, Pa., told his wife, Alyssa, to pack her bags for a surprise getaway to celebrate their seventh wedding anniversary in August. Thinking she was headed to the Caribbean, she stuffed her suitcase with swimsuits, sandals and resort clothes. But Mr. Wachob had another destination in mind: South Bend, Ind.

title: Yielding To the Power of Persuasion
description: In his haunting, beauteous ''Werckmeister Harmonies,'' the avant-garde Hungarian filmmaker Bela Tarr meditates on mankind's place in the cosmos, the wonders of God and the timeless immanence of evil and irrationality that loose anarchy and invite tyranny.

title: The New Face of Honey, Creating Some Buzz
description: AMY DUBOIS BARNETT, the editor in chief of Honey magazine, is remarkably composed on a recent afternoon, particularly given that her computer ate every word of her essay on Aaliyah, the young pop singer who died in an August plane crash in the Bahamas.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with the biographical sketches of terrorism victims at the World Trade Center, for the profile of Jenny Low Wong, who moved to New York at age 12 from Venezuela to seek opportunities and by 25 was an assistant vice president at Marsh & McLennan, was published in error. It showed Jennifer Y. Wong, another victim. The picture appears today with a profile of Jennifer Wong, on Page B15.

title: Bailout for Airlines Showed the Weight Of a Mighty Lobby
description: Just one day after terrorists hijacked and crashed four commercial jets, lobbyists for the airline industry were already at work, laying the groundwork for a multibillion-dollar plan to rescue the industry.

title: First Sept. 11 Book Is Out
description: JAY ROSEN, chairman of the journalism department at New York University, has helped publish ''09/11 8:48 AM: Documenting America's Greatest Tragedy,'' a compendium of eyewitness accounts and other reactions to the Sept. 11 attacks. The 75 contributors included seven N.Y.U. professors and 11 N.Y.U. students. Mr. Rosen said the book was the first one published on the events and was ''not meant to be a first draft of history, but individual voices reacting to startling events.'' Although it is not in local bookstores yet, it is available on some Web sites, including www.booksurge.com. Karen W. Arenson

title: Previn and the Philharmonic Let the Strings Be the Stars
description: Andr Previn is conducting the New York Philharmonic through this week, leading programs that lean toward the popular but that are by no means unchallenging. The centerpiece of the first program, for example, was the Britten Serenade (Op. 31), a work that makes extraordinary demands on the solo hornist, to say nothing of the tenor. And the heart of the second program is the Rachmaninoff Second Symphony, a big work that can be difficult to keep cohesive.
