description: Adapted from Da Ivan

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Wyoming: Delay In Trial Of Pakistani
description: A District Court judge in Casper has granted a Pakistani man a 90-day delay in his trial on first-degree murder charges because of the recent terrorist attacks. The judge, Thomas Sullins, ruled that hostility toward Muslims and people from the Middle East might result in jury prejudice. The Pakistani, Rehan Bhutto, 30, is accused of shooting his girlfriend, Valerie McCarthy, 25, in their home on April 25. He has pleaded not guilty. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: American States of Mind: Anxiety and Resolve; Wars of Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Customs Switches Priority From Drugs to Terrorism
description: The new head of the United States Customs Service said today that terrorism has replaced drug smuggling as the agency's top priority, and that he has redeployed hundreds of agents to provide round-the-clock inspections at the Canadian border to prevent terrorists from entering the country.

title: Winning Party In Poland Forges Link With Farmers
description: Poland's former Communist Party, which came out ahead in national elections last month, formed a coalition yesterday with the Polish Peasants Party. The move will allow the former Communists to form a government, but could force them to pay homage to nationalistic and anti-European groups.

title: Officer Fatally Shoots Man Who Shot Him, the Police Say
description: A city police sergeant who was shot yesterday afternoon during a traffic stop on a Queens street corner returned fire, killing a suspect, the police said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I just thought of myself as black. But now I feel like I'm an American, more than ever.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASNIS, MYRON W., DDS
description: ASNIS-Myron W., DDS. On October 8, 2001, formerly of Roslyn, N.Y. Beloved husband of Ruth. Dear father of Deborah, Gregory and the late Stephen. Adored grandfather of Matthew, Joshua, Jeremy, Aviva and Shoshanah. Services on Thursday 12 noon at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, L.I.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Layoffs Are Planned At Agencies in 2 States
description: Two agencies are making layoffs.

title: U.S. Pounds Afghan Targets for the 4th Straight Day
description: American warplanes pounded Afghanistan early today for the fourth day in a row, targeting military sites around Kandahar, the ruling Taliban's spiritual headquarters in Afghanistan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Homicide Suspect Killed
description: An Ohio man wanted in connection with an August killing in East New York has been shot and killed by officers while he was in a vehicle with three other passengers, the authorities said. Two children in the car, ages 8 and 4, and another passenger were unhurt in the incident. The officers were treated for minor injuries at area hospitals and released. The man, Shannon Vinson, 28, of Columbus, Ohio, was pulled over at a traffic stop about 9 p.m. on Monday. As the officers tried to arrest him, the police said, he reached for a handgun and tried to drive away, dragging one officer. The officers shot Mr. Vinson seven times. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Satisfying New York Tastes With a Click on the Internet
description: New York boosterism is in full swing, and a way for city-lovers everywhere to climb on the bandwagon is to indulge in some of New York's favorite treats, many of which are sold on the New York First Web site. There is chicken soup with matzo balls from Artie's Deli on the Upper West Side, cheesecake from Junior's in Brooklyn, and Yonah Schimmel knishes and corned beef from Katz's Delicatessen, both on the Lower East Side. Also, Morisi-Coppola pasta from Brooklyn, steaks from Smith & Wollensky, a frozen hot chocolate mix from Serendipity 3 and even Ray's pizza, to name some. Perishables are sent overnight, so delivery charges may be high. All are available from www.newyorkfirst.com, Gotham Grocery or (800) 581-7599.

title: America's Muslim Allies: A Time of Trial
description: Just how big a threat to moderate Arab and Muslim regimes is Osama bin Laden's militant sword of Islam?

title: Reservoir Security is Tight, 2 Journalists Learn Firsthand
description: After two reporters for The Daily News were able to slip potentially deadly carry-on items like knives and scissors past checkpoints at 10 major airports last week, the newspaper splashed the story across its front page.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Layoffs At Hospital
description: St. Joseph's Regional Medical Center has laid off 120 workers and reduced the salaries for others to close a $30 million budget deficit, officials said yesterday. Andrea Simon, the center's vice president for business development, said the layoffs and salary reductions were intended to help close the deficit, but she could not estimate the cost savings.

title: Bush, Angered By Leaks, Duels With Congress
description: President Bush and leading members of Congress from both parties clashed sharply today over Mr. Bush's order limiting classified military and investigative briefings to eight senior lawmakers.

title: Liberties; Where Are You, Mrs. Miniver?
description: Wednesday, Oct. 3: I call my doctor to plead for Cipro, the antibiotic that may not work on the Deadly Anthrax Virus but then again may. I tell him a man in Florida near the hijackers' training ground has been stricken.

title: New Jersey Security Head
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco of New Jersey yesterday named Attorney General John J. Farmer Jr. as interim head of the state's new Domestic Security Task Force, which was created last Wednesday in a special session of the Legislature.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Airport-To-Mall Tunnel
description: Construction began this week on the underground part of an 11.6-mile light-rail tunnel connecting Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport with downtown Minneapolis and the Mall of America in Bloomington. The underground part of the $142 million project will consist of two 7,300-foot parallel tunnels. Federal officials asked the metropolitan Airport Commission to examine security for the tunnel last week. The project is expected to be completed by 2003. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Doctors Are Told to Watch for Symptoms Linked to Biological Attacks
description: Walking a fine line between informing the public and trying to avoid panic, state and local health officials have asked doctors throughout New York to be on the lookout for any unusual symptoms or clusters of diseases that could be linked to bioterrorism.

title: Sept. 11 Attack Narrows the Racial Divide
description: In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, a crew of black and Latino teenage boys say they can no longer think of the police as enemies. Since Sept. 11, the boys say, the officers who patrol their neighborhoods, most of whom are white, no longer eye them with suspicion.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: This Time, Morocco

title: Senate Stalls On U.S. Role In Screening At Airports
description: After more than a week of meetings, the Senate remained bogged down over the scope and cost of a bill to federalize the jobs of baggage screeners at major airports.

title: When the Right Way to Drive Is on the Left
description: I HAVE always thought of myself as a good driver. I learned to drive in Memphis, where people often do not look where they are going. I zip through the streets of New York, Boston and Washington. Maneuvering down icy New Jersey roads with screaming children in the back seat? No problem. I can parallel-park within two inches of a curb in one reverse, one forward.

title: The Cookie Is Crispy, Crunchy and French
description: When it comes to cookies, freshly baked is usually better than packaged. But there are exceptions, like the deep golden croquants de Cordes, shatteringly crisp sugar-and-almond-crusted ovals hinting of praline that are produced by Christian Bruyre and imported from France. Eating just one is virtually impossible, and they are just about perfect with ice cream. Fairway sells them, in boxes holding a little more than three ounces, for $4.19. I only hope that other versions of these crispy cookies, like the ones made with walnuts or chocolate and sold in the Dordogne region of southwest France, will make it to our shores.

title: A Riskier Phase, a Widening Focus and Stress and Strain All Around
description: On the third day of American airstrikes against Afghanistan, the Pentagon already had its eye on the next phase of the operation, and it seemed likely to be riskier than anything carried out thus far.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Charter Names Chief Executive
description: The nation's No. 4 cable television provider Charter Communications Inc. said Carl Vogel would become president and chief executive, effective immediately. Less than three weeks ago, the company, which is controlled by the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen, announced that its chief, Jerald L. Kent, would leave the company at the end of the year. Although the company did not give a reason for his departure, analysts indicated there was tension between Mr. Kent and Mr. Allen. Mr. Vogel, a longtime broadband management executive, was a vice president of Liberty Media. He has also been chief operating officer for AT&T's broadband field operations, chief executive of the satellite television company Primestar Inc. and president of EchoStar Communications. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Off Limits With O'Neill
description: Even though Paul O'Neill is expected to retire after this season, he has consistently declined to discuss the topic since spring training.When O'Neill was asked if he was doing so to avoid being a distraction or because he is not comfortable discussing the end, he said, ''both.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Australia: Firm 'No' To Stranded Migrants
description: The government stuck to its hard line against stranded asylum seekers, turning away the latest shipload of 187 Iraqi refugees. While offering no alternative, Prime Minister John Howard said: ''They're not coming to the Australian mainland. That's one choice that is not available.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Russians Say Evidence Indicates Ukrainians Shot Down Jet
description: Russian officials appeared to confirm today that Ukraine's military accidentally shot down a Russian passenger jet over the Black Sea last week, after investigators at the crash site found fragments of an antiaircraft missile in the wreckage.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rises
description: In another sign of deterioration in Europe's biggest economy, Germany's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose in September to 9.4 percent from 9.3 percent. The numbers reflected the slowdown that Germany had been experiencing for most of this year, but analysts said the economic fallout from the terrorist attacks would make an even bigger impact several months from now. Economists at Deutsche Bank predicted that unemployment could creep to 9.5 percent by the end of this year and nearly 10 percent by the end of next year. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: American States of Mind: Anxiety and Resolve; Wars of Words
description: To the Editor:

title: BDO SEIDMAN FILES SUIT AGAINST ACCOUNTING ASSOCIATION
description: BDO Seidman, an accounting and consulting firm based in Chicago, filed suit in federal court in New York yesterday against the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the industry's trade association, claiming that the association's for-profit subsidiary CPA2Biz Inc. has violated federal antitrust laws. In its complaint, the firm, which is a member of the institute, argues that CPA2Biz has the unfair advantage of exclusive access to information collected by the trade association from its members. In a statement, the institute said the lawsuit was without merit. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: Not All Extended Warranties Are Created Equal
description: AS cars grow more reliable and some standard warranties soar toward a 10-year mark, it might seem safe to assume that extended warranties would be beside the point. Yet in the last few years, the market for extended warranties has never been richer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENDLER, BETTY
description: PENDLER-Betty. The Board of Directors, staff, participants and friends of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, NYC Chapter, mourn the passing of Betty Pendler, a good friend, a former member of the Board of Directors and professional. She was committed to people with disabilities, their families, and those who serve them. She will be remembered as a person of commitment, good will, new ideas and new approaches to service. Betty was a powerful and enlightened advocate. Our condolences go to her daughter, Lisa, her son, Paul, and the other members of her family. A memorial service will be held on October 21 at 1 P.M. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the AHRC Foundation in Betty's memory. 212-780-2690. Al Agovino, President Michael Goldfarb, Exec. Director

title: Best Policy for Oakland's Manager Is Silence, Not Honesty
description: The news conference with Manager Art Howe yesterday was about five minutes old and five questions had been asked. One was a request for the Athletics' lineup, so that should not have even counted as a question. The sixth question should have been another easy one for the manager, but it was not. He made it difficult and made the glaring error of tweaking his opponents. Oh, by the way, the opponents Howe slapped are chasing their fourth straight World Series title.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia And Georgia: Which One Bombed?
description: Russia and Georgia traded angry accusations of warmongering after aircraft bombed two villages in Georgia's Kodori Gorge, where rebels shot down a United Nations helicopter on Monday. Georgia said the aircraft came from Russia, and its air force threatened to shoot down any planes that enter its territory. Russia said the aircraft appeared to have come from Georgia and its defense minister, Sergei Ivanov, said the incident showed that Georgia cannot control its territory or may be manipulating ''terrorists,'' a reference to rebels in the gorge who Russia claims have attacked Russian peacekeepers with Georgia's assent, if not outright help. Both the attack on the helicopter and the bombing took place in Abkhazia, a breakaway region of Georgia that has maintained its independence since 1993. Neither Georgia nor the United Nations recognizes Abkhazia's independence. Nor does Russia, athough it has peacekeepers in Abkhazia and has shown clear sympathy toward the region's claims of sovereignty. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Knicks' Johnson Will Retire
description: Larry Johnson will retire today from the National Basketball Association -- ending a 10-year career -- because of a chronically sore back. Johnson, the Knicks' co-captain, accepted a buyout and will receive the final $29 million that remains on his contract, a person close to him said.

title: Europeans Expected to Fine Daimler in Antitrust Case
description: The European Commission is expected to impose a fine Wednesday on DaimlerChrysler A.G. as it concludes a five-year antitrust investigation of the German carmaker.

title: Bills Game Shows Jets The System Does Work
description: It was back in August, before the real games had begun, when Paul Hackett, the Jets' offensive coordinator, drew the time line for his offense.

title: Satisfying New York Tastes With a Click on the Internet
description: New York boosterism is in full swing, and a way for city-lovers everywhere to climb on the bandwagon is to indulge in some of New York's favorite treats, many of which are sold on the New York First Web site. There is chicken soup with matzo balls from Artie's Deli on the Upper West Side, cheesecake from Junior's in Brooklyn, and Yonah Schimmel knishes and corned beef from Katz's Delicatessen, both on the Lower East Side. Also, Morisi-Coppola pasta from Brooklyn, steaks from Smith & Wollensky, a frozen hot chocolate mix from Serendipity 3 and even Ray's pizza, to name some. Perishables are sent overnight, so delivery charges may be high. All are available from www.newyorkfirst.com, Gotham Grocery or (800) 581-7599.

title: 5 Ex-Soviet Asian Republics Are Now Courted by the U.S.
description: The five countries that emerged in Central Asia after the collapse of the Soviet Union a decade ago -- Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan -- are unknown to most Americans but are now being urgently courted as the United States seeks to destroy terror bases in nearby Afghanistan.

title: Lynne Cheney Disputes Official's Call for More Teaching of Multiculturalism
description: Lynne Cheney, wife of the vice president, has challenged Judith A. Rizzo, deputy chancellor for instruction in New York City schools, on what should be taught in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, though Dr. Rizzo said her original remarks were misinterpreted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about an assault by Israelis on Palestinian neighborhoods in Hebron referred imprecisely at one point to its connection with an attack on a bus station on Thursday in which a Palestinian killed three Israelis. The Israeli assault on Hebron was partly in response to the wounding of two women in Hebron by Palestinians on Friday. It was not, as the article noted elsewhere, in retaliation for the attack at the bus station.

title: THE CHEF
description: LOTS of people look through my menu and order the squid pasta. But sometimes diners are surprised to find that the squid is the pasta.

title: In the Mideast, New Turns in an Old Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISHER, DAVID
description: FLEISHER - David. (Retired Professor at Yeshiva University.) Beloved husband of the late Bella. Devoted father of Michael and Martin. Services Thursday 1:45 ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ, 1-800-522-0588.

title: Censorship in Pashto and Arabic
description: Since the end of the cold war, the Voice of America's radio programs have metamorphosed from government echo into real journalism. The station, which broadcasts in 53 languages worldwide, is for many people the only available counter to their governments' propaganda. Surveys of men in Afghanistan last year showed that 67 percent listened to the V.O.A. every day. The need to maintain a credible alternative source of news for Muslims today makes the administration's efforts to censor the V.O.A. all the more objectionable. The V.O.A. today is an independent agency, but it is government-funded and still susceptible to State Department and Congressional pressure. The advent of war should be an occasion to strengthen its independence.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Lisa Marie Faller, executive vice president heading client services and new business at FKQ Advertising and Marketing, Clearwater, Fla., was named president. She succeeds Robert O. Faller, who becomes chairman.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Gun Lawsuit Dropped
description: Bridgeport will not appeal a State Supreme Court decision rejecting a Bridgeport lawsuit seeking to hold gunmakers accountable for medical and other costs associated with gun violence. The United States Supreme Court refused to hear a similar appeal from another state, a spokesman for Mayor Joseph Ganim, above, said yesterday. The highest court declined to review a Louisiana Supreme Court ruling upholding that state's prohibition on lawsuits against gunmakers. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: The Tried and True Is Enough for Torre
description: Every fall, Joe Torre's thoughts seem to wander through all lineup possibilities, different combinations that would include unusual choices. And every fall, Torre usually turns to the veterans who have won championships for him in the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUNIE, PAULINE SOPHIE
description: PUNIE-Pauline Sophie (London). Of Sunrise, Florida, formerly of Laurelton, N.Y. Peacefully on October 5, 2001, in her 96th year. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Iris Schornstein and the late Joan Ribler. Loving grandmother of Lori (Ronald) Seitenbach, Lawrence (Rebecca) Ribler, Kenneth (Jill) Ribler, Lisa Schornstein & David Schornstein. Devoted great-grandmother of Justin, Grant, Cameron, Johanna and Jackson. Thank you dear Nanna for being such a strong influence in our lives. You were the foundation upon which we all leaned. Your unselfish caring and giving are the legacies you leave to us. We will always be grateful for your support and unconditional love.

title: National Crises, Real and Imagined
description: FASTER than would have been imaginable, we've been transformed from a nation of peace and prosperity to one of insecurity and economic stress. There are now real crises to worry about; we no longer have to invent them to enliven public debate.

title: Last Year's Roster Is Pruned, So Red Storm Is Set to Blossom
description: St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis was speaking metaphorically yesterday when he compared this season's basketball team with a plant that had been pruned in order to improve its form.

title: American States of Mind: Anxiety and Resolve
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, ISIDORE A.
description: BECKER-Isidore A. On October 8, 2001. Beloved husband of Adele. Loving father of Steven, his wife Abbe, and Carol. Adored grandfather of Robert, Meredith, Emily and Alison. Dear brother of Russ. He will live in our hearts forever and will always be a part of our lives. He was the strength and rock of our family. Service Thursday, 9:30AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Norris Houghton, Theater Director, Dies at 92
description: Norris Houghton, a theatrical producer and designer, and founder of the Phoenix, one of the first and most successful of New York's not-for-profit Off Broadway theaters, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, said Frank Lloyd Dent, a longtime friend and neighbor. He was 92.

title: The Moods They Are A'Changing In Films; Terrorism Is Making Government Look Good
description: For more than 30 years, a staple of popular culture in movies, books and television has been the depiction of the government as a hostile, corrupt, even evil force spinning elaborate conspiracies to manipulate and suppress Americans.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Menem Account Frozen
description: A Swiss judge told Argentina that he had identified a bank account belonging to former President Carlos Saul Menem and ordered that the Swiss account be frozen. The judge said he would investigate the origins of the $620,000 found in the account, opened before 1990, to see if it may be connected to illegal arms sales to Croatia and Ecuador in the early- and mid-1990's. Mr. Menem has been under house arrest since June 7 on charges that he masterminded the arms transfers while serving as president. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about President Bush's popularity ratings since Sept. 11 referred incorrectly to crises that faced Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt, John F. Kennedy and Jimmy Carter. They were not entirely free of threats to the American mainland. Roosevelt faced some during World War II, notably Japanese bombing runs over Oregon, which set off forest fires, and balloons with incendiary bombs launched by the Japanese against the West Coast.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Railtrack Vows Court Action
description: The British railroad company, Railtrack, said it would sue to recover $510 million in assets frozen after the government refused to bail out the company. Trading in its shares has been suspended. Railtrack, which owns the signals, tracks and stations of Britain's aging rail system, said the frozen money should be freed to pay shareholders. Separately, John Robinson, Railtrack's chairman, turned down a government offer to become chairman of a nonprofit trust to succeed Railtrack. The company's chief executive, Steve Marshall, quit on Monday to protest the government's treatment of the company and investors. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: National Education Talks Languish in Shadow of War
description: The governors of 25 states and the chief executives of three dozen Fortune 500 companies were committed to attend the fourth national education summit conference here today. Organizers also received strong and repeated signals from the White House that President Bush would be here, too, just as his predecessors had addressed the education conferences in 1989, 1996, 1999. But ultimately the conference could not compete with the major distractions produced by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and the war in Afghanistan. Attendance was sparse, with nine governors sending regrets.

title: How Some Live With AIDS With Little or No Therapy
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 9  Celina D'Costa, speaking here to scientists and researchers from all over the world, reminds her audience that she has received virtually no treatment during her seven years of infection with H.I.V.  even though drug companies in her homeland, India, now produce the medicines that have vastly prolonged the lives of Western AIDS patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESEL, ISRAEL (SOL)
description: WIESEL-Israel (Sol), 82, of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of New York City, died in Boca Raton, FL on October 6, 2001. Beloved husband of Terry, loving father of Marcia Wiesel, devoted brother of George and Florence. Funeral services & interment were held on Monday in Boynton Beach, FL.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages yesterday about ''Here Is New York: A Democracy of Photographs,'' an exhibition relating to the World Trade Center attack, misstated the proj ect's Web address. It is www .hereisnewyork.org. (not .com).

title: Attack Overshadows The Race for Mayor
description: In the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack and in the face of an ailing municipal budget, the New York mayoral election is one of the most critical in the city's history. Yet it may also prove to be among the least noticed -- time and again overshadowed by events both global and local.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: School Finance In Connecticut
description: The Legislature has scheduled a public hearing on possible changes in how the state finances public schools. Room 2-D, Legislative Office Building, Capitol Complex, Hartford, 4 p.m. Information: (860) 240-0300.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the diversion of shipping from New York to Baltimore referred incorrectly to a longshoremen's work rule. Although contracts once barred them from working in the rain, they now handle cargo in all weather.

title: Dance, Chant, Volcanoes: A Hula Opera Comes to TV
description: Hawaii has hundreds of hula schools, called halau, but only one, Halau o Kekuhi, is at the pinnacle of this indigenous dance. Nalani Kanakaole and Pualani Kanakaole Kanahele, Hawaiian sisters who run this school, stunned Hawaiian audiences in 1995 and '96 with their five-act tour de force, ''Holo Mai Pele,'' the first hula opera.

title: Fallon Worldwide To Expand Operations
description: Fallon Worldwide said yesterday that it would expand operations by opening offices in Hong Kong; So Paulo, Brazil; and Singapore. The agency has headquarters in Minneapolis and offices in London and New York.

title: Restaurants Grieve, Family Style
description: TO an outsider it looked like a reunion, which, in a way, it was. Friends greeted friends with hugs and with tears. ''I've missed you so much,'' someone said. ''It feels like years since I've seen you.'' Someone else walked over to the front plate-glass window and smoothed the edges of the American flag where the tape had sagged. Then the group filed into the empty party room to hear what their boss had to say.

title: Second Loss Compounds Widow's Grief
description: Jorge Morron was supposed to become a United States citizen on Sept. 17. To record the event, he wanted his pregnant wife, Sonia, to bring a video camera to the swearing-in ceremony, at the Immigration and Naturalization Service bureau in Garden City, N.Y.

title: In the Mideast, New Turns in an Old Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Calvin Hernton, 69, Scholar Of American Race Relations
description: Calvin C. Hernton, a scholar, critic and poet whose work explored the terrain where American race relations collide with American sexual politics, died on Oct. 1 at his home in Oberlin, Ohio. He was 69.

title: Mixed Signals As Motorola's Loss Meets Expectations
description: Investors nervously awaiting earnings data reflecting the business impact of the Sept. 11 attacks received mixed signals late yesterday from Motorola, the first large technology company to report earnings for the quarter that ended on Sept. 30.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Tuesday about assessments of the taped speech by Osama bin Laden misstated the government background of one authority, Daniel Benjamin, a former United States official who is writing a book on religious terror. He served in the Clinton administration, not the Bush administration.

title: New Jersey Official Questions Schundler's Budgetary Record
description: The top state official in charge of local government finances issued a blistering critique today of Bret D. Schundler's budgetary practices as mayor of Jersey City, informing Mr. Schundler's Democratic successor that the city faced a cash deficit of $54 million, or 16 percent of its yearly revenues, as of June 30, when Mr. Schundler left office.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: A Call For Terrorist Profiling
description: Representative John Cooksey, a Republican who recently apologized for belittling people who wear turbans, is running a television commercial that advocates ''terrorist profiling.'' In the advertisement, Mr. Cooksey says, ''We know the faces of the terrorists and where they're from.'' Mr. Cooksey, who is running in 2002 against Senator Mary L. Landrieu, the incumbent Democrat, says that his earlier words about men who would wear ''a diaper on his head'' were too strong, but ''our security and safety are our most important rights.'' David Firestone (NYT)

title: For Australians, Paris Opens a Door to the World
description: PARIS  At best Australian fashion conjures up colorful images of funky swim and surf wear. At worst, as those who experienced Bondi Beach in the '80s will tell you, it's those short little shorts otherwise known as Stubbies that still come back to haunt them.

title: Visa and MasterCard Ordered To Allow Rival Cards at Banks
description: Visa International Inc. and MasterCard International Inc. must end their practice of barring member banks from distributing rivals' credit cards, a federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: World Briefing | The Africa: Ivory Coast: Leaders Boycott Peace Talks
description: The government opened a two-month reconciliation convention in Abidjan intended to settle differences among the country's main political parties and put an end to two years of chronic instability. None of the main opposition leaders took part in the opening ceremony. But officials from one of the parties said that its leader, Henri Konan Bdi, the former president who has been in exile in Paris since a coup in December 1999, would return to Ivory Coast later this month. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Howe's Confident Talk Shows Little Respect for Yankees
description: Before the doors to visitors' clubhouse at Yankee Stadium swung open to members of the news media yesterday, an Oakland executive reminded the players to avoid all inflammatory comments. Keep all remarks bland and benign, lest anything be construed as a knock on the Yankees; compliment the Yankees.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Emergency Sewage Repair
description: The 26th Ward wastewater treatment plant in Starrett City will temporarily close tomorrow and result in the release of tens of millions of gallons of sewage into Jamaica Bay, officials said yesterday. Officials suggest that people avoid contact with the waters until the week of Oct. 21. The plant will be closed for repairs to a ruptured water main. The repairs will take three days and will result in approximately 60 million gallons of sewage being pumped daily into Jamaica Bay, said Charles G. Sturcken, the Department of Environmental Protection's chief of staff. ''Our modeling shows the effects on the environment will be minimal,'' he said. Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: A Move For Smaller Schools
description: Baltimore's school system plans to break up nine huge, often chaotic high schools and replace them with smaller ones as part of a five-year, $55 million overhaul. The high schools have suffered from poor attendance, low scores on standardized tests, violence and a dropout rate of 70 percent between 9th and 12th grades. The high schools, with up to 2,000 students each, will be replaced with schools averaging 400 to 500 students. The plan calls for renovation and reorganization of existing schools and new schools in office buildings, neighborhoods, on college campuses and shopping malls. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Yahoo Adds An Advertising Executive
description: The big Internet search site Yahoo hired a former DoubleClick Inc. executive, Wenda Harris Millard, to oversee Yahoo's advertising sales, which have dwindled in the last year. Ms. Millard, 47, was named chief advertising sales officer and will be responsible for selling advertising and marketing services in North America, Yahoo said. She was previously chief Internet officer at Ziff Davis Media and president of Ziff Davis Internet. Ms. Millard, above, will report to Gregory Coleman, executive vice president for North America operations, Yahoo said. Ms. Millard replaces Anil Singh, who quit in May to pursue personal interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSEN, JEFFREY
description: OLSEN-Jeffrey, F.D.N.Y. Engine 10. Of Great Kills, Staten Island, on September 11th, 2001. Beloved husband of Denise (nee Caputo). Loving father of Vincent, Tori Rose and Noah Olsen. Devoted son of Peter and Carol Olsen. Dear brother of John and Neil Olsen, Jane Wilson, Mary Olesky and Cynthia Dinkins. Loving uncle of 15 nieces and nephews. Memorial gathering at Casey McCallum Rice South Shore Funeral Home, 30 Nelson Avenue, Great Kills, Staten Island, Thursday, October 11, 2-4, 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, on Friday, October 12, at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Olsen Children Education or U.F.A. Widows and Childrens Fund, 204 East 23rd Street, New York, New York 10010.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENDRICK, BRIAN
description: KENDRICK-Brian. The officers, members and staff of the Pawling Mountain Club mourn the passing of our fellow sportsman and dear friend. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Philip Bonanno, Chairman Peter Cholnoky, President

title: Jury Is Shown Second Videotape In Case of Wedding-Day Killing
description: Last week, jurors saw a videotape of a businessman shooting his former girlfriend hours before she was to marry another man. Today, they saw a tape showing the accused man with his arm around the woman at a supermarket earlier the same day.

title: Thomas, the Pupil, Is Ready To Fill Johnson's Big Shoes
description: Who could blame Kurt Thomas for being cocky? He had led the nation in scoring and rebounding, had been selected 10th by the Miami Heat in 1995 and had been annihilating all comers at the downtown Y.M.C.A. in Dallas.

title: Pakistan, in a Border Clash, Turns Back Taliban Forces
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 9  Border troops fought a two-hour gun battle today with Taliban soldiers at a frontier crossing with Afghanistan. The fighting increased pressures on President Pervez Musharraf as he struggled to keep the lid on spreading pro-Taliban protests across Pakistan.

title: Our Towns; Even in Crisis, Finding Room For Outsiders
description: HIS name is Jimmy, he said in Spanish, 24 years old and two months in America from Costa Rica. He stood in the doorway of the Dunkin' Donuts here at 5:30 Monday morning, huddled against the cold, waiting for a boss who spoke no Spanish, whose name he did not know, a big gringo with blond hair in a Chevy Suburban, coming to pick him up for a day's work at a construction site. At first, the young man said he was in America legally, then he said he could not give his whole name because he feared deportation. His dream? Marry an American girl and get legal fast. ''Of course I feel like an outsider,'' he said, standing on the quiet suburban street. ''Me siento solo'' (I feel alone).

title: Preparing Early for the First of the All-Important Tests
description: The desire to catapult their children into a top-flight school is so intense among Chinese-American parents that on a recent Sunday afternoon, a group of 50 parents and children subjected themselves to five hours of a lecture that was part harangue and part pep talk.

title: A New and Cautious Age In American Intervention
description: WAR IN A TIME OF PEACE

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Alters Licensing Program
description: Responding to an outcry from some of its largest customers, Microsoft announced changes to the controversial new volume licensing program it began rolling out the first week of October. The most notable change is an extension of the customer deadline for upgrading to the program, called Software Assurance. Customers now have until July 31, 2002, rather than Feb. 28, 2002, to become ''current'' on Microsoft Windows, Office and other Microsoft software titles they use, a requirement for participation in Software Assurance. At the same time, Microsoft said customers running Office 2000 would not be forced to upgrade to the new Office XP to be eligible. Microsoft has faced a chorus of complaints since it announced the upgrade program in May 2001, mainly from corporate customers buying software in volume, who say the licensing program will sharply increase their upgrade costs. Microsoft, which views the new program as an important step toward its model of offering software as a service rather than a product, estimates that only 20 percent of customers will have a cost increase. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: A Not-So-Tranquil Farm Where Worlds Collide
description: Damien Odoul's ''Deep Breath'' (''Souffle''), which will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight, is a dreamy, lyrical black-and-white film that treads the permeable boundary between fantasy and reality. The setting is a scruffy corner of rural France where the 20th century, never mind the 21st, seems barely to have penetrated. David (Pierre-Louis Bonnetblanc), a 15-year-old boy sent from the city to live with his uncle after some trouble at school, is the film's sole link to modernity. He listens to heavy metal and hip-hop on his headphones, and his anarchic temperament clashes with the slow and lazy life around him.

title: New Cars, New World, New Doubts, New Deals
description: FOR car dealers and buyers, early fall is usually a bustling time, a period when the new year's models are about to be shown and the deals on the previous year's overstock make a shopper's blood run faster.

title: Van Horn And Kittles Start Fast
description: Keith Van Horn's first hook shot slid sweetly off his fingers for the Nets' opening score of their preseason.

title: Motoring in the Aftermath and Other Going Concerns
description: THERE'S no question that the Sept. 11 attacks in New York and Washington are already changing how Americans travel.

title: When More Options Are Standard, the Choices Boil Down
description: THERE was a time, when the moving assembly line was young, that all cars were built pretty much the same way and all the customer could choose was the body style and the number of doors. Almost every item of optional equipment, from radios and heaters to rear-view mirrors and spare-tire covers, was arranged for and installed by the selling dealer.

title: In Italy, an Earthy Heaven
description: THIRTY years ago, in ''The Food of Italy,'' Waverley Root advised travelers to hunt for obscure restaurants if they wanted to experience the true glories of the Italian table. Otherwise, he cautioned, ''you are likely to encounter an artificial confection without roots in the soil, a patchwork of bits and tatters which echo, usually distantly, a hodgepodge of reminiscences of disparate regional dishes.''

title: Students Return, Taking Small Steps
description: Neha Patel was still a block away from Stuyvesant High School, but she could no longer hold back the tears. Casting furtive glances at the skyline where the twin towers of the World Trade Center should have been -- and where they were the last time she took her familiar route to school -- she broke down.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Opposition Figures Freed
description: The government released five imprisoned members of the democratic opposition in what it called a good-will gesture to coincide with the arrival of an envoy from the United Nations who will assess the the country's rights record. The envoy, Paula Sergio Pinheiro, is leading a three-member team on a two-week visit. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: India, Upset by Kashmir, Rejects 2nd Pakistan Invitation
description: Pakistan invited Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India again today to visit Islamabad for talks and said if he could not go, India's external affairs minister should make the trip ''as soon as possible.''

title: Insurance Prices Soaring, A.I.G. Chief Says
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, the chief executive of the American International Group, said yesterday that insurance prices were rising ''by leaps and bounds'' in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: For Some Lawyers, Lost Case Files and Lost Clients
description: It was a week before Lawrence H. McGaughey could get back inside his law office at Broadway and Vesey Street, and then for only 30 minutes. He and his secretary retrieved what they could -- two computers and some files -- loaded them onto two luggage carriers, bumped their way down six flights of stairs, and headed for the subway.

title: Bruins Add Defense to a Potent Mix
description: Three years ago, when unbeaten U.C.L.A. squared off in early December against the University of Miami to gain a berth in the national championship game, they accumulated 670 yards and scored 45 points. It was the type of dominating offensive performance that the Bruins, led by Cade McNown, who passed for 513 yards and 5 touchdowns, had put together all season. The Bruins could not be stopped.

title: Unger of S.E.C. Plans to Resign
description: Laura Unger, who was acting chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission for six months earlier this year, said today that she was leaving the agency to take a job in the private sector.

title: NORDSTROM LOWERS PROFIT EXPECTATIONS FOR QUARTER
description: Nordstrom slashed its profit forecast for the fiscal third quarter because of declining sales and profit-eroding price cuts. Earnings in the period ending this month will be 3 cents to 6 cents a share, below the previous estimate of 17 cents to 20 cents, the company said. Analysts had cut their average forecast to 10 cents from 17 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call, as the slowing economy and the terrorist attacks hurt consumer spending. Nordstrom's September same-store sales dropped 9.4 percent from a year ago. The company is based in Seattle.

title: Sports of The Times; A Childhood Yankee Fan Comes Home
description: JUST because Jason Giambi will be a free agent, just because the Yankees might be interested in him, just because Giambi finds himself in Yankee Stadium, does not mean he is obsessing about playing for the Yankees next year.

title: Building a Democratic Memorial
description: OKLAHOMA CITY

title: Police Say Janikowski Overdosed at Club
description: Oakland place-kicker Sebastian Janikowski fell at a nightclub because of ''an apparent drug overdose,''cutting his face and requiring five stitches a few hours after the Raiders' game against Dallas, the police said yesterday.

title: Recipe: Sauce Gribiche
description: Adapted from Rick Laakkonen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNING, MATTHEW D.
description: HORNING-Matthew D. Age 26, of Scotch Plains, on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Beloved son of Kurt and Diane Horning. Dear brother of Dana Horning. Grandson of Ruth Horning and Ruth Jannuzzi. Beloved boyfriend of Maura Landry. Memorial visitation will be held on Friday, October 19th from 7-10PM at Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Boulevard, Watchung, NJ, with remarks from friends and family at 8:30 PM. A Memorial Mass will be held at 11:00 AM on Saturday, October 20, 2001 at Our Lady of the Mount R.C. Church, Warren, New Jersey. Memorial contributions may be made in the name of Matthew D. Horning to: New York Mets Foundation, Shea Stadium, Flushing, New York 11368, or to Heifer InternationalWorld Headquarters, P.O. Box 8058, Little Rock, Arkansas 72203.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Set Aside Ruling Against Prayer Organizers
description: The Supreme Court today set aside an appeals court's ruling that enabled the City of Tucson to charge a religious gathering for the municipal services that it provides free to other groups holding events in the city's parks under nonprofit sponsorship.

title: An Evening of Beer, Breasts and a Surprise Ending
description: Eye doctors in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn can expect a modest surge in business thanks to ''Witch Mountain, Black Tarantula,'' the latest exercise in theater that isn't theater from the experimental troupe Collapsable Giraffe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPERMAN, JACOB H.
description: KUPERMAN-Jacob H. Age 94, peacefully on October 7, 2001. Devoted father of Elaine Lewis and Howard Kuperman, loving husband of the late Rose, grandfather of three, and brother of Adele. A great and honorable man, he was adored and respected by all who knew him. Services are private.

title: Three Days in Brussels
description: Europe Express has three-night packages to Brussels in the fall starting at $399 a person, based on double occupancy. That price includes round-trip air fare on Continental from New York, three nights' accommodations with daily Continental breakfast and all hotel taxes and service charges. Adding a night in Bruges is $130, including round-trip rail fare from Brussels. For three nights in Brussels and three in London, the price starts at $639, including one-way Eurostar train fare from Brussels to London, where the return flight departs from. Packages are available Nov. 1 through Dec. 14, and must be booked by Oct. 15. Weekend surcharges and airline departure taxes are extra. Information: (800) 927-3876 or www.europeexpress.com .

title: Torre Has Confidence in Justice
description: Derek Jeter sliced a liner to right field during batting practice, one of his typical shots to the opposite field, a double waiting to happen. There is usually no reason to watch where the balls land two hours before a game. But there was a reason last night because David Justice, the new right fielder for the Yankees, was desperately pursuing it.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: No Pardon For Nazi Criminal
description: President Jacques Chirac has refused for the third time to pardon an aging wartime official, Maurice Papon, who was convicted of shipping hundreds of Jews to death camps during World War II. Mr. Papon, 91, who is serving a 10 years for complicity in crimes against humanity and suffers from heart problems, asked for a pardon on health grounds in June. His lawyer, Francis Vuillemin, told Le Figaro he believed that the rejection of the pardon was linked to the April elections in which the conservative Mr. Chirac is expected to face the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAZEN, WILLIAM H.
description: HAZEN-William H. On behalf of the Directors and all the members of The Anglers' Club of New York, we express our profound sorrow at the loss of our past president, advisor, friend and raconteur without equal and extend our utmost sympathy to Judy and his family. Dr. John I. Larkin, President

title: Pakistan, in a Border Clash, Turns Back Taliban Forces
description: Border troops fought a two-hour gun battle today with Taliban soldiers at a frontier crossing with Afghanistan. The fighting increased pressures on President Pervez Musharraf as he struggled to keep the lid on spreading pro-Taliban protests across Pakistan.

title: PCB's in the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Knoblauch Gets His Chance
description: Chuck Knoblauch said his goal was ''to be a pain in the neck for the A's,'' something that Joe Torre would love to see. That is why Torre slotted Knoblauch in the leadoff position. Even though Knoblauch batted .250, with a .339 on-base percentage, Torre has repeatedly expressed confidence that Knoblauch will be a feisty, annoying player.

title: Sergeant Designs a Better Box For Dropping Food to Afghans
description: Eighteen months ago, Master Sgt. Donny Brass was handed what seemed a daunting task: build a better box for dropping food from cargo planes flying at high altitudes. Little did he know that subsequent events would make his job critically important.

title: Faraway Events Hit Home For Town in Eastern Oregon
description: The little airport at the edge of town now is barricaded by a fortress flank of concrete so jarring that everyone calls it the Ugly Wall, and trembles at its sight. The crop-dusters are flying again, seeding next year's alfalfa, but nobody looks at them in the same way. And the walk-in mental health clinic has never known such a clutter of nerves, nightmares and edgy what-ifs.

title: Not So Fast, Senator Says, as Others Smooth Way for Terror Bill
description: Senate leaders tried to begin action on antiterrorism legislation tonight under special streamlined procedures that limited amendment and debate, but their efforts were blocked by objections on civil liberties grounds.

title: Looking for Sports?
description: Because its late-news printing capacity is limited to four parts, The Times is publishing the metropolitan and sports reports back to back today to accommodate the special section on ''A Nation Challenged.'' Readers who flip this section over, bottom-side up, will find the pages of SportsWednesday in their accustomed sequence, starting with S1.

title: Legal Community Is Divided by the Prospect of Lawsuits for Attack Victims
description: Despite efforts by the leading national trial lawyers' group to promote an alternative to lawsuits for victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, some lawyers have in recent days begun breaking ranks and promising multibillion-dollar suits.

title: Shake-Up in the Shipping Industry
description: The port of Tacoma, Wash., was expecting a slack fourth quarter even before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. With slowing trade between North America and Asia, container traffic through the port was 11.7 percent lower in August than a year earlier, and Douglas V. Ljungren, the port's business planning manager, was forecasting an 8 percent decline in the final three months of the year.

title: A Public Flooded With Images From Friend and Foe Alike
description: ''The face and the voice of the enemy,'' Peter Jennings said after showing Osama bin Laden's videotaped message following the attacks on Afghanistan Sunday. But as strange as it was to see the enemy with such sudden and chilling intimacy in our living rooms -- that gaunt, incongruous figure in a traditional turban holding a modern microphone -- the bin Laden tape was only the first dramatic marker of how different this televised conflict is from any war coverage we have known.

title: Obtaining Anthrax Is Hard, but Not Impossible
description: Just as growing a particularly exotic species of plant takes the right seed, growing an anthrax culture that is virulent enough to kill people requires just the right seed stock.

title: Claiming 'Star Trek'
description: As much as television has changed over the years, one thing has remained constant: television stations throughout the country show reruns of ''Star Trek: The Next Generation.''

title: Prosecutors In Bombings Seek Payment
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have asked a judge to order four terrorists convicted in the embassy bombings case to pay $26.3 million in restitution to victims and their families and for the loss of United States property.

title: Milosevic, Indicted Again, Is Charged With Crimes in Croatia
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague today published its second indictment of the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, charging him with war crimes in Croatia, including the persecution, deportation, torture and murder of civilians in 1991 and 1992.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swissair Increases Flights
description: Swissair will be operating 70 percent of its intercontinental flights and 60 percent of its scheduled European service starting tomorrow, the carrier said. After its two-day grounding last week, Swissair has been operating at about half capacity. Its newly posted schedule, which includes 25 European and 34 intercontinental cities, will continue through Oct. 27, the day before most of its operations are to be handed over to its former regional subsidiary, Crossair. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Ferrer Returns Fire, With Help From Some Prominent Names
description: Fernando Ferrer, who faces Mark Green in a runoff tomorrow, released a television commercial yesterday in response to one by Mr. Green that Mr. Ferrer called ''ugly and divisive.''

title: ATTACK ON AFGHANISTAN / Fear of Bioterrorism: 2 Florida Anthrax Cases Probed as Criminal
description: Health officials and investigators in the United States on Tuesday sought a possible criminal origin  but hesitated to use the word terrorism  as they looked for the source of two cases of pulmonary anthrax, a disease so rare that most doctors see it only in medical textbooks.

title: Four Spoons, Please, And Plenty Of Syrup
description: Each of these desserts requires a group effort, friends with especially sweet teeth. As they settle in at a table in the lounge or bar or finish dinner at Asia de Cuba, 237 Madison Avenue (37th Street), they face the task of choosing among five oversize extravanganzas with names like Latin Lover (chocolate cake, mousse and custard), Cafe Con Leche (espresso flan, roasted macadamias and dulce de leche wontons) and Coconut Invasion (coconut cake and chocolate syrup). Each costs $9. The ultimate is Bay of Pigs, with ice cream, whipped cream, cookies, cake, sauce, nuts and bananas ($14).

title: Lapping Up Normalcy
description: It has not been easy being a teenage television viewer just trying to return to normal life during this time of national crisis.

title: The Fine Art of Shifting Slips Into a Lower Gear
description: IN the world of car guys, not all of whom happen to be male, it's an axiom that if you want to drive (really drive, that is, not merely commute or cruise), you'll choose a stick shift.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, IRWIN M.
description: ROSENBLATT-Irwin M. The former Lopez Edwards Frank Partners and the Partners and Staff of M.R. Weiser & Co LLP deeply mourn the passing of our retired Partner Irwin M. Rosenblatt. We wish to extend our deepest sympathy and condolences to his wife Carole, his children and grandchildren.

title: Failure Follows A's Hudson Into Game 2
description: If numbers do not lie, they at least can deceive or confuse in the case of Tim Hudson.

title: The Balancing Act That Is Thai, Salads Not Excepted
description: MANY people adhere to the benchmark method of assessing restaurants. By tasting a single dish -- cold noodles with sesame sauce in a Sichuan restaurant, for example, or lamb vindaloo in an Indian place -- they say they can determine the level of skill and dedication in the kitchen. A confident few even contend that they learn everything they need to know about a restaurant simply by nibbling a piece of bread.

title: Master of a Home-Grown Art
description: In November 1969, I drove to Washington from Tallahassee, Fla., in a dilapidated Volkswagen van, along with other student protesters, to demonstrate against the Vietnam War. Somehow, between marching by candlelight to Arlington National Cemetery and catching my first whiff of tear gas at Dupont Circle, I called Herbert R. Block, the editorial cartoonist at The Washington Post, introduced myself as the cartoonist for the Florida State University student newspaper and asked to visit him at his office. For me, meeting Herblock at the time was like meeting the North Star. He was a fixed point by which we all, aspiring cartoonists and civilians alike, set our bearings.

title: How Ovid Helps Deal With Loss And Suffering
description: The images of loss repeat, distort, freeze and transform. Orpheus, a prisoner of his own memory, makes his famous mistake again and again, looking backward as his bride slips, unreclaimable, into the underworld. A sad, hopeful wife stands at the ocean's edge, scanning the horizon for the return of her long-dead husband, just as she did on the day his ship set sail. A girl, torn from her lover in the night, is evoked by words said softly three times by a narrator: ''She's going to suffer.''

title: American States of Mind: Anxiety and Resolve; The Protests
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel; The F.A.A. has spoken on carry-on items. Now let's hope airport screeners get the message.
description: FINALLY, travelers have clear guidelines on what may be carried on board an airplane under the new security procedures.

title: Deciding What Our Loss Means
description: Although it is natural to want to envision how America ought to memorialize those who died in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, it is still too soon to begin to design any kind of memorial for the dead.

title: Agreement Is a First Step For Licensing Online Music
description: In a hard-fought deal that paves the way for the introduction of new Internet music services, the major recording companies said today that they had licensed digital distribution rights from songwriters and music publishers.

title: Little Truck, Big Horn: One Man's Quest for Volume
description: I HAVE this very tough vehicle, a 1989 Toyota Land Cruiser, precurvy one, which goes up mountains, down rainy ravines and through snowdrifts and streams. Big knobby tires. Satellite navigation system. Auxiliary lighting. Rust.

title: Official Urges New Response To Bioterror
description: The chairman of a new federal advisory council on bioterrorism said today that while the public health system had worked well in identifying and containing a potential anthrax outbreak in Florida, the case was not a good test of the nation's ability to respond to a germ attack.

title: In a muted environment, agencies try new approaches to drum up domestic tourism.
description: WITH a fervor perhaps not evidenced since Dinah Shore last belted out ''See the U.S.A. in your Chevrolet,'' the organizations that help market American tourist destinations are working determinedly to deliver pitches meant to resonate with consumers now leery of traveling.

title: Remember the Emmys?
description: The future of this year's Emmy Awards remains unsettled, with an answer to whether the event will be held at all expected this week.

title: Too Many Teachers, for a Change
description: As the Board of Education is lamenting a shortage of qualified teachers, one of New York City's hardest-to-staff districts, an area in East New York of poor black and Hispanic families has found itself in the odd position of having hired 60 to 70 more teachers than it needs. ''In my own mind, I think he may have been a victim of his own success,'' ANTHONY SHORRIS, a deputy chancellor, said of VICTOR R. RODRIGUEZ, the superintendent of District 19. As a so-called breakthrough district, which awards bonuses to teachers and principals who raise test scores, District 19 was encouraged to hire second-career and foreign teachers, Mr. Shorris said, and many came. The excess teachers, Mr. Shorris said, will be put into substitute pools or offered other jobs in the system; none will be laid off.

title: MetroStars Move Chivas Match
description: The MetroStars announced yesterday that their Copa Merconorte game against Chivas of Mexico has been rescheduled, moving back to its original date of next Wednesday, Oct. 17, at 8 P.M. at Giants Stadium.

title: Veracruz Fusion Finds Its Way North
description: VERACRUZ, a long, narrow strip of land that runs along the Gulf of Mexico, is home to one of Mexico's most complicated melting-pot cuisines. In ''Zarela's Veracruz,'' her new cookbook, Zarela Martnez teases out the influences, historical and geographic, that make the food a highly distinctive blend of ingredients from Spain, Mexico, Cuba and Africa. There are reasons why so many of the dishes include green olives and almonds, and why the first dish presented to diners at Danzn, Ms. Martnez's new restaurant, is a heap of sliced, fried plantains with a chilled spicy dipping sauce based on peanuts.

title: American States of Mind: Anxiety and Resolve
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fast-Growth List Shows Internet Isn't Everything
description: With all the doom and gloom befalling dot-com companies lately, one might think most entrepreneurs had packed up their laptops, sold their sleek office furniture at a discount and headed back to the security of big corporations.

title: Titans Are Finding That Pieces Don't Fit
description: The St. Louis-Tennessee Super Bowl two years ago signaled a new era in the N.F.L., illustrating how a little tinkering in the free agency-salary cap system can quickly turn bad teams into good ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARYE, LEONORA
description: ARYE-Leonora. Passed away peacefully October 8, 2001. Beloved and loving wife of Leonard for more than 47 years. We never stopped laughing. Loving and adored mother of Larry, Lowell and Lane. Loving mother-in-law of Linda & grandmother of Mollie. A gifted sculptor and writer, who was too modest for the gifts she had. Her last days were much like her life, brave and uncomplaining. We will love and remember her to the end of our days. Funeral on October 10, 11 AM, Zion Memorial Chapel, 767 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMANN, PATRICIA BEVERLY BULL
description: BERGMANN - Patricia Beverly Bull. Age 78, of Hopkinton, Massachusetts, formerly of Manhasset, NY, died Sunday in Leonard Morse Hospital, Natick, MA, as a result of injuries she sustained in an automobile accident September 21, in Wellesley, MA. Born in Brooklyn, NY, she was raised in West Orange, NJ. She married Theodore Bergmann, an advertising executive and television producer, in 1946. She resided in Manhasset from 1949 until 1976, moving to Pacific Palisades, CA. She moved to Hopkinton in 1988. She was a member of the Hopkinton Women's Club. She leaves four sons, T. Douglass Bergmann of Los Angeles, Donald G. Bergmann of Medway, MA, David L. Bergmann of Prides Crossing, MA, and J. Derek Bergmann of Hopkinton; two daughters, Laura B. Weinman of Pacific Palisades, CA, and Lisa J. Bergmann of Iowa City, IA; and a brother, William L. Bull of Florida; and eleven grandchildren. Services are pending. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Baypath Humane Society.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Challenge For Widow Senator
description: Former Representative James M. Talent, a Republican who lost a race for governor last year, said he would seek the Senate seat held by Jean Carnahan, a freshman Democrat, in next year's election. Mr. Talent, 44, announced his candidacy in downtown St. Louis, adding that he planned to begin a two-month tour of the state this week. Mrs. Carnahan was appointed to the Senate after her husband, Gov. Mel Carnahan, was killed in a plane crash last year, just weeks before the election in which he was running for Senate. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Mistakes Are Measured Here, Not Towed Away
description: ONE thing you cannot do with a crash-test dummy is get it drunk.

title: U.S. Ambassador Warns Iraq Against Stirring Up Trouble
description: The United States ambassador to the United Nations relayed a warning to Iraq this week not to ''take advantage'' of the attacks on New York and Washington by stirring up trouble, American officials said today.

title: Green's Latest Commercial Calls for a Closer Look at Ferrer
description: Mark Green began broadcasting the first negative television commercial of the Democratic runoff election on Monday night, a 30-second spot called ''A Closer Look.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Court Grants Chirac Immunity in Corruption Probe
description: PARIS, Oct. 10  France's highest court of appeal today granted President Jacques Chirac broad presidential immunity while in office, effectively derailing efforts by five investigating magistrates to question him on a range of corruption allegations dating from his time as Mayor of Paris.

title: Dior's Aggression Misses The New Romantic Beat
description: PARIS  For all his soaring imagination, richly romantic sensibility and sunny showmanship, John Galliano is stuck in a rut at Dior. His attempt to turn his superb round-the-world-in-40-outfits July couture show into "Street Chic" highlighted the shift in public mood since the events of Sept. 11. And it made his exuberant take on an all-American Elvis Presley pantsuit, following floaty shalwar kameez dresses and turban headgear, seem insensitive, almost offensive.

title: These Hybrids Are Rough, Tough and Not So Efficient
description: AFTER years of research, debate and anticipation, new kinds of hybrid gas-electric vehicles are headed toward the market.

title: Life After Chteau Margaux
description: WHEN I first met Bernard Ginestet almost 30 years ago, he was Bordeaux's enfant terrible. Scion of a famous family, restless, voluble, alternately sardonic and charming, he seemed convinced that, single-handedly, he would drag the Bordeaux wine trade into the 20th century. Bordeaux did modernize, not without pain, and Bernard may have helped it along.

title: Stocks End Higher as Investors Gain Some Confidence
description: Stocks rallied broadly today as investors showed signs of overcoming their initial nervousness following the American military strikes in Afghanistan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Inmate Criticizes Prison Conditions
description: A man facing trial on charges of taking part in a terror conspiracy with Osama bin Laden is in virtual solitary confinement and almost completely unable to leave his cell after the attack on the World Trade Center, his lawyer told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday. After the court appearance, the lawyer, John Jacobs, also said he was considering asking the judge for a change of venue because he fears his client cannot receive a fair trial in Manhattan. The defendant, Mohamed Suleiman al Nalfi, a native of Sudan, ''has been in basically a total lockdown'' in the Metropolitan Correctional Center since Sept. 11, Mr. Jacobs told the judge. But Mr. Jacobs said prosecutors had indicated that conditions might be relaxed after the sentencing this month of four terrorists convicted in the embassy bombings case. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Rangers Hope Jagr's Visit Brings Out Worst in Ulanov
description: Rangers Coach Ron Low cornered Igor Ulanov before a pregame skate last week and bluntly asked him when he had last angered an opponent.

title: Networks Ask If 'Message' By bin Laden Is Really News
description: The organization of Osama bin Laden threatened more terrorist attacks on Americans in a second taped message yesterday, obliging television news executives to consider whether broadcasting such statements served viewers, or Al Qaeda's propaganda goals.

title: That New Brightness on the Plate? It's a Classic
description: ORDER the whole roasted fish at Ilo at lunchtime and you get a nice fat pitcher of rich sauce to slather on the boned fillets, and on anything else in the vicinity. The tangy blend of sieved eggs suspended in a vinaigrette with capers, cornichons and herbs coats fish, asparagus, potatoes and even bread like a chunky mayonnaise.

title: Safety Caps Are Considered For Cosmetics
description: The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission is expected to enact a regulation this month requiring manufacturers to put child-resistant caps on an array of household products that contain hydrocarbons, including baby oils, suntan oils, spot removers and certain cleansers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about military exercises in Egypt for troops from Europe, the Mideast and the United States misidentified a Marine Corps site in California that contributes participants. It is Camp Pendleton, not Fort Pendleton.

title: Two Competing for Post of Democratic Whip in the House
description: House Democrats will vote on Wednesday to elect a new deputy to the minority leader, with each of the two contenders for that job of party whip claiming the ability to turn the party into a majority in the 2002 election.

title: Longing for Safety, After 130 M.P.H.
description: I'M a standard model, few options. I grew up believing that boys were born to drive and that cars were vehicles for escape, sex and hostile self-expression. While my current car is a mild-mannered 1987 Volvo, no snarly grilled, tailgating truck ever made it move over just by blinking its lights and blowing its horn. And if I did begrudgingly get out of the way, I'd mouth an insult and flip a bird.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA OFFERS TO BUY UNITED PAN-EUROPE BONDS
description: Liberty Media offered to buy as much as $1.5 billion worth of United Pan-Europe Communications's bonds in a move that analysts said was likely to give it control of the company, the second-biggest cable company in Europe, for about $300 million. Liberty, based in Englewood, Colo., already has an agreement to take control of United Pan-Europe's parent, and is unlikely to pay more than $300 million because the bonds are trading at less than 20 percent of face value, said Bala Ramakrishnan, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. The offer depends on Liberty's receiving at least 30 percent of the notes. United Pan-Europe's parent company is UnitedGlobalCom, based in Denver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODRIGUES, ANTONIO

Beloved husband of Christina. Loving father of Adam and Sara. Dearest son of Jose and Cecilia of Portugal. Dear brother of Marisa Silvestre. Reposing at the Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Keep all remarks bland and benign, lest anything be construed as a knock on the Yankees; compliment the Yankees.

title: Exam Czar Calls It Quits
description: ROBERT TOBIAS, who holds the none-too- relaxing job of overseeing standardized testing in the city's 1,100 schools, will resign this month after 33 years in the system. Mr. Tobias, who analyzes the test scores of the city's 1.1 million schoolchildren and tries to explain fluctuations from year to year, told Schools Chancellor HAROLD O. LEVY that he was leaving for personal reasons. Mr. Levy has appointed LORI MEI, Mr. Tobias's deputy, acting testing director while he conducts a search for a permanent replacement. It was Mr. Tobias who essentially discovered the scoring error by a national testing company that mistakenly sent thousands of city students to summer school in 1999.

Her husband Michael, her children and she are very much a part of the AHRC family. Our grief and prayers go to members of her family. We will miss Dorothy as we miss her husband. Al Agovino, President Michael Goldfarb, Exec. Director

Thanks to slow summer sales, an even slower economy and post-Sept. 11 jitters, dealer lots are jammed with last year's cars. While such circumstances usually cry out for aggressive marketing, advertisers are wary of offending the public with pitches that might appear insensitive during a time of mourning and reflection.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Union Drive At Brown
description: Two Democratic members of the state's Congressional delegation have signed a statement urging Brown University not to oppose a unionization drive by graduate students. Brown's president, Ruth J. Simmons, has said she would fight the effort, but the two Democrats, Patrick J. Kennedy and Jim Langevin said it would be appropriate for the university to remain neutral. An arm of the United Auto Workers is seeking to organize Brown's 650 graduate and teaching assistants. In May, the Brown Graduate Employee Organization petitioned the National Labor Relations Board to schedule a unionization election. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: The Young and Reckless, Ready to Drive
description: WHILE teenagers make up only 7 percent of the driving population in the United States, they account for about 18 percent of automobile accidents in this country. In fact, driving accidents are the leading cause of death among teenagers, 6,000 every year. While traffic-related deaths for all other age groups fell over the past decade, those for 16-year-olds increased.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Joins XP Campaign
description: Microsoft and Advanced Micro Devices said they had agreed to jointly market products that share the XP name. Officials of Microsoft, whose Windows XP operating system goes on sale Oct. 25, appeared at a news conference yesterday to promote Advanced Micro's newest microprocessor, Athlon XP. The companies said they would work together to train retail clerks about the performance of Windows XP running on Athlon XP, to create promotions for computer distributors and to organize events aimed at consumers and small-business owners. John Frederiksen, general manager of Microsoft's PC Experience group, said his engineers had worked hard to maximize the performance of Windows XP on Athlon. But he added that they did the same for chips made by Advanced Micro's larger rival, Intel. ''We want Windows everywhere,'' he said. Chris Gaither (NYT)

His staunch defense of affirmative action and minority access to higher education has made him a moral role model. He is also a distinguished educator. The University of Michigan, in an attempt to hold onto him, offered a hefty raise.

title: Lost Internet Link Causes 'Panic'
description: When two hijacked planes struck the World Trade Center, Harold O. Levy, the school chancellor, called MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN, chancellor of the City University, ''in a panic'' according to a story Mr. Goldstein told at the Harvard Club last week. School administration offices, situated across the East River in Brooklyn, had lost their Internet connection to the school system and Mr. Levy was unable to communicate with superintendents and principals throughout the city. ''We sent in a team, and within hours the Board of Education was able to communicate,'' Dr. Goldstein said. The Internet connection, explained MICHAEL RIBAUDO, CUNY dean for technology, goes through a Verizon hub that was next to the twin towers. CUNY restored service by rerouting it through a Kingsborough Community College link to the board, where it has remained since, he said.

title: Contingency Plans to Fill Reservists' Shoes

title: The Signs Of a Buildup Are Becoming More Evident

title: For Mark Green in the Runoff

The runoff will be held tomorrow, in the middle of an international crisis. A race that was declared boring only a month ago now has so much on the line that people seem almost unable to comprehend its full import.

title: Review/Fashion; Small Escapes, With Flounces and Twirls
description: In some sense, Fashion Week here is set up like the perfectly planned fifth-grade school day. Upon arrival, editors engage in the exercise of show and tell. What gets shown is usually something that was purchased the previous week in Milan from Prada or Gucci; what is broadcast is how little that something cost taking into account the strong dollar, the VAT and the 30 percent discounts offered to certain members of the fashion press.

title: Making the Most of a Leek Just Got Easier
description: The trouble with leeks is that you use only a few inches of the white part and maybe just a bit of pale green, throwing away the verdant ribbons at the top. But now from Belgium come leeks with nearly foot-long batons of white to pastel green, topped by relatively little dark green. They are grown by mounding soil higher than usual around the stalks to keep out the sunlight and prevent the green from developing, resulting in more usable leek. They are $1.49 a pound at Citarella, Agata & Valentina and Amish Markets.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Ex-Minister Sought In Coup
description: A judge has issued a warrant for the arrest of a former economy minister, Carlos Bolon, on charges that he helped plan an aborted coup against President Alberto Fujimori in March 2000, in the days leading up to presidential elections that were widely criticized as fraudulent. The police were searching for Mr. Bolon, who reportedly has gone into hiding while waiting to hear the exact charges filed against him. According to legislators, Mr. Bolon was to serve as a provisional president. Mr. Fujimori, who became president in 1990, won the election but was forced to resign last year as a variety of scandals swirled around him. He fled to Japan. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Amazon Bolsters Images
description: You still cannot sip a double espresso while you shop, but Amazon.com is trying to make it easier to browse through its book catalog. Today, users will be able to view a selection of images from 25,000 of its top-selling books, including the cover flaps, tables of contents, indexes and some sample pages. For years, Amazon and Barnesandnoble.com, its main rival, have included chapters of some books in text form. And Barnesandnoble has a handful of images from art books. But Amazon will now have more pages from more books as graphic images. For now, Amazon will not charge publishers to display pages from their books, said Jason Kailar, its vice president for book, music and video sales. Amazon's motive, he said, was not the revenue from publishers but increasing the number of browsers who become buyers. Saul Hansell (NYT)
