title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHAN, WILLIAM G., M.D.
description: CAHAN-William G., M.D. The staff and leadership of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourn the death of William G. Cahan, our colleague and friend for more than half a century. We extend our condolences to his wife Grace and to his children. As a clinician, researcher and teacher, Bill strived to improve the treatment of cancer, particularly breast and lung cancer. Yet simply treating cancer was not enough for Bill, and early in his career he began a lifelong crusade to prevent the disease. Bill quickly recognized the danger posed by tobacco use and became a tireless advocate for the eradication of smoking, and a persistent critic of the tobacco industry. His forceful advocacy was important in changing America's attitude toward tobacco use. Bill was a man of great integrity, intellect and personal charm. Laurance S. Rockefeller James D. Robinson III Douglas A. Warner III Richard I. Beattie Louis V. Gerstner, Jr. Harold E. Varmus Boards of Overseers & Managers David W. Golde, MD Physician-In-Chief Murray Brennan, MD Chair, Department of Surgery and the Staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

Reopell, she was a native of Arkansas who became a loyal Wall Streeter and a quintessential ''New Yorker''. She loved the City for its art, theatre, music and especially opera. She will be buried in her native Ozark foothills in the Spring, when the dogwoods are in bloom, a sight she treasured as much as the lights of Broadway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPOFFORD, MARGARET W. ''ZEE''
description: SPOFFORD-Margaret W. ''Zee''. Died peacefully at home in her 97th year. Lifelong resident of New York and Fishers Island. She is survived by her four children, Nancy Yerkes, Nick Spofford, Peggy Benkard and John Spofford, her brother Shaw Walker, 13 grandchildren and 21 great-grandchildren. Memorial service at The Brick Church, Thursday October 11 at 11AM ; memorial service and commital St. John's Church, Fishsers Island, Friday, October 12, 3PM. In lieu of flowers, contrubutions in her memory to Guiding Eyes for the Blind or Planned Parenthood of NY would be appreciated.

description: Four security guards working the night shift were killed near Kabul when the local headquarters of a United Nations-supported organization in Afghanistan was struck during an air attack by the United States.

title: Indians' Heat Is Too Much For Mariners
description: The Cleveland Indians and the Seattle Mariners have come of age together. They were among the worst teams in baseball for years, then became regular playoff participants in 1995. Since then, the teams have made 10 postseason appearances, but neither has won a World Series. The Mariners have lacked a well-rounded game, the Indians an ace in their rotation.

title: World Briefing | The Africa: Somalia: Protest Over Shaky Currency
description: Thousands of Somalis staged a violent demonstration in Mogadishu demanding that business owners and money dealers accept 500-shilling notes, which are worth about two cents. With the Somali shilling at an all-time low -- 2,620 to the dollar -- many merchants turn away the notes because they are worth so little. Likewise, money changers demand 30,000 shillings to the dollar for those with 500-shilling notes, well above the 20,500 rate offered on the street. To protest the practices, demonstrators burned trash and tires, looted street vendors' stalls and smashed car windows. President Abdiqasim Salad Hassan, who heads Somalia's one-year-old transitional government, called for calm over the radio. Somalia lacks a central bank, so businessmen and faction leaders have been paying to have bills printed in Canada and Southeast Asia and then shipped to Somalia, where they can control the supply. Marc Lacey (NYT)

description: Disregarding the spirit of wartime bipartisanship, the House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill late tonight that would give the Bush administration enhanced authority to negotiate trade agreements.

description: MEIGHAN-Grace Leonie McCann. Passed away on October 8, 2001 in St. Petersburg, FL. Beloved wife of the late Burton C. Meighan. description: In the dozens of combat missions that planes from the Enterprise have flown in recent days, relatively few carrier-launched bombs have been dropped on Afghanistan, commanders say. By the account of a senior ordnance officer, the number Tuesday afternoon, after two days of strikes, was no more than 27.

title: Hurricane Kills Virginia Dive Club Members in Belize
description: As many as 20 people, mostly Americans on a diving vacation in Belize, died on Monday night after their chartered luxury boat capsized when 15-foot tidal surges whipped by Hurricane Iris's 140-mile-per-hour winds overwhelmed the dock where they had sought safe haven.

description: IT flashes, points and lights up puddles. The humble side mirror has come a long way from simply supplying a rearward glimpse of traffic, and it is all because of new lighting technology.

description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York has withdrawn a lawsuit against the Omnicom Group in New York and a former executive of an Interpublic agency in connection with the loss of the Quaker Oats account to Omnicom.

description: CYMERMAN-Henry. 10/10/81 Always in our hearts. Anne, Caryl and Isabel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMADESSA, JOHN J.
description: PALMADESSA-John J. On October 8, 2001 at age 73. Loving husband of Mary, and devoted father to Danielle and Douglas. Grandfather to Douglas Jr. Brother-inlaw to Anthony Aglione who was his ''brother at heart'' and many devoted nieces and nephews. Korean War Veteran, self-made entrepreneur and inventor. Founder and owner of Red Ball Interior Demolition. Resident of New York City and Palm Beach, FL. Former resident of Ho-Ho-Kus and Spring Lake, NJ. He was a giant of a man in his achievements. His generosity, caring, and compassion will be in our hearts always. John has inspired many pople and was greatly admired. He will be missed by all who have crossed his path. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass, St Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, Thursday Oct 11, 9:30am. Entombment to follow at Madonna Cemetery, Ft. Lee , NJ.

description: Rather than lining up two, three or even four small trivets on the buffet to accommodate a large pot or casserole, why not use an expandable trivet that will be a perfect fit? Even if traditional square or round hot pads are the right size, they never seem to be the right shape to hold large serving dishes.

description: Three scientists at American research institutions were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics yesterday for producing a bizarre state of matter in which atoms merge into a single wavelike entity that is much like a beam of laser light.

title: Widening Gap: Arafat Struggles to Control Hamas
description: The violence that exploded among Palestinians on Monday subsided today, as Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, worked to contain his worst internal crisis in years by redirecting anger at the cause all factions could agree on: resisting Israel.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Breakup Plan Dropped
description: British Telecommunications has backed away from plans to split its retail and wholesale divisions into separate entities, ending its long restructuring, people close to the company said. British Telecommunications still plans the spinoff of its wireless division, which is to be completed next month, but the plans for a full-scale breakup have been canceled. British Telecommunications had previously considered a legal separation of its consumer business from its infrastructure unit, which would have had its own stock market listing. But wobbly stock markets have made the plan unfeasible, and the company is less in need of cash than it was six months ago, having sold off some assets, these people said. The company's change of heart was first reported in The Financial Times. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOWAN, EDWARD J.
description: McGOWAN-Edward J. Formerly of Massapequa and Saltaire, N.Y. On October 5, 2001 at age 78 after a long illness. Dear husband of Jane. Loving father of Edward and Judith, Terence and Suzanne, Michael and Anna, Denise and Joseph, and Christine. Devoted grandfather of Henry, Patrick, Madeleine, Charlotte, & Katherine. A private Mass of the Christian Burial will be held at Our Lady of the Magnificat R.C. Church, Kinnelon, N.J. on October 13, 2001. The State Street Firefighters were so kind to Ed in his final illness, and they lost four of their brothers in the WTC attack. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Engine Company 226, NYFD, 409 State St, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11217.

title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: New Zealand: Airline's Chief Departs
description: Gary Toomey, chief executive of Air New Zealand, which the government bailed out last week, has resigned. He led the company for less than a year, leaving a deputy chief executive role at Australia's largest carrier, Qantas Airways, to lead New Zealand's only major airline. The group had included Australia's second-largest carrier, Ansett, until last month when Air New Zealand effectively cut ties to the unit. Roger France, a newly appointed director, will fill in until a new chief executive is named. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: From the Table to Those in Need
description: TOMORROW, one month after terrorists attacked the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, thousands of restaurants around the world will donate part of their evening's receipts to organizations helping the families of victims. And the effort is only beginning. In coming weeks and months, scores of restaurants, wine shops and food-related businesses will sponsor programs to benefit major charities like the Red Cross as well as fire and police families and others in need as a result of the attacks.

title: Another Turkish Delight
description: IN many ways, this is my favorite season for cooking because many vegetables are still available from local farms and it is not too hot to turn on the oven. This combination of factors inspired me to recreate a dish I had in Istanbul last spring, a bubbly casserole of shrimp, tomatoes and vegetables in which the dominant flavors are basil and butter.

description: The Harlem Globetrotters have scheduled games against nine college teams next month, including one against St. John's at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 10. The games will be exhibitions for the colleges and will not count toward their regular-season records.

title: California Builders Must Show Water Is Sufficient
description: Illustrating just how precious water has become in parts of California, Gov. Gray Davis has signed into law a bill that forces builders to prove that there will be adequate water to supply their new developments.

title: 10,000 at Memorial Service
description: It is an arena more accustomed to the noise made by hockey players and their fans, but last night, the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale echoed with hymns, chants and amens, as 10,000 people gathered for the Diocese of Rockville Centre's memorial Mass for the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Rebels Set Peace Strategy
description: Rebel groups in Congo met with their Rwandan and Ugandan backers in Goma to prepare for peace talks next week in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital. Officials of African countries involved in the Congolese war will meet with spokesmen from several rebel movements: the Rwandan-backed Congolese Rally for Democracy, the Ugandan-backed Congolese Liberation Movement, the Rwandan Patriotic Front and the R.C.D. Liberation Movement. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: METROMEDIA FIBER NAMES CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Metromedia Fiber Network Inc. named Randall Lay as its chief financial officer one week after the money-losing builder of communications networks secured $611 million in financing to avoid a bankruptcy filing. Mr. Lay was most recently the chief financial officer at International Specialty Products. At Metromedia, he will replace Jerry Benedetto, who was hired in 1998 and is leaving to pursue other options, the company said. Metromedia has lost 97 percent of its share value in the last year as customers, including Internet companies, cut spending, reducing demand for Metromedia's services.

title: Federal Help for New York City
description: With Mayor Rudolph Giuliani at his side, Gov. George Pataki unveiled a broad plan on Tuesday to make New York economically whole in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center. He asked the federal government for $54 billion to carry it out. The plan, which would reimburse the city and state for everything from cleanup costs to lost tax revenues, is undeniably comprehensive. It is also an excessively ambitious wish list that is too diffuse to generate the kind of support that can be realistically expected from Washington. The two politicians should refine the list, focus on recovery and hew closely to the maxim enunciated by the mayor himself: ''The federal aid that we ask for should be honestly connected to the World Trade Center.''

title: Bush Lifts Some Restrictions On Classified Information
description: Under pressure from Congress, President Bush agreed today to restore access to classified briefings to a wider legislative audience, after lawmakers balked at Mr. Bush's initial effort to limit such information to just eight senior leaders.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: 4KIDS ENTERTAINMENT INC., New York, said it had agreed with Nintendo Co., Kyoto, Japan, to continue licensing Pokmon cartoon and video game products outside of Asia for the next five years.

title: Light Up the Room, With Jazzy Shades
description: Stylish lampshades don't have to be expensive. Kmart is offering taupe-colored string shades in an 11-inch-high rectangle and a 10-inch-high cone, above, by Martha Stewart, for $12.99 each. Other shades at Kmart are made of silk, rice paper, cotton-duck and linen, from 4 to 14 inches high. They come pleated, woven and plain and in neutral colors as well as pastel blue, green and yellow. Some are edged in chrome, others are scalloped. Prices are $3.99 to $29.99. A list of store locations is available at (800) 866-0086 or www.bluelight.com.

title: U.S. Lists Most Wanted Terrorists and Offers Reward of Millions
description: President Bush today announced the creation of a most wanted list of international terrorists, a roster of 22 suspects led by Osama bin Laden and several of his lieutenants.

title: Saying Goodbye to the Stylus
description: OVER the past few years, Liam D. Comerford, a speech engineer at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center, has developed a habit of conversing with his Palm III. Sometimes he tells the device about his chores. Other times he will listen as the machine reminds him of a scheduled meeting. Once in a while he'll simply ask it for the time.

description: WOLFE-Jack. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoted stepfather, father-in-law, grandfather and great grandfather. Retired member of Local 1, IATSE.

description: Fifty-six Islamic nations holding an emergency meeting here issued a statement today that avoided directly condemning the United States' attacks against the Taliban in Afghanistan, while warning against inflicting civilian casualties or striking against other Arab states.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Printer Cuts Forecast
description: The commercial printer Quebecor World of Montreal cut its third-quarter profit forecast 15 percent and said it was laying off 2,400 workers, 6 percent of its payroll. The group also plans to take a pretax revamping charge of about $225 million in the fourth quarter, and to close 7 of its 160 plants. Most cutbacks will be in the United States. Charles G. Cavell, the chief executive, said printing had historically been resistant to economic downturns, but the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks caused a significant drop in ad spending.

title: Contaminants Below Levels For Long-Term Concerns
description: The quality of the air has become a matter of widespread anxiety among people who live or work in Lower Manhattan -- anxiety compounded in many cases by open disbelief in assurances from government and public health officials that the air, while acrid and sometimes smelly, is generally safe to breathe.

description: LEGO bricks bring to mind rudimentary cars and houses snapped together by children. But a 37-year-old hobbyist has added a twist, literally, to building-block construction: he has created a Lego robot that solves Rubik's Cube.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: State Says Used Uniforms Should Lose Badges
description: In new antiterrorism precautions, the Department of Public Safety has asked stores that sell used clothing to remove badges and military insignia from military or law enforcement uniforms. The department also asked dry cleaners to require identification from customers picking up uniforms to keep impostors from using them to enter restricted areas. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

Something did not feel right, they said. They had traveled from Morristown, N.J., and caught their first glimpse in person of New York's altered skyline.

description: THE AMERICAS

title: AT&T CABLE UNIT HAS WARRANT TO BUY STAKE IN FOX NEWS
description: The AT&T cable television unit can buy a 20 percent stake in the Fox Entertainment Corporation's Fox News Channel for $280 million, under terms of a five-year-old agreement. AT&T Broadband, the largest cable TV company, holds a warrant to buy a nonvoting stake in Fox News that is exercisable until Jan. 2, a Fox spokesman, Andrew Butcher, said. The warrant is part of AT&T's agreement to carry Fox News on its cable systems. Terms of the agreement had not previously been disclosed.

title: As Schundler Calls for His Firing, a Trenton Official Stands by His Critique
description: The top state official in charge of local government services expressed regret today over the public release of a letter that harshly criticized Bret D. Schundler's fiscal management as mayor of Jersey City. But the official, Marvin Corwick, did not retract any of the contents of the Tuesday letter, which accused Mr. Schundler of leaving a $54 million cash deficit when his term ended on June 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERROW, MARGARET LORD
description: MERROW-Margaret Lord. Died October 9, 2001. Wife of John Griswold Merrow. Mother of Marty Wilson, John Merrow, Hattie Simpson, Rob, George and Jim Merrow. Grandmother and greatgrandmother of 16. She will be missed forever by many of us. Griswold Merrow

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Fox's Party Loses
description: Citing evidence of election violations, a federal tribunal overturned the conservative National Action Party's mayoral victory in Ciudad Jurez, a political setback for President Vicente Fox's party, which won its first significant political battles there more than a decade ago. The federal tribunal confirmed a state finding that the mayor, Gustavo Elizondo, had unfairly used his office to influence the outcome. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: In One Month, A Presidency Is Transformed
description: The night before the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, while having dinner with his brother and friends at the Colony resort in Longboat Key, Fla., President Bush heard about a new book: Jay Winik's ''April 1865,'' a day-by-day account of how the closing month of the Civil War transformed the politics of the nation.

title: Herbert Ross, Broadway Choreographer Turned Hollywood Director, Dies at 74
description: Herbert Ross, a Broadway choreographer-turned-film director who brought serious dance into the Hollywood mainstream with movies like ''The Turning Point,'' translated five Neil Simon comedies to the screen and directed a pantheon of actresses in some of their most memorable roles, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan..

title: Truckers' Drive to City Is Far From Leisurely
description: Truck drivers have a long list of grievances with New York City.

title: Drawn to the Heart of Country Music
description: Duncan Houston was strumming his guitar at the Legends Corner bar downtown on the morning of Sept. 11, and he was there again at noon today, in his ponyskin boots and cowboy hat, singing about good times and hard times and love and America.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: F.T.C. Challenges Merger
description: The Federal Trade Commission said it would challenge the MSC Software Corporation's 1999 acquisition of two rivals, Universal Analytics and Computerized Structural Analysis and Research. MSC is a global supplier of engineering software called Nastran, developed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Universal Analytics and Computerized Structural Analysis were the only other companies that provided advanced versions of Nastran. ''We emphatically deny engaging in anticompetitive activities and will vigorously defend our position,'' said Frank Perna, MSC's chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINN, IRENE
description: GINN-Irene. Irene passed away, peacefully, October 10, at Arbor Hospice, Ann Arbor, Michigan, surrounded by her family. Burial services will be private. Irene ''Gave it the good fight''. She was my companion-beautiful, kind, considerate and loving-a constant joy. She loved life, and gave that love to so many. The Finkelstein family shares in expressing their great sorrow. Seymour Finkelstein

title: U.S. Missions Are Stocking Antibiotics
description: The State Department has ordered its diplomatic missions to stock up on antibiotics to counter any attack by terrorists using anthrax, the spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said today.

title: Nervousness Spreads, Though Illness Doesn't
description: Public health officials across the country were buffeted by calls yesterday from jittery people afraid that they might have been exposed to deadly anthrax bacteria.

title: Loading Up the Discs For the Big Move to XP
description: With the nagging fear of leaving important things behind, moving to a new computer can be just as stressful as moving to a new house. To help ease the pain, the Iomega Corporation released a free program this week called the Iomega Moving Kit, which is designed to help users trading up to brand-new Windows XP computers.

title: Leader Offers a Salve for Britain's Tories
description: Could there possibly be a worse time to be leader of the British Conservative Party?

title: Technology Briefing | Software: At Home Halts Subscriptions
description: The Internet service At Home said it had stopped adding customers to save money after filing for bankruptcy protection. The company, which does business as Excite@Home, stopped accepting new customers for the Internet service it provides over cable television lines at midafternoon Eastern time. The company, which has 3.7 million customers, filed for bankruptcy protection on Sept. 28.

title: Air Force Loses Another Unmanned Spy Aircraft Over Iraq
description: An unmanned American reconnaissance aircraft disappeared over southern Iraq today, Pentagon officials said. It was the third drone lost over Iraq in less than two months.

title: At Ceremony for Firefighters, Words Come Only Haltingly
description: Once each year, state officials and a throng of firefighters gather here at a gleaming slab of polished granite, a short stroll from the State Capitol, to unveil the names of all the New York firefighters who died in the line of duty the previous year.

title: Fire Sprinkler Recall Sought
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission said yesterday that it would file an administrative lawsuit today to force two companies to recall a fire sprinkler that the government contends poses a safety hazard.

title: Honey Trade Said to Provide Funds and Cover to bin Laden
description: American officials say they have evidence that Osama bin Laden is using a network of shops that sell honey -- a staple of Middle Eastern life since biblical times -- to generate income and secretly move weapons, drugs and agents throughout Al Qaeda, his terrorist network.

title: Final Approval Is Awaited On School-Building Chief
description: The School Construction Authority is close to selecting the former owner of an engineering and construction company as its new chief executive, city officials said yesterday.

title: Candidate Demands Revote, Even Though He's the Winner
description: John Baxter, the landslide victor in the race for the Independence Party line in the 32nd Council District, wants a revote.

title: Senate Backs Bill to Tighten Security at Airports and Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  After more than a week of negotiation and delay, the Senate unanimously approved legislation this evening that would heighten security at airports and airplanes in response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But the bill faces a very uncertain future in the House.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Missile 'Mistake'
description: Ukraine tacitly admitted that its military had accidentally downed a Russian passenger jet headed from Tel Aviv to Siberia last week, killing all 78 people on board. President Leonid Kuchma, in comments to reporters in Kiev, indirectly acknowledged that a stray missile from a Ukrainian military training exercise had shot down the plane, saying that mistakes happen everywhere. ''Look around the world, in Europe; we are not the first and not the last,'' Itar-Tass quoted him as saying. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: The Coming of Age Of the Middle Class
description: Extensive Dutch trade in the 17th century led to the rise of the first middle class. More people were able to afford private homes and enjoy filling them. ''Art and Life: Dutch Interiors in the Age of Rembrandt,'' at the Newark Museum, pairs 50 paintings and 70-odd artifacts commonly found in homes of the period, from foot stoves and colanders to brandy bowls and cabinets. Right, a Japanese export jar fitted with Dutch silver mounts and, above, ''Mother Nursing'' by Pieter de Hooch. Wednesday through Jan. 20. The museum is in the arts district, 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6550.

title: Green and Ferrer End Runoff Race With Softer Tone
description: The candidates in today's Democratic mayoral runoff ended their last full day of campaigning yesterday by dropping the combative tone of the past few days and focusing largely on shoring up their political bases.

title: What's Doing Around Town
description: From Broadway and Off Broadway to concert halls and jazz clubs, New York City's stages are returning to normal schedules. Here is a sampling of performances.

title: Can Pakistan's Leader Hold On?
description: With Pakistan's pro-Taliban policy buried in the wreckage of the World Trade Center, President Pervez Musharraf has struggled to put Pakistan back on track and restore the badly bruised relationship with the United States. Joining the antiterrorist coalition may prove to be a fateful choice, one that opens onto a future of more difficult choices.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar was little changed against the euro and the yen. In New York, the euro settled at 91.07 cents, down from 91.30 cents on Tuesday. The dollar traded at 120.39 yen, up from 120.24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, BERNARD
description: NEWMAN-Bernard. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear Burrie. Like a brother, he never forgot a birthday, anniversary, or holiday greeting. We'll miss those special phone calls. One of a kind. Roseann, Irwin and Claire

title: A Broadcast Low For Cleveland-Seattle
description: Game 1 of the Cleveland-Seattle American League Division Series on Tuesday posted a 3.2 Nielsen rating on Fox Sports, the lowest ever for a broadcast network telecast of the first-round series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, ANNE
description: SACKS-Anne. Died October 9, 2001 at the age of 88. Widow of Louis Sacks. Mother of Henry Sacks, Rebecca Sacks Mansdorf, and Victor Sacks. Grandmother of Lucy and Nick Mansdorf. A singularly energetic, independent and modern woman, she found her calling bestowing hospitality as the proprietor of Sacks Lodge in Saugerties, NY, which she ran with enthusiasm and devotion for over 55 years. She was beautiful and had great wit, intelligence and taste. She also displayed enormous courage and determination in the face of unbearable tragedy. Donations may be made to Alzheimer's research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOWANDE, MILDRED B.
description: SOWANDE-Mildred B. 10 days before her 92nd birthday, died on September 29, 2001 of multiple organ failure after a long illness. Talented Musician and Dedicated Educator. The only child of Joseph and Anna Etta Marshall. Beloved mother of Beverly Folasade Sowande and Leanne Adeyola Sowande. Devoted grandmother of George Avery Middleton, Gregory Allen Middleton, Stephanie Elizabeth Young and Melanie Leanne Taylor. Cherished greatgrandmother of Michael Jordan Hilliard, Lauren Beverly Harris, Gregory Allen Middleton, Jr., Breanne Denise Middleton, Robert Eddie Martin, Alyssa Lazette Middleton, Steffon Fitzgerald Martin and Hope Danielle Taylor. You were such a precious gift from God, Mom. Services on October 12, 2001 will be private.

title: Postseason Is Still a Problem for Johnson
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks' combination of Curt Schilling and Randy Johnson, a pair of 20-game winners, was supposed to provide an overwhelming edge in the postseason. Schilling completed his mandate Tuesday by shutting out the St. Louis Cardinals. But Johnson failed to match Schilling today, and the Diamondbacks were baffled by Woody Williams in a 4-1 Cardinals victory at Bank One Ballpark.

title: Hotel Upgrade
description: Getting more than you bargained for is a good deal, and beginning next month, the Hotel Guanahani on St. Barts in the Caribbean will offer free upgrades to all guests, based in availability at check-in. For those in the highest-priced room category, there's a fourth-night-free offer. Also, the hotel, on 15 acres at the islands northeast end, will offer a free lunch or dinner each day. Both offers run through Dec. 18. The offer must be booked through one of the following tour operators: Wimco, (401) 849-8012; Island Destinations, (914) 833-3300; St. Barth Properties, (508) 528-7727.

title: Penn Station Faces Delay Of Expansion
description: The attack on New York City has claimed -- at least temporarily -- one of the more celebrated development projects of recent years: an ambitious plan to expand Pennsylvania Station into a vast new glass-covered ticketing hall and concourse in the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue.

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering; The Home Front
description: To the Editor:

title: An Inside Look At Grand Apartments
description: There are two types of people who will want ''The New York Apartment Houses of Rosario Candela and James Carpenter'' by Andrew Alpern ($65, Acanthus Press). Those curious about the 16-room apartments and circular foyers in Carpenter buildings like 635 Park Avenue, right. And those considering buying an apartment by Candela or Carpenter. ''It has a pedestrian use for those who have arrived and a wishing and hoping use for those who someday hope to arrive,'' said Barry Cenower, the publisher of Acanthus. Mr. Carpenter created sophisticated layouts in 44 apartment houses starting in 1910; in 82 buildings, Mr. Candela defined the city's characteristic terraced setbacks and signature penthouses. The book contains photographs and floor plans for 121 buildings. Acanthus Press: (800) 827-7614.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DONALD J.
description: COHEN-Donald J. The Joseph Slifka Center for Jewish Life at Yale mourns the passing of our great friend and former President, Donald J. Cohen. Donald exemplified what it means to live a Jewish life. He was a warm and caring friend to generations of our students, a wise and inspiring leader of our Board and the brilliant general of the campaign to create our Center. In every word and gesture we could see an expression of his lifetime of engagement with Jewish learning and values. May our Center always embody his spirit of openness and inclusion and his love of Jewish life. We offer our prayers to Donald's family. May the remain part of the Slifka Center for generations to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAMSON, WILLIAM FRASER
description: ABRAHAMSON-William Fraser, of Cortlandt Manor, NY. Bill was a victim of the WTC senseless tragedy. Beloved husband of Ann. Cherished father of Erik. All who knew him have lost a friend with a great enthusiasm for life, and an unbridled love for all people. A memorial service will be at the Holy Name of Mary RC Church, 110 Grand St., Croton-on-Hudson, NY, at 10AM Saturday, Oct. 13. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the William F. Abrahamson Memorial Fund, C/O McCarthy, Fingar et al., 11 Martine Avenue, White Plains, NY 10606.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, EDWARD F.
description: HOWARD-Edward F. Died in September of Parkinsons Disease. A valued communications consultant for AT&T for many years, he was a founding partner of Schorr, Howard & Megill. He is survived by his wife Vyvyan, sons Jeffrey and Craig and four grandchildren.

title: Curtain Going Up at the Performing Arts Library
description: In the cultural diadem of Lincoln Center, the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts seemed like an added jewel -- the smallest of the buildings, the one nestled between the Metropolitan Opera House and the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Now, after a $38 million, three-year renovation, the streamlined library, newly named the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center, can take its proper position of centrality. It is, in fact, the one constituent of Lincoln Center that links all performing arts.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose after a report showed a smaller-than-expected increase in inventories. In New York, natural gas for November delivery rose 9.2 cents, or 3.8 percent, to $2.48 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Expansive Role for Greenspan Brings Out Critics of Fed's Chief
description: Alan Greenspan has been everywhere in guiding economic policy in the wake of the terrorist attacks, slashing interest rates, helping to get Wall Street running again, shaping the tax cuts being developed by Congress and evaluating which airlines should receive government loan guarantees.

title: It's All in the Signal: 2 Kinds of Cable TV
description: Q. I keep seeing offers for ''digital'' cable television. What makes this different from regular cable television? Do I need a special TV?

title: Devils Look for Answers Following Abysmal Opener
description: The Devils have worked for four days on the inefficiencies that led to their trouncing by the Capitals in Washington in their first game of the season. They believe they found some answers in those days of preparation for their home opener against the Islanders on Thursday night.

title: Microsoft Denies It Tried to Hinder Inquiry
description: The Microsoft Corporation denied today that it misled the European Commission in its antitrust investigation into the company.

title: V.S. Naipaul Awarded 2001 Nobel Prize in Literature
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct 11 -- Trinidad-born British writer V.S. Naipaul won the 2001 Nobel prize for literature on Thursday.

title: Tolerating Cellphones
description: To the Editor:

title: Runoff Choices
description: Voters will choose Democratic nominees in two citywide races in New York today. The Times has endorsed Mark Green as the Democratic nominee for mayor and Betsy Gotbaum for public advocate. The polls will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENDEROFF, BENJAMIN
description: SENDEROFF-Benjamin, Peacefully, October 10, after a long illness. Ever-loving and beloved husband of Edna. Treasured father of Paul and Joanne and fatherin-law of Barbara. Cherished grandfather of Robert, Stephanie, Lauren. Favorite uncle of Louise Salet Cameron. Dear friend of Herminia Williams. Services at The Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Ave, Riverdale, NY on Friday, October 12 at 1:00PM.

title: President Hints He Will Halt War if bin Laden Is Handed Over
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- President Bush said today that United States forces would attack Afghanistan for "as long as it takes" to destroy the Qaeda terrorist network of Osama bin Laden, but he offered to reconsider the military assault on Afghanistan if the country's ruling Taliban would surrender Mr. bin Laden.

title: Pataki Names Ex-F.B.I. Man To New Post
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday named the former head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York to head a new state office in charge of bolstering security to prevent terrorist attacks.

title: Runoff Is Today In Mayoral Race
description: The candidates in New York City's Democratic mayoral runoff dropped their combative tone yesterday and focused on shoring up their political bases. Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, and Mark Green, the city's public advocate, urged people to vote today in an election that has been overshadowed by the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack.

title: Wake Up, Officialdom
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Will Appeal Tax Ruling After Talks With Europe Fail
description: The United States and Europe have failed to settle a multibillion-dollar dispute over tax laws, leading the Bush administration to appeal a crucial trade ruling soon before global trade talks begin in November.

title: Economic Scene; Even in good times, airlines depend on a hairline balancing of supply and demand.
description: ON a recent flight from Los Angeles to Dallas, the American Airlines pilot thanked the passengers profusely at the beginning and end of the trip.

title: Berlusconi, Courting Left, Gains Support for Strikes
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi secured bipartisan support today for Italian participation in the American-led military strikes in Afghanistan, mollifying the left and Islamic leaders still ruffled by his recent criticism of their religion with talk of a heavy Western investment for Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODRIGUES, ANTONIO
description: RODRIGUES-Antonio. Age 35, of Port Washington, Long Island on September 11, 2001. A Port Authority Police Officer, he was a hero of the World Trade Center disaster. Beloved husband of Christina. Loving father of Adam and Sara. Dearest son of Jose and Cecilia of Portugal. Dear brother of Marisa Silvestre. Reposing at the Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 1 PM Our Lady of Fatima Church. Interment in Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Drop Continues In Inventories
description: Wholesale inventories fell for a third consecutive month in August and sales rose, government figures showed today, indicating that companies made progress clearing warehouses before Sept. 11.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Don't Touch Those Keys!

title: Wartime Secrecy
description: President Bush wisely backed away yesterday from his threat to curtail classified military and intelligence briefings to Congress. The president's impatience with Congress risked short-circuiting the constitutional powers of the legislative branch. Since the terror attacks on Sept. 11, the administration has made abundantly clear that it would like to tightly control the flow of information about the war on terrorism. This attitude could ultimately undermine public support for Washington's antiterror campaign by depriving Americans of information they need to assess the administration's actions and the state of the nation's security.

title: A Month to the Day, Americans Reflect on a Changed World
description: One month ago today, after four commercial airplanes were hijacked by terrorists, everything changed.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zanzibar: Peace Accord Signed
description: Rival political parties in Zanzibar signed an agreement aimed at ending the turmoil that has ravaged the islands for years, alienating donors and tourists alike. The accord revises voting laws and boosts opposition participation in government, an effort to address longstanding allegations by the main opposition Civic United Front that the governing Chama Cha Mapinduzi Party has rigged elections. ''This is one of the brightest days in our country's history,'' said Amani Karume, president of the semiautonomous archipelago off the coast of Tanzania. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: State Board Rejects Proposed Nassau Budget
description: The state board charged with helping Nassau County wade its way out of a financial crisis rejected a proposed county budget today, saying it would sink the county $55.3 million into debt next year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Abkhazia: Border Beefed Up
description: Russia sent more troops to Abkhazia, the separatist province of Georgia, to bolster its peacekeeping force there after an apparent new influx of guerrillas into the Kodori Gorge. The rebels, whose origin is in dispute, shot down a United Nations helicopter on Monday, and on Tuesday, unidentified planes dropped bombs on two villages in the gorge. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Danbury: Sentencing In Counterfeiting
description: A Danbury woman has been sentenced to two years in prison for counterfeiting $1 million in $50 and $20 bills, the United States attorney's office said yesterday. The woman, Josette Traino, 30, and two other suspects were arrested May 14 after a Secret Service investigation. Ms. Traino had bought counterfeiting equipment from an undercover agent, told him about her business and paid him more than $3,000 in counterfeit bills, investigators said. Ms. Traino and another suspect pleaded guilty. The third suspect is awaiting trial. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Retailers Battle For Loyalty of British Shopper
description: LONDON  The tough fight for business among Britain's fashion retailers just got tougher. A spate of initiatives launched this autumn is raising the temperature to boiling point.

title: U.S. Advisers May Aid Philippine Antiterror Effort
description: A senior Philippine official said yesterday that the United States planned to send a ''sizable'' contingent of military advisers to the Philippines in the next few weeks to help it crackdown on terrorist groups suspected of having ties to Osama bin Laden.

title: Attacks on Taliban Troops, Blackouts in Kabul and the Money Trail
description: United States warplanes trained their sights on new targets in Afghanistan. At first, the focus of the bombing campaign was almost entirely on air defenses, command centers and terrorist training camps. But now Taliban troops in the field have been pounded, and apparently hard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARYE, LEONORA
description: ARYE-Leonora. Passed away peacefully October 8, 2001. Beloved and loving wife of Leonard for more than 47 years. We never stopped laughing. Loving and adored mother of Larry, Lowell and Lane. Loving mother-in-law of Linda & grandmother of Mollie. A gifted sculptor and writer, who was too modest for the gifts she had. Her last days were much like her life, brave and uncomplaining. We will love and remember her to the end of our days. Funeral on October 10, 11 AM, Zion Memorial Chapel, 767 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, New York.

title: Giuliani Says City Won't Accept $10 Million Check From Saudi
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said today that New York City would not accept a $10 million charitable donation from a wealthy prince from Saudi Arabia who criticized the American government's policies in the Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GALISE, ROSALIE B.
description: GALISE-Rosalie B. October 10, 1929-October 7, 2000. Lovingly remembered and greatly missed today and every day. Your Devoted Family

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering
description: To the Editor:

title: Profit Up 22% At Genentech
description: The biotechnology company Genentech reported today that its operating profit rose 22 percent in the third quarter on better-than-expected sales of its cancer drugs.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Dan Bagan was named publishing director at Supermarket News, New York, part of the business-to-business division of Fairchild Publications, a unit of Advance Publications. He had been publisher at Chain Store Age, New York, published by Lebhar-Friedman.

title: Deutsche Bank's Negotiations For a Korean Bank Collapse
description: Talks between the government and Deutsche Bank about the sale of SeoulBank, on the trading block since the worst days of the South Korean economic crisis in 1998, ended today after the government refused to take on additional bad loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENBAUM, REV. BERNARD
description: TANNENBAUM-Rev. Bernard. On October 9, 2001. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Devoted father of Penny, Matthew and Jeremy. He was a loving man devoted to family and excellence. Funeral service Friday 1PM at Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUTOS, PETER C.
description: MOUTOS-Peter C., 44. Of Chatham, NJ (formerly of Manhattan) missing from the World Trade Center (Marsh USA Inc.) on September 11th. Beloved husband of Mary ''Meg'' (nee Cooney). Son of Gus Moutos of Salinas, CA and Gladys Moutos of Enid, OK. Stepson of Lanette Moutos of Salinas, CA. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Patrick's Church, 85 Washington Ave., Chatham, NJ on Saturday, October 13th at 11:00 AM. For further information go to www.bradleyfuneralhome.com

title: A Dream Stands Up to Disaster
description: UNDER the best conditions, home renovating is fraught. Since Sept. 11th, it has taken on even more tedious dimensions as contractors face obstacles from skittish workers booking the next flight home to erratic deliveries from abroad. Some contractors won't even show up at jobs below Chambers Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SAMUEL E.
description: SCHWARTZ-Samuel E., MD. Retired New York family physician, died on October 6th in Phoenix, Arizona. Dr. Schwartz was born on September 3rd, 1910, in New York City. He was a graduate of City College of New York in 1931 and New York University School of Medicine in 1938. He interned at Willard Parker and later served in the United States Army during WW II. He practiced for over 40 years in Jackson Heights before retiring and moving to Scottsdale, Arizona in 1983. He is survived by his wife Lee A. Schwartz, children Judy Warner, Stanley Schwartz and Nanci Ryder, 4 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. He was interred at Mount Sinai Mortuary in Los Angeles.

title: Judge Accepts F.B.I. Agent's Death in Attack as Excuse for Late Indictment
description: Leonard W. Hatton's final case was the prosecution of a man suspected of being the getaway driver in a Queens bank robbery, and it is still chilling to see his name signed on the last page of the federal complaint.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVAK, JUDITH IRIS
description: NOVAK-Judith Iris. Age 58 died October 8, 2001 at home after a long, gallant and arduous battle with lung cancer. Devoted daughter of the late Leon H. and Helen Novak. Beloved sister of Ronald and Rose Novak. An inspiring and courageous mother of Vanessa (Joe Kmetz) of Bozeman, Montana and Jillian of New York and Los Angeles. Loving aunt of Mara (Dr. Mitchell Miller) and Leila and great-aunt of Gareth and Zoe. Judy was a graduate of Pratt/NYU & an innovative and witty graphic designer. She lived in Florida for a number of years, but joyfully came home to Manhattan six years ago. She then received an M.A. in Counselling from NYU and had begun to plan for a PsyD at the time of her initial diagnosis. During her illness she continued to paint. The Judiff was forever young and beautiful, gifted and funny, and modest. She was and will always be an endless source of strength for her children, her family, her friends and all who are blessed to have known her. The family will be at home Thursday, Friday and Saturday from 4-8 PM. A memorial service will be held at The National Academy of Design, 1083 5th Avenue at 90th Street, Monday, October 15, at 11:30 AM.

title: Expatriates on Alert: Vigilance Abroad:Forget the Cowboy Boots
description: "Dress like an Austrian" urges a popular magazine in Vienna, dusting off Rule No. 1 from the Gulf War a decade ago: If you are an American abroad, do not advertise your nationality.

title: Footlights
description: Through Yankee Eyes

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering; The War Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Two Agencies Name Creative Directors
description: Two agencies have selected creative directors.

title: Nominees Are Announced For National Book Awards
description: The nominees for this year's National Book Awards, announced yesterday by the National Book Foundation, represent the panoply of the American experience: immigration, cross-culturalism, the celebration of nature, childhood. Jonathan Franzen's ''Corrections'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), a traditional family chronicle with postmodern flourishes, was nominated for fiction, along with ''Highwire Moon,'' by Susan Straight (Houghton Mifflin), the story of a poor Mexican girl's search for the mother she thinks has abandoned her.

title: New Premier in Bangladesh Vows to Stamp Out Corruption
description: Khaleda Zia, a nationalist leader, was sworn in this evening as prime minister of Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest and most populous nations, after an election in which a surprising 75 percent of the registered voters went to the polls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODENHEIMER, MARGOT
description: BODENHEIMER-Margot. On October 9, 2001. Survived by her son, Dr. Ronald (Hildegard), grandchildren, David & Miriam. Graveside services 10:30 AM at Beth El Cemetery, Washington, NJ. Contributions to Jewish Home Foundation, 2021 S. Winton Road, Rochester, New York 14618.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Baltimore Technologies Appoints A Chief
description: Baltimore Technologies, a developer of security software, appointed Bijan Khezri as chief executive, replacing its founder, Fran Rooney, who resigned in July amid poor trading conditions and hundreds of job cuts. The company also reported a 9 percent drop in third-quarter revenue, to 15 million ($21.8 million). Mr. Khezri held a strategic development position on Baltimore's board until November 2000, but rejoined after Mr. Rooney left. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Bridge; Custodian of Master Points Constructed Fiendish Deals
description: A quiet man who did a great deal for the game behind the scenes died last week in Geneva at age 69. His name was Pietro Bernasconi, and for many years he was the custodian of master points for the World Bridge Federation. He and his computer recorded the performances of players in 80-odd countries and noted when they advanced in rank. Virtually none of them thanked him or were aware of his effort. He was more visible for his role in constructing fiendishly difficult deals, which were then presented as par problems to the world's best players.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Slows
description: With companies keeping a lid on prices to protect already weak sales, Brazil's inflation rate fell in September to its lowest level in almost a year. Restrained by food and gasoline prices, inflation rose only 0.28 percent last month compared with 0.7 percent in August. The government is counting on weak consumer demand to temper inflation after a steep devaluation in the real forced the central bank to increase its 2001 inflation projection to 6.5 percent. The government had set a maximum inflation target of 6 percent.

title: INSIDE
description: Feuding at Lincoln Center

title: Sports of The Times; Eager to See The Return Of Peanuts
description: I WANT to miss ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game.'' I want to miss the inanity of it, of the peanuts and the Cracker Jack and not caring if I never get back. And I indeed miss the time, a lifetime ago, a hundred thousand years ago, it seems, in a world now so utterly unrecognizable, so relatively benign, that we could indeed forget our problems for three hours at a ballpark.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Ex-Mayor Won't Seek To Renew Title
description: Former Mayor Richard Arrington Jr. of Birmingham, who announced this summer that he was leaning toward running for his old job in 2003, has reversed course, saying he will not run after his allies fared poorly this week in City Council elections. Mr. Arrington, left, retired in 1999 after serving five four-year terms. He had been interested in challenging his successor, Bernard Kincaid, but candidates supported by Mr. Kincaid in Tuesday's council elections did well, while many of those supported by Mr. Arrington lost badly. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: New Bomb Raids Near Kabul and Refugees Flee Kandahar
description: The heaviest airstrikes of the United States-led campaign continued against Afghanistan for a fifth day this morning as new bombing raids were made near Kabul, the capital. As a result of the attacks thousands of civilians were reported fleeing Kandahar, the ruling Taliban's spiritual base.

title: Sports of The Times; Clemens's Unfinished Business
description: JUST when the Yankees were hoping that Roger Clemens would soar, the 280-game winner known as the Rocket sputtered and crashed.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Death Sentences For 2 Mayors
description: Mu Suixin, the former mayor of the major northeastern city of Shenyang, and Ma Xiangdong, former deputy mayor, were both given death sentences for bribery and corruption, state television reported. Mr. Mu's sentence was suspended. Dozens of other city officials including two top judges, the chief prosecutor and the head of the tax bureau are also being punished in one of China's most sweeping scandals in recent years, with evidence that many city leaders worked in league with a violent criminal group. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: In America; Protecting Children
description: In a report released in March 2000, the American Academy of Pediatrics made it clear that a terrorist attack with chemical or biological weapons would have a disproportionate and potentially devastating effect on children.

title: Doubt Is Raised on Lawsuit On 'The Wind Done Gone'
description: A federal appeals court in Atlanta sent a copyright-infringement lawsuit filed against the publisher of ''The Wind Done Gone'' back to a lower court yesterday but expressed doubts about its eventual success.

title: Why I (Gulp) Don't Mind Targeted Ads
description: Afew weeks ago, I interviewed representatives from the major cell-phone carriers for an article. One conversation in particular, with a guy from Sprint PCS named Dan Wilinsky, stuck in my head.

title: A Delta Plane Is Diverted With a Military Escort
description: A Delta Air Lines jet flying from Atlanta to Los Angeles was escorted by military jets to an unscheduled landing in Shreveport, La., today after a man handed an intimidating note to a flight attendant, federal authorities said.

title: Nasdaq Wins Web Ruling
description: The Nasdaq stock market won a challenge yesterday against a Canadian group that had registered four Internet domain names containing the word ''Nasdaq.'' Nasdaq officials took the challenge to the World Intellectual Property Organization, which appointed an arbitrator, Michael Swinson, to examine the issue. Mr. Swinson found that Green Angel, a Toronto group, had used the names to aid its Web site marketing and advertising, and ordered the four names to be returned. The group has 10 days to challenge the order.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: A Pared-Down Marathon

title: Ads Down, Yahoo Expects a Hard Quarter
description: In the face of a dismal market for advertising, Yahoo said yesterday that it barely met its forecasts for revenue and profit in the third quarter, but it sharply cut its sales forecast for the fourth quarter.

title: New York Carries On, but Test of Its Grit Has Just Begun
description: Imagine being told a month ago that security checkpoints would be established at the bridges and tunnels leading into Manhattan. Imagine being told a month ago that the police would prevent single-occupant cars from crossing into Midtown or Lower Manhattan on weekday mornings.

title: Rowland Urges Special Session As Shortfall Imperils Budget
description: Gov. John G. Rowland announced today that Connecticut faced a growing budget shortfall that could reach $300 million -- more than three times the amount estimated earlier this week -- and urged a special session of the Legislature to cut spending.

title: Fear Keeps Some Shoppers Away From Mall of America, but a Defiance Remains
description: The giant temple of consumerism called Mall of America plays a central role in the heartland's consciousness and draws huge crowds every day. That is why some people who work and shop here are nervous these days.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Backs Groove Networks
description: Microsoft has invested $51 million in Groove Networks, the peer-to-peer communications company started by Ray Ozzie. The investment gives Microsoft a minority equity stake in the company, and the two companies also said they would work together to promote Internet-based services to businesses. ''Microsoft's investment in Groove Networks indicates just how important this relationship is to both companies,'' said Mr. Ozzie, above, the creator of the popular business communications tool Lotus Notes and Groove's chief executive. Groove's software, which has been described as Napster for office workers, relies on technology that lets groups of workers share data and files online. Microsoft's .NET initiative also emphasizes such distributed computing.

title: Pataki Defends $54 Billion Aid Request
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday defended his request for $54 billion from Congress to help New York recover from terrorist attacks, including proposals to use federal aid to balance the state budget and to pay for state transportation projects.

title: Suffolk Police Arrest Neighbor In 1996 Killing of Teenager
description: A Suffolk County man was arrested yesterday in the 1996 killing of a 16-year-old Long Island honors student. Her death had shocked and bewildered the quiet, upper-income neighborhood where she lived and had frustrated investigators for more than five years.

title: Dagmar, 79, Foxy Blonde With First-Name Status in 50's
description: The statuesque performer who won fame as Dagmar, a dumb-as-a-fox blonde on one of television's first late-night shows, died on Tuesday at her home in Ceredo, W.Va. She was 79.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Sept. 30 about penalties for the personal use of marijuana in Jamaica misstated the position of a commission advising the government. It called for the decriminalization of the drug, not legalization.

title: New Bomb Raids Near Kabul and Refugees Flee Kandahar
description: The heaviest airstrikes of the United States-led campaign continued against Afghanistan for a fifth day this morning as new bombing raids were made near Kabul, the capital. As a result of the attacks thousands of civilians were reported fleeing Kandahar, the ruling Taliban's spiritual base.

title: Raw Desire and Trysts, But No Sign of a Tango
description: The melodrama ''Intimacy,'' playing today at the New York Film Festival, is a one-of-a-kind, and some might say unholy, hybrid: ''Last Tango in Paris'' meets

title: U.S. SHIFTS FOCUS OF ATTACK IN AFGHANISTAN BY BOMBING GROUND FORCES OF TALIBAN
description: American warplanes pounded barracks, garrisons and troop encampments across Afghanistan yesterday in the heaviest airstrikes yet against ground forces of the Taliban regime, the protectors of the suspected terrorist Osama bin Laden and his network.

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from Oct. 11.

title: Damon the Catalyst
description: Center fielder Johnny Damon began his first season with the Oakland Athletics by going hitless in his first 17 at-bats. In mid-June, he was barely hitting above .200.

title: At the Mayor's News Conference, a Return, Almost, to Normalcy
description: For the first time since Sept. 11, Rudolph W. Giuliani returned to trying to be just the mayor of New York City yesterday. He made political commentary, poked fun at his own thin skin, and told people they should eat out: ''I mean, come on,'' he said.

title: Airlines Try to Smooth Fear Out of Waiting; Heavy Security Is Creating New Stress
description: As travelers slowly return to the skies after the terrorist attacks of last month, the nation's airlines are shifting some of their emphasis from luring back customers to ensuring that their travel experiences do not scare them away all over again.

title: Sheepishly Hoarding For a Rainy Day
description: NOT to brag, but my laundry room is a storage lover's dream space. If there were a magazine called Pack Rat (and judging by the shopping habits of some of my friends, there would be a big audience), the editors could put my laundry room's spacious floor-to-ceiling shelves on the cover of the premiere issue.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Stocks Rise, Led by a Technology Rally
description: Stocks rose sharply today, led higher by a strong rally in the technology sector, as much of the market reached levels not seen since the day before terrorist attacks a month ago.

title: Seeking a Shelter From the Storm, Divers Found Peril
description: To the men commiserating at Dive Expressions, a store that sells scuba diving gear, nothing is so serene as the depths of the sea.

title: Shares Rally as Worries Over Afghanistan Fighting Ease
description: Stocks rallied broadly yesterday as investors showed signs of overcoming their initial nervousness after the military strikes in Afghanistan.

title: Smith Making Believers, Yard by Yard
description: The signs are scattered through the Miami Dolphins' locker room. ''If you want something you've never had,'' they say, ''you better be willing to do something you've never done.''

title: Murky Picture Emerges of Life Under Bombardment
description: As American warplanes zeroed in on Afghanistan on Sunday night, the supreme leader of the ruling Taliban left his bleak, fortified compound in Kandahar and sought shelter in a nearby irrigation tunnel. A few minutes later, his house was leveled, one of the first targets in the air war against Afghanistan.

title: 3 Americans Awarded Nobel for Economics
description: Three American economists were awarded the 2001 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday for their pioneering research in the shortcomings and imperfections of market systems.

title: Woman in the News; A New Vote Counter -- Nancy Patricia Pelosi
description: When Nancy Patricia D'Alesandro answered the phone as a Baltimore teenager, she often gave directions on ''how to get somebody on welfare, into a hospital bed, into a project,'' she recalled today, even ''out of jail.''

title: Doctors Study The Gory Details
description: The blood-and-gristle medical thriller is a hardy genre, so it is very natural for physicians and surgeons to try jumping over the frustration of their professional lives by the writing of such novels. After all, many of them believe that if they were smart enough to get into medical school, it follows that they can do just about anything. They do know the territory, and feel certain a doctor can write more than just prescriptions and journal papers.

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering
description: To the Editor:

title: A Buyer's Market for Autos Is a Tough Development for Chrysler
description: Dieter Zetsche is holding an arm's length pair of cardboard scissors. The Romeo High School band has played ''The Star Spangled Banner.'' A big American flag is unfurled into a cloudy sky. Veterans salute and a pastor prays. Now it's time for Mr. Zetsche, the chief executive of the Chrysler Group, to cut the big red ribbon stretching over the entrance of Orchard Chrysler, Jeep, Dodge, a new dealership nestled next to a Fashion Bug and a Farmer Jack, several miles north of Detroit.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Arrested In Infant Death
description: A Crown Heights woman has been arrested in the death of her 5-month-old daughter. The woman, Tarsha Flynn, 21, was charged with second-degree murder in the July 23 killing of Cheyanna Flynn. The infant was discovered by the police floating in a bucket of water in Ms. Flynn's home. Ms. Flynn said she was soaking her feet and holding the infant when she fell asleep and the child slipped into the water accidentally, according to investigators. Last month, however, the medical examiner's office ruled the death a homicide.

title: Experts Doubt Iraq Had Role in Latest Terror Attacks
description: The attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon brought immediate accusations not only against Osama bin Laden but against Saddam Hussein of Iraq as his likely partner in crime.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Widow Asks Leniency
description: The widow of the State House majority leader, Paul Sliter, is urging a judge not to imprison her husband's best friend, Shane Hedges, left, a former policy adviser to Gov. Judy Martz. Mr. Hedges, 27, was driving drunk when his sport utility vehicle rolled over on Aug. 15, killing Mr. Sliter. His widow, Elaine Sliter, is one of more than 100 people who have written to Judge Thomas Honzel of Helena, asking for leniency for Mr. Hedges, who was not seriously hurt in the crash. Mrs. Sliter has recommended house arrest and community service. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: City Is Reopening Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel Outbound, and Some Streets in Lower Manhattan
description: City transportation officials said yesterday that they would reopen the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel to regular traffic for the first time since the attack on the World Trade Center, making it available to Brooklyn-bound traffic only beginning at 6 on Saturday morning.

title: Forms That Trace a Previous Era's Angst
description: IT was a time when America was getting used to a new kind of war during peace and daily life was taking on new rhythms and shapes. A sense of fear and tension bubbled beneath an exuberant pop culture.

title: V.S. Naipaul Awarded 2001 Nobel Prize in Literature
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct 11 (Reuters) - Trinidad-born British writer V.S. Naipaul won the 2001 Nobel prize for literature on Thursday.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Fleet and Its Targets

title: Boy, 16, Admits He Set Homeless Man on Fire
description: When Louis Medina arrived in court yesterday morning, he still had not come to terms with the part he played in setting fire to a homeless man in Chelsea in May.

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering; The War Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Is Served as A's Strike the First Blow
description: Inevitably there will be an October when the Yankees do not win the World Series, when their seemingly ageless stars break down and pressure finally buckles them. Inevitably there will be an October without a parade.

title: For High-Speed Access to the Web, a Dish-to-Dish Route
description: FRUSTRATED with the four and a half hours it took to download Microsoft Internet Explorer, Ronald Marshall of Parkville, Mo., decided last spring to investigate high-speed Internet options.

title: They Meet in a Gallery, God Looking On
description: The music, selections by Smashing Pumpkins played at full volume, comes at you like a raging lawn mower. Heard before ''The Shape of Things,'' the seriously contrived new play by Neil LaBute, and between every scene, the songs are loud enough to pre-empt any attempt at conversation or, for that matter, thought. They also present an implicit challenge: are you strong enough to stomach the harsh truths that await you?

title: After Month Off, Parties Resume Efforts
description: Ending a monthlong respite that followed the terrorist attacks, the Democratic and Republican Parties have resumed political events and the soliciting of contributions. And officials of each party suggested today that their counterparts were capitalizing on the tragedy for partisan gain.

title: Passenger-Screening Companies Lobby for Expanded Role
description: The companies that screen passengers and baggage at the nation's airports readily acknowledge that they do not do their job very well. Yet as Congress debates the future of aviation security, these companies are lobbying hard for an expanded role, arguing they are the only ones who know how to do it right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, RENEE
description: KAUFMAN-Renee. Beloved wife of the late Sigfried and sister of Gertrude Lobbenberg, died peacefully on October 9, 2001. Her family will miss her deeply.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Nets Add Goodrich, Ex-Princeton Center
description: The Nets announced yesterday that they had signed Steve Goodrich, a 6-10 center out of Princeton, who appeared in 12 games with the Chicago Bulls last season, averaging 1.6 points and and 1.8 rebounds a game. Terms of the contract were not announced.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about peace rallies misstated the name of a Southern Baptist Convention body headed by Richard D. Land, who said war was permissible only to resist aggression and defend those victimized by it. He is president of the Ethics and Religious Liberty Commission, not Ethics and Public Policy.

title: After Much Finger-Wagging Touch Screens Get the Point
description: A fingertip may not be the most ideal instrument for navigating a hand-held computer, but to many users, it is the most convenient. Why bother with the stylus when information can be retrieved with a few well-placed pokes?

title: Energy Self-Sufficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Life Term Sought In Homicide
description: Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, said he would not seek the death penalty for a Brooklyn man indicted in the killing of a pizza deliveryman in a botched robbery last spring. Mr. Hynes said he would seek life imprisonment without the possibility of parole for Mark Rushion, 24, who is accused of shooting Ivan Martinez, 17, who worked as a deliveryman. Mr. Martinez was returning by bicycle to the restaurant where he worked. Mr. Rushion and three friends used the $40 stolen from Mr. Martinez to buy chicken wings, the authorities have said.

title: Article 2001101190681394337 -- No Title
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); }

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering
description: To the Editor:

title: Donations in Monthlong Campaign Total $35 Million
description: The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund ends its active appeal for donations today, one month after a terrorist attack leveled the World Trade Center and left nearly 5,000 people dead or missing.

title: Still on the River, Shifting Views
description: FOR New Yorkers, to stay or to leave, whether in crisis or not, has always been a kind of daily universal question. But with the nation warring, the pressure to make peace with a place, or to secure a sense of safety, seems greater than ever.

title: A City of Exiles Dreams of Power Regained
description: They hold meetings, drink green tea, hold more meetings, drink more tea. Occasionally, they call Washington or Islamabad or Rome. These are exciting days. The world seems to have turned upside down, and that means they may be back on top.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSKIND, JAKUB (JANEK, JACK)
description: SUSSKIND-Jakub (Janek, Jack). Suddenly, on October 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Leah. Dear father of Sara, her husband Tom, and Tania. Adoring grandfather of Zachary. Devoted brother of Anna Kanarek. Funeral services and interment were held on October 3 in Jerusalem. Shiva is being observed at his home in Manhattan through October 15. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Israel Cancer Research Fund, 1290 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10104.

title: Israel, America and the Fight Against Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Slower Growth and Wider Deficit Are Seen for Indonesia
description: Underscoring how security concerns have clouded Indonesia's economic outlook, the International Monetary Fund agreed today that the country's government would be forced to run a wider budget deficit than planned next year.

title: Saudi Cooperation on bin Laden Lags, U.S. Aides Say
description: Saudi Arabia has so far refused to freeze the assets of Osama bin Laden and his associates, and has proved unwilling to cooperate fully on the investigation of the hijacking suspects in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, Bush administration officials said today.

title: Under the Grit and Ash, a Garden Endures
description: THERE are still bits of ash on the leaves of the Japanese anemones in Battery Park, but their pink buds are swelling. And last week, as gardeners with respirators donned heavy rubber gloves and knelt among the Siberian irises to scrape up gray dust and bits of paper -- vestiges of the lives that were blasted out of the twin towers on Sept. 11 -- it seemed a bit of a miracle to see the blue salvia blooming.

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering; The War Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: Scripps Profit Falls 36%
description: The E. W. Scripps Company, owner of the Home & Garden Television cable network, said today that third-quarter profit fell 36 percent after a decline in advertising sales that was aggravated by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTONE, MYRA
description: GREENSTONE-Myra. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mrs. Myra Greenstone, an esteemed member, and extend to her beloved husband, Jay, and family its deepest sympathy. Kenneth Apfel, President Sidney Gottlieb, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAYNE, OSCAR
description: WAYNE-Oscar. On October 8. Beloved husband of Adele. Devoted father of Vivian and her husband Brian Henderson. Cherished grandfather of Alexis and Olivia. He will be deeply missed by all and will forever remain in our hearts. Funeral is private. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: More Arrests and Charges In Assault on Terror Rings
description: The assault in Europe on the network believed to be behind the terror attacks in the United States continued today, with the arrest of four people in Italy and Germany and charges brought against four people suspected of being Islamic militants in France.

title: Filming of commercials in New York is making a comeback after the disruption of Sept. 11.
description: WHEN Jeff Gorman, a commercial director, was making arrangements to shoot a spot for a government agency, he was working out logistical details for the site selected for the production, an emergency call center in Jersey City.

title: High-Octane Offense Tilts Field Rams' Way
description: The matchup in St. Louis Sunday between the Rams and the Giants seems unfair.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: The Elusive Cherry Bush

title: Bird's-Eye Views, Made to Order
description: AMONG the indelible images from the terrorist attacks last month were commercial satellite photographs showing smoke and dust of volcanic proportions stretching for miles from the ruins of the World Trade Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a memorial service for employees of the Port Authority who were killed on Sept. 11 misstated the surname of a police officer who spoke. He was Edward K. McQuade, not McCabe.

title: Corrections
description: Aheadline on Sept. 30 about penalties for the personal use of marijuana in Jamaica misstated the position of a commission advising the government. It called for the decriminalization of the drug, not legalization.

title: Report Says Egypt Plot With Pilots Was Blocked
description: Egyptian security forces said today that in May they arrested a group of Islamic militants who were preparing to carry out attacks inside Egypt and that two of them had received training as civilian pilots.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures yesterday and on Tuesday with biographical sketches of Jenny Low Wong and Jennifer Y. Wong, terrorism victims at the World Trade Center, were reversed. Both sketches appear again today, with the correct pictures, on Page B15.

title: Rangers' Future Goalie Gets Dose of Present Futility
description: The Rangers hung their future out to dry last night.

title: Acquisition Lowers Profit For PepsiCo
description: PepsiCo said today that its third-quarter profit fell 17 percent because of costs related to the purchase of the Quaker Oats Company, the maker of Gatorade.

title: One Man's Daring Escape From the Final Solution
description: In 1979, while he was making ''Shoah,'' his nine-hour documentary about the Nazi attempt to obliterate the Jews of Europe, Claude Lanzmann filmed a long interview with Yehuda Lerner, a survivor of the Sobibor camp in eastern Poland. The story that Mr. Lerner had to tell -- about a carefully planned, surprisingly successful uprising of camp inmates against their would-be murderers -- was not included in ''Shoah.'' The purpose of that film was not to document exceptional acts of mercy and bravery, but rather the more normative experience of inhumanity, terror and death.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Cashman's Status Near Resolution
description: The Yankees' general manager, Brian Cashman, and principal owner, George Steinbrenner, could soon resolve Cashman's uncertain contract negotiations. Cashman will either settle with Steinbrenner on an extension of his contract, which expires Oct. 31, or he will join the lengthy list of Yankees executives who have pursued opportunities with other teams.

title: Transcript of Dr. Thomas J. O'Connell's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, Oct. 9, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Dr. Thomas J. O'Connell. Dr. O'Connell, a thoracic surgeon, joined DRCnet to fight for doctors and patients rights to manage their own pain.This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPARACIO, THOMAS
description: SPARACIO-Thomas. Age 35, of Staten Island, N.Y. Has not been heard from since the attack on the WTC September 11, 2001. Loving husband of Cheri Magnus Sparacio, adoring and devoted father of 2-year-old twins Eric & Jonathan and soon-to-be-born Baby S.
