Beloved son of Edith Sparacio and brother of Edward, Deborah, Doreen and Jack, uncle to 16 nieces and nephews, cherished son-in-law of Irwin and Judith Magnus, and grandson-in-law of Sylvia Marcus. Also survived by his father, Jack Sparacio. Worked as a currency trader at Euro Brokers. Thomas will be honored at a memorial service on Saturday, October 13, at Harmon Home, 571 Forest Ave, Staten Island, 2-5PM and 7-9PM with service at 8PM. Call 718-442-5056 for directions. Donations may be made to an educational fund for Eric and Jonathan Sparacio, C/O J. Magnus, 115 West 27th St. 4th floor, NY, NY 10001.

title: Calmly, Hospitals Prepare For the Wave of Wounded
description: Standing beside a stockpile of medicine and bandages, a hoard for the wounded who are expected to wash through Peshawar as soon as this war really begins, a woman in a spotless white uniform looked out on a makeshift emergency ward filled with empty beds. ''I hate war,'' said the woman, Ruksana Bano, the head nurse in a special ward at Government Lady Reading Hospital in Peshawar.

title: U.S. Finds Itself Lacking Experts on Afghanistan
description: As the United States takes up a war against terrorism that will demand human intelligence as much as smart bombs, it faces a nationwide shortage of Americans with deep knowledge of the languages and cultures of Afghanistan and the surrounding region, academic and national security experts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, ISIDORE A.
description: BECKER-Isidore A. On October 8, 2001. Beloved husband of Adele. Loving father of Steven, his wife Abbe, and Carol. Adored grandfather of Robert, Meredith, Emily and Alison. Dear brother of Russ. He will live in our hearts forever and will always be a part of our lives. He was the strength and rock of our family. Service Thursday, 9:30AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Infield Defense May Be Astros' Weakest Link
description: The Atlanta Braves keep finding more ways to beat the Houston Astros, and the Astros keep getting more frustrated.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In the past we allowed ourselves to be passive victims because we figured it was safer. Now we know it's not safer.''

title: Air Passengers Vow to Resist Any Hijackers
description: Up at 30,000 feet, the rules have changed.

title: G.E. Hires Wife of British Prime Minister to Help Honeywell Bid
description: BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) -- General Electric Co. lost the first battle when the European Union blocked its bid for to International. But the company is still pulling out the big guns.

title: Essay; On Everyday Bravery
description: ''Calm down, relax,'' advised Mayor Rudy Giuliani at New York's Columbus Day parade. He added: ''Be brave.'' President Bush agrees, urging us to fly again and ''enjoy life.''

title: Cardinal, at Rome Synod, Reflects on New York and Sanctity
description: When Pope John Paul II asked Cardinal Edward Egan of New York to spend October here, helping him run a monthlong gathering of bishops from around the world, the cardinal could hardly object.

title: Browser Battle: Beyond the Numbers
description: IN the old days, software companies used a simple numbering scheme. Upon the release of a major overhaul of a program, the version number changed -- for example, from FileMaker 3 to FileMaker 4. When the changes involved only a few features, the number after the decimal point changed, as from Word 5 to Word 5.1. And when bugs were fixed, we got the double-decimal-point upgrade, as from Linux 2.4.1 to 2.4.2. You could gauge the magnitude of the improvements just by looking at the number.

title: Bleak Outlook For Quarter At Motorola
description: Motorola, which is one of the first major technology companies to offer investors guidance on the economic outlook each quarter, announced plans yesterday for shedding 7,000 more jobs and quashed hopes on Wall Street that it was about to return to profitability.

title: A Weak Spot: the Luggage Hold
description: Now that Tom Ridge has moved into the White House as the new director of homeland security, Americans will be looking for firm new measures for air travel safety. The events of Sept. 11 proved that air travelers need the protection of steel-reinforced cockpit doors, sky marshals and better transponders. But while we concentrate on providing better security inside cockpits and passenger cabins, we must also remember that clever terrorists don't strike twice in succession in the same way. Next time, there could be a bomb in the baggage hold.

title: Afghanistan's Distance From Carriers Limits U.S. Pilots' Flights
description: As airstrikes in Afghanistan continued today, commanders said air operations had been constrained by the sheer distances involved in striking targets in a landlocked country whose neighbors have refused to let the United States launch its attacks from their territory.

title: A Navy Man And Muslim Reconciles Two Worlds
description: With the United States at war against terrorists who claim to have acted in the name of Islam, a Navy lieutenant named Muhiyyaldin finds himself at the center of two worlds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIZZARDINI, ADELAIDE
description: NIZZARDINI-Adelaide. Of Bronx, on Wednesday, October 10, 2001. Beloved wife of Anthony. Survived by son Robert. Cherished sister of Howard Hurwitz. Adored aunt of Esther Wertlieb, Miriam Shapiro, Amy Thau and their families. Grandmother of four, great grandmother of four. Loving sister-inlaw and aunt. Adelaide worked side by side with her husband Tony at their business, Masonic Supply Co., where they have been tenants of the Flatiron Building in Manhattan for over 50 years. Adelaide was an exceptional lady and will be greatly missed by all whose lives she touched. Services 12 noon Friday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ. The family will receive their relatives and friends at the funeral chapel from 11 AM until 12 noon. For directions to the chapel please call 1-800525-3834. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Shriners Hospitals, care of Mecca Temple, 71 West 23 Street, NY NY 10010.

title: Conflicts Split Lincoln Center, With Redevelopment Project at Core; Proposals for Dome and New Opera House Are Proving Especially Volatile
description: Faced with the abrupt resignation of its president and other problems, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is being torn by a new level of conflict among its powerful performing arts groups, with the center's billion-dollar redevelopment project hanging in the balance.

title: Living On With a Bitter Fact: 'Yes, Aidan, Daddy Is Dead'
description: ''Mommy, is Daddy dead?''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Muslim Clergyman Attacked
description: A Muslim clergyman was attacked Tuesday night in the Bronx by three men who walked into a mosque and, without a word, struck him over the head with a piece of wood, the police said. Details were sketchy yesterday, but the mullah suffered only minor injuries. The police said the assault on the mullah, who is also black, was being investigated as a possible hate crime. The mullah, 35, whose name was not immediately released, was confronted about 8 p.m. by three men inside the Islamic Cultural Center at 371 East 166th Street, the police said.

title: Patience and Antiterrorism
description: The antiterrorism packages that are moving swiftly toward a vote in the House and Senate represent a more thoughtful attempt to balance civil liberties and national security than the measure hastily assembled by Attorney General John Ashcroft less than a month ago. But certain provisions still need refining, especially those governing surveillance and the detention of aliens.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Yahoo Cuts Sales Forecast And Is Considering Layoffs

title: Israel, America and the Fight Against Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Athletics Back Up The Brash Talk Of Their Manager
description: No one necessarily said that Art Howe was wrong in what he said; the question was why he said it.

title: Knicks' Johnson Retires, Preferring to Fade Away
description: There was no elaborate news conference at Madison Square Garden. No halftime ceremony to say goodbye. No video montage to celebrate his achievements.

title: Counting the Minutes
description: To the Editor:

title: House G.O.P. Tax-Cut Plans Jeopardize Chance of a Deal
description: Republicans in the House said today that they planned to draw up their own package of tax cuts and begin voting on it as soon as this week, casting doubt on efforts to reach a quick bipartisan deal to reduce taxes and increase spending in response to the economic downturn.

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering; The War Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada's Health Care Shows Strains
description: Canadians may earn substantially less than Americans, but most of them still rate their quality of life higher, and their government-administered health service has long topped the list of reasons. That health service is now in trouble. How to fix it without ''Americanizing'' it is the problem.

title: Sri Lanka's President Dissolves Parliament and Calls Elections
description: Facing certain defeat in a confidence vote on Thursday, Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, dissolved Parliament tonight and called new elections in December.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 5:30 p.m. Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the induction ceremony for the new Roman Catholic archbishop of Newark misspelled his surname in some copies and reversed his given and middle names. He is John Joseph Myers, not Meyers.

title: A Little Bit of the United Kingdom, in the United States
description: The last thing the British Design Council wanted right now was any hint of a British invasion. So they changed the name of a festival of English, Irish, Scottish and Welsh design -- 200 events starting Sunday and running through Oct. 28 -- from ''UKinNY'' to ''UKwithNY.''

title: Broadway Shows Rebound, But With Fewer Tourists
description: One month after being emptied by the World Trade Center attacks, Broadway theaters are showing signs of bouncing back to near normal attendance, according to new figures from the League of American Theaters and Producers. The numbers reflect a stronger than usual turnout by New Yorkers and suburbanites, whose boosterism has helped compensate for a drop in theatergoing tourists from outside the area.

title: Arrest in Texas Murder Case May Have a New York Angle
description: The police in Galveston, Tex., are trying to determine whether a suspect charged with murdering and dismembering a 71-year-old man there is a member of the wealthy and influential Durst real estate family in New York, the authorities said.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Acquisition Reconsidered
description: The WPP Group, the big advertising company, has asked regulators to let it walk away from its proposed acquisition of the Tempus Group, a media-buying agency, on the ground that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks caused a material adverse change in Tempus's business prospects. Tempus will have a chance to respond to WPP's arguments before regulators make a ruling. WPP's bid of 434 million ($629.3 million) topped a rival bid from Havas of France. Havas has since walked away from the deal. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: B-2 Bombers Return From 'Other Side of the Globe'
description: Talk about your long day at the office. Two-man crews from Whiteman Air Force Base here flew what officials say were the longest combat sorties in history this week, logging 44 straight hours in the world's most expensive aircraft, the B-2 bomber, to help open the attacks in Afghanistan.

title: Justice Dept. Takeover of Terror Prosecutions Concerns U.S. Attorney
description: The decision to shift authority over potential criminal prosecutions stemming from the Sept. 11 terror attacks from New York to Washington has upset and frustrated law enforcement officials who have investigated Osama bin Laden for nearly a decade.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Trinidad And Tobago: Elections Set
description: After months of political discord, Prime Minister Basdeo Panday has called for national elections on Dec. 10. The move was in anticipation of a confidence vote by the opposition People's National Movement. Mr. Panday's United National Congress won a slim Parliamentary margin earlier this year, but it was overshadowed when the opposition contested two of his party's Parliamentary seats because the winners held dual citizenship. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: A Post-Dorm Take, From Some Alumni
description: The Rhode Island School of Design has gone entrepreneurial. RISD/Works, a retail store selling work by alumni and faculty, opened last week in a Victorian bank building in historic downtown Providence. ''This is a way to provide visibility for what RISD is all about,'' said Roger Mandle, the school's president. Mr. Mandle says his is the first school of art and design to open a shop like this in the United States.

title: 3 Win Nobel for Better Chemical Reactions
description: Two Americans and a Japanese were awarded this year's Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing more efficient chemical reactions to produce many medicines, including L-dopa, the standard treatment for Parkinson's disease.

title: After Meeting, Asia-Pacific Health Ministers Vow to Fight AIDS
description: After their first meeting on the issue, health ministers from nearly all Asian-Pacific countries pledged today to devote more resources to the problem of H.I.V./AIDS, which has recently exploded in the region.

title: The Big City; Damage, And Now, Collateral
description: NEW YORK'S spirit of unity may be fraying in the mayoral race, but it was wonderfully intact at Gov. George E. Pataki's office in Midtown on Tuesday afternoon. He and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani were joined by labor and business leaders all fervently united in the belief that they could all use more money.

title: Time to End That Infallible Attitude in Entertainment
description: So many front-page pronouncements from the entertainment industry, and so many sotto voce calculations. What do audiences want? What do we owe them, for God's sake? What are they willing to spend their money and time on now? I'm content that ''Collateral Damage'' has been returned to the studio vaults, at least for a time, but I had planned to avoid it long before Sept. 11. Anyway, are the producers and directors and writers responsible for the basic Arnold Schwarzenegger persona likely to change it radically?

title: Palestinians Still Stunned by Shooting by Their Own Police
description: The Palestinian authorities have swept the streets clear of the detritus of a deadly protest here on Monday: the stones, the bullet casings and the burning tires. But they cannot sweep away the anger, now directed squarely and intensely their way.

title: Jordan Will Play After All
description: Michael Jordan said he would start Washington's first two preseason games, changing his mind hours after saying he would not appear in his first game in a Wizards uniform until Oct. 18.

title: Tyson Not Included In Conference Call
description: Mike Tyson let his camp do the talking yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Venture To Make Products For Doctors
description: The drug maker Pfizer Inc. joined I.B.M. and Microsoft yesterday to announce the official start of Amicore, an independent software and services company that aims to provide office automation products to doctors. The company named Jim Fitzsimmons as president and chief executive and said it had acquired a Connecticut health care software developer, the PenChart Corporation. Amicore enters an already competitive market. WebMD, one of the first companies to try to link doctors and insurance providers over the Web, has not been able to turn a profit, losing more than $800 million in the quarter ended June 30. WebMD and a competing alliance of insurance companies called MedUnite have encountered hurdles in their attempts to streamline the health care industry by linking various participants on the Net. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: A Digital Chair That Can Sense And Relieve the Pain
description: The Inada massage chair, soon to arrive in the United States, harnesses technology that makes the La-Z-Boy seem lazy indeed. Known as a ''medical chair'' in Japan, it uses infrared sensors to scan the user's physique. The chair then calculates the positions of the user's tsubo, pressure points where shiatsu therapists can adjust what they see as the flow of energy in the body.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Blocked From W.T.O.
description: Iran asked, for the third time this year, to start talks on joining the World Trade Organization but was again blocked by the United States. Tehran, which has said it is prepared to expand economic relations and trade, initially asked to start its membership process in 1996. However, lack of consensus among the trade body's 142 members kept even its request off the agenda until last May. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAZEN, WILLIAM H.
description: HAZEN-William H. The Manhattan Institute for Policy Research and its Trustees mourn the passing of William H. Hazen. Bill was a devoted and loyal friend who understood the enormous consequence of ideas & the great responsibilities of citizenship. We shall miss him, and our prayers are with his family.

title: Time to Move the Car
description: It was a tiny dispensation in a month of crisis. Since Sept. 12, the city's suspension of alternate side parking rules has given thousands of car owners one less thing to worry about.

title: Transforming a Fluorescent Glare Into a Guiding Light
description: THEY were once the hallmark of institutional monotony. No more, though: the drab fluorescent tube has been rehabilitated.

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering; The War Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: Rsum Program Makes An Offer of Its Own
description: With unemployment climbing, Individual Software Incorporated is making an offer that someone looking for work might find hard to refuse. The company recently released Version 9.0 of ResumeMaker Deluxe and says it can guarantee that its customers will create a better rsum to find a better job within 90 days -- or they will get their money back. More than a collection of standard CV templates, ResumeMaker lets users check wage ranges, offers tips on negotiating a salary and includes 500 warm-up interview questions and a built-in search engine that patrols the Web looking for job openings. ResumeMaker Deluxe 9.0 sells for $39.95 and will work with all versions of Windows from 95 to XP. The program can be bought in stores or downloaded from www.individualsoftware.com. With rsum firmly in hand, the job seeker can concentrate on important pre-interview matters like checking for coffee stains on the lapel and open buttons. J. D. Biersdorfer

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lower Alloways Creek: Power Plant Security
description: National Guard combat troops have started patrolling four nuclear-power plants that provide about one-quarter of New Jersey's peak power requirements. Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco ordered the deployment Sunday, after the terrorist attacks last month and the beginning of the bombing in Afghanistan. The troops, from units in Mount Holly and Vineland, joined existing private security guards on Monday at the three plants here -- Salem I and II, and the Hope Creek -- and the Oyster Creek plant in Forked River. The four units are capable of producing 3,800 megawatts of electricity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Nursing Home Larceny Charged
description: A Queens nursing home was supplied with unlicensed nurses, ''putting the health of those residents at risk,'' Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said yesterday. No patient is known to have been endangered, but an investigation is continuing. Ten people -- including Elise Pierre and Lovely Pierre, the husband and wife who headed the employment agency that referred the nurses -- were charged with grand larceny and other crimes. The home, Holliswood Care Center at 195-44 Woodhull Avenue in Hollis, paid $200,000 in salaries and placement fees. Donna Este-Green, the lawyer for the Pierres, declined to comment.

title: New Bomb Raids Near Kabul and Refugees Flee Kandahar
description: The heaviest airstrikes of the United States-led campaign continued against Afghanistan for a fifth day this morning as new bombing raids were made near Kabul, the capital. As a result of the attacks thousands of civilians were reported fleeing Kandahar, the ruling Taliban's spiritual base.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Georgia Supreme Court's decision that electrocution was unconstitutionally cruel and unusual punishment misstated the legal situation of Timothy Carl Dawson, one of two men whose cases were at issue. While he has been charged with four murders, he has not been convicted and sentenced to death.

title: PC Leaves More Desk Space And More Legroom
description: Those wowed by sleek desktop computers have a new machine to salivate over. This week, I.B.M. announced remodeled versions of its NetVista X flat-panel computers, already the gold standard in understated flat-screen design. The NetVista X41 comes with a Pentium 4-based C.P.U. nestled in a small space directly behind the flat-panel monitor, making it look as though your C.P.U. has gone missing. It now offers a choice of 15- or 17-inch thin film transistor, or T.F.T., displays as well as a new embedded security chip that protects software and data.

title: Sojo Gets the Call
description: Luis Sojo left Yankee Stadium Tuesday afternoon after the team's workout wondering if the final days of his career would be spent sitting next to Manager Joe Torre as an observer, his last chance to play ended by the numbers of the postseason roster cut. But by late Tuesday Torre had let Sojo know he had a roster spot, a decision that Sojo conceded surprised him.

title: Giambi And Long Provide A's Power
description: Through the first three innings last night, the Oakland Athletics played fundamentally sound baseball. They moved runners up, hit to the right side at the right time and did all the little things that showed a new level of experience. But they also had only a precarious one-run lead over the Yankees to show for it.

title: $850 Million for Charity, Not Centrally Monitored
description: A month after the terror attacks in New York City, a system for distributing some $850 million in charitable donations is fast emerging. It is a system that largely rejects centralized decision-making, depending instead on individual relief groups to collaborate informally on how best to help victims with a wide range of needs. It is also one that is rapidly expanding the notion of who deserves aid to include recipients well beyond the families of those killed or injured.

title: Court Shields President Chirac From Corruption Inquiries
description: France's highest court of appeal today granted President Jacques Chirac broad presidential immunity while in office, effectively derailing efforts by five investigating magistrates to question him on a range of corruption allegations dating from his time as mayor of Paris.

title: Counting the Minutes
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil, Paraguay: Oviedo Extradition Blocked
description: A federal judge has temporarily blocked the extradition to Paraguay of that country's former military strongman, Gen. Lino Oviedo, saying that he has not received due process on his request for refugee status. General Oviedo, detained in Brazil last year, is being sought in his homeland on charges that he helped organize the 1999 assassination of Vice President Luis Mara Argaa. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Days Are Normal in Kabul, But Nights Are Terrifying
description: For the people of Kabul, life under American bombardment has fallen into a slow, predictable and terrifying routine.

title: SMUCKER TO BUY 2 PROCTER & GAMBLE BRANDS
description: The J. M. Smucker Company, the maker of jams and jellies, agreed to buy Procter & Gamble's top-selling Jif peanut butter and Crisco cooking oils for about $675 million. Procter & Gamble, the largest maker of household goods, will spin off the businesses to shareholders, who will then be paid with Smucker shares. Procter & Gamble shareholders will own 53 percent of Smucker after the transaction is completed, the companies said. Adding the No. 1 peanut butter and shortening in the United States will increase Smucker's sales to about $1.3 billion a year, Smucker said. Procter & Gamble is selling the brands as part of a plan to reduce the number of products it carries to focus on faster-growing cosmetics and health care lines, including Cover Girl makeup. Procter & Gamble is spinning off Jif and Crisco first rather than selling them outright to take advantage of tax laws that allow it to avoid paying capital gains taxes on the sale.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PORTNOY, MORRIS B.
description: PORTNOY-Morris B. 10/11/16 to 5/11/85. A loved and loving man. Carol, Mark, Susanna, Mike and Pete

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From dining in New Orleans to touring Malaysia, readers share their insights and answer other readers' questions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTANZA, DIGNA A.
description: COSTANZA-Digna A. On September 11, 2001 of Woodside, NY. A victim of the World Trade Center disaster. Beloved wife of John. Loving daughter of Uriel & Albertina Rivera. Dear sister of Ingrid and Uriel D. Rivera. Memorial Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, corner Ascan Avenue and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Saturday, October 13, 2001 at 3:30 PM. Donations may be made to Red Cross of Greater NY P.O. Box 3756 New York, NY 10008.

title: 7 Formats? Sorting Out The Camcorders
description: IN 1993 Scott Billups became the first person on the planet to shoot, edit and transmit a television program entirely in a digital format. But he risked breaking his back in doing so.

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering
description: To the Editor:

title: Mourning the Loss of the Prewar Superficial Values
description: THERE was a time -- it is celebrated and scorched in the movie ''Dinner Rush'' -- when New Yorkers stood in line at the restaurant of the moment and ate pumpkin risotto, and if the noise was deafening, who cared, because nobody listened anyway.

title: European Commission Approves Aid for Airlines
description: The European Commission said today that it would allow member states to help European airlines recover from the turmoil after the attacks on Sept. 11, but it ruled out further government assistance for airlines whose problems predated the attacks.

title: Viewing Mass Destruction Through a Microscope
description: GERMS

title: One Month Later: The Ways of Remembering; The War Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Vows to Avenge Victims of Attack on the Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  The victims of the attack on the Pentagon were mourned and honored today as President Bush vowed that their deaths would be avenged, just as surely as an older generation of Americans avenged the bloodshed of Pearl Harbor.

title: A Shop for Everything, From Perfect Sheets to Thirties Chic : London Gets Boutique Fever
description: LONDON  From Chelsea to Covent Garden, London's retail scene is buzzing with new boutiques featuring everything from fashion by young designers to unique denim to that perfect pair of pure white sheets.

title: Hatchette Trying to Shed His Invisibility Cloak
description: His agent has talked to the Jets, and Coach Herman Edwards has also had a sit-down with Matthew Hatchette. The message has been the same: Hatchette is doing nothing wrong, and he has to be patient with his role in the Jets' offense.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the ''What's Doing Around Town'' column of the arts pages on Monday about ''In Memoriam,'' an exhibition at the New-York Historical Society that pays tribute to men and women in uniform who were lost on Sept. 11, misstated the museum's address. It is 170 Central Park West, not 17.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Daily News photographer and reporter who the police said were stopped as they approached the Rye Lake reservoir while working on a report about the security of the New York City water supply paraphrased imprecisely from a remark by Ken Frydman, a spokesman for the newspaper. While he confirmed most of the police account, he did not acknowledge that the journalists had intended to climb a fence around the reservoir.

title: Networks Agree to U.S. Request To Edit Future bin Laden Tapes
description: The five major television news organizations reached a joint agreement yesterday to follow the suggestion of the White House and abridge any future videotaped statements from Osama bin Laden or his followers to remove language the government considers inflammatory.

title: Operating Profit Up at SunTrust
description: SunTrust Banks Inc. said today that third-quarter profit from operations rose 6.7 percent, to $354.3 million, as higher fee income offset a rise in loan losses.

title: With Anthrax Fears, Bayer Is to Lift Antibiotic Output
description: Bayer, the German drug company, said yesterday that it would increase production of its antibiotic Cipro, which is the only medicine specifically approved for the treatment of inhaled anthrax.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Cuts At Optus
description: The telecommunications company Cable and Wireless Optus lowered its profit and sales forecasts and said it would cut 3 percent of its work force. Optus, which was acquired last month by Singapore Telecommunications, hopes to save $50 million by the end of the fiscal year on March 31, but expects its profit to be down significantly from the prior year. Optus will lay off 350 people and more layoffs are possible. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUGHTON, NORRIS
description: HOUGHTON-Norris. December 26, 1909-October 9, 2001. Theater man extraordinary and evangel for all arts at all learning levels, he never lost Hoosier energy, thespian charm, educator's loyalty to the art in himself. Author and editor of more than a dozen theater related (reprinted) books, his engaging writing and teaching style linked stagecraft expertise with humane values. Off-Broadway pioneer (Phoenix Theater), ''Arts, Education, Americans'' advocate (1976 ''Coming To Our Senses'' Panel Report), scholarly globetrotter from Vassar, SUNY Purchase on fellowships from Guggenheim, Rockefeller, Bingham, NEA and other sources, he made friends worldwide for theater and art as inspired quests. Funeral 2PM October 15, First Presbyterian, NYC, 5th Avenue and West 12th. Contributions to Community Funds Inc. for Norris Houghton Theatre Fund, 2 Park Avenue, NYC 10016.

title: PlayStation Shatters Transatlantic Mark
description: Steve Fossett and the nine-man crew aboard his maxi-catamaran PlayStation roared into the English Channel yesterday morning and shattered the 11-year-old transatlantic speed sailing record. PlayStation set out from New York early last Friday afternoon.

title: Florida Inquiry Finds Anthrax In Third Person
description: Federal officials announced tonight that a third person in South Florida had tested positive for exposure to anthrax and said forcefully that their efforts had become a criminal investigation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Spy Trial Begins
description: Prosecutors closed the courtroom as the espionage trial of a physicist from Krasnoyarsk, Valentin Danilov, resumed after a break, the Interfax news service reported. The state accuses Mr. Danilov of spying for China, where he was under contract to perform research for a Chinese company. Mr. Danilov and fellow scientists are urging a public inquiry into the charges, saying his work was unclassified. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Starbucks Stock
description: Shares in Starbucks Coffee Japan, the local subsidiary of the Seattle chain, surged on the first day of trading. The stock closed at $581 a share, 9 percent above its initial offering price of $531. The stock is traded on Nasdaq Japan in Osaka. Demand for the stock was strong as it opened at $664 a share and traded as high as $692 before settling back. The company will use the 17.9 billion yen ($149 million) it raised to add 180 new shops to its 300-store chain over the next three years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Mostly Clear Weather Helps Allied Effort
description: Afghanistan's climate, although as harsh and varied as its terrain, is likely to favor American and British attackers more than it endangers them, experts on the country and its climate say.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Food-Price Controls
description: The government of President Robert Mugabe has reintroduced price controls on basic foodstuffs to appease disaffected consumers. Prices have soared lately, the state news agency said, and soaring inflation, unemployment and growing hunger have fueled support for the leading opposition party, particularly in the cities, as the nation braces for presidential elections expected next year. Officials said the government would control the prices of bread, cornmeal, sugar, cooking oil, detergent and meat. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: London Journal; This Mild Schoolboy, Lost in the Islamic Inferno
description: Until he encountered Muslim refugees from Bosnia's war in the early 1990's, Ahmed Omar Sheikh seemed immune to the crucible fires of Islamic extremism.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Ooh, Circa '94

description: To the Editor:

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: NO ISLAMIC CONDEMNATION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NYDORF, SEYMOUR
description: NYDORF-Seymour. Of Port Washington, NY, on September 30, 2001. Loving husband of Elsie. Father of Amy (Eric), Ethan, and Roy (Terry). Grandfather of Alana. Advertising designer and fine artist. Included in the Artists for Victory ''America in the War'' exhibition (1943). Solo painting exhibition at Ward Eggleston in New York (1966) favorably reviewed in Art News, New York Herald-Tribune, and Arts Magazine. Work represented in the Library of Congress Print Collection.

title: Lucas Still Hurt By Jets Parting
description: The former Jet quarterback Ray Lucas, now with the Dolphins, can't quite hide his bitterness toward his old team.

title: A New Reality Wrapped Up in Silk, Paint and Leather
description: BACKSTAGE at this year's French Designer Showhouse was like a scene from Luis Buuel's film ''The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie,'' the surreal 1972 classic that follows a band of friends through a series of outrageous plot twists -- infidelity, assassination attempts, armies of unannounced dinner guests -- that fail to undermine the characters' unflappable self-control.

title: 14 Arrests in Smuggling of Afghan Refugees
description: Police officials across Central Europe have dismantled a people-smuggling gang that has brought tens of thousands of Afghan refugees into the European Union, the Czech police said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENTRY, BRAD
description: GENTRY-Brad, 47. On Tuesday, October 2, 2001. Beloved brother of Carol Rausch, brother-in-law of Carl, uncle of Adam and devoted life partner of Joe. Formerly of Baltimore, MD and last residing in New York City in Fire Island Pines. Served as Director of Merchandise Planning for Saks Fifth Avenue. Fought his long illness with dignity and courage. A kind gentleman and good natured, he will forever stay in our memories. We will always love him. Private service was held at Raynor and D'Andrea Funeral Home in Sayville, NY. A celebration of his life will be held in July 2002 in Fire Island. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Brad's name to your favorite charity.

title: Steinbrenner Voices Displeasure With Umpires' Calls
description: Alfonso Soriano dived headfirst into third base last night and Eric Chavez may or may not have tagged him before Soriano's hand touched white. Umpire Rick Reed called Soriano out, and before Soriano finished wiping the dirt off his uniform, George Steinbrenner had dived headfirst into General Manager Brian Cashman's box to commiserate and complain.

title: A Slow Turn as the Briquettes Glow
description: Nobody can accuse Brett Neveu's likable dark comedy "The Last Barbecue" of being talky. Most of the time its five characters speak in short, seemingly innocuous sentences ("Are you getting bit up?" "No." "I could light a citronella candle." "I'm fine." "Here."). They seem largely ill at ease with one another. And it's amazing how much they convey.

title: Halloween, Haunted; Real-Life Horror Overshadows a Mock-Sinister Ritual
description: Demons are in New York City. There is evil in the wispy cloud still hanging above the jagged ruins of the twin towers, in the sight of rescue workers wearing gas masks and people lining up for antibiotics in fear of anthrax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONNELL, BRIAN
description: McDONNELL-Brian, N.Y.P.D. Police Officer. Tragically lost in the line of duty on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center disaster. Survived by his beloved wife Margaret and cherished children Katie and Thomas, dear brothers Robert and Kevin, devoted sister Alicia, and his loving mother Ann Claire. Brian was a loyal friend to many, and he will be sorely missed. His command was Emergency Service Squad #

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: County Ban On Thermometers
description: The Westchester county executive, Andrew J. Spano, has signed a bill banning the sale of thermometers containing mercury, as well as the use of mercury gauges for testing gas pressure. The law stems from an incident last year in which a Tarrytown family had to be evacuated from their home when plumbers broke a mercury gauge and tried to vacuum up the mercury, converting it into a dangerous vapor. On Oct. 19 and 20, county residents can exchange mercury-based thermometers for free digital ones at Franklin D. Roosevelt State Park in Yorktown, Mr. Spano said Tuesday. Next spring, when the law goes into effect, violators will face fines of $150.

title: Israel, America and the Fight Against Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Drawing Closer to an Old Friend
description: THE other night, standing outside a Broadway theater during intermission, I found myself looking up at the Empire State Building. The top of the building was shrouded in fog. I've seen it that way hundreds of times, but this time I panicked, imagining for a split second that the floors I couldn't see were missing.

title: Sailors' Extended Absence Hits a Virginia Town Hard
description: Like thousands of other people in this seaside city, Jim Svec had been looking forward to October. This is the month that the aircraft carrier Enterprise was supposed to return with its crew after half a year at sea.

title: Indians Win and Embrace Role as Underdogs
description: As an underdog, the Cleveland Indians should be a tough sell. They are a veteran team with a bulging payroll whose players have seen it all. But they have never won 116 games in a season, as the Seattle Mariners just did, so they understand their position. This is a new role for the Indians, who are finding that change can be healthy.

title: President Is Using TV Show and the Public in Combination to Combat Terrorism
description: Osama bin Laden skillfully used television news programs to deliver his defiant message.

title: Preserving the Voices of the Twin Towers
description: AS they watched news accounts of the World Trade Center disaster, a detail caught the attention of Davia Nelson and Nikki Silva, two independent radio producers in California.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a dispute between President Bush and Congress over access to classified information rendered a phrase incorrectly in a comment from the president. He said, ''It is unacceptable to leak classified information when we have troops at risk.'' He did not say ''when American forces are at risk overseas.''

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Gun-Tracking Incomplete
description: Not all the background checks of criminals whose guns have been confiscated are reaching a special state task force, the head of the task force said yesterday. The checks are intended to track the circulation of weapons in Connecticut. The chairman of the Statewide Weapons Trafficking Task Force, Police Chief Thomas Sweeney of Glastonbury, said results of a recent report indicated erratic levels of firearm seizures and checks. This suggests some chiefs may be turning the checks over to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms instead of to him, Chief Sweeney said. The task force has asked all local police chiefs to report directly to the task force the results of background checks. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: When a Plane Is as Good As a Flag
description: Moss, which has set a standard for home design since it opened in 1994, is not ordinarily the place to buy conventional Americana. But after Sept. 11, Franklin Getchell, an owner, said he was eager to find something for the ''sophisticated patriot.'' Murray Moss, the other owner, found the 18-inch scale model of Air Force One, and the store has sold more than 40 planes in the last two and a half weeks. The Boeing VC-137, above, was retired in 1998; the new VC-25A Air Force One is also available. $120 at Moss, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Schundler and McGreevey Meet In Combative New Jersey Debate
description: Bret D. Schundler laced into James E. McGreevey last night in a spirited first debate between the candidates for governor of New Jersey, saying that Mr. McGreevey would raise taxes if elected and suggesting that he lacked the courage to say no to the many groups that have endorsed his campaign.

title: Hispanics Near Whites in Voter Turnout, Study Says
description: Challenging traditional thinking about political participation in New York City, the gap between white and Hispanic turnout narrowed in the mayoral primary election two weeks ago, a new analysis of voting patterns has shown.

title: Seeing Digital Pictures On Screen Without a PC
description: Buyers of two new digital cameras will be able to pull out their memory cards and plug them into a DVD player for viewing on their television sets. The Kodak EasyShare DX3700 and DX3215 are the first products created by Kodak with the Zoran Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., which makes digital camera and DVD player processors.

title: What Do You Want to Sell?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Nobel in Literature Goes to Naipaul, an Explorer of Exile
description: LONDON, Oct. 11  V. S. Naipaul, the eloquent Trinidad-born English writer who uses fiction, nonfiction and sometimes a fusion of the two to explore themes of exile, dislocation, and the agonizing dilemmas of postcolonial societies, was awarded the 2001 Nobel Prize in Literature today by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm.

title: 900 Workers In Software To Lose Jobs
description: Computer Associates International, the world's fourth-largest software company, said yesterday that it would lay off 900 employees, or 5 percent of its work force, in the face of slowing corporate spending on technology.

title: Rivals Worry About Access As Verizon Seeks Buffer
description: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, is raising the ire of competitors who worry that its efforts to increase security in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks will restrict their access to Verizon work locations.

title: Plumbing the Mysteries of Inheritance
description: A sampling of work by V. S. Naipaul:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about injuries resulting from the use of beanbag weapons by the Los Angeles police misstated the affiliation of the researchers who reported on them. They are at the University of Southern California, not the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREITBART, ROBERT S.
description: BREITBART-Robert S. Age 87, Died suddenly on October 11, 2001. He was a graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School. He was an attorney practicing law since 1936. He was also a professor at Pace University teaching law and taxation from 1945 through 1995. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend, Ellen. Cherished father of Carol Furst and Barbara Bader and sons-in-law Robert Furst and Gary Bader. Adored grandfather of Jennifer and Joseph Casey, Alison and Dana Furst, and Daniel and Amy Bader. Services on Friday, October 12, 1PM at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment will follow at Shaarey Pardes Cemetery in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Afghan Region's Politics Snarl U.S. War Plan
description: After five days of American airstrikes on Afghanistan, the goals set by President Bush in committing military power -- rooting out Al Qaeda terrorists and the Taliban government with them -- have become deeply entangled in the murky politics that have kept Afghans fighting for more than 20 years.

title: LONG WAR IS SEEN
description: The United States and Britain made clear today that they are marshaling for a long engagement in Afghanistan, stretching into next summer and including the possible use of ground forces.

title: At Harvard, Images in a Distinctive African Style
description: The several buildings and collections that make up the Harvard University Art Museums encompass riches beyond count, though the art of Africa isn't among them. Not that Harvard owns no African art. It owns plenty, but most of it is housed, as it has been for well over a century, in a separate on-campus institution, the Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, where it stays.

title: Lydia Estelle Bravo: A Passion for Food
description: The night before the planes hit, Lydia Bravo cooked a pot of ribollita, the Tuscan stew of beans and greens. She and her fiance, Anthony Bengivenga -- "she called me Antonio" -- opened a bottle of Sangiovese. They had just returned from a week in Mexico. Ms. Bravo, a nurse at Marsh & McLennan, returned to work on Tuesday, Sept. 11.

title: Screening Company Is Faulted Again
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  The security company that was fined $1.2 million last year and put on probation for hiring convicted felons to screen passengers at Philadelphia International Airport has continued to hire screeners without checking whether they have criminal records, a United States attorney says.

title: Some Pearls Of Wisdom And Delight
description: On the subject of pearls, ancient Romans held them to be the frozen tears of oysters or the gods. Greeks attributed pearls to lightning strikes at sea. Then there was the dew theory, espoused in the first century A.D. by the learned but often fanciful Roman Pliny the Elder, who wrote:

title: Damon's Early Steal Gives A's Fast Start
description: In the first game, the Oakland Athletics stole a page from the Yankees' playbook.

title: Anthrax Found in NBC News Aide
description: An assistant to the NBC anchor Tom Brokaw has tested positive for anthrax infection more than two weeks after she opened a threatening letter addressed to Mr. Brokaw that contained a white powder, officials said yesterday.

title: To Stay Alive, Snipe, Snipe
description: Before the dance, there is the walk.

title: NBC Says New York Employee Tests Positive for Anthrax
description: An NBC News employee in New York has the skin form of anthrax in a case that was detected in tests done after the network received mail containing a suspicious powder, authorities said Friday.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Murdoch Expects Flat Year
description: Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, said the immediate effects of the Sept. 11 attacks cost the company at least $100 million. In the two weeks after the tragedy, advertising bookings were virtually nonexistent, Mr. Murdoch told the annual general meeting in Adelaide. However, despite the global economic downturn and an uncertain advertising market, results this fiscal year will be flat against the prior year, he predicted. But promising signs have emerged, he said. Television revenue bookings are higher than in recent months. Also, the company is in talks with the Hughes Electronics Corporation over its satellite unit, DirecTV. There is a 50-50 chance a deal will be struck, Mr. Murdoch said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMOLENSKI, JOSEPH R., SR.
description: SMOLENSKI-Joseph R., Sr., of New Hyde Park, New York, Jamesport, New York, and Jensen Beach, Florida, passed on quietly after a long illness on October 10, 2001. Devoted and loving husband of Amy (nee Kasperowicz). Supportive and adoring father of Joseph R., Jr. and his wife Janet, and Carol Elizabeth Small and her husband Jay. Proud and loving grandfather of Joseph R. III, Dina, Diana, and Lisa Smolenski, and Hannah Small. Cherished and loving brother of Virginia Brachocki and the late Stephen P. He was preceded in death by parents Joseph and Fannie of Hempstead. He was the owner and president of the New Hyde Park Funeral Home. He was also a founder of State Bank of Long Island, exempt member of the New Hyde Park Fire Department-Enterprise Company, past president of the Kiwanis Club of New Hyde Park, charter member of B.P.O.E. #

title: Honor for Former Yankee
description: Frank Tepedino played parts of five seasons with the Yankees in the late 1960's and early 1970's, but somehow he managed to accumulate only 77 at-bats in 55 games.

title: Now It's Time For the Yankees To Start Sweating
description: The legions rose repeatedly at Yankee Stadium last night, imploring a generation of Yankees to respond as it has responded so often the past five years. ''Paulie! Paulie!'' the fans chanted, and they cheered for Tino and Derek and Bernie, begging and cajoling. And a generation of Yankees who have won three consecutive World Series titles, four in the past five years, had nothing more to give.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Governor's Aide Avoids Prison
description: Shane Hedges, a former aide to Gov. Judy Martz, was sentenced to community service and six months in a halfway house for driving while drunk and causing the death of Paul Sliter, the state House majority leader, when his sport utility vehicle rolled down an embankment. Mr. Hedges, 27, pleaded guilty last month to negligent homicide, but pleas by his friends, including Mr. Sliter's widow, Elaine, helped persuade Judge Thomas Honzel not to send Mr. Hedges to prison. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: They're Thieves, but Sweet
description: Billy Bob Thornton, left, and Bruce Willis play a pair of charming bank robbers in Barry Levinson's new heist comedy, ''Bandits.''

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: False Anthrax Threats
description: About 800 employees of the Connecticut State Department of Environmental Protection here were evacuated yesterday after a powdery substance was found with a written threat that it was anthrax. But the F.B.I. said agents found nothing dangerous. In Canton, a water treatment plant was reopened yesterday after closing Tuesday when a dog was found dead in the water. The dog was deliberately drowned, a local official said, and not poisoned by the water or another nearby substance.

title: Sci-Fi Slapstick, With Spacemen Bursting Into Song
description: The unremittingly eccentric science-fiction musical ''The American Astronaut'' is not a picture that is likely to have you walking out of the theater murmuring that there's nothing else like it. What you may say after sitting through it is that you've never seen so many kinds of leftovers crammed between the same two slices of bread. Its purview is emphatically perverse, a salute to the Midnight Movie, a cultural land mass that spawned John Waters and David Lynch.

title: A Fighter Pilot, a Math Wiz, A Boy Who Loved School
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the Pentagon:

title: Theresa Munson: Traveling Grandmother
description: Theresa Munson -- Terry to friends -- was a gypsy with her daughter, Christine Hayes, and her granddaughter, Kaitlyn, hitting the road to places like Walt Disney World in Florida or Pennsylvania Dutch country.

title: Frankfurt Journal; Can't Say That? Muzzling the Modern Germans
description: In German television news, Ulrich Wickert is about as close as anybody here can come to Dan Rather. As anchor for 10 years of the nightly news on ARD, one of Germany's two main public networks, Mr. Wickert has attracted big followings with steadiness, style and wit.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, INGA
description: JOSEPH-Inga. Died October 9 from injuries sustained during the September 11 attack on the World Trade Center. She leaves behind family and friends in her native Berlin and in New York City. A New Yorker for over 3 decades, she revelled in the great music of a great city. Services Saturday 7 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made in Inga's memory the Metropolitan Opera Guild, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMPSON, IRVING
description: SIMPSON-Irving. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Loving father of Robert and Phyllis Simpson and Nancy and Thomas Blank. Dear brother of Cynthia Kaplan. Cherished grandfather of David and Jeffrey Blank. Services today 12 Noon at ''The Riverside'', 21 West Broad St, Mt Vernon, NY. Contributions may be made to The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 1950 Sawtelle Blvd, Suite 328, Los Angeles, CA 90025.

description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Warmth, but No Aid Commitment, for Pataki in Washington
description: A month after a terrorist attack destroyed the World Trade Center, Gov. George E. Pataki made the rounds in the capital today to drum up support for a $54 billion plan not only to resurrect the destroyed buildings, but to buttress the state's battered economy as well.

title: Florida Is Developing New Rules For Counting Mismarked Ballots
description: Because of the contentious 2000 presidential election, when thousands of voters' ballots were rejected or contested, Florida officials are developing new rules to guide the review of ballots in the next election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, ELINOR M.
description: PARKER-Elinor M. Died Wilmington, DE, October 9, 2001, age 95. Former resident New York City and Morristown, New Jersey. BA in English Lit. Bryn Mawr College. Forty-two years with Charles Scribner's Sons, retiring as Editor, VP & Director. Author of 16 books including ''Cooking For One'', a biography of Queen Elizabeth II, and several poetry anthologies. Served on the Altar Guild at St. James Episcopal Church. Interests were sailing, hiking, knitting and needlework and classical music. She enjoyed travel, especially to the British Isles. Survived by 3 generations of nieces and nephews. Services at Christ Church Christiana Hundred, Wilmington October 16, 2001 at 1:00PM. Burial at Northeast Harbor, ME. at a later date. Please no flowers, contributions to Bryn Mawr College, 101 N. Merion Avenue, Bryn Mawr, PA. 19010-2899. For further information Chandler Funeral Home.

description: THERMO ELECTRON, the No. 1 maker of medical laboratory instruments, said it would spin off its Viasys Healthcare unit as a dividend to shareholders.

title: Flow of Afghan Refugees Is Stalled by Pakistan
description: The United Nations refugee agency said today that preparations for an expected influx of Afghan refugees had been stalled by security concerns and restrictions imposed by the government of Pakistan.

title: A Family Stunned When Death Strikes
description: Nanni Moretti's small, touching film ''The Son's Room'' is a portrait of a closely knit Italian family whose contented middle-class existence is shattered with the death of the teenage son, Andrea (Giuseppe Sanfelice), in a scuba-diving accident. As most of us know too well -- especially in light of the events of Sept. 11 -- tragedy has a way of striking out of nowhere, leaving the survivors stunned, grief-stricken, angry and desperately groping for answers and for some stability.

title: To Reassure World, Bush Flies Confidently and Forcefully Without a Net
description: He bit the inside of his cheek and looked tense striding up the red carpet to his lectern under the scrutiny of television lights and an anxious, waiting nation. He blinked nervously when delivering his opening, prepared remarks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASSANANTI, HORACE
description: PASSANANTI - Horace. Taken from us tragically on September 11, 2001. A memorial gathering will be held at Marriott Hotel, Adelphi Room, Hempstead Turnpike, Uniondale, Long Island, Sunday, October 14, 1:00-4:00PM.

title: Questionable Allies
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniel Lugo: Too Proud Not to Work
description: Daniel Lugo's asthma was acting up, and his physician had detected the advent of prostate cancer and was debating the most effective course of treatment. Everybody gave him the same advice: leave his job as a Summit security guard at the World Trade Center and concentrate on getting healthy. But Mr. Lugo, 45, didn't listen.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: 'Rebirthing' Mother Pleads Guilty
description: The mother of an adopted girl who died in a therapy known as rebirthing has agreed to plead guilty to child abuse in exchange for no jail time and a promise that her conviction will be expunged if she commits no crimes in the next four years. The mother, Jeane Newmaker, participated in the therapy, in which her 10-year-old daughter, Candace, was covered in blankets and pillows to simulate a womb and was told to push her way out. The ''rebirthing'' is meant to create a bond between mother and child. The two therapists who conducted the session were sentenced to prison terms of 16 years. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: The Phoenix Rises
description: To the Editor:

title: Pressure Builds on Two Nations Over Groups Linked to Terror
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Bush administration vowed today to seize the assets of more individuals it says support terrorism, including a prominent businessman from Saudi Arabia, a United States ally whose reluctance to move against people and groups with ties to Osama bin Laden has become a politically sensitive issue.

title: Why, Big Brother, Why?
description: Since the Supreme Court voted to reinstate capital punishment in 1976, more than 730 people have been executed in the United States. While some opponents of the death penalty work steadily for its repeal, the executions have become part of life. They are grimly applauded by many people and numbly ignored by others who object -- but not enough to take action or even pay much attention.

title: Roberto Campos, 84, Apostle For the Free Market in Brazil
description: Roberto Campos, one of the most prominent figures in Brazilian economic, intellectual and political life, died of a heart attack at his apartment here late Tuesday. He was 84.

title: As Earnings Plunge, the Market's P/E Ratio Sets a Record
description: THE bubble burst a long time ago, and now stock market valuations are far more reasonable.

title: Schilling Is Making Plans To Pitch With Less Rest
description: Curt Schilling may reappear in the National League division series between the Arizona Diamondbacks and the St. Louis Cardinals sooner than expected.

title: Cupid's Arrows Fall Among the Missiles
description: In the shadow of war, amid destruction and unremitting enmity, what is there to say of life? That it will never be the same? Or that life goes on?

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISENSTEIN, ALVIN GORDON
description: EISENSTEIN-Alvin Gordon Remembered always by his loving family and friends October 12, 1915-October 26, 198

title: Jesus N. Cabezas: Stone Face, Warm Heart
description: Jesus N. Cabezas was full of whimsy and scrappiness. At his daughter's wedding, he cast his chiseled Ecuadorean features into a stone-faced glare as he posed for a picture. "He called it his picture face," said his daughter, Blanca I. Bowers, laughing. "You'll see a lot of pictures of him looking really serious. But if you know him you laugh, because he's just being silly."

title: White House Seeks to Limit Transcripts
description: The Bush administration asked newspapers yesterday to refrain from publishing full transcripts of statements issued by Osama bin Laden or his followers, asserting that such statements could inflame Mr. bin Laden's followers and may contain coded messages that could incite attacks on American targets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVAK, JUDITH IRIS
description: NOVAK-Judith Iris. Age 58 died October 8, 2001 at home after a long, gallant and arduous battle with lung cancer. Devoted daughter of the late Leon H. and Helen Novak. Beloved sister of Ronald and Rose Novak. An inspiring and courageous mother of Vanessa (Joe Kmetz) of Bozeman, Montana and Jillian of New York and Los Angeles. Loving aunt of Mara (Dr. Mitchell Miller) and Leila and great-aunt of Gareth and Zoe. Judy was a graduate of Pratt/NYU & an innovative and witty graphic designer. She lived in Florida for a number of years, but joyfully came home to Manhattan six years ago. She then received an M.A. in Counselling from NYU and had begun to plan for a PsyD at the time of her initial diagnosis. During her illness she continued to paint. The Judiff was forever young and beautiful, gifted and funny, and modest. She was and will always be an endless source of strength for her children, her family, her friends and all who are blessed to have known her. The family will be at home Thursday, Friday and Saturday from 4-8 PM. A memorial service will be held at The National Academy of Design, 1083 5th Avenue at 90th Street, Monday, October 15, at 11:30 AM.

title: Fine for Steinbrenner Seems Most Unlikely
description: George Steinbrenner criticized the umpires, especially Rick Reed, during the Yankees' 5-3 loss to the Oakland Athletics in Game 1 on Wednesday night. But an official with major league baseball said it was most unlikely that the principal owner of the Yankees would be fined for his remarks.

description: Max Keeble's Big Move

title: Empire Blue Cross Takes Space in Midtown
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, one of the insurance companies displaced by the attack on the World Trade Center, has found a new home in Midtown, becoming yet another company forced to move its big chunk of offices away from the financial district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, MURRAY
description: SCHWARTZ - Murray. Loving brother of Jack Lawrence, passed away on October 5, 2001. You were loved and will be forever missed. Your dreams will go on, sleep well. Jack Lawrence

title: Mexicans Move to Pry Open Potentially Explosive Files
description: More than a year after Mexicans celebrated the most free national elections in their history, the struggle for democracy has shifted from the ballot box to the most secretive corners of the government.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Games; Racing So Real You'll Need a Tuneup
description: I CAME to the Smokey Mountains racetrack for the view, but I stayed for the racing. Polyphony Digital's racing simulator, Gran Turismo 3 A-spec, is one of the best-looking games ever made for the Sony PlayStation 2, so I chose tracks based on how pretty they were.

title: Metro Matters; Maybe Now, Some Talk Of Issues
description: HISTORY is against him. So are the polls and the political realities of New York. Though he's spent $29 million of his own money so far, Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican candidate for mayor, has to be considered very much the long shot in his race against Mark Green.

title: A Nobel for Mr. Naipaul
description: In the work of V. S. Naipaul, who has just been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature, the reader walks on sure-footed sentences into a place where the ground is suddenly uncertain, the crust thin and broken, the familiar landmarks replaced by eruptions that no one but the author seems to notice. Like many writers, Mr. Naipaul is often a better guide to the world in his prose than in his spoken remarks, which have resulted in accusations of homophobia and racism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, BIANCA
description: LLOYD-Bianca. On October 11, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Loving mother of Julianne and Rafi David, and George and Illana Lloyd. Cherished grandmother of Liron, Daniella, Reuben, Shachar, Elazar and Tal. Devoted daughter of the late Maks and Zofia Stein. Dear sister of the late Jack Stein and sister-in-law Sephora and dear aunt of John and Maxine. Service today, 9AM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to Kadimah Hadassah or West Side Hatzoloh.

title: Anxiety Grows in South Florida as Mystery of Anthrax Cases Lingers
description: With increasing anxiety spreading across South Florida, officials said today that the third person here who tested positive for exposure to anthrax had worked in the mailroom of American Media Inc. alongside one of the two other people who were exposed to the bacteria.

title: Supplements Work to Treat Vision Loss In Elderly
description: High doses of certain dietary supplements provide the first effective treatment for the leading cause of vision loss among the elderly, a new nationwide clinical study has concluded.

title: Alisha Levin: Loved Work and Her Family
description: Alisha Levin lived alone in her own apartment and loved New York -- the lifestyle, the rhythms of the city. She loved her job as vice president for human resources at Fuji Bank. Loved working at the World Trade Center and looking out the window on a clear day. "She hated it when it rained because she couldn't see through the windows," said her aunt Marlene Roseman, who lives in Philadelphia. "She just enjoyed getting up every day and going to work."

title: Steven Cafiero: Marriage, Babies, Red Wine
description: When Steven Cafiero took his girlfriend, Donnamarie Striano, to Las Vegas in August, he wanted her to marry him then and there. She told him she would rather wait until family and friends could be with them. "We were more married than most, because we lived together and we were so happy," she said. "But I only wish I could have fulfilled his every wish."

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose on speculation that OPEC would cut output to keep inventories from swelling as demand slumps. In New York, crude oil for November delivery rose 81 cents, or 3.6 percent, to $23.34 a barrel.

title: Violent and Deadly But Innocent: Hawks
description: The hawk watchers were sitting on folding chairs in the bright sun. From their perch on the top of Hook Mountain in Upper Nyack, N.Y., they had a 360-degree view, up and down the Hudson River and to ridges east and west.

description: BASEBALL

description: LOTTMAN-Evan A. Memorial service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, October 14, 2PM.

title: Lloyd Brown: Doted on His Children
description: Lloyd Brown liked playing basketball with friends and co-workers at Cantor Fitzgerald. He loved playing on the computer. And he also doted on his two children, even though they now lived across the country.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Mayor in Demand

title: Closing Out Yanks Was Just Part of It
description: Jason Isringhausen had just thrown the biggest pitch of his career, freezing Jorge Posada with a perfect fastball on the outside corner to put the Oakland A's two outs away from escaping Yankee Stadium with a stunning two-games-to-none lead in their American League division series against the Yankees. Jason Giambi wandered over from first base, spying the grimaces and gum-chewing that racked the neophyte closer's face, and told him to relax.

title: A Critical Mayoral Race, but Attention Shifts
description: The final two candidates, energized and articulate, agree that the mayoral election in this racially fractured river city is one of the most critical in decades. But the headlines have been bolder for that far-off mayor called Rudy. And the stare of Osama bin Laden seems the only photograph seizing voters' attention.

title: A Crucial Link Between Two Styles of the Paris Avant-Garde
description: Gregarious, curious, comfortably well-off and unflaggingly energetic, the French painter Paul Signac may have been the busiest European artist since Rubens. Painting was the center of his life, but it shared the stage with his activities as a collector, writer, bibliophile, exhibition organizer, Neo-Impressionist proselytizer, and friend to artists from van Gogh to the Fauves. There was also his lifelong passion for left-wing politics, which didn't have much effect on his art, and for sailing, which did. The first of the 30 boats he owned during his lifetime was named ''Manet Zola Wagner''; the second was christened ''Olympia,'' after Manet's painting.

title: 'Grateful Dawg'
description: Directed by Gillian Grisman

title: President Hints He Will Halt War if bin Laden Is Handed Over
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  President Bush said today that United States forces would attack Afghanistan for "as long as it takes" to destroy the Qaeda terrorist network of Osama bin Laden, but he offered to reconsider the military assault on Afghanistan if that country's ruling Taliban would surrender Mr. bin Laden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTONE, MYRA S.
description: GREENSTONE-Myra S. Quietly pased away on October 10, 2001 after a courageous battle with cancer, leaving her cherished husband Jay, her beloved children Michael and Amy, Howard and Brigette, Daniel and Jessica, Scott and Laura, and her beloved grandchildren Jason, Rachel, Justin, Joshua, Brandon and Isabella. Myra possessed true beauty, style, intelligence and grace. As a career-minded woman who committed her life's work to helping others, for the past twelve years Myra devoted her time & resources to the Hackensack University Medical Center, and recently was elected Second Vice Chair of its Board of Governors. Myra also served as Vice President of the United Jewish Community of Bergen County, Chair of the New Jersey Woman's Division of UJA, and President of the Jewish Hospital and Rehabilitation Center of New Jersey. Services Sunday, October 14, 12:30 PM at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey (800) 378-1892. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Hackensack University Medical Center Foundation for the Myra S. Greenstone Memorial Fund will be kindly appreciated.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. The CMJ Music Marathon, the annual music-business convention, began on Wednesday and continues through tomorrow. Its showcase concerts bring multiple bands playing short sets to many of New York City's clubs, and although this year's lineup is reduced and more weighted toward local bands than originally planned, the marathon still offers abundant choices. At events denoted here as ''a CMJ show,'' a limited number of conventioneers will receive free admission with their laminated badges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUGHTON, NORRIS
description: HOUGHTON-Norris. December 26, 1909-October 9, 2001. Theater man extraordinary and evangel for all arts at all learning levels, he never lost Hoosier energy, thespian charm, educator's loyalty to the art in himself. Author and editor of more than a dozen theater related (reprinted) books, his engaging writing and teaching style linked stagecraft expertise with humane values. Off-Broadway pioneer (Phoenix Theater), ''Arts, Education, Americans'' advocate (1976 ''Coming To Our Senses'' Panel Report), scholarly globetrotter from Vassar, SUNY Purchase on fellowships from Guggenheim, Rockefeller, Bingham, NEA and other sources, he made friends worldwide for theater and art as inspired quests. Funeral 2PM October 15, First Presbyterian, NYC, 5th Avenue and West 12th. Contributions to Community Funds Inc. for Norris Houghton Theatre Fund, 2 Park Avenue, NYC 10016.

description: DC Moore

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SALERNO, MARY
description: SALERNO-Mary. A Memorial service will be held at St. Bart's, Chapel, Park Avenue at 51st Street, on October 13 at 11:30 AM.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Olympic Guard Loses Appeal
description: A state appellate court has upheld a lower court's ruling that Richard Jewell, a security guard initially suspected of a bombing at the 1996 Olympics, is a public figure, a setback for Mr. Jewell in his libel suit against The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. The state Court Of Appeals also reversed the lower court's ruling that two reporters for the newspaper must reveal the sources who informed them that Mr. Jewell was a suspect in the bombing. Mr. Jewell was later cleared by federal investigators of any suspicion in the attack. His lawyer said he would appeal to the Georgia Supreme Court. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Into the Homestretch
description: Now that the Democratic Party has finally selected Mark Green as its nominee, the final campaign for mayor of New York City can begin in earnest. There are three and a half weeks to go before the general election on Nov. 6. That should be plenty of time for a serious discussion of the issues, as long as both Mr. Green and his Republican opponent, Michael Bloomberg, are willing to engage in a frank and open debate over who can best revive the city.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Air Traffic Slows
description: Britain's biggest airport operator, BAA, which runs Heathrow near London and Logan in Boston, said cargo volumes slumped 28 percent and passenger traffic on North Atlantic routes fell 38 percent in the three weeks after Sept. 11. BAA's shares fell as much as 2.2 percent but recovered to close 2.4 percent higher at 544 pence. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Greenspan Rejects Idea of Inflation Targets
description: Choosing a specific inflation target for the Federal Reserve to meet would not help the central bank set interest rates, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Interim Executive Named
description: A former Hudson County Democratic chairman began serving as interim county executive on Wednesday, after the resignation last month of Robert C. Janiszewski, left. The interim executive is Bernard M. Hartnett Jr., 72, of Jersey City, a lawyer selected by Democrats to serve pending a special election next November. Mr. Janiszewski cited personal reasons for his resignation, but is reportedly cooperating in a federal corruption investigation. Hudson Republicans lost a lawsuit that would have prompted a special election this November. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: For a while, rumors circulated that JoJo, Jean-Georges Vongerichten's little Upper East Side bistro, might close for good. The prospect of its demise caused genuine distress, which speaks volumes about the hold this little sliver of a restaurant has on its neighborhood. Barely six years old, it's far too young to be an institution, but it is. The Upper East Side without JoJo? Unthinkable.

title: Eddie Futch, Who Trained Fighters His Way, Dies at 90
description: Eddie Futch, who trained six heavyweight champions with a firmness and compassion that inspired the confidence of his fighters and whose boxing roots went back to the Joe Louis era of the 1930's, died Wednesday in Las Vegas. He was 90.

title: Lawrence D. Getzfred: A Navy Man, Bottom to Top
description: Capt. Lawrence D. Getzfred saw a lot of the Navy in his 39 years of service. He saw it from the bottom, when he enlisted out of high school in 1963. And he saw it from the top, as a commander of aircraft squadrons over the Pacific and as an officer in the Navy Command Center at the Pentagon.

title: C.E.O. Takes Charge for the Battery's Displaced
description: FOUR days into homelessness, Donald Scherer, an antsy software executive who categorizes his blood type as C.E.O. positive, was bedeviled by a pair of humble but primal fears the likes of which he, an ambitious upper-middle-class guy with a two-year lease and a valid law degree, had never experienced. Would he and his six-months-pregnant wife, Alyssa, ever reoccupy their two-bedroom apartment in Battery Park City? Why was there zero information about when or if it was safe to go home?

title: Timothy J. Maude: 'The Army Needed Him'
description: After Lt. Gen. Timothy J. Maude ruptured his spleen in an accident at the Pentagon last November, doctors told him to rest for a month and forget about his duties as the Army's deputy chief of staff for personnel. He didn't listen.

title: Few Palestinians Back Assault on Afghanistan, Poll Shows
description: Only 7 percent of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza felt that the United States would be justified in attacking Afghanistan, according to a poll taken just before the attacks began, while one in four thought the terrorist attacks against civilians in the United States were consistent with Islam.

title: Westhoff Focuses On Injuries, Not Miami
description: Mike Westhoff wishes he had more time to think about his abrupt departure from the Miami Dolphins after 15 years. Perhaps he would dwell more on his fractured relationship with Dave Wannstedt, or think of all the special teams players he tutored.

description: Master Warrant Officer Craig Sincock finished his counseling duties for the families of victims on Wednesday. Today he was part of the throng praying outside the Pentagon in a final memorial to the 189 people who died on Sept. 11.

title: Larsen Has a Rooting Interest
description: On the 45th anniversary of his perfect game in the 1956 World Series, Don Larsen said he was still watching and rooting for the first hit or first base runner in every game to preserve his place in history.

description: The Knicks' star system still revolves around Latrell Sprewell and Allan Houston, with Houston scoring 18 and Sprewell 10 in a 90-85 victory over the Nets tonight. But the Knicks also got a boost from Othella Harrington, who added 16 points after replacing an injured Marcus Camby.
