description: Friends and family knew that Brady Kay Howell was excited to be a presidential management intern, but he was thrilled when he was assigned to a civilian post for the chief of naval intelligence this year.

title: A European Dragnet Captures New Clues to bin Laden's Network
description: One was a former soccer player from Tunisia arrested in Belgium, another an Algerian forger detained in Spain. A third was picked up in Dubai on his way from Afghanistan to France, reportedly to coordinate a suicide attack on the American Embassy in Paris. There have been about three dozen others.

title: Bloomberg Says He Can Handle Hard Decisions and Hard Times Ahead

Bloomberg, the Republican businessman running for mayor, said yesterday that there would be tough economic decisions to make and reiterated his view that his management experience with his own company made him better qualified than any Democratic rival.

title: A New, Uneasy Burden
description: President Bush has been dragged by events and his allies to a place he never wanted to be: at the center of an exercise in nation-building, constructing a new Afghanistan from whatever is left once his bombing campaign and commando raids are over.

title: Clemens's Leg Injury Doesn't Bother Torre
description: Every time Roger Clemens covered first base this year, he would stand up slowly and step carefully, as if he were going through a mental checklist of his physical well-being. Calves? Check. Hamstrings? Check. Groin? Check.

description: President Bush said today that United States forces would attack Afghanistan for ''as long as it takes'' to destroy the Qaeda terrorist network of Osama bin Laden, but he offered to reconsider the military assault on Afghanistan if that country's ruling Taliban would surrender Mr. bin Laden.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.

title: Earnings Increase 3% at General Electric
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 3 percent over the same period last year, despite huge insurance losses related to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Without those losses, which carved 4 cents a share off earnings, the increase would have been 16 percent. G.E. also vowed to generate double-digit earnings growth this year and next.

title: Nobel in Literature Goes to Naipaul, an Explorer of Exile
description: V. S. Naipaul, the eloquent Trinidad-born English writer who uses fiction, nonfiction and sometimes a fusion of the two to explore themes of exile, dislocation, and the agonizing dilemmas of postcolonial societies, was awarded the 2001 Nobel Prize in Literature today by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Sunday about Lance Tumulty, a trader at Euro Brokers, former high school football captain and avid hunter lost in the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, misstated his hometown. It was Bridgewater, N.J., not Wayne.

title: The War, the Press and bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You still have a second chance. Just bring him in. And bring his leaders and lieutenants and other thugs and criminals with him.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Cuts Forecast
description: The Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, the second largest bank in the world, cut its half-year profit forecast as a result of write-offs for bad loans and losses on its stock portfolio. Sumitomo Mitsui is the fourth of the four leading banks in Japan to lower its earnings forecast, and the only one to still expect a profit. Sumitomo Mitsui expects a 500 billion yen ($4.2 billion) profit in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30, almost 30 percent lower than initially expected.

title: Police Officer Honored
description: Frank Tepedino played parts of five seasons with the Yankees in the late 1960's and early 1970's, but somehow he managed to accumulate only 77 at-bats in 55 games.

title: Foreign Affairs; Bush To Bin Laden
description: The White House has asked U.S. networks to limit broadcasts of statements by Osama bin Laden. I wish that instead of censorship, the president would respond to him. Here's what Mr. Bush could say:

title: Bank Chief Vows to Stay in Post for Full 8-Year Term : ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged
description: FRANKFURT  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED October 13th, 2001:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWINE, ROBERT M.
description: LEWINE-Robert M. On October 10, 2001. Husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Irene. Dear brother of Frances. Adoring grandfather of Lyle and Carl. Service is today, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Internet Access Service on Verge of Closing
description: The MobileStar Network Corporation, a driving force in offering wireless Internet access in public places, said yesterday that it had laid off its entire work force and would sell its assets if it could not find a buyer to continue its service.

title: William Howard Donovan Jr.: Always Making Lemonade
description: Cmdr. William Howard Donovan Jr. was a rising star in the Navy who had just been promoted to commander. At 37, the Nunda, N.Y., native was in the "pipeline."

title: The War, the Press and bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: A Spinoff of Afghanistan: Is Iraq Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: The outlook for campaigns is cloudy as marketers reassess spending and agency rosters.
description: EVEN though there is continued uncertainty in the advertising economy after the terrorist attacks, some decisions are moving forward, most notably changes in assignments on accounts with total billings estimated at $300 million. But the outlook remains clouded as marketers reassess spending plans in addition to agency rosters, all of which are being felt in revenue declines at media companies as well as layoffs at agencies.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Oct. 5 about Lawrence Davidson, a broker for Aon lost in the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, who had rekindled his relationship with his adult son in recent years, misspelled the son's given name. He is Marc Davidson, not Mark.

title: Middle East, Elusive on Film
description: Films about the Middle East and Islamic issues aren't readily available in the United States. A videocassette of PBS's broadly ranging historical documentary ''Islam: Empire of Faith'' can be ordered at the end of its broadcasts or from other outlets. For less promoted titles, feature or documentary, you go looking. ''Considering all the Middle Eastern films, the number you get on video is disproportionately small,'' said Ray Privett of Facets Video, a Chicago distributor and mail-order company that specializes in foreign titles.

title: 'Jails, Hospitals And Hip-Hop'
description: Directed by Danny Hoch and Mark Benjamin

title: Sports of The Times; Priorities Changed Before Jordan's Mind
description: SOMETIME around 6 a.m. yesterday, Michael Jordan became the first test case of my rearranged priorities. I'd spent an evening and early morning debating whether to fly to Detroit to watch Jordan's first exhibition game since announcing his comeback last month. Until 3 p.m. Wednesday, there had been no debate: I was going and, in fact, I was headed toward the airport when word came that Jordan said he would not play.

title: 'Not a. Lear'
description: Gracie Mansion

title: Time for Yankees to Start Sweating
description: The legions rose repeatedly at Yankee Stadium last night, imploring a generation of Yankees to respond as it has responded so often the past five years. "Paulie! Paulie!" the fans chanted, and they cheered for Tino and Derek and Bernie, begging and cajoling. And a generation of Yankees who have won three consecutive World Series titles, four in the past five years, had nothing more to give.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Hoisting The Sub, Slowly
description: The submarine Kursk, which was lifted from the bottom of the Barents Sea by a Dutch consortium on Monday and towed to shore on Wednesday, will be hoisted onto a floating dock next week, several days later than expected. Never has such a structure been hauled onto a floating dock, said Capt. Vladimir Navrotsky, spokesman for Russia's Northern Fleet. The 17,000-ton Kursk was powered by two nuclear reactors and carried cruise missiles and torpedoes. Two still unexplained explosions sent the Kursk crashing to the sea floor in August 2000, killing all 118 crewmen. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Information on Anthrax Is Derived From Cases Mostly Outside the U.S.
description: Inhalation anthrax, the form of the disease that killed Robert Stevens, a photography editor in South Florida is so rare that very few doctors have ever seen it. But anthrax is a common disease of livestock and other animals in much of the world and the bacterial spores that produce it are commonplace in the soil of many countries.

title: Congress Acts With Dispatch To Tighten Toxin Laws
description: Congress is rushing to tighten regulation of biological agents and toxins that could be used by terrorists.

title: Bernard Curtis Brown II: Fan of Basketball and School
description: Unlike many 11-year- olds, Bernard Curtis Brown II bounded out of his house every school day. "He lived to go to school," said his mother, Sinita. "If he was sick, he would always say he was feeling better so he could get to school."

title: Dow Jones Says Net Meets Estimates, but 4th Quarter Looks Weak
description: Dow Jones & Company posted third-quarter earnings yesterday that were in line with reduced estimates and said fourth-quarter profit would miss analysts' forecasts as advertising sales slump.

title: Surreal Adventures Somewhere Near the Land of Nod
description: There are those who will insist that the best way of approaching ''Waking Life,'' Richard Linklater's witty cosmic wow of a movie, is in a chemically altered state, and it's easy to see why.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS. The dollar climbed, lifted by gains in United States stocks and expectations the economy will recover in coming months. In New York, the euro settled at 90.30 cents, down from 91.07 cents on Wednesday.

title: Bribery Trial Witness Says Ex-Newark Mayor Paid Him
description: The former Irvington school board member who is the prosecution's key witness in the federal bribery and fraud trial of a former Newark mayor, Kenneth A. Gibson, testified today that Mr. Gibson had paid him $13,000 in connection with a $50 million school construction project.

title: Superior Interiors Upstage the Merchandise : Stores by Architects Steal the Limelight
description: PARIS  What lures you into a store: its design, or the merchandise? The question sounded preposterous until big-name fashion houses began retooling their shops with ambitious architecture that makes the clothes seem almost an afterthought.

title: New Warning Puts the Police In a Quandary On Security
description: The latest F.B.I. warning of possible new terrorist attacks has prompted police departments around the country to consider further tightening security efforts that many say were already quite strict following the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: A Battle of the Rsums
description: In a city hammered by crisis, the mayoral contest between Michael R. Bloomberg and Mark Green that begins today is shaping up as a fight over qualifications rather than issues: which of two men who have spent their lives in very different ways is better suited to lead New York through the difficult years ahead.

title: A New War Reshapes Old Alliances
description: War changes everything. The war against terrorism, now a hot war in Afghanistan, has this in common with the cold war: It affects all parts of the world and reshapes their politics. How will it reshape Europe?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMKOFF, CLAIRE
description: SAMKOFF-Claire. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Holly Shapiro and Julie Samkoff Gavurin. Loving sister of Lila Breiter. Adored grandmother of Jodi, Alex and Eve. Services were held on Thursday at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel'' in Hewlett. In lieu of flowers donations to your favorite charity.

title: Banned Substances Found in Many Food Supplements
description: An International Olympic Committee analysis of 600 over-the-counter nutritional supplements found that one-quarter contained banned substances such as anabolic steroids, Jacques Rogge, the I.O.C.'s president, said yesterday.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Better Living, at Least for a While, Through Chemistry
description: UNCLE TUNGSTEN

title: Panel Backs House Bill On Monitoring Of Finances
description: A House committee overwhelmingly approved broad new legislation today to combat money laundering, including a provision to require financial institutions to identify large depositors.

title: Bin Laden's Terrorism Isn't About the Palestinians
description: In 1990, Saddam Hussein claimed that he had invaded Kuwait to help the Palestinians. He understood that he was isolated and needed to link his invasion to a cause that might appear legitimate. While his claim was absurd on its face, the United States had to fight the linkage argument as it put together the coalition against Iraq in 1990.

title: Nielsen Rating Is Up
description: Game 1 of the divisional series between the Athletics and the Yankees on Fox Sports on Wednesday night produced a 5.9 Nielsen rating, up 11 percent from the comparable prime-time game featuring the same teams on Fox last year.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New London: Sentencing In 1999 Fire
description: Two men were sentenced to 18 months in prison for setting fire to a Y.M.C.A. day camp in North Stonington two years ago. No one was injured in the fire. The men -- Thomas W. Furst, 22, and Eric A. Roseacker, 27 -- pleaded guilty in August to criminal mischief charges related to the March 1999 fire, prosecutors said. On Wednesday, a trial judge also sentenced the men to three years' probation. Four men set fire to camp buildings after one of them had been dismissed from the camp. The two others are to be sentenced next week. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Concussion Sidelines Isles' Peca
description: Michael Peca, who signed with the Islanders this season and inspired their 3-0 start, did not play last night's game against the Devils in New Jersey.

title: Fight Enters Another Round Over Takeover in Venezuela
description: The AES Corporation of Arlington, Va., said yesterday that Venezuela's largest telephone company had failed to provide investors in the United States with precise information in the latest chapter of one of Latin America's most visible hostile takeover disputes.

title: Bouncing Back Off Broadway
description: FOR nearly a decade ''Blue Man Group'' has been regularly selling out the 299-seat Astor Place Theater, exposing hundreds of thousands of audience members to the simple joys of exploding Jell-O, abstract art and fractal geometry. Waiting lines before the show are common, as are fans lingering after for blue kisses from those blue lips.

title: Bicycle Daredevil, a Fearless Cook and a 79-Year-Old Mountaineer
description: JOSEPH KELLER

title: Hopes Are Modest as Israelis and Arabs Await Bush Plan
description: Israelis and Palestinians are anxiously awaiting the details of a peace initiative promised by the Bush administration, which has said it envisions the creation of a Palestinian state as part of any final agreement to end the conflict here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLIN, HELEN
description: GOLIN-Helen Herman on October 10, 2001 in West Palm Beach, Florida. Loving wife of Albert Golin and mother of Nancy Wiadro and Jane Strom. Also survived by four grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Funeral Service Sunday at Temple Beth El, 350 Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT at 1:30 PM. Burial Beth El Cemetery, Stamford, CT.

title: Sotheby's And Christie's Plan Layoffs Worldwide
description: Bracing for a period of unpredictable sales and revenue, Sotheby's and Christie's announced significant layoffs in their worldwide staffs this week.

title: Small Shops Feel Lost In Aid Effort
description: It was considered a bargain in the financial district, but even though the little Bangladeshi restaurant called Taste of Tandoor offered most of its lunches for $4 and change, it earned enough from day to day to support five immigrant families across the city.

title: Man Is Accused of Murder, but Not the Long-Suspected One
description: For nearly 20 years, Robert A. Durst, a scion of one of the city's richest and most influential real estate families, has been dogged by the circumstances involving the mysterious disappearance of his young wife. Kathleen Durst had disappeared in 1982, her case unsolved, her family openly accusing Mr. Durst of having played a role in her vanishing.

title: Swiss Banks Find $10 Million From Holocaust
description: A search of Swiss bank accounts dormant since World War II recovered $10 million that has been awarded to families of Holocaust victims, an international tribunal announced today.

title: Mr. Bush's New Gravitas
description: The George W. Bush who addressed the nation at a prime-time news conference yesterday appeared to be a different man from the one who was just barely elected president last year, or even the man who led the country a month ago. He seemed more confident, determined and sure of his purpose and was in full command of the complex array of political and military challenges that he faces in the wake of the terrible terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. It was for the most part a reassuring performance that gave comfort to an uneasy nation. In the weeks ahead, Mr. Bush should return to this and similar venues to talk to the American people. He's better at it than he and his aides think.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B.

title: Michael Cawley: Proud to Be a Firefighter
description: When Michael Cawley was 3, some firefighters drove past and yelled: "Hey, Michael Cawley! How are you?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSKIND, JACK
description: SUSSKIND-Jack. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of Jack Susskind, husband of dedicated ACWIS Board of Directors member Leah Susskind, generous supporter of the Weizmann Institute, and benefactor of the Jack and Leah Susskind Postdoctoral Fellowship in Cancer Research at the Weizmann Institute. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Leah, daughter Sara and her husband Tom, daughter Tania, grandson Zachary, and the entire family. Robert H. Asher, Chairman, American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Martin Kraar, Executive V.P. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President

title: Crucial Link Between Styles
description: Paul Signac's ''Plane Trees, Place des Lices, St.-Tropez'' (1893), above, is part of his retrospective at the Metropolitan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FOSTER, GLORIA
description: FOSTER-Gloria. A memorial service for family & friends of Gloria Foster will be held Mon., October 15th at 6PM in the Luesther Hall at The Public Theatre (425 Lafayette St.). In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Broadway Cares/ Equity Fights AIDS (165 W. 46th St., Suite 1300, N.Y., NY 10036).

title: Government Role at Issue In Proposal to Help Industry
description: As the nation's leading insurers have coalesced around an aid package to protect them against losses from future terrorist attacks, an ideological rift has developed both within the administration and in Congress about the government role in protecting industries in distress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCK, MARGARET L.
description: STOCK-Margaret L. Of Bronxville, NY on October 10, 2001. Wife of the late Frederick J. Stock. Mother of Carol Stock Mahony, Suzanne Stock Macdonald and the late Frederick J. Stock, Jr. Grandmother of ten, great grandmother of fifteen. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 1 to 5PM Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Monday, October 15 at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Joseph's Seminary, Yonkers, NY 10704, Attn: Msgr. James M. Connolly Scholarship Fund.

title: Use of Private Aircraft Remains Restricted
description: A month after terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, federal law enforcement officials are keeping a tight rein on private aviation, re-examining the ease with which aircraft can be purchased and flown.

title: Carol Rabalais: Forgiving and Optimistic
description: Carol Rabalais and her elder sister Patricia Tate exchanged harsh words during the summer when Ms. Rabalais mistakenly booked some standby plane tickets instead of reserved ones for a family vacation to their native Jamaica. But by the next day, Ms. Rabalais was her usual sunny self, the standby upset seemingly forgotten.

title: Add Clemens Injury to List of Yankees' Woes
description: Every time Roger Clemens covered first base this year, he would stand up slowly and step carefully, as if he were going through a mental checklist of his physical well-being. Calves? Check. Hamstrings? Check. Groin? Check.

title: Bush Promotes Energy Bill as Security Issue
description: President Bush urged the Senate today to pass an energy bill that would allow drilling for oil in an Alaskan wildlife refuge, casting the issue as a matter of national security.

title: A Spinoff of Afghanistan: Is Iraq Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMINERIO, FRANCES (FRANKIE)
description: SIMINERIO-Frances (Frankie). A valiant lady, a very dear friend. Anita & Sy

title: World Briefing | Europe: Liechtenstein: War On Dirty Money
description: Daniel Thelesklaf, the former chief of Switzerland's money-laundering reporting office, will head this principality's war on white-collar crime. It had been listed by the international Financial Action Task Force as a haven for dirty money, but was removed this year and has stepped up efforts to crack down. Mr. Thelesklaf will set up a new agency to monitor and carry out tougher regulations. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch yesterday about a victim of the World Trade Center attack who made a living as a French horn player and a social worker before becoming a vice president at Carr Futures misstated his given name. He was David W. Nelson, not Paul.

title: Bill Greatly Expanding Surveillance Power in Terrorism Fight Clears the Senate
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to give the government expanded surveillance and investigative powers intended to combat terrorism, with lawmakers citing the urgency of the threat and the need for a swift response.

title: Ford Fulfills YSL Hopes With a Modern Moroccan Safari
description: PARIS  It was like a scene from a fashion movie. Betty Catroux, Yves Saint Laurent's muse, was throwing her arms round Tom Ford saying, "I loved it." Stephanie Seymour's husky voice proclaimed that she was longing to go off on safari. Dennis Hopper was taking happy snaps. And the sound track was crooning "You Put a Spell on Me" in versions from Bryan Ferry through Screaming Jay Hawkins.

title: Enemy's Planes 'in Pieces,' Air Wing Commander Says
description: With the American airstrikes against Afghanistan entering a fifth night, most of the early tension on this vessel seems to have lifted, and the air wing commander allowed himself a small moment of bravado tonight. He allowed himself to be identified by name -- Capt. David J. Mercer of the Navy -- something until now taboo aboard this vessel, under a policy set by top officers.

title: Katie Mcgarry Noack: A People Person
description: When people met Katie McGarry Noack at parties, they remembered her. She had a knack for turning strangers into acquaintances and acquaintances into friends. "We were at a party in Australia for just a few hours," said Brad Noack, her husband, who grew up in Sydney. "But they all still remember the Yank."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISLER, SAMUEL
description: ISLER-Samuel. National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the passing of our generous benefactor Samuel Isler, who together, with his beloved wife Marilyn, played a vital role in NJOP's efforts to assure a Jewish future for American Jewry. Yehi Zichro Baruch. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Opposition To Hynix Plan
description: The Korea Exchange Bank, the lead creditor for Hynix Semiconductor, has encountered opposition from some creditors opposed to a new $5.3 billion plan for rescuing the company. HSBC Holdings and two regional South Korean banks said they would pull out of the plan if possible by selling their loans to other creditors. Since Hynix owes them only about $27 million out of total debts of $6.8 billion, their reluctance is not likely to derail approval of the plan. Other creditors, however, have objected to the component in the rescue that calls for an infusion of nearly $800 million in fresh loans. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: The War, the Press and bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Happy Ending Eluding O'Neill
description: The starting players for the Yankees always run sprints across the outfield grass about 20 minutes before each game. One by one, they pop out of the first-base dugout, trot in foul territory to reach the right-field line and then start sprinting to shallow center. It is a monotonous exercise, one they dwell upon as deeply as most people ponder brushing their teeth.

title: Everything Happens to Florida
description: It used to be that in the mind of the nation, Florida was just one long sunny day. Florida was that palm-treed peninsula hanging like a gaudy promise at the end of the gothic Deep South: bright, easy, dreamy. Florida was where parents took their children to pay homage to the castrato-voiced Mouse. It was where the golf courses were plastic green and as smooth as a supermodel's cheek. Florida was where New York and New Jersey went to ease out of life.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Unemployment Assistance
description: More than 3,700 New Yorkers asked for unemployment assistance last week because of the World Trade Center disaster, the New York State Department of Labor said yesterday. As of Oct. 10, the number of people who have asked for jobless benefits because of the disaster rose to 20,493, up from 16,747 the previous week. Throughout the state, the number of people applying for first-time unemployment insurance benefits edged down slightly during the first week of October, to 30,073 from 30,464 during the last week of September. But those figures are far higher than they were a year ago, when the economy was humming. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Jensen Roars Back to Life in Britain
description: JENSEN MOTORS, a mostly forgotten speck of auto history, is back in business. It began selling a new roadster called the S-V8 in Britain last month, a quarter-century after its predecessor company collapsed in bankruptcy.

title: Sri Lankan Rebels Said to Be Recruiting Children
description: Amnesty International reported today that separatist Tamil rebels in Sri Lanka have been aggressively recruiting hundreds of children in the northern and eastern areas they control, to fight in an ethnic conflict that has taken more than 62,000 lives since 1983.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALVO, CARLTON F. II
description: VALVO-Carlton F. II. The Dalton community mourns the loss of Dalton parent Carlton F. Valvo II. Our deepest sympathy to Lori, Dante and their extended family.

title: Steinbrenner Fine Unlikely
description: George Steinbrenner criticized the umpires, especially Rick Reed, during the Yankees' 5-3 loss in Game 1 on Wednesday night. But an official with major league baseball said it was most unlikely that the principal owner of the Yankees would be fined for his remarks.

title: Green Defeats Ferrer in N.Y. Mayor Runoff
description: Against a backdrop of civic trauma and deep anxiety about the future of New York City, Mark Green won the Democratic nomination for mayor last night. He defeated Fernando Ferrer in a racially divided contest in which voters embraced Mr. Green's declaration that recovering from the World Trade Center attack should be the central focus of New York's next mayor.

title: China Seeks World Support in Fight With Its Muslim Separatists
description: The Chinese government made its most explicit call yet for international support to fight Muslim separatists in its far West, saying it had evidence of their ties with terrorist groups abroad.

title: Clouds Seen for Emerging Markets
description: The last thing that financial markets need now is another shock. But the world's emerging markets could provide one.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Readies Power-Saving Chips
description: I.B.M. will announce today the availability of the first of a new family of Power PC microprocessors designed to monitor what task the chip is performing and use that information to minimize power consumption. The chip also uses hardware to handle encryption and voice recognition functions that were previously done with software. Analysts said the chip uses much less power than other chips in many wireless applications and should spur the development of novel personal digital assistants, improved cellphones and portable Internet devices.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Investment Restrictions
description: After meeting with executives from several international security concerns, South Africa's minister of safety and security said he would abandon the government's effort to ban foreign investors from the country's lucrative security industry. Companies like Securicor of Britain and ADT, a unit of Tyco International, based in Exeter, N.H., have acquired South African subsidiaries over the last year. Under the ban, such companies would have to sell their holdings in South Africa. Lawmakers advocating the ban said the foreign ownership in the industry was a threat to national security, but economic policy makers said the measure went too far and would threaten desperately needed investment. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Senate Votes to Federalize Job of Airport Screening
description: With sponsors calling air travel a national security matter, the Senate unanimously passed legislation today intended to make flying safer by federalizing the job of passenger and baggage screening at major airports and requiring that all suitcases and bags be examined.

title: They May Rob You Blind, But They'll Never Shoot
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is the best thing to happen to movie bank robbers since nitroglycerin; it provides cinema's larcenous sweethearts with extra gilding for their hearts of gold by insuring accounts for up to $100,000. It's the rationale that Joe (Bruce Willis) and Terry (Billy Bob Thornton) use for their crimes in the shaggy-dog romantic heist comedy ''Bandits.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Abkhazia: Rebel Zone Bombed
description: The self-proclaimed government of Abkhazia, a breakaway region of Georgia, said it had bombed the region's lawless Kodori Gorge, where unidentified rebels who oppose the separatists used grenade launchers earlier this week to shoot down a United Nations helicopter. Abkhaz officials said they had inflicted casualties, but there was no way to verify that. Georgia and Russia, which tacitly supports Abkhazia's separatist movement, have angrily accused each other this week of inflaming tensions in the Abkhaz region, where peace talks had been under way. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Missile Role Still Under Study
description: The National Security Secretary, Yevgeny Marchuk, said he did not exclude the possibility that a missile fired during a Ukrainian military exercise accidentally shot down a Russian passenger jet over the Black Sea last week. Mr. Marchuk fell short of assuming responsibility for the crash of the SibirAir TU-154 airliner that killed all 78 people on board, saying that Ukraine would await the conclusions of all experts studying the crash. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Man Arrested In Equipment Theft
description: A man was arrested at a construction site while operating a piece of earth-moving equipment stolen from the World Trade Center site four days after the terrorist attack, the police said. The police-owned piece of equipment was to be used in the rescue effort. It was reported missing on Sept. 15 from 2 Rector Street in Lower Manhattan, the police said. The man, Louis Gregorio, 37, of West Brighton, was arrested Wednesday and charged with grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property and forging a vehicle-identification number.

title: First Round of Budget Cuts Aren't Enough, States Find
description: As states start to assess the economic damage in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the outlook is dismal and getting worse.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry Sales Fall
description: Sales at Burberry retail stores declined 15 percent in the three weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, its parent company, Great Universal Stores, said. Before the attacks, sales had been growing, and for the six months to Sept. 30 showed an increase of 31 percent at constant exchange rates, the company said. Great Universal Stores said it still planned to proceed with a partial public offering of Burberry shares before June 2002. Burberry is the latest luxury goods company to warn of shrinking demand, as shoppers, fearful of terrorism and its possible effect on the economy, have refrained from buying expensive handbags and clothes. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, KURT
description: STERN-Kurt. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Margot Stern upon the loss of her husband. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Wednesday about the possibility of action by the United States against terrorist groups in the Philippines and Indonesia misidentified the leader of Abu Sayyaf, an organization tied to Osama bin Laden that operates from the Philippines. The leader was believed to be Khaddafi Janjalani. (Abdujarak Abubakar Janjalani was his brother, who founded and headed the group but was reportedly killed in a firefight in the Philippines in 1998.)

title: S.& P. PUTS CREDIT OF TOYS 'R' US ON ITS WATCH LIST
description: Standard & Poor's said yesterday that it had put the credit of Toys ''R'' Us on watch for possible downgrade because of concerns that the company's turnaround will take longer than expected. Standard & Poor's put the company's BBB+ long-term corporate credit, senior unsecured debt and bank loan ratings on its watch list. S&P affirmed the company's A-2 short-term corporate credit and commercial paper ratings. Toys ''R'' Us, based in Paramus, N.J., said earlier this week that its fiscal third-quarter loss would be wider than forecast. Shares in Toys ''R'' Us rose $1.43, or 7.7 percent, to $20.11.

title: Tangling and Untangling, It's Awkwardness as Art
description: Chunky Move is a cheeky troupe.

title: Rights to Patriotic Children's Book Sold
description: Lynne Cheney, the former chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities and the wife of Vice President Dick Cheney, has sold the rights to a children's book she has written about patriotism to Simon & Schuster, a division of Viacom. The book, titled ''America: A Patriotic Primer, '' will be published in the spring and be illustrated by Robin Preiss Glasser.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Jobs For The Poor
description: President Alejandro Toledo mounted an antipoverty program designed to create 49,000 jobs in the poorest areas of Peru. The plan will limit imports of food to encourage domestic grain production, spur new public works and maintenance of roads and step up efforts to develop tourism. Mr. Toledo took office in July promising to make the fight against poverty and corruption the centerpieces of his administration. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: A's Starters Are Poised to Finish the Yanks
description: All the Yankees have to do to stay alive in their playoff series against the Oakland Athletics is beat Barry Zito, who was the American League pitcher of the month for August and September. The Yankees know about good pitching. In the past three years, they soared to postseason success on the wings of their pitchers.

title: A Neighborhood Anchor in Flux; Parents Fear School May Become Another Casualty of Attack
description: There are certain hardships that the children of Public School 89 have come to endure patiently: squeezing into borrowed classrooms with up to 55 students; not being able to use the cafeteria or playground at the school temporarily housing them; doing homework and having play dates in hotel rooms instead of the Battery Park City apartments in which many have lived since birth.

title: City Views: Wide-Eyed, Wide-Angle
description: Every person sees New York through his own prism. In ''Manhattan Unfurled,'' a new show of panoramas of New York that opened this week, the New-York Historical Society explores how the city has inspired some foreigners during the last 150 years. The show, which runs through Jan. 6, pairs a contemporary rendering of the Manhattan skyline by a New York-based architect and illustrator, Matteo Pericoli, with a sweeping panorama drawn between 1842 and 1845 by a Swiss entrepreneur, Edward Burckhardt (1815-1903).

title: Some Pentagon Officials and Advisers Seek to Oust Iraq's Leader in War's Next Phase
description: A tight-knit group of Pentagon officials and defense experts outside government is working to mobilize support for a military operation to oust President Saddam Hussein of Iraq as the next phase of the war against terrorism, senior administration officials and defense experts said.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Silicon Storage Projects Profit
description: Defying analysts' projections, Silicon Storage Technology, a maker of computer memory products, said yesterday that it expected to post a profit of 1 or 2 cents a share in the third quarter, excluding items, on projected revenue of $73 million to $77 million. According to consensus estimates, analysts had expected the company to lose a penny a share on revenue of about $60.3 million. At its upper end, the projected profit would be an improvement over the last quarter, when Silicon Storage earned 1 cent a share on revenue of $62.7 million. Silicon Storage, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., also said that it would take a charge to inventory of $40 million to $45 million during the third quarter. Silicon Storage shares rose $1.90, or 30.3 percent, to $8.18. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 3 about the career of Irwin Meyer, who set up NetCurrents Inc., which monitors the Internet for remarks about a specified person or company, referred incorrectly at two points to his past activities. One of Mr. Meyer's companies, the Producers Entertainment Group, agreed to acquire a company called eSat, but the deal was never completed; Mr. Meyer did not buy eSat. While Mr. Meyer was president of Ventura Entertainment, it acquired a company that produced television commercials. Mr. Meyer himself did not produce commercials. Mr. Meyer raised concerns about the article in an e-mail message to The Times several days after publication. This correction was delayed for research.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Vote On City Clerk
description: The City Council is set to vote today on the appointment of Victor L. Robles as city clerk. Mr. Robles is a city councilman who has represented parts of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Bushwick and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, since 1985. He is barred from re-election by term limits. If appointed, Mr. Robles, who as the Council's majority whip and chairman of its health committee earns $110,000 a year, would earn $141,000 a year, said Jordan Barowitz, a Council spokesman. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, JEFFREY
description: WILSON-Jeffrey. Beloved husband of Christina. Adoring father of Sammy and Jacob. Son of Merle and the late Irving. Aunt Fran and Uncle Herb

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Fishing Protest
description: A South Korean delegation goes to Moscow this weekend to ask Russia not to reach a deal with Japan that would bar South Korean fishing boats from waters around the southern Kurile Islands. Fishermen protested in Pusan, Korea's largest port, as Japan and Russia were reported near the agreement. Russia has permitted Koreans to fish near the islands, seized by Soviet forces at the end of World War II and claimed ever since by Japan. The fishermen objected to the government's decision to receive the Japanese prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, arriving in Seoul on Monday for talks. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Official Who Criticized Schundler's Budgetary Record Is Fired
description: The DiFrancesco administration today dismissed the top state official in charge of local government services because of a letter he wrote on Tuesday that severely criticized Bret D. Schundler's budgetary practices as mayor of Jersey City.

title: Father Sought to 'Swap' Girl, 4, For Sexual Abuse, Officials Say
description: A Dix Hills man was arraigned today on charges that he sexually abused his 4-year-old daughter, then tried to temporarily ''swap'' her over the Internet for another child victim.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: U.S. To Assist Tajiks
description: The United States promrised to give Tajikistan $3 million in agricultural aid to help farmers offset a severe drought nation and its neighbors, the Agency for International Development said. Tajikistan, which borders Afghanistan, is a crucial ally in the American-led military campaign against terrorism, but American officials said the aid had been earmarked before the antiterror drive began. The United Nations said a million of Tajikistan's 6.2 million citizens could be hit by famine this winter; the situation could worsen, officials say, if a flood of Afghan war refugees joins them. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Green, Evoking Elections Past, Says Wait Is Over
description: When Mark Green took to the stage of the Sheraton New York hotel last night to the beat of the Jackson Five to accept the Democratic nomination for mayor, he spoke about his youth as a Brooklyn Dodger fan.

title: Absent Police Cadet Sought After Disappearance
description: A police cadet who went off to work the morning of the World Trade Center attack has not been seen since, prompting unusual attention from the New York Police Department and federal authorities.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Long-Delayed Chip Ready To Ship
description: The Sarnoff Corporation of Princeton, N.J., a subsidiary of SRI International, said it was ready to begin selling commercial quantities of Acadia, a high-speed graphics and video microchip that it had originally hoped to have ready for marketing a year ago. Sarnoff said that the chip could perform 80 billion operations a second and would make it possible to provide at ''consumer prices'' the kind of visual processing power that is currently available in $100,000 workstations. Potential uses include improved teleconferencing, collision avoidance systems in cars and high-performance surveillance cameras. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: 295 Students in National Guard Denied Tuition Aid
description: In the days before the Sept. 11 attacks, New York State notified hundreds of National Guard members that they would not receive the college scholarships they had expected in return for enlisting.

title: Great Books To Count On
description: Psychoanalysts and critics have long studied fairy tales and children's books, searching for hidden meanings. Now a new show at the Children's Museum of Manhattan reveals a subtext even Freud never thought of: math lessons.

title: From a Montclair Trove, Americans at Their Best
description: It's not surprising that in the very shadow of New York City's cultural behemoths, the Montclair Art Museum was born and developed a flourishing life of its own. In the late 19th century this bucolic town across the river was a thriving art colony whose best-known member was the landscapist George Inness (1825-1894).

title: Blair, as Face of Coalition, Ends Tour of Arab World
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, ending a whirlwind tour meant to defend the attacks on Afghanistan to jittery Arab leaders, called today on ''people of all faiths, of all political persuasions'' to join the fight against international terrorism.

title: Scorsese Pays Tribute to Italian Cinema
description: To watch ''Il Mio Viaggio in Italia,'' Martin Scorsese's monumental introduction to postwar Italian cinema, is to be indelibly reminded of how much movies can matter. Contemplated apart from klieg-lighted hype and movie star gossip, even a flawed film can be seen as a revealing dreamscape of ideas, images and feelings, a vision of the world narrowed into a fragment of a collective unconscious, if you will. And when that vision is directed by a serious artist, it can change the way we see.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a book review yesterday about ''Germs: Biological Weapons and America's Secret War'' referred incorrectly to the discovery after 1969 that an ability to use biological weapons was in the hands of small adversaries and was being pursued by anti-American terrorists. The writers said the discovery was made by humanity, not by the Soviet Union.

title: Gotbaum Is Victorious In the Runoff
description: In the race for public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum soundly defeated Norman Siegel last night, according to early, unofficial returns.

title: Ulf R. Ericson: Adventurous Vacationer
description: At 79, Ulf Ericson was still working full time as a civil engineer at Washington Group International. On vacations, he trekked in the Himalayas and explored Antarctica. "My father saw himself as someone much younger," said his daughter Catherine. "He had a real passion for engineering. Every year I would say: 'Dad, do they know how old you are?' But he didn't see age as limiting."

title: The Way You See: Intricate Insights
description: A GIACOMETTI story: In 1939, Giacometti chose, for a while, to make figures from memory rather than from life, but no matter how hard he tried, the figures kept turning out smaller than he wanted. The problem persisted two years later when he decided to visit his mother, who was then in Geneva, promising friends and also his brother Diego that he would return to Paris with works of a less absurd size.

title: Review/Fashion; Said the Phoenix: Don't Give Up on Fantasy
description: In the long view, which is the only view to take in fashion, the attacks of Sept. 11 and their aftermath will not change the need to express oneself, nor will they rob women of the pleasures of dressing. But they will change habit, and whether it's a desire to stay closer to home or escape into whirls of leopard print chiffon, this habit will change fashion.

description: The primary role in shaping a future government out of the squabbling factions of the Afghan resistance has been handed to a veteran mediator and United Nations trouble-shooter, Lakhdar Brahimi, diplomats here say.

description: The average number of workers filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose over the last four weeks to the highest in almost a decade as job losses increased after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the government reported today.

title: Bryan C. Jack: 'A Real Intellectual'
description: For days, friends thought Bryan C. Jack, a budget analyst for the Defense Department, was missing in the ruins of the Pentagon. By a strange twist of fate, it turned out that he was among the passengers aboard American Airlines Flight 77, which crashed at the place where Mr. Jack, on most days, would have been crunching numbers at his desk. On Sept. 11, he was on his way to California on business.

title: Juniper Posts Loss but Exceeds Wall St. Forecast
description: Juniper Networks, the maker of networking equipment, said today that it posted a loss for its fiscal third quarter, but the company exceeded Wall Street's expectations after excluding several extraordinary charges.

title: Retail Sales for September Show Allure of Discounters
description: The nation's merchants reported sales for the month of September yesterday, and they were mostly dismal. They were not, however, an across-the-board disaster.

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks Must Come Back Hard Way
description: THE Yankees are not arrogant. They are not even cocky by normal street standards. They do, however, have institutional memory.

title: Assets Worth $24 Million Frozen as U.S. Goes for More
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  President Bush said today that world governments had frozen $24 million in assets linked to terrorism suspects after more than 100 countries agreed to cooperate with the United States- led effort to bar Osama bin Laden and his associates from using the international banking system.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Bush Leads In Money Race
description: Gov. Jeb Bush has raised $1.25 million for his 2002 re-election campaign, reports filed with the state Division of Elections show. The reports cover three months of fund-raising efforts. The governor, a Republican who opened his campaign account in June, leads Janet Reno, the former United States attorney general who is considered the front-runner for the Democratic nomination, by 12 to 1 in fund-raising. Ms. Reno, who did not enter the race until last month, had raised $102,179 by Sept. 30. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Hard-Driving Akers Gives In to Retirement
description: She was in grade school, about age 10, when Michelle Akers decided that she could not play soccer wearing cultural manacles. Female athletes of her generation were not supposed to sweat, to get dirty or even to admit a passion for ferocious victory. Parents glared at her or made remarks when she ran over their less-aggressive children. Akers tried to restrain herself, but this social harness felt unnatural to a girl whose ultimate dream was to play for the Steelers.

title: NBC Is Paying $1.98 Billion For Telemundo
description: Acknowledging the importance of the fast-growing Spanish-speaking population in the United States, NBC agreed yesterday to buy the Telemundo Communications Group, the nation's second-largest Spanish-language broadcaster, for $1.98 billion.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Leasing Concern Gets $100 Million Infusion
description: USInternetworking, a company that leases software over the Internet, said that it would receive a $100 million equity investment from Bain Capital. Shares in USinternetworking, a software company in Annapolis, Md., rose sharply on the news, closing at 34 cents, up 8 cents, or 31 percent. Like many software companies, USinternetworking, also known as USi, has had a difficult year, complete with layoffs, a plummeting share price and lowered expectations. The company's management says its losses are being contained. Andrew A. Stern, above, chief executive of USi, suggested that the investment by Bain, a Boston-based investment firm, would assure clients that the company was still viable. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Stocks Surge; Most Indexes Have Recouped September Loss
description: The American stock market rose sharply yesterday, providing more evidence that investors are regaining their confidence after the terrorist attacks. Most major averages in the United States, as well as several other countries, have now recovered all the losses they suffered after Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: I.M.F. Sees Economic Health
description: The International Monetary Fund gave Russia a clean bill of health and said the economic changes under President Vladimir V. Putin have led to remarkable growth. Russia, which no longer needs financial assistance from the I.M.F., said it would let the fund monitor the country's economic progress. On an official visit in Moscow, the I.M.F.'s managing director, Horst Khler, also urged the Russian government to fix its poorly functioning banking system.

title: Hilda Taylor: Giving Students the World
description: As a native of Sierra Leone who came to the United States to further her own education, Hilda Taylor believed in exposing her urban elementary school students to a world beyond Washington.

title: Corrections
description: A Political Memo article on Wednesday about events that have overshadowed the mayoral election misstated the reason that the Democratic primary runoff was scheduled for yesterday rather than Tuesday. It was in deference to the Jewish holiday of Simhat Torah, which began on Tuesday, not because Monday was Columbus Day.

title: Tawanna Griffin: Family Meant Everything
description: Tawanna and Bobby Griffin met in the kitchen of a Wendy's restaurant in East New York, Brooklyn, where they had after-school jobs in high school. Romance blossomed over the deep fryers, and their life together began soon after.

title: Strong Finish By Islanders Continues Hot Start
description: The banners that marked them as division and conference winners last season had been raised before the Devils stepped onto the Continental Arena ice tonight for their 20th home opener. The Devils fell a game short of raising a Stanley Cup banner but there was still a great deal of emotion on this night. A month after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, most fans in the crowd of 17,123 chanted ''U.S.A.!'' after the national anthem.

title: Cantor Details Aid to Survivors
description: Cantor Fitzgerald, the trading firm that lost 700 employees in the World Trade Center attack, said the victims' families would receive health insurance for 10 years and a share of the partnership's profits for five years.

title: A Game of Cat and Mouse Resumes on City Streets
description: New York City has endured countless disruptions of normal life in the last 30 days. Only one of them was universally welcomed, and yesterday it came to an end, with a whir of the mechanical broom and the itchy summons finger of the traffic enforcement agent.

description: For some it was a day to pause and remember, a chance to step back from a tumultuous month to assess altered lives and a changed city. But a month after two jets crashed into the World Trade Center, many of those who work or live in downtown Manhattan found the wounds too fresh and painful for any meaningful retrospective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATELSON, BERNICE
description: NATELSON-Bernice. On October 10, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Vincent. Cherished mother of Anne and the late Mark. Loving sister of Steve and Edna Kornberg. She will always be remembered for her kind heart, generous spirit and loving nature.

description: The security company that was fined $1.2 million last year and put on probation for hiring convicted felons to screen passengers at Philadelphia International Airport has continued to hire screeners without checking whether they have criminal records, a United States attorney says.

A 13-page advisory detailing symptoms of anthrax was sent to emergency medicine directors, infection control practitioners, and infectious disease physicians, laboratory directors and others. description: Turner Field was quiet early this afternoon, but the scoreboard flashed an impressive message that read ''Atlanta Braves, 10 straight division titles.''

title: Developer Sues Suffolk County Over Ban on Buying Property
description: A real estate investor filed a federal lawsuit against Suffolk County today, charging that county lawmakers acted unjustly when they refused to sell him land because of crimes committed by his son.

title: WILLAMETTE SAYS HIGHER BID MUST PRECEDE TALKS
description: Willamette Industries, a maker of lumber and paper, said yesterday that it would agree to takeover talks if its suitor, Weyerhaeuser, sweetened its offer of $7.18 billion, or $50 a share. ''If you make a written offer in the high $50's, we will agree to sit down for discussions,'' William Swindells, Willamette's chairman, said in a letter to Steven R. Rogel, the Weyerhaeuser chairman and chief. It was the first time that Willamette had publicly suggested what it thought was a fair offer, and the move may bring an end to an 11-month stalemate. Willamette is under pressure from shareholders to sell the company as profits decline with the slowing economy. Mr. Rogel has said he will increase the offer only if Willamette negotiates first.

title: Gerald P. Fisher: An Eternal Optimist
description: As one of Booz, Allen & Hamilton's most respected consultants, Gerald P. Fisher never saw the need to dress for success.

title: City Must Translate for Food Stamp Recipients
description: A federal judge approved a settlement agreement yesterday that will require city officials to provide translated documents and interpreters to food stamp recipients who speak little or no English.

title: Britain Presses U.S. for 'Nation Building' in Afghanistan
description: LONDON, Oct. 11 — Britain, America's most active ally in the struggle against terrorism, is pushing the Bush administration to ease its often-stated resistance to "nation building" and to support a post-Taliban government in Afghanistan brokered by the United Nations, senior British officials say.

title: Citing Comments on Attack, Giuliani Rejects Saudi's Gift
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city was rejecting a $10 million donation from a wealthy prince from Saudi Arabia who criticized the American government's policies in the Middle East.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Europe: Rates Steady
description: Turning aside fears that Europe is heading toward a recession, the European Central Bank disappointed at least some investors by refusing to reduce interest rates. The central bank kept its baseline interest rate at 3.75 percent, refusing to add to the emergency rate cut it made nearly two weeks ago. In holding rates steady, the European central bankers again diverged from the course of the United States Federal Reserve, which cut rates repeatedly before and after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Analysts said the European bank might be waiting for more signs of the fallout from Sept. 11, and they speculated that the bank had been put off by hints of strengthening growth in the last few days. But most experts still say European rates will be cut at least one more time before the year's end. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: F.T.C. SAYS HEARST WILL PAY $4 MILLION TO SETTLE CHARGES
description: The Hearst Corporation, owner of The San Francisco Chronicle and other newspapers, has agreed to pay $4 million to settle charges that it withheld information on its 1998 acquisition of Medi-Span, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday. In a complaint filed in April, the F.T.C. charged that Hearst's failure to produce the documents hindered the agency's ability to analyze the acquisition of Medi-Span, a drug-price database company. In a related case filed earlier this year, the F.T.C. charged that Hearst's acquisition of Medi-Span, based in Indianapolis, gave it a monopoly over the market for drug-price databases.

title: Middle East, Elusive on Film
description: Films about the Middle East and Islamic issues aren't readily available in the United States. A videocassette of PBS's broadly ranging historical documentary "Islam: Empire of Faith" can be ordered at the end of its broadcasts or from other outlets. For less promoted titles, feature or documentary, you go looking. "Considering all the Middle Eastern films, the number you get on video is disproportionately small," said Ray Privett of Facets Video, a Chicago distributor and mail-order company that specializes in foreign titles.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buffalo: Review Of City's Cash Flow
description: The state comptroller has agreed to review Buffalo's cash flow problems in an attempt by the city to avoid bankruptcy, a spokesman for Comptroller H. Carl McCall said yesterday. The city, one of a group of upstate governments hurt by the economic downturn, may have trouble meeting its payroll and other obligations, the spokesman, Jeffery Gordon, said. The comptroller's office will study what is slowing cash flow and make recommendations, he said. Syracuse and Utica have requested similar analysis, Mr. Gordon said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: Talks On Forging A Government
description: Five African heads of state joined leaders of Burundi's main rebel groups in a regional summit meeting in Pretoria, South Africa, aimed at forging a power-sharing government between the Hutu and Tutsi in Burundi. The talks, led by the former South African president, Nelson Mandela, centered on the creation of a protection force to ensure the safety of politicians returning from exile to take partin the new interim government in the Burundi capital of Bujumbura. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Fassel In No Rush For Barber To Return
description: Running back Ron Dayne returned to Giants practice today, but Tiki Barber, whose hamstring injury is healing more slowly than expected, did not. Barber's chances of playing Sunday against the St. Louis Rams are remote. In fact, Coach Jim Fassel said today that he did not know if Barber would be ready for the game against Philadelphia Oct. 22.

title: Charles F. Burlingame: A Classmate Like a Brother
description: To those who knew him, Capt. Charles F. Burlingame's dependability was legend. "He was kind of a go-to guy," said Perry Martini, a former classmate of Captain Burlingame, a Navy fighter pilot many affectionately remember by his nickname, Chic. "If you needed something done and done right," Mr. Martini said, "you would call on Chic."

description: The developers of two high-profile cultural projects proposed for Downtown Brooklyn are worried that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's call to trim $1 billion in city spending will stall their plans, which depend partly on millions of dollars in city funding.

description: Every time Roger Clemens covered first base this year, he would stand up slowly and step carefully, as if he were going through a mental checklist of his physical well-being. Calves? Check. Hamstrings? Check. Groin? Check.

title: Joseph Keller: His Motto: 'Let's Do It!'
description: On that last Sunday, Joseph Keller, bona fide grown-up -- father, husband, homeowner in Park Ridge, N.J., and department head at the Marriott World Trade Center Hotel -- had what would be a final fling with his daredevil teenage self. He and two buddies from high school got together and dusted off their old bicycle freestyling stunts. Mr. Keller, 31, who had competed in the extreme sport, still had the chops to pull off a funky chicken. (Don't ask.)

description: BERNSTEIN-Elma, 90. Died September 28. A lifelong advocate for social justice. Preceded in death by her husband, Milton. Beloved mother of Stanley Bernstein and Judith Fischer. title: United Nations and Kofi Annan Share Nobel Peace Prize
description: The United Nations and Secretary General Kofi Annan were jointly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today, an honor that Mr. Annan said he found humbling and encouraging but one that also "challenges us to do more and to do better, not to rest on our laurels."

description: The F.B.I. issued a warning this afternoon that there could be new terror attacks in the United States or abroad in the next several days.

description: Britain, America's most active ally in the struggle against terrorism, is pushing the Bush administration to ease its often-stated resistance to ''nation building'' and to support a post-Taliban government in Afghanistan brokered by the United Nations, senior British officials say.

description: CROLL-Irma. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member Irma Croll. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIRO, RAPHAEL P. (PHIL)
description: SPIRO-Raphael P. (Phil). October 11, 2001. Beloved as a husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, cousin, friend, and community member. He will be missed by his wife Leah; daughters Nina and Anita and their husbands; grandchildren Alana, Valerie, Max and Carly; brother Julie, extended family and friends and many others whose lives he touched through his work in various New York State social service agencies. Funeral Sunday, Oct. 14, noon at ''Wien & Wien'' 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ. Donations to VNS Hospice of NY 212-290-3884.

title: A Month Later, Warnings and Hope, and Plans for a Long Campaign
description: Yesterday was one month since the terror bombings in New York and Virginia, and with the memorial services came reminders that the crisis was far from over. The F.B.I. warned that terrorists could strike against the United States at home or abroad in the next several days, while President Bush said American forces would fight in Afghanistan ''as long as it takes.''

title: Rhonda Ridge Rasmussen: Reading Harry Potter Aloud
description: Rhonda Ridge Rasmussen read to her husband, Floyd, just about every night before going to bed. His eyes are bad, he says, and she enjoyed reading to him. The couple had just started a new book, one of the Harry Potter series.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Britain: Probable Cause In 1986 Baby Death
description: A judge has ruled there is probable cause to proceed with a murder trial against a woman accused of killing her infant son 15 years ago, the state attorney's office said yesterday. The woman, Jeanette Poulin, 45, originally of Bristol, pleaded not guilty Wednesday. The six-week-old boy's death on Aug. 31, 1986, was originally attributed to sudden infant death syndrome, but detectives reopened the case in 1996. They uncovered evidence that something had been deliberately stuffed in the boy's mouth, the state attorney's office said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Emerita De la Pena: Best Friends Forever
description: Emerita de la Pena and Judith Diaz-Sierra met in business school as teenagers and soon became best friends. Each was the maid of honor at the other's wedding, they vacationed together with their husbands, and they both worked as administrative assistants at Fiduciary Trust Company International, where Mrs. De la Pea had helped recruit Ms. Diaz-Sierra in 1997.

title: Muslim Scholars Back Fight Against Terrorists
description: A panel of prominent Muslim scholars in the Middle East has issued a fatwa, or religious opinion, denouncing the terrorist attacks on the United States and saying it is the ''duty'' of Muslims to participate in the mission to apprehend the terrorists.

title: F.B.I. Debunks E-Mail Threat
description: At a time when Americans are plagued by a generalized fear of an invisible enemy, the latest Internet rumor warns specifically of a terrorist attack on a mall on Halloween.

title: Fugitive Easy to Find In the Stores
description: Beside the T-shirts emblazoned with American flags, the Statue of Liberty and other patriotic symbols, a souvenir shop here is selling one that bears the face of Osama bin Laden in a Wild West poster format that says, ''Wanted, Dead.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRIS, LOUIS, M.D.
description: FERRIS-Louis, M.D. Died on October 10, 2001. Beloved husband of Marie. Devoted father of Dina and Spiro. Loving grandfather of Alexander, Evan & Serena. Dr. Ferris had a distinguished career as a physician for 50 years. In 1970 His Eminence Archbishop Iakovos awarded Dr. Ferris the Medal of St. Paul for outstanding service to the Greek Orthodox community. He was loved and appreciated by the elderly at St. Michael's Home for the Aged, where he gave medical service since it was founded in 1953. In 1972, His Eminence awarded him the title Archon Actouarios and appointed him to the Board of the Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, where he served for many years. Louis Ferris was a dedicated physician and humanitarian. He will be greatly missed. Funeral service will be held Saturday, October 13, 2001 at 11AM at the Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, 319 E. 74 St., New York City. For information, contact the Riverdale Funeral Home, 212-942-4000.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Surge In AIDS Orphans
description: South Africa will have more than two million AIDS orphans by 2010, a 13-fold increase, the Finance Ministry reported. The officials said the government must plan for the children, increase health spending and train more nurses and teachers to replace those killed by the disease. With 4.7 million people infected with the AIDS virus, South Africa has more people living with H.I.V. than any other country. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Novartis Sales Are Up
description: Novartis said that sales over the last nine months rose 11 percent, better than expected, as it benefited from two popular heart medications. The chairman of Novartis, Daniel Vasella, said that the company was on track for double-digit growth this year, with sales of its blood pressure drugs, Diovan and Lotrel, and its Alzheimer's treatment, Exelon, surging in the United States. Novartis, based in Basel, had $14.5 billion in sales in the first nine months of 2001, up from last year's $12.7 billion total. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

''Using the Western style, we have broken many taboos.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the possibility of action by the United States against terrorist groups in the Philippines and Indonesia misidentified the leader of Abu Sayyaf, an organization tied to Osama bin Laden that operates from the Philippines. The leader was believed to be Khaddafi Janjalani. (Abdujarak Abubakar Janjalani was his brother, who founded and headed the group but was reportedly killed in a firefight in the Philippines in 1998.)

title: Paris Regains Its Place At Forefront of Design
description: PARIS  A wave of new hotels, shops, restaurants and showrooms  plus an increasing focus on the talent of French designers  has rejuvenated Paris in the last 18 months, giving a new design identity to the city that many considered to have been left behind by London and New York in the '90s.

title: James Martello: Big Man With a Big Heart
description: Jimmy Martello wrote a lot of checks he did not have to. This foundation, that foundation, this friend in need, that stranger with the brain tumor and three children. He had grown up solidly middle class, a hefty Jersey guy -- 6 feet 3, 240 pounds -- who became a varsity linebacker at Rutgers and an impressively successful trader at Cantor Fitzgerald. Feeling blessed, he was always thinking of ways to give back.

title: Green Beats Ferrer in Democratic Mayoral Runoff
description: Against a backdrop of civic trauma and deep anxiety about the future of New York City, Mark Green won the Democratic nomination for mayor last night. He defeated Fernando Ferrer in a racially divided contest in which voters embraced Mr. Green's declaration that recovering from the World Trade Center attack should be the central focus of New York's next mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENDEROFF, BENJAMIN
description: SENDEROFF-Benjamin, Peacefully, October 10, after a long illness. Ever-loving and beloved husband of Edna. Treasured father of Paul and Joanne and fatherin-law of Barbara. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIFTER, DR. ELI.
description: SEIFTER-Dr. Eli. The Department of Surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine extends its deepest, heartfelt condolences to Dr. Sam Seifter, brother, and the entire family of Dr. Eli Seifter, Professor Emeritus of Surgery and Biochemistry, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, who died in Cleveland, Ohio on October 3rd, 2001. Dr. Seifter was an extremely valuable, inspiring member of our faculty, who made a number of important original, creative discoveries in oncology, tissue repair, and metabolism. He was a dedicated, charismatic teacher, a generous, unselfish colleague, and an effective bridge between basic science and clinical medicine and surgery. Dr. T.S. Ravikumar, Professor and University Chairman, Department of Surgery Dr. Stanley M. Levenson, University Professor Emeritus Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York

title: In Hawaii, Public Schools Feel a Long Way From Paradise
description: Kalani High School serves some of the more affluent neighborhoods in the United States, including a long strand of gated homes that open on the Pacific in the majestic shadow of Diamond Head.

title: Amazon Populist's Killing Exposes Bitter Conflicts
description: A lot of people here wanted Ademir Federicci dead, and some of them did not hesitate to say so. But up and down the length of the Trans-Amazon Highway, the question being asked is this: who actually killed Mr. Federicci, the region's most outspoken labor, peasant and environmental leader?

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Guilford: Officer Arrested In Drug Raid
description: A police officer and another man have been arrested and charged with operating a drug factory, the state police said yesterday. The officer, Keith Putzel, 41, a member of the Guilford police force, and Rodney Huff, 36, were arrested Tuesday after police seized cocaine, marijuana, and drug paraphernalia from a private residence and traced it to the two men. Mr. Putzel was released on $50,000 bond while Mr. Huff remained in custody yesterday in $25,000 bail. Hope Reeves (NYT)

description: No one, on either side, will acknowledge it, but Jason Giambi is as good as gone from the Oakland Athletics once their playoff run expires. The further they go in the postseason, the longer he will remain the heart of the Athletics. When he becomes a free agent, Giambi might leave his heart in Oakland, but he will take his bat elsewhere.

description: In the first Congressional action on legislation to stimulate the economy in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, the House Ways and Means Committee today approved tax cuts that would put an extra $100 billion into corporate treasuries and people's pockets over the next 12 months.

title: The Sometimes Dismal Nobel Prize
description: On Dec. 10, the Nobel Prize will turn 100, and to celebrate, the Nobel Foundation is planning a sumptuous weeklong party in Stockholm. Virtually every living Nobel Prize winner will be there. Along with laureates in physics, biology, chemistry, medicine and literature, naturally, will be the two dozen or so laureates in economics.

title: North Korea Cancels Reunions With the South
description: North Korea canceled today what was to have been the fourth set of reunions of families separated during the Korean War, citing South Korea's decision to place its armed forces on alert after the United States began airstrikes on Afghanistan last weekend.

title: Post Office To Proceed In Expanding Penn Station
description: After suggesting otherwise, the United States Postal Service has said it is ready to move full speed ahead on plans to expand Pennsylvania Station into a vast new ticketing hall and concourse in the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue.

title: A Pianist's Raw Emotion That Suits The Moment
description: For the past month performers have had to focus on -- and to some extent juggle -- some essential questions about the arts and their place in a world that changed suddenly and keeps changing. The question of whether to perform was settled early on: the consensus was that they must. But that left open questions of what to perform and how, and what a performance means in any case.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Teenage Pregnancy Rate Drops
description: The pregnancy rate for teenagers fell for the fifth consecutive year last year, following a national trend, state health officials announced. Oregon reported 14 pregnancies per every 1,000 girls ages 10 to 17 in 2000, or a total of 2,653, three years after Gov. John Kitzhaber started a statewide program to combat teenage pregnancy. The state surpassed its goal, set in 1997, of 15 pregnancies for every 1,000 girls for last year.

title: Breaking the Record, Time and Again
description: These big, brawny record-setters continue to steal our childhood dreams of permanence. In the wake of a new, iconic sports record -- Barry Bonds's 73 home runs -- fans again find their eternal verities shattered. Is there nothing that will last?

title: Most Precise Tests for Anthrax Take Time, Care and Money
description: Testing a suspicious powder for anthrax spores can be quick and inexpensive or slow and costly, experts said yesterday. And mistakes can be frequent, unless investigators take care and perform cross-checks.

title: State Owes Guardsmen Tuition, Legislators Say
description: Legislative leaders said today that the state should pay for college scholarships that were denied to National Guard troops after the program ran out of money, but Gov. George E. Pataki's office declined to take a position.
