Contributions to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: CONOCO TO SELL GULF PROPERTIES TO STONE ENERGY
description: Conoco Inc., the fourth-largest oil company, agreed to sell eight oil and natural gas properties in the Gulf of Mexico to the Stone Energy Corporation for about $300 million. Proceeds will be used to pay debt, a Conoco spokeswoman, Caroline Churchill, said. Conoco, based in Houston, said the sale would not affect its exploration and production in the gulf's deep waters. Stone Energy said yesterday that it agreed to buy an undisclosed number of gulf properties for as much as $300 million. Stone, an oil and gas explorer based in Lafayette, La., did not disclose the seller. Other companies with interests in the properties have bidding rights, and the final price for the transaction depends on which owners choose to exercise their rights, Conoco said. The sale to Stone Energy is expected to close Dec. 31, Conoco said.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER SETS CUTBACKS AT FREIGHTLINER
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., the largest truckmaker, said it would cut 2,700 jobs, close as many as three plants and take a $330 million charge in the fourth quarter to try to return its Freightliner truck unit to profitability. The unit -- the maker of Freightliner, Western Star and Sterling trucks -- will eliminate 1,600 union workers and 1,100 salaried positions, bringing the work force down to 11,700, a reduction of more than half since 1999. Freightliner, based in Portland, Ore., expects to cut about $850 million in costs annually by 2004. The truck unit has been hurt by a drop in demand as the economy slowed. DaimlerChrysler, based in Stuttgart, Germany, has also been hurt by a contractual obligation to repurchase trucks from customers for fixed prices.

description: In answer to inquiries from readers, The Times wishes to point out that no copies of the newspaper are printed in its Manhattan headquarters, where a letter and an unidentified substance were handed over to health authorities yesterday for testing. title: Outlook Isn't Brilliant for Yanks
description: The Yankees and their dynasty teetered for another day yesterday, trying to say and do what is normal for perennial champions while being burdened with a situation that is abnormal for them. So, honestly, nothing felt right. Not the somber five-hour flight to get here. Not the subdued workout. Not the tepid body language. The Yankees are stumbling down a dark street while wearing a blindfold, unsure of where to turn or whom to turn to.

title: Venezuela Doesn't See 'Carlos' as a Terrorist
description: The government of President Hugo Chvez, who has a reputation of not shying from incendiary comment, touched off a controversy this week by saying that it did not consider a Venezuelan-born assassin a terrorist. Government ministers also cast doubt on Washington's antiterrorism effort.

title: Finding the Great Fitzgerald In the Eyes That Knew Him
description: The Jazz Age. Flappers. Nattily dressed young people in convertibles, their scarves flying in the wind. It all seems like so many lifetimes ago that it's easy to forget there are still people alive who were there, and many others who knew the central players later in life, after the euphoric times had ended.

title: Reality Show Must Defer To Some Realer Reality
description: President Bush's prime-time news conference on Thursday did more than postpone the start of ''Survivor.'' That 45-minute delay would have been a strange enough misalignment of the stars, leading Dan Rather to look into the camera and say soberly, ''The premiere of 'Survivor: Africa' is right up next.'' More eerily, the president's appearance bumped off the air CBS's last show of the night, its C.I.A. series, ''The Agency,'' which happened to be about anthrax.

description: The red pads are staying. Chris Osgood will face his former teammates for the first time Saturday night, after the Detroit Red Wings left him unprotected in the waiver draft two weeks ago. But Osgood said today that his wearing the red pads was not to remind the Red Wings that he was once on their side, or that they might have made a big mistake when they got rid of him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: A New Stimulus Package
description: Faced with what it predicts will be its worst recession since it achieved independence in 1965, Singapore announced yesterday a $6.2 billion economic stimulus package intended to cushion the effects of a global slowdown on its export-dependent economy. The package, which comes after a $1.2 billion package announced in July, includes tax rebates, accelerated government spending and relief measures for the unemployed. Singapore now estimates its economy will contract 3 percent this year. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: A Wagnerian Voice Reaches For 'Norma'
description: It took Jane Eaglen's arrival on the scene as a major Wagner soprano for the Metropolitan Opera to bring ''Tristan und Isolde'' back after an absence of 20 years. That acclaimed new production was introduced in the fall of 1999.

title: This Could Be China's Year In Battle for Bermuda Bowl
description: The Bermuda Bowl, contested every other year, has never been won by a team from Asia, although Taiwan and Pakistan have come close. But when the title is contested in Paris later this month, China is likely to be a strong contender. That country's players have been getting better and better since Deng Xiaoping, an enthusiast himself, gave bridge his blessing after the Cultural Revolution in the People's Republic.

description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre and General Manager Brian Cashman may each complete negotiations for a contract extension within a week, all but assuring that George Steinbrenner's brain trust will remain intact for another season.

title: Nobel Peace Prize Is Awarded to Annan and U.N.
description: Declaring that the United Nations was rising at last to the mission for which it was created in 1945, the Norwegian Nobel Committee today awarded the Nobel Peace Prize to Secretary General Kofi Annan and to the international organization itself.

title: Russian Gas Company to Sell Media Holdings
description: Russia's natural gas giant, Gazprom, announced today that it would sell its media holdings, including the NTV television network, which Gazprom, a government-controlled company, took over in a boardroom coup this spring.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Matsushita Electric Sees Larger Loss
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, already battered by a downturn in spending on technology and consumer electronics, said the decline in the value of its stock portfolio pushed it further into the red for the first half of its fiscal year. Matsushita Electric, which makes the Panasonic brand, expects to report a loss of 68 billion yen ($562 million) for the six months that ended Sept. 30, about 50 percent larger than the loss it forecast in July. Under new accounting rules, companies must value their shareholdings at market value rather than their original purchase price. During the half-year that ended in September, the benchmark Nikkei 225 fell 25 percent.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Cease-Fire Setback
description: Straining Ulster's shaky peace, Britain ruled that cease-fires called by the Ulster Defense Association and the Loyalist Volunteer Force no longer exist, after months of attacks on Catholics and the police. This means that members of the two Protestant paramilitary groups freed under the 1998 Good Friday agreement could be sent back to jail. But Protestant officials said the action would foment violence. Britain also said the Loyalist Volunteer Force was almost certainly responsible for the killing last month of an investigative reporter, Martin O'Hagan, the first journalist assassinated in three decades of sectarian conflict. The Irish Republican Army is still regarded by Britain as maintaining its cease-fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLOOM, BENJAMIN
description: ROSENBLOOM-Benjamin. Hillel: Foundation for Jewish Campus Life extends its deepest condolences to the Rosenbloom family on the passing of our beloved friend and benefactor, Benjamin Rosenbloom. Ben was committed to passing on the light of Jewish living to the next generation, an objective he accomplished magnificently through his children and grandchildren, and through his commitment to Hillel. He is survived by his wife Esther, his sister Mildred Hecht, his children Howard and Harriet, and his grandchildren Cynthia, Keith, Sandy and Robert. May his menschlichkeit always be a source of inspiration. Edgar M. Bronfman, Chairman Lynn Schusterman, Co-Chair Michael Steinhardt, Co-Chair Richard M. Joel, President

title: SHARES OF PROVIDIAN, CREDIT CARD ISSUER, FALL SHARPLY
description: Shares of Providian Financial fell as much as 34 percent after the company said yesterday that third-quarter earnings were about 75 percent lower than expected because more people could not pay their credit card bills. Shares of Providian, the fifth-largest issuer of MasterCard and Visa credit cards, fell $6.90, to $13.45. Other credit card issuers also tumbled. Providian, whose customers include people with weak credit histories, said that earnings were 19 cents to 21 cents a share in the quarter. On Sept. 4, it expected to earn 82 cents to 84 cents. Lenders to people with high debt-to-income ratios may have more difficulty than other credit card companies in coming months, particularly if the economy does not rebound soon, analysts said.

title: Anthrax Found in NBC News Aide
description: An assistant to the NBC anchor Tom Brokaw has tested positive for anthrax infection more than two weeks after she handled two threatening letters addressed to Mr. Brokaw, one that contained a white powder and the other a sandlike substance, officials and NBC executives said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Court Bars Execution
description: A federal appeals court panel commuted the death sentence of a convicted killer because he could understand his punishment only if the state forced him to take anti-psychotic drugs. The ruling, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, came in the case of Charles L. Singleton, 42, who was convicted of murdering a grocer in 1979.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Apology For 26 Lost Migrants
description: The minister in charge of South Korea's information service, Park Joon Young, has apologized to China for the deaths of 26 Chinese men who suffocated in the hold of a boat that was smuggling them to South Korea. Mr. Park called it a horrible crime and promised a thorough investigation. So far, however, the police have found none of the bodies, which were dumped into the ocean as the ship was nearing South Korea. Another 34 people arrived safely. The police blame an organized gang that specializes in smuggling illegal migrants. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: Anthrax is not contagious. Symptoms usually appear 12 hours to 5 days after exposure. In rare cases, symptoms may take 6 weeks to develop.

title: Nearly Silent Universes With No Need for Words
description: This year the New York Film Festival begins ''Views From the Avant-Garde,'' its annual tribute to experimental film, with a program featuring potent pieces by three celebrated masters of the form: Robert Beavers, Stan Brakhage and Nathaniel Dorsky. It's hard not to be impressed by the films' sound (or the lack of it), which is by far the most prevalent element. This is an act of bravado, daring audiences to train their attention on the screen and on the way these filmmakers mold space. They want us to respond to the purity of cinema.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Forecasts A Loss
description: The Japan Airlines Company became the latest international carrier to lower its earnings estimate after the terrorist attacks in the United States. The airline, Japan's flagship carrier, expects to lose 40 billion yen ($331 million) as a group in the year ending next March, after anticipating a profit earlier. The company also lowered its sales forecast by 9.6 percent. Last week, Japan Airlines grounded almost one-quarter of its trans-Pacific flights.

title: A Slow Turn as the Briquettes Glow
description: Nobody can accuse Brett Neveu's likable dark comedy "The Last Barbecue" of being talky. Most of the time its five characters speak in short, seemingly innocuous sentences ("Are you getting bit up?" "No." "I could light a citronella candle." "I'm fine." "Here."). They seem largely ill at ease with one another. And it's amazing how much they convey.

title: The Giants' First Line of Defense Will Be Pivotal
description: Before this season began, the Giants' defensive front four was widely lauded as the N.F.L.'s best. After a slow start, the unit has been playing better. But if there was ever a game when the Giants will need a commanding, authoritative performance from the team's touted defensive line, and especially its most noted player, Michael Strahan, then it is Sunday in St. Louis. No unit on the Giants has the opportunity to have a greater impact on the game.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Pregnant Woman Faces Stoning
description: A pregnant 30-year-old woman has been sentenced to death by stoning by an Islamic court in Sokoto State that found her guilty of having engaged in premarital sex. It was the first time an Islamic court in Nigeria had sentenced a woman to death since a dozen predominantly Muslim states in the north adopted Islamic law over the last two years. Early this year, a 17-year-old girl in Zamfara received 100 lashes for the same offense.

title: Czechs Fear That U.S. Radio Station Is Target in Their Midst
description: The United States-led airstrikes against Afghanistan have raised fears among some Czech government officials that Radio Free Europe, based here since 1995, could become a target for terrorism. In recent days, top officials have suggested in interviews in local news media that the radio service should move out of the city center.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Numbers Say Recession
description: The state's unemployment rate rose in September, officially putting the state in a recession, state economists say. The rate rose from 6.3 percent in August to 6.4 percent last month, its highest level in more than seven years. The unemployment rate is more than a percentage point higher than the nation's average, and is one of the country's highest. Manufacturing had the largest number of layoffs last month. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Minister Resigns Under Fire
description: Finance Minister Jorge Gallardo resigned in order to fight criminal charges that he and eight other officials misused funds when he was president of a government-run bank last year. Mr. Gallardo, left, who was in Washington trying to secure $300 million in new funding from Ecuador's foreign creditors when his departure was announced, is to be replaced by Carlos Julio Emanuel, a former president of the central bank.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Credit Rating Cut
description: Argentina's credit rating has been cut by Moody's Investors Service for the fourth time this year, taking it below that of any other country. Moody's said it was concerned that the government was taking steps that could lead to a debt default. Moody's reduced Argentina's ratings for foreign and local currency debt to Caa3 from Caa1, after the government demanded that domestic investors swap bonds for new securities paying lower interest. The exchange may presage a similar swap with international bondholders, Moody's said. Foreign funds and institutions own 60 percent of Argentina's $132 billion debt. Argentina, which has defaulted four times since it became an independent country, secured an $8 billion loan in August from the International Monetary Fund.

description: GILMORE-Naomi. The National Treasury Employees Union notes with deep sorrow the death of one of our most effective and beloved leaders, Naomi Gilmore, former president of NTEU Chapter 99. Naomi's gifts of humor, intelligence, wisdom, warmth and kindness complimented her unrelenting pursuit of justice and fair play. She taught people how to assert and win their rights to be treated with dignity and respect, giving others the confidence to believe in themselves. This world is a far better place for her having lived. In bereavement, we embrace her husband Seth, and children Brian and Lisa, her daughter-in-law Janet, grandchildren Hannah, David and Rachael, her parents and sister. National Treasury Employees Union Colleen M. Kelley National President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Wants More For World Cup
description: AXA, a large insurance company, said it would withdraw from covering next year's World Cup soccer finals unless it could renegotiate terms to account for greater risks after the terrorist attacks on the United States. The World Cup is scheduled to be held in Japan and Korea May 31 through June 30. FIFA, soccer's ruling body, has a policy for 1.4 billion Swiss francs ($853 million) with AXA's German unit, AXA Konzern, to insure the tournament against cancellation. ''We want to renegotiate,'' said Ingo A. Koch, an AXA spokesman in Cologne, Germany. ''There is a totally new risk situation in the world since Sept. 11. Our strong wish is to arrive at a solution.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFENDINI, RICHARD
description: DEFENDINI-Richard. The Division of Neuropathology and the Department of Pathology at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons mourn the loss of our respected friend and colleague, Dr. Richard Defendini, 75, who passed away on October 9, 2001. An accomplished neurologist and neuropathologist, Richard was a mainstay of our Division for 25 years after joining the faculty in 1970. He was widely admired for his broad knowledge and scholarly approach to clinical neuroscience. We will miss his experience, counsel and optimistic view of life. Our deep condolences to his wife, Alma Elena del Villar, and family. James E. Goldman, M.D., Ph.D. Arthur P. Hays, M.D. Michael L. Shelanski, M.D., Ph.D. Divison of Neuropathology

title: Why Fear National ID Cards?
description: At many bridges and tunnels across the country, drivers avoid long delays at the toll booths with an unobtrusive device that fits on a car's dashboard. Instead of fumbling for change, they drive right through; the device sends a radio signal that records their passage. They are billed later. It's a tradeoff between privacy and convenience: the toll-takers know more about you -- when you entered and left Manhattan, for instance -- but you save time and money.

description: Although the F.B.I. was notified on Sept. 25 about a suspicious letter sent to NBC, neither the letter, nor the powder residue inside them were tested until nearly five or six days later, and then only because a private doctor notified city public health officials about a troubling skin condition in the news assistant who had handled the mail, officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: Journal; No News Is Good News
description: We learned this week that if we can't bring Osama bin Laden to justice dead or alive, the White House can still slap him with that most American form of capital punishment -- kicking him off network television.

title: The President and the War: A Status Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about preparations by the United States and Britain for a long military engagement in Afghanistan misattributed statements about how long the campaign might last. It was Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, not President Bush, who said: "You have to prepare for the worst and hope for the best. But we expect it to be a long effort. And we're getting arranged so that we can sustain ourselves over a period of time."

title: Alienated Teenagers Find Sanctuary in a Pop Star
description: In the early days of MTV -- the ''I want my MTV'' days -- one of the cable outlet's slogans was ''too much is never enough.'' The same attitude could apply to the New York Film Festival offering ''All About Lily Chou-Chou,'' which offers an onslaught of feelings and footage that's quite daunting.

title: The Return of Partisanship
description: The brief era of cooperation on the economy, fraying around the edges for days, all but fell apart in Washington yesterday. Almost as soon as President Bush finished hugging the high ground Thursday night in his news conference, House Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee spent all day Friday ramming through a $100 billion tax-cut package filled with bonuses for corporations, wealthy Americans and others least in need of help. Republicans waited until 10:30 p.m. the night before to spring the bill on Democrats, reverting to the poisonous old practices of steamrolling legislation through and, this time, exploiting a tragic national emergency in the process.

title: Dwindling Numbers, Constant Faith; Mostly Black Order of Nuns in Harlem Celebrates 85 Years
description: Sister Mary Magdalen, 91, spends her days in the parlor of the convent of the Franciscan Handmaids of Mary in Harlem, watching ''Mother Angelica Live,'' a television program on the Eternal Word Television Network, and crocheting blankets and dresses for dolls that are sold at the convent's yearly bazaar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, NAOMI LEAH
description: SOLOMON-Naomi Leah. Died September 11 at the World Trade Center disaster. Formerly of Chase Bank and Vice President of Callixa. She was well known and respected throughout the financial community. Naomi was cherished and will forever be missed by her loving parents, Dr. Herbert and Lottie Solomon, her brothers Mark and Jed and their wives, Caroline and Leslie. A most devoted aunt to Jake and Sarah and to Nathaniel Liam born on September 18, 2001 and named in her memory. Naomi was also cherished by her uncles and aunts Seymour and Ruth, Henry and Jacqueline and cousins. That she was brilliant, charming with a magnetic personality is evident by the effect she had on all who knew and loved her. A memorial service is being held for Naomi at Beth Am Synagogue, Los Altos Hills, Calif. on Sunday, October 14 at 3:30PM.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: ISLAM -- Cairo; Thousands Hear Call Of Prayer and Politics At World's Mosques
description: In mosques yesterday, Muslims gathered for Friday Prayers, and in many instances the preaching was political and sharply anti-American. Here is a sampling from some of the largest mosques in Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: German Bank May Invest In Rails
description: A major German bank said it might invest in Railtrack, the bankrupt owner of Britain's train tracks and stations. It is unclear whether the bank, Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozen, or WestLB, would buy Railtrack's 20,000 miles of track and 2,500 stations, or provide financing to a new company that would control the assets. The government wants to create a nonprofit trust to run Railtrack; the trust would be required to invest all profits back into the business. Railtrack shares ceased trading on the London Stock Exchange on Monday, prompting an outcry from investors, who accused the government of back-door renationalization of Railtrack, which was privatized in 1996. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Yankees Get a Look at the Brink in Oakland
description: Yogi Berra's mantra of ''It ain't over till it's over'' was written on the cap Manager Joe Torre wore during the Yankees' workout today. He met with his weary players for about 10 minutes and reminded them to try not to do too much, to try to keep everything simple when the series resumes Saturday.

title: Camby, Injured Again, To Miss at Least a Week
description: The Knicks spent the off-season searching for a big man to help Marcus Camby. The search could take on more significance after the team announced today that Camby would miss at least a week with plantar fasciitis in his left foot.

title: SEGA, GAMES DEVELOPER, ADDS TO MICROSOFT DEAL
description: The Sega Corporation, the creator of the Sonic the Hedgehog game character, said it would develop two more games for Microsoft's Xbox game console, extending an alliance the two companies formed in March. Sega, which scrapped its own Dreamcast console earlier this year because of poor sales, said it would develop Shenmue II and Phantasy Star Online for Xbox. The games will be developed by two Sega units devoted to software design. With the additional games, Sega, which is based in Tokyo, is now developing 13 titles for the Xbox, Microsoft's first foray into the $20 billion video game industry. Sega, which has lost money the last four years, has shifted gears this year, getting out of the hardware business and focusing on software design for its own game library and for companies like Sony and Nintendo. Xbox will make its debut in the United States on Nov. 15 at $299.

title: Operation Slick Moniker: Military Name Game
description: For a few days in September it looked as if the United States would be fighting a war named Infinite Justice. By late September the name was gone. The Council on American-Islamic Relations had found the name offensive because it sounded too much like Eternal Retribution. In other words the United States seemed to be assuming God's role. On Sept. 25 Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld announced that the military operation would be called Enduring Freedom.

title: The President and the War: A Status Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Campaign So Far
description: After five days of airstrikes against Taliban and Al Qaeda targets in Afghanistan, the United States eased its attacks yesterday, the Muslim day of prayer, before resuming the bombing of fixed targets early Saturday morning. Pentagon officials said the week's attacks had disrupted communications, weakened the Taliban military, and damaged its air defenses.

title: Giuliani Is Resolute on Extending His Term
description: Now that the Democratic mayoral primary runoff is over, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is making it clear that he meant what he said about wanting to stay.

title: Abroad at Home; Mr. Bush's New World
description: In one traumatic month President Bush's view of America and the world has been transformed. One sentence at his press conference Thursday made that stunningly clear.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: ISLAM -- New Delhi; Thousands Hear Call Of Prayer and Politics At World's Mosques
description: In mosques yesterday, Muslims gathered for Friday Prayers, and in many instances the preaching was political and sharply anti-American. Here is a sampling from some of the largest mosques in Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, ELINOR M.
description: PARKER-Elinor M. Died Wilmington, DE, October 9, 2001, age 95. Former resident New York City and Morristown, New Jersey. BA in English Lit. Bryn Mawr College. Forty-two years with Charles Scribner's Sons, retiring as Editor, VP & Director. Author of 16 books including ''Cooking For One'', a biography of Queen Elizabeth II, and several poetry anthologies. Served on the Altar Guild at St. James Episcopal Church. Interests were sailing, hiking, knitting and needlework and classical music. She enjoyed travel, especially to the British Isles. Survived by 3 generations of nieces and nephews. Services at Christ Church Christiana Hundred, Wilmington October 16, 2001 at 1:00PM. Burial at Northeast Harbor, ME. at a later date. Please no flowers, contributions to Bryn Mawr College, 101 N. Merion Avenue, Bryn Mawr, PA. 19010-2899. For further information Chandler Funeral Home.

title: For Mail Clerks in Florida, A New and Dire Concern
description: As the urgent search for people exposed to anthrax moved today into the post offices of South Florida, the workers who sort the nation's mail became increasingly concerned that they might have distributed the deadly disease and come in contact with it.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Bush's manner during his news conference on Thursday night misstated the surname of the CNN commentator who drew a Shakespearean analogy to the president's growth. The speaker was Jeff Greenfield, not Greenberg.

title: Realtor's Heir Is Investigated In 2 Killings
description: Los Angeles detectives investigating the Christmas Eve murder of a confidante of real estate scion Robert A. Durst will go to Texas early next week to inspect a weapon the police said Mr. Durst had with him on Tuesday when he was arrested in the murder and dismemberment of a 71-year-old man in Galveston.

title: Nobel Peace Prize Is Awarded to Annan and U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 12  Declaring that the United Nations was rising at last to the mission for which it was created in 1945, the Norwegian Nobel Committee today awarded the Nobel Peace Prize to Secretary General Kofi Annan and to the international organization itself.

title: Executive Retiring at ChevronTexaco
description: The ChevronTexaco Corporation, formed this week when Chevron bought Texaco, said that Richard Matzke, the vice chairman, will retire next year after 40 years with Chevron. He will be succeeded by Peter Robertson, the vice president.

title: Broad Market Falls but Nasdaq Rises a Bit
description: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell yesterday for the first time in three days as a drop in profits at Providian Financial, a credit card company, heightened concern more consumers will default on loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVAK, JUDITH IRIS
description: NOVAK-Judith Iris. Age 58 died October 8, 2001 at home after a long, gallant and arduous battle with lung cancer. Devoted daughter of the late Leon H. and Helen Novak. Beloved sister of Ronald and Rose Novak. An inspiring and courageous mother of Vanessa (Joe Kmetz) of Bozeman, Montana and Jillian of New York and Los Angeles. Loving aunt of Mara (Dr. Mitchell Miller) and Leila and great-aunt of Gareth and Zoe. Judy was a graduate of Pratt/NYU & an innovative and witty graphic designer. She lived in Florida for a number of years, but joyfully came home to Manhattan six years ago. She then received an M.A. in Counselling from NYU and had begun to plan for a PsyD at the time of her initial diagnosis. During her illness she continued to paint. The Judiff was forever young and beautiful, gifted and funny, and modest. She was and will always be an endless source of strength for her children, her family, her friends and all who are blessed to have known her. The family will be at home Thursday, Friday and Saturday from 4-8 PM. A memorial service will be held at The National Academy of Design, 1083 5th Avenue at 90th Street, Monday, October 15, at 11:30 AM.

title: White House Said to Have Relief Plan For Insurers
description: The White House plans to propose that the federal government relieve insurance companies of 80 percent or more of the cost of damages from any terrorist attacks over the next year, administration officials and Congressional officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIGEN, MORRIS
description: EIGEN-Morris. A prominent NY dress manufacturer for over 70 years, and friend to hundreds, passed away in his home. He was 93 years old and had recently returned from a trip to Vietnam and Cambodia with his family. His wife, Beatrice Eigen, had passed away in 1983. Co-Founder of Bloom & Egan, Heiser-Egan and Brilliante, Mr. Eigen is survived by his children, Lewis Eigen and Ramona Arnett of Potomac, MD, Judith Sarna and Morris Sarna of New York, his grandchildren, Jonathan and Anna Eigen, his greatgranddaughter, Thalia Beatrice Eigen, his siblings, Mrs. Pearl Tyrell of Del Ray Beach, Mrs. Fran Matlick of Great Neck, and Jay Eigen of Indianapolis, and his very close friends, Mr. Jules Gantman and Mrs. Gyrene Privette. Funeral services will be held at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, 1:15PM, October 15th. The family will sit Shiva at the home of Judith and Morris Sarna, 6 West 77 St., from October 15-19. Donations in his name should be sent to The Abraham Fund, 477 Madison Ave., NYC; National Coalition of Children of Alcoholics, 11426 Rockville Pike, Rockville, MD 20852; or The Letricia Privette Scholarship Fund, C/O Judy Sarna, charities on which his children serve as directors.

title: Disaster Relief for the Schools
description: Count the New York City school system among the victims of Sept. 11. Already struggling before the terrorist attack, the schools have been rocked by disaster-related expenses that have further undermined the system's ability to provide the basic education that the city's children are entitled to under the law.

title: Uzbekistan to Let U.S. Use Bases In Return for Promise of Security
description: The United States and Uzbekistan announced an agreement on Friday that would give the American military flexibility in operating from bases in the former Soviet republic in return for Washington's assurance to protect Uzbekistan's security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMKOFF, CLAIRE
description: SAMKOFF-Claire. The family of Lila and Harold Breiter mourns the loss of Claire Samkoff; beloved sister of Lila Breiter; loving aunt of Alan and Diane, Jeanne and Ken and Linda and Joe; grand-aunt of Russell and Randee, Abbe and Jeffrey, Stacy and Eric, Jennifer, Meredith and Joshua; great grand-aunt of Samantha, Steven, Noah and Rachel. Our condolences to Claire's daughters Holly, Julie and son-in-law David, and her grandchildren Jodi, Alex and Evie. We will all miss her and always cherish the many happy times we shared together.

title: The Deep Intellectual Roots of Islamic Terror
description: Long before Osama bin Laden appeared on television screens with an AK-47 by his side, he released earlier videotapes in which he appears in the guise of a holy man, sitting peacefully in front of a wall of books. That scholarly backdrop is an important symbol for Mr. bin Laden's terrorist movement as he tries to legitimize his extremist views of Islam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTONE, MYRA
description: GREENSTONE-Myra. A gracious lady, always caring, always giving, who made a difference. We will miss you. Blossom, Angela and Sam

title: A Labor Leader on the Rise as His Workers Are Down
description: FOR the last two years John Wilhelm, president of the nation's largest hotel workers' union, has been considered the man to watch in the labor movement.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Airline Security Stalemate

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERMAN, FAYE (NEE ROGOFF)
description: KERMAN-Faye (nee Rogoff). On October 12th, 2001 of Roslyn, LI. Beloved wife of Samuel. Devoted mother of Jeffrey (Marilyn) and Thea. Dear sister of Gussie Gruber and the late Sherry Lawrence. Cherished grandmother of Alex and Matthew. Services on Sunday, 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Spare Times for Children column of Weekend yesterday for a ''Kids N' Comedy'' performance on Sunday at 4 p.m. at the Gotham Comedy Club in Manhattan misstated the telephone number. It is (212) 877-6115.

title: Slowly, More Roadways Reopening in Manhattan
description: Getting into and around Manhattan by car is getting a bit easier, as the city is once again easing restrictions on nonemergency traffic.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Four-Day Week To Save Energy
description: Responding to the failure of the northeastern region to cut electricity consumption by 20 percent, as required in the emergency rationing plan that went into effect four months ago, the government has ordered a four-day work week in the nine-state area beginning later this month. The 50 million residents have cut electricity use by little more than half the mandated amount. With hot summer weather on the way and a drought still prevailing, the government imposed the harsher measures in order to avoid California-style rolling blackouts. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: BID FOR COMDISCO SALVAGE UNIT IS CHALLENGED
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company will challenge SunGard Data System's agreement to acquire the computer disaster-recovery business of Comdisco Inc. for $825 million in a bankruptcy-court auction. SunGard, which makes software that automates stock and bond trades and also has a disaster-recovery business, topped a $610 million bid made by Hewlett-Packard in July. SunGard offered $775 million in August for the unit, which helps companies minimize loss of data and technology in disasters. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said SunGard's purchase would violate antitrust laws. Hewlett-Packard said its bid was ''pro-customer and pro-competition.'' The sale to SunGard is subject to approval by the Federal Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of Illinois at a hearing on Oct. 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOETZ, RUTH
description: GOETZ-Ruth. On October 10th, 2001, of Roslyn, LI. Devoted mother of Dorianne Zammetti. Loving aunt of Miles and Russell Haber. Services Sunday, 2:30 PM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: National Briefing | Education: Pledge Day
description: Students across the country joined in a coordinated pledge of allegiance to the American flag. Participation in the nationwide pledge, led by President Bush at the White House and Secretary of Education Rod Paige, was described as far higher than in previous years, although education officials said they did not have figures.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Governor Seeks More Troops
description: Gov. Angus King has asked for federal financing for more National Guard troops to oversee Maine's border crossings with Canada. More attentive inspections have led to long waits at some of the state's 23 official checkpoints, which Mr. King said was impeding trade between Canada and border states. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: The Mayor, the Prince and the $10 Million
description: To the Editor:

title: Opposition in Zimbabwe Fights Mugabe, but Also Itself
description: Zimbabwe is headed into one of its most controversial presidential elections since white rule ended in 1980, with the leading opposition party pitched not only against the incumbent, Robert Mugabe, but often against itself.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Farmers Rally For Land Reform
description: Angry over the government's slow pace in granting them land, and buffeted by a drought that destroyed many crops in Central America this summer, thousands of indigenous farmers blocked roads in a protest. The farmers put up about 100 roadblocks demanding land reform and pay increases. President Alfonso Portillo agreed to meet with indigenous leaders, but has ruled out large-scale agrarian reform. The protest came on what indigenous groups, who form the majority of the population, consider the Day of the Race, as opposed to Columbus Day.

title: No New Anthrax Cases Found at Florida Company
description: Federal authorities said today that they had completed testing of nearly all of the 1,000 people connected to the American Media building here and found no new cases of anthrax exposure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALL, GERTRUDE
description: SMALL-Gertrude. Of New Rochelle, on October 12, 2001. Wife of Dr. Louis A. Small. Mother and mother-in-law of Robert & Carla Small and Stanley and Amy Small. Grandmother of Samantha, Gabrielle and her husband Mark Tullman, Katie and Michael. Great grandmother of Anya. A graveside service will be held at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY on Sunday, October 14 at 1 P.M.
