description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, INGA
description: JOSEPH-Inga. Died October 9 from injuries sustained during the September 11 attack on the World Trade Center. She leaves behind family and friends in her native Berlin and in New York City. A New Yorker for over 3 decades, she revelled in the great music of a great city. Services Saturday 7 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made in Inga's memory the Metropolitan Opera Guild, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023

title: Beni Montresor, Artist in 2 Worlds, Dies at 78
description: Beni Montresor, who conjured magical, dreamlike images in the children's books he illustrated and the sets and costumes he designed for opera productions around the world, died on Thursday in Verona, Italy, near the village where he was born. He was 78.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LECHTERS INC., Harrison, N.J., a housewares retailer that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in May, said it would close its 315 stores after 90-day going-out-of-business sales as part of its liquidation of assets.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Accusations Against Fund-Raiser
description: As part of a long-running federal investigation of Atlanta's City Hall, a fund-raiser for Mayor Bill Campbell was charged with structuring financial transactions to evade currency reporting requirements. The fund-raiser, C. R. Thornton, a developer, was accused of aiding others in avoiding currency transaction reports in directing $56,000 in contributions to Mr. Campbell's 1997 campaign. The United States attorney's office in Atlanta said that Mr. Thornton was expected to plead guilty next week. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about preparations by the United States and Britain for a long military engagement in Afghanistan misattributed statements about how long the campaign might last. It was Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, not President Bush, who said: ''You have to prepare for the worst and hope for the best. But we expect it to be a long effort. And we're getting arranged so that we can sustain ourselves over a period of time.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, WINIFRED WOOD
description: CLARK-Winifred Wood. October 11, 2001. Sarah Lawrence College records with sorrow the death of Winifred Wood Clark, devoted alumna (Class of 1932) and trustee of the College for over 40 years. She was a woman of extraordinary grace, widsom, and dignity. We will miss her greatly, and extend our deep sympathy to her family. Margot C. Bogert, Chairman of the Board Michele Tolela Myers, President

title: Budget Woes Of the M.T.A. Grow Worse
description: Anyone who has glanced at a subway map printed after Sept. 11 can understand the immense physical damage wrought to the system by the World Trade Center attack: an eerie, empty space where a subway line once ran, its tunnels now collapsed and three of its stations closed.

title: U.S. Raid Kills Unknown Number in an Afghan Village
description: Karam is a village in the hills of eastern Afghanistan, barely an hour from the border with Pakistan. Villagers say a training camp for Islamic guerrillas was once situated nearby, though it has been closed for several years.

title: F.B.I. Did Not Test Letters to NBC Or Immediately Notify City Hall
description: Although the F.B.I. was notified on Sept. 25 about suspicious letters sent to NBC, neither the letters, nor the powder residue inside them were tested until nearly two weeks later, and then only because a private doctor notified city public health officials about a troubling skin condition in the news assistant who had handled the mail, officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: DIVIDEND IS INCREASED FOR FIRST TIME SINCE 1997
description: The Eastman Kodak Company increased its dividend for the first time in four years and said it would shift payments to a semiannual basis from quarterly. The dividend was increased to 45 cents from 44 cents and will be paid on Dec. 20 to shareholders of record as of Dec. 3, the company said. Kodak will then switch to semiannual payments in July and December. The company, based in Rochester, expects to pay full-year dividends of $1.80 a share in 2002.

title: Rising Fears At Drugstores, And Suspicion Of Office Mail
description: The store's supply was long depleted and there had been one too many calls, so when the phone rang yet again, the pharmacist picked it up and blurted, ''We're out of Cipro!''

title: Irmgard Aluli, 89, Hawaiian Singer Known as Auntie Irmgard
description: Irmgard Farden Aluli, a songwriter and performer whose many tenderly eloquent compositions in a career of more than 70 years made her one of the last links to a golden era of Hawaiian popular music, died on Oct. 4 in Honolulu. She was 89.

title: White House Battles Plan On Airports
description: The White House today continued to resist a Senate plan to turn all airport workers who screen passengers and luggage into federal employees and said it would impose new aviation security measures by executive order if Congress does not agree on a plan soon.

title: Company Tried To Capitalize On Sept. 11
description: On Sept. 21, at least 76 families of passengers who died in the four terrorist hijackings of Sept. 11 received packets containing a leatherlike portfolio stuffed with $50 to $200 in cash, prepaid calling cards and the names of four law firms with ''extensive experience in major airline and other similar mass disasters.''

title: Privacy Debate Focuses on F.B.I. Use of an Internet Wiretap
description: Carnivore, the F.B.I.'s Internet wiretap system, is one of the best-known technologies for monitoring computer communications and is at the heart of the debate over the antiterrorism bills moving through Congress this week.

title: Mariners Remain Upbeat Despite Unknown Pitcher
description: The Seattle Mariners understood the importance of winning Game 2 of their American League division series on Thursday. They just did not talk about it, and they certainly did not act as if more was at stake.

title: Trade Officials Hope to Clear Air Before Big Meeting
description: Top trade officials are heading for Singapore this weekend for a meeting aimed at breaking a logjam of issues standing in the way of a new global trade liberalization round.

title: The Mayor, the Prince and the $10 Million
description: To the Editor:

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: ISLAM -- Quetta, Pakistan; Thousands Hear Call Of Prayer and Politics At World's Mosques
description: In mosques yesterday, Muslims gathered for Friday Prayers, and in many instances the preaching was political and sharply anti-American. Here is a sampling from some of the largest mosques in Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

title: Quieter Guns, a Worrisome Infection, the Flow of Money
description: The Bush administration disclosed more elements of a rapidly expanding military and financial campaign against Osama bin Laden's network, talking yesterday of impending operations on the ground in Afghanistan, and naming an additional 27 individuals and groups as financial supporters of the terrorists. The list included a prominent Saudi businessman, adding to pressure on the reluctant Saudi royalty to take stiffer measures against financiers in their country.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FANIZZI, JOSEPHINE M.
description: FANIZZI-Josephine M. October 13, 1901. Dear Mom, in a hundred ways, we remember. Ann and Rose

title: Bowden Has Still Got the Charm at Florida State
description: Inside Wings Sports Grille, Bobby Bowden used commercial breaks of his show to shake hands and hold babies and smile while proud parents snapped pictures. Bowden, in his 26th season as the Florida State football coach, also autographed helmets and footballs while a nervous director counted down the time before the live broadcast would resume on local television and statewide radio.

title: Anthrax in New York
description: The discovery of an anthrax case in New York City -- coming on top of three anthrax exposures in Florida -- has heightened concern in a nation that was already jittery and waiting for the next terrorist act to occur. Top officials at NBC announced yesterday that an employee had developed a full-fledged case of anthrax several days after the network received ''suspicious mail.'' She is being treated with antibiotics and is said to be doing well. Nevertheless, her case has multiplied the fears generated by an episode at a Florida newspaper publisher where one editor died of anthrax apparently inhaled at his workplace and two others who worked in the mail room were exposed to the anthrax germ but have not become sick.

title: Green's Campaign Angers Backers of Ferrer
description: Many of Fernando Ferrer's strongest supporters say they were outraged by what they considered heavy-handed and racially charged tactics of the Green campaign in the final days before Thursday's runoff election.

title: Sudan Government Tops List of Those Causing Agony for Oil
description: Since Sudan began producing oil two years ago, pumping crude in fields near here, Nyekek Luok has been wandering on foot, terrified and uprooted by fierce new fighting in the continent's longest and most murderous civil war.

title: Former Teamsters President Is Cleared of Lying Charges
description: Ron Carey, the former president of the Teamsters union, was found not guilty yesterday on federal perjury charges after a four-week trial in Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Inching Toward An Admission
description: The government came closer to admitting that its miltary had shot down a Russian passenger jet over the Black Sea last week, but fell short of assuming responsibility for the crash, which killed all 78 people on board. The national security secretary, Yevgeny Marchuk, said the crash could have been caused by an unintentional hit by an S-200 missile during air defense exercises.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B.

title: U.S. Has Received Additional Credible Threats of Attacks
description: In the last 24 hours, the government has received additional credible threats of imminent terror attacks against Americans inside the United States or overseas, possibly as early as Sunday, senior government officials said today.

title: Bush Easing Stand on Sharing Of Secret Data
description: President Bush took another step today toward loosening his recent restrictions on sharing classified information with Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, LEE
description: KORN-Lee. Passed away on October 11th, 2001, age 95. Widow of the late Irving Korn with whom she shared 69 years of wonderful marriage. Survived by her cherished children, Sheldon and Irys Korn, and Robert and Joan Korn, and by her beloved grandchildren and great grandchildren, Ilene and Dave Zatt, Stacie, Gary, Ross and Lucas Spielfogel, Melanie, Keith, Casey and Dylan Stanton, Gary, Shari, Jordan, Jamie and Emily Korn, and Wendy, Erik, Daniel and Matthew Bronstein. She was a loving and intelligent woman, a very devoted wife and mother, and a wonderful grandmother, great grandmother and friend. She will live on in our hearts always. Services will be private.

title: The Philippines Moves Against Bank Secrecy
description: Last month, the United States thrust this Asian country into an awkward spotlight, declaring that Muslim militants in the southern Philippines had financial ties to Osama bin Laden.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about anthrax cases in Florida referred incorrectly in some editions to the source of the information that two Boca Raton postal workers had been tested for the disease. It came from William Burrus, executive vice president of the American Postal Workers Union, not from Lori Groen of the Postal Service.

title: The Melancholy World Weariness of Godard's Twilight Work
description: Jean-Luc Godard's elliptical, melancholy new film, ''loge de l'Amour,'' is being released in America under the title ''In Praise of Love.'' The translation, while literally accurate, inevitably sacrifices some nuance. If this is a song of praise, it is a decidedly mournful one, a celebration of something that has been lost. To some degree the discrepancy between the two languages -- ''loge'' has a literary connotation that ''praise'' lacks -- supports Mr. Godard's central polemical claim, which is that Americans, besotted by celebrity culture and disconnected from history, lack the cultural wherewithal to grasp the depth and difficulty of experience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTANZA, DIGNA A.
description: COSTANZA-Digna A. On September 11, 2001 of Woodside, NY. A victim of the World Trade Center disaster. Beloved wife of John. Loving daughter of Uriel & Albertina Rivera. Dear sister of Ingrid and Uriel D. Rivera. Memorial Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, corner Ascan Avenue and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Saturday, October 13, 2001 at 3:30 PM. Donations may be made to Red Cross of Greater NY P.O. Box 3756 New York, NY 10008.

title: Saudi Sheik Regrets Giuliani Turned Down His Donation
description: Prince Alwaleed bin Talal bin Abdul Aziz Alsaud expressed regret today that his proposed $10 million donation to the Twin Towers Fund had been rejected by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The prince said, however, that he had no qualms about his criticism of American policy in the Middle East, which he expressed in a news release.

title: Two Views: Can the Koran Condone Terror?
description: Osama bin Laden has cited Islamic law to justify his terror against the United States, a view that most Islamic scholars say is a gross distortion. Nonetheless this highly unorthodox view is finding some support in the Muslim world. This is an excerpt from an article by Muhammad Ishrat Husain, a retired accountant, that appeared on Oct. 5 in the opinion section of Dawn (www.dawn.com), the largest English-language newspaper in Pakistan. He is writing about the Koranic justifications for jihad and qital, or combat.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Abkhazia: Withdrawal Offer By Putin
description: President Vladimir V. Putin, moving to calm the dispute in the separatist Georgian region on Russia's southwest border, said he was willing to withdraw Russian peacekeepers from Abkhazia, as Georgia's Parliament has demanded. Russian troops have patrolled the border between Georgia and Abkhazia since the mid-1990's, but Georgia demanded their removal this week after Russia accused it of sending Islamic fundamentalist guerrillas to disrupt Abkhazia's rulers. Russia has tilted toward Abkhazia in the past. But Mr. Putin said Russia respected Georgia's territorial integrity and had no desire to meddle. ''We have enough problems of our own,'' he said.

title: Continuing the Blood Drive
description: Things have slowed down at the city's blood donation centers since the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. That week, the wait to donate blood was as long as eight hours in some places, and the New York Blood Center was so inundated with would-be donors that it was asking people to come back in a few weeks.

title: Fassel Has Another Car Stolen
description: For the second time in four years, Giants Coach Jim Fassel had a car stolen while it was parked off New Jersey's Route 17. On Thursday night, as he did when his car was stolen in 1997, Fassel called the thief on his cellphone, which was left in the car.

title: NASA to Tighten Security and Offer Comfort to Attack Survivors
description: NASA is responding to last month's terrorist attacks with increased security at the nation's space centers and plans to fly thousands of American flags into space, then present them to survivors and the families of victims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARIAS, SYLVIA
description: ARIAS-Sylvia. October 11. Beloved mother of Irwin Arias and Joan Gordon. Mother-in-law of Lyuba Varticovski and Donald J. Gordon. Adored grandmother of Jon, Debbie, Linda, Larry, Wendy and Nancy. Loving great-grandmother of 13 great-grandchildren. The family matriarch, loved and loving for over 100 years. Graveside service at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Sunday at 11:00 AM.

title: The President and the War: A Status Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Bergen Catholic Is Back, And Hackensack Is Waiting
description: When Bergen Catholic plays host to Hackensack today, it will be a meeting of two of the most successful New Jersey high school football programs of the 1990's. During that span Bergen Catholic won the Parochial title seven times and Hackensack matched that with seven Section 1, Group 4 state titles.

title: For California Governor, a Land-Use Decision
description: Gov. Gray Davis has until Sunday to decide on a state measure that would close a legal loophole that developers have used to buy large tracts of pristine land, subdivide them using old lot lines and then resell for millions of dollars in profits.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Monetary Policy Holds Steady
description: With financial markets stabilizing in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States, the Bank of Japan saw no need to ease monetary policy at its two-day meeting that ended yesterday. The bank promised to ''provide ample liquidity'' to the market -- at least 6 trillion yen ($50 billion) -- but did not lower its official discount rate, which it cut to a record low of 0.1 percent at its last meeting, in September. Lawmakers have urged the bank to buy more government bonds to bail out the country's banks and help finance the billowing deficit, but the monetary board made no mention of this in its statement. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: U.S. FREEZES MORE ACCOUNTS; SAUDI AND PAKISTANI ASSETS CITED FOR TIES TO BIN LADEN
description: The Bush administration vowed today to seize the assets of more individuals it says support terrorism, including a prominent businessman from Saudi Arabia, a United States ally whose reluctance to move against people and groups with ties to Osama bin Laden has become a politically sensitive issue.

title: Beliefs; A philosopher-priest's new look at the old question: God in a world of so much evil.
description: The one great theological problem, it has often been said, is the problem of evil. How can there be a God who is all-good, all-powerful and all-knowing when at the same time there is so much suffering in a world that this God is said to watch over?

title: A Reservist at Fort Dix Shoots 4 Before Being Killed by Police
description: A military police reservist who was being expelled from the Fort Dix Army Reserve post because of suspected psychological problems shot and wounded two soldiers and two local police officers this afternoon before being fatally shot by the authorities, military officials said today.

title: The Mayor, the Prince and the $10 Million
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nerves of a Nation Stretch From Coast to Coast
description: At the Golden Gate Bridge, a nerve-racked driver likened his daily commute to a game of Russian roulette.

title: A Recipe-Following Fireman, a Wiseacre Dad and a First-Time Visitor
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: By Limiting Targets, U.S. May Have Foiled a Bin Laden Plot
description: PARIS  By focusing its military strikes just on Afghanistan rather than conducting a broad campaign against many countries that could have quickly backfired, the Bush administration has avoided falling into a strategic trap apparently set by accused terrorist mastermind Osama bin Laden, according to Western officials and experts interviewed this week.

title: Downbeat Mood on Wall Street; For Many Traders, the Fun Has Gone Out of Their Jobs
description: A top market strategist for J. P. Morgan has canceled all trips that would take him more than a four-hour drive from his family's suburban home.

title: Day 4: Atlanta Sweeps and Arizona Takes Lead
Flee to a Camp. To What Kind of Life?
October 7-13; Even Faster
description: Seven days after Naoko Takahashi of Japan became the first woman to run 26.2 miles in under 2 hours, 20 minutes, Catherine Ndereba of Kenya shattered the world record by winning the Chicago Marathon in 2:18:47. Ndereba, who lives part of the year in Norristown, Pa., and trains on the hills and trails of Valley Forge, broke the previous mark by 59 seconds, and rekindled discussions about whether women might eventually run the marathon faster than men. The gap between the men's and women's records -- 13 minutes, 5 seconds -- has never been narrower. Jere Longman

title: A Hauppauge Company Tries to Stop the Bleeding
description: THREE years is all it took. During that time Hirsch International of Hauppauge, a high-tech embroidery company serving the apparel industry, saw its market unravel and its sales plummet, a victim of changing trade patterns, slipping demand and global competition.

title: Absolute Dunleavy: Vodka and Tonics at Langan's
description: These days were made for a guy like Steve Dunleavy, the big-talking, big-drinking columnist for The New York Post, the unblinking defender of smokers and gun owners and cops.

title: Envelope Sent to an Office in Reno Contained Anthrax, Governor Says
description: A piece of mail received by a Microsoft office in Reno contained anthrax, the governor of Nevada said today, making this the third known location involving anthrax contamination in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, HERBERT D.
description: ROSS-Herbert D. Dear friend, you will be sorely missed. Our condolences to the Ross and Jaffe families. Barbara and Richard Marks

title: The Book of Jobs
description: SELLING BEN CHEEVER

title: Beware Calling A Bottom Too Soon
description: FOR a moment last week, it seemed that investor confidence, so crippled by the terrorist attacks and so crucial for the nation's economic well-being, was in the ascendancy again. One month to the day after the September calamities, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite had returned to their pre-attack levels.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEIN, JOSEPH
description: STEIN-Joseph. October 13, 2000. Dear dad, we think of you each day. Love, Mom and the kid

title: Reckonings; Harvest Of Lemons
description: What does a Princeton degree have in common with a peacock's tail? Both are ornaments that demonstrate their possessor's quality. And the winners of this year's Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science showed, among other things, why it may be worth acquiring such ornaments, even at considerable cost.

title: SOAPBOX; A New York State of Mind
description: A MOUNTAIN creek rushes steadily past our home, hushing us to sleep each night in this tiny hamlet of 300 people, Jamestown, Colo. The skies are crisp and clear blue most days, the Aspen trees are blazing with golden leaves and the days have become cool and breezy.

title: In an Urban Underbelly, Hidden Views of Terror's Toll
description: The devastation above ground at the World Trade Center site is obvious to anyone with a television set. But below the street, in spaces that are home to much of what keeps New York City running, billions of dollars of damage remains unseen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ABRAHAM (ABBY)
description: ROSENBERG-Abraham (Abby), 86. Passed away peacefully at home in NYC, October 7, 2001. Loving husband of the late Gertrude Rosenberg. Beloved father, father-in-law, and grandfather of Beth and Robert Reichert, Toby & Stanley Sitko, & Mara Reisman. Devoted brother, brother-in-law, and dear friend. Contributions to WTC Fund Safe Horizon, 2 Lafayette St., New York, N.Y. 10007.

title: Devils Are 0-3 and Out of Sorts
description: After allowing 12 goals in losing the first two games of the season, the Devils were determined to reverse matters tonight. But they fell into the same trap of playing well only sporadically and lost, 3-1, to the Montreal Canadiens before 19,393 at the Molson Center. The loss marked the first time the Devils have started a season with three losses.

title: New Concern About Security Of the Water Supply
description: FOR years, environmentalists and some New York City officials have argued that the city has not done enough to protect its water supply from a terrorist attack. Suddenly their warnings seem more urgent.

title: The Money Culture Fizzles
description: IT wasn't the hottest ticket in town last week (that was probably a tour of ground zero with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani) but there was a crowd waiting on West 67th Street on Wednesday to see a taping of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire.'' This was not my idea of fun. But my decidedly nonmaterialistic parents looked thrilled. They adore Regis Philbin and his mild-mannered show.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Sept. 9 about the wedding of Claire Alexandra Styron and Edward Lewis Beason misspelled the minister's middle name. He is the Rev. William Sloane Coffin, not Sloan.

title: LOVE IN THE 21ST CENTURY
description: It was Saturday, four days after the World Trade Center attack. It was a new world. My wife, Lara, and I, for better or worse, were the same old us, doing what we typically do when the world shakes us up -- we were ignoring each other. Lara is a psychologist, and it had obviously been a big week for feeling crazy, and she was worn out, she had that excuse. As for me, I had been throwing out everything I had ever written and was uselessly, ceaselessly revising. Through overwork and now tragedy, we had fallen into a rhythm of mutual avoidance. We had closed down.

title: The End of Innocence
description: ON the southernmost tip of New York, in the Staten Island town of Tottenville, there sits a stony building by the sea, called the Conference House. In the early 1700's, local farmers called it the Billopp House after its owner, Christopher Billopp. But its lasting name and tourist attraction fame comes from a historic meeting held here in the shaky first days of the American Revolution.

title: Sloan-Kettering's Tower Proposal Pits Medicine Against Development Fears
description: The landscape of New York City has never been constant. It has long embodied power, political expediency and ideals of progress. Still, debates about civic development have seldom touched on life, death and the future of scientific progress.

title: The 22 Most Wanted Suspects, in a Five-Act Drama of Global Terror
description: Last week, the United States released the names of what it regards as the 22 most wanted terrorists in the world. They come from a number of countries but mostly from Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Lebanon. The men cited have been indicted by American courts in four acts of terror -- the 1985 hijacking of a Trans World Airlines flight, the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, the 1996 truck bombing of an American military barracks in Saudi Arabia and the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa. A fifth effort, a plan to blow up American airplanes in 1995, was foiled.

title: 'I Do,' in Color
description: WEEKS after my husband and I married, we received the contact sheets from our wedding photographer, expecting confirmation of what a beautiful, charming, happy couple we had been. Instead, the pictures of my husband saying his vows showed him looking pale and seasick. (We weren't on a boat.) Photos of me at the cocktail hour offered hard evidence of hair so sloppy, it appeared I had been riding in a convertible. It was like receiving a bad report card when you expected straight A's. We never had a single photograph developed.

title: Hunsicker Pondering Future of the Astros
description: Now that the Houston Astros have taken their usual leave of the playoffs after one series, Gerry Hunsicker can devote his complete attention to trying to resolve a dilemma he faces this off-season. In a baseball variation on ''Hamlet,'' Hunsicker can engage in a soliloquy with himself.

title: Tweaking Nature: Turtle and the Bunny, a Cautionary Tale
description: We live in the ''betweens'' -- between suburb and countryside, a place far enough that nature sometimes provides us with harsh lessons, but close enough to still imagine that we may, on occasion, affect the outcome. My boys and I are also in the ''betweens'' -- they, between childhood and adolescence, me, between, well, at 51, between the beginning and the end.

title: The World; Rebuilding What War Has Destroyed
description: THE American-led alliance has already begun planning how to remake Afghanistan, arguably the world's least modern state, into a more open, tolerant, stable, prosperous and peaceful place. The giveaway was the choreographed symmetry in the skies: the C-17's dropped pre-packaged snacks; the B-52's dropped smart bombs.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report column on Sept. 30, about the tightened security at Canadian airports, misstated the requirements for passengers taking flights to and from Canada. To re-enter the United States from Canada, either a certified birth certificate plus a photo ID or just a passport is required. A driver's license is not enough.

title: Flee to a Camp. To What Kind of Life?
description: Their escape, an emergency, has become their confinement, a predicament. Nearly one million Afghan refugees live in dozens of camps in or near Peshawar, in the Northwest Frontier Province of Pakistan. War, poverty and, during the last four years, drought have turned them into desperate vagabonds. Their flight was meant to be temporary, but for many their stay has lasted 5, 10 or 20 years. "Afghan refugee" is their identity, the way it once might have been "Afghan farmer." The camps, in all their dreariness, have become their homes.

title: Afghanistan Can Learn From Its Past
description: The people of Afghanistan, after a century of misrule, are in desperate need of a way to govern themselves that will offer some defense against the abuses of power that have marked Afghan history. Now that President Bush has acknowledged the need to help build a stable government in Afghanistan, perhaps under leadership of the United Nations, many are asking: Who should rule? Once the Taliban are defeated, several parties want to rule: the ex-king, Muhammad Zahir Shah; the Pashtun ethnic group; the opposition Northern Alliance; and of course the Taliban. But the better question is: How should Afghanistan govern itself?

title: A TriBeCa Revival
description: Nearly all of the restaurants in TriBeCa had to close when access to the area was restricted in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack. Many are struggling to get going again as TriBeCa becomes more accessible. The 1, 2, A and C trains are now running to Chambers Street, and cabs are being allowed in. Now is a good time to call for what can be an impossible reservation.

title: Experts Offer Advice on Handling Potentially Dangerous Mail
description: There are many ways a business or institution could cut the risk of being contaminated by anthrax or another biological agent arriving in the mail, experts say.

title: Avoid Ego
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-14-01; In My Tribe
description: You may be like me: between the ages of 25 and 39, single, a college-educated city dweller. If so, you may have also had the unpleasant experience of discovering that you have been identified (by the U.S. Census Bureau, no less) as one of the fastest-growing groups in America -- the ''never marrieds.'' In less than 30 years, the number of never-marrieds has more than doubled, apparently pushing back the median age of marriage to the oldest it has been in our country's history -- about 25 years for women and 27 for men.

title: The Don Rickles of Sushi
description: ''WHAT are you doing here?'' Yang, the sushi chef, said, looking up from his work. ''I don't love you anymore. I told you before to go away. I don't want your business.''

title: Where His Heart Is: a Sweet Home in Suburbia
description: ABOUT midway through three decades of turning his tumultuous love life, troubled relationships with parents and children and slow physical decline into wry, precise songs, like a particularly gifted comic recording a 30-year nervous breakdown, Loudon Wainwright III wrote an ode to the county where he grew up. It was not a coal miner's paean to Harlan County, Kentucky.

title: Fed Is Urged to Be More Open
description: A group of leading international economists has concluded that while the Federal Reserve has changed ''dramatically'' since 1993 under Alan Greenspan, it still lags behind other major central banks in the openness of its operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODES, MARION EDWARD, M.D., PH.D.
description: HODES-Marion Edward, M.D., Ph.D., 76, Prof. of Medical Genetics at Indiana U. School of Medicine, Pelizaeus Merzbacher disease specialist, died September 28, 2001 of cancer. Dr. Hodes received his M.D. in 1947 and his Ph.D. in 1955. He was a consultant to Eli Lilly & Co. and participated in clinical research on vinca alkaloids, a mainstay in the treatment of leukemias. Dr. Hodes discovered one of the mutations causing Pelizaeus Mertzbacher disease, and was a leading authority on its diagnosis and genetics. He produced over 500 scientific works. He spent sabbatical years in Israel, two at the Weizmann Institute of Science and one at Hadassah. Dr. Hodes served as chairman of the Executive Council of the Scientific Advisory Board of the Israel Cancer Research Foundation from 1988-1994 and as chairman of its Scientific Review Panel from 1988-1996. Dr. Hodes married Halina Markowicz on November 23, 1949. He is survived by his wife; sons Marquis Hodes, MD, PhD, Zachary Hodes, MD, PhD, Jonathan Hodes, MSc, MD; daughter Abigail Hodes; sister, Roberta Hodes; and nine grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to the Israel Cancer Research Fund, 1290 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 550, New York, NY 10104.

title: Waving the Flag And Journalistic Principles
description: In the face of the tremendous grief and pain brought to our shores by savages who cloak themselves in religion as an excuse for murder and devastation, Americans of every political, social, ethnic, religious and cultural heritage have come together in historic unity to stand proud of our nation.

title: O.K., Men, Get Into Tights And Line Up at the Barre
description: IT is Brooklyn, Borough Park, 1954. I am playing punch ball in the school yard of P.S. 131 on 44th Street near Fort Hamilton Parkway, and my sleek, black, paper-thin attach case, secretly housing my blue cotton tights, size small dance belt and ballet slippers, is leaning against the school building inconspicuously. I will it to be inconspicuous and practice makes it so. The ballgame over, I, with a gait belying its contents, coolly pick up my dance bag, alias attach case, and catch the elevated West End train for Manhattan to take my ballet class at the School of American Ballet, at Madison and 59th Street, with Madame Tumkovsky.

title: Amy Francis, Michael McCarter
description: Amy Alexandra Francis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Francis of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Joseph McCarter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. McCarter of Lombard, Ill. The Rev. Michael C. Palmer performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Wilton.

title: A Lengthening Season of Gloom Darkens an Otherwise Gem of an Indian Summer Saturday
description: What do you do on a spectacular Saturday in October, when the sun seems to be smiling overhead and, with just a tiny stretch of the imagination, the warm gushes of air make it feel like summer is back?

title: Vanquishing Myths About Tree Planting
description: PLANTING a tree is easier than it used to be, not from new technology in digging equipment but because new research into trees' responses to various planting practices has dispelled many myths. The best season for planting has even been shifted from the traditional spring back to fall for most tree species.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: The Military Is Standing At Attention
description: FOR years, people in Wrightstown and Browns Mills could drive along any of four roads that cut through the 50 square miles of Fort Dix as they went about their business. That was before Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, ROBERT, M.D.
description: HALL-Robert, M.D. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society record with profound regret the recent death of their Associate Fellow, Robert Hall, M.D.

title: Bills Would Help New Jobless Keep Insurance
description: President Bush and Congress are working on legislation to provide health benefits to hundreds of thousands of people laid off in recent months. But they disagree over how to deliver the aid and how much to spend.

title: The Nation: Past Ground Zero; The Distance Traveled in a Month of War
description: ONLY a month has passed, but ''only'' means different things to different people. For many Americans, the wounds from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks remain raw, as if inflicted but a day or two ago. For others, the topsy-turvy world they now inhabit has become quickly familiar, curiously so, as if life has been like this for a year. Hard to believe, they say, that a mere month has gone by.

title: JoAnne Constance, Kevin Kenny
description: JoAnne Barbara Constance, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Constance of Sands Point, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin Peter Kenny, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Kenny of Plandome, N.Y. The Rev. Dennis Strouzas performed the ceremony at the Archangel Michael Greek Orthodox Church in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

title: Stacy Levins, Darren Esser
description: Stacy Mara Levins and Darren James Esser were married last evening by Rabbi Geri Zeller at Bridgewaters, a caterer in Manhattan.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-14-01: The ethicist; Group Dating
description: Some friends and I use a Jewish Internet dating service. When I mentioned an ad placed by a Hispanic woman who likes to date Jewish men, a female friend of mine remarked that ''they should stay away from our stuff.'' I argued that the Hispanic woman was upfront about her ancestry and so did nothing wrong. Please shed some light. D.G., Long Beach, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An essay on Sept. 2 about Yelapa, a fishing village near Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, referred incorrectly to the practice of hanging beds from the ceiling by ropes as protection against scorpions. A reader pointed out in an e-mail message dated Sept. 13 that while some beds are hung that way, not all are. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: When Golden Arches Are Too Red, White and Blue
description: HOURS after the United States started its bombing raids in Afghanistan last week, the backlash began. In Pakistan, angry crowds vandalized McDonald's outlets in Islamabad and Karachi. In Indonesia, demonstrators burned an American flag outside a McDonald's restaurant in the resort town of Makassar and then stormed it, while across the country in Yogyakarta, other protesters blockaded yet another McDonald's.

title: Cardinals' Vina Doesn't Disappoint
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 14  Fernando Vina may not be a classic leadoff hitter like Vince Coleman or Willie McGee, but Vina and St. Louis Manager Tony La Russa both made it a point Saturday to focus the Cardinals' offense around him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, NAOMI
description: ROSENFELD-Naomi. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Naomi Rosenfeld, associated with The Times from 1947 until 1981.

title: Hardcover Fiction
description: This

title: Minor Grapes Transformed
description: Francophiles consider Domaine de Pouy, a light, dry, citric Gascon white imported by Robert Kacher of Washington, a cameo year after year. The 2000 edition is charming and appetite-whetting. Minor grapes (75 percent ugni blanc, 25 percent Colombard) from a minor region are transmuted into a major treat. Windsor Wine Shop, 474 Third Avenue (33rd Street), Manhattan, charges a bargain $7.50. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Counselors for the Grieving Are Waylaid by Outsized Task
description: Catherine Masterson arrived at the armory on Lexington Avenue and 26th Street in New York at 6 a.m. that first Saturday after the terrorist attacks and spent the next 14 1/2 hours counseling grief-stricken families of the victims. She especially remembers how she coaxed a 9-year-old girl who had lost her father into talking about her feelings by giving her two stuffed kittens, one wrapped in bandages and the other wearing a Red Cross uniform.

title: Erica Fishlin, Joshua Fox
description: Erica Lori Fishlin, the daughter of Judith and Lewis H. Fishlin of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to Joshua Jay Fox, the son of Rita and Martin Fox of Oradell, N.J. Rabbi Neal I. Borovitz officiated at the Chanticler, a catering establishment in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Word for Word/What Price Honor?; The Stuff of Patriotism, And Cheap, Too
description: FOR weeks, the nation's leaders have called on Americans to return to the rhythms of their lives: to get back on airplanes, go see a show and generally try to keep the economy running. On Thursday, in a news conference about the American strikes on Afghanistan in response to the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, President Bush repeated the suggestion. ''We cannot let the terrorists achieve the objective of frightening our nation to the point where we don't conduct business, or people don't shop,'' he said.

title: A Tower in Alpine Keeps New York TV On the Air Now
description: THE Alpine Tower rises high above the tree line along the Palisades Parkway, an ungainly red and white structure with three arms jutting out hundreds of feet and ganglia of wires and radar dishes up and down its superstructure.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SEEING THROUGH PLACES: Reflections on Geography and Identity, by Mary Gordon. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.) The novelist sheds light on her fictional world in eight essays about places she inhabited, from her grandmother's guilt-ridden household (more Addams Family than cozy sanctuary for the young Mary) to Rome, where she first felt free. ''Re-evoking the places and objects that once were so much darker and more fearful is a fine work of restoration,'' Rosemary Dinnage wrote here last year. ''Gordon knits them all together in a satisfying pattern.''

title: Many Feel a Need to See World Trade Center Site
description: RENEE CHO and her husband, Paul Mesches, didn't know anyone killed in the attack on the World Trade Center. Still, they were so shaken by the carnage that they felt compelled to visit the site with their sons, Tai, 15, and Kim, 12.

title: Searching for Secrets On the Bays' Bottom
description: ALMOST as soon as the scientists lowered the side-scan sonar device into Peconic Bay, an acoustic image of an ancient riverbed more than 30 feet below lit up Dr. Roger D. Flood's topside computer screen.

title: 'Edith and Woodrow: The Wilson White House'
description: The deathbed admonition of Woodrow Wilson's angelic, admiring first wife, Ellen, that her husband, a great man, should not become a lonely great man, paved the way to his remarriage. Enter Edith Bolling Galt — and the rest is "history," idealized, sanitized, and indeed, invented in her autobiography: a story played out in Washington and Paris and around the world, against the guns of World War I and the partisan cross fire over the eventual refusal of the United States to join the League of Nations. The story of Wilson's second marriage, and of the large events on which its shadow was cast, is darker and more devious, and more astonishing, than previously recorded.

title: New Emergency Powers Are Proposed for S.E.C.
description: Congress is considering legislation that would give the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to impose broader and more enduring emergency measures to stabilize markets during crises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STENGEL, GEORGE
description: STENGEL-George. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George Stengel, associated with The Times from 1947 until 1989.

title: Knicks Losing Johnson's Stabilizing Force
description: The most noticeable difference about the Knicks is that they look nothing like the team you used to know, the perennial playoff club that usually found a way to survive and advance.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions last Sunday on Page 1 of this section and with an article inside about a new generation of bridge players misidentified the site of a class taught by Steve Becker. It is the Greenwich Y.W.C.A., not the Y.M.C.A.

title: Hardcover Nonfiction
description: This

title: Student Newspapers Confront Sept. 11
description: STEVE KANNAN had to shout a call to order.

title: America Singing in Many Voices
description: This latest morphing of a PBS series into a book is inevitably tilted toward neophyte fans, but AMERICAN ROOTS MUSIC (Abrams, $49.50) boasts enough solid information and seductive images to please more experienced roots music aficionados as well. Sections devoted to the history of blues, country, gospel, folk, Cajun and zydeco, Tex-Mex and Native American sounds are followed by brief mini-biographies of a handful of key figures in the evolution of these vernacular American musical forms. The abundant illustrations, many in full color, are often familiar but still suggestive. The book's best moments evoke the larger cultural transformations of America during the last century, as the nation became a postmodern society struggling toward integration and hit by tidal waves of information. The folk revival, for instance, as Alan Jabbour points out in his fine essay, may have peaked in the 1960's but was made possible much earlier by factors like the ''surge of social and cultural activism during the New Deal era.'' These days, when the forgotten, far-flung musical shards for which collectors once trawled through attics and cellars are easily available on compact disc, a primer like ''American Roots Music'' may be more useful than ever. Though at times it lapses into dry musicology or repetitive superficiality, at its best ''American Roots Music'' offers a textured and expert guide to America's many musical subcultures. Gene Santoro

title: 'Designing Democracy: What Constitutions Do'
description: Every society contains innumerable deliberating groups. Church groups, political parties, women's organizations, juries, legislative bodies, regulatory commissions, multimember courts, faculties, student organizations, people participating in talk radio programs, Internet discussion groups, and others engage in deliberation. It is a simple social fact that sometimes people enter discussions with one view and leave with another, even on political and moral questions. Emphasizing this fact, many recent observers have embraced the aspiration to deliberative democracy, an ideal that is designed to combine popular responsiveness with a high degree of reflection and exchange among people with competing views. But what are the real-world consequences of deliberation? In a constitutional democracy, how can deliberation be made to work well? When and why does it work poorly?

Women who desire a Reddi Wip-type experience can choose from among Este Lauder's Perfectly Clean Foaming Cleanser ($16.50 at Saks Fifth Avenue), Sisley's Creamy Mousse Cleanser ($65 at Saks Fifth Avenue) and Caudalie's Fleur de Vigne ($25 at Sephora) -- all of which simulate the aerosol action of a dessert topping. For those who prefer to lather up by hand, Origins' Checks and Balances Frothy Face Wash ($15 at Origins), Shiseido's Benefiance ($28.50 at Bloomingdale's) and Cl de Peau's Mousse Nettoyante Tendre ($50 at Takashimaya) come in easier-to-control lotions; rub your palms together and bubbles appear. And if you want something even more solid to grip, Origins offers Chunk of Clay ($12.50), a block of green eucalyptus-scented soap that foams practically at the touch. Of course, with all the froth it produces, your face may be clean, but your soap dish less so.

title: A Lauren With a Sweeter Shop
description: Trick or treat? This week, self-professed candyphiles Dylan Lauren (daughter of Ralph) and Jeffrey Rubin, the brainchild behind F. A. O. Schweetz, the candy store in F. A. O. Schwarz, are opening Dylan's Candy Bar, a 5,500-square-foot sugar-coated emporium. It's a way to showcase the elegance of candy in a museumlike setting, said Mr. Rubin, who met Ms. Lauren through mutual friends. Located at 60th Street and Third Avenue, the sweet factory is a mix of art, fashion and candy, and the home of what the two say is the world's largest lollipop (44 inches tall), $5,000 collector's Pez dispensers, every type of Hasbro spin pop ever created and 21 exclusive colors of M&M's, as well as M&M cameras, desk lamps and karaoke machines. The shop itself, a duplex, is as colorful as the confectionary delights inside. Stairs are made of resin and embedded with all sorts of gummies. (Gummies are beautiful when you hold them up to the light, Ms. Lauren said.) A mountain of oversize Jelly Belly beans rises from the bottom floor to the main floor. An enormous lollipop sculpture is on the main floor, as is the cafe bar, which features candy-cane-inspired bar stools. A candy gallery doubles as a private party room. Television monitors throughout the store show old-school candy commercials (''Sometimes you feel like a nut, sometimes you don't''). Surely they'll also play ''Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory''? ''Daddy, I want it now!'' KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: The Markets Are Back. But More Problems Await.
description: SINCE Sept. 17, when Wall Street went back to work after the terrorist attacks of the week before, brokers and traders have tried defiantly to return the nation's securities markets to business as usual. That has not quite happened. Yes, the physical disruptions were largely patched during the four lost trading days. But there is the matter of investor sentiment, perhaps still too bullish, perhaps for patriotic reasons or from sheer denial. There is the matter of risk, perhaps not yet incorporating the new, more uncertain world. There is the matter of vulnerability caused by another, direct terrorist strike, perhaps alleviated by moving to totally electronic market. There is the matter of the economy, perhaps headed for a deep recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, ETHEL DAGABERTA HOLLAND CHERRY (NEE BRANSOME)
description: BURNS-Ethel Dagaberta Holland Cherry (nee Bransome) born February 4, 1911 to Emil and Isabelle Bransome after a long courageous battle with Alzheimers disease passed into glory on Sunday, September 30 at 1:02 PM. The death of her father forced her to leave school at 14 to support her mother and 3 brothers, continuing to sustain them all throughout their lives. She had a beautiful voice and sang in the choir of Temple Beth-El in Bradley Beach, NJ. In the 1940's she had three high fashion stores in Miami Beach, FL. carrying haute couture in sportswear and evening clothes. In 1947 she was lauded by Women's Wear Daily as The Small Business Woman of the Year. After Mr. Cherry's death she closed the stores and opened a Barton's candy store in what is now the Bal Harbor shops in Miami Beach, FL. In the 1970's she went to work for a fledgling bridal designer in NYC & built the business from nothing to success. After working 5-1/2 days a week for 26 years she ended her career at the age of 85 when she decided that Alzheimer's disease was robbing her of the things she needed to work: memory & spatial logistics. She was a paragon, the epitome of everything generous and gracious, giving of herself unstintingly to anyone who crossed her path. She graced our lives with compassion, strength and boundless love. Humanity has suffered a deep and abiding loss. Her memory is truly a blessing for all who knew her. Beloved, cherished mother of Joanbarbara Holland Weinstein, adored mother-in-law of Jerome Weinstein, beloved sister of William Bransome, loved sister-in-law of Patricia Bransome, treasured aunt of nine nieces, nephews and grand niece, step-grandchildren Daryl and Seth Weinstein, step-great-grandchild Alexander Weinstein. During her illness she was ministered to by arch-angel Dorinda Lord & angel Antoinette Hampton. Memorial Service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street on Thursday, October 18 at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in Ethel's memory may be made to Alzheimer's Association Research, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Suite 1100, Chicago, Illinois 60611. Our hearts are broken for ourselves but we know Ethel is in Paradise sitting ringside.

title: 'This Rock'
description: Preacher Liner said he would let me preach the Sunday after Homecoming. He was a big heavy feller with droopy jowls, and he said it as a favor to Mama more than anything else, because no preacher likes to share his pulpit, not any that I ever heard of. But Mama was a pillar of the church, and her pa had give the land for the church and built the first church in the valley back when the county was founded. And for some reason Preacher Liner was afraid of Mama, maybe because she'd read more than him and knowed more Scripture. So when I told Preacher Liner I felt I had the call, that I'd been studying up to preach a sermon, he said he'd let me fill the pulpit, soon as there was an opportunity.

title: Around the Island

In July, Arrow announced cost containments, including more than 1,200 layoffs, salary reductions and cuts in discretionary spending. The company will also be making valuation adjustments to more accurately reflect current conditions, and will take a special charge expected to range from $175 million to $200 million. . . . The Nu Horizons Electronics Corporation (Nasdaq: NUHC) of Melville reported that net income for the second quarter dropped to $437,000, or three cents per share, compared with $9.4 million, or 59 cents per share, in the same period last year. Net sales from continuing operations for the quarter dropped to $69.9 million from $170.1 million for the comparable period last year. The company produces computer components. title: 'Aquagenesis'
description: There may be a place on Earth—albeit somewhat inaccessible—where we might be able to see conditions not unlike those that the earliest life forms saw. Where the sea floor pulls apart (a phenomenon known as "sea-floor spreading"), cracks or rifts are created in the crust of the Earth. This activity usually, but not always, takes place along the mid-ocean ridge, a 40,000-mile-long undersea series of mountain ranges that snakes around the planet like the seams of a baseball, and is the largest single geological feature on the Earth's surface. The rifts mark the edges of the lithospheric plates, which bear the continents in their inexorable movement on the first 100 to 250 kilometers of the surface of the planet. The plates such as those of North America and Africa drift over the less rigid athenosphere, much like giant icebergs in the ocean. The formation of the plates occurs at the mid-ocean ridge, and they are consumed at "subduction trenches," where one plate slides under the lip of another. Where plates interact, earthquakes occur, volcanoes erupt, and mountains are pushed up. All three were manifest in November 1963, when the Icelandic island of Surtsey was born in a spectacular cataclysm of fire, lava, and steam. The rifts caused by the separation of the plates fill up with lava that wells up from within the earth, flowing outward from the center and moving across the ocean floor. As described by J. R. Heirtzler and W. B. Bryan (1975), "Bizarre as the idea seemed at first, it was becoming evident that the mid-ocean-ridge system was nothing less than a vast unhealed volcanic wound."

title: A Brief History of Bad Advice
description: Now that ''I Love Lucy'' has finally faded into television prehistory, where do we go for some really good marital slapstick? Here's an idea: let's turn the current crop of marriage manuals into sitcoms. They have so much comic potential -- absurdist sex tricks (the wife cuts a hole in the crotch of her panties; the husband watches), financial high jinks (he takes over the family finances, despite his history of bouncing checks) and far-fetched scenarios supposed to improve a marriage but more likely to end in farcical misery (she pretends to share his interest in antique cars, even though they bore her silly). The authors could be written in as amusing minor characters, since they have the unfortunate habit of confessing to minor domestic crimes (I threw mugs of coffee at my husband!) without grasping that such defects of character make them ridiculous as role models.

title: Against Love
description: Love is, as we know, a mysterious and controlling force. It has vast power over our thoughts and life decisions. It demands our loyalty, and we, in turn, freely comply. Saying no to love isn't simply heresy; it is tragedy -- the failure to achieve what is most essentially human. So deeply internalized is our obedience to this most capricious despot that artists create passionate odes to its cruelty, and audiences seem never to tire of the most deeply unoriginal mass spectacles devoted to rehearsing the litany of its torments, fixating their very beings on the narrowest glimmer of its fleeting satisfactions.

title: Television/Radio: The Good, the Bad, the Lucy: A Legacy of Laughs; Coolly Confident, Timelessly Funny
description: I LOVE Lucy. I've loved her since I was a grade-schooler watching reruns on my parents' black and white console TV. ''I Love Lucy'' was my first favorite show, and I'd still rather watch it than most of what pass for sitcoms today. I love Lucy's red heart lips and her curly updo. I love the sheer inevitability of her schemes to break into show biz against the wishes of her Cuban bandleader husband, Ricky Ricardo. I love her nose-in-the-air self-satisfaction when a scheme is going right, her open-mouthed double take of disbelief when it's not, her curled-lip, scrunched-nose ''Yeeeuww!'' when she's finally caught. I love how Lucy always drags her doubting, dumpy neighbor Ethel Mertz along for the ride as part handmaid, part henchman. I love the way Lucy was like a human special effect -- put her near a meat locker, a candy factory assembly line, a tub of wine grapes, and you knew something spectacular was going to happen.

title: Polymorphous Normal
description: Gabriel and I are sitting in her Harlem apartment, which smells faintly of incense. The cat is lurking behind the sofa. I am asking her about a woman she used to date, and whether it bothered Gabriel that the woman thought of herself, then and still, as straight. ''I'm not a future tripper,'' Gabriel says. ''I can't look beyond what happens at the moment. At the moment, we were in it. Then we weren't.'' She is relaxed, thoughtful -- flirty or inwardly amused, I'm not sure which. Once an avid raver, Gabriel, a small African-American woman who still wears an open loop of gold through her nasal septum, now works in public-health research at a major university. She's light on her feet, like a dancer. I ask her if she sees herself as falling at some particular point on a continuum of sexual identity, and she smiles.

title: QUICK BITE/Princeton; Thin Crust Worth a Long Walk
description: Hungry and pressed for time on a beautiful fall day, I walked into the local pizza place near my office in the heart of Princeton. Then I left. The heavy smell of dough and cheese warned me that the fare was going to be as uninspired as the multitone Formica tables and benches. My feet took orders from my taste buds: ''Forget your deadline. Go to Old World Pizza.'' So I made the five-block walk to a storefront spot that has a fresher, lighter, more appetizing scent. The Old World crust -- thin and crunchy with a perfect balance of breadiness -- is wonderful support for a light, slightly peppery sauce and thin squares of fresh mozzarella. No heavy, sliding sheets of cheese here. The restaurant offers a variety of add-ons. I prefer to top it off with paper-thin slices of Old World's store-made sausage. Sometimes I pull a stool up to the paper-plate-deep counter, but mostly I eat on the walk back to my office. With less mass than some pizza, Old World slices tend to cool quickly, so there's no need for disciplined waiting for the first bite. And a warning: perhaps more than other pizza, Old World's thin crust suffers from even a few minutes of being boxed up in cardboard on the passenger seat of a car. So if you're ordering it to take home, be sure to be there to pick it up as they are sliding it into the box. But really, who needs to put pizza on a table? You could have a great meal on your way from the counter to your car.

title: 'Selling Ben Cheever'
description: IPICKED UP MY RED CHENILLE SUIT, WIG, AND BEARD AT one P.M. on the Wednesday after Thanksgiving. `Take 684 North from White Plains,' I was told, `and get off at Exit 2.' The homeless shelter for which I was headed is on the grounds of the Westchester airport. In another life, I used to go there to catch Pegasus, the corporate plane that belonged to the Reader's Digest . There were never more than six of us aboard, and if you had a bag, the pilot would offer to carry it. I remember having jetted to Washington, D.C., for dinners with those in sympathy with the magazine. Former senator Sam Nunn, former representative Jack Kemp, and former secretary of the navy John Lehmann Jr. come immediately to mind. The Digest team would fly back that same night, drinking scotch and smoking Cuban cigars. I remember studying the profiles of the older men to see if they liked me, and if they didn't like me, to see what I could do about it. Their affection—if earned—might translate itself into cash and position. In the meantime, I enjoyed the free dinners and the richness of my surroundings. When I was anxious, the liquor helped.

What the reporter wanted to know was whether the Rosenthal picture was a fake: a posed propaganda piece intended to stir up patriotic fervor at home. His body begins to float upward, as if some mysterious force were tugging him into the atmosphere, away from the world and its everyday reality. After all this time, Chris still lights up, describing the moment he first laid eyes on Debbie, in a crowded bar in Providence, R.I., where they both were with other partners. ''I thought, my God, that's the most beautiful woman I've ever seen,'' Chris says, slapping a palm exuberantly to his knee. Debbie, a willowy woman with lively brown eyes and full lips, was not instantly in love with Chris. She is, by nature, the more cautious of the two. Where Chris is an optimist, Debbie is a worrier. Where Chris's love is sometimes blindly romantic, Debbie's is more analytical, more brooding, though no less strong. After all this time, Debbie still laughs wildly at Chris's jokes. And Chris likes to stroke Debbie's arm when she's talking, as if to show how carefully he's listening.

title: The Ex

The Saturday before the World Trade Center disaster, he called to find out if I could pick him up Tuesday night. He lived in New Hampshire. We, our son, Zach, and I, live in Fountain Valley near Los Angeles. Doug was scheduled to come help us get Zach moved into his dorm at U.C.L.A. On Sept. 11, I was in Texas on business. We were driving to work when I heard the horrendous news. I immediately flashed: he was going to be flying in that morning. When I talked to my son, I said, 'Zach, your dad,' and he said, 'Yes, I know.' We confirmed he was on the flight. The financial officer of my company rented a car, and we drove back 22 hours.

Beloved sister of Ronald and Rose Novak. An inspiring and courageous mother of Vanessa (Joe Kmetz) of Bozeman, Montana and Jillian of New York and Los Angeles. Loving aunt of Mara (Dr. Mitchell Miller) and Leila and great-aunt of Gareth and Zoe. Judy was a graduate of Pratt/NYU & an innovative and witty graphic designer. She lived in Florida for a number of years, but joyfully came home to Manhattan six years ago. She then received an M.A. in Counselling from NYU and had begun to plan for a PsyD at the time of her initial diagnosis. During her illness she continued to paint. The Judiff was forever young and beautiful, gifted and funny, and modest. She was and will always be an endless source of strength for her children, her family, her friends and all who are blessed to have known her. A lot of us are walking down the aisle leaning not only on our partner but also on a bottle of pills.

title: Bat Man

But bats do live in the attic of the 1761 John Brearley House in Lawrenceville, a farmhouse restored by the township, whether people want them to or not. There have been several attempts to relocate the Brearley House bats to other places, but ''they keep finding ways to return to that attic,'' said Rick Dutko a zoologist with the state Deparment of Environmental Protection. They stream out at dusk, and visitors will probably see them starting around 4 p.m. Friday when it is ''Bat Night at the Brearley House.'' Mr. Dutko will be on hand for the family event, rain or shine. He will tell what bats are really like and will do so with a bat or two from the attic on his arm. The cost is $2 a person or $10 a family; reservations, (609) 895-1728. The Brearley House is at the end of Meadow Road off of Princeton Pike, beside the Princessville Cemetery. Margo Nash

title: 'Terrorism and U.S. Foreign Policy'
description: Combating international terrorism is—now, as at times in the past—a major objective of the United States. There is broad support for this effort within different branches of government, across the political spectrum, and among the American public. The commitment to the fight against terrorism, which is often spoken of as a “war,” is reflected in the statements of national leaders about the persistence and fortitude that the fight will require. President Bill Clinton stated in 1998 that the United States was in “a long, ongoing struggle between freedom and fanaticism, between the rule of law and terrorism.” 1 The president later told the United Nations General Assembly that “terrorism is at the top of the American agenda—and should be at the top of the world agenda.” 2 The breadth of the commitment has been reflected in the resources provided to counter-terrorism, including two supplemental appropriations for that purpose during the past five years.

title: The Future of Afghanistan
description: Now that President Bush has committed himself to building a stable Afghanistan after military actions there end, the United States must come up with a workable plan. Mr. Bush and his aides began discussing options last week. Stabilizing Afghanistan will not be easy, given the divisions there and the lack of an international consensus about future governance of the country. Success is more likely if three basic principles are respected. No government should be imposed from outside. All the country's major ethnic, language and religious groups must be fairly represented. Political and economic reconstruction efforts will require sustained international support.

This was achieved with an economy of means: two pianists, some well-chosen readings and three vocal soloists of individual and striking talents.

description: Barbara L. Kaiser, a former judge of Westchester County Family Court, died on Sept. 26 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 84. A former resident of Westchester, she lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: After Dancing on Edge, Yankees Reach Home
description: Joe Torre is a practiced storyteller and recites anecdotes from the 1,435 days the Yankees have been champions in his time as their manager. Now he's got a tale to top them all. He will begin with a question: Remember 2001? Remember how we lost the first two playoff games to Oakland, he will say, and then came back and twice beat a team that seemed unbeatable?

title: The Constituency of Terror
description: Newspaper headlines and television anchors across the United States ask, ''Who are these people who hate us so much?'' We who live in the Third World and the former Soviet nations know terrorism well. The 21st century terrorists we confront are ruthless politicians with domestic ambitions. Killing innocents is but a means to an end: taking control of political power in their own countries.

title: A Humane War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIPPER, DR. PHILIP E.
description: SHIPPER-Dr. Philip E. October 13. Beloved husband of Roslyn for 56 years. Loving and proud father of Laura and Marc, and David and Clancy. Phil always maintained a special and unique bond with each of his grandsons, Howard, Andrew, Joshua and Michael. Dear brother of Ethel, Arthur, Judith and the late Irving. Devoted uncle to many nieces and nephews. He practiced dentistry in NYC for 55 years and was a founding member of the American Analgesia Society. He embodied the spirit of New York and was always a superb athlete and sportsman. Funeral services Monday, 10 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam. We will mourn our loss but celebrate his life.

title: Threat of Terrorism Leaves Trade Summit Plans in Doubt

Arizona's Curt Schilling appeared immune to such quirks of history, but when he allowed a game-tying home run to the St. Louis Cardinals' J. D. Drew in the eighth inning tonight, Bank One Ballpark went silent. Could the Diamondbacks squander another postseason chance?

description: Jeremy Giambi, the younger brother of Jason, who has disappeared from this American League division series, expressed a novel view of the Oakland Athletics' plight after their failure to close out the series in their two games at home. ''It's been a frustrating four games for us,'' Giambi said. ''We have to look at it as a positive, that we still have Game 5, that we do have another game. Instead of packing to go home, we're going to New York for another game.''

Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday, October 15th, 9-11 AM, with services 11:30AM. We will join her many friends and colleagues at a memorial service October 18 at 2PM at St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan. Board of Directors, BHT

title: Condemnation Without Absolutes
description: During the interval between the terrorist attacks and the United States response, a reporter called to ask me if the events of Sept. 11 meant the end of postmodernist relativism. It seemed bizarre that events so serious would be linked causally with a rarefied form of academic talk. But in the days that followed, a growing number of commentators played serious variations on the same theme: that the ideas foisted upon us by postmodern intellectuals have weakened the country's resolve. The problem, according to the critics, is that since postmodernists deny the possibility of describing matters of fact objectively, they leave us with no firm basis for either condemning the terrorist attacks or fighting back.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Farmingdale: Van Used At Kennedy Is Stolen
description: A van routinely used in secure areas of Kennedy International Airport was reported stolen over the weekend, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The white 1996 Ford van is used to transport maintenance workers to de-ice planes, load cargo and perform other duties that provide them access to aircraft. The van has a broad blue stripe, the words ''Triangle Services'' on its side, and large yellow smiley-face decals on its rear panels. It was stolen between 9:30 p.m. Saturday and 7 a.m. yesterday from Allied Aero Services Inc., a maintenance facility in Farmingdale, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

From large foundations to small schoolchildren, Americans have showered New York City with more than $850 million in donations and pledges. This beneficence comes without strings. But it imposes upon the people responsible for distributing the money a powerful obligation to spend it wisely, equitably and efficiently. Failure to meet that obligation would not only shortchange the victims but sour the good feeling that has sprung up between the city and the rest of the country in the weeks following Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADLEY, JAMES PATRICK
description: LADLEY-James Patrick, 41, a Cantor Fitzgerald Partner and Corporate Bond Broker, was working at 1 World Trade Center on the 104th floor. James was last spoken to at work on the morning of September 11th. He was a lifelong resident of Staten Island, NY, where he attended Saint Adalbert's and Moore Catholic High School. An accomplished athlete, he lettered four years and was captain of the baseball and basketball teams. He earned a baseball scholarship to North Adams State College, Massachusetts, where he played for four years in his best known position as catcher. He graduated in 1982 and was awarded a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration. James Ladley returned home to Staten Island where his love for baseball resumed with the TWYFord Muche Leagues. At the same time, he pursued his interests in Finance and Economics, which ultimately led him to a successful career. James P. Ladley began his career on Wall Street 17 years ago. He started as an assistant broker at Fundamental Brokerage, Inc. James spent many evenings entertaining clients and built strong business relationships as well as friendships along the way. He moved to Chapdelaine Corporate Securities, became a Partner and held a position within the corporate bond division. James continued his successes as he accepted a new position at Cantor Fitzgerald. For over six years he enjoyed working for the firm as a Partner and as a corporate bond broker, one of the top producers for the firm. James won the respect and admiration of his many friends and co-workers. He expected a lot from himself and out of life. He had a tremendous work ethic and a rigorous schedule that began at 5 AM and ended at 7 PM: it was just a day's work. James P. Ladley also loved the recreational game of golf. He truly enjoyed the friendships and the beauty it offered. These past few years on any given Saturday, he could be found on the Green at the Colts Neck Golf Club. He was the first club member to achieve a ''hole in one'' on the 10th. Settling in Colts Neck 11 years ago, he took great pride in being an active member of his community. James contributed throughout his life to many charities, funds and organizations. Being a New Yorker and having such great appreciation for athletics, he became a die hard Yankees and Rangers fan. He liked going to restaurants, concerts, shows and most of all, he enjoyed coming home to his family, to a nice meal and watching a ball game. James' motivation in life was the love for his family, instilled by his loving parents James and Dolores and siblings MaryAnn, Eileen, Daniel and Patrick. He was a respectful, caring son, and being the oldest, he was the perfect example of a big brother. He always took pride in himself and the importance of always trying to do what was right. James Ladley was loved by all who knew him, especially his family. Jim was a terrific husband and dedicated father, and was cherished by his wife, Sheri, and their two young children, Elizabeth and James. He is the heart and soul of a secure and loving home. Jim, Jimmy, Daddy and Uncle Jimmy will always remain in our hearts and will be missed deeply. Memorial Mass Monday, October 15,2001, 2PM, the Cathedral of St. Patrick's, Madison and East 50th, New York City. In lieu of flowers: ''The Memorial Trust F/B/O the Children of James Ladley,'' c/o First Union, Colts Neck Office, State Highway 34 Artisan Way, Colts Neck, NJ 07722. Visit website: www.jamesladley. com for more information.

Campbell, based in Camden, N.J., said it had no position on the offer. TRC's president, Lorne Albaum, said the firm wanted the stake because ''the company has made a number of management changes in the past year that we think are favorable.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Bell Labs Gets New President

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Start-Up Gets $90 Million

That could make it the first company into the long-distance market with equipment that operates at 40 gigabits a second, quadruple the speeds of today's networks. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAERST, RALPH
description: VAERST-Ralph. Died on October 11, 2001. Services will be held at 11:00AM on Thursday, October 18th, 2001 at the Colonial Mortuary of Crosby-N. Gray & Co., Burlingame. Mr. Vaerst was born in Surabaya, Indonesia on November 21, 1927, the only child of Dr. Louis and Mrs. Sarah Vaerst. In 1946 he moved to Holland to finish his engineering studies at the University of Amsterdam. In 1958 he immigrated to the United States and settled in Boston 5 years as an engineer for High Voltage Engineering Corp., and manufactured large particle accelerators where he also worked with Niels Bohr in Denmark. In 1962 he married Bodil Orbell, the daughter of Frans Orbell, the Mayor of a Stockholm suburb. That year they moved to Palo Alto where he was one of the initial employees of Stanford Linear Accelerator (SLAC) and worked there until 1968. In 1970 he was a founder of Ion Equipment Corp. Ion was one of the first companies that Larry Sonsini took public in 1971. In 1971 Ralph Vaerst also was given credit for coining the phrase ''Silicon Valley.'' Since then he founded or invested in a variety of companies. With some European partners he was a principal and Director of NMS-France, a company that produced electronic displays for the European auto industry which was sold to TRW in 1992. He was also a principal and President of NMS-Switzerland, a company that produced most of the electronic modules for the Swiss watch industry. NMS-Switzerland was sold to a Swiss holding company in 1997. Until his recent death, he has been Chairman of the Board of Borg Instrument, a $200 million company in Germany that produces electronic systems and telematics for the European auto industry. For the past twenty years he lived simultaneously in Atherton and Hillsborough, California, Bastad, Sweden and Paris, France. He is survived by his wife Bodil, his children Sunna Vaerst, Peter Vaerst, and Mary Ann May and six grandchildren. Private interment Skylawn Memorial Park, San Mateo. Viewing will be held at the Mortuary Chapel between the hours of 6:00 and 9:00PM on Wednesday evening.

title: CANTOR FITZGERALD SHUTS FRANKFURT AND PARIS OFFICES
description: Cantor Fitzgerald L.P. said yesterday that it was closing its Frankfurt and Paris offices, as it tried to reduce expenses. The 56-year-old firm, which before last month handled about a quarter of the trades in the $3 trillion United States government bond market, shifted most trading to its eSpeed Inc. unit, an electronic-trading system. Customers in Germany and France can continue trading electronically, a spokeswoman, Cara Kiewel, said, adding that operations would be handled by the London office. About 700 Cantor employees were killed on Sept. 11 in the attacks on the World Trade Center.

Shareholders choosing the cash option will receive 45 percent more than Lafayette's closing share price Friday of $16.47. The combined company would have $2.7 billion in assets. First Merchants is based in Muncie, Ind.
