description: While Oakland Manager Art Howe created headlines by announcing that the Yankees would have to play great to beat the Athletics, his team failed to deliver a great performance when it needed one.

title: Echoes of Anthrax Scare Reverberate Across Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Part of a huge Senate office building was closed today after laboratory tests confirmed the presence of anthrax spores in a letter received by Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic majority leader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JELLINEK, KURT, M.D.
description: JELLINEK-Kurt, M.D. Dedicated physician, beloved husband of Kate, father of Michael (Barbara), grandfather of David, Abraham, Isaiah and Hannah Rose and uncle of Peter, Shane & Jessie, brotherin-law of Susie. Born in Vienna on May 1, 1908. He will be missed by everyone who knew him. Services 1 PM Tuesday at Riverside Chapels, 76 Street & Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Baseball Playoffs: All in the Fox Family
description: In its first season of owning the rights to baseball's postseason -- by paying $2.5 billion through 2006 -- Fox Sports has tried to alter viewing habits, not entirely for the better.

title: Is a National ID Card the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shaken But Still Undiluted Opinions
description: When the first plane crashed into the World Trade Center, Reno was sound asleep in her apartment eight blocks away. Reno, the comedian and performance artist, had been up until 6 or 7 a.m. writing some new material about Christian fundamentalists, she says. ''Rebel Without a Pause,'' her one-woman show at La Mama, begins with an answering machine message received hours later from her friend Pat, saying in part, ''Reno, we're under terrorist attack,'' and assuring her that she isn't joking.

title: Not Over Till It's Over. It's Over.
description: Joe Torre felt his throat tighten as the Yankees' improbable comeback began to appear imminent last night, and each roar of the Yankee Stadium crowd -- the loudest Torre ever heard -- squeezed more emotion from him. He fought back tears as the seventh inning ended, and then the eighth.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Delays For Kursk
description: Hoisting the submarine Kursk to a floating dock is taking longer than expected. The sub was raised from the bottom of the Barents Sea last week, but officials said new problems concern placing two pontoons under the barge that is carrying the 17,000-ton Kursk and its two nuclear reactors. The submarine sank in August 2000, killing all 118 crewmen. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: Age of Opulence

title: India Shells Kashmir Area, Imperiling Delicate Balance
description: On the eve of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's visit here to calm mounting tensions between India and Pakistan, India today pounded Pakistani posts across the dividing line in Kashmir, a land both countries claim, with heavy mortar, rocket and machine-gun fire.

title: Harm Reduction as Alternative
description: Harm Reduction as Alternative

title: A Calmer Fassel Still Rues the Giants' Mistakes
description: A day later, Coach Jim Fassel's face was no longer the fiery crimson it had been during his clenched-teeth postgame address to reporters in the wake of the Giants' wrenching 15-14 loss Sunday to the St. Louis Rams. Fassel had spent most of the night reviewing film of the game, and now he had the pallid complexion to prove it.

title: E*TRADE TO BUY $1.5 BILLION IN DEPOSITS FROM J.P. MORGAN
description: E*Trade Group Inc., a leading online broker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy $1.5 billion of deposits from J. P. Morgan Chase & Company to increase its banking business. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The certificate of deposit and money market accounts will increase E*Trade's deposits by nearly one-fifth, to $9.5 billion. J. P. Morgan's 33,000 accounts will bring E*Trade's total to 469,000. J. P. Morgan Chase had $276.8 billion in deposits on June 30.

title: Ford Denies Top Executive Will Leave by Year's End
description: Jacques A. Nasser, the chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, will probably be out of a job by the end of the year, according to a person close to the company.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B.

title: Bush Administration Says G.O.P. Tax Cut Bill Goes Too Far
description: The Bush administration signaled today that it would not support the full package of tax cuts that Republicans will bring to the House floor this week as their plan for giving a boost to the weakened economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNE, ROBERT M., M.D.
description: BERNE-Robert M., M.D. Former professor and chair of the Department of Physiology at the University of Virginia, School of Medicine, died at his home in Charlottesville, Virginia, Thursday, October 4, 2001. An alumnus of the University of North Carolina and Harvard Medical School he authored over 200 scientific papers, and several textbooks. He co-developed the medication Adenocard, used in the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which he received the American Heart Association's 1979 Research Achievement Award and Merit Award and the 1985 Gold Heart Award as well as the Lifetime Achievement Award of the Science Museum of Virginia in 1989. He was elected to the Institute of Medicine in 1979 and the National Academy of Sciences in 1988. Royalties from the Adenocard patent funded the Robert M. Berne Professorship in Cardiovascular Research, established in 1992. In addition to his scientific interests, Dr. Berne was an avid fisherman, hunter, tennis player, & guitarist. Bob Berne is survived by his wife of 57 years, Beth Goldberg; a sister, Peggy Leavitt; four children and their spouses, Julie & Phil Speasmaker, Amy and Steve Kaminshine, Gordon and Rosalyn Berne, and Michael and Mary Berne as well as 8 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the University of Virginia Chapel in Charlottesville on October 21, 2001, at 12PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Robert M. Berne Educational Fund, CVRC, Univ. of Virginia, 409 Lane Road, MR-4 Bldg., Room 6032, Charlottesville, VA. 22908.

title: Letter Containing Anthrax Sent to U.S. Senate Leader
description: The nation's ever-widening anthrax investigation spread to Congress and to the infant son of an ABC News employee today, as President Bush declared that Osama bin Laden or his terrorist allies might be linked to the recent attempts to poison Americans with the deadly germ.

title: C.D.C. Team Tackles Anthrax
description: Fifty years ago, the federal government set up an elite corps of medical detectives to counter a threat it hoped never to face. Now, with the emergence of anthrax, that corps, the Epidemic Intelligence Service, is facing the challenge of that mission: tracing the cause and stemming the spread of a disease that that may have been deliberately introduced -- in other words, a biological attack.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, BARRY
description: KLEIN-Barry, Miss you and love you more than words can say. Not a day goes by. I take you with me everywhere I go. Sherry

title: Two Named to Head Fund Benefiting Victims
description: A veteran philanthropist and a former Washington financial administrator have been named to run the Sept. 11 Fund, one of the largest of the private funds set up to serve victims of the terrorist attacks last month.

title: Rowdiness Reflects A Time Foreseen
description: At Irving Plaza on Wednesday night Joe Strummer ignored requests to sing ''Rock the Casbah,'' the Clash's 1982 hit about rock defying fundamentalist repression; it includes a line about dropping ''bombs between the minarets.'' With the Clash, Mr. Strummer brought political fervor and premonitions of apocalypse to punk rock. He hasn't lost them, and his voice is still the same brusque, leathery bawl. But while bombs were falling on Afghanistan, he wasn't about to indulge in his youthful bravado.

title: Foreign Affairs; Saudi Royals and Reality
description: Three cheers for Mayor Rudy Giuliani for returning the $10 million donation made by a Saudi billionaire, Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, after he toured the World Trade Center ruins, handed the mayor a check and then declared that it was time to get at the ''roots'' of this terrorism -- which the Saudi royal defined as the U.S. failure to push Israel to make peace with the Palestinians and to stop Israel from ''slaughtering'' Palestinians.

title: 'Body of St. Luke' Gains Credibility
description: A new DNA analysis gives tentative support to the belief that the remains in an ancient lead coffin are those of St. Luke, traditionally considered the author of the third Gospel and the Acts of the Apostles.

title: ''Voices From the Sky''
description: The drama and terror of Sept. 11 unfolded over air traffic control frequencies from New Hampshire to Virginia, from Ohio to Long Island. Here are excerpts prepared for investigators from transcripts of audiotapes at the control centers that were communicating with the four planes. All times are Eastern Daylight Time.

title: Yankees Audio
description: Postgame audio from Game 5 of the A.L. division series between the Yankees and the Oakland Athletics provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Transcripts of Flight 11 and Flight 175
description: Following is a transcript of the radio communications of American Airlines Flight 11 (AAL11) and United Air Lines Flight 175, which took off from Logan International Airport in Boston and then were crashed into the World Trade Center. The transcripts were obtained by The New York Times.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland, Netherlands: Lockerbie Appeal Set
description: The appeal by the Libyan sentenced to life imprisonment last January for the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, will be heard beginning Jan. 23, a special Scottish court ruled. A panel of five judges from Scotland's highest court will hear the appeal by Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi at a courthouse on a former NATO airbase in the Netherlands, where the trial was held and Mr. Megrahi is imprisoned. If his conviction on 270 counts of murder stands, he will finish his sentence in Scotland. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: The Antiterror Pill That House Republicans Won't Swallow
description: When the Senate voted 100 to 0 last week to pass a bill that would nationalize the baggage screening system at airports, conservative House Republicans seemed to have had enough.

title: An Investigator Is Forced Out
description: The Police Department has transferred a respected lieutenant who was playing a key role in the investigation of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and for eight years was the top police supervisor on the F.B.I.-N.Y.P.D. Joint Terrorist Task Force.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Witness Procedures
description: In a change designed to reduce mistaken identification of suspects, New Jersey began yesterday asking witnesses to crimes to view mug shots one at a time, rather than side by side. Research, suggests that simultaneous identification risks witnesses falsely choosing the picture that most resembles the witness's mental image of the suspect. New Jersey, which announced the policy change in July, was the first state to use sequential lineups. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Doctors With Sick Parents See a System's Flaws
description: Dr. Mark L. Rosenberg had always been proud to be a doctor. A former practicing physician and now the director of the Task Force for Child Survival and Development in Decatur, Ga., he followed his mother, a family practitioner, into medicine, graduating from Harvard Medical School in 1972.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit For Phone Gear Maker
description: The struggling British telephone equipment manufacturer Marconi reported operating profit that met a previously lowered target and said sales declined 24 percent compared with a year ago to 1.9 billion ($2.7 billion). Marconi had an operating profit of 5 million in the second quarter, after reporting a 227 million operating loss in the first quarter. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: MYLAN SHARES PLUMMET AFTER UNFAVORABLE COURT RULING
description: Mylan Laboratories shares fell 8.9 percent after an appeals court reversed an order that had forced regulators to approve Mylan's generic version of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company's anti-anxiety drug BuSpar. Mylan fell $3.11, to $31.86 a share. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ruled on Friday that a federal judge erred in March when he ordered the Food and Drug Administration to remove a new Bristol-Myers patent from its registry of drug patents. That judge had also ordered the F.D.A. to approve Mylan's generic medicine, and Mylan began selling the drug soon after. Mylan, based in Corona, Calif., said that it would ask the court to reconsider.

title: SALT PRODUCER WILL SELL BUSINESSES FOR $640 MILLION
description: IMC Global, the world's third-biggest salt producer, will sell its salt and Ogden businesses for about $640 million to an affiliate of the closely held management firm Apollo Management L.P. IMC Global, one of the biggest makers of fertilizer, will initially receive about $600 million in cash from Apollo, and the remainder of the purchase price will be a stake in the salt business, now owned by Apollo, which is based in New York and managed by the investor Leon Black. The Ogden, or Great Salt Lake, evaporation operation makes solar salt, sulphate of potash and magnesium chloride. The sale will help IMC Global, which is based in Lake Forest, Ill., concentrate on its main fertilizer business, a spokesman, David Prichard, said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Industrial Acquisition
description: Europe's second-largest ball-bearing manufacturer, FAG Kugelfischer Georg Schaefer A.G., advised shareholders to accept a higher bid from its rival INA-Holding Schaeffler K.G., after resisting a takeover bid for four months. The agreement came after INA raised its offer 9.1 percent, valuing Kugelfischer at 731 million euros ($666 million). The combined company would be the world's No. 2 ball-bearing producer after SKF A.B. of Sweden. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: A New Mother's Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Anthrax Investigation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARE, BEATRICE
description: VARE-Beatrice. The Board of the Central Queens YM & YWHA expresses its profound condolences to Margaret Hammerschlag and Elizabeth Rosenblum, beloved daughters, on the passing of Beatrice Vare, our esteemed Board Member for over 18 years. For eight decades, Beatrice carried the torch of social responsibility in her professional social work career and numerous charitable involvements. She emobdied the qualiities of caring, insight and concern for social justice that are central to Jewish community. May her memory be a blessing. Shep Porter, President Judith Rosen, Chairman of the Board David Posner, Executive Director

title: Pay Gap Remains for Women in Life Sciences
description: In the robust and decidedly lively field of the life sciences, at least one verity refuses to die: for every dollar that a male scientist earns, a woman earns not quite 77 cents.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Press Owner On Trial
description: Prosecutors asked a court to sentence the owner of Chosun Ilbo, the country's largest newspaper, to seven years in prison and a fine of $10 million for tax evasion and embezzlement. Bang Sang Hoon, president of the newspaper, held without bail for two months along with several other news media executives, told the court the ones on trial are ''the Korean media as a whole, and Korea's freedom of the press.'' The conservative Chosun Ilbo and Dong A Ilbo, whose top executive is also on trial, have criticized President Kim Dae Jung's efforts at rapprochement with North Korea. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Favre and His Helpers Are Having Fun Again
description: If you watched Brett Favre slice and carve the Baltimore Ravens' trumpeted defense on Sunday, you witnessed the reincarnation of Favre as a championship-caliber quarterback and the Packers as a legitimate Super Bowl contender.

title: Information, Please
description: For the Bush administration, a week of bombing and missile attacks on Afghanistan have proceeded with dispatch and, at least so far, success. But the war at home has been much harder.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Fit for a Queen

title: In Shift, Officials Look Into Possibility Anthrax Cases Have bin Laden Ties
description: Federal authorities say they are now investigating the possibility that followers of Osama bin Laden were behind the anthrax cases around the nation.

title: World Briefing | Outer Space: Workout For Spacewalkers
description: Two Russian cosmonauts took their second spacewalk in as many weeks. Mikhail Tyurin and Vladimir Dezhurov spent six hours in space setting up new equipment for docking and spacewalks and science experiments for the Japanese Space Agency. They are midway through a four-month mission on the International Space Station, a 16-nation project. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: The President's Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 7 p.m. Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABISH, SHELDON
description: ABISH-Sheldon. On Sunday, October 14, 2001 at his home in NYC. Beloved husband of Sheila, brother-in-law of Alfred Carlson, cherished uncle of Kenneth Carlson & family. A CPA with a successful NY practice spanning 40 years, he served on the Board of Directors of Westend Intergenerational Residence and was a graduate of Brooklyn College. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56 Street, NYC. Notification of memorial service will be announced.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Canaan: Possible Arson At Historic Site
description: A fire at a historic railroad station early Saturday may have been arson, state police said yesterday. The fire started away from the kitchen in Keilty's Depot Restaurant, which is in one wing of Union Station, believed to be the oldest operating train station in Connecticut. The wooden station, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, also sustained damage to offices. The cost of the damage has not been determined.

title: Kofi Annan, Nobel Laureate
description: To the Editor:

title: Site Named for 2 Small Long Island Power Plants
description: In the latest step toward increasing Long Island's energy supply, the Long Island Power Authority and the KeySpan Energy Corporation presented plans today to build two small power plants in Port Jefferson, a harbor village in Suffolk County.

title: Thomas Could Still Come Off The Bench
description: Since it became clear on the first day of Knicks training camp that Larry Johnson would retire, the assumption has been that Kurt Thomas would inherit Johnson's starting spot at power forward. Thomas, coming off his best season as a pro, seemed poised to do something special in his new role.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MARY THACHER
description: BROWN-Mary Thacher. Age 90. Died peacefully on October 13, 2001. Preceded in death by her husband Daniel N. Brown. Loving mother of Cynthia B. Lloyd, grandmother of Emily D. Lloyd, sister of Thomas Thacher and the late Sarah T. Storm, and beloved aunt and friend to many. Mary Brown was an artist and naturalist who actively supported environmental and humanitarian causes. Memorial service October 23 at 11:30 at The First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, send contributions in her memory to Noble Horizons, 17 Cobble Road, Salisbury, CT 06068.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Federal Hall Reopens
description: Federal Hall, the building on the site where George Washington was sworn in as the first president of the United States, reopened yesterday, more than a month after the collapse of the World Trade Center covered it and much of Wall Street in dust and debris. Officials said the building, which is three blocks from ground zero, is safe for the public to enter. But the collapse widened a hairline crack dating from the 1920's to a half inch or more, said Edie Shean-Hammond, a spokeswoman for the National Park Service, which manages the building. The damage will cost $15 million or more to repair, she said.

title: Tunnel Vision; Fearing Something in the Subway Air, Beyond the Odor
description: Some people try to laugh about it, but it's not very funny anymore. ''For years,'' wrote one subway rider, in an Internet discussion, ''I had always joked that the air in the subway would overpower any bacteria/virus that could be introduced.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the effect of road closings at the Ashokan Reservoir on businesses in Shokan, N.Y., misstated the situation of New York City's $30 million plan to increase security in its watershed. The plan has been adopted by the city Department of Environmental Protection and is going forward; it is not awaiting City Council approval.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Stan Adams was named to the new post of senior vice president and chief marketing officer at Hakuhodo Advertising America, New York, owned by Hakuhodo. He had been senior vice president at the Nantucket Group, New York, a strategic consulting company.

title: The Puzzling Watts Towers, Restored but Not Revealed
description: Few people know the baffling, elegant Watts Towers as Zuleyma C. Aguirre does. For 13 years she headed the team that painstakingly restored these monuments, which have always seemed like the exclamation points at the end of an only half articulated sentence.

title: In Hallways And Offices, Speaker Race Is Now Raging
description: More than two months before the new City Council is sworn in, the race for Council speaker has begun in earnest, characterized by a barrage of letters, telephone conversations and meetings with incumbent council members and candidates who won last month's Democratic primary races.

title: Iran Dances A 'Ballet' With U.S.
description: In an important sign of growing cooperation with the United States in its war against Afghanistan, Iran has sent a secret message to the Bush administration agreeing to rescue any American military personnel in distress in its territory, American and Iranian officials said today.

title: Lower Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Shows 2 Candidates Rewarded Contributors
description: Bret D. Schundler and James E. McGreevey have handsomely rewarded contractors and professional firms that contributed to their campaigns for mayor, a new study of campaign and municipal records in Jersey City and Woodbridge has found.

title: The Fish Return to Fulton Market (Along With the Mongers)
description: Commerce has returned to the Fulton Fish Market. The landmark market on South Street along the East River reopened for business yesterday in the dark morning hours as the tide ran hard and the rain fell lightly.

title: Arthur D. Little in Talks to Sell Majority Stake
description: Arthur D. Little, a consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass., has entered into exclusive negotiations to sell a majority stake in the firm to a group of private investors.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Job Fair For Displaced Workers
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city would hold a job fair for New Yorkers who lost their jobs as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center last month. The city and private employers say they have identified 13,000 temporary and permanent job openings in the city. The fair, called Twin Towers Job Expo, will be held at the Madison Square Garden Expo Center tomorrow from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Employers from several industries, including retailing, finance, health care and food service will interview prospective employees there.

title: A Feeling of Control
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Inquiry Is Under Way On Online Music Business
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it was investigating whether the major recording companies were engaged in anticompetitive practices in the nascent online music market.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Big Brothers Big Sisters, the corporate mentor program, misstated the effect of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. While most large corporations that lost offices downtown have ended their participation, the program itself continues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASKINS, CARYL P.
description: HASKINS-Caryl P. The Trustees of the American Museum of Natural History are saddened by the death of Dr. Caryl P. Haskins, Trustee of the Museum since 1973, an Honorary Trustee since 1988. He was a valued member of the Board who brought extraordinary intelligence and dedication to the Museum's mission to educate the public about the natural world and global cultures. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President American Museum of Natural History

title: Lord Hailsham Dies at 94; A Tory With a Lighter Side
description: Lord Hailsham of St. Marylebone, a leading British Conservative politician who served in six governments, including Churchill's wartime administration, and was the longest-serving lord chancellor, or head of the British judiciary, in the 20th century, died on Friday at his London home. He was 94.

title: Leslie Caps a Big Year With Another Award
description: There are many facets to Lisa Leslie.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Defense Minister Returns
description: At Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee's request, George Fernandes, left, as minister of defense, although Mr. Fernandes, who had resigned, has not yet been cleared of the taint of a defense procurement scandal by a special committee. Undercover reporters for a dot-com magazine, posing as agents of a military equipment company, captured Jaya Jaitley, Mr. Fernandes's companion and the president of his political party, on videotape talking about campaign contributions for the party and saying she would put in a word for the company. Opposition leaders denounced Mr. Fernandes's return. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADEN, HERBERT J.
description: BADEN-Herbert J. on October 13 in NYC. Former Long Island Regional Director of The Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services. Beloved son of the late Herbert and Fannie. Loving brother of Irving of Florida and the late Gerald and Edna. Cherished uncle of many nieces and nephews. Arrangements will be private. Donations to your favorite charity in Jack's name will be appreciated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Cutting Jobs
description: After a supervisory board meeting, Commerzbank said it would cut 3,400 jobs and close 62 branches to reduce costs by ''at least 500 million euros'' ($455 million) during the next year. Commerzbank said it lost 120 million euros in July and August, and expects to report a loss for the full third quarter. The chief executive, Klaus-Peter Mller, above, expects the company to post a profit for the full year and to pay a dividend. Commerzbank also said that two board members in charge of the asset management division and the retail banking operations, both underperforming divisions, will be succeeded by Martin Blessing, former chairman of Advance Bank, and Mehmet Dalman, head of Commerzbank's security operations. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Tightening of Border Pinches Local Economy
description: Tight new security restrictions at crossings with Mexico are choking the economic life out of border towns in California and the Southwest, congressmen from the region say.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Handspring Shares Rise
description: Shares of Handspring, the hand-held computer maker, jumped 27 percent after the company introduced models that integrate a mobile phone, e-mail, text messaging and a Palm organizer into a single wireless device. Named Treo, the device will be released early next year. Handspring stock, which has fallen from a 52-week high of over $99, rose 59 cents yesterday, to $2.78. The increase follows a 31 percent gain on Friday after rumors circulated about the new products. Handspring and Palm Inc., which use the same operating system but are hardware rivals, have more than 50 percent of the market. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Eye-Surgery Concern Posts a Wider Loss
description: TLC Laser Eye Centers Inc. said today that its fiscal first-quarter loss widened, prompting further cost reductions at the company, North America's largest laser eye-surgery provider.

title: Transplanted Englishman Is Remembered as a 'Good Ol' Boy'
description: The news helicopters, the photographers and the investigators are gone, but neighbors say life on Massachusetts Drive will not be the same without Robert Stevens, the photo editor at American Media Inc. who died of anthrax 10 days ago at the age of 63.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Officer Still Hospitalized
description: A Mansfield police officer who was shot by a Fort Dix reservist who went berserk and wounded four people was listed in stable condition yesterday. The police officer, Lt. William Kerr, remained hospitalized at Cooper Hospital/University Medical Center in Camden, said Sharon Clark, a hospital spokeswoman. The reservist, Loren J. Janeczko, of Fincastle, Va., had behaved erratically before he wounded two soldiers at Fort Dix, and later Lieutenant Kerr and another officer on Friday, and was shot by the police. The three other victims were treated and released. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Ruth Goetz, 93, Who Co-Wrote 'The Heiress'
description: Ruth Goetz, a playwright who collaborated with her husband, Augustus Goetz, on ''The Heiress'' and other plays, died Friday at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey. She was 93 and had been living in the Actors' Fund Home in Englewood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHKIND, HILDA (HAMERLING)
description: ROCHKIND-Hilda (Hamerling), 92. Died at home in Manhattan on October 14, 2001, after a brief illness. The sixth of seven siblings, she emigrated from Poland in 1920 and lived in New York City for her entire life, except for a 20-year period ending in 1995, when she lived in West Palm Beach, FL. Her husband, William, an attorney, died in 1955. She is survived by her daughter, Esta Walsh, and son, Mark Rochkind, both of New Jersey; and by a granddaughter, Tara Rochkind, of New York, and a grandson, William Rochkind, of Memphis, TN.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Acquisition By Money Manager
description: Credit Suisse Asset Management said it planned to expand its reach into Britain's pension and retail fund market by buying the British-based SLC Asset Management Group, a unit of Sun Life Financial of Canada. Terms were not disclosed. The deal would increase the Credit Suisse unit's funds under management by almost $16 billion. Credit Suisse said it planned to phase out the SLC name and fold SLC's operations into its headquarters in London. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Accord Seen With F.C.C. On Licenses Of NextWave
description: Federal officials and several of the nation's largest wireless communications companies may announce as early as today a settlement in a dispute over who owns more than 200 valuable licenses to provide wireless service, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Division in the Sky Over Europe
description: Big European airlines say they are worried that their American rivals are using government rescue money to undercut European carriers' prices on trans-Atlantic flights.

title: Powell, in Pakistan, Focuses on Shape of Post-Taliban Regime
description: Little more than a week into its Afghan campaign, the Bush administration is undertaking its first high-level discussions with South Asian leaders on how to help orchestrate a new government in Afghanistan or respond to political collapse there.

title: Accounts
description: * PeopleSoft, Pleasanton, Calif., a software and services provider, to the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account, which had been at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners West, San Francisco, part of Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, which is owned by the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Gannett Reports 16% Decline in Profit
description: The Gannett Company said today that its third-quarter profit fell 16 percent after the terrorist attacks last month accelerated advertising declines. The company said fourth-quarter profit might miss analysts' estimates.

title: Kofi Annan, Nobel Laureate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAITZ, BETTY (NEE RUSSAK)
description: SAITZ-Betty (nee Russak). Of North Shore Towers and formerly Jericho, died in her home early Sunday morning. Beloved widow of Samuel, loving mother of Phyllis Saitz, Lisa Saitz-Sokol (Larry) & granddaughter Samantha. Services were held Monday. Shiva will be at the Sokol house Tuesday through Thursday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Officers Kill Robbery Suspect
description: Police officers fatally shot a man and wounded an accomplice last night after the pair robbed a Chinese restaurant in Queens and rammed a car with a plainclothes officer inside as they fled, the police said. The plainclothes officer suffered a broken leg and was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. The wounded accomplice was also at the hospital, listed in stable condition, the police said. Details were sketchy, and no names or the location of the shooting were released, though the address of the restaurant was given as 74-22 Jamaica Avenue, in the Woodhaven section. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Research Is Urged for Healthier Breast Milk
description: With her 7-week-old baby nursing at her breast, Dr. Sandra Steingraber spoke at a conference held recently in New York to address an important issue: the presence of low levels of chemical residues in breast milk.

title: Kofi Annan, Nobel Laureate
description: To the Editor:

title: EMI Group's Top Executive for Recorded Music Quits
description: In an admission that attempts to rebuild its presence in the United States had fallen flat, the EMI Group said today that Ken Berry, its well-known head of recorded music and its highest paid executive, had left the company.

title: Harm Reduction as Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: A Return to Fund-Raising as Usual
description: If America were led by angels, every step taken by its leaders at a time of emergency would be selfless. But while President Bush and Congress grapple with the current crisis, they have also quietly begun to return to the business of politics. That includes campaign fund-raising among special-interest groups, a process that taints all the other important work the nation is trusting them to do. Both political parties have actually been appealing to some donors to give in the spirit of patriotism. Meanwhile, tax bills favoring big business, airline bailouts and energy legislation that emphasizes drilling in the Arctic wilderness are all front and center on Capitol Hill.

title: Security Concerns Piniella
description: Mariners Manager Lou Piniella said the anthrax cases in Florida, New York and the rest of the country raised concerns for ballplayers who received a lot of mail from the public.

title: Any Day Is Now a Game Day as TV Schedules Expand
description: History will be made tonight at Papa John's Cardinal Stadium in Louisville. A college football game will be played there -- on a Tuesday night. No one can recall a regular-season game being played on a Tuesday, the traditional night for ''Frasier,'' not for college football.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Splinter Candidate Chosen
description: The opposition Forum for Democracy and Development has elected the former vice president, Gen. Christon Tembo, to be its candidate in presidential elections expected next month. But the nomination is being challenged by the government, which says General Tembo's father was born in neighboring Malawi, making his son ineligible to be president under a 1996 change in the Constitution. General Tembo was among those who quit the cabinet to protest President Frederick Chiluba's efforts to change the Constitution to allow him to run for a third term. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE DECLINES. Coffee fell on expectations that increased production next year in Brazil would exacerbate a glut of beans. In New York, coffee for December delivery fell 0.85 cent, or 1.9 percent, to 43.85 cents a pound.

title: For Steinbrenner, It's High Anxiety and High-Fives
description: He looked like every passionate, obsessive grandfather at a Little League game, biting his fingernails, pounding his fists on the table and raising his hands above his head to clap vigorously. He wore the customary white turtleneck and gray slacks, but the customary blue blazer was absent and a maroon blazer was folded neatly beside him. It is easier to give high-fives without the jacket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBINO, THOMAS
description: GAMBINO-Thomas, 42. Of NYC, is presumed to have died in the collapse of the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Mr. Gambino was a graduate of West Point and Harvard Law School. He was the son of Thomas Gambino of Chadds Ford, PA., and the late Frances L. Gambino. Also survived by his brother and sister-inlaw, Michael and Laura Gambino of Greenville, DE., and sister, Maria Renee Gambino of Philadelphia. Private memorial services will be held in November. Donations may be made to the American Red Cross Relief Fund or charity of your choice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Abkhazia: Air Strikes On Rebels
description: Abkhaz helicopters attacked Georgian and Chechen rebels in the disputed Kodori Gorge after President Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia asked Russia to help prevent escalation of the fighting in the breakaway Georgian region. Abkhazia has accused the Chechens and Georgians of trying to retake the region. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOETZ, RUTH
description: GOETZ-Ruth. The Officers and Members of Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the passing of Ruth Goetz. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Toni Wiener, President

title: TRW SAYS IT PLANS TO ELIMINATE 16% OF AEROSPACE JOBS
description: TRW Inc. plans to cut 1,100 aerospace jobs, about 16 percent of the division's staff, to cope with slowing demand for commercial aircraft products aggravated by the Sept. 11 attacks. About half the jobs to be eliminated are in Britain. About 300 temporary workers will be laid off immediately and the rest by the end of 2002, TRW said. The division employs about 6,900. Airlines have pared about a fifth of scheduled flights since Sept. 11. The business makes engine and flight controls, and cargo-handling hoists and winches. TRW is based in Cleveland.

title: On a Warm Day, a Chill Wind in Louisville
description: Shannon Moert, 38, said someone held a gun to her head once and she kept her cool. In August, she said, she sat outside an operating room for more than seven hours while her son Jonathan, who was 8 months old at the time, had open-heart surgery.

title: The Battlefield In the American Mind
description: In Afghanistan, the targets are running out. Such are the frustrations of the powerful; Joseph Conrad, writing of an African ''heart of darkness'' a century ago, well understood: ''Once, I remember, we came upon a man-of-war anchored off the coast. There wasn't even a shed there, and she was shelling the bush. In the empty immensity of earth, sky, water, there she was, incomprehensible, firing into a continent.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about communications between the F.B.I. and other agencies in the anthrax investigation misstated the number of suspicious letters received at NBC News that were delayed at the bureau before being tested and reported to city officials. The article also misstated the length of the delay, and a correction in this space on Sunday dealt with the errors incompletely. (A comment in the Liberties column on the Op-Ed page on Sunday reflected both errors in some copies.)

title: COMMERCE ONE TO CUT 1,300 JOBS AND SPIN OFF SOME UNITS
description: Commerce One, which sells software and services for buying goods on the Internet, said yesterday that it would cut about 1,300 jobs and spin off some consultant businesses. The company will lay off 700 employees of its 2,800 and spin off some of the services groups acquired when the company bought AppNet Inc. for $1.85 billion last year. That will move 600 employees from Commerce One, said a spokesman, Andrew McCarthy. The cuts are intended to pare costs and sharpen the company's focus on developing software.

title: When Athletes Drink Souped Up Water
description: Athletes who drink so-called superoxygenated water because they think it will help their performance are wasting their money, a new report says.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Power Shift In Senate
description: The opposition Justicialist party retained control of the Senate and replaced the ruling Alianza coalition as the leading political force in the lower house of Congress, according to vote tallies from elections on Sunday. President Fernando de la Ra said he would listen to the voters and urged opposition governors, labor leaders and businessmen to join him in efforts to lift the country from its 40-month recession. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Transcript American Airlines Flight 11
description: Following is a transcript of the radio communications between air traffic controller at Logan International Airport [46R] in Boston and several jetliners identified by their call signs on the morning of Sept. 11. Among the jetliners were American Airlines Flight 11 (AAL11) and United Air Lines Flight 175 (UAL175), which took off from Logan and then were crashed into the World Trade Center. The transcripts were obtained by The New York Times .

title: Responding to Anthrax Attacks
description: Discovery that a child who visited ABC News has contracted cutaneous anthrax and tests showing that the office of the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, has received anthrax-laced mail bearing the same Trenton postmark and date as an anthrax-contaminated letter sent to NBC News in New York are reason for increased concern about biological terrorism. The spate of attacks is still limited and the number of people actually coming down with illness quite small. However, the incidents have revealed weaknesses in the public health system that need to be fixed if the nation is to handle even bigger biological attacks in the future.

title: Young Japanese Breaking Old Salaryman's Bonds
description: Toward the end of the week, when Keisuke Sauri gets bored driving a kerosene delivery truck, he does something very un-Japanese. He skips work and follows his inner passion for antiquing.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSIMANO, JAMES M.
description: CUSIMANO-James M. September 17, 2001 at age 58. Beloved husband of Beverly (nee Haferbier) for 36 years. Preceded in death by his parents Salvatore and Elsie (nee Piper) and by brother Charles and sister Arlene Fredrichsdorf. Jim was a graduate ABD of University of Wisconsin, Madison. His work was in public relations and freelance writing. He is survived by brother David, sisters Angeline Hacherian and Marion Johnson, many nieces, nephews and a host of friends. Graveside services were held privately in Milwaukee. A celebration of his life will be held at Downtime, 251 West 30 St, NYC between 7 and 9PM on October 24. Please contribute in Jim's name to your favorite charity.

title: Q & A
description: Sea of Grass

title: Sports of The Times; Old Champs Outlasted The Kids
description: CONTRARY to urban legend, the baseball season is not over yet at the fortified castle in the Bronx.

title: Hormones Bothering Him As Much as Kryptonite
description: Superman purists won't like it. People abnormally devoted to established teenage shows from which it borrows won't like it. But anyone with a flexible streak should find plenty to admire in ''Smallville,'' a new series about Clark Kent's high school days, at least if future episodes match tonight's attention-getting debut.

title: Strains on a Man and the City, Distilled in 10 Minutes
description: MOUKHTAR KOCACHE has the future to think about. He's the director of visual and media arts for the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, which brought the arts to the financial district. The council lost an artist and its offices in the World Trade Center attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, HERBERT
description: ROSS-Herbert. American Ballet Theatre's Dancers and Staff pay tribute to one of our family, Herbert Ross (1927-2001). He will forever remain in our hearts and our thoughts.

title: Powell Arrives in India Seeking Peace in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 16  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell came to India today on his tour of South Asia, which has taken on new urgency with the latest violent confrontation between India and Pakistan over their conflicting claims to the disputed land of Kashmir.

title: PRUDENTIAL RECEIVES APPROVAL TO ISSUE STOCK
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America received final approval yesterday from the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance to go ahead with a plan to reorganize and issue stock after decades as a mutual insurer owned by its policyholders. The Newark company, which will change its name to Prudential Financial Inc., is expected to issue stock toward the end of the year. As a part of the conversion, the company's 10.5 million policyholders will share accumulated profits of about $20 billion. In approving the plan, New Jersey's regulators had ignored the protests of some policyholders that Prudential's plan to distribute the money was unfair. Some of the policyholders filed lawsuits. Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Company Plans a Buyback
description: The board of Venezuela's largest telecommunications company approved a share buyback yesterday in the latest wrinkle of a takeover dispute involving several multinational investors, people close to the company said. The company, Cia. Nacional Telfonos de Venezuela, or CANTV, said it would offer $30 a share for about 15 percent of its outstanding stock, in addition to a dividend of $550 million to be paid in two installments. The offer by CANTV, whose large shareholders include Verizon Communications and Telfonica of Spain, comes after a hostile bid by the AES Corporation of Arlington, Va., to seek control of the company for $24 a share. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Yankees Silence Athletics and Drum
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, did not go to Oakland for what turned out to be two Yankees victories that tied the American League division series, but his presence was felt nonetheless.

title: Review/Fashion; Avoiding Overt Sensuality at a Time of Vulnerability
description: It seems an eternity ago, though it was just a few seasons back, that a movie as sexually detonating as Luis Buuel's ''Belle du Jour'' held fashion under so powerful a sway. As the spring 2002 collections ended in Paris last week, replete with clothes that invoked first holy communion dresses, collars that called to mind Mary Queen of Scots and caftans that would have found a friend in Mama Cass, it was apparent that seduction had been declared last millennium's news.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Revisit Anonymity In Door-to-Door Canvassing
description: Six years after ruling that the Constitution protects the right to distribute anonymous campaign literature, the Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether that right extends to anonymous door-to-door advocacy for a political or religious cause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, SARAH
description: RUBIN-Sarah. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of the beloved sister of our devoted member Louis Orwasher. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

description: CLASSICAL MUSIC

description: ''The bottom line is we all need to take a breath and realize that there does not have to be a single illness from this point forward if we handle these situations calmly.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, HYMAN R.
description: SHAPIRO-Hyman R. Though the years pass your love remains forever in my heart. Ruth

title: California Strengthens Handgun Laws and Partners' Rights
description: In a last-minute flurry over the weekend, Gov. Gray Davis signed into law sweeping new rights for domestic partners, stronger protections against harassment for those entering abortion clinics and some of the strictest requirements in the nation for prospective handgun buyers.

title: Brill's Content Closes; Web Site, Inside.com, Is Cut Back
description: A few years back, Steven Brill had a brainstorm: the public, he thought, was fascinated with news about highly visible media organizations, and this appetite could be converted into a business that would thrive as it revealed the mysteries and missteps of those organizations.

title: Operating Profit Rises 23% at Fannie Mae
description: Fannie Mae, the leading buyer of mortgages in the country, said today that its third-quarter operating earnings rose 23 percent as homeowners refinanced loans at a record pace.

title: 2 Airlines to Resume Concorde Flights Next Month
description: The Concorde will return to the skies early next month, Air France and British Airways announced yesterday, but travelers said that the sluggish economy and post-Sept. 11 safety concerns might quell enthusiasm for the expensive swanlike supersonic jets.

title: A Young Man in a Strange Place at a Time That Can Never Be Right
description: HALF A LIFE

title: A Whole Cast Of Thousands At the Piano
description: Alone at her piano Tori Amos was a one-woman crowd when she performed at the Beacon Theater on last Tuesday night. She was a dreamer, a rape victim, a little girl, a threatening boyfriend, an abandoned lover, a beauty queen, a blasphemous Christian, an ancient myth. She was sweet and remote, cagey and raw, pained and merciless.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: 8 Suspended By Opposition
description: The leading opposition party suspended eight senior party members, including four members of Parliament, in an effort to crack down on political infighting within its ranks. Among the suspended legislators was Job Sikhala, who had accused fellow members of the Movement for Democratic Change of orchestrating a violent attack on his house. The opposition party is trying to overcome its internal divisions so that its president, Morgan Tsvangirai, can concentrate on challenging President Robert Mugabe in the presidential election expected next year. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JENSEN, JIM
description: JENSEN-Jim. Your courage and common sense are sorely missing in this world. I miss my partner in love, life and raising our son. Rachel

title: Balkan Instability Could Create a Terrorist Haven
description: For 10 years, the Balkans have presented Europe and America with one of their greatest foreign policy challenges. The aftermath of four violent conflicts has consumed billions of taxpayers' dollars in aid. In March 1999, the Balkans triggered the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's first war, almost 50 years to the day after the alliance was founded. And bitter disputes over Balkan policy occasionally threatened the foundations of America's relations with Europe and, indeed, harmony within Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASMUSSEN, SARA J.
description: RASMUSSEN-Sara J. On October 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Harold F.; mother of David of Old Greenwich, Connecticut, Garret of Washington, DC, Anne Fraser of Rye, New York. Six grandchildren. Service Saturday, Oct. 20, 2 PM at Christ's Church, Rye, NY.

title: Awaiting Tally, Democrats Try to Close Ranks
description: The leaders of the state and national Democratic parties both worked to reconcile Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer and their supporters yesterday, trying to head off any lasting rift between the two campaigns that could damage the party's chances of recapturing City Hall in November.

title: Taliban Leader a Target of U.S. Air Campaign
description: Since the first day of its air campaign, the Pentagon has been trying to attack Mullah Muhammad Omar, the supreme leader of the Taliban, according to American officials.

title: A Leader of Afghan Rebels Says They Are Near a Crucial Taliban City
description: The Northern Alliance said today that its troops had advanced to the outskirts of the strategic city of Mazar-i-Sharif, capitalizing on what it said were a rash of defections from the Taliban army and setting the stage for a decisive battle for control of northern Afghanistan.

title: Struggle to Survive for an 'Urban Whale'
description: Out of the dark waters off the west side of San Juan Island, three great black fins rise in unison as a trio of killer whales surface for air and then slowly descend to pursue a run of salmon.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the television program ''Third Watch'' misstated the location of the filming of an outdoor scene. It was Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, not Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ANTWERPEN, DR. FRANKLIN J.
description: VAN ANTWERPEN-Dr. Franklin J. Died October 13, 2001 in Doylestown, PA. Former Executive Director of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers in NYC. Survived by his widow Dorothy, son U.S. District Judge Franklin S. of Easton, daughter Virginia of Apex, NC, six grandchildren and one great grandson. Visitation Tuesday 7-9 PM, The Ashton Funeral Home, Easton. Service private.

title: An Electro-Punk Groove That Makes Fans Rock
description: When Orbital took the stage on Saturday night at Roseland as part of the CMJ Music Marathon, all that was visible were four points of light, bobbing and swaying in pairs. Phil and Paul Hartnoll, the brothers from Britain who founded Orbital more than a decade ago, were wearing glasses equipped with small light bulbs next to each lens. The lights not only helped illuminate the knobs and buttons that were turned and punched for the next 90 minutes but also allowed the Hartnoll brothers to create the illusion of dancing by merely nodding their heads.

title: U.S. Steps Up Leaflets and Radio Broadcasts to Sway Afghans
description: An American bomber on Sunday delivered Washington's latest weapon against the Taliban leadership in Afghanistan -- leaflets. ''The Partnership of Nations is here to help,'' declared one of the 385,000 slips of paper dropped from a B-52 over locations in the northwestern and southeastern regions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Demand Outpaces Supply Of Drug to Treat Anthrax

title: Spores Found At Post Office In Boca Raton
description: Health authorities said today that they had found a minuscule amount of anthrax spores in the main post office of Boca Raton, which serves the tabloid publishing company where an employee died of the disease earlier this month.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE 20th SUSPECT; Man Held in U.S. Was Wired 2 Large Sums From Germany
description: A 33-year-old immigrant who has emerged as a key suspect in the investigation of the Sept. 11 terror attacks received $15,000 in unexplained money transfers from Germany in August, say German investigators who are trying to determine if the plot had its origins in their country.

title: 'We Have Some Planes,' Hijacker Told Controller
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  American Airlines Flight 11 had fallen mysteriously silent. The air traffic controller called over and over for a response. None came. Then he heard an unidentified voice from the cockpit: "We have some planes. Just stay quiet, and you'll be O.K. We are returning to the airport."

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Software Company Buys Rival
description: The Caminus Corporation, whose software helps utilities and gas producers trade energy commodities, has agreed to buy the software business of Altra Energy Technologies for $61.7 million in cash and stock. Caminus will pay about 1.98 million shares, or $31.7 million, based on Friday's closing share price of $16.05, and $30 million in cash for the Altra unit. Altra's software helps manage natural gas transactions.

title: Anthrax Fears Send Demand for a Drug Far Beyond Output
description: As fear of anthrax continues to rise and demand for the antibiotic Cipro skyrockets, the German company that makes the drug in the United States has only begun to increase its production and will probably take several months to produce the drug in the quantities the government wants.

Mother of Michael (Marsha) of Los Angeles, CA, and Tom (Marlene) of Acton, MA. Sister of Jay and Harold Fischer. Grandmother of Jonah, Seth, Lisa and Karyn. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY, on Wednesday, October 17, at 2:00 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with a biographical sketch of Jeffery Randall Smith, a victim of the World Trade Center disaster who enjoyed medieval poetry and rooted for the University of Miami football team, was published in error. The subject was unidentified. The sketch is reprinted today, with a correct picture, on Page B11.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Redistricting Deadline Passes
description: The State Supreme Court declined to rule on 13 challenges to Secretary of State Bill Bradbury's redistricting plan for the Legislature, letting its deadline for approving the state's new political boundaries pass. The court now has until Nov. 1 to recommend changes in Mr. Bradbury's plan. Mr. Bradbury, a Democrat, has acknowledged minor flaws in the plan. He was handed the redistricting job in July after legislators failed to reach an agreement. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: High Cost of Being Well: Benefits at a Premium; Employees Will Pay A Sharp Increase For Insurance Plans
description: Workers now signing up for health plans for next year are facing the largest rate increases in 10 years.

description: KRAUT-Philip. Beloved husband of Lillian and the late Pearl. Devoted father of Arthur (Barbara), Ted (Ann), Larry (Kathy). Cherished grandfather of seven and great grandfather of 10. Fond brother of Ben and Rose Bernstein. Dear stepfather of Doris Brody. Services today 1 PM at Temple Beth Sholom, 390 Broadway, Lawrence, L.I.

title: Anthrax Scare Reaches Europe Despite Lack of Known Cases
description: PARIS, Oct. 16  Buildings have been evacuated and people sent to hospitals for observation as an anthrax scare spread across and beyond Europe, where envelopes containing white powder were received in a number of countries.

description: Earlier this year the fall and holiday movie season promised to be packed with gung-ho images of American soldiers in uniform. But one by one, most of those films have dropped off the Hollywood release schedule.

title: A Half Effort by the Jets Brings a Share of First
description: The Jets' split-personality victory over the Miami Dolphins on Sunday was confounding enough, a game that was so evenly divided between dreadful and dynamic that Coach Herman Edwards jokingly denied having performed lobotomies on his players at halftime.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens Cuts Jobs
description: The German electronic and engineering company Siemens A.G. said that it would cut a further 7,000 jobs from its networking and mobile phone divisions in addition to about 10,000 planned layoffs already announced this year. Half of the latest cuts will be in Germany. The company, which posted a surprise third-quarter loss, hopes to save more than 2 billion euros ($1.82 billion) from layoffs and plant closings. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Heavier Economic Clouds Are Gathering Over Japan
description: In its latest monthly economic report, the Bank of Japan has thrown aside the customary carefully shaded jargon and declared in blunt language that Japan's economy is in bad shape and becoming worse.

description: The second debate between the candidates for governor resolved none of New Jersey's most vexing issues, like taxes, auto insurance or gun control. But one thing seemed perfectly clear when it was over tonight: Bret D. Schundler does not think much of his Democratic opponent, James E. McGreevey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLSON, LILLIAN ESTHER ROSSYN (NINI)
description: HILLSON-Lillian Esther Rossyn (Nini). Died of respiratory failure after a long illness in Chambersburg, PA, formerly of Shutesbury, MA and Teaneck, New Jersey, at the age of 75. Preceded in death by husband, Dr. Maurie Hillson, for whose agonizing absence is ended. Survived by sons Jonathan and Edward, sister Betty Jaffe, grandchildren Isaac and Alexanna, nieces and nephews. Contributions to George and Dorothy Rossyn Scholarship Fund, Hadassah, Major Gifts Department, 50 W. 58th Street, New York, NY 10019-2500. Sons donating to Doctors Without Borders USA (for Afghani Refugee Relief), PO Box 2247, New York, New York 10016-2247.

description: BERNE-Robert M., M.D. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our distinguished friend and colleague. In 1987, The Mount Sinai Alumni presented its most coveted award, the Jacob Medallion, to Dr. Berne in acknowledgment of his profound professional achievements and his extraordinary service to the Medical Center and the Alumni. A caring and beloved physician, he will be missed. Our sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., President William G. Stein, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria L. Padilla, M.D., Secretary George Raptis, M.D., Treasurer

title: National Briefing | Washington: Extension Of Internet Tax Ban
description: The House voted to extend a ban on Internet access taxes for two years, a victory for state and local governments that opposed a longer moratorium favored by Internet companies. The ban, which would have expired on Sunday, prevents state authorities from imposing taxes that target Internet service providers like AOL Time Warner's America Online service. The bill does not address sales taxes on Internet commerce, which some lawmakers say will have to be dealt with later.

Reposing at Weigand Bros., 49 Hillside Avenue, Williston Park. Funeral Mass Thursday, October 18th, 2001, at 10 A.M., St. Aidan R.C. Church, 505 Willis Avenue, Williston Park. description: DANNENBERG - Janice Van Raalte. Loving wife of Edgar for sixty-five years. She maintained courage and strength valiantly despite many misfortunes in her lifetime. Sleep Well, My Feisty Love. Services private as she ordered. If desired memorial contributions can be made to Partnership for Caring.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Army Exercises To Resume
description: Ater a three-year delay, the Army is to resume training with live ammunition today in the Makua Valley in Hawaii. Training had been halted since September 1998, when it caused a large fire that led to a lawsuit by local environmentalists. Under an agreement reached early this month, the Army will conduct a study of the training's impact on the environment within three years. Today's training will include artillery and aircraft fire in support of troops advancing down a corridor, said Maj. Nancy Makowski, a spokeswoman for the Army.

title: Jeb Bush Tries to Avert Panic; 2nd Anthrax Victim Is Healing
description: Gov. Jeb Bush came to South Florida today, urging calm in a community that for weeks has been on the verge of panic about exposures to anthrax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, DR. ALBERT H.
description: SILVERMAN-Dr. Albert H. Born November 12, 1914, married to the late Lilian Berkovits Silverman, Cleveland, Ohio. Brother to the late Gertrude Hearn (Murray). Father of Adrienne Chiron, grandfather of Stewart Chiron (Melody), Pamela Lee (Steven) and Diana Goldberg (Lee). Great-grandfather of Ashley Lauren Chiron. Services were held in Miami, Fla.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Meningitis Cases
description: State health officials have identified 91 cases of viral meningitis in an outbreak that they believe began in July at a camp on Prince William Sound. No one has died, but since August, cases have been identified in Anchorage, Chenega Bay, Cordova, Fort Wainwright, Homer, Nanwalek, Port Graham, Tatitlek, Valdez and Wasilla, with the youngest patient only 3 months old. Viral meningitis is spread through contact with bodily fluids. Health officials think those who attended the camp may have spread the virus when they returned home. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Doctors Face Threat, and Fear, of Anthrax
description: With panic spreading about anthrax and other more esoteric ills, these are confounding times for doctors. They must diagnose diseases they have only read about in textbooks, become public health educators and epidemiologists virtually overnight, reassure anxious patients, and prescribe or deny antibiotics to a clamoring public.

title: New Jitters for London
description: From certain floors at 1 Canada Square, Britain's tallest building and the centerpiece of the Canary Wharf development that is fast becoming London's new financial center, the view out the window is a source of uneasiness these days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLITZER, AARON
description: BLITZER-Aaron. Age 94, on Oct. 15. Cherished husband of Esther, devoted father of Rosa Blitzer Oppenheim and Alan Oppenheim, adored grandfather of Adam and David Oppenheim. Services on Friday, 10:30 AM, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Poached, Not Parched
description: CHICKEN breasts and dense, white-fleshed fish like halibut and monkfish come with a built-in difficulty: they must be cooked through to be tender, but such thorough cooking tends to make them dry. Among the techniques that solve this problem is one that is not used as often as it might be: poaching in olive oil.

title: Eleanor McDonald, 66, Breeder of Champion Bichon, Dies
description: Eleanor Ann McDonald, who bred a fabulously and famously cute marshmallow of a dog -- a bichon fris judged best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show this year -- died Oct. 11 in Port Chester in Westchester County, N.Y. She was 66.

title: U.S. Attorney in New Jersey Is Cleared of Misconduct Charges
description: The Justice Department has cleared the United State's attorney's office in New Jersey of allegations of professional misconduct made this year by the Bergen County prosecutor.

title: White House Balks At Further Bailouts
description: In response to a flood of calls for bailouts from industries hurt directly or indirectly by the terrorist attacks, from restaurants and theme parks to steel makers, the Bush administration has developed the following official policy position: forget it.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Grand Central Royalty

title: And You Still Thought 'Hamlet' Was a Tragedy
description: Jeremy Dobrish, the artistic director of the Adobe Theater Company, has taken over ''The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged)'' in its second Off Broadway revival since it appeared here in an international arts festival 10 years ago. Improbable as it may seem to people who saw the 1991 and 1995 presentations, the production under Mr. Dobrish's direction at the Century Center for the Performing Arts is funnier than ever.

title: Ridge Keeps Low Profile as Insecurity Is on Rise
description: With the country still on alert for a new terrorist attack, some of the nation's mayors are coming here next week to work with the federal government on homeland defense.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe last Wednesday for roast herbed duck, with an article about Da Ivan, an inn in Fontanelle, Italy, omitted an instruction for pouring off the fat. A corrected version follows.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 7 p.m. Tuesday.

title: Control Towers' Safeguards Aren't Adequate, Union Says
description: Air traffic control radar centers and towers are poorly protected, and more than half have no guards at all, the president of the controllers' union said today.

title: More Indications That W.T.O. Will Move Talks to Singapore
description: Indications are growing quite strong that the World Trade Organization's conference in November, meant to start a new round of global trade talks and formally accept China as a member, will be relocated to Singapore from Doha, Qatar, because of fears about security in the Middle East.

title: Oil Company Defends Role In Sudan
description: Talisman Energy, a Canadian company with oil and gas operations in Sudan, offered a defense today against criticism that its activities were aiding a repressive government suspected of harboring and helping Al Qaeda, the terrorist network held responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States.

title: Out of Work, and Out of the Benefits Loop; Restrictions Will Keep Millions From Receiving Help
description: When Larry Johnson applied for unemployment benefits the week after the World Trade Center collapsed, he seemed like just the kind of person government officials have been talking about helping since Sept. 11.

title: Anthrax Alert: When Fear Arrives in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, KATHLEEN A.
description: BURNS-Kathleen A., 48. Of Staten Island, NY on September 11, 2001 as a victim of the attack on the World Trade Center in New York City. Kathy was born on Staten Island where she lived most of her life. She was employed for more than 15 years by Fiduciary Trust Company International, most recently as Vice President for Office Automation. Kathy will be forever missed as the loving companion of her parents John and Eunice Burns and the treasured friend of her brother John J. Burns, her aunts Shirley Donohue and Helen Susarchick, her uncles and cousins, her co-workers and the many friends she made throughout her life will always remember her frequent smiles, zest for life and endless interests in the wider world. A memorial service will be held on Friday, October 19th at 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Friends are invited to visit with the family one hour before the service. In lieu of flowers contributions in her name to The American Red Cross would be appreciated.

title: Jets' Robinson Is Fined After Arrest on a Weapons Charge
description: Jets free safety Damien Robinson will be fined a week's pay -- about $30,000 -- by the team and will have to undergo counseling and perform community service after his arrest for possession of an assault rifle before Sunday's game at Giants Stadium.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett's Post-Merger Team
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company has named six more executives to run the company after its planned merger with Compaq Computer. In a note posted to employees that was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Carleton S. Fiorina, the chairwoman and chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, said the executives would assume their posts after shareholders and regulators approved the merger. Senior vice presidents retaining similar positions at the enlarged company include Susan Bowick, in charge of human resources; Debra Dunn, responsible for community engagement; Allison Johnson, in charge of branding and communications; and Dick Lampman, who leads the research laboratories. Two Compaq managers, including the chief information officer, Bob Napier, and the chief technology officer, Shane Robison, will occupy similar positions in the new company. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: A First-Round Rally Keeps a Dynasty Alive
description: The dynasty was about to disappear. After five incredible years in which the Yankees won four World Series titles and always thought they could have won the one that evaded them in 1997, they looked defeated.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: The People V. Mrs. Marcos
description: Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, was fingerprinted and released on bail after a court ordered her arrest on four counts of corruption involving transactions of more than $350 million in money she is accused of stealing during the 1970's. Mrs. Marcos has for several years been facing corruption charges, and $629 million in Swiss bank deposits have been frozen pending determination of the true owners. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Corporate Profits on Tax Returns Were Sharply Lower in '98
description: After rising for six years, corporate profits reported on tax returns plunged in 1998, just as Treasury officials first warned that the aggressive use of tax shelters was helping companies appear ever more profitable to investors but impoverished to the I.R.S.

title: Tokyo Announces Its Stimulus Package
description: The Japanese government will spend 1 trillion yen ($8.3 billion) to stimulate economic growth this year, Finance Minister Masajuro Shiokawa said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, BRIAN P.
description: WILLIAMS-Brian P. Dear son of Kenneth E. Sr. and Kathleen G. (nee Burke), 29 years of age, resident of New York, formerly of Edgewood, KY. Graduate of Columbia University and broker for Cantor-Fitzgerald. Mass of Christian Burial St. Pius Church, Edgewood, KY on Sunday, October 21, 2001 at 5:00 PM. Memorials are suggested to The Kenny and Brian Williams Memorial Fund, C/O Covington Catholic High School, 1600 Dixie Highway, Park Hills, KY. 41011.

title: CALENDAR
description: Cheese at Grand Central

title: Trivia Question
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: Ex-CUNY Board Head Wins Seton Award
description: The National Catholic Educational Association presented JAMES MURPHY, the former chairman of the board of the City University of New York, with a Seton Award recently in Washington. Named for Elizabeth Seton, the founder of the Roman Catholic school network in the United States, the award is the highest honor given by Catholic educators. Mr. Murphy was given the award for his fund-raising for inner-city Catholic schools. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: David Kahn, president at the Conde Nast Image Center, part of the Conde Nast unit of Advance Publications, New York, is leaving, the company said, to pursue other interests. Mr. Kahn had been named to head the Image Center in July, when he relinquished his post as publisher of The New Yorker to his predecessor, David Carey. But now Conde Nast says that the startup of the Image Center, meant to market and license material from the Conde Nast archives, is being put off for the immediate future.

title: Too Many Cooks Can Spoil the Lesson
description: A small group of students sip wine as they gather around their instructor, Paul Vandewoude, in the kitchen of the Miette Culinary Studio, which specializes in cooking classes for no more than 10 students at a time. Mr. Vandewoude, formerly the chef at two Greenwich Village cafes, Tartine and Titou, teaches them how to roast lamb or chicken, make paella and bake chocolate cake, among other dishes.

title: Web Site for Post-Attack Wish Lists
description: One school wants an architect to visit and help fourth graders design memorials to the World Trade Center victims. Another hopes to buy books about the Middle East. A third has requested "recovery journals" in which students can write and draw responses to the terrorist attack.

title: What Can We Do Next? Just Watch Jeter Play
description: We know the score, the season and the shortstop. We see the stadium, standing room only. We feel the pressure and we are sure he must feel it, too. Derek Jeter of the Yankees stands in the middle of all we see and he spends a good portion of his day making faces. He grins, he smiles, he smirks. He catches the eye of third baseman Scott Brosius and laughs, he jokes with a base runner. If a ball is hit his way, well, he will catch it. He knows that.

title: Mohamed Atta in Close Call In Incident at Miami Airport
description: For Mohamed Atta, the meticulous and intensely disciplined figure who is believed to have helped organize the Sept. 11 attacks, mistakes did happen, or at least nearly did. One of them came on Dec. 26 at Miami International Airport.

title: Pataki Pledges 'Bold Steps' And Job Cuts
description: Six days after pleading with Congress to bail out New York State, Gov. George E. Pataki vowed today to cut at least $3 billion in state spending over the next 18 months, and to start by trimming 5,000 workers through a hiring freeze and early retirements.

title: Mailing Lethal Substances Is a Rare Crime, Tough to Solve When Not a Hoax
description: In January 2000, someone mailed more than a dozen letters to abortion clinics and schools in a Milwaukee suburb. The letters contained a coarse white powder and the message: ''This is anthrax and you will die.''

title: Having Your Gravy and Eating It, Too
description: COMFORT food is a very personal thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, FRANK
description: KORN-Frank. Died peacefully on October 15, 2001 at the age of 88 at his home, with his family by his side. Beloved husband of Chizuko & the late Marian. Devoted father of Evelyn Radin, Carol Korn-Bronson and Susie Korn and father-inlaw of Harley Radin and John Bronson. Adored grandfather of Jason Radin. Treasured brother of Eva Danton and brother-in-law of the late Eugene Danton. We will feel his loss and celebrate his generosity, devotion and love for life, knowledge and beauty forever. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, October 16, from 6 to 8PM, with services on Wednesday, October 17, at 9:30AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Frank Korn Scholarship Fund, C/O The San Francisco School, 300 Gaven Street, San Francisco, CA. 94134.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B.

title: Many at Wall St. Journal Set to Return to Manhattan
description: The Wall Street Journal and its corporate parent, Dow Jones, plan to move back to their old home at the World Financial Center by the end of the year. Their building's view, once blocked by New York City's tallest towers, now opens onto a vista of cranes and backhoes removing the rubble where more than 5,000 people perished on Sept. 11.

title: The American League on Fox: Cover Your Ears
description: When the Yankees-Seattle American League Championship Series starts at 4 p.m. today, Fox's Thom Brennaman will be calling the game. He will also call Game 2 tomorrow before he shifts to the N.L.C.S., and Joe Buck takes over for the remaining games. For Yankee games, that's good news.

title: From Fighting the Taliban To Battling Blazes in Idaho
description: FIRE
