title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAINMAN, FLORENCE P.
description: KRAINMAN-Florence P. Peacefully on October 16th at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Herman Krainman. Loving mother of Rhoda, Luise and Richard. Adoring grandmother of Randy, Kathy, Elizabeth, Adam & David. Doting great grandmother of Jocelyn, Seth, Katie and Alex. She will be missed by all her family and friends who enjoyed her jokes and zest for life. She was an amazing woman. Services today 10 AM at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Johnson Leaves No Doubt This Time
description: Randy Johnson has won three Cy Young awards, has struck out 300 batters in a season four times and has won 20 games twice in his career. But he took a seven-game postseason losing streak into today's game.

title: Venezuela Waits for 'Revolution' to Bear Fruit
description: He still speaks lovingly to the throngs, sometimes for hours at a time on everything from the Bible to Sammy Sosa's bat to his idol, the 19th-century South American liberator, Simn Bolvar. Spotting a familiar face, he stops in midsentence, delighting a crowd by asking about a relative's welfare or how much rain has fallen in a far-off hamlet.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose on a forecast that colder-than-normal weather this winter will increase demand. In New York, natural gas for November delivery rose 21.4 cents, to $2.592 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Fishermen Drop Suit
description: Commercial fishermen on the Eastern Shore are dropping a lawsuit challenging new rules that cut the crabbers' workday to 8 hours from 14. Anthony G. Gorski, an Annapolis lawyer representing the fishermen, said they concluded the legal challenge had little chance of succeeding. The fishermen, Mr. Gorski said, will instead pursue a publicity campaign to argue that the state's crab shortage has been exaggerated. The regulations, which took effect in July, also shortened the crab season by a month, ending it on Nov. 1. Fishermen say the regulations will ruin them. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Labor Leaders Say Trade Bill Threatens Bipartisanship
description: Union leaders warned today that Congressional bipartisanship, already strained, could fall apart if the Bush administration and House Republican leaders pressed ahead with a trade promotion bill vigorously opposed by labor.

title: Nibble These Chilies, And One or Two Might Nibble Back
description: Pimientos de padrn, a tapa tradition in Galicia, in northwestern Spain, are now being grown in California.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the emergency response to an odor in a Manhattan subway station misstated the location. It was at 191st Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, not Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Rumsfeld to Appeal to Arab Public on Mideast TV Network
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld spoke today on a Middle East television network to assure Arab viewers that the United States was waging war against terrorists in Afghanistan, not the Afghan people.

title: Business Travel; Concern over anthrax could be a distraction from fundamental flaws and gaps in airline security.
description: IN her blacker moods, the writer Dorothy Parker would occasionally answer the telephone by demanding to know, ''What fresh hell is this?''

title: Talented Islanders Survive Early Test
description: Six days after the collision, Michael Peca still had two black eyes and a line of thick stitches wedged between his left eyebrow and eyelid. These are minor inconveniences. Peca said today that his head was clear, and he planned to suit up for the Islanders immediately.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Independent Journalism Prizes
description: A group of newspaper editors, academics and directors of nongovernment organizations announced the creation of an independent journalism-awards competition. Organizers said the awards would be modeled after Columbia University's Pulitzer Prizes, and said they hoped that the independent awards would eventually replace those that are organized and financed by the government. Critics charge that the government awards -- cash prizes of about $15,000 each, distributed by the president of Mexico -- undermine the integrity and independence of the news media. The first winners of the independent contest are scheduled to be announced on May 3, the United Nations International Day of the Press. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: The Spicier Side of Turkey
description: EXCEPT for Thanksgiving dinner, I'm not much of a fan of turkey. It's the carob of meats, substituted for beef, lamb or chicken in the name of fewer calories but generally insipid. So I groaned at the prospect of turkey shawarma at Alibaba, a new Yemenite-Israeli kosher takeout spot on the Upper West Side.

title: House and Senate Leaders Clash on Banking Measure
description: With some bankers and conservative groups alarmed about legislation intended to make it harder for terrorists to move money through the banking system, House and Senate leaders are clashing about whether to include banking controls in the pending terrorism bill.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Pan-Asian Arrival

title: Bowing to Nation's Mood, Retailer Cancels Issue of Racy Catalog
description: Abercrombie & Fitch, the apparel retailer known for campaigns that celebrate the pulchritude and pleasures of youth, will announce today that it has canceled the holiday issue of its quarterly publication because the content and tone were deemed inappropriate after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Banks' Profit Up On Lower Costs
description: The Bank One Corporation, Wells Fargo and Company and other banks had higher third-quarter profit as costs dropped and falling interest rates increased revenue from lending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, ROBERT L.
description: AUSTIN-Robert L. Of Pomona, NY died October 15, 2001. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of Douglas and his wife Melissa, Tracey and her husband Jim Shannon and Meredith Austin. Dearest brother of Charles and his wife Yvette and adoring grandfather of Nicholas, Julia and Daniel. Services are on Thursday at 1 PM at The Higgins Funeral Home in New City, New York.

title: Pilots Told to Fire at Will in Some Zones
description: American pilots have for the first time been freed to choose their own targets and fire at will within specific zones around Taliban strongholds in Afghanistan, senior Pentagon officials said today. United States commanders warned that none of the Kabul leadership's forces were immune from attack.

title: Web Site for Post-Attack Wish Lists
description: One school wants an architect to visit and help fourth graders design memorials to the World Trade Center victims. Another hopes to buy books about the Middle East. A third has requested "recovery journals" in which students can write and draw responses to the terrorist attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABISH, SHELLY
description: ABISH-Shelly. We will miss his indomitable spirit, the smile on his lips as he thought of a joke appropriate to the moment. He wanted great things for his friends and his love and care for Sheila surpassed everything. Don Buchwald

title: Refugees Make Harrowing Trip to a Desolate Haven in Pakistan
description: On Monday, during four exhausting hours, a man named Asadullah trudged through the mountains, leading his 10 children out of Afghanistan. His right leg, a prosthesis of plastic, was chafing against the stump. But his discomfort, however great, was less than his wife's: Malika, atop a mule, was in labor.

title: From Picasso, Playwright: Hues of Innocence and War
description: There is a reason few people know that Pablo Picasso wrote plays, and that reason is being spelled out in a wearying, intermissionless 90-minute production at the Clemente Soto Velez Cultural Center on the Lower East Side. The New York premiere of Picasso's second and last play, ''The Four Little Girls,'' is highly inaccessible. To say the least.

title: Earnings Fall Again at Charles Schwab
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the discount brokerage firm, said today that its earnings fell for the fourth consecutive quarter, affected by the recent four-day market shutdown and individual investors' continued retreat.

title: Tight Security At Sentencing For Bombings
description: Security will be heightened at the Old Federal Courthouse in Lower Manhattan tomorrow, with federal marshals carrying 12-gauge shotguns, as the four men convicted this year in the bombings of two American Embassies appear in court to be sentenced.

title: Rebel Leader Rejects Role For Taliban In New Regime
description: A senior official of the Northern Alliance declared today that his group would not accept surviving members of the Taliban in any future coalition government set up to run the country if the current Taliban leadership is driven from power.

title: Nibble These Chilies, and One or Two Might Nibble Back
description: Pimientos de padron, a tapa tradition in Galicia, in northwestern Spain, are now being grown in California.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen dropped on speculation that the Bank of Japan will cheapen the currency to help pull the economy out of a slump. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.33 yen, up from 120.96 yen on Monday.

title: Robert M. Berne, 83, Cardiologist, Medical Educator and Author
description: Dr. Robert Matthew Berne, a heart specialist and educator whose textbooks were used by generations of doctors, died on Oct. 4 at his home in Charlottesville, Va., where he was a professor emeritus at the University of Virginia Medical Center. He was 83.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Transmeta Replaces Chief Executive
description: In its second major executive shake-up this year, the Transmeta Corporation, a maker of high-performance semiconductor chips, announced yesterday that it was replacing Mark K. Allen as chief executive. The company said its board chairman, Murray A. Goldman, above, would be the new chief executive, while Hugh Barnes, another board member, would take over as president and chief operating officer, two jobs that have been vacant since Mr. Allen became chief executive in March. Several weeks ago Transmeta warned that sales for the third quarter would be lower than expected, as a result of the worsening economy and the slowdown in the chip industry. On Oct. 8, Mr. Allen said the company would report revenue for the third quarter of about $5 million, down from $10.5 million in the second quarter. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., is to report its earnings tomorrow. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Brennaman Will Shift Gears
description: When the Yankees-Seattle A.L.C.S. starts at 4 p.m. Wednesday, Fox's Thom Brennaman will be calling the game. He will also call Game 2 Thursday before he shifts to the National League Championship Series, and Joe Buck takes over for the remaining games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOLL, WILBUR
description: TOLL-Wilbur. Longtime Scarsdale resident, died October 15, 2001 at the age of 82. He is survived by his wife Olga (nee Mendell), three sons: David (Marce), Stanley (Julie) and Lawrence, one brother Lionel and several grandchildren. Mr. Toll had been in the book publishing business and upon his retirement did volunteer work in Westchester County. Please make any contributions to your favorite charity in remembrance of Wilbur. Funeral service is on Thursday, October 18, 2001, 9:30 A.M., at ''Westchester Reform Temple'', 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York. Interment will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. The family will receive friends at the Toll residence, Thursday afternoon, 44 Huntington Avenue, Scarsdale.

title: Mariners Are Chasing History and the Shadow of the '98 Yankees
description: If the Seattle Mariners are to eclipse the success of the 1998 Yankees, they could have no more appropriate opponent in American League Championship Series than the 2001 Yankees.

title: Permanent Driving Restriction Into Manhattan Is Considered
description: It has been a near-constant refrain since Sept. 11: ''Life will never be the same.'' And yesterday, city officials raised the possibility that one inconvenience, the partial ban on single-occupancy vehicles entering Manhattan, might become permanent.

title: Reunited in an Erotic Quest for Love
description: Benediction, party, pagan ritual, girlie show -- the concert on Monday night by the reunited Jane's Addiction was all of those at once. For Jane's Addiction, the cheap thrills of mass entertainment can be the equivalent of revelations, and primal emotions offer an opportunity for spectacle.

title: Downtown, More Steps Forward
description: IN the first couple of weeks after the World Trade Center attack, Oceana restaurant in Midtown took its signature dish, wild striped bass on chive mashed potatoes, off the menu. Its chef, Rick Moonen, who buys nearly two-thirds of his fish from the Fulton Fish Market, could not get wild striped bass or other local fish, like skate. To save the streets for rescue vehicles, the fish market, on South Street, had been moved to a parking lot with inadequate refrigeration in the Hunts Point Market in the Bronx.

title: Tests and Calls Swamp States' Laboratories
description: The nation's doctors and hospitals are being deluged as frightened citizens seek anthrax tests, and public health laboratories are being strained to their limits as the authorities bring in package after suspicious package for analysis.

title: Minnesota Students Help Out
description: Meanwhile, students displaced from Public School 89 near the destroyed trade center are receiving some help from Rockford Middle School in Rockford, Minn. The Minnesota students spent a week voting on which teachers they most wanted to see get a pie in the face. Each vote cost $1. By week's end the students had raised $3,500 and the student council threw pies at five teachers and the school's principal, HAROLD GREFETH. Ultra Manufacturing Company of Hamel, Minn., donated $1,000. On Friday RICH PUDAS, a seventh-grade language arts teacher, will present both checks, one for $3,500 and the other for $1,000, to the students of P.S. 89, along with letters from Rockford students hoping to gain pen pals. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Long Fall for Paterno in the Autumn of His Career
description: Penn State has never opened a season with no victories and four losses, not in 114 previous years, not until now. The disaffected have begun to wonder whether Joe Paterno is past his peak, as if they were speaking of autumn foliage instead of the football coach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, FAYE, (NEE NEUWIRTH)
description: ROTH-Faye, (nee Neuwirth), 91. Passed away October 14, 2001. A lifetime New Yorker and independent spirit, she charted her own course. Wife of the late Larry Roth, beloved mother of her three sons, Richard, Kenn (Uzi Ran), and Paul (Yuval Ron), her daughters-in-law, Roberta, Erit and Rachel. Grandmother to Asa and his wife Ayelet, Ziv, Liat, Matan, Roiee, Shachar, Na'ama, and Yonatan. Great-grandmother to Gili and Noga. Funeral services today, Wednesday, October 17, at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave. and W. 76th St., 11:30 AM. Donations to The NY Police & Fire Widows' and Children's Benefit Fund in Faye's name would be appreciated.

title: Durst Jumps Bail, and a Nationwide Dragnet Is On
description: The Police Department in Galveston, Tex., said yesterday that it had begun a nationwide manhunt for Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate scion, after he failed to appear at a bond hearing in connection with charges that he dismembered and beheaded a 71-year-old man last month.

title: Recruiters Fawn Over Ex-Airline Employees
description: When Traci McCoy, a former flight attendant for Continental Airlines, walked into a company-sponsored job fair for former employees this month in Newark, she braced herself for rejection. Instead, she encountered prospective employers so eager to meet with her that one practically ripped her rsum out of her hands.

title: POWELL SUGGESTS ROLE FOR TALIBAN
description: The United States and Pakistan agreed today to work urgently for the creation of a new, broad-based government in Afghanistan that both sides said could include moderate elements of the Taliban movement whose present leadership is now a target for the American-led military campaign.

title: A Rush for Cipro, and the Global Ripples
description: America's demand for Cipro, an antibiotic for treating anthrax, could raise serious questions for the United States government, and poor countries seeking cheaper drugs to treat their own epidemics of AIDS and other diseases will be looking closely at the way they are answered.

title: Anthrax Alert: When Fear Arrives in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: At 5:37 a.m., The Yankees Check In
description: Bernie Williams explained how he had perfected the art of sleeping on a plane. But it is really not much of an art. Williams finds the first row of empty seats on the Yankees' charter plane, jams a pile of pillows into the corner, tunes out his teammates and snoozes like a baby.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Muslim Firefighters Object
description: A Muslim group of firefighters clashed with the Fire Department yesterday over the department's choice of its first Muslim chaplain. The group, the Islamic Society of Fire Department Personnel, said that it did not object to Abd'Allah A. Adesanya as chaplain, but said that the group's recommendation had been solicited by the department and then ignored. Kevin James, president of the group, said that Catholic and Jewish groups in the department had traditionally been allowed to name the chaplains from their faiths. Frank Gribbon, a department spokesman, denied that the choice was a retaliation against the group, which has filed a bias lawsuit against the department. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Tribulations And Triumphs For WNYC
description: When Brian Lehrer returned to his studio at WNYC last week, preparing to do his daily talk show there for the first time in nearly a month, he discovered a kind of time capsule. Before taking up the morning's topic, American military strikes against Afghanistan, he told his listeners in a measured, reedy voice what he had found.

title: Oil Money Pulls Sudan Out of Its Isolation and Toward an Uncertain Future
description: On the pleasant shore of the Blue Nile, a stone's throw from where it meets the White Nile on their eventual way to Egypt, stands a large, stately hotel named the Grand Holiday Villa.

title: Devils Look for Rhythm, and Victory
description: The Devils had never started a season with three losses, not even during the days when Wayne Gretzky called them a Mickey Mouse organization 18 years ago.

title: Businesses Finding That Good Security Is No Longer Optional
description: They are hiring security guards, requiring employees to wear identification badges at all times, taking X-rays of packages and reviewing evacuation plans.

title: Nobu Matsuhisa
description: THIS recipe uses a technique I learned from home cooks in Peru. They pour hot oil over steamed fish to seal the surface and add richness and flavor.

title: Nets Pull Out Victory in Detroit
description: The Nets took advantage of late turnovers by the Detroit Pistons to earn a 91-87 preseason victory tonight. Led by Jason Kidd's 19 points and strong defense by his backcourt mate Kerry Kittles, the Nets had to wait until the final minute of play to take their first lead of the second half. Kittles held the Pistons' top scorer, Jerry Stackhouse, without a field goal in the first quarter and to 10 points over all on 3-of-15 shooting.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about the Miss Tennessee beauty pageant, held in Clarksville as troops nearby at Fort Campbell were preparing for possible war duty, misstated the surname of the winner in a companion contest, Miss Tennessee Teen USA. She was Rachel Smith, as the article said, not Clark.

title: Lovie Smith Turns Rams' Defense Around
description: It was 2:30 a.m. Monday when Lovie Smith was stirred out of bed, awakened by a caldron of emotions. A close uncle had recently died, a stirring last-second victory over the Giants just 10 hours earlier had kept his blood pressure high, and there was his usual preoccupation with game-film study, something that keeps him up late anyway.

title: Beyond Calamity, Death Goes On; Grief Unrelated to Terror Takes on a Broader Context
description: Randi Wittlin-Weiss died young, at 40. In her eulogy, as in so many eulogies of late, her husband, Ken Weiss, said things he never would have said before Sept. 11.

title: Altered Corn Is Cleared
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would allow companies to sell a genetically modified corn for seven more years after finding the gene-spliced crop posed no risk to monarch butterflies, birds and animals or human health.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sales Up At Roche
description: The health care company, Roche Holding A.G., said that its revenue rose 8 percent, to $8.6 billion, in the first nine months of the year. Roche, which is based in Basel, said sales in the third quarter rose 10 percent, mainly because of cancer drugs. Roche, whose diagnostic division sales increased 14 percent, said that its operating profit for this year would at least match last year's level.

title: Study Says AIDS Is Now Chief Cause of Death in South Africa
description: AIDS has become the leading cause of death in South Africa, and young adults are especially hard hit, with the overall death rate of women in their 20's now higher than that of women in their 60's, the country's leading scientific institute reported today.

title: Mostly Behind the Scenes at the Cliburn Competition
description: About a century ago, Claude Debussy described musical competitions as ''purely arbitrary affairs,'' and complained not only that ''the contestants are trained like racehorses,'' but also that the blue ribbon -- or the gold medal in today's inflated terms -- excused listeners from exercising their own critical judgment.

title: T.G.I. Friday's Begins a Review
description: T.G.I. Friday's

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cantor Adds To Network For Its Data On Prices
description: Cantor Fitzgerald, the dominant broker in the United States Treasury market, began yesterday to distribute its price data through several sources, including Bloomberg terminals.

title: Camby Is Taking an Optimistic Approach
description: Marcus Camby will not make a prediction concerning his injured left foot. But when asked today whether he would play in the Oct. 30 season opener against Michael Jordan and the Washington Wizards, Camby did not waver, answering with a confident, ''Yeah.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, WALLY
description: SCHWARTZ-Wally. 10/17/23 to 2/4/98. Happy Birthday, Daddy. I know you are taking care of the victims of September 11th. Thank you for the strength you taught us. Love, Your Girls

title: To Establish Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: The Great Escape, at Vintage Tables
description: NATIONAL GUARDSMEN were pacing the waiting room at Grand Central Terminal. A zipper in a newsstand was reeling out an update from the F.B.I. that read like an inscription on a Barbara Kruger photograph: ''Terror could come at any time.''

title: Sports of The Times; How Much Is Left In the Tank?
description: HALF an hour after the Yankees defeated Oakland to win their division series, General Manager Brian Cashman stood in the clubhouse, stunned, weary and elated.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages on Monday about the reopening of the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore misstated its area code. The information number is (410) 547-9000.

title: Finding the Presence of Anthrax
description: Sources: Dr. Stuart Isaacs and Dr. Elizabeth Colston, both of the University of Pennsylvania

title: MetroStars' Game Tonight Canceled
description: The Copa Merconorte game scheduled for tonight at Giants Stadium between the MetroStars and Chivas of Mexico has been canceled. The Mexicans notified the MetroStars that they did not want to fly to New York for security reasons and that they also have a crucial league game in Mexico this weekend against Club America.

title: At the Top of the Executive Ladder, Many Women Experience Vertigo
description: A few women have pierced the glass ceiling in recent years, but many who rise near the top of the corporate ladder find they are uneasy about their roles and responsibilities.

title: Recall of Faulty Microwaves Leads to a Loss at Whirlpool
description: Whirlpool said yesterday that it would recall and repair 1.8 million microwave ovens that can overheat and catch fire. The move by the company resulted in a $300 million pretax charge and a loss for the third quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUT, PHILIP
description: KRAUT-Philip. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member and former Gabbai, Philip Kraut. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Steven Wolinsky, Chairman of the Board

title: ANTHRAX MAILED TO SENATE IS FOUND TO BE POTENT FORM; CASE TIED TO ILLNESS AT NBC
description: The anthrax mailed to the office of the Senate majority leader was pure and highly refined, consisting of particles so tiny that they could spread through the air without detection, government officials said tonight.

title: Laura Bush, Ex-Teacher, Goes Back to Kindergarten
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16  Amid tight security and with reporters in tow, the first lady, Laura Bush, visited the brightly colored kindergarten classroom of an elementary school here today where she read a story, gave a geography lesson and otherwise soothed 18 5-year-olds with hugs, tender touches and cooing words.

title: Production of Cipro Is Being Tripled, German Company Says
description: The German drug company that makes the antibiotic Cipro said yesterday that it was tripling production of the medicine in the face of intensifying public fears about anthrax.

title: Cipro Isn't the Only Drug That Can Be Prescribed, Anthrax Experts Say
description: Though the antibiotic Cipro has become the drug of choice among people worried about anthrax, several other widely available and less expensive antibiotics are very likely to work as well.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the resumption of Concorde service by Air France and British Airways next month misstated the planned number of Air France flights from New York to Paris. It is five a week, not six.

title: A Pasta Pot That Puts The Colander in the Lid
description: A pound of spaghetti fits nicely into the new Bialetti pasta pot from Italy, which is oval in shape and holds four quarts of water. The lid, which clamps onto the rim, is studded with holes, turning the pot into its own colander and making it easy to drain the pasta when it is done. Sauce can then be added directly to the hot pasta. The interior of the heavy-gauge aluminum pot is lined with a type of Teflon that is not damaged by metal utensils. The Bakelite handles stay cool. The pot is also fine for boiling potatoes or other vegetables, and you can have any color you want, as long as it's metallic midnight blue. The pot costs $34.99 at Bed Bath & Beyond stores.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Milford: Jai Alai Court To Close
description: The Milford Jai Alai, Connecticut's only remaining jai alai fronton, has announced that it will close Dec. 12. Jai alai, a Latin American game resembling handball, had once been an important part of the state's parimutuel business. But faced with competition from Foxwoods Resort Casino and Mohegan Sun, two large casinos in Connecticut, Milford Jai Alai has lost money for two years, according to Leonard Meyers, the company president. The fronton, or court, opened in 1977 and employs 200 people, including 48 players. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Zhang Xueliang, 100, Dies; One-Time Chinese Warlord Who Changed Course of Chinese History
description: Zhang Xueliang, a one-time warlord who in two turbulent weeks in 1936 helped turn the course of Chinese history  and then spent the next 55 years under house arrest, gradually and reluctantly becoming a national hero  died on Sunday in Honolulu, where he had been living in recent years. He was believed to be 100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOETZ, RUTH GOODMAN
description: GOETZ-Ruth Goodman. October 12, 2001. Beloved wife and collaborator of the late Augustus Goetz. Wonderful mother of Judy Goetz Sanger. Delighted grandmother of Katie Firth. Service Thursday, October 25, 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. Interment services private at Keller's Church Cemetery, Bucks County, PA. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Dramatist Guild Fund of America and Young Playwrights Festival.

title: Willam Christensen, 99, Dies; Helped Ballet Flourish in U.S.
description: Willam F. Christensen, an enthusiastic champion of American ballet who headed important companies in Portland, Ore., San Francisco and Salt Lake City, died on Sunday in Salt Lake City, where he lived; he was 99.

title: On a Day of Jitters, City and F.B.I. Differ Over Anthrax Sweep at ABC
description: The inspection of ABC News offices for traces of anthrax was delayed yesterday as federal investigators and New York City officials disagreed over just how extensive the survey needed to be to ensure that the hundreds of workers at the West 66th Street building were not at risk, network executives said.

title: Scouting Report: Yankees vs. Seattle
description: Pitching

title: Bush Voices Pride in Aid, But Groups List Hurdles
description: President Bush promoted his relief fund for Afghan children at the headquarters of the American Red Cross today, but international relief groups said the American bombing campaign was making it virtually impossible to deliver large amounts of food to starving Afghans.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the figure skater Irina Slutskaya and her performance at the opening of the Rockefeller Center rink misidentified the dignitary who attended the event with Mayor Giuliani. He was Prince Andrew of Britain, not Prince Albert of Monaco.

title: T.G.I. Friday's Begins a Review
description: T.G.I. Friday's in Dallas, part of Carlson Restaurants Worldwide, said yesterday that it would begin a review for the strategic, creative and media duties on its national account, with billings estimated at $40 million to $50 million. Those duties have been handled for seven years by the Dallas office of Publicis in the West, part of the American operations of the Publicis Groupe, which will take part in the review.

title: Bagpipe Practice
description: The intersection of Leroy and Bedford Streets is part of a squiggle of streets in Greenwich Village, home to a few small bars, a restaurant or two, brownstones and a few small apartment buildings. The other night, it was also home to three dozen drilling bagpipers, in uniform, from the New York City Fire Department.

title: Common Interests In a Hazardous World
description: President Bush's trip to China tomorrow to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting may mark a qualitatively new and more mature phase in relations between the two countries. The current campaign against global terrorism, in which the two governments have already cooperated extensively, offers the opportunity to improve a relationship that has been plagued by difficulties.

title: Permanent Driving Restriction Into Manhattan Is Considered
description: It has been a near-constant refrain since Sept. 11: "Life will never be the same." And yesterday, city officials raised the possibility that one inconvenience, the partial ban on single- occupancy vehicles entering Manhattan, might become permanent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENENBAUM, CHARLES L.
description: TENENBAUM-Charles L. On October 15. World War II veteran, real estate developer and owner, philanthropist. Beloved husband of Rita (nee Richmond). Devoted father of the late Bruce, Thomas, Martin, and Beth Jassin. Adored grandfather of Andrew, Douglas, Gerald, Alexander, Lena, Sam and Alexandra Jassin. Our cherished memories will always be treasured. Services today, 1PM, at the Riverdale Temple, West 246th Street and Independence Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, HAROLD G., M.D.
description: JACOBSON-Harold G., M.D., died on October 14, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Richard and Arthur and their spouses Judy and Peninah. Proud grandfather of David, Sam and Ben. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Ruth and Harold Jacobson Fund at Beit Rabban, 8 West 70th St, NYC 10023.

title: An Art-Loving Politician Comes Home to Warhol
description: JOEL WACHS had been depressed -- a state in which it is difficult to envision him -- when he lost his bid for mayor of Los Angeles last April. So melancholic -- placing fourth after 30 years as a city councilman -- that he didn't answer the phone in his house for two days. He picked it up only because he thought it might be his elderly mother's caretaker.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New London: Programs To Curb College Drinking
description: Four Connecticut universities have received a federal grant to develop programs to help curb student drinking, because, officials said, Connecticut college students appear to drink more than the national average. A total of $30,000 was granted to Connecticut College, Eastern Connecticut State, the University of Hartford and Wesleyan University. At Connecticut College, for example, nearly 97 percent of students there reported in a survey that drinking was central to social life and two out of five said they regretted a post-drinking incident.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Bloomberg Sees Race Overtones In Final Days Of Green Effort
description: Republican Michael R. Bloomberg, inserting himself into a racially charged dispute among the Democrats, yesterday characterized the final days of Mark Green's runoff campaign against Fernando Ferrer as racially hued and said Mr. Green owed the voters an explanation.

title: Powell Scholarship to Medical Student
description: A freshman medical student from Whitestone, Queens, is the fourth recipient of a scholarship awarded yearly by the family of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to a student at City College, from which Secretary Powell graduated in 1958. The Maud and Luther Powell America's Promise Scholarship, which gives up to four years of free tuition to students with outstanding records in academics and community service, was given Monday to NICHOLAS PANTALEO. Kathleen Carroll

title: Schedule for Playoffs Fits Yanks' Rotation to a T
description: Andy Pettitte had his spikes at hand and was ready to pitch when Roger Clemens went to the bullpen to warm up Monday night before Game 5 of the division series. If Clemens had been unable to pitch or if he had faltered, Pettitte would have stepped in, and Mike Mussina was ready to relieve as well: anything to win that deciding game against the Athletics.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Disco Bombing Trial
description: Lawyers for the victims of a 1986 anti-American bomb attack on the La Belle disco in Berlin requested life sentences for four people charged with the bombing. Earlier this month the prosecution also demanded life sentences for the four, a Palestinian, Yasir Shraydi, a Libyan, Musbah Eter, and Ali and Verena Chanaa, both German nationals. Prosecutors said Mr. Shraydi, who worked for the Libyan Embassy in East Berlin, had organized the attack on behalf of the Libyan secret services. The bombing killed two American servicemen and a Turkish woman and injured more than 200 people, many of them American soldiers. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: French Cut Wireless License Prices
description: Shares of French mobile phone operators surged after the government lowered the price of acquiring third-generation licenses. Instead of a block payment of 4.95 billion euros ($4.5 billion) for each license, the companies will now pay 619 million euros up front, and then fees based on subscriber rates once the services are operational. The government also extended the length of the licenses by 5 years, to 20 years. The revised terms apply to two licenses that have yet to be sold, as well as two bought last year by France Tlcom and Vivendi Universal. Vivendi had threatened to withhold payments until better terms could be agreed.

title: A New Division At Cramer-Krasselt
description: Cramer-Krasselt is forming an autonomous public relations division after 14 years of having public relations staff members work as teams within the agency. The division, CKPR, will have 85 employees in the four cities where Cramer-Krasselt has offices: Chicago; Milwaukee; Orlando, Fla.; and Phoenix. CKPR will have revenue estimated at $10 million from clients like Corona beer and Hershey Foods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFT, JUNE
description: HAFT-June. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our devoted member, Nancee Bloom. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Anthrax Alert: When Fear Arrives in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Guillen Is Expected Back for Mariners After Bout With TB
description: Lou Piniella has managed the Seattle Mariners as he would a National League team, relying on a deep bench for the best possible lineup combinations. Losing the switch-hitting shortstop Carlos Guillen in the first round limited him. But Piniella should have more flexibility against the Yankees in the American League Championship Series. Guillen, who has been out since Sept. 28 after being told he had pulmonary tuberculosis, is expected to return to the roster.

title: Tracking the Origin of Anthrax
description: Sources: Dr. Martin E. Hugh-Jones, Louisiana State University (natural occurrences); World Federation for Culture Collections (germ banks); U.S. Office of Technology Assessment (biowarfare programs)

title: A Fireball, a Prayer for Death, Then an Uphill Battle for Life
description: This is the story of a woman who decided to live. No one knows yet if she will.

title: Schools Closest to Twin Towers Struggle for Continuity
description: As debris and concrete dust from the collapsing World Trade Center rained down around them on Sept. 11, 1,300 students from two small public high schools ran toward the East River, with some vaulting over park benches as teachers chased the stragglers. An aide gave a piggyback ride to a girl in a wheelchair.

title: CNN Submits 6 Questions After Overture By bin Laden
description: CNN has asked Osama bin Laden whether he or his followers have weapons of mass destruction and whether they plan to use them, the network said last night.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Loss Widens At Veritas
description: The Veritas Software Corporation, a maker of data-storage management software, had a wider third-quarter loss on acquisition costs, as sales rose. The loss was $162 million, or 40 cents a share, compared with a loss of $148.1 million, or 37 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 7.3 percent, to $340.2 million. The company's growth has slowed with the lagging economy. Sales fell from $390.2 million in the second quarter, the first quarter-over-quarter decline since 1996. Excluding costs related to acquisitions and $16.1 million in investment losses, Veritas said it would have earned 12 cents a share. Its shares rose $1.50, or 5.4 percent, to $29.43.

title: Fighting Infection
description: Source: Drug companies

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Pohang's Earnings Fall
description: The Pohang Iron and Steel Company reported a 37 percent decline in earnings in the third quarter of this year compared with last year. The company said that it earned $152 million in the period and that the decline resulted almost entirely from declining exports. The company relies on the domestic market for 75 percent of its sales.

title: Article 2001101791099999070 -- No Title
description: The New York Times

title: Airlines and the Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Household Names In Their Households
description: The most curious thing has overcome the Giants: confidence.

title: G.M. TO BUY STAKE IN COMPANY THAT DEVELOPS FUEL CELLS
description: General Motors will get a stake of as much as 28 percent in the Hydrogenics Corporation as part of an alliance with the company, a maker of fuel cells, to develop low-pollution technology to power cars and trucks. Hydrogenics, which is based in Toronto, develops fuel cells and equipment to test them and has been in business since 1995.

title: Endangered Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the copyright case brought against the publisher of ''The Wind Done Gone,'' which revisits the setting of Margaret Mitchell's ''Gone With the Wind,'' misidentified the lawyer who argued on behalf of the Mitchell estate. He was Richard A. Kurnit; his partner Martin Garbus is the lead lawyer on the case.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Detente Erodes
description: South Korea today rejected a North Korean request for a change of venue for talks by the two countries, casting further doubt on their sputtering detente. Earlier North Korea, citing security concerns, suddenly announced that it would not attend the next round of talks between the two countries, and proposed instead that they be held at a secluded North Korean mountain resort. That word came after the rejection last week of a fourth round of family reunifications originally scheduled for this week. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Job Counseling For Olympians Now Available
description: Eric Heiden, the physician with five Olympic gold medals in speedskating, and Jim Craig, the former goalie with a gold medal and a brief career in the N.H.L., remembered the yesteryears when their lives were absorbed by only one thing: making the Olympics.

title: I.B.M. Seems Confident as It Reports Sound Profits
description: Despite the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and economic turmoil, International Business Machines came through the third quarter remarkably unscathed, reporting solid profits yesterday that slightly exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Belgium Is Hindering Investigation, U.S. Says
description: American investigators say that the Belgian authorities have denied them access to suspects and evidence in their inquiry into the European network linked to Osama bin Laden and a thwarted plot to blow up the American Embassy in Paris.

title: Enron Reports $1 Billion In Charges And a Loss
description: The Enron Corporation, the nation's leading wholesale electricity marketer and natural gas trader, posted a third-quarter loss yesterday because of more than $1 billion in one-time charges for various businesses.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Luis Garca Navarro, 61, Opera Conductor of Spain
description: Luis Antonio Garca Navarro, one of Spain's best known conductors and the first music and artistic director of Madrid's newly restored opera house, the Teatro Real, died on Oct. 10 in a Madrid clinic after a long illness. He was 61.

title: No Swift Anthrax Test
description: In response to the recent spate of anthrax threats, anxious citizens are demanding that doctors test them for the disease. But, unlike strep throat, there is no rapid screening test for anthrax.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Raises Still Planned
description: Pay raises for city supervisors and City Council staff members will still go into effect, even as agencies struggle to cut spending by as much as 15 percent in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center, officials said yesterday. The increases are intended to make supervisors' pay keep pace with the salaries of those they manage, officials said. The raises, which a city official said were authorized before the attack, range up to 4 percent, closely tracking the city's agreement with District Council 37, the largest municipal employee union.

title: The New York Times's N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining its record against other teams.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article in some editions on Sunday about the United States loss in a Davis Cup doubles match misidentified a former player. The partner of Robert Seguso was Ken Flach; Doug Flach was another player.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: Stretching Miles
description: Through Nov. 15, American, T.W.A., United, Delta, Continental and US Airways are among the airlines doubling frequent-flier awards and discounting the miles needed for a round-trip ticket. Typically, an economy-class ticket within the continental United States will require 15,000 miles instead of 25,000. There are similar reductions on other routes, but the double-miles offer does require registration by telephone. For information on registering, visit www.aaa.com/offers for American and T.W.A., www.ual.com , www.continental.com , www.usairways.com and www.delta.com .

title: I'm a Beacon Of the Road
description: Recently, a state police officer was stationed next to my tollbooth pulling people over for not wearing seat belts. An older woman came flying through the E-ZPass lane and smashed into his car. She got out and started pointing to her watch and yelling at him. It looked to me like she had an appointment and was telling him that now she was going to be late. Three other police officers pulled up a few minutes later.

title: Ballet Theater Appoints New Director
description: The American Ballet Theater today named a veteran arts administrator as its new executive director after two years of board and staff resignations and backstage furor that rivaled any onstage drama.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AKIN, ADOLPH
description: AKIN-Adolph. October 15, 2001. The adored and adorable husband of Evalyn, who was cherished and will be cherished forever and ever. For funeral information, call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC: 212-288-3500

title: Irish and Making Fun Of 'Riverdance'? O.K.
description: The Nualas can sing like angels and joke like devils.

title: A New Bronx Cheer
description: New York doesn't often get to see Yankees fans cheering with a subtext. But it happened Monday night. With every Mariano Rivera pitch in the top of the ninth, the roar of the crowd at Yankee Stadium seemed, somehow, to square itself, to find a depth and a height it had never found before, despite all the championship games played there in the past. The fans were cheering something unprecedented -- a victory in a 3-of-5 series after two opening losses at home -- and they were cheering the manner of that victory, too: Derek Jeter's plunge into the seats to catch a foul ball, David Justice's late-inning home run, Rivera's poise, and the cleverness of this redoubtable team and its manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, HELEN E.
description: GREENFIELD-Helen E. Died peacefully on October 16, 2001. The loving and much beloved wife of the late Benjamin; proud, devoted mother of Jeff Greenfield and Janet Elmo; delighting in their life partners, Dena Sklar and Lou Elmo. Loving grandmother of Marc Elmo, and Casey and Dave Greenfield. A celebration of her life will be held on Friday, October 19th, 10:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Development Office of the 92nd Street YMHA, 1395 Lexington Avenue, NYC 10128. (212) 415-5479.

title: Seattle Scrambles to Find a Prosecutor's Assassin
description: As a prosecutor in the United States attorney's office here for 18 years, specializing in fraud and white-collar crime, and as president of a statewide gun-control group, Thomas C. Wales certainly made some enemies.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about chefs' revival of classic sauces misstated the name of a dish served with a lobster Amricaine sauce at Le Cirque 2000. It is quenelles de brochet (pike dumplings), not quenelles en brochette.

title: A Pakistan City Tied by Tribe to Afghanistan
description: The city of Quetta, Pakistan, has thrived down the centuries as a center for commerce on the ancient Silk Road and the home of tribal groups whose loyalties bowed neither to the sword of invaders nor to the demands of governments. The ruling Taliban in Afghanistan, whose border lies just 60 miles northwest, are mostly from the Pashtun ethnic group, which dominates political and business life in Quetta. The tribal link contributes to the backing here for the Taliban, though the depth of support is hard to gauge.

title: Nassau County Legislator Is Indicted on Mortgage Fraud Charges
description: A Nassau County legislator was indicted today on federal charges that he conspired to help people obtain mortgage loans through fraudulent documents inflating their incomes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTON, EUGENE W.
description: WALTON-Eugene W., President of Walton Hauling and Warehouse Corp., died October 15, 2001 after a short struggle with cancer. As President of Walton Hauling and Warehouse Corp., he succeeded his father and grandfather before him in steering the company into its current position. Having dedicated over 60 years to the business, he will be missed by many friends and business associates in the Broadway Theatrical Community. The company began in 1879, transporting for the vaudeville stage, and has grown into a multifaceted organization serving theater, movies, and television. 609 West 46th has housed this vital New York institution for the last 60 years and continues to serve as its headquarters. He was also a lifetime Board Member of the Community Church of Elmhurst, where he served as Trustee, & dedicated many hours in service to the church. Mr. Walton was born in Hell's Kitchen, New York City, on August 18, 1916. Dear companion of Doris Sulzer. Beloved father of Barbara Damiano of Ft. Myers, Florida, Linda (and Walter) Hackenjos of Tequesta, Florida, Dale Walton of Elmhurst, NY, and Eugene P. Walton of Clifton, NJ. Brother of Elizabeth Eggebrecht of Great Neck, NY and Herbert of Little Neck, NY. Grandfather to four children and two great-grandchildren. He is predeceased by his wife, Alice, of 53 years and brother Richard. He will be missed by all. The family will receive visitors at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park, NY on Wednesday, October 17th and Thursday, October 18th from 2:00-4:00 and from 7:00-9:00. A funeral service will be conducted at the Community Church of Elmhurst, 79-11 Caldwell Ave., Elmhurst on Friday, October 19th at 10 AM. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made to The Actors' Fund and The American Cancer Society.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Leader's Brother Back On Team
description: Anura Bandaranaike, who had long been estranged from his sister, President Chandrika Kumaratunga, and who had joined forces with her political rivals, resigned from the opposition United National Party. There was widespread speculation that he would join his sister's political coalition, which is facing elections in December after losing its parliamentary majority. The brother and sister are inheritors of the Bandaranaike political dynasty. Their father and mother were both prime ministers of Sri Lanka. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Anthrax Fears Appear to Spread, Even Without New Verified Cases
description: The anthrax scare sent health and law enforcement authorities scrambling yet again yesterday, to offices, abortion clinics and even a chamber of commerce, putting people on edge even though no new cases of exposure were detected.

title: Court Says Individuals Have a Right to Firearms
description: In a case that had drawn intense national attention from supporters and opponents of gun control measures, a federal appeals court in New Orleans ruled yesterday that the Constitution guarantees individuals a right to have firearms.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the history of anthrax hoaxes misstated the given name of a senior research scientist at the Center for Nonproliferation Studies in Monterey who has studied them. He is Jason Pate, not Justin.

title: Pataki Seeks Aid for Guard
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday asked four neighboring states to lend New York the use of 600 National Guard troops to ease the strain on New York guard units called to active duty since the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Anthrax Alert: When Fear Arrives in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: On Capitol Hill, Issues of Fear And Safety Hit Close to Home
description: With a fleet of police cars parked in front of the Capitol and no tourists inside, the Capitol looks like a village under siege, though most members proudly maintain that they have no fear.

title: Rooting for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKER OF JIM BEAM SELLS ITS WHISKEY BUSINESS IN BRITAIN
description: Fortune Brands, maker of Jim Beam bourbon and Titleist golf balls, sold its Scotch whiskey business in Britain to the unit's management for $290 million in Scotland's largest buyout. The transaction creates a leading Scotch maker with 9 percent of the whiskey market. The whiskey unit's management has formed a company, Kyndal International Ltd., to purchase the business, which consists of five malt distilleries; a grain distillery; Invergordon Distillers' own-label business; and whiskey, vodka and liqueur brands.

title: A Comforting Little Italian Spot Fills a Void Uptown
description: MAX SOHA is a perfect example of a blindingly obvious entrepreneurial move that, when it succeeds, makes everybody snap their fingers and ask, ''Why didn't I think of that?''

title: Production At Factories Declined 1% Last Month
description: Industrial production fell 1 percent in September, the 12th consecutive monthly decline, the government said today. The series of declines is the longest since World War II.

title: Security Company Faulted Again
description: The airport security company that was fined $1.2 million last year for hiring convicted felons to screen passengers at Philadelphia International Airport has committed more violations, a federal task force said tonight.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMANUEL, RITA
description: EMANUEL-Rita. We mourn the loss of one of our esteemed founding members and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Mordecai Waxman, Rabbi Steven Markowitz, President

title: Politics and a Texas Airline
description: My mother worked seven days as a keypunch operator. She told us, ''You're as rich as you make yourself.'' We were Vermonters and forced to be thrifty. She could stretch tuna fish like you wouldn't believe.

title: The Balm of Rebuilding In Recuperating Berlin
description: Long before the terrorism of Sept. 11, the German art-noise ensemble Einstrzende Neubauten -- whose name translates as ''Collapsing New Buildings'' -- made its mark by using power tools in addition to instruments to create assaultive sound. In using the group to score his cool-to-the-touch German-language documentary about the rebuilding of post-wall Berlin, ''Berlin Babylon,'' the director Hubertus Siegert almost seems too on the nose.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Slashed At Subway Station
description: A 38-year-old New Jersey woman was slashed across the face Monday evening by another woman in an East Harlem subway station, the police said yesterday. No one has been arrested and there are no suspects, they said. The victim, whose name was not immediately released, appeared to have been singled out for the attack, but the motive was unclear, the police said. The victim was cut across the top of her head and down to her ear and chin about 5 p.m. as she stood on the stairs in the subway station at 125th Street and Lexington Avenue. She was listed in stable condition yesterday, the police said.

title: Bucharest Journal; It's Still No Breeze for Gays, Even Diplomatic Ones
description: ''It's a real Soviet style disco!'' Adrian Coman shouted over the thumping music, waving apologetically at the pool tables at the back and the cheap plastic plants. But, the dcor aside, the Casablanca disco has been at the forefront of smashing old Communist taboos.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Are Still Short a Big Man
description: GLOOM is a word that must be carefully used these days, not frivolously employed. Also, words like grim, and bomb, and devastation, which once upon a time -- like before four weeks ago -- had been used regularly on the sports pages, must be given another thought.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Intel and I.B.M. Post Drop In Third-Quarter Earnings

title: Anthrax Spores Found in Pataki's Midtown Office
description: Authorities ordered the midtown Manhattan offices of Gov. George E. Pataki closed today after tests revealed the possible presence of anthrax spores.

title: Small Business, Badly Damaged
description: Radiating out from Ground Zero in Lower Manhattan, thousands of offices and storefronts are still boarded up. Computer terminals and cash registers are silent; merchandise sits on shelves thick with dust. The city estimates that 14,632 businesses in the area close to the World Trade Center were destroyed, damaged or significantly disrupted by the terrorist destruction of Sept. 11. The financial loss to these businesses is in the billions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASMUSSEN, SARA J.
description: RASMUSSEN-Sara J. On October 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Harold F.; mother of David of Old Greenwich, Connecticut, Garret of Washington, DC, Anne Fraser of Rye, New York. Six grandchildren. Service Saturday, Oct. 20, 2 PM at Christ's Church, Rye, NY.

title: Couscous Flies Italian Colors
description: EVERY time I browse through Kalustyan's, an emporium of spices and Indian and Middle Eastern foods on Lexington Avenue, I find something new. Recently, it was a twist on an old favorite: tricolored couscous.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: MSNBC Starts Arabic Site
description: MSNBC inaugurated an Arabic-language news Web site yesterday, entering an area that is a hot market for news and media. The Web site, at www.gn4msnbc.com is produced with Good News 4 Me, a media company based in Cairo that was founded by Emadeddin Adib, a veteran journalist and television host. The site will provide selected news reports as well as streaming audio and video in Arabic. Good News 4 Me will operate and maintain the site. MSNBC already had Turkish, French and German versions of its site, but its deal with the Egyptian company is its first Arabic-language content. MSNBC.com, like other news sites, has had a surge in audience traffic since Sept. 11. According to a recent Jupiter Media Metrix report, MSNBC.com had a 66 percent jump in traffic in September, to 22.2 million visitors. CNN had even greater growth, with Web visitors more than doubling, to 24.8 million. CNN is creating CNNarabic.com, an Arabic-language site to be run out of a new CNN bureau being built in Dubai.

title: No Way to Run an Election
description: New York voters must be wondering whether they will ever again see an election with a clear-cut winner. Now New York City's antiquated system has failed to deliver a clean, swift and official verdict on who won the Democratic mayoral runoff last week. Once more, voters are asking why a city that advertises its speed and efficiency has to rely on horse-and-buggy elections.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Operations and Diplomacy

title: Anthrax Alert: When Fear Arrives in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Aide's Son Arrested
description: Khaleda Zia, the new prime minister, promised to crack down on crime and corruption; now the police have arrested the son of her new minister for post and telegraph. He is accused of kidnapping the brother of a journalist in the western Kushtia District and of threatening to kidnap the journalist because he did not like his articles. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: Focus on Film

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buffalo: Sentence In Church Arson
description: A teenager who pleaded guilty to setting fire to his church has been sentenced to six months of weekend jail time and 250 hours of community service at a local burn unit, the Erie County district attorney said yesterday. The teenager, George Liaros, 18, was also sentenced Monday to five years' probation and ordered to seek counseling. Mr. Liaros admited in June to setting the fire on May 20. It caused more than $1 million in damage to a church that his family helped found, the Hellenic Orthodox Church, said Frank J. Clark, the district attorney.

title: Our Towns; What Color Would the Pie Have Been?
description: ABOUT the time of the World Trade Center attack, Ed Bozzi was walking through his family's pick-your-own pumpkin patch when there, on the far side of the field was a pumpkin, the likes of which he'd never seen in his 69 years. ''A pink pumpkin!'' he marveled. ''Growing on our vine.'' He called seed companies and a University of Connecticut expert and they all said they'd never seen a pink pumpkin.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''She's got to pull through, because she's got 700 families' worth of love. It's not fair, but she's part of their hope.''

title: 'Rocky Horror Show' Is to Rock Again
description: Let's do the time warp again.

title: Stranger Than Chatwin's Fiction
description: At the end of ''Utz,'' Bruce Chatwin's novel about a reclusive Czech collector of Meissen porcelain, the narrator speculates that the man destroyed the collection before his death to keep it out of Communist hands. In the 1992 screen version of the book, also called ''Utz,'' the collector's housekeeper is shown smashing hundreds of intricate rococo figures as the dying Utz observes her with a satisfied smile.

title: ETHAN ALLEN FORMS PARTNERSHIP WITH MFI FURNITURE
description: Ethan Allen Interiors, the furniture maker and retailer, formed a partnership with the MFI Furniture Group to open stores in Britain. The companies will open as many as five retail stores in the first phase of the partnership. Each company will invest 2 million ($2.89 million) and hold a 50 percent stake in the venture, said MFI, the largest furniture retailer in Britain. The stores will sell premium-brand furniture and have the Ethan Allen name. Ethan Allen, which is based in Danbury, Conn., has more than 300 stores in North America and Mexico. MFI is based in London.

title: Batter in a Box, Ready for the Oven
description: Maury's Bake Your Own frozen cakes make it easy on the cook: the batter comes in cardboard packages that safely serve as the baking pan once the lid is removed. Baking them directly from the freezer takes only about 15 minutes in a conventional oven and about a minute by microwave -- faster, perhaps, but not quite as crusty and delicious. You get a single serving of spice cake, moist corn bread (right) or a brownie with or without walnuts. Maury Rubin, the owner of City Bakery in Manhattan, who came up with the cakes, says they are best eaten warm, right from the package. They are about $2.50 at D'Agostino, Fairway and Whole Foods supermarkets.

title: Anthrax Alert: When Fear Arrives in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Official Charged With Larceny
description: A Board of Education official has been arrested and charged with stealing supplies intended for workers at ground zero -- including hard hats and work boots -- from a Red Cross emergency station, Edward F. Stancik, left, the special commissioner for investigations for the New York City School District, said yesterday. The school official, Frank Zanotti, 66, of Armonk, N.Y., is a plumbing supervisor; he is accused of stealing the donated supplies from Public School 234 in TriBeCa. The school was used as a disaster-relief station after the World Trade Center attack. Mr. Zanotti was released without bail yesterday after pleading not guilty to larceny and criminal possession of stolen property. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Terror, Excuses And Explanations
description: When Judith Rizzo, deputy chancellor of the New York City schools, said the terrorist attacks demonstrated the importance of teaching about Muslim cultures, she was denounced by Lynne Cheney, wife of the vice president. Ms. Cheney, former chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, charged Dr. Rizzo with implying that terrorism was America's fault, a result of our failure to understand Islam.

title: Gunship Use Signals Start Of Attacks On Troops
description: PARIS  The Pentagon's decision to begin using low-flying AC-130 gunships in Afghanistan this week signals the start of a bloody offensive against Taliban ground forces that will involve an arsenal of new helicopter-borne firepower and Special Forces, defense officials and other experts said Tuesday.

title: How to Cover a War
description: The problem is as old as the republic, only it's now getting worse: How much information is the press, and therefore the public, entitled to get during wartime? And how can the press, burdened by government and budgetary pressures, do its job effectively?

title: A Tower Survives Greatly Exaggerated Rumors and Prepares to Reopen
description: One Liberty Plaza, the sleek black skyscraper just east of the World Trade Center, was the subject of numerous reports of collapse and serious structural damage in the hours and days just after Sept. 11. Rumors of its demise, however, were premature. The building is reopening, with a celebration scheduled for Monday. A ribbon will be cut at the 54-story building, which has arguably been pronounced ''structurally sound'' more times than any other skyscraper in the city.

title: Sign of Escalating Threat
description: The discovery of what government officials say is high-grade anthrax in a letter mailed to Congress is the most worrisome development yet in a series of bioterrorist attacks that has already rattled the nation.

title: A Focus on Bioterrorism, a Show of Military Might
description: No new cases of anthrax were confirmed yesterday, but that did not ease the nation's fears of what is being called bioterrorism. Quite the opposite. Anxiety grew with the discovery that the anthrax mailed to the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, was a strain both highly potent and sufficiently refined that it could float a considerable distance through the air. Thus it is possible that someone has obtained a germ weapon that can inflict enormous casualties.

title: Those Who Stayed
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Asian News Programs
description: Seeking to capitalize on increasing demand from Pakistani and Indian migrs for news in their native languages, the News Corporation has signed a deal with Telewest, Britain's second-largest cable operator, which will begin showing programming from the Asian Star News and Star Plus channels on Friday, people involved in the talks said. The channels are leading providers of news and entertainment in Central Asia, and started in Britain in January through Star's sister company British Sky Broadcasting, of which the News Corporation owns 36 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Good and Evil
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Ontario Premier Resigning
description: The Ontario premier, Mike Harris, announced plans to resign as leader of Canada's largest province and head of the provincial Progressive Conservative party. Elected in 1995 and 1999, Mr. Harris, 57, led Ontario's Common Sense Revolution, a right-wing platform of tax cuts, privatization and sweeping changes in education, welfare and health care. In recent months, Mr. Harris has been accused of covering up his role in the death of a protester shot by provincial police in 1995 and of instituting cutbacks that contributed to a public health scandal in which seven residents of Walkerton, Ontario, died from drinking water tainted by E. coli bacteria. Susan Catto (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Bush Leaves for Trade Talks With Wider Agenda as Goal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  President Bush departed for Shanghai today with his country at war, his citizenry intensely nervous about what appears to be a strain of anthrax at the Capitol building, and his diplomatic game plan  especially in Asia  about to veer in a dramatically different direction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED, RUTH (NEE NEWMAN)
description: FREED-Ruth (nee Newman). October 14, 2001. Mother of Alan (Carole Sheridan) Freed, Robert (Bobbie) Freed, and Cathy (Daniel) Dellinger. Sister of the late Frances Newman and Nathan Newman. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Thursday, 12 Noon, Shalom Memorial Park, Lower Moreland, PA. Contributions to Jewish Federation of Greater Philadelphia. For info, call Goldsteins Rosenbergs Raphael-Sacks, 1-800-622-6490.

title: Anthrax Alert: When Fear Arrives in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian Session Will Focus On Terrorism And Trade
description: Trade and terrorism will compete for top billing here beginning on Wednesday when 21 Asian and Pacific Rim countries formally open a series of meetings in what will be the largest gathering of government leaders since Sept. 11.

title: Reality Check, Please, For Cult Wines
description: RALPH HERSOM hasn't sold one in a month. Rocco DiSpirito doesn't order them any more. Tim Kopec sells them because, he says, he has to, and Piero Selvaggio said his sales have slowed to a crawl.

title: Ferrer and Green Camps Continue Fight Over Count
description: The camps of Fernando Ferrer and Mark Green squared off yet again last night over the vote count, with an adviser to Mr. Ferrer accusing the Green campaign of challenging valid ballots and Mr. Green's spokesman accusing the adviser of misleading New Yorkers.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Oct. 6 with an article about problems at the Bank of New York stemming from the collapse of the World Trade Center misstated the address of one affected building. It is 100 Church Street, not 120.

title: Web Site for Post-Attack Wish Lists
description: One school wants an architect to visit and help fourth graders design memorials to the World Trade Center victims. Another hopes to buy books about the Middle East. A third has requested ''recovery journals'' in which students can write and draw responses to the terrorist attack.

title: Deepening Wrinkles in the New Economy
description: The strong productivity gains of the late 1990's were concentrated in only 30 percent of the private sector and are likely to be whittled away in the coming months and years, according to a study released yesterday by McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm.

title: A Lighthouse's Biggest Fan, and Small-Town Tastes for City Niceties
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Anthrax Alert: When Fear Arrives in the Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Bride's Killer, Taking Stand, Says He Fired Gun in Shock
description: A once-prominent Dominican businessman testified today that he fatally shot the woman he loved in a state of shock and confusion after he went to her house and learned that she was to marry another man hours later.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DUN & BRADSTREET CORP., Murray Hill, N.J., a provider of business information, agreed to buy Harris InfoSource International Inc., Twinsburg, Ohio, a privately held database company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Warriors Match Jackson Offer
description: The Golden State Warriors matched the six-year, $24.4 million offer sheet that center Marc Jackson signed last month with Houston, the Rockets said.

title: Suzuki: Made in Japan, Making It in America
description: It was the end of spring training, and Ichiro Suzuki needed an apartment in Seattle. He told Roger Jongewaard, a Mariners vice president who scouted Suzuki in Japan, that he wanted a place with three bedrooms.

title: Intel Meets Forecasts and Expects Slightly Better Earnings
description: The Intel Corporation met its financial projections for the third quarter today and said it expected profitability to slightly improve in the last three months of the year, leading some analysts to predict that the semiconductor industry has seen the worst of its precipitous sales decline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHLER, SANDRA ZOOK
description: FISCHLER-Sandra Zook. Beloved wife of William. Devoted mother of Sabrina Zook Brotman and Julianne Zook, adoring grandmother of Matthew and Alex Brotman, Gabriel and Daniel Fischler. Sandra participated in the NYC Marathon for many years and she proudly ran with a runner from the Achilles Club in her last marathon appearance. She was the first patient representative for the FDA for a period of five years and voted during her tenure to approve use of the two breast cancer fighting drugs, which ironically Sandra used in her own fight against cancer. Service at 11:45 A.M. today at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Memorial contributions to SHARE at 1501 Broadway, New York, New York 10036, would be appreciated.

title: Terror Searchlight Sweeps Familiar Territory
description: In the years since a group of Jersey City men helped orchestrate the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993, New Jersey residents may have assumed that the state's role as a staging ground for terrorists was simply an aberration.

title: An Executive's Change of Heart on the Military
description: Mark Brinkman, chief executive of Brinkman Technologies Inc. in Carrollton, Tex., had had it with the military. One of his top executives had already served more than 600 days on active duty in Honduras, Italy and in the Persian Gulf, since joining the company in 1986, yet the Army was ordering him to fly off again to Bosnia, 5,900 miles away, for a nine-month stint with American peacekeeping forces there.

title: Pressuring the Enemy
description: The intensified airstrikes now under way against the Taliban, a blitz of day and night operations, are intended to crack the leadership in its moment of weakness.

title: Keeping Peace in the Subcontinent
description: The last thing Secretary of State Colin Powell needed as he began a delicate diplomatic mission to Pakistan and India this week was a flare-up of violence in Kashmir. Thanks to an untimely attack by India on Pakistani border posts, that is just what he got. The clash served notice, if any were needed at this volatile time in South Asia, that maintaining some sort of equilibrium in relations between Pakistan and India will be essential to waging a successful international war against terrorism.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer To Buy Stores
description: The British retailer Marks & Spencer said it accepted an offer from Galeries Lafayette to buy 19 stores it wants to shed in France as it sells overseas businesses to focus on the food and clothing markets at home. The deal, whose value was not disclosed, is conditional on French labor union approval and could save the jobs of 1,500 Marks & Spencers employees threatened with dismissal in France. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Dessert That Means Business
description: THE new caramel cake at Musette, a takeout shop, should be called the Now and Later Cake. It is so intense that it took me two sittings to finish one slice. And that's my best test of a dessert.

title: Israeli Rightist Leader Slain, Dealing Blow to Peace Effort
description: JERUSALEM, Thursday, Oct. 18 -- Israel's minister of tourism, a leader of the far right, was shot and killed on Wednesday in a stealthy, audacious attack at a hotel here. Stunned and outraged, the Israeli government threatened early today to oppose the Palestinian Authority as a terrorist organization unless it immediately handed over gunmen blamed for the assault.

title: Woman to Head Computer Department
description: Men still greatly outnumber women in computer science departments. But with the appointment of MARGARET H. WRIGHT, left, as chairwoman of New York University's computer science department effective in January, N.Y.U. will join Columbia as one of a handful of universities with female computer science chiefs. KATHLEEN McKEOWN became chairwoman at Columbia in 1997. Dr. Wright, a member of the National Academy of Engineering, received her bachelor's degree and Ph.D. from Stanford University and worked at Stanford until 1988, and then at Bell Laboratories.

title: AT&T and British Telecom Will Shut Down Joint Venture
description: Legions of sales representatives competed for the same customers. Products sold by one partner were often incompatible with those sold by the other. And competing interests prevented them from uniting behind a single strategy.

title: At Lincoln Center, Folk Dance In a Village Square (Sort of)
description: Performing arts are living arts. So it was a fine idea to have a performance celebrate the renovation of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.

title: Hoarding Cipro
description: A run on Cipro, the antibiotic most recommended to combat exposure to anthrax, is causing shortages of the drug at some pharmacies and even at some medical institutions. This is a worrisome example of how the nation's overwrought response to a handful of anthrax incidents has the potential to do more harm than good.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: A Close Call for Suspect

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Monday with an article about the Miss Tennessee beauty pageant, held in Clarksville as troops nearby at Fort Campbell were preparing for possible war duty, misstated the surname of the winner in a companion contest, Miss Tennessee Teen USA. She was Rachel Smith, as the article said, not Clark.

title: An Image Makeover, From Prices to Kitchen
description: A GOOD chef in the wrong place can make for a painful situation, and in recent years, Joseph Fortunato seemed to find one after another. After holding sous chef and chef de cuisine jobs at top restaurants like Picholine, Tribeca Grill and Layla, he toiled in vain at the relentlessly mediocre Scarabee and the awful Quantum 56 in the Swisstel.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Assistance
