description: The South Korean air carriers, Korean Air and Asiana Airlines, are to receive $191 million in loans under a special $1.5 billion budget. The plan also provides for rolling over about $300 million in bonds that were issued by Korean Air along with a request that Asiana's creditor banks, most of them owned by the government, extend nearly $200 million in new loans. In addition, the two airlines were exempted from paying about $11 million in taxes through 2002. The losses for the airlines as a result of declining business since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States were expected to total $400 million this year.

title: Palestinian Offers Idea: Get Israelis On Our Side
description: In a speech to an overflow crowd of Israelis at the Hebrew University on Monday night, Sari Nusseibeh, the new political representative of the Palestinians in East Jerusalem, aired views rarely heard here after more than a year of violence.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Philips Expects A Loss
description: Royal Philips Electronics, the largest consumer electronics manufacturer in Europe, said that it would lose about $540 million in 2001, the first time in five years that it has not made a profit. Philips said third- quarter sales dropped 23 percent as its customers bought fewer televisions, computer screens and semiconductors. The chief executive, Gerard Kleisterlee, said consumer confidence was hurt by the terrorist attacks in the United States. Philips said that it lost money in the third quarter and expected to do the same in the fourth. Its shares, which have fallen 38 percent this year, rose 5 percent.

title: Taking Baby To the Office, Then Living A Nightmare
description: He wore a short-sleeved shirt with bunnies on it and a pair of navy blue pants, a 7-month-old whose mother had taken him around ABC News's offices on one of the first semicalm news days since the World Trade Center collapsed.

title: Anecdotes About His Family And a Life in Show Business
description: Charles Nelson Reilly tells a good story. Like the time his father -- who worked for Paramount Pictures in Manhattan drawing watercolor billboards -- was visited by a soft-spoken man who told him what a wonderful artist he was and invited him to come and work with him in California. But the elder Mr. Reilly's wife would hear nothing of it; her family was in Connecticut, and she was not moving 3,000 miles away. So she and her husband stayed in the Bronx, only to watch movie studios switch to photographs for outdoor advertising, sending the careers of movie-studio artists downhill fast. The soft-spoken visitor with the job offer, the younger Mr. Reilly now reveals, with an appropriate dramatic pause, was Walt Disney.

title: A New Beachhead for Modern Design
A New Image
Spreading the Word
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: O'Neill's 2nd Hit Of the Postseason Lands in the Seats
description: The regular season was almost over and the topic inside the Yankees' clubhouse was the incredible Seattle Mariners. Paul O'Neill, who is no fan of the team and no fan of Lou Piniella, Seattle's manager and his manager when he played for the Cincinnati Reds, did not want to hear about how great the Mariners are.

title: Anthrax Scares Are Stretching Thin Blue Line
description: As anthrax and bomb scares continued to jangle nerves around the country, a growing number of police departments said yesterday that their resources were being stretched well beyond normal by the need to respond to calls from jittery residents.

title: Coast Guard's Gunboats On Watch Against Attack
description: A half dozen times a day, in the choppy waters off Staten Island, a team of Coast Guard officers, police and federal agents board the 800-foot-long cargo ships that steam into the Port of New York and New Jersey from points around the world.

title: Bush Says Aim Is to Ease Entry Of Land Force
description: President Bush said today that the blitz of American air attacks in Afghanistan was intended to pave the way for anti-Taliban forces on the ground to defeat the government.

title: Quiltlike Windows (Gift Shop Inside)
description: The American Folk Art Museum, near Lincoln Center, has acquired a new facade and incorporated the gift shop that was next door. The redesign was by David van Handle, an architect who once worked with Tod Williams and Billy Tsien. ''Instead of the original large glass window, we decided to break it up into smaller panes -- some of colored glass -- to give the window a quiltlike pattern,'' Mr. van Handle said. The colors were inspired by Shaker paints. Handmade items include ceramics (above) by Jill Rosenwald, with prices ranging from $140 to $180, as well as Shaker-style side chairs ($225) and toy chickens ($25). 2 Lincoln Square (Columbus Avenue at 66th Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: He Came, He Saw, He Pointed and Snapped
description: THE challenge was to move an American family of five (mine) from our five-acre lair in Colorado to an apartment in downtown Tokyo sight unseen to a skeptical audience: my wife, Elizabeth, and our three boys. Before I left for Japan on a house- and school-hunting trip, Susan Catto, a researcher for The Times in Toronto, pressed into my hand a yellow and white box with a Kodak PalmPix camera.

title: In Houston, Much Ado About Powder
description: Tommy Erickson and his fellow firefighters on Houston's hazardous materials unit usually battle chemical fires and wade into hydrochloric acid spills. But on this day they are responding to their umpteenth panicked call to investigate an unidentified white powder that has aroused fears of anthrax.

title: In America; The Democrats Fiddle
description: Anyone who thought the city's most influential Democrats would recognize that New York and the nation are caught in a grave crisis, and therefore all cheap and petty and divisive politics should be put aside, has been thoroughly, if not sickeningly, disappointed.

title: Yanks Audio
description: Postgame audio from Game 1 of the A.L. Championship Series between the Yankees and the Seattle Mariners provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Suspensions Over Missile Error
description: The defense minister, Oleksandr Kuzmuk, suspended the commander of the air defense force and the commander in charge of air defense training, the first disciplinary actions since the military accidentally shot down a Russian passenger plane two weeks ago, killing 78 people. The measure may be temporary: the suspensions last only through a presidential investigation into the crash, the Russian news agency Interfax reported. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: 4 Sentenced to Life in Prison for Roles in Embassy Bombings
description: The four terrorists convicted of bombing United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998 were sentenced today by a federal judge to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''More people have been struck by lightning in the last 10 days, I'll bet, than have contracted anthrax. The country badly needs to settle down.''

title: Powell's Message: America's Courting of Pakistan Will Not Come at India's Expense
description: The Bush administration sought to reassure India today that America's intensifying alliance with Pakistan would not come at the expense of India, its rival.

title: The War Over There: Arms and Arguments
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Cutbacks For Aluminum Producer
description: The aluminum producer Alcan plans to trim its work force by 5 to 7 percent in response to what the company called challenging market conditions. Alcan presently employs 52,000 people. Releasing third-quarter earnings, the company estimated that the cuts and other cost-saving measures would save $200 million a year before tax. Net income in the third quarter, after good will and amortization, fell to $151 million, or 46 cents a share, from $181 million, or 85 cents, in the period a year earlier. Revenues rose to $3.2 billion from $2 billion, chiefly from the merger last year with Alusuisse Group.

title: Series Rescheduled On Rachmaninoff
description: Several of the concerts in Lincoln Center's ''Rachmaninoff Revisited'' series that were postponed after the Sept. 11 attacks have been rescheduled to January, the center has announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREGMAN, IDA
description: BREGMAN-Ida. On October 16, 2001, of Teaneck and Fort Lee, NJ. Devoted mother of Larry, Donald, Lisa and Ellen Jacobson. Loving grandma of Michele, Andrew, Brian and Ross. Adored Aunt and great Aunt. Memorial services are Thursday, 2:00 PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Atlanta's Afternoon Newspaper Says It Will Close in November
description: The Atlanta Journal, whose reporting once invalidated a crooked state senate election, paving the way for the victory of a peanut farmer named Jimmy Carter, will publish its final edition on Nov. 2.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 7 p.m. Tuesday, 5,250 people were killed or still missing and presumed dead in the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADEN, HERBERT J.
description: BADEN-Herbert J. On October 13, 2001, former Long Island Regional Director of The Office of Alcholism and Substance Abuse Services. Donations to your favorite charity in Herbert's name will be appreciated.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Tightening The State's Belt
description: Washington budget officials said state agencies should expect some programs to be cut or privatized to deal with a looming $1.2 billion deficit. The Office of Financial Management said large agencies should expect budget cuts of 15 percent in the next fiscal year, with education exempted. Departments have just two weeks to provide solutions, including the ''elimination programs not needed to deliver core services,'' to meet the budget cuts.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Rebels Kidnap Italian Priest
description: A group of eight men kidnapped an Italian priest, the Rev. Giuseppe Pierantoni, while he was saying Mass in a church in the southern Philippines and fled with him in a speedboat. The incident was close to the area where Muslim separatists belonging to the guerrilla group Abu Sayyaf are holding two American missionaries and eight Filipinos. Seth Mydans(NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Philips Sues Over Patents
description: The largest consumer electronics manufacturer in Europe Royal Philips Electronics said it had sued four computer parts makers in the United States and four in Taiwan, accusing them of copying a technique that allows discrete electronic components to work together in a device. In the suits, Philips asserted that the United States defendants made computer circuits that illegally copied Philips technology and that the Taiwan companies exported illegal products including circuits, motherboards and computers to the United States. Earlier this week, citing poor market conditions, Philips reported an unexpectedly large third-quarter loss. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Expands on Economic Plans
description: In releasing a plan for economic development yesterday, the Republican mayoral candidate, Michael R. Bloomberg, rejected the idea of a new state authority to oversee the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, and also proposed putting high schools on Governors Island to free up school buildings citywide.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VECTOUR INC., Blue Bell, Pa., a charter transportation company, filed for bankruptcy protection as revenue from several of its units fell by 25 to 50 percent after the terrorist attacks.

title: Bush's New Focus Requires A Shift in His China Policy
description: President Bush, who came into office just months ago talking of China as a ''strategic competitor,'' departed for Shanghai today on a trip expected to complete a significant shift in his policy toward Beijing as he seeks to build, maintain and expand a global coalition against terrorism.

title: Anthrax Itself May Point to Origin of Letter Sent to Daschle
description: As they begin the hunt for whoever sent highly concentrated anthrax to Congress, the government's science detectives are focusing on whether it came from a foreign scientist or nation experienced in making biological weapons, officials say.

title: Teaming Up to Design Tomorrow's Internet
description: Q. What is Internet 2? Is it a separate network from the original Internet?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AOL Meets Projections, But Internet Unit Falls Short

title: Life Insurers Seek Study Of Terror Aid
description: At a time when the fear of bioterrorism is spreading, the life insurance industry plans to ask the White House and Congress today to consider providing aid in the event of a major attack, according to the industry's chief lobbyist.

title: Green Wins the Official Count of Machine Vote
description: Mark Green's lead over Fernando Ferrer in the Democratic runoff for mayoral candidate has narrowed to 18,029 votes, according to the first official machine count, the Board of Elections said last night.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees Shrug Off The Miles
description: HERE's a question nobody ever asked Jackie Robinson and Allie Reynolds and Bobby Thomson half a century ago when New York held a Subway Series just about every year:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Army Finds Huge Bomb
description: British Army experts dismantled a 130-pound homemade bomb in the countryside near Omagh, County Tyrone, on Tuesday night. The police arrested six people and said that dissident republicans were responsible. Security forces in Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic have recently infiltrated and uncovered republican organizations like the Real I.R.A., the paramilitary group responsible for the 1998 bombing in Omagh that killed 29 people. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the closing of Brill's Content magazine misstated its original publication schedule. It appeared 10 times a year, not monthly.

title: A New Beachhead for Modern Design
description: ATLANTIC AVENUE in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn is a new destination for moderately priced modern furniture, lighting and rugs as well as antiques. If you are going to the Brooklyn Museum of Art's new show, ''Vital Forms: American Art and Design in the Atomic Age, 1940-1960,'' Atlantic Avenue is a worthwhile detour.

title: Studies Find Resistant Bacteria in Meats
description: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria are widespread in commercial meats and poultry and can be found in consumers' intestines, researchers are reporting. The findings suggest that many food-borne illnesses will not respond to the usual treatments, and that some cases may even resist all current drugs.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about Israeli troops' withdrawal from Palestinian-controlled areas of Hebron referred incorrectly in some editions to Israelis who had spray-painted graffiti on homes. They were Israeli settlers, not Israeli soldiers.

title: CORNING PLANT TO MAKE EMISSION CONTROL PRODUCTS
description: Corning Inc. said yesterday that it would build a plant in Erwin, N.Y., for $200 million to make diesel emission control products. The new plant will produce diesel filters and diesel catalyst substrates, the company said. The company will start construction by early next year. Corning, which is based in Corning, N.Y., said it expected the market for diesel filters and diesel catalyst substrates to be worth $1.5 billion by 2008.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURGER, JAKOB L.
description: HAMBURGER-Jakob L. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Gaby Friedman upon the loss of her father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Woods Eager to Play After Layoff
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Oct. 17  Tiger Woods might feel rusty this week, but he will also be well rested.

title: The Awkward Middle Child Of Computers Resurfaces
description: A few years ago, while travelers were carrying around seven-pound laptops and pretending that they didn't have shoulder strain, some computer makers had a lovely idea: why not make a truly light computer -- say, under two pounds -- that would function like a laptop but sync with a desktop, just like a Palm? Thus was born the subnotebook, a promising technology that arrived at the wrong time. Squeezed between the growing power of hand-helds and the shrinking prices of laptops, it never found its niche.

title: You Can Never Be Too Thin (or Cheap)
description: UNTIL recently flat-panel liquid crystal display monitors played the same role that credenzas once did in corporate offices: they were given only to senior managers as a sign of their status.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, DANIEL B.
description: STERN-Daniel B. Age 90 of Scarsdale, on October 16. Loving husband of Marjorie. Devoted father of Ellen Stern and Martin Teeman of Katonah, & Elizabeth Stern and Thomas Purcell of Bethesda. Proud grandfather of Scott, Alex, Cassie, and Emily. Memorial service Friday, 3:00 P.M. at Ballard-Durand, White Plains. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to White Plains Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEBERG, ESTHER
description: SCHNEBERG-Esther. Deceased October 16th, died as she wished, at her new home in Portland, OR. She was a valiant survivor of cancer, but she could shadowbox no longer. She will be remembered as a champion of the disenfranchised-a teacher and guidance counselor at Thomas Jefferson High School. The funeral service will take place at Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave. in Brooklyn on Sunday, October 21st, at 11:30 AM, 718-338-1500.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Internet Gambling Crackdown
description: The state attorney general said that New Jersey authorities were cracking down on eight Internet gambling sites that were illegally accepting wagers from state residents. Attorney General John J. Farmer Jr. said on Tuesday that the divisions of Gaming Enforcement and Consumer Affairs had sued the sites to stop accepting bets from New Jersey, account fully for money won by residents in the past year and repay money the sites have won through betting by residents. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'REILLY, BERNICE
description: O'REILLY-Bernice. Age 84. Wife of the late Joseph G. O'Reilly. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Born in Newark, NJ, raised in Glen Ridge, NJ. Longtime resident of Greenwich Village, NYC. Worked professionally as a beauty and hair consultant and retailer for Macy's and Lord and Taylor. Memorial Mass to be held at Sacred Heart Church, 76 Broad St., Bloomfield, NJ on Saturday, October 20th at 10 A.M.

title: Scene 1: On a Joist, Brooding
description: THE house in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., gazes loftily out over the Pacific Ocean. The house on Montauk Point looks across native grasses onto the Atlantic. Separated by 3,000 miles, the houses form the centers of two movies opening this month.

title: Testing Links Anthrax In Florida and at NBC
description: Preliminary DNA tests show the strain of anthrax that caused a skin infection in an employee of ''NBC Nightly News'' appeared to be identical to the anthrax involved in the incident at the offices of American Media Inc., federal health officials said yesterday.

title: A Phone That Fits the Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Tactics Thwart Afghan Rebels
description: The night, like the 10 before it, began with the same sense of expectation and ended with the same sense of disappointment. Soldiers in this rebel-held mountainside village watched American warplanes bomb the Afghan capital, Kabul, in the distance and ignore front-line Taliban positions in the valley below.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, BEATRICE
description: ADELSON-Beatrice. Of Dobbs Ferry, NY, formerly of Brookline, MA on October 16, 2001. Owner of the Beaze Shop of Coolidge Corner. Beloved wife of the late Harry Adelson. Dear daughter of the late Helen and Philip Gellar. Devoted mother of Warren Adelson and his wife Jan of Scarborough, NY. Dear grandmother of Harry, Alan, Adam and Alexa. Graveside services at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA on Friday, October 19 at 1:45 PM. Remeberances to the Beaze and Harry Adelson Research Fellowship for American Art, Boston University Art History Department, 725 Comm. Avenue, Boston, MA. 02215. For information, call Brezniak-Rodman Funeral Directors, 1-800-554-2199.

title: Running With the Bulls, Riding Horses at Dawn, Painting the Town Red
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: 4 Terrorists Ordered to Pay Restitution to Victims
description: Four convicted terrorists with ties to Osama bin Laden will be ordered to pay restitution to victims of the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa, a federal judge in Manhattan said yesterday. Lawyers put the figure at roughly $33 million.

title: Anthrax Menace Exposes Badly Coordinated Defense
description: The growing alarm over anthrax has exposed a lack of coordination among federal agencies and between federal and state authorities that experts say has hampered the government's health response and its law enforcement investigations.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''The Operator'' in Weekend on Friday misidentified the character who suggests to a man that his ailing mother be murdered. It is the telephone operator, who calls herself Shiva, not the film's protagonist, Gary.

title: Who Made the Anthrax?
description: Let's call it what it is: Sending mail laced with anthrax is an act of terrorism. Terrorists aim to cause terror, and in this they have succeeded, up to a point. The run on Cipro at pharmacies demonstrates that. If they also aim to use biological weapons to kill on a large scale, they have not succeeded -- not yet.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina, Germany: Ex-Junta Member Arrested
description: Argentina has arrested Carlos Guillermo Surez Mason, 77, a retired general and former junta member accused of ordering the kidnapping, torture and murder of a German student, Elisabeth Kasemann, in 1977, prosecutors in Nuremberg, Germany, said. The student, who had political differences with the military regime, had lived in Argentina for six years. Mr. Surez Mason has, according to investigators, admitted ordering her murder while he was chief of the First Army Corps. An international arrest warrant was issued by German authorities in July this year. A German investigation in 1980 was abandoned because the Argentine authorities did not cooperate. Now Argentina must decide whether to extradite Mr. Surez Mason to Germany. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Bush administration's opposition to bailouts for industries other than airlines and insurers misstated the amount of loan guarantees offered by the administration to airlines. It is $10 billion, not $15 billion.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDEL, BENJAMIN K.
description: HANDEL-Benjamin K. Of North Miami Beach, FL., died October 17th, 2001. He is survived by his beloved wife Emma of 54 years, his son Jeffrey and his daughter Janet. For 23 years he held the post of the Sunday Magazine Editor of the New York Daily News.

title: A New Image: Why Pros Go Digital
description: FOR years now, digital cameras have been nice gadgets for the amateur photographer. They offer instant gratification in viewing or sending, without the cost of film or development. And they lend themselves to all sorts of other possibilities once the images are transferred to a computer.

title: Las Vegas Savings
description: The MGM Grand in Las Vegas has rooms starting at $79.95 a night on selected dates in November and December. The deal includes a 20 percent saving on tickets to the stage show "EFX Alive," a two-for-one meal at the MGM Grand Buffet and free admission to the Studio 54 nightclub. Eligible dates are Nov. 18 to 21. Nov. 25, Dec. 4 and 5 and Dec. 9 to 20. Subject to availability. Information: (888) 468-6646 or www.mgmgrand.com .

title: CBS Employee Contracts Anthrax; Third TV Network to Be Affected
description: Awoman who works in the office of Dan Rather at CBS News has tested positive for the skin form of anthrax, the company said today, making it the third network to be affected by the bacteria.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Recovering The Kursk
description: The mangled front compartment of the Kursk submarine will probably be lifted from the Barents Sea by the Russian Navy next summer, said a submarine designer, Igor Spassky, confirming what naval officials have been saying. The section was cut off last summer to ease the work by a Dutch consortium lifting the Kursk, which exploded and sank in August 2000. Mr. Spassky said the cause of the disaster may be found in the rest of the submarine, scheduled to be hoisted onto a floating dock, but said that the compartment still on the seabed may also hold important clues.

title: Footlights
description: Man and Music

title: Marbury, From Afar, Remains Van Horn Skeptic
description: Ever since the Nets traded Stephon Marbury to Phoenix for Jason Kidd in July, the talk in New Jersey has been that Kidd, with his pass-first mentality and league-leading assist totals, will make Keith Van Horn a better player. Kidd has said it. Van Horn has said it. And the Nets' brass is banking on it.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Tuesday with an article about Israeli troops' withdrawal from Palestinian-controlled areas of Hebron referred incorrectly in some editions to Israelis who had spray-painted graffiti on homes. They were Israeli settlers, not Israeli soldiers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Electronics Venture
description: Two electronics makers, the Toshiba Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, which makes the Panasonic brand, will combine the divisions that make liquid-crystal display screens for cellular phones, computers and other electronic devices. Toshiba will own 60 percent of the venture, which will hold 12 percent of Japan's 1.38 trillion yen ($11.5 billion) market, second after Sharp. Together, the two companies employ 4,000 people at four factories in Japan, with sales of 250 billion yen ($2.1 billion). Japanese liquid-crystal makers are looking for ways to cut production costs in the face of tough competition from manufacturers in South Korea and Taiwan. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Precursor to Tiniest Chip Is Developed
description: In an advance that presages the tiniest of computer circuitry possible, researchers at Lucent Technologies have built a transistor in which the layer that switches currents on and off is only one molecule thick.

title: Egypt and Saudi Arabia Shield Passenger Lists
description: Federal officials said today that Saudi Arabia and Egypt had refused to cooperate with American efforts to identify terrorists and other criminals on aircraft flying to the United States.

title: In 'Uncharted Territory,' Giuliani Campaigns Against Fear
description: Yesterday, soon after the United States Capitol closed, and the world learned that more than two dozen people on the Senate majority leader's staff had been exposed to a potent form of anthrax, and Gov. George E. Pataki and other state workers began taking Cipro, and environmental testing began at City Hall, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani held a news conference with four large puppets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, CARALYN ANNE
description: SHAPIRO-Caralyn Anne. On October 13, 2001. Age 46. Beloved wife of DeWitt Nelson and devoted mother of Lani Anna. She leaves her parents David and Madelyn, her brothers Peter and Joseph & many friends. Memorial service October 21, 2001 at 1PM at the Miller/Schoen residence, 267 Mossy Brook Road, High Falls, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIKORSKY, GREGORY R.
description: SIKORSKY-Gregory R. Of Wesley Hills, New York, lost his life on September 11th, 2001 while heroically saving others in the World Trade Center. Greg was born on October 5, 1966 to George and Luzia Sikorsky in Manhattan, New York. Greg graduated East Ramapo High School in 1985 and worked as a mechanic in his family's business. In 1996 Greg joined the FDNY and was assigned to Engine 46 in the Bronx. Prior to transferring to Squad 41 last year, he was also stationed in Engine 47 and 50 Truck. He was a volunteer with Hillcrest Fire Department for sixteen years. Greg also served in the Marine Corp. Reserves and was a veteran of the Persian Gulf War. Greg is survived by his wife Marie, their son Steven, 3 years old. His parents George and Luzia Sikorsky. Three brothers Perry and his wife Maria and George and his wife Barbara and Kenny. Nephew Danny & niece Kasey & several aunts, uncles and cousins. Greg also leaves behind Marie's parents, mother Margaret Topkin and father George Topkin, her eight sisters and their families including seventeen nieces and nephews. Greg was a devoted son, a loving husband, a proud father, a wonderful brother, a special uncle & a dedicated firefighter. He had a unique way of touching the lives of everyone who knew him. He was a true friend to all & will be deeply missed but forever remembered. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, Oct. 20, 2001 at 10 AM from St. Boniface R.C. Church, 5 Willow Tree Road, Wesley Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Squad 41 Family Hero Fund, 330 East 150th Street, Bronx, New York 10541. For guest book and directions please visit www.Legacy.com

title: Tough but Hopeful Weeks For the Muslims of Laramie
description: In the first week after the September attacks, when Saha Waheed had become perhaps the most visible Muslim in the cowboy state of Wyoming, she was walking at dusk when two men rushed up behind her and said that anyone who wore a scarf on her head should die, she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, DORISLEE KADIS
description: CARR-Dorislee Kadis. Devoted daughter of the late Jean and Isadore Kadis. Beloved mother of the late Susan Carr Radice, sister of the late Buddy Kadis and grandmother of Julia Radice. Service 10AM Friday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her memory to Chemotherapy Foundation.

title: Readers Lash Back on Targeted Ads
description: As usual, my e-mail column on targeted cell-phone ads last week triggered a huge volume of reader responses. (I get the feeling that a column on shoelaces would trigger a huge volume of reader responses.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, BARBARA
description: KAISER-Barbara. The staff and Board of the American Civil Liberties Union note with great sadness the passing of Judge Barbara Kaiser on September 26th. Judge Kaiser was a dedicated civil libertarian and a passionate advocate for women's rights. She began her formal affiliation with the ACLU in 1972 as a member of the Board of Directors of the organization's New York affiliate - a position she held until 1981. We extend our condolences to Barbara Kaiser's family for their great loss.

title: Four Sentenced to Life in Prison for Roles in Embassy Bombings
description: The four terrorists convicted of bombing United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998 were sentenced today by a federal judge to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: Lincoln Center Renewal
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers and Richter End Dominance by the Devils
description: It is not often that one can say goaltenders were the story of a 4-3 game. But they were last night as the Rangers defeated the Devils for the first time at Madison Square Garden since Jan. 12, 1997. Theo Fleury's power play goal 1 minute 20 seconds into overtime won the game.

title: Nascar Drivers Will Use Safety Restraint Systems
description: Nascar said today that it would mandate the use of head-and-neck restraint systems in its three national touring series starting immediately. Drivers in the Winston Cup, Busch and Craftsman Truck Series will have to wear either the HANS device manufactured by Hubbard/Downing Inc., or the Hutchen's Device made by Mattec Corporation while on the track.

title: Counsell Supplying a Spark
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 17  He ditched his batting gloves months ago. He says his World Series ring is tucked away in a closet at his home. His batting stance looks painful. Oh, and he has a knack for being in the middle of the action in nearly every postseason game he has played.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUTTERMAN, THELMA
description: PUTTERMAN - Thelma. Distin guished Officer of the Flatbush and Shaare Torah Jewish Center and well known interior designer. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Dear mother of Marc, Seth and Jules. Adored grandmother of Rita, Victoria, Laurence, Jared, Harald, Carl and Aaron. She will be missed by her many friends, relatives and the community. Services at Flatbush and Shaare Torah Jewish Center, Church Ave and E. 5th St., Bklyn, N.Y. today, 10:30AM.

title: CALENDAR
description: Open Lofts

title: Agencies tread carefully, rounding all the edges to produce messages that soothe and reassure.
description: MORE advertising is taking on the trappings of public service campaigns as marketers seek to find the right approach to reach consumers after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: A Watchdog for Danger at the Workshop for Peace
description: FEW seats are hotter than the one occupied by Michael McCann, the security chief for the United Nations. The international organization was a target of a foiled terrorist plot in 1993. Its annual gathering of world leaders is next month. As if that weren't enough, the focus on the United Nations intensified on Friday when it, along with Secretary General Kofi Annan, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: U.S. Offers $1 Million for Anthrax Attacker's Capture
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  The federal government offered a $1 million reward today to help catch whoever is responsible for the spate of anthrax attacks. At the same time, officials sought to calm public anxiety with some simple numbers.

title: Demand for Cipro May Be a Break for Bayer, and a Headache
description: Its pharmaceutical business has been reeling from a major drug recall, a plant shutdown and disappointments in drug research. Now, Bayer A.G. would finally seem to be blessed with the most hotly desired drug in the United States: Cipro, the drug of choice for treating inhaled anthrax.

title: At High-Rise Towers, Views Without Terror
description: WHEN terrorists attacked the World Trade Center, most people nearby fled down stairs and uptown, but Joseph Lombardi did the opposite: despite injuring his leg in the tumult, he headed to Liberty Tower on Nassau Street, one block from ground zero, and took an elevator to his penthouse apartment on the 29th floor.

title: The War Over Here: Anthrax Spreads Its Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Coping With Bioterrorism; Beyond Safety
description: One of the challenges of living in the post-Sept. 11 world is defining acceptable risk. We know now that mail can contain anthrax, that tall buildings can be brought down by hijacked airplanes. We have been informed that it's at least conceivable for the subway to be flooded with toxins, Disney World to be crop-dusted with biological weapons and smallpox to be spread through a shopping mall. The question now is what we do with that information.

title: NASA's Longest-Serving Administrator Says He Will Step Down
description: Daniel S. Goldin, who revamped and re-energized the nation's space program during almost a decade as head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, announced today that he was resigning.

title: Strange Yet Convincing, a Requiem Breaks the Rules
description: Requiems are intended to terrify (Verdi) or to comfort (Faur). Berlioz, on the other hand, took the medium in a third direction. The Berlioz Requiem, which the Boston Symphony and Seiji Ozawa took to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, is like a lyrical voyage into outer space. It is a triumph because it is so strange and so convincing.

title: Analysts Scale Back Earnings Estimates
description: Analysts are reducing earnings estimates for 2001 and 2002 for the three largest agency companies.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Quiet Corners, the Roots of Afghan Rebellion
description: While bombs fall in Afghanistan, a quieter war is being waged in the dusty border city of Quetta and, farther north, in the mud-brick city of Peshawar. It is a clandestine affair, intended to win converts for an attempt to overthrow the Taliban.

title: Islanders, Continuing to Win, Just Might Not Be a Mirage
description: The Islanders played in front of rows of empty seats for the first time this season, and there is usually more cheering at a movie theater than there was tonight at the Entertainment and Sports Arena. What a perfect trap to play a lousy game.

title: Torre Scolds Soriano For His Lack of Hustle
description: Alfonso Soriano crossed home plate in the ninth inning today, an insurance run for the Yankees, and everyone in the dugout greeted him with high-fives. Except one.

title: Board Votes to Require Recitation of Pledge at Public Schools
description: The New York City Board of Education unanimously adopted a resolution last night to require all public schools to lead students in the Pledge of Allegiance at the beginning of every school day and at all schoolwide assemblies and events.

title: These Days, Even Soap Is a Suspicious Powder
description: Scenes from a region on edge.

title: Doctor in City Reported Anthrax Case Before Florida
description: Three days before anthrax was first detected in Florida, a Manhattan doctor called the New York City Department of Health to report a suspicion: one of his patients might have contracted anthrax.

title: Widow of Terror Victim Seeks His Place on Ballot
description: A month after the attack on the World Trade Center, one victim's widow is in the middle of an escalating political battle over whether she can run in her husband's place for a spot on the Westchester County Legislature.

title: G.M. Extending Incentives As Ford Posts Another Loss
description: General Motors today extended interest-free financing deals on its vehicles through mid-November, escalating a price war with the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Group that began last month.

title: 'Please Don't E-Mail My Dad, Mr. Weatherbee'
description: ROBERT WILKOFF likes to keep an eye on how his children are doing in school. But last year he got almost more than he bargained for. His daughter's teacher set up a Web site and e-mail system to alert parents to everything that was going on in class, including each homework assignment, a schedule of tests and the latest rundown on the child's grades.

title: Visas for Foreign Students at an Anxious Time
description: When Senator Dianne Feinstein of California called for a six-month moratorium on student visas shortly after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, Marylee Carter cringed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, HAROLD G., M.D.
description: JACOBSON-Harold G., M.D., died on October 14, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Richard and Arthur and their spouses Judy and Peninah. Proud grandfather of David, Sam and Ben. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Ruth and Harold Jacobson Fund at Beit Rabban, 8 West 70th St, NYC 10023.

title: On Death Row, China's Source Of Transplants
description: Sitting in a dimly lit Russian hotel room last month, Huang Peng, a Chinese prison official who had fled across the border just hours before, spoke matter-of-factly about the supply of human organs for the vast majority of transplants in China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSFIELD, ANTHONY RAYMOND
description: MANSFIELD-Anthony Raymond, 58. Of Middletown, NJ on Tuesday, October 16, 2001. Beloved husband of Pasley Fisher Mansfield, loving son of the late Raymond John and Anita Mansfield, devoted father of Kenneth Jude Mansfield, Steven Anthony Mansfield, Michele D'Avanzo and Christina Savastano, dear brother of Arthur Wright Mansfield, loving grandfather of Taylor and Austin Savastano. Services are Saturday, 8:30 AM at Day Funeral Home, 361 Maple Pl, Keyport, NJ, followed by a 9:30 mass at St. Anthony's RC Church, Red Bank, NJ. Interment Mt. Olivet cemetery, Middletown, NJ. Friends may call Friday, 79PM at the funeral home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOVEY, ELEANOR HELEN
description: SOLOVEY-Eleanor Helen. On October 16, 2001. Beloved sister of Sylvia and the late Esther Friend. Graduate of Columbia University. Work honorably discharged from the U.S. Navy, October 1945. Funeral services today 1 PM from Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Gleefully Skewering The Quirks Of Humanity

He died in 1999, and now the Atlantic Theater Company, with whom he had a long relationship, is presenting 10 of his short plays under the rubric ''An Adult Evening of Shel Silverstein.''

description: Andy Pettitte and Paul O'Neill shared one of their last meals as teammates Tuesday night, the conversation inevitably turning to the Yankees and how their level of play rises in October.

title: Keeping Knoblauch in June Proves a Boon in October
description: The Yankees were ready to unload Chuck Knoblauch to the Seattle Mariners in June, ready to jettison their unproductive leadoff hitter for another struggling outfielder and a Class AAA pitcher. They were weary of Knoblauch's failure to get on base, the asset that makes him valuable. They were ready to make a deal for Al Martin and Brett Tomko, slightly more of a return than weekend refills at Starbucks.

description: NEW YORK

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rapper Pleads Guilty
description: Jay-Z, the Grammy Award-winning rap performer, will be placed on probation for three years after pleading guilty yesterday to stabbing a record producer at a Times Square nightclub two years ago. Jay-Z, 31, whose real name is Shawn Carter, admitted to stabbing Lance Rivera, 35, at the Kit Kat Klub on Dec. 1, 1999. Mr. Rivera dropped a civil suit against Jay-Z after they settled out of court for an undisclosed amount. Jay-Z will return to Manhattan's State Supreme Court on Dec. 6 for formal sentencing. An unrelated weapons charge stemming from a gun found in an SUV Jay-Z was riding in last April 13 was dropped on Tuesday. His chauffeur admitted owning the weapon and was sentenced to one year in prison. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Dickinson's Second Home
description: EMILY DICKINSON (1830-1886) is often portrayed as a recluse who never left the austere Dickinson Homestead in Amherst, Mass. This is not quite true: She sometimes went next door to her brother Austin's splendid Italianate villa, the Evergreens. A side door was always kept unlocked for her, and in the ornate parlor she sometimes played her own compositions on the piano.

title: At High-Rise Towers, Views Without Terror
description: WHEN terrorists attacked the World Trade Center, most people nearby fled down stairs and uptown, but Joseph Lombardi did the opposite: despite injuring his leg in the tumult, he headed to Liberty Tower on Nassau Street, one block from ground zero, and took an elevator to his penthouse apartment on the 29th floor.

title: A Close Family's Struggle Becomes a Son's Concerto
description: When the composer Stewart Wallace sat down to create a new concerto in 1996, he was mourning the loss of his aunt Edna Freedman, who had recently died of ovarian cancer. Drawing inspiration from her struggle, Mr. Wallace tried to wrestle art from tragedy, and the result, ''Gorilla in a Cage,'' had its New York premiere on Friday at Carnegie Hall. The piece was played by the National Symphony with the percussionist Evelyn Glennie as soloist.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Center-Right Taking Reins
description: Kjell Magne Bondevik, left, who was prime minister from 1997 to 2000, is set to become the new prime minister on Friday. He heads a center-right coalition that will replace the Labor government of Jens Stoltenberg, who announced his intent to resign after a poor showing in recent elections. Mr. Bondevik said he would form a minority government of his own Christian Democrats and the Conservative and Liberal parties. To stave off no-confidence measures, his coalition will need support from the populist Progress Party. The Conservative Party has more seats in Parliament than the Christian Democrats but ceded the post of prime minister to Mr. Bondevik to secure his cooperation in ousting Labor.

title: Experts Say Spores Won't Spread in Ventilation System
description: Experts on biological warfare and building design said yesterday that it was extremely unlikely that the anthrax spores mailed to Senator Tom Daschle could have been spread in dangerous amounts to the rest of the Hart Senate Office Building through the ventilation system.

title: A Downturn Settles In Downtown; Shoppers Are Indulging, But Not Near Attack Site
description: By the time Jose Hernandez arrived at his job at Broome Street Flowers and Interiors in SoHo on Sept. 11, he had already seen the fiery slashes in the World Trade Center and knew a catastrophe was in the making. Still, he followed his routine, prepping newly bought willow and berry branches for display.

title: Europe Agrees to Belgian Rescue of Sabena
description: The European Commission set aside its past antipathy for state aid to airlines today and approved a stay of execution for Sabena, the bankrupt Belgian airline. The Belgian government, Sabena's principal shareholder, may proceed with a monthlong bridge loan of 125 million euros ($113.5 million) to the airline on favorable terms, the commission said.

title: Essay; Bush's Shanghai Gesture
description: Here are a few do's and don'ts that will help coalition-wary realists measure President Bush's success or failure at this week's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Shanghai.

title: In Woodbridge, Borrowing Doubled Under McGreevey
description: In his campaign for New Jersey governor, James E. McGreevey presents himself as the candidate of fiscal common sense. He derides the major proposals of his opponent, Bret D. Schundler -- to eliminate tolls on the Garden State Parkway and allow parents to use tax dollars for private school -- as risky and outlandishly expensive, while portraying himself as a disciplined budget manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DAVID KELLOG
description: LEWIS-David Kellog. Professor of Philosophy at Princeton, F.A.H.A., Doctor of Letters honoris causa of the University of Melbourne, a frequent visitor, and a constant friend to the Melbourne Philosophy Department. His many friends mourn his loss and offer Steffi our deepest sympathy.

title: Argentina Tries to Swap Bond Debt
description: Shrugging off a warning from two credit agencies, Argentine officials continued to negotiate a plan today with local pension funds and banks to swap as much as $16 billion in high-yield government bonds for securities that pay lower interest but offer stronger guarantees.

title: 4-Alarm Fire Destroys Queens Warehouse
description: A furniture warehouse in Astoria, Queens, was destroyed yesterday in a four-alarm fire, one of the first major blazes that city firefighters have battled since the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, the Fire Department said.

title: Uzbeks Near Border Praise Attacks on Taliban
description: The old man turned away from the fresh vegetables he was considering buying and extended hands browned and thickened by years of picking cotton. He wore the full-length robe and black skullcap that mark Uzbek nationalists and Muslim peasants.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Doubleclick Trims Media Division
description: The Internet advertising agency DoubleClick began eliminating many positions in its media division yesterday in response to a sharp downturn in the ad market, executives close to the company said. The media group represents about 90 of DoubleClick's 1,500 employees, officials said. The DoubleClick chief executive, Kevin Ryan, above, said last week that the company planned to lay off workers in the fourth quarter. The company has been increasing its focus on its e-mail marketing and technology businesses. Mr. Ryan did not return calls for comment. Its shares fell 66 cents, or 8.3 percent, to $7.26. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, ERMA
description: BRENNER-Erma, 1911-2001. An author and educator with a special interest in children's play, sends her last adieux to the many relatives, friends, and colleagues who loved and admired her and to the much larger number of children who profited from her efforts on their behalf. Erma was discovered to have multiple myeloma in July 2001. She died of it on October 15th. Her long life was vibrant and full. A born story teller, she was author of ''A New Baby, A New Life!'' (Christopher Award, 1973), numerous children's stories, and a fictionalized memoir called ''Echoes.'' The crowning achievement of her later years was a children's program called ''Small House,'' a play program for children of elementary school age that served two functions. It brought joy into the lives of the children for whom it was designed and it was a highly successful means of crisis prevention for many children who were emotionally disturbed by current events in their lives. In April 2001 the Parent/Child Center of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute arranged a special meeting for the presentation and discussion of the ''Small House'' program. The meeting was largely attended and enthusiastically received. In addition, an ''Erma Brenner'' prize award was established by a generous friend and admirer for the best paper on children's play. At Erma's request there will be neither funeral nor a memorial meeting to celebrate her accomplishments. She said, ''I don't need a memorial meeting. The April meeting was the best tribute to my work that I could have wished for, and I was there to enjoy it as well.'' Those who wish may contribute to the Parent/Child Center of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, 247 East 82nd Street, New York, New York 10028. For 66 years Erma was the devoted, inspiring, and beloved wife and best friend of Dr. Charles Brenner, who survives her. She is also survived by two daughters, three grandchildren and a newly arrived great-grandson.

Stan Javier, up next, bounced back to the mound and Suzuki danced off second, nearly drawing a throw from Mariano Rivera. Then came one wild pitch, and Suzuki moved to third. Then another, and he scored.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Stolen F.B.I. Documents
description: A Long Island lawyer pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he conspired to receive stolen Federal Bureau of Investigation records about a client under investigation and lied to the F.B.I. about how he got them. The lawyer, Herbert Jacobi, 62, of Dix Hills, was released on a $1 million bond, officials said, shortly after his arrest in June. He faces up to 10 years in prison. The officials said the documents had been stolen by James J. Hill, a former low-level security analyst with the F.B.I.'s Las Vegas office. He pleaded guilty to four separate counts last month.

title: Vote Approves New Powers For Antiterror Investigators
description: The House passed legislation to fight money laundering today, then tonight Congressional negotiators reached a deal that could clear the way for the new antiterrorism surveillance and investigatory powers sought by the Bush administration.

title: More Swissair Problems
description: Just two weeks after Swissair resumed flying after a humiliating two-day grounding for lack of cash to pay its bills, the plan to salvage its core flight operations by transferring them to a financially healthier regional subsidiary, Crossair, is once again in doubt. Cost estimates for the transition have soared to $2.5 billion, and cash to keep Swissair flying until the Oct. 28 takeover date is drying up.

title: They Nap, They Cry. But They'd Like to Direct.
description: Considering that Intel is one of the driving forces behind the digital revolution, the company has an elementary sense of fun.

description: New anthrax alarms shifted away from newsrooms in New York and Florida yesterday to Capitol Hill and Gov. George E. Pataki's office in Manhattan, reversing roles in the nation's most arresting television drama.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTAN, WALTER
description: ROTAN-Walter. Of New York City. Died October 15, 2001. Born in Baltimore, MD. in 1912, sculptor & teacher. Honored with prizes by the Pennsylvania Academy, the National Academy of Design and the Allied American Artists, his sculptures were included in exhibitions at the Art Institute of Chicago, the Metropolitan Museum, the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the Pennsylvania Academy and galleries in New York City. His works are in the collections of museums such as Brookgreen Gardens, S.C.

title: A BLOW TO PEACE
description: Israel's minister of tourism, a leader of the far right, was shot and killed on Wednesday in a stealthy, audacious attack at a hotel here. Stunned and outraged, the Israeli government threatened early today to treat the Palestinian Authority as a terrorist organization ''and to act accordingly'' unless it immediately handed over gunmen blamed for the assault.

title: Part Chandelier, Part Fan And Fully Variable Lighting
description: What do you get when you cross a Frank Lloyd Wright lamp with an Alexander Calder mobile? A chandelier-cum-ceiling fan, far right, handmade by Stephane Pagani of Cotule Lighting Design in Brooklyn. Found at the French Designer Showhouse (47 East 68th Street), the chandelier has three seven-foot arms of ipe wood (a Brazilian teak, pronounced E-pay) that turn at half a revolution per minute. The lights are shaded with sandblasted Murano glass, and because of the asymmetrical spacing, the light changes as the arms move. Mr. Pagani and his wife, Frouwjke, worked on the show house together. He likes making mobile lights. ''The motion energizes the space, makes the house alive,'' he said. The chandelier is $11,200; Mr. Pagani is represented by Clodagh, 670 Broadway (Bond Street). DAVID COLMAN

title: U.S. and China, Entwined in Commerce and Mistrust
description: The coming of jihad to American soil, with jets turned into flying bombs and the mails used to carry anthrax, brings on a strange kind of nostalgia for the cold war. Even at its most frightening moments -- the Berlin blockade, the Cuban missile crisis -- Soviet and American leaders pulled back from the brink. The deterrence doctrine of mutually assured destruction assumed an enemy that, unlike radical Islam's holy warriors, did not welcome suicidal martyrdom as the fast track to paradise.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Deal Lifts Parthus
description: The American depository receipts of Parthus Technologies P.L.C. rose $1.09, or 22.7 percent, to $5.90, after the company, a semiconductor designer in Ireland, said it had formed a partnership with Motorola Inc. Motorola, the No. 2 maker of mobile phones, licensed the Parthus technology, and the two companies will work together on chips that extend battery power in wireless devices. Parthus also said its third-quarter loss widened to $3.25 million, or 0.6 cent a share, from $2.28 million, or 0.4 cent, in the year-earlier period, as a result of research and development costs.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ariba Names A Chief Executive
description: The maker of Internet-commerce software Ariba Inc. promoted its chief financial officer, Robert Calderoni, to chief executive and said its fiscal fourth-quarter sales beat reduced forecasts. Mr. Calderoni, 41, who was also named president, will continue as chief financial officer until the position is filled, the company said. The former chief executive, Larry Mueller, resigned July 19. Ariba said sales in the quarter ended Sept. 30 were $62 million to $63 million, more than the $59 million average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Earlier this year, a First Call estimate projected fourth-quarter sales of $91.7 million.

title: With Ishmael in That Island City; Though Everything Has Changed, Melville's Landlocked Dreamers Linger
description: The book, published 150 years ago today, speaks to you. I don't mean this as an empty gesture of literary piety but as a literal description. That famous first sentence -- ''Call me Ishmael'' -- is in the second person. Someone wants your attention. He is a New York character, and the encounter is one most New Yorkers have had at one time or another. A stranger approaches you on the street and starts talking. It's not entirely clear what he wants, but his speech is rapid and urgent. He tells you his name, though it occurs to you that it may not be his real name. You nod, you look at your watch, you keep walking, quickening your pace, instinctively checking the placement of your wallet or purse. Is he panhandling? Threatening? Is he lost? Crazy? Maybe a little:

title: A Single New Gadget Where Three Would Do
description: The new Handspring Treo is a tiny gadget that packs a mobile phone, a personal organizer based on the Palm OS and a Blackberry-style text messenger into one device. The company will release two models early next year: Treo 180, which has a tiny qwerty-style keyboard, and Treo 180g, which uses the Graffiti handwriting recognition system. Each model will cost about $400, not including wireless service fees. (Handspring says you'll be able to use your existing mobile provider.) Gartner Dataquest, a research firm, recently reported that quarterly shipments of personal digital assistants were down 21 percent from a year ago. But Jeff Hawkins, Handspring's chief executive, says, ''Treo is a breakthrough product in the same way that the Pilot was a breakthrough product.'' It should at least be worth some attention around the water cooler. Andrew Zipern

title: ROADWAY TO SELL A WAREHOUSING UNIT FOR $105 MILLION
description: The Roadway Corporation, a leading trucking company, plans to sell a warehousing and shipment-tracking unit, for $105 million. Roadway, which is buying Arnold Industries of Lebanon, Pa., for $475 million, said it had agreed to sell the business to a group that includes Arnold's chief executive, Edward Arnold. Roadway agreed in August to buy Arnold Industries to add overnight truck shipments as customers request faster, more frequent delivery service.

title: The Hunger Factor
description: American and British forces are aiming their bombs carefully to avoid harming civilians, but the war could still cause a catastrophe in Afghanistan. Food supplies, already inadequate, are dwindling further as relief efforts are disrupted by the intensifying war. The Bush administration needs a better plan for averting large-scale famine and starvation in Aghanistan -- and quickly.

description: Concern about biological terrorism heightened today as preliminary tests showed that 31 workers on Capitol Hill were exposed to anthrax spores from the contaminated letter sent to the office of the Senate majority leader.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl Shot To Death
description: An unidentified 16-year-old girl was shot to death and a bystander wounded after a street dispute with two other young women in northeastern Brooklyn, the police said. The girl, had had an argument with the two other women outside 235 Fountain Avenue earlier in the day, and the two women returned with two young men about 7:45 p.m., the police said. Shots were fired. The girl was hit, as was a 19-year-old woman who was walking by. The girl died at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. The second victim, who was shot in the leg, is in stable condition at Brookdale, a police spokesman said. Eric Atherley of 237 Fountain Avenue said he was sleeping, ''but I woke up when I heard the EMT and the mother of the girl screaming.'' Robert Worth (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Economy Tumbles
description: At least 25,000 jobs were lost in the manufacturing sector in the first four months of this year, a sign of the country's worsening economic plight, according to Barclays Bank, Zimbabwe's largest commercial bank. The Confederation of Zimbabwe Industries warned that more firms will likely close because of recently imposed price controls which have slashed prices of basic goods. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Woods Eager to Play After 6-Week Layoff
description: Having not played tournament golf since Sept. 9, Tiger Woods will return to action today in the National Car Rental Golf Classic in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.

title: Russia Closing 2 Major Posts For Snooping, One in Cuba
description: Scrapping an outdated symbol of its superpower days, the Kremlin said today that it would abandon its largest electronic eavesdropping post in the West, at Lourdes, Cuba, and spend much of the savings on modern weapons for its armed forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTON, DAVID H.
description: WINTON-David H. 29, of Brooklyn Heights, NY, and Wethersfield, CT, died September 11, 2001 at The World Trade Center. David was the beloved son of Joan Wise Winton and the late Peter A. Winton, adored brother of Sara Elizabeth Winton and fiance of Amy Elizabeth Lane, of Manhattan. He was born in Hartford and grew up in Wethersfield. Dave graduated from Wethersfield High School in 1990, where he was an honor student, member of The Student Council, President of the Ski Club and Captain of the baseball and soccer teams. He graduated from Fordham University, College of Business Administration, Bronx, NY, in 1994. While at Fordham he was an honor student, member of The Globe Program, studied at University College, London, and was Chief Executive Officer of the student-run Fordham Federal Credit Union. At graduation he received the CBA Alumni Association Award. Dave was employed by Keefe, Bruyette and Woods, where he was Vice President and Equity Research Analyst. He was a Chartered Financial Analyst, and member of The New York Society of Security Analysts. Amy and Dave planned to be married on November 17, 2001. Dave leaves many relatives and a host of cherished friends across the country. He was a loyal friend with a quick wit and a helping hand whenever needed. A Memorial Mass to celebrate his life will be offered on Saturday, October 20, 2001, at noon in Corpus Christi Church, 601 Silas Deane Highway, Wethersfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The David H. Winton Memorial Scholarship Fund, Fordham University Office of Development and University Relations, 113 West 60th Street, New York, NY 10023-7484, Attention: Patricia Berry. Friends may call Farley-Sullivan Funeral Home, Wethersfield, CT at: 860-563-9999 for directions to the Church.

title: Garcia to Go on Short Rest

That is what Lou Piniella calls Garcia, and that is why he is confident Garcia can pitch well on three days' rest in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series.

description: A gas station chain began selling a Tiki Barber bobblehead doll this week. Up and down New Jersey's Route 17, and not far from where Coach Jim Fassel left his keys and lost his Mercedes, there are giant posters advertising Barber's hand-painted ceramic countenance.

title: TITAN WILL SPIN OFF ITS FOOD-TREATMENT UNIT
description: The Titan Corporation, a satellite communications and information technology company, said it would spin off its SureBeam Corporation food-treatment unit to shareholders. Titan will seek the approval of the Internal Revenue Service for the tax-free distribution in the next few weeks and will complete the spinoff as soon as possible after receiving approval, the company said. SureBeam, which is based in San Diego, makes a device that treats meat, poultry and fruit to kill harmful bacteria.

description: President Bush used the terrorist attacks today to press for a quick vote on new authority to negotiate trade agreements without allowing amendment by the Senate.

She was a member of the National Executive Board of Israel Bonds, a past chair of the Central Ohio Israel Bonds Women's Division & recipient of the prestigious Golda Meir Award. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Rabbi Samuel Rubenstein, rabbi emeritus at Agudas Achim Synagogue in Columbus, Ohio, and to her entire family. title: Early Gilliam, Fright-White Teeth and All
description: Terry Gilliam's early work was all about excess; his animation pieces for ''Monty Python's Flying Circus'' often featured some hapless know-nothing flashing a horizonwide grin before getting squashed by some huge, plummeting object. (In Mr. Gilliam's famous opening of the ''Python'' show, it's a giant foot.)

title: Frederick DeMatteis, 78; Prospered as a Builder
description: Frederick DeMatteis, longtime chairman and chief executive of the DeMatteis Organizations, a large development and construction corporation, died on Tuesday at his home in Old Westbury, N.Y. He was 78.

title: Companies Start Fund to Reward Hospitals for Better Care
description: Within days after the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences shocked policy makers in late 1999 by reporting that mistakes in hospitals were killing tens of thousands of Americans each year, some of the nation's largest companies met and agreed to throw their weight behind efforts to make hospitals safer.

title: Income Doubles at TRW
description: TRW Inc., a maker of air bags, said today that its third-quarter net income more than doubled, to $77 million, because expenses dropped when it laid off workers and closed plants. Sales fell 4.7 percent, to $3.86 billion, led by a decline in auto-related revenue. Net income rose to 61 cents a share, from 26 cents, in the quarter a year ago. TRW, which also makes aerospace and military equipment, said this week that it would cut 3,500 jobs.

title: Impact Of Grounding Jets Is Still Unclear
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration suggested in a speech today that an order to ground all planes on the morning of Sept. 11 had prevented additional jets from being hijacked.

title: Something New To Chew On
description: When I was wandering the children's section at a large bookstore recently, I was astonished at the splendid selections of book books and book toys that very young children can chew on, splash with in the bathtub, pull tabs and stuffed and metal toys from or hear music and all sorts of other noises from and, not incidentally, be read real stories from. The first and most obvious question is, Does all this turn babies into adolescent and adult readers? The answer is that the connecting of words to images certainly doesn't hurt, and that at the least it provides some quality lap time between child and parent.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC TO SELL A MILL AND CUT 190 JOBS
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, a building products maker, plans to sell a pulp mill in Canada and eliminate 190 jobs. The company will also suspend production at some lumber mills in North America for two weeks. The pulp mill, in Chetwynd, British Columbia, stopped operations in April and will remain closed, Louisiana-Pacific said. The company expects to take a fourth-quarter charge of $5 million to $10 million for severance costs. The company, based in Portland, Ore., said more production halts might be necessary.

title: Bush Opposes More Aid Now For New York
description: The Bush administration balked today at providing billions more dollars in new aid to New York this year, in effect quashing any hopes Gov. George E. Pataki might have had that his $54 billion aid request would be considered soon.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Retirement Plan At Michelin
description: The French tire maker Michelin reached an agreement with unions to allow 4,900 employees in France, or 3.8 percent of its work force, to retire early. Under the cost-cutting measures, workers who are older than 56 are eligible to retire by 2006 and would be replaced by 2,000 new workers. The announcement follows a series of layoffs at Michelin, which the company attributes to reduced car production in North America and Europe. In September, Michelin said it would cut 2,000 jobs in the United States, and it recently announced that it would cut 280 jobs in Stoke-on-Trent, England, and 450 jobs in Burnley, England. Michelin shares rose 4.3 percent yesterday. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Senator's Farm Plan Would Tie Subsidies to Need, Not Acreage
description: The ranking Republican senator on agricultural issues today unveiled a new farm bill that would give subsidies to farmers based on need rather than acreage.

title: Tonight's N.F.L. Matchup
description: Buffalo (0-4) at Jacksonville (2-2)

title: 2 Big Banks Register Drops In Earnings
description: Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase reported lower third-quarter earnings yesterday in the wake of last month's terrorist attacks. But both companies made the case that they had performed as well or better than expected under the circumstances, thanks to tight cost control measures like layoffs.

title: Candidates for Governor Have Differences, on Tolls and in Polls
description: A day after a radio debate that turned into a noisy free-for-all, the candidates for governor of New Jersey today sniped back and forth over parkway tolls and a new poll that may or may not show the race tightening.

title: Locking Up The Plastic; Many Americans Cut Back On High-Interest Debt
description: Worried about rising layoffs and a falling stock market, Americans in recent months have cut back on their use of credit cards for the first time in almost 10 years. The trend seems to have accelerated in the weeks since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, bank executives say.

title: Apologetic Robinson to Play
description: A contrite Damien Robinson apologized again today for his arrest on weapons charges Sunday at Giants Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AKIN, ADOLPH
description: AKIN-Adolph. October 15, 2001. We deeply mourn the loss of our beloved Adolph. Adolph was Evalyn's devoted husband and best friend. He was a kind, caring, and gentle uncle to us. We will always remember him. Rest in peace, dear Adolph. Judy, James, and Joan

title: Jay Livingston, 86, Who Wrote Hit Songs With Ray Evans for the Movies, Dies
description: Jay Livingston, the pop composer and lyricist who collaborated with Ray Evans on three movie songs that won Academy Awards -- ''Mona Lisa,'' ''Que Ser, Ser'' and ''Buttons and Bows'' -- died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 86 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Primedia Tries to Recover From Its Internet Party
description: Two years ago, Henry Kravis chose Tom Rogers of NBC Cable to bring Primedia into the digital age. Mr. Rogers promised to remake the ''sleepy little media company,'' the publisher of Seventeen, New York and American Baby magazines.

title: Economic Scene; The stimulus package should fix the unemployment insurance program first.
description: IT is often said that unemployment insurance is the first line of defense in a recession. The line needs some strengthening, however, because the program has not kept up with changes in the work force and has been neglected by many state legislatures.

title: Mixing Palm With Phone: Another Try
description: ASK any 1-year-old: mashing random objects together is fun. Just look at all of the wonderful combinations that have resulted from grown-ups' doing so: clock radios, toaster ovens and Reese's Peanut Butter Cups.

title: The Shanghai Summit
description: President Bush's diplomatic skills will get a workout over the next few days in Shanghai. Instead of talking economics, the usual subject at this annual autumn gathering of 21 Asian and Pacific Rim nations, Mr. Bush will be trying to strengthen the international coalition against terrorism that he has been assembling since Sept. 11. He should use his meetings with other leaders, including Presidents Jiang Zemin of China and Vladimir Putin of Russia, to clarify what help they are prepared to offer and what they expect in return.

title: 'Kind of Blue' Is a Tribute By Parsons
description: The Parsons Dance Company bounded into the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with three new works that were easy on the eye and mind. The most enjoyable was David Parsons's ''Kind of Blue,'' a sleekly constructed quartet set to Miles Davis's ''So What,'' an excerpt from his 1959 album, ''Kind of Blue.''

title: Taliban Chief Urges Troops: Defy 'Infidel'
description: As if to prove that he has survived the heaviest American bombing so far in Afghanistan, the Taliban's supreme leader broke four days of silence today with an appeal to his soldiers not to buckle under pressure from the United States.

title: Punks See Their Reflection in Polished Metal
description: Sum 41 spends a lot of time establishing its heavy-metal bona fides. At Irving Plaza on Sunday night the group asked audience members to stump the guitarist Brown Sound by naming a metal band whose songs he couldn't play. Meanwhile Stevo 32 adorned his drum kit with skeleton heads and wore a long black wig that recalled the former Motley Crue drummer Tommy Lee.

title: Shutdowns, Uncertainties and, Suddenly, Smallpox as a Topic
description: It has been virtually a national mantra: Americans must go about their business as usual, or the terrorists will have won. Whoever the culprits are, they may not have won. But they did seem to be momentarily ahead on Capitol Hill.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the raising of a torn flag from the World Trade Center, in Westwood, N.J., at the funeral of an attack victim, Michael T. Wholey, misstated his job and that of his co-workers. They were Port Authority police officers, not firefighters.

title: Lopez's Homer Starts Braves Rout
description: Miguel Batista wanted to dismiss the notion that the Arizona Diamondbacks advanced to the National League Championship Series merely because of their two overpowering pitchers, Curt Schilling and Randy Johnson. Batista wanted to prove that Arizona was much more.

title: Psychiatrist Calls Killer Unbalanced
description: A psychiatrist testified today that a man charged with shooting his former girlfriend, shortly before she was to marry another man, ''wasn't playing with a full deck.''

title: Moscow Journal; Wired Radio Offers Fraying Link to Russian Past
description: Anyone who still regards this as the land of the balalaika hasn't listened much to its radio stations, where, increasingly, heavy metal competes with Britney Spears and Natalia Oreiro, a singer who gained a cult following from roles in the Argentine soap operas that dominate daytime television here.

title: A Wind Scatters Dancers And Gathers Them Back
description: ''Drumming'' swept along with gusts of gusto.

description: Special Congressional elections held in Massachusetts and Florida produced expected results on Tuesday and left unchanged the narrow edge Republicans hold over Democrats in the House.

title: Budget Crunch; Teaching Photography With Analog Tools
description: JIM GENSHEIMER is in a predicament. As a staff photographer at The San Jose Mercury News, he sees the world of photojournalism moving to digital cameras. But as the new interim director of the photojournalism program at San Jose State University, he sees a school frozen in time. The darkroom was built in 1990, and its faucets had become corroded from photo-processing chemicals. The school replaced the faucets, but what it would really like is a digital lab.

title: Just Because It's Fall Doesn't Mean It's Over
description: WHY do people think gardens stop blooming after Labor Day? Do they think it has something to do with buying new pencils for school? Soccer practice?

description: VERDON-Gwen. One year ago today. Lovingly remembered. Paul

description: The Dow was shaky on Wall Street Tuesday, but the men and women who trade in the Lord's Word were experiencing something of a rally.

title: Canada Pushes Broad Antiterror Measure, Alarming Some Who Fear Erosion of Rights
description: The Canadian government introduced the most stringent antiterrorism legislation in the country's history this week, allowing preventive arrests and broader electronic surveillance.
