description: NORTHWEST

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertiser Favors Merger
description: The Tempus Group said there were no grounds for the WPP Group to invoke a material adverse change clause that would allow it to walk away from its $638 million bid to buy the company. Last week, WPP sought regulatory approval to cancel the deal, arguing that Tempus's business had been severely hurt by the Sept. 11 attacks. Tempus responded by making its own case to regulators, effectively arguing that its business prospects, while suffering a downturn along with the rest of the industry, remained stable. As such, ''there are no grounds for allowing the material adverse change condition to be invoked,'' the company said. A regulatory panel is hearing arguments in the case and is expected to offer a ruling as early as next week.

title: A Prize-Winning Japanese Architect Casts a St. Louis Museum in Concrete
description: The Japanese architect Tadao Ando is known for concrete boxes (churches, art museums) pierced with light. He won the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 1995, but his profile should rise even higher with recent commissions to design the Alexander Calder Museum in Philadelphia and to extend the Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, IRMA (NEE BERGER)
description: KAHN-Irma (nee Berger). Peacefully on October 15, 2001 at age 94. Devoted and cherished mother of W. Harvey Mayer and Beatrice Birnbaum, and their spouses Irene, Barbara and Daniel, much beloved grandmother of Gordon, his wife Katie, Joanna and Rebecca, and great-grandmother of Max. Services on Thursday, 1 PM at Hirsch and Son, 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, ISABEL (VIRSHUP)
description: WERNER-Isabel (Virshup). On October 16, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Louis S. Werner. Loving mother of Rita Gordon, Susan Kaufman and mother-inlaw of Arthur Kaufman. Cherished grandmother to Amanda and Lucy Gordon, Lewis and Jonathan Kaufman. Dear sister of Anne Moore and Mae Zachary. Services Thursday 12:30 P.M. at Riverdale Temple, 246 Street and Independence Ave., Riverdale. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, MILDRED
description: ROTHMAN-Mildred. Age 88. Formerly of Queens, N.Y. Survived by son and daughter-in-law Joel and Vida Peskay and grandchildren Elissa, Joshua (Jessica) and Matthew. Graveside service Friday, 1:30PM, Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. Donations to The New York Times 9/11 Fund would be appreciated.

title: White House Details Plan for $20 Billion for Emergency
description: The Bush administration proposed a plan today for dividing the next $20 billion of emergency government spending among military and domestic needs, and said it did not intend to seek any more money from Congress for the war effort at least for the rest of this year.

title: The New York Times Co. Registers a Sharp Drop in 3rd-Quarter Earnings
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings fell sharply as higher circulation revenue was more than offset by a decline in advertising brought on by the weak economy.

title: Coping With Bioterrorism; New Anthrax Fears
description: One of the most important weapons against public hysteria in a time of crisis is clarity on the part of the government. This week, as word spread that the anthrax sent to Senator Tom Daschle's office had been made by terrorists with a high degree of sophistication, the failure of the Bush administration to fully explain what was happening seemed inexcusable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, JOHN F.
description: JOHNSTON-John F. October 16, 2001, age 79. Talented teacher, UFT activist. Mourned by his family, wife and best friend, Louisa; children, Trevor & Elinor, & son-in-law, Carl. Funeral services will be held Thursday, October 18, 11 AM, at the Plaza Funeral Home, Amsterdam Avenue and 91st St. Donations may be sent to Jewish Labor Committee, 25 E. 21 Street, NY, NY 10010, or Faculty and Friends Campaign of NYU Medical Center, Dr. Edward Katz, 550 1st Avenue, NY, NY 10016.

title: Adopting a Country, Then Crashing Its Best-Seller List
description: Dai Sijie came to France in 1984 to study the history of Western art and instead ended up as France's first Chinese movie director. But by the late 1990's, his career was faltering. His first movie, ''China, My Sorrow,'' was well received but was seen by few people, his second flopped, and after he completed his third its producer went bankrupt. Dismayed and eager to distract himself, Mr. Dai decided to try his hand at fiction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHONBRUN, MARGARET LUCRETIA THOMSON
description: SHONBRUN-Margaret Lucretia Thomson. A longtime resident of NYC and a native of Gainesville, FL. died on October 3, 2001. She was 75. Ms. Shonbrun was an award-winning poet, playwright and journalist. She is survived by five children and 3 grandchildren. Donations may be made to the MS Society in her name.

title: Home Front? Combat? A Mission for Barbie
description: A LOT of people don't remember Army Barbie.

title: 'Sale' Signs Stay Out
description: NEVER in recent memory have so many people looked to home as such a safe haven. So wisdom suggests that they would at least buy a few accent pillows.

description: THE two words used most frequently this week to describe Agenda 2002, the first gathering of computer industry executives since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, were ''sober'' and ''subdued.''

title: Music Appreciation
description: To peddle beer, brewers have sponsored sports teams, emblazoned their brand names on merchandise, conducted beauty contests and invented fanciful sales forces like the Swedish Bikini Team. Now the importer of Heineken beer hopes to do well by doing good with a cause-related marketing campaign centered on music education.

title: Wiggling Fans and Other Ways to Keep a Computer Cool
description: HOT air rises, but none too easily inside computers, because the source of most of the heat -- the silicon chips that run the show -- are buried deep in the machine.

title: Winnie Mandela to Be Arrested in Bank Fraud in South Africa
description: From the elegant halls of Parliament in Cape Town to the dusty, traffic-choked streets of Soweto, it is South Africa's burning question: Is it all over for Winnie Madikizela-Mandela?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSCHEL, MOE
description: WEINSCHEL-Moe. Of Belle Harbor, NY on October 16, 2001, age 84. Beloved husband of Aida for 59 years. Cherished father of Alan and Sara Ameri. Adored father-inlaw of Barbara and the late Bob Ameri. Devoted grandfather of Daniel, Sharon, Lawrence, Jennifer, Adam, Naomi, Jessica, and Abigail. Loving surrogate grandfather to many. A man of many talents, he was a former glassblower, police officer, auto mechanic, business consultant, teacher and salesman. He was also a numismatist and president of American Israel Numismatic Association; member and former officer of Jewish War Veterans; former member of the Board of Temple Beth-El, Rockaway Park; a community activist; and a good friend to all he encountered. There will be a huge gap in many lives. Services October 18, 2001, 12 noon, at Boulevard Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY.

title: In Field Hockey, a Twist on Title IX
description: Before a smattering of about 50 people in the stands at Arthur H. Roberts Field, the leading scorer for the junior varsity field hockey team at Amherst-Pelham Regional High School swerved through the opposition, keeping the ball on the nub of the stick, churning forward. Several parents rose from their seats, their voices laced more with venom than with enthusiasm.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Flights Cut
description: Japan's second-largest carrier, All Nippon Airways, will discontinue nine flights to the United States as the company grapples with a 35 percent decline in international traffic after the terrorist attacks in the United States. All Nippon will merge its daily Chicago and Washington flights and halt two weekly flights to Guam. Though All Nippon is filling fewer seats on its international flights, traffic on domestic routes rose 3 percent in September, partly offsetting the downturn. Japan Airlines, the country's largest carrier, eliminated one-quarter of its trans-Pacific flights this month. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Countryside Prices In a City Basement
description: Country prices for country furniture, accessories and tableware can be found on the East Side. Kenneth Savinski, the owner of Freedom House Antiques, has moved his old and new wares from a large 1830's house on the Eastern Shore of Maryland to the city. Inventory in his minuscule basement shop is replenished from his warehouse. Antique and vintage dressers are $300 to $600, late 19th-century tables, $245 to $380. A pitchfork is $99, and new English mixing bowls (on shelf) are $14 to $49. Pink-and-white lusterware dinner plates from about 1910 are $32 each. Assorted creamware plates and serving pieces (old and new) are available. Twenty percent off everything through Nov. 12. Freedom House, 238 East 58th Street (Third Avenue). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Reaching the Heights of Seating
description: Stacking chairs were once intended only for convention centers and high school cafeterias. Now it appears every designer must do them. They are ''a simple solution for consumers who are strapped for space,'' said Lars Larsen, a distributor for the Chairik, left. Designed by Erik Magnussen, Chairik uses up-to-date techniques for molding plywood. Offered in 10 color laminates, with bent stainless chrome-plated legs, the Chairik is $249; (888) 320-6909 for store information. The ArcoBellini, above, updates the classic Bellini chair, introduced in 1998. This new version has a more elegant shape and comes in six bright colors including red, yellow and violet. It will be available in two weeks for $70; information is available at www.helleronline.com. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

description: VARE-Beatrice. The Faculty, Advisory Council and Alumni Association of the Columbia University School of Social Work note with sadness the death of Beatrice Vare, a member of the Class of 1941. An esteemed alumna and family counselor. She was a generous supporter of the School and the University and dedicated to her profession and the work of many community welfare organizations. Our deepest condolences are extended to her family. Sheila B. Kamerman, Interim Dean

title: Unexplained Ailments at Stuyvesant High
description: Board of Education officials said yesterday that they were at a loss to explain why dozens of students and teachers at Stuyvesant High School had experienced headaches and breathing problems since returning last week to the building, which is four blocks north of the collapsed World Trade Center.

description: By Sept. 25, two weeks after the terror attack on the World Trade Center, volunteers from Canada formed a brigade of brawn, technical skills and heavy equipment -- all headed to ground zero.

description: Wireless telephones are getting so petite that even last year's models are starting to feel as heavy as Soviet Army field phones. Two new offerings due next month from Panasonic can lighten one's load further: the Allure, weighing 2.7 ounces, and the Versio, tipping the scales at 3.1 ounces, are both dual-band wireless phones that pack a lot of features into the tiny handset.

title: Jets Are Wary of Rams' Supercharged Offense
description: St. Louis Rams receiver Isaac Bruce called his friend, Jets cornerback Aaron Glenn, on Tuesday night. He needed three tickets to Sunday's game between the two teams at Giants Stadium. Glenn was ready to cut a sweetheart deal: he would get Bruce the three tickets, if Bruce would let him get three interceptions.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Gambia: 1 Killed In Election Violence
description: As Gambians prepared to vote on Thursday, violence cast doubt on the election's fairness. President Yahya Jammeh, 36, who seized power in a coup seven years ago, is expected to win through the political intimidation that has marked his rule. In dispersing opposition supporters near the capital, Banjul, the police fatally shot one demonstrator, a 25-year-old man. Gambia is one of Africa's tiniest countries, a narrow strip of land that juts into Senegal. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: TriBeCa Brokers, Waiting to Exhale
description: WHEN her plane was coming in from San Francisco, Michelle Bach looked down on Manhattan, ''so clear it was like a cartoon.'' Passengers were craning their necks, she said, trying to glimpse ground zero. ''It was devastating, horrible,'' she said. ''Yet, personally, we were excited to be here.''

title: Letter Sent From U.S. to Kenya Tests Positive for Anthrax
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 18  Kenyan authorities reported today that a letter mailed from the United States to a Nairobi businessman had tested positive for anthrax spores and that two other suspicious envelopes containing white powder were being tested in a government laboratory.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPPMAN, CHARLES DAVID
description: LIPPMAN-Charles David. You've been gone for one year, R.H., yet I feel so blessed. You were my angel who visited me for just a little while, but in those sixteen years, you filled my life with everlasting love and joy. Your Q.T.

Ellen's husband, Murray, a cherished friend and longtime leader of UJA-Federation, currently serves on our Commission on the Jewish People. We extend our deepest sympathies to Ellen and Murray; to Dorothy's husband, Melvin; to Dorothy's daughter, Risa; to her four grandchildren; and to her entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Joan Ginsburg, Chair of the Women's Campaign

McKinney, an outspoken Atlanta congresswoman, has stirred strong emotions among Jews, Muslims and political leaders here by writing a letter to a Saudi prince supporting his call for a re-examination of American policy in the Middle East, which the prince said was an issue leading to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pearson Outlook Falls
description: Hit by a falloff in advertising, Pearson, which owns The Financial Times and a number of educational publications, said annual profits would be ''significantly'' lower than initially forecast. Marjorie Scardino, left, Pearson's chief executive, said the shortfall was almost entirely because of the advertising slump. The company said that full-year profits from its FT Group newspaper business could be down 40 percent if advertising did not recover. Additionally, Pearson invested heavily in online ventures during the dot-com boom but now expects those businesses to lose up to $87 million in the second half, it said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

description: THEY came from Nyack and Ho Ho Kus, not to mention Bushwick and Rego Park. They were nowhere near the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, and they were down the block.

description: On Tuesday, October 16, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Peter Christ. Mr. Christ, a retired police captain, became one of ReconsiDer: Forum on Drug Policy's first members, and quickly became the group's leading spokesperson. This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: Thousands of Out-of-Work People Attend Job Fair
description: By the time the doors opened yesterday morning at the Twin Towers Job Expo, a city-sponsored effort to assist New Yorkers who lost their jobs in the wake of the World Trade Center disaster, the line wound three times around the two square blocks at Madison Square Garden and Pennsylvania Station.

title: U.N. Envoy Says All Options Are Open on a Post-Taliban Afghanistan
description: At his first news conference since being named the United Nations point man on Afghanistan, Lakhdar Brahimi stressed today that the quest was only beginning for what to do about Afghanistan once the bombing was over and the Taliban defeated. Diplomats said his private message has been that ''all options are bad.''

title: U.S. Has 2 Strong Teams in World Tourney
description: When the world championships begin on Monday in Paris, the United States will have two of the favored teams in the Venice Cup for women. One includes Lynn Baker, Karen McCallum, Irina Levitina, Kerri Sanborn, Jill Meyers and Randi Montin. The other, with a Texas nucleus, is almost the same as the one that won the Olympiad Women's Teams in Maastricht, the Netherlands, a year ago: Petra Hamman, Joan Jackson, Robin Klar, Kay Schulle, Mildred Breed and Shawn Quinn. Those two teams may meet in the semifinal, for the conditions of contest rule out an all-American final.

title: EMC Reports Drop in Sales And a Loss In the Quarter
description: The EMC Corporation, a major supplier of data storage systems, said yesterday that sales in the third quarter that ended Sept. 30 had tumbled to $1.21 billion, down 47 percent from a year ago, and that it had its first quarterly loss since 1989.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Cuts And A Freeze
description: Gov. Parris N. Glendening imposed a statewide hiring freeze, ordered departmental spending cuts and delayed $65 million in construction projects. About $6 million in spending for added security since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks contributed to the budget squeeze, Mr. Glendening, a Democrat, said. He also cited a softening national economy and a decline in state tax revenue in the past month. All state departments except those with ''critical security personnel'' must freeze hiring and cut spending by 1.5 percent. The cost-cutting is expected to save $205 million by the end of the state's fiscal year on June 30.

title: Apple Tops Analysts' Lowered Forecasts

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hempstead: Wage Law Passed
description: The village of Hempstead has passed a living-wage law, the third such statute passed on Long Island in recent months. The law, which was approved on Tuesday, goes into effect in January. It requires minimum hourly wages of $9 with medical benefits, or $10.25 without, for village employees, people working under village contracts and employees of companies that receive subsidies, like tax incentives, from the village. The law, which the Hempstead mayor estimates will raise wages for about 150 people, is part of a growing movement to address high living costs by setting standards that are more generous than the federal minimum wage. Last summer, Suffolk County and the town of Oyster Bay, in Nassau County, passed similar laws. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Digital Maps for a World That Suddenly Seems Smaller
description: With place names like Quetta, Peshawar, and Uzbekistan in the news every day, there is renewed interest in world geography. One reliable source of maps for over a century has been National Geographic Magazine. For those without a subscription, National Geographic Maps: The Complete Collection from Encore Software is an eight-disc CD-ROM set of 535 detailed and colorful printable maps as well as information about ethnic peoples, terrain, climate and changes in mapping techniques in the years since the magazine was founded. There are multimedia tours using maps to illustrate topics like ''Europe Through the Ages'' and ''Our Changing Earth and Space.'' For users with an Internet connection, the program links to National Geographic's Map Machine Web site, which provides updates on maps that have changed since the program was finished. The magazine created a new map of Afghanistan over the last month.

title: PHILIP MORRIS PROFIT RISES ON SALES OF PREMIUM BRANDS
description: The Philip Morris Companies said third-quarter profit rose slightly as sales of premium brands like Marlboro increased in the United States while declining currencies hurt results abroad. Net income rose to $2.33 billion, or $1.06 a share, from $2.32 billion, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales climbed 12 percent to $22.4 billion from $20.1 billion. Sales volume to overseas retailers rose 4 percent, fueled by demand in Central and Eastern Europe, though a weaker euro sapped revenue and profit. In the United States, sales jumped 9.3 percent after Philip Morris raised prices in April.

title: When a Tiny Taut Gesture Upstages Demons and Noise
description: A BOY and a girl walk across an old stone bridge, stopping when they reach a section that has collapsed. The boy jumps across the gap, reaches for the other side and pulls himself up. He stretches his arm out and calls out over the roaring wind for the girl to jump across. Nervously she paces the edge, trying to decide whether she can make the jump, then stops and leaps. For a moment it seems she will miss the boy's hand, but he grabs her wrist, almost pulled off the bridge by her weight.

The onetime state official who negotiated the initial contract said the new one invited scandal, but a commission spokesman said the state's ethics laws sufficiently addressed the issue. Ross E. title: Don't Follow The Herd

But when the ring is the stage for Theaterworks/USA, the producer of musicals for children, and the bull is Ferdinand, the flower-smelling hero of the storybook by Munro Leaf and Robert Lawson, then you can be sure that no cape-waving, sword-wielding matador is going to get the better of him.

title: In the Body's Place
description: Most of us have been forced, in the past few weeks, to reconsider the assumptions we have quietly, unconsciously made about death and dying. One of the most basic is the assumption that whatever else death takes away, it leaves behind a body. This is a truth profoundly ingrained in us by religion, by experience, by simple biological order. The body that remains after death becomes a locus for grieving, a comfort, strangely, because its very presence helps define what has been lost. In the rituals that attend burial and cremation, there is a gravity, a certainty, that in time helps replenish those who live on.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: False-ID Charges
description: A man and a woman have been arrested and accused of making hundreds of false driver's licenses, identification cards and other documents out of a Jackson Heights storefront, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said. After an undercover investigation, the accused -- Adriana Martinez, 34, of Flushing, and Arnaldo Rinaldi, 54, of Manhattan -- were found on Oct. 11 with three computers, photographic equipment and more than 200 forged identification documents, the district attorney said. Richard Spivack, Ms. Martinez's lawyer, said his client was not guilty and that he doubted whether the prosecutors ''could make their case.'' Richard Horowitz, the lawyer for Mr. Rinaldi, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.

title: AT&T IS SELLING ITS STAKE IN CABLEVISION
description: AT&T is raising $1.5 billion to pay down debt by selling its 30 percent stake in the Cablevision Systems Corporation, the largest cable television operator in the New York City area. AT&T sold 22 million shares for $36.05 each, raising $793.1 million. AT&T raised an additional $969.4 million selling units that are convertible into the rest of its Cablevision shares through a trust. AT&T got the stake when it bought Tele-Communications Inc., whose chairman was John C. Malone, in 1999. Earlier this year, AT&T asked Cablevision to let it sell the stake so it could get money to pay down debt, which totaled $39.5 billion as of July. Shares of Cablevision, based in Bethpage, N.Y., had fallen 37 percent since May 31. The shares fell 7 cents, to $35.98, today.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Amusement-Park Injuries
description: The number of serious injuries at New Jersey amusement parks has declined in the past four years, according to a new state report by the Division of Codes and Standards. The most recent statistics, as of Sept. 3, show that there were 6 serious injuries in 2001, up from 3 in 2000, but down from 12 in 1999, 16 in 1998 and 24 in 1997. Serious injuries are defined as a broken bone or an injury requiring an overnight stay in the hospital. Officials attribute the decline to more stringent inspections before a ride is opened and while it is in operation, as well as strict reporting obligations.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Leaves Insurer
description: Britain's fifth-largest insurer, the Legal and General Group, said a top executive, David Rough, 50, would retire next year. Mr. Rough, group director of investments, overseeing some 163 billion in assets, is credited with building Legal and General into a top seller of index-tracking funds in Britain, second only to Barclays Global Investors. He will be succeeded by Tim Breedon, 43, who is currently the managing director of the index fund division. Mr. Breedon will assume his new role on Jan. 1, but Mr. Rough will remain through June to help the transition. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Influential American Muslims Temper Their Tone
description: One is an African-American who guided his followers away from black nationalism toward mainstream Islam. Two are brothers from Egypt who settled in Los Angeles nearly 30 years ago. A fourth is a white convert, born in California, who bridges Eastern and Western intellectual currents.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASEY, ELIZABETH F.
description: CASEY-Elizabeth F. 10/19/601/30/98. Our Lizzie, the bonds of love are eternal and you live in our hearts forever. We cherish the memories of your vitality, strength, feistiness and love for family and friends. We are thankful for having had you but you left us too soon and we miss you so. The Casey Family

title: Link Suspected in Anthrax and Hijackings
description: Investigators pursuing the anthrax exposure cases in New York, Washington and Florida say they suspect that the rash of contaminated letters is related to the Sept. 11 attacks and are investigating the possibility that Al Qaeda confederates of the hijackers are behind the incidents.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Surreal Fable Considers The Realities Of Prejudice
description: As emotional browbeating goes, nothing beats the efficiency with which the movies can stir up fear. And the kind of fear evoked by ''Focus,'' Neal Slavin's expressionistic adaptation of Arthur Miller's 1945 novel about anti-Semitism and demagogy, is acute social paranoia. In spite of the screenplay's one-note didacticism, the movie's nightmarish atmosphere is intense enough to box you into a scary corner.

title: Bausch & Lomb Profit Up
description: One-time gains lifted Bausch & Lomb's third-quarter profit 58 percent, but earnings from operations fell once more because of slowing demand for contact lenses and laser eye surgery equipment.

title: Tribute for Isaac Stern
description: Carnegie Hall will present a tribute to the violinist Isaac Stern on Oct. 30 at 3 p.m. Mr. Stern was central in saving Carnegie from destruction in 1960 and had been the hall's president since then. He died on Sept. 22.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Wedding-Day Homicide
description: Jurors are scheduled to begin deliberations today in the murder trial of a man who fatally shot his former girlfriend on her wedding day in 1999. After closing arguments here in State Superior Court yesterday, Judge William C. Meehan told the 12 jurors that they could convict the defendant, Agustin Garcia, 49, of North Bergen, of the lesser charge of manslaughter. But, he said, the jurors could do so only if prosecutors failed to disprove four points: that Mr. Garcia was provoked; that the provocation impassioned him; that he did not have time to calm down; and that he did not calm down before firing the three shots that killed Gladys Ricart, 39. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Reagan National Airport Will Expand Flight Schedule
description: Flight operations at Ronald Reagan National Airport will be expanded to an additional 18 cities on Oct. 26, the Department of Transportation said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTNER, FLORENCE
description: WITTNER-Florence. Beloved wife of David; loving mother of Honorable Bonnie Wittner and Ilene S. Wittner of New York City; cherished sister of Conrad Cohen, Anne Gainen and Frances Goldberg. She was a beautiful and gracious lady. Graveside services at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, on Sunday, October 21, at 11:30AM. The family will receive friends on Sunday from 6PM at 320 Central Park West.

title: An Afghan Story
description: To the Editor:

title: UTILICORP UNITED TO GET ITS FIRST UTILITY IN EUROPE
description: UtiliCorp United Inc. and an unidentified partner have agreed to buy Midlands Electricity in Britain from the FirstEnergy Corporation for $362 million and $1.7 billion in assumed debt to give UtiliCorp its first utility in Europe. UtiliCorp, which runs utilities in seven states, said the transaction depended on the completion of FirstEnergy's purchase of GPU Inc., Midlands's current owner. FirstEnergy would use the proceeds to pay off debt, said a spokesman, Ralph DiNicola. The purchase would give UtiliCorp a leading British utility and a stake in a power plant close to London. UtiliCorp, based in Kansas City, Mo., has already bought and expanded electric and natural gas utilities in Australia, New Zealand and Canada. GPU, based in Morristown, N.J., has been trying to sell Midlands for more than a year. FirstEnergy, based in Akron, Ohio, expects the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve the GPU acquisition this month, Mr. DiNicola said.

title: Clemens's Hamstring Is a Question Mark
description: The Yankees won't get a true read on the condition of Roger Clemens's right hamstring until he pitches Game 4 at Yankee Stadium Sunday. But Clemens worked out here early this afternoon with Andy Pettitte and Brian McNamee, and he looked all right as he moved around the outfield.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, FRANCES CLAUDET
description: JOHNSON-Frances Claudet. Died peacefully at her home on Wednesday, October 17, 2001, during sunset, her favorite time of day. She was the beloved wife of the late Worthington Johnson. The daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hayman Claudet of Ottawa & Victoria, Canada, Mrs. Johnson was a former Olympic figure skater (1932 Lake Placid) and was choreographer for the original Shipstad & Johnson Ice Follies for 33 years. She was a member of the Country Club of Fairfield, the Lyford Cay Club, Bahamas; the Colony Club, New York, and The Maycourt Club, Ottawa, Canada. She is survived by her sister, Mrs. Norman Gilchrist of Toronto, Canada; a stepson, Worthington Johnson Jr. of Greenwich, CT.; three stepdaughters, Marina Sutro of Nantucket, MA., Joan Stott of North Palm Beach, Florida, and Margo Johnson of Delray Beach, FL. and eight step-grandchildren. A gathering will be held at the Country Club of Fairfield, CT on Sunday, October 21, 2001 at 5:30 PM. Memorial donations may be made in her memory: Wakeman Boys and Girls Club, 385 Center Street, Southport, CT. 06490.

title: Nations Rush to Meet Germ War Threat
description: The rash of anthrax scares and hoaxes that has swept around the world has driven governments into an intense review of public health planning.

title: War on Terror Fuels Political Feuds in Malaysia
description: Sahimah sells Islamic books, tapes and head scarves from her sidewalk kiosk here. But pride of place is reserved for a new arrival: T-shirts emblazoned with Osama bin Laden's face and the phrase ''Man of the World,'' available in adult and children's sizes.

title: Her Name Still Rings A Bell
description: THE preadolescent girl in the faded photographs has long curls, a noble profile and an expression of intelligence and good humor. But who could have known then, a century ago, that her name would live on long after she was largely forgotten, on some of the best-known automobiles in the world?

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Capital Garden

title: Biggest Surprise For Jets Is Coles
description: Keyshawn Johnson still hovers over the Jets like an unreachable ghost. They drafted Santana Moss in the first round this year to replace him, and signed Matthew Hatchette during free agency to provide Johnson's size. As a result, Laveranues Coles, last year's third-round pick who had had the word troubled attached to his name with regularity, wondered what the Jets had in store for him, and braced for his slide down the depth chart.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Anthrax Investigation

title: Experts Adjust Approach To Each New Anthrax Case
description: The response to the new anthrax case at CBS News was decidedly lower-key than the response to the very similar case at NBC last week, health officials said yesterday, because epidemiologists are applying the lessons they have learned since they began their investigation.

title: He May Think It's Passion, But She Knows It's Science
description: Last spring the Pulitzer Prize for drama went to a play about a mathematical proof. Last year New York imported a London stage hit about Heisenberg's uncertainty principle. So why not a play about intracytoplasmic sperm injection? But that drama, ''An Immaculate Misconception,'' doesn't come close to the depth of ''Proof'' or ''Copenhagen.'' It's a competent, straightforward but workmanlike play, written by Carl Djerassi, the Stanford University chemistry professor known as the father of the birth-control pill, now 77 and writing what he calls ''science in fiction.''

title: More 'Godfather' Than Ever
description: DVD was on another of its surges this week. Multidisc editions of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," "Star Wars: Episode I  the Phantom Menace" (released on Tuesday by Fox), "The Godfather DVD Collection" and "The Terminator" crowd the best-seller list. (Will video never tire of "The Terminator"?)

title: In the War of Nerves, the Capitol Is a Front
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil declined on increasing evidence that a slowing world economy was hurting energy demand. In New York, crude oil for November delivery fell 50 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $21.31 a barrel.

title: Case Offered Odd Mix: Patriotism And Anger
description: When they saw it, they knew: the attack on the World Trade Center was the work of Osama bin Laden. The two women said they had good reason to believe this. After all, they had sat through five months of testimony about Mr. bin Laden and his terrorist group as jurors in the embassy bombings trial.

title: A Governor Works in Mysterious Ways
description: Here in Minnesota, our governor has gone under cover, so far as we can figure out. The governor -- who I will refer to as Larry so as to throw terrorists off the trail -- had a fit in New York recently when he flew there for a photo op at Ground Zero, a trip paid for by ABC-TV, which then got exclusive rights to film the governor's grief and concern. When a few Minnesota reporters questioned him on these arrangements, Larry said he would never speak to any of them ever again. Later, he amended this to say that he would speak to some of them but never with tape recorders present.

title: Jazz Clubs Swing Back to Life
description: TIMES in jazz are hard enough. Chain-store music retailers are taking fewer and fewer jazz albums. Back catalogs are permanently endangered as parent companies of labels like Blue Note, Atlantic and Verve shift among new mergers and new top executives. Jazz clubs are becoming harder to sustain, and after the flowering of new jazz spots around Manhattan in the mid- and late-90's, the attrition process had already begun. Then downtown fell apart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, CHARLES JR.
description: IRWIN-Charles Jr. October 17, 2001. Major USMC (retired). Beloved husband of Jane Darlington Irwin. Devoted father of Charles D. Irwin and his wife Dona. Cherished grandfather of Carter, Robert and Roger. He graduated from Schreiner Military Academy and Southern Methodist University, class of 1942. Decorated Combat Marine Corps Officer in the Pacific Theatre during World War II & The Korean Conflict. Partner of the Wall St. firm W.C. Langley Co. An ardent student of history and a friend to all who knew him. Service on Tuesday, October 24th, 10 AM at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Avenue and 53rd St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Marine Corps. Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 3008, Princeton, New Jersey 08543, or to St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Tram Is Over Budget
description: A tram connecting the Camden and Philadelphia waterfronts will cost an additional $6 million, or more than 20 percent, over the original budget, a Delaware River Port Authority official said yesterday. Changes in contracts and unexpected construction obstacles led to the increases, a spokesman for the Port Authority said. The authority's board of commissioners approved the extra funds on Wednesday, bringing the total for the project to $32 million. The tram, expected to be completed by 2003, will carry passengers about a mile across the Delaware river. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Some Wholesalers Rationing Their Shipments of Antibiotic
description: Two of the nation's three largest drug wholesalers say they are limiting the distribution of Cipro, the antibiotic recommended for treating inhaled anthrax, to prevent hoarding.

title: Willem de Kooning and John Chamberlain -- 'Influence and Transformation'
description: PaceWildenstein

title: Gateway Reports Loss of $520 Million in Third Quarter
description: Continuing its struggle to make money selling personal computers, Gateway reported a wide quarterly loss yesterday as revenue fell to nearly half the level of the comparable period last year.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Cemex Drops TPI Polene Deal
description: Cemex, the world's third-largest cement manufacturer, has withdrawn from a deal to buy a $300 million controlling stake in TPI Polene, the Thai cement company. TPI Polene's steering committee rejected Cemex's offer because it asked creditors to forgive $300 million of TPI's $1.12 billion debt. The offer expired on Wednesday night. Cemex officials would not say that they were entirely out of the deal. Cemex runs a small plant in Thailand called Cemex Thailand. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Suit On Workplace Rules
description: A coalition of business organizations is challenging workplace ergonomics rules adopted in May 2000 by the State Labor and Industries Department. The group, Washington Employers Concerned About Regulating Ergonomics, filed suit in Thurston County Superior Court, saying the rules, intended to address workplace hazards that the state says injure 50,000 workers a year, are unscientific. Businesses are required to comply with the rules by July 2002. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TiVo In Licensing Deal With Sony
description: The Japanese electronics giant Sony and TiVo Inc. announced a seven-year licensing pact giving Sony rights to include TiVo personal digital recording technology in its consumer electronics products, aiding TiVo's efforts to develop a licensing business and promote a technical standard. TiVo's technology allows TV viewers to record, replay and pause live programming. The companies did not release financial details of the agreement, but TiVo's chief executive, Mike Ramsay, said in a conference call that he expected TiVo to get $10 million to $15 million in revenue during the deal's first year. TiVo's shares rose 99 cents, or 21.8 percent, to $5.54. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Bush Officials Step Out in Force In Effort to Calm Anthrax Fears
description: After more than a week of sometimes conflicting information from federal authorities about the threat of bioterrorism, Tom Ridge, the Bush administration's new domestic security chief, and other senior health and law enforcement officials stepped forward today to try to calm public fears about anthrax.

title: Experts Say Cipro Overuse Could Lead To Problems
description: Infectious disease experts are increasingly concerned that overuse of the antibiotic Cipro by people worried about anthrax may cause a second wave of health problems.

title: Anthrax Is Found In 2 More People
description: Two more people in the New York region have tested positive for cutaneous anthrax, a CBS News aide in Manhattan and a postal worker in Trenton, cases that seem to fit a broader pattern that began to emerge last week, when the first New York anthrax case was confirmed, officials said yesterday.

title: The Rifle and the Veil
description: Anyone who has paid attention to the situation of women in Afghanistan should not have been surprised to learn that the Taliban are complicit in terrorism. When radical Muslim movements are on the rise, women are the canaries in the mines. The very visible repression of forced veiling and loss of hard-won freedoms coexists naturally with a general disrespect for human rights. This repression of women is not about religion; it is a political tool for achieving and consolidating power.

title: Beauty, Finely Honed
description: In ''Treasury of the World: Jeweled Arts of India in the Age of the Mughals,'' more than 300 examples of jeweled objects from the Kuwait National Museum are displayed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Silent Echoes From Sept. 11; John Jay Has a Special Link With Many Who Died
description: John Jay College of Criminal Justice was shaken to its soul by the events of Sept. 11. Its very mission is bound up with the work of police officers and firefighters, and more than 100 of its alumni and students were lost in the collapse of the World Trade Center.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW JERSEY

title: U.S. Wireless Talks Go On, With Court Deadline Today
description: Federal officials and executives from several wireless communications companies were still trying to reach a settlement yesterday over the disputed ownership of $16 billion worth of wireless spectrum licenses.

title: Kenneth L. Hale, 67, Preserver of Nearly Extinct Languages
description: Dr. Kenneth Locke Hale, a master of more than 50 languages and the keeper of aboriginal tongues in danger of vanishing with their speakers, died on Oct. 8 at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 67.

title: Russia and U.S. Optimistic on Defense Issues
description: Russia and the United States signaled tonight that they were near a breakthrough on the key strategic issues that had divided the two countries since President Bush came into office, in particular Washington's plans to build missile defenses and Russia's troubled relations with an expanding NATO alliance.

title: Glittering Prizes From the East, Melding Metals and Cultures
description: If bedazzlement is the first and perhaps the better part of learning, at least in art, expect to learn a great deal from ''Treasury of the World: Jeweled Arts of India in the Age of the Mughals,'' a sumptuous exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The show is a visual feast.

title: Woman at New York Post Tests Positive for Anthrax Exposure
description: An employee of The New York Post and a postal worker in New Jersey today became the latest Americans diagnosed with a skin form of anthrax, which was previously traced to the offices of NBC and CBS in New York City and the Capitol Hill office of Senate Majority Leader Tom Daschle in Washington.

title: Clemens's Hamstring Is Still a Question Mark
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 18 — The Yankees won't get a true read on the condition of Roger Clemens's right hamstring until he pitches Game 4 at Yankee Stadium Sunday. But Clemens worked out here early this afternoon with Andy Pettitte and Brian McNamee, the strength and conditioning assistant, and this much is for sure: Clemens can throw the heck out of a football.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Microsystems Posts Loss
description: As expected, Sun Microsystems Inc., which makes servers that run Web sites and corporate networks, posted a fiscal first-quarter loss as sales slid 43 percent. The loss in the period ended Sept. 30 was $180 million, or 6 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $456 million, or 13 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell to $2.86 billion from $5.05 billion, the company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said. Sun said earlier this month that quarterly sales had missed targets and that its loss would be wider than analysts expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIRDEN, LILLIAN SUDLER
description: VIRDEN-Lillian Sudler. Born in Sussex County Delaware, died on October 17, 2001 in her 108th year. Devoted wife of the late Prospere Shelton Virden, loving mother of Ellen Virden White and the late Prospere S. Virden, Jr. and Suzanne V. Patterson. She is survived also by 13 grandchildren and 24 great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, October 20 at 12:30PM, Barratts Chapel, Frederica, Delaware. Contributions in her memory may be made to Historic Houses of Odessa, Odessa Delaware and the Amercan Red Cross

title: Etta Jones, Jazz Standards Vocalist, Dies at 72
description: Etta Jones, a great and permanently underrated jazz singer who for three decades toured constantly with her musical partner, the saxophonist Houston Person, died on Tuesday at her home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. She was 72.

title: Detention and Accountability
description: The continuing terrorism threat justifies aggressive efforts by the Justice Department to get to the root of the Sept. 11 attacks and to prevent future disasters. It does not justify the department's refusal to provide basic information about the hundreds of people who have been arrested and detained.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From figuring out a mildew odor to a jeep that's losing its get-up-and-go, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Tyco's Earnings Fall but It Beats Estimates
description: Tyco International said yesterday that its income had fallen 28 percent in its most recent quarter because it had a gain in the year-earlier period from the sale of a stake in its fiber optic cable business.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Wednesday about second-half earnings for Reuters carried an erroneous credit. It was by Bloomberg News, not by Reuters.

title: QWEST COMMUNICATIONS TO PURCHASE KPNQWEST SHARES
description: Qwest Communications International Inc. agreed to buy 14 million shares of KPNQwest N.V. for $64 million as KPNQwest expands operations in Europe. Qwest said it would pay $4.58 a share, and its principal shareholder, the Anschutz Company, will buy an additional six million shares at the same price. The move comes as KPNQwest said it would buy units of Global TeleSystems Inc. for $580 million. ''Owning a larger stake in KPNQwest is a well-timed strategic opportunity,'' Qwest's chief executive, Joseph Nacchio, said.

title: Sales Fall At Eli Lilly; Merck's Profit Rises by 6.1%
description: Eli Lilly & Company said here today that its third-quarter profit fell as it lost almost half its American sales of the antidepressant Prozac to cheaper generic versions.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: Independence Foe Returns
description: One of the most notorious leaders of the anti-independence militias, Nemecio Lopes de Carvalho, returned from self-exile in Indonesian West Timor, along with hundreds of his followers, two years after participating in violence that ravaged East Timor after it voted for independence in 1999. The government of East Timor has been negotiating for nearly a year with militia leaders, offering reconciliation and a fair trial. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: French Uproar Over Right to Death for Unborn
description: During the 18 years of his fragile life, Nicolas Perruche has had little contact with the world around him. He cannot hear or speak and is largely blind. His heart is weak, and he moves only when carried or put into a wheelchair.

title: Wines of the Week
description: Seems like last year's millennium celebrations are a distant memory, but you'll be seeing the date again as wines from the landmark vintage make their appearance on store shelves. Here are some 2000s that are both easy on the wallet and welcome on the dinner table:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Nobody's calling us unilateral anymore. That's kind of gone away for the time being; we're so multilateral it keeps me up 24 hours a day checking on everybody.''

title: Schundler Record: Taxes Held Down, but at a Cost
description: At almost every campaign stop, Bret D. Schundler recounts how he held property taxes down in his eight and a half years as mayor here by reforming government to make it more efficient.

title: The Big City; Feeding Workers, Not Patrons
description: TIM ZAGAT was doing a firsthand survey of the restaurants downtown, and he did not like the empty tables he saw on Wednesday night. Some of the city's top-rated restaurants were offering discount meals and still weren't full. By his count, 30 downtown restaurants were out of business, and another three dozen were closed and in danger of not reopening.

title: 'Cool & Crazy'
description: Directed by Knut Erik Jensen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMEO, DOMENICK R.
description: ROMEO-Domenick R. On October 17, 2001. Dom has gone to the ''big cutting room in the sky.'' Forever in tandem with his wife Grayce, most loving & hip father of Erica and Nat, Marc and Leane, Peter and Helene, proud grandfather of Erin, Ethan, Lucas, Eden and Grayce. Also survived by his sister Mary Senyk. Dad, call us when you get there. Funeral Mass Friday, 11 AM at Queen of Peace R.C. Church, Flushing, NY. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY.

title: Top Executives Are Leaving Agencies
description: Top executives are leaving agencies as their posts are eliminated.

title: New York City Jobless Rate Jumps to 6.3%
description: The effects of the World Trade Center disaster are only beginning to show up in economic statistics, but already the unemployment rate in New York City has surged, the New York State Department of Labor announced yesterday.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Hijacking-Anthrax Tie Sought

title: Afghan Aid Now Allowed To Cross Uzbek Border
description: As a United Nations convoy carrying 40 tons of relief aid left the capital here for the border city of Termez, the Uzbek government said today for the first time that it would open its fortified border to allow aid supplies to cross into northern Afghanistan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about third-quarter results for The New York Times Company misstated the operating profit of the company's online division, New York Times Digital. It was $786,000 ($6.1 million was the figure for the company's broadcast business).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURBERG, DR. JESSIE
description: TURBERG-Dr. Jessie, died on Wednesday, October 17, 2001, in Glen Cove. She was in her mid 80's. She was married to the late William Cohen. She is survived by her daughter, Nina Cohen-Ryan, her son-in-law, Philip D. Ryan, and her three grandchildren, Rebecca, Sean and Ben. Born in the time when opportunities for women were few, Jessie created the world she envisioned. Structural barriers did not limit her. With New York City as the fuel behind her soul, she achieved enormous success and changed the course of people's lives, over and over again. She was a champion of the family and worked tirelessly to better relationships for families. She did this as a professor at NYU, as a teacher and supervisor at the Ackerman Family Institute, and as a private clinician. She measured who she was by what she gave to others. Jessie was the kind of woman who loved silk and elegance and intellectualism, hard work and cherished creativity. She was the greatest fan for those she loved and when speaking of her family, she would say that her heart ''burst with pride.'' Today we honor her and our hearts burst with pride for all the memories, for all the moments and for all the love that her life brought into everything she touched. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in her name to the American Cancer Society.

title: Television Bureau Chief Leaves Anonymity Behind
description: KOFI ANNAN threw his annual reception for journalists at his Sutton Place home last week and a lot of the stars were there. So was Ghida Fakhry, who covers New York and the United Nations for Al-Jazeera. Her prestige has gone up enormously since she no longer has to explain to people whom she works for. Peter Jennings went over to her to talk.

title: In the War of Nerves, the Capitol Is a Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Threats Don't Deter Visitors to California Sights
description: While anxieties may be soaring on the East Coast after a series of anthrax scares, from the vantage of the Disneyland park here, things did not seem much scarier to Angie Davis than the crowded and newly redecorated Haunted Mansion behind her.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's response to anthrax fears referred imprecisely to the closings of government offices in Washington. While all six House and Senate office buildings were closed for further screening, the Capitol was not closed.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about plans to increase the supply of drugs to counter anthrax misstated a recommended dose of antibiotics for treating the inhaled form. The recommendation, from a panel convened at Johns Hopkins University in 1998, calls for 100 milligrams of doxycycline every 12 hours, not 1,000 milligrams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, WALTER H. JR.
description: JOHNSON-Walter H. Jr. Business executive in tourism, communication, marketing and transportation. A Notre Dame graduate, a Marine veteran, executive at American Airlines, Capital Airlines, Interpublic, a director at TIACA, TIANS, a director at Marymount College, Harvey School, Stowe School, and the graduate school at Syracuse University, a lecturer at Harvard, Syracuse, Virginia, Michigan State, and many others, an advisor to presidents, a great husband, parent and grandparent. Services at St. Aloysius Church, New Canaan, CT. on Monday, October 22 at 11 A.M. Donations in lieu of flowers to Walter and Marcelle Johnson Fund, Harvey School, Katonah, NY 10536.

title: Jeter Is Quietly Playing Through Pain
description: Derek Jeter follows the same boring but necessary routine after every game. He tosses his uniform on the floor, he hobbles into the trainer's room, he gets enough ice to equip a weekend's worth of barbecues attached to his right shoulder and left leg, and he limps back out and answers questions about himself and the Yankees.

title: Dial's Sale Not Imminent
description: The Dial Corporation, the consumer products company that put itself up for sale in August, said today that a transaction was not imminent after its third-quarter loss widened because of costs from the sale of its cosmetics and lotions business. The loss widened to $185.4 million, or $2.03 a share, from $26.2 million, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 12 percent, to $430.5 million from $385.6 million. The chief executive, Herbert Baum, has pared Dial's product offerings to eliminate slow sellers, like Sarah Michaels lotions and Freeman cosmetics, which were sold in August. While the moves will help Dial top forecasts for this year and 2002, Mr. Baum said a sale of the whole company might not be near and that he was willing to stay on through 2003. Dial's board decided in August to put the company up for sale.

title: Art in Review
description: Willem de Kooning and John Chamberlain

title: World Briefing | Europe: England: No Right To Die
description: In a test of England's law against euthanasia, a three-judge High Court panel turned down a terminally ill woman's request to allow her husband to help her die without being prosecuted for assisted suicide, which carries a maximum 14-year jail term. Diane Pretty, 42, who suffers from motor neuron disease and is paralyzed from the neck down, argued that being forced to endure degrading treatment infringed her privacy and human rights. Lord Justice Tuckey said her human right was ''to live with dignity, not die with dignity.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Eli Manning Inherits the Reins at Ole Miss
description: From the juke joints of the Delta to the feed stores of northern Mississippi, he is called Archie's boy, a son of one of sports' most famous Sons of the South. In Tuscaloosa, Ala., in Knoxville, Tenn., and in every other castle in the Southeastern Conference football kingdom, he is Peyton's brother.

title: Gaffe Can't Dim Soriano's Good Impression
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 18 — Alfonso Soriano loved playing shortstop, and in the spring of 2000, when his name became a part of all the Yankees' substantive trade talks — Jim Edmonds, Darin Erstad, Sammy Sosa — his desire to stay in that position might have outweighed his desire to play with the Yankees.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Menem Declines Immunity Offer
description: Newly elected Senator Eduardo Menem offered to step down and give his seat to his brother, former President Carlos Sal Menem, left, giving Mr. Menem parliamentary immunity on charges of conspiracy to sell arms to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995. The former president, now under house arrest, was elected last Sunday in La Rioja province as a stand-in should an elected senator resign or otherwise leave his post. Mr. Menem thanked his brother but said he was confident he would be cleared by the judicial system. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Merrill Set for Changes That Will Cost Thousands of Jobs
description: Signaling that the Stan O'Neal era has begun in earnest, Merrill Lynch & Company started preparing investors yesterday for big changes in its operations that will inevitably involve eliminating thousands of jobs.

title: Call by Torre Unorthodox But Effective

title: Bush Meets China's Leader and Emphasizes Need to Fight Terrorism Together

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Official Slain In Aceh
description: In the latest assassination of a government official in the province of Aceh, gunmen riding on two motorcycles shot dead Muclis Ali, the district secretary for the town of Lhokseumawe, which is home to a large petrochemical complex operated by Exxon-Mobil Corp. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Microsoft's Profit Report Beats Wall St. Estimates
description: Microsoft reported quarterly profits yesterday that surpassed Wall Street's expectations -- ignoring, as most securities analysts do, a big charge for bad investments in telecommunications and cable-television companies. And Microsoft executives delivered an optimistic outlook for the company's prospects, despite further weakening in the economy and the personal computer business in the aftermath of terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.

Multidisc editions of ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' ''Star Wars: Episode I -- the Phantom Menace'' (released on Tuesday by Fox), ''The Godfather DVD Collection'' and ''The Terminator'' crowd the best-seller list. title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Bus Hijacking Foiled
description: Passengers on a Greyhound bus bound for Nashville from Portland, Ore., thwarted what the police described as a hijacking attempt when they overpowered a man who had grabbed the steering wheel. Several passengers wrestled with the man before he and a woman with him ran off the bus about 15 miles east of Salt Lake City. State troopers later arrested the couple, identified as Troy Matzek, 34, and Becky Hyde, 25, both of Wichita, Kan., near a downtown Salt Lake truck stop. Officers said Mr. Matzek probably had a mental problem. He and Ms. Hyde were charged in a federal court with carjacking. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: SAP Reports A Loss
description: A leading maker of business-management software, SAP A.G., surprised investors with a third-quarter profit drop. Third-quarter net income fell 55 percent on lower license revenue, acquisition costs and losses at a partner, Commerce One, a spokesman said. Analysts had expected profit to almost double. The co-chief executive, Henning Kagermann, above, assured investors just four weeks ago that the company was on track to meet its forecast after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

That may not be the sort of music you would expect to hear in such a place. But then the Blue Iguana isn't just any old West Coast fleshpot but a microcosm of this sad, lonely world and its lost female souls who cater to male lust.

Other cities include London (starting at $399, at the Central House), Paris (from $399, Hotel Veronese) and Venice (from $649, Hotel Capri). Applicable dates vary; in most cases, they are from November through mid-December. In each city, there is a choice of hotels at differing prices, from standard to superior. Rates, which are per person, double occupancy, include hotel taxes and service charges; weekend surcharges and departure taxes are extra. Flights from Miami, Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles cost more; (800) 927-3876 or www.europeexpress.com .

The role of Beverly Donofrio in the film, adapted from Ms. Donofrio's memoir, is easily the most challenging of Ms. Barrymore's career, and in carrying it off she masters a tricky emotional balancing act.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: '.Museum' Cleared For Action
description: The first new domain name sponsored by an interest group, ''.museum,'' will be joining the ranks of .com, .org and .net. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, which oversees the Internet's address system, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Museum Domain Management Association to oversee the operation of .museum. The new domain will be open to museums and other qualified organizations and people involved in museums worldwide. The group said that more than 500 .museum names had already been requested and that it hoped to have them working by early November.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Netradio Goes Offline
description: The Netradio Corporation, a provider of audio over the Internet, ceased all operations and laid off most of its employees on Wednesday, after a long struggle. As recently as last December, the company said it employed 50 people. Founded in 1995, Netradio was one of the Internet's original Webcasters, streaming more than 100 channels including both music and spoken material. It said a deal announced in August, under which the Advisory Board, a New York investment company, would have acquired a majority stake for about $13 million, was canceled because of a lack of financing.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HALLIBURTON CO., Dallas, the world's largest oil field services company, and its rival DSND Subsea, Oslo, said they would merge their underwater units in an equally shared joint venture to meet an expected increase in demand for underwater oil exploration and production.

title: Acting Governor Will Seek New Term in Massachusetts
description: Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift, who made history as the first governor to give birth while in office, said today that she would run for governor of Massachusetts in 2002.

One of the men, Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, was also a sworn member of Al Qaeda, Mr. bin Laden's terrorist organization, while another, Wadih El-Hage, was a close aide and former personal secretary.

description: The opening of the Hughes Brothers' film ''From Hell,'' a heady snort of paranoia about the trail of terror left by Jack the Ripper, gets its tone not only from the mordant graphic novel by the writer Alan Moore and the artist Eddie Campbell but from a surprising source: Sergio Leone, the Italian director. ''From Hell'' is shot in the wide-screen expanse that he favored.

title: New Bloodshed in the Middle East
description: The murder of Israel's tourism minister this week was a disturbing escalation of Palestinian terrorism against Israeli democracy. It occurred at a particularly sensitive moment, with Washington trying to hold together a disparate coalition against international terrorism that includes Arab nations as well as Israel. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, must now act firmly and responsibly to contain the consequences of the attack. Missteps by either could rapidly escalate the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians and jeopardize the broader campaign against terror.

title: KEEFE, BRUYETTE REPLACES CHAIRMAN KILLED IN ATTACK
description: Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., which lost its chairman and 66 other employees -- it had about 170 employees in New York -- when 2 World Trade Center was destroyed in a terrorist attack last month, said it created a three-member team to run the firm. The new office of the chairman will comprise John Duffy, Andrew Senchak and Thomas Michaud. Mr. Duffy, the chief executive, will be chairman, a post formerly held by Joseph Berry, who was killed. Mr. Senchak, director of corporate finance, was promoted to president, and Mr. Michaud, director of equity sales, was named chief operating officer.

We extend our sincerest condolences to Pasley and the entire family.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Barnesandnoble.com Offers E-book List
description: The online bookstore Barnesandnoble.com accelerated its push into electronic books with its first list of original digital books, including some books now in print from traditional publishers and a few books never published before in any form. Michael Fragnito, publisher at Barnesandnoble.com's electronic books division, said the company would publish about 15 electronic books a month. Mr. Fragnito said the company would offer a variety of titles across various categories each month at $5 to $10 apiece. Barnesandnoble.com has previously published digital editions of books with expired copyrights. Now the company is beginning to publish electronic books still under copyright, setting it up to compete with traditional publishers for both sales and authors. David D. Kirkpatrick (NYT)

title: Media Heavyweights Chip In by Organizing an All-Star Benefit Concert
description: Days after the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, three New York media moguls arrived at a plan to throw their weight behind a spectacular benefit that would raise tens of millions of dollars and help lift the city's spirits.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Soccer Star Arrested
description: Hector Chumpitaz, who was captain of Peru's World Cup teams in the 1970's, was put under house arrest on suspicion he took a bribe from the former intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, to run for the Lima City Council in 1998. Mr. Chumpitaz, 57 and still a national legend, was identified in a video secretly taped by Mr. Montesinos as having accepted $10,000 a month to be a candidate in Lima in 1998. Mr. Chumpitaz successfully ran on a ticket supported by the former president, Alberto K. Fujimori, but denied taking bribes. Mr. Montesinos is in jail and awaiting trial. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: In New York, Cheney Says War on Terror Is on Course
description: Vice President Dick Cheney made the pilgrimage yesterday to the rubble pile that was once the World Trade Center, and then, in his first public appearance since the attacks, declared that the nation's war against terrorists ''can only end with their complete and permanent destruction.''

title: Making Films And Hay, Too
description: Steve Zahn has become one of the most popular actors of his generation, but not by playing leading men. ''I've never read a script and thought, 'Ah, the handsome superman -- that's definitely me, I can make that part great,' '' Mr. Zahn said. ''I've always read for the other guy, the hero's buddy or whatever, and I just thought that was something I could do a little better. There's something about a character who's vulnerable. I think people listen to them a little bit more.''

Peter is also survived by his mother, Helen Hess, two brothers, James and Joseph, three sisters, Aileen, Susan, and Joanne, nieces, nephews and loving friends. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan Expects Higher Profit
description: The second-largest automaker in Japan, the Nissan Motor Company, said that it expected to post a higher profit for the third consecutive six-month period. The company predicted that it would report a profit of 187 billion yen ($1.6 billion) in the period that ended Sept. 30; that is 39 percent higher than in the period a year earlier. The results, which would exceed analysts' expectations, were helped by a program to reduce purchasing costs. In addition, the weakness of Japan's currency helped offset a 3.8 percent decline in sales outside Japan, including a 14 percent slide in the United States, Nissan said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Chip Maker Slips
description: Europe's biggest chip maker, STMicro electronics, based in Geneva, said that third-quarter profits fell 91 percent because of decreased demand for chips powering devices like mobile phones and digital cameras. The company, which is known for outperforming its peers, fared better than Texas Instruments and Royal Philips Electronics, which both posted third-quarter net losses. The chief executive at STMicroelectronics, Pasquale Pistorio, said that he expected sales and growth for the fourth quarter, typically the industry's strongest, to remain at third-quarter levels.

Actually, instant pudding will do almost as well; so will peanut butter straight from the jar. As long as what's consumed is smooth, sticky and slightly synthetic-tasting, it should have the right calming effect, transporting the eater to a safe, happy yesterday that probably never existed.

title: Russia Becoming an Oil Ally
description: With the developed world nervously eyeing the security of oil supplies in the Middle East, Russia is stepping forward as a new friend in need. Alongside its support for the United States' military campaign in Afghanistan, Russia is offering its oil fields as a secure alternative to dependence on the turbulent Persian Gulf.

title: A Crucial Question for Tom Ridge
description: Responding to a wave of criticism over the government's uncoordinated and uncommunicative response to the bioterrorism threat, Tom Ridge, director of the new Office of Homeland Security, held his first press briefing yesterday and tried to demonstrate that government agencies are working together around the clock to protect the public. It was at one level a reassuring performance, mostly because Mr. Ridge himself has an unruffled persona, better able to instill confidence than the sometimes uneven efforts of Tommy Thompson, the health and human services secretary, or the hard-edged rhetoric of Attorney General John Ashcroft. But the briefing, conducted by an array of top officials, left the public confused about the critical new element in the anthrax scare -- the degree to which the anthrax sent to Senator Tom Daschle's office is of such high grade that it warrants a whole new level of concern.

title: A Marriage Like Other Marriages, Only It's Victoria's
description: If ever a young woman suffered under a manipulative mother, Victoria, the future Queen of England, did. The Duchess of Kent refused to let her daughter have a bedroom of her own, insisting on sharing the room, even when Victoria was in her late teens. The duchess, with the help of Sir John Conroy, even stole her daughter's mail (from the king!) and dictated her responses. So it's no wonder that when Victoria became queen, in 1837, less than a month after her 18th birthday, she promptly had her mother installed in an apartment on the other end of Buckingham Palace. (The two didn't make up until Victoria's first child was born.)

title: Schilling Hopes to Keep the Volume Up Against the Braves
description: The last time Curt Schilling faced the Atlanta Braves in the postseason, he set a National League Championship Series record with the Philadelphia Phillies by striking out the first five batters he faced. That was in 1993, and Schilling went on to earn the series' most valuable player award.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mazda Expects Profit
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation of Japan said it expected to post a profit of 1 billion yen ($8.3 million) in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30, reversing its previous forecast for a 9.5 billion yen ($79 million) loss. Cost-cutting measures and a weaker yen, which increased export profits, contributed to the turnaround. However, Mazda, a third of which is owned by Ford Motor, did not revise its forecasts for the second half of the fiscal year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Boundless Urbanity In Just a Few Lines
description: No one in the 20th century (or the 21st, for that matter) has sent up the culturati of New York and Hollywood for as long and as stylishly as Al Hirschfeld, the caricaturist who at 98 still has the sharpest pen around. Following the performing arts -- theater, film, television, opera and dance -- for nearly 80 years, he has performed brilliantly enough at the drawing board to become a player himself. In 1996 he was, in fact, dubbed a New York Living Landmark by the city's Landmarks Commission.

When President Kennedy also said Americans were going to do many grand and wonderful things, not because they were easy but because they were hard, Coalwood’s men continued to walk out of fog-shrouded hollows and descend beneath their mountains to grub out the coal by the millions of tons to send to the blast furnaces of Ohio and Pennsylvania so as to make steel. For if coal failed, the people of Coalwood believed, steel failed. title: 'Haussmann, or the Distinction'
description: There is a story that Baron Haussmann, who rebuilt Paris in the middle of the last century, on his deathbed wished all his work undone.—Would that it died with me! he is supposed to have said, though as he died of a congestion of the lungs his last words may have been garbled. If the doctor who heard them and, astonished, wrote them down, made no mistake, then we're left with a riddle, for in life Haussmann seemed incapable of regret. Regret is a backward-turning emotion, and the Baron was famous for straightforwardness; he made the boulevards and razed the crooked lanes where tanners' sheds fronted cracked courtyards and sewer ditches spilled over into the bins of wire and paper petals of the artificial-flower makers for which the city, before his arrival on the scene, was famous. To Haussmann's German name and the sense of order which, we can only assume, came with it, we owe the sidewalk cafés with their six tiers of wicker chairs, the public urinals and Morris columns for theatrical advertisements, the insane asylum of Sainte-Anne and the park at Boulogne; to him we owe the rows of plane trees which in summer catch dust and sunlight in their leaves, and the pastime of strolling that caught on as the sidewalk widened into the twentieth century. Stop a moment on the avenue Foch, one afternoon, and thank Haussmann; stop again on the boulevard Raspail on your way home, weigh the oblong package of dates tucked under your arm, and wonder why the Baron, having made all this, wished it undone? Was it selfishness? Or as death approached did he see for the first time that the Emperor had been wrong, the speculators had been wrong, the engineers had been wrong, he had been wrong—did he see that, in all his work, there was something to regret?
