Knute Rockne's legend is safe.

title: Sports of The Times; Rising Above The Yankees, And the Past
description: SOMETIME this morning, Lou Piniella will address his Seattle Mariners. A few hours later they will play Game 3 of the American League Championship Series against the Yankees at the Stadium.

title: Investigators, Seeking Source of Anthrax, Focus on Carrier's Route
description: Federal agents converged on this normally quiet suburb today, testing mailboxes for traces of anthrax, interviewing pharmacists and knocking on doors as their effort to find whoever sent a tainted letter to the NBC anchor Tom Brokaw last month. They focused on a one-square mile of a postal delivery route.

title: Corrections
description: A signature in Circuits on Thursday on a letter about the copy-protection features of Microsoft Windows XP was misspelled. The writer was Richard Einhorn.

title: 'The Radical Center'
description: Consider the contrast between three countries. One is a preindustrial, agrarian nation with a population the size of Eritrea's. Nine out of ten people live on farms. The cities—scarcely more than villages by our standards—have arisen chiefly along the coasts and rivers. Roads and other forms of overland transportation are primitive. The distribution of wealth is highly unequal. A small number of land-owning families and a few urban merchant families are extremely rich. The majority of the population consists of small farmers and farmworkers laboring on the estates of the rich landlords. The central government is weak and dependent on customs duties for its limited revenues. National politics is constantly agitated by talk of rebellions, and rival politicians—mostly members of the tiny upper class—accuse one another of plotting to dismember the country and planning military coups d'etat.

title: Ground War Makes Stateside Soldiers Proud, and Spouses Nervous
description: Here on Bragg Boulevard, the anticipation has ended.

title: Mexico City
description: September has marked the nadir of the low tourist season for so long in this city of castles and museums that workers in restaurants and hotels refer to it as "Septi-hambre," a play on the Spanish word for hunger.

title: U.S. Restricts Cuban Diplomats In Capital After Spy Charges
description: The Bush administration has restricted the movements of Cuban diplomats in Washington three weeks after federal authorities charged a top Defense Department intelligence analyst with spying for the Havana government, officials said.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Nicaragua: Panel To Hear Ortega Case
description: The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights has agreed to hear a case stemming from unresolved sexual-abuse allegations by Zoilamerica Narvaez Murillo, a stepdaughter of Daniel Ortega, the former Sandinista leader. She said in 1998 that she had been abused by Mr. Ortega from age 11, but the case stalled when courts refused to lift his immunity as a congressman. The commission will decide only whether the government failed to provide adequate remedies. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Piniella Knows What Mariners Are Up Against
description: Ask Mariano Rivera a question and he is likely to begin his answer with, "I tell you what." For a Panamanian who speaks English as a second language, this is more idiom than it is affectation, but Lou Piniella, who is conversant in English and in Spanish, comprehends Rivera loud and clear, as a closer with a cause.

title: U.S. Appeals Phone-Case Ruling
description: The United States government asked the Supreme Court today to review a June appeals court decision that returned mobile phone licenses worth $16 billion to NextWave Telecom Inc.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Examining The Kursk
description: Vladimir Ustinov, Russia's prosecutor general, said investigators might start examining the remains of the submarine Kursk as early as Monday, once it is hoisted onto a floating dock near the Arctic city of Murmansk. Removing and identifying bodies will be the first priority, he said. The main section of the nuclear sub, which sank in August 2000 killing 118 crew members, was raised on Oct. 8. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 5 p.m. Friday, 5,113 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: F.B.I. Asks if Hijacking Plot Included Plane at Kennedy
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into whether a United Airlines flight scheduled to leave Kennedy International Airport for San Francisco was a target of hijackers on Sept. 11, aviation and law enforcement officials said.

title: Russians Are Unfazed by Anthrax, a Common Rural Problem
description: The United States has recorded 40 or so cases of exposure to anthrax since Sept. 11, a total that moves Russians to blanch and yawn at the same time. Just this week, after all, 36 people were sent to hospitals for anthrax tests in Tuva Province alone. Tuva's population is about the same as Cincinnati's.

title: Praise for Levy in a Review That Also Points to Failings
description: In its first review of Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy's job performance, the Board of Education praised Mr. Levy's efforts over the last 22 months to recruit teachers, slash the board bureaucracy and use data to pinpoint strengths and weaknesses throughout the school system.

title: Gillette Says Its Profit Fell, But Sales Rose Unexpectedly
description: Gillette said today that third-quarter profit fell 15 percent after it spent more on advertising. Sales rose unexpectedly, lifting its shares 5.3 percent.

title: 2 Drugs Received Federal Approval Long Ago to Fight Anthrax, Agency Says
description: On Oct. 17, as fears of possible shortages of the antibiotic Cipro grew, Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, made a statement that may have added to the confusion about which drugs can be used to treat and prevent anthrax.

title: When an Israeli Official Is Killed
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bolero From Cuba: 2/4 Rhythm With Tension
description: If music embodies spoken rhetoric, the Cuban bolero is provocative speech: a ballad that's not torchy so much as a stealthily rising succession of crescendos, then grows piercing when the singer summons loss or regret however he can.

title: G.E. Role in Satellite Concern to Rise
description: A Luxembourg company, the Socit Europenne des Satellites S.A., will give the General Electric Company a larger stake in itself to pay for G.E.'s satellite unit after postponing a new public share sale.

title: Green Woodland Sprites, Perhaps From the 18th Century
description: Dance as Ever

title: Notebooks; Cultural Groups Need Help
description: The city's community of cultural institutions is the latest segment of its $25 billion tourism industry to appeal to native New Yorkers to take up the slack left by tourists who have stopped flying to New York, staying in hotels here, eating in restaurants and shopping in certain neighborhoods.

title: Saudis Seek to Add U.S. Muslims to Their Sect
description: In a costly and quietly insistent campaign to spread its state religion, Saudi Arabia has been trying for decades to induce American Muslims to become followers of the puritanical Islamic sect that sustains the power of the Saudi royal family.

title: Polly Rowles, 87, Actress In TV and Film
description: Polly Rowles, an experienced character actress in theater and film whose most famous role was as Inspector No. 12 in a series of television commercials for Hanes underwear, died on Oct. 7 at a nursing home in Concord, N.H. She was 87.

title: Hynix, the Korean Giant Chip, Is Ready to Seek a Buyer
description: The technology slump has hit South Korea's semiconductor giants so hard that one, Hynix Semiconductor, said today that it was ready to discuss selling its assets to any interested investor.

title: The Other World Trade Centers Vow to Persevere
description: These are perilous times for any entity calling itself a World Trade Center.

title: Israelis Invade Bethlehem for First Time in Year of Battle
description: Israeli troops and tanks invaded Bethlehem today, seizing several buildings and trading staccato gunfire throughout the day with Palestinian fighters. It was the first push by the Israeli Army through the outskirts of Bethlehem into the city itself since the current conflict began a year ago.

title: Rosie the Riveter In a New Generation; Military Industry Regains Self-Respect
description: In the heyday of the new economy, the Raytheon Company's military plant in the Southern California industrial town of Goleta was easy to ignore. Corporate mergers and cuts in military spending sliced the work force in half. There was little to keep employees loyal when Internet executives from nearby Santa Barbara came calling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, CLARA
description: REISS-Clara. A patron of the arts. Died October 19, 2001 at her residence on Park Avenue. Born August 29th, 1904, married to Professor Frederick Reiss, M.D. who was a world renowned specialist in tropical dermatology. She is survived by her nieces Maria Gero and Suzanne Palocz. Service Sunday, 1 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Two Men Held in Money-Smuggling Attempt
description: Four days after federal officials moved to freeze the assets of several honey businesses in Yemen, saying they were tied to Osama bin Laden, two men were arrested at Kennedy Airport on charges that they tried to smuggle more than $100,000 in cash to Yemen in boxes of honey.

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL AGREES TO BUY REST OF TYCOM
description: Tyco International, a leading maker of electronic controls, has agreed to buy the 11 percent of Tycom Ltd. that it does not already own for about $863.5 million, reacquiring all of the company just 15 months after selling the stake to the public. Tyco increased its previous offer from $748 million, or about $14 a share. Tyco will pay $15.42 each for about 56 million shares, the company said. Tyco raised $2 billion in July 2000, selling shares in the stake at $32 each. The shares of Tycom, a maker of undersea fiber optic cable that is building its own global undersea network, had plunged 57 percent this year before Tyco's offer was announced Oct. 4, as industrywide sales and profit slumped. The shares have regained some of their value. Tycom and Tyco are based in Hamilton, Bermuda.

title: In a Switch, Braves Relying on Their Relievers
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 19 — The names seem to change every season. As the Atlanta Braves repeat their drive into the playoffs each October, their strength has remained their starting pitching, but their relievers have been in constant flux.

title: Coast Guard Reservists, Unexpectedly Needed, Patrol Nation's Shores
description: In normal times, Jose Chavez is a letter carrier in Yakima, 140 miles inland from here, over on the sunny side of the Cascade Mountains.

title: Briefing by Gen. Richard B. Myers
description: Following is a transcript of the briefing.

title: Airline Stops Offering Creamer and Sweetener
description: As a precaution against a growing number of reports of suspected anthrax on its planes, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would no longer give passengers powdered coffee creamer or artificial sweeteners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTIN, BERNARD
description: KURTIN-Bernard, Oct. 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Jeanie; father of Owen & Sabryna; grandfather of Jean-Michael, Noah and Dora; brother of Elayne; and English teacher of thousands of New York City high school students.

title: Europe Getaways
description: Europe Express has packages with air fare to seven European cities and four nights in a hotel with daily Continental breakfast, starting at $349. That's for departures from Newark and the Vendome Hotel in Brussels. The Holiday Inn is $449 and the Royal Windsor $549. Other cities include London (starting at $399, at the Central House), Paris (from $399, Hotel Veronese) and Venice (from $649, Hotel Capri). Applicable dates vary; in most cases, they are from November through mid-December. In each city, there is a choice of hotels at differing prices, from standard to superior. Rates, which are per person, double occupancy, include hotel taxes and service charges; weekend surcharges and departure taxes are extra. Flights from Miami, Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles cost more; (800) 927-3876 or www.europeexpress.com .

title: Correspondent; Building on Prosperity
description: THE last time George W. Bush visited China, it was 1975 and he was just out of business school. His father was ambassador to Beijing. The son found the country unbearably drab and yearned to go back to Texas and seek his fortune. The few sentences he devoted to that youthful experience in his 1999 campaign biography have been mocked as evidence of his incurious nature and his knack for the obvious, but reading them here this week, I was struck by something else. His unsophisticated reaction to China as a young man -- apparently unchanged as he packaged his life story for the electorate two years ago -- coincided closely with what the Chinese say about themselves today. Mr. Bush took no notice of political or religious repression or the explosive question of Taiwan. He did not suggest that China might be tamed by American pressure.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Hong Kong
description: Despite its claims to being the Manhattan of Asia, Hong Kong has reacted to last month's terrorist attack in New York in a way that reveals the distance between this financial center and its American counterpart.

title: In Albany, Getting Serious About Casinos
description: The World Trade Center disaster has rekindled serious negotiations for Indian casinos in western New York and the Catskills, with Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature said to be close to a deal for five or six casinos as lawmakers desperately seek new revenues to stave off budget cuts.

title: Reinterpreting Classics, Celebrating Men's Lives
description: Lar Lubovitch can tell a story, a rare gift in today's modern dance. Even better, he seems to assume that his audience knows how to think. And his narrations tend to plunge right into the tale, without any tiresome scene-setting, in luscious movement that is one of the chief pleasures of his choreography.

title: Leonard LaRue, Rescuer in the Korean War, Dies at 87
description: Brother Marinus Leonard LaRue, who as a merchant marine captain in the Korean War evacuated 14,000 refugees from a besieged North Korean port, died on Sunday at St. Paul's Abbey in Newton, N.J. Brother Marinus, who became a Benedictine monk after two decades at sea, was 87.

title: Role of Religion In a Varied Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris
description: If you hate waiting in line and are never organized enough to make a hotel or restaurant reservation weeks in advance, this is the time for you to be a tourist in France. Attendance is down all over, from the visitors lining up to see the Eiffel Tower to those filing past the "Mona Lisa" at the Louvre. Even Disneyland Paris reports that fewer reservations are being made right now.

title: Isles to Honor Bryan Trottier
description: The Islanders will hold a ceremony today at 1 p.m. at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y., to retire the No. 19 worn by Bryan Trottier. That would be enough excitement for fans during these recent lean years, but New York will then play San Jose, and these Islanders are playing as well as the old Islanders did.

title: VORNADO REALTY ADDS ALL OF CHARLES SMITH COMMERCIAL
description: Vornado Realty Trust has agreed to buy the rest of Charles E. Smith Commercial Realty, the largest office building owner in the metropolitan Washington area, for $1.58 billion in securities and assumed debt, expanding in a market with one of the lowest vacancy rates in the country. Vornado, the largest owner of office buildings in New York, will issue $599 million of partnership units and assume $985 million in debt for the 66 percent stake it did not already own, Vornado said. Smith owns and manages about 18.4 million square feet of office properties in Washington and Northern Virginia, of which 42 percent is leased to the government.

title: Central America Reminded Of Its Own Era of Conflict
description: The war against terrorism may be focused on Central Asia, but it has revived fears and memories across the political spectrum in Central America, where the United States was long ensnared in civil wars and skulduggery in the battle against Communism.

title: Coast Guard Will Not End Boat Patrols Near A-Plants
description: After a public outcry over security, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that the Coast Guard would not end round-the-clock patrols of the Indian Point nuclear plants until state authorities reviewed safeguards at the site.

title: Role of Religion In a Varied Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Notebooks; Luring Business Leaders With Dinner and a Show
description: Time was you could lure executives to New York City by offering them dinner and a show. Now, it takes breakfast with the mayor and a visit to ground zero. But at least they are willing to come.

title: BUSH MEETS JIANG
description: President Bush said here today that ''support is near unanimous'' among Pacific Rim nations for both the military strikes in Afghanistan and the broader war he has declared against terrorism. But to cement the antiterror coalition, he spent his first day in China playing down a series of contentious issues with his hosts and with the president of South Korea.

title: Terrorism Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: In Terror Inquiry, Student Is Charged With Perjury
description: A Jordanian student was charged yesterday in Manhattan with lying before a federal grand jury investigating the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Federal prosecutors said that the student, Osama Awadallah, had lied about his associations with Khalid al-Midhar, one of the suspected hijackers who helped crash a jetliner into the Pentagon.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Supermarket Losses
description: Japan's largest supermarket operator, Daiei Inc., lost 3.9 billion yen ($32.2 million) in the six months ended Aug. 31, as shoppers continued to forsake its groceries for discount and convenience stores. Sales fell 12 percent from the period a year earlier, complicating Daiei's struggle to reduce 2.3 trillion yen in debts ($19 billion). Three other large Japanese chains have closed in the last 18 months. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Abroad at Home; The Inescapable World
description: After Sept. 11 it was said by many that our world had irrevocably changed. That is true in a sense that we have not yet grasped.

title: A Head-On Collision Of Alien Cultures?
description: Is this the clash of civilizations that you have been warning about nearly a decade?

title: Pineda Chacon Is M.V.P. of M.L.S.
description: Miami's Alex Pineda Chacon was named the Honda most valuable player in Major League Soccer yesterday. The announcement was made in Columbus, Ohio, where the championship game will be played tomorrow between Los Angeles and San Jose.

title: Toronto
description: Autumn comes to Ontario with the same bright colors and crisp sunny days that draw visitors to the American Northeast. Toronto is a base for foliage tours and visits to harvest festivals in the surrounding countryside as well as a destination in its own right, with all the urban attractions  restaurants, museums, cultural events and vibrant ethnic neighborhoods  plus a long Lake Ontario waterfront.

title: Richard Buckle, 85, Author on Dance
description: Richard Buckle, an influential British dance critic and dance historian and the organizer of imaginative exhibitions, died on Oct. 12 while being taken by ambulance from his country cottage in Dorset to a hospital in Salisbury. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMER, WILLIAM J.
description: BAUMER-William J. On October 17, 2001. Director of Publications, Hunter College, CUNY. Former editor, TimesFax, and writer/editor, Associated Press and Queens College. Beloved son of Nelson and Catherine nee Boyle. Loving brother of Nelson, brother-in-law of Donna, adoring uncle of Fiona and Megan. Visiting Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:45 AM at St. Andrew's Church. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to Hunter College Foundation/Film and Media Studies, Room 1313, 695 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, CHARLES JR.
description: IRWIN-Charles Jr. October 17, 2001. Major USMC (retired). Beloved husband of Jane Darlington Irwin. Devoted father of Charles D. Irwin and his wife Dona. Cherished grandfather of Carter, Robert and Roger. He graduated from Schreiner Military Academy & Southern Methodist University, class of 1942. Decorated Combat Marine Corps Officer in the Pacific Theatre during World War II and The Korean Conflict. Partner of the Wall St. firm W.C. Langley Co. An ardent student of history and a friend to all who knew him. Service on Tuesday, October 23rd, 10 AM at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Avenue and 53rd St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Marine Corps. Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 3008, Princeton, New Jersey 08543, or to St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: When an Israeli Official Is Killed
description: To the Editor:

title: Cairo
description: The Egyptian government, travel companies and hotels are staggering to cope with the raft of cancellations during what would normally be the high season.

title: For Some Students Studying Overseas, a Reconsideration
description: The terrorist attacks in the United States and the reprisal bombings in Afghanistan have sent shudders through the more than 75,000 American college students who are studying abroad this fall, causing some to change their routines or even reconsider their plans.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sales Increase For Nestl
description: Nestl S.A., the world's biggest food company, had a 4.9 percent increase in sales, to $38.3 billion, for the first nine months, despite slower growth in the third quarter. Its bottom line was helped by sales of bottled water. The company also said it might float a minority stake in its eye care subsidiary, Alcon, next year, which could be worth up to $12.2 billion. Nestl said it expected higher sales and profits this year despite the economic slowdown. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: U.S. Military-Jet Makers Join a Scramble for Seoul's Favors
description: With the sky still streaked from a display of stunt flying by his country's newest jet fighter, an official with the French company that makes the aircraft sneered at an American F-15 taxiing for takeoff.

title: An Early Tee Time Is Useful To Smith
description: Jerry Smith figures the safe way to keep his PGA Tour card is to play his best this weekend.

title: No Evidence Suspect Met Iraqi in Prague
description: Czech officials say they do not believe that Mohamed Atta, suspected of having led the attack on the World Trade Center, met with any Iraqi officials during a brief stop he made in Prague last year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merrill Is Said to Offer Buyouts Ahead of Layoffs

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREIBERG, SYLVIA
description: FREIBERG-Sylvia. 7/15/11-10/20/ 98. We miss her humor, her social conscience, her insights, her love. Life's not the same without her. The Family

title: Rome
description: Usually, the guys dressed up like Roman centurions for the tourists' benefit spend their days getting their picture taken outside the Colosseum, where their duties include flirting, cooing at children and, sometimes, cursing at the clueless if they fail to tip properly.

title: Rebuilding Downtown New York
description: Politicians, civic leaders and ordinary citizens alike agree that the only appropriate response to the tragic events of Sept. 11 is to refashion the southern tip of Manhattan into a vibrant commercial center that offers an attractive place to live and work and an appropriate memorial for the World Trade Center victims. There is certainly no shortage of ideas about what to do. The question now is how best to manage the restoration, and on this point there is far less agreement. In fact, there are already inklings of a turf war between the state and city. Surely in this case political rivalries need to be set aside in service of the larger cause.

title: Their Lives Are Now Etched in Sorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: THE HUNGER WARRIORS

title: Indonesia's Ex-President Expects to Be Restored
description: Less than three months ago, Abdurrahman Wahid was swept from the presidency on a wave of public exasperation after a truncated tenure that one prominent scholar calls ''one of the strangest periods in Indonesian history.''

title: J. B. Slowinski, 38, an Expert On Venomous Snake Species
description: Dr. Joseph B. Slowinski, an expert on venomous snakes who was in the middle of an ambitious inventory of the reptile and amphibian populations of Myanmar, died on Sept. 12 in the northern reaches of that country. He was 38.

title: Corrections
description: The On Stage and Off column in Weekend yesterday referred incorrectly to the inactivity on Broadway this fall. One new play is indeed scheduled -- Neil Simon's ''45 Seconds From Broadway,'' opening on Nov. 11 at the Richard Rodgers.

title: Friend Stole Tower Victim's Card, Police Charge
description: For Cantor Fitzgerald, the brokerage firm devastated by the World Trade Center attacks, it was yet another piece of bad news.

title: Ford Motor Cancels Program To Give PC's to Its Employees
description: The Ford Motor Company today canceled its program to give employees personal computers as the company tries to reduce expenses because of slowing sales and financial losses.

title: Their Lives Are Now Etched in Sorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A map of Manhattan in the arts pages on Thursday with an article about following the route of Ishmael, the narrator in Herman Melville's ''Moby-Dick,'' along the southerly shores of the island, located Delancey Street incorrectly. It is the third street south of Houston; the fifth is Grand Street.

title: A Scramble To Counter Any Threat Of Smallpox
description: After announcing plans to stockpile 300 million doses of smallpox vaccine, the government must now determine where it can quickly get so much.

title: AVENTIS UNIT ORDERED TO PAY $33 MILLION FINE TO F.D.A.
description: A unit of the drug maker Aventis was ordered by a federal judge to pay $33 million in penalties, after pleading guilty to conspiring to deceive the Food and Drug Administration about its manufacturing of the drug Cefaclor. The unit, Roussel Uclaf S.A., which became a part of Aventis, misled the agency about where and how the drug, used to treat upper and lower respiratory infections, was made. The purpose of the deception was to make more Cefaclor available for sale in the United States, the company admitted in its plea agreement. From April 1995 to September 1996, the company manufactured Cefaclor in Italy, France and Romania that had not been included in an F.D.A. application, according to the plea agreement.

title: U.S. Seeking a Stronger Role For Banks on Terrorists' Cash
description: Government and banking industry officials are working on a plan to allow banks to serve as a front line for law enforcement in detecting financial transactions by terrorist groups, people involved in the effort have said.

title: Beneath the Eccentricities Lurks a Wide-Open Mood
description: During Macy Gray's surprise show on Wednesday at the Supper Club, the singer's preferred posture was a loose-limbed squat, which she assumed every so often to better touch the hands of fans in the front row, or sing a provocative verse or just get out of her big band's way and let the funk wash over everyone.

title: Judge Denies Move to Bar Testimony in Auction Trial
description: A federal judge in Manhattan denied a request yesterday by A. Alfred Taubman, the indicted former chairman of Sotheby's auction house, to bar the appearance of a witness expected to offer crucial testimony against Mr. Taubman in his criminal antitrust trial next month.

title: Don't Doubt Steadfastness Of Taliban, Envoy Insists
description: When the man who has become the Taliban's last remaining voice outside Afghanistan returned here today after a week traveling at home, his message to the United States seemed more than just defiant. In fact, he sounded positively smug: bomb us as you will, he seemed to say, and we will still be there to thwart you.

title: Metro Matters; Winning Lets A Candidate Stop Running
description: IT'S not that Betsy Gotbaum has regrets. The former parks commissioner resoundingly won her primaries and, with just nominal opposition in the general election, will definitely be New York City's next public advocate, one of three citywide elected officials. Nice, she readily admits, nice indeed.

title: Woman Is Killed in Brooklyn Lobby
description: ABrooklyn woman was stabbed to death late Thursday in the lobby of her apartment building, the police said yesterday.

title: To Bioterror, a Local Response
description: Some of the most searing images of Sept. 11 involve those who risked their lives to save others. Now rescue crews in moon suits are rushing into office buildings to investigate suspicious letters that could contain anthrax. Public health and medical personnel quickly follow to administer tests, offer a soothing word and, if necessary, provide antibiotics to ward off the onset of a disease turned into a twisted tool of terror. What all these public servants have in common is this: They are local.

title: Secret Trove May Resolve 'Copenhagen'
description: After more than half a century, historians and scientists still cannot agree on why the Nazis were never able to develop an atomic bomb, or on why the leader of their bomb program, the physicist Werner Heisenberg, visited his old mentor Niels Bohr in occupied Denmark in 1941.

description: Dance as Ever

title: Some Taliban Warlords Reported Ready to Turn Against Ruling Faction
description: Exiled Afghan politicians in Pakistan said on Thursday that a delegation of tribal leaders and clerics had gone to Afghanistan for talks with disaffected Taliban warlords who were ready to turn against the governing faction.

title: Schilling Continues His Domination in the Playoffs
description: There was Curt Schilling, baseball's one-man obstacle course, rumbling down the third-base line in the fifth inning. Schilling has almost single-handedly carried the Arizona Diamondbacks deep into the playoffs with his pitching, but now Schilling was scaring his teammates because he used his head running.

title: SHARES OF PROVIDIAN, CREDIT CARD CONCERN, TUMBLE
description: Shares in the Providian Financial Corporation fell 58 percent yesterday after the company, which issues Visa and MasterCard credit cards, said losses were mounting and its chief executive would resign. Stock in the company, which is based in San Francisco, closed down $7.25, to $5.15. Shares fell 34 percent a week ago when Providian said it would report lower third-quarter earnings than it projected in early September. Profit fell 71 percent in the three months, the company said yesterday.

title: No Way to Boost the Economy
description: The first item on the House agenda next week will be the Republican leadership's economic stimulus bill. Nobody doubts the need for an economic transfusion of some sort. But this bill is not the right way to achieve it. Even the Bush administration has expressed doubts. Paul O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, described the measure as partly ''show business.'' And while the White House rebuked Mr. O'Neill for his apostasy, President Bush himself is said to have misgivings about adding a huge new layer of tax cuts to those already enacted.

title: When an Israeli Official Is Killed
description: To the Editor:

title: No Anthrax in Letter Sent to Times Bureau in Brazil, Officials Say
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 20  A second round of tests on a suspicious letter received by the Rio de Janeiro bureau of The New York Times earlier this week has ruled out the possibility that the correspondence was contaminated with anthrax, the Brazilian authorities said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: QUEST DIAGNOSTICS INC., Teterboro, N.J., the biggest provider of medical laboratory tests, bought Clinical Diagnostic Services, a closely held testing lab that serves New Jersey and New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Fight Over Fighter Sales
description: BAE Systems, the former British Aerospace, has offered to take an equity stake in the Czech Republic's jet trainer producer, Aero Vodochody, if the Czech government agrees to buy 36 BAE/Saab Gripen fighters for about $2 billion. Aero has lost $500 million since Boeing bought 35 percent of the company in 1997. BAE is battling Boeing and Lockheed Martin in a bid to sell new jets to the Czechs to replace their aging Soviet-built MIG's, despite warnings that the program is too costly for the Czech military. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Role of Religion in a Varied Land
description: To the Editor:

title: S, We Have Cipro; the Panicky and the Profiteers Head to Mexico
description: On Revolution Avenue the bars are all but empty, the restaurants and mariachis are quiet, the tourists are scarce, and the Cipro is rapidly changing hands.

title: The Mariners' Moyer Is Steady as He Goes
description: When Seattle Manager Lou Piniella stood at the lectern after Game 2 of the American League Championship Series on Thursday night, it was with frustration and fire that he guaranteed that the Mariners would be back in Seattle for a sixth game. When Jamie Moyer, the man entrusted with the task today of helping to get the Mariners there, took his seat on the podium yesterday afternoon, it was a far different sight.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Lottery Commission Restores Ban

Then again, the Giants' defensive backfield has muffed several potential interceptions this season, including two crucial drops by safeties Sam Garnes and Shaun Williams that could have reversed the outcome of the Giants' 15-14 loss to St. Louis last weekend.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rolls-Royce Cuts 5,000 Jobs
description: With major airlines delaying purchases of airplanes, Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the world's second-largest maker of jetliner engines, said it would cut its work force by 11 percent, eliminating 5,000 jobs in anticipation of a 30 percent drop in sales next year. Rolls-Royce said 2002 pretax profit would fall by half but it maintained an earlier forecast of increased earnings in 2003. With airlines canceling flights and grounding planes, the aviation industry has suffered badly, shedding 41,500 jobs, including those from Rolls-Royce. Labor union officials said Rolls-Royce had lost its nerve and had overreacted. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Europe Wary of Wider Doors for Immigrants
description: In the wake of the terror attacks in the United States, Grard Herault, the mayor of this tidy Paris suburb, took the step he could to reduce immigration to France: he decided he would no longer issue ''certificates of welcome,'' the papers required to show that a potential visitor, asking for a visa, has a place to stay.

description: Amid the national flurry of alarms over feared terrorist activity, the Philadelphia police found a powerful amount of C-4 plastic military explosive yesterday in a suitcase stored in baggage locker in a downtown bus terminal.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Aer Lingus Cuts Work Force
description: Aer Lingus, the Irish national airline, has laid off more than 2,000 of its 6,300 employees and has frozen wages for three years in an effort to keep the company out of bankruptcy. The company's unions are expected to object to the job cuts, which were announced by the new chief executive, Willie Walsh, the company's fourth since 1998. The carrier loses $2.2 million a day, and the Irish government is fighting for European Union approval to guarantee a $120 million loan. But even that amount will not cover payments to the laid-off employees. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Evidence of Anthrax Discovered in House Mailroom
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  Evidence of anthrax was found today in the mailroom of the House of Representatives, the third site on Capitol Hill where spores have been discovered.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: New Charges For Terrorist
description: Johannes Weinrich, 54, who is serving a life sentence for terrorism, has been charged with other attacks in France, Greece and Germany between 1975 and 1983. The new charges include six cases of murder and 153 counts of attempted murder and implicate him in attacks on a railway station in Marseille in 1983, the bombing of the Munich studios of Radio Free Europe in 1981, the car bombing attack on the Saudi ambassador in Athens in 1983 and a failed bazooka attack on an Israeli passenger jet at a Paris airport in 1975. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Journalists Face Fines For Crossings
description: Journalists looking to test United States border security are also trying the patience of the Border Patrol. Two television reporters were caught trying to cross into the United States from Canada at East Franklin, Vt., which is not an official crossing point. The authorities say this is the sixth time since Sept. 11 that journalists sneaked across the border to check on security, wasting the time of Border Patrol and Customs agents. The two television reporters face civil fines of $5,000. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

Wojciech Jaruzelski, back in court on charges that he gave the orders to shoot striking workers during anti-Communist demonstrations in 1970, proclaimed his innocence on Thursday. General Jaruzelski, now 78, called the incident a tragedy but said he did not give the orders to fire, although he was defense minister at the time. Forty-four people were killed in the protests. title: Death Meets Spunk, and It's O.K. to Cry
description: Who could criticize ''Jenifer''? This film, which CBS is offering tomorrow, portrays courage and family solidarity in the face of a cruel illness, then invites you to contribute to the research effort that could ultimately save the woman whose struggle inspired the exercise. Nobody watches a disease-of-the-week weepie expecting great drama. You do hope for an emotional jolt or two, which this movie delivers. And since it also delivers moments of memorable acting, it exceeds expectations for its hardy genre.

title: Fear, the New Virus Of a Connected Era
description: In that distant world far, far away that was America before Sept. 11, much was written about how the Internet and cable television were creating a newly fragmented, decentralized world -- a culturally splintered world of niche marketing, special-interest publications and identity politics. As one 1990's survey of Internet politics concluded, virtual communities ''resemble the semiprivate spaces of modern health clubs more than the public spaces of agoras'': ''instead of meeting to discuss and debate issues of common concern to the society, members of these virtual communities meet largely to promote their own interests and to reinforce their own like-mindedness.''

title: AMERICAN CLASSIC VOYAGES FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: American Classic Voyages, a cruise ship company controlled by the billionaire Sam Zell, sought bankruptcy protection in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Delaware after customers canceled trips following the Sept. 11 attacks. Cruise bookings fell 50 percent after Sept. 11, and cancellations increased 30 percent, the company said. American Classic listed assets of $37.4 million and debts of $452.8 million. The company is the largest American-flagged cruise line, operating seven vessels with 3,480 passenger berths. American Classic will cease operating its Hawaii vessels today and will shut down four of the five Delta Queen vessels in the next three days. (Bloomberg News)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Committee Restricts Field Trips
description: Worried that big cities are more likely targets for terrorism and affiliated hoaxes, a small-town school district outside Boston is looking to keep its children close to home. The school committee in Marshfield, 25 miles southeast of Boston, passed a moratorium on field trips to or through Boston for one year, fearful that children might be caught in an anthrax scare. The Boston mayor, Thomas Menino, reacted quickly, offering to take school committee members on a tour of the city and discuss the matter over a free lunch. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

Plants will be closed in France, Germany and Spain before the end of the year as car sales slow in North America and Europe. The company, which makes clutches and headlights, has announced plans to close or sell 35 of its 170 plants and expects production to fall to 10 percent next year. Bloomberg News reported that cuts at Valeo's plant in Rochester would result in charges of as much as $450 million over several years. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOUGH, ROSA TRILLO
description: CLOUGH-Rosa Trillo. Passed away in West Palm Beach June 28, 2001. Born 1906 in New York City, B.A. in Italian from Hunter College, M.A. and a Ph.D. in Italian from Columbia University. Professor of Italian at Hunter College from 1928 to 1956, headed Modern Language Department of Finch College 1956-1971. She founded the Center for Italian Studies in the Palm Beaches, Florida, and was Director until the end of 2000. She authored many articles on Italian art, literature, and culture and published 11 books, including a definitive Italian grammar, major works on Futurism, and Italian art history. Dr. Clough was knighted in 1972 and 1996 by the Italian government, receiving the title of ''Commendatore, Ordine al Merito della Repubblica Italiana.'' In 1995, she was elected to the Hunter College Hall of Fame. She was an educator with boundless energy whose accomplishments are evident in the success of her students. She is mourned by many friends, by her two sons, Shepard A. Clough of Lexington, MA., and Peter N. Clough of Paris, and their families, by a nephew Salvatore Trillo of Glendora, CA, by her cousins, and by her seven grandchildren and thirteen great-grandchildren. A memorial service is planned at the Ann Norton Sculpture Gardens in West Palm Beach on December 1. Tax deductible donations may be made to the Rosa T. Clough Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Paul Clough, Comins & Newbury, 84 State Street, Boston, MA 02109.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINDER, DR. LEON
description: SINDER-Dr. Leon. Noted cultural anthropologist and professor at Long Island University, UNESCO field representative and businessman, died on October 3rd as a result of an accident; he was 79. Dr. Sinder was born in Ediniti, Romania on September 5th, 1922 and came to the United States in December 1930. He grew up in the Bronx and was a graduate of Dewitt Clinton High School, New York University, and earned his Ph.D. in Anthropology in 1960 from Columbia University. During World War II, he served as an airman in the U.S. Army Air Corps in the Pacific, flying over 50 missions. He was awarded the Air Medal with two Oak Leaf Clusters and the Philippine Liberation Medals. Dr. Sinder was Professor of Anthropology and Sociology at Long Island University in Brooklyn, New York from 1958 to 1981. From 1982 to 1991, he served in a number of pivotal rolls at the United States International University in San Diego, California. Dr. Sinder's close association with the Republic of Korea began in 1960 when he represented UNESCO in Suwan, Korea. He was awarded a Fulbright Professorship to Korea for 1963-64. He also served the UN in the Republic of Columbia in 1966, the Kingdom of Laos in 1967, and the Republic of China during 1970-71. In 1983, he was made an honorary citizen of Jeon-Ju City, Korea by the governor of the province and carried the torch prior to the 1988 Olympics through the center of Jeon-Ju City. Dr. Sinder was one of only two non-Koreans so honored. Dr. Sinder received a number of awards and honorary doctorates during his career. In 1971 he received two citations from the Republic of China for contributions to Human Development. Dr. Sinder published a number of books and many major articles. Leon Sinder was married in 1948 to Mary Glenn Hardin and is survived by her. ''Leon was a lover of stray cats, dogs, and people and I never knew when he might bring one or the other home,'' said Mary Sinder. Leon was bright, compassionate and respected by presidents, kings, and people from many nations and walks of life. His death brings great sadness to his family and friends, but also resounding congratulations on a life well lived.

description: New commercial and residential developments are nearing completion in the first area of this city to be cleared of elevated roadways and other remnants of an industrial past after 10 years of construction on the Big Dig and related infrastructure improvements. As the developments bring new life to the long-languishing City Square district in the historic Charlestown neighborhood, planners and city officials are pointing to the changes as examples of what might be done in the wake of the enormous physical changes being made by the $14.5 billion Central Artery Project, which is to be completed in 2005.

They claimed they were escaping Popish influences, but they were really escaping the horrible climate of the east coast of England. They settled on Long Island, where -- because of nostalgia or lack of imagination -- they founded a new town of the same name, in a county of the same name. But no matter how they searched, they couldn't find the necessary wold anywhere on the North Fork. In old English, a wold is a hill or piece of high ground. Being honest folk and not wishing to make any false claims, they called their new settlement Southold, without the ''w.''
