Memorials to Hospice of Palm Beach County, J. Robert Lauer Unit, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407, in Roy Ross's name.

title: Wait Ends for Paterno As Penn State Wins First
description: Joe Paterno and his Penn State Nittany Lions have had their share of firsts this season, none of them good. Penn State had started its season 0-4 for the first time in its 115-year history and had been handed its first shutout at home since 1965.

title: Boone Finally Breaks Out of Slump
description: Two on, two out, and the Seattle Mariners were two runs behind. Bret Boone lunged at the first pitch and lofted a lazy fly to short right field. He flipped his bat to the side and rolled his eyes. Not again.

title: Carry-On Rules: List Grows Long
description: DO not try flying US Airways with a pinned-up hem, or for that matter, with a red, white and blue ribbon affixed to your shirt. Because a safety pin -- along with all sharp objects and anything else that could be used as a weapon -- will be confiscated if you try to take it aboard, according to signs posted throughout La Guardia's US Airways terminal.

title: October 14-20; Russia Closes Cuba Station
description: Russia's eavesdropping station at Lourdes, Cuba, is a cold war jewel: 28 square miles of antennae and computers that message Russian embassies, submarines and spies, and vacuum up U.S. satellite and radio communications. But with Russia's superpower status a thing of the past, and no threat from America, President Vladimir V. Putin said the country was giving it all up and spending the savings -- $200 million a year in rent -- to re-equip its military. Michael Wines

title: AMNESTY ON CHILD SUPPORT
description: Next week, New Jersey Child Support Services will offer amnesty to the nearly 39,000 parents with outstanding warrants for delinquent child-support payments. From tomorrow through next Saturday those who face jail time may agree to a payment schedule. This is the first time New Jersey is offering such an amnesty. Jo Piazza

title: NEW MUG SHOT PROCEDURE
description: In a step intended to reduce mistaken identification of suspects, statewide guidelines went into effect last week recommending that the police and prosecutors have witnesses view mug shots one at a time, rather than side by side. Research has suggested that simultaneous identification risks witnesses falsely choosing the picture that most resembles the witness's mental image of the suspect. The state is the first in the country to encourage the use of what are called sequential lineups. Steve Strunsky

title: If It Feels Significant, Do It
description: WHAT a difference a year can make. Twelve months ago, most of young America was mired in the material world, obsessed with stock options and where it would luxuriate after retiring at 40. Whiz kids controlled multimillion-dollar companies, the offices were often college dormitory rooms, and the money flowed like merlot. Thank goodness we all had therapists to help us cope with our newfound wealth.

title: BackTalk; Baseball Playoffs Provide Comfort Food to the Fans
description: In a time when kill boxes get more attention than batters' boxes and finding your combat rhythm seems more urgent than finding your zone, sport does not necessarily become less important, but it does shift roles. The baseball playoffs are not so much about thrills (more on Derek Jeter later) as they are about comfort.

title: British Painting Through the Centuries
description: THE new show at the Yale Center for British Art illustrates that since the 16th century, the figure and the portrait have remained staples of British painting.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Sonja Klein, Benjamin Sugerman
description: Sonja Jenia Klein, the director of a photography gallery, and Benjamin Eli Sugerman, a candidate for a Ph.D. in astrophysics, are to be married today in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Henry Glazer is to officiate at the Glen Island Harbour Club.

title: First of the Stinging Jabs
description: The United States commando raid in Afghanistan reflected the start of a new, fast paced and, the military hopes, determining stage of the war.

title: Documenting Humble Shrines of Private Grief
description: Last year, Dario Oleaga's friends would call him whenever they spotted one of those makeshift street shrines to a victim of an accident or a shooting. Mr. Oleaga, a 29-year-old artist living in Washington Heights, would then head out to photograph the memorial.

title: Lives; Locked Down
description: On a summer morning just over two years ago, Abdul Qayim watched as 12 fellow inmates were picked out from a group that had been gathered into the yard of the Taliban prison in Kandahar. Two foreign fighters, an Arab and a Punjabi, had introduced themselves and said that they had just been released from an alliance prison liberated by the Taliban. Now they wanted revenge.

title: Art/Architecture; An Elegant Marriage Of Inside and Outside
description: AGGRESSION is a particle, desire is a wave. They represent two different ways of experiencing life. But nowadays it matters to go with the waves. To get through this crisis in our collective and interconnected civic, national and global life, we must all become beach bums and ride our desires.

title: Providing Support For a Free Spirit
description: I have known Frank Davison [''Caboose in Yard Is a Direct Line to Court,'' Long Island Journal, Oct. 7] for about 20 years and if I can keep a boat in my driveway, or someone else can keep a car or what have you in theirs, then Frank can keep his caboose in his. Many communities have their own renowned eccentric and Frank is ours and somehow we're the better for it.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-21-01; Feds Up
description: Back in the era that ended on Sept. 11, life in Washington was burdened by a curious form of self-loathing. A good many of the capital's residents habitually deplored it as an irredeemably sinful place -- though as missionaries from the heartland they took no blame for its corruptions. You can trace the evolution of this attitude from Ronald Reagan's first Inaugural Address, when he said that government was not the solution but the problem, through Newt Gingrich's railings against the ''corrupt'' bureaucracy to the rather poignant attempt by that quintessential Washington figure, Bob Dole, to cast himself as an outsider when he ran for president.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LOVE THAT DOG

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: Hardcover Advice
description: This

title: Some Players Arming Themselves for Security
description: A Jets player was asked his thoughts on the arrest of his teammate Damien Robinson, the safety who was caught with a Bushmaster .223 assault rifle in the trunk of his car by security officials while trying to enter Giants Stadium last Sunday.

title: Sahara Stone, Jordan Pynes
description: Sahara Gayle Stone, the daughter of Jacqueline and Harry Stone of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in New York last evening to Jordan Fox Pynes, a son of Dr. Ellie F. Pynes of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Benjamin Pynes of San Diego. Cantor Bernard Dienstag officiated at the New York Palace Hotel.

title: Some Are Traveling Again, to Some Places
description: WHEN the nation's airlines resumed flying a few days after terrorists hijacked four planes on Sept. 11, Linda Myers in Ithaca, N.Y., resolved to go ahead with plans to attend a family bar mitzvah in Kansas City, Mo., over the Oct. 5 weekend. So did her 93-year-old aunt, Anne Lewis, who flew from Boston.

title: Julia Shaw, Matthew Rienzo
description: Julia Justine Shaw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Edward Shaw of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Matthew Charles Rienzo, a son of Francis X. Rienzo of Falls Church, Va., and the late Joan Rienzo. The Rev. Otto Hentz, a Roman Catholic priest and a professor of theology at Georgetown University, performed the ceremony at Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Sports of The Times; Martin Enjoys Being Chased Into the End Zone
description: RUNNING backs don't just like to run. Sprinters just like to run. Running backs like to run while being chased.

title: Introduction
description: Articles on the economy, patriotism, Afghanistan and Israel drew a spate of mail. Readers found Paul Krugman's lesson in economics particularly enlightening, wishing only that the remedy for the current financial decline was half as clear. Other writers were riveted by John Sifton's portrait of Afghanistan.

title: A Time for Growing Up
description: THOUGH I wasn't at Cantor Fitzgerald, I did once work on Wall Street at a firm just like it. During my first office Christmas party, I'll never forget, we danced on table tops.

title: Nissan Mailing Of Pill Bottles Is Ill-Timed
description: WHEN Michael Friedman opened his mailbox on Oct. 9, he found a lumpy white package. It had a clear return address, Nissan Information Headquarters in Fenton, Mo., but also, incongruously, the ''Rx '' symbol for a medical prescription. The postmark, from ZIP code 90746, was unfamiliar.

title: A Virginia Theater True to Shakespeare
description: AVirginia Theater True to Shakespeare

title: The World: Ground Up; After the War, Rebuild a Nation. If It's a Nation.
description: SHAPING nations has never been a neat or easy business, especially for outsiders. President Bush used to love to make that point. But now, with United States Special Forces operating on the ground in Afghanistan, he's going to have to give it a try.

title: Children's Books; Young Man Goes East to the West
description: It is a familiar storybook tale: when drought parches his farming village, a fatherless boy must leave his mother and little sister to seek his fortune in America. But in Elizabeth Partridge's ORANGES ON GOLDEN MOUNTAIN (Dutton, $16.99; ages 4 to 8), the voyage is to the West Coast, not the East.

title: An Esoteric Rattigan Play That Wants to Entertain
description: PRESENTING a play by the British playwright Terence Rattigan, whose glory days were from 1936 to 1956, is a long shot. This is because Rattigan's works are better known to American audiences as period pieces, the last vestige of British theater convention.

title: Pirro-Castro Debate Canceled; New One Is Set
description: A LOCAL branch of the League of Women Voters last week canceled a debate between the two candidates for district attorney, saying it feared the Democratic challenger would not refrain from personal attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREER, SUZANNE RUTH (NEE MARTEN)
description: GREER-Suzanne Ruth (nee Marten). Died October 5th at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Her humor, intelligence, love of the Fine Arts and the game of bridge, and her friendship live on in her children and friends. Survived by loving children, Nancy, James and Paul, and grandchildren, Allison and Evan.

title: The Day the Music Died
description: FRAMED gold and platinum records line the walls of WSOU-FM at Seton Hall University -- tokens of appreciation that hard rock bands like Megadeth, Slipknot, Iron Maiden and Kid Rock sent to the station after they sold one or two million copies of their breakaway albums.

title: Contract Watch Continues
description: It appears only a matter of time before the contract extensions for Manager Joe Torre and General Manager Brian Cashman are announced. ''It's not done, but we're a lot further along,'' Torre said.

title: The World Gets Its Guard Up: Berlin
description: With the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington, security measures, always palpable in Berlin, have been increased. Security is especially visible around American institutions, like the United States Embassy, or those buildings considered to be in extra danger, like the New Synagogue on Oranienburger Strasse, the new Jewish Museum and the Israeli Embassy.

title: Casual and Hip With Moderate Prices
description: WHEN Mim's opened in Syosset in 1987, it was a trailblazer: a casual, hip cafe with one foot in Manhattan and the other in California. Now, 14 years later, a second Mim's has made the scene in Roslyn. The newcomer is very much in the mold of its sibling.

title: Living in Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Hands of Children
description: IT began as a fifth-grade class project after the attacks on the World Trade Center: flag pins made with beads and safety pins. It has turned into a cause that has galvanized this suburb and raised more than $37,000 for the families of the missing.

title: The 'Me, Too' Mind-Set of Disaster Aid
description: ''IN a disaster, it's never fair,'' said Pat Owens, the former mayor of Grand Forks, N.D., a city of 47,000 that was ravaged by floods in April 1997. ''You have to make the best choices you can with the dollars you have to work with.''

title: Children's Books
description: GHOST WINGS

title: Letters
description: Articles on the economy, patriotism, Afghanistan and Israel drew a spate of mail. Readers found Paul Krugman's lesson in economics particularly enlightening, wishing only that the remedy for the current financial decline was half as clear. Other writers were riveted by John Sifton's portrait of Afghanistan.

title: Film; Back on Home Turf, a Breeding Ground of Unrest
description: ROBERT GUDIGUIAN'S new film ''The Town Is Quiet'' (''La Ville est Tranquille'') was inspired by a memory of Marseille.

title: Quel Senor Wins In Steeplechase
description: Despite a mistake at the second jump, Quel Senor took the lead at the 10th jump, then galloped out to a 5-length victory in the $250,000 Breeders' Cup Steeplechase yesterday in Far Hills, N.J. He won the race over two and five-eighths of a mile in 4:54 1/5.

title: Ways to Sacrifice At a Time of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking the Consumers' Pulse
description: The weakened economy, combined with continuing concerns about terrorism, kept depressing consumer activity last week. Here are statistics measuring consumer behavior.

title: New Luxury Apartments Are Handyman Special, Some Say
description: Jamey Altman pays about $4,000 a month for a 25th-floor apartment at 180 Montague Street, a building with glorious views of New York Harbor, 24-hour concierge service and, according to its Web site, ''Old World finishes.''

title: Fear Itself
description: My thanks to Paul Krugman (Sept. 30) for the most cogent piece in recent memory on the underlying dynamics of our economy and the possible directions it might take. If our economy follows the path that Japan's has taken, our political leaders will need fortitude to execute the unconventional steps Krugman outlines, steps that Japan's leaders have shied away from with devastating results for their country and its people.

title: Karpov Regains His Touch At a Buenos Aires Tourney
description: Anatoly Karpov showed that he could still do it when he won the Miguel Najdorf Memorial Tournament which ended on Oct. 13 in Buenos Aires. His last first prize was in August 1996.

title: Recapturing The Flag
description: If Packer truly believes, as he writes, that after the cold war ''patriotism all but disappeared from American politics,'' why is it that only the left is accused of ''irony and contempt''? And his suggestion that Comedy Central versus Fox News was the paradigm for left versus right in pre-Sept.11 America is a gratuitous slap at both networks.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 30 with an article about effects of the terrorist attacks on the American economy misidentified a damaged hotel near the World Trade Center. It was the Millenium, not the Marriott. The caption also misstated the number of people missing at the nearby Marriott. It was two, not none.

title: Yankees Do Their Homework
description: It was hard enough for the Mariners to take advantage of opportunities in the division series against the Cleveland Indians, when they hit .188 with runners in scoring position. Then they came up against the Yankees and went 0 for 10 in those situations in the first two games of the championship series.

title: Bic Tran, David Gassman
description: Bich-Ngoc Tran, a daughter of Dr. Ho Luong Tran and Dr. Ninh Xuan Tran of Chicago, was married last evening to David Kevin Gassman, a son of Meryl and Stephen Gassman of New York. Rabbi Wendy Spears officiated at the Wyndham Bel Age Hotel in Los Angeles.

title: Emroz Khan Is Having A Bad Day
description: Emroz Khan destroys for a living. He dismantles car engines, slicing them open with a sledgehammer and a crooked chisel, prying apart the cylinders, tearing out pistons, dislodging screws and bolts and throwing the metal entrails into a pile that will be sold for scrap. He is 21 and has been doing this sort of work for 10 years, 12 hours a day, six days a week, earning $1.25 a day.

title: At School for Deaf, It's a Natural Fit
description: NEXT month, the oldest school in the nation for teaching deaf children will be led for the first time by a deaf man: Harvey J. Corson.

title: Susan Konner, Jonathan Sabin
description: Susan Elizabeth Konner, a daughter of Carol and Harold Konner of Water Mill, N.Y., was married last evening to Jonathan Robert Sabin, a son of Pamela Saunders of San Francisco and Andrew Sabin of Amagansett, N.Y. Jack McGovern, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated at East Hampton Point, a restaurant in East Hampton, N.Y. Cantor David Benedict took part in the ceremony.

title: Diamonds on the Soles of His Shoes
description: ELEVEN blocks separate Yankee Stadium, that hallowed home of the reigning World Series champions, from St. Mary's Park, a rocky plot cut into the heart of the South Bronx. But the two couldn't appear more distant.

title: Food-Friendly Whites
description: A pair of well-made, food-friendly whites from Palmer Vineyards in Aquebogue on the North Fork provide basic learning opportunities for wine-buying novices without sacrificing the pleasures of more experienced drinkers.

title: Democrats Are Pushed On Judicial Nominees
description: Senate Republicans are engaged in a full-scale campaign to press Democrats to quickly confirm President Bush's judicial nominees, with some asserting that a failure to do so could harm the war on terrorism.

title: Dead Man's Wife Wins Ballot Slot
description: A state Supreme Court justice ruled Friday that the widow of a man killed in the World Trade Center attack can take her husband's place on the Nov. 6 ballot as a Republican candidate for a seat in the Westchester County Legislature.

title: Correspondent's Report; Slow Crawl at the Border
description: IT all used to be so simple. Americans who drove into Canada or Mexico on vacation didn't need passports. Customs inspectors rarely left their booths. In rural areas along the northern border, a traveler's biggest worry was getting through before 10 p.m., when officials left an orange traffic cone or two in the road and went home for the night.

title: October 14-20; Tiniest Transistor
description: Scientists at Lucent Technologies' Bell Labs have made a transistor where the layer that switches currents on and off is just one molecule thick, and that promises faster, better chips. And the transistors seem easy to make. The chip is dipped into a solution of chemicals, and as the liquid evaporates, the specially designed molecules of the switching layer pop into place. Kenneth Chang

title: The Martyr's Son
description: IN THE SHADOW

title: BackTalk; A Midnight Run: Closer to Ground Zero, Closer to the Truth
description: The flight arrived at La Guardia airport a little before midnight on Oct. 4, and I took a taxi directly to my grandmother's apartment at 14th Street and First Avenue. My grandmother has lived in the same apartment for 56 years, and as I lugged my bags up to the third floor, I marveled that the building had not changed substantially: the same shabby paint I remembered from my childhood, the same cracks on the wall, the same narrow staircase. Once inside, I hugged my grandmother and told her about my uneventful flight from Arizona, then put on shorts, a T-shirt and running shoes.

title: The Ship Of State Arrives
description: IT may no longer clip along the high seas at 33 knots, or fire shells the size of cars with precision accuracy, but the battleship New Jersey is serving the latest war effort in a very real way: as a testament to the country's military might.

title: Hiking From Tub to Tub In Rural Northern Japan
description: I HAD only 10 minutes to get from the train to the bus in the village of Tazawako, Japan. It took me five to find the bus station and buy my ticket to Nyuto Onsen, where I wanted to sample the hot springs. With the clock ticking, I dashed out into the village's main street, hauling my backpack, to locate the one essential item I hadn't remembered to take on my six-day hiking trip last month in northern Japan's most geothermically active region: a bottle of sake.

title: Time to Look at Stock Options' Real Cost
description: IN these times of terror, it is gratifying to see a lawmaker stand up against a force of destruction in our midst.

title: After Sept. 11, What Is Truth?
description: To the Editor:

title: If Martinez Awakens, Beware a Comeback
description: The Yankees are over it, that is, the Yankees who are still Yankees. They have since won four World Series, and that development has produced enough salve to cover the wounds.

title: Moderate Muslims Fear Their Message Is Being Ignored
description: Since the September attacks, Al Azhar the revered mosque, the distinguished university, the leading voice of the Sunni Muslim establishment -- has renewed with accustomed grace the roles it has played in the world of Islam for more than 1,000 years.

title: Schilling Displays Domination on the Bases, Too
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 20 — Curt Schilling allowed a run Friday night and he almost appeared vulnerable. Then the Atlanta Braves allowed him to run the bases and they were really in trouble.

title: DataBank; More Than Earnings on Traders' Minds
description: More than one-third of the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index reported quarterly earnings last week, an event that in usual circumstances would dominate the news affecting the stock market. But investors seemed more concerned with the United States military action in Afghanistan and a fresh wave of anthrax scares, creating a nervous mood on Wall Street that left major indexes lower for the week.

title: A Sail for Pride Off Newport Remembers Victims
description: Residents of Newport, R.I., and its neighboring towns can be forgiven if, after gazing out on the water last weekend, they gave their calendars a double take. For while the changing shoreline foliage was a sure sign of autumn, the dozens and dozens of sailboats racing on Narragansett Bay were a snapshot from a summery Saturday afternoon.

title: Turning a Safety Requirement Into the Season's Newest Accessory
description: IN a week when fear of bioterrorism was added to lingering anxiety over the Sept. 11 attacks, businesses all around the country, and especially in New York, began requiring employees to wear identification at all times. That meant stepping up to the camera and submitting to the kinds of indignities previously endured only at the motor vehicles department.

title: Hundreds of Arrests, but Promising Leads Unravel
description: After 40 days of the most aggressive criminal investigation in American history, federal law enforcement officials have arrested 830 people but have failed to develop evidence that anyone now in custody was a conspirator in the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: Cartoon Network
description: DUGAN UNDER GROUND

title: Megan Sheehan, Nicolas Mahedy
description: Megan O'Neill Sheehan, the daughter of Maureen and Timothy Sheehan of Brooklyn, was married on Friday to Nicolas Stanley Mahedy, the son of Margaret and Stanley Mahedy, also of Brooklyn. The Rev. Joel Warden performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Oratory Church of St. Boniface in Brooklyn.

title: New Yankee Fan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Eager To Seize The Power
description: AS autumn leaves litter walkways and mild breezes give way to brisk dawns, there is another unmistakable sign that a change of seasons is upon the State House: the steady buzz of rsums grinding through fax machines.

title: Ashwani Balaganapathy Scott Hanson
description: Ashwani Priya Balaganapathy and R. Scott Hanson were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in Manhattan. The Rev. Nicholas Genevieve-Tweed, an A.M.E. minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Yes, I'm American. How Did You Guess?
description: WHAT is an American? Both common sense and the census make clear that there is no single answer. But there may be a way to say what an American looks like, and it probably starts with the shoes.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the merchandizing of patriotism misstated the Web address of a vendor of slogan- and flag-bearing buttons. It is TheDiscountPrinter.com.

title: The View From/Bridgeport; Make Way on the Ice For Latest Newcomers
description: THE big video screens were flashing red and blue on either side of the scoreboard high above the ice inside the Arena at Harbor Yard in Bridgeport. The scoreboard was blinking with red numbers. Every so often the whirring of a pneumatic drill alternated with the clanking of a new row of chairs being set into place by construction workers.

title: How Britain Became Great
description: A HISTORY OF BRITAIN

title: How's Business? Terrorist Acts Deal a Blow To the Economy
description: ON the surface, little has changed in Westchester since Sept. 11.

title: On Sept. 11, Even Monks Watched Television
description: The 65 Trappist monks of the Abbey of Our Lady of Gethsemani are theoretically removed from the distractions of the everyday world. But on the morning of Sept. 11, the abbot, Damien Thompson, after receiving a telephone call from a neighbor, told them to go to the infirmary, where there was a television.

title: A Fitting Tribute: Memorial Stadium
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Chinese Rights Cases, Once Near Resolution, Now Languish
description: As President Bush met for the first time with President Jiang Zemin of China this week, emphasizing their new cooperation, several high-profile human rights cases sat in a strange kind of limbo in Chinese courts, unresolved despite intense foreign interest and pressure.

title: Theater; A Return to Cuba, A Search for Himself
description: ON Oct. 30, 1961, at the age of 8, Eduardo Machado left Cuba with his younger brother in the exodus known as Operation Pedro Pan, an airlift that brought to the United States some 14,000 unaccompanied Cuban children whose parents feared Communist indoctrination, or worse, under the new revolutionary government of Fidel Castro.

title: Museum to Grow, but Nobody Agrees on How
description: EVERYONE in the Village of Southampton seems to agree that it would be fine, no, even wonderful, if the Parrish Art Museum modernized and expanded. But consensus ends there.

title: Soup and Sandwich
description: SOUPE DU JOUR is no Denny's. It is tucked away off the main street of this little town, with only a vaguely tattered sign to show the way to the parking lot and the low building at the end of it. Inside, it's far out, or something -- the walls decorated with Grateful Dead photographs and the front page from the day Nixon resigned. The peeling ceiling is a sky blue with trompe l'oeil clouds here and there. The 12 tables are a little tight, a little loft holds extra paper towels, a cupboard stores about 30 cookbooks and other supplies. In the teeny tiny bathroom, there are a pair of fish-net-stockinged legs mounted on the wall and crossed suggestively.

title: The Same Blue Uniform, An Unsettling New Terrain
description: DETECTIVES Patrick Divers and Al McCoy of the Brooklyn North narcotics squad used to spend their days running buy-and-bust drug operations in Bushwick. But lately, they have been doing different tasks; far different, like searching for body parts in debris from the World Trade Center at the Fresh Kills landfill, and escorting office workers to their buildings at ground zero.

title: INVESTING WITH/John C. Lui; BNY Hamilton Small Cap Growth Fund
description: WHILE the stock market remains unsettled in the aftermath of Sept. 11, John C. Lui, who runs the $325 million BNY Hamilton Small Cap Growth fund, sees slow but steady growth ahead.

title: Recapturing The Flag
description: Packer's musings on liberalism illustrate the kind of cultural elitism that continues to make the term ''liberal'' a bad word. His characterization of the Peace Corps as a ''not quite satisfying alternative'' serves as an affront to the almost 165,000 Americans, myself included, who have proudly served in its ranks during the past 40 years. All of us experienced, in good measure, the ''danger, commitment and sacrifice'' he vicariously craved. Peace Corps volunteers possess hard-won, detailed knowledge of those troubled areas that are so often featured in today's headlines. Never before in our history has there been such a pressing need for that kind of understanding than today.

title: Shelters Have Empty Beds; Abused Women Stay Home
description: Refuge House, the battered women's shelter in Tallahassee, Fla., is usually full -- so full that there are plans to replace the 28-bed facility with a 70-bed shelter.

title: Nuts and Bolts Vs. Holiness As the Bishops Meet in Rome
description: A monthlong bishops' conference scheduled to end this week has exposed an unexpectedly clear gap between two distinct Catholic worlds, divided along geographical as well as ideological lines.

title: Forced Out of Chinatown, Seeking Greener Pastures
description: Street vendors selling CD's and knock-off T-shirts have long added to the shuffle of street life in Chinatown. As the neighborhood's stream of shoppers has markedly slowed since Sept. 11, many of the vendors have moved on. But where?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 16 for the cover of The Sophisticated Traveler, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, misstated the location of a scene that included a penguin. As readers have pointed out, initially in an e-mail message received on Sept. 17, it was Jabet Peak, on the Antarctic peninsula, as viewed from Wiencke Island; it was not South Georgia Island. This correction was delayed for checking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, NAOMI
description: SOLOMON-Naomi. On October 18, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Alfred. Loving mother of Audrey and Stephen Lang. Dear sister of Henry Rosenberg. Adoring grandmother of Donna, Michele and Scott, Patricia and Gregory. Greatgrandmother of Spencer, Madison and Matthew. Private service.

title: Manhattan Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: BOND MONEY RECOMMENDATIONS
description: The State Library Public Library Construction Advisory Board has recommended that the state designate $45 million in construction aid to to 73 public libraries. The aid would come from bonds authorized by former Governor Christie Whitman. The Joint Budgetary Oversight Committee of the Legislature will decide Nov. 4 whether to designate grants to the libraries recommended by the board. The aid would go toward renovations and expansions as well as to the construction of new libraries in towns including Princeton and Rahway. Sarah Rubenstein

title: After Sept. 11, What Is Truth?
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: A Nuclear Question Mark; India and Pakistan Face New Pressures for War, and Peace
description: THE winds that have blown across India and Pakistan since the terrorist attacks on America have borne the seeds of both war and peace, and no one can be sure which will come to fruition.

title: Theater; Truth As Refuge, Even When It's Ugly
description: ENTER the theater, be seated and as the lights go down, let the troubled outside world recede into darkness. I am hardly alone in a near-desperate desire right now to flee the theater of war whenever I can. Give me a world elsewhere. But of what sort? Ibsen and Strindberg exposed, attacked and longed for something better. They were, in Shaw's words, the Arch-Individualists of the 19th century, twin giants whose ''sieges and stormings'' were aimed at all bogus pieties -- psychic, legal, religious, sexual -- about marriage, family life and the social order. Here are the cat-and-mouse games of intimacy and formality, played by men and women, or by servants and masters. Here is what the pileup of disease and stunted desire, year after year, does to bodies and souls.

title: A Leading Role for the Security Council
description: In the past month, the world has witnessed something previously unknown: a common stand taken by America, Russia, Europe, India, China, Cuba, most of the Islamic world and numerous other regions and countries. Despite many serious differences between them, they united to save civilization.

title: For Artists Who Lived Near Towers, Disaster Brings Its Own Palette
description: The World Trade Center rises again, on her canvas, as two faint, whitish towers shimmering above multihued cornfields lit by three suns.

title: After Sept. 11, What Is Truth?
description: To the Editor:

title: Eavesdropping, U.S. Allies See New Terror Attack
description: More than a month after the September terror attacks, the United States and its close allies are still intercepting communications among Osama bin Laden's associates and are convinced more attacks are coming, intelligence officials in several countries say.

title: LODI PROSTITUTION CASE
description: A complaint filed by William Schmidt, the Bergen County prosecutor, against two assistant United State's attorneys for their handling last summer of an investigation of the Lodi police department and a local massage parlor has been dismissed by the federal Department of Justice. The attornies, Robert Holmsen and Treby Williams, were not guilty of misconduct, according to a letter sent to Robert J. Cleary, United States attorney in Newark, by the Justice Department's Office of Professional Responsibility, which conducted the investigation. Mr. Schmidt charged the lawyers with improperly shielding the owner of Ultima Spa in Lodi, Luke Hoffman, from prosecution on charges of operating a house of prostitution while he acted as an informant on the investigation of the Lodi police department. Karen DeMasters

title: Interpreting Islamic Law for American Muslims
description: For millions of American Muslims, the centuries-old body of Islamic law explains how they should live their lives in this country. But what, exactly, does the law say? Who decides what it says? The answers are far from simple.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Pro Football Notebook column last Sunday about the falling performance of the Dallas Cowboys and the Washington Redskins misstated the combined total of Super Bowls they have won. It is 8; 13 is the combined total of Super Bowls in which they have played.

title: Drug Makers Wrestle With World's New Rules; A Delicate Balance: Patriotism vs. Business
description: WITH fears of bioterrorism growing by the day, the nation's pharmaceutical companies are facing a quandary -- trying to show that they are patriots, not profiteers, even as they protect their way of doing business.

title: The Case For Buying Municipal Bonds
description: TAX-EXEMPT municipal bonds have had a heady run. Since the start of last year, general municipal-debt mutual funds posted an average cumulative total return of 17.22 percent through Wednesday, according to Lipper. The insured category of such funds was up 17.99 percent.

title: Music; A Sideman Steps Out And Shines on His Own
description: FOR nearly two decades the guitarist Marc Ribot has distinguished himself as a resourceful sideman in bands led by Tom Waits, Elvis Costello, John Zorn, Don Byron and John Lurie. What all these artists have in common, besides their irreproachable taste in hiring Mr. Ribot, is their penchant for straddling the line between expressive authenticity and cagey self-consciousness. Their appeal is inseparable from their outsize, half-invented personas.

title: Military Is Putting Heavier Limits on Reporters' Access
description: The Pentagon today presented a fleeting and grainy glimpse of its commando raid in Afghanistan on the television and computer screens of the world.

title: What's News? (And What's Not)
description: NBC's Al Roker and Court TV's Catherine Crier (right) are the hosts of ''Mind Over Media: Voices From the Middle School,'' to be shown tomorrow at noon and 6 p.m. as part of Court TV's ''Choices and Consequences,'' a series for young viewers. The hourlong program is devoted to media literacy, which Scoot MacPherson, an executive at Court TV and director of the project, describes as ''a methodology that teaches kids and parents to be better consumers and viewers of the media.'' ''Mind Over Media'' had been planned well before Sept. 11, but the terrorist attacks on that day, and the ensuing barrage of images and reports, have made it especially timely. In a recently added segment, Amanda Thieroff, a 16-year-old reporter, interviews the ''Today'' show hosts Katie Couric, Matt Lauer and Ann Curry, who covered the disaster as it unfolded.

description: THE e-mail from Deepak Chopra to 22,000 of his fans began with a simple greeting: ''Dear Friends.''

description: HELMAN-Herb. Died October 19, 2001. Services Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., 11:30 AM, October 21. Our beloved, yours is the spirit that will be forever with us. Now it is your time to rest. Your loving family

title: Arrests Are Said to Have Disrupted Attacks
description: The major terrorist attacks that the F.B.I. warned were imminent 10 days ago may have been delayed or prevented by a worldwide campaign of arrests and detentions of suspected Al Qaeda operatives and their allies, according to American officials.

title: Like Mom And Dad: Good-Guy Costumes
description: This Halloween, it has become a trick to know how to treat, as parents struggle to find their children costumes that carry a lower scare factor. In particular, boys' costumes, which traditionally tend toward a guts-and-gore theme, are being toned down. And while fire and police outfits were the immediate favorites in September, more recently a variety of other patriotic costumes have become the top choice: army uniforms and Uncle Sam suits are leading the pack.

title: Corrections

The picture reminiscent of the famous Iwo Jima scene, was by Thomas E. Franklin of The Record of Hackensack, N.J., not from a news agency.

title: October 14-20; More Russian Warmth
description: Russia, after opening its air space to the American military campaign in Afghanistan, also offered its oil fields as a secure alternative to dependence on the turbulent Persian Gulf. And in advance of a meeting set for today between President Bush and the Russian president, Vladmir V. Putin, word came that high-level talks had cleared the path for a breakthrough on key divisive issues: missile defenses and an expanding NATO alliance. ''Not only is the cold war over,'' Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said, ''the post-cold-war period is also over.''

title: G.I. Raid Struck Taliban Leader's Compound
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  The airborne commando raid into southern Afghanistan overnight Friday attacked a military airfield and a headquarters compound of Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban's leader, in a daring strike to uncover information about the location and activities of Taliban and Al Qaeda leaders, the Pentagon said today.

title: Murphy's Laws
description: As the state prepares to elect its first governor of this century, a book has appeared about the first governor of the last one. He was Franklin Murphy, born in Jersey City, a Civil War veteran who became a successful businessman and then a politician. ''A Billy Yank Governor'' (Phoenix Publishing, $35) was written by Bernard Olsen of Little Silver, a Civil War buff who edited a collection of letters from the war, and the Civil War section of this book gets strongest emphasis. As a member of the 13th New jersey Volunteers, Murphy survived such battles as Antietam, Chancelorsville and Gettysburg and took part in the march from Atlanta to the sea. Back in Newark, he established the Murphy Varnish Company. From Newark councilman and then assemblyman, he rose to become a progressive Republican governor, cleaning up the polluted Passaic and improving roads, still good ideas.

title: Learning to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb
description: THE other day, I thought about going to the Mall at Short Hills. But there had been this e-mail warning from a friend of a friend of a friend whose Afghan boyfriend had begged her not to go to the mall on Halloween, which suddenly made shopping till you drop seem dangerous.

title: On Edge, Again
description: NEW YORK is still the city that never sleeps. Fear will do that.

The company will continue to be known as Cooper Leder Marketing, and encompass the personnel, accounts and resources of both companies. . . .Coactive Marketing Group (Nasdaq: CMKG) of Great Neck announced on Oct. 11 that it has formed a strategic alliance with Redna, a multimedia production company based in Cincinnati. Redna is the former in-house production company of Procter & Gamble, a longtime client of Coactive. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

title: Can Peace Finally Come to Kashmir?
description: If the United States is serious about removing the sources of anti-American terrorism, then at some stage Washington will have to tackle the conflict in Kashmir. At present this is the last thing American officials want to do. They have enough on their plate in Afghanistan. But as Secretary of State Colin Powell's experiences in Islamabad and New Delhi illustrated, the Kashmir dispute has the potential both to infuriate India and to weaken the regime of our Pakistani ally, President Pervez Musharraf.

The Rev. John McVean, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victory Church in Rochester.

title: The Other Graveyard
description: Fresh Kills, the 53-year-old Staten Island landfill, had been closed for 172 days on Sept. 11, a closure that was supposed to be permanent. But within hours of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, debris from the wreckage was being ferried across the harbor and Fresh Kills had been called out of retirement. This was debris of a kind never seen there before, carefully sifted on site, hosed down to remove dust before it left Lower Manhattan, then resifted by investigators wearing protective clothing once it reached Fresh Kills.

title: Art/Architecture; Even Scientific Images Have Trouble Telling the Truth
description: SCIENTIFIC pictures are not decoration but knowledge. They support our health, our industry, our search for an understanding of ourselves, our world and the universe. William M. Ivins Jr., who was, starting in 1916, the first curator of prints at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, later said that science couldn't exist without reproducible images. Modern science certainly cannot: it is difficult even to imagine astronomy advancing solely on words and numbers.

title: Fear Itself
description: Krugman seems to suggest that decisions by consumers to reduce their level of spending are somehow irrational and that ''the only thing we have to fear is fear itself.'' Often it is a realistic appraisal of the situation, not fear, that makes people cut back on their spending. It may be that reducing spending is a rational response in the face of massive layoffs. How much more credit-card debt can we take on?

title: Music; A Madama Butterfly Made, More or Less, in Japan
description: LAST June, the diva received this note from a boxholder: ''I was astonished by your performance tonight. Never have I seen such a dramatic Butterfly. You truly lived the part. I have seen every performance since the theater opened. Never have I heard such a fantastic and frantic curtain call as the one you received tonight. You have created a legend.''

description: TED ELIOT, a former American ambassador to Afghanistan, remembers standing on a medieval parapet above a desert in this harsh, fiercely beautiful country and seeing a river of red in the sand.

title: Jihad's Women
description: In some of the larger cities in Pakistan, like Islamabad, Lahore and Karachi, many women work, go to the movies, eat at McDonald's, wear pants and otherwise live a modern, Western-influenced life. But in certain areas, particularly in the Northwest Frontier Province, which abuts Afghanistan, many girls and young women spend much of their time in one of the more than 100 religious schools, or madrassahs, for women. (There are about 10,000 madrassahs for boys and men throughout Pakistan.) Here they are steeped in Islamic fundamentalism -- reading and reciting the Koran many hours a day and learning Arabic grammar and pronunciation. At some of these madrassahs, like Jamia Khadijatul-Kubra-Lil-Binat, immersion is complete; students, who tend to come from poor or lower-middle-class families, board during the week and leave only on weekends to visit their homes. These madrassahs instill a religious ideology that is at the heart of the jihad now being waged against the United States.

title: Guam's New Attraction: Possible Meteor Storm
description: Each year in mid-November, the Earth travels through debris left behind by the comet Tempel-Tuttle -- the Leonid meteors (so named because they appear to radiate out of the constellation Leo).

title: Sag Harbor Factory's Toxic Legacy Lingers
description: BUILT in 1881 by the son-in-law of a whaler on the site of a cotton mill built by out-of-work whaling captains, the Bulova Watch Case building once anchored Sag Harbor's industrial economy. The largest factory in a village of factories, it gave Sag Harbor a blue-collar tinge that made it the ''unHampton'' even into the booming 1980's.

description: THE town of New Canaan's woes might easily be confused with blessings.

title: October 14-20; 2 Gadfly Magazines Close
description: For years, explaining and excoriating the foibles of the news media has been a national sport. Just listen to talk radio. A more rarified group enjoys dissecting the vagaries of the academic world. But it is tough to turn enthusiasms into financially viable magazines. Steven Brill shuttered Brill's Content, his three-year old media-centric magazine (circulation 325,000), saying the idea had not worked. Then Lingua Franca (circulation about 15,000), which since 1990 chronicled real and imagined culture wars, suspended publication when its lone financial backer withdrew.

title: Alone of All Her Kind
description: Elena Michaels, the 30-year-old narrator of Kelley Armstrong's frisky first novel, BITTEN (Viking, $24.95), is a journalist with a devoted boyfriend and a dark secret: a decade earlier, she was bitten by a werewolf and survived, a rare feat that makes her ''the only female werewolf in existence.'' Every few weeks, preferably when her clueless boyfriend is out of town, she sprouts fur and claws and takes a furtive nocturnal run through the streets of Toronto. Passing in human society means disguising her ravenous appetite by devouring sausages and hunks of cheese on the sly and pretending to be demure and physically weak. And Elena is determined to pass. She spent much of her 20's living with a small community of civilized werewolves (known as ''the Pack'') in upstate New York, but has decided to break from her past because she can't give up her ''ordinary, mediocre dreams of a home, a family, a career and, above all, stability. None of that was possible living as a werewolf.'' The novel tells the story of what happens when Elena is summoned to help the Pack defend itself against a band of lawless werewolves (they're called ''mutts''), including several serial killers handpicked and recruited from the human population. (These newly-bitten werewolves are particularly savage.) The plot is that of a thriller, and it's a little shaky: there are too many villains and they are cartoonishly sinister. But the novel also tells a rather sweet love story, and suggests that being a wolf may be more comfortable for a strong, smart young woman than being a human. Jennifer Reese

description: Warren A. Stephens, president and chief executive of the Stephens Group, an investment bank in Little Rock, Ark., has some therapy for market bulls disheartened by the bearish mood since Sept. 11: more movies and more golf.

description: An eight-piece band played Barry White. A redheaded couple ogled diamond-encrusted rings but settled on a pair of simple white gold wedding bands. And a photographer displayed a set of engagement shots depicting two men dressed in khakis and blue oxford shirts kissing on the beach.

title: Business Seeks Youth. The Young Seek Housing.
description: BRIAN POTTS, 25, lives with his parents in East Islip, in the bedroom where he grew up. It's not his ideal living situation, said Mr. Potts, a video technician who works for Hofstra University. ''I could move into a fraternity house near Hofstra,'' he said. ''But I know how the guys live there, and it isn't for me.''

title: It's All in the Details for a Weston Folk Artist
description: THE latest exhibition by the folk artist Kathy Jakobsen ''Innocence of Vision'' had its opening reception at the Housatonic Museum of Art on Sunday, Sept. 9. Two days later, the World Trade Center came crashing down.

title: October 14-20; Israeli's Killing Ignites Fury
description: The slaying of a far-right Israeli cabinet minister in a Jerusalem hotel reversed tentative progress toward peace in the Middle East. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine claimed responsibility for shooting Rehavam Ze'evi, the 75-year-old minister of tourism. The Israeli government said that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, must turn over the killers or be treated as a sponsor of terrorism. But Mr. Arafat insisted that the Palestinians would try any suspects. While the consequences of his rejecting the ultimatum were not clear, Israeli forces occupied several Palestinian-controlled areas of the West Bank. James Bennet

title: Investing; Insurers May Turn to Catastrophe Bonds
description: FACING huge losses from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, insurance companies needing protection against natural disasters are considering catastrophe-linked bonds, securities not known far beyond the circles of institutional investors and Wall Street.

title: Nassau Police Say They're Already Strapped
description: AT 2:30 a.m. on a Saturday morning in late September, detectives from the Nassau County Police Department's Third Precinct were called out from their headquarters in Williston Park to investigate a robbery and shooting in Hempstead. Soon after, an armed robbery was reported at a nightclub in East Meadow. Four men were arrested at the scene.

title: Music; Gospel Speaks a Language Germans Understand
description: IT'S a Saturday night in the southwest part of this city, and a small Roman Catholic church, the Salvator-Kirche Wilmersdorf, is packed to the rafters. The occasion is not a Mass but Gospelnacht, a benefit concert by three local choral societies, and except for one visitor, everyone present (including the choirs) seems German. How strange, then, to hear ''Goin' Up Yonder,'' ''Joshua Fit the Battle of Jericho,'' ''Take a Little Time'' and other African-American gospel classics, sung in colloquial English and accompanied by drums, keyboard, saxophone and trombone.

title: 'Who Is This Kafka That People Keep Mentioning?'
description: Dr. Al Bader al-Hazmi was not asleep when the F.B.I. came knocking before dawn on the morning after the World Trade Center attack. An early riser anyway, he had suffered a fitful night in his San Antonio town house, dreaming of a man jumping from a twin tower engulfed in flames. In the dream, the man expected Hazmi to catch him, and the doctor was running and running with his arms outstretched. Shaking off the dream, Hazmi got up, prayed and then stretched out on his bed to study gastroenterology for a coming medical exam. Becoming board certified as a radiologist is the sole purpose of the 31-year-old Saudi citizen's stay in America.

title: October 14-20; Ukrainian Missile Shakeup
description: After adamantly denying that it had accidentally downed a Russian airliner with an antiaircraft missile -- and then admitting it -- Ukraine had not just egg on its face, but an entire omelet. The cleanup included suspending two air-defense officers who ran the Crimean training exercise from which the missile strayed 150 miles and struck a jet carrying 78. Less clear was what will really happen: President Leonid Kuchma, who recently said other nations had made bigger mistakes, has refused his defense minister's resignation, and Ukrainian justice is not noted for its speed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYON, ELIZABETH
description: LYON-Elizabeth. Psychiatric social worker and housing restorer, died in New York on October 5. She was 89. Born in Cincinnati, Ms. Lyon served in the American Red Cross during World War II, received her MSW from Columbia University, and worked as a psychiatric social worker for the U.S. Army, Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital and Columbia Medical Center. In 1962 she founded Bierer House, the first halfway house for mental patients in New York City, successfully running it as a private, nonprofit facility in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood until 1979. In 1974 she purchased and restored a row of five decaying houses in Newburgh, New York, beginning a restoration movement that has resulted there in the largest historic preservation district in the state, A memorial service is planned for her today at 1:30 PM, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 346 W. 20 St., Manhattan.

title: ON THE MAP; Restoring Remnants of a Moravian Planned Town
description: Amid the bucolic dairy farms of northwestern New Jersey appears a surprising cluster of limestone buildings about 200 years old, remnants of an industrious religious community settled by Moravians. The sect originated in Bohemia in the 15th century and, after bouts of persecution, its followers sought refuge in the New World. In 1769 they established Hope, one of America's early planned towns. Hope failed to become economically self-sufficient and church officials decided to end the venture. In 1808 the settlers held their last service before packing up, leaving behind a gristmill, a distillery, a meetinghouse and other buildings. This spring the New Jersey Historic Trust awarded a $30,000 grant toward restoration of one of those structures, the Long House. Mio French, the treasurer of Help Our Preservation Effort (HOPE), which bought the building in 1998, recently discussed the project.

title: The Freedoms Of Expression

But there was no better time to show that Western fashion is all about women's freedom and their right to choose how they will cover their bodies. In contrast to Afghanistan, where the burqa, a head-to-toe covering, is imposed on women by the Taliban, Paris fashion is all about seduction, status, joy, and the almost forgotten nonprescription remedy of the lifting of spirits of both wearer and viewer.

title: Recording Daily Life, In Glorious Details
description: DUTCH paintings from the 17th century, referred to as a golden age, are often glorious. But they have another side, one that is plainer and sometimes even earthier. Members of the middle class in that era, made rich through trade and manufacturing, admired the plain-spoken and wanted to see their everyday lives recorded in paint. Contemporary viewers get pleasure from these paintings, not only because they are a look at how life was lived, but also because they show how art can transcend the ordinary while faithfully recording it. And that is the joy of seeing ''Art and Home: Dutch Interiors in the Age of Rembrandt,'' the Newark Museum's new show.

In this lyrical and very political film about false security, Mr. Mikhalkov plays a Soviet Revoluntionary hero enjoying a peaceful country existence with his wife (Ingeborga Dapkunaite) and their 6-year-old (Nadia Mikhalkov, the director and star's daughter), until one of the wife's former lovers (Oleg Menshikov) comes for a visit, bringing Stalinsim with him - Sunday at 1 p.m. and Sunday/early Monday at 2 a.m. on Bravo.

title: Temporal Vertigo
description: John Sifton (Sept. 30) recognizes Afghanistan as ''complicated and weird,'' as premodern and postmodern, and he does so with empathy. He describes the effects of years of war on Afghanistan in unexpected, startling and at turns beautiful but more often harrowing detail. His description of a father rearranging a rock on the grave of his child is heartbreaking. Yet he does this with no trace of the self-righteousness that we, citizens of conflagration-ridden states, have come to associate with visiting Western aid workers. Instead, he traces the workers' dive into despair: the one who gets a high from saving others and the one who must literally get high in order to work.

title: E-Mail From an Anxious State
description: In his fascinating account of making aliyah, Daniel Gordis (Sept. 30) observes that George W. Bush's inauguration was laden with Christian theological references that at best discomforted and at worst alienated the many Americans who are not Christian. While I felt the same way about the inauguration, I was taken aback by Gordis's assertion that this is to be expected because ''the U.S. . . . is simply a Christian country.'' It has always seemed to me that what distinguishes this country is not -- or not only -- its commitment to freedom: after all, there are many democratic nations that value freedom highly. Rather, it is our intentional diversity, our promise of liberty and justice for all. This is a promise that we have not always made good on, but to abandon it is to abandon what is best about the United States. Surely it is not an accident that in the days following the Sept. 11 attack many of the photos published in newspapers and magazines showed the still-standing Statue of Liberty, symbol of welcome to people of all cultures and creeds.

description: Long-awaited talks to end the Congo conflict lasted a matter of days before the array of parties gathered in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, opted to call it quits and reconvene later in South Africa. The three-year civil war, which involves foreign nations, rebel groups and various militia, has cost an estimated 2.5 million lives. Organizers of the talks urged the parties not to squander the chance for peace in central Africa. Marc Lacey

description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-21-01: Questions for Paul Rega; By the Book
description: Q: ''Bio-Terry: A Stat Manual to Identify and Treat Diseases of Biological Terrorism'' came out more than a year ago. What got you started worrying about bioterror?

title: Fire Island Waits For Beach Erosion Solution
description: I met twice with Susan Antenen, director of coastal conservation for the Nature Conservancy on Long Island, who was quoted in the Oct. 14 article as saying, ''beach replenishment has negative short- and long-term consequences.'' I offered to take the Nature Conservancy people out to survey the Fire Island shoreline, which is so eroded that breaches are probable in some areas. Ms. Antenen said that a breach would be beneficial to the Great South Bay but seemed blas about the likelihood that a breach would flood portions of the South Shore. She said that even if flooding on the South Shore occurred, Good Samaritan Hospital could protect itself with some sort of dike. Other properties south of Montauk Highway would be unprotected.

title: Music; A Russian Soprano Born to Sing Verdi
description: IN 1849, while composing his 15th opera, ''Luisa Miller,'' Giuseppe Verdi insisted that its heroine should be both ''ingenuous and extremely dramatic.'' Luisa's vocal and theatrical demands, like those of Violetta in ''La Traviata,'' swell as she evolves from the ingnue of Act I to the tragic heroine of Act III. It may be, in part, the difficulty of finding a soprano who can embody these paradoxical traits that has relegated ''Luisa Miller'' to the margins of the repertory.

title: The Lofty Mystery of Why Sturgeon Leap
description: The sturgeon shot spinning out of the water like a spear, its gray flanks and white belly flashing, before crashing back and vanishing. Moments before, some enigmatic urge had compelled the great fish to aim its snout up and accelerate skyward, allowing me a sight that had long eluded me.

title: Footlights; On-Location Painting

Painting ''en pleine air'' like the Impressionists may sound dreamy, but it's not always romantic, said Christopher M. Magadini, a landscape artist. Snow gets into the paint or bugs get stuck in the paintings. Palettes flood in the rain and fingers freeze in the cold.

title: October 14-20; Bush Meets Jiang
description: George W. Bush had big plans for his first meeting with President Jiang Zemin: celebrating China's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization, drawing lines on Taiwan, human rights and arms proliferation. But by the time they actually met, in Shanghai at the beginning of the Asian economic summit, Mr. Bush wanted to talk largely about the war against terrorism, so the sharp edges were sanded off the message he might have delivered a year ago, when he was calling China a ''strategic competitor.''

title: In England, Arsenal Takes Over First
description: Bolton rallied to stun Manchester United, 2-1, in Premier League action yesterday, allowing Arsenal to move into first place despite a 3-3 tie against visiting Blackburn.

title: Food; Mellow Yellow
description: When I was growing up, the most exotic thing anybody could possibly serve was a chicken or shrimp curry. This was in the 60's, in the South, long before we had ever heard of red or green Thai curries. And certainly long before home cooks thought to make their own freshly roasted and hand-ground blends of spices. A ''curry'' was a dish made with marigold yellow curry powder straight from the jar, blended with heavy cream or coconut milk and served with at least a dozen little bowls of delicious condiments ranging from chutney to crumbled bacon and chopped bananas. Its foreign associations put it in the same exalted league of dinner party fare as, say, chicken Kiev, but its flavors were more nuanced and its presentation was far more festive.

title: Eleanor McDonald, Breeder of Champion Bichon, Dies at 66

Perhaps I am not destined to understand it, I who am so distant from art.''

title: When the Spirit Isn't Willing

There were people who faced their own imminent deaths, clear-eyed and sober. There were people who went down fighting. People who thought of others above themselves. Hearing of these people, we are filled with pride by association; touched, vicariously, with virtue. There were people, people like us, who were blessed in a moment of crisis with the Right Stuff.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: Voices of Quetta; A Pakistan City Tied by Tribe To Afghanistan
description: The city of Quetta, Pakistan, has thrived down the centuries as a center for commerce on the ancient Silk Road and the home of tribal groups whose loyalties bowed neither to the sword of invaders nor to the demands of governments. The ruling Taliban in Afghanistan, whose border lies just 60 miles northwest, are mostly from the Pashtun ethnic group, which dominates political and business life in Quetta. The tribal link contributes to the backing here for the Taliban, though the depth of support is hard to gauge.

Already, people unnerved by the presence of enemies on American soil pushed up gun sales after Sept. 11 by 15 percent, though only for two days.

title: Television/Radio; Loving 'Raymond,' A Sitcom for Our Times
description: IT has never exactly been cool to like ''Everybody Loves Raymond,'' the smash CBS comedy that began its sixth season on the network and its first in syndication last month. ''Raymond'' is that object of contempt among professed television sophisticates: a traditional family sitcom. It doesn't feature vaginal eruptions (''Sex and the City'') or transsexual mothers (''Friends'') or horny twentysomethings leaping in and out of bed (everything else), only a horny fortysomething pleading with his wife for sex. It doesn't gleefully break television taboos. It isn't postmodern and self-referential in the ''Seinfeld'' mold. It isn't about nothing. In fact, ''Raymond'' is about everything.

title: 'A History of Britain. Volume II'
description: ‘Great Britain?’ What was that? John Speed, tailor-turned map-maker and historian, must have had some idea, for in 1611 he published an atlas of sixty-seven maps of the English counties, Wales, Scotland and Ireland, loftily entitled The Theatre of the Empire of Great Britaine . An energetic opportunist, Speed was taking advantage of King James's widely advertised desire to be known, not as the Sixth of Scotland and First of England, but as monarch of Britain. The fancy of a British history had been given fresh authority by William Camden's great compilation of geography, the antiquarian chronicle, Britannia, already in its sixth edition by 1607. On its frontispiece sat the helmeted personification of the island nation, flanked by Neptune and Ceres, together with an emblem of British antiquity — Stonehenge — thought to have been built by the Romano-British hero Aurelius.

title: QUICK BITE/South Orange; Where Sloppy Is Neat
description: To the rest of the country a sloppy Joe is that war horse of school cafeterias, ground beef drowned in a sweet tomato sauce and served on a roll. But in North Jersey it is a huge sandwich, which serves at least three, made with a variety of meats on three layers of thinly sliced rye, bound with Russian dressing and laced with cole slaw. These sandwiches are said to have originated at Town Hall Delicatessen in South Orange, and their highest expression is found there. There is nary a kreplach nor a blintz at Town Hall for it is an old-fashioned German deli, one that sells chicken  la king, macaroni and cheese and rice pudding topped with meringue. But the best reason to visit is the sloppy Joe. The most common sloppy (as they are known) is turkey and roast beef ($15.65), but they are made in any requested combination, which could also include tonque and corned beef, all made in the deli's kitchen. Another version is made with smoked salmon, creamed cheese and egg salad ($15.25). Town Hall has been making sloppies since the 1930's, according to one of its owners, Jack Burdorf, when a Maplewood politico, Thomas Sweeney, returned from a vacation in Cuba. There he spent time at a bar named Sloppy Joe's where the owner laid out fixings and patrons put sandwiches together. Mr. Sweeney asked Town Hall to cater his poker games with the same sort of sandwiches, and they caught on. Mr. Burdorf and his partner, Ron Joost, have put Town Hall on the market. They are hopeful that a new owner will keep on making sloppies, but you might not wait too long before ordering a sloppy for that poker game.

description: SAMROCK-Hyla. Died at home on Friday, October 19, 2001. She was 84. Married for nearly 60 years to Victor Samrock, who passed away in 1995, she is survived by her children, Carl and Ellen; grandsons Gabriel and Steven; daughter-in-law Carol and other family members and friends. Born in Hartford, CT, Hyla (Rubin) came to New York as a teenager to study dance and joined the legendary modern dance pioneer Doris Humphrey and her troupe. She left the company in her early 20's to become a wife, mother and homemaker while continuing to follow her passionate commitment to liberal causes. She never finished high school but, through extensive reading and travel, became better educated and more knowledgeable than most college graduates. She loved the arts, especially theatre, music and painting. Her devoted family deeply mourns her passing. Memorial service to be held today, at 2 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. title: The Close Reader; At War With the World
description: Anyone who doubts that literary critics can play a part on the bloody stage of history should consider the example of Sayyid Qutb. Qutb, born in Egypt in 1906 and university educated, was a Western-style literary critic until he devoted himself to Islam after spending two years in the United States exposed to what he viewed as our decadence. He died in 1966, when he was hanged along with other Muslim radicals by the government of Gamal Abdel Nasser. Qutb's books of hard-line political theology have had a direct influence on the Saudi Arabian Muslim opposition; the Islamic Salvation Front in Algeria; the Palestinian group Hamas; the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt, Jordan, Iraq and Lebanon; Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the Egyptian cleric jailed for several thwarted terrorist plots and linked to the 1993 World Trade Center bombing; and the Iranian writer Ali Shariati, who helped foster the Islamic revolution in Iran.

The stockpile makes sense as a preparedness measure, even though there is absolutely no information in hand that suggests a smallpox attack is imminent or likely. That is an area where an accelerated federal effort is clearly warranted.

description: It appears to be campus drama week Off Broadway. Like ''The Shape of Things'' by Neil LaBute, Billy Aronson's ''Light Years'' is a courtship dance for four college students and at its heart a coming-of-age story. But unlike Mr. LaBute, whose mean and crafty play sends his characters out into adulthood betrayed and wounded, with lessons under their belts that no one would ever hope to learn, Mr. Aronson provides a lightly absurdist view of the college years that is in the end melancholy and hopeful.
