description: To the Editor:

title: Emotional Return Awaits Graves
description: Mark Messier knows better than most what will be going through Adam Graves's mind tonight when Graves makes his return to Madison Square Garden for the first time as a member of the San Jose Sharks.

title: Yankees Audio: A.L.C.S. Game 5
description: Postgame audio from Game 5 of the A.L. Championship Series between the Yankees and the Seattle Mariners, provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Oct. 12 about Lydia Estelle Bravo, a nurse at Marsh & McLennan who was a victim of the World Trade Center attack, misstated the name of the school where she studied cooking. It was Peter Kump's New York Cooking School, not Peter Gumps. (Since Sept. 17, the school has been called the Institute of Culinary Education.)

title: Equity Offerings Planned This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft and PC Industry Prepare for Windows XP

title: Roar of the Warplanes Overhead Bolsters the Hopes of the Rebels
description: The roar of the first jet this afternoon prompted reflexive fears of an enemy attack on this rebel-held territory. But when another and then another jet thundered overhead, flying so high they could not even be seen, it dawned on people what might finally be happening: the end of their years of isolation and defeat.

title: The Ultimate Hatred Is Nuclear
description: Bioterrorism, like the anthrax threats currently rattling America, is horrific. But perhaps the ultimate horror in our newly uncertain world is the prospect of terrorists with nuclear weapons. There is no evidence that any terrorist has nuclear materials now, but the possibility is serious enough so that the government should be heightening security at home by monitoring foreign nations' weapons more closely and planning for military raids, if necessary, to keep weapons out of the wrong hands.

title: A Youth Is Slain in Bethlehem, and Passions Flare
description: The spot in Manger Square where Johnny Thaljieh fell has already become a shrine, or perhaps an exhibit. His blackening blood on the cobblestones is surrounded by rocks and blue metal barricades, to honor his memory and to shield the evidence of what his family said was a random slaying by Israeli soldiers after church on Saturday.

title: One Reconstructed Face, but Many People in Disguise
description: LOOK AT ME

title: Enlightenment on Energy
description: The events of Sept. 11 have inspired some sErious rethinking of a whole range of issues, from airline safety to intelligence gathering. On the face of it, this should also be the perfect time for a measured reassessment of the nation's energy strategy. Turmoil in the Persian Gulf and Middle East has again raised fears about disruptions in the oil supply while providing yet another reminder of the country's increasingly precarious dependence on imported oil. Regrettably, Congress and President Bush, transfixed by the notion that America can drill its way to energy independence, are in danger of letting this opportunity for enlightened policy-making slip away.

title: New Economy; During emergencies, officials need access to wireless communications systems. But regular people do, too.
description: ONCE again, the federal government has asked the telecommunications industry to find a way to provide public safety officials with priority access on wireless communications systems in times of crisis. And once again, those involved in the effort are discovering the difficulty of carrying out such a mission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, ERMA
description: BRENNER-Erma. A dear old friend whose buoyant nature gave my wife and me enduring pleasure over many decades of friendship. To Charlie, her devoted husband, my loving condolences. David Mayer

title: Displaced, but Lucky
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Rams' Trickery Works, Then Goes Overboard
description: The Jets were holding the St. Louis Rams to 7 points with about five minutes left in the second quarter yesterday, and that counted as a moral victory against The Greatest Show on Earth. The Jets were confident. They had swagger. They were beating up Kurt Warner, and the injured superstar running back Marshall Faulk was on the Rams' sideline wearing a T-shirt and ugly sunglasses. The crowd was into it. There was hope.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about bills signed and vetoed by Gov. Gray Davis of California referred incorrectly to legislation to require financial institutions to get permission from customers before selling information about them. While he opposed the bill, the Legislature never passed it, so he did not veto it.

title: Accounts
description: * Yellow Book USA, Rockville Centre, N.Y., which publishes yellow pages directories, to Trahan, Burden & Charles, Baltimore, to handle its account, which had been in-house. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $20 million. Yellow Book USA is a unit of Yell, owned by Apax Partners & Company and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst.

title: Job Seekers Flood Spy Agencies
description: The nation's intelligence agencies have experienced a surge in job seekers since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, a boom born of lofty patriotism and cold economic realities, recruiters say.

title: Kuala Lumpur Journal; On Muslim Soil, a Lesser Fear of Great Heights
description: Jan Schouten peered down from the sky-bridge at the Petronas Towers, 557 feet above the street. The view from part-way up the world's tallest buildings was dazzling -- a magic-carpet ride over the Moorish domes and minarets of this Southeast Asian city.

title: Auto Rates Are a Campaign Issue Again as Insurers Prepare to Leave
description: Four years ago, James E. McGreevey nearly won the governorship of New Jersey with a campaign that harnessed voter anger over high automobile insurance rates. This time, the rate debate has been muted at best -- in part because Mr. McGreevey has chosen to make his Republican opponent, Bret D. Schundler, the main issue, and in part because the Sept. 11 attacks have voters worrying about larger questions of safety and survival.

title: The Role of the Press in Wartime
description: To the Editor:

title: Magazines closely weigh ad rates for the fourth quarter and early 2002 in a moribund market.
description: MICHAEL G. EARLS has big plans as he reintroduces Appellation magazine next month: a new name, Wine Country Living; an added editorial focus on homes, cooking, culture and lifestyle, as well as wine and travel; and a drive to double the rate base, the circulation guaranteed to advertisers, to 100,000.

title: Stocks End Higher Amid Wave of Confidence
description: Stocks climbed strongly today, gathering momentum and adding to a rally that began late Friday afternoon, as investors showed confidence in an eventual economic recovery.

title: Sports of The Times; Jets on a Treadmill to Middling
description: ROUGHLY a third of the way through the 16-game schedule, the 3-3 Jets appear to be on a treadmill to an 8-8 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTIN, BERNARD
description: KURTIN-Bernard, Oct. 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Jeanie; father of Owen & Sabryna; grandfather of Jean-Michael, Noah and Dora; brother of Elayne; and English teacher of thousands of New York City high school students.

title: Spreading Charity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZMAN, ROBERT
description: HOLTZMAN-Robert. On October 21, 2001, of Coconut Creek, FL. Beloved husband of Muriel. Loving father of Ellen and Marvin, Michael and Judy, and Wendy and Doug, and cherished grandfather. Funeral service 12 noon, Monday at I.J. Morris Inc, 46 Greenwich St, Hempstead, NY.

title: Feverish Protests Against the West Trace to Grievances Ancient and Modern
description: From the eerily passionless voice of Osama bin Laden to the fevered chants on the streets of the Middle East and across the Islamic world, a litany of historical grievances against the West is being aired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, WILLIAM F., JR.
description: BURKE-William F., Jr., Captain, FDNY Engine 21, Manhattan, NY, heroically in the line of duty at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Beloved son of the late William F., Sr. (retired Deputy Assistant Chief, FDNY) and Agnes H. (nee Crowe). Loving brother of Elizabeth Berry, Christopher, Michael, James and Janet Roy. Adored friend of Jean Traina and Terri Seir. Cherished uncle to many nieces and nephews. Billy also worked for many years as a Life Guard at Robert Moses State Park. Memorial visitation at the Vernon C. Wagner Funeral Homes, Inc., 125 Old Country Rd., Hicksville on Wednesday, October 24, 2001 from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Memorial Mass Thursday, October 25, 2001 at 2:00PM at St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made in Billy's memory to Engine 21, World Trade Center Fund, 238 East 40th Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: Bullpen Can't Save Seattle
description: Norm Charlton was a Nasty Boy, part of the famed Cincinnati Reds bullpen trio that produced a World Series title in 1990. But that bullpen is not the best Charlton has pitched for.

title: Officials Fear Tuberculosis Epidemic in Camps
description: Even as aid workers struggle to provide enough food to countless Afghans displaced by war, drought and Taliban repression, health officials say they are increasingly concerned that both Afghanistan and Pakistan face another threat: a potential epidemic of tuberculosis.

title: Davenport Wins Swisscom in Zurich
description: Lindsay Davenport defeated Jelena Dokic, 6-3, 6-1, to win the Swisscom Challenge in Zurich yesterday for her sixth title of the season.

title: Herman S. Sandler: Card Tables and Confidence
description: Herman S. Sandler was a presence, Thomas F. O'Neill said yesterday. When he walked into a room, you could not fail to notice. He had enormous confidence and a wonderful laugh. He looked like Daddy Warbucks: a tall man with a shaved head. He loved being out on the water — in the Hamptons, in Palm Beach, on his boat. He had a permanent tan.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Afghan Opium Resurgent

title: One Swing in Ninth, and Soriano's Sins Are Forgiven
description: Alfonso Soriano swung his 35-inch, 34-ounce maple bat in the bottom of the ninth inning last night, the largest bat used by any of the Yankees, and he felt the ball relent. Right away, he thought of his angry manager and teammates.

title: Essay; Advance The Story
description: Veteran reporters and creaking commentators have a single goal in writing about great events: advance the story. Unearth facts that policy makers do not know, do not want to know, or do not want the public to know they know.

title: Departures Continue on Madison Avenue
description: TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ), is laying off employees at its United States offices, in New York; Playa del Rey, Calif.; and San Francisco. The layoffs are to total fewer than 20 people, around 2.5 percent of its United States staff of 800.

title: Aggressive Strategy Brought On Inquiry of Recording Industry
description: For several years, some consumers and financial analysts have accused the major record labels of moving too slowly onto the Internet. Now, the government and the companies' competitors are saying the labels may have moved online too aggressively.

title: Newsweeklies Run to Keep Up On Tricky Turf
description: At 11 a.m. Friday, about two dozen Newsweek staff members gathered around a conference room table. The photo department had just been reopened after an anthrax scare that proved to be a false alarm. And word had spread that morning of new activity by United States Special Forces on the ground in Afghanistan, throwing up in the air the contents of the issue closing the next day.

title: No Ordinary Election in Nassau County
description: Missing a chance to make a classy exit, Thomas Gulotta, Nassau County's lame-duck county executive, submitted a final budget proposal that is wildly out of whack. The oversight board monitoring the county's precarious finances appears to have given up on trying to extract from him a responsible four-year plan that avoids adding to the huge deficits his administration created with fiscal mismanagement and political sleight of hand.

title: Yankees Audio: A.L.C.S. Game 4
description: Postgame audio from Game 4 of the A.L. Championship Series between the Yankees and the Seattle Mariners provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Patents; Extending timetables for applications by those affected by the attacks on the trade center.
description: FACING the Potomac, the Patent and Trademark Office complex is in sight of the Pentagon. When its neighbor was attacked on Sept. 11, employees evacuated their buildings, fiery ruins and frantic rescue efforts visible on the horizon.

title: Coca-Cola Site in India Bombed In a Protest Over Afghanistan
description: A banned, far-left rebel group bombed a Coca-Cola plant in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh today. Its members left behind a note in the local Telugu language saying the attack was to protest the American bombing of Afghanistan and threatening more such actions.

title: Jets' Defense Is Overrun as Rams and Canidate Have a Field Day
description: You could almost see Coach Mike Martz flipping through the St. Louis playbook today, searching for the next way to embarrass the Jets. If the Jets' defense could be brought to its knees with an option play, why not step on their necks with a direct snap to a rookie running back? And then grind them into the ground with an onside kick.

title: Mexican Human Rights Lawyer Is Killed
description: One of Mexico's most prominent human rights lawyers was found shot to death in her office here on Friday, bringing criticism of the administration of President Vicente Fox from environmentalists and rights advocates.

title: Weekly Business Events
description: MONDAY

title: Admiral Is New Domestic Security Aide
description: The White House chief of domestic security, former Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, has selected a retired four-star admiral, Charles Stevenson Abbot, as his deputy, administration officials said yesterday.

title: Some Comic Strips Take an Unpopular Look at U.S.
description: The events of the last six weeks have challenged creators of newspaper comic strips. Some have responded by simply avoiding references to terrorism and patriotic fervor. Others, like Aaron McGruder, have tackled those topics head on.

title: Wacky, Upstairs and Downstairs
description: Miranda Hoffman's festive costumes alone are enough to make you smile. Suzanne (Rinne Groff) is in her white wedding ensemble: a strapless bustier, leggings and a sheer overskirt. The men are dressed in various combinations of leggings, elegant coats, clunky high heels and garters. There are a lot of midriffs showing. Target Margin Theater's production of ''The Marriage of Figaro'' is, in the company's tradition, deliberately wacky. The cast has a collective way with deadpan humor.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies After Fistfight
description: A Brownsville man was fatally injured during a fistfight with a neighbor when he fell and struck his head on pavement, the police said yesterday. It was unclear what prompted the fight on Saturday night, but the police said it was part of a continuing dispute. The man, James Estmond, 47, was taken to Brookdale Hospital, where he died, the police said. Officers immediately arrested the neighbor, Prince Bartholomew, 22, outside his home at 93 Williams Avenue, where the scuffle broke out around 10:30 p.m. The police said that charges against Mr. Bartholomew were pending yesterday. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Bears' Thomas Runs All Over the Bengals
description: Downtrodden teams that seek to turn into brave and bold contenders have been jostling atop the N.F.L. this season, and that attitude was epitomized this afternoon when the Chicago Bears and the Cincinnati Bengals tangled. The Bears and the Bengals have been so bad for so long that it was hard to believe that both entered this matchup with winning records.

title: The New York Times Top 50
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining its record against other teams.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 4 about Capt. Jack O. Bennett, who piloted the first supply plane of the Berlin Airlift in June 1948, misidentified the craft. It was a Douglas DC-4; the DC-8 did not enter commercial service until the mid-1960's. This correction was delayed for research in military and commercial aviation archives to resolve conflicting information from experts and publications, some of which listed it as a DC-3; American Overseas Airlines and McDonnell Douglas are no longer in business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALOMON, EDNA B.
description: SALOMON-Edna B. The Collegiate Chorale notes with profound sadness the passing of Edna B. Salomon. We thank her for generaous and long standing support of the Music Director's Chair, and express our condolences to her family. We will remember her in our music. Susan L. Baker, Chair Robert Bass, Music Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSKY, DOROTHY (NEE SHOSPAK)
description: LIPSKY-Dorothy (nee Shospak). ''Bads,'' 89, died peacefully in her sleep at Parkway Hospital on Saturday, October 20. She is survived by her devoted husband of 65 years, Daniel, her two loving children, Ina and David, her three grandchildren, Julia, Daniel and Suzanne, and her brother Arnold. Dorothy was a sensitive artist, decorator, art teacher and caring wife and mother. She always had a smile and kind word to say to children and adults from all walks of life.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From recipes for green tomatoes to the perils behind making homemade wine, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: 2nd Triumph by Cceres, Or 2 More Than Expected
description: When the PGA Tour season began, hardly anyone expected Jos Cceres to win more tournaments than David Duval, Vijay Singh, Ernie Els or Davis Love III.

title: Son Cheers, and Posada Can Smile Again
description: The happy boy sat on top of the Yankees' dugout two weeks ago, his feet dangling and his mouth moving, while a few Yankees took batting practice at a barren Yankee Stadium. His mother allowed the 23-month-old to frolic in the terrific seat and watch his father hit, but she clutched him tight. The mother and the father clutch Jorge Posada IV even tighter these days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ROY
description: LERNER-Roy. On October 19. Beloved husband of Ceil; loving father of Arthur and Gene and their wives Barbara and Elaine; adored grandfather of Scot, Stacy, Stefanie, Lisa and Jay; and greatgrandfather of Jake, Harrison, Charles and Lily. Your love and dedication will live in our hearts forever.

title: In America; Democrats Make Nice (Finally)
description: It was like watching a rerun of ''All in the Family.''

title: Ghent Meeting Underscores Factionalism : Fight Against Terrorism Opens Fissures in the EU
description: PARIS  Rather than consolidating the European Union into a political force, the campaign against terrorism in Afghanistan is turning it into a center of factionalism, moving the EU away from its goal of becoming a single, operative voice on issues as vast and sensitive as peace and war.

title: The Role of the Press in Wartime
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Crown; Questioned Vietnam Policy
description: Joseph H. Crown, who was active in the Lawyers Committee on American Policy Towards Vietnam, died on Sept. 28 at his home in Cuernavaca, Mexico. He was in his mid-90's and also had a home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: U.S. Faces Tough Choices If bin Laden Is Captured
description: Lawyers are beginning to ask the next question: What do we do if we catch him?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day last Monday about the Verizon Communications office damaged by the Sept. 11 attacks referred incorrectly to the abilities of telephone networks to reroute traffic. Like information on the Internet, such traffic can indeed automatically reroute itself if it encounters a damaged path. The Internet's ability to do that is not unique.

title: Shattering The Silence, Illuminating The Hatred
description: ''Focus'' sprang off the streets of New York in the 30's and 40's. With no money for college, I had spent three years driving trucks, pushing carts in the garment district and working as a parts clerk in a warehouse. I knew what I knew, what I had seen and heard, and too often it didn't match what I was reading in the papers and hearing on the radio. Especially the Big Secret -- the city was pulsing with hatred. Perhaps not always but on certain days, yes. On certain days Hitler was rising, but not only in Germany.

title: Arms Control: Russia and U.S. Agree to Agree
description: For President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Bush, the road to Crawford, Tex. -- and the tantalizing goal of rewriting the rules of arms control -- may have rounded its last corner here in Shanghai.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the British politician Lord Hailsham on Tuesday misstated the year he had Enoch Powell dismissed from the Conservative shadow cabinet over racial issues. It was 1968, not 1974.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, CHARLES JR.
description: IRWIN-Charles Jr. October 17, 2001. Major USMC (retired). Beloved husband of Jane Darlington Irwin. Devoted father of Charles D. Irwin and his wife Dona. Cherished grandfather of Carter, Robert and Roger. He graduated from Schreiner Military Academy & Southern Methodist University, class of 1942. Decorated Combat Marine Corps Officer in the Pacific Theatre during World War II and The Korean Conflict. Partner of the Wall St. firm W.C. Langley Co. An ardent student of history and a friend to all who knew him. Service on Tuesday, October 23rd, 10 AM at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Avenue and 53rd St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Marine Corps. Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 3008, Princeton, New Jersey 08543, or to St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Sorry They Were Missing
description: Joe Torre called a team meeting before yesterday's game to remind his players of their obligation to be available to the news media. Seven of the eight starting position players -- first baseman Tino Martinez, shortstop Derek Jeter, third baseman Scott Brosius, outfielders Chuck Knoblauch, Bernie Williams and Paul O'Neill, and catcher Jorge Posada -- departed Yankee Stadium after the 14-3 loss in Game 3 before members of the news media were admitted to the clubhouse.

title: U.S. Women to Skip Hockey Event
description: USA Hockey officials announced Saturday that they had decided to pull the women's national team out of the Four Nations Cup in Finland next month. It was the team members, however, who apparently made the decision.

title: Britain Adopts Emergency Law to Deter Anthrax Hoaxes After Spate of False Reports
description: Saying its police, medical and post office services were being overwhelmed by a spate of anthrax hoaxes, Britain today adopted an emergency law with immediate effect that punishes violators with jail terms of up to seven years.

title: Security First, Then the Cheers
description: George Steinbrenner arrived at Yankee Stadium the other day and approached a security checkpoint. The personnel were asking for photo identification and examining contents of all bags, but they hesitated as Steinbrenner walked up; the rank- and-file employees at Yankee Stadium fear Steinbrenner.

title: Bacteria on the Farm
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From News Conference on Anthrax in Postal Workers
description: Following are excerpts from the news conference held Monday afternoon by Tom Ridge, director of the Office of Homeland Security; Mayor Anthony Williams of Washington; John Potter, postmaster general; and Vincent Sombrotto, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers, after they met with President Bush.

title: First-Time Fatherhood at 57 Brings a New Perspective
description: TWO days after terrorists unleashed their globe-shaking assault, Senator Christopher J. Dodd's own world changed substantially when he became a father for the first time.

title: Excerpts From News Conference on Anthrax in Postal Workers
description: Following are excerpts from the news conference held Monday afternoon by Tom Ridge, director of the Office of Homeland Security; Mayor Anthony Williams of Washington; John Potter, postmaster general; and Vincent Sombrotto, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers, after they met with President Bush.

title: Worker Finds Gains At Airport Are Mixed
description: Long before the Sept. 11 terrorist hijackings, Danilo Orcullo, who screens airline passengers from 4 a.m. to noon each day, thought airport security was a mess, he says.

title: POSTAL EMPLOYEE IN WASHINGTON HAS ANTHRAX IN LUNGS
description: A worker at the Washington post office that handles all mail delivered in the capital was infected with a dangerous form of anthrax, health officials said today. The diagnosis comes a day after anthrax bacteria was also detected in a building that processes mail for the House of Representatives.

title: O'Neill Plans to Play Game 5
description: Yankees right fielder Paul O'Neill aggravated the stress fracture in his left foot in the third inning of last night's American League Championship Series game, but he says he expects to play in Game 5 tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, HAROLD
description: SIEGEL-Harold. Beloved husband of Carol. Father of Peter, David (Lisa) and Andrew (Meredith). Adoring grandfather of Ruby and Gabriel. We will love you and we will miss you.

title: This Week
description: Stepping Out

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, GERTRUDE K.
description: MILLER-Gertrude K. 93, on October 20, 2001. Mother of David A. & Richard J. Miller. Sister of Jerome C. Klein. Grandmother of eight, great-grandmother of eight. Funeral service Monday, 12 noon, Temple Beth El, Chappaqua, NY. Interment to follow at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Contact Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY; 914-769-0001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLEBY, DORIS R.
description: APPLEBY-Doris R. On October 21, 2001. Wife of the late Aaron Appleby. Mother of Jean Baltzly and the late Joseph Appleby. Sister of Thelma Eisen, Walter Weiss, and the late Lillian Romm. Mother-inlaw of Edward Baltzly. Burial at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: James Phillips, 70, Environmentalist Who Was Called the Fox
description: James F. Phillips, an environment advocate who used flamboyant tactics like putting metal caps on top of belching smoke stacks, then leaving a note signed ''the Fox,'' died on Oct. 3 in Aurora, Ill. He was 70.

title: A Gimpy Camby Is Set to Put His Foot Down and Return to the Knicks
description: When the rest of the Knicks called it a day after a long and painful practice today, Marcus Camby hobbled onto the floor with a sneaker on his right foot and a walking boot on his left. He grabbed a basketball and tossed up a set shot, hardly moving in a way that would indicate he was close to returning to action.

title: Scramble for New Business Web Addresses Is Delayed by Added Tests and a Lawsuit
description: Open registration for Internet addresses ending in .biz, originally scheduled to begin tomorrow, has been pushed back to Nov. 7, according to the company that manages the .biz database, NeuLevel.

title: Americans Plead to Remain in Bosnia
description: Drinking espresso and chain-smoking, Ljubisa Maksimovic surveyed the rifle-toting American soldiers walking patrol outside the Venera, one of this war-gutted city's few vibrant nightspots. What would happen, he was asked, if those troops were to leave?

title: Lady Jean Rankin, 96, Dies; Waited on Queen Mother
description: Lady Jean Rankin, who held an archaic job as a Woman of the Bedchamber to Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, for more than 40 years, died in Edinburgh on Oct. 3. She was 96.

title: Where Guests Used to Visit, Anxiety Sets In
description: At the SoHo Grand and the Tribeca Grand, two chic hotels in Lower Manhattan, the lounges and bars are beginning to fill up, along with the guest rooms. At the Bryant Park Hotel in Midtown, more than half of the 129 luxury rooms are occupied. At the Plaza Hotel, a Fifth Avenue landmark, fears that the famed Oak Room and Oyster Bar will close have dissipated.

title: Sooners and Huskers Stay Perfect
description: College football fans know the history of their sport and they remember their famous coaches on the basis of first names and nicknames. So they understood the significance Saturday when JoePa won to tie Bear while Bobby won to tie Pop. They also know that current results and rankings affect bids to bowls and why defeats last weekend hurt the long-term hopes of previously unbeaten teams like Oregon and Fresno State.

title: San Jose Captures M.L.S. Cup on a Goal From a Late Replacement
description: The San Jose Earthquakes went from last place last season to the championship of Major League Soccer this afternoon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Castle Clinton To Reopen
description: The Castle Clinton National Monument, the 19th-century fort that until recently housed National Guard troops after the attack on the trade center, is set to reopen today. Completed in 1811 to protect New York Harbor from British invasion, it later became the site of balloon launchings, an immigration station and an aquarium. The fort now serves as a ticket booth for ferries to the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, which are still closed.

title: Sele to Pitch Tonight
description: Since 1998, Mariners pitcher Aaron Sele is 69-35. Only Randy Johnson, Greg Maddux and Tom Glavine have won more games in that span. Sele has been an All-Star twice, and his teams have reached the playoffs in all of those seasons. By all rights, he could be regarded as a premier starting pitcher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, JOHN
description: KANTOR-John. October 15, 2001. Beloved husband of Marion. Cherished father of Linda Kantor Swerdlow. Adored grandfather of Benjamin. Beloved father-in-law of Michael Swerdlow. Survived by sister Sonia Coburn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, ITZAHAK
description: PERRY - Itzahak. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ, mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Jeffrey R. Parker, President

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are saying we want to go to the gates of Kabul and stop there.''

title: Corrections
description: The Outsider column in Weekend on Oct. 5 about old-growth forests misspelled the name of a waterfall in the Catskills. It is Kaaterskill Falls, not Katterskill.

title: Islam Attracts Converts By the Thousand, Drawn Before and After Attacks
description: Since she became a Muslim six months ago, Angela Davis has given up many things. She stopped listening to music, started sleeping on the floor, put away her 100 Disney videos and traded her porcelain doll collection for velvet posters with verses from the Koran.

title: U.S. Begins Search for Medicine Used to Treat Adverse Reactions to Smallpox Vaccine
description: As the federal government starts negotiating to procure enough smallpox vaccine to inoculate every American, a separate effort has already begun to obtain large quantities of the scarce medicine needed to treat people with adverse reactions to the vaccine, federal health officials said today.

title: Insurers Push for Cap on Future Payouts
description: Late last month a senior executive from Swiss Re, the world's second-largest reinsurance company, paid an unheralded visit to the White House. He told top economic advisers to President Bush that his company planned to quit providing coverage to the property and casualty insurers for losses from future terrorist attacks.

title: AN OVERVIEW: Oct. 21, 2001; Bombs on the Northern Front, Finger-Pointing in Washington
description: The common wisdom since the bombing of Afghanistan began two weeks ago has been that Kabul, the capital, should not fall until a coalition government is ready to take charge. But the Pentagon has apparently concluded that winter is a greater threat and ordered the first major bombing of the Taliban's northern front.

description: We are at a critical juncture in the fight to cut off the funding for Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network and other terrorist groups. Both the United States Senate and the House have taken important steps by passing anti-money-laundering measures that are now being considered in relation to broader antiterrorism legislation. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Train Service To Newark Airport
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey opened train service from Manhattan to Newark International Airport yesterday. New Jersey Transit and Amtrak trains leaving from Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan can now stop at a new station that connects directly to the airport's monorail system. Tickets from Penn Station for the 20-minute trip to the airport cost $11.15 on New Jersey Transit. Amtrak tickets cost $23 on weekdays and $24 on weekends. The $415 million project was financed by the Port Authority and by a fee taken from Newark airfares. Service from other stations, including Philadelphia, Princeton Junction and Long Branch, is also available. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Sights as Well as Sounds Tell Shostakovich Tale
description: Shostakovich's 15th and last string quartet is a melancholy chronicle of one man's life, at least its final chapter. Its string of mournful, indeed painful, slow movements bring to mind Haydn's great ''Seven Last Words of Christ,'' although its bruised hopelessness is at a distance from the earlier man's dignity and reserve. The Shostakovich is also a wonder of plain speaking. Its tonal language speaks directly to the tradition-bound listener, and yet it finds new and personal ways to arrange the grammar of the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, THOMAS JAMES
description: KANE-Thomas James. Passed away on October 20, 2001, at 91 years of age in New York City. He was the beloved husband of the late Beatrice Staunton Kane, loving father of Anne Shea, Kathryn Conboy, Beatrice O'Connell, Thomas Kane, Jr. and Edward Kane. He was the cherished grandfather of 17, and the great-grandfather of two. He graduated from Manhattan College in 1932 and received a Masters Degree from Columbia University in 1934. His entire career was in Hotel Management, primarily at the Waldorf Astoria. Upon graduating from Manhattan, during the Depression, he took a job in the mailroom and rose to become a Vice-President and General Manager of the Waldorf twenty-five years later. He came to know diplomats, heads of State, and four Presidents of the United States, and was admired and respected by everyone from porters to executives at the Waldorf, the Biltmore and the Roosevelt. He was an outstanding New Yorker. Friends will be received at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St. at Kraft Ave., Bronxville, NY, 7-9 PM, Monday, October 22, 2001. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lexmark To Cut Work Force
description: Lexmark International, which makes computer printers, said it would cut as many as 1,600 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force. Third-quarter revenue was up about 8 percent compared with the same period last year; profits rose almost 6 percent, to $70 million, because costs declined and sales of printer supplies increased. But fourth-quarter profits will be lower, Lexmark officials said, because the company's sales have dropped off -- along with overall personal computer sales -- and the economy has weakened. ''These difficult steps are necessary to intensify our focus on being the low-cost producer in the industry,'' said Paul J. Curlander, chief executive of Lexmark. Shares of Lexmark fell $5.58, to $44.77.

She left the company to become a wife, mother and homemaker while continuing to follow her passionate commitment to liberal causes. Contributions to Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th St., NYC 10022 are appreciated.

title: 'La Bohme' Once More, Emphasis on the Characters
description: A confession: the prospect of seeing another ''La Bohme'' on Friday night did not fill the critical heart with glee. A happy revelation: by Act II the New York City Opera production was getting the magic across. This is exactly what City Opera is supposed to do, present young voices in a fine staging that brings out the work's dramatic relevance. Perfect? No. Compelling? Yes.

title: Ripple Effect From Attack: Suppliers Have No Demand
description: In the 40 years that Bik Ka Ng has been manufacturing clothes, he has never heard sewing machines come more swiftly to a halt than they did after Sept. 11. The owner of a factory at 148 Lafayette Street, which produces trousers for stores like Ann Taylor and Brooks Brothers, Mr. Ng has had to lay off 60 sewers, and there is not enough work for his remaining 100 employees.

title: Rumsfeld Says Attacks Seek to Help Rebels Advance
description: American warplanes concentrated strikes on front-line Taliban positions today, and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said the United States was hitting targets to give direct support to anti-Taliban forces in northern Afghanistan.

title: USX-U.S. Steel Posts 3rd-Quarter Loss
description: The USX-U.S. Steel Group, the nation's leading steel maker, reported a third-quarter loss yesterday, blamed lower steel prices for the results and said fourth-quarter shipments would decline.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Lawmakers Vote To Cut Their Pay
description: On the first day of a special session where legislators must cut Florida's budget by $1.3 billion, the House of Representatives voted to cut legislators' pay. The members voted 104 to 7 to roll back a 2.5 percent raise that all 160 legislators began receiving on July 1. The bill would lower the salaries to $27,000, from $28,608. Those who voted against the bill said the pay cut would make it even harder for those not wealthy to serve as legislators. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGAN, NANCY HANNAH
description: REGAN-Nancy Hannah, of Port Washington. Beloved wife of Ronald. Devoted mother of Daren, Evan and Genevieve. Loving daughter of Michael Gluck and Ethel Gluck. Dear sister of Andrew. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Mark Green Ducks Debates
description: Throughout his years in politics, Public Advocate Mark Green has always spoken out forcefully for political openness and debate. Until now, that is. Suddenly, as the Democratic nominee and front-runner in the race for mayor of New York City, Mr. Green has decided that he needs to limit public exchanges with his main opponent, the Republican nominee, Michael Bloomberg.

title: Rubin Will Be an Adviser, if Green Wins
description: Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for mayor, will announce today that Robert E. Rubin, the Citigroup executive and former treasury secretary, will serve as a senior adviser to his administration.

title: W.T.O. Still Set on Conference in Qatar
description: The World Trade Organization said today that it would hold its ministerial conference in Qatar next month, in spite of fears of security threats after the Sept. 11 attacks in New York and Washington and the United States-led strikes in Afghanistan.

title: Corrections
description: The E-Commerce Report column in Business Day yesterday, about online money lenders, referred incorrectly to the operation and main customers of LendingTree. The company operates an exchange that brings together lenders and borrowers. It does not make loans. The company has consumers and direct lenders among its customers. It does not rely almost exclusively on brokers for its business.

title: Medical Advocates Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Is Losing Money on Cars It Seizes From Drunken Drivers
description: The Nassau County government, whose repeated deficits and towering debt have earned notoriety and special state oversight, has even flopped as a used-car salesman.

title: The Parks We Deserve
description: In the aftermath of the World Trade Center collapse, New York City's parks have played an integral role in the healing process for our city. Union Square became a sacred meeting ground for thousands of mourners, with messages, flags, flowers and candles. All over the city, makeshift memorials were created in neighborhood parks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLNESS, ELSA
description: HOLNESS-Elsa. October 23, 1985. In God always loving; In God forever loved. Nieces, Shirley and Lorrain

title: A Nation Challenged
description: From the Battlefield

title: Advanced Energy Cuts Staff by 8%
description: Advanced Energy Industries, which makes parts for semiconductor-manufacturing equipment, laid off 107 workers last week, or 8 percent of its work force, because of reduced demand for chips.

title: On Many Fronts, Experts Plan for the Unthinkable: Biowarfare
description: Protection against biological and chemical attack was never very high on lists of national priorities -- until the days after Sept. 11, when it collectively occurred to Americans how vulnerable they were.

title: Hague Tribunal Chief Says Yugoslavia Still Isn't Cooperating
description: The chief prosecutor for the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague came to Belgrade today and said the Yugoslav authorities were continuing to block cooperation with the tribunal and were still not ready to face the past.

title: Yankees Rout Mariners by 12-3 And Win 4th Pennant in a Row
description: The roll call of Yankees championships lengthened by one last night, the 38th pennant for a team that will now attempt to win its fourth consecutive World Series, fifth in six years and 27th over all. The Yankees routed Seattle, 12-3, in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series and will meet the Arizona Diamondbacks in the World Series, which begins Saturday.

title: C.D.C.'s Frustrating Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: On Many Fronts, Experts Plan for the Unthinkable: Biowarfare
description: Protection against biological and chemical attack was never very high on lists of national priorities -- until the days after Sept. 11, when it collectively occurred to Americans how vulnerable they were.

title: An upturn in account spending that was expected in 2002 may not come until 2003, executives say.
description: THE current steep decline in advertising spending will begin to reverse itself later than had been expected, several leading marketers and agency media executives predicted yesterday, partly because of the effects of the terrorist attacks and partly because of the softness in the economy before Sept. 11.

title: Hawaii Schools Suddenly Lose Their Leader
description: The Hawaii public school system, still recovering from a teachers' strike last spring and bracing for federal intervention as soon as next month, is suddenly searching for a new leader.

title: Pettitte Turns It Up And Tunes Seattle Out
description: Andy Pettitte clutched his crystal most valuable player trophy as he stood behind a curtain in the Yankees' clubhouse last night. How does it feel? Terrific, was the obvious answer. Pettitte chose the word crazy.

title: Another Option: The Mind Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Insights of a Warrior in Ancient Afghanistan
description: In the few weeks that the world has focused on Afghanistan, almost everyone has heard about the long history of failed attempts at conquest, from the Mongols to the British and the Russians. Ethnic, tribal and religious divisions have also prevented the Afghans themselves from uniting their country.

title: Suzuki Kept Off Balance And Off Base by Yanks
description: Ichiro Suzuki's quick feet served him in an unexpected capacity in the American League Championship Series. Rather than running out hits, as he did during the regular season, Suzuki, the batting champion, kept skipping over pitches near his shoes and ducking under others, in what was the foundation of the Yankees' strategy to shut him down.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: A Quick Response for Politicians; A Slower One for Mail Workers
description: The response was swift and decisive when an aide to Tom Daschle, the Senate Democratic leader, opened a letter containing anthrax. Mr. Daschle's office was quarantined, the Capitol's mail system was shut down, public tours were suspended, and 50 people, most of them aides to the senator, were prescribed the antibiotic Cipro while they were tested for anthrax exposure.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend on Friday about the Metropolitan Museum's exhibition of jewelry and jeweled objects from India's Mughal period misidentified the English mountain climber whose explanation for scaling Mount Everest -- ''it is there'' -- was invoked to account for the artistic carving of natural rock on the southeast coast of India. The climber was George Leigh Mallory, not Sir Edmund Hillary.

title: Louis Zara, 91, a Publisher Who Wrote Historical Novels
description: Louis Zara, a publisher and editor of magazines and books who was best known for his own historical novels, died on Oct. 5 in his Manhattan apartment. He was 91.

title: F.B.I. Finds Bulk Candy Purchase to Be Harmless
description: When bioterrorism concerns and the perennial Halloween hoaxing season coincide, the results can be disconcerting. That was the case last Wednesday, when a man described by a sales clerk as looking foreign bought a large quantity of candy from the Costco Warehouse in Hackensack, N.J., the police said.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Spending Increase Expected
description: Online spending is expected to reach $9.9 billion during the holiday season this year, up 43 percent from $6.9 billion during last year's holidays, according to a study by Nielsen/NetRatings, a joint venture of NetRatings, Nielsen Media Research and ACNielsen. In addition, more than 106 million people will shop online in December, a 27 percent increase from the 85 million people who shopped online last December, the study predicted. An increase in Internet commerce activity is expected, ''despite the effects of the economic slowdown and recent national events,'' said Sean Kaldor, vice president for analytical services at NetRatings. The online shopping estimates were based on past online spending trends from Nielsen/ NetRatings and Harris Interactive, in product categories like books, clothing and toys.

title: In North Dakota, Security Takes On a New Urgency
description: Everybody is watching. They watch the people getting off the Greyhound bus at the exit of I-94. They watch the planes in the sky and the anhydrous ammonia fertilizer tanks in the fields. At night, more deliberately than before, Dave Freland, the one policeman, checks the bank, the Laundromat, the one-story brick federal office building, the water plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MARTIN
description: KATZ-Martin, 73, a private investor, passed away October 18 following a fall at his home the preceding week. Until several years ago, Mr. Katz was president of PS Products, Inc., a specialty printer. An alumnus of The Townsend Harris School and Rutgers University, he is survived by his fiancee/ companion of seven years, Pearl Rind Schoenberg, a brother and sister-in-law, Edward C. Katz and Candace Leeds. Mr. Katz served in the U.S. Army occupation forces in Japan following World War II (1946-1947). Mr. Katz maintained a life-long interest in military history. He was also a member of the Metropolitan Opera Guild and gave liberally to various animal charities. Mr. Katz enjoyed his retirement, spending many pleasant hours with friends at the Colonial Heights Tennis Club. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 28, 2001 at 1:00 pm at the Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to your favorite charity in his memory.

title: Labor Party Leaders Weigh Leaving Sharon's Coalition
description: With Israeli forces engaged in their broadest action in years against the Palestinians, tens of thousands of Israelis poured into the streets here tonight to protest. Their message: the government should be even tougher on the Palestinians.

title: On Many Fronts, Experts Plan for the Unthinkable: Biowarfare
description: Protection against biological and chemical attack was never very high on lists of national priorities -- until the days after Sept. 11, when it collectively occurred to Americans how vulnerable they were.

title: Americans at Odds In Bridge Tourney
description: The world bridge championships began here today with American teams battling each other in two events. It is standard practice for compatriots to face each other at the start, to avoid the possibility of collusion at the end of qualifying play should one team be out of contention.

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL TO CLOSE PLANT IN GERMANY
description: The Eastman Chemical Company, which plans to split into two companies this year, said it would close a plant in Dsseldorf, Germany, and take a charge against fourth-quarter earnings as part of a plan to consolidate its coatings operations. The plant makes specialty chemicals used in coatings, inks, adhesives and sealants. Eastman , based in Kingsport, Tenn., is planning to form a new company that will make specialty chemicals.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, THEODORE W.
description: ADLER-Theodore W. Died at home in Scarsdale, NY on October 22, age 95. Devoted husband of Martelle and loving father of Louise and the late Thomas. Senior partner of Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman and Herz, LLP. Born in Des Moines, IA, brought up in Mattoon, IL, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Cornell University in 1928 and from Harvard Law School in 1931. He was a captain in the U.S. Army Air Force in WW II. Services private. Friends may call at home Tuesday, October 23, and Wedneday, October 24, 5-7 PM. Contributions may be made to White Plains Hospital or Cornell University.

title: Francesco Cordasco, 80, Sociologist and Writer
description: Francesco Cordasco, a sociologist who wrote or edited more than 100 books on subjects from bilingual education to 18th-century historical figures, died on Oct. 4 at a hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 80.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summmit meeting in Shanghai misstated the title of the Malaysian leader Mahathir bin Mohamad. He is prime minister, not president.

title: What Lingers in the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLEGHENY TO CLOSE PART OF FACTORY IN HOUSTON
description: Allegheny Technologies Inc., a maker of alloy metals and stainless steel, plans to close part of a plant in Houston and lay off 220 people because of falling demand for stainless steel. The company will close the part of the plant that makes raw stainless steel by the end of the year. The plant's rolling mill, which flattens metal into sheets, will keep running, Allegheny Technologies said. The company has about 11,000 employees. The Pittsburgh-based company's net income fell 81 percent in the third quarter from the year-earlier period, partly because of a drop in demand for aerospace metals as plane makers scale back production.

title: Some Airlines Say the Pace Of Bailout Aid Is Too Sluggish
description: Some airlines, concerned that they will not get the help Congress promised them soon after last month's attacks, are complaining that a new board placed in charge of doling out $10 billion worth of loan guarantees is moving too slowly.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Big Investment In Genencor
description: Dow Corning will invest up to $35 million over the next two years in Genencor International research programs aimed at creating products based on the combination of biological materals and silicon. Dow Corning, a joint venture of Dow Chemical and Corning, based in Midland, Mich., is a leading producer of products based on plastic polymers derived from silicon. Genencor, a joint venture of Genentech and Corning, based in Palo Alto, Calif., develops a wide range of biotechnology products. The research is aimed at inventing products like biosensors and drug delivery systems. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Displaced Children Go to New School, Again
description: When Jodi Carse's two children climbed onto the yellow school bus yesterday morning at Fifth Avenue and 21st Street for a trip to their new temporary school, so did she.

title: U.S. Insurers Are Concerned About Lloyd's
description: United States insurance executives raised concerns today about the ability of Lloyd's of London to pay its share of claims in the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Hasbro's Net Quadrupled As Cost Cuts Aided Results
description: Hasbro Inc. said today that its third-quarter profit almost quadrupled as the company reduced expenses and increased sales of G.I. Joe action figures and Bob the Builder toys.

title: U.S. Aiming to Cut Supplies to Lift the Taliban's Grip
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- As the United States launched a third day of air raids against Taliban troops on the front lines in Afghanistan, senior Pentagon officials said for the first time today that they hoped to choke off fuel, food and other supplies that the Taliban leaders need to maintain their grip on power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALOMON, EDNA BARNES
description: SALOMON-Edna Barnes. The New York Public Library deeply mourns the passing of its beloved friend and benefactor, Edna Barnes Salomon. The wife of the Library's esteemed Chairman Emeritus, the late Richard B. Salomon, and mother of current Library Trustee Richard E. Salomon, Mrs. Salomon was herself a longstanding Library Conservator and member of the President's Council. She and her family have been among the most dedicated advocates and most generous supporters in The New York Public Library's modern history. Their devotion and philanthropy have resulted in a significant strengthening of the Library's endowment, a major expansion of its exhibitions and public programs, and sustained growth of the collections of its Science, Industry and Business Library. We are very proud that one of the Library's major exhibition spaces, the Edna Barnes Salomon Gallery, honors her name and her memory. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her sons, Richard, Robert, and Ralph, and the entire Salomon family. Samuel C. Butler, Chairman Paul LeClerc, President Mrs. Vincent Astor, Honorary Chairman Andrew Heiskell, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti

title: A Ballerina Moves On Vicariously
description: What is a hapless dance reviewer to do when confronted with dance that calls for the pulling out of one's rustiest superlatives? The wisest course may be simply to give in to the delight of a company like the Suzanne Farrell Ballet, which performed this afternoon at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, and to spread the word that the company ends its tour Tuesday night with a performance at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BILOWIT, DEBBI WASSERMAN
description: BILOWIT-Debbi Wasserman. 2/3/46-10/23/86. A lifetime ago your too-brief life brought happiness to many. We mourn and remember you. Time has not lessened the loss of the loneliness.

title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: Setting A Date For Independence
description: The interim assembly of East Timor notified the United Nations that it wants May 20 to be the date the territory is granted full independence. Since breaking away from Indonesia in 1999, the former Portuguese colony has been administered by the United Nations. The assembly was elected in August in preparation for full independence. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, CHRISTOPHER D.
description: JONES-Christopher D. 53. Of Huntington, NY, on September 11, 2001, at The World Trade Center. He worked at Cantor Fitzgerald where he was a partner. Born and raised in England, he graduated from Cambridge University, Fitzwilliam College in 1969. Beloved husband of thirty-one years of Susan, and loving father of Sarah and Lucy. A Memorial Service will be held at Old First Presbyterian Church, 125 Main Street, Huntington, NY, on Saturday October 27th at 2 P.M.

title: Bayer Reaches Deal on Cipro to Protect Patent in Canada
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 23  Bayer A.G. ( news/quote ), which manufactures the anthrax-fighting drug Cipro, has fended off a big challenge to its patent on the drug by reaching a deal to supply the Canadian government with one million tablets within two days.

title: Seton Hall Is Brushing Up on Its Chemistry
description: Chemistry may be one of the elusive elements that can make or break a college basketball team, but usually not in October. Seton Hall does not begin its season until Nov. 16, yet chemistry dominated the conversation today at the university's news media day.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Role Reversal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROADS, DANIEL
description: BROADS-Daniel. On October 20, 2001. Formerly of Yonkers, N.Y. Husband of Ruth Broads. Father of Suzie Flax and the late Norman Broads. Also survived by granddaughters and a sister. Interment services Mount Hope Cemetery, Westchester, N.Y. Tuesday, October 23rd, 1:30PM.

title: $1 Billion Proposal Would Create Hybrid Swiss Airline
description: After days of intense negotiations, the Swiss government patched together a $1 billion package today to keep a national airline flying after the collapse of Swissair three weeks ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Disney Said to Be Near Getting a Price Cut in Fox TV Deal
description: The Walt Disney Company is close to an agreement to reduce the price that it will pay for the Fox Family Worldwide cable television operation by as much as $100 million, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Aching O'Neill Homers and Hears the Chants
description: As Paul O'Neill made his way around the bases after his fourth-inning home run last night, the familiar chants of "Paulie! Paulie!" reverberated around Yankee Stadium. But before he could make it to home plate, the chant was drowned out by a pleading chorus of "One more year!"

title: West Point Graduates And ABC Unit in Pact
description: Graduates of the United States Military Academy at West Point and a division of ABC are to announce today a marketing partnership that will include sponsorships, a two-hour television special and other efforts to commemorate the 200th anniversary of West Point next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, HARRY ''HESH''
description: HERMAN-Harry ''Hesh''. Of Cherry Hill, N.J. Beloved husband of Jean. Devoted father of Carl, Roy, Deborah Wein, and Paul. Brother of Martin and eight grandchildren. Services Tuesday. Call ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Traces of Anthrax Are Found in Dan Rather's Office
description: Traces of anthrax have been found in and around Dan Rather's office at CBS News on West 57th Street, reinforcing the suspicion that a letter was the most likely source of the bacteria that infected one of Mr. Rather's aides last month, network officials said.

title: World Briefing | World: A Call For Laboratory Security
description: A United Nations arms expert said scientists should tighten security at laboratories to hinder easy transportation of material that could be used in biological weapons. Patricia Lewis, who heads the Geneva-based United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research, said it was common practice for researchers to remove small quantities of bacteriological substances from laboratories, especially those at universities, and take them through customs without declaring them. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Easygoing Camaraderie And Unadorned Renditions
description: Margaret Whiting

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Police In Rebel Zones
description: Macedonian police officers resumed patrols in several villages in the north and west of the country in a major step to re-establish government control over areas previously held by ethnic Albanian rebels. Explosions, but no injuries, were reported last night in two municipal buildings in one of the villages after the police had left for the night. The rebels disbanded under a peace plan last month, but political reforms remain deadlocked in Parliament. Carlotta Gall (NYT), (Reuters)

title: Giants Contain McNabb Until They Can No More
description: The second pass Philadelphia quarterback Donovan McNabb threw against the Giants last night was a slider barely scooped up by wide receiver James Thrash. It went for minus-1 yard. It takes a lot to throw a forward pass in reverse.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit At Yahoo Japan
description: Profit at Japan's largest online directory, the Yahoo Japan Corporation, nearly doubled in the July-September quarter as sales of modems offset slowing advertising revenue. Yahoo Japan, a subsidiary of the Softbank Corporation and the Yahoo Corporation of the United States, earned 1.3 billion yen ($10.7 million), 91 percent more than in the period a year ago. With online advertising rates collapsing, Yahoo Japan started selling modems for high-speed Internet connections to another Softbank subsidiary, BB Technology. Yahoo Japan's sales more than doubled in the quarter, with modem sales making up 43 percent of that total.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISEL, SARA
description: MEISEL-Sara, of Miami Beach, formerly of Belle Harbor, NY, passed away Saturday, October 20, 2001. Beloved wife of the late William G. Meisel. Loving mother of Ilene Silver and Louis Meisel. Cherished grandmother of Perry, Jane, Erica and Jordan. Adored great-grandmother of Cleo, Elan, Dena, Sydney, Drew and Justin. We love you. Services 11:00 AM, Wednesday, October 24, 2001, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY. For information call Blasberg Rubin Zilbert Chapels, Miami Beach, Fla., 305-865-2353.

title: U.N. Plans Relief Airlifts
description: United Nations officials said today that they were planning airlifts of food and medicine to Afghans who, because of their remote locations, could no longer be supplied by road.

title: Claims to Federal Fund For Victims Trickle In
description: Fewer people than expected have contacted a lawyers' group that is offering to represent those seeking compensation from a federal fund for losses in the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Henryk Tomaszewski, 81; Known for Wordless Theater
description: Henryk Tomaszewski, a Polish theater artist who surprised the West with his dreamlike, wordless presentations and influenced American avant-garde artists like Robert Wilson and Meredith Monk, died on Sept. 23 in Kowary, near Wroclaw, Poland. He was 81.

title: A Dream Fulfilled, a Devoted Father and a Mother With No Answers
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Jury Returns Murder Verdict in Wedding-Day Killing of Ex-Girlfriend
description: A jury this morning found a businessman guilty of murder in the shooting of his former girlfriend on her wedding day two years ago, rejecting his bid for a manslaughter conviction.

title: Sunoco Estimates Value of an Offering
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (Bloomberg News)  Sunoco Inc. ( news/quote ), one of the largest fuel sellers in the Northeast, estimates that it will raise $108 million from an initial offering for a limited partnership formed to store and transport crude oil.

title: In Less Than Two Minutes, Eagles Drill Giants
description: For the first 58 minutes of the game tonight at Giants Stadium, the Eagles had been thoroughly outplayed by the Giants. The Giants' defense had been dominant, and if the Giants' offense had been erratic, it had helped them hold the lead from the game's opening moments.

title: Bumpy Routine of Sorting Can Free Spores in Letters
description: At regional mail distribution centers like the one in Washington where several workers apparently developed anthrax lung infections, envelopes are repeatedly shaken, jostled and squeezed as they speed through canceling and sorting machines.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Explosion At Nazi Site
description: The giant Congress Hall at the former Nazi parade ground in Nuremberg, where a documentation center on World War II and the Holocaust is to open Nov. 4, was rocked by an explosion that killed one person and severely damaged part of the building used as a warehouse, the police said. Investigators said they did not know the cause of the blast. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS. The dollar rose, lifted by gains in United States stocks and optimism the economy will benefit from a series of interest-rate cuts. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.54 yen, up from 121.17 yen on Friday.

title: Diamondbacks Have Time to Set Starting Rotation
description: In the midst of a beer-drenched celebration in the visiting clubhouse at Turner Field in Atlanta on Sunday night, Randy Johnson peeked ahead to the World Series, where he and his Arizona Diamondback teammates will be playing this weekend.

title: Sasaki, a Fly Ball Pitcher, Let One Fly
description: In Lou Piniella's mind, the Seattle Mariners had boarded the plane and were almost halfway home. They had a one-run lead with five outs remaining in Game 4, and a victory would even the American League Championship Series at 2-2 and ensure that it would end in Seattle.

title: Rash of No-Shows at Conventions
description: A dwindling number of people are going to conventions these days, but those who plyed the cavernous floor of the McCormick Place Convention Center this weekend sounded a lot like Randy Scholtz, a 49-year-old food service manager who insisted he was getting on with life.

title: Aid Program Set Up to Help Small Stores
description: Samuel's Hats, two blocks from the World Trade Center, was among the many small shops dealt a severe blow by the center's destruction.

title: 3M's Profit Declines 21% In Last Period
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 21 percent and that its fourth-quarter profit might be less than some estimates.

title: In Tougher Times, It's a Life of Affluence Minus Trimmings; Pinched, But Not Really Pinching Pennies
description: Only one stock in Gary Markle's portfolio is still in the black, but that did not stop him from buying a 2002 Mercury Mountaineer sport utility this month for his wife.

title: Special Night for Graves, But Not for the Rangers
description: Adam Graves had become just another player in a teal sweater by the middle of last night's game. A Rangers fan stood and yelled that he wanted to see Graves get hit -- and hit hard. Instead, Graves wriggled away. Join the club, Gravy.

title: Being Left In Gloom Of Night Over Threat
description: The deadly news raced up the hill, stunning the crowd of postal workers who were already anxious enough as they emerged from the hospital, freshly swab-tested and handed 10 days' supply of anti-anthrax pills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSSBAUM, JACQUELINE RUTH (NEE COHEN)
description: NUSSBAUM - Jacqueline Ruth (nee Cohen). Died October 21, after an illness. She is survived by a sister, Elizabeth Hittner, two daughters Debra Nussbaum Cohen and Laura Solomon, their husbands, Marc Cohen and Mark Solomon, and five grandchildren. Jacqueline was 62. She was a gracious, generous and loving woman whose thoughtfulness and warmth touched everyone who knew her. Her favorite role was as Grandma Peaches to her beloved and cherished grandchildren Aryeh, Aliza and Elana, Avi and Adin. She mustered everything she had in order to be here for them. Sadly for us, the Creator had other plans. Shiva will be observed at her daughters' homes in Brooklyn and Philadelphia. Donations may be made to the Philadelphia Jewish Family and Childrens Services, 7607 Old York Rd., Elkins Park, PA 19027.

title: U.S. Jets Pound Front-Line Taliban
description: Volleys of tank, rocket and machine-gun fire thundered overnight across the strategic Shamali Plain just north of Kabul as the rebel Northern Alliance and the Taliban engaged in their heaviest fighting here since American bombing began more than two weeks ago.

title: Speaking the Language of Success
description: With attention focusing on Japan's car industry as the Tokyo Motor Show opens Wednesday, the man in the spotlight will be the president of the Nissan Motor Company, Carlos Ghosn, the foreign manager that Japanese love to love.

title: Chairman of Lincoln Center Redevelopment Resigns
description: The real estate executive in charge of Lincoln Center's fractious billion-dollar redevelopment project resigned yesterday, months before he had planned to leave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROUTY, HELEN ELLIS THORNE
description: PROUTY-Helen Ellis Thorne, 87, of 88 Notch Hill Rd., North Branford, died Monday, October 22, 2001. She was the wife of Charles Newton Prouty. She was a nurse at Yale-New Haven Hospital and a founding trustee of Connecticut Hospice. Besides her husband, she leaves two daughters, Phebe Thorne Wilcox of Sun Valley, ID and Keene Valley, NY, and Cynthia Thorne Ayres of Sheffield, MA, a stepson, Charles S. Prouty of Hingham, MA, seven grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. Memorial service at Trinity Episcopal Church, Bransford, CT Thursday morning at 11. Memorial gifts may be sent to Connecticut Hospice, Inc., 100 Double Beach Rd., Branford, CT 06405.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Woman Testifies In American's Rape Trial
description: A Japanese woman who says she was raped by an American serviceman in Okinawa denied during cross-examination that she had consented to sex with the defendant, Timothy Woodland. The 24-year-old woman said the airman's assertion that she had voluntarily engaged in sex in the parking lot of a shopping center was ''outrageous.'' The case has roiled relations between Japan and the United States, with Okinawans demanding the withdrawal of American soldiers from the island, where roughly half of the 47,000 American troops in Japan are stationed. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Shares Rise Despite Poor Earnings and Economic Figures
description: Stocks climbed yesterday, as investors continued to show confidence in an eventual economic recovery.

description: Here's the crucial question about this year's Big Apple Circus: Is it the children or the adults who will enjoy it more?

title: Office Tower Near Rubble Can't Reopen On Deadline
description: City officials canceled the reopening yesterday of 1 Liberty Plaza, a 54-story office building just east of the ruins of the World Trade Center, and declined to say when its tenants would be allowed back in.

title: COMSTOCK RESOURCES OFFERS TO BUY DEVX ENERGY
description: Comstock Resources Inc., which explores and drills for oil and natural gas in Texas, Louisiana and the Gulf of Mexico, offered to buy a rival, DevX Energy Inc., for about $93.3 million. Comstock is offering to buy DevX common stock for $7.32 a share. In September, DevX, which is based in Dallas, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had about 12.75 million shares outstanding. The offer is 41 percent more than DevX's closing price on Friday of $5.20.

title: Soybean Processor Exceeds Forecasts
description: The soybean processor Bunge Ltd. said today that profit more than tripled in the third quarter on improved sales of food ingredients and animal feed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORROW, BENJAMIN DAVID
description: MORROW-Benjamin David. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its devoted member, Dr. Ira Morrow. May his family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTIN, BERNARD
description: KURTIN-Bernard, Oct. 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Jeanie; father of Owen & Sabryna; grandfather of Jean-Michael, Noah and Dora; brother of Elayne; and English teacher of thousands of New York City high school students.

title: Heightened Security Sought
description: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut said yesterday that he wanted the federal government to provide extra security around Millstone, the state's nuclear power plants in Waterford, and various other sites in southeastern Connecticut in light of the recent terrorist attacks in the country.

title: U.S. News & World Report Cuts Salaries to Avoid More Layoffs
description: Brian Duffy, the editor of U.S. News & World Report, announced across-the-board salary cuts of up to 10 percent yesterday for all but the lowest-paid staff members and some highly paid contract writers. Mr. Duffy said he himself was taking the pay cut.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Junior College Enrollment Up
description: Student enrollment this year has increased at two-year colleges in New Jersey, officials said. Enrollment has risen 4.5 percent to more than 130,000. Jacob Farbman, spokesman for the New Jersey Council of Community Colleges, said the exact reason for the rise isn't known. But he noted that all 19 presidents of community colleges had agreed to freeze tuition for the next four years.

title: Corrections
description: An opera listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for ''The Floating Box,'' a chamber work at the Asia Society, misstated this week's schedule. The performances will be at 8 on Friday through Sunday, not Thursday through Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summmit meeting in Shanghai misstated the title of the Malaysian leader Mahathir bin Mohamad. He is prime minister, not president.

title: For Williams, the Supernatural Has Become Routine
description: The Yankees were gathered around two big-screen televisions in their lounge last night watching replays of their 12-3 victory over the Seattle Mariners in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series, the game that sent them to another World Series. They were like a bunch of frat boys at a keg party, especially when they watched Bernie Williams's sweet swing again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ILSON, MIRIAM (NEE HERTZ)
description: ILSON-Miriam (nee Hertz). Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Devoted mother of Audrey and Leonard Lambert. Loving grandmother of Peter and Jill. Interment services private. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave, 5th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10017.

description: In the latest skirmish between code breakers and digital copyright holders, an anonymous programmer has published software on the Internet that disables Microsoft technology that is designed to regulate what consumers do with music they purchase online.

description: To the Editor:

title: Other Drugs to Combat Anthrax Are in Ample Supply if Needed, Health Official Says
description: Despite concerns over a possible shortage of Cipro, the antibiotic most widely used to treat anthrax, government officials and drug makers say there is an ample supply of other drugs that are effective against the potentially deadly bacterium.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Bad Appendix Remains Hard to Spot
description: Although several new techniques have been developed for diagnosing appendicitis, the number of unnecessary operations has not decreased, a new study in The Journal of the American Medical Association says.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Hard to Argue With This System
description: For numerous Yankee haters citywide -- and nationwide -- the image of Alfonso Soriano rounding the bases late Sunday night, having struck the blow that ripped the happy ending out of Seattle's 116-victory storybook season, was another ominous sign for the immediate and long-term future. The harvest of homegrown heroes continues, with no apparent end in sight.

description: The Black and the Gray

title: LEAGUE HONORS THE DEVILS' ELIAS
description: The Devils' Patrik Elias, who finished third in the league in scoring last season with 96 points, was named the player of the week in the National Hockey League yesterday.
