description: At 9:03 a.m. on Oct. 12, the cashier's office at the New York Stock Exchange received this handwritten letter over the fax machine:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRE, JOAN BUTLER
description: BEHRE-Joan Butler, 72. Of Pensacola, FL died peacefully at home Oct. 20, 2001. A native of New Rochelle, Mrs. Behre graduated from Wellesley College, worked for American Cyanamid in New York and was a stockbroker with A.G. Edwards & Sons. Survivors include daughter Jennifer of New York City, son Robert and his wife Holly and three grandchildren, Dorothy, Henry and Joseph, of Charleston, SC, a brother Herbert Butler of Nellysford, VA, a sister Judith Cummings of Manakin Sabot, VA, and a sister-in-law Joan Behre of New Canaan, CT. A memorial service will be held at 4 p.m. Oct. 25 at Trinity Presbyterian Church in Pensacola. Memorial contributions may be made to the Joan B. and Merrill C. Behre Scholarship Fund, c/o Phillips Exeter Academy, 20 Main St., Exeter, NH 03833.

title: From the Rubble, a Picture and a Friendship
description: Tim Sherman spotted the photograph near the end of his first day of digging, on the Friday after that Tuesday. The time of day, he recalls, was ''after dark.'' He had been on the move since dawn. A gang from his job at the Middlesex Water Company had come to New York to help, with strong backs and water main know-how and willing spirits. In a way, there was nothing to do.

title: American Express Reports Profit Dropped by 60% in 3rd Quarter
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 60 percent as its card customers spent less on travel and entertainment after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: CENTURYTEL BUYING 675,000 VERIZON PHONE LINES
description: CenturyTel Inc., which sells local and wireless phone service in 21 states, agreed to buy about 675,000 telephone lines in Alabama and Missouri from Verizon Communications Inc. for $2.16 billion. The transaction expands CenturyTel's local-phone market in rural regions by 37 percent, and lets Verizon focus on selling phone service mostly in metropolitan areas, Verizon said. The additional lines are expected to generate $530 million to $550 million in annual revenue, and per-share earnings of 4 cents to 7 cents in the first year, CenturyTel said. The company, which is based in Monroe, La., is getting lines in growing cities like Branson, Mo., and Dothan, Ala. Verizon, which is based in New York, said in September it wanted to sell 1.2 million rural phone lines in Alabama, Kentucky and Missouri.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Sonera To Raise Cash
description: As Europe's telecommunication companies wrestle with debt, Sonera of Finland said yesterday that it would follow British Telecommunications in selling discounted shares to existing stockholders to raise cash. Sonera's debt is now 4.4 billion euros ($3.9 billion), compared with its market value of less than three billion euros ($2.7 billion). After posting a record loss of 325 million euros ($292 million) in the third quarter, Sonera said it would sell as many as 743.5 million shares to its current investors to raise $900 million. The price will be set on Nov. 9. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: Just Playing

title: Sir John Plumb, British Historian, Dies at 90
description: Sir John Plumb, a prolific British historian of the 18th century whose lucrative and popular history books and unerring knack for picking brilliant students may have eclipsed his own potential as a serious historian, died Sunday in Cambridge, England. He was 90.

title: Soriano and Mom Savor Heroics
description: Andrea Soriano watched her youngest child being interviewed on television after he had hit the game-winning homer against the Seattle Mariners on Sunday night, and she was so excited that she called his cellular phone. Not once, not twice, but again and again.

title: Mayor Welcomes New Recruits To Replace Victims in the Attack
description: In words both encouraging and elegiac, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday welcomed 307 recruits to the Fire Department, whose ranks were decimated in the World Trade Center attack.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Domain Name Registration Soars
description: More than 500,000 Internet addresses ending in .info have been registered since the new domain extension was introduced in July, Afilias, the company that manages the .info database, plans to announce today. Dot-info is one of seven new domains that were approved to offer an alternative to .com, .org and .net names. As of late June, 24.3 million .com addresses, 4.9 million .net addresses, and 3.2 million .org addresses were registered, according to VeriSign, the company that manages those domains. Afilias said applications for more than 52,000 .info addresses were submitted this summer during a preregistration period intended for trademark owners, though some of those registrations are being challenged because they were made with false trademark data.

title: Playoff Fade Turns Mariners Into a Footnote
description: The Seattle Mariners began the postseason looking forward to joining the National League representative in the World Series this weekend. Last night they joined the 1906 Chicago Cubs in the league of ignominy. Obvious lesson to all teams for future seasons: don't win 116 games.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Death Sentence For High Official
description: A former vice minister of public security received a death sentence with a two-year reprieve for his role in a huge smuggling scandal. Li Jizhou, who helped run the nation's police, is one of the highest officials convicted of corruption. He was found guilty of accepting more than $600,000 in bribes from a smuggling ring in the southern city of Xiamen and of tipping off ringleaders to police investigations. Reprieved death sentences are often converted to life imprisonment. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGGIA, OSCAR A.
description: MAGGIA-Oscar A., 94, of Crotonon-Hudson, formerly of Plandome Manor, NY, on October 19, 2001. Retired financial officer of Ruberoid and GAF Corporations. Predeceased by wife, Vera. Survived by daughter, Vera Plummer of Croton-on-Hudson, granddaughter Elizabeth Plummer of NYC, grandson William Plummer of Beijing. Funeral Mass at Holy Name of Mary Church, Croton-onHudson, Wednesday, October 24, at 10AM.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the guilty pleas of two contractors, Alfred Lenoci Sr. and Alfred Lenoci Jr., to charges of having bribed associates of the mayor of Bridgeport, Conn., misspelled the name of a former housing project where the two men had planned to build a light-industry park. It was Father Panik Village, not Panic.

title: Aching O'Neill Homers And Hears the Chants
description: As Paul O'Neill made his way around the bases after his fourth-inning home run last night, the familiar chants of ''Paulie! Paulie!'' reverberated around Yankee Stadium. But before he could make it to home plate, the chant was drowned out by a pleading chorus of ''One more year!''

title: Down the Road, Drug May Still Do Harm
description: People who use the drug Ecstasy appear to suffer long-term memory damage even after they give it up, a new study from the Netherlands concludes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARQUSEE, JANET MORAND
description: MARQUSEE-Janet Morand, died on October 22nd, aged 69, peacefully at her home among her beloved family and her collection of beautiful art. She was an extraordinary wife, mother, sister, grandmother, friend and aunt. She was also a serious and original artist, an enthusiastic art-dealer, a selftaught scholar of American art and an activist for peace and social justice. She relished her life, her family and the entire visual world. She is deeply missed by her children, Mike and Liz, Jeff, Joanne and Larry, Susan and Alan, and Ellen and Barry, her brother, Martin, and her grandchildren, Alex, Hannah, Rebecca, Sarah, Alison, Lindsay, Rachel and Isabel. A memorial service will be held Sunday, October 28th, 2 PM, at the Lotos Club, 5 E. 66th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the NOW Foundation, 733 15th St., NW, Washington, DC 20005.

description: Facing growing fear over anthrax, the United States has signed an agreement with Uzbekistan to remove tons of deadly anthrax spores from a remote island where the Soviet Union buried them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Dies Trying To Escape Flames
description: A man fell five stories and died last night while trying to escape a fire caused by chemicals in the Bronx building where he was working, the police said. The man, Ivan Defoster, 36, of Brooklyn, was refinishing floors at 655 Pelham Parkway when the chemicals he was using caught fire. He ran to the window to escape the flames, and fell, the police said. He died at Jacobi Medical Center. Robert Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUTNER, HANA
description: MAUTNER-Hana. On October 20, 2001 at the age of 82. Beloved wife of the late Victor Mautner. Loving mother of Sylvia Trzesinski and Carl Mautner. Survived by sister Nelly Berger of Tel Aviv, son-inlaw Paul E. Trzesinski, and granddaughters Stacey and Randi Trzesinski.

They recited statements that Mr. Bloomberg had made in the past that they said demonstrated his lack of understanding of policing and of city government.

That was the case last Wednesday, when a man described by a sales clerk as looking foreign bought a large quantity of candy from the Costco Warehouse in Hackensack, N.J., the police said.

description: BERLIN, Oct. 23  Germany arrested a Turkish man last week at Frankfurt Airport as he was about to board an Iran Air flight to Teheran with luggage containing camouflage clothing, a chemical-weapons protection suit, a ski mask and materials to produce an explosive detonator, the German federal prosecutor said today.

title: At Home Creditors Ask Judge to Rule On Fee Payments
description: Creditors for the At Home Corporation, the high-speed Internet access provider that does business as Excite@Home, have asked a bankruptcy judge to shut down the service unless it can get its corporate customers to increase their payments to the company.

title: Sanders Hits Ground Talking
description: The exchange happened at the end of Deion Sanders's feature about the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on Sunday on CBS's ''The NFL Today.'' Sanders, the newest member of the program, was talking to Warren Sapp, the unplugged defensive tackle.

title: West Point Graduates and ABC Unit in Pact
description: Graduates of the United States Military Academy at West Point and a division of ABC are to announce today a marketing partnership that will include sponsorships, a two-hour television special and other efforts to commemorate the 200th anniversary of West Point next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARNOFF, BARBARA HAMILTON
description: SARNOFF-Barbara Hamilton. We mourn the loss of our beloved mother and grandmother, the beautiful Barbara, on October 22, 2001, at 94 years. She fought valiantly against Alzheimer's. Lately of Easton, PA, and previously of Westport, CT, and Palm Beach, FL, she leaves daughters, Elizabeth Burrell, of Toronto, and Barbara Rothkopf, of Easton, PA, and four grandchildren. Burial to be private.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Archer/Malmo, Memphis hired four staff members. Gary Bridgman was named public relations account executive; he had been in corporate communications at International Paper, Memphis. Donna Brinkley was named database analyst and developer; she had been a project manager and associate editor at Towery Publishing, Memphis, working on the American Community Network, a former Web site of Towery. Jason Garrison was named junior database analyst; he had been a student. And Janet McQuarrie was named account coordinator for direct marketing; she had been an account executive at Broadslate Networks, Memphis.

title: Medical Students Get Taste of Real-Life Doctoring
description: It is a tiny stage: a 10-by-12-foot room. The cast is also tiny: two players. The props include an examination table, a sink, some drawers, a blood pressure gauge and other medical instruments. And though the performers will not earn rave (or any) reviews in tomorrow's newspaper, they both know that how well they play their roles could someday make the difference between someone's life and death.

title: Crucial Test for Mars Mission Comes Tonight
description: After the failures of its two predecessors, an American spacecraft is fast approaching Mars for a try at restoring success to the program of exploring the planet's geological and, just possibly, biological history.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: World Trade: Meeting In Qatar Still On
description: Barring a ''seismic or catastrophic'' event, Doha, Qatar remains the site of the top-level meeting of trade ministers in three weeks, the World Trade Organization said. The head of the organization, Mike Moore, said after a brief trip to Doha that the W.T.O. was ''going ahead.'' Mr. Moore also received assurances from officials of the United States that its delegates would attend.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline Refinances Leases
description: Air Canada, trying to improve its finances amid a slump in air travel, refinanced aircraft-leasing contracts to gain an additional 170 million Canadian dollars ($108 million). Air Canada refinanced the sale and leaseback of five Airbus A320 aircraft and the delivery of a new Boeing B767-300 plane, the carrier said. The airline, which is based in Montreal, also said it had reached an agreement with the union representing ticket and reservation agents to reduce their work hours by one-fifth for a 26-week period.

title: Don Maurer, 47, Top Executive At McKinney & Silver Agency
description: Don S. Maurer, a longtime advertising and marketing executive who was president and chief executive at one of the largest ad agencies in the Southeast, McKinney & Silver, died on Saturday. He was 47.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COTTER, WILLIAM J.
description: COTTER-William J. October 23, 1998. Dearest Will, life is so wrong without you. Thanks for all those memories. Much love, Elaine

title: U.S. Presses for New Talks By Israelis and Palestinians
description: The United States urged Israel today to withdraw its forces from Palestinian-governed territory immediately, deploring the Israeli Army's killing of civilians over the weekend.

title: World's Largest Germ-Bank Union Acts to Keep Terrorists From Stealing Deadly Stocks
description: After years of complaints by American officials that security measures were too lax, the world's largest organization of scientific germ banks said yesterday that it was taking steps to bar terrorists from obtaining deadly microbes.

title: Indicators Fell In September; Biggest Drop In Five Years
description: The index of leading economic indicators for September showed the biggest drop in more than five years, a sign the slowdown may last through the first quarter of 2002, a private industry group said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Printing Service Introduced
description: Yesterday, a group of technology companies introduced PrintMe Networks, an Internet-based service that would permit remote printing without cables or any special setup. Created by Electronics for Imaging, a Foster City, Calif., company that makes printing products, PrintMe Networks will permit people like business travelers or mobile workers to print documents while away from their desks. Under the plan, customers will send their print job through a laptop computer, a hand-held device or a mobile phone to a network of printers -- housed in hotels, airports, print shops and coffeehouses around the world. In a conference call, Guy Gecht, the chief executive of Electronics for Imaging, described PrintMe as ''a whole new way to think about printing'' and said the system would have the speed of a fax machine with the quality and security of traditional printed documents. Jonathan Rosenzweig, a research analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said that there was ample opportunity in the market, but that PrintMe would need to get enough compatible devices into the marketplace to be viable.

title: Medical Advocates Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Container Maker Acquired
description: Cinven, a British buyout firm, has agreed to buy Pentaplast, a German plastic-wrap business for $832 million from WCM Beteiligungs-und Grundbesitz A.G., a German investment company. WCM had inherited Pentaplast after it bought Klckner-Werke A.G., a packaging company, in January. Pentaplast produces plastic wrap and containers for companies and is Klckner-Werke's most profitable unit. In the most recent fiscal year, it had sales of 870 million euros ($778 million), and employed 3,100 people. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Howard Finster, Folk Artist and Preacher, Dies at 84
description: Howard Finster, a Baptist preacher whose evangelical faith, outgoing personality and compulsive work habits made him one of the most prominent and prolific folk artists of the 20th century, died yesterday in a hospital in Rome, Ga. He was 84 and lived in Summerville, Ga., a few miles from the Paradise Garden, the junk-and-cement environment that brought him his first recognition in the middle 1970's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKS, CLAIRE ELIZABETH MCINTYRE
description: HICKS-Claire Elizabeth McIntyre, 78, of Rumson. Died Saturday at Riverview Medical Center, Red Bank. She was a graduate of the Jersey City Medical Center, receiving her R.N. in 1944. She graduated from NYU School of Education in 1955. She was a participant in the Harvard University Nurses Study for over 25 years. Born in Rahway, NJ, she moved here in 1955. Her husband David T. Hicks died in 1992. Surviving are a son, David T. Hicks, Jr. with whom she lived, two daughters Elizabeth G. Hicks of Cambridge, MA and Susan H. Sawicki of Westmont, NJ. A memorial service will be held at Saint George's Church, Rumson, on Wednesday at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the VNA of Central Jersey, 141 Bodman Pl, Red Bank, NJ 07701.

title: Alliance of Convenience: Rebels Useful to U.S.
description: The United States decision to support the Northern Alliance is part of a calculated strategy to accelerate the collapse of the Taliban by striking at it from all sides.

title: MGM Loss Reflects New Accounting Rule
description: The movie studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which is controlled by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, reported today a third-quarter loss on higher costs to promote new films like ''Legally Blonde.''

title: French Barge
description: Abarge trip in the fall through southern France includes the air fare from the United States and a hotel stay in Paris for $200 more. That's the deal from eWaterways on the Nov. 17 sailing of the Chardonnay, a 50-passenger barge that will follow the Rhone to Avignon, the Cotes du Rhone and Chateauneuf-du-Pape vineyards and the Roman ruins in Arles. The price, $2,199 a person based on double occupancy, includes air fare to Paris from most United States cities, a six-night cruise, two nights in a three-star Paris hotel, TGV rail transfers between Paris and the barge, all meals on board, wine with lunch and dinner, and sightseeing. Similar fares on other barges are available next month; (800) 676-6613 or www.ewaterways.com .

title: State Restores Scholarship Aid For 295 in the National Guard
description: Legislative leaders and Gov. George E. Pataki agreed today to pay for college scholarships for National Guard members who were denied the aid because the program had run out of money.

title: Raytheon Moves to Reduce Debt
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., Oct. 22 (Bloomberg News)  The Raytheon Company ( news/quote ) said yesterday that it would offer 29 million common shares, expected to raise $1 billion, to reduce debt, a move analysts said was intended to keep its credit rating from being downgraded to junk status.

title: Maytag Contract Rejected
description: The Maytag Corporation, a leading appliance maker, said today that striking workers at its refrigerator plant in Amana, Iowa, had rejected a second contract offer. The workers, represented by the International Association of Machinists Local 1526, rejected the proposal on Sunday. Workers have been on strike since Sept. 23, Maytag said. The plant made all Amana refrigerators and some refrigerators under the Kenmore brand for Sears, Roebuck & Company, a spokesman, Jim Powell, said. Union representatives could not be reached.

title: An Easy Means of Prevention: A Flu Shot
description: While millions of Americans fret over the threat of anthrax spread by terrorists, they may ignore another infectious disease that will soon descend on the country and probably claim tens of thousands of lives. That disease is influenza. And while an anthrax vaccine is not available to the general public, a flu vaccine is, and it can prevent a vast majority of cases of influenza and the death and disability they can cause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOETZ, RUTH GOODMAN
description: GOETZ-Ruth Goodman. October 12, 2001. Beloved wife and collaborator of the late Augustus Goetz. Wonderful mother of Judy Goetz Sanger. Delighted grandmother of Katie Firth. Service Thursday, October 25, 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. Interment services private at Keller's Church Cemetery, Bucks County, PA. title: Arab Owners Are Not Running to Belmont for the Breeders' Cup
description: Horse racing has long been known as the sport of kings, but that definition has recently loosened to include all kinds of royalty within its ownership ranks. Some are from popular culture like the Broadway composer Lord Andrew Lloyd Webber and the television writer and producer David Milch. Others spring from the realm of commerce like Michael Tabor, the former owner of a string of betting shops in Britain.

description: It has been called a masterpiece, a ''profoundly interesting'' and ''enormously influential'' example of the Modernist movement in architecture.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Begins Selling $500 Million In Bonds
description: New York City began the sale of $500 million in bonds yesterday, its first major borrowing since the attack on the World Trade Center. The sale, set to be completed today, is an important test of the city's ability to borrow money as it begins to rebuild Lower Manhattan. The bonds are known as general obligation bonds because they are backed by the city's taxing power. Credit-rating agencies graded the issue at solidly investment grade, single A by Standard & Poor's and A2 by Moody's. But Colleen Woodell, managing director at Standard & Poor's Public Finance, noted that ''future credit direction will be tied to the city's ability to manage these extraordinary fiscal and economic issues at a time when political leadership is changing.''

title: The Parks We Deserve
description: In the aftermath of the World Trade Center collapse, New York City's parks have played an integral role in the healing process for our city. Union Square became a sacred meeting ground for thousands of mourners, with messages, flags, flowers and candles. All over the city, makeshift memorials were created in neighborhood parks.

title: 2 Soldiers Remembered for Their Focus and Patriotism
description: Wayne Korhonen, a psychology teacher at East High School here, came to work today as many Americans do during a time of war, wearing bold symbols of patriotism. A ribbon of red, white and blue was pinned to his lapel. His tie bore a likeness of the Stars and Stripes.

title: Soriano Savors Moment of Glory
description: Alfonso Soriano was late for stretching exercises before last night's game against the Seattle Mariners, the sort of infraction that would normally cause the Yankees to fine him or at least cause teammates to tease him. But Soriano waited until the Yankees were looking away and deftly sneaked into formation. No one noticed he was tardy. A day later, things were still going well for him.

title: Terrorists Could Still Be Plotting In Germany, an Official Warns
description: Germany is trying to determine if followers of Osama bin Laden are still be operating within its borders and could strike again, the German interior minister said today.

title: Jets' Defense Lives Down To Ranking
description: The answers about what is wrong with the Jets' run defense are starting to sound repetitive. So the outcome against the St. Louis Rams should not have been a surprise.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Author's Home Is To Be Museum
description: State officials hope to turn the Jackson home of the novelist Eudora Welty into a museum. Miss Welty, who lived most of her life and wrote many of her short stories and novels there, had deeded the house, built by her father, to the Mississippi Department of Archives and History, but lived in it until her death in July at age 92. Officials hope to raise $3 million from private sources and are applying for a matching grant of up to $1 million from the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Homicide Rates Fall Among Couples
description: The rate at which men were killed by their wives or companions fell by close to two-thirds over the last 20 years, according to a new report published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Big Step For A Space Program
description: India launched a satellite equipped with a camera for remote-sensing experiments, as well as a Belgian satellite and a German one. Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee said the triple launching proved that India's space program was self-reliant in building satellites and in putting them into space. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Scares and Investigations Snarl the Subways
description: A handful of pranks and false alarms snarled subway trains yesterday morning, feeding on fears of a possible anthrax contamination while spreading confusion among riders who were delayed for hours, transit officials said. They warned this might become typical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRINKOFF, LOTTIE
description: TRINKOFF-Lottie. Age 96. On October 22, 2001. Widow of Lew. Loving mother of Irwin and Burt and their spouses Maxine and Arline, who were like daughters. Devoted grandmother to Lloyd and Carole, Donna and Jan, Alexandra and Jeff, Paul and Grace, Joel, David and Laura. Wonderful great grandmother to Daniel, Jonathan, Kyra, Benjamin, Zachary, Lauren, Jennifer, Michael, Seth, Alyson, Marc, Julia, Alexandra (deceased) and William. Always willing to help, always there when you needed her. She was a stalwart to her entire immediate family, relatives, friends, and all who came in contact with her. She will be dearly missed but never forgotten. Servies Wednesday, October 24th, 12:45PM at ''Parkside Funeral Home,'', 98-60 Queens Blvd, corner 66 Ave, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sentence In Shop Murders
description: A Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to 50 years to life in prison for the murders of two men during a botched robbery in a muffin shop in Lower Manhattan two years ago. The man, Terrence Wells, 24, had been convicted in the shooting deaths of Gary Crissey, left, the co-owner of the Connecticut Muffin Shop, and Jimmy Brown, the store manager. Mr. Wells and an accomplice, Lerone Grant, had been trying to steal the store's $10,000 payroll, prosecutors said. Another employee and a customer were severely wounded in the incident. Mr. Grant's trial is scheduled to begin this week. Jane Fritsch (NYT)

title: Samsung Electronics Reports Plunge of 75% in Earnings
description: Officials at Samsung Electronics maintained an air of determined optimism today even as they announced a huge plunge in quarterly earnings. But they carefully avoided any mention of what many experts say Samsung needs most: for its ailing rival, Hynix Semiconductor, to collapse once and for all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTE, SADIE I.
description: ETTE-Sadie I. On September 11, 2001, at the World Trade Center. Beloved daughter of Sunday and Ekaete Essien Ette. Cherished sister of Itauma and Edu. Adored niece, cousin and friend. Memorial service Saturday, October 27, 2001, 4 PM, at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bristol: Insanity Plea In Killing Of Priest
description: A man accused of beating a priest to death with an altar candlestick will plead not guilty by reason of insanity, his lawyer said yesterday. A judge ruled recently that the man, Michael Ouelette, 34, was competent to stand trial. But Mr. Ouelette's lawyer, Kenneth Simon, said his client was paranoid schizophrenic when he killed the priest, the Rev. Robert Lysz, in June 1999. Mr. Ouelette told the police he was defending himself against the priest, Mr. Simon said. Prosecutors say Mr. Ouelette was aware of the nature of his act. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CLARENCE
description: WILLIAMS-Clarence. The Jewish Foundation for Education of Women notes with sadness the passing of Clarence Williams, husband of Dr. Essie Lee, an esteemed member of the Board for 30 years. Our heartfelt condolences to Essie and family. Jean Bronstein, President Susan Schatz, Chairman

Loving grandmother of Nicholas and Michael. Dear sister of George Michel. Loving aunt of Celia and Sophia Costas and William Michel. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 11:30AM. Visiting hours Wednesday and Thursday, 6PM-9PM.

description: Two postal workers here died today of what health officials said was probably anthrax, and two others have been hospitalized with anthrax in their lungs, as concerns about bioterrorism reached a new level.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Official Wants More 'Facts' On Crash
description: Ukraine's top national security official refused again to concede that an errant Ukrainian antiaircraft missile destroyed a Russian jetliner over the Black Sea this month, killing all 78 people aboard, despite new computer-modeling evidence that traced the missile to a launch site in Crimea. Russia's security chief, Vladimir Rushailo, who heads the formal inquiry into the crash, disclosed the new simulation, which bolsters the near-unanimous conclusion that a Ukrainian S-200 missile caused the disaster. But Yevhen Marchuk, Ukraine's security chief, said ''experts need calculations and facts as proof.'' Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: EMC and Dell Begin Venture
description: EMC, a market leader in large data storage systems, and Dell Computer, a leading vendor of inexpensive data equipment for smaller applications, said yesterday that Dell would adopt EMC's Clarion products as its main data storage offering to the middle market. Such equipment costs $50,000 to $500,000. The terms of the five-year alliance between the two also provide for Dell to help EMC sell EMC's larger Symmetrix line to Dell's corporate customers and for EMC to use Dell's supply chain to cut manufacturing costs for Clarion. The deal resumes a connection between Dell and Clarion that was interrupted when EMC acquired Data General, Clarion's developer, in 1999. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: 30% Drop in Profit Leads SBC To Job and Web Project Cuts
description: SBC Communications said here today that its third-quarter profit fell 30 percent and that it would eliminate several thousand jobs and reduce spending on an Internet project.

title: Experts Revisit Views On Surviving Anthrax
description: People with inhalation anthrax may survive if their cases are diagnosed promptly and they receive aggressive treatment in the early stages of the infection, experts in infectious disease say, basing their opinions partly on the course of the illness in two of the cases diagnosed this month.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Columbine Families Sue Drug Maker
description: Families of some victims of the 1999 Columbine High School shootings have sued the maker of the antidepressant drug Luvox, which one of the gunmen, Eric Harris, had been taking. An autopsy revealed a therapeutic amount of the drug in Mr. Harris. The relatives of five of the victims claim that the drug maker, Solvay Pharmaceuticals, did not adequately warn Mr. Harris's psychiatrist about the drug's side effects, which may include impaired judgment. Two of the victims whose families are involved in the suit died, and three were wounded. The families seek $75,000 each. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Insurer Sues to Limit Its Payout for World Trade Center
description: After trying unsuccessfully to negotiate a lower bill, the biggest insurer of the World Trade Center went public with a conflict yesterday. The insurer, Swiss Re, sued to limit how much it will pay to half of what the buildings' managers are asking.

title: Anthrax Offers Lessons in How to Handle Bad News
description: In recent decades, social scientists have learned much about how government authorities can best inform and reassure an anxious public faced with a new and unfamiliar threat.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: U.S. Challenges Sungard Deal
description: SunGard Data Systems said yesterday that federal antitrust officials were challenging its plan to buy Comdisco's computer disaster-recovery business for $825 million. Comdisco, short for the Computer Discount Corporation, filed for bankruptcy protection in July. At an Oct. 11 bankruptcy auction, SunGard topped Hewlett-Packard's $700 million offer for the Comdisco unit. SunGard, based in Wayne, Pa., said in a statement that it would ask a federal judge in Washington to reject -- before the company's offer expires on Dec. 5. -- an attempt by the Justice Department's antitrust division to block the sale. James L. Mann, SunGard's chief executive, said: ''With Comdisco in bankruptcy and its disaster-recovery business continuing to support companies devastated by the terrible events of Sept. 11, a prompt resolution of this antitrust challenge is critical.'' A hearing on the sale is scheduled for today in United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Simpson Testifies In Road-Rage Trial
description: O. J. Simpson, testifying at his road-rage trial, denied reaching into a man's car and grabbing his eyeglasses. Mr. Simpson, 54, said that the man, Jeffrey Pattinson, instigated the Dec. 4 incident in a suburban Miami neighborhood. Mr. Simpson said he did not remember touching Mr. Pattinson's glasses. He said he thought Mr. Pattinson was ''pretty excited'' and told him, ''You can cause an accident and get someone killed.'' Mr. Pattinson ''blew up'' after that remark, Mr. Simpson testified. Earlier, Judge Dennis Murphy of Circuit Court rejected a request for a mistrial because jurors had talked among themselves in the jury box. Mr. Simpson could face up to 16 years in prison if convicted of felony auto burglary and misdemeanor battery. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMANN, STEPHEN GARDNER
description: FLEISCHMANN-Stephen Gardner. Died peacefully in his sleep on Wednesday, October 17th. The cause was a heart attack. Born on May 24th, 1953 in New York City, son of the late Nancy M. Schmidt and the late Peter F. Fleischmann, and stepson of Jeanne C. Fleischmann and the late Benno C. Schmidt. Survived by his loving sister Ruth G. Fleischmann, his brother James R. Fleischmann, his stepmother Jeanne C. Fleischmann, and his stepbrother David Wilson. He will be dearly missed by his Schmidt stepbrothers, Benno, Ralph, John and Bill, and their families and by his many friends. Devoted and beloved uncle to Kate, Nancy, Ruth and Russell Planitzer. Stephen graduated from the Buckley School in New York City, the Hotchkiss School and Yale University, Class of 1975. Stephen had worked at The New Yorker magazine, founded by his grandfather Raoul H. Fleischmann. Other pursuits included medical research with Dr. Samuel Perry at New York Hospital, real estate development and private investing. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to his local fire house, Engine 22, Ladder 13, 159 East 85th Street, New York, NY 10028, or the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York City, 10021. The service will be at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue at 73rd Street at 11 AM, Tuesday, October 23rd.

title: Horrors! Time for an Attack Of the Metaphors?; From Bug Movies to Bioterrorism
description: In a gloomy, concrete labyrinth beneath a storm drain, Dr. Harold Medford stares into the squeaking, screeching tangle of giant baby ants emerging from their enormous eggs. ''When man entered the atomic age, he opened a door to a new world,'' Dr. Medford says, ruefully. ''What we'll eventually find in that new world, nobody can predict.''

title: The Terror Economy
description: America was pushed decisively into recession when the terrorist attacks on the country undermined consumer confidence, disrupted commerce and destroyed wealth. These, however, are temporary shocks from which the economy can recover. Terrorism is also causing a more persistent kind of damage as it forces what are likely to be lasting changes in the way Americans do business and lead their lives.

title: Sinn Fein, for First Time, Asks I.R.A. to Begin Disarming

The carefully orchestrated move, announced simultaneously in Belfast and New York, set the stage for imminent I.R.A. action to rescue the faltering peace process in Northern Ireland.

title: Safeco Posts $100 Million 3rd-Quarter Loss
description: The Safeco Corporation reported a third-quarter loss yesterday and said it reflected claims from last month's terrorist attacks and a $240 million addition to reserves for asbestos, workers compensation and other business claims.

title: Still Dealing, Leaders Study An Expansion Of Gambling
description: Negotiations over a final state budget that would authorize several new American Indian-run casinos and video gambling machines at horse tracks intensified today, but Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders still had not resolved several pivotal details late yesterday evening.

title: Sunday Earns Higher Ratings
description: The two league championship series games played Sunday night -- the Yankees' 3-1 victory over Seattle and Arizona's pennant-clinching victory over Atlanta -- earned a 12.4 overnight Nielsen rating for Fox Sports, up 36 percent from last year for Game 4 of the St. Louis-Mets National League Championship Series.

description: Three days after the terrorist attack on the United States, Sheik Muhammad Gemeaha, leader of a prominent mosque on East 96th Street in Manhattan, delivered a sermon in English to an interfaith audience calling for peace, healing and love among people of all religions.

title: A Mind's Eye on the Mind's Devious Tricks
description: Dr. V. S. Ramachandran has devoted his life to unraveling the mysteries of the human brain. ''What excites me is I can go in there, pretend I'm Sherlock Holmes and try and figure out what has gone wrong,'' he says early in ''Secrets of the Mind,'' tonight's installment of ''Nova'' on PBS. The magnetic Dr. Ramachandran, the program's focus, is the director of the Center for Brain and Cognition at the University of California, San Diego. When he speaks -- with a hint of his native India and a lot of the pear-shaped tones and rolling R's of a veteran Shakespearean -- you can share his palpable excitement over confronting some of the baffling brain abnormalities.

title: Terror in the Mail
description: The war keeps expanding. Some 800,000 postal employees entrusted with 680 million pieces of mail daily now find themselves on the front lines in the struggle against terror. Two of their colleagues who worked in Washington's central processing facility have died of what is believed to have been anthrax inhalation. Two other workers at the facility, where the contaminated letter sent to Senator Tom Daschle's office was processed, have been hospitalized with anthrax in their lungs.

title: On Many Fronts, Experts Plan for the Unthinkable: Biowarfare
description: Protection against biological and chemical attack was never very high on lists of national priorities -- until the days after Sept. 11, when it collectively occurred to Americans how vulnerable they were.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Rhodia Trade Halted
description: The French market regulator ordered that trading in Rhodia stock be suspended after shares jumped 23 percent on speculation that two rivals, BASF and DSM, were battling to take over the company. Shares for Rhodia, France's largest specialty chemical maker, climbed 1.80 euros, or 19 percent, to 11.31, before the halt. Aventis, a French drug company, said it had been approached about selling its stake in Rhodia. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: NORANDA TO CLOSE AUTO WHEEL PLANT IN KENTUCKY
description: Noranda Inc. said yesterday that it would shut its American Racing Equipment plant in Warsaw, Ky., and cut 200 jobs because of slumping demand for automobile wheels. Noranda will move production to other plants by the end of the year, said a company spokesman, Dale Coffin. Noranda, which is based in Toronto, also makes aluminum wheels in Rancho Dominguez and Gardena, Calif., and Queretaro, Mexico. The Warsaw plant, which opened in 1995, produced about a third of American Racing's three million wheels annually.

title: NETS REDUCE ROSTER
description: The Nets announced yesterday that they had waived the free-agent guards Danny Earl and David Vanterpool, bringing their roster to 15. Vanterpool had been sidelined by a knee sprain.

title: After a Surge, Limits Return to School Prayer
description: The prayer circle formed at midfield, just before Friday night's kickoff between the Greenbrier Panthers and the Searcy Lions. Boosted over the public school's loudspeakers, Jayla Johnston's soft voice filled the stadium. ''In the name of Jesus,'' Miss Johnston intoned. ''Our Father, who art in heaven . . . ''

title: I.R.A. Relents on Arms, Saves Peace Accord
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 23 -- In a dramatic break with its armed history, the Irish Republican Army declared today that it had started to dismantle the arsenal of weapons and bombs that sustained its decades-long war to try to evict the British from Northern Ireland.

title: In Tougher Times, It's a Life of Affluence Minus Trimmings; For Retailers Of Luxury Goods, Business Has Dried Up
description: Stylish sales people spend their days in idleness. Consumers get mailers promising them money back if they will just come in and buy something. Stores that once were havens for the elite and those who felt they belonged in their company are ghost towns, their products on display but hardly in demand.

description: The United States has signed an agreement with Uzbekistan to remove deadly anthrax from a remote island in the Aral Sea where the Soviet Union dumped tons of lethal spores, Bush administration and Uzbek officials said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: Dead Soldiers A Health Threat
description: The United Nations called on the governments of Ethiopia and Eritrea to collect the bodies of more than 300 soldiers killed during the border war that ended a year ago. The bodies are in the security zone that now stretches along what used to be the front line in the two-year conflict between the Horn of Africa neighbors. The United Nations said the remains were a serious health hazard to international peacekeepers who have patrolled the area since a cease-fire agreement was signed last December. Marc Lacey (NYT)

Pitney of NJ. Funeral service Thursday, 11AM, Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSINI, PIERO
description: CORSINI-Piero. Mrs. Christine Marietta Corsini, daughters Alessia and Benedetta, son Lorenzo and sister, Dori Masotti are saddened to announce the loss of Piero Corsini, art dealer, in Monaco, October 21, 2001 at the age of 63. The funeral will be held on Thursday, October 25, 2001 at 10:30 AM at The Church of Saint Charles in Monte Carlo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWANDER, GABRIEL
description: LEWANDER-Gabriel. Died October 22. Loving husband to Joan. Devoted father to Dr. William Lewander and wife Treacy, Marjorie Gould and husband Barry. Adored grandfather to Perry and David Gould, David and Mollie Lewander. Extended family: Joan's children Larry and Linda Fields, Paul and Audrey Fields; treasured grandfather to Steven, Melissa, Eric, Brendon and Dillon. Survived by brother Arthur and sister Blanche. We all love you and miss you. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76 St., Wednesday, October 24, 11:45 AM.

title: For Some, Anthrax Falls To the B-List
description: Even as New Yorkers flinched at every new mention of anthrax last week and fought rising panic, the regular Monday meeting of the city's infectious disease specialists unfolded more or less as usual.

title: Settsu Journal; All the Spin Came First, and Then the Agitation
description: In a shopping mall parking lot, beneath a banner that proclaimed ''We Love Humans and the Earth,'' Masamitsu Kobayashi squirted baby food and barbecue sauce on a white oxford shirt, part of a sales pitch for an invention that is rattling Japan's detergent industry: ''the world's first zero detergent washing machine.''

title: AOL Wins Some China TV Rights
description: AOL Time Warner said today that it had been given approval to transmit limited programming into a small area of Guangdong province in southern China. In return, the company will carry Chinese programming on its cable systems in New York, Los Angeles and Houston.

title: Camby Set to Test Aching Foot
description: Marcus Camby was examined yesterday by Dr. William Hamilton, a foot specialist, and told that the condition of his left foot had improved. But whether Camby, who has plantar fasciitis, will be available for the Knicks' season opener against Michael Jordan and the Washington Wizards on Oct. 30 remains a mystery.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Dogs used to be the worst thing we worried about on this job.''

title: A Flurry of Hugs for 'Gang of Five' in Capital
description: When President Bush smothered the highest-ranking Democrats, Senator Tom Daschle and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, in bear hugs last month after he addressed a joint meeting of Congress, Mr. Bush wondered if he had gone too far.

title: More Deaths, More Questions, More Bombs
description: The deaths of two postal workers, to all appearances from anthrax, and the infection of two others with the most lethal form of the disease thrust bioterrorism back to the forefront in a country torn between the fascination of an unfolding military campaign and the tangible fear of a mysterious germ.

title: Lou and the Boss Get Reacquainted
description: Lou Piniella was in the interview room in the basement at Yankee Stadium before Game 4 of the American League Championship Series, and suddenly, just inside the doorway of the adjacent pressroom, there stood George Steinbrenner.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONVERGYS CORP., Cincinnati, a provider of customer services to telecommunications companies, won two contracts with AT&T Corp., New York, the long-distance phone company, to handle billing, order management and repair requests for its local-phone and Internet businesses. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls
description: Japan's trade surplus fell 18.3 percent in September from a year ago, the 15th consecutive decline, as exports to the United States, Europe and Asia plunged. Shipments of machinery, audiovisual equipment and metals declined sharply after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, when air and sea transportation was temporarily disrupted. Exports fell 11.1 percent in September, the largest slide in more than two years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Indivisible, With Meaning for All; Recitation of the Pledge Becomes a Learning Occasion
description: For as many years as its principal, Pearl Schulson, can remember, the children of Public School 175 in Rego Park, Queens, have stood up in their classrooms every morning, put their hands over the hearts and recited the Pledge of Allegiance. Then they have sung the anthem beginning, ''My country 'tis of thee.'' Only then have they sat down and begun to work.

title: New Doubts About Treatment for Premature Babies
description: Doctors are raising serious questions about a practice that has become commonplace: giving weekly doses of steroids to pregnant women who are at risk of starting labor too early and having premature babies.

title: The French Establishment Salutes a Dedicated Rebel
description: If some art can be deemed quiet, Jean Dubuffet set out to make noise. Bent on disrupting conventions and deriding officialdom, he took his inspiration from the nave images created by primitive, psychotic or child painters to produce what he called ''art brut,'' or raw art. And if that did not stir enough turmoil, he was also a prolific writer, pouring out explanations of his own art and often uncharitable comments on the work of others.

title: United They Stood, for an Awfully Long Time
description: The wardrobe of Destiny's Child summed up the difference between the Concert for New York City on Saturday and United We Stand, the concert held Sunday at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium here and scheduled for broadcast Nov. 1 on ABC.

title: Accounts
description: * Finlandia vodka to Bozell New York, part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its first worldwide creative account. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Finlandia is 45 percent owned by Brown-Forman, Louisville, Ky., and 55 percent owned by the Altia Group, Helsinki, Finland. The last agency of record for Finlandia in the United States was Mezzina Brown & Partners, New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Operating Profit At Daewoo
description: The bankrupt Daewoo Motors posted an operating profit of $26.9 million for the third quarter, which ended Sept. 30. The report was expected to ease final negotiations with General Motors, which has signed a nonbinding agreement to take over Daewoo for $400 million. The operating profit was up from $17.4 million in the second quarter and contrasted with a deficit of $35.7 million in the first quarter. The company attributed the profit to cost cuts and increased sales.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Suit Seeks to Limit Claim

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Conviction In Ferry Death
description: Joseph Mitlof, the owner of Hudson Valley Waterways, was convicted of manslaughter yesterday in Federal District Court in White Plains in connection with a 1998 ferry accident in which one person died. Mr. Mitlof, 59, could be sentenced to as much as 10 years in prison. Evidence at a nine-day trial showed that the company's two ferry boats did not have certification to operate on the Hudson River. The boat involved in the accident was unfit to carry passengers, according to prosecutors. On a trip from Nyack to Tarrytown on Aug. 23, 1998, the boat began to take on water, then capsized. One passenger, Dr. Milton Salkind, drowned. Jane Fritsch (NYT)

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, SIMON REYNALDO
description: GONZALEZ-Simon Reynaldo. October 20, 2001. United Nations (retired), Sr. Spanish language Editor. Of Freeport, LI, NY, formerly of Guanabacoa, Havana, Cuba. Beloved husband of Esperanza Noemi Gonzalez. Devoted and cherished father of Cesarina Gonzalez Berrigan and Maria GonzalezWalling (William). Dear grandfather of A1C Andrew Berrigan and Delia Berrigan. Loved brother of Blanca G. Jimenez (Idelfonso) of Augusta, GA; of Mirta Gonzalez Garcia of Havana, Cuba; and brother-in-law of Clarivel and Israel Garcia. Cherished uncle of several nephews. Friends may call 2-4 and 7-9pm at Weigeind-Pensa Funeral Home, 22-83 Grand Ave, Baldwin NY Tuesday, October 23, 2001. Funeral Mass Wednesday 9:45am at RC Church Queen of the Most Holy Rosary, 196 W Centennial Ave, Roosevelt LI, NY.

title: China Eases Rules Binding People to Birth Regions
description: For the last few years, Li Xiangen has refused to live in the countryside and work as a farmer -- even though his registration at birth as a rural resident allows him few legal alternatives. Instead, he has made his home in Santai, a small city near this provincial capital, working as an itinerant fountain pen repairman.

title: The Terror Economy
description: America was pushed decisively into recession when the terrorist attacks on the country undermined consumer confidence, disrupted commerce and destroyed wealth. These, however, are temporary shocks from which the economy can recover. Terrorism is also causing a more persistent kind of damage as it forces what are likely to be lasting changes in the way Americans do business and lead their lives.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Tug Of War Over Fujimori
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan told President Alejandro Toledo of Peru that former President Alberto K. Fujimori, left, could be tried in Japan on charges that he was involved in death-squad activities and corruption but said that Mr. Fujimori would not be extradited. In a meeting at the end of a gathering of 21 leaders of Asian and Pacific nations in Shanghai, Mr. Toledo told Mr. Koizumi that Mr. Fujimori must be tried in Peru, where he served as president for a decade before fleeing to Japan last year. Japan refuses to extradite Mr. Fujimori because he is the son of Japanese immigrants and has claimed Japanese citizenship. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about Manhattan jazz clubs' recovery from the attacks of Sept. 11 misidentified the recipient of the performance fees donated by the saxophonist Michael Brecker after he played at Iridium on the weekend of Sept. 14-16. The donation went to The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund, not to the club.

title: Fighting Back When Foe Is Prostate Cancer
description: ''Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer,'' by Patrick C. Walsh and Janet Farrar Worthington, Warner Books, $25.95.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants' Field Goals Not Enough to Win
description: COMING through the tunnel after the Philadelphia Eagles' 10-9 victory last night, defensive end Hugh Douglas could be heard shouting: ''Everybody's talking all that junk before. Nobody's talking anything now. We shut 'em up.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIMBERG, ALAN
description: CIMBERG - Alan. ''Grandpa Pookie'' to family and friends, died in his sleep at home on October 21, 2001. Beloved husband of Freda for 64 years. Loving father of Janice Cimberg and the late Dr. Robert Cimberg. Adored grandfather of Jonathan Fried, his wife, Sharon Greenberger, and Andrew Fried. Devoted great-grandfather of Madelyn and Josie. The youngest of seven children, Alan was born on the Lower East Side on January 1, 1911, and in his 90th year was still working as a professional speaker, giving courses on sales motivation. Alan was one of Dale Carnegie's earliest students and this experience and his training as a instructor in Carnegie's method sparked a lifelong interest in speaking and selling. Alan worked for 20 years as a salesman with The Borg/Warner Company, achieving the position of Field Sales Manager, before finding a second career, and his true calling, as a motivational speaker to the sales forces of top businesses around the world. Alan was one of the founders of The National Speakers Association and was honored with their Hall of Fame Award. He was also a Certified Hypnotist and Lifetime Member of the International Association of Counselors and Therapists. He was a founding member of the Malverne Jewish Center and remained an active congregant. Alan believed in the power of positive thinking and he lived that belief: riding a motorcycle, walking on fire and parasailing very late in life. He will be remembered for the cheerful greetings he had for everyone he met and for seeing the possibility for success in each new challenge. Services today, October 23, 10 AM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the United Jewish Appeal are requested.

title: Egyptian Raised Terror Funds in U.S. in 1990's
description: In 1995, when American intelligence officials were just beginning to pay attention to Osama bin Laden's international terrorist network, one of its top commanders slipped into the United States and embarked on a coast-to-coast fund-raising tour and bought satellite communications equipment with the help of Arab-American operatives.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Vitesse Posts 4th-Quarter Loss
description: The Vitesse Semiconductor Corporation, which makes chips for fiber optic networking equipment, said yesterday that it had a fiscal fourth-quarter loss, compared with a profit a year earlier, as sales plunged 73 percent. The loss was $59.2 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with net income of $11.6 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier, Vitesse said. Revenue in the quarter ended Sept. 30 dropped to $37.2 million from $138 million. Sales in the first quarter will be $36 million to $40 million, Lou Tomasetta, the chief executive, said during a conference call. Sales at Vitesse and its rivals, including PMC-Sierra and Applied Micro Circuits, plummeted last quarter as much as they boomed in 2000. Telecommunications companies reduced spending on equipment that used the semiconductor makers' products, leaving a glut of chips in inventory. Vitesse shares rose 66 cents yesterday, to $9.56, and were little changed in after-hours trading after the report. They declined 88 percent in the last year.

title: Post Offices Handle Less Mail, With More Caution
description: Sorting and stamping and sifting through mail is not what it used to be at the postal processing center in this western suburb of Boston. There is far less mail. There are far more signs of anthrax-related anxiety.

title: How a Patient Assassin Does Its Deadly Work
description: The anthrax spore lurks in the soil for months or decades, a patient assassin waiting for its sleep to be disturbed. One day, perhaps when a grazing cow yanks up a plant by its roots, the tiny spores shake loose and are eaten, or are sniffed into the cow's lungs, or dust its skin with a deadly bloom. Then begins a precise but terrible execution.

description: Ann Hampton Callaway

title: Panel Seeks Tighter Security for Disease Agency
description: The leaders of a House subcommittee on terrorism said today that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention here needed more money to protect its buildings from possible attack and to improve communications with local governments around the country.

Spacing Out
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Israelis Rebuff U.S. On Pullout Request
description: Israel turned down President Bush's request to withdraw its forces from Palestinian-controlled territory, putting new pressure on American-Israeli relations and the anti-terror coalition with Arab allies. Israel's foreign minister, Shimon Peres, said in Washington that Israel would not pull out until the Palestinians arrested the men who killed Israel's tourism minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JACK
description: SCHWARTZ-Jack. 76, ''Papa Jack'' peacefully on October 22. Beloved husband of Sherrie, his ''Babe''. Devoted and loving father of Jeffrey, Kenneth, Judy and Richard and their spouses Debbie, Betty and Bob. Cherished grandfather to Jason, Matthew, Jessica, Danny, Sam, Alex and Lara. Brother of Norbert (deceased). Born in Austria, migrated by ''Kindertransport'' to England and ultimately Chicago. A true original, he will be remembered for his infinite devotion to his family, wonderful sense of humor and unique style and use of the English language. A man with a whole-hearted zest for life, we will never forget you.

title: Residents in Rebel Village Tell of Rockets Fired by Taliban Forces
description: Taliban forces fired rockets on Tuesday at the market in this Northern Alliance village, killing two people and wounding dozens, residents said.

title: Time to Savor Pennant and Study Up
description: The plastic cups of Champagne in the Yankees' clubhouse were disappearing quickly early yesterday morning and George Steinbrenner was late for the celebration. Wearing his lucky combination of blazer and turtleneck, Steinbrenner strode through a crowd of reporters, answering a question or two. What he really wanted was to get to the party that had started without him.

title: Citizens Union Backs Bloomberg's Mayoral Bid
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican candidate for mayor, received the backing yesterday of the Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic organization founded more than a century ago to fight the corruption of Tammany Hall.

title: Giuliani, Amid Anthrax Scare, Urges People to Get Flu Shots
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani urged all New Yorkers today to get vaccinated for the coming flu season, largely because early symptoms of the anthrax disease mirror the flu.

title: From Paris, by Way of the Great Pumpkin
description: Parisians don't celebrate Halloween as we do, but La Maison du Chocolat, the Parisian confectionery company, has gotten into the spirit with plump chocolate pumpkins garnished with an orange leaf. Inside are the real treats: morsels of delicious caramelized toasted almond praline coated with milk or dark chocolate. Each pumpkin weighs 20 ounces and is $45. The almond morsels, Swiss Rocks, are also sold separately for about $3.50 an ounce. The company has sacks of small pumpkins and ghosts in milk or dark chocolate, too; $8 for four ounces, $16 for eight ounces. All are sold at 1018 Madison Avenue (78th Street) and 30 Rockefeller Plaza (on 49th Street). There is a new seating area in the Rockefeller Center store, where coffee, tea and dessert are served.

title: Xenakis Leaves a Mystery About His Music's Source
description: Iannis Xenakis died in February, but his music goes on loud with life. On Friday night at the Miller Theater the Ensemble Sospeso presented five works that were different in time and different in sound, but all had the same raw energy. Some excellent performances, conducted by Rand Steiger, fully communicated it.

title: Fear Rides the Rails
description: Aminor transformer fire in a tunnel south of the Canal Street station leading to the Manhattan Bridge caused chaos, frightened tears and long delays in service yesterday morning on the Q and W lines during the morning rush. No one was hurt.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sun Unveils Web Platform
description: Sun Microsystemsrolled out the first phase of its Sun One, or Open Net Environment, software platform, a suite of products that are designed to let customers create and deploy Web services that function on a range of devices. At a demonstration event held in Santa Clara, Calif., Sun announced the availability of a four-CD kit for developers and introduced a software package, called the iPlanet Portal Server, that enables Internet service providers and enterprises to support instant messaging among employees, business partners and suppliers. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: A Supercool Setting, but a Warm Welcome
description: MAN RAY ought to have the DNA of a velvet-rope restaurant. The Parisian original is a celebrity magnet, the kind of loud and large New York-style dining spot that younger French diners adore. Thierry Klmniuk, hoping to repeat the formula in Manhattan, has the star-power backing of investors like Johnny Depp, Sean Penn, John Malkovich and Harvey Weinstein. The artfully decadent retro Asian dcor, the waitresses in slinky silk mandarin dresses -- it all spells the kind of restaurant where mere mortals feel worthless, and the food does not even pretend to be anything more than a fashion accessory.

title: Name That Car
description: In 1896, Wealthy Austrian Emil Jellinek promised to order 36 cars from Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft if they would name the cars after his daughter, Mercedes.

title: A New Disco Has a Twisted Past and Present
description: One way to judge the relative quality of a horror movie is by examining its vision of hell. Just how original and how hellish is it? By that standard, Ernest Dickerson's Halloween-ready scream fest, ''Bones,'' ranks high.

description: The American Red Cross is to benefit from an advertising initiative that improbably pairs a fast-food chain and the fashion photographer Richard Avedon.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Le Monde To Sell Shares
description: Journalists at Le Monde, the French newspaper, voted on Monday in favor of listing the company on the French stock market within two years. The resolution, which passed with 52 percent of the vote, would make Le Monde the first French newspaper to be traded publicly. Outside shareholders own 47 percent, but no group owns more than 5 percent. Management hopes to raise $89 million by issuing 20 percent of its shares. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

description: Pavel G. Bunich, a moderate Russian economic reformer and two-time Parliament member who broadly supported the switch to a market-based economy under Presidents Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, died on Saturday in Moscow. He was 71.

title: Russian Envoy Says Chechen Proposes Talks on Ending War
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24  A top aide to the political leader of Chechnya's separatist guerrillas proposed today to open talks with the Kremlin on disarming the rebels and ending the two-year-old war, President Vladimir V. Putin's envoy to southwest Russia said.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Indian Activist Changes Affiliation
description: Russell Means, a leader of the American Indian Movement, has decided to run for governor in 2002 as an independent instead of as a nominee of the Libertarian Party. He said that he would not officially announce his candidacy until the deadline next July. Gov. Gary E. Johnson, a two-term Republican, is barred by term limits from running again. Several Republicans are planning to run, and Bill Richardson, the former energy secretary in the Clinton Administration, has formed an exploratory committee concerning the Democratic nomination. Mindy Sink (NYT)
