It is fashionable now, especially among New York sports teams' players and coaches, to wear these caps representing the police and firefighters, honoring the workers searching for bodies in the rubble in Lower Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, JEFFREY T.
description: WILSON-Jeffrey T., Wall Street Trader and philanthropist, died Wednesday, October 10th in Houston, Texas. After surviving a terrible automobile accident on September 11, 2000, Mr. Wilson fought against the odds towards recovery. His recovery spanned from Hollywood Memorial Hospital in Florida to New York Presbyterian Cornell Medical Center to Mary Manning Nursing Home in New York City and finally the Institute of Research and Rehabilitation in Houston, Texas. Just 5 days short of his return home to Boca Raton, Florida, Mr. Wilson was overcome by infection, pneumonia, and then further complications. After completing college at Northeastern University in Boston, Mr. Wilson went to Wall Street where he started as a market maker for STS Securities on the floor of the American Stock Exchange. After a couple of years, Mr. Wilson broke away to form his own company, Rockrimmon Securities. Starting with 4 traders on the Amex floor, Mr. Wilson went on to build a group of companies spanning across the country, employing several hundred traders. Some of the companies he started are JAS Securities, Rockrimmon Commodities, Tiger Options, Pacific Coast Capital, West Coast Capital, JGM Securities and Broadway Trading, LLC. Mr. Wilson also had an interst in entertainment, where he had partnerships in the Art Bar in Stamford, CT., Christopher's Night Club in Ft. Lauderdale, FL., and Direct Tickets in Florida. In 1997, Mr. Wilson turned his interest towards charity as he felt very fortunate with his successes in business, he felt the strong need to help others not as fortunate. In 1998, Mr. Wilson was named one of the Top 50 Jewish Community Builders of South Palm Beach County. In 3 years Mr. Wilson made a significent impact to the community. He was on the Board of Directors for the Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County, Ruth Rales Jewish Family Services and the Jewish Braille Institute. A Trustee to the Washington Institute and the Simon Weisthenthal Center. A member/supporter of the Anti-Defamation League, the Jewish Adoption and Foster Care, Florence Fuller Child Development Centers, the Jewish Federation's prime Ministers Club, the Israeli Bond Society and United Way's Alexis de Tocqueville Society. Mr. Wilson founded and funded the Hebrew Free Loan Society and the Big Pals/Little Pals program for Ruth Rales Jewish Family Services. As chairman for King David Society of Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County, Mr. Wilson organized and led a mission to Cuba in 1999. He was also a major contributor to Clerisy Academy in Boca Raton, Florida. Never one to say ''no'', Mr. Wilson would provide the Christmas toys to several organizations where there weren't enough funds. Though Mr. Wilson's life was short, he left an enormous impact on all of those he met. Full of life and love, he is survived by his wife Christina and their two sons, Sammy and Jake, mother Merle Schwartz and siblings Lauren Heller, William Wilson and Elizabeth Shapiro all of Boca Raton, Florida. Funeral Services took place on October 14, 2001 at Temple Beth El in Boca Raton, Florida.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Bush Favored Over Reno
description: A poll taken in mid-October by Florida's teachers unions shows Gov. Jeb Bush ahead of former Attorney General Janet Reno 60 percent to 26 percent in the 2002 election for governor. The poll, on Oct. 12-14, was to ask voters about budget cuts and taxes for education but also asked voters their choice in a race between Mr. Bush and Ms. Reno, the leading Democratic candidate. In May, a poll published by The Miami Herald showed Mr. Bush defeating Ms. Reno 49 percent to 43 percent. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: Survivors Tell Of Many Dead In Sea Disaster Off Indonesia
description: It took just 10 minutes for the small wooden ship to sink, survivors said, with 200 people trapped inside its hull. More than 100 others died after floating in the water for hours in a driving rain.

title: Showalter Is Left on the Outside Looking In
description: Imagine this. You managed a baseball team that was a fiasco and developed it into a strong club. You molded the team after yourself: competitive, savvy, dedicated. But you missed out on a title and left the organization you loved because of a bitter relationship with the owner and a superior offer from another team. Then your old team won a championship the year after you left.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: U.S. Advisers To Help Against Muslim Rebels
description: American military advisers arrived in the southern Philippines to help train Philippine troops who are fighting Muslim militants. The rebels are holding at least 12 hostages, including two American missionaries. They are believed to have links with the terrorist network of Osama bin Laden.

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: Fear Of Beef Wanes
description: The panics over mad cow disease and foot-and-mouth disease seem to be easing, said the European Union's agriculture commissioner, Franz Fischler. Beef sales, which had plummeted, have risen again, but meat consumption is expected to be 10 percent lower this year than last. No new foot-and-mouth cases have been seen in Britain for 23 days, longer than the 14-day incubation period, leading to hopes that the epidemic is over. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: The Manhattan Skyline's 'Phantom Limb'
description: At first, Michael Mailer, an independent film producer, considered editing the twin towers out of his new picture, ''Empire,'' which he calls a ''Latin 'Godfather' movie'' set in New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Rate Lowered
description: The Bank of Canada lowered its benchmark interest rate target three-quarters of a percentage point, pushing borrowing costs to the lowest since 1961. The cut puts the target for overnight loans between banks at 2.75 percent.

title: Heaven Can Wait, Give Me Hot Chocolate
description: Hot chocolate made with real chocolate is to cocoa what brioche is to bread, far more buttery and rich. Made with the new hot chocolate mix from Jacques Torres Chocolate in Brooklyn, the result has an uncommon intensity, with sugar taking a back seat to the fine chocolate. For a devilish little kick, the mix also comes in a version with some chilies ground in. Both kinds are $14 a pound at Jacques Torres Chocolate at 66 Water Street (Dock Street) in Dumbo.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Mixed Message On Terrorism
description: North Korea, which condemned the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, criticized the American airstrikes on Afghanistan, saying the killing of innocent civilians cannot be justified. The new American ambassador to South Korea, Thomas Hubbard, welcomed the condemnation of the attacks but said the North had been less forthcoming in supporting the coalition against terrorism.

title: Our Towns; Where Ghosts Are Seen But Not Sworn
description: THE Jersey City Municipal Court is one step up from the street when it comes to legal importance, but right at the peak in terms of volume of justice, processing 30,000 tickets a month, the busiest court in the state. ''If you spit on the sidewalk,'' says Martin Dolan, the court director, ''this is where you wind up.'' Junkies, winos, pickpockets, brawlers, ladies working the stroll mix with speeders, parking scofflaws and commuters trying to sneak through the E-ZPass lane at the Holland Tunnel. ''When I was a prosecutor in this court,'' Mr. Dolan says, ''I'd move 150 cases a day.'' Traffic tickets pile up, overflow filing cabinets, bury clerks' desks. ''If you're not careful,'' he says, ''you can be lulled by the stacks of paper.''

title: Maker of Small Jets Sees a Silver Lining
description: When the first of the sleek new 70-passenger ERJ-170 jets from Embraer rolls out of the factory next Monday, it will fly off into a world vastly different from the boom times in which it was conceived two years ago.

title: On Menus Everywhere, A Big Slice of Patriotism
description: IT wasn't too many days after Sept. 11 that a hot dog began to dominate my thoughts. It was a classic dog, spread with mustard and piled high with relish. It looked a lot like the hot dog you see advertised at the beginning of a drive-in movie, along with the dancing tub of popcorn and the singing French fries.

title: Lawmakers' Votes on Economic Legislation Will Test Talk of Bipartisanship
description: For all their recent pledges of bipartisanship, Republicans and Democrats are headed for an ideological showdown over how best to revive the economy.

title: On the Bioterror Front: Fear and Vigilance
description: To the Editor:

title: Selig Denies Two Teams Will Fold
description: Commissioner Bud Selig had a conniption about contraction yesterday. The possibility that Major League Baseball will eliminate two teams for economic reasons has existed for the past year or so, but a Canadian newspaper reported that the decision had already been made and that the Montreal Expos and the Florida Marlins would be jettisoned after the World Series.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: Police Seize Missile Part
description: What appeared to be the warhead of a sophisticated anti-tank missile was discovered in an empty apartment, taken by the police to a firing range and then detonated, the police said. The missile part was not live, Lt. Mark Deal, a spokesman for the Waterbury police, said yesterday. Construction workers found the three-foot section of the missile, called a tube-launched, optically tracked and wire-guided weapon, just after 5 p.m. Monday. Investigators say the missile was available only to military personnel in the 1970's. They said they did not know who owned it or why it had been left in the apartment. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: THE BOSS; Black Gold's Calling Card
description: My father died when I was 15. We lived on a small farm/ranch near Texarkana, Ark., and mother wasn't experienced in managing money.

title: Weak Demand, Price War And Typhoon Hurt Compaq
description: Compaq Computer, which is being acquired by Hewlett-Packard, reported a third-quarter loss today, blaming weak demand, a price war and supply interruptions. Compaq, a maker of personal computers, forecast a loss for the fourth quarter, as well.

title: Lewis Is Seeking His Misplaced Intensity
description: Here in the Poconos, where he trains in a hotel's fitness center/miniature golf course, Lennox Lewis says he is finding the intensity he lacked when he lost his heavyweight titles to Hasim Rahman in April in South Africa.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Jos Van Dam Cancels Dates
description: The bass-baritone Jos van Dam, who was to sing works by Duparc and Mahler with the New York Philharmonic in four programs beginning tomorrow, has canceled because of an injury, the orchestra announced yesterday. He is to be replaced by the soprano Jessica Jones, who will sing four Duparc songs. The concerts are tomorrow, Friday and Saturday nights at 8 and Tuesday night at 7:30.

title: New President for SUNY Maritime
description: The State University of New York's trustees yesterday named the superintendent of the United States Naval Academy, Vice Adm. JOHN R. RYAN, president of SUNY's Maritime College in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx, effective next June. SUNY officials said they hoped that the appointment would give new momentum to a campus that has struggled in recent years. SUNY Maritime is the oldest Coast Guard-approved nautical college in the United States, but its enrollment fell sharply in the 1990's. In 1999, Muslim cadets from the Middle East said they had been harassed and beaten by classmates. SUNY's chancellor, ROBERT L. KING, said the campus was ''now on sound footing, and enrollments are increasing.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: WPP Defends Tempus Case
description: The British advertising agency WPP Group said it had received new information that supported its efforts to abort a takeover of the Tempus Group. WPP said the Sept. 11 attacks had brought an adverse change to Tempus's business. Last week, the companies made their case to regulators, who are expected to reach a decision this week. WPP executives declined to elaborate on the information, but people close to the companies suggested it came from documents Tempus had filed with regulators. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Traditional Cook-It-Yourself Korean Feast
description: FEW things are as comforting as a campfire. For Americans, campfires offer warmth and security, representing comfort and sustenance in threatening times. In the wilds of Manhattan, though, campfires are few, unless you head for the Korean restaurants on West 32nd Street, where you'll find a campfire on almost every table.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENBOGEN, JOAN L.
description: ELLENBOGEN-Joan L., 59, on October 23, 2001. She is survived by her loving sister, Leni Goodman, and her adoring niece, Cache, and her caring circle of close friends. Services Thursday, October 25, 12noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65 St.

title: U.S. Says Bayer Will Cut Cost of Its Anthrax Drug
description: The Bush administration said tonight that it had won a major price concession from Bayer A.G. for its anthrax medicine, Cipro, after the administration threatened to buy generic alternatives instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROUTY, HELEN ELLIS THORNE
description: PROUTY-Helen Ellis Thorne. The Dean and Faculty of Columbia University School of Nursing wish to express their deepest condolences to the family of Helen Ellis Thorne Prouty, our distinguished and beloved alumna. Her charm, grace and unwavering support of the School will be long remembered and cherished.

title: Responding to the Anthrax Threat
description: Just when it looked as if the nation's public health system was gaining control of the evolving anthrax crisis, incidents at two postal facilities have revealed gaps that need fixing. Alarmingly, a hospital in Maryland failed to correctly diagnose inhalational anthrax in a postal worker who returned a day later and died within hours. The man had worked at a big mail processing center in Washington, D.C., that handled the anthrax-contaminated letter sent to Senator Tom Daschle.

title: Talks on Vaccine For Smallpox
description: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said yesterday that the government was negotiating with seven companies to manufacture smallpox vaccine that could be used in case of a terrorist attack.

title: The Roots of an Afghan Nation
description: We are now heavily engaged in discussions on post-Taliban political structures in Afghanistan. Afghans must be the main players, but outsiders also have major roles, and that clearly includes the United States. We will have much of the responsibility for giving post-Taliban institutions traction and staying power. Political negotiations on Afghanistan have always been extremely intricate. Those now under way can be more successful if we understand that there is space in Afghan politics between universalist Islam and the ethnic groupings that are so often painted as that unhappy country's only options.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: New Children's Hospital
description: The Montefiore Medical Center yesterday opened its new Children's Hospital, which includes one of the region's largest centers for treating childhood asthma. The 106-bed hospital cost $120 million and is intended to serve patients from the Bronx and southern Westchester. A pediatric emergency room is already in operation, and an intensive-care unit is to open next week. The project was inspired, in part, by the late astronomer Carl Sagan, who was impressed by the medical care he received there and wanted children to receive a similar level of care. The lobby has astronomical exhibits.

title: Heroin Price Falls, but Not For Users In Europe
description: The price of Afghan heroin has dropped, but police departments across Europe say that is unlikely to affect street prices much and has not done so to date.

title: Sense of Trust Is Shaken in Man Who Took Suspects Into Home
description: As a deeply religious man and one of the few Muslims in San Diego involved in civic affairs, Abdussattar Shaikh tends to speak of a world of certainties. He is sure, he says, that God rewards devotion, that trust can bridge religious differences and, perhaps most important, that if you spend much time with another person, you can see into the heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORDES, DITE M. (APHRODITE FOTIADES, NEE MICHEL)
description: FORDES-Dite M. (Aphrodite Fotiades, nee Michel). On October 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Nicholas. Devoted mother of William and George. Cherished mother-in-law of Taryn and Julia. Loving grandmother of Nicholas and Michael. Dear sister of George Michel. Loving aunt of Celia and Sophia Costas and William Michel. Also survived by her sisters-in-law Helen and Anne Michel and numerous cousins. Reposing at Dahill Funeral Home, 2525 65 St, Brooklyn until Friday, 10:30AM. Funeral Liturgy at S.S. Constantine and Helen G.O. Church, 11:30AM. Visiting hours Wednesday and Thursday, 6PM-9PM.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Services Agree To Ratings
description: Some of the biggest companies in the online world said they would take part in a voluntary labeling system to help parents shield children from online content, like nudity, the parents find objectionable. AOL Time Warner, Yahoo and the Microsoft Network voiced support for the Internet Content Ratings Association, which promotes the worldwide adoption of tools for blocking sites that are included in the major Internet browser programs. The group says it offers an alternative to government regulation. Jerry Berman, executive director of the Center for Democracy and Technology, applauded the efforts, but said parents should use sites like www.getnetwise.org to see the full range of options. ''We don't think there's a one-size-fits-all strategy,'' he said. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about China's exports of missile technology referred incorrectly to an American action toward Pakistan. After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Washington waived sanctions imposed on Pakistan as punishment for its nuclear testing in 1998, and it is considering waiving others. But it has not lifted sanctions against Pakistan's National Development Complex related to that agency's purchase of missile components from China earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BILOWIT, DEBBI WASSERMAN
description: BILOWIT-Debbi Wasserman. 2/3/46-10/23/86. A lifetime ago your too-brief life brought happiness to many. We mourn and remember you. Time has not lessened the loss or the loneliness

title: Even in a gloomy business outlook, magazine executives see some long-term opportunities.
description: THOUGH magazines are facing perhaps their most clouded business outlook in decades, executives at a conference said yesterday, the problems confronting the industry bring with them opportunities to strengthen operations to prepare for the inevitable cyclical upturn.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the site of the World Trade Center collapse misidentified the people in the picture and the work they were doing. They were welders cutting steel beams, not firefighters spraying water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBRINK, STUART H.
description: STEINBRINK-Stuart H., on October 22, 2001. Devoted husband of Ruth nee Sundheimer, proud father of Barbara and Ira Levine and Richard and Diane Steinbrink, joyful grandfather of David and Susan Steinbrink, Judy and Alan Garet, Carolyn and Brian Coonin, Ronald Levine and Ellen and Jack Soloff, and great-grandfather of ten. Dear brother of the late Miriam Abelow. Memorial service Thursday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Breeders' Cup Favorites Have a Foreign Flair
description: He is just the house rider. He concedes that he has more in common with the lads who groom and exercise the horses than he does with sheiks who sign his paycheck, but the jockey Frankie Dettori has his opinions. He made them known yesterday:

title: HORTON ACQUIRES ANOTHER HOME BUILDER
description: D. R. Horton Inc. has agreed to buy Schuler Homes for $653 million in cash and stock, continuing a consolidation in the home construction industry. Horton will also assume $552 million in debt for Schuler, which is based in El Segundo, Calif. The deal will create the nation's second-largest home builder, Horton said. Schuler's shareholders will get $4.09 and 0.57 Horton share for each share of Schuler that they own, Horton said. This values Schuler at $16.12 a share, a 34 percent premium over the company's closing price on Monday. Horton is based in Arlington, Tex.

title: Liberties; Going Really Postal
description: The federal government is starting to remind me of the Amity town council in ''Jaws.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMMON, R. THEODORE
description: AMMON-R. Theodore. The board, staff and artists of Jazz at Lincoln Center are profoundly saddened by the death of our chairman, R. Theodore Ammon. Ted was a great and loyal friend of this organization, since joining the board in 1996 and becoming chairman in March of this year. A tireless supporter, Ted brought his passion for jazz and his tremendous enthusiasm for our mission to everything he did. His strong belief in the power of jazz to bring all kinds of people together will remain a source of inspiration. We all loved him very much, and he will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and friends. Wynton Marsalis, Artistic Director Bruce MacCombie, Exec. Director

title: LARGE INSURANCE COMPANY TO LAY OFF 500 IN NEW YORK
description: AXA, an insurance company based in France, will lay off 500 employees at its AXA Financial unit in the United States as part of a plan to cut costs 10 percent next year. The staff cuts ''are the last element in the program to reduce expenses by $250 million'' at AXA's United States operations, an AXA Financial spokesman, Jeff Tolvin, said. The cuts will fall in AXA Financial's insurance unit, which employs 5,535 people, Mr. Tolvin said. Axa Financial has 10,450 employees.

title: Again, Afghan's Flight Matches His History With His Country's
description: Abdul Hadi pulled into the central bus station here today, sitting in the passenger seat of his hired Datsun pickup truck, four sons in the back under the tarpaulin and all his worldly possessions -- a blue wheelbarrow, a bicycle, 12 yellow jerry cans, bundles of clothes and two metal containers -- strapped to the roof.

title: Beaten in Pakistan, Battered in Brooklyn
description: Haider Rizvi, a freelance journalist and native of Pakistan, has spent much of the last six weeks talking to cabdrivers, deli workers and other New Yorkers who have been picked on, yelled at and roughed up because, to untrained eyes, they resemble the terrorists who struck the World Trade Center. Late last month, he wrote an article about such bias for a South Asian news service.

title: XEROX REPORTS WIDER LOSS IN 3RD QUARTER
description: Xerox reported a third-quarter loss yesterday that was worse than last year's and said that its sales were slowing. Standard & Poor's cut the company's credit rating to junk because its sales and profit would probably be lower than expected this year and next. The loss increased to $211 million, or 29 cents a share, from $191 million, or 30 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Sales fell 13 percent, to $3.9 billion from $4.5 billion, the company said. It was Xerox's fifth consecutive quarterly loss. Xerox said two weeks ago that the loss was about twice as large as forecast.

title: The Specter of Joseph Stalin Descends Over Mayoral Race
description: Never mind the state of the public schools, the qualifications of the two candidates or even what the city should do to recover from the attack on the World Trade Center. The campaign to be the next mayor of New York turned yesterday on two unlikely subjects: Stalin (as in Joseph) and South Africa.

title: Decadence Meets Death On an 1800's Plantation
description: Here's a real UFO, an extremely low-budget, genuinely independent film by a 22-year-old writer-director from Philadelphia that immediately establishes a distinctive and promising voice.

Norman Schwarzkopf largely ran the campaign, and the far more restrictive approach of the 1999 conflict in Kosovo, when top civilians from President Clinton on down reviewed bombing targets and rejected some as too risky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANSCOMBE, FRANCIS JOHN
description: ANSCOMBE - Francis John. Professor (Emeritus) of Statistics, Yale University, died on October 17 in New Haven. He was 83. Born in Elstree, England, he studied Mathematics at Trinity College, Cambridge, taking First Class Honours in 1939. He taught at Cambridge, Princeton, and the University of Chicago before moving to Yale, where he founded the Department of Statistics in 1963. He was the beloved husband of Phyllis and loving father of daughter Elizabeth Valeika and sons Francis, Anthony, and Frederick. He also leaves his brother Anthony and five granddaughters. Funeral service will be at 10:00 Thursday at St. John's Church, 400 Humphrey Street, New Haven.

title: Lucent Reports $8.8 Billion Loss and a Dim Outlook
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. announced a quarterly loss of $8.8 billion yesterday that was within analysts' expectations, but the company offered an industry outlook for next year that was more dismal than its previous forecasts.

title: Indictment in Towers Theft
description: A Bronx man who the authorities say posed as a rescue worker at the site of the World Trade Center was indicted yesterday on charges that he stole at least six expensive watches and about $2,500 in cash from the Tourneau store below the complex.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Charges In Killing Of 'Bandit Queen'
description: The police charged 11 men with the July 25 slaying of Phoolan Devi, the ''Bandit Queen,'' who abandoned a life of crime to become a legislator. Ms. Devi became a hero to some and a villain to others after 22 upper-caste men were killed to avenge her rape by upper-caste men in 1981. The police said the main figure accused in her murder, Sher Singh Rana, had sought to establish himself as an upper-caste leader by masterminding her killing. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: A Passport Home, Wherever That May Be
description: THE desire to cook a large, bountiful meal for family and friends is something that probably does not come to you every night, or even most nights. It is more likely a whimsical urge, something that hits you and is like a trance, tempting you to pull out every last pot and page through your cookbooks. It comes at the holidays, on vacations, at moments of procrastination or when times are difficult. It is an urge that should be embraced, for we all know that entertaining at home has become rare, if not rarefied.

title: 2 Rail Companies Report
description: Cost cuts at the CSX Corporation helped increase third-quarter profit 69 percent, while rising expenses contributed to a 13 percent earnings decline at the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation.

description: To the Editor:

title: Are They Too Old to Win Another Ring? The Yankees Don't Think So
description: The chant of ''One more year!'' from the crowd at Yankee Stadium on Monday night was directed toward Paul O'Neill, but it could have been a message sent to a number of players and management. As the Yankees approach the final step in their quest for a fourth straight World Series championship, the team is faced once again with the question: Is this the last stand?

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Sending Monaco's Finest?

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Agency Fears Attacks' Effect On Refugees
description: The United Nations' refugee agency said it is worried that asylum seekers are being victimized and refugee protection standards are being eroded because of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. The high commissioner for refugees said in a statement that the agency fears ''attempts to create unwarranted links between refugees and terrorism'' as a result of governments' efforts to prevent terrorists from entering countries by claiming asylum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, JOSEPH
description: WEISS-Joseph. The National Officers of EMUNAH of America mourn the passing of Joseph Weiss, beloved husband of our esteemed Honorary National President, Renee Weiss. For the past 50 years, Joe was a devoted partner to his wife Renee in building EMUNAH, both in the United States and in Israel. He will be sorely missed by all who were priviliged to know him. We extend our deepest condolences to his children Jerry and Roberta Epstein, Howard and Rita Weiss, and Neil and Amy Weiss, grandchildren, great grandchildren, and to his brother David. Marcia Genuth, National President Carol Sufian, Executive Director

title: Reckonings; Ban the Bonds
description: As bad ideas go, the proposal to create a new class of war bonds hardly seems worth mentioning. After all, it doesn't compare to the tax-cut package the House will probably pass today, which sets new standards for cynicism. So why pick on a proposal that, while generally acknowledged to be silly, also seems harmless?

title: FINANCIAL PRINTING BUSINESS ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS
description: Bowne & Company, whose main business is financial printing, said yesterday that it planned to cut jobs because it had a third-quarter loss caused by a decline in initial public stock offerings and mergers and acquisitions. Bowne will cut 10 percent of the work force at its financial printing business, the company said. Bowne, based in New York, said September was the first month in 25 years with no registration filings for initial public offers. The company did not say how many jobs would be eliminated. The third-quarter loss was 5 cents to 10 cents a share, based on a preliminary review. Bowne will release full financial results on Nov. 7.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Enthusiasm Is Stirring Yet Again In Arizona
description: In the past 24 hours, the Arizona Diamondbacks, born in 1998, have finally transformed this sprawling southwestern metropolis into a baseball-mad city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGENHARD, CHRISTIAN MICHAEL OTTO
description: REGENHARD-Christian Michael Otto. Age 28. FDNY. Missing since responding to the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Christian graduated from the Fire Academy on July 27, 2001. He was a Firefighter for six weeks. Born and raised in Co-op City, Bronx, he graduated from the Bronx H.S. of Science in 1991. Christian enlisted in the United States Marine Corps on his 19th birthday and after five years of distinguished service, earned the rank of Sergeant. He received twelve medals and awards for excellence during his career including The Armed Forces Expeditionary Medal and the Navy Achievement Medal. His extensive travels and adventures took him to 22 countries around the world. He had a great love for rock climbing and traveled extensively to South America where he acquired a great affinity for the people, culture and language. An artist, writer, athlete, humanitarian and environmentalist, he was a thoughtful and compassionate person, greatly admired and loved by all who knew him. His great magnetism as a human being attracted people of all ages and cultures to his friendship. A beautiful person in body, mind and spirit, his charm, good looks, humor and sincerity bonded people to him wherever he went. He worked for too short a time at Ladder 131, Engine 279, Red Hook Firehouse, Red Hook, Brooklyn. His brother firefighters agreed that they never met anyone like Christian Regenhard. He leaves behind legions of shocked and heartbroken friends and relatives all over the world. He was the loving son of Sally Regenhard and Det. Sgt. Al Regenhard, who retired after 39 years on the NYPD on the same day that Christian was appointed to the FDNY, and the treasured brother of Christina Regenhard. Loving nephew of Kevin and Evelyn Regenhard and Maureen Laughlin. Treasured godfather to Nicole Neri and loving cousin to the Doherty, Laughlin, Mahon and Hyman families. In Ireland, greatly missed by the Kelleher, O'Connor and Mahon families. Memorial Mass Friday, October 26, 2001 at 9:30 am at the Cathedral of St. Patrick, 50th Street & 5th Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Christina Regenhard, administrator for The Christian Michael Otto Regenhard Fund for Justice, Humanity and the Environment c/o P.O. Box 70, Woodlawn Station, Bronx, N.Y. 10470.

title: U.S., Hoping to Give Warning and to Get Clues, Issues Copies of Anthrax Letters
description: The Justice Department released copies of three anthrax-contaminated letters today in hopes that they would serve as a warning for people to be wary of similar ones that investigators fear are moving undetected through the postal system.

title: Officials Admit Underestimating Danger Posed to Postal Workers
description: As more postal workers fell sick and two were confirmed dead from anthrax, federal officials dramatically stepped up their public health response today and acknowledged that they had underestimated the danger that anthrax-contaminated letters posed to those who carry and sort the mail.

title: The Tug of Faith Unsettles Many British Muslims
description: When Pakistan's cricket team toured Britain this past summer, the British captain, Nasser Hussein, complained that many Britons like him whose parents had emigrated from the Indian subcontinent seemed happier cheering the visiting and victorious Pakistan players than the British side.

title: U.N. Insisting Afghans Get A Government They Want
description: With American bombs now softening the way to Kabul, officials at the United Nations, in Washington and in other capitals are racing to find at least an interim way to secure the city if the Taliban abandon it.

title: U.S. Moves to Block General Dynamics Bid for Shipbuilder
description: The government moved yesterday to block the General Dynamics Corporation's $2.1 billion offer to acquire Newport News Shipbuilding, effectively endorsing a competing bid by Northrop Grumman.

title: Bailout Plan For Swissair Called Unfair By Rivals
description: The deal that the Swiss government struck with the country's biggest businesses to stitch together a national airline from the remnants of Swissair, its once-proud flag carrier, ran into immediate criticism from rivals and the European Union today.

title: MacCulloch Plays Into His Comfort Zone
description: Todd MacCulloch took the microphone tonight and welcomed the sellout crowd of 14,313 at the Bi-Lo Center before the Nets played the Washington Wizards.

title: Kwan Suddenly Fires Longtime Coach
description: In front of a monitor backstage, Frank Carroll struck the pose of a protective coach last spring as he nervously eyed the final scores of Michelle Kwan's rival at the world figure skating championships.

title: Nobu Matsuhisa
description: THE sweetness of sea scallops inspired this simple recipe. It's a new dish for me. My most popular scallop dish is almost a gratin, with the scallops baked under a creamy, lightly browned blanket of mayonnaise, which I sometimes season with wasabi or some other spicy ingredient.

title: 3 Fugitives Named as Part of Hamburg Cell
description: The Justice Department today identified three fugitives believed by American investigators to have been part of a terrorist cell based in Hamburg, Germany, that carried out the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States.

title: Majority of Eighth Graders Again Fail Statewide Tests
description: For the third straight year, most eighth graders throughout New York State have failed annual mathematics and reading exams, raising the usual questions not only about the quality of middle school instruction but also newer ones about the content and scoring of the state tests themselves.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: A Lot Of Help For The Countryside
description: The government received a $1 billion aid package from a group of lenders led by Spain and the Inter-American Development Bank intended to create more than 270,000 jobs in rural areas. Aides to President Alejandro Toledo said the program would be central to their efforts to lift the poorest areas of the Andes and revive farm production, which has been depressed for decades.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Lisa Bowers was named marketing director at the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association. She had been principal at her own company, Smooth Sailing Marketing, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NISBET, FANNIE
description: NISBET-Fannie. On October 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Thomas S. Caring mother of Judith Walker and her husband Bill, and the late Thomas S. Devoted grandmother of Anne Butler, Lynn Aguirre and Karen Reynolds, and their husbands Thomas, Joseph and Joshua. Also survived by seven great grandchildren. Visiting 2-5 and 7-9PM Thursday and Friday at Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home, Inc., 36-46 Bell Blvd, Bayside. Mass of Christian Burial at Precious Blood R.C. Church, Long Island City, Saturday, 9:45AM. Interment Flushing Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, EARL B.
description: BROWN-Earl B., 83, of Larchmont, NY died Sunday, October 21, 2001. Chief of Allergy at Lenox Hill Hospital, President of NY Allergy Society, Adjunct Professor of Internal Medicine at Columbia Physicians and Surgeons, pioneered research in treatment of allergies with steroids. An internationallyknown allergist, he is survived by Gertrude, his wife of 59 years, and their children, Earl, Jr., his wife, Margaret, of Radford, VA; Paul, his wife, Margaret Watson, of Seattle, WA; Jay, his wife, Alison, of Hackettstown, NJ; Martha, her husband, Paul Rosenblum, of Prospect, KY. He will be missed by his grandchildren, Emily, Colin, Andrew, Joshua, Lauren, and Nathaniel. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 25th at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont, NY. The family will receive friends starting at 11 am with the service starting at 12 noon.

title: Cramped and Scattered, Congress Resumes Work
description: With their office buildings still closed for anthrax testing and their staffs scattered, members of Congress reconvened today and tried to complete sweeping antiterrorism and money laundering legislation. But after debating the bill for 40 minutes, the House adjourned so members could go home to dinner. A vote was set for Wednesday.

title: Consumer Group Has Plan For Managing Insurers' Loss
description: With skepticism in Congress deepening over proposals that the government pay a major share of insurance costs from future terrorist attacks, a new proposal from a consumer group would help insurers manage their losses with long-term federal loans.

title: Scientists Report Gains In Knowledge Of Bacterium
description: Scientists reported two major advances yesterday in their understanding of the anthrax bacterium -- discoveries they hope will be the basis for a new generation of effective treatments.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: For Laughs

title: Installation of Peddie School's Head
description: JOHN F. GREEN will be installed as the 15th head of the Peddie School in Hightstown, N.J., a boarding and day school for Grades 8 to 12 that was founded in 1864. When he was named to the position in November, Mr. Green was the dean of faculty at St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H. Mr. Green is expected to continue the school's traditions of interdisciplinary instruction, longer classes and an emphasis on technology. Every student enrolled in the school receives a laptop. In 1993, the school received a $100 million gift to endow a scholarship program from Walter Annenberg. The school uses this money to remain diverse by providing 50 percent of its 500-member student body with financial aid. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, MARIAN WEINBAUM, PH.D.
description: FISCHMAN-Marian Weinbaum, Ph.D. On October 23, 2001. Beloved wife of Dr. Herbert D. Kleber. Dear mother of Eric (Riva) Fischman, Sharon (Michael Lazar) Fischman and Amanda (Matthew) Henshon, and stepmother of Elizabeth Kleber, Marc (Judith) Kleber and Pamela (Rees) Shad. Beloved daughter of Sarah and the late Hyman Weinbaum and sister of George (Carol) Weinbaum. Cherished grandmother of Hallie, Jason, Gideon, William, Isabel, Juliet, Dylan and Lillian. Aunt of Evie, Cindy, Laura and Elliot. Dr. Fischman was considered one of the foremost scientists in the United States investigating new treatments for cocaine and heroin addiction. Services Thursday, October 25th, 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Fight Against Terrorism / The Ground War : Winter Could Stall Afghan Rebel Drive on Key Cities
description: PARIS  Dire winter weather is unlikely to hamper U.S. Special Forces on hit-and-run raids in Afghanistan, but it is liable to paralyze local American allies such as the anti-Taliban guerrillas of the Northern Alliance  a factor adding urgency to the rebels' current drive to seize key Afghan cities and approach the capital, Kabul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, PAULINE
description: JOSEPH-Pauline. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Pauline Joseph, beloved mother of our devoted members, Alan and Arleen Joseph. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: F.T.C. Rejects Sale of Seagram To Diageo And Pernod
description: United States regulators moved yesterday to block the sale of the Seagram wine and spirits business to Diageo and Pernod Ricard of Europe, the first major deal to be rejected by the Bush administration.

title: M.T.A. Restricts Information on Scares That Delay Travelers
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it had decided to limit the amount of information it releases about subway and other transit delays caused by anthrax scares or reports of suspicious bags.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Casino Official Resigns
description: A senior official of MGM Mirage suddenly resigned yesterday, citing, in part, the delayed opening from next year to 2005 of the Atlantic City casino project he oversaw. The official, Mark Juliano, said he wanted to pursue ''more immediate options.'' Mr. Juliano had signed on in 1999 to lead the $1.5 billion casino. Alan Feldman, a spokesman for the Las Vegas-based casino, said Mr. Juliano would not be replaced until closer to the opening date. Mr. Feldman cited Mirage's recent merger with MGM and continuing lawsuits from Donald Trump as one of the reasons for the delay. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: KPMG Is Paying $9 Million To Settle Medical Fraud Case
description: KPMG, the international accounting firm, agreed yesterday to pay $9 million to settle government accusations that it helped a group of hospitals in Florida and Kentucky defraud Medicare through the use of bogus expense claims.

title: House Passes Bipartisan Anti-Terror Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The House of Representatives today overwhelmingly passed a bill giving law enforcement a broad array of new powers to fight terrorism.

title: Britian, Embracing I.R.A. Decision, Dismantles Police Bases
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 24  Britain and pro-British Protestant political leaders of Ulster moved swiftly today to capitalize on the long-awaited decision by the Irish Republican Army to begin dismantling its arms.

title: Gambling Expansion Is Part of Albany Budget Agreement
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has reached a budget agreement with legislative leaders that would allow the largest expansion of gambling in New York State since the lottery began in 1966.

title: Daimler Says Chrysler Lost Less Than Expected
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. gave investors their first positive surprise in nearly two years today, reporting that third-quarter losses at the Chrysler group had been lower than expected and saying that it can still meet an overall profit goal set earlier this year.

title: Across America, Restaurants Adjust to a Stay-Put Nation
description: THE aftershocks of last month's terrorist attacks have resonated in restaurants far beyond New York and Washington. Perhaps the hardest hit in the rest of the country was the San Francisco region, where restaurants had already been hurt by Internet company failures. The city's restaurants are strongly dependent on visitors. After Sept. 11, leisure travel fell 25 percent and business travel about 80 percent compared with a year ago, according to the Convention and Visitors Bureau.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KAPLAN, New York, a provider of educational services, said it had won a contract from New York City for state teacher certification exam courses. Kaplan said the contract was worth $1 million to $2 million.

title: South Koreans Seek Truth About '48 Massacre
description: A half-century later, Kim Hyoung Choe has no trouble finding his way back to the spot where he hid in the brush on this fragrant, nutmeg-forested mountain and watched helplessly while soldiers mowed down much of his family.

title: City Proposes Priority Uses Of Federal Aid
description: The Giuliani administration has set two priorities for the aid it is seeking from the federal government to encourage the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan, concentrating on a small portion of the $54 billion that the state had requested.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKERMAN, ANN
description: BECKERMAN-Ann. Very dear daughter, loving sister of Dan and the late Larry. Your intelligence and talent matched your beauty, and you gave of yourself to help others. The void in our lives can never be filled. Mom and Dan

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Agere Reports A Big Loss
description: Agere Systems said yesterday that it had lost $3.35 billion, or $2.05 a share, in its fiscal fourth quarter after sales plunged 40 percent. Agere, which makes computer chips and other components for communications systems, said sales had dropped to $600 million from $1.49 billion in the quarter ended Sept. 30. Lucent Technologies, which itself announced an $8.8 billion loss yesterday, plans to spin off Agere in the next few months. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Devils Emerge From Darkness Victoriously
description: Thunderstorms caused a power failure at the Corel Center tonight, delaying the start of the game between the Devils and the Senators for nearly 90 minutes. When the lights returned, the Devils seemed to struggle.

title: Arrests in Britain and Germany of 2 Men Linked to Terrorist Activities
description: Germany arrested a Turkish man last week at Frankfurt Airport as he was about to board an Iran Air flight to Tehran with luggage containing camouflage clothing, a chemical-weapons protection suit, a ski mask and materials to produce an explosive detonator, the German federal prosecutor said today.

title: Safety Panel Nudges Agency on Pilot Rest Rules
description: Citing the case of the American Airlines airplane that ran off the end of a runway in Little Rock, Ark., in June 1999, the National Transportation Safety Board said today that the Federal Aviation Administration should promptly rewrite its rules on how many consecutive hours airline crews were allowed to work.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Booming Car Sales, but at a Price
description: Corporate earnings are plummeting, unemployment is rising, consumer confidence is shaky, the country is at a war footing at home and abroad. Yet auto sales have rarely been better.

title: AT&T Names 3 to Lead Cable TV Unit
description: AT&T staged a wholesale leadership transfusion at its cable television unit yesterday, hours before the company announced quarterly results that underscored just how tough times have become both for AT&T and the telecommunications industry at large.

title: New Home For a Trove Of Music; Cristbal Daz Ayala Bequeaths His Huge Archive of Cuban Sound
description: To build his huge music library, it has taken Cristbal Daz Ayala 25 years, countless missed family vacations, much of his savings and every skill he has learned in a multifarious life.

title: Apple Introduces What It Calls an Easier to Use Portable Music Player
description: Apple Computer introduced a portable music player today and declared that the new gadget, called the iPod, was so much easier to use that it would broaden a nascent market in the way the Macintosh once helped make the personal computer accessible to a more general audience.

title: On Women and Leadership
description: Barnard is assembling an array of prominent women from politics, academe, the news media and other areas for what it is calling a summit on women and leadership this weekend. Among the speakers are JANET RENO, the former United States attorney general; JANE SWIFT, the governor of Massachusetts; MARIAN WRIGHT EDELMAN, president of the Children's Defense Fund; CAROL GILLIGAN, a professor at Harvard and New York University; MAMPHELA RAMPHELE, a managing director of the World Bank; MARIE WILSON, president of the Ms. Foundation; ROSABETH MOSS KANTER, a Harvard Business School professor; and SHEILA WELLINGTON, president of Catalyst. The three Saturday panels will be moderated by GWEN IFILL of PBS, JUDY WOODRUFF of CNN and JUDITH SHAPIRO, left, the president of Barnard. A forum on Friday afternoon will focus on the future of women in business.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS VOICE NEW WORRY AFTER TRACES OF ANTHRAX TAINT OFF-SITE WHITE HOUSE MAILROOM
description: Traces of the deadly anthrax germ showed up in a remote White House mailroom today, as health officials announced that more ''hot spots'' had also been found at the capital's main mail sorting center, necessitating intensified treatment of workers.

title: A Librarian as a Sleuth in Hot Pursuit
description: ''Underneath the Lintel,'' a monologue by Glen Berger that opened at the SoHo Playhouse yesterday, is the kind of piece that works harder to be winning than it does to be heartfelt or original.

title: 2 Private Firms Taking Stake in Casualty Insurer
description: With insurance premiums rising, two private investment firms plan to announce a major investment today in the Arch Capital Group, a casualty and property insurer based in Bermuda.

title: Community Agonizes at Prospect of No Sports at School
description: Over the last five years, signs that the local school district is in dire straits have been unmistakable: in 1996, the state's Education Department threw out the Board of Education. Since then there have been five superintendents. Last spring, the high school was closed for two days after a series of bomb threats and fights. And unless the state intervenes again, the district will run out of money in March.

title: Concerns That U.S. Food Supply Is Vulnerable to Terrorist Attack
description: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, expressed concern today that the nation's food supply could be the target of a terrorist attack and urged Congress to authorize the hiring of hundreds of additional food inspectors.

title: Eisley To Begin On Bench In Opener
description: Jeff Van Gundy moved a step closer to solidifying his rotation yesterday, but the Knicks remain steeped in too much uncertainty for the coach's liking.

description: Five large drug makers posted mixed results yesterday.

title: By the (Gelatin) Sheet
description: THE gelatin most of us know is Knox powdered gelatin, sold in packets containing two and a half teaspoons each. But there is gelatin that comes in paper-thin transparent sheets. Sheet gelatin must be soaked in cold water for 10 minutes until soft and slithery. Gently squeeze it to remove excess liquid, then add it to any hot mixture, stirring until it is melted.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Ganim's Campaign Report
description: Mayor Joseph P. Ganim, hobbled by a municipal corruption scandal, has had trouble raising campaign contributions, according to his latest campaign finance report. In the last three months, he did not receive a single campaign contribution. Mayor Ganim's administration is the subject of a federal investigation into possible corruption. The mayor's campaign had about $150,000 as of Oct. 11, down from more than $203,000 in July, the report shows. A spokesman for Mayor Ganim said he had no explanation for the lack of contributions.

title: A Lesson in Technology: It's Virtual Tug of War, but the Rope Burns Are Real
description: The scientific principle is called haptics. And the manifestation yesterday was one group of children in Queens and another group in Manhattan competing in a teeth-gritting, hard-burning game of tug of war.

description: THE Yankees had won their fourth consecutive American League pennant, and in the clubhouse Monday night, the difficult part began: asking players variations of questions we had asked and they had answered for three consecutive autumns. ''Is this one more satisfying?'' or ''How does this one compare with the last three?''

title: A Sculptor's Child Is No Longer Glittering
description: It was not long after his wife burst into his sculpture studio in Ganslberg, Germany, on Sept. 11 that Fritz Koenig decided to book a flight to New York City.

title: Amazon Had Smaller Loss On Flat Sales In 3rd Quarter
description: Losses at Amazon.com narrowed as much as analysts expected in the third quarter, but its sales fell short of expectations. The company also said yesterday that its sales in the fourth quarter would be sharply below its earlier forecasts.

title: Heroin Users in Europe Don't See Price Drop
description: PARIS, Oct. 23  The price of Afghan heroin has dropped, but police departments across Europe say that is unlikely to affect street prices much and has not done so to date.

title: Corrections
description: The Big City column on Friday, about restaurants near the World Trade Center site, misspelled the name of the ''Star Wars'' character played by Harrison Ford, one of those who served food to recovery workers. It is Han Solo, not Hans.

title: Criticism of Postal and Health Officials Grows Louder
description: The news that a seriously ill New Jersey postal worker is believed to have contracted pulmonary anthrax has intensified complaints that the United States Postal Service and state public health officials did not act quickly or aggressively enough to contain the problem.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Returning Pakistan's Verbal Fire
description: A day after Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, spoke harshly about India, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee fired off some zingers of his own, accusing Pakistan of opportunism in its abandonment of the Taliban militia, which it had nurtured at the insistence of the United States. ''Who will trust them?'' Mr. Vajpayee asked about Pakistan. ''If we are friends, we are real friends. We stand by our friends and are ready to pay any price for it. There is no opportunism in our policies nor are they dictated from outside.'' Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Workers at Postal Hub Become Surly and Grim
description: The mood among the 6,000 workers at the post office's largest mail-sorting center in New York is often bad, but this week it has turned surly and grim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZUR, HELEN

description: When the call came from the MacArthur Foundation, Sandra Lanham, a conservationist and pilot, was preparing to fly her 1956 Cessna from Tucson, Ariz., to La Paz Bay in Mexico to help researchers look for whale sharks.

title: The Way Lollipops Imagine Themselves to Be
description: In my personal hierarchy of candy, lollipops usually rate pretty low, just a few notches above jelly beans. But then a friend gave me a package of See's Candies toffee lollipops -- compact, sturdy squares wrapped in gold foil.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Antiterror Aid Sought
description: Acting Governor Donald T. DiFrancesco said yesterday that he would seek nearly $29 million in federal aid to bolster antiterrorism efforts. He also said he planned to seek ''disaster status'' that would open access to federal aid for businesses and individuals, as well as long-term recovery. Mr. DiFrancesco plans to travel to Washington tomorrow to meet with the New Jersey Congressional delegation. New Jersey needs $28.7 million to bolster arson and bomb squad units, upgrade digital wiretapping technology, strengthen state and local disease investigations, hire additional epidemiologists, and reimburse towns for overtime pay, Mr. DiFrancesco said.

description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B.

title: Split in Ranks: Commissioner Hears the Boos Of Firefighters
description: The Fire Department is often described as a family, and in the days after the attack on the World Trade Center, it reacted like one, as firefighters rushed to rescue colleagues, share the burden of grief and regroup after devastating losses.

title: Event Will Aid Twin Towers Fund
description: Agroup of Olympic boxers from the 2000 Sydney Games and several contenders from the New York area added their names yesterday to help the victims of the World Trade Center attack on Sept. 11.

title: Cross-Country Love Affair, Set to Violins and Applause
description: When the New Mexico Symphony Orchestra chose Guillermo Figueroa as its new music director, he quipped, ''I will be living on an airplane.'' Mr. Figueroa also had recently been named director of the Puerto Rico Symphony, and he is well known in New York as the concertmaster of the New York City Ballet and one of the rotating concertmasters for the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank Expects Income To Fall
description: The biggest bank in the Netherlands, ABN Amro, said it expected its full-year earnings to fall 26 percent, to 2.3 billion euros ($2 billion), as fallout from the Sept. 11 attacks spreads. The bank also indicated that it was bracing for the fallout from possible loan losses as European airlines reel from the slowdown. ABN Amro said second-half profit would fall about 36 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink Reports A Loss
description: The Internet service provider EarthLink Inc. said its third-quarter loss had widened. Still, buttressed by a $2 monthly price increase, the company was able to beat Wall Street's estimates. The company, based in Atlanta, lost $77 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with a loss of $72.5 million, or 65 cents, in the year-earlier period, when there were fewer outstanding shares. Excluding merger and acquisition costs, EarthLink lost 17 cents a share in the latest quarter. ''We continue to look to high-speed access to drive further growth,'' the chief executive, Garry Betty, above, said in a statement. Shares in EarthLink fell $2.51, or 14.5 percent, to $14.85. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Where Planes Are Built, a Setback
description: Cattle may once have been king in Wichita, but that was a long time ago. For years, airplanes have been the big thing.

description: U.S. Obtains Concession On Price of Anthrax Drug

title: William H. Kirk Dies at 92; Aided East Harlem Diversity
description: The Rev. William Henry Kirk, a prominent figure in the settlement-house movement and a community leader in East Harlem as it underwent a historic transformation, died last Friday in Branford, Conn. He was 92 and lived in Hamden, Conn., and on Isle au Haut, Me.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the pop composer and lyricist Jay Livingston on Thursday referred incorrectly to the occupation of Sammy Cahn, with whom he had worked, as did an obituary on Friday about the jazz singer Etta Jones, who often performed Mr. Cahn's work. Mr. Cahn was a lyricist, not a composer.

title: Installation of Peddie School's Head
description: JOHN F. GREEN will be installed as the 15th head of the Peddie School in Hightstown, N.J., a boarding and day school for Grades 8 to 12 that was founded in 1864. When he was named to the position in November, Mr. Green was the dean of faculty at St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H. Mr. Green is expected to continue the school's traditions of interdisciplinary instruction, longer classes and an emphasis on technology. Every student enrolled in the school receives a laptop. In 1993, the school received a $100 million gift to endow a scholarship program from Walter Annenberg. The school uses this money to remain diverse by providing 50 percent of its 500-member student body with financial aid.

title: Business Travel; In a sign of desperate times, many airlines on many of their flights will serve no meals.
description: ''WOULD you care for dinner?'' the flight attendant asks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ORMAN, ELIZABETH MCKEEN
description: VAN ORMAN-Elizabeth McKeen of Short Hills, N.J. on Sunday October 21, 2001. Wife of the late Francis Van Orman. Mother of Philip Van Orman. Grandmother of Elizabeth Van Orman and Margaret Higgins. A memorial service will be held at a later date in Christ Church, Short Hills. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Christ Church Memorial Fund, 66 Highland Avenue, Short Hills, N.J. 07078

title: The Likable Yankees
description: A halo of good feeling has surrounded the New York Yankees' seemingly relentless march to what could be their fifth world championship in six years. Usually, among outlanders in general and Mets fans in particular, the Yankees are to be reviled, as much for their swagger as for their superiority. This year, however, one senses a more tolerant, even admiring attitude. One reason is that this is a hard team to dislike. They go about their business in a workmanlike way, they are free of the annoying egos that characterized past Yankee teams, and even their owner, George Steinbrenner, seems to have grown less churlish with age.

description: St. Louis Coach Mike Martz said last week that he had always kept an eye on Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet, and that Chrebet would fit into the Rams' explosive offense.

title: Hindsight's Soldier Is History's 'Best'
description: AS the United States goes to war, more than a few Americans must be worrying about the performance of our troops. After all, it is widely believed that today's soldiers went to failing schools. Their literacy and numerical skills are regarded as poor. They have been passed from grade to grade without mastering the curriculum. Their drug and alcohol use has been undisciplined. Without a good background in history or literature, they can understand little of the cultural and political traditions they must fight to uphold.

title: More Streets in Trade Center Zone Reopen
description: The Mayor's Office of Emergency Management widened public access to the area around the World Trade Center disaster site again yesterday, hoping to ease traffic for downtown businesses and residents. Meanwhile, rescue workers found more bodies yesterday, and city officials urged families to continue to register DNA evidence with the police to expedite the identification process.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Airport Planned Near Nature Preserve
description: Transportation officials announced that Mexico City's new airport would be built in the Texcoco lakebed northeast of the city's center. Environmentalists oppose the decision because Mexico City's largest nature preserve for migratory birds is nearby. The decision came three decades after officials began searching for a site to replace the current airport, which is operating at near capacity. They said that after the new airport opens in five or six years they will convert the current airport into a city park. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Windows XP Partnerships Have a Familiar Ring
description: Can lightning strike the same place twice? Maybe it will for Microsoft.

title: GE CAPITAL GETS APPROVAL FOR PURCHASE OF HELLER
description: The General Electric Company's GE Capital, the largest nonbank financing company, won European Union permission to buy Chicago-based Heller Financial Inc., to expand its loan business. GE Capital agreed on July 30 to pay $5.3 billion for Heller, which lends to small and midsize businesses. Earlier this month, GE Capital said 93 percent of Heller voting shares had been tendered by the close of business Sept. 28. GE Capital has assets of more than $370 billion with customers in 47 countries. Heller Financial has nearly $20 billion in assets with clients in the United States, Europe, Asia and Latin America.

title: GROUND RAIDS SEEN AS LONG AND RISKY
description: With combat in Afghanistan moving from exclusive reliance on airstrikes to complex commando operations, Britain's top military officer said today that ground troops may have to operate in Afghanistan for weeks at a time if they are to ferret out Osama bin Laden and destroy his terrorist network.

title: Manhattan Mail Sorters Fear They Will Be Next
description: Ten stories high and covering two full city blocks, Morgan Station, New York City's largest mail-sorting center, looks like a fortress, but that has not stopped many of its workers from feeling a sense of dread.

title: Failure to Win in '97 Left Mark on Yankees
description: For most players and teams, the baseball season ends basically at the end of September. Play 162 games and go home. The Yankees' season, however, is like a run-on sentence; it just keeps going.

title: Red Cross Agrees to Database
description: The American Red Cross has tentatively agreed to participate in the creation of a central database that would keep track of how donations raised in the aftermath of Sept. 11 are distributed to victims' families.

title: Just in Time for the Harvest, Baskets of All Kinds
description: Throughout New York City there are new baskets from Africa and Asia, Europe and South America that can hold autumn leaves or freshly picked apples or turn a potted plant into a centerpiece. Above, from left to right: Marguerite Lhuillier's bamboo basket ($98) at the Asia Society; an American wire basket from San Francisco is $98 at the American Folk Art Museum; grass and bark baskets from Mali are $35 to $100 at the Museum for African Art; a yellow wire basket is from South Africa ($79) at the American Museum of Natural History, and colored paper baskets are $65 to $100 at the American Craft Museum. Below, Furniture Co.'s exhibition and sale ''Hand-Woven Baskets,'' through Dec. 1, has artistic baskets (like the tilted one, fourth from right, $2,450) and plain, like the light ones from Colombia on either side for $40 to $75 at 818 Greenwich Street (Jane Street).

title: Greenspan Says Protectionism Is Hardly an Antidote to Terror
description: Calling globalization ''the antithesis of terrorism,'' Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, set out a case tonight for continuing to knock down trade barriers and integrating economies across borders.

description: Hemmed in by an unusually brief campaign season and his own lack of experience in politics, Michael R. Bloomberg is encountering repeated difficulties as he moves into the final phase of his mayoral campaign, struggling to engage an increasingly confident and politically aloof Mark Green.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Budget Balancing Act Fails
description: The state is again in the red, three months after Gov. Dirk Kempthorne balanced the budget with $36 million in cuts from state agencies, a report from the state's Division of Financial Management said. Mike Ferguson, the state's chief economist, said that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks had compounded a continuing downturn and that revenues were $17.7 million below expectations since the new budget year began in July. The new forecast could mean further cuts in state services. The state had $64 million in reserves in March. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

description: COHEN-Bernard H. October 24,2001. Known for his generous heart and joking nature. Beloved husband of Gloria L. Cohen, cherished father of Lynne and Barry Reik, adoring grandfather of Dana and Zoe, devoted brother of Janice Brant. Graveside service 11AM Friday, Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings. Visitors received at home through Tuesday.

title: Son's Decade-Long Quest Ends in the Rubble

Sometimes Mr. Penny, now a married man of 33 with small sons of his own, would drive from his home in Virginia to the Brooklyn brownstone his family used to own, just hoping for word of the emotionally troubled dad who wandered away more than a dozen years ago.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, IRENE BALL
description: FRANKEL-Irene Ball, 84. October 13, 2001 in Palo Alto, California. Formerly of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Loving mother to her sons Ronald Ball of Scarsdale, New York and Gregory Ball of Littleton, CO, and wonderful grandmother to Michael, Jacquelyn, Geoffrey and Alexandra. A memorial service will be held at 2:00PM on Nov. 10 at Channing House, 850 Webster Street, Palo Alto, CA 94301. Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to The Sierra Club, 85 Second St, 2nd fl, San Francisco, CA 94105.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Aftermarket PC Speakers For Digital Music Lovers
description: With the popularity of digital music, computers have become the playback medium of choice among many consumers. NPD Intelect, a research company in Port Washington, N.Y., reports that more than 3.3 million speakers were purchased last year to replace standard-equipment PC speakers.

title: Israelis Storm Village in the West Bank
description: Hours after President Bush appealed for an Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian territory, Israeli troops stormed into another West Bank village early this morning, killing at least 5 Palestinians and arresting 11 more, including two men the Israelis said helped kill a cabinet minister last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORDOS, GLADYS
description: NORDOS-Gladys. Age 89. Born Brooklyn, NY, Febuary 22, 1912. Died Golden Valley, MN, August 29, 2001. Survivors: brother Arnold (Marian) Olsen; sister-in-law Ruth Moore; daughters Meredith (Glenn) Stone, Dorothy Scott, Thelma (Kenneth) Fricke; former son-in-law Thomas Scott; grandchildren, Karl-John (Beth Ann) & Rolf Stone, Kristin & Andrew Scott, Lars & Erica Fricke. Burial November 3, 2001, 11:00 AM, Tongore Cemetery, Olive Bridge, NY. Memorial Service, 12:00 Noon, Olive Bridge United Methodist Church. Luncheon follows. Memorial gifts earmarked for child victims of WTC disaster to United Lutheran Appeal, 366 N. Broadway, Suite 404, Jericho, NY 11753.

title: Stocks Rebound, Led Higher by Technology Shares
description: The stock market staged a striking turnabout today, posting solid gains that contrasted with sharp early losses, as investors displayed confidence in the government's ability to stimulate the economy.

title: TELIGENT PURCHASE PRICE RENEGOTIATED TO $72.5 MILLION
description: Teligent Inc., a telephone services company currently being liquidated by a bankruptcy court, has agreed to be bought for $72.5 million in cash and other stock considerations, according to a regulatory filing. The sale to a management-led group, Teligent Acquisition, is expected to be completed at a hearing on Oct. 30. The group agreed to buy Teligent two months ago and the new price was renegotiated form the original $115 million. That sale was originally planned for earlier this month, but was put off because ''adverse capital markets'' after the terrorist attacks made financing difficult, a Teligent lawyer, Matthew Kleiman, told Judge Burton R. Lifland of United States Bankruptcy Court on Oct. 12. Teligent sells phone and data services to businesses using signals transmitted to rooftop satellite dishes.

title: Burb Cocooning? Who Has Time?
description: ONE inevitable result of a disaster like Sept. 11 is a profusion of quasi-scientific ruminating about the psychic health of the nation. My favorite is the notion that the American people have entered a period of intense national ''cocooning'' that may last from 3 months to 10 years.

title: A Gym-Ready MP3 Player That's Already on a Diet
description: Some barriers were made to be broken. The speed of sound. The four-minute mile. Sixty-one home runs in a season. Now Panasonic has smashed another benchmark. Its new digital music player with removable storage, the SV-SD80 audio player, weighs in at less than one ounce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCANN, THERESA ANN
description: McCANN-Theresa Ann. Lifetime New Yorker returned to her creator in her 73rd year on Tuesday Oct. 23, 2001. Beloved daughter of the late Jane and Luke. Loving sister of James, Marilyn and Rev. Luke McCann. Her life was a triumph of loyalty & love. Family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY. today 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be held Friday at 10 AM at the Queen of Peace Chapel at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Interment to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of your choice.

title: Apple's Musical Rendition: A Jukebox Fed by the Mac
description: APPLE doesn't send out greeting cards very often, especially by FedEx. So when the company mailed cards to reporters last week, too soon for Christmas and too rushed for Halloween, some curiosity was understandable. The message inside heralded the imminent unveiling of ''a breakthrough digital device'' that Apple wouldn't identify, except to say that it wasn't a Mac.

title: Thank You, Tech Support
description: To the Editor:

title: At 36, a Vocal Jackson Is Knicks' Father Figure
description: He was supposed to be inconspicuous. After all, as an 8-year-old in a league full of 10-year-olds, Mark Jackson was playing only because he and his parents had fibbed about his age.

title: Blasts Rock Kabul as U.S. Jets Drop Bombs in Nighttime Raid
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 25  A string of explosions rocked Kabul, the Afghan capital, as American jets roared overhead late tonight and dropped bombs, witnesses said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SALOSHIN, EDITH
description: SALOSHIN-Edith. It's been four years since you left us. Truly outstanding and deeply missed. Fred and Cliffor

title: Ukraine Defense Chief Resigns Over Downing of Passenger Jet
description: President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine accepted the resignation of his defense minister today and suspended all missile and antiaircraft firing in a belated and unequivocal admission that his military accidentally destroyed a Russian airliner on Oct. 4.

title: A Literary Lion And Oprah Tangle
description: To the Editor:

title: Inventing a Way to Index 50,000 Memories of the Holocaust
description: THE Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation, a center devoted to collecting and preserving the testimony of Holocaust survivors and witnesses, has an embarrassment of riches: more than 116,000 hours of video, representing the memories of more than 50,000 people. But until now it has been largely keeping them to itself.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Prosecutor Becomes U.S. Attorney
description: Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the lead federal prosecutor in the recent embassy bombings trial in Manhattan, was unanimously confirmed by the Senate as the United States attorney in Chicago. A Harvard Law School graduate, Mr. Fitzgerald joined the United States attorney's office in Manhattan in 1988. He was co-chief of the terrorism unit and helped supervise that office's investigation of Osama bin Laden, who is now suspected of masterminding the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Microsoft Launches Windows XP
description: Following is a compilation of articles from The Times about Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, WILLIAM H.
description: KIRK-William H. Yes, Bill Kirk was a civic leader in his generation, but he was also, to the next generation and together with Mary, a wonderfully genial and welcoming host to his daughters' chums and suitors. The Claremont-Riverside Gang

title: Pakistani Man Dies in I.N.S. Custody
description: An illegal immigrant from Pakistan who was picked up for questioning by federal officials after the trade center attacks was found dead in his New Jersey jail cell Tuesday, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSON, ROBERT
description: EDELSON-Robert. 89, formerly of Brooklyn, passed away peacefully on October 23, 2001. Caring, devoted and loving husband of 65 years to Beatrice. Proud father of Drs. Kenneth and Stephen. Loving father-in-law of Carol. Doting grandfather to Dana, Richie, Alex, Bradley and Joshua, and devoted friend to many. He will be missed. Funeral held in Atlanta.

title: Several Orchestras Are Troubled Financially
description: Two major symphony orchestras, the St. Louis Symphony and the Toronto Symphony, are on the brink of bankruptcy and are asking musicians to take pay cuts and possibly shorten their seasons, while a third, the Chicago Symphony, is projecting deficits for the first time in 15 years.

title: New Signs of a Weakened Economy
description: More evidence emerged today that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks caused a severe deterioration in the nation's already-weak economy, as consumer demand contracted more sharply than Wall Street anticipated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ROBERT P.
description: MARCUS-Robert P., life-long love, companion, and best friend of his wife Betty G. Marcus; beloved son of the late Libby P. Marcus and Bernard K. Marcus; caring and devoted son-in-law of the late Ziuta Gerstenzang Akston and Leo Gerstenzang; proud and loving father of his daughter, Lauren Marcus Hughes; adoring grandfather of Christopher Robert Marcus Hughes and Meghan Ruth Marcus Hughes and father of Gary P. Marcus. He enriched the lives of all those he met and all those who called him friend, for he was a kind, caring, wise and gentle man. He was a natural leader who spent a lifetime quietly and selflessly helping others and improving the lives of untold numbers of people. He will be remembered by all those he touched forever and ever. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00 AM on Sunday, October 28, 2001 at Ferncliff Cemetery, 280 Secor Rd., Hartsdale, NY. For information, contact Quattlebaum Funeral Home at 561-832-5171.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOTMAN, DR. NORMAN
description: GOOTMAN-Dr. Norman. We mourn the passing of our father, Dr. Norman Gootman. He was a devoted and loving husband of the late Phyllis M. Gootman. Beloved father of Sharon Rosen and Craig Gootman. Cherished grandfather of Joshua and Nathaniel Rosen, and Alexandra Gootman, and friend to many. Our father's devotion was felt throughout our lives, as he successfully balanced his family life with his professional life.
