He was Chief of Pediatric Cardiology at Schneider's Children's Hospital of Long Island Jewish Hospital, where he also conducted cardiac research with our mother. His loss will be felt by all who knew him. We will miss you very much, Dad. Graveside services Thursday, October 25th, at the Hungarian Union Fields Cemetery, Cypress Hills, New York.

title: Racing Against Attention Spans
description: Remember, not long ago, when the hot-button book topics were Bill Clinton's banana-peel exit from the presidency and George W. Bush's singular slide into the White House? Now all those books are gone, laid to rest at least for now by the terror of terrorism.

title: Pataki Backs Bloomberg as Campaign Struggles for an Edge
description: Gov. George E. Pataki endorsed Michael R. Bloomberg for mayor yesterday, giving him a lift at a moment when his campaign seems to be struggling with how best to engage his Democratic opponent, Mark Green.

title: Time Runs Out on Welfare
description: About 50,000 New York families will reach the five-year federal limit for cash welfare benefits in December, and become eligible for a last-ditch state safety net. At a time when America is being battered by a slowing economy and terrorist scares, the state is in a poor position to do an in-depth screening of all these cases. The best approach, for both the government and the families, is to make the short-term transition as easy as possible.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: ABB Speeds Layoff Plans
description: The Swiss-Swedish electrical engineering group ABB said it expected its profit to fall 10 percent this year and would speed plans to cut 12,000 jobs, nearly 8 percent of its work force. ABB said its sales in the first nine months rose 4 percent, to $16.9 billion, but new orders were down 8 percent, at $17.9 billion, amid slowing demand for its factory robots and power cables. ABB, which is also facing rising costs from asbestos lawsuits and insurance losses from the Sept. 11 attacks, said it expected sales to rise 6 percent this year, in line with its average target for the next few years. Last year, the company, which is based in Zurich, had sales of $23 billion. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Unveiling a New Gadget
description: There's a golden rule in the technology business: Don't unveil a product before it's ready. As soon as consumers know that something better is coming, they'll stay away from the current product line, and the company's sales will take a nosedive.

title: To Get a Handle on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: State Dept. Mail Worker Infected With Inhalation Anthrax
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 — A worker at the State Department's mail center in suburban Virginia is the latest person to come down with inhalation anthrax, the department said today. And New Jersey health officials said they had found another suspected case of the disease.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball Botches It Both Ways
description: LUGGING a bat, the first Yankee on the field yesterday was Mike Stanton, who is not only a pitcher but a relief pitcher. Under the ill-considered rules of the American League, folks like Stanton are rarely encouraged to bat even during practice.

title: Security Measures Are Announced
description: New York City Marathon officials announced new security measures yesterday for the Nov. 4 race.

title: Ireland Looks to Sale of Airline
description: It would be hard to imagine a worse time to sell a minority stake in a money-losing state airline. But the Irish government has decided that a sale is the only way to keep the state airline, Aer Lingus, flying.

title: KODAK QUARTERLY EARNINGS DECLINE 77 PERCENT
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, posting a 77 percent decline in third-quarter profit, said yesterday that it would eliminate as many as 4,000 jobs and that its fourth-quarter earnings would be about a third of forecasts, sending the company's shares down sharply. Profit at Kodak has declined five quarters in a row, hurt by competition with the Fuji Photo Film Company and eroding prices. Shares of Kodak fell $3.46, to $30.71. Kodak said net income dropped to $96 million, or 33 cents a share, from $418 million, or $1.36 a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales fell to $3.31 billion from $3.59 billion. The company, based in Rochester, expects to save as much as $450 million next year through the layoffs. The latest round of cuts will bring the total this year to about 7,500 positions, or about 9 percent of the company's 78,000 workers.

title: Why I Stay at Home: A Mother's Story
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: An Autumn Surprise

title: Not Quite Monsters, But Bears Are Back
description: Being a student of history -- and that is exactly what he was at Yale in the early 1970's -- Dick Jauron knows the importance of the Chicago Bears to their fans, to their city and to the N.F.L.

title: Thermo Plans to Cut Jobs
description: The Thermo Electron Corporation, a leading maker of laboratory measuring instruments, said today that it would cut 300 to 500 jobs and said this year's earnings will be at the low end of its forecasts.

title: In Anthrax Crisis, Health Secretary Finds Unsteady Going
description: When Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, spoke to the American Public Health Association on Monday, he had an audience of more than 6,000 people eager for guidance on the anthrax threat. But he left some of them disappointed.

title: Run by Green's Brother, Building Had been Cited
description: For the past 13 years, Stephen L. Green, the real estate executive whose brother, Mark, is the Democratic candidate for mayor, has controlled and operated the 87-year-old office building at which five workers died in a scaffolding collapse yesterday.

title: Event Will Aid Twin Towers Fund
description: A group of Olympic boxers from the 2000 Sydney Games and several contenders from the New York area added their names yesterday to help the victims of the World Trade Center attack on Sept. 11.

title: For the Cafeteria Set: Mystery Meat as Gadget
description: What is this thing? Billed as a mobile phone, music player, text messenger, FM radio and video-game player, the Nokia 5510 doesn't particularly look like any of those things. It looks more like a pencil box with a bunch of buttons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSDORFF, DAVID M.
description: HAUSDORFF-David M. Died on October 23, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Fanny R. Hausdorff, father of Henry, Riley and the late Thomas. Also survived by nine grandchildren and 30 great-grandchildren. Burial in Israel. Shiva at his home in Boca Raton, FL.

title: 4 Drug Makers Finally Outline Their Intentions
description: For weeks, most of the largest pharmaceutical companies have largely kept quiet as the nation prepared to battle anthrax, smallpox and other potential agents that could be used by terrorists.

title: Reports Show New Signs of Weakness
description: More evidence emerged today that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks caused a severe deterioration in the nation's already-weak economy, as consumer demand contracted more sharply than Wall Street anticipated.

title: Death Toll Could Climb in Swiss Alps Tunnel Crash
description: ERSTFELD, Switzerland, Oct. 25 — Fire continued to rage in the Gotthard Tunnel near here today, more than a day after an early-morning collision claimed the lives of at least 10 people.

title: Bill That Expands Gambling Is Approved by Legislature
description: The State Legislature approved the largest expansion of gambling in state history early this morning after an impassioned debate, laying the groundwork for six Indian casinos in the Catskills and western New York. The State Senate voted 52 to 8 late Wednesday to approve a bill authorizing the six new Indian-run casinos, the inclusion of New York in the multistate Powerball lottery and the installation of video slot machines at horse tracks. After midnight the Assembly gave final approval to the bill, voting 93 to 40 in favor.

title: Sisterly Relief For Grieving Brotherhood
description: EVERYONE is trying to see the woman with the bangs, the small one dressed in red, white and blue, a Mickey Mouse watch on her wrist. People line up outside her office, phone messages pile up on her desk. ''Hi, how ya doin'?'' she greeted a man hovering in the hallway last week. ''Well, it's one day I didn't go to a funeral, memorial or wake,'' he said, warming to her interest, though seeming embarrassed at what might sound like complaining. But she nodded understandingly. ''You need to take a day off,'' she said softly. She's been saying that a lot lately.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, FRANCIS, ESQ.
description: MINTZ-Francis, Esq. The Joint Retirement Board for Conservative Judaism deeply mourns the passing of ''Fritz'' Mintz -a devoted Trustee who worked tirelessly for the benefit of our members and for all of Conservative Judaism, to which he referred as his ''beloved second family of the past forty years.'' He was an esteemed attorney whose wise counsel, refreshing sense of humor and bright disposition will be sorely missed. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alan M. Edelstein, CPA, JD, Chairman of the Board Nina Rone, CPA, Chief Operating Officer

title: Leader's Aide In Chechnya Calls to Offer Peace Talks
description: A top aide to the political leader of Chechnya's separatist guerrillas proposed opening talks with the Kremlin on disarming the rebels and ending their two-year-old war, President Vladimir V. Putin's envoy to southwestern Russia said today.

title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: New Zealand: Bid For Energy Drink Maker
description: Group Danone of France has bid $121 million for New Zealand's largest fruit drink marker, the Frucor Beverages Group, extending a string of investments in bottled drink companies. Danone said it had already struck a deal with Frucor's largest shareholder, Bain Pacific, to acquire one-fifth of the company at the bid price of 2.35 New Zealand dollars (98 cents) a share, a 25 percent premium over Tuesday's closing stock price. Frucor, which sells the energy drink V, leads that market in Australia and New Zealand. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Driving Windows XP to Market
description: After his sophomore year at Stanford University, Chris Jones showed up at Microsoft for a summer job in 1989 and was escorted to an office with a personal computer running MS-DOS, the operating system that helped make Microsoft the dominant PC software company.

title: Sears Plans to Cut Jobs and Revamp Store Designs
description: HOFFMAN ESTATES, Ill., Oct. 24 (Bloomberg News)  Sears, Roebuck ( news/quote ) will cut 4,900 jobs, or 22 percent of its salaried workers, and overhaul its stores to compete with discount chains like Wal-Mart Stores ( news/quote ) and Target.

title: As Investigation Churns, More Attacks Are Expected
description: Law enforcement officials said today that they believed additional anthrax attacks were a virtual certainty, even as they acknowledged that their extensive investigation into the germ-laden letters had left them baffled.

title: E.D.S. Says Earnings Beat Expectations
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the computer services and consulting company, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings had beat Wall Street's expectations and risen 17 percent from the comparable period last year.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Muslim Rebels Said To Surrender
description: The military and the police said six Muslim rebel suspects surrendered in the south and three were captured, including one who said he had witnessed the beheading of an American hostage, Guillermo Sobero. Mr. Sobero is presumed to have been killed but this is the first witness claim. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Airport Security Companies Talk of Lawsuits if U.S. Takes Over Their Duties
description: Rival proposals in Congress to overhaul airport security could enrich or severely harm the companies that now perform the task -- with costs as yet unclear for the airlines, travelers and taxpayers.

title: The D.J.'s New Mix: Digital Files and a Turntable
description: ON a recent Wednesday night at Centro-Fly, a trendy Manhattan dance club, Richie Hawtin was using two turntables to play the latest and best techno, a crisply syncopated hybrid of dark, electronic drum rhythms and metallic high-hat and snare effects. Like so many other celebrity disc jockeys on the international circuit, Mr. Hawtin was mixing records together to imprint his style on the night's music: he played two records simultaneously to blend the drum kick of one song with the melody of another, waited about 45 seconds before replacing the drum sounds with a new album of more pronounced bass sounds, and manipulated audio effects equipment to further tweak what clubgoers were hearing. So it went for hours, Mr. Hawtin adding and subtracting sounds and the crowd of about 600 dancing and cheering when they heard a mix they liked.

title: Viacom Posts Loss for Third Quarter
description: Viacom Inc. ( news/quote ), the owner of the CBS television network, posted a third-quarter loss yesterday because of costs at Blockbuster and lower TV and radio advertising sales after the terrorist attacks.

title: A Truce: Legions of Yankee Haters Are Temporary Rooters
description: Just look at them, Yankee haters always say: fans who make a simple hello sound like a taunt, ballplayers who make enough money to buy their kids the Milwaukee Brewers for Christmas, and an owner who dresses like Thurston Howell III. And enough already with that storied-history blather that has Bob Costas getting weepy every time a Yankee hits a bloop single. You've won a lot of World Series; got it.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Shh! I'm Downloading

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Airline's Step Hurts Travelocity
description: Travelocity .com Inc. fell $5.83, or 29 percent, to $14.07 after the largest Internet travel agency was downgraded by an analyst on news that Continental Airlines had eliminated commissions on travel sold on the Web. The analyst, Mark Rowen at Prudential Securities, downgraded Travelocity .com after Continental stopped paying a 5 percent commission to travel agents for tickets sold through the Internet.

title: Metro Matters; An Old Tactic: Painting A Rival Red
description: AT a breakfast appearance this week, Mark Green spoke more substantively than ever about the grave problems confronting New York City, about the anemic economy and how to rebuild downtown, about the argument for tax credits and the need for cooperation from Albany and Washington.

title: The Antipiracy Mission; Aiming for Full Compliance With an Elusive Standard: S.D.M.I.
description: Among the technical specifications listed for its MiniDisc player, Sony says that it is S.D.M.I.-compliant.

title: Lazard Chief Plans To Resign From Post
description: The international investment bank Lazard L.L.C. said yesterday that its chief executive, William Loomis, would step down less than a year after being appointed to run the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, ARNOLD P.
description: ROSEN-Arnold P. The President, Chancellor Emeritus, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the death of Arnold P. Rosen, generous benefactor and devoted friend of the CollegeInstitute. A member of the Cincinnati Board of Overseers and the Board of Governors for nearly three decades, Mr. Rosen served as a member of the Executive Committee and Treasurer of the Board. As a dedicated member of the Jerusalem Building Committee Mr. Rosen was a driving force behind the building of the Jerusalem campus. Deeply committed to the Mission of the College-Institute Mr. Rosen, an honorary member of the Board maintained close ties with HUC-JIR. We are the richer and the wiser for having shared his life with us. We offer our sincerest condolences to his beloved wife, Muriel, and family whose loss we profoundly share. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Emeritus Rabbi Paul M. Steinberg, Special Assistant to the President Mr. Burton Lehman, Chair Board of Governors

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Prize Steer Fails Drug Test
description: A contestant in the state fair steer competition was stripped of his award and about $5,000 because his steer failed a drug test. It is the first time a contestant has been expelled since the fair began testing for illegal drugs 10 years ago. Tests on Brandon Lusk's steer found a diuretic. Steve Pooch, assistant fair manager, said the drug could help a steer qualify for a lighter weight class, then it could be rehydrated to gain weight. Mr. Lusk, 19, denied giving the steer the drugs. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: The Tree That Died And Yet Lived On
description: When a tree, just one tree, falls in an English forest, how many functional objects can it become? That was the question posed three years ago by the British furniture designers Peter Toaig and Garry Olson, organizers of an exhibition called ''Onetree,'' which includes hundreds of housewares, toys and objects made from one oak, a 170-year-old specimen.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: Israel Storms Village

title: Numbers Vary In Tallies Of the Victims
description: Six weeks after the twin towers collapsed, the companies and organizations feared to have sustained the greatest losses of life have completed their official count of their missing and presumed dead. But the total, which includes those lost by Cantor Fitzgerald, the New York Fire Department, the more than 165 diners and staff at Windows on the World, as well as the passengers on the two planes, comes to only 2,405.

title: Troopers Reported Near Deal in Profiling Case
description: Prosecutors and lawyers for two state troopers charged with wounding three black and Hispanic men on the New Jersey Turnpike in 1998 are close to an agreement in which the troopers would resign and admit they engaged in racial profiling, officials close to the negotiations said yesterday. Under the agreement, they would avoid jail, the officials said.

title: A Daughter of Islam, and an Enemy of Terror
description: APOLOGETIC and barefoot, Aasma A. Khan leads the way inside a barren Washington Heights apartment where a lace tablecloth from India is set with tea things and spread out on the green living-room carpet. Giant pillows in shades of green are the only furniture. With a divorce in the works, most of her belongings are in storage, but her indispensable dark green prayer rug is rolled up in the corner. Ms. Khan, 30, laughingly calls herself a color-coordinated daughter of Islam.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, EARL, DR.
description: BROWN-Earl, Dr. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Gertrude. Corey B. Rabin, President Ronald M. Stuart, Secretary

title: Corrections
description: An opera listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for ''The Floating Box,'' a chamber work at the Asia Society, misstated this week's schedule, as did a correction in this space on Tuesday. The performances will be at 8 on Saturday and Sunday, not Thursday or Friday.

title: CUNY Officials Seek Relief From Spending Cuts
description: Officials from the City University of New York warned a City Council committee yesterday that the spending cuts required of most agencies in the wake of the World Trade Center attack would lead to faculty layoffs, canceled classes, lowered enrollment and a significant loss in state financing for the system's six community colleges.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Smaller Loss At Nextel
description: The wireless company Nextel Communications said yesterday that although it would report a third-quarter loss, revenue rose 30 percent as subscriber growth met expectations. The results were better than analysts had expected, and the company's shares rose $1.29, or 17.43 percent, to $8.69. The company, which is based in Reston, Va., said sales had grown to $1.99 billion from $1.53 billion a year earlier, while its subscriber base grew by 650,000, to 9.6 million. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Isles See No Trend of Allowing Late Goals
description: The Islanders are precisely 14.5 seconds, or two very late defensive breakdowns, from being undefeated. Coach Peter Laviolette said today that this did not qualify as a glaring problem or a even a trend. But he had his socket wrench and power sander out anyway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEBBINS, BEATRICE COBB
description: STEBBINS-Beatrice Cobb. 90, of Pensacola, died Saturday October 20, 2001. Born October 8, 1911 in New York City. Graveside services will be held at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY, Monday October 29, 2001. Those wishing to send flowers may send them to Woodlawn Cemetery, Webster Ave & E. 233rd Bronx, NY 10470 or donations may be made to the Audubon Society. For information Harper-Morris Memorial Chapel, Pensacola, FL 850-478-3292.

title: Diamondbacks Give Anderson Surprise Start
description: Bob Brenly spotted Brian Anderson in the outfield Tuesday while his Arizona Diamondbacks took batting practice at Bank One Ballpark. Brenly had exciting news to share, but Anderson feared the worst.

title: Long Before War, Green Berets Built Military Ties to Uzbekistan
description: In 1999, teams of Green Berets arrived at former Soviet garrisons outside the capital here. They were some of the Army's finest soldiers, they traveled in small groups and in the two years that followed they came and went every few months.

title: Durst Not Suspect in the Death Of a Friend From Los Angeles
description: Los Angeles detectives say that the real estate scion Robert A. Durst is not a suspect in the murder of a longtime friend, Susan Berman, who was found shot to death in her home in Benedict Canyon last December.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Avaya Expecting Sales Decline
description: Avaya Inc., a former unit of Lucent Technologies that makes office communications equipment, warned investors yesterday that it expected sales to decline the next 12 months as the nation's economy slows. Avaya, which is based in Basking Ridge, N.J., had sales of $6.79 billion the last year. The company yesterday reported a loss of $328 million, or $1.17 a share, in the latest quarter, compared with a loss of $543 million, or $1.95, a year earlier. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: At a Design Auction, Silence Will Be Golden
description: Donna Warner, editor in chief of Metropolitan Home magazine, and James Druckman, the president of the New York Design Center, have organized ''Design Cares,'' a silent auction of furniture, rugs and accessories with all proceeds benefiting the Sept. 11th Fund. The 245 items include the Freedom chair, above, designed by Niels Diffrient, and pieces from Odegard and M2L. On Nov. 1 at the New York Design Center, 200 Lexington Avenue (32nd Street), at 6:30 p.m., with bids closing at 8. Previews and showroom tours on Oct. 31 at 12:30 and 3 p.m. and on the day of the auction. $50 for the preview, including the auction; auction alone, $20. Reservations are required: (212) 679-9500, extension 30.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Final Agreement Reached With Bayer on Cipro Price

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Comdisco Bid Is Delayed
description: A federal bankruptcy judge has delayed for two weeks the hearing to approve SunGard Data Systems Inc.'s acquisition of Comdisco's Availability Solutions business for $825 million. The delay came after Justice Department officials filed a lawsuit against SunGard seeking to block the deal on antitrust grounds. In a separate development, Hewlett-Packard offered $750 million for the Comdisco unit, which offers disaster-recovery services, and its offer was approved by Comdisco's board of directors. The SunGard chief executive, James L. Mann, said the Justice Department's suit was without merit. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Governor Sets Redistricting Session
description: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove, a Democrat, told state lawmakers there would be a Nov. 1 special session to resolve a legislative impasse over how to redraw Congressional districts as the state loses one of its five seats. State House leaders appear to be backing a plan that favors United States Representative Ronnie Shows, a Democrat. Lt. Gov. Amy Tuck, a Democrat, is pushing a plan more favorable to Representative Charles W. Pickering Jr., a Republican. Under the Voting Rights Act, the Department of Justice needs at least 60 days to review the new plan. The deadline for candidates to qualify for 2002 elections is March 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARQUSEE, JANET
description: MARQUSEE-Janet. The Board of Directors and entire membership of the Private Art Dealers Association deeply mourn the passing of our good friend and founding member, Janet Marqusee. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family at this time. Timothy Baum, President

title: BRUNSWICK TO BUY HATTERAS FOR $80 MILLION IN CASH
description: The Brunswick Corporation, the country's leading maker of recreational boats and marine engines, agreed to buy Hatteras Yachts Inc. from closely held Genmar Industries Inc. for about $80 million in cash and said it would trim jobs and idle some plants. Brunswick will close a Sea Ray plant in Phoenix and cut about 370 jobs there, less than 2 percent of its work force, a spokesman, Dan Kubera, said. Brunswick plans additional cuts and closings, but has not specified where they will be, he said. The purchase of Hatteras, which is based in New Bern, N.C., adds to Brunswick's boating line, giving it high-end yachts that complement its Boston Whaler, Trophy and Baja brands. Genmar is based in Minneapolis.

title: To Get a Handle on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Makers Plan Vaccines For Smallpox
description: The Bush administration's plan to buy enough smallpox vaccine to inoculate every American has produced an unexpected surge of interest by pharmaceutical companies, federal health officials said today.

title: Wines of the Week
description: The adage "what's old is new again" certainly holds true for wine as grape varieties synonymous with Old World wines are thriving in the New World. Pinot noir, the grape responsible for red Burgundy, is causing a buzz in New Zealand; syrah, a star in France's Northern Rhone region, is rising to new heights in Chile; and barbera, a staple of Italy's Piedmont region, has found a home in California's Gold Country.

title: Mayors Place Their Bets
description: The silly bets between mayors of cities with teams in the World Series moved into the realm of leisure activities when Phoenix Mayor Skip Rimsza and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York wagered free rounds of golf at local municipal courses.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: A Difference in the Count

title: Challenges of Do-It-Yourself Checkout
description: ON a recent weekday evening, scores of work-weary people waited to check out materials at the Mid-Manhattan branch of the New York Public Library while, a few yards away, two self-service checkout machines stood idle.

title: Sex With Dead Film Stars Means Breakfast for One
description: COLDHEART CANYON

title: 9 Killed in Swiss Alps Tunnel As Trucks Crash and Burst Into Fire
description: A head-on collision between two trucks killed 10 people, and possibly more, on the main north-south road through the Swiss Alps today in the latest in a series of tunnel disasters to strike the Alpine region in the last several years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, MARTHA
description: GORMAN-Martha. Died October 24th, 2001 at the age of 87. Following the performing career under the stage name of Marny Frances, she was the beloved wife of the late David Gorman. She was the loving mother of Gail Furman and mother-in-law of Jay Furman; devoted grandmother of Jason and Jesse Furman, Ariela Dubler, and Eve Gerber; and adoring great grandmother of Ilan David Dubler-Furman. She is survived as well by her devoted caregivers, Sonia Reid and Beverly Golding. We all loved her very much, and she will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue on Sunday, October 28th at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may made to Planned Parenthood of NYC, 810 Seventh Avenue, New York, New York 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOETZ, RUTH GOODMAN
description: GOETZ-Ruth Goodman. October 12, 2001. Beloved wife and collaborator of the late Augustus Goetz. Wonderful mother of Judy Goetz Sanger. Delighted grandmother of Katie Firth. Service Thursday, October 25, 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. Interment services private at Keller's Church Cemetery, Bucks County, PA. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Dramatist Guild Fund of America and Young Playwrights Festival.

title: Does the U.S. Still Trust Markets to Work?; If Every Bailout Could Be Like Chrysler's
description: In 1983, Lee A. Iacocca, then the chief executive of Chrysler, proudly posed with a check for $813,487,500, the company's final payment of the $1.2 billion it had borrowed with a government guarantee in 1980. Without federal help, Chrysler would have gone broke.

title: Iceland Shows Its Charm Is Still Vigorous
description: When Bjork emerged in the 90's as one of the most important and individual solo artists of her generation, she seemed like an aberration, with her Icelandic nationality simply another testament to her eccentricity. Then this year, Sigur Ros descended from Iceland as one of the best and most original post-rock bands since Radiohead, while Icelandic films like ''101 Reykjavik'' traveled the world festival circuit.

title: Cities Seek Millions in Crisis Aid
description: Mayors meeting in Washington said today that they were asking the Bush administration for millions of dollars to help pay for the emergency and policing responsibilities thrust on them since Sept. 11.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B.

title: Essay; Bush's Mideast Charade
description: To read the headlines, you would think a major rift was growing between the U.S. and its only dependable ally in the Middle East.

title: Studies Suggest Lower Count For Number of U.S. Muslims
description: A new survey, and a study of other polls and surveys, indicates that the Muslim population of the United States may be smaller than has previously been widely estimated.

title: The News and the Score Wherever You Go
description: EVEN before Sept. 11, the average amount of time adults ages 18 to 64 reported listening to the radio last year was three hours a day, with 90 minutes devoted to news, according to a study by the Radio-Television News Directors Association. It seems reasonable that people are spending even more time tuned in now -- and on Saturday, the World Series starts. Lightweight, compact radios and televisions slip into a pocket, briefcase or handbag to provide round-the-clock access.

title: Fishy Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Women
description: To the Editor:

title: After I.R.A. Move, British to Dismantle Base and Towers
description: Britain and pro-British Protestant political leaders of Ulster moved swiftly today to capitalize on the long-awaited decision by the Irish Republican Army to begin dismantling its weapons.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: 6 Men Charged With Running Narcotics Ring
description: When New York City firefighters searched the building at 300 Albany Street on Sept. 11 looking for people who might need help as the World Trade Center collapsed, they encountered a lone man who seemed reluctant to leave. They wanted to know why.

title: IVillage Advertising Rose 19% in Third Quarter
description: In a small sign that all is not bleak at companies that sell Internet advertising, iVillage, the big Web site for women, said its sales increased 19 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter and its pretax operating earnings turned positive for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARON, ALICE
description: VARON-Alice. At age 81. Devoted wife of the late Harry Robert Varon. Mother of Mark, Joseph and Dorothy. Grandmother of Amos and Chanthoeun. In our hearts always. Rest in peace.

title: Restraint Used in Bethlehem, Israeli Major Says
description: With the Paradise Hotel burning a few blocks away and gunfire resounding around the Israeli position there, Maj. Kobi Katz unfolded a large black-and-white aerial photograph of Bethlehem on the concrete floor of an army outpost here this morning.

title: Leaders of the Old Afghanistan Prepare for the New
description: With hundreds of colorful turbans atop hundreds of weathered heads, a huge assemblage of pre-Taliban Afghan leaders met here today to map strategy for a post-Taliban Afghanistan, this time vowing not to make such a mess of their country.

title: The House Acts Badly
description: The razor-thin margin by which the House Republicans passed their economic stimulus package yesterday was a tribute to how really dreadful that proposal is. A huge package of tax cuts, no matter how ill advised, can generally attract supporters. But despite desperate pressure from the House leadership, and the assurance that whatever they voted for would be made more sensible by the Senate, the stimulus plan squeaked through the House by only two votes.

title: For a Special Message, Say It With Fake Buds
description: Is it possible to love roses, but not want the real thing? Fake flowers need no watering, don't spread any pollen, don't make people allergic and won't wilt for years.

title: Signature Wallpaper Strides Two Worlds
description: In Japan, traditional culture is now juxtaposed with modern. ''Several years ago, they didn't have graffiti,'' said Corky Tyler, vice president of Takashimaya in Manhattan. ''They have it now. You see girls with body piercing inside a traditional paper shop selecting handmade paper.'' The store's Japanese Street exhibition, through Nov. 17, reflects that mix. Ms. Tyler commissioned MUK, a Manhattan graffitist, to interpret Japanese-style graffiti, left. The shop also sells handmade paper in 65 designs, $12 for a 26-by-38-inch sheet. Takashimaya's staff reinterpreted the function of Japanese stamps, used to sign documents, by making the stamps twice as large to make wallpaper, background. At 693 Fifth Avenue (54th Street).

title: Package Deal
description: The Diamondbacks decided to take advantage of their new popularity by offering 1,000 World Series tickets to fans who put a $750 deposit on a 2002 full-season ticket package. ''These were held back from the beginning,'' said Scott Brubaker, senior vice president for sales and marketing. He said the club was trying ''to build up our season ticket base.'' Attendance at Bank One Ballpark has declined from 3.6 million ticket sales in 1998, the team's first season, to 2.7 million this year.

title: Grade A Fares
description: AirTran Airways is discounting fares on flights through Feb. 13, under its Grade A sale. Tickets must be bought by Wednesday, and there is an advance-purchase requirement of seven days. Among the one-way fares: between Dallas-Fort Worth and Newark, $103; Memphis-La Guardia, $84; Boston- Tampa, Fla., $88; Philadelphia-Fort Lauderdale, $66; Boston-Atlanta, $78; Washington (Dulles Airport) and Fort Myers, Fla., $79; and Newark and Raleigh-Durham, N.C., $73. Fares are nonrefundable and availability is limited; there are blackout dates, and taxes and fees are extra. Round-trip travel is not required, and there is an extra 5 percent discount if bought at www.airtran.com . Through Dec. 31, the airline will give a free round-trip ticket after the purchase of three round trips; (800) 247-8726.

title: National Party Hasn't Clogged The Airways For Schundler
description: Just two months ago, national Republicans seemed ready to spend substantial sums of money on advertising in the New Jersey governor's race, prompting fears and a lawsuit from Democrats.

title: A Dark View of Anthrax, Errant Bombs, the Saudi Connection
description: One of the more bewildering, and worrisome, questions in the anthrax threat has been how to assess it: quite seriously or scared-half-to-death seriously. Given confusing and sometimes ill-informed signals from Washington, the answers have not come easily for the average American.

title: A Literary Lion And Oprah Tangle
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Buys Davids I. for $6.5 Million to Use as a Park
description: A small island in Long Island Sound where several projects have failed in the last three decades -- including proposals for a nuclear power plant and a Trump high-rise complex -- will become a public park for Westchester County, officials announced today.

title: With a Little Help From Its Friends
description: AN odd thing happened to the MiniDisc player on its tumble toward the ash heap of failed electronic products. The devices, developed by Sony, began getting popular. Very popular.

title: Bayer Agrees to Charge Government a Lower Price for Anthrax Medicine
description: Federal health officials and executives of Bayer A.G. reached an agreement today that would nearly halve the price that Bayer charges the government for its anthrax medicine, Cipro.

title: Unity in Wartime
description: To the Editor:

title: Concealing the Names Of E-Mail Recipients
description: Q. I often need to send an e-mail message to a group of people but don't want each recipient to be able to see all other recipients' names and addresses. I can't find a Bcc line in the Outlook Express window, so how can I avoid revealing the addresses?

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional gocardlf. These rankings are from Oct. 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTZKIN, MAXINE
description: MOTZKIN-Maxine. Of Boca Raton, FL. Passed away October 22, 2001. Beloved wife of Morris. Loving mother of Robert (Diane) Motzkin and Lynne (Charles) Weiss. Grandmother of Jonathan and Jordan. A Graveside service today, October 25, 2001, at 2 P.M. at Glenville Jewish Cemetery, Glenville, CT. Information, call ''Gutterman's'', 1-800-992-9262.

title: European Converts to Laissez Faire See the Rush to Intervene as Heresy
description: For decades, the United States' economic prescription to friend and foe was almost a mantra in its consistency: leave it to the market.

title: Success in the Big East Comes With Experience
description: Mike Tranghese, the Big East commissioner, was hard pressed to find a favorite for the coming men's basketball season, although Boston College and Georgetown were picked by coaches to win their divisions. Those teams are favored largely on what they accomplished last season and on a couple of stars.

title: Tracing the Steps (and Near Success) of a Taliban-Trained Attacker
description: In mid-December 1999, when an Algerian living in Canada tried to enter Washington State with a car full of explosives, the event was overshadowed by larger concerns: the country was gripped by the possibility that computers would go haywire and create chaos when they hit the year 2000. The terrorist, Ahmed Ressam, was arrested and convicted of planning to blow up the Los Angeles airport, but what came to be called the millennium bomb plot was a speck on the national consciousness. To the extent that it registered at all, it added to a disastrously false sense of security. After all, the plot was thwarted, no one was hurt, the computers could still count, and the country's safety nets seemed to work.

title: Before Bonhomie Ends
description: To the Editor:

title: Godolphin Switches Sakhee to the Classic
description: The Breeders' Cup Classic, the premier event on Saturday's championship-day card at Belmont Park, picked up an unexpected and intriguing challenger yesterday when Godolphin Racing announced that its star 4-year-old, Sakhee, would bypass the $2 million Turf for the $4 million dirt event that is scheduled to be run some 30 minutes later.

title: A.I.G., GOLDMAN AND CHUBB FORM INSURANCE VENTURE
description: American International Group Inc. joined Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and the Chubb Corporation said they have formed a new insurance venture based in Bermuda. The new business may enable A.I.G. and Chubb to expand their reinsurance operations. An A.I.G. spokesman, Joe Norton, and Chubb's chief financial officer, Weston Hicks, declined to comment. Goldman Sachs did not return telephone calls seeking comment.

title: Divided House Approves Economic Recovery Plan
description: Saying business tax breaks are the best way to preserve jobs and revive the economy, Republicans muscled their version of an economic recovery plan through the House today, brushing aside criticism from Democrats that the bill did too little for the unemployed and other people who need help the most.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the purchase of KKWB, a television station in El Paso, referred imprecisely to the buyer, Entravision Communications. It is not a full affiliate of Univision Communications, though it carries some Uni vision programming.

title: Windows of Opportunity
description: Bill Gates comes to New York today to tout the wonders of Microsoft's new operating system, Windows XP. To hear him talk, Windows XP will improve our lives in almost every way. What he'll talk less about, I suspect, is how Windows XP will advance Microsoft's domination over the world of personal computing. Then again, he may see the goals as identical.

title: Home Front Is a Minefield For President
description: When President Bush's helicopter touched down on the South Lawn of the White House in the early hours Monday, the president emerged fresh from solid victories abroad: He had cemented Russia as an enthusiastic partner in the war on terrorism, neutralized China's objections, and, by remote control from his hotel room, overseen the first operation involving ground troops in Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANYON, GILBERT
description: ANYON-Gilbert. Of North Salem. Born June 29, 1921; passed away October 19, 2001 of heart failure. Beloved husband of Connie Fox & cherished father of Timi Hallem & Jill Anyon. The best grandfather Elissa and Seth Hallem could have had. The world is richer for his life and poorer for his loss. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center, MADD, or Greenpeace.

title: Bush Advisers Press for Help For Insurers
description: President Bush's senior economic advisers told lawmakers today that the nation would face an economic crisis if Congress failed to quickly guard the insurance industry against losses from any future terrorist attacks. But the administration's proposal, which would have the government pay at least 80 percent of any claims next year, ran into a storm of criticism from both Democrats and Republicans.

title: Blight to Some Is Home to Others; Concern Over Displacement by a New Times Building
description: Blight is what state officials see on the block of Eighth Avenue between 40th and 41st Streets: a shabby blend of sex shops, prostitution, loitering and drug dealing that scarcely welcomes the world to the new Times Square.

title: Airlines Make Changes To Their Campaigns
description: The two airlines whose jets were hijacked for the terrorist attacks are moving ahead with advertising plans that are significantly different from their campaigns before Sept. 11.

title: Sears to Cut Jobs and Revamp Stores
description: Sears, Roebuck will cut 4,900 jobs, or 22 percent of its salaried workers, and overhaul its stores to compete with discount chains like Wal-Mart Stores and Target.

title: A Field Trip on the Road to Bargains
description: If you have a sofa or chairs that need reupholstering, your decorator or architect can buy Duralee's current fabrics at the D&D Building (979 Third Avenue at 58th Street) for $25 to $120 a yard. Or you can travel 45 miles east of Manhattan, to the Duralee factory outlet on Long Island and sort through 1,500 to 2,000 bolts of discontinued fabrics, most of them in traditional patterns -- at $3 to $8 a yard. You may have to be flexible, as at any outlet, because patterns vary daily and so do quantities. But there is always tremendous choice, said Lee Silberman, a vice president of Duralee, and ''it is never a problem to find enough of a fabric to cover two club chairs or a three-seat sofa.'' Curtain and drapery fabrics are available too. The Duralee factory outlet is at 1775 Fifth Avenue, Brentwood, N.Y.; (631) 273-8800 for hours and directions.

title: Stung by Criticism, Aides Gather To Coordinate Efforts on Anthrax
description: After a day of recriminations over how the government handled information about anthrax attacks, public health and law enforcement authorities gathered at the White House tonight to devise a strategy for responding to future strikes, which they say are almost certain to occur.

title: Plans for Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Business Confidence Falls
description: In its first survey of British business confidence since Sept. 11, the Confederation of British Industry, a leading business organization, said confidence among British businesses was at a three-year low with 6 percent of more than 1,000 companies surveyed expressing optimism about business prospects. The confederation urged the Bank of England to lower interest rates by half a percentage point when policy makers meet next month. The bank's monetary policy committee has cut rates six times this year, to 4.5 percent, and investors are expecting another quarter-point cut. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about journalists' frustration with restrictions on close-up coverage of military action in Afghanistan misstated the name of an aircraft carrier on which reporters have been working. It is the Carl Vinson, not Vincent.

title: Insurance Rates Are Rising Sharply Across U.S.
description: The terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon have triggered steep increases in insurance prices across the nation, raising costs for small businesses, factories, farms, homeowners and drivers, as well as large corporations.

title: Zeroing In on the Suspicious Number Above the State Motto
description: CAR washes use them to cut down on nonpaying customers. Parking garages use them to prevent customers from swapping tickets and paying lower fees. But while digital license plate readers, which read and verify a vehicle's license plate, have primarily been used in the United States as a means of ensuring payment, they are now being sized up as security tools.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Group Gives Bay A Low Health Score
description: The health of the Chesapeake Bay has declined for the first time in years, a watchdog group said in its annual report. The group, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, pointed to increased development, nutrient pollution and a decline in the blue crab population. The foundation rated the bay's health at 27 on a scale of 0 to 100. The score, down one point from 2000, is based on 13 areas like pollution, habitat and fish stocks. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: In Courtroom In Texas, Engrossing Bit Of History
description: The book on a most absorbing corner of Texas history was perhaps closed for good this evening when a state district jury in this dusty city just north of the Mexican border delivered a unanimous civil verdict favoring the defendant, a charitable trust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFEN, ANNA (BIRSHTEIN)
description: GEFFEN-Anna (Birshtein), 94. Died Wednesday, October 24, 2001 in Atlanta, GA. The Officers, Board of Directors, Membership and Staff of Temple Israel, Scranton, PA, mourn the passing of Anna Geffen, beloved mother of our spiritual leader Rabbi David Geffen. Adored mother-in-law of Rita Geffen. Cherished grandmother of Avie, Elissa, Chemi, Tuvia and Karen and a loving great grandmother. Graveside services will be held today at 1 PM in Greenwood Cemetery, Atlanta, GA. Memorial contributions may be made to The Anna and Louis Geffen Book Fund (Special Collections) Woodruff Library, C/O of Emery University, Atlanta, GA. Shiva will be observed at the residence of Rabbi David Geffen. 835 North Webster Ave., Scranton, PA 18510, Monday, October 29th from 7-9PM and Tuesday, October 30th from 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: U.S. Bridge Team Is No. 1
description: One of the four American teams was out in front, and the others were in qualifying positions at the world team championships here today.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Saturday about a World Trade Center attack victim, Daniel Afflitto, a Cantor Fitzgerald employee known for elaborate barbecues and parties, misspelled the name of his New Jersey hometown. It is Manalapan, not Manalpan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Maker's Profit Rises
description: The drug maker, AstraZeneca, reported a 10 percent increase in third-quarter earnings, as a patent dispute kept generic versions of its ulcer treatment, Losec, off the market in the United States. Profit from continuing operations was $720 million, or 41 cents a share, compared with $654 million, or 37 cents a share, the year earlier. Sales rose 4 percent, to $3.95 billion. One of Losec's main patents expired on Oct. 5, but AstraZeneca says other patents cover the drug, sold as Prilosec in America, for several more years. Generic drug makers like the Andrx Corporation, which want to make their own ulcer treatments, have accused AstraZeneca of stalling, and a trial is scheduled to begin in New York on Dec. 5. In the meantime, AstraZeneca has begun selling Nexium, an improved version of Losec. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Scary Decorations? Not This Halloween
description: IN the last year of her life, my grandmother saw ghosts. This was not big news in my family, since we routinely enjoyed encounters with the departed. Most famously, a few months after my Uncle Billy died, he sat in the passenger seat of an old convertible and told jokes all night long to keep his sister awake at the wheel.

title: For Truly Portable Typing, A Curvaceous Keyboard
description: Being all thumbs can come in handy for those who want a faster way to put text into a Palm V. The new, 1.4-ounce ThumbPad Keyboard, made by Targus, is one of the smallest external keyboards for any Palm organizer. The ThumbPad snaps onto the hand-held computer's serial port and draws its power from the computer. Because of its curved design, it does not need to be used with a flat surface or support stand.

title: The Industrialist's Ghost Paces the Pages
description: Henry Clay Frick, the steel magnate, collected houses as keenly as he collected art. Every few years, he would hire star designers like Elsie de Wolfe and Ogden Codman Jr. to build or expand a mansion for his old master paintings.

title: Jury Acquits O. J. Simpson In a Trial On Road Rage
description: While much of the country has been fixed on bioterrorism and the war in Afghanistan, a celebrity trial ended here today without the gavel-to-gavel coverage and daily headlines that were present the last time the defendant stood accused.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTEUS, CHRISTINA T. (NEE HEFFNER)
description: PORTEUS-Christina T. (nee Heffner). Resident of Asharoken, NY, for 54 years, on October 23, 2001, in her 92nd year. Former Village Trustee and Clerk. Longtime member of Asharoken Garden Club and Northport Historical Society. Beloved wife of the late Thomas. Loving mother of Nancy, Britton, Eileen White, and Judith Porteus-Baner. Cherished grandmother of Christina Holz and Lila White Gardella. Reposing at Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10 AM, at St. Philip Neri R.C. Church, Northport. Interment at Northport Rural Cemetery. Donations to the Northport Fire Department Rescue Squad, 204 Main Street, Northport, NY 11768, in her memory appreciated. Visiting hours Thursday, 7-9 PM, and Friday, 2-5 & 7-9 PM.

title: Enron Ousts Finance Chief As S.E.C. Looks at Dealings
description: The Enron Corporation, its stock battered by a sudden loss of investor confidence, yesterday ousted its chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, whose involvement in complicated transactions with Enron has drawn the scrutiny of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Talks On Asylum Seekers
description: Foreign Minister Hasan Wirayuda said Indonesia planned an international conference on the flood of Middle Eastern asylum seekers who were passing through his country en route to Australia, which now refuses to accept them. Nearly 400 people died Friday when an overloaded vessel sank on the way to Australia. A United Nations official has cited allegations that police officers forced refugees onto the unseaworthy boat before it left Bogor. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: To Get a Handle on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Parent of American Airlines Posts Record Quarterly Loss
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, posted the largest quarterly loss in its history yesterday after an already difficult third quarter was turned into a financial disaster by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDSTEIN, MARK
description: FELDSTEIN - Mark. Renowned photographer and dedicated teacher. A guiding presence of our photography program, loved by his students for his capacity to inspire and guide and by his colleagues and friends, for his intelligence and wit. We mourn his sudden untimely death, and offer our condolences to his wife, Laura, and son, Gideon. Department of Art Hunter College

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERRICO, DONATO
description: ERRICO-Donato. To my incredible, loving father-in-law. Thank you for all the wonderful times & memories. You have always been so special. Love always and forever. Robyn Errico

title: CANTV Shareholders Approve Buyback of Stock
description: The shareholders of Venezuela's largest telecommunications company approved a share buyback and dividend yesterday in the latest chapter of a takeover battle involving two prominent American companies, the AES Corporation and Verizon Communications.

title: The Pope Apologizes for the Catholic Church's 'Errors' in China
description: Pope John Paul II apologized to China today for ''errors'' in the Roman Catholic Church's missions there and expressed his strong willingness to work toward full diplomatic relations with Beijing.

title: Mistrial Declared In Genentech Case Over Back Royalties
description: A California judge declared a mistrial today in a lawsuit brought by a leading medical center against Genentech when the jury could not reach a verdict after six days of deliberation.

title: A Patriarch, a Woman Who Had Time for Others and a Lifelong Friend
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, ELI
description: EPSTEIN-Eli. Died Oct. 22 after a brief illness. A Social Worker who was committed to social justice throughout his life. A loyal and devoted friend who will be missed by his family and his many friends. Services at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue at 10th Street, Thursday at 2 PM. Donations may be made to Jews For Racial & Economic Justice, 140 W. 22nd Street, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENBOGEN, JOAN L.
description: ELLENBOGEN-Joan L., 59, on October 23, 2001. She is survived by her loving sister, Leni Goodman, and her adoring niece, Cache, and her caring circle of close friends. Services Thursday, October 25, 12noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65 St.

title: Contradicting Some U.S. Officials, 3 Scientists Call Anthrax Powder High-Grade
description: Scientists in and out of government said yesterday that the anthrax strike on Capitol Hill involved an advanced, highly refined powder that is quite dangerous and not the primitive form of the germ that some federal officials have recently described.

title: Union Chief Offers Assurance Amid Skepticism
description: Patricia Johnson, a career postal worker, is keeping to her appointed rounds, delivering not mail but the best reassurances she can muster for the many mail handlers in her union local anxious about the threat of anthrax.

title: Flu Shots Are Encouraged To Reduce Anthrax Fear
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani went beyond the usual recommendations of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention yesterday by urging all New Yorkers to get a flu shot, in part so that they do not confuse flu symptoms with those of inhalation anthrax.

title: Tonight's N.F.L. Matchup
description: Indianapolis (2-3) at Kansas City (1-5)

title: With the World Redesigned, What Role for Designers?
description: FOR the last two years, the field of design has enjoyed the popularity of a professional lifetime. It has appeared on the covers of Time and Business Week, its now famous figures profiled on Ted Koppel's ''Nightline'' and Charlie Rose. Annual awards were created, and new design-related publications proliferated.

title: In a Shift, Muslim Groups Cast Themselves as Loyal Critics
description: Ever since terrorists razed the World Trade Center, Michel Shehadeh says, his tongue has grown sore from biting it so much. He is being only somewhat facetious.

title: Ballet Theater Opens a Visit With Samples And Spirit
description: American Ballet Theater opened its two-week fall season at City Center on Tuesday night with a gala performance called ''A Tribute to the American Spirit.'' Happily, the program was a cheerful romp through a collection of ballets that offered, as one wag in the audience put it, a ''taster's menu'' of the season's repertory to come rather than the usual exhausting gala fare of truncated classical divertissements. The evening's tone was captured perfectly in Eliot Feld's ''Variations on America,'' a sly Americana pas de deux set to music by Charles Ives that was danced to cheeky perfection by Angel Corella and a glittering Erica Cornejo.

title: Convicted Terrorists Sent to Pennsylvania
description: Federal authorities moved quickly to transfer four convicted followers of Osama bin Laden to a high-security prison in Pennsylvania after they were sentenced last week in the embassy bombings trial.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; With stocks weakened further, some retirement investors seem ready to sell low and buy high.
description: THE overwhelming majority of workers are frightened about the declining value of their retirement accounts, and nearly half intend to change their investment strategy if the stock market remains weak at the end of the year, a new survey shows.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Suit Against New York
description: A group of injured workers from New York, mostly low-wage textile workers, arrived in Mexico to file suit against New York State for failing to resolve their workers' compensation claims, some dating back nearly a decade. The group is using a provision in the North American Free Trade Agreement that permits such labor suits. They are hoping the Mexican government will support the suit because many plaintiffs are Mexican emigrants. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: U.S. Postpones Three Tests of Missile-Tracking System
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The Bush administration, racing to strike a deal on offensive and defensive strategic arms with Russia, has postponed a series of antimissile tests that Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today might be interpreted as violating the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLINGSWORTH, PAULINE CURTIS
description: HOLLINGSWORTH-Pauline Curtis of Cambridge. On Monday, October 22, 2001. First wife of the late Schuyler Hollingsworth, mother of four sons, Amor of Fullerton, CA, Schulyer of San Marino, CA, Curtis of Lincoln, MA., and Frazier Hollingsworth of Denver, CO. Sister of Laura Curtis of Old Westbury, N.Y., and the late James Freeman Curtis and the late Frazier Curtis. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend a Memorial Service on Saturday October 27, 2001 at 1:00 PM at Christ Church, Zero Garden St. Cambridge, Massachusetts. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society of Massachusetts, 101 First Avenue, Waltham, MA. 02154-1115. For information J.S. WatermanEastman-Waring Funeral Service, Boston, MA., 617-536-4110.

title: Pataki Visits Washington, But Aid Plea Meets Doubt
description: Gov. George E. Pataki of New York emerged from a meeting at the White House today and for the first time expressed doubts about the prospects of his $54 billion plan to help the state recover from last month's terrorist attack at the World Trade Center.

title: Mussina Is the Winner in a Win-Win Situation
description: Joe Torre spotted Mike Mussina in the clubhouse before yesterday's workout at Yankee Stadium and told him he would be starting the opener of the World Series against the Arizona Diamondbacks at Bank One Ballpark on Saturday. There was no detailed explanation, no frills to the conversation, no handshake. Then the eloquent manager and the stoic pitcher parted ways and continued working. The Yankees, even Mussina, understand the postseason routine.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Governor's Race Expands
description: Less than a year after celebrating his party's takeover of the State Senate, Stan Matsunaka of Fort Morgan said he would seek the Democratic nomination to challenge Gov. Bill Owens in 2002. A frequent critic of Mr. Owens, who plans to seek a second four-year term, Mr. Matsunaka is the third Democrat to join the race. Mr. Owens is not expecting a serious challenge for the Republican nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDERMOTT, CATHERINE (NEE FOX)
description: McDERMOTT - Catherine (nee Fox). On October 21, 2001. Last surviving child of the late John J. Fox, founder of John J. Fox and Sons Inc., funeral directors since 1893 and Elizabeth (nee Bracken). Loving wife of the late Thomas Delmour, Sr. Beloved mother of Catherine E., of Washington, DC. and Sarah A. of New York City, and the late Thomas Delmour, Jr. Also survived by her grandson, John Delmour McDermott of Omaha, Nebraska. and many loving nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at John J. Fox Funeral Home Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY, Friday 4-6PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 10AM, St. Mary Star of the Sea Church, City Island, New York. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ROSEMARY A.
description: SMITH-Rosemary A. Of Staten Island. An employee of Sidley Austin Brown and Wood, LLP. Tragically at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Beloved mother of Rosemary Kempton and mother-in-law of Kevin. Loving daughter of Mary Smith. Cherished grandmother of Kyley and Kamy Kempton. Dear sister of Charles Smith, Georgeanne Smith Giddio and sister-in-law of Marianne. Adored aunt of Keith and Kristy Smith. Memorial Mass Saturday, October 27 at 11 AM at Our Lady of Pity Church, 1616 Richmond Ave., SI, NY. Friends will be received at church Saturday at 10 AM. For information, call Casey Funeral Home 718-447-4242.

title: Blocking Spam
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Debates Link to Dollar
description: With the economy falling and public discontent rising, Hong Kong has been questioning one of its cornerstones: the linking of its currency to the United States dollar at a fixed exchange rate.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Indians Occupy Ranches
description: Members of the Pataxo Ha-Ha-Hae tribe have occupied 84 ranches and farms in Bahia to protest what they describe as the illegal occupation of their ancestral land by cocoa and cattle interests. The government has sent negotiators to discuss a deal that would permit it to buy the disputed land and give it to the tribe. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Battery Park City Landlords Are Giving Breaks to Tenants
description: In an effort to encourage tenants to stay in their apartments near ground zero, landlords in Battery Park City have begun to offer rent reductions, rent credits and other amenities to make the area battered by the World Trade Center attacks more attractive.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Confusion Over Trial For Fujimori
description: The Japanese Foreign Ministry denied that Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi had told President Alejandro Toledo of Peru that Peru's ex-president, Alberto K. Fujimori, could be tried in Japan. A communiqu implied that Mr. Toledo had misunderstood Mr. Koizumi when he said Japanese law would be applied. Peruvian prosecutors say Mr. Fujimori was involved in corruption and death-squad activities, for which they seek his extradition. Peruvian officials stood by Mr. Toledo's interpretation of the conversation. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about journalists' frustration with restrictions on close-up coverage of military action in Afghanistan misstated the name of an aircraft carrier on which reporters have been working. It is the Carl Vinson, not Vincent.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Enron Corporation's efforts to reassure investors misstated the initial of its chief executive. He is Kenneth L. Lay, not W.

title: Whose Opinions Have The Zip of a Fastball?
description: For those who think filing lawsuits is the real national pastime, Oyez Baseball is the perfect game. An interactive quiz that went online this month at baseball.oyez.org, the game asks visitors to take a swing at deciding which major league baseball players share traits with the 108 past and present justices of the United States Supreme Court. Clicking the correct choice -- for example, matching John Marshall Harlan, the ''tobacco-chomping justice,'' with the spitball pitcher Gaylord Perry -- yields a home run and earns the crowd's cheers.

title: Fliers Voice Their Concern Over Security
description: Seasoned, confident professionals who are technically skilled and accustomed to being in control, airline pilots are becoming frustrated and worried about security.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From Tahoe to Thailand, readers share their insights and answer other readers' questions.

title: Senate Clears Anti-Terror Bill for Bush's Signature
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The Senate passed sweeping anti-terrorism legislation today, sending President Bush a measure that would expand the government's ability to conduct electronic surveillance, detain immigrants without charges and penetrate money-laundering banks.

title: YankeeNets Planning To Shut Operations
description: Harvey Schiller, the chairman of YankeeNets since early 2000, is expected to leave the company by the end of the year as its functions fade away, said two YankeeNets officials who asked not to be identified.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Bank Bidders Line Up
description: The Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency said 18 investors, including two units of J. P. Morgan Chase, had expressed interest in buying its 51 percent of Bank Central Asia. The agency gained control of the bank in the financial crisis of 1997 and 1998 and must sell it under the terms of Indonesia's $5 billion economic package with the International Monetary Fund. Political delays to such sales have been a source of friction between Jakarta and the I.M.F. Separately, Cemex of Mexico, one of the world's largest cement manufacturers, has warned that its more-than-two-year effort to buy the cement company Semen Gresik is being held up by political obstacles, with only two days left before the purchase deadline. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: It's the Cars, Not the Tires, That Squeal
description: IT is a typical weekend on a busy turnpike. The toll plaza is swamped, so drivers maneuver around one another searching for the shortest line. But just a few lanes over, other drivers cruise past the tollbooth thanks to tiny transmitters in their cars.

title: After the Taliban
description: With American warplanes now directly supporting Afghanistan's rebel Northern Alliance, there is an urgent need to come up with a viable plan for the installation of a new government in Kabul. The alliance's ground forces can be an important military asset in dislodging the Taliban. But its fractious and ethnically unrepresentative leaders must not be allowed to exploit an American-backed drive on the capital to position themselves as the nation's dominant political figures. Such a lopsided government would have little chance of gaining nationwide legitimacy or acceptance by important neighbors like Pakistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRAN, WILLIAM J. JR.
description: CURRAN-William J. Jr. 73. Of State College, PA, died Tuesday, October 23, 2001. Born February 7, 1928 in Brooklyn, son of the late William J. Sr., and Jane F. Horan Curran. Graduate of Fordham University. Retired Lt. JG of The U.S. Navy. Vice President for Bell System of New York. Survived by wife of 49 years, Joan Frances Forker, ten children, Mary Ellen Curran, Nancy McNally, Elizabeth LeBlanc, Jane McGuirk, Joan Frautschi, Kathleen Doyle, William III, Kevin, Dennis, and Christopher, brother Robert P., and seventeen grandchildren.

title: CALENDAR
description: Model Tenements

title: Conceding to Autumn
description: Out in the wood-burning country, the long fire has not yet been lit. Some mornings you can smell the tang of wood smoke mingling with fog in the valleys, but the woodstoves die out again in the tepid afternoons. The wind scatters leaves across the shingles, against windows and clapboards, but it's a warm wind. Some nub of the season began with the first bare trees -- the sudden exposure of so much reptilian bark -- but it won't be confirmed until the woodstoves burn continuously, banked at night, stoked in the morning, right through till spring.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Alternative Schools Sue State
description: A group of 33 alternative high schools in New York State filed a lawsuit yesterday to block a requirement that their students take the Regents exams. The group, which calls itself the New York Performance Standards Consortium and includes 30 schools in New York City, evaluated the academic performance of students at the member schools. They contended that their own standards were often higher than the state's. The state education commissioner has declined to exempt the alternative school students from the Regents tests, which are required for graduation. A hearing is to be held tomorrow in State Supreme Court in Albany. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: Downloading a Pie Recipe At the Refrigerator Door
description: If you have ever wished you could make a videophone call from your refrigerator, your day has come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, THEODORE W.
description: ADLER-Theodore W. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Theodore W. Adler. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Martelle, and to the entire family. James M. Dubin, President Richard Bronstein, Secretary

title: MORE CHECKED FOR ANTHRAX; U.S. OFFICIALS ACKNOWLEDGE UNDERESTIMATING MAIL RISKS
description: Health officials here monitored increasing numbers of people for suspected anthrax today while John E. Potter, the postmaster general, acknowledged that he could not guarantee the safety of the mails. President Bush warned that the nation was ''still under attack.''

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Warnings and Precautions

title: Nightclub With a Chameleon Personality
description: The renovated Exit nightclub, below, is opening to the public on Saturday with mist machines to spray the sweaty, dancing bodies below. The club is also equipped with Gobos -- stencils that can be projected -- so a client's silhouette or logo can be beamed onto the floor. David Marvisi, the owner of the club, designed it to be ever changing, so clients can customize fashion shows and corporate parties. Junior Vasquez, the head D.J., has a booth on a hydraulic lift. The in-house painters can also custom paint the walls (they will be orange for Halloween). ''The Blue Room became the White Room, became the Circus Room -- many colors on the walls,'' said Jessica Geula, the chief operating officer at Exit. Acrobats will perform on some Saturday evenings, swinging from new rigging in the ceiling. A three-tiered Secret Room, not shown, has light boxes embedded in the walls so that the walls can change color, and a lighting truss that spins around to project images on the walls and floor. The renovation cost $8 million. Exit, 610 West 56th Street (11th Avenue), from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m.; admission, $30; (212) 582-8282.

title: Post Office to Install Devices to Destroy Deadly Organisms at Mail-Processing Centers
description: The Postal Service said last night that it would buy devices that would use powerful beams of high-energy electrons to kill anthrax or other deadly organisms in sacks of mail collected and delivered to mail-processing centers.

title: To Get a Handle on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARDINAL HEALTH INC., Dublin, Ohio, a drug wholesaler, said it bought a manufacturing plant in Raleigh, N.C., from the Schering-Plough Corp., Kenilworth, N.J., to expand production of drug formulations. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Chrebet to Sit Out Game With Panthers
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards met with receiver Wayne Chrebet, who quickly got the message: there is no point in lobbying; he is not going to play this week.

title: Key Witness Undergoes Harsh Questioning During Trial of Rabbi Accused in Wife's Killing
description: A lawyer for a prominent rabbi accused of arranging his wife's murder in 1994 contended in court today that the confessed killer and his roommate acted without the rabbi's knowledge.

title: Ivory soap uses a bar that sinks, a $250,000 contest and old-style packaging to increase sales.
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE is embarking on a multimillion-dollar campaign for Ivory soap, one of its oldest and best-known brands, that emphasizes Ivory's purity and heritage.

title: Israel's Self-Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Catastrophe bonds could fill the gaps in reinsurance.
description: THE insurance industry faces claims of at least $40 billion tied to the World Trade Center attacks, and it remains exposed to significant risk from future incidents. Retail insurance companies are considering exclusions for terrorist damage, leaving property owners unable to buy the coverage they need.

title: Footlights
description: Practiced Performer

title: Viacom Posts Loss for Third Quarter
description: Viacom Inc., the owner of the CBS television network, posted a third-quarter loss yesterday because of costs at Blockbuster and lower TV and radio advertising sales after the terrorist attacks.

title: In America; Collateral Damage
description: When the Yankees clinched yet another trip to the World Series by thrashing the Seattle Mariners, 12-3, before 56,000 chanting, screaming fans in the Bronx on Monday night, it was like a giant pep rally for a beleaguered city.

title: Dazed but Game at Furniture Expo
description: WITH buyer attendance off nearly 30 percent and SWAT teams stationed on the roofs, the International Home Furnishings Market opened here last Thursday on a subdued note. There were few flamboyant debuts or blockbuster collections. Visitors saw a surprising range of sectional sofas, some splashes of orange and chartreuse, new striped fabrics and moderate-price sofas that can be ordered in custom lengths.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Sunday about Sareve Dukat, a World Trade Center attack victim who was an employee of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, misidentified the place where she walked the beach on weekends near her family's summer home. It is Long Beach Island, in New Jersey, not Long Beach, N.Y.

title: Unforgotten Soldiers
description: My husband, Neil Levin, the executive director of the Port Authority, was one of the thousands who died at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. I am like others who have lost someone they love. What I have left of my husband are his love, my memories and the place where his life ended.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I know a couple of sports fans; regardless of the tragedy, they still don't want the Yankees to win. I said, 'Come on, lighten up.' I think New York needs a lot of loving right now.''

title: Naming of Hijackers as Saudis May Further Erode Ties to U.S.
description: Fifteen of the 19 men who hijacked four airplanes on Sept. 11 were from Saudi Arabia, Federal authorities have said, a disclosure that is likely to complicate an already tangled and difficult relationship between Washington and Riyadh.

title: Be Alert to Anthrax Clues, Doctors Are Told
description: As federal health officials analyze information about patients with inhalation anthrax, they are urging doctors to look aggressively for the potentially lethal condition even when they see postal workers in the Washington area with mild, vague symptoms.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADLER, SHIRLEY
description: WADLER - Shirley. Highmount, NY. On October 24, 2001. Beloved wife of Herman Wadler, loving mother of Jason, Lisa, Steven and his wife Karen, doting grandmother of Alex. She loved life, loved to ski and dance, and filled her home with warmth and baking. No one left her table wanting.

title: George Feyer, Cafe Pianist And Entertainer, Dies at 92
description: George Feyer, a gifted pianist and delightfully versatile entertainer who charmed Manhattan cafe society at the Carlyle, Stanhope and Waldorf-Astoria hotels for three decades, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: G.P.S. Aids Investigators at Attack Site
description: JOSEPH W. PFIEFER, the battalion chief who was in charge of the fire department's planning and strategy at the World Trade Center site, realized within days of the Sept. 11 attack that recovery workers were having trouble recording the location of evidence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, ROBERT F. LT. FDNY
description: WALLACE-Robert F. Lt. FDNY. Engine 205 Ladder 118 of Woodhaven, NY formerly of Brooklyn, NY in his 43rd year heroically in the line of duty while helping others at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001.
