A member of the FDNY for 21 years. Beloved husband of Nancy, a loving and devoted father of Jeanine, Bobby, Daniel and Alex. Devoted son of Elizabeth and Eugene (ret. Lt. FDNY). Loving brother of Gene, Liza and John. Cherished son and brother-in-law to many. Survived by many loving nieces, nephews and cousins. A memorial mass to celebrate Bob's life will be held on Saturday, October 27, 2001 11:00 AM at St. Thomas the Apostle, 8719 88th Ave., Woodhaven, Queens. Following the memorial mass there will be a gathering of all his friends and family in the school cafeteria. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Bob's name would be appreciated to the NYC Fire Department Burn Center Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, NY 10475.

title: Giants Plan to Make Changes in the Red Zone
description: Sean Payton, the Giants' offensive coordinator, expects scrutiny. He selects every play the Giants run, and since his choices near the goal line in Monday night's loss to Philadelphia were unproductive, Payton accepts that they were unpopular, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMMON, R. THEODORE
description: AMMON-R. Theodore. The Board of Directors and staff of the YMCA of Greater New York are deeply saddened by the death of Ted Ammon. As a member of the Board from 1991 to 1999, Ted demonstrated a deep commitment to youth. His leadership, compassion and enthusiasm helped strengthen the YMCA and inspired substantial support for youth programs. We will miss his wise counsel, his spirit and his friendship. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Ammon family now and always. Robert Annunziata, Chairman Board of Directors Paula L. Gavin, President YMCA of Greater New York

title: Lernout Is Declared Insolvent
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, the once highflying software company brought low by an accounting scandal and management turmoil, was declared insolvent today by a court in Ypres, Belgium, where it is based. The court appointed five liquidators to dispose of the company's Belgian assets.

title: Microsoft Launches Windows XP
description: Following is a compilation of articles from The Times about Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system.

title: Judah Says He Can Undo Tszyu's Punch
description: Zab Judah is no different from most boxers. He is not about to reveal his complete strategy before a big fight. But he made one piece of it very clear today.

title: Yankees Ranked With Any Dynasty
description: The Yankees are trying to become the first team since the 1949-1953 Yankees to win four straight World Series titles, but Manager Joe Torre does not believe they need the fourth straight championship to stamp themselves as one of the greatest teams ever. When Torre was asked if the 1996-2001 Yankees rank with any sports dynasty, not just baseball, he answered affirmatively.

description: Since Sept. 11, more and more Iranians have turned to opposition television channels beamed into the country by satellite, and these channels in turn are stepping up efforts to reform or even topple the strict Islamic religious government.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Lays Off 15% Of Staff
description: Napster, the Internet music service based in Redwood City, Calif., said it was laying off 16 employees, or 15 percent of its work force, to cut costs. Napster, which had 104 employees prior to the layoffs, also said it was redeploying some employees in anticipation of the still-unscheduled start of a for-pay service but declined to say how its remaining work force would be realigned. Napster, whose service has been down since July following a court order, remains in litigation with the five major record labels. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, MARIAN WEINBAUM
description: FISCHMAN-Marian Weinbaum. The faculty, staff, students, and alumni of Columbia University's Health Sciences Division mourn the passing of esteemed colleague & mentor, Dr. Marian Weinbaum Fischman, Professor of Behavioral Biology at The College of Physicians & Surgeons, on October 23, 2001. A pioneer and expert in the field of drug abuse and addiction-and founder of the highly regarded Substance Use Research Center, at The New York State Psychiatric Institute-Dr. Fischman will be missed by the countless students, researchers, professors, and patients, whose lives she enriched with her expertise. We extend our most heartfelt sympathies to Dr. Fischman's widower, Columbia psychiatry professor, Herbert Kleber, M.D.; to her mother, brother, children, and grandchildren; and to her large and loving extended family. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences, Columbia University Health Sciences

title: Francis John Anscombe, 83, Mathematician and Professor
description: Francis John Anscombe, a mathematician who helped computerize statistical analyses while seeking to avoid flawed interpretations of such data, died Oct. 17 at his home in New Haven. He was 83.

title: Some Suppliers Say Kmart Has Pressed For Deals
description: Attention Kmart management: your suppliers are steaming mad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORMAN, ERIC T.
description: NORMAN-Eric T., 89. A man of extraordinary spirit & drive, gifted with a truly great natural voice. Working at WOR in the 40's and 50's Big Band era, nightly Eric announced big name band shows, e.g. ''Harry James Live from the Astor Roof'' and most of Duke Ellington's ''Live from Birdland'' broadcasts. Eric was a staff announcer on the original ''Rambling with Gambling''. His family and friends mourn their loss-he gave the impression that he'd go on forever. Service Friday, October 26, 10:30AM at McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville. Visiting on Thursday, October 25 7-9 PM. We miss you, Eric. Survived by his wife, Alba, and children, Regina, Eric Jr. and Bruce.

title: 'Peaceful Countryside' Has New Meaning
description: MAXINE COLE, 64, lived through World War II. After moving to the East Village in 1983, she witnessed hair-raising street crime. Still, Sept. 11 was something new.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The Senate passed sweeping anti-terrorism legislation today, sending President Bush a measure that would expand the government's ability to conduct electronic surveillance, detain immigrants without charges and penetrate money-laundering banks.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Volvo Posts Loss
description: A leading European truck maker, Volvo, posted a third-quarter loss as the company cut jobs and took charges for closing plants in response to slowing demand. The third-quarter loss was 1.54 billion kronor ($140 million) compared with net income of 369 million kronor ($34.7 million) a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 47 percent, to 41.1 billion kronor ($3.8 billion), including revenue from Renault's truck unit. The chief executive, Leif Johansson, has cut 5,200 jobs this year and increased sales with the addition of Renault's Mack truck unit in the United States and RVI in Europe. Volvo, which is based in Gothenburg, said it had taken charges of 1.4 billion kronor, including the cost of cutting capacity in North America.

title: Attack Victims Are Expected to Turn Law Against Terrorists
description: One important battle in the war on terrorism is likely to be fought in American courts through civil lawsuits against terrorists, the countries that helped them and the individuals and organizations who financed them, lawyers say.

description: BERNSTEIN-Sol. Two years today in a world without you, and now mother is gone too. To the kindest father ever, my heart will always see you and miss you. BB

title: Uzbek Border to Open for Afghan Aid
description: A United Nations delegation and Uzbek officials agreed today on a plan that would open Uzbekistan's sealed border with Afghanistan to provide relief aid to Afghan civilians.

title: Terror Bill Clears House; Moves to Senate
description: The House today overwhelmingly passed sweeping antiterrorism legislation including new attacks on money laundering. The bill stalled for the day in the Senate, but was scheduled for a final vote on Thursday, when adoption is all but certain.

title: Errant Cluster Bomb Leaves Danger Behind, U.N. Says
description: A United Nations official said today that a cluster bomb used in an American bombing raid early Tuesday on Herat, in western Afghanistan, had left a village near a Taliban military camp strewn with deadly unexploded ''bomblets'' that were yellow in color and the size of soft drink cans.

title: Hallowed Ground Zero; Competing Plans Hope to Shape a Trade Center Memorial
description: How will the horror be remembered? Since the World Trade Center attack on Sept. 11 there have been no shortage of ideas for a memorial for the thousands of people who died there.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Plattsburgh: Scout Leader Sentenced
description: A former Boy Scout leader and head of an elementary-school organization has been sentenced to 60 years in prison for sexually abusing seven boys, the Clinton County district attorney said. The defendant, David Doherty, 36, of Dannemora, was sentenced Tuesday after being convicted in August of 18 charges of sexually abusing boys, ages 8 to 13, from the summer of 1997 through the fall of 2000. The victims were neighbors of Mr. Doherty's but not scouts or members of the elementary-school organization, the district attorney, Penelope C. Clute, said. All of the boys testified against him, she said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about J&R Music and Computer World, which has reopened after cleaning up damage caused by the attack on the nearby World Trade Center, included an outdated reference to the company's layoff policy. On Oct. 18, after an owner discussed the business in an interview but before the article appeared, 48 people were indeed laid off, J&R's first such action.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOTMAN, NORMAN, M.D.
description: GOOTMAN-Norman, M.D. The founding Chief and Chief of Pediatric Cardiology at Long Island Jewish Medical Center from 1965 to 1988. He was Professor of Pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and made seminal contributions to the medical literature on pediatric cardiology. He established the first Pediatric Catheterization Laboratory and Pediatric Intensive Care Unit at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. His talent, dedication and hard work contributed in great measure to the establishment of the Schneider Children's Hospital of Long Island Jewish Medical Center. He was a compassionate and dedicated physician and a gentle man who will be greatly missed by his family, friends and colleagues. Philip Lanzkowsky, M.D., Chief of Staff, Schneider Children's Hospital, NS-LIJ Health System

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Insurer's Net Plummets 81% After Attack
description: American International Group Inc. said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings slumped 81 percent, hurt by $820 million of claims from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and merger expenses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEVLIN, ALEXANDER
description: SHEVLIN-Alexander. Of Atlantic City, NJ, died on October 20, 2001. Formerly of Philadelphia and Honolulu. Son of the late Isador and Celia Shavelenko and husband of the late Jean Korn Shevlin. He is survived by his sister Sally and her husband Abbe, and their two sons David Edward and Ian Seth, and numerous cousins. Dr. Shevlin was a true Renaissance man. He loved and was touched by people, the arts, flowers and animals. In Philadelphia, from 1961 to 1971, he hosted an educational TV adult literacy program called ''Operation Alphabet.'' He also edited a curriculum for the Philadelphia school system on teaching the Holocaust. Dr. Shevlin's body was willed to science and there will be no formal service for him. If you wish to visit his home in Atlantic City, his sister will be in residence on November 2, from 2 to 7 PM, November 3, from 10 AM to 7 PM, and November 4, from 10 AM to 8 PM. Dr. Shevlin will be remembered lovingly by family and friends for his cheerfulness, kindness and charm. The world will be a poorer place without him. Donations in his memory may be the Americn Diabetes Association, or any animal humane association of your choice.

title: New York's 2012 Bid Makes Cut
description: The United States Olympic Committee is expected to announce today that New York City is one of its candidates to be the host of the 2012 Summer Olympics.

description: With Election Day less than two weeks off, the race for governor of Virginia has tightened as voters preoccupied with the war on terror finally take some time to focus on political personalities and issues.

description: For a team with a craving to shine before a national television audience and hoping to show the Bowl Championship Series that its ranking system is flawed, the University of Miami needed the second-half work of a freshman to put an exclamation point on its case tonight.

title: The Stormy and Productive History of the Jews in Portugal Since Ancient Times
description: Portugal does not spring immediately to mind as a powerful force in Jewish history. Yet Jews and Portuguese have had important interactions -- some good, some not so -- since before Portugal was established as a nation in the 12th century.

title: COCA-COLA JOINT VENTURE BUYS PHILIPPINE DRINK COMPANY
description: San Miguel, the Philippine food and beverage company, and its joint-venture partner Coca-Cola agreed yesterday to pay 14 billion pesos ($269 million) for the Philippines' second-largest soft drink company, Cosmos. The purchase, which defeated a bid by PepsiCo, will give the joint venture, Coca-Cola Bottlers Philippines, a 90 percent share of the Philippines' $1-billion-a-year soft drink market. The deal was approved when Cosmos's majority owner, the RMF Corporation, agreed to accept a lower offer after San Miguel discovered that some Cosmos equipment was below Coca-Cola's standards. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLOVIN, WILLARD BAYER

Interment services were private. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made in his name to The Masters School Community Service Program, 49 Clinton Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. 10522, or Scenic Hudson, Inc., 9 Vassar Street, Poughkeepsie, N.Y 12601.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Ex-Official Indicted
description: Paulo Maluf, a former presidential candidate who has also been governor of the country's largest state and mayor of its largest city, Sao Paulo, has been indicted on charges that he did not declare election campaign donations in 1992 and 1998. Mr. Maluf, who said it was his party's responsibility, not his, to file the donation reports, is also being investigated on charges that he funneled bribes from contractors to secret accounts overseas. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Ridge Deflects Pleas to Help The Cities Pay Security Costs
description: Tom Ridge, director of the Office of Homeland Security, turned away pleas from the nation's mayors today for help in paying millions of dollars in overtime to police and firefighters, even as he praised those same people for guarding the ''front line of domestic security.''

The winning players get a Cuban sandwich and a can of soda. The losing team gets to watch the winners gobble up a Cuban sandwich and guzzle a can of soda.

title: Salmonella Is Found in Vials Sent to Clinton
description: Plastic vials containing salmonella, a bacteria that is one of the most common causes of food poisoning, were sent this month to Bill Clinton at his Harlem office, the Secret Service said yesterday.

title: Boggs Leaves The Devil Rays
description: Wade Boggs, a five-time American League batting champion and a 12-time All-Star third baseman, resigned as hitting coach of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays after one season, citing a desire to spend more time with his family, the team said.

description: The director of the agency that runs Logan International Airport in Boston, who has been criticized since the airport was the departure point for the two hijacked jetliners that hit the World Trade Center, resigned yesterday.

description: Cantor Fitzgerald said yesterday that it had started distributing more than $45 million in bonuses to the families of employees lost in the World Trade Center attacks.

title: WPP Is Rebuffed in Effort to Break a Deal
description: The WPP Group, the giant British advertising agency company, had a setback today in its attempt to abandon a deal to acquire the Tempus Group, a media-buying concern, when British regulators ruled that it must proceed. The deal is worth more than $620 million at current exchange rates.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It must have taken months to sweep out the losing betting slips, but somehow a busy OTB parlor evolved into Tan Da. The two-level restaurant, named after a Vietnamese poet, has a lounge sensibility, and a shadowy, seductive decor, which is not surprising, since two of the owners were partners in Moomba, the restaurant of the moment for at least several moments before it closed this spring. The silk throw pillows on black banquettes are mauve. Wicker light shades that look like birdcages cast spider-web shadows on the ceiling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINGOLD, NORMAN S.
description: FEINGOLD-Norman S., 78. On Oct. 24, 2001 after a long and courageous fight against lymphoma. Born in Brooklyn, NY, December 11th, 1922. Most dearly beloved husband of Natalie (Arond). Cherished father of Carol Feingold Neiditch, Roberta Palant (Hy Shuster), Elise Feingold. Proud and loving grandfather of Shana, Emily, David, Jana and Mitchell. Predeceased by his sister Ruth Kopilow. Graduate of CCNY School of Engineering (1943) & member of the SKT fraternity family. Innovative, introspective, logical & analytical. An independent person of high moral standards and integrity, he lived by his principles and imparted them to his children and grandchildren. True to his personal heritage and proud supporter of American manufacturing industry. Mentor to many. He was highly respected and left a lasting impression on everyone who met him. Truly one of the Greatest Generation. Contributions may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY 10605 or the American Red Magen David for Israel, 888 7th Avenue, Suite 403, NY, NY 10102. Services today 11:30AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Call For Election Overhaul
description: A state election task force has submitted 29 recommendations to Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon after a 10-month review of election processes. One proposal would allow voters to cast absentee ballots for any reason for 29 days before an election; another would let voters with questionable eligibility cast provisional ballots. Secretary of State Sue Anne Gilroy said the changes would cost up to $30 million. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

description: Saying they want to cut into the lucrative market dominated by ticket scalpers, the producers of ''The Producers'' are preparing to set aside at least 50 seats every performance and charge the unprecedented amount of $480 a ticket.

title: Traditions From Australia Face Contemporary Life
description: Bangarra Dance Theater is a modern-dance troupe unlike any other. Its members have been trained in several dance techniques. But what makes the group special is that its works are inspired by the cultural traditions of Australian Aborigines.

title: Going In, Diamondbacks Stress Defense
description: Before the first game of the World Series on Saturday, each member of the Arizona Diamondbacks will get a condensed scouting report on the Yankees. Manager Bob Brenly will meet Friday with his team's top scout to decide what will be included in the report, but his players already know one thing: they cannot make mistakes.

title: People Who Live in Glass Houses Shouldn't Stow Ghosts
description: ''Thirteen Ghosts'' is a production so mammoth in its stupidity that it took two studios, Warner Brothers and Columbia Pictures, to wrestle it to the screen. It is provisionally a remake of the old William Castle B picture, and as they say when handing out grades in freshman English courses, this kind of B throws off the entire curve.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Land Reform Roils Communists
description: Communist legislators stormed the podium and unfurled banners in Parliament in a protest aimed at stopping a proposal that would allow the state to sell its vast farmland holdings to private buyers. The 450-member Parliament has 113 Communists, and the Interfax news agency reported that nearly all of them took part in the protest, holding banners that read ''To sell land is to sell the homeland.'' Ukraine, once a Soviet breadbasket, has 81.5 million acres of fertile farmland but efforts to overhaul the Soviet collective-farm system have gone slowly and production is low.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Anthrax Scare On Tokyo Subway
description: One of Tokyo's main subway lines was shut down for nearly an hour during rush hour yesterday evening after a white powder was reportedly found in an underground bathroom, prompting fears of anthrax. Traffic was restored to normal on the Hibiya Line a short while after emergency workers removed the powder and determined that it was probably not toxic. Tokyo suffered a major chemical weapons attack in 1995 when the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect released sarin nerve gas on several subway lines, including the Hibiya Line, killing 12 people and injuring 5,500. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Level 3 Communications To Cut 750 Jobs
description: Level 3 Communications plans to cut 750 jobs, or about 17 percent of its work force. Level 3 Communications, a money-losing telecommunications company, said the cost of the reductions would be reflected in its fourth-quarter earnings. For the third quarter, Level 3 Communications said it lost $531 million, or $1.42 a share, compared with a loss of $351 million, or 96 cents, in the quarter a year ago. Revenue rose 10 percent, to $375 million. Level 3 Communications, created in a 1998 spinoff by the construction and mining company Peter Kiewit Sons, took on $8 billion in debt to build its United States network.

Frankly, we think its just what the doctor ordered.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: President Reins In Soldiers
description: President Olusegun Obasanjo has ordered soldiers to stop any activity in the state of Benue where civilians were reportedly killed in reprisal attacks by the military. The state governor, George Akume, said between 120 and 130 civilians had been killed by soldiers angry over last week's killing of 19 soldiers. The killings, which were said to have taken place in remote villages now under military control, could not be confirmed independently. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hempstead: Wage Law Under Scrutiny
description: Just over one week after the Village of Hempstead unanimously passed a so-called living wage law, some of its officials tried to repeal it, although they failed for now. The law, which requires minimum hourly wages of $9 with medical benefits or $10.25 without for village employees, people working under village contracts and employees whose companies receive village subsidies, was approved Oct. 16. Mayor James A. Garner said the law was passed with the understanding that its scope would later be narrowed, but that village trustees have been unable to agree on how to amend it. At a special session yesterday, a motion to begin repealing the law failed by a 2-to-2 vote. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Choosing Bells or Whistles
description: ''Most things in the movie business are disappointments,'' said Ben Feingold, president of the Columbia TriStar Motion Picture Group. DVD isn't one of them. Industry figures show that the average price of DVD players, expected to be in 25 million homes by the end of the year, is about $180, down from about $500 when the format was introduced in 1997. No one can be sure of anything in the current economic climate, but retailers consider $200 a price for the people.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Renault Lowers Forecast
description: France's second-largest carmaker, Renault, reported its second profit warning in five months. The company warned that profit would be little changed as demand declines in Europe and in Argentina, where Renault manufactures Clio small cars and Kangoo small trucks. Shares in Renault fell as much as 9.5 percent in the third quarter, for a total drop of 37 percent this year. Most of Renault's profits are now coming from its 36.8 percent Nissan Motor stake, which it acquired in 1999. Nissan is, however, expected to announce as soon as next week that it will acquire more than 10 percent of Renault, The Financial Times reported.

title: 128 Missing in Swiss Tunnel Fire; 11 Confirmed Dead
description: The Swiss police said today that 128 people were listed as missing and 11 had been confirmed dead a day after a truck collision set off an inferno inside the world's second longest tunnel, one of the main north-south links through the Swiss Alps.

title: Magnificence With the Flair Of a Warhol
description: William Beckford (1760-1844) was the Andy Warhol of his day, a self-conscious aesthete, compulsive collector of art and furniture, an author, designer and famous style maven. ''Beckford is largely legend yet truly legendary,'' wrote Timothy Mowl, one of his many biographers. ''He was, by his taste and by his flamboyant lifestyle, the ice breaker in the frozen sea of 18th-century English classicism and the morning star of the English Romantic movement.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBMAN, BERNARD

Mr. Liebman was a staff sergeant during World War II and served as a photographer in the Army Signal Corps. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: More Layoffs At Bank
description: Germany's second-largest bank, HVB Group, formerly HypoVereinsbank, will cut 2,200 jobs in addition to the 7,500 already announced this year. The third-quarter earnings, adjusted for an acquisition, fell to 68 million euros ($61 million) from 267 million euros ($239 million). The group hopes to save 1.2 billion euros ($1.1 billion) through the layoffs and by shutting one-third of its German branches. German banks have announced a total of about 22,000 job cuts this year. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Another Postal Worker Contracts Inhaled Anthrax
description: A mail handler at a State Department postal center in suburban Virginia has anthrax in his lungs, officials said today. He is the fifth postal worker in the Washington area to have a confirmed case of the disease and the first who does not work at the capital's main mail processing center on Brentwood Road.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Police Say Abduction Was Thwarted
description: The abduction of an 8-year-old girl whose father was attempting to fly her to Morocco was thwarted by the Stamford police and the girl returned safely to her mother, the police said. The father, Nourddine El-Hardouzi, 41, originally from Morocco, was arrested at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday, Capt. Richard Conklin of the Stamford police said. The investigation began Monday morning when the girl's mother, whose name was not immediately released, told the police that her estranged husband, who had visitation rights, had not returned their daughter Sunday night. Mr. Hardouzi will be extradited from New York to Stamford on Nov. 1 and charged with custodial interference, a felony, the police said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Anthrax Traces Found at C.I.A. and Mail Center for High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Small amounts of anthrax have been found at a warehouse that handles mail for the United States Supreme Court, at the Central Intelligence Agency headquarters in Virginia and at an Army research center in Maryland, the authorities said today.

title: The Unveiling of Windows XP
description: Microsoft, the software giant that manages to be one of America's most successful and most controversial corporations, is introducing its latest operating system this week. Unlike the debut of Windows 95 six years ago, the appearance of Windows XP hasn't turned into a national event. The subdued reaction says a good deal about the changed state of the computer business. The information age has matured a lot since 1995.

title: ANTITERRORISM BILL PASSES; U.S. GETS EXPANDED POWERS
description: The Senate passed sweeping antiterrorism legislation today, sending President Bush a measure that would expand the government's ability to conduct electronic surveillance, detain immigrants without charges and penetrate money-laundering banks.

title: At Ground Zero, Rebuild and Honor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Patient With Powers
description: In ''K-Pax,'' Kevin Spacey, above left, plays a character who is either a disturbed mental patient or a being from a distant galaxy. Jeff Bridges, right, is his doctor, who clearly needs to heal himself.

title: Yanks Work Out in Phoenix
description: Until this World Series, the schedule had never brought the Yankees to Bank One Ballpark. When they worked out tonight after arriving in Phoenix about 3:15 p.m., it was the first time many players had been to the stadium.

title: An Overloaded Hoist Is Suspected in Scaffolding Collapse
description: Investigators looking into the deadly scaffold collapse at a Gramercy Park office building said yesterday that they were reviewing whether the accident had been caused by a makeshift hoist that was overloaded and acted like a counterweight, pulling the framework away from the building's facade and toppling it.

title: Officials, Expanding Search, Warn Against Drawing Conclusions on Anthrax Source
description: Investigators said yesterday that they were broadening their search for the source of the highly refined anthrax that has killed three people and infected at least four others.

title: INSURANCE REGULATORS GIVE LLOYD'S A BREAK
description: In yet another twist, American insurance regulators said yesterday that because Lloyd's of London was facing liquidity problems in connection with claims from the World Trade Center attacks, the company would be granted an exception to the rules governing its operations in the United States. The regulators said Lloyd's, based in Britain, would have four and a half months to set aside an amount equal to its estimated billions of dollars of losses in the attacks as a guarantee that claims will be paid. For now, Lloyd's will be permitted to set aside 60 percent of the money. On Monday, the regulators said they would be flexible toward Lloyd's. The next day, they said no exceptions would be made. Yesterday, they reversed themselves again. Lloyd's said it was pleased to have the situation clarified. Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Domain Injunction Lifted
description: A court-ordered injunction preventing 58,000 ''.biz'' Internet addresses from being assigned was lifted yesterday, according to the company that manages the .biz domain, NeuLevel. The injunction was issued earlier this month in connection with a lawsuit contending that NeuLevel's process for distributing the new Internet addresses constituted an illegal lottery. The injunction affected only addresses for which NeuLevel had received more than one application. It was lifted after the plaintiffs failed to post a $1.6 million bond ordered by the judge to cover any losses if NeuLevel wins the case, which will still proceed.

title: Former Top Chicago Detective Admits to Leading Theft Ring
description: A former chief of detectives in the Chicago Police Department pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court to charges of running a sophisticated jewel-theft ring across several states for more than a decade.

title: On Smuggling Routes, There Are Good Taliban and Bad
description: The smugglers come down from the mountains each morning at sunrise, their donkeys in tow, laden with rice and tea and cooking oil.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckold's Nest
description: It takes a singing dead man to bring a spark of life to ''Thou Shalt Not,'' the limp and lugubrious musical tale of lethal passion that opened last night at the Plymouth Theater. Portraying a murder victim who returns to haunt his killers in the show's second act, a young actor named Norbert Leo Butz provides this fascinatingly ill-assembled production with something it has been aching for since its first scene: a shot of showbiz adrenaline.

title: Ford Settles Ignition Suits By Extending Warranties
description: A California judge yesterday approved a proposal by the Ford Motor Company to settle lawsuits in five states by reimbursing current and former owners who replaced flawed ignition systems on millions of cars and trucks.

title: Bloomberg Drive Takes a Carnival Twist
description: As Michael R. Bloomberg stood on the back of a blue Chevrolet pickup truck, Al Leiter and Mark Johnson of the Mets at his side and salsa tunes playing over a loudspeaker, he pulled off his suit jacket and shouted toward a campaign worker holding a video camera.

title: How to Regulate The Trade in Toxins
description: The anthrax attacks through the mail, which so far have killed three people and sickened nine, have shown clearly that more must be done to prevent deadly germs from falling into the wrong hands. Although anthrax bacteria can be obtained from natural sources like diseased animals, it is far easier for terrorists to steal virulent strains from a laboratory freezer or to order them by fax or letter under false pretenses.

title: ChevronTexaco's Third Quarter Surpasses Analysts' Estimates
description: The ChevronTexaco Corporation, created two weeks ago by the Chevron Corporation's $45.8 billion acquisition of Texaco Inc., said third-quarter earnings fell at both companies because of lower oil and natural gas prices.

title: Jupiter, Internet Research Firm, Is Being Bought by NetRatings
description: Jupiter Media Metrix, the Internet research firm that once was one of the pillars of Silicon Alley in New York, agreed yesterday to sell itself to the much smaller NetRatings of Milpitas, Calif., in Silicon Valley.

title: A Clock Strikes 13 and Leads to a Victorian Garden
description: Fans of the endlessly intriguing puzzle that is time travel can list a new destination, at least through Nov. 4. It is the New Victory Theater, where ''Tom's Midnight Garden'' mingles past and present to touching effect in an award-winning play based on a prize-winning novel.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What we're trying to do here is strike a blow at the heart of the scalping operation. The scalpers and their profits serve no one but the scalpers. Those monies belong to the people who created the show, pure and simple.''

title: Tokyo Show Is Smaller and Subdued, but Still Outlandish
description: FEAR kept many industry officials and journalists at home, but previews of the Tokyo Motor Show went on this week, a bit subdued but with the show's usual distinctive blend of high technology, wild ideas and basic instincts.

title: Gambling Bill Is Questioned On Constitutional Grounds
description: The sweeping gambling bill passed Wednesday night by the Legislature is likely to be tied up in court for years, with opponents, some state lawmakers and legal experts saying that it might violate the State Constitution's restrictions on gambling in several ways.

title: WorldCom Net Slips 47% as Sales Skid at MCI
description: WorldCom Inc. said today that its third-quarter earnings declined 47 percent after sales dropped at the MCI Group's consumer long-distance phone business and profit fell at the company's data and international unit.

title: Changed Panama Banks Root Out Terror Funds
description: When United States officials recently asked Panamanian banks to search for suspicious accounts that might have been used to hide terrorists' funds, responses came quickly. Had the same request been made a year ago, it could have languished for months because of lax banking laws that had landed Panama on an international blacklist.

title: Schilling Builds on Father's Influence
description: There will be more than 48,000 fans at Bank One Ballpark when Curt Schilling throws the first pitch of the World Series on Saturday. At least one of the seats will be empty.

title: SKECHERS U.S.A. SAYS IT WILL CUT 5% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Skechers U.S.A., which makes boots, sneakers and sandals, said yesterday that it planned to cut 5 percent of its work force and close its mail-order division. The number of affected jobs was not disclosed. Skechers announced the cuts as it reported its third-quarter results. The company said its income fell to $11.4 million, or 30 cents a share, from $15.3 million, or 40 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 40 percent, to $287.9 million from $205.7 million, the company said.

title: Another Postal Worker Contracts Inhaled Anthrax
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  A mail handler at a State Department postal center in suburban Virginia has anthrax in his lungs, officials said today. He is the fifth postal worker in the Washington area to have a confirmed case of the disease and the first who does not work at the capital's main mail processing center on Brentwood Road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERRICO, DONATO
description: ERRICO-Donato. To my incredible, loving father-in-law. Thank you for all the wonderful times & memories. You have always been so special. Love always and forever. Robyn Errico

title: In a No Man's Land of Memories and Loss
description: AUSTERLITZ

title: False Claims, Then an Arrest
description: On Sept. 15, a woman told New York City authorities that her three siblings had been in a meeting at Windows on the World on the morning of Sept. 11. She filed missing persons reports, tried to get money from a city agency and eventually collected $1,000 from the Veterans Administration, claiming that her siblings had left several children she would have to care for. She also received $2,000 from a charitable group in Westchester County, where she lives, said Anne Marie Corbalis, a spokeswoman for the Westchester County district attorney's office.

title: Ericsson Cites Weak Demand in Latin America for Third-Quarter Loss
description: Ericsson A.B., the large Swedish wireless communications equipment company, reported a third-quarter loss yesterday after sales declined nearly 20 percent because of weakness in Latin America and other markets.

description: To the Editor:

description: Translated by Nicholas de Lange

title: Winterfest Hotel Discounts
description: The Kimpton Hotel Group, with 35 boutique hotels in 12 cities in the United States, is offering Winterfest rates that are 30 percent lower than a year ago. The prices, valid Nov. 1 to March 31, 2002, are good for a double room and do not include tax. In San Francisco, for example, the Clarion Bedford, Cartwright and Monticello Inn are $99 a night; the Monaco and the Tuscan Inn are $149; and the Juliana, Vintage Court and Serrano are $119. In Seattle, the Vintage Park is $150 and the Alexis is $160. The Topaz and Hotel Rouge in Washington are each $109, and the Monaco in New Orleans is $89. Specify the Winterfest rate when booking, at (800) 546-7866 or www.kimptongroup.com .

title: Straight to Video
description: Other new titles of interest, some of which may have had a theater release, appeared on television or been on videocassette or DVD in earlier editions.

title: Anti-Taliban Forces Say Light U.S. Strikes Lift Foes' Morale
description: The American plane roared overhead at 1:30 p.m. today, and Shir Muhammad and his soldiers in the Northern Alliance paid little attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHER, DANIEL L.
description: MAHER-Daniel L., 50. Was a victim of the World Trade Center attack. Beloved husband of 26 years to Kathy. Devoted father & father-in-law to Daniel and Lisa, Joseph and his girlfriend, Renee. Cherished son to Jeanne and the late Raymond Maher, and son-inlaw of the late Frances and Anton Stolz. Dear brother to Raymond, James and Jeanne. Loving uncle to many nieces & nephews. Dan will always be remembered in our hearts. A memorial mass will be celebrated on Saturday, October 27, 1 PM, at St. Gregory the Great Church, in Hamilton Square, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Wednesday about a biohazard crew moving equipment after the detection of anthrax misstated the status of the House office buildings. All three were still closed on Wednesday (two were reopened yesterday).

title: 'Austerlitz'
description: Translated by Anthea Bell

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Rebuffed Republican To Run Again
description: Having received a cold shoulder from the Republican Party, Merrill Cook, left, said he intended to retake the seat in Congress he lost last year by running as an independent next year. Mr. Cook, a two-term representative, said he chose to leave the party after Representative Thomas M. Davis III of Virginia, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said he hoped Mr. Cook would not run. Mr. Cook was the only Republican incumbent to lose in a primary in 2000; the victor lost the general election to Jim Matheson, a Democrat and son of a former Utah governor, Scott Matheson. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: The Sounds Of Peace
description: With roaring saws and power tools, British soldiers began dismantling four of their surveillance posts and bases along the Irish border as part of Britain's pledge to reduce its military presence after the Irish Republican Army announced on Tuesday that it had begun to get rid of some of its weapons. The British Army will maintain some of its remaining 11 watchtowers to combat the threat of violence from dissident republican paramilitaries. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Taliban Foe Tells of Calm, Quiet Assassins
description: The wounded sole survivor of a suicidal attack on Ahmed Shah Massoud, the legendary commander of Afghan forces opposed to the Taliban, rolled up in a wheelchair today to give his first public account of the day Afghanistan lost perhaps its greatest guerrilla fighter.

title: Classical Music and Dance Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Citing Deteriorating Operations, Moody's Cuts AT&T's Credit Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service reduced the credit rating of AT&T yesterday to a level that may make it more difficult for the telephone company to issue commercial paper.

title: Bin Laden Family Liquidates Holdings With Carlyle Group
description: The Saudi family of Osama bin Laden is severing its financial ties with the Carlyle Group, a private investment firm known for its connections to influential Washington political figures, executives who have been briefed on the decision said today.

title: Ernest Briggs
description: Anita Shapolsky Gallery

title: After a Week of Reassurances, Ridge's Anthrax Message Is Grim
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  After a week of sending calming messages about the threat posed by the anthrax in a letter that was opened on Capitol Hill, Tom Ridge, President Bush's director of homeland security, said publicly for the first time today what others have said in private: the germs were very pure, very concentrated and very deadly.

title: Daniel Wildenstein, 84, Head of Art-World Dynasty, Dies
description: Daniel Wildenstein, the French-born head of one of the art world's wealthiest and most secretive dynasties who was also a prominent figure in thoroughbred horse-racing circles, died on Tuesday in a Paris hospital, the Wildenstein Institute announced here today. He was 84.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 8 Indicted In Weapons Sales
description: Eight associates of the Bonanno organized crime family have been indicted on racketeering charges, accused of selling weapons, narcotics trafficking, loansharking, and gambling, the Manhattan district attorney's office announced yesterday. The defendants were accused of selling 185 weapons -- including machine guns, silencers, and bayonets -- to an undercover detective posing as a drug dealer. The office said the leaders of the group were Fred Kuletsky, 62, of Mount Vernon, and his son, Michael, 39, of Yorktown.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Nursing Home To Close
description: In a rare move, state authorities have told a nursing home it has a month to find new facilities for its 90 residents after it failed to correct what authorities called serious deficiencies, including failure to adequately treat bedsores and properly follow up after a patient's alleged rape. The 37-year-old home, The Waters of Syracuse, will also stop receiving Medicare and Medicaid. Robert Kenny, a State Health Department spokesman, said the decision came after an April 2001 inspection found 23 violations and a series of follow-up inspections found some of these violations had not been remedied. Teresa Blumberg, the home's administrator, said all but one of the violations had been remedied and that the home planned to challenge the state's action. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Bayer Halves Price for Cipro, But Rivals Offer Drugs Free
description: When Bayer agreed on Wednesday to sell 100 million tablets of its anthrax medicine, Cipro, to the government for 95 cents apiece, Bayer and the Bush administration said the deal assured an ample supply at a very low price.

title: 'Extreme Canvas'
description: Cavin-Morris Gallery

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Talks With South In Doubt
description: The government rejected a South Korean proposal for holding the next round of cabinet-level talks at Mount Myohyang near the North Korean capital, Pyongyang. The North insists on the remote resort area of Mount Kumkang as the site of the talks, scheduled to start Sunday and last for three days. At a meeting last month in South Korea, Northern and Southern officials agreed to meet again in Pyongyang but the North now wants all talks at Mount Kumkang. South Koreans say the North does not want Southerners mingling with Northerners in Pyongyang.

title: Doing the Right Thing By Taking to the Road
description: ''Tenacity is an art form,'' says Eric Saperston, the star, director and producer of ''The Journey,'' a shape-shifting documentary. With his round face and quick grin, he looks like Spike the Bulldog from the old Warner Brothers cartoons, and like a bulldog he is determined to get what he wants. This mild and sprightly documentary goes through more changes than any one person should be able to cram into a 90-minute nonfiction film.

title: A Mosaic of Plots, a City in Violent Flux
description: In his unsettling urban panorama, ''The Town Is Quiet,'' the director Robert Guediguian invests the French port city of Marseille with the same epic sense of drama that infused Robert Altman's ''Nashville.'' Raw, wrenching and more starkly tragic than Mr. Altman's satire, ''The Town Is Quiet'' evokes a similar vision of a city as a teeming organism in violent, spasmodic flux.

title: National Briefing | Washington: G.O.P. Upbeat At Fund-Raiser
description: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, chairman of the Republican Governors Association, insisted that participants at the group's fund-raising dinner last night were content to have Vice President Dick Cheney as speaker. President Bush backed out on the eve of the event. ''It's the right decision,'' Mr. Rowland said, explaining that it was better for Mr. Bush to tend to the war on terrorism than to raise $1 million. ''Our members will be happy as clams at high tide with the vice president.'' But Ronald Kaufman, the association's finance chairman, said some 20 donors of about 1,000 participants asked about getting their $1,000 checks back. Richard L. Berke (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Slide, Jeremy, Slide, Slide
description: SLIDE, Jeremy, slide, for you carry the weight of history on your broad back.

title: Afghan Gathering in Pakistan Backs Future Role for King
description: A two-day conclave of Afghan leaders in the frontier Pakistani city of Peshawar concluded today with the approval of a resolution that calls for a post-Taliban government of peace, harmony between rival ethnic and political groups, and the return of the former king.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLER, KATZ, MAY
description: MILLER-KATZ-May. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, November 3 at 3:30 PM at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th St.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMUELS, HOWARD J.
description: SAMUELS-Howard J., 10/26/84. How deeply missed you are in these perilous times-and always. See you, partner. B.B.F.

description: To the Editor:

title: West's Envoys Travel to Seek An Alternate To Taliban
description: As military strikes against the Taliban government in Afghanistan have intensified, so has the urgency for international diplomacy in search of a government to replace it.

title: Microsoft Launches Windows XP
description: Following is a compilation of articles from The Times about Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system.

title: Senate Drug Aid Cut Upsets White House
description: The Senate has voted to cut $164 million from the Bush administration's counterdrug program for the Andean region, and administration officials voiced concern today that the reductions could jeopardize efforts to assist Colombia in its battle against drug-financed rebels and to avoid the spread of violence and corruption.

title: For Now, Port Authority to Keep Offices Out of Lower Manhattan
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which moved to temporary offices in Jersey City after its headquarters at the World Trade Center were destroyed, said yesterday that it would split its nearly 2,000 displaced workers between offices in Manhattan and Newark.

title: Magic Transforms Ordinary Materials Into Extraordinary Works
description: The survey of the maverick artist Tom Friedman, now at the New Museum for Contemporary Art in SoHo, is not on first encounter a very pretty sight, or a very cohesive one either. But perhaps that is to be expected.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Arnold Hatters, one of the businesses on Eighth Avenue that would be displaced to make way for a new headquarters for The New York Times Company, misstated the name of a man handling a homburg hat. He was Fitz G. King, a salesman who was steaming the homburg, not Jack Maple, a customer. (Mr. Maple, who died last August, was a regular customer who favored that style of hat.)

title: Dyspeptic in Paradise, as Life Falls Apart; Then ...
description: If there is paradise on earth, Irwin Winkler's nervous tear-jerker ''Life as a House'' locates that heaven in an affluent Southern California community where the cliffside view of the Pacific yields the most breathtaking sunsets this side of a Hallmark card. How could anyone be miserable in such a place, you wonder? But when we first meet the movie's main characters, they seem as dyspeptic as the affluent suburbanites of ''American Beauty.'' And the film's early scenes offer a convincingly nasty portrait of a spoiled upper-middle-class extended family consumed by gnawing resentments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, MARIAN, PH.D.
description: FISCHMAN-Marian, Ph.D. We are much saddened by the death of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. Marian Fischman, who, throughout a productive and distinguished career, made unique and valuable contributions to research on substance abuse. Her research was innovative and vital, and the methodological advances from her laboratory over the years have been adopted by many colleagues engaged in drug abuse research nationwide. As a colleague, a mentor and a friend, Dr. Fischman was an inspiration to all. She was a rare person. John M. Oldham, M.D. Director New York State Psychiatric Institute

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PINE, ARTHUR (ARTIE)
description: PINE-Arthur (Artie). October 26, 2000. Our friendship began in 1946. We loved him and miss him so much. My daily reports are going nowhere. Leonard Wurzel

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Defendant To Be Tried As Adult
description: One of 13 teenagers accused of fatally beating a homeless man will be tried as an adult, a state judge has ruled. The teenager, Freddy Rivera, 17, faces at least 30 years in prison if convicted of murder in the death of the homeless man, Hector Robles, 42. Prosecutors, who want to prosecute all of the defendants as adults, say the defendants punched, kicked and hit Mr. Robles over the head with a beer bottle on June 20. Mr. Rivera's lawyer, Adolph J. Galluccio, said yesterday that the witness against his client was a co-defendant with little credibility. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Nets Rout Knicks
description: Jason Kidd was not just running the fast break tonight, he was leading the stampede. The Nets dominated the Knicks, 100-84, at the Pepsi Center. Kidd had a team-high 11 assists, all in the first half, and a team-high 11 rebounds, finishing short of a triple double with 8 points. Kenyon Martin had five dunks off Kidd's alley-oop passes and finished with 21 points, shooting 9 of 13.

title: Safety Questions Remain About Air at Ground Zero
description: Air quality in Lower Manhattan has gradually improved since the early days after the World Trade Center disaster last month, when a gritty, acrid residue of combustion and dust hung over parts of the city like a shroud. But at certain times, under certain conditions -- usually for brief periods -- the bad air still returns.

title: Another Sept. 11 Casualty: Class Trips for Some Pupils
description: At least one New York City school district has canceled class field trips beginning this week because of traffic congestion created by police checkpoints and frequent disruptions in subway service caused by a spate of false anthrax scares.

title: Great at Slogans but Shy With the Ladies
description: ''On the Line,'' a pleasant wisp of a romantic comedy starring Lance Bass and Joey Fatone from the pop group 'N Sync, is a movie that means business: specifically the shoe business. The main character, Kevin (Mr. Bass), works at a Chicago ad agency as a copywriter on the Reebok account and is credited with coming up with a catchy slogan for the company's international ad campaign. Unfortunately for Kevin, his hostile supervisor (Tamala Jones) steals the credit during a presentation.

title: Few Hospitals Are Ready for a Surge of Bioterror Victims
description: Hospitals across the country are scrambling to prepare for terrorist attacks, anticipating situations that seemed like science fiction nightmares before Sept. 11. But public health experts and hospital industry officials say that many hospitals are far from ready for a surge of patients in the event of a major attack.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bayer Seen Breaking Even On Cipro Deal and May Profit

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Teachers' Union Backs Green, Citing His Pledge to Raise Salaries and Cut Class Size
description: The New York City teachers' union finally endorsed Mark Green for mayor yesterday after passing him over twice for the primary and runoff elections, causing renewed disagreements over education with his Republican opponent, Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Primedia Reports A Wider Loss
description: Primedia, the publisher of more than 280 magazines, said yesterday that its third-quarter loss had widened and that the company had laid off workers and frozen salaries and hiring to cut costs.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Port Authority Moves to Enhance Ferry Service
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has moved to bolster ferry service across the Hudson River in an effort to ease congestion on PATH trains and improve commuter access to Lower Manhattan in the wake of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: House Passes a War-Bond Bill, but Bush Is Not Enthusiastic
description: Eager to strike a patriotic chord, the House passed a bill this week to offer old-fashioned war bonds for the first time since World War II.

title: New Legal Powers, Fresh Anthrax Worries, Resilient Taliban
description: A few days after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, President Bush asked Congress for new law-enforcement powers to hunt down terrorists. Now he has them. The president did not get everything he wanted. But he got enough -- certainly more than civil liberties groups were happy with -- to be able to sign a sweeping antiterrorism bill into law, probably today.

title: W.T.O. Says Trade Growth Will Be Virtually Stagnant
description: World trade, growing by leaps and bounds a year ago, has now all but stagnated, according to a study released today by the World Trade Organization. Meager growth of 1 or 2 percent is the best that can be expected this year, the study said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: Long Road For Turkey
description: Turkey, which wants to join the European Union, has made headway on human rights issues but has a long way to go before meeting union standards, according to a committee report to the European Parliament. The report hailed improvements in Turkey's penal code, antiterrorist law and political freedoms but said that ''torture and the degrading treatment of prisoners continues to be frequent, freedom of expression is still abnormally restricted, and several thousand people are today incarcerated for offenses which we would consider differences of opinion.'' Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: The Return to Liberty Plaza
description: An office tower just east of the World Trade Center wreckage, 1 Liberty Plaza, reopened Wednesday -- two days later than scheduled and without the fanfare that the owner had originally planned.

title: G.M. Is Said To Be Near Picking Winner For DirecTV
description: After 18 months of negotiations, General Motors hopes to decide tomorrow whether to sell its communications satellite business to the News Corporation or the EchoStar Communications Corporation, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: New York's Senators Outline Plan to Assist Lower Manhattan
description: New York's senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, today released the broad outlines of their plan to spur the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan in the wake of last month's terrorist attacks.

title: U.S., Awaiting Putin, Delays Missile Defense Tests
description: The Bush administration, moving to strike a deal on offensive and defensive strategic arms with Russia, has postponed three antimissile tracking tests that Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today might be interpreted as violating the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: Microsoft Introduces New Operating System
description: With a concert by the rock singer Sting and the personal thanks of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Microsoft yesterday introduced its Windows XP operating system, a product that carries the hopes of reviving sales for the beleaguered personal computer industry.

title: 'Kill by Inches'
description: Directed by Diane Doniol-Valcroze and Arthur Flam

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of 2 p.m. yesterday, 4,854 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: 'The Brother'
description: David Greenglass never cried for his sister. He didn't cry when she was arrested, when she was convicted, or even when she was sentenced to the electric chair, so perhaps it wasn't out of character that he didn't cry on that hellish Friday in June 1953 when she died.

title: Camby No Longer Sure He Can Play in Opener
description: A day after sounding as if he would play in the season opener Tuesday against the Washington Wizards, Marcus Camby cast doubt on the idea.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Friday about a news conference at which the CBS anchor Dan Rather discussed an assistant's exposure to anthrax misstated the title of Andrew Heyward, who answered questions with Mr. Rather. He is the president of CBS News, not its executive producer.

title: William F. Melville Jr., 80, Bank Executive
description: William F. Melville Jr., the former chief executive of a large credit card company and executive of a bank, died on Oct. 10 at a nursing home in Arnold, Md. He was 80 and lived in Severna Park, Md.

title: Gelsenkirchen Journal; A Different Germany Takes to the Soccer Field
description: Gerald Asamoah is not the first nonwhite man to play for Germany's national soccer team. But as he likes to observe, ''I'm definitely the blackest.''

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Ken Aston, 86, Soccer Referee Who Originated the Red Card
description: Ken Aston, the referee for one of the most infamous World Cup soccer matches and the originator of the cards used to indicate that a player is guilty of misconduct, died Tuesday in Ilford, England. He was 86 and lived in Ilford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYER, GEORGIA RUHLING
description: SAYER-Georgia Ruhling, 94 years young, on October 24, 2001 of Rye, New York, formerly of Garden City and Wading River, New York. Beloved wife of the late Donald C. Devoted mother of Donald of Menifee, Calif., David of Stamford, CT. and Peter of Ridgefield, CT. Adored Gigi to seven grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Visiting hours 4 to 7PM on Sunday, October 28, at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, N.Y. Service Monday, October 29, 11AM at Christ's Church, Rectory Street, Rye, New York.

description: A table in Business Day yesterday showing yields on money market accounts and certificates of deposit carried incorrect figures for several banks. A corrected table appears today on Page C7.

title: THE ACES MAY BE KINGS
description: Mike Mussina has shifted from one pronoun to the other all year, like a driver constantly changing lanes, weaving from ''we'' to ''they'' without signaling. When he says we, he means the Yankees. When he says they, he means the Yankees.

title: Poll Shows Skepticism Of Schundler
description: Bret D. Schundler's promises to cut taxes and expand state financing of private schools are not persuading New Jersey voters that he should be the state's next governor, a New York Times poll has found.

Services Congregation Beth Elohim, Eighth Avenue & Garfield Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn on Sunday, October 28, 2001 at 1:15 P.M.

title: Bush Supports House Bill on Airport Screeners
description: The White House threw its weight today behind a House Republican plan that would put the federal government in charge of baggage and passenger screening but would not require 28,000 screeners to be federal employees.

title: Sony Loss of $107 Million Adds to Gloom in Japan
description: The bad news pouring in from Japan's electronics industry is reinforcing fears about the depth of the global economic downturn.

title: Nervous in New Jersey
description: More than 7 in 10 New Jersey residents are concerned that they or someone close to them could be exposed to anthrax, and 35 percent are very concerned, a New York Times poll of 1,039 adults has found.

title: Top Taliban Foe Is Executed; U.S. Raids on Kabul Continue
description: Aleader of the Afghan opposition who had crossed into Afghanistan from exile in Pakistan to try to start a rebellion against the ruling Taliban was captured and executed today, the Taliban announced.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Number Of Obese Nearly Doubles
description: The number of obese Floridians has increased 94 percent since officials began monitoring the health problem in 1986, a state Department of Health report said. According to the study, 38 percent of adult Floridians are overweight; 18.5 percent are obese. The obesity rate rose 82 percent among Hispanics, 65 percent among non-Hispanic whites and 51 percent among non-Hispanic blacks during a 10-year period from the late 1980's to late 1990's. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has awarded the department $345,000 to initiate statewide efforts to control obesity. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: ALLIANT AGREES TO BUY AMMUNITION UNIT FROM BLOUNT
description: Alliant Techsystems, a maker of munitions, missile systems and other products for the military, agreed yesterday to buy Blount International's ammunition unit for $250 million in stock. Blount, a maker of logging equipment and sporting goods, will get about 2.9 million Alliant shares. Blount, based in Montgomery, Ala., is 85 percent owned by Lehman Brothers. The ammunition business, part of Blount's sporting-equipment group, makes small-caliber bullets and other products. Alliant, based in Edina, Minn., also said yesterday that its second-quarter income rose to $18.9 million, or 85 cents a share, from $16.1 million, or 77 cents, a year ago.

title: Economic Data Are Suggesting Slower Recovery
description: With the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates and Congress vowing to pass a large stimulus package, economists have said that the current downturn could end up being a short one. The economic shock from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks would make the slowdown worse, many analysts said, but the reaction would have the economy growing again by the start of next year.

title: State Office's Anthrax Testing Given Priority
description: Some New York media organizations waited several days last week for results of laboratory tests for anthrax that were being conducted by the State Health Department, while similar tests on the Manhattan offices of Gov. George E. Pataki were expedited and produced results within 24 hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, MARTHA
description: GORMAN-Martha. The faculty and staff of the NYU Child Study Center mourn the loss of Martha Gorman, beloved mother of Dr. Gail Furman, one of our founding board members and steadfast supporters. Gail's energy, enthusiasm and generosity for children in need is an enduring legacy and memorial to her mother. We extend our sympathy to Gail and the entire Furman family. Brooke Neidich Chair, Board of Directors Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D. Arnold and Debbie Simon Professor of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry and Director, Child Study Center New York University School of Medicine

title: Following Thoreau Away From Anxiety
description: The day was bright and breezy, and the news was all anthrax, all the time. I had planned to park myself on a beach on the South Shore of Long Island and watch the behavior of gulls, but at the last minute I changed my mind. I didn't want to do anything stationary. I wanted to move. So I opened my hiking guidebook, picked out a good destination and took off.

title: American Stand-In Singers Are Salve to New York's Wounds
description: When the Cincinnati May Festival planned its concert at Carnegie Hall for Oct. 9, no one could foresee how tragically topical Benjamin Britten's ``War Requiem'' would become.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DICOVSKY, DR. CARLOS
description: DICOVSKY-Dr. Carlos. In memory of Dr. Carlos Dicovsky, we miss you more and more each day. Your loving children, Sonia and Claudio, daughter and son-in-law Marcela and Santiago, grandchildren Claus, Christopher and Chloe

title: Foreign Affairs; We Are All Alone
description: So let me see if I've got this all straight now: Pakistan will allow us to use its bases Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays -- provided we bomb only Taliban whose names begin with Omar and who don't have cousins in the Pakistani secret service. India is with us on Tuesdays and Fridays, provided it can shell Pakistani forces around Kashmir all other days. Egypt is with us on Sundays, provided we don't tell anyone and provided we never mention that we give the Egyptians $2 billion a year in aid. Yasir Arafat is with us only after 10 p.m. on weekdays, when Palestinians who have been dancing in the streets over the World Trade Center attack have gone to bed. The Northern Alliance is with us, provided we buy all its troops new sandals and give U.S. passports to the first 1,000 to reach Kabul.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON CONTACT LENS SETTLEMENT APPROVED
description: A New Jersey judge yesterday approved Johnson & Johnson's $860 million settlement of lawsuits that had accused the company of misleading consumers into prematurely throwing away disposable Acuvue contact lenses. The judge, John Fratto of New Jersey Superior Court, found that the settlement was a ''fair and reasonable'' resolution of lawsuits by consumers who said they were deceived into thinking they could use one-day Acuvue lenses only a single time, even though the product is identical to Acuvue lenses that may be worn as long as two weeks. Johnson & Johnson has agreed to pay consumers as much as $840 million in cash, coupons and eye examinations. Consumers' lawyers will get $20 million under the settlement.

title: A Collection Where Cultures Connect and East Meets West
description: ''We're all connected'' is the big-picture story of art. It always has been. If you have any doubts, visit the Walters Art Museum here, where that message comes across soft and clear, and in exquisitely concentrated form.

title: Pornography Takes Over Financial Site For Children
description: Visitors to a financial Web site for children this week were in for a shock: the math-and-money game they expected to find had been replaced by a pornography site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVLIN, MARY EUGENIA
description: DEVLIN-Mary Eugenia. Beloved wife of Paul J. Devlin, M.D., died peacefully at home in Rye, NY, October 24. She was surrounded by her husband, children and grandchildren who were her greatest joy in life. Born in Manhattan in 1914, Mrs. Devlin resided in Bronxville, NY and Gulf Stream, FL before moving to Rye in 1995. Mary, known affectionately to her family and many friends as ''Mamie'', is survived by her husband, her brother William Oswald, eight children: Maureen Koecheler, Paul Devlin, Gene Devlin, Kathy Botts, Mary Ellen McGuire, Patty Giesen, Christopher Devlin and Michael Devlin, seven sons-and daughters-in-law, 22 grandchildren and eight (soon to be nine) great grandchildren. She was predeceased by her son-in-law Gary Koecheler who died September 11. Visiting hours will be Friday, October 26, 4-8 PM at Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY. The Funeral Mass will be celebrated at Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY, Saturday, October 27, 12 PM.

title: When Terror Seems Both Near and Very Far
description: Here in Kansas, we know anthrax as a disease that cows get rarely. We've been told to steam-iron any suspicious envelopes, but we're not really expecting to see much germ-laden mail. The Salina skyline is ruled by the 12-story United Building, shorter than some grain elevators and not much of a target for a terrorist. And our airline travel is daily turboprop service to Kansas City.

title: Bush White House Reverses Clinton Decision on Mining
description: The Bush administration today reversed an 11th-hour Clinton administration ruling on mining policy, making it easier for companies to mine for gold, copper, zinc and lead on public lands. It also issued a legal opinion that could clear the way for a Nevada company to dig an open-pit gold mine in a part of the California desert considered sacred by a local Indian tribe.

title: In Shift, Agency Recommends Combinations of Antibiotics for Anthrax Cases
description: Federal health officials made important changes yesterday in their recommendations for treating both the skin and inhalation forms of anthrax.

title: Corrections
description: The Life's Work column in the Workplace section on Wednesday, about the mood of employees, misspelled the name of a nutritionist who said she was having a hard time persuading her clients to stick to their diets and keep off cigarettes. She is Bonnie Taub-Dix, not Dix-Taub.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nippon Cuts Forecast
description: Japan's largest telecommunications carrier, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, cut its profit forecast by 30 percent for the year ending in March 2002 because of mounting losses at fixed-line operations. N.T.T., of which the government owns 40 percent, now expects to earn 89 billion yen ($724 million) in this fiscal year. The company also trimmed its sales estimate by 1.3 percent as a growing price war between carriers forced it to cut local phone rates. N.T.T. also said it would resist calls by regulators who want to break up the holding company to encourage competition. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Affymetrix And Hyseq Resolve Dispute
description: Affymetrix, the largest maker of gene chips for drug research, and Hyseq, which conducts gene research to develop new drugs, said they had settled patent infringement lawsuits over their DNA analysis technologies and would form a joint venture. The settlement, which gives each company access to some of the other's patents, ends a series of lawsuits and legal actions between Affymetrix and Hyseq that began in 1997. They now plan to form a joint venture to develop new DNA analysis tools. The venture, to be called, N-Mer, will be a subsidiary of Hyseq's newly formed Callida Genomics unit. It will focus on developing and marketing high-speed DNA sequencing chips and will have access to Affymetrix's gene chip technology and Hyseq's DNA analysis technology.

title: Salmonella Is Found In Vials Sent To Clinton
description: Plastic vials containing salmonella, a bacteria that is one of the most common causes of food poisoning, were sent this month to Bill Clinton at his Harlem office, the Secret Service said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Start-Up To Get $45 Million
description: Flarion Technologies, a start-up wireless technology company based in Bedminster, N.J., is expected to announce today that it has received $44 million in equity financing from a group of investors that includes Cisco Systems, Pequot Capital and Nassau Capital. The success of Flarion Technologies in securing financing comes as venture capital for new telecommunications and wireless companies is scarce. Flarion Technologies has attracted attention for the development of new technology that allows mobile communications companies to provide high-speed Internet access at a lower price than competitors using existing technological standards. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: U.S.T.A. Withdraws Team From Fed Cup
description: After consulting with players and government officials, the United States Tennis Association yesterday withdrew the defending champion Fed Cup team from the finals in Madrid next month, citing security concerns after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Foam That Kills Anthrax Is to Be Used in Mailrooms
description: Cleanup workers are preparing to apply a new type of foam that kills anthrax spores and bacteria to contaminated mailrooms on Capitol Hill, officials said yesterday.

description: ELLENBOGEN-Joan. The distinction and enthusiasm with which she served our profession shall provide a continuing source of inspiration for the Fellowship. Sylvia Goldschmidt, President AAML, NY Chapter

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: VeriSign Profit Accelerates
description: VeriSign, which provides Internet security and domain-name registration services, said its revenue for the third quarter was $255.2 million, up from $173.1 million in the period a year earlier. VeriSign shares rose $3.89 in anticipation of the news, which was released after the market had closed, to end the day at $53.34. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., said it had a pro forma quarterly profit of $59.7 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with a pro forma profit of $36 million, or 17 cents, a year earlier. Wall Street analysts were expecting about 16 cents a share. VeriSign said the improved results could be attributed to a big jump in sales and a reduction in merger costs. Executives from the company said that it would focus on promoting international domain names, Internet telephony and other voice and data services. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Harvey Pitt's S.E.C.: From Guard Dog to Friendly Puppy?
description: CAN the new, friendlier Securities and Exchange Commission enforce the laws and assure investors that corporate financial reports are trustworthy?

description: ost things in the movie business are disappointments," said Ben Feingold, president of the Columbia TriStar Motion Picture Group. DVD isn't one of them. Industry figures show that the average price of DVD players, expected to be in 25 million homes by the end of the year, is about $180, down from about $500 when the format was introduced in 1997. No one can be sure of anything in the current economic climate, but retailers consider $200 a price for the people.

description: The number of foreigners living legally in Germany declined slightly last year, the Federal Statistics Office reported, putting the total at 7.29 million, down from 7.34 million in 1999. About 80 percent come from other European countries.
