description: James E. McGreevey said tonight that he would not raise taxes if elected governor of New Jersey and forcefully denounced his Republican opponent, Bret D. Schundler, for his positions on education, gun control and abortion in a caustic fourth debate between the two candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DER VLIS, DIANA (DONALD)
description: van der VLIS-Diana (Donald), 66. On October 22, in Missoula, MT, after a brief illness. Gifted actress, beloved wife and mother, cherished friend. After studying at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London, her distinguished acting career began at the Crest Theater in Toronto. She appeared in a broad range of plays, including the Broadway productions of The Happiest Millionaire (for which she was nominated for a Tony), Visit to a Small Planet, Comes a Day, A Shot in the Dark, Waltz of the Toreadors; the Stratford, CT productions of As You Like It (playing Rosalind) and Love's Labour's Lost; and the Kennedy Center production of Present Laughter. Her films included The Man With the X-Ray Eyes, The Incident, and The Swimmer. She also appeared in numerous nighttime television shows, including Alfred Hitchock Presents, The Man from U.N.C.L.E., The Fugitive and The Defenders. Her daytime credits included Where the Heart Is and Ryan's Hope, on which she played two different characters. In recent years, she divided her time between New York and Montana. Survived by her husband Roger, son Matthew and daughter Adrienne. A celebration of her life will be held at in Swan Valley, MT on October 26. A memorial service will be scheduled later in New York.

title: Investigators Remove 3 Bodies From Newly Raised Russian Sub
description: Investigators entered the hull of the Russian nuclear submarine Kursk today in a closed military port on the Barents Sea, removing the bodies of three of the 118 sailors who perished when the craft sank 14 months ago.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Rocky Hill: Anti-Threat Law Sought
description: Prompted by an outbreak of anthrax hoaxes, Chief State's Attorney John M. Bailey is proposing a law that would make hoaxes that inconvenience or harm the public punishable by up to five years in prison. Current law punishing false bomb threats and false fire alarms by up to one year in prison is too lenient for today's attacks, Mr. Bailey said. No law addresses chemical and biological threats. The proposed law would also require restitution for wasted resources, like public-health testing or police overtime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDERMAN, BETH OLDS
description: BIDERMAN-Beth Olds, 80. Tranquilly on October 24, 2001. To the end more concerned about others than herself: first her loved ones, but not far behind the causes of world peace and progressive humanism with which she was professionally and personally involved through all of her adult life. 1942-45: administrative secretary on the Manhattan Project at University of Chicago and Oak Ridge, Tenn., then manager, American liaison office in Montreal with the British and French scientists. 194547: executive secretary of the Emergency Committee of Atomic Scientists and Atomic Scientists of Chicago. 1948-52: executive secretary of the National Sharecroppers Fund to fight for farm worker rights, board member several years thereafter. 1967-70: executive director of Park Association of New York, consultant to Parks Council 1972. Activist in Greenwich Village and summer residence on Fire Island, co-founding Saltaire Citizens Advisory Association. Music buff, conservationist, gourmet cook extraodinaire. Her enjoyment of wry humor & dry martinis persisted to the very end, as did her bravery and determination. Beloved and devoted wife for fifty-four years of George, mother to Tina (Vartanian) and John, grandmother to Alexandre Vartanian and Lauren Scharf. Memorial to be announced.

title: Conflicting Testimony Is Given in Rabbi's Trial
description: In contradictory and at times bizarre testimony, one of the confessed killers of a rabbi's wife said today that he had hit her twice in the head with a pipe and had shared as much as $12,500 with the other killer.

title: NORTHROP HALTS SHIP PROJECT; 1,750 WORKERS AFFECTED
description: Northrop Grumman has stopped building two 1,900-passenger cruise ships for American Classic Voyages, a move that will put about 1,750 employees, or 17 percent of the staff, at its Pascagoula, Miss., shipyard out of work. The move comes less than a week after American Classic Voyages filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and failed to get a federal loan to complete the ships. Northrop's Litton unit agreed to build the ships for $880 million in 1999. Northrop said it would pursue financing from the United States Maritime Administration and would take a $60 million charge if efforts to keep the project alive failed.

description: It is getting late early again for the Rangers, who were pounded for the third consecutive game, this time, 5-1, by the Blues tonight.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Is Up At Puma
description: The sportswear and athletic shoe manufacturer Puma said that its third-quarter profit had more than tripled, setting off a sharp rally in its share price. Net income at Puma rose to 17.5 million euros ($16 million) from 4.5 million euros a year earlier. Sales increased 32 percent, to 197.1 million euros ($180.2 million), and the company raised its forecast for total sales this year. The chief executive, Jochen Zeitz, has focused on advertising and product development and has combined sportswear with street styles to support sales. Shares of Puma rose 4.15 euros, or 20 percent, to 25 euros ($22.86) a share.

title: N and R Subway Service Will Resume on Sunday
description: Service on the N and R subway lines, which was suspended after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, is scheduled to begin again on Sunday, several months earlier than expected, transit officials announced yesterday.

title: Biotechs Gain VC Respectability
description: Venture capitalists have seen the future-and it's biotech. Biotech venture capitalists spent the past few years looking on with a mixture of envy and amazement as their counterparts in the Internet and information technology sectors became obnoxiously rich and famous. But now it's their turn in the sun. While other startups starve for cash, almost every day a new biotech firm scores funding. Earlier this month, four biotech companies raised $90 million in a single day. The ugly specter of bio-terrorism has also helped underscore the importance of the biotechnology industry and the need to pump money into the field.

description: BLANC-Nancy Scott. On October 21, 2001. Beloved wife of Robert S. title: Now Arriving on Track 10: The 3:15 From Outer Space
description: In ''K-Pax,'' Kevin Spacey plays a character -- either a profoundly disturbed mental patient or a being from a distant galaxy -- who regards the strivings of ordinary earth folk with an amused detachment that combines smug superiority and gentle pity. So what else, you may well ask, is new? Mr. Spacey's gift for irony, his attraction to roles that hide emotional distress behind a cloak of knowing composure, is starting to look like a vice.

For example, at the 125th Street station on the A, B, C, and D lines, witnesses said a man spilled the substance that turned out to be baby powder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ARTHUR M.
description: MILLER-Arthur M., April 19, 1922October 23, 2001. Beloved father of Dianne Newman & Howard Miller, M.D.; grandfather to Leigh, Jill and Stacy and loving partner of 40 years to Hal Bishop. Born in Ft. Worth, Texas, Arthur established a home accessory business in Meachems Dept. Store before moving on to New York where he began Arthur Miller Associates, a leading decorative accessory business at 225 5th Avenue in New York. He was on the forefront of bringing products from around the world to the market with his keen sense of style and taste. In 1972, he moved to Los Angeles as President of Dorothy Thorpe, Inc. Following that he created Quadrille, a showroom in the L.A Mart. His interests also included bridge. He was a life master respected by his peers around the country. He was also an owner of thoroughbred racehorses. A private service will be held at his home on Saturday, October 27th. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated in Arthur's name to the charity of your choice. Interment at Pierce Bros., Westwood Memorial Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGAMATSU, GEORGE R., MD.
description: NAGAMATSU-George R., MD. New York Medical College is saddened by the passing of our alumnus, esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. George R. Nagamatsu, distinguished Emeritus Professor of Urology and Chairman of the Dept. of Urology for 15 years. A 1934 graduate of the School of Medicine, Dr. Nagamatsu devoted nearly his entire career to the College. Decorated by Japan's Consulate General and awarded the Valentine Medal, one of the highest honors in urology, he was a pioneering surgeon, urologist and engineer. We extend our sympathy to his wife and family. Ronald F. Poe, Chairman Board of Trustees Rev. Msgr. Harry C. Barrett, D.Min., MPH President and CEO Ralph A. O'Connell, MD, Provost and Dean School of Medicine

title: Tale of the Tape: An Anthrax Spore
description: In amateur preparations, anthrax spores stick together in fairly large clumps. But if clumps are ground into individual spores, each only one or two millionths of a meter wide, then the spores may have been able to escape through even a well-sealed envelope.

title: Not Yet Citizens but Eager to Fight for the U.S.
description: As a youth in Kazakhstan, Alexandr Manin had no interest in the war that the Soviet Union was waging in Afghanistan in the 1980's. But since arriving in New York three years ago, he has had a change of heart, and has joined the military.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGAN, JAMES RUSSELL, JR.
description: FORGAN-James Russell, Jr. Age 71. Investment banker. Died peacfully at home on October 22, 2001 after a long illness in New York City. Beloved husband of Kathryn Zahony Livingston; dear brother of the late Joan F. Parks of Denver, Florence F. Wheeler of Lake Forest and Ada F. Addington of Chicago. His survivors include a stepson Bret B. Livingston, a step daughter Valerie V. Livingston, 10 nephews and nieces and 13 grand nephews and nieces. He was the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Forgan of New York City and Watch Hill, RI; the grandson of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Forgan of Evanston, IL and Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Johnson of St. Louis, MO. He was born August 4, 1930, graduated from the Buckley School in New York City, St. Marks School in Southborough, MA and Princeton University Class of 1952. He served as an Army Lieutenant in the Korean War. He held a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. His lifetime special interest was writing and producing plays and screen plays. He was a founder of the night club, El Morocco when it was revived in the 60s, and in the 70s launched a school for backgammon playing. Private funeral services are planned for October 25 in Watch Hill, RI. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, November 7, 2001 at 11:00 AM at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Ave & 53rd St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to St. Mark's School in Southborough, MA., or Princeton University in Princeton, NJ.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suspect Shot By Police
description: Two suspected robbers were arrested last night and one of them was shot and critically wounded as they tried to escape from the police in southern Brooklyn, according to a Police Department spokesman. After robbing a woman on Shore Parkway at 5:30 p.m., the men approached another woman about 10 minutes later on Avenue Z, the police said, but they got back into their car they saw police cars approaching. After hitting several other cars while trying to escape, the suspects' car flipped over and they got out and fired at the officers, who shot back, the police said. One suspect, Careem Miller, 26, was shot in the neck and was reported in critical condition at Lutheran Medical Center. He was arrested as was Eugene Elmore, 31. Robert Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, ROBERT F. LT. FDNY.
description: WALLACE-Robert F. Lt. FDNY. Engine 205 Ladder 118 of Woodhaven, NY formerly of Brooklyn, NY in his 43rd year heroically in the line of duty while helping others at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. A member of the FDNY for 21 years. Beloved husband of Nancy, a loving and devoted father of Jeanine, Bobby, Daniel and Alex. Devoted son of Elizabeth and Eugene (ret. Lt. FDNY). Loving brother of Gene, Liza and John. Cherished son and brother-in-law to many. Survived by many loving nieces, nephews and cousins. A memorial mass to celebrate Bob's life will be held on Saturday, October 27, 2001 11:00 AM at St. Thomas the Apostle, 8719 88th Ave., Woodhaven, Queens. Following the memorial mass there will be a gathering of all his friends and family in the school cafeteria. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Bob's name would be appreciated to the NYC Fire Department Burn Center Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, NY 10475.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ROBERT P.
description: MARCUS-Robert P., life-long love, companion, and best friend of his wife Betty G. Marcus; beloved son of the late Libby P. Marcus and Bernard K. Marcus; caring and devoted son-in-law of the late Ziuta Gerstenzang Akston and Leo Gerstenzang; proud and loving father of his daughter, Lauren Marcus Hughes; adoring grandfather of Christopher Robert Marcus Hughes and Meghan Ruth Marcus Hughes and father of Gary P. Marcus. He enriched the lives of all those he met and all those who called him friend, for he was a kind, caring, wise and gentle man. He was a natural leader who spent a lifetime quietly and selflessly helping others and improving the lives of untold numbers of people. He will be remembered by all those he touched forever and ever. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00 AM on Sunday, October 28, 2001 at Ferncliff Cemetery, 280 Secor Rd., Hartsdale, NY. For information, contact Quattlebaum Funeral Home at 561-832-5171.

title: 'Scourge'
description: In a maximum-security facility in Atlanta, the world's most dangerous prisoner sits in solitary confinement, awaiting execution. Wanted for the torture and death of millions of people, this mass murderer was captured in a global dragnet lasting more than a decade. Although the prisoner has been condemned to death, the jailers are debating whether or not to carry out the sentence. Some believe that studying the killer's methods could help to develop better defenses against such crimes, yet others fear that the prisoner could escape and wreak mayhem on an even greater scale. While the debate continues, the execution has been postponed.

title: Confirmed Anthrax Cases
description: Acase of pulmonary anthrax was confirmed in a State Department mailroom worker at a center near Dulles International Airport. A second worker at NBC in New York was confirmed as having skin anthrax. Here is the total number of anthrax cases to date:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITT, LEAH
description: PITT-Leah. Beloved mother of Joel and Ann (Amy) and motherin-law of Marie. Loving grandmother of Lisa, Aric, James, Robert, Josh, and Zack, great grandmother of Alanna, Natalie, and Zachary, sister of Henrietta. Devoted friend & caring teacher. She had a long, full life. We will all miss her. Funeral services 11:30AM, Sunday, October 28, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. Shiva at home of Joel Pitt in Princeton, N.J., on Monday and Tuesday, at home of Amy Pitt in Rochester, NY on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

title: The Big City; Skating Along Despite Trying Times
description: AFTER the guys in moon suits appeared for the second time in our building to investigate powder-filled letters, I asked a clerk in the mailroom how he was coping with the new drawbacks of his job. He said he didn't like working with plastic gloves (too hot) or worrying that any piece of mail could be fatal. But what really bothered him was his commute.

title: A Familiar Battle Fought and Won
description: Lawmakers today hailed the antiterrorism legislation passed by Congress as an appropriate balance between civil liberties and the heightened security needs of a nation at risk. But civil liberties advocates asserted that the new law jeopardized fundamental rights and would require vigilant oversight to keep the authorities in line.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CURTISS-WRIGHT, Lyndhurst, N.J., said it would pay $41 million to the closely held Lau Acquisition for its Lau Defense Systems and Vista Controls units, which make components for military vehicles.

title: Lonely, but Steadfast in Midtown; Tourists Scarce, Manhattan Chili Rethinks Its Business
description: Seven years ago, Sally Sterman cleaned out her bank account and gave all her cash -- $34,000 -- to her son, Bruce, so he could move his restaurant to an unpopular but promising neighborhood: Times Square.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 7
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Hunter College Wins Another CUNY Title
description: Hunter College defeated City College in the CUNY championship match yesterday and extended two streaks in the process.

title: A Pragmatic Aid Plan
description: The costs of recovering from the World Trade Center attacks are so enormous that many officials cannot imagine how New York City and the state will manage unless the federal government comes through with a huge amount of additional aid. Meanwhile the Bush administration, which has already committed nearly $20 billion for the city, is looking with alarm at suggestions that $50 billion or so more might be necessary. If New York is going to get the help it needs, its leaders are going to have to be both restrained and politically canny in what they ask for.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Plan For Separatist Region
description: Parliament has approved a bill that would grant broad political and economic autonomy to the remote province of Irian Jaya, where separatists are fighting for independence. The bill would allow the mineral-rich province to keep 70 percent of royalties from mining and 80 percent from logging and fishing. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Winning With a 1-2 Punch of Pitching? Many Have Tried
description: In a seven-game World Series, a team with two truly outstanding starting pitchers should have a tremendous advantage. In the nine-day period that includes two travel days, each can pitch at least twice, and one of them three times. Two such starters can provide the four necessary victories, regardless of all other comparative team strengths and weaknesses.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: A Series Of Hiccups

title: Edwards Points at Ellis and Abraham
description: It was late Tuesday night and Coach Herman Edwards was weary. There would be no trade with Oakland for Darrell Russell, a move that would have shored up the Jets' run defense but would have also cost them either John Abraham or Shaun Ellis. But that decision did not answer the question that has hovered over the defense all season: Why are Ellis and Abraham looking nothing like they did as rookies, when they combined for 13 sacks?

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Monday about the Complicite theater company's ''Noise of Time'' on Thursday at the John Jay Theater, with the Emerson String Quartet, gave an erroneous reason announced from the stage for a delay in the starting time. It resulted from problems in the theater, not from preparations for a BBC recording.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Cuts At Hynix
description: All 14,000 employees of Hynix Semiconductor will have to go on a one-month unpaid leave sometime in the next five months so the company can reduce its labor costs by 30 percent. Hynix Semiconductor said the plan had the approval of its labor union. Hynix is trying to persuade creditors to agree on a $5.3 billion bailout; it reported a record $1.24 billion net loss in the third quarter.

title: James Siena
description: Gorney Bravin & Lee

title: Owner of Observer Sells Litchfield County Times
description: The Litchfield County Times has been sold by Arthur L. Carter, an investor who made a reputation in journalistic circles publishing The Nation and The New York Observer.

title: New Battles on the West Bank
description: Last week's assassination of an Israeli cabinet minister should have spurred the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to find and arrest the killers without delay. Regrettably, Mr. Arafat has not done so, and his inadequate response has provoked Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, to launch ill-advised military operations in Palestinian-ruled areas of the West Bank. Mr. Sharon's actions have made it less likely that a reduction in violence will be negotiated any time soon and have strained relations between Israel and the United States.

title: 'Half a Life'
description: Willie Chandran asked his father one day, "Why is my middle name Somerset? The boys at school have just found out, and they are mocking me."

title: Sorting Machines at Mail Center Are Contaminated
description: The Postal Service announced yesterday that laboratory tests had found anthrax contamination at four high-speed sorting machines at the largest mail distribution center in New York City.

title: Not Now. I'm Fighting With My Car.
description: FIRST, Sony gave the world a robot, Aibo, that thought it was a dog. Now, the company has teamed with Toyota to make a conceptual car that's part pet and part nag.

title: WATCHING MOVIES WITH/Denzel Washington; An Eye For Bold Choices
description: WHEN Denzel Washington was growing up, the son of a minister, he was not allowed to go to the movies. As a young man, after he had turned to acting and moved to Manhattan, he went through the usual phase of fairly regular moviegoing. But then he moved to Los Angeles in the early 80's and became established as a top star, and once again he found himself seeing fewer and fewer movies.

title: Arming Soldiers for a New Kind of War
description: During his campaign for president, George W. Bush endorsed the need to transform the American military in response to new types of threat. This now seems prescient, given the unconventional attacks on Sept. 11 and the ensuing war against terrorism. The first war of this new century is not even a distant cousin of the Persian Gulf War, much less of the cold war that still determines, in many ways, the size, form and orientation of our military.

title: News organizations try to dispel the notion that ads and bad news don't mix.
description: MEDIA companies whose properties provide news coverage are for the first time forcefully seeking to persuade marketers and agencies to reconsider a reluctance to advertise alongside the coverage of calamities.

title: News Helicopters Curbed by Air Restrictions
description: Squirming restlessly, Aaron Fitzgerald spends much of his day at a desk now, flipping the channels of his three police scanners in the distant hope that he will come across something really worthwhile. A fire. A car chase, perhaps. Maybe even a bomb scare.

title: One House Building Reopens; Inspection Continues at Another
Swiss Tunnel Fire Is Put Out; Search Goes On for the Missing
description: AIROLO, Switzerland, Oct. 26  The fire that raged after two trucks collided in the Gotthard Tunnel two days ago was extinguished early this morning, and rescue workers were trying to shore up the precarious tunnel roof to reach the area where they suspect more bodies lie.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: McCain Endorses Nassau Candidate
description: Senator John McCain ofArizona, left, has weighed in on the race for Nassau County executive, endorsing Bruce R. Bent, the multimillionaire financier running on the Republican ticket. In television advertisements scheduled to begin yesterday, Mr. McCain praises Mr. Bent as someone who can ''clean up the financial mess made by the career politicians.'' Mr. Bent, 64, is running against Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi, 39, the four-term Democratic mayor of Glen Cove, for leadership of the wealthy but fiscally troubled county. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Sure, He Has a 6-Foot Rabbit. Does That Mean He's Crazy?
description: The influence of John Hughes is fully felt in the melodrama ''Donnie Darko.'' This first film written and directed by Richard Kelly is a wobbly cannonball of a movie that tries to go Mr. Hughes one better; it's like a Hughes version of a novel by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. You want the movie to work, even though it becomes evident early on that it doesn't, succumbing to a need to crawl into the head of its troubled young protagonist, Donnie Darko (Jake Gyllenhaal).

title: An Economy Keeping Its Guard Up
description: Weyerhaeuser closed part of its saw mill in Barnesville, Ga., last week when some workers discovered a white powder on some new bandsaws they were unpacking. The men were quarantined for several hours until the saw maker assured Weyerhaeuser that the powder was just a rust preventative, not anthrax spores. Yet ''the mill kept working,'' Frank Mendizabal, a Weyerhaeuser spokesman, said.

title: Bailey's Edge Is Strength And Smarts
description: Jerry Bailey is not exactly in love with horses. He likes them, O.K. -- after all, thoroughbreds have provided him and his family a nice living, homes on Long Island and in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and, most important, an opportunity to win. As a boy in El Paso, those chances were few.

title: Buying the Writes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: 3 of 4 U.S. Teams in Paris Likely to Qualify for Playoffs
description: Three American teams are virtually certain to qualify for playoffs at the world championships here, but a fourth is in trouble. Three matches remain in the preliminaries, which end Saturday.

title: Deutsche Bank May Sell Cable TV Unit to Liberty Media
description: Furthering a push into the German cable television market, Liberty Media is in talks to buy a large regional system from Deutsche Bank, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Gerald Solomon, 71; Spurred Conservative Causes in House
description: Gerald B.H. Solomon, a conservative former congressman from New York who led crusades to punish flag burners and draft dodgers, died today at his home in Glens Falls, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEVLIN, ALEXANDER
description: SHEVLIN-Alexander. Of Atlantic City, NJ, died on October 20, 2001. Formerly of Philadelphia and Honolulu. Son of the late Isador and Celia Shavelenko and husband of the late Jean Korn Shevlin. He is survived by his sister Sally and her husband Abbe, and their two sons David Edward and Ian Seth, and numerous cousins. Dr. Shevlin was a true Renaissance man. He loved and was touched by people, the arts, flowers and animals. In Philadelphia, from 1961 to 1971, he hosted an educational TV adult literacy program called ''Operation Alphabet.'' He also edited a curriculum for the Philadelphia school system on teaching the Holocaust. Dr. Shevlin's body was willed to science and there will be no formal service for him. If you wish to visit his home in Atlantic City, his sister will be in residence on November 2, from 2 to 7 PM, November 3, from 10 AM to 7 PM, and November 4, from 10 AM to 8 PM. Dr. Shevlin will be remembered lovingly by family and friends for his cheerfulness, kindness and charm. The world will be a poorer place without him. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Diabetes Association, or any animal humane association of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDRICH, LARRY
description: ALDRICH-Larry. The staff of The Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Connecticut, mourns the passing of the Museum's founder and Chairman Emeritus, Larry Aldrich, and celebrates his commitment to emerging artists and the art of our time. His support of the Museum's curatorial and education mission was steadfast and unwavering. His boldness of vision and willingness to take risks are an inspiration to us. We are dedicated to carrying forward his vision of a Museum committed to championing emerging artists. His funding for the purchase of work by emerging artists at the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art, as well as his opening of the Soho Center for Visual Arts in 1973, brought his love for contemporary art to a wider audience. His quiet support of many causes and activities in the Town of Ridgefield, which he loved so well, has improved the life of its citizens. His spirit of adventure, keen intelligence, serene confidence, and sly humor will be deeply missed by us all. We look back fondly on his love for The Aldrich Museum and its exhibitions, how he sang to himself as he walked up the stairs to see a new exhibition, and how his eyes would light up at the sight of children in the Museum's education programs.

title: From Riches to Relative Rags
description: For years, Kevin Ingram lived the Wall Street dream: a multimillion-dollar salary as a top trader at Deutsche Bank; mentors like Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, and Senator Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey -- both from his days at Goldman, Sachs; and all the trappings of the good life, including a yellow Ferrari, a silver Porsche and a striking young third wife.

title: Red Cross President Quits, Saying That the Board Left Her No Other Choice
description: Dr. Bernadine Healy abruptly quit her job as president of the American Red Cross today, telling reporters through tears that she had been forced out.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: A Governor and a Mayor Join in Honoring 2 Brothers
description: A joint funeral yesterday for two brothers from Long Island -- one a New York City firefighter and the other a city police officer, both killed in the World Trade Center disaster -- was as much a celebration of their lust for life as of their heroic deeds.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Online Diary column in Circuits on Thursday about the demise of free Web sites referred imprecisely to the subscription policy imposed recently by the online magazine Salon. While there is a charge for access to news and political coverage, the editors say most of the site's content remains free.

title: Disaster Fades Into the Past, But Generosity Does Not
description: The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund has received $42 million for the victims of the attack on the World Trade Center, their families and those who lost jobs as a result of the disaster and the skittish economic climate.

title: Union Wants Postal Center Fully Cleaned
description: Alarmed that anthrax spores were found in four sorting machines at New York City's largest mail-distribution center, the executive board of the city's largest postal workers union voted yesterday to file a lawsuit to have the facility closed for a thorough cleaning.

title: O'Neill Not Starting; Sojo May Be Dropped
description: Two veterans who have been a part of the last four Yankee championships may not be a part of Game 1 of the World Series on Saturday. The utilityman Luis Sojo will probably be dropped from the 25-man roster to make room for a more serviceable player, and right fielder Paul O'Neill -- in the final days of his career -- will not be in the starting lineup against the Arizona right-hander Curt Schilling.

title: If Hamilton Doesn't Start, Legree Is Set to Take His Place
description: When the Giants signed Lance Legree as an undrafted free agent in April, the defensive line coach Denny Marcin received a phone call from Greg Mattison, the defensive coordinator and line coach at Notre Dame, where Legree had played.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: CHIEF OF C.D.C. SAYS ANTHRAX IS LIKELY IN ADDITIONAL MAIL
description: A top public health official said today that it was likely that more than one letter containing anthrax went through the government's mailrooms, and the authorities announced the discovery of anthrax spores in mail centers serving the C.I.A., the Supreme Court and the Walter Reed Army Medical Center and its research lab.

title: Getting It Right: Strategy Angst
description: Before the first American warplanes dropped a single bomb on an airfield in Afghanistan, before the first Army Ranger touched down near Kandahar to raid Taliban headquarters, President Bush declared, ''The new war on terror is going to be a different war.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Airline Profit Falls
description: Profit for the six months ended Sept. 30 at Singapore Airlines fell 88 percent, the company said, adding that avoiding posting its first full-year loss since going public in 1985 would be a challenge. Net income in the period fell to 134.8 million Singapore dollars (about $74 million).

title: INSIDE
description: Met's Levine Will Also Lead

title: No Changes From Brenly
description: There were no surprises when Arizona Manager Bob Brenly announced his lineup for Game 1. Tony Womack will lead off, followed by Craig Counsell, Luis Gonzalez, Reggie Sanders, Steve Finley, Matt Williams, Mark Grace, Damian Miller and Curt Schilling.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Syphilis Cases Increase
description: Syphilis is on the rise in San Francisco, health officials said, driven by men having unprotected sex with multiple male partners. Infections have doubled among gay and bisexual men in the last year, a city report said. The report cites 93 cases through September, compared with 47 in all of 2000, 29 in 1999 and 10 in 1999. In all, 116 syphilis cases were reported through September, compared with 71 cases in 2000, 47 in 1999 and 39 in 1998. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B.

title: A Governor and a Mayor Join in Honoring 2 Brothers
description: Ajoint funeral yesterday for two brothers from Long Island  one a New York City firefighter and the other a city police officer, both killed in the World Trade Center disaster  was as much a celebration of their lust for life as of their heroic deeds.

title: Modernist House in Nassau Seems Safe From Demolition
description: A Long Island house considered a prime example of Modernist architecture has been saved from demolition, a preservationist group said yesterday.

title: Journal; How to Lose a War
description: Welcome back to Sept. 10.

title: Failed Belgian Company Attracting Potential Bidders
description: The remains of Lernout & Hauspie, the once highflying Belgian software maker declared insolvent and ordered liquidated by a court on Wednesday, are already the subject of spirited maneuvering among potential buyers, who are deluging the liquidators with inquiries.

title: A Healthy Nets Team Is Too Much to Wish For
description: The Nets' underlying goal this preseason was to make it to the regular season healthy.

title: Former No. 2 In Nassau Is Accused In Scheme
description: Federal prosecutors today accused the former top deputy to Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta and six others of bribery, fraud and money laundering in a health insurance scheme that cost taxpayers $25 million and netted those charged $12.5 million in illicit fees and payoffs, according to indictments filed here.

title: Checking Forwards Recast by Devils to Spark Offense
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 26 — Seven games into the season, the A-Line has been the only line that is producing consistently for the Devils. Of the 16 goals produced by the forwards, 13 have been scored by the line of center Jason Arnott and wings Patrik Elias and Petr Sykora.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 23 Seasons, 12 Teams, One Happy Ending
description: Mike Morgan speaks in excitable ramblings. He will talk about giving up someone's 400th home run in 1979 and seconds later mention a player a few lockers down who was born that same year.

title: Swiss Lower Estimate of Toll in Tunnel Fire
description: The raging Alpine tunnel fire that broke out here on Wednesday appears to have killed far fewer people than originally feared, the police said today.

title: Koreans in China Find Their Capitalist Roots
description: South Korean businessmen and tourists are common sights here, filling the flights from Seoul, vying for rooms at the few top hotels and clambering aboard buses and vans for the five-hour ride to the slopes of Mount Paektu, the sacred mountain that straddles China's border with North Korea.

title: U.S. Is Planning an Aid Package for Pakistan That Is Worth Billions
description: The Bush administration has put together an aid package for Pakistan that is likely to total several billion dollars and includes sweeping debt rescheduling, grants stretching over many years and trade benefits as a reward for its support against terrorism.

title: Ferris Fain, A.L. Batting Champion in 1950's, Dies at 80
description: Ferris Fain, the American League batting champion in 1951 and '52 and a slick-fielding first baseman for the lackluster Philadelphia Athletics, died on Oct. 18 at his home in Georgetown, Calif. He was 80.

title: Egypt's Elite Torn by Arab Roots and Western Ties
description: In the old days, before Sept. 11, cosmopolitan Egyptians shuttled between the Arab world and the West as effortlessly as they switched from Arabic to English in mid-conversation. No one asked them to choose sides.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the use of Global Positioning System devices in identifying evidence at the World Trade Center site referred incorrectly at one point to their operating principle. The prospective hoisting of an antenna near the site is meant to improve reception of satellites' radio signals, used by the devices to calculate location; the devices do not send signals.

title: A Freshman Has Learned to Go the Distance
description: On the University of Michigan campus in Ann Arbor, Mich., Ron Warhurst, the men's cross-country coach, has a new role this fall. He has to get his athletes accustomed to reporters, big crowds, autograph hounds and all sorts of attention -- an unprecedented fuss in the low-key world of collegiate cross-country.

title: A Family, Coming From Africa To Grieve
description: When Edu Ette caught sight of the Statue of Liberty for the first time, she smiled and pointed. But it did not hold her attention for long. Instead, as she debarked from a Hudson River ferry, she was gently herded along to another sight: the remains of the World Trade Center, where on this windy day the water streaming from the fire hoses had rainbows trapped in its mist. Where her older sister, Sadie Ette, had worked on the 106th floor.

title: Talks Fail to Entice Montenegro to Stay Yugoslav
description: Long-awaited talks between the presidents of Yugoslavia and of the tiny independent-minded republic of Montenegro broke off today without agreement on how to run a federal Yugoslav state, and the two leaders said Montenegro must hold a referendum on independence next spring.

title: Peru's Ex-Spymaster Exercises Power From His Jail Cell
description: For a decade as Peru's spy chief, Vladimiro L. Montesinos bugged the presidential palace, videotaped the goings-on in bordellos and restaurant bathrooms to blackmail the nation's power brokers and controlled everything from drug trafficking to the army and, some said, even the president himself.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN POSTS PROFIT OF $213 MILLION
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the largest military contractor, said yesterday that it had a third-quarter profit of $213 million after reducing expenses, paring assets and selling more fighter aircraft. Net income was 49 cents a share. In the year-earlier quarter, Lockheed had a loss of $704 million, or $1.74, after almost $1 billion in expenses related to a loss on the sale of a business. Sales rose 7.1 percent, to $6.38 billion. Lockheed, based in Bethesda, Md., received payments on $500 million in F-16 orders in the quarter. Lockheed won a contract yesterday to build the $200 billion Joint Strike Fighter.

title: Beyond 'The Twilight Zone': An Impressionist Composition
description: Riverside Symphony

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOND, WILLIAM I.
description: HAMMOND-William I., Major, USAF, retired, age 79, of Fairfield, CT. Formerly of Garden City, L.I., NY, died on October 24, 2001. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, October 29, 2001 at 10:45 A.M. in St. Patrick's Church, Huntington, L.I. Burial with full military honors in Arlington National Cemetery, For information, Spear Funeral Home, Fairfield, CT. 203-259-0824.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENBOGEN, JOAN L.
description: ELLENBOGEN-Joan L., 59. To a courageous and unique special person, friend and attorney. You had a helluva run and there is no one quite like you. Let all who knew you commemorate and celebrate your life. Marcia C. Goldstein

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN PEACE
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. October 27th, remembrances of wonderful birthday celebrations, we miss your loving advice & your brilliant guidance. You were our tower of strength, which is so greatly missed. Love you, Malvin. Audrey, Irik and Jaar-me

title: Melding a Half-Century of Jazz Traditions
description: As a saxophonist, composer, arranger and educator, Jimmy Heath, who turned 75 two days ago, has been a connecting agent, bringing together branches of the jazz tradition.

title: Two Networks Get No Reply To Questions For bin Laden
description: More than a week after submitting lists of questions to be answered by Osama bin Laden, neither CNN nor Al Jazeera, the Arabic-language news network, has received a response or any indication that one will be coming soon.

title: Giuliani Backing Pataki In 2002 Governor's Race
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani weighed in on next year's governor's race yesterday, saying, ''I have a very important announcement to make.''

title: Offers of Free and Discounted Medicine May Help Industry Prevent New Regulations
description: The nation's largest pharmaceutical companies have tried in many ways over the last several days to show that they are good corporate citizens, offering free or discounted drugs to treat anthrax and pledging today to supply teams of their best experts to help fight bioterrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNICHOLL, KATHLEEN KING
description: McNICHOLL-Kathleen King. On October 25, 2001 of Bayside, New York. in her 95th year at Ozanam Hall. Beloved wife of the late George A. McNicholl. Devoted mother of Patricia McNicholl Quill and her husband Jeremiah, Frederick B. McNicholl, Kathleen A. Lynch and the late Elizabeth F. Carey. Grandmother of Kathleen Tellez and her husband Gustavo, Ronald Quill, Maureen, Brian and his wife Claire, and Dennis McNicholl, & Maura, Sheila and Daniel B. Lynch, Jr. Great grandmother of Claudia, Gabriela and Cristina Tellez. Daughter of the late John and Agnes King. Beloved sister of Ellen Corrigan, Agnes McGrath & the late Mary Monaghan, Bridget Rogers, Elizabeth Earnshaw and Patrick King. Also survived by many nieces and nephews in the U.S. and Ireland. Reposing at Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home, Bayside, N.Y. Visiting Saturday, October 27th, 7-9PM and Sunday, 2-5PM only. A Mass of Christian Burial, Saint Robert Bellarmine, Bayside, New York, 10:30 AM, Monday, October 29th. Burial will follow in Calvary Cemetery, Woodside. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to Carmelite Sisters Generalate, 600 Woods Rd., Germantown, New York 12526.

title: JDS Uniphase Chief Looks for an Upturn
description: The JDS Uniphase Corporation's chief executive, Jozef Straus, predicting that the streak of falling sales will stretch at least four or five quarters, said today that he was preparing for the day that orders finally rise.

title: Rival Is Executed by Taliban After Secret Return
description: Within a week of making furtive entry back into Afghanistan, Abdul Haq, a former guerrilla commander who was seen by some American officials as the potential leader of an anti-Taliban uprising, was caught and executed, his Taliban captors said today.

title: New Jersey District Map Still Helps Incumbents
description: A New Jersey commission approved a plan today to redraw the state's Congressional districts in a way that is likely to preserve the current lineup of seven Democrats and six Republicans.

title: Fire Safety Alert
description: Standard time resumes at 2 a.m. tomorrow, and clocks should be set back an hour.

title: Bloomberg Sets a $41 Million Spending Record
description: Michael R. Bloomberg has spent a record-shattering $41 million on his mayoral campaign, according to documents his campaign filed yesterday, allowing him to establish supremacy over the airwaves in television advertising, plaster the subways with campaign posters, take out full-page ads in dozens of small newspapers and even hand out blue ''Mike for Mayor'' T-shirts at campaign events.

title: PHELPS DODGE, COPPER PRODUCER, SEES QUARTERLY LOSS
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the second-largest copper producer, will lose $1.20 to $1.35 a share in the fourth quarter as the price of the metal fell, its chief executive, J. Steven Whisler, said yesterday. Three months ago, Mr. Whisler said he expected a loss of $3.10 to $3.30 a share. Copper prices are close to a two-year low in New York and a 14-year low in London as weakening economies erode demand for wire and pipes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Bush Quickly Signs Measure Aiding Antiterrorism Effort
description: President Bush signed into law today antiterrorism measures that he said would ''help law enforcement to identify, to dismantle, to disrupt and to punish terrorists before they strike.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANDROFF, BERTHA
description: SHANDROFF-Bertha. Died on October 26th at 94 years old. Daughter of Samuel and Sarah Yager. Beloved sister of the late Rose Hader and Rae Scolnick and Mitchell and Jack Yager. Wife of the late George Shandroff. Mother of Marilyn Averett and Arlene Kahn (Donald). Grandmother of Dr. Susan Greenberg (Dr. Michael), Laurie Segal (Dr. Mark), Wendy Wolff (Dr. Michael). Nana of Ariel, Asher, Alissa, Erica, Aaron, Emily, Melissa.

title: Promoting Pataki for Speeches, Agency Cites His Ground Zero Role
description: The agency that arranges for Gov. George E. Pataki to make paid speeches around the country is making a new pitch these days, billing him as someone who can offer lessons from ground zero of the World Trade Center attacks.

title: Rush for New Drugs Raises Questions About Testing
description: The rush to develop new vaccines and drugs to counter bioterrorism will pose another challenge: How should such drugs be tested so they can be approved for use?

title: CMS ENERGY SELLING SOME ASSETS OUTSIDE OF THE U.S.
description: The CMS Energy Corporation expects to raise $2.4 billion by selling assets outside the United States as the company, which owns utilities in Michigan, moves to expand its North American pipeline network and energy-trading business. CMS, which reported a third-quarter loss, said it was in talks to sell stakes in the Loy Yang power plant in Australia, as well as natural gas fields and a methanol plant in Equatorial Guinea, for $1.2 billion. CMS did not disclose a potential buyer. It is also shedding power businesses in Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela. After the sales, 90 percent of CMS's operations will be in the United States. CMS, based in Dearborn, Mich., is trying to reduce risk and cut its $6.82 billion long-term debt.

title: New York Is Selected as One of Four Finalists for the 2012 Summer Games
description: The United States Olympic Committee took the first step to naming its candidate to play host to the 2012 Summer Olympics yesterday by whittling its roster of hopefuls to New York, Washington, San Francisco and Houston. Los Angeles, Cincinnati, Tampa, Fla., and Dallas were eliminated.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Deal on Insurance Bailout

title: Who Are America's True Allies?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Company Seeks Support
description: Hyundai Asan pleaded for the government to double its financial support for the company's politically important tour service to Mount Kumkang in North Korea. The company said it needed another $35 million to operate a ferry from South Korea to a pier near the base of the mountain. The tours have lost money since they began in 1998, but they are an important part of the Seoul government's efforts to improve relations with North Korea. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Frantic Call for U.S. Help Came Too Late
description: The Mayday from Afghanistan arrived at Central Intelligence Agency headquarters on Thursday.

title: A Reminder
description: Standard time resumes at 2 a.m. tomorrow. Clocks are set back one hour.

title: Scare Halts Train Service
description: Service on the Nos. 1, 2 and 3 subway lines on the West Side was halted in both directions from 6:15 to 8:13 last night as the police responded to what was apparently an anthrax scare at the 79th Street station.

title: Inspired to Create Sculpture
description: Six years ago, after a warehouse fire set by an arsonist killed four Seattle firefighters, Randi Hubbard, a sculptor and teacher from Aberdeen, Wash., and her students began working on a memorial. As of Sept. 11, it was still unfinished.

title: Clerics Against Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The headline and first paragraph of an article yesterday about anthrax testing conducted by the State Health Department in Albany incorrectly described the pace of testing for a sample taken from Gov. George E. Pataki's Manhattan office. Although the testing from the governor's office was completed several days before samples taken the same day from the offices of ABC and CBS, the article did not show that it was ''expedited'' or ''given priority.''

title: New Regulations in California Will Reduce Diesel Emissions
description: California's Air Resources Board has adopted tough standards that would for the first time sharply reduce emissions from diesel engines, which are among the heaviest polluters on the roadways.

title: Condit Is Quietly Heading Toward Run for an 8th Term
description: It was an autumn day as bright as new copper, and the last thing anyone sipping caff latte outside the downtown Starbucks wanted to talk about was Modesto's former man in the news, Gary Condit.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISSINGER, HARRY GERARD II.
description: BISSINGER-Harry Gerard II. On October 25, 2001, age 75. Beloved husband of Eleanor Lebenthal Bissinger. Loving father of Ann Bissinger and Harry Gerard Bissinger III. Adoring grandfather of Gerry, Zachary and Caleb Bissinger and Sarah Poor. Dear brother of Eli Kaufman. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Sunday, October 28th, 2-5 and 7-9PM with service Monday, October 29th at 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is concern not only in the Islamic world, but the entire world, in the West and in the United States, at all the civilian casualties and the miseries that the civilians are being put through in Afghanistan.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILDENSTEIN, DANIEL
description: WILDENSTEIN - Daniel. The Board and staff of the French Institute Alliance Francaise extend their deepest sympathy to the family of Daniel Wildenstein. Often behind the scenes, the Wildenstein family has played a crucial role in advancing French - American friendship and French culture throughout the United States. Indeed, their unselfish leadership gave light to many major presentations and projects of the French Institute Alliance Francaise without any wish for recognition. We are saddened by the loss of this soft-spoken man and pay tribute to the contributions he has made to the world of art and culture in his lifetime. Our heartfelt condolences to his son, Guy, an outstanding member of our Board, his brother, Alec, and the entire Wildenstein family. John H.F. Haskell, Jr., President Board of Trustees David S. Black, Executive Director

title: Lockheed Wins $200 Billion Deal for Fighter Jet
description: ''The Lockheed Martin team was a clear winner,'' said James Roche, the secretary of the Air Force, who was in charge of the selection process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMMON, TED
description: AMMON-Ted. Age 52, on October 22, 2001. Survived by his wife Generosa. Loving father of Alexa and Gregory. Devoted brother of Sandi Williams. Memorial service Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, Monday, October 29th, 1 P.M. Contributions in his memory may be made to Jazz at Lincoln Center, 33 West 60th St, NY, NY 10023-7999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, RICHARD N.
description: DANIEL-Richard N. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. John D. Martin, President

title: Vaccines for Smallpox
description: To the Editor:

title: Sooners and Huskers: Two Originals in a Sequel
description: In the Game of the Century, Johnny Rodgers made the play of the day. Less than four minutes into the game between Nebraska and Oklahoma on Nov. 25, 1971, in Norman, Okla., Rodgers produced a weaving, 72-yard punt return for a touchdown that helped Nebraska to a 35-31 victory. The game 30 years ago between two great teams from nearby states in search of a national championship was a shifting struggle until the final moments. Will there ever be another like it?

title: Anthrax Brings the Profiteers Out in Force
description: Polaris International is worried that you are not doing enough to protect yourself from an anthrax attack.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Path Cleared For Settlement
description: The European Union security chief, Javier Solana, said he had succeeded in breaking the deadlock between leaders of the main Macedonian Slav and ethnic Albanian political parties over constitutional changes. An agreement on the last sticking point, the wording of the preamble, is expected to pave the way for Parliament finally to ratify a package of political reforms as part of a peace agreement. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Italy's Global Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Sex Offender's Arrest, Some at Rutgers Still Worry
description: A jailed sex offender was charged this morning in a string of summertime burglaries and assaults against three female Rutgers University students.

title: Twin Sisters Dominate Races
description: A pair of twin sisters -- Kate and Laura O'Neill of Yale, and Catherine and Megan Guiney of Boston College -- dominated two of the three collegiate cross-country running championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

title: Fear Feeds Bull Market In Private Security; After Sept. 11, Former Law Enforcers See a Surge in Demand for Their Skills
description: A year ago, things at Robert H. Silbering's private investigative and security company on Third Avenue were, if occasionally exotic, still fairly predictable.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro dropped against the dollar, which was buoyed by a better-than-expected University of Michigan consumer sentiment index. In New York, the euro settled at 89.22 cents, down from 89.37 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSING, GEORGE J.
description: MESSING-George J. Of Woodmere, New York, Oct. 25, 2001. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Cherished father & father-in-law of Joel & Barbara, Fred & Laura, Rick & Carol, Michael and Carol. Beloved stepfather of Sunny and John, Michael and Diane, Sheryl & Hap. Proud grandfather. Mr. Messing worked in women's wear manufacturing. He served as a Staff Sergeant in US Army Air Forces during WWII. Services 9:30 AM Sunday, Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Bdwy, Hewlett, LI.

title: U.S. PLANES BOMB A RED CROSS SITE
description: American warplanes bombed and largely destroyed the same Red Cross complex in Kabul that they struck 10 days ago, an error the Pentagon admitted tonight, saying it occurred because military planners had picked the wrong target.

title: Reliant Energy Quarterly Net Falls 25%
description: Reliant Energy Inc., the owner of Houston's utility, said today that its third-quarter net income fell 25 percent because of cooler weather, higher generator costs and a loss from its European unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'LOUGHLIN, JANET WARD
description: O'LOUGHLIN-Janet Ward, 90. Of Evergreen Woods, North Branford, CT, died October 25, 2001.

description: The Taliban's Harsh Hand

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, DAVID
description: SAVAGE-David. October 27, 1989. Remembered always, with love, by his family.

title: The War Has Just Begun
description: After three weeks of American bombing runs, the limits of air power are evident in Afghanistan. Osama bin Laden remains in hiding and the Taliban have not crumbled. In a costly mistake yesterday, a Red Cross warehouse was accidentally bombed again. Word also came that an important opposition leader whom Washington had looked to as a potential rallying point for dissident Pashtuns had been captured and executed by Taliban forces.

title: Bloomberg Is Said To Get Nod From Mayor
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided to endorse Michael R. Bloomberg for mayor, and the announcement could come as early as today, according to Republicans familiar with the decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ROBERT P.
description: MARCUS-Robert P., life-long love, companion, and best friend of his wife Betty G. Marcus; beloved son of the late Libby P. Marcus and Bernard K. Marcus; caring and devoted son-in-law of the late Ziuta Gerstenzang Akston and Leo Gerstenzang; proud and loving father of his daughter, Lauren Marcus Hughes; adoring grandfather of Christopher Robert Marcus Hughes and Meghan Ruth Marcus Hughes and father of Gary P. Marcus. He enriched the lives of all those he met and all those who called him friend, for he was a kind, caring, wise and gentle man. He was a natural leader who spent a lifetime quietly and selflessly helping others and improving the lives of untold numbers of people. He will be remembered by all those he touched forever and ever. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00 AM on Sunday, October 28, 2001 at Ferncliff Cemetery, 280 Secor Rd., Hartsdale, NY. For information, contact Quattlebaum Funeral Home at 561-832-5171.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, JERRY
description: GOODMAN-Jerry. President of Grand Machinery Exchange. Beloved husband of Pearl. Devoted father of Susan (Dr. George) Schabes and Larry (Andrea) Goodman. Cherished grandfather of Madeline & Caroline Goodman, Alena, Jason & Amanda Schabes. Services on Sunday, October 28, 11:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Czerkawski Revives Old Habit to Continue Isles' Run
description: Mariusz Czerkawski, smiling and clearly relieved, would joke later that he should have kept the puck. He would joke that he had gone so long without scoring that he had almost forgotten how to do it.

title: Behind the Veil
description: To the Editor:

title: Agents Start Digging Up Old Files On Hoaxes
description: A series of cases in recent years involving anthrax threats has drawn the attention of federal investigators, who are reviewing their files for clues to the source, motive and possible identity of the people behind the recent anthrax-contaminated letters.

title: McGreevey and Schundler Say Failing Teachers Should Go
description: With education topping the list of issues in the New Jersey governor's race, both James E. McGreevey and Bret D. Schundler are vowing to make it easier to fire poorly performing teachers who have tenure. But they take starkly different approaches, and some experts say each has its flaws.

title: America Doesn't Know What the World Is Saying
description: America has a problem of linguistic security: We don't understand the languages of our attackers. Just a week after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the Federal Bureau of Investigation was offering $38 an hour for translators of Arabic or of Pashto, the language of about 35 percent of the people of Afghanistan, including the Taliban. Many in Afghanistan, where bilingualism is widespread, understand both.

title: Williams Pushed for an Edge He Hopes to Keep
description: The Yankees' second full spring training workout had been over for about an hour and the clubhouse at Legends Field was empty. Thirty minutes passed from the last player's leaving until Bernie Williams, his face drenched with sweat and his uniform soiled, even ambled into the empty room in Tampa, Fla.

title: Cybersleuths Take On the Mystery of the Collapsing Colossus
description: A newspaper headline in the northern French town of Beauvais put the question bluntly: ''Will the Americans Save the Cathedral?.'' The Americans in this case are a team of architectural historians and computer scientists from Columbia University. The cathedral is the local behemoth: a 700-year-old, extravagant experiment in High Gothic architecture that was once the tallest building in Europe but is now on the World Monuments Fund's list of 100 most endangered sites.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT CLIMBS. Wheat rose on speculation that heavy rains might damage fields in Argentina, a big exporter. Wheat for December delivery rose 6 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $2.95 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBENZINGER, NATHAN
description: OBENZINGER-Nathan, 94. October 24, 2001. Beloved husband of Romana, loving father of Ronald, Mark and Hilton and generous grandfather to Rachel, Isaac and Eric. A good man, a good husband and a good father. Our love for him goes on.

title: Human Rights in Mexico
description: Last week's killing of Digna Ochoa, one of Mexico's foremost human rights lawyers, had all the markings of a political execution carried out by powerful interest groups that are confident they can act with impunity, as they always have. Ms. Ochoa was shot at close range in her downtown Mexico City office. A note left behind warned other human rights lawyers that they would be next.

title: James Levine To Take Post In Boston
description: In a seismic occurrence in the classical musical world, James Levine, the longtime artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera and one of the world's most celebrated conductors, has accepted the post of music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, succeeding Seiji Ozawa, people close to the agreement said last night. He will keep his position at the Met.

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: ALL SUICIDE BOMBERS ARE NOT ALIKE

title: An Economic Stimulus Bill With Corporations in Mind
description: Late last winter, when President Bush was shaping his $1.35 trillion tax cut, corporate lobbyists were told to wait, their turn would come. And now, their turn is here.

title: In Yet Another Mystery, North Korea Has Suddenly Turned Testy
description: In an unusual statement even for a country known for frequent rhetorical excesses, the North Korean government said today that it was no longer interested in dialogue or improved relations with the United States.

title: Grenada Discounts
description: The Blue Horizons Cottage Hotel in Grenada is taking 30 percent off its room rates on seven-night stays or longer, valid through April 15. Bookings must be made by Dec. 15. The rates at the 32-cottage hotel are $84 to $91, down from $120 to $130 a night, for a double, through Dec. 15. From Dec. 16 through April 15, the rates rise to $126 to $133 a night. All rooms have kitchenettes. The hotel is about a quarter-mile from Grand Anse Beach and it has a pool. Information: (473) 444-4316 or www.bluegrenada.com .

title: Brenly Keeps It Simple
description: As a member of the Arizona Diamondbacks' front office said yesterday, ''It's been embellished a thousand times.'' In the interest of historical accuracy, then, just in case the Diamondbacks beat the Yankees in the World Series, the moment their quest began is hereby presented in the words of the man who created it.

title: Oil and Patriotism
description: To the Editor:

title: Ismat Kittani, 72, Kurdish Diplomat Who Loyally Served Iraq
description: Ismat Kittani, an adroit Kurdish diplomat who represented Iraq at the United Nations from 1985 to 1989, was president of the General Assembly and served five secretaries general in senior posts, died on Tuesday in Geneva. He was 72. The cause was cancer.

title: Yankees Have a Plan to Beat Arizona's Heat
description: Curt Schilling has not pitched against the Yankees in a couple of years, but the Yankees' hitters have a pretty good point of reference as they prepare for Game 1 of the World Series. They see a pitcher who is a lot like Schilling once every five days: Roger Clemens.

title: Paris Journal; With A B C's of Dining, France Raises Epicures
description: It is 9:30 a.m. and the second-grade class at the cole de la Bienfaisance is deep into its first lesson. The instructor has chalk in hand. The blackboard is filled with diagrams.

title: KRAFT FOODS IS OFFERING EARLY RETIREMENT
description: Kraft Foods, which is integrating Nabisco Holdings into its business, is offering some workers in the United States early retirement in a program that is expected to eliminate 1,000 jobs. Kraft, which trails Nestl in sales, has been shedding some plants, businesses and administrative staff to reduce costs. Kraft's parent, the Philip Morris Companies, bought Nabisco last December for $18.9 billion. The plan will save the company $80 million a year and will cost $160 million pretax in the first quarter, Kraft said. On Oct. 12, Kraft announced plans to close three Nabisco plants in Latin America and lay off 500 workers as it moves operations to other countries. The company employs 117,000 workers worldwide.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: A New Chief At Ericsson
description: Encouraged by a change in management that will cause Ericsson's longtime chairman to step down, investors bid the stock up 2.9 percent, to $4.48. Ericsson, the large Swedish wireless equipment manufacturer, said late on Thursday that Michael Treschow, above, chief executive of Electrolux, the Swedish appliance manufacturer, would succeed Lars Ramqvist as chairman. Ericsson is expected to post a loss for 2001, its first in more than half a century. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Anthrax Outbreak of '57 Felled a Mill but Yielded Answers
description: It started with a scratchy throat, a parched sensation that would not go away no matter what Albert Langlois did. It was 1957 and Mr. Langlois had started a new job just two months earlier, working at the Arms Textile Mill, pulling out wool and goat hair that was too short to be made into fabric.

title: An American Report Finds the Taliban's Violation of Religious Rights 'Particularly Severe'
description: The Bush administration designated the Taliban leadership of Afghanistan today as a ''particularly severe violator'' of religious freedom and said the status of ethnic and religious minorities in the country had deteriorated over the last year.

title: There's No Business Like 'The Producers'
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Jets' Swayne Is a Player for All Seasons
description: Kevin Swayne has not had a week off since January. If he is lucky, or good, he will not get another this season -- an entire year of football without a break.

title: Pakistan Chief Says the U.S. Should End Bombing Soon
description: Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said today that the United States should end the bombing of Afghanistan soon and switch to a ''political strategy'' that would produce a post-Taliban government capable of meeting American objectives.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Picks Up
description: Britain's economy grew more than expected in the third quarter, with output up 2.2 percent from the third quarter of 2000. The oil and gas industry was among the best-performing sectors, while growth in services slowed from the second quarter. Retail spending continued to buoy the economy, while manufacturing continued to contract. Growth rates have been rising all year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Who Are America's True Allies?
description: To the Editor:

title: Straddling Realms Sacred and Secular
description: New York Virtuoso Singers

title: A Cadre of Survivors True To Punk's First Principle
description: The fans at the Damned show on Monday at Irving Plaza were the kind who'd grown into their tattoos. These men in leather and women in fishnet greeted one another with the warmth that comes from years of traveling in the same tribe. They were gathered to revel in the antics of a band that, from one perspective, started punk, and that may be the longest to survive it.

title: Sports of The Times; In Age of Old Warriors, an Antique Seeks a Breeders' Cup Upset
description: THE horse's name is Bet on Sunshine and, at 9, he is what you would call a veritable racing antique. Roger Clemens, at 39, will be pitching in the World Series next week. Michael Jordan, at 38, will be leading off pro basketball's opening-night highlights package. If trainer Paul McGee's veteran thoroughbred can pull off an upset this afternoon at Belmont in the Breeders' Cup Sprint, we may want to establish this as ancient warriors' week.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Oct. 11 about a discussion between the White House national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and executives of the five major television networks about the presentation of videotapes of Osama bin Laden mischaracterized an outcome of the talks. The executives agreed to consider editing such tapes to remove language that might incite violence against Americans, but not to do so automatically. They said they would determine what to exclude, not the government.

title: A Special Sign of Respect
description: The students at Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx, a Roman Catholic school for boys, take death and violence in stride. In fact, there is a standard procedure when a boy loses a parent: everyone in his homeroom is bused to the funeral.

title: Mixed Notices For the $480 Ticket
description: The producers of ''The Producers'' said yesterday that calls were pouring in asking how to buy the handful of tickets they are offering to each performance for the record-shattering price of $480 apiece. But the reviews of their plan -- which they described as a war on rampant ticket scalping -- were more mixed than anything else received by the hit musical.

title: What Made the I.R.A. Disarm?
description: DOWNPATRICK, Northern Ireland -- The decision of the Irish Republican Army to begin disarming is a significant milestone in the Northern Ireland peace process. It signals an irreversible shift to democratic politics and a final abandonment of the bullet in favor of the ballot box.

title: Montclair's Collins Expects to Be No. 1
description: Almost from the day he arrived at Montclair State, Ed Collins declared the university would win a Division III national title while he was the quarterback. That Collins was a 22-year-old freshman who had been playing professional baseball the previous four years did not faze receiver Eric Magrini.

title: The Lost Years
description: Until he joined the Diamondbacks, Luis Gonzalez had a decidedly mediocre career. He played for nine seasons and never hit 25 homers, drove in 80 runs or batted over .300. Since arriving in Arizona in a December 1998 trade from Detroit for Karim Garcia, Gonzalez has topped all those marks each season.

title: 10 Writers Receive Whiting Awards
description: Ten writers were named winners of the 2001 Whiting Writers' Awards on Thursday at the Pierpont Morgan Library. The $35,000 awards, established in 1985, are given annually to emerging writers by the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation. Five fiction writers, two poets, two nonfiction writers and a playwright were chosen by a committee of writers, literary scholars and editors.

title: Each of the Races Is an Event in the Olympics of Horse Racing
description: The Irish trainer Aidan O'Brien was talking about the star of his barn, Galileo, and how he might capture North America's richest race: the Breeders' Cup $4 million Classic. ''He wants a strongly run race,'' O'Brien said of Galileo, a 3-year-old colt who has won six of seven races and more than $2.2 million. ''He likes a fast run that comes down to a grind rather than a slowly run race where they quicken at the end.''

title: Czechs Confirm Iraqi Agent Met With Terror Ringleader
description: The Czech interior minister said today that an Iraqi intelligence officer met with Mohammed Atta, one of the ringleaders of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, just five months before the synchronized hijackings and mass killings were carried out.

title: New York's Olympic Bid
description: The United States Olympic Committee gave a vote of confidence in New York when it designated the city yesterday as a finalist among the American sites for the 2012 Olympics. Some committee members no doubt wanted to help the city in its time of trial. But holding the games in New York made sense in many ways before Sept. 11, and continues to be an exciting prospect -- if questions of financing and facilities can be resolved. Unfortunately, the if's still loom very large.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Belatedly, An Heir To The Throne
description: King Gyanendra declared his only son, Paras, left, as next in line for the throne, an announcement that is believed to have been delayed by people's resentment over Paras's past conduct. Gyanendra assumed the throne in June after his brother, King Birendra, and Queen Aishwarya were shot to death along with six other members of the royal family by Birendra's son Dipendra, who died of self-inflicted gunshot wounds, according to the official account. The oldest son is traditionally appointed crown prince when a king ascends the throne. Paras is unpopular because of his reputation as a carouser and his involvement in two fatal car accidents. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Neutrality Is Old-Fangled, Leader Says
description: Chancellor Wolfgang Schssel said his country's neutrality is ''an old convention'' that no longer fits ''the complex reality of the beginning of the 21st century.'' Mr. Schssel, a conservative, spoke yesterday on the anniversary of Austria's independence in 1955, when the World War II Allies agreed to end their in return for Austrian neutrality. The current coalition against terrorism has made many question the value of that neutrality. ''The old conventions,'' Mr. Schssel said, ''whether they are Mozart balls,'' an Austrian candy, ''Lipizzaner or neutrality, don't cut it any more in the complex reality of the beginning of the 21st century.''

description: The decision of the Irish Republican Army to begin disarming is a significant milestone in the Northern Ireland peace process. It signals an irreversible shift to democratic politics and a final abandonment of the bullet in favor of the ballot box.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Governor Rejects Smoking Ban
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, overruled the state health board and rejected a ban on smoking in restaurants. The board had voted 15 to 4 to ban smoking in public establishments that earn more than 30 percent of their income from food sales. Mr. Huckabee, a nonsmoker who has received tobacco industry campaign contributions, said he could not act based on personal preferences. ''The issue is not whether smoking is good or bad,'' Mr. Huckabee said. ''Restaurants are privately owned. No one is forced to be a patron or an employee.''

title: White House and Key Senators Revise Proposal on Aid to Insurers
description: The Bush administration and the three senior members of the Senate banking committee reached agreement today on a framework for a financial assistance package for the insurance industry. Under the plan, the government would not provide any assistance until after the industry suffered significant losses, perhaps as high as $10 billion, from any terrorist attacks next year, administration and Congressional officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Pain From Low Chip Prices
description: The NEC Corporation, the Toshiba Corporation and the Sanyo Electric Company all reported sharply lower earnings for the half-year that ended Sept. 30, because of falling semiconductor prices and a steep decline in spending on electronics in Japan and the United States. Toshiba, the No. 2 manufacturer of software chips after Intel, lost 123 billion yen ($1 billion); NEC, ranked No. 3, lost 29.8 billion yen (about $242.4 million). Sanyo, whose products range from washing machines to cellphone batteries, posted a 6.4 billion yen ($52 million) profit, down 68 percent from the period last year. NEC said it would close a disk-drive factory in the Philippines that employs 1,400 workers. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: All that remains of the freighter New Carissa is 2,300 tons of rusting steel: a severed engine room leaning heavily to starboard and a crane mired in the breakers near the passage to Coos Bay.

description: President Vladimir V. Putin signed a measure that permits the purchase and sale of nonagricultural land, overturning a Soviet-era ban. Although people were already permitted to own buildings and houses, they can now buy and sell the land these are built on. The new code covers 3 to 10 percent of the country's land. The sale of farmland will be regulated by laws the government says it will formulate by the end of the year. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Corrections

The executives agreed to consider editing such tapes to remove language that might incite violence against Americans, but not to do so automatically. They said they would determine what to exclude, not the government.

title: FINANCING ARM SELLS $6 BILLION WORTH OF DEBT
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financing arm of G.M., sold $6 billion worth of debt. ''Despite all the troubles in the auto sector, these bonds are good buys,'' said Robert Kinsey, who placed an order for the 10-year notes for the $11.5 billion of fixed-income assets he helps manage at ING Pilgrim Investments. The bond sale comes as G.M.A.C. is offering no-interest loans to General Motors customers who buy cars beginning Sept. 19, and has extended its offer until Nov. 18. The financing unit was able to sell its bonds after retaining its A2 rating from Moody's Investors Service, which cut its rating on G.M. to A3. General Motors and G.M.A.C. had had the same Moody's rating since 1982.
