title: October 21-27; Some Kursk Answers
description: Fourteen months after it exploded and plunged to the Barents Sea floor, and two weeks after a monumental salvage effort raised it 350 feet back to the surface, the Russian nuclear submarine Kursk finally began to surrender the last of its 118 crewmen. In the closed military port of Roslyakovo, far above the Arctic Circle, a military team entered the aft section and removed 3 bodies, adding to the 12 that divers had recovered in that area a year ago. But the answer to why the Kursk sank probably lies in the sub's shattered bow, which was sawed off during the salvage operation and still lies on the sea floor. It may be recovered next year. Michael Wines

title: Trophy House
description: People call it a hunting lodge -- which is understandable, since it's filled with animal heads, antlers and tusks -- but no hunting goes on here. Indeed, Piero Ambrogio Busnelli, the owner of this 19th-century cow barn turned weekend retreat, calls it a ''museum'' and describes its 39-acre park outside Milan as ''sacred.'' Although he hunted many of the trophies displayed inside the house, he treats the sheep, deer and birds he keeps outside with almost the same fondness he reserves for Bello, the malamute that roams the property with him.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: ''BELIEVE me, he don't take it from nobody,'' says Vincent D'Onofrio as Robert E. Howard, describing his creation Conan the Barbarian. ''He'll fight man, beast, devil or god.'' THE WHOLE WIDE WORLD (1996), a wonderfully acted romantic drama, reveals the awful truth: big, bad Conan was created by a small-town Texas boy still living at home with his parents. Bob's love interest, Novalyne Price (Renee Zellweger), is a teacher but also an aspiring writer (with a stack of rejection slips from confession magazines). Bob impresses her, even when he brings her a copy of Weird Tales magazine, but there are problems. He's creepily close to his mother and has some deep-seated anger. This film, directed by Dan Ireland, was released just before Ms. Zellweger won America's collective heart in ''Jerry Maguire.'' She might not have the courage to do Novalyne's unglamorous lumbering walk these days -- Sunday at 6 p.m. on WE.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDRICH, LARRY
description: ALDRICH-Larry. The staff of The Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Connecticut, mourns the passing of the Museum's founder and Chairman Emeritus, Larry Aldrich, and celebrates his commitment to emerging artists and the art of our time. His support of the Museum's curatorial and education mission was steadfast and unwavering. His boldness of vision and willingness to take risks are an inspiration to us. We are dedicated to carrying forward his vision of a Museum committed to championing emerging artists. His funding for the purchase of work by emerging artists at the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art, as well as his opening of the Soho Center for Visual Arts in 1973, brought his love for contemporary art to a wider audience. His quiet support of many causes and activities in the Town of Ridgefield, which he loved so well, has improved the life of its citizens. His spirit of adventure, keen intelligence, serene confidence, and sly humor will be deeply missed by us all. We look back fondly on his love for The Aldrich Museum and its exhibitions, how he sang to himself as he walked up the stairs to see a new exhibition, and how his eyes would light up at the sight of children in the Museum's education programs.

title: October 21-27; New Power for Investigators
description: When President Bush signed a new antiterrorism bill, he said it would protect constitutional rights while ''preventing more atrocities in the hands of the evil ones.'' But the law also reaches beyond terrorism, making it easier for federal agents to eavesdrop on all kinds of potential criminals and to search homes and electronic communications without notice. The bill's money-laundering provisions may have more targets in organized crime and drug trafficking than among terrorists. Adam Clymer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADENBAUM, DAVID
description: ADENBAUM-David. 86, died October 27, 2001, after a gracious struggle with heart disease and leukemia. Beloved husband of the late Betty (nee Sachs). Adored father of Samuel and his wife Gilda Kramer, Ann and her fiance Alan Schramm. Proud grandfather of Jacob and Benjamin Adenbaum. Caring brother-in-law of Norma Sachs. Uncle of Edwin Schwimmer, George Stanton, David and Robert Sachs, and Terry Newman. Brother of the late Selma Schwimmer and Alex Adenbaum. He served as an officer in the U.S. Army during WWII and participated in the Normandy Invasion. Services on Monday, October 29, 12 noon, at Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, NY. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Guidance Center in New Rochelle, NY, or Lafayette College in Easton, PA.

title: Stranded
description: To the Editor: Like Jon Margolis, my husband and I were in Missoula, Mont., on vacation Sept. 11. Our reservations to fly home to New Jersey were not until the 17th, so we had more time than Mr. Margolis to devise an alternative plan of transportation.

title: The Islands Feel an Autumn Chill
description: IT did not take long for Caribbean resorts to feel the aftershocks of Sept. 11. At the seven island properties managed by Wyndham Hotels and Resorts, which include the 488-room Wyndham Rose Hall Resort in Jamaica and 300-room Wyndham Sugar Bay Resort in St. Thomas, occupancy levels plunged. They dropped to between 20 and 30 percent the week of Sept. 16, half the normal rate for the slow autumn season.

title: The World; Is There One War Against Terrorism, or Two?
description: FOR the United States and Israel, the events of Sept. 11 created a burst of solidarity. But as the shock has worn off, the impression has grown that the two nations are pursuing parallel wars. Although the two countries have one of the strongest strategic alliances in the world, they seem to be getting increasingly in each other's way -- and on each other's nerves.

description: The California Institute of Technology has announced that it has received the largest gift to a university, $600 million from Gordon Moore, the longtime chairman of the Intel Corporation, and his wife, Betty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHKRUG, PAUL
description: ROTHKRUG-Paul. In San Francisco on October 23, age 86. Inspiring mentor, noted for his integrity; compassion; unflinching activism for human dignity and environmental survival. Harvard Class of '36; WW II (Battle of the Bulge; Counter - Intelligence Officer); made history again after the war during his nationally honored 40year career in life insurance/employee benefits, as the first ever to pass all parts of CLU exams at first and only sitting. Retired from Connecticut to San Francisco in 1980, Paul focused his passionate intellect and spirituality on environmental action, published his ''Mending the Earth-A World For Our Grandchildren,'' 1991; founded Environmental Rescue Fund. He leaves his wife Shirley, daughters Barbara and Dana, son Stephen, brother Lionel, and many nieces and nephews. Memorial contributions requested to AppalachiaScience in the Public Interest, 50 Lair St., Mt. Vernon, KY 40456.

Adoring grandfather of Ethan D'Ver and Talia Eshel Gloster. Dear brother of Helen Richards and the late Amos E. Gloster. He filled our lives with love and laughter.

description: ''The Life and Times of Little Jimmy B,'' inspired by the childhood of James Baldwin, is a portrait of the artist as a young black writer, unmoored and isolated in the ghetto of Depression-era Harlem. The short film, written and directed by Alison McDonald, a graduate film student at Columbia, is one of half a dozen works about New York included in the fifth annual Shorts International Film Festival. Nov. 12-14 at Loews Lincoln Square Theater, 68th Street and Broadway, and Nov. 12-13 at the Tribeca Grand Hotel, 2 Avenue of the Americas (White Street).

description: THE Clancys of City Island in the Bronx do not consider themselves a military family. Even though one of their male relatives is buried in a mass grave near the Argonne, the forest in France where thousands of soldiers died in World War I. Another stormed a beach in Normandy on D-Day and ended up posing for a picture in Hitler's captured Alpine retreat. Yet another, First Lt. Gregory J. Clancy, 24, is on high alert with his Marine Corps unit in North Carolina and expects at any time to be sent to fight the Taliban.

description: IF Osama bin Laden were captured tomorrow and brought to America for trial, Eddie Jacobs Jr. would be glad to defend him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, ALBERT B., M.D.
description: STEWART-Albert B., M.D. Age 93, died after a short illness, in Fort Lauderdale, formerly of New York, NY, on Saturday, October 20. He was a wonderful father, and a good-hearted man, who never said a harsh word about anyone. He was a physician, an anesthesiologist, a ''renaissance man,'' whose vast knowledge of so many subjects astounded his family up until the end, as he always had a drop of wisdom to share. He is survived by his second wife, Meri Sherman Stewart, an artist (his first wife and mother of his children was Estelle P. Stewart, a New York City school teacher who died in 1984); his children, Barbara Stewart Consiglio, M.D., & Connie Stewart Slow, M.D., and their husbands, Michael A. Consiglio, M.D., and Jan Slow, M.S.W.; his grandchildren, Gabrielle and Peter, and a sister, Koti Max in Australia. He will be sorely missed and never forgotten. Contributions may be made in his memory to the American Red Cross. Burial to be private.

People have been calling to request information about programs and ask whether there is room to stay for a few days.

description: AT the heart of the sudden collapse in investor confidence in the Enron Corporation are unusual trades it entered into with partnerships led by its chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, beginning in the summer of 1999. Because they were transactions among related parties, the company was required to disclose them, but the disclosures raised as many questions as they answered. Following are some questions that investors are asking, and the currently available answers.

title: An Aging Beauty Could Get a Needed Nip and a Tuck
description: Orchard Beach, once famously known as the Riviera of the Bronx, is shrinking. Acres have been lost to erosion since the 1930's, when Robert Moses oversaw the creation of the crescent-shaped beach that gave Bronx residents an accessible summertime retreat. No new sand has been added since 1964.

title: Huntsville Journal; Olympian Security as a Town Prepares for Games
description: In less than four months, the world's best downhill skiers will converge on this tiny town of fewer than 600 residents and its ski resort, Snowbasin, for some of the premier events of the 2002 Olympics.

title: The Making of The Speech
description: At any other time, I might have read and then dismissed the efforts of the Bush administration to hone a perfect speech as just another example of manipulative president-packaging (D.T. Max, Oct. 7). However, given its juxtaposition to the image of Osama bin Laden, microphone in hand, delivering exaltations and threats as adroitly as a seasoned field correspondent filing an exclusive battlefield report, I am now a shameless booster of the administration's efforts. I have an uneasy feeling that bin Laden is the best-packaged man on the planet.

title: University Develops Housing in Chicago
description: In an effort to both expand and enhance its downtown campus, the University of Illinois has teamed up with a consortium of private developers to transform a formerly blighted Near South Side neighborhood into a community with almost 1,000 new homes. About 80 percent of the homes will be sold at market rates, the remainder at lower prices with income ceilings for buyers.

description: IF you cross Carmen Miranda with Lenny Bruce and Tina Turner, you might come up with the choreographer and performance artist Patricia Hoffbauer. A lusciously physical dancer with a theatrical face and a deep voice, she spices up performances with witty, sometimes raunchy rants. When she gets worked up, her body undulates for added emphasis.

description: The House of Representatives last week approved the sale of war bonds for the first time since World War II, but the Treasury was lukewarm about the measure.

title: MacARTHUR GRANT
description: A Princeton University astrophysicist, David Spergel, was among 23 recipients of MacArthur Fellowships named last week. His work has ranged from researching the origin of the universe to searching for Earth-like planets. The $500,000 grants, awarded by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, recognize those who provide new ideas that can improve people's lives or encourage movement on important issues. Sarah Rubenstein

title: October 21-27; Fleeing Into Disaster
description: It is the new route to freedom, but so far it has ended mostly in disappointment and disaster. In recent months, increasing thousands of asylum seekers from the Middle East have been flying by various routes to Indonesia, where they board smuggling boats for the short journey to Australia.

Day of Henderson, Nev. The Rev. Thomas N. Synan performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

description: Symbol Technologies (NYSE: SBL) of Holtsville reported a net loss of $35.7 million for the third quarter and described the results as being in line with expectations during a time of ''macroeconomic uncertainty.''

title: Theater; Annals of Asia In America, In Small Bites
description: MATHEMATICALLY speaking, Columbus Park in Lower Manhattan is not a perfect square. Some of its sides stretch longer than others, paths diverge into the street and trees obscure its edges. The park, on the corner of Bayard and Mulberry Streets in Chinatown, is where Cantonese meets Mandarin on a Sunday afternoon. Where -- despite recent police barricades and American flags tacked to dim sum menus -- one still hears the rhythmic click-clack of mah-jongg tiles on cardboard tables, sees clairvoyants peddle palm readings (''Trust me -- 30 years on job!'') and feels the resilient thrust of life carrying on.

title: Nancy O'Neill and Phillip Van Horn
description: WHEN the bombs stopped falling in Kosovo in the summer of 1999, Nancy Taylor O'Neill went to work. As a deputy public affairs officer for the State Department, she helped the province get back on its feet, creating a network of local radio stations, establishing Internet centers to help entrepreneurs and doing advance work for visiting dignitaries as they tried to rebuild the war-torn region.

title: Susan Herzlinger, Matthew Botein
description: Susan Freida Herzlinger, the daughter of Regina and George A. Herzlinger of Belmont, Mass., was married last evening to Matthew Bernard Botein, the son of Barbara Botein of New York and Atlanta, and Michael H. Botein of South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Earl A. Grollman officiated at the Four Seasons hotel in Boston.

title: The Making of The Speech
description: I am tired of reading how intemperate President Bush was with comments like ''wanted: dead or alive.'' To my mind, he said just what we needed to hear. We need someone who will fight for our country.

title: Young Scores 4 Times to Lead Army's Offensive Show
description: Army had many reasons to welcome Tulane to Michie Stadium today. For one, the Black Knights had beaten the Green Wave here last season to end a 10-game losing streak. Second, Tulane came into the game with the worst defensive statistics in Conference USA. Third, Tulane was without its record-breaking quarterback, Patrick Ramsey, who was sidelined with a laceration on his passing hand.

title: That Motorcyclist May Be Your Pediatrician
description: HOWARD SCHNEIDER of Plainview is a psychologist specializing in the treatment of autism and other developmental disabilities. Mr. Schneider, a homeowner, husband and father of three, drives around in a Volvo wagon, but his inner child rips up the road in a Kawasaki Vulcan 750.

title: Madeleine Sanchez, Matthew McGinley

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ELI
description: GOLDSTEIN-Eli. Thank you, darling Eli, for your unconditional love, devotion and the beautiful memories you have given us. You will always be with us. Your family-Florence, Bruce, Judy, Rachim, Jessi and Becky

title: Door Locks And Weights From Africa
description: THE African Art Museum of the S.M.A. Fathers (Society of African Missions) has three new exhibitions in its compact but very efficient space here.

title: SOAPBOX; The Eczema Files
description: FROM sightings of the Jersey Devil to tales of the exit ramp in Franklin Lakes that makes cars drift backward uphill, readings abound regarding legends of Garden State hauntings. Jerseyans are more than familiar with tales of knife-wielding psychotics, chain-saw killers and rabid creatures. And those are just the neighbors.

title: Panama Is Putting Journalists on Trial
description: Julio Briceo has a million-dollar drawing on his desk at La Prensa, the newspaper where he is an editorial cartoonist famous for his sharp pen and sharp wit. Unfortunately, that sum is what the paper might have to pay in damages to a former vice president of Panama who was offended by the sketch, which criticized his newfound political alliance with old enemies.

title: First, Gouge Their Eyes
description: WAS he delusional? Was it simply a simpler time? My father actually believed he could make me safe. Living in New York, I'd be just fine if I did exactly what he told me to. No matter what apocalyptic disaster struck, if I was prepared for it I'd be O.K..

description: Florida State quarterback Chris Rix said with a smile that it turned out to be a good thing today when Maryland linebacker E. J. Henderson knocked him out of the game for a series with a head injury.

title: American Ingredients in French Dishes
description: MERITAGE in Roslyn breaks the conventional brasserie mold. Rather than trying to recreate a French haunt, shipped over piece by piece from Paris, its owners, Tom Schaudel (of Tease and Coolfish) and Blake Verity (Blake's Bistro and before that Panama Hatties), have opted for a French-American amalgam. Their very affordable new restaurant, at 1362 Old Northern Boulevard (516-625-7771) where Cafe Laguna had been, is a refined brasserie-bistro that frequently uses American ingredients in comforting French dishes.

description: WHEN George and Lynn Kimmerle finally received zoning approval from Stonington to renovate their weekend house in the borough last January they thought the controversy was finally over.

title: COMMUNITY COLLEGES
description: Enrollment in community colleges has increased statewide this year, according to the New Jersey Council of County Colleges. Combined enrollment of full-time and part-time students at the 19 schools has risen 4.5 percent, bringing the total to 130,246. Full-time enrollment increased by 7.1 percent, the largest rise since 1991. A spokesman for the council attributed the increases to recruitment efforts and slowly rising tuition. All 19 colleges plan to freeze tuition next year in return for a $12 million increase in state aid. Sarah Rubenstein

title: Your Home; It's Not Easy To Break A Lease
description: BREAKING a lease can mean different things to different people. When a below-market-rate rent-regulated tenant walks away from a lease, lawyers say, in many cases the landlord will be happy to have a vacant apartment to lease to a new tenant for a higher rent. The defaulting tenant's costs may be limited to forfeiture of the security deposit and a blot on his tenant history.

title: Naked Under the Gold
description: The protracted embraces of Gustav Klimt's dreamy figures and the opulent golden mosaics that adorn them have made him a popular favorite. But critics in his lifetime and scholars since have not always known what to do with him, as Colin B. Bailey, chief curator at the Frick Collection, explains in the vivid and substantial GUSTAV KLIMT: MODERNISM IN THE MAKING (Abrams/ National Gallery of Canada, $60). Born in 1862, Klimt, the son of a poor goldsmith, trained at Vienna's commercially oriented School of Applied Arts, where he learned how to integrate metalworking techniques with painting. Bailey emphasizes the importance of Klimt's often disregarded public commissions, particularly ''Philosophy,'' a mural at the University of Vienna that portrays the human condition as a chain of naked bodies entangled in ''the endless cycle of birth, procreation and death'' (this city was, after all, home also to Freud, Klimt's contemporary). The mural's pessimism and blatant sexuality caused an uproar in 1900, when it was first exhibited, and the scandal haunted Klimt until his death in 1918. In a bit of bravura scholarship, Bailey links Klimt's wounded retreat from public projects with the development of the dazzling patterns that he used to embellish -- and protect -- his human figures. These are literally cloaks -- there are fully realized nudes underneath, as we can see in one unfinished composition of a woman with spread-eagled legs, which Klimt had just begun to ornament. When viewed this way, Klimt's abstraction, derided by critics as too superficial, decorative and out of step with the avant-garde, seems loaded with psychological and erotic content. Hilarie M. Sheets

The 24-hour long spookfest includes ''Night of the Living Doo,'' a series of animated spots spoofing the gang's encounters with monsters and celebrities that feature the madcap antics of David Cross, Mark Hamill, Gary Coleman ad Big Bad Voodoo Daddy.

description: Increasingly worried that they are vulnerable to sabotage, the nation's biggest food companies are scrambling to tighten security to protect against an attack on the food system.

Patrick Benson of Wallingford, Pa. The Rev. Pierce A. Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Princeton University Chapel, with the Rev. David A. Davis, a Presbyterian minister, taking part.

title: Reckonings; Taking Care of Business
description: Cynics tell us that money has completely corrupted our politics, that in the last election big corporations basically bought themselves a government that will serve their interests. Several related events last week suggest that the cynics have a point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSENSTEIN, HERBERT F.
description: WEISSENSTEIN-Herbert F. Age 56, of New York City and Sharon, CT, died October 26, 2001, of cancer after a short illness. Beloved husband of Constance Shuman, cherished father of Kathryn and Michael, loving son of Ruth Popper, and the late Heinz Weissenstein. Dear brother of Peter, Robert, David, Stephan, Karin, Lenora, Evelyn and Thomas. Devoted son-in-law of Marjorie Shuman, caring brother-in-law of Peter, John and Laura. Services private. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

description: The Agriculture Department has tightened security at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center off the tip of Long Island's North Fork as a precaution against terrorist attack, Congressman Felix J. Grucci Jr. has told East End officials.

description: To the Editor:

title: Art/Architecture; When Horror Can Be Healthy
description: IN a time of high anxiety, why should we add to our troubles with monsters of our own invention? Who needs this? Many parents must be asking themselves this as Halloween approaches, with its peculiar mix of prepackaged horror and youthful high spirits.

title: Postings: Design Competition for Transforming Fresh Kills Landfill; Planning Ahead, Looking Back
description: The idea of the international competition was to find designers with imagination and ability enough to plan the transformation of Fresh Kills, the 2,200-acre landfill on Staten Island, which stopped taking the city's garbage earlier this year.

title: Our Towns; After Too Many Funerals, a Priest Could Use a Blessing
description: IT was the last one. The 17th at St. Thomas the Apostle Church. By midday yesterday, Bob DeAngelis Jr., 47, of the 91st floor, had been eulogized by Msgr. Jim Lisante. Finally, the monsignor had no more funerals or memorial services scheduled for the Sept. 11 dead.

description: Sullivan's article is wonderfully informative. My impulse was to say that it should be required reading -- which shows how seductive is the trap that Sullivan describes so well: everyone should read it, and if they don't, I will make them.

title: Chinese Come a Long Way; Then Take On the Russians
description: In recent years, China has made the most impressive, admirable advances in chess. The women's world champion is their Xie Jun, although it must be kept in mind that she ranks well behind Judit Polgar of Hungary, who ranks among the top 30 players in the world, men as well as women.

title: OPINION; When Nassau's G.O.P. Falls Short
description: THE contrast could not have been more dramatic. In New York City, a neighbor that became the grisly bull's-eye for a horrific terrorist attack, the administration has responded with grit, courage and international leadership. In Nassau County, we see a county government that can't provide the political leadership required to save its own financial skin.

description: With Oklahoma and Virginia Tech losing for the first time today, the U.C.L.A. Bruins had an excellent chance to solidify their position in the Bowl Championship Series ranking.

title: A Japanese Cuisine With Style and Spark
description: EXCEPT for the dolls, the folk art and the doodads for sale above and behind the sushi bar, Yooki Yama in Branford looks like many other Japanese storefront restaurants. No special frills. No special ethnicity.

title: All 4 American Teams Make It to Bridge Playoffs
description: The World Bridge Championships reached their midpoint here today, and all four American teams survived the qualifying stage and reached the playoffs.

description: Wendy Evans Joseph and Dr. Jeffrey Victor Ravetch were married yesterday at their apartment in New York. Mayor David E. Kapell of Greenport, N.Y., officiated.

title: Business; With Aircraft Idle, Income Reads Zero
description: THE roar of propellers and the whir of chopper blades have returned to airfields, heliports and landing pads across much of the country as the federal government has gradually eased a blanket ban on small aircraft enforced in the weeks immediately after Sept. 11. ''Much,'' however, is the operative word.

title: Music; To Regain Glory, The New Michael Imitates the Old
description: WHICH kind of weirdo is more unsavory: the one who rants about the way the world is out to get him, or the one who won't stop trying to cozy up to women and children? That's the choice offered by Michael Jackson's ''Invincible,'' his first full-length album since he attached a disc of new material to his 1995 greatest-hits collection, ''HIStory.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUSEMAN, JOAN
description: HOUSEMAN-Joan. The Acting Company notes with great sadness the loss of our dear friend, board director and wife of John Houseman, our co - founder. Among her many lasting gifts to the Company was assisting Nicholas Martin's direction of our acclaimed production of The Rivals. We will miss her greatly and send deepest sympathy to Michael and Sebastian. Edgar Lansbury, Chairman Joan Warburg, President Margot Harley, Producing Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANDROFF, BERTHA
description: SHANDROFF-Bertha. Died on October 26th at 94 years old. Daughter of Samuel and Sarah Yager. Beloved sister of the late Rose Hader and Rae Scolnick and Mitchell and Jack Yager. Wife of the late George Shandroff. Mother of Marilyn Averett and Arlene Kahn (Donald). Grandmother of Dr. Susan Greenberg (Dr. Michael), Laurie Segal (Dr. Mark), Wendy Wolff (Dr. Michael). Nana of Ariel, Asher, Alissa, Erica, Aaron, Emily, Melissa.

title: Long Haul to the Winner's Circle Ends in a Sprint
description: Losing streak? What losing streak?

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-28-01; Fragmented We Stand
description: One Sunday morning not long after the terrorist attacks, I went, as usual, to the dump here in my town in western Massachusetts. I ran into an old friend. He's an anthropologist and has spent much more time than I have in Islamic countries, and in front of the recycling bins we fell to talking about a theme that has, of course, underlain many conversations, everywhere, in recent weeks: why do they hate us? He spoke of those things that go beyond Middle East policy, of the inexorable spread of American cultural exports, of ''Baywatch'' and Madonna and Britney Spears and so on, and the inflammatory effect they have on fundamentalist believers. And of course we took pleasure in remarking that we didn't like this stuff much ourselves. We seemed to be offering each other a weird kind of reassurance: we, at least, are not what they hate.

title: October 21-27; Steel Protections Near
description: The American steel industry came closer to getting sweeping protection from imports when a quasi-judicial government trade panel, the International Trade Commission, determined that the industry suffered heavily from foreign competition. The ruling, which backed a broad complaint by the Bush administration, will allow the president to impose high taxes on most foreign steel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINGOLD, NORMAN S.
description: FEINGOLD-Norman S., 78. On October 24, 2001 after a long and courageous fight against lymphoma. Born in Brooklyn, NY on December 11, 1922. Most dearly beloved husband of Natalie (Arond). Cherished father of Carol Feingold Neiditch, Roberta Palant (Hy Shuster), Elise Feingold. Proud and loving grandfather of Shana, Emily, David, Jana and Mitchell. Pre-deceased by his sister Ruth Kopilow. Graduate of CCNY School of Engineering (1943) & member of the SKT fraternity family. Innovative, introspective, logical & analytical. An independent person of high moral standards and integrity, he lived by his principles & imparted them to his children and grandchildren. True to his personal heritage and proud supporter of American manufacturing industry. Mentor to many. He was highly respected and left a lasting impression on everyone who met him. Truly one of the Greatest Generation. Contributions may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY 10605 or the American Red Magen David for Israel, 888 7 Av, Ste 403, NYC 10102.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRAYER
description: DRAYER-My darling Doris, October 31 will be two years since you left. Not a day goes by when something doesn't remind me of you in our love and happiness. Rest well, my darling. Sonny, Michelle, Joe, Emily, Billy, Caroline.

title: Laura Freher, Steven Becton
description: Laura Ellen Freher, a daughter of Elizabeth and Edward Freher of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven Allen Becton, the son of Betty and Allen Becton of Media, Pa. The Rev. Cathy Eck officiated at the Pleasant Plains Presbyterian Church in Staatsburg, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Palazzo, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Aaron Sorkin Works His Way Through the Crisis
description: Exactly two weeks after terrorists ambushed New York and Washington, killed more than 5,000 of us and changed everything, and nothing, Aaron Sorkin, creator of ''The West Wing,'' leans anxiously against a long table filled with actors and production assistants. This is the high-tech briefing area where the show's main character, President Josiah Bartlet, huddles with the military brass when make-believe blips on the radar grow alarming. In the conspicuously insider patois of the show, the space is called ''the Sit Room,'' and this is roughly the Situation: for the last two years, ''West Wing'' has become one of the most popular shows in America because, among other things, Sorkin has been able to give his kinder, gentler, nobler White House enough verisimilitude to seem tantalizingly possible. ''The only reason it's not 'Touched by an Angel,''' Sorkin says, ''is that it imitates just enough the sounds and appearance of reality. And the way I do it is by saying words you don't normally hear on television shows, like 'Democrat' and 'Republican,' and having the place look real and the hardware look real and abbreviations be right. If I can do just enough of that, then hopefully we're on board.''

title: You, You, You
description: To the Editor:

title: Emily Rome, William Mone
description: Emily Lispenard Rome, the daughter of Carol Lispenard Cheney of Hamden, Conn., and Richard J. Rome of Houston, was married yesterday to William Edward Mone, a son of Carol Schlesinger Mone and William D. Mone of Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. Kathleen McTigue, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Century Association in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGAN, JAMES RUSSELL, JR.
description: FORGAN-James Russell, Jr. Age 71. Investment banker. Died peacfully at home on October 22, 2001 after a long illness in New York City. Beloved husband of Kathryn Zahony Livingston; dear brother of the late Joan F. Parks of Denver, Florence F. Wheeler of Lake Forest and Ada F. Addington of Chicago. His survivors include a stepson Bret B. Livingston, a step daughter Valerie V. Livingston, 10 nephews and nieces and 13 grand nephews and nieces. He was the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Forgan of New York City and Watch Hill, RI; the grandson of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Forgan of Evanston, IL and Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Johnson of St. Louis, MO. He was born August 4, 1930, graduated from the Buckley School in New York City, St. Marks School in Southborough, MA and Princeton University Class of 1952. He served as an Army Lieutenant in the Korean War. He held a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. His lifetime special interest was writing and producing plays and screen plays. He was a founder of the night club, El Morocco when it was revived in the 60s, and in the 70s launched a school for backgammon playing. Private funeral services are planned for October 25 in Watch Hill, RI. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, November 7, 2001 at 11:00 AM at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Ave & 53rd St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to St. Mark's School in Southborough, MA., or Princeton University in Princeton, NJ.

title: Ideas & Trends; It's Been Dark Before
description: ADRIFT in a sea of troubles, the United States seems in danger of coming unmoored from its own historical identity. Americans have been pounded by the surprise attacks of Sept. 11, beset by anxieties about anthrax and cowed out of airports, shopping malls and even the halls of Congress. Their righteous anger is not matched by conviction of eventual victory. They are little comforted by the still-inconclusive raids against Afghanistan, nor are they fully assured that their leaders are up to the job of protecting them from whatever unnameable horrors the future might hold. They are unaccustomedly edgy and off balance. For history's most secure, self-confident and forward-looking people, these are disquietingly unfamiliar feelings.

title: Where Food Is Homey and Aura Is Cozy
description: THE approach to Peter Pratt's Inn here fills one with pleasant expectations: the leaves of autumn are poised for their brilliant display and the stately house itself promises the experience of generations. In the stonewall cellar Tack Room, with its briskly burning fireplace and mellow lighting, guests feel nestled by history and coddled by an attentive staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, MARCIA KUYPER
description: SCHNEIDER-Marcia Kuyper. Age 74 of Clearwater Beach, FL formerly of New York City died October 17, 2000 at her residence. Born in Chicago, she grew up in Pella, Iowa. She worked as a television director for NBC Television Network for over 40 years, and retired to Florida. She had many achievements including directing ''Sing Along with Mitch'', ''Christmas in Rockefeller Center'', public service shows such as ''The First Estate'', and news for WNBC-TV. She was the recipient of 4 Emmy Awards, one of which was as the Associate Director for ''S' Wounderful, S'Marvelous, S'Gershwin with Jack Lemmon''. She also received an ''Angel Award'' for Religion in Media. She was also Associate Director of ''Your Show of Shows'', ''Perry Como'', ''Hallmark Hall of Fame Specials'', and ''The Bell Telephone Hour''. Later, she worked as a Producer, Director, & Associate Director for numerous NBC News events. A memorial service will be held October 29, 2001 at 10:30 at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Catholic Church at Austin Street and Ascan Avenue in Forest Hills. She is survived by her husband of 45 years Francis Schneider a retired art director for NBC for 25 years, a daughter Pamela Schneider Butler of HoHo-kus, NJ and 3 grandchildren, Matthew, Laura, & Kristin Butler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, JANET RUTHERFORD
description: ADAMS-Janet Rutherford. Of Bayside, NY on October 20, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Robert Adams. Devoted mother of Robert, Carol, & Anne Margaret. Cherished mother-in-law of Sharon, Perry, and Andrew. Loving grandmother of Ian, Ciarra, Zachary, Genavieve and Robert. Beloved sister of the late Annie Dockrell and William Sloan. Survived by sister Peggy Gibb of Scotland. Janet led an active life including careers with The United Kingdom Mission to the United Nations and The National Society of Colonial Dames as well as long membership in the British War Veterans of America. She was a dignified and courageous woman who had a love of life. She will be interred in Glasgow, Scotland.

title: Visions of a Long Struggle, Strains on Police and Help for Victims
description: It was little more than a week ago that the Pentagon proclaimed that Taliban forces in Afghanistan had been ''eviscerated'' by American airstrikes. The United States owned the Afghan skies, it was said. The Taliban air force was no more. Command centers were turned to dust. Abandoned training camps once run by Osama bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda, had been leveled.

title: Film; The Ghosts Who Infest The Living
description: THE ghost stories we tell one another rely on the shadows of our own imaginations, but in movies it's pretty easy to know when we've seen a ghost. The cartoon ''Casper,'' with his giggly little ''Boo!,'' or the corny, double-exposed Patrick Swayze in ''Ghost'' tend to overact and overdress. Ghost stories with scarier ambitions often have their phantoms making dramatic entrances in tired storylines about the vengeance of the wronged or the haunting of the house. Predictable and gimmicky, as convincing as their special effects, ghosts blow in to spook the living with a glimpse of the bloodless world ahead.

title: Political Briefing; Defeated Senator Sees Future in House
description: It is unusual in the world of national politics for a senator who loses a re-election bid to try to make a comeback by running for a seat in the House. Senators have a way of looking upon themselves as rarer political birds than representatives, if for no other reason than there are only 100 senators and they run statewide, whereas there are 435 House members and, as senators tend to see it, they represent mere districts.

title: Television/Radio; The Games People Played in a Simpler Time
description: I'M GOING to eat lots of chocolate now,'' an actress friend of mine announced, apropos of nothing, at the end of a recent e-mail. I knew how she felt. You can only derive so much comfort from high-mindedness, and in the twitchy weeks since Sept. 11 most of my friends have succumbed to the urge to gobble ''chocolate'' of one sort or another -- edible, aesthetic, even sexual. So if the day's news has got you down, let me steer you to a tasty piece of mind candy guaranteed not to cause acne, obesity or herpes: ''Black and White Overnight,'' a two-hour block of old prime-time game shows that can be seen from 4 to 6 each morning on the Game Show Network.

title: Travel Advisory; Fodor's Comes Out With E-Book Guides
description: Fodor's has introduced a series of e-book guides for 26 destinations, allowing a vacationer in Aruba or a business executive traveling to Munich to take along its guidebooks in a laptop or Palm Pilot.

title: Overdoses of Painkiller Are Linked to 282 Deaths
description: An extensive federal review of autopsy data has found that the powerful painkiller OxyContin is suspected of playing a role in the overdose deaths of 282 people in the last 19 months, more than twice the number in some previous estimates. The nation's top drug enforcement official recently called the new finding ''startling.''

title: The Rabbi Has His Day In Court
description: THERE is a theater group in New Jersey that re-enacts famous trials, sometimes in the very courtrooms in which they took place. This month, Century Productions was in the stately, white-columned courthouse in Flemington, acting out the trial in which Bruno Richard Hauptmann was convicted of kidnapping and murdering the child of Charles and Anne Morrow Lindbergh.

title: Whole New Ballgame in Phoenix
description: While the Phoenix area is no stranger to big sporting events — including the N.B.A. finals and a Super Bowl — baseball is king of the desert this weekend, with Games 1 and 2 of the World Series.

title: The Legal Aspects Of Fighting Terrorism
description: THE terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 have changed many things, including the curriculum at Pace University Law School.

title: Political Briefing; C. Boyden Gray Silent on Senate
description: To hear the political buzz down in North Carolina, C. Boyden Gray, big-time Washington lawyer, sometime television talking head and one-time White House counsel to the first President Bush, is thinking about -- or has been urged to think about -- joining the growing field of Republicans seeking to succeed Senator Jesse Helms, who is retiring.

title: Velarde at First
description: Joe Torre has all but decided that right-handed-hitting Randy Velarde will start at first base in Game 2, against the Arizona left-hander Randy Johnson. This way, the Yankees' entire lineup of position players will be right-handed. Left-handed batters hit .196 with one home run in 107 at-bats against Johnson, and right-handed batters hit .204 with 18 homers in 783 at-bats.

title: Ukraine Farmland Is Issue
description: Ukraine's Communist Party has said it plans to ask the constitutional court to overturn a law passed this week that allows the sale of farmland.

title: Political Briefing; A Talkative Gore Is Quiet on '04 Plans
description: Everybody knew that Al Gore would be the featured speaker when Democrats gathered last night in Manchester, N.H., for a Jefferson-Jackson Dinner. The event made political sense, given that the former vice president is pondering whether to run for president again in 2004 and given that the first primary in 2004 will be, of course, in New Hampshire.

title: A Few Laughs Even Amid The Anxiety
description: THE other day, there was a moment of much-needed comic relief at the Columbia University subway station at 116th and Broadway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILDENSTEIN, DANIEL. WE
description: WILDENSTEIN-Daniel. We, the Directors of The Florence Gould Foundation and our wives express our profound sorrow to the Wildenstein family on the death of our distinguished colleague, Daniel Wildenstein. From the beginning, the activities of the Foundation have always been enriched by the wisdom and informed counsel of Daniel Wildenstein as well as by his lively and generous spirit. We consider ourselves very fortunate to have been blessed for so long by his friendship, his competence, and his discerning intelligence. His legacy to the mission of the Foundation will endure.

title: Torre Keeps Choate and the Trusted Sojo
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 27  Manager Joe Torre's loyalty extends all the way to the end of his bench.

title: Columbia Wins Its Second Straight
description: With an inspired effort on defense, Columbia won its second game in a row yesterday, topping Yale, 28-14, at Wien Stadium. The Lions' defense returned an interception for a touchdown in the second quarter and did not give up an offensive score until late in the fourth quarter.

title: Music; Downtown Divas Expand Their Horizons
description: WHEN Susan Botti steps on stage at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening to sing the premiere of ''EchoTempo'' with Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic, she will become the first vocalist in the orchestra's 159-year history to perform her own composition at a regular subscription concert. (In 1984, Joan La Barbara sang three of her own pieces during the Philharmonic's Horizons festival, a typically ghettoized new-music showcase.) At the same time, Ms. Botti and her music will finally be breaking into the ''uptown'' musical scene.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of 2 p.m. Thursday, 4,854 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: The View From/Greenwich; A Book Answers a Question That Few Asked Before Sept. 11
description: THE last time a plane crashed into a New York City skyscraper, before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was on July 28, 1945, when an Army Air Corps B-25 bomber, headed from Bedford, Mass., to Newark, lost its way on a foggy day and slammed into the 79th floor of the Empire State Building.

title: A Watchful State
description: Thank you for Jeffrey Rosen's (Oct. 7) excellent and timely article on closed-circuit television in Britain. I returned to London at the end of August and was shocked by the presence of cameras everywhere. I felt as if I had stumbled into an episode of ''The Prisoner.''

title: Melville Has Never Looked Better
description: ONE HUNDRED FIFTY years ago this month Herman Melville's ''Moby-Dick'' was first published, to mixed reviews and, as they say in the trade, disappointing sales. In our own moment of horror and heroism, it is a book more salient than ever -- unflinchingly honest about the human capacity for hate and brutality, yet filled with an undiscourageable love of humanity. In its own day, it was received by many critics as a half-mad rant.

title: A Kind Offer Leaves Workers in Limbo
description: WORKERS from the city's Human Resources Administration have played a direct role in disaster relief since Sept. 11, working extra hard to open job centers for the suddenly jobless and provide emergency social services. They have also helped in an indirect way. Three days after the attack, Mayor Giuliani, hoping to keep businesses in Lower Manhattan, offered the agency's sleek, 25-story headquarters at 180 Water Street to displaced companies.

title: Amid Tighter Security, Arab Owners Stay Away
description: Racing fans arriving yesterday at Belmont Park for the Breeders' Cup were greeted with heightened security measures in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAUB, RITA
description: TRAUB-Rita. On October 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Ben Traub. Loving mother of Robert and Mark. Aunt to Lois Silverman and Melvin Tan. She will be dearly missed by her family and friends.

title: Unions Rethink Links to Undocumented Labor
description: SHOULD organized labor reach out to the undocumented worker, even when met with suspicion or hostility? Or should labor view illegal immigration as a force that depresses wages and threatens to reverse the movement's hard-won gains in higher wages, greater benefits and improved work conditions?

title: New Housing Development In Yonkers Gains Financing
description: A Denver company has provided financing for the first new housing development in Yonkers in 30 years, to be known as Harbor Park. Ground was broken Thursday at the site, at the foot of Main Street on the city's waterfront.

title: Surprising Meltdown for Weiss
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 27  Michael Weiss has spent more than two years practicing Olympic visualization, imagining every detail of the 2002 Winter Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAZ, PETER
description: PAZ-Peter. Photographer. 64. He has died in Nice, France, after a lengthy illness. Known mainly for his corporate annual report and advertising photography, he was winner of the Clio Award for the Otis Annual Report. Represented by the Image Bank, his clients included, among other multi-nationals, Monsanto, Exxon, McCormick and Aerospatial. Mr. Paz also traveled extensively on assignment for the Jordanian government, NBC News, and Business Week. In his earlier career as a professional dancer under the name Yigal Paz, he danced with the Anna Sokolow dance company and the Batsheva de Rothschild company. He is survived by his daughter Lyrissa, his ex-wife Luba Paz, and his companion of many years in Nice, Beverly Pimsleur.

title: An E-Bargainer's Reward
description: Living up to his company's slogan, Richard S. Braddock, chairman of Priceline.com ( news/quote ), the online auctioneer, named his own price  and scored a bargain.

title: Muslim Leader Who Was Once Labeled an Alarmist Is Suddenly a Sage
description: Two years ago, an obscure Muslim spiritual leader named Sheik Muhammad Hisham Kabbani stepped to the microphone at the State Department and issued a chilling admonition to Americans to beware the Muslims in their midst.

title: Missing
description: I hope that my friends who live outside New York City will read Marshall Sella's fine article. They often ask me to describe what city life is like since Sept. 11.

description: This

title: FLIGHT RESTRICTIONS EASED
description: The Federal Aviation Administration eased the restrictions on general aviation flights around Philadelphia International Airport last week, allowing pilots to use visual flight rules again, as they had before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Since then, pilots flying within 20 nautical miles of the airport, covering much of Burlington, Camden and Gloucester Counties, were severely restricted and in some cases banned from flying at all. Restrictions on general aviation are still in effect in North Jersey within 18 nautical miles of Kennedy Airport. Robert Strauss

title: Music; Down From the Mountain, Singing With More Serenity
description: HERE'S a Zen question: does spending the better part of five years in a mountaintop abbey, meditating and cooking, cleaning and putting chains on the abbey's truck, change a person? Leonard Cohen, having descended last year from the enclave of Joshu Sasaki Roshi in the hills above Los Angeles, would like to suggest that he is still the same old romantic known for his ways with wine, women and song. Or perhaps not.

title: Canadian Company Moves Workers to Purchase
description: A Canadian company is relocating 90 employees who were displaced on Sept. 11 from 1 Liberty Plaza near the World Trade Center to Purchase.

title: School Plans for 2-Year Kindergarten
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 25  It is not unusual for kindergartners coming into Andrew Jackson Elementary School here to be unsure how to hold a pencil or use scissors. They often do not know their colors, shapes or even how to hold a book.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ROBERT P.
description: MARCUS-Robert P., life-long love, companion, and best friend of his wife Betty G. Marcus; beloved son of the late Libby P. Marcus and Bernard K. Marcus; caring and devoted son-in-law of the late Ziuta Gerstenzang Akston and Leo Gerstenzang; proud and loving father of his daughter, Lauren Marcus Hughes; adoring grandfather of Christopher Robert Marcus Hughes and Meghan Ruth Marcus Hughes and father of Gary P. Marcus. He enriched the lives of all those he met and all those who called him friend, for he was a kind, caring, wise and gentle man. He was a natural leader who spent a lifetime quietly and selflessly helping others and improving the lives of untold numbers of people. He will be remembered by all those he touched forever and ever. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00 AM on Sunday, October 28, 2001 at Ferncliff Cemetery, 280 Secor Rd., Hartsdale, NY. For information, contact Quattlebaum Funeral Home at 561-832-5171.

title: Giants Again Trying to Make the Point
description: It was the first week of December 2000 and the crossroads of the Giants season was Washington's FedEx Field. On a blustery day, the loser of the game between the 8-4 Giants and the 7-5 Redskins figured to be out of the chase for the division title, if not the playoff race entirely.

title: Moderates Start Speaking Out Against Islamic Intolerance

The day after that, six photos appeared of one man, asking, ''Do You Know This Man?'' And the next day the bomber was in custody. Ubiquitous surveillance is the only effective means to apprehend violent criminals rapidly. Most British lavatories are also ''under surveillance'' because the I.R.A. put bombs in toilets. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, RICHARD NICHOLAS
description: DANIEL-Richard Nicholas. Briarcliff, NY, October 25, 2001. Richard Nicholas Daniel, the former chairman and CEO of Handy & Harman, one of the world's foremost manufacturers of precious metals, and a 30-year resident of Briarcliff Manor, New York, and New York City, died on Thursday at Sleepy Hollow Country Club on the 6th hole after shooting a perfect game, of a heart attack. He was 66. Mr. Daniel retired from Handy & Harman in 1998 after 27 years. Known for his people oriented management style during his leadership, Handy & Harman became a highly respected multi-national diversified industrial manufacturing company. Prior positions included vice president of operations at Wheelabrator-Frye, vice president of finance at Laird Enterprises, Inc., and planning associate at Mobile Corporation. For the last several years Mr. Daniel worked in merchant banking and sat on various boards, including Keyspan Corporation Gabelli Funds. Mr. Daniel was a 1957 graduate of St. John's University and Wharton Business School in 1959. He was a member of Deepdale Country Club in Manhasset, Blindbrook Country Club in Ryebrook, and a past president of the Sky Club of New York City. Mr. Daniel was an inspiring individual who put his family, his friends and his work before himself. He always joked of going from ''Who's Who'' to ''Who's He?'' To friends, he was Dick; to the poker group, he was ''killer,'' and to all, he was an amazingly selfless man. Mr. Daniel is survived by his wife Elaine Sherman Daniel, his sons Matthew Daniel of Philadelphia and Jeffrey Daniel of Washington, DC, and his sister, Linda Llewellyn of Aiken, SC. Visiting hours will be held at Waterbury and Kelly Funeral Home in Briarcliff Manor, NY, on Sunday, October 28, from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. A funeral service will be held at Saint Theresa Catholic Church in Briarcliff Manor, NY, on Monday, October 29, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in honor of Mr. Daniel to The Children's Health Fund of New York City; call 212-452-3340 or www.childrenshealthfund.org. Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, 1300 Pleasantville Rd, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510; 914-941-0838. L

title: QUICK BITE/New Brunswick; Bread That Welcomes Souls Back Home
description: In Mexico, and wherever people of Mexican descent live, the Day of the Dead, observed on Nov. 1 and 2, is a time to welcome home the souls of the departed. The holiday is observed at family dinners at which the favorite food and drink of the departed are served and the table is set with ornaments mocking death like dancing papier-mch skeletons and breads in the shape of little people called muecos. Muecos are for sale now at Gaby's Bakery in New Brunswick, which also bakes ojaldres, round breads with sesame seed crosses on them, which are also traditional for the Day of The Dead and are also called pan de muertos. Both breads -- made of cinnamon, eggs, sugar, flour and sesame -- come in two sizes, the ojaldres 8 inches ($1.50) and 16 inches across ($4) and the muecos 4 and 16 inches tall, also $1.50 and $4. Gaby's owner, Gabriel Roman, who grew up in Mexico City, says the breads are handmade, and he is selling them again this year -- beginning thi8s weekend until Friday. ''People make a table at home, and on the table they put gifts for the dead, food, fruits, rice pudding -- if the dead maybe liked tequila, a shot of that -- beer and sweet drinks like hot chocolate,'' he said. ''The table is set with candles and marigolds in a half-circle, and we hang the little muecos on the marigolds.'' Mr. Roman likes to wash down his Day of the Dead breads with a cup of coffee of hot chocolate. If the souls of the dead don't want to travel, Mr. Roman said, Mexican families will deliver: it is also a tradition to go visit the grave sites of loved ones and leave food there.

The gatekeeper of a shrine to health and fertility, she has a shrunken head that is too small for her body, her words are nonsense and screams, and even her face, with its pointed forehead and wide, round jaws, is in the shape of a tear.

title: Niccole Siegel, Jeremy Kroll
description: Niccole Joleene Siegel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Siegel of Norwood, N.J., was married last evening in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Jeremy Michael Kroll, a son of Lynn Korda Kroll and Jules B. Kroll of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Paley officiated at the Castle at Tarrytown.

description: MARY JONAS moved slowly through the purple print corridors of the Trump Taj Mahal. She was headed for the lunch buffet, hoping to see some friends she had not met up with since the summer.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-28-01: Encounter; Hyphenated Americans
description: Daniel K. Inouye walked into the Holiday Inn banquet room on Capitol Hill looking younger than his 77 years, his suit jacket empty where his right arm should have been. He was alone, which in Washington is somewhat remarkable; a senator rarely goes anywhere ''unstaffed,'' especially to a speech. But as Inouye, the country's fourth most senior senator, told me, he has been around long enough to dispense with pretension. (Though it is little remembered, he was the keynote speaker at the Democrats' 1968 convention in Chicago.) And on this night, he knew he would be among brothers: soldiers from the Army's famed 442nd Regiment Combat Team, the segregated Japanese-American unit in which Inouye served during World War II.

But for the last month 30-year, fixed-rate mortgages have carried rates below 7 percent in New York state, and they are among the lowest in a generation.

title: McGreevey for New Jersey Governor
description: Voters in New Jersey have no reason to complain about cookie-cutter candidates in this year's gubernatorial race. The contest between James McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge, and Bret Schundler, the former mayor of Jersey City, is a contest between men with dramatically different world views. Mr. McGreevey, the Democrat who nearly beat former Gov. Christie Whitman four years ago, has returned to stake his claim to the state's middle ground. Mr. Schundler, who stunned G.O.P. regulars in June when he won the Republican primary so handily, has an energetic conservative message and a far more committed following that goes with it. Although we appreciate Mr. Schundler's willingness to think outside the box, it seems obvious in this difficult period that Mr. McGreevey would be the better choice for governor.

Johnson was rushing out of a news conference, and seconds later Bonds was arriving with family and friends.

title: Republican Zealotry
description: Taking ideological consistency to an absurd extreme, House Republican leaders are putting their aversion to ''big government'' ahead of the nation's security needs. Dick Armey, Tom DeLay and other conservative congressmen are standing firm against aviation security legislation that has already been approved unanimously by the Senate. The House leaders oppose the creation of a federal airport security force, and in their fierce opposition to anything that would increase the rolls of government employees, they have been blocking passage of legislation that is desperately needed both to protect air passengers and to revive the airline and tourism industries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDERMAN, BETH OLDS
description: BIDERMAN-Beth Olds, 80. Tranquilly on October 24, 2001. To the end more concerned about others than herself: first her loved ones, but not far behind the causes of world peace and progressive humanism with which she was professionally and personally involved through all of her adult life. 1942-45: administrative secretary on the Manhattan Project at University of Chicago and Oak Ridge, Tenn., then manager, American liaison office in Montreal with the British and French scientists. 194547: executive secretary of the Emergency Committee of Atomic Scientists and Atomic Scientists of Chicago. 1948-52: executive secretary of the National Sharecroppers Fund to fight for farm worker rights, board member several years thereafter. 1967-70: executive director of Park Association of New York, consultant to Parks Council 1972. Activist in Greenwich Village and summer residence on Fire Island, co-founding Saltaire Citizens Advisory Association. Music buff, conservationist, gourmet cook extraordinaire. Her enjoyment of wry humor & dry martinis persisted to the very end, as did her bravery and determination. Beloved and devoted wife for fifty-four years of George, mother to Tina (Vartanian) and John, grandmother to Alexandre Vartanian and Lauren Scharf. Memorial to be announced.

title: Footlights; A Macedonian's Debut
description: Ilinka Manova may or may not be the first Macedonian artist to perform at Carnegie Hall, but the Purchase College student's Nov. 3 concert at Weill Recital Hall illustrates music's fluid internationalism. The pianist was born in Macedonia, received a bachelor's degree in Germany and won an international competition in Italy.

title: Television/Radio; The Rising Career Of a Young Director. No, Really Young.
description: THE reporters in the front row were caught off guard when Chaille Stovall stuck his head out from underneath a table at the Miami restaurant and thrust a microphone into Senator John McCain's face. ''Excuse me, Senator,'' Chaille said in his high-pitched voice -- high-pitched even for a 10-year-old. ''Why should kids be interested in politics?''

title: Flying With Kids and Qualms
description: AFTER the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Jon and Heidi Boyd of Des Moines, Iowa, reconsidered the family vacation they had planned for the following month. At such a sad, uncertain time, should they still fly to New Hampshire with their two sons, 5 and 8, to visit Mrs. Boyd's parents? ''We were torn, as any parents would be,'' said Mr. Boyd, 37, an architect.

description: MANY concertgoers associate electronic music with the experience of sitting passively in a boxy auditorium, surrounded by loudspeakers, listening to some predetermined piece being played on a tape recorder or through a computer program. Actually, there is an extensive body of works that combine electronically produced sounds with orchestral instruments in live performances. Most traditional orchestras have been timid about exploring this repertory and commissioning such works. Not the plucky American Composers Orchestra.

title: Music; A Festival That Eluded the Soviet Hug
description: WARSAW may not be the most beautiful city in Eastern Europe, but it is one of the most inspiring. However badly wartime destruction and the subsequent Stalinist suffocation scarred their capital, the Polish people ensured that the city would survive as a great cultural center, and as such it remains very much alive today. All the arts are well represented, but one in particular has played an unexpected role in this story: contemporary classical music.

title: Tiznow Keeps His Crown
description: Chris McCarron was not ready to take his horse to the winner's circle. He pulled Tiznow up before the Belmont Park grandstand, circled him regally and then he hoisted his pink helmet until it shone like a star against the chrome sky. The prolonged bow was much deserved yesterday after Tiznow turned a narrow defeat into an improbable victory in the Breeders' Cup Classic, pushing his nose ahead in the final stride against a European challenger.

title: The Endless Supper
description: Jeffrey Steingarten, the food writer for Vogue, had ignored a request for a dinner with Mr. Latte. They didn't exactly hit it off on the first try (something about Mr. Latte correcting him on the title of a book). So I thought to introduce him to my friend and peer in the world of food writing Jonathan Reynolds. Jonathan is omnivorous in life and brings this hunger to his writing. But he had never witnessed the likes of Jeffrey. And indeed, when I descended the stairs at Town, late as usual, I was pleased to spot their two white heads and suit coats, standing out like weeds in a field of blond and black.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the problems of venture capital funds referred imprecisely to an investor's concern about the future performance of Technology Crossover Ventures' Fund III. The investor worried that the fund would have to struggle to return profits, not to return the investors' initial capital. Technology Crossover Ventures says the fund has returned $429.7 million on the $417.3 million in committed capital.

description: HALLOWEEN had gone Hollywood on Long Island. Skeletons came out of the closet and were hung from trees; lawns were strewn with tombstones and coffins; spotlights shone on Grim Reapers. A house without a Fogmaster was hardly worth a trick-or-treater's visit. Sound effects -- sudden screams or ghoulish laughter -- were not uncommon.

title: October 21-27; Mars in Reach
description: After back-to-back failures of Mars-bound spacecraft two years ago, NASA rebounded with a success. After 93 million miles, its Mars Odyssey craft swung into a wide looping orbit of the planet without a hitch, and began maneuvers to descend gradually into a shorter, two-hour circular orbit 250 miles above the surface.

Kennedy's favorite place to stay in New York is now covered with netting, as engineers repair its trademark beige terra cotta. And the hotel's new owner says that after the netting comes off, the tower will get a bit of a new look.

title: October 21-27; Alpine Traffic Disasters
description: Routes through the Alps are few, and getting fewer. A truck collision inside the St. Gotthard Tunnel in Switzerland set a fire that burned for two days and left more than 10 people dead and about 30 missing. Experts say the damaged tunnel may be closed for months, cutting a major artery of north-south European traffic. One alternative, the St. Bernhard Tunnel, was twice closed for fatal accidents. The St. Gotthard had been overburdened by a vast increase in freight traffic diverted from the Mont Blanc tunnel between France and Italy, which has been closed since a 1999 accident that killed 39. Elizabeth Olson

title: Angling Hubris Muddies Waters of an Alaskan Stream
description: A cottonwood sapling, tangled roots and all, bobbed along at a jogging pace just a short cast from where Chris LeWand, my wife, Moira, and I stood on a wide gravel bar in the Aniak River. Swollen with runoff the color of coffee with cream, its rushing waters looked more like the Beaverkill after a good spring thaw than the classic, clear-running Alaskan river we saw from our bush plane earlier that week. Even in the sub-Arctic, it turns out, freak storms can send salmon streams into flood stage.

title: Business; Sharing the Wealth, for Capitalism's Sake

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEXTER, JOAN C., R.N., ED.D.
description: HOEXTER-Joan C., R.N., Ed.D. Died Saturday, October 20, age 85. Devoted aunt of Michael, Wendy and Adam. Professor Emerita of nursing, a distinguished nursing educator who taught and was admired and beloved by many generations of graduate students in New York University's Division of Nursing. Passionate urban gardener who avidly tended her plot in the LaGuardia Corner Gardens. Member of the Army Nurse Corps during World War II. Former supervisor in the lower east side office of The Visiting Nurse Service of New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions for the Joan C. Hoexter Scholarship Fund to support graduate students in nursing at NYU, should be sent to NYU, Division of Nursing, 246 Greene St, New York, NY 10003, Att: Barbara Mellor. title: Art/Architecture; An Outpost Of the East In the West
description: THE cattle are gone from the ranch of Willard G. Clark here in the San Joachin Valley, where his grandfather settled in the 1870's, where he was born 70 years ago and where he made his small fortune. They have been replaced by a flourishing Japanese garden and one of the nation's newest and smallest art museums. Built six years ago in a 100-acre walnut grove, the Ruth and Sherman Lee Institute of Japanese Art at the Clark Center exhibits and studies the Japanese paintings, scrolls, screens, sculptures, ceramics and baskets that Mr. Clark and his wife, Elizabeth, started collecting when they first visited Japan in the late 1950's.

Hundreds of other students sent personal letters: ''If you were to take away my sports and my magnet program, then what would I do?'' one boy wrote. ''Please don't take them away from me.''

description: As Sullivan points out, there is much talk in the Koran of peace and tolerance, but there are also the violent passages he quotes. The fact is, few American Muslims have spoken out in the last decade against the rise of Islamic fundamentalism and violence. The majority have been silent, either out of fear for themselves or out of secret agreement. Now the Acura division of Honda has come through with the RSX, a muscular front-drive coupe. Better yet, there is a more powerful, better handling variant called the Type-S.

title: Nowhere Man
description: In his attempt to illuminate the mind of Mohamed Atta, Fouad Ajami fails to express a hint of censure (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 7). Atta was, at best, a sociopath. He boarded a plane and piloted passengers and crew to their deaths, causing also the deaths of thousands of other innocent people. He apparently did this without the slightest hesitation. Groves and Sons Co. where he built the airport in Antigua, B.W.I., enlarged Newark Airport in anticipation of D-Day and built the water system for Caracas, Venezuela. He was also the Chairman, President and CEO of Orinoco Mining Co in Venezuela. The Chairman of AMAX Iron Ore Co in New York, the Chairman of the Joint Companies Board for Development of Mt. Newman in Australia, an Executive Advisor to D.K. Ludwig for the development of the Jari Project in Brazil. He later served as advisor to CVG in Venezuela. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARBERG, CRAIG FREDERICK
description: SCHWARBERG-Craig Frederick. March 27, 1956 - October 18, 2001. Craig Frederick Schwarberg passed away October 18, 2001, after a long illness. Craig was born in Pasadena, California, and raised in Whittier and Tiburon, California. He attended Stanford University, was a member of the Varsity Water Polo team, and graduated in 1978 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Political Science. Craig worked briefly at Evanston Hospital in Illinois. In 1980, he moved to Abu Dhabi, the United Arab Emirates as an executive for the country's health and hospital program. After returning to the United States, Craig earned his Master of Business Administration degree from the University of Chicago in 1982. He began working in public finance at Shearson Lehman Brothers in San Francisco, and in 1986, moved to New York City to work in the corporate finance area. In 1992, he joined International Insurance Advisors, a private equity fund focused on the insurance industry. He served on many boards of directors, in this country and abroad. Craig moved to Kansas City in 1996, where he became involved in a number of community organizations. He was a committed Cub Master for the Boy Scouts of America. He served as a member of the Board of Directors at the Alliance for Epilepsy Research and also for the Kansas Cancer Institute. He was Chairman of the Board of ReStart, an organization serving the homeless of greater Kansas City. Craig was a mentor with the Helzberg Entrepreneurial Mentoring Program, and served as Vice President of Finance for the National Brain Tumor Foundation, headquartered in California. Craig is survived by his wife, Joann; their children Carter, Guerin, and Laine; his parents Clifford and Katherine Schwarberg of Belvedere, California; his sisters Lynn Lubbock of Tiburon, California and Ann Gaillard of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; and nieces Jaime and Lindsey Lubbock. A Celebration of Life memorial service was held Friday, October 26th in Prairie Village, Kansas. Any memorial contributions may be made to ReStart, 918 E. 9th Street, Kansas City, Missouri, 64106 or The National Brain Tumor Foundation, 414 13th Street, Oakland, California, 94612.

But when Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature passed laws that authorize the largest expansion of casino gambling and electronic slot machines in the state's history, they did not put it to a vote of the people. They passed a budget package that authorizes Mr. Pataki to enter into compacts with Native Americans to open six new casinos in the Catskills and upstate New York and will put the electronic equivalent of slot machines at most tracks. And when the numbers, which come from surveys conducted by the University of Michigan and the Conference Board, drop and stay below a certain level, economists expect a recession. This happened in September. That's why, nine times this year, the Fed has lowered interest rates -- at least partly to counter weakening confidence. But when we asked several economists to clear up a couple of points about consumer confidence, perhaps as many doubts were raised as answers.

Eschewing the customary key lighting that gives actors' eyes a special shine, they made it seem as if there were a dark cloud hovering over everyone's head. The effect is so subtle that it might not register on a conscious level, but it creates a mood -- one that the 26-year-old Mr. Kelly remembers from his own adolescence and that now appears weirdly prophetic of the nation's collective depression and anxiety since Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ARTHUR E., JR.
description: LEWIS-Arthur E., Jr. October 13, 2001. Died in his sleep from cardiac arrest in West Nyack, NY with his fiancee, Laura Buckley, at his side. He was 68. Born in Manhattan on January 4, 1933, he was raised in the South Bronx and attended Morris High School. He later moved to Queens, where he graduated from Jamaica High and was named the school's best athlete. At age 17, Mr. Lewis left home in order to finish high school. He graduated from St. John's University in 1956. He subsequently earned four masters' degrees: an M.B.A. and M.S. in taxation, an M.S. in accounting and an M.P.A. After receiving his M.P.A. from John Jay College of Criminal Justice this past spring, he immediately began working toward a master's degree in criminal justice at John Jay. Mr. Lewis received his license to practice law by clerking at New York City Corporation Counsel and was admitted to the Bar in 1986. Before becoming a lawyer, he was a parole officer at the New York State Division of Parole from 1959 through 1970. Mr. Lewis won the AAU Judo Championship in 1964 and came in second in the Metropolitan Black Belt Championship in 1968. He was a CPA with his own accounting practice and taught accounting at Trenton State College. Following his admission to the Bar, Mr. Lewis worked as a solo practitioner in Brooklyn, specializing in criminal defense. He is best known for his successful defense of Lemrick Nelson in the 1992 Crown Heights case in Brooklyn Supreme Court. A Major in the New York State Guard, he was known for his patriotism and his passion for American history. His fiancee said he will be remembered for his lifelong love of learning and his compassion for those less fortunate. A memorial service will be held at the Brooklyn Supreme Court at 360 Adams Street on November 15, 2001 at 5:30 PM. For further information, call 845-638-5352.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sex-Shop Statute
description: A City Council committee has approved amendments to part of the city's 1995 zoning law governing sex-oriented businesses. The amendments clarify the part of the law known as the ''60-40 provision,'' which held that no more than 40 percent of an establishment's inventory and space be used for so-called adult entertainment. The amendments, approved on Thursday, say the provision does not apply to eating and drinking establishments and set criteria for defining what officials have called ''sham compliance'' by book and video stores. The full Council will vote on the amendments at the end of this month. Diane Cardwell(NYT)

title: Stocks Close Sharply Lower
description: The stock market fell sharply and broadly today as investors cashed in on last week's rally and dumped shares of the Boeing Company ( news/quote ), which lost what is expected to be the largest military contract in history on Friday.

title: Online Elegies and Tone Poems Respond to Tragedy
description: The composer Phil Kline, who lives near ground zero, was still reeling from the Sept. 11 attacks when a friend sent him an e-mail message that said, ''It might be a good time for one of your walks.'' Mr. Kline writes music for what could be called orchestras of boombox-toting pedestrians, and he quickly crafted a gentle dirge he described as ''a complete surrender to the process of grief.''

title: Court Takes Rejected Oil Worker Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  The Supreme Court expanded its examination of federal disability law today by agreeing to decide whether an employer can refuse to hire someone who can perform the requirements of the job but, because of a medical condition, would put their health or life in danger by doing so.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: More Losses for Knicks, But More Fun to Watch
description: Things will be different for the Knicks this season. The coach, known to chastise his team frequently, sometimes viciously, has mellowed. The offense, long regarded as one of the league's most basic, most boring, most difficult to watch, has been revamped. And the conviction that the team will contend for a championship, ushering in every Knicks season for a decade, has withered into just a dream.

title: Independents to Join Book Data Collection

title: Gunmen Kill 16 Christians in Church in Pakistan
description: At 8:50 a.m. today, on a bright autumn Sunday in this Indus Valley town, three young men with Kalashnikov rifles walked into St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church just as the last part of the liturgy, known in the old English version as ''Lord, now lettest thou thy servant depart in peace,'' was being sung in Urdu. A group of 35 Pakistani Protestants who borrow the church for their services, weddings and funerals were just preparing to go home.
