description: While the nation's attention is focused on the war against terrorism, the Bush administration is moving, both overtly and covertly, to dismantle major elements of Bill Clinton's environmental legacy. It is difficult at a moment of crisis to devote much thought to things like mining rules or snowmobile bans. But if the president's top officials have time to undermine environmental regulations, the public needs to pay attention as well.

title: Mark Green for Mayor
description: The New York City mayor's race seems to have both run forever and never started at all. After a primary interrupted by terrorism, a Democratic runoff tainted by charges of racism and complicated by vote-counting problems, the final round between Public Advocate Mark Green and his Republican opponent, Michael Bloomberg, seems to be occurring in a haze. Mr. Bloomberg, who has spent tens of millions of dollars of his own money for television ads, is having trouble making a dent on the public consciousness. Mr. Green, meanwhile, has been attempting to cruise to victory as quietly as possible. His recent campaign has not been the kind of effort designed to make voters excited about a Green mayoralty. Nevertheless, this is an easy call. Mark Green gets our endorsement for mayor.

title: When Pettitte Starts, His Father Is at Risk
description: Tom Pettitte did not want to get onto an airplane in New York to fly here and watch his son, Andy, pitch in Game 2 of the World Series. He has a 90 percent blockage in his heart, he worries about his erratic blood pressure and, the day before he was supposed to sit on a plane for at least five hours, he contracted a severe ear infection.

title: Schilling Set to Go
description: It seems all but confirmed that Curt Schilling will start for Arizona on three days' rest in Game 4 on Wednesday. Schilling, who threw just 102 pitches over seven innings of Arizona's Game 1 victory on Saturday, would then be in line to start a potential seventh game. No pitcher has started three games in one Series since Jack Morris in 1991.

Total strangers took their picture in the lobby, in the parking lot, in their seats in the upper deck. It was absolutely incredible. All six of them felt like rock stars all night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, WILLIAM III
description: ELLIOTT-William III. Native and longtime resident of New York died from pneumonia on October 9, 2001, in Tucson, AZ. Born on March 14, 1925, he was secretarytreasurer of Bowne & Company for many years. A graduate of Columbia University, he was a member of the Harvard Class of 1946, the Fly Club, the Sons of the Revolution and the St. Nicholas Society. He was also a former member of the New York Yacht Club, the Knickerbocker Club and a Past Commissioner of the Elliott Clan Society, U.S.A., in California and Arizona. The son of William Elliott II and Glory Thomas, and grandson of playwright Augustus Thomas, he was by avocation a devoted researcher, compiler and publisher of family history and genealogy. He is survived by his wife Susanne Smith Elliott of Tucson, his daughters Elizabeth Elliott and Ann Elliott (Bridgers) of Berkeley, CA, Phyllis Elliott Dworsky of Los Angeles, Sarah Bayard Elliott of New York City, his brother Graeme Elliott of San Diego and grandchildren Susan and David Dworsky and Sophie Bridgers. He will forever be in the hearts of family and friends who remember and loved him as a man of uncommon gentleness, intelligence and humor. Donations in memory of William Elliott may be made to the Alzheimers Association of Tucson, 5132 East Pima St., Tucson, AZ 85712.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Middletown: DNA Links Man To Murder
description: A man whose DNA was taken at a rape scene in Colorado and then linked to a 12-year-old upstate New York murder case has been arrested, an assistant Orange County district attorney, John Geidel, said last week. The man, Peter McGrath, being held in El Paso County, Colo., was scheduled for an extradition hearing today. Mr. McGrath will be charged with murder for the 1989 killing of a man who allegedly interrupted him while he was raping a Deerpark woman, Mr. Geidel said. Mr. McGrath's DNA, entered into the National DNA Database, matched evidence from the 1989 scene, Mr. Geidel said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADENBAUM, DAVID
description: ADENBAUM-David. 86, died October 27, 2001, after a gracious struggle with heart disease and leukemia. Beloved husband of the late Betty (nee Sachs). Adored father of Samuel and his wife Gilda Kramer, Ann and her fiance Alan Schramm. Proud grandfather of Jacob and Benjamin Adenbaum. Caring brother-in-law of Norma Sachs. Uncle of Edwin Schwimmer, George Stanton, David and Robert Sachs, and Terry Newman. Brother of the late Selma Schwimmer and Alex Adenbaum. He served as an officer in the U.S. Army during WWII and participated in the Normandy Invasion. Services on Monday, October 29, 12 noon, at Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, NY. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Guidance Center in New Rochelle, NY, or Lafayette College in Easton, PA.

title: An Extra Night
description: The Chenay Bay Beach Resort in St. Croix is offering five-night stays for the price of four nights through Dec. 20. Rates start at $157.50 a night for a garden-view cottage, good for up to two adults. Children 18 or younger can stay in the same room as their parents at no extra charge, and those 12 or younger can eat free. The hotel is on a beach on the island's north shore, on a cove sheltered by a small island wildlife preserve. It is three miles from Christiansted; a beachfront bar and grill serves three meals a day. Information or reservations: (800) 548-4457 or www.chenaybay.com .

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Homicides Rise In Chicago
description: Homicides are up in Chicago. As of yesterday there were 540 so far this year, 18 more than in the same period last year. If the killings continue at the current rate, 2001 will be the first year since 1994 to have an increase. There were 629 homicides last year, 641 in 1999 and 704 in 1998. A police spokesman, David Bayless, said that despite the 3 percent rise in homicides so far this year, crimes had dropped over all. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

description: A day after Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, again asked for talks with Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, Mr. Vajpayee ruled out meeting the general during the United Nations General Assembly next week. After conferring in Delhi with Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany, who urged new talks, Mr. Vajpayee said: ''If I have to meet Musharraf, I don't have to go to New York.'' India has insisted that what it calls Pakistan-supported terrorism must stop before talks resume. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: U.S.-Neustar Pact On Address
description: The Commerce Department announced yesterday that it had signed a contract with NeuStar Inc. to manage the database of Internet addresses ending in .us, which was previously administered by VeriSign Inc. The .us suffix is the country code top-level domain assigned to the United States, which has been used primarily by state and local governments and schools. NeuStar plans to market .us addresses more widely to individuals, companies, government entities and public service organizations. NeuStar, based in Washington, administers the database that telephone companies used to route phone calls in North America; its subsidiary, NeuLevel Inc., operates the database of Internet addresses ending in .biz. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, ROBERT NATHAN
description: NEUMAN-Robert Nathan. 82, October 28, 2001. Proud proprietor of the Rosedale Fish Market since 1937, he devoted his life to the pursuit of excellence in his trade. In loving memory of his father Billy he ruled his store with humor, wisdom, dignity and single-minded purpose; Charming, challenging and nourishing both the body and the spirits of those he touched. A lifelong New Yorker and member of the City Athletic Club, he served with the 3rd Marines in the Pacific during W.W. II, returning in 1945 to resume building his beloved business. Mentor to many, friend to the downtrodden, a student of the lives of Robert Scott and Sacco and Vanzetti, he leaves the world a better and more compassionate place. He is survived by his wife of 51 years Doris, sons Alan and Paul, four grandchildren and his devoted staff. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Tuesday, October 30, 5-8 PM with service Wednesday 11:30 AM. In lieu of donations please perform a random act of kindness for someone in need.

Dear brother of Peter, Robert, David, Stephan, Karin, Lenora, Evelyn and Thomas. Devoted son-in-law of Marjorie Shuman, caring brother-in-law of Peter, John and Laura. Services private. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Crisis Is a Painful Misadventure For a Longtime Friend of the U.S.
description: Helge H. Wehmeier, the chief executive and president of Bayer's American operations, has had a rough time lately even by the standards of the turbulent pharmaceutical industry.

title: An Unmuseum Guaranteed to Be Uncrowded
description: The opening of the Pulitzer Foundation for the Arts here, in a building by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando on the site of a former auto repair shop, has raised this city's arts profile and may help renew the Grand Center district, once nearly derelict, as civic and arts leaders are hoping. The building itself is a work of art.

title: Referees in Tough Spot Over Jordan's Camp
description: In places longing for an N.B.A. championship like New York, Utah and Indiana, the conspiracy theories have always run amok. Just as Patrick Ewing is allowed to hop and skip and Shaquille O'Neal to bump and grind, Michael Jordan, the theory goes, always gets the calls because of who he is.

title: Police Departments Ask What More They Can Do
description: It was the kind of chillingly stark warning that used to make police departments snap into action, deploy extra officers, get emergency response teams at the ready.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARL, NAT
description: PEARL-Nat. Beloved husband, father and grandfather passed on October 28, 2001. Survived by his beloved wife of 54 years, Beatrice; son Howard and wife Suzette, grandsons, Austin and Cody; son Ronald and wife Ellen, granddaughters Alexis and Carra, daughter Adria & granddaughter Justine. Services are at 11:30 A.M. today. Robert Schoem Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rte 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: Americans Aiding Philippines In Fight Against Terrorist Group
description: American military officers are in the Philippines providing advice in the fight against a terrorist group linked to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today.

title: Drug Producer Shifts to a Profit
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., Oct. 29 (Bloomberg News)  King Pharmaceuticals ( news/quote ) said here today that it had a third-quarter profit on sales of its heart medicine Altace and thyroid hormone replacement Levoxyl, reversing a loss in the period a year earlier from acquisition costs.

title: Front Row
description: Earth Shoe Returns, Walking Tall

title: Boeing Tries to Reassure Seoul On Plans for an Advanced Jet
description: Stung by losing to Lockheed Martin last Friday in the competition to build the Joint Strike Fighter for the United States, Boeing moved quickly over the weekend to reassure South Korean officials that it was still ready to build advanced fighter jets for overseas customers.

title: Suozzi for Nassau County Executive
description: It took years of mismanagement and reckless budgeting for the Republican administration of Thomas Gulotta, Nassau County's lame-duck county executive, to create the county's current fiscal crisis. But whomever voters choose next Tuesday to lead this populous Long Island county will need to move swiftly to restore fiscal responsibility and to reshape a patronage-bloated bureaucracy.

title: Nigeria Army Said to Massacre Hundreds of Civilians
description: The Nigerian soldiers said they had come in peace, the residents of this small village recalled. The soldiers arrived, around 1 p.m. last Monday, in four armored vehicles and five trucks, and asked the men to gather at three spots on the main street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABOUSHA, HAYIM
description: HABOUSHA-Hayim, 82. On October 29, 2001. Beloved husband of Adele. Loving father of Racheline and Nadine and Edward Cohen. Dear brother of Albert of Paris and Ezra of Tel Aviv. Devoted grandfather of Reuben and Daniel Cohen. Shiva will be observed at his home.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Arrests In Animal Rights Protests
description: Twenty animal rights activists were arrested outside the Little Rock offices of Stephens Inc., an investment banking company, after they tried to break through a barricade in the final hours of a three-day protest over animal testing. Two protesters suffered minor injuries. Those arrested were among more than 150 demonstrators demanding that Stephens divest itself of Huntingdon Life Sciences, Britain's largest drug and chemical testing concern, which uses animals in testing pharmaceuticals and chemicals. Stephens holds a controlling interest in Huntingdon.

title: Exogenous May Race Again
description: Less than 48 hours after a freakish and potentially life-threatening accident before the Breeders' Cup Distaff, the 3-year-old filly Exogenous was in the midst of a dramatic recovery yesterday morning, leading to cautious optimism that all she suffered was a mild concussion.

title: Editorial Observer; The Not-Yet-Ready-for-Prime-Time Novelist
description: Five years ago, when Oprah Winfrey had not yet come knocking, the novelist Jonathan Franzen wrote an essay for Harper's magazine called ''Perchance to Dream.'' The most illuminating passage is one in which he imagines how he would respond to a hometown St. Louis audience after the publication of his first novel, ''The Twenty-Seventh City.'' Mr. Franzen does what just about every writer does when his book is about to come out. He pictures himself as the hero of an urbane conversation that manages to soothe irate readers, charm the intelligentsia and win the praise of nearly everyone, himself included. Then Mr. Franzen invites us to imagine his surprise when reality lets him down and even he has trouble liking himself.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: M.T.A. Board To Meet
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will have its regularly scheduled meeting. Fifth Floor Board Room, 347 Madison Avenue, near 44th Street, Manhattan, 9:30 a.m. Information: (212) 878-7178.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Expects Profit
description: France's biggest bank, Crdit Agricole, expects to post a profit of about $1.3 billion for 2001, up 9 percent from levels a year ago, and expects a 5 to 10 percent rise in 2002 profits from 2001. The bank released the figures ahead of its initial public offering in December, which will be the biggest in France since Orange Telecom's stock offering earlier this year. Twenty percent of Agricole's capital will be floated. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: After Prison, Former Contractor Disputes Case
description: Richard Bernardi has served his prison time, paying the price for a crime he says he did not commit. But five years after he was convicted of conspiring to bribe a city official here, Mr. Bernardi is waging a lonely campaign for vindication, saying he was poorly represented by his lawyers, then harshly punished by a prejudicial judge.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Jennifer Birch was named to head a new color department at Jager Di Paola Kemp Design, Burlington, Vt. She had most recently been footwear color and trend manager at Adidas International, Portland, Ore.

title: Information Sharing
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called for legislation that would significantly increase the amount of information shared between federal and local law enforcement agencies and said the F.B.I. should set up an office to coordinate such communication.

title: Enron Credit Rating Is Cut, And Its Share Price Suffers
description: Shares of the Enron Corporation fell sharply yesterday after Moody's Investors Service lowered the company's credit rating, igniting concern that it might have more difficulty raising the cash it needs to finance day-to-day operations.

title: Seven Men and One Woman Equal Explosion
description: With two splendid alternating casts, ''Clear,'' a new work by the Australian choreographer Stanton Welch, is already the major hit of American Ballet Theater's season at City Center.

title: Goaltending Gives Rangers Reason to Be Optimistic
description: Only one thing prevented the Rangers from taking a demoralizing four-game losing streak into last night's game against the Dallas Stars at Madison Square Garden: Mike Richter's play in net against the Boston Bruins on Saturday night.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Saturday: Help On Federal Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Service has scheduled a problem-solving day for individuals and small businesses, including those hurt by the Sept. 11 attack. While an appointment is not necessary, taxpayers are encouraged to schedule a meeting as soon as possible at 1-800-829-1040. Taxpayers with issues related to the attacks can call 1-866-562-5227. I.R.S. offices at 110 West 44th Street in Manhattan and 622 Fulton Street in Brooklyn will be open from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Gesture From Junta
description: The government announced that it had freed eight more political prisoners, bringing the total to 182 since it began discussions with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize winner and leader of the democratic opposition. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, GERTRUDE
description: ARONSON-Gertrude. On October 28, 2001 in Fairfield, CT. Widow of Dr. Martin E. Aronson, predeceased by son, Marc Eric Aronson, devoted sister of Pearl Silver of Westport, CT, Bess Halpert of Bridgeport, CT, cherished grandmother of Michael Aronson and Jennifer Schissler, and loving aunt to her many nieces and nephews. Memorial service Wed., October 31 at Congregation B'nai Israel, 2710 Park Ave., Bridgeport, CT.

title: Investment Banks Pay Some Workers Not to Show Up
description: When Jamie Odell, a recent graduate of Princeton University, received the e-mail note from J. P. Morgan Chase, his prospective employer, he was relieved.

title: Another Blow to AT&T's Debt Ratings
description: The debt ratings of AT&T were lowered yesterday by Standard & Poor's, which said the company faced further cuts.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar fell on concern that government reports this week will show that the United States economy is shrinking. In New York, the euro settled at 90.32 cents, up from 89.22 cents on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELMAN, ROBERT
description: ZELMAN-Robert. On October 28. Beloved husband of Rose. Father of Lois and Eric S. Weiss. Grandfather of Gabe, Mona, Bradley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTONE, CLARICE
description: GOLDSTONE-Clarice. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Clarice Goldstone. To her family and loved ones, we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

description: In the months to come there will be much speculation about what James Levine's appointment as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra means for this 121-year-old orchestra, for the Metropolitan Opera and for American music overall.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Gibraltar: Deadline For Talks
description: Britain and Spain have set a 14-month deadline to try to settle a centuries-old dispute over Gibraltar, which has been British since 1704. Options include shared sovereignty or a transition to Spanish rule, but the Foreign Office said it remained committed to giving the 30,000 residents final say in a referendum. They are thought to favor continued British control or independence to a Spanish takeover. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Supreme Court justices refused to work at the court because anthrax was in their mail building, so why should we be forced to work in a building where anthrax was found?''

title: A Gas Grid For Asia's Southeast
description: SINGAPORE  Concerned at the possible disruption of oil supplies from the Gulf as military operations by the U.S.-led coalition against terrorism in Afghanistan intensify, Southeast Asian nations are pressing ahead with moves to use more natural gas from within the region.

title: Taliban Foes Mobilizing, Possible Sign Of Offensive
description: The opposition Northern Alliance mobilized at least three attack units north of Kabul today in what could be the first sign of an offensive against Taliban forces on the front line here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, LEONARD O.
description: FRIEDMAN-Leonard O. On October 28, 2001. Beloved husband of Mildred. Devoted father of Vinson and Ellen. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Melanie, Scott and Rachel. Loving brother of Joseph. Services Tuesday 12 Noon at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, HELEN
description: HALPERN-Helen. October 26, 2001, of Oceanside, New York, and Plantation, FL. Retired office manager. Beloved and adored wife of 39 years of the late Eli Halpern who passed away in 1979. Loving mother of Ronald and wife Susan, Martin and wife Helen Webb, and Kenneth. Devoted grandmother of Amanda & David Halpern and Sheila and Leah Webb-Halpern. Cherished sister of Mollie Blatt, Shirley Leiboff and the late Harry Persoff. Dear wife of the late Morris Kaltinick. Also survived by dear nieces, nephews, friends & loving companion Harry Lippe. Services will be Wednesday, October 31, at noon at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 46 Greenwich St, Hempstead, NY, 516486-2500. In lieu of flowers donations to ACLD, 807 South Oyster Bay Road, Bethpage, NY 11714.

title: Possible Anthrax Case Shuts a New York Hospital
description: A 61-year-old Bronx woman is in critical condition with what officials believe is the first case of inhalation anthrax in New York City, a preliminary diagnosis that has led the city to temporarily shut down the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, where the infection may have occurred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, JOHN
description: ROBERTS-John. Died on October 27. Beloved husband of Rona. Adored father of Jennifer and Douglas. Brother of William, Keith and Kathy. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUTHS, EVELYN S.
description: TUTHS-Evelyn S. Of Southampton, formerly of Valley Stream and Rockville Centre, New York on October 28, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Philip M. Tuths, MD. Loving mother of Carmel, Evelyn J., Donna, Philip M., Paul and Michael E. Tuths. Cherished grandmother of eleven grandsons. Also survived by her brother Edward C. Svete. Predeceased by an infant son, Philip J. Tuths. Reposing Thursday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at the Brockett Funeral Home, Inc., 203 Hampton Road, Southampton, NY. Funeral Mass Friday 1 PM at Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary RC Church, Hill Street, Southampton. Private cremation to follow. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations in Mrs. Tuths' name to the Rogers Memorial Library, 91 Coopers Farm Road, Southampton, New York 11968, or East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978, would be appreciated.

title: NOMURA IN TALKS FOR STAKE IN U.S. INVESTMENT BANK
description: Nomura Holdings is in talks to buy a stake in a San Francisco-based investment bank. Nomura, Japan's biggest broker, may buy a stake in Thomas Weisel Partners, which invests in and provides underwriting and merger advice to computer-related companies, a Nomura spokesman, Toshiyasu Iiyama, said. He said no agreement had been reached. Nomura plans to invest 20 billion yen, or $163 million in the bank, the Nihon Keizai newspaper reported earlier. A Thomas Weisel spokeswoman, Amanda Duckworth, declined comment.

title: Killer Said Rabbi Did Not Plot Murder, 2 Men Testify
description: Two New Jersey convicts testified today that a man who implicated a prominent Cherry Hill rabbi in the 1994 murder of his wife told them that the rabbi had nothing to do with the killing.

title: 2 U.S. Bridge Teams Win
description: Two American teams marched on at the world bridge championships here today, but two others crashed to defeat.

title: Argentina May Restructure Its Debt, Risking Default
description: Argentine bond and stock prices fell sharply yesterday after the country's economy minister indicated that he wanted to voluntarily restructure Argentina's billions of dollars in public-sector debt, including that owned by foreigners.

title: Merrill Alters Pay of Brokers in Effort to Court Wealthy as Clients
description: In the latest step in its effort to attract more wealthy Americans and fewer customers of modest means, Merrill Lynch said yesterday that it would overhaul the way it pays its 15,000 brokers.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/John McWhorter; How Language Came To Be, and Change
description: On a warm recent afternoon, the conservative author and social critic Dr. John H. McWhorter, 36, was sitting in a New York sushi parlor, discussing his other profession: linguistics professor at the University of California at Berkeley with an expertise in language change and evolution.

title: Particles Are Tiny, but Damage Can Be Great
description: Until anthrax spores started spreading through the mail, few people gave much thought to the minuscule particles that drift almost invisibly in the atmosphere, infiltrate buildings and plunge deep into lungs. Not so for environmental scientists, who have spent decades studying the physics and physiology of particles very much like those in the most dangerous forms of biological weaponry.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: West Berlin: Supermarket Strike Settled
description: More than 700 supermarket employees who have been on strike for seven weeks will go back to work after ratifying a new contract, union officials said. The contract was approved on Sunday, and employees of the 10 affected ShopRite stores in southern New Jersey will resume work before Thursday, Clay Bowman, president of the United Food and Commercial Workers Local 1360, said yesterday. The agreement calls for wage increases of $1.60 per hour over the next four years and will let the union maintain control of its pension and health benefits funds, Mr. Bowman said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about quarreling between the Giuliani administration and the State Assembly over school aid omitted the given name and title of a legislator who criticized the potential shift of more funds away from the suburbs. He is Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Westchester County.

title: At Home Abroad; Is There an Answer?
description: Ariel Sharon made his sortie onto the Temple Mount on Sept. 28 last year. The second Palestinian intifada began the next day, and Yasir Arafat quickly embraced it.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of 5 p.m. yesterday, 4,754 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLER, ARTHUR
description: HILLER-Arthur. The National Board and Membership of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the loss of Arthur Hiller, 90, of Coconut Creek, FL, formerly of Chicago, father of our esteemed National President, Bonnie Lipton. Mr. Hiller is survived by his loving wife, Nellie, of 65 years, two devoted daughters, and sons-in-law, Bonnie and Alan, Claudia & Dick Nanberg, adoring grandchildren, Andrea, Susan, Ronnie, Steven, and Michael, & eight great grandchildren. Mr. Hiller took great pride in Hadassah's achievements, & was a generous supporter of our programs. Hadassah has established the Arthur Hiller Memorial Fund. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. June Walker, National Treasurer Ellen Marson, National Executive Director

title: Numbers Game Doesn't Work
description: Joe Torre played it by the book in the first two games of the World Series, leaving Paul O'Neill on the bench both nights, and sitting the left-handed-hitting Tino Martinez in Game 2 in favor of the right-handed-hitting Randy Velarde, who had hit Randy Johnson well throughout his career. But with David Justice in right field in Game 1 and striking out in each of his three at-bats and Velarde 0-3 with a strikeout and a walk in Game 2, Torre was not so sure he would play the percentages against the left-hander Brian Anderson tonight.

title: VOUGHT AIRCRAFT TO LAY OFF 1,200, 20% OF ITS STAFF
description: Carlyle Group's Vought Aircraft Industries unit, which makes airplane tails and wings, said it would lay off 1,200 workers, or 20 percent of its work force, because of falling sales. Vought employs 6,000, and the company declined to say at which offices the jobs would be eliminated. A spokeswoman, Lynne Warne, said the cuts would begin next month. Vought, based in Dallas, was sold last year by Northrop Grumman for $1.2 billion to Carlyle Group, an investment concern. Demand for aircraft parts has fallen along with air travel since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Vought sells 80 percent of its parts to Boeing, which is laying off 20,000 to 30,000 workers.

title: With World Series and Marathon, New York Is Already on Heightened Alert
description: As Attorney General John Ashcroft warned of the possibility of more terrorist strikes in the next week, New York City was already on heightened alert because of several high-profile events in the next few days, including the World Series game at Yankee Stadium tonight, which President Bush plans to attend, and the New York City Marathon, scheduled for next Sunday, which is likely to draw hundreds of thousands of spectators.

title: Clemens Must Heal For Must-Win Game
description: Roger Clemens has won both of his World Series starts as a Yankee, but they have hardly been of the back-to-the-wall variety that he will face in Game 3 tonight at Yankee Stadium.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Look For Asylum System
description: The government announced plans for a ''radical and fundamental reform'' of the asylum system, which has been widely criticized as unfair both to people seeking asylum and to the communities that house them. The government plans to issue identification cards with photographs and fingerprints to asylum seekers and house them in reception centers, paying for their room and board and giving them spending money to replace the current vouchers. More than 100,000 people sought asylum last year. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Financial Exchange Accepts Bid
description: In a surprise move, the London Financial Futures and Options Exchange rejected a takeover offer from the London Stock Exchange in favor of an $805 million all-cash bid from Euronext. Euronext's bid of 18.25 ($26.10) a share topped the London exchange's bid of 12 in cash and 7 in stock. Euronext said investors representing 51 percent of Liffe's shares had agreed to the offer. The decision is a blow to the London Stock Exchange's new chief executive, Clara Furse, the former deputy chairwoman, of Liffe, who joined the exchange in February. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: U.S. Said to Seek Syrian Help

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Steel Venture
description: ThyssenKrupp of Germany and the Baosteel Group of China will officially open a $1.43 billion stainless steel manufacturing plant in Shanghai this week, representing one of the largest foreign investments yet in the country. ThyssenKrupp holds 60 percent of the joint venture, which will produce stainless steel for the domestic market. Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, left, is expected to attend the opening ceremony on Friday. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Watching Jordan Play: Priceless
description: IN a gentler time, in the early 1970's, Bobby Fischer, the reclusive chess champion, was taken by a friend to a basketball game at Madison Square Garden to see the Knicks, then also the champs. The crowd was going wild at one point as the Knicks staged a late-game comeback. Fischer, seated near courtside, looked over his shoulder at the screaming masses. ''Are they dangerous?'' he asked his companion.

title: U.S. Switches to Older Drug Against Anthrax
description: Cipro, the antibiotic that has become a household name as the drug of choice against anthrax, is no longer being recommended by the federal health authorities, who said today that people exposed to anthrax spores would be given an older and cheaper medicine, doxycycline.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: SPSS To Buy Netgenesis
description: SPSS Inc., a maker of datamining and analysis software, announced yesterday that it planned to buy the NetGenesis Corporation for $44.6 million. SPSS, based in Chicago, will pay 2.4 million shares, or $1.80 a share, to NetGenesis shareholders. NetGenesis specializes in technology that tracks the behavior of Web site visitors to help companies develop online marketing campaigns. The acquisition is expected to extend SPSS's analytical capabilities in the online arena, enabling the company to market both online and offline data analysis tools. Shares of SPSS closed at $17.06, down $1.81. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Turning the Unexpected to Lyrical Good Use
description: Charles Dutoit and his Montreal Symphony are regular visitors to Carnegie Hall, and they have always been welcome for two reasons. One is that Mr. Dutoit's repertory choices regularly veer away from the Central European classics that virtually all visiting orchestra's offer in New York. Perhaps not surprisingly for a Quebec orchestra led by a Swiss conductor, the center of musical gravity for the Montreal players is more typically early-20th-century France and Russia than 19th-century Austria and Germany.

description: Handel's 'Saul'

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Introduces Two Inexpensive Systems
description: Sun Microsystems started selling two new inexpensive server computers that dish up Internet pages, as the company tries to bolster its business outside high-end machines. The Sun Fire V880 and Netra 20 use Sun's new UltraSparc III chips. The V880 is an entry-level system the company says costs as much as 46 percent less than competing products and can tackle the work of three rival machines. The Netra 20 is an updated version of the company's thin, rack-mounted server.

title: Washington As Still Life: The Crowds Are Gone
description: A sunny, crystal-clear fall day in the nation's capital would normally lure throngs of people from their workplaces, at least for lunch or a stroll around the Mall.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Seattle Mayoral Endorses
description: Mayor Paul Schell endorsed City Attorney Mark Sidran in Seattle's November mayoral election, which Mr. Schell left after winning just over 20 percent of the vote in a September primary. Mr. Sidran faces Greg Nickels, a King County councilman; both are Democrats, and a recent poll showed them about even. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Spores Are Found in 4 More Federal Buildings
description: Anthrax spores have been discovered in four more government buildings here, health officials said today. But the amounts found were small, officials said, and all except the Supreme Court Building, which was already closed, remained open. The officials said workers were not in danger of contracting the disease.

title: French Star Injured In Training Accident
description: Rgine Cavagnoud, an Alpine skier from France who was expected to be a leading contender at next year's Salt Lake City Olympics, was in critical condition here tonight after a collision with a German coach during a training run.

title: Alliance With U.S. Spotlights Uzbek Rights Abuses
description: The child in a knit cap and two sweaters insisted on a firm handshake and led the way down an alley. Passing through a courtyard, he slipped off his shoes and stepped into a room with women whose husbands are gone.

title: Diamondbacks Spread Cheer
description: A group of 40 from the Diamondbacks' organization, including about 15 players, made a two-hour trip yesterday to the World Trade Center site, visiting police officers, firefighters and rescue workers, signing construction helmets, police caps and firefighters' hats.

title: DOCUMENTS TAKEN IN U.S. GROUND RAID ARE OF LIMITED USE
description: The collection of documents, computer disks and other material seized during a nighttime raid by special operations forces in southern Afghanistan 10 days ago failed to produce the intelligence bonanza that the Pentagon had sought, military and government officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the resignation of Dr. Bernadine Healy as president of the American Red Cross misstated her specialty as a physician. She is a cardiologist, not a surgeon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELLI, GLADYS NEE FOX
description: CASTELLI-Gladys nee Fox, 97. Of Dallastown, PA, formerly of NYC, died on October 26th, 2001 at her residence in Pennsylvania. Wife of the late Albert Castelli. She worked as a switchboard operator for the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in NY until she retired at age 85. Funeral service will be held today, at 11 AM, in Dallastown, PA.

title: Small Office, Wide Authority
description: The members of Congress who say the new Office of Homeland Security should become a cabinet department want to make sure the office has enough authority, muscle and money to fight terrorism. But if history is any guide, creating a full-fledged cabinet department not only isn't necessary but is not the best way to achieve those aims.

title: Strife May Delay Some Expeditions
description: In the first Afghan War, 1839-42, the British army officer and Assyriologist Henry Creswicke Rawlinson had to abandon for years the research that would eventually lead to critical breakthroughs in the decipherment of the cuneiform writing system, which in turn opened up the ancient history of the Middle East.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: LEAN HOGS RISE. Hog prices gained after a report signaled that pork supplies will be smaller than expected early next year. In Chicago, hogs for December delivery rose 1.8 cents, or 3.8 percent, to 49.65 cents a pound.

description: On a clear day, visitors to the Sears Tower observation deck can see across Lake Michigan to Indiana and Michigan. But since Sept. 11 no tourists had been allowed up to the deck, on the 103rd floor of the nation's tallest building, to take in the view.

title: From Edwardian Intrigue To Wild West Antics
description: Some theaters may be sparsely attended these difficult days. But vociferous audiences filled City Center for performances by American Ballet Theater on Friday night and Saturday afternoon. The company is having a terrific season, both in its dancers and in its repertory, which includes a vivid new production of Antony Tudor's ''Dim Lustre,'' presented at both performances.

title: Exxon Says Way Is Cleared for Development in Russia
description: Breaking a logjam that has held up Western-led oil development in Russia for years, ExxonMobil said today that it was ready to spend $4 billion over five years to develop large offshore oil and gas fields in far eastern Russia. The project, which could grow to $12 billion over its life of 30 to 40 years, will be Russia's largest single foreign investment so far.

title: Illegal Immigrants Bring Halt to Channel Tunnel Traffic
description: PARIS, Oct. 30  The Channel Tunnel was closed to freight traffic for 11 hours today after dozens of asylum-seekers broke into a freight yard near Calais and tried to hide on trains bound for Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANNHEISSER, ELAINE (MRS. WERNER H.)
description: DANNHEISSER - Elaine (Mrs. Werner H.). The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art, along with the members of its International Council, join the art world in mourning the loss of Elaine Dannheisser. Elaine had served as a Trustee of the Museum since 1995, a member of its Committee on Painting and Sculpture since 1990, a member of its Committee on Photography since 1996, and a member of its International Council since 1991. However, these positions do not begin to convey the many ways in which she permanently influenced the Museum's collection, as well as the way in which we experience and study contemporary art. Just four years ago, we celebrated the opening of On the Edge: Contemporary Art from the Werner and Elaine Dannheisser Collection at the Museum. The works of art that entered the Museum's collection on this occasion were as crucial to the collection as the bequest that came to us from one of the Museum's founders, Lillie P. Bliss, whose gift was the basis of our permanent collection and included many works that continue to be most closely associated with the Museum. Our founding Director, Alfred Barr, believed that the Museum's collection should evolve ''as a torpedo moving through time,'' and Elaine's gift enabled it to do just that. Future generations will identify this Museum with works from the Dannheisser collection, such as those by Matthew Barney, Joseph Beuys, Felix Gonzalez-Torres, Robert Gober, Jeff Koons, Brice Marden, Bruce Nauman, Sigmar Polke, Robert Ryman, Richard Serra, and Cindy Sherman, just as current ones identify it with Water Lilies, The Starry Night, and Les Demoiselles d'Avignon. Beginning as a girl from Brooklyn whose mother brought her to the Museum to see Guernica, Elaine has now taken her place alongside such benefactors as Mrs. Simon Guggenheim, Harriet and Sidney Janis, Philip Johnson, William S. Paley, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Louise Reinhardt Smith, and Gordon Bunshaft. Elaine was a consummate collector (acquiring new work right up until the very end), but was also the most insightful benefactress. Over the years, Elaine formed a collection that was deeply personal and distinctly her own. When she decided to give it to the Modern, however, she was doubly generous: in addition to making a monumental gift, she allowed the Museum to accept the works that were needed to build a balanced collection. In some cases, she helped augment existing areas of the collection that were missing key pieces. In others, she gave us the collection's seminal works, such as the first major Barney. Thanks to Elaine, the Museum has the most important collection of Gonzalez-Torres anywhere, and arguably the most important collection of Nauman and Gober in any American museum. Elaine was ever a prescient collector who remained on the sharpest part of the cutting edge of the art world, understanding and appreciating works that were often difficult for those half her age to appreciate or even understand. It is impossible to think of Elaine without thinking of her husband Werner. She clearly had the eye that formed the collection, but she credited Werner with giving her the support (both moral and financial) to realize her vision. At the opening of the exhibition, Elaine described their partnership and her own transformation in these words: ''Werner is the one who created me. He took a young, curious girl and taught her to focus. He opened all the doors for me and made it all happen. In 1982, a young professor at Columbia heard I was collecting works from emerging artists at a furious pace. She called me up to ask if I would speak to her class. I said that I was not qualified, that I had nothing to say, but that I would be happy to answer her students' questions. We set up a date. The morning of our appointment, Werner and I were having breakfast, and he asked what I was doing that day. I said that I was giving a talk at Columbia. He said, ''This I have to see,'' and called up his secretary to cancel all of his appointments for the day. He came up to Columbia with me and sat in the audience with the students. They asked questions nonstop and I answered them all. Werner was so impressed with me that he raised my art allowance. And the rest is history.'' Elaine has passed from being simply a collector, patron, and friend into being a historical figure whose spirit and devotion will live on forever at The Museum of Modern Art. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY Sir Brian Urquhart, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

The figure was in line with the administration's forecasts in recent weeks, but it was down from $237 billion surplus of the year before and well below the administration's projection in the summer. Excluding revenue from the Social Security program, the government ran a $34 billion deficit for the year.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Cuts Some Prices

Intel reduced the cost of a 2-gigahertz Pentium 4 chip to $401 from $562, the company said on its Web site. The price of a 1.9-gigahertz version fell 27 percent, to $273 from $375, with the 1.8 gigahertz chip dropping 12 percent, to $225 from $256. The chip maker had already cut the price of the Pentium 4 by as much as 84 percent since its November introduction, trying to lure consumers and businesses to buy new machines that use the processor.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Delays New Service
description: Napster, the online music service, has pushed back the starting date of its for-pay subscription service until the first quarter of 2002, Konrad Hilbers, the company's chief executive, said yesterday. Originally, the company had said it intended to introduce its service by the end of the summer, as did a handful of other companies with competing music services that also have yet to begin. In the case of Napster, Mr. Hilbers said the delay was not due to technological hurdles, but to the fact Napster had not yet obtained licenses from major record labels to sell their content. Mr. Hilbers said if Napster did not secure them, he would seek to start the service without content from the major record labels. Napster, once a free music exchange with tens of millions of users, was sued by the major recording companies for copyright infringement and has been offline since July, following a court order. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: The Great Markdown
description: Much like any weekday in late afternoon, a smattering of customers browsed through merchandise at Macy's flagship Herald Square store on Monday, Oct. 8. Problem is, it wasn't just any afternoon. It was Columbus Day, not only a federal holiday, but one of the most highly publicized sales events of the year, and the first time in months Macy's had offered coupons on top of items already reduced as much as 50%. Still, instead of ringing up purchases or tending to the usual throng of holiday shoppers, a large portion of Macy's staff was busying itself by tidying merchandise and displays, and several saleswomen had more than ample time to stop and comment on what they described as surprisingly low activity for any coupon event, let alone a holiday. Customers agreed.

title: PENSION FUND AND ADVISER TO BUY CABOT INDUSTRIAL TRUST
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System and a partner agreed to buy the Cabot Industrial Trust, a real estate investment trust that owns warehouses and industrial property, for about $1 billion. Calpers, the biggest public pension fund in the nation, and Rreef America, will pay $24 a share, 20 percent more than Cabot's closing price on Friday of $19.95, said Cathy Reardon, a spokeswoman for Cabot, which is based in Boston. Cabot owns about 370 warehouse and industrial properties with more than 40 million square feet of space in Seattle, Phoenix, South Florida and elsewhere. Rreef, a Chicago-based pension fund adviser, and Calpers are operating through CalWest Industrial Properties, a joint venture.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Samsung To Reverse Losses
description: The president of the division of Samsung Electronics that produces memory chips said yesterday that an improved economy in the second half of next year would reverse the losses the company had sustained this year while it begins to mass produce the 512-megabit dynamic random access memory semiconductor. The president, Hwang Chang Gyu, said that both the 512-megabit chip and the 12-inch wafer from which it is made had gone into regular production in limited quantities, while the 256-megabit chip had become its biggest moneymaker. Mr. Hwang outlined the company's plans just a week after it announced a third-quarter loss of $294 million. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cisco Offers New Products
description: Cisco Systems, the world's leading maker of computer-networking equipment, said it would begin offering a dozen new Internet protocol telephone products to run on a network and provide voice, video and data services. The products, which include both hardware and software, will be available by the end of the year, company officials said. The announcement comes amid declining sales and and broad losses in the technology industry. Experts predict that spending on telecommunications equipment will continue to fall next year. As recently as the late 1990's, overall spending on new hardware, software and technology services routinely surged 20 percent or more each year. In August, Cisco posted an annual loss for the first time in 11 years, and said its fiscal first-quarter sales could be down by as much as 5 percent. But Hank Lambert, director of product marketing, said Cisco would ''continue to innovate when times are tough'' to be well positioned when consumer demand bounces back.
