title: Traces of Anthrax Are Found at 2 More D.C. Area Post Offices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 - Traces of anthrax have been found in two more post offices in the Washington area, but no new incidents of disease have turned up in or near the capital, officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Oct. 20 about the effect of the decline in tourism on New York City cultural institutions referred incorrectly to the American Craft Museum. While lower-level staff members spoke of financial troubles that existed before Sept. 11, the director, Holly Hotchner, says the museum's finances are strong.

title: A Lukewarm Endorsement And an Exchange of Ads
description: Mark Green stood yesterday at the latest in a series of news conferences with unions jumping onto his campaign train -- this time the giant health care workers' union, led by Dennis Rivera -- when he decided to take a gamble.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Toms River: Suspect In 12-Year-Old Homicide
description: Twelve years after a landlady was found stabbed to death in the rooming house she owned in Lakewood, the authorities have charged a former tenant with killing her. DNA evidence found at the scene where the landlady, Matilda Hammock, 67, died, was reviewed by Ocean County's cold-case task force, said Gregory L. Sakowicz, the executive assistant county prosecutor. The former tenant, Carl Harris, 56, was arrested in Virginia Beach, Va., on a murder warrant on Oct. 19 and extradited to New Jersey on Friday. He is being held in the county jail in $250,000 bail. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ebay Optimistic About Revenue
description: EBay Inc., the largest Internet auctioneer, said yesterday that it was on track to increase revenue by 50 percent next year and meet its 2005 revenue goal of $3 billion as it expands into more categories and regions. EBay ''remains confident'' in its revenue projections for 2005 as well as for next year, Meg Whitman, the chief executive, said in a presentation to analysts and investors. EBay's 2002 revenue was forecast to rise 40 percent, to $1.03 billion from this year's projected $737.5 million, according to analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: The Finer Points Of the Spinner's Art
description: D.J. Shadow and Cut Chemist

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a memorial service at the site of the World Trade Center attack misidentified the soprano who sang. She was Rene Fleming, not Kathleen Battle.

title: Bulk Sales Bolster USA Today's Lead in National Circulation
description: USA Today, the flagship newspaper of the Gannett Company, solidified its title as the nation's circulation leader yesterday, according to six-month figures compiled by the Audit Bureau of Circulations. But the latest report also showed that the newspaper's bulk sales, like those to hotels, newspapers, conventions and colleges, made up 44 percent of its average daily sales of 2,242,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOTUFO, HARRY C.
description: LOTUFO-Harry C. Age 80, on October 28, 2001. Mr. Lotufo was a former VP and partner of the Fred Gardner Advertising Agency, NYC. He is survived by his wife, Marge; his children, David G. Lotufo, MD & Mrs. Sarah Ferber; his brother, Donald A. Lotufo; his grandchildren, Christopher and Kiera Ferber; his son-in-law, Donald Ferber and sister-in-law, Elsi K. Lotufo. Wake Wednesday, 2-4 & 7-9 PM at Sinatra Memorial Home, 601 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers. Religious services Thursday, 11 AM at F.H. Chapel. Burial at St. Joseph Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers contributions to Retinitis Pigmentosa Int'l, PO Box 900, Woodland Hills, CA. 91365.

title: Accounts
description: The Danone Group, Paris, to MediaCom Worldwide, New York, part of the Grey Global Group, to handle the consolidated media planning and buying duties for three divisions: Dannon, Danone Waters of North America and Lea & Perrins. Spending was estimated at $57 million.

title: The Pain of the Long-Distance Runner
description: Anyone who has ever run a marathon can testify to the toll it can take on the body, from painful shin splints to disabling stress fractures.

title: Many of the Newly Laid Off Head for Retraining
description: One was a flight attendant who wanted to become a private investigator. Another, cradling his 2-year-old son in his arms, had been a baggage handler but wanted to learn how to repair heaters and air-conditioners. Yet another had known only one job since turning 20 -- he had been an airplane mechanic for 11 years -- but said he was hoping he could apply those same skills to fixing computers.

title: Estimates of Future Human Death Toll From Mad Cow Disease Vary Widely
description: The human form of mad cow disease may peak at 100 cases per year in Britain and kill no more than a few thousand people in coming decades, according to new estimates from a highly respected group of epidemiologists in London.

title: Richter's Play Overshadows Teammates' Career Marks
description: The milestones just kept on coming at Madison Square Garden last night as the Rangers, behind another sterling effort from goaltender Mike Richter, moved above .500 with a 4-2 victory over the Dallas Stars.

title: A Tribute of Tibetan Horns and Aged Chants for the Trade Center Victims
description: Tibetan horns brayed and chants muffled the traffic noise around Union Square last evening when Buddhist holy men and women from around New York gathered to pray for the World Trade Center victims.

title: A Pivotal Choice for Cingular Wireless
description: Cingular Wireless, the nation's second-largest mobile phone carrier, intends to announce broad changes in its technology today, people close to the company said yesterday. The decision will benefit some of Europe's largest communications equipment companies at the expense of competitors in the United States and Canada.

title: Mixing It Up For Causes Downtown
description: New York City has two distinct versions of downtown: the financial capital where the twin towers of the World Trade Center stood until Sept. 11, and the hotbed of free-thinking arts. The Beastie Boys, representing the second downtown, organized a benefit for the first downtown with two sold-out shows Sunday and last night at the Hammerstein Ballroom under the rubric New Yorkers Against Violence. Proceeds went to the New York Women's Foundation and the New York Association for New Americans, which helps recent immigrants, including undocumented victims of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Pepsi Files Suit to Stop Dasani Talks
description: PepsiCo ( news/quote ) has gone to court to prevent executives from a former agency, the Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding, from meeting with a new client, the Coca-Cola Company ( news/quote ), PepsiCo's competitor.

title: Beneath the Rubble, the Only Tool Was a Pair of Cuffs
description: As the officers ran, a small arsenal of tools clanked around each man's waist: Guns. Ammunition. Flashlight. Handcuffs. Racing through the trade center concourse, the team of five Port Authority police officers stopped at security closets to collect more gear -- Scott Airpaks, helmets, axes -- and piled it into a canvas laundry cart. Then they ran the cart toward a freight elevator, but it was 9:59 a.m. on that Tuesday, and the first of the towers was falling above them, burying light and space, men and women.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: 2 Judges Join High Court
description: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove appointed two Circuit Court judges to the state's nine-member Supreme Court in a move that business groups and trial lawyers praised as fair. The two judges, James E. Graves Jr. and George C. Carlson, will serve until a special election.

title: The Senate's Quaking Moderates
description: As the Senate prepares to consider an economic stimulus package, the atmosphere is much different from earlier this year, when it passed President Bush's unaffordable and unfair tax cuts. Back then many moderate Republicans and Democrats voted for what they saw as a popular program to share the surplus with the taxpayers, despite their own quiet misgivings. Now there is a sense of crisis, demands for sacrifice, a realization that the federal surplus is gone and a determination to pass something that will actually boost the economy. Unfortunately, the stimulus package being put together by the Republican Senate leadership fails in every way to address the new circumstances.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Utility's Profit Is Up
description: Malaysia's state-controlled national electric utility, Tenaga Nasional, said its profit rose 62 percent in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, but warned that slowing economic growth might crimp demand and sales this year. It said it earned 2.11 billion ringgit ($555 million) on 14.4 billion ringgit in revenue. Earnings were buoyed by a 785.5 million ringgit foreign exchange windfall stemming largely from the Japanese yen's depreciation against the ringgit, which is pegged at 3.8 to the dollar. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDOR, CHRISTINA
description: SANDOR-Christina. Born Satzger von Balvanyos in Vienna passed away on October 26, 2001. She was widowed to Archduke Carlos Habsburg Bourbon, once claimant to the thrown of Spain and married to Gyorgy Sandor, renowned concert pianist and protege of the composer Bela Bartok. She is survived by her two daughters Alejandra & Inmaculada Habsburg and her son Michael Sandor. She is also survived by her grandchildren: Alejandra, Carlos, and Pedro Riera & by Carlos, Juan-Leopoldo, and Anthony Dobkin. Her greatgrandchildren are Mar and Violeta Montaner and Laura and Blanca Riera. She is also mourned by Jose Maria Riera, John Dobkin, and Eunice Sandor and by Baldo Montaner, Mireia Mateu & Alienor Benoist. Carmen Galicia, who cared for her with great love during her most vulnerable years, gri eves with us as a member of our family. Her memorial Mass will be held at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street on Friday, November 2, 11 AM.

title: Penelope, Only One Person Could Describe That Bed
description: More than 350 years have passed, but Monteverdi's ''Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria,'' which opened in a new production at the New York City Opera on Saturday afternoon, still has moments as poignant as any in opera, not least in its final scene. As in Homer, Penelope has been reluctant to recognize the stranger in Ithaca as her husband come back, but Monteverdi and his poet collaborator Giacomo Badoaro tell the denouement a little differently.

title: Detentions After Attacks Pass 1,000, U.S. Says
description: Justice Department officials said today that the number of people who had been detained in connection with the Sept. 11 attacks had surpassed 1,000, and civil liberties advocates said the government's refusal to disclose the identities of those held and the charges against them raised the possibility of secret detentions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOMOWITZ, SHIRLEY
description: SLOMOWITZ-Shirley. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of our member and extends its heartfelt condolences to the entire bereaved family. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus Howard Wolf, President

title: Pictures of the Culinary Past Worth a Thousand Recipes
description: ood Mania," by Nigel Garwood and Rainer Voigt (Clarkson Potter, $35), is nearly 400 pages of often amusing illustrations about food production, preparation, consumption and serving. Its focus is European and American lithographs, paintings and advertisements from the 19th and early 20th centuries, like the little butter makers, above, from "A Children's Book of Trades," circa 1870. Not much text accompanies the art, but words aren't needed: the pictures say it all.

title: TV Stations Scrambling for Antennas, Ratings and Revenue
description: Six weeks after the collapse of the World Trade Center, hundreds of thousands of homes in the New York area remain unable to receive more than two television stations, and the local broadcasting industry, already reeling from economic losses of tens of millions of dollars, finds itself increasingly desperate to find a long-term solution that will restore its ability to reach every possible viewer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Farmland Preserved In Agreement
description: After years of litigation over its future, former farmland in Jericho will be preserved to protect underground water supplies, the Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, announced yesterday. The 81-acre site, known as the Underhill property, is at the northwest corner of Jericho Turnpike and Routes 106 and 107. Tilles Development, which had proposed building 270 homes on the property, will instead sell it. The price has not been set, but the county and the Town of Oyster Bay will pay at least $5 million each, and the state is to pay the rest, according to the Society to Preserve Underhill, an environmental group. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Tunnel Vision; Welcomed: The Never and the Rarely
description: Before Sept. 11, the N and R subway lines were not what you might call beloved.

title: Student Designers Undaunted by the Prospects
description: BEFORE it was clear to her that ''you only have so much time on earth, so you had better spend it doing what you love,'' Diane Reeves sold computers for Dell. Ms. Reeves's clients were mostly corporate health care centers. She had a degree from the University of Texas, a husband, a young son, a house and a career that many might envy. So it came as a considerable surprise to those close to her when Ms. Reeves decided a year ago to quit her job, pick up stakes and move to New York to become, of all things, a fashion designer.

title: Price Dips for Market Seat
description: ANew York Stock Exchange seat sold for $2.2 million yesterday, a $100,000, or 4.5 percent, decline from the previous seat sold, on Oct. 18.

title: Footlights
description: Saying Hello

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: R. R. DONNELLEY & SONS CO., Chicago, a commercial printer, said it had extended its directory contract with the information services unit of Verizon Communications, New York, the nation's largest local phone company, and would print and bind about 850 titles for Verizon through 2013.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Money & Business on Sunday about Douglas R. Cliggott, senior stock market strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, omitted two figures in citing the percentage change that would result in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by next spring if it were to fall to 800, a development that he believes possible. The index would be nearly 28 percent below its close of 1,104.61 on Friday.

title: Catering for Rescue Workers Angers Restaurant Owners
description: Since Sept. 11, a Long Island catering company, working under contract with the Salvation Army, has been providing an average of 7,500 meals a day to rescue workers in New York City, delivering waffles, stuffed shells and pork chops from its kitchens in Suffolk County.

title: DNA From Slain Yale Student Doesn't Match That of Suspect
description: DNA from skin cells found under the fingernails of a Yale student murdered nearly three years ago does not match that of James Van de Velde, her former thesis adviser and the only named suspect in the case, state investigators have concluded.

title: The Twin Tower, the Full Life, the Policeman Who Spoke Swedish
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Company Admits Pollution
description: A Danish company whose oil tanker sailed into Baltimore Harbor with a rust hole in its hull pleaded guilty to trying to conceal the leak and deliberately polluting the harbor. The indictment included not only the captain but also two supervisors. While the company, D/S Progress, agreed to a fine of at least $250,000, the people who were charged are fugitives, prosecutors said. When the ship, the Freja Jutlandic, arrived in Baltimore on March 22, 2000, a crew member warned a Coast Guard inspector of the hole. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Veiled Messages of Terror May Lurk in Cyberspace
description: The investigation of the terrorist attacks on the United States is drawing new attention to a stealthy method of sending messages through the Internet. The method, called steganography, can hide messages in digital photographs or in music files but leave no outward trace that the files were altered.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pension Drops Stocks
description: Britain's biggest pharmacy chain, Boots, sold all of the stocks in its $3.3 billion pension fund and bought bonds, according to the fund's trustee review. As of April 2000, the fund held 75 percent of its assets in stocks. Over the next 15 months, through July 2001, the fund, with 72,000 members, sold stocks and bought bonds with an average maturity of 30 years, the report said. ''We now have a more conservative investment strategy that aims to secure members' pensions and reduce investment risk to a minimum,'' John Watson, the chairman of Boots Pensions, wrote in the review. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A New Terror Warning, a New Poll, a New Agency's First Meeting
description: The government issued a new warning yesterday that terrorists might strike again in the next week. It was the second such warning this month, and, as with the first one, the authorities said they knew nothing more. They did suggest that the earlier warning might have somehow prevented an attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, MORTON
description: SILLS-Morton, 87. Beloved father of Josh, Rocky and Chris. Cherished husband, brother, uncle, grandfather, friend and mentor. Patron of the Brecht Forum. A true lover of life, he fought to enhance it collectively and for individuals. His passing is a loss to all.

title: USA Networks Settles a Dispute
description: USA Networks, owner of the Home Shopping Network, paid $20 million for a minority stake in the National Leisure Group to settle a dispute over cancellation of an agreement to buy National Leisure.

title: City Cultural Squabbles
description: To the Editor:

title: A Threatening Note Diverts an Airliner
description: An American Airlines flight from New York to Dallas was diverted to Dulles International Airport outside Washington tonight after a threatening note was found on board, airport officials said.

title: MTV Networks to Lay Off About 450
description: MTV Networks, home to the Nickelodeon, MTV and VH1 cable television channels, said yesterday that it would lay off about 450 full-time employees, or 8 percent to 9 percent of its work force, to reduce costs.

title: Spores Are Found in 4 More Federal Buildings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  Anthrax spores have been discovered in four more government buildings here, health officials said today. But the amounts found were small, officials said, and all except the Supreme Court Building, which was already closed, remained open. The officials said workers were not in danger of contracting the disease.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Repairs For Nuclear Plant
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant will be shut down for about a month so that its new owner, the Entergy Corporation, can make repairs that company officials say will improve the reactor's efficiency. Workers will replace three safety valves on the cooling system and a joint in a condenser and repair some of the electronic components. Jim Steets, an Entergy spokesman, said the maintenance had been planned by the company before August, when Entergy bought Indian Point 2 from Consolidated Edison. The repairs are not related to heightened security at the plant since Sept. 11, he said.

title: Jacqueline Hudson, 91, Landscape Painter
description: Jacqueline Hudson, a landscape painter, graphic artist and benefactor of the arts, died Wednesday at her home in Damariscotta, Me. She was 91.

title: Clemens Dominates in Game 3
Mummies Unwrapped
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Digi International Deal
description: Digi International, a networking equipment maker, said today that it had agreed to pay $50 million in cash and stock for NetSilicon, which makes chips and software for copiers, fax machines and printers. Digi International will exchange 0.65 share for each share of NetSilicon, or an equivalent amount in cash, it said. The deal values NetSilicon at about $3.53 a share. Digi International said it expected the purchase to begin adding to its earnings in 2003. The company expects to complete the purchase in the first quarter of next year. Digi International's shares fell 7 cents, to $5.43. Shares of NetSilicon, which is based in Waltham, Mass., rose 20 cents, to $2.60. The acquisition was announced after the close of regular trading.

title: Stocks Tumble, Spurred by Dive in Consumer Confidence
description: Stocks again fell sharply yesterday as stunned investors responded to a report that consumer confidence in October fell to its lowest level in seven years.

title: Woman Dies of Inhaled Anthrax; First Case in New York City
description: AManhattan hospital worker died today from inhalation anthrax, the most serious form of the disease.

title: More Questions Than Answers in Contaminated Letters From Trenton
description: Federal health officials did not hesitate when asked early this month what seemed like an obvious question: If anthrax-contaminated mail had been sent to a politician in Washington and news anchors in New York, did it present a hazard to people who handled the envelopes?

title: Not for Just an Hour, Not for Just a Day . . . but Always
description: THE COMPLETE LYRICS OF IRVING BERLIN

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Tribute To Turkish Workers
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder paid tribute to the economic contribution of Turkish immigrants as the country marked the 40th anniversary of the agreement inviting Turkish workers to help meet the labor shortages of its booming postwar economy. He also said that ''integration must be more strongly promoted through a conscious exchange between cultures and religions'' and that ''there are still hurdles to overcome.'' The 2.5 million Turks are Germany's largest minority group. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: In the Life of a Midwest City, Life Goes On
description: Joe Neill was channel-surfing late Monday night when he saw the replay of Attorney General John Ashcroft's announcement that the nation should be on high alert for the possibility of a new terrorist attack. Mr. Neill, who had heard the news earlier, flipped to an old horror movie. Flipping channels again, he watched Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's announcement that a hospital worker in New York City appeared to have inhalation anthrax.

title: Alert Said to Be Tied in Part to Monitoring of Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The Bush administration said today that its latest nationwide warning of possible terrorist attacks resulted from credible intelligence sources, some of them connected to Osama bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GHALIB, SAEEDA
description: GHALIB-Saeeda, on October 18, 2001, at age 45, leaves to mourn her passing six daughters, four sons, eight sisters, seven brothers, other relatives and friends. A devoted woman of faith, strength and exceptional courage.

title: For Inspiration, Bat Boy Turns to the Fat Boy Within
description: THE bats will fly tonight, in dark celebration of Halloween, but Deven May, the star of ''Bat Boy,'' the Off Broadway musical, will not. He will have done his flying earlier, out to California for two days for a screen test. An understudy will play his role tonight, hanging upside down in a cage for a good minute, singing his bat heart out as he yearns for normalcy and love, or at least the ability to get rid of his pointed bat teeth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWLING, MARY YOLANDA
description: DOWLING-Mary Yolanda, 46. Of Rosedale, NY, heroically and tragically on September 11, 2001, working for AON at the World Trade Center. Beloved daughter of Christy Dowling and the late Mary C. Dowling (nee Dolan). Cherished sister of Christopher, Andrew & Rosaleen Shea. Sisterin-law of Judy Dowling and Bob Shea. Adored aunt of Kristina, Devin, Christopher, Robert and Mary Kate. She will be missed by many relatives and friends in the United States and Tullamore, Ireland. Your glorious voice is now heard in Heaven's choir of angels. Remembrance wake to be held on Friday, November 2nd, 2-5PM and 7-9:30PM at O'Reilly Funeral Home, 137-40 Brookville Blvd, Rosedale, NY. Memorial Mass to be held on Saturday, November 3rd, 9:30 AM at St. Clare's RC Church, Rosedale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Yolanda's memory to St. Clare's RC Church, 137-35 Brookville Blvd, Rosedale, New York 11422.

title: Series Ratings Up
description: The first two games of the Yankees-Arizona World Series averaged a 12.7 national Nielsen television rating, up 6 percent from last year, when the Yankees played the Mets.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about the testing of drugs to counter potential bioterrorism gave a misspelled surname in some copies for a former commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration. She is Dr. Jane E. Henney, not Tenney.

title: Business Travel; Airlines are increasingly using a profiling database to select passengers for extra searches.
description: ''THE following names come to the podium,'' the woman at the Continental Airlines departure-gate counter said into her microphone. She read out three names, including ''Sharkey.''

title: Precautions Turn House That Ruth Built Into the Fortress That Bush Visited
description: Law enforcement officials prepared defense strategies in a room near the players' lockers. Secret Service agents led dogs through the stands to sniff for explosives. Police snipers stationed themselves on nearby roofs. Hot dog vendors were screened by federal agents.

title: Trail of Death and Illness on a Tainted Letter's Path
description: On Tuesday, Oct. 9, someone put a prepaid envelope, sealed with tape and containing anthrax, in a mailbox or slot in central New Jersey and it started a six-day journey to the office of Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader. On Monday, Oct. 15, an aide to Mr. Daschle opened it in the Hart Senate Office Building, releasing a puff of spores.

title: Fordham-Columbia On Thanksgiving
description: The Fordham-Columbia game that was postponed on Sept. 15 because of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has been rescheduled for Nov. 22.

title: Service Units Need Cash At Swissair
description: Another cash shortage is threatening to ground Swissair again -- this time because subsidiary companies that perform aircraft maintenance and handle computerized ticketing and reservations are nearly out of money themselves. But the Swiss government said today that it had done all it could for the airline with last week's $2.5 billion bailout package.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRINGER, JOHN
description: SPRINGER-John. We deeply mourn the loss of our very dear friend and fellow Player. His contributions to our club were monumental. His very presence made every visit an event. He is irreplaceable. Our love and prayers to June and their family. We'll never forget you, man! The Players

title: Stocks Close the Day Mixed
description: Desperate for an injection of good news, the stock market at first rallied today after the government reported that the nation's gross domestic product declined less in the third quarter than Wall Street had feared.

title: 4 Companies Chosen to Prep Teachers
description: The New York City Board of Education has selected four companies to provide preparation courses for the New York State teacher certification exams: Kaplan Learning Services; Princeton Review; the Center for Integrated Teacher Education; and the Center for Professional Performance Enhancement. The courses will be financed with a $3.5 million state grant. With a shortage of certified teachers, the board hopes to reduce the high failure rate on the exams. Allison Fass

title: Isaac Stern Recalled at His Carnegie Hall
description: ''Welcome to Isaac Stern's favorite room,'' Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Carnegie Hall, said yesterday afternoon in greeting the audience that filled the hall for the memorial concert to Mr. Stern, the beloved American violinist and longtime Carnegie Hall president, who died on Sept. 22 at 81. Mr. Stern used to say that he could feel the spirits of Tchaikovsky, Horowitz and other musical giants every time he entered the hall, Mr. Weill recalled. Now, he added, ''Isaac Stern's spirit has joined them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANNHEISSER, ELAINE (MRS. WERNER H.)
description: DANNHEISSER - Elaine (Mrs. Werner H.). The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art, along with the members of its International Council, join the art world in mourning the loss of Elaine Dannheisser. Elaine had served as a Trustee of the Museum since 1995, a member of its Committee on Painting and Sculpture since 1990, a member of its Committee on Photography since 1996, and a member of its International Council since 1991. However, these positions do not begin to convey the many ways in which she permanently influenced the Museum's collection, as well as the way in which we experience and study contemporary art. Just four years ago, we celebrated the opening of On the Edge: Contemporary Art from the Werner and Elaine Dannheisser Collection at the Museum. The works of art that entered the Museum's collection on this occasion were as crucial to the collection as the bequest that came to us from one of the Museum's founders, Lillie P. Bliss, whose gift was the basis of our permanent collection and included many works that continue to be most closely associated with the Museum. Our founding Director, Alfred Barr, believed that the Museum's collection should evolve ''as a torpedo moving through time,'' and Elaine's gift enabled it to do just that. Future generations will identify this Museum with works from the Dannheisser collection, such as those by Matthew Barney, Joseph Beuys, Felix Gonzalez-Torres, Robert Gober, Jeff Koons, Brice Marden, Bruce Nauman, Sigmar Polke, Robert Ryman, Richard Serra, and Cindy Sherman, just as current ones identify it with Water Lilies, The Starry Night, and Les Demoiselles d'Avignon. Beginning as a girl from Brooklyn whose mother brought her to the Museum to see Guernica, Elaine has now taken her place alongside such benefactors as Mrs. Simon Guggenheim, Harriet and Sidney Janis, Philip Johnson, William S. Paley, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Louise Reinhardt Smith, and Gordon Bunshaft. Elaine was a consummate collector (acquiring new work right up until the very end), but was also the most insightful benefactress. Over the years, Elaine formed a collection that was deeply personal and distinctly her own. When she decided to give it to the Modern, however, she was doubly generous: in addition to making a monumental gift, she allowed the Museum to accept the works that were needed to build a balanced collection. In some cases, she helped augment existing areas of the collection that were missing key pieces. In others, she gave us the collection's seminal works, such as the first major Barney. Thanks to Elaine, the Museum has the most important collection of Gonzalez-Torres anywhere, and arguably the most important collection of Nauman and Gober in any American museum. Elaine was ever a prescient collector who remained on the sharpest part of the cutting edge of the art world, understanding and appreciating works that were often difficult for those half her age to appreciate or even understand. It is impossible to think of Elaine without thinking of her husband Werner. She clearly had the eye that formed the collection, but she credited Werner with giving her the support (both moral and financial) to realize her vision. At the opening of the exhibition, Elaine described their partnership and her own transformation in these words: ''Werner is the one who created me. He took a young, curious girl and taught her to focus. He opened all the doors for me and made it all happen. In 1982, a young professor at Columbia heard I was collecting works from emerging artists at a furious pace. She called me up to ask if I would speak to her class. I said that I was not qualified, that I had nothing to say, but that I would be happy to answer her students' questions. We set up a date. The morning of our appointment, Werner and I were having breakfast, and he asked what I was doing that day. I said that I was giving a talk at Columbia. He said, ''This I have to see,'' and called up his secretary to cancel all of his appointments for the day. He came up to Columbia with me and sat in the audience with the students. They asked questions nonstop and I answered them all. Werner was so impressed with me that he raised my art allowance. And the rest is history.'' Elaine has passed from being simply a collector, patron, and friend into being a historical figure whose spirit and devotion will live on forever at The Museum of Modern Art. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY Sir Brian Urquhart, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

description: Trump Says He May Miss Bond Interest Payments

title: HOSPITAL WORKER'S ILLNESS SUGGESTS WIDENING THREAT; SECURITY TIGHTENS OVER U.S.
description: City and public health officials yesterday began giving antibiotics to hundreds of hospital employees and started tracking down thousands of patients and visitors as investigators searched for the mysterious source of the infection that has left a Manhattan hospital worker critically ill with inhalation anthrax.

title: Direct-Mail Marketers Tackle Issue Of Security
description: With the holiday season approaching, the mail order industry is scrambling not only to prepare for the busiest period of the year but also to reassure Americans suddenly leery of unsolicited mail.

title: A Trilogy Carefully Plotted
description: Random Dance Company

title: Walking a Wary Line
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  President Bush was in the Bronx, home of one of the latest victims of inhalation anthrax, watching the World Series. Vice President Dick Cheney was in a secure location to preserve the chain of succession in the face of the second nationwide terrorism alert in three weeks.

title: U.S. Campaign On 2nd Front: Public Opinion
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld is planning to leave this week for Russia and nations near Afghanistan as the Bush administration strives to hold together its coalition for the military campaign against Osama bin Laden and the Taliban government that protects him.

title: Britain Charges Man in Death Of a Top Afghan Rebel Leader
description: An Egyptian who was said to have given a letter of accreditation to two men who posed as television journalists to assassinate the Afghan rebel leader Ahmed Shah Massoud was charged today with conspiracy under Britain's antiterrorism law.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Post-Sept. 11 Shake-Up
description: Virginia Buckingham, who resigned last week as head of the Massachusetts Port Authority, will get $112,500 in severance pay. The authority's board also signed a two-year consulting contract with Ms. Buckingham for $62,500. She resigned after the governor assigned a commission to overhaul the agency following the terrorist attacks. Two of the planes hijacked on Sept. 11 took off from Boston. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Flood of Asylum Seekers Closes Channel Tunnel for Freight
description: The Channel Tunnel was closed to freight traffic for 11 hours today after dozens of asylum seekers broke into a freight yard near Calais and tried to hide on trains bound for Britain.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Stock Market Monitor Slain
description: An official who policed the legality of stock market transactions was found stabbed and shot to death in his apartment building elevator, the police said, the latest victim of mafia-connected clans that dominate Ukraine's business and financial sectors. Olexy Romashko, 38, served on the government stock-market regulatory commission. Three years ago, the head of Ukraine's stock market was found shot to death in his apartment-building elevator; that case has not been solved. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing the percentage of households that subscribe to cable and satellite television services referred incorrectly to the market area with the largest percentage of cable subscribers. That market includes Rochester, Minn., Mason City, Iowa, and Austin, Minn. It is not in Illinois.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: LexisNexis Acquiring Courtlink
description: The database company LexisNexis, a unit of Reed Elsevier, will announce today that it is buying CourtLink, a privately held company in Bellevue, Wash., that sells online services to law firms and corporations. CourtLink, which has 160 employees, developed a filing system that enables judges, lawyers and court clerks to process pleadings, motions and other documents electronically over a secure connection. The company now provides online access to more than 200 million court records from 1,400 courts in the United States. The companies would not disclose the terms of the deal that is still subject to approval by shareholders of LexisNexis, which is headquartered in Miamisburg, Ohio. Lisa Guernsey (NYT)

title: U.S. Accuses The Japanese Of Inflexibility On Trade Talks
description: Using unusually blunt language to pressure a leading ally, the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, said today that Japan's pursuit of its own ''narrow-minded interests'' threatened to obstruct efforts to forge agreement at a long-planned world trade summit meeting.

title: Sports of The Times; Visitors Are Imperfect In a Perfect Setting
description: THE circumstances were not the same as in all those other autumns in the Bronx. The alert men with the tiny wired speakers in their ears were not your boisterous midtown bankers and brokers, lucky tigers with tickets behind home plate. These platoons were there to back up the grand old American tradition of a chief executive who decided he'd just pop up to New York and take in a World Series game.

title: New Bcom3 Units In Multicultural Hue
description: The Bcom3 Group in Chicago said yesterday that it had formed two divisions specializing in multicultural advertising and media services. They will handle assignments with billings estimated at $330 million for marketers like Coca-Cola, General Motors and Procter & Gamble.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Electronics Losses
description: Hitachi and Matsushita Electric Industrial, two of Japan's largest electronics makers, had losses in the half year ended Sept. 30, as prices for semiconductors and flat-panel screens plunged and spending on everything from computers to cellphones declined. Hitachi lost 110.5 billion yen ($906 million) and now expects a full-year loss of 230 billion yen ($1.9 billion); it said it was considering deeper cuts in its payroll. Matsushita's sales slumped 9.4 percent; it had a 69.5 billion yen ($570 million) half-year loss. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Batista Proves His Value, in Limbo
description: Miguel Batista was listed among the Arizona Diamondbacks' relievers for Game 3 of the World Series last night, although he was also tentatively scheduled to start Game 4 tonight.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: South Bows To North On Talks
description: South Korea yielded to North Korea's demand to hold the next round of cabinet-level talks at a resort in North Korea, saying continuity in the peace effort was more important than the question of the site of the talks. The North had ruled out sending negotiators to Seoul, saying South Korea could not guarantee their safety after putting its troops on alert when the United States began airstrikes in Afghanistan. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Op-Art
A Visitor From London Blends India and the West
description: Akram Khan

title: A Vulnerable Food Supply, a Call for More Safety
description: LAST week Tommy G. Thompson , the secretary of health and human services, told Congress that he was more fearful about the safety of the American food supply than anything else.

title: U.S. Seeks Anthrax Vaccine for Almost a Million People
description: The government wants access to a stock of anthrax vaccine large enough to protect almost a million people, Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said yesterday.

title: Miller Emerges Behind Plate for the Diamondbacks
description: They are united in purple, teal and black, these Arizona Diamondbacks, but almost all of them made their mark somewhere else. Randy Johnson was a Mariner, Curt Schilling a Phillie, Mark Grace a Cub and so on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALASZ, LASZLO
description: HALASZ-Laszlo. New York City Opera mourns the pasing of Laszlo Halasz, the first artistic and musical director of our company. The enthusiastic vision, shared by Mr. Halasz and Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia, of a company with young singers and performances at affordable prices has continued unabated for almost sixty years. He established a formidable roster of singers and conductors and began an eclectic repertory of operas that has withstood the test of time. A champion of minority singers, he presented both Todd Duncan and Robert McFerrin in their New York debuts, creating the opportunity for them to have major careers. He conducted a production of Tosca as the inaugural performance of City Opera on February 21, 1944, and also led the American premiere of Ariadne auf Naxos, the New York premiere of The Love for Three Oranges and the world premiere of Troubled Island, among many others. City Opera, & the entire music world, is indebted to him for his tenacity, enthusiasm & devotion to our company. He will be missed. Paul Kellogg General Director

title: In a Small Brooklyn Store, A Trove of 100 Cheeses
description: Tuller Premium Food, 199 Court Street (Bergen Street), in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, is a tiny shop, so it chooses its cheeses carefully -- and there are gems among the 100 on display. They include Borough Market Stilton ($11.99 a pound); Cheddar and Cheshire from England ($11.99 a pound); Pleasant Ridge Reserve, a Gruyre-style Wisconsin cheese ($16.99 a pound); and the Old Chatham Sheepherding Company's creamy new blue cheese, Ewe's Blue ($18.99 a pound). The store, owned by Robert Tuller, below, also sells Magnolia Bakery's ice creams ($3.99 a pint), rustic pastas from Italy and prepared foods, including excellent marinated roasted beets, parsnip pure and potatoes roasted in chicken drippings, all $5.99 a pound.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Reports A Loss
description: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, said yesterday that earnings fell 46 percent in the third quarter, to $1.86 billion, or 69 cents a share, from $3.47 billion, or $1.27, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Verizon, which was formed last year by Bell Atlantic's acquisition of the GTE Corporation, said sales in the quarter had climbed 2.8 percent, to $17 billion. The company's financial performance was hurt by the Sept. 11 attacks, which destroyed switching equipment in Lower Manhattan, and by weaker demand for telephone services. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEKER, SONIA
description: BEKER-Sonia. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of the cherished mother of YU philanthropist Harvey Beker. Together with his wife Jayne, YU Trustee and founding member and current chair of the Board of Governors of Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology, he has always been devoted to Jewish education and communal causes. The Bekers are YU Benefactors who recently established an innovative program at Ferkauf to upgrade psychological services at Jewish day schools and high schools. We extend heartfelt condolences to Harvey and Jayne Beker, William Beker, Carol and Rodney Grundman, and their families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: U.N. Official Urges Restraint in Bombings to Avoid Casualties
description: The head of the United Nations refugee agency called today for ''self-restraint'' by the United States and Britain to prevent civilian casualties in the bombing of Afghanistan.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Perot Systems Reports A Loss
description: The Perot Systems Corporation, the computer-services company founded by the billionaire H. Ross Perot, had a third-quarter loss of $18.1 million, or 18 cents a share, compared with net income of $12.1 million, or 11 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 11 percent, to $307 million from $276.1 million.

title: In France, the Prune Holds a Noble Station
description: AS we drove west along the broad Lot River in southwest France, the vineyards of Cahors and massive castles of Aquitaine slowly gave way to flatter farmland planted with fruit trees. We recognized apples and pears. But there were others, set in stately rows and bedded in straw, their fine leaves starting to glint gold in the still warm sun of early fall.

title: A Jailhouse Pregnancy
description: Gloria Trevi, the Mexican pop star, has managed to get pregnant while being held in isolation in a Brazilian jail cell.

title: For Truth, Not Spin, on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Justices Weigh Law Barring Virtual Child Pornography
description: The Supreme Court today heard the government's defense of a recent federal law that treated ''virtual'' child pornography -- computer-generated images of children or productions using young-looking performers who were really adults -- as if it were the real thing.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Environmental Impact Of Sept. 11
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on the environmental impact of the terrorist attack on Lower Manhattan and the subsequent cleanup of the area. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7700.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Oct. 7 showing St. Paul's Cathedral in London during German bombing in 1940, with an article about New York's prospects for rebuilding after Sept. 11, was reproduced in mirror image during transmission by The Associated Press. The clock on the south tower is at the right, not the left.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Freehold: Optometrist Found Guilty
description: An optometrist has been convicted of defrauding 29 insurance companies out of $200,000. A jury on Monday found that the optometrist, John Amabile, 39, of Spring Lake Heights, billed companies for some 600 procedures he never performed, said Paul Loriquet, a spokesman for the sate attorney general's office. Mr. Amabile faces up to 10 years in prison and $190,000 in fines, and is to be sentenced on Dec. 14. Mr. Amabile's lawyer, Michael Wilbert, was unavailable for comment, his office said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Scarsdale Warned Not to Boycott State Tests
description: It was the ultimate in playing hooky. Encouraged by their parents and local school officials, most students in Scarsdale, N.Y., where schools enjoy a reputation as golden as the price of the surrounding homes, boycotted the state's tough new eighth-grade tests last spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONAHAN, JOHN JOSEPH JR.
description: MONAHAN-John Joseph Jr., 71. Of Hamilton, New Jersey passed away October 26 at home. Born in Brooklyn, New York he resided in New Jersey for most of his life. He retired from the New York Times as a member of the pressmen's union. He was a veteran of the Korean War, serving in the U.S. Marine Corp and the U.S. Army. Joe was a member of the Ewing Elks, Disabled American Veterans, and Ancient Order of Hibernians in Hamilton. Joe was the son of the late Joseph and Margaret Monahan & the brotherin-law of the late William Punch, he is survived by one sister, Kathleen Punch of Brooklyn, New York; two sons, Rory Monahan of Hamilton and Jon and his wife, Jodi Monahan & their daughters, Megan of Ewing; one nephew, William Punch Jr. and his sons, William and Daniel of Brooklyn, New York; one niece, Margaret Punch of Brooklyn, NY; one daughter, Joellynn Monahan of New York. A Funeral service will be on Friday at 9:30 A.M. from the Saul Colonial Home, 3795 Nottingham Way, Hamilton Square, New Jersey. Interment will follow at the Brigadier General William C. Doyle Veterans Cemetery, Wrightstown, New Jersey. Visitation will be Thursday evening from 6:00 P.M. to 9:00 P.M. at the Colonial Home. Contributions in Joe's memory may be made to the Ancient Order of the Hibernians, 2419 Kuser Road, Hamilton Township, New Jersey 08610.

title: COMDISCO AGREES TO SELL UNIT TO HEWLETT-PACKARD
description: Comdisco Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in July, agreed to sell its computer disaster-recovery business to the Hewlett-Packard Company for $750 million. An $825 million bid from SunGard Data Systems Inc. stalled last week after antitrust officials sued to block it. Hewlett-Packard, a leading computer maker, agreed in July to buy the unit for $610 million and then raised its bid last week in response to the higher bid from SunGard.

title: German Art Arrives In Its Bijou Museum; Lauder's Pet Project Nears Completion
description: As workers scrambled one recent morning to put finishing touches on the Neue Galerie before its official opening on Nov. 16, Ronald S. Lauder arrived at the Louis XIII-style mansion, on 86th Street and Fifth Avenue, and headed straight to the director's office on the top floor. There, in a sunny space filled with furniture and objects by early 20th-century architects and designers like Otto Wagner and Josef Hoffmann, he zeroed in on a large wooden crate leaning against a wall.

title: Princeton Applications
description: With findings of anthrax in the New Jersey postal system, Princeton University suspended campus mail delivery for a few days this week. But the university is telling early decision applicants, whose applications are due this week, not to worry. "We are being appropriately sensitive and flexible with respect to our deadlines," FRED A. HARGADON, dean of admission, said on the office Web site. Princeton is asking early decision applicants who have mailed applications in the last 10 days to fax Part 1 to (609) 258-6743. If the university does not have the rest of an application within a reasonable time, it will notify the applicant.

title: The Celebrities Turn Out For Comeback by Jordan
description: The chance to watch Michael Jordan brought a contingent of celebrities to Madison Square Garden that was large even by the see-and-be-seen standards of the Garden.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Imation Cleared To Sell Tape Drives
description: A California court said yesterday that the Imation Corporation could continue selling tape-drive cartridges based on the Quantum Corporation's technology, but ordered Imation to pay Quantum a 30 percent royalty on each cartridge. Imation, which has filed an unrelated antitrust lawsuit against Quantum, has been selling cartridges for DLT tape drives without authorization from Quantum since Oct. 1. In granting the preliminary injunction, Judge William J. Elfving of Santa Clara County said a preponderance of evidence shows that Imation had misappropriated Quantum's trade secrets, but he did not order Imation to stop selling the cartridges. Imation said it would continue to sell the cartridges, and a spokesman said the court's order for a 30 percent royalty payment exposed the unusually high royalties sought by Quantum. John Gannon, president of Quantum's DLT Tape Group, denied the antitrust claims and said Imation's products failed to meet Quantum standards. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Shipped Tonight, Thawed Tomorrow And Steamed for Supper
description: To buy a Claw Island lobster is to break the rules -- the ones about buying only live lobsters or those that are freshly cooked. These lobsters are cooked as soon as they are trapped off Vinalhaven Island, Me., flash frozen and then shipped in dry ice. They can be kept in a home freezer. That way, you can be guaranteed lobsters on demand. Thaw them (36 hours in the refrigerator or 45 minutes in warm water), steam them for a few minutes, and then serve. The lobsters are delicious, with excellent flavor and succulent texture, perhaps because they spend no time in tanks, in conditions where they are not fed and often lose weight.

title: In a Changed World, The Comeback Pales
description: He pirouetted along the right baseline in the first half, releasing a pretty fallaway over Shandon Anderson. The move, the basket, even the way his right foot kicked forward slightly, came from another time -- when Michael Jordan and the Bulls were indomitable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, ROBERT NATHAN
description: NEUMAN-Robert Nathan. 82, October 28, 2001. Proud proprietor of the Rosedale Fish Market since 1937, he devoted his life to the pursuit of excellence in his trade. In loving memory of his father Billy he ruled his store with humor, wisdom, dignity and single-minded purpose; Charming, challenging and nourishing both the body and the spirits of those he touched. A lifelong New Yorker and member of the City Athletic Club, he served with the 3rd Marines in the Pacific during W.W. II, returning in 1945 to resume building his beloved business. Mentor to many, friend to the downtrodden, a student of the lives of Robert Scott and Sacco and Vanzetti, he leaves the world a better and more compassionate place. He is survived by his wife of 51 years Doris, sons Alan and Paul, four grandchildren and his devoted staff. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Tuesday, October 30, 5-8 PM with service Wednesday 11:30 AM. In lieu of donations please perform a random act of kindness for someone in need.

title: Anthrax Prods a Rewriting Of Medical Dogma, Quickly
description: Inhalation anthrax used to be seen as virtually a death sentence. Now, doctors are not so sure. With 10 confirmed cases in recent weeks, the death toll stands at three, with a fourth patient very seriously ill.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLIDES. The dollar fell after the Conference Board said its consumer confidence index dropped to its lowest level in more than seven years. In New York, the euro settled at 90.50 cents, up from 90.32 cents on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLANE, SR. MARY, RSM (FORMERLY SR. MARY EUGENE)
description: DILLANE-Sr. Mary, RSM (formerly Sr. Mary Eugene) on October 26, 2001 in Florida. Principal at Our Lady of Victory, Dobbs Ferry for 20 years. Survived by her brother John and her sister-in-law Jane. Prayer service on Friday 7:30PM Marian Woods Convent, 152 Ridge Road, Hartsdale, NY. Mass of Resurrection Saturday 11am Sacred Heart Church, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to Sisters of Mercy Service Fund, 150 Ridge Road, Hartsdale, NY 10530.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the appointment of James Levine as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra referred imprecisely to the 1989 production of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle under his direction at the Metropolitan Opera. It was not the Met's first ''Ring'' in half a century but its first in that period performed within a single week. The article also misstated the year Mr. Levine was named musician of the year by the magazine Musical America. It was 1984, not 1994.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Suing BB-Gun Maker
description: The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission voted 2 to 1 to sue the Daisy Manufacturing Company to force the recall of 7.5 million BB guns. Two high-velocity models allow BB's to lodge inside the magazine, giving a false impression that a loaded gun is empty, said Ann Brown, the commission chairwoman. Daisy models 880 and 856 have been responsible for 15 deaths and 171 injuries since 1972, Ms. Brown said. Daisy has denied that the guns are defective. Julian E. Barnes (NYT)

title: Everyday People, Extraordinary Day
description: There were heros who had jobs to do that day and did them, whatever the cost. And there were other, unsung heros who did not have the jobs they knew had to be done and did them anyway.

title: Tomato Power In a Powder
description: There is something new for the spice rack: scarlet, sand-textured powder from sun-dried tomatoes. Sprinkle it on a sandwich or on pasta or risotto, or add it on fish for a touch of intense tomato flavor. The powder is $10 for a 2.6-ounce jar, but a little goes a long way. It is available at Oliviers & Company stores in Grand Central Terminal, at 249 Bleecker Street (Seventh Avenue South) and at 198 Columbus Avenue (69th Street).

title: Linking Poor Performance To Working After School
description: AMERICAN student proficiency seems to decline sharply in adolescence. On international tests, pupils here perform relatively well in elementary school, but then fall behind in middle school and even more starkly in high school.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the departure of James E. Goodwin as chief executive of UAL, the parent of United Airlines, misstated the year he became chief executive. And a correction in this space yesterday misstated the year he joined the company. Mr. Goodwin became chief executive in 1999, not 1991; he joined the company in 1967, not 1999.

description: KORN-Jack. June 18, 1910-October 31, 1994. Forever remembered and loved by his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DETERMANN, PATRICIA MARIE (NEE FAHEY)
description: DETERMANN - Patricia Marie (nee Fahey). After a quiet, courageous battle with cancer. Native of L.I., NY. Beloved mother of 11 heartbroken children, 25 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Leaves behind a husband of 52 years, Herman Determann.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, LT. PAUL T. F.D.N.Y.
description: MITCHELL-Lt. Paul T. F.D.N.Y. Of Annadale, Staten Island, on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Maureen (nee Brown). Devoted father of Jennifer and Christine. Loving son of Rosemary Mitchell. Dear brother of Marie Mitchell and Susan McCormick. Memorial gathering of family and friends at the Casey McCallumRice South Shore Funeral Home, 30 Nelson Ave, Great Kills, Staten Island, Thursday, November 1st, 24 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be celebrated at Our Lady Star of the Sea Church, Friday, November 2 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the New York Firefighters' Burn Center, C/O Engine 66, Ladder 61, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, N.Y. 10475, would be appreciated.

title: Heavy Bombing Outside Kabul as U.S. Slams Range of Targets
description: United States warplanes pounded a wide range of targets today, from the strategic northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif to Taliban front lines north of Kabul, the capital, witnesses said.

title: Unemployment in Japan Hits Postwar High of 5.3%
description: Unemployment in Japan surged to 5.3 percent in September, the highest level since the aftermath of World War II, while household spending sank, deepening the woes of the world's second-largest economy.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Human Rights Review
description: Foreign Minister Stan Mudenge told the state media that the government had agreed to European Union demands for a meeting to review the country's human rights record but would resist efforts by the union to impose election monitors on the country. Elections are scheduled for next year, and the country's longtime president, Robert Mugabe, is running for re-election. Many diplomats, religious leaders and opposition figures say that after months of political turmoil and intimidation around the country extensive election monitoring is essential. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Life in a Time of Terror
description: Americans are wondering how to respond to Attorney General John Ashcroft's warning that terrorists are planning new attacks against the United States in the near future. Mr. Ashcroft says he simply wants to give citizens ''a basis for continuing to live their lives the way they would otherwise live them'' but with heightened vigilance. It's hard to imagine how that would work out in practice. In the past, Mr. Ashcroft has suggested that people take note if they see a stranger photographing nuclear facilities. But that sort of encounter isn't exactly common. When people hear general warnings like this, their response is probably less along the lines of civil defense than of assessing the odds of danger in their daily behavior. Should they put off air travel for a week? Stockpile Cipro? Keep their children home from the school field trip?

title: Third-Quarter Profit Drops 17% at Kellogg
description: The Kellogg Company, the maker of Rice Krispies cereal, said today that third-quarter profit fell 17 percent after the company delayed some products and cut back on less-profitable items to concentrate on integrating the Keebler Foods Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Egypt's Westernized elite misstated the relationship of Taher Samir Helmy, a prominent Cairo lawyer, to President Hosni Mubarak. Although Mr. Helmy served on a presidential council, he was not an official adviser to Mr. Mubarak.

description: Lyudmila Petrova is 33 and from Novo Cheboksary in Russia. Svetlana Zakharova is 31 and from Cheboksary, a half-hour drive from Petrova's hometown.

description: Armed with a favorable ruling from the Supreme Court, the Bush administration has begun its first major crackdown on the distribution of marijuana for medical purposes, Justice Department officials say.

description: The fear of anthrax first flared here on Monday, Oct. 15. That morning, when an aide opened a letter to Senator Tom Daschle in the senator's office in the Hart Building near the Capitol, an odd powdery substance was visible.

title: For a Night, Diamondbacks Forget What Got Them to Series
description: For one lonely moment, Damian Miller did not look at Bob Brenly as his manager. During a pitching change in the middle innings of Game 3 of the World Series last night, Brenly was simply a former catcher who could relate to Miller's woes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSS, JOSEPH G.
description: CROSS-Joseph G., 88. Of Hobe Sound, FL passed away Saturday, October 27, 2001 at Martin Memorial Hospital South, Stuart, FL. Born in Brooklyn, New York he had been a resident of Hobe Sound for the past 22 years. He moved to the area from Long Island, Woodbury, New York. Prior to retirement he was Vice President of Merrill Lynch on Wall Street for 25 years. He was pre-deceased by his daughter, Maureen Cross Wendt. Survivors include his wife of 59 years, Mildred Cross of Hobe Sound, FL; his grandson, Eric Wendt; two nieces and three nephews. Friends may call from 3:005:00 PM, Thursday, November 1st at the chapel of Young & Prill Funeral Home, Stuart. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 1:00 PM, Friday, November 2nd at St. Christopher Catholic Church in Hobe Sound, FL, with Father Michael Tschudi officiating. Committal Services will follow at the Riverside Memorial Park in Tequesta, FL. In lieu of flowers, those who wish are asked to consider contributions to Charity of Choice. For information Young & Prill Funeral Home, Stuart, FL.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Ex-President Off One Hook
description: A court effectively dismissed a perjury charge against former President Joseph Estrada, barring crucial prosecution evidence from the case. The former president, who is in custody, still faces several corruption charges including plunder, which carries the death penalty. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Where Donald Trump sees trouble in Atlantic City, bondholders see an effort to cut a deal.
description: WITH the outlook gloomy for his Atlantic City casinos, Donald Trump said yesterday that he might not make about $90 million in interest payments due next month on his bonds.

title: MGM Mirage Reports a Loss
description: MGM Mirage, owner of the Bellagio and Golden Nugget casinos in Las Vegas, said today that it had a third-quarter loss because fewer people visited Las Vegas and its casinos after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: General Gives Uzbek Leader Warm Words And Spotlight
description: Nearing the end of a visit to allies in the war against the Taliban, the United States Army general who is commanding the military campaign met today with the president of Uzbekistan to cement the expanding cooperation between the two nations.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From vegetarians restaurants in New York to riverboat cruises in Mississippi, readers share their insights and answer other readers' questions.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Observatory column of Science Times yesterday about a climate-change study that used data from an annual contest to predict the time a frozen river in Alaska will break up misstated the finding. On average, the researchers found, the river breaks up five and a half days earlier than it did 80 years ago, not five and a half days later.
