description: EUROPE

title: Condition of Injured French Skier Worsens
description: The condition of Rgine Cavagnoud, the French champion skier who was gravely injured in a training accident, deteriorated today, and physicians were increasingly pessimistic about her chances of recovery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Teacher Sentenced In Sex Case
description: A former high school teacher who was found guilty of having sexual relations with three students was sentenced yesterday to 4 to 12 years in state prison. A jury convicted the former special-education teacher, Marci Stein, of 10 criminal charges, including statutory rape, on Aug. 4. She was forced to resign from Hendrick Hudson High School in Montrose in March 2000 over allegations that she had had sex with students at her home. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Will Serbs Take a Chance on Kosovo?
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo -- More than two years after air strikes by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ended the harrowing of Kosovo by Slobodan Milosevic, Kosovo's Serbs remain beset by anxieties. Perhaps half of all Kosovo's Serbs have left for fear of retribution. Hundreds remain missing and unaccounted for. Half of the Serbs still in Kosovo live in small, fortified enclaves where they feel safe only thanks to the presence of NATO troops. Many Serbs cite these conditions, and the fear of Kosovar independence, as reasons for not voting, on Nov. 17, in the first free general elections Kosovo has ever had. But they are seeing the world upside down. These elections are the great opportunity for them, as they are for us, Kosovo's Albanians.

title: Economists Split on the Effect of Terror Attacks on Downturn
description: Among economists, there is no doubt that the terrorist attacks on America disrupted consumers and businesses alike and pushed the economy into a recession, the first in 10 years. But gauging how bad that recession will be is much more difficult.

title: Officials Fail to Guarantee Mail Is Not Contaminated
description: Traces of anthrax were discovered in two more Washington post offices today, and Bush administration officials acknowledged that they could not guarantee that the mails were free of contamination.

title: All Hallows Eve, 2001
description: Halloween looks a little broken this year. The decorations are in place -- synthetic spider webs, orange lights dripping from the eaves, double-jointed paper skeletons with rivets at the hips, knees and elbows. Children walking from house to house, clutching bags of candy, will make a satisfying rustle in the dry leaves. But if there's any fright left in this poor, creedless holiday, it will be only a nutritional fright. The guile is gone. The real world is too full of real tricks.

title: Paul C. Warnke, Johnson Pentagon Official Who Questioned Vietnam War, Dies
description: Paul C. Warnke, the highest ranking Pentagon official in the Johnson Administration to openly question the aims and conduct of the war in Vietnam, died today at his home in Washington. He was 81.

title: A Diving Spencer Saves One For Yanks
description: Shane Spencer called Matt Williams's blistering liner to left field a bullet. A bullet that he knew he had to chase. A bullet that he did not think he could catch. A bullet straight at him. The toughest play for an outfielder is the ball lined right at him.

title: Reckonings; The One-Eyed Man
description: Somewhere I read that to really understand legislation you have to look for the clause giving special consideration to one-eyed bearded men with a limp -- that is, you have to look for the provision that turns a bill ostensibly serving a public purpose into a giveaway for some special interest.

title: On Guard at the Pentagon
Experiment Is a Success As the Gomez Line Excels
description: The experiment involving Scott Gomez paid dividends tonight for the Devils, who defeated the Bruins in overtime, 4-3.

title: A Portfolio for Giuliani
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. To Buy CrossWorlds
description: I.B.M. announced yesterday that it would buy CrossWorlds Software Inc., for $129 million, in a move intended to strengthen its Internet software business. CrossWorlds, based in Burlingame, Calif., makes software that automates the tracking of supply, shipping and customer data in the computer networks of companies. Its software is tailored for specific industries like telecommunications and banking. CrossWorlds will become part of I.B.M.'s Websphere unit, which sells Internet commerce software and whose sales rose 75 percent in the third quarter. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Letting a Pop Idiom Speak for Itself
description: 'The Look of Love'

title: Hard-Edged Insurance Chief Is Taking On a New and Public Face
description: Before Sept. 11, insurers thought the risk of a passenger jet causing major damage in a crash into buildings and people on the ground was so remote that they did not even bother to charge extra for the coverage.

title: Boldly, Off With Its Head
description: THE latest thing from New Zealand? Screw caps for fine wine. In spite of formidable odds, 27 New Zealand wineries, tired of apologizing for bad natural corks and unimpressed with the plastic variety, have decided to bottle most of their wines in bottles with screw-top caps. They call their group the New Zealand Screwcap Wine Seal Initiative, and they are reintroducing an old solution to a problem for wine consumers and the wine industry.

title: For Truth, Not Spin, on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Nerves Are Steady So Far, and Employers Can Take Some Credit
description: American workers are showing that they are not easily intimidated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHALAN, FLORENCE D., REV. MSGR.
description: COHALAN-Florence D., Rev. Msgr. 93, of New York City. Ordained to the priesthood June 11, 1938. Msgr. Cohalan served the Archdiocese of New York at the Church of St. Peter, Staten Island, NY, as Professor of History at Cathedral College in NYC and as Pastor of the Church of St. Paul, Staten Island, NY. In retirement he served the Church of the Annunciation at Crestwood, NY and the Church of St. Agnes, NY, NY. Survivors include three nieces: Maureen Cohalan Curry, Derval Brown, Tyrell Connor; one nephew, Daniel F. Cohalan; many grand nieces and nephews and great grand nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street on Wednesday & Thursday 2-5, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Friday 10:30 AM at the Cathedral of St. Patrick, 5th Ave. & 51st Street. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: A Military Quagmire Remembered: Afghanistan as Vietnam
description: Like an unwelcome specter from an unhappy past, the ominous word ''quagmire'' has begun to haunt conversations among government officials and students of foreign policy, both here and abroad.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: A Rare Nod To Pakistan
description: Defense Minister George Fernandes is not known for kind comments about Pakistan, India's nuclear-armed neighbor, but he said at a seminar on terrorism that he believed that Pakistan's nuclear arsenal was safe and that those in charge of its nuclear program were responsible. ''Politics apart, I must give them credit that they are responsible people and will not allow people to walk away with nuclear weapons,'' he said. Some American officials fear that Pakistan's nuclear materials could wind up in terrorists' hands. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: States Assign More Troops After U.S. Terror Warning
description: State officials in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey have deployed more National Guard troops at transportation centers, water supplies and nuclear power plants after the federal government's warning of possible additional terrorist attacks.

title: Tracing the Deadly Path of Anthrax
World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Drought Plan Needed
description: Kenya is in the midst of a major drought, the second in two years, but has yet to draft a policy to address the problem, according to Kenyan and international experts. The World Food Program, a United Nations agency, estimates that more than four million Kenyans need emergency aid as a result of a drought. Last year, a drought led to power and water rationing. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Honda Profit Rose Sharply in Last Quarter
description: Profits were up sharply at Honda Motor in the quarter ended Sept. 30 because of strong sales, cost reductions and a favorable trend in exchange rates, the company said today.

title: Soros Fund Hires Ex-Dresdner Executive
description: Soros Fund Management, the $11.5 billion hedge fund group of George Soros, hired William Stack to be its chief executive yesterday, according to a letter sent to shareholders.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: An Italian Master in a New Groove
description: WHEN Pino Luongo burst on the New York scene nearly 20 years ago with Il Cantinori, he looked like a culinary Pavarotti in the making. His restaurants, by combining high quality with flashy presentation, put sizzle back in the steak Florentine. Italian food seemed exciting again. Il Cantinori begat Le Madri, which begat assorted Coco Pazzos, and before long, Mr. Luongo was running neck and neck with Mario Perillo for the title of Mr. Italy.

title: Brenly Casts His Lot With Schilling
description: Proclaiming Curt Schilling as ''the right guy to pitch,'' Bob Brenly wasted no time last night making the decision that could turn out to be the pivotal move of the World Series. If it turns out right for the Arizona Diamondbacks, Brenly will be saluted as a genius; if it turns out badly, he will be painted as a rookie manager who panicked in the World Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, CLIVE (IAN)
description: THOMPSON-Clive (Ian), 43. Of Summit, formerly of Surrey, UK. Lost September 11, 2001 in terrorist attack on World Trade Center. Adored husband and best friend of Lucy, loving father of Ella and Rachel and dear brother of Keith. Much loved uncle, brother-in-law, godfather, colleague, EMT and friend to many. Service in Summit on Friday, November 2 at 5PM. Inquiries to lucian@worldnet.att.net

title: O'Neill Leaves His Seat and Returns to Lineup
description: Paul O'Neill reluctantly agreed to be one of the Yankees allowing members of the news media to interview him at Bank One Ballpark a day before the World Series opener against the Arizona Diamondbacks. O'Neill, who often treats questions about himself the way a 7-year-old treats a flu shot, did not really want to be in the spacious room. He did it because he had committed.

title: Bloomberg Sought More Proof of Rape Allegation
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican nominee for mayor, suggested in 1998 that an independent witness would need to be present for him to believe an allegation of rape by an employee, according to excerpts from a sworn deposition that appear in today's Village Voice.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of 4 p.m. yesterday, 4,777 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Excruciating Lessons In the Ways of a Disease
description: The diagnosis of inhalation anthrax in a New York hospital worker throws into question many of the assumptions about an outbreak for which the scientific and medical wisdom was already being revised daily, sometimes hourly.

title: Brenly Shuffles Lineup
description: With the designated hitter rule in effect at Yankee Stadium, Diamondbacks Manager Bob Brenly thought making a lineup would be as easy as sliding a big bat into his established order. But Brenly said he and his staff considered a couple of dozen ideas but ''basically came down to two different lineups.''

title: Just how safe is that catalog in your mailbox? The direct mail industry is working on assurances.
description: AS the crucial holiday shopping season approaches, executives of companies that sell billions of dollars of merchandise a year through direct mail and catalogs are disclosing myriad steps being taken to increase security and safety for customers made anxious by anthrax.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLE, CHARLES J.
description: COLE-Charles J. April 5, 1923October 30, 1992. Dad, always in our thoughts and hearts with a lot of love. We miss you. The Gang

title: High Hair, High Camp and Four-Part High Anxiety
description: The Kinsey Sicks must want a diverse audience. One minute Rachel, Trixie, Winnie and Trampolina seem overjoyed by their own naughtiness (lines like, ''We put the ho in hosiery,'' and bawdier wordplay). The next they're getting political, with a parody of ''Chapel of Love'' lamenting the laws against gay marriages. And there's so much Jewish humor in the group's new show that one song is performed entirely in Yiddish.

title: Laszlo Halasz, First Director Of City Opera, Is Dead at 96
description: Laszlo Halasz, the first music director of the New York City Opera, died on Friday at his home in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 96.

title: Alert Said to Be Tied in Part To Monitoring of Al Qaeda
description: The Bush administration said today that its latest nationwide warning of possible terrorist attacks resulted from credible intelligence sources, some of them connected to Osama bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's partly a matter of getting information out that they think is important. But it's also that they don't want to be caught holding the bag if something bad happens.''

title: Hospital Worker's Illness Suggests Widening Threat
description: City and public health officials yesterday began giving antibiotics to hundreds of hospital employees and started tracking down thousands of patients and visitors as investigators searched for the mysterious source of the infection that has left a Manhattan hospital worker critically ill with inhalation anthrax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, GERTRUDE
description: BLOOM-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Loving mother of Daniel and the late Roberta. Cherished grandmother of Jacqueline and Ferna. Adored great grandmother of Benjamin. Dear friend of Ora. Service on Wednesday 12 noon at Riverside, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Hunt For Child Molester
description: A convicted child molester whose lawsuit helped shorten the sentences of hundreds of sex offenders is now wanted on charges of molesting a 14-year-old he met at church. The man, Vance Martin, 35, was convicted in 1993 of molesting a 10-year-old girl in Denver. He violated probation and was resentenced in 1997, but appealed. The State Supreme Court's ruling in July led to changes in parole and jail time for more than 1,500 sex offenders in Colorado. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Series Audio: Game 3
description: Postgame audio from Game 3 of the World Series between the Yankees and the Arizona Diamondbacks provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Private Flights Are Halted Near Nuclear Installations
description: The government today temporarily banned private airplanes from flying within 11.5 miles of 86 nuclear power reactors and government nuclear sites ''for reasons of national security.''

title: Smart Shopping by the Pentagon
description: The Pentagon's decision to buy a new generation of stealthy fighters from Lockheed Martin can be a good deal for the military and taxpayers alike, even though total costs could run to $200 billion over the next few decades. Economies of scale and design are concepts not usually associated with mammoth Pentagon purchases. The joint strike fighter program, intended to produce more than 3,000 planes at the relatively modest price of $38 million each, may turn out to be a happy exception.

title: Mourning 4 Students Lost on a Curve at 70 M.P.H.
description: It is hard for any high school to open its doors the day after a student's death. But for Herricks High School, the death of four students in a car accident on Monday was almost too much to bear.

title: CARGILL SAYS IT WILL BUY CONTROL OF CERESTAR
description: Cargill Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy control of Cerestar from Montedison in a plan that values Cerestar at 1.25 billion euros ($1.13 billion). Cargill will pay 33 euros a share for Montedison's 56 percent stake, 59 percent more than Cerestar's share price before the Sept. 26 announcement of talks between the two. Cargill will assume 400 million euros' worth of Cerestar debt and must bid for the rest of the company to comply with French law. Cerestar, based in Paris, makes starches and sweeteners and has about 27 percent share of the European market for starches, analysts said. Cargill currently supplies about 7 percent of the starch market there. Montedison is selling Cerestar to focus on energy and repay debts.

title: Hunting a Deadly Germ by Scrutinizing a Life
description: As a petite and private woman from the Bronx lies in critical condition at a Manhattan hospital, everything about her life -- from the mail she received at home to the desk that she used at work -- is being urgently scrutinized in a broad investigation into the way she contracted the city's first case of inhalation anthrax.

title: Indian Chief Miffs Canada, Not Sparing Indians
description: One year into his term as Canada's paramount Indian chief, Matthew Coon Come is catching trouble everywhere.

title: Liberties; These Spooky Times
description: Last week, Georgetown University held a job fair. At the booths of the big Wall Street companies and banks, students had little wait. But to talk to a C.I.A. recruiter, the line stretched for over half an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HYMAN
description: COHEN-Hyman. Beloved husband of the late Sadie. Devoted father of Jacqueline and Frank Brascia and Barbara and Edward Held. Loving brother of Molly Mintz. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Wendy, Alyssa, Marc, Jennifer. Great grandfather of Leahsarah, Nachama, Dori, Richard and Zachary. Services today 11:30AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Peres Says He May See Arafat, Drawing Criticism From Right
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said today that he would probably meet this week with Yasir Arafat, and that he had drafted a new peace plan for the Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSENSTEIN, HERBERT F.
description: WEISSENSTEIN-Herbert F. The Center for Arts Education mourns the passing of Herbert Weissenstein. Through his counsel and belief in our mission, Herb transformed the Center from an ambitious concept to an organization that has helped restore arts education to thousands of New York City public school children. We will miss Herb's wit, guidance and insights. Our condolences to Constance, Kathryn and Michael, and his colleagues at HF Weissenstein and Company. Laurie Tisch Sussman, Chairman Hollis Headrick, Exec. Director

title: Head of a Credit Suisse Unit to Leave
description: John F. Nelson, the chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston Europe, will leave the firm early next year, the investment bank said today.

title: In Testimony, Rabbi Denies Plotting His Wife's Murder
description: A rabbi on trial on charges of arranging the murder of his wife in 1994 testified in his own defense today and said he played no role in the slaying.

title: Law Firm May Lay Off 10% of Associates
description: Shearman & Sterling, a law firm based in New York with about 1,000 lawyers in 18 offices worldwide, has quietly informed employees that as many as 10 percent of its associates might be laid off because of the slowing economy, a person close to the firm said yesterday. A majority of the lawyers who will be affected work on corporate transactions, this person said.

title: Economists Split on the Effect Of Terror Attacks on Downturn
description: Among economists, there is no doubt that the terrorist attacks on America disrupted consumers and businesses alike and pushed the economy into a recession, the first in 10 years. But gauging how bad that recession will be is much more difficult.

title: Nassau Budget Is Approved Over Republican Objections
description: Barely beating a midnight legal deadline to adopt a new budget -- and with an eye on next week's election for control of county government -- Nassau legislators wrangled tonight over how to balance the books.

title: Companies Cut Textile Orders From Pakistan
description: American Eagle Outfitters normally orders tens of millions of dollars of goods from Pakistan each year. But weeks into the ordering season for spring merchandise, American Eagle is taking a pass. ''We are not going to put our people at risk,'' Laura A. Weil, the chief financial officer, said out of concern for employees overseeing any orders in Pakistan.

title: Green Says City Faces Fiscal Crisis As Bad as in 70's
description: Mark Green warned yesterday that the $4-to-6-billion deficit that the city is expected to face next year is its greatest fiscal crisis since it nearly went bankrupt in the 1970's, and he said that he has ''the experience in government to make hard choices, tell the public hard truths and take the heat.''

title: Troy Bell Sidelined With Knee Injury
description: Boston College guard Troy Bell will be sidelined two to six weeks after tearing cartilage in his right knee.

title: Global Cooperation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JULAY, TERKA
description: JULAY-Terka. Died September 17, 2001 at the age of 97. Dr. Julay was a psychotherapist in New York City from 1946 to 1995, when she moved to Maine. She will be missed by her many friends, the Lax family, former patients and her family. Survivors include her sister Anne Marton, a nephew Dr. J. Osvath and two nieces, Esther Lacognata and Katalin Diossy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEIGEBORN, SYLVIA
description: NEIGEBORN - Sylvia. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Her life was filled with love of family. She joins her beloved Sam in eternity. We treasure her memory. Helen and Burt; Beth and Walter; Amy and Paul; Lenore and Scott; Ellen and David; Allyson and Patrick; Gregory and Julie; Henry; Leslie; Emily, and Hannah. Services at ''Wien & Wien,'' Hackensack, NJ on Wednesday, October 31 at 12 noon.

title: Medical Treatment Should Not Await a Definitive Diagnosis of Anthrax, Health Officials Say
description: Confirming a case of anthrax requires several steps, and results are not immediate. Because a patient can fail rapidly once inhalation anthrax takes hold, health officials say treatment should begin immediately, without waiting for test results, in anyone likely to have been exposed to anthrax spores.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The American Advertising Federation, Washington, named five individual and six corporate winners of its first Mosaic Awards, which honor achievements in diversity and multicultural marketing and advertising. The individuals are: David Bell, vice chairman at the Interpublic Group of Companies, New York; Joaquin Blaya, chairman and chief executive at Radio Unica, Miami; John H. Johnson, publisher, chairman and chief executive at Johnson Publishing Company, Chicago; Arthur Liu, president and chief executive at Multicultural Radio Broadcasting, New York; and Robert L. Wehling, recently retired global marketing officer at the Procter & Gamble Company, Cincinnati. The six corporate winners are: Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group; Lincoln Mercury, Irvine, Calif., part of the Ford Motor Company; PepsiCo, Purchase, N.Y.; Procter & Gamble; the United States Postal Service, Washington; and Verizon Communications, New York.

title: Tribute to New York From the Nation's Upper West Side
description: There were many somber moments Monday night on the stage of Town Hall here, where members of a dozen performing arts companies gathered to pay tribute to a distant place where nearly all the participants had spent considerable time and from which all said they continued to draw artistic inspiration: New York City.

title: Zirndorf Journal; Germans Piece Together Nation's Stasi-Riven Past
description: At this pace, it will take them more than 150 years to finish. But 16 civil servants still toil away here, with tweezers and tape, trying to piece together the files that the East German secret police, the Stasi, tried to destroy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMMET, WINTHROP S.
description: EMMET-Winthrop S., 91. October 26, 2001 in West Stockbridge, MA. He was a graduate of Groton, Harvard College (1934), and Harvard Law School. He was a World War II Navy officer awarded the French Croix de Guerre and helped try Nazi war criminals at Nuremberg in 1945. He was later a New York lawyer and trust officer for National City Bank. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Mary-Jane Emmet; a daughter, Daphne Emmet Hallowell; three stepchildren, Francis Criss Laidlaw, William Laidlaw, and Christian (Annie) Selke; a grandson Christopher Emmet Hallowell; and four step-grandchildren. Memorial service 11 A.M. November 2, 2001, Trinity Church, Lenox, MA. Burial private. In lieu of flowers, send contributions to Lenox Library, Lenox, MA. 01240, or Hospice Care In The Berkshires, 369 S. Street, Pittsfield, MA. 01201.

title: 3 Close Bridge Matches in Paris Tourney
description: There were three close matches in the semifinals of the World Bridge Championships here today.

title: Nassau Package
description: The 700-room Radisson Cable Beach Resort in Nassau, the Bahamas, has reduced its nightly all-inclusive rates to $139 a person from $250, based on double occupancy, through Dec. 22. That includes all meals and drinks, unlimited golf, nonmotorized water sports, use of a fitness center and tennis courts, nightly entertainment, airport transfers, and all hotel taxes and tips. The golf course is being upgraded, and only nine holes may be open. Information: (800) 333-3333 or www.radisson-cablebeach.com .

title: For Truth, Not Spin, on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: S.& P. Warns Argentina of Debt Default
description: Standard & Poor's said today that Argentina's plan to issue new securities in exchange for as much as $95 billion of outstanding bonds is tantamount to a default.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREM, FRANK HERBERT III (TERRY)
description: PREM-Frank Herbert III (Terry). Age 37, of Housatonic, MA, died on October 24, 2001 of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. He is survived by his father, F. Herbert Prem Jr., and his stepmother, Patricia Ryan Prem of New York, NY; his mother, Barbara Herrick and stepfather, Scott Herrick of West Stockbridge, MA; and his sister, Julia Nichols Prem of Housatonic, MA. Private services Wednesday, October 31, at South Berkshire Friends Meeting House, Great Barrington, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Terry Prem Scholarship Fund at Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Ave., New York, New York 10022.

title: Role Players Help Islanders Maintain Their Torrid Pace
description: The Islanders' Shawn Bates took off after Brad Ference as if the Florida defenseman possessed something important, like the Stanley Cup. Ference had the puck, and was no more than 30 feet in front of his own net.

title: Gillette, Defying Economy, Introduces a $9 Razor Set
description: Gillette, the world's leading maker of razors, plans to pit the strength of its consumers' loyalty against the potency of the country's economic downturn.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: New Gas Field
description: The giant Russian energy company Gazprom, which controls one-third of the world's natural gas reserves, began production today at the Zapolyarnoye field, whose estimated three trillion cubic meters of gas surpass the capacity of all other European sources. By 2005, Gazprom hopes to pump 100 billion cubic meters of gas a year from the field, equivalent to one-fifth of all current Russian production. Gazprom's output had been falling in recent years for want of investment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOVERS, CHRISTOPHER NUGENT
description: BOVERS-Christopher Nugent, cofounder of Force Five Watersports and The Haul-Over outdoor stores in Nantucket, Massachusetts died suddenly on Sunday, October 28, 2001. He was 44 years old. He is survived by his wife Francie Ziminsky Bovers of Nantucket, Massachusetts; his sisters Kathleen Bovers of Bedford, NY, Heidi Johnston of Cross River, NY, and Hilary Finnegan, of Harvard, Massachusetts; and a brother Donald Bovers of New York City. Mr. Bovers was raised in Demarest, New Jersey, and later went to Cranwell School in Lenox, Massachusetts, and then to Boston College. He moved to Nantucket in 1978, and with his future wife Francie Ziminsky, founded Force Five Watersports, a surf shop and wind surfing store. In 1980, he worked for Mabon Nugent and Company as a Eurodollar Broker and in 1984 moved back to Nantucket full time. In 1995, he and his wife founded the Haul-Over, also located on Nantucket. He was a loving family man who was married 17 years as of September, 2001. His extended family included eleven brothers and sisters-in-law and 26 nieces and nephews whom he adored. An expert skier, fly fisherman, surfer, and wind surfer, Mr. Bovers helped teach thousands of visitors and islanders about his love of the ocean, fishing, and the mountains. A gregarious, fun-loving, larger-than-life figure, his generosity, soul, and love for Nantucket will be sorely missed. There will be a funeral mass on Wednesday, October 31 at 11:00 AM at St. Mary Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church in Nantucket, Massachusetts. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Nantucket Ice, PO Box 3155, Nantucket, Massachusetts 02554.

title: Braising Veal To Loveliness
description: THIS is a gentle, delicious, easygoing dish with a quiet elegance. At its heart are fast-cooking chunks of veal, whole Belgian endives and carrots. Simmered quickly and relatively briefly in a bit of stock, these marry so perfectly that I have come to think that the finishing touch of cream and mustard, which makes the sauce altogether glorious, may be superfluous.

title: P.& G. Profit Fell in Quarter But Is Seen Rising for the Year
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's largest maker of household goods, said today that its fiscal first-quarter earnings fell 4.4 percent but that its annual profit would surpass forecasts because of lower costs for labor and raw materials.

title: Prayer or Patriotism?
description: DONNA CAYOT, an atheist and the mother of a fourth grader at Somers Intermediate School in Westchester, has complained to the State Education Department that her son's school led its students in prayer, and asked the department to bar the school from having prayers. She said her son, ERIC BRYANT, had been asked to sing ''God Bless America'' at an assembly, and that one line, ''As we raise our voices in a solemn prayer,'' showed that the song is really a prayer. RICHARD L. BRODOW, superintendent of the Somers Central School District, responded that the song was an expression of patriotism, not a prayer. The education department denied Ms. Cayot's request for a stay and is considering a long-term response. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTTOMLEY, ROBERT R.
description: BOTTOMLEY-Robert R. A resident of Florida and Maine, died October 27 in Portsmouth, NH, of heart disease. He was a resident of New York City for 38 years and was an English teacher at Mineola High School for twenty-seven years. Survivors include a sister in Fishkill & a longtime companion.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Warns On Earnings
description: Adobe Systems Inc., the maker of Photoshop photo-editing software, said yesterday that sales and profit for its fiscal fourth quarter, excluding certain costs, will lag expectations. It also said that it was eliminating about 150 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force. Excluding some expenses, profit in the quarter ending in November will be 20 to 22 cents a share on sales of $275 million to $285 million. Analysts had expected Adobe to earn 26 cents. Sales were expected to be $308.2 million.

title: Illegal Immigrants at CUNY
description: In the wake of the terrorist attacks, State Senator FRANK PADAVAN from Queens, has told the City University of New York that allowing illegal immigrants to study at CUNY was both a national security issue and ''an insult to every citizen and legal immigrant seeking a higher education.'' CUNY said it admitted qualified foreigners without regard to immigration status, and that more than 2,700 illegal immigrants were enrolled last year. The university said the approach reflected the city's historic support for immigrants and conformed to policy laid out by Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1989. Karen W. Arenson

title: An Appreciation; A 'Cathedral' to Some, The Stadium to Others
description: Yankee Stadium's right-field stands are known in the lingo of broadcasters as ''the short porch.'' That is, the fence is not all that far from home plate, easily reachable by the left-handed power hitters who have long been a staple of the Yankee lineup, beginning with Babe Ruth, for whom the short porch was constructed.

title: Times Internet Snag
description: Access to the Internet from The New York Times was disrupted yesterday, preventing the updating of The New York Times on the Web for four hours during the afternoon.

title: Tribute for Firefighters Will Have a Global Reach
description: Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen said yesterday that the city and the International Association of Firefighters would stage a memorial service on Nov. 18 at Madison Square Garden for the 343 firefighters who died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Special Forces, On the Ground, Aid the Rebels

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT RISES. Wheat rose after a report showed dry weather has stunted newly planted crops that will be harvested next spring. In Chicago, wheat for December delivery rose 4.25 cents, or 1.5 percent, to $2.955 a bushel.

title: Few Businesses Seek Disaster Aid; Fewer Are Approved
description: More than half of the small businesses in New York City that have applied for federal disaster loans since the World Trade Center attack have had their applications rejected, resulting in one of the lowest loan-approval rates in recent years among communities that have had to grapple with large-scale disasters.

title: Hunting a Deadly Germ by Scrutinizing a Life
description: As a petite and private woman from the Bronx lies in critical condition at a Manhattan hospital, everything about her life  from the mail she received at home to the desk that she used at work  is being urgently scrutinized in a broad investigation into the way she contracted the city's first case of inhalation anthrax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MURRAY

title: Stepping Out on My Own
description: I was in my early 30's, a senior account executive, getting ready to receive a trophy for salesman of the year. I was making it into the Federal Express sales hall of fame. Fred Smith, the founder of Federal Express, was there.

title: Jordan Returns to the Garden But His Magic Doesn't Follow
description: He did not have the rise in his legs, the touch on his jump shot or, in the final minutes, his matchless basketball savvy. In the genesis of his second comeback, Michael Jordan was barely above average last night, and the Knicks were the beneficiaries. Despite their sloppy play, the Knicks edged the Washington Wizards, 93-91, in their season opener at Madison Square Garden.

title: A Deeper Anthrax Mystery, an Ashcroft Alert, G.I.'s on the Ground
description: Even crises can settle into patterns, and for a while that seemed the case with the anthrax threat. Appalling as it was, it had acquired a certain familiarity. Its victims fell broadly into a few categories: government employees, notably postal workers, and staff members of news organizations. All of them handled mail. Then came Kathy T. Nguyen to break the pattern and raise the specter of an epidemic more dire than suspected.

title: Meanwhile, in New Jersey, New-Look Nets Win
description: Before the Nets' season opener tonight against the Indiana Pacers, Jason Kidd made a brief, soft-spoken statement welcoming the 8,749 loyal fans to Continental Arena. ''We know there are two other shows in town,'' Kidd, the new Nets captain said, ''but this one is going to be the best to come to.''

title: Miller's City College Secret
description: When the playwright ARTHUR MILLER got a medal for artistic devotion to New York from the City College Alumni Association this month, he had a surprise to present. For a ''remarkably brief'' period, he said, he had been enrolled at City College. ''It was 1932, I believe,'' he said at the awards dinner. ''They wrote and told me that I was going to be taking physics, chemistry and mathematics, none of which I had a prayer of ever learning. But at that time, I was working at a warehouse on 68th Street, where Lincoln Center is now, and I was living at the other end in Brooklyn. So by the time I got to my classes, I was sleeping, and I lasted three weeks. I tallied up, no doubt, the worst academic record ever seen on this continent. So I pulled out and decided to save some money.'' He later went to the University of Michigan. Karen W. Arenson

description: Music may not be universal any more than language itself is. But here is a sentiment to chill a music lover in any culture: ''There is no life for my music here.''

description: In an often rowdy encounter before a hooting, cheering audience, Michael R. Bloomberg and Mark Green offered differing views last night on rebuilding New York, on improving public education and on what the city needed in its next mayor. They poked and jabbed away at each other's credentials and style, and the audience egged them on.

title: Williams Is Next Speed Bump for Jets' Defense
description: Ted Cottrell, the Jets' beleaguered defensive coordinator, took home a game ball and a dose of relief from the team's victory over the Carolina Panthers on Sunday. His defense had finally shaken off its malaise and, at least for one week, had thrown off the embarrassing cloak of being the worst defense in the league.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYER, DONALD S.
description: TAYER-Donald S. The American Jewish Committee mourns the death of our dear friend Don Tayer. Don served AJC with distinction as president of our San Francisco Bay Area chapter and, as a longstanding member of our national Board of Governors. In 1987 we honored him with our Distinguished Service Award. Devoted to the law, the Jewish people and his community, Don contributed his considerable talents and humanity to each endeavor. We send heartfelt condolences to his wife Joyce, his children and grandchildren. Harold Tanner, President David A. Harris, Exec. Director

description: President Bush threw out the ceremonial first pitch before Game 3 last night, the first president to do so at a World Series at Yankee Stadium in 45 years.

title: AOL Is Ordered to Stop Using PlayMedia Software
description: A federal court has ruled that America Online has probably violated a copyright of a small software company and ordered the huge online service to remove the online music player feature from the AOL 6.0 software used by more than 10 million of its customers.

title: Another Swiss Tunnel Shut After Truck and Car Crash
description: Less than a week after a truck collision in a tunnel set off an inferno that killed at least 11 people and closed one of the Continent's critical roadways, another accident today briefly halted traffic through a mountain pass that provides the closest alternate route.

title: A Vulnerable Food Supply, A Call for More Safety
description: LAST week Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, told Congress that he was more fearful about the safety of the American food supply than anything else.

description: In that way 2-year-olds have, Patricia Mary Smith once promised to buy her mother, Moira Smith, a boat. That was before Officer Smith of the New York City Police Department died as she was evacuating people from the World Trade Center's south tower.

title: Embracing Duty, With Gloved Hands
description: The first batch of the national capital's infamously suspect mail came slinking into town like a midnight scandal, triple-sealed in biohazard bags with only 90 minutes' notice to the mayor.

title: Industry Seeks U.S. Contracts To Develop Antibiotics
description: As a handful of antibiotics become the weapons of choice against bioterrorism, drug companies are asking for government contracts to undertake research on bioterrorism drugs, creating an uneasy debate among executives, politicians and consumer advocates over how close the industry should be to the government.

title: 2 Black Men Charged in Killing Of White Officer in 1969 Riot
description: A continuing self-examination of a troubling episode in this city's past has led to more murder charges stemming from a race riot more than three decades ago.

title: Clemens Preserves Series Hopes As Things Start to Fall In for Yanks
description: The flood of runs the Yankees expected in Game 3 of the World Series never came last night, innings and opportunities passing without result, the tension increasing. But Yankees players spoke afterward about a sense of inevitability, a habit reinforced over the past four years.

title: A Worrisome Medical Puzzle, Wrapped in a Workaday Life
description: She left Vietnam in 1977 and came to America with the aid of a soldier whose stateside job was as a policeman in New York. She had owned a bar in her country, but fled without her money and, after passing through the East Side of Manhattan, settled in a cheap third-floor apartment in the Bronx.

title: The Pyrenees, Alive With Fish, Figs and Lentils
description: BASQUE restaurants don't seem to register much on New York's culinary radar.

title: When Bats Go Silent, Yankees Go Back to Old Routines
description: The Yankees' hitters had never been in a larger collective slump as they were after the first two games of the World Series. They produced 6 hits in 59 at-bats and one run in Games 1 and 2, and, as always, they reverted to trusted habits to extricate themselves from their offensive problems.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: No Talks With U.S.
description: Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, rejected direct talks with the United States and said that those who do not comply with the policies of the Islamic Republic are ''religiously forbidden'' to carry on their duties. ''It is based on a reasonable and fundamental notion that we believe relations, or even direct talks, with the United States is against our national interests,'' he said. His remarks came after reformist members of Parliament, who set up a special commission to review foreign policy, said Iran must hold direct talks with the United States to establish an active role in regional events. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB WILL CUT JOBS AT DRUG UNIT
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company will cut about 40 percent of the work force at the drug business it recently purchased from the DuPont Company, the first step in a plan to reduce the unit's costs by as much as $600 million, the company said yesterday. Bristol-Myers will cut almost 2,000 of the unit's 5,000 positions in the next two weeks, said Wilson Grabill, a Bristol-Myers spokesman. Bristol-Myers completed its $7.8 billion cash purchase of the unit on Oct. 2, adding AIDS and heart medicines to help replenish Bristol-Myers's product line amid increased competition from generics.

title: First Passive And Invisible, Then Ruinous And Glowing
description: In ''The Man Who Wasn't There'' Billy Bob Thornton plays Ed Crane, a barber plying his trade in Santa Rosa, Calif., in 1949. The title is only slightly overstated. In this silver-gray film noir world, Ed at first seems as substantial as a shadow or the smoke from his unfiltered cigarettes. (He smokes so many of them that the movie deserves a surgeon general's warning to go with its M.P.A.A. rating.) He is content to work the second chair in his brother-in-law's barber shop and to go home to a bungalow on a shady street, where he lives in passionless matrimony with Doris (Frances McDormand), who keeps the books at a local department store.

title: Stocks Close the Day Mixed
description: Desperate for an injection of good news, the stock market at first rallied today after the government reported that the nation's gross domestic product declined less in the third quarter than Wall Street had feared.

title: Washington's Balanced Reds, With a Bow to Irrigation
description: IT may surprise some people to learn that, after California, no state devotes more acres to growing wine grapes than Washington. After all, Washington's reputation is for rain, rain, rain, not exactly the best environment for vineyards. Although some grapes are indeed grown in the wet western part of the state, around Puget Sound, a majority are grown east of the Cascade Range, where they are shielded from the Pacific precipitation.

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan, a Bit Older, Comes Up Short
description: Michael Jordan never made it all the way to the podium in the Madison Square Garden rotunda through the tunnel from the arena late yesterday morning after the Washington Wizards' shoot-around. He pulled up short of the area set up for a news conference, the way he would settle for jump shots last night against the Knicks and, in the final count, come up short.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of All Saints' Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Will Serbs Take A Chance in Kosovo?
description: More than two years after air strikes by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ended the harrowing of Kosovo by Slobodan Milosevic, Kosovo's Serbs remain beset by anxieties. Perhaps half of all Kosovo's Serbs have left for fear of retribution. Hundreds remain missing and unaccounted for. Half of the Serbs still in Kosovo live in small, fortified enclaves where they feel safe only thanks to the presence of NATO troops. Many Serbs cite these conditions, and the fear of Kosovar independence, as reasons for not voting, on Nov. 17, in the first free general elections Kosovo has ever had. But they are seeing the world upside down. These elections are the great opportunity for them, as they are for us, Kosovo's Albanians.

title: Article 2001103192551477710 -- No Title
description: An article on Saturday about Egypt's Westernized elite misstated the relationship of Taher Samir Helmy, a prominent Cairo lawyer, to President Hosni Mubarak. Although Mr. Helmy served on a presidential council, he was not an official adviser to Mr. Mubarak.

title: Award to Professor at Hunter
description: The Ameritec Foundation has named MARIE T. FILBIN, a neuroscientist and biology professor at Hunter College, one of two winners of its Ameritec Prize for significant achievement toward a cure for paralysis. Dr. Filbin and MU-MING POO, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, will each receive $40,000 at the Neurotrauma Symposium in San Diego Nov. 10 for their work (done independently) on how a molecule called cyclic AMP affects the regeneration of nerve axons after injury. The director of Hunter College's Specialized Neuroscience Research program, Dr. Filbin is the first woman to win the prize since it was established in 1987. She became interested in curing paralysis growing up in Northern Ireland, where she saw victims of violence who were paralyzed for life. Karen W. Arenson

title: Milosevic Calls Tribunal Unfair, Infantile and 'a Farce'
description: If there had been any doubts about the warlike strategy Slobodan Milosevic had in mind for the international tribunal that will try him, then he dispelled them today in court.

description: Like thousands of my fellow Saudis, I studied in the United States, do business with American companies and have a great affection for New York City. Being educated in New York has given me a deep respect for the city and its people, many of whom I count as friends.

title: Dominant Clemens Brushes Off Injury
description: Nearly everyone who set foot in Yankee Stadium last night was subjected to body searches and metal detectors. But flash cameras got through, and as Roger Clemens paused in his pregame warm-ups in the Yankee bullpen to watch President Bush throw out the first pitch, he saw Bush throw a strike that coincided with a Stadium full of flashbulbs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 New Bishops Named
description: Pope John Paul II has appointed three new auxiliary bishops for New York, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said yesterday. The bishops -- the Rev. Msgrs. Josu Iriondo, pastor of St. Anthony of Padua Church in the Bronx, Timothy McDonnell, pastor of St. John and St. Mary Parish in Chappaqua, and Dominick Lagonegro, pastor of St. Columba Parish in Hopewell Junction -- will assist Cardinal Edward M. Egan, above. Their pastoral administration duties will include confirmations, and ordinations of deacons and priests, said the spokesman, Joseph Zwilling. They will replace three retiring auxiliary bishops, he said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Around The Nation: Halloween Fears
description: At least two governors have changed their Halloween plans because of security concerns. Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, on the advice of state police, canceled plans for the annual handing out of candy at the Governor's Mansion out of concern that the building could be a target for terrorists. Gov. Judy Martz of Montana will also break a tradition of handing out candy at the Governor's Mansion. Instead, she will distribute candy at seven elementary schools in Helena.

title: Top Democrats Are Confident Of a Victory by McGreevey
description: In a signal that Democrats are increasingly confident about winning the New Jersey governor's race, the national party chairman, Terry McAuliffe, campaigned at the State House here today, not for James E. McGreevey, but for three legislative candidates from Mercer County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCHALE, PATRICIA CAMERON
description: McHALE-Patricia Cameron. Died at her home in Palm City, FL. on October 28, 2001. She was born Patricia Ann Cameron on September 26, 1921 in Detroit, MI and was the niece of Walter O. Briggs. She was educated at The Convent of The Sacred Heart and graduated from Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart with a degree in philosophy. She married longtime baseball executive, John J. McHale at Sacred Heart Church on the campus of the University of Notre Dame. She is survived by her husband of 54 years, her six children Cameron Glaws (Peter), John Jr. (Sally), Kevin, Anne McLeod (James), Brian (Susana), Mavie, and 15 grandchildren. She was a resident of Palm Beach and St. Lucie Counties for the past 33 years. An elegant, graceful and intensely competitive sportswoman, she possessed a prodigious and uncompromising intellect. She loved God, her husband, her children, and grandchildren, and never wavered from the sacrifices required by that love. A Mass of Affirmation will be held at 10 AM on Saturday, November 3, 2001 at Holy Redeemer Catholic Church in Palm City, FL. following a private interment.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Protestant Slain
description: A 30-year-old Protestant, an ex-paramilitary member, was killed by two masked gunmen on Monday as he left the home of his Catholic girlfriend in Strabane. The police blamed dissident republicans for the killing of Charles Folliard, who was released from prison in 1998 after serving seven years on bomb charges. They said renegade republicans were also responsible for the bombing on Monday night of an empty bus outside a West Belfast police station. The dissidents oppose the Northern Ireland peace accord and the decision last week by the Irish Republican Army to begin disarming. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Baby Dies After Return To Father
description: A 7-month-old infant was shaken to death by his father after state authorities had twice removed him from his home because of suspected abuse, the police said. State Child Advocate Jeanne Milstein is investigating the case. The infant, Ezramicah Hilliard Jr., died Saturday, two months after returning to his parents. His father, Ezramicah Hilliard Sr., 21, was arraigned Monday on charges of murder and risk of injury to a minor. Bond was set at $1 million. Kristine Ragaglia, commissioner of the Department of Children and Families, said a judge in August ordered the infant returned to his parents despite the agency's objections. The judge, Howard Owens Jr., said yesterday that the department had not opposed the child's return, and called its representation of the case ''highly inaccurate.'' Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Killed In Hit-And-Run
description: A 76-year-old woman was killed yesterday when she was hit by a truck in a Middle Village intersection, the police said. The truck was driven by an on-duty employee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art who fled the scene but was later arrested, the police said. The woman, Doris Clark, was pronounced dead at Elmhurst Hospital Center at 10:41 a.m., the police said. The driver, Moises A. Morales, 44, of Brooklyn, was charged with leaving the scene of a fatal accident, they said. Other charges are pending, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: COCA-COLA WILL BUY ODWALLA, MAKER OF FRUIT DRINKS
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Odwalla Inc., a maker of fruit and vegetable drinks, for about $186 million in cash and assumed debt to gain a bigger share of the fast-growing market for noncarbonated beverages. Coca-Cola, based in Atlanta, agreed to pay $15.25 a share for Odwalla's common stock, a 29 percent premium over Monday's closing price of $11.83. Coca-Cola will assume about $5 million in debt, said a spokesman, Ben Deutsch. The acquisition is expected to add to earnings after a year, Coca-Cola said. Odwalla will become part of Coca-Cola's Minute Maid juice business. Coca-Cola has made several small acquisitions this year to increase sales of juice, water and noncarbonated beverages to combat sluggish demand for soft drinks. Odwalla is based in Half Moon Bay, Calif.

description: Bucking the trend of gloom that has settled over much of the media industry, Vivendi Universal S.A. of France, Europe's biggest media company, announced strong quarterly financial results yesterday.

description: In his first act as chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, William Clay Ford Jr. named a pair of seasoned executives to run the company's automotive and financial operations, a clear signal he will not hesitate to seek out experienced help.

description: When Bret D. Schundler was growing up in a crowded and competitive household, his older brothers say, he learned to delve into social problems, convince himself of the solutions, and defend his reasoning against all challenges.

Ilene Claude weaved through the crowd. For days, it had been one crisis after another. When things looked darkest, it seemed to fall to her. ''Yes,'' she said, grabbing the receiver. ''Yes. No. Hold on.'' She dropped the phone and hollered across the room, ''Do we have any gorilla costumes left?''

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: More Aid For Homeless

title: The New York Times's N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining its record against other teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTMAN, ELIAS BERNARD
description: SALTMAN-Elias Bernard, 89. On October 29, 2001. A true intellectual with an intense concern for fairness and equality for all. For Eli, food, knowledge & classical music were the keys to life. Beloved husband of Alice (nee Mintz) for 66 years. Father of David (Pemmy), Melissa Meyer (Brad) and Susi Brooks. Loving grandfather of Julie Saltman, Jennifer Summers (Ron), Nicholas, Jacob, and Nathaniel Meyer and Sabrina Brooks. With Bachelor's and Master's degrees from N.Y. University and membership in the Cadeucean Society, he devoted most of his professional career to the people of New York as a Probation Examiner, and Director of Intake and Aftercare, Division of Youth. He served as consultant to the President's Commission on Law Enforcement and Administration. He was committed to assisting people toward a better life and thousands benefitted from his efforts. Contributions may be made to American Jewish Congress. Graveside service Wednesday, October 31, 2001 at Dover Mt. Sinai Cemetery, Randolph, NJ. For information, contact Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.

title: A Southern Burger, Hold the Beef
description: MOST Southern foods have taken flight since World War II, landing in far-flung places around the nation. There's decent Texas-style barbecued brisket in Queens, Krispy Kreme doughnuts in Albuquerque and admirable grits in Baltimore. But a few Southern regionalisms still cling to their roots. Shrimp burgers, found in small coastal villages in the Carolinas, are nearly unheard of in upstate Greenville or Charlotte.

description: President Bush announced yesterday that he intended to nominate a former New Mexico attorney general to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

description: Players and fans have been finding ways to help the victims of last month's terrorist attack, some by playing games to raise money, like the four professional teams from New York and Washington; some by volunteering their services, and others by simply demonstrating their support.

title: Tribute for Firefighters Will Have a Global Reach
description: Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen said yesterday that the city and the International Association of Firefighters would stage a memorial service on Nov. 18 at Madison Square Garden for the 343 firefighters who died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Pictures of the Culinary Past Worth a Thousand Recipes
description: ''Food Mania,'' by Nigel Garwood and Rainer Voigt (Clarkson Potter, $35), is nearly 400 pages of often amusing illustrations about food production, preparation, consumption and serving. Its focus is European and American lithographs, paintings and advertisements from the 19th and early 20th centuries, like the little butter makers, above, from ''A Children's Book of Trades,'' circa 1870. Not much text accompanies the art, but words aren't needed: the pictures say it all.

title: 22 Acquitted In the Deaths Of 9 Poles In 1981 Strife
description: Twenty-two former police officers were acquitted today in the killing of nine miners in December 1981, three days after a coup toppled the Polish government and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski and other military leaders moved to crush the Solidarity trade union.

title: The Latest Angle For Cup Measurements
description: Until now, the usual way to measure a liquid was to set a measuring cup on a counter, and then fill it while bending over to squint at the fine lines and numbers printed on its side. A new measuring cup from Oxo allows the cook to simply look down at the inside of the cup, where an angled ridge is imprinted with large, easy-to-read red-on-white numbers: cup measurements on the left, milliliters on the right. Measurements are also printed in their usual spot, outside the cup.

title: Economic Expansion Ends; G.D.P. Falls by 0.4 Percent
description: The nation's longest period of economic growth, spanning 99 months, came to an official close in the third quarter, the government reported today.

description: The elegant little hospital, famous mostly for cosmetic surgery, cataract procedures and turf battles between star physicians, found itself at the front line of the anthrax war yesterday.

title: The Urgency of Cheaper Drugs
description: When the federal government wanted to stockpile the antibiotic Cipro as a treatment for anthrax, Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy Thompson persuaded Bayer, the patent holder, to cut the price of the drug by threatening to buy generic versions. Yet the Bush administration is derailing efforts by poor countries ravaged by AIDS to facilitate their efforts to do the same.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARUCH, SULAMITA, M.D.
description: BARUCH-Sulamita, M.D. The physicians and staff of QueensLong Island Medical Group, PC, are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved former colleague and we extend our condolences to her family. Dr. Baruch was a distinguished and dedicated internist with our group for more than 16 years, who also served as the Director of Emergency Medicine at LaGuardia Hospital. Her work with us and later with Hospice Care Network reflected a life dedicated to healing and comforting others. We are honored to have known her.

description: WASHINGTON  As President George Bush signed new legislation last Friday aimed at strengthening anti-money-laundering procedures, most private banks in the United States were not anticipating any major changes in the way they do business.

title: District in Beijing to Shut Schools for Migrants
description: ''Dear Parents,'' began the beguilingly polite letter from local officials, who handed out their message as they blocked the gates of more than 50 primary schools serving 10,000 students in the gritty southeast of Beijing.

title: O'Neill Delivers in Return to Lineup
description: Paul O'Neill reluctantly agreed to be one of the Yankees allowing members of the news media to interview him at Bank One Ballpark a day before the World Series opener against the Arizona Diamondbacks. O'Neill, who often treats questions about himself the way a 7-year-old treats a flu shot, did not really want to be in the spacious room. He did it because he had committed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Economic Opening
description: At a conference of foreign investors in Moscow today, President Vladimir V. Putin called on the international community to include Russia in the global economy. Noting that Russia had made considerable progress in stabilizing its economy and enacting liberal reforms, he said that since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, ''a new principle of global rights and duties is emerging,'' and that ''all factors of cooperation are important here -- and economic ones perhaps even more so.'' Officials said relations with the United States in particular were warming significantly.

title: Bush Advisers Say Congress Must Act Now on Economy
description: The Bush administration warned today that failure by Congress to pass an economic recovery package would endanger the prospects for a rebound next year, but it offered no compromises to break a partisan deadlock on Capitol Hill.

description: It has been nearly a month since Robert Stevens, a photo editor for a supermarket tabloid, entered the history books as the first person in America to die of inhalation anthrax since 1957 and the first ever to die in a known biological attack.

It was his last chance to avoid prison for his felony conviction for possession of cocaine.

title: Conseco Posts Loss And Lowers Outlook For 4th Quarter
description: Conseco, the finance and insurance firm, posted a loss for a second quarter, as it wrote down $471 million of junk bonds, mortgage debt and other assets. The company also said today that it had cut its fourth-quarter forecast.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. Project Draws Big Names
description: I.B.M. will announce today that it has signed up more than 20 companies to help with its Project Eliza to develop computer networks that can largely manage themselves, recognizing faults and repairing them without human handlers. The company's long-term, multibillion-dollar effort, which spans I.B.M.'s hardware, software and research operations, was announced in April. The announcement shows I.B.M. has convinced some large corporate customers to join the initiative, including Merrill Lynch, Nortel Networks, BMC Software and Terra Lycos. ''They will help us define the road map going forward,'' said Gregory Burke, director of the project. I.B.M. is also announcing today an early byproduct of the Project Eliza work, a software tool for predicting and intercepting problems. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: The Noodle and I: A Face-Off at the Oven
description: UNTIL last week, my lasagna record was clean. I might have eaten it, but I never made it. Why bother boiling noodles and simmering sauce and laboring over layers just to get a dish I associate with dining experiences at 30,000 feet?

title: Boldly, Off With Its Head
description: THE latest thing from New Zealand ? Screw caps for fine wine. In spite of formidable odds, 27 New Zealand wineries, tired of apologizing for bad natural corks and unimpressed with the plastic variety, have decided to bottle most of their wines in bottles with screw-top caps. They call their group the New Zealand Screwcap Wine Seal Initiative, and they are reintroducing an old solution to a problem for wine consumers and the wine industry.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Plea In Internet Rape Case
description: An Astoria man accused of repeatedly raping a Massachusetts teenager who was first imprisoned by a Long Island couple has pleaded guilty to first-degree rape, the Queens district attorney's office announced yesterday. The man, Michael Montez, 35, is expected to be sentenced to nine years in prison on Nov. 19, when he is scheduled to appear before a judge. Mr. Montez's lawyer did not immediately return a call seeking comment. The couple, James Warren and Beth Loschin, are accused of befriending the 15-year-old girl in an Internet chat room, abducting her, and subjecting her to a week of physical and sexual abuse. The couple have been arrested and charged separately in Nassau County.
